https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/world.main_headline: Blocked Funds Put U.S. Role In Seville World Fair in Doubt
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/world.print_headline: Blocked Funds Put U.S. Role In Seville World Fair in Doubt
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/world.body_text: **********As work advances on the new auditoriums, pavilions and stadiums for the Seville World's Fair, Expo '92, Spanish and American officials are concerned that construction may never begin on one of the main attractions: the United States pavilion. **********Congress has approved only $2.9 million of the $15 million in seed money needed for the United States to officially guarantee its attendance. **********The money has been budgeted for the fiscal year 1990 to contribute to the building of the United States pavilion, and it is hoped that a further $30 million will come from private sponsors. **********Former President Reagan, in a letter to King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia of Spain, committed the United States to participation in Expo '92, which is to draw 103 countries as well as at least 20 corporate exhibitors. President Bush endorsed Mr. Reagan's commitment. **********Money Is Frozen **********But the rest of the $15 million has been frozen by Representative Neil Smith, Democrat of Iowa, and Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, who strongly oppose Federal financing of trade fairs. Mr. Smith and Mr. Hollings are the chairmen of the House and Senate Appropriations subcommittees, which allocate the money. **********In 1992, Spain will be host not only to Expo '92 as part of celebrations of the 500th anniversary of Columbus's voyage to the New World, but also to the Summer Olympics in Barcelona. The absence of the United States from the first of these events would dampen Spain's celebration of its new self-image as a mainstream European player. **********Though several American corporations are planning to take part, Spanish officials are increasingly concerned that the United States Government may not occupy the 90,000-square-foot site allocated to it, the second largest after Spain's. **********''We are worried because the United States is a star participant,'' said Emilio Casinello, president of the Expo '92 State Corporation. Referring to the fair's theme, ''The Age of Discovery,'' he added, ''How can the United States stay away from the age of discovery when they are the discoverers and innovators of modern times?'' **********U.S. Officials Anxious, Too **********Mr. Casinello said the United States trade deficit could grow if it stayed away from Seville while all its major competitors were represented. American officials are also anxious. ''It would send the wrong signals not just to Europe on the eve of economic unification,'' Marvin Stone, commissioner general of the United States national section at Expo 92, said in a telephone interview. **********Mr. Stone said that ''at this point it's a possibility'' that the United States might not attend. **********But Spanish officials say they are confident that the United States will officially confirm its attendance. **********''Every Western country, every member state of the O.E.C.D., every NATO member will be there,'' said Inocencio Arias, Under Secretary General of the Spanish Foreign Ministry. ''The United States cannot afford not to come.'' **********But he added that if the United States did not show up, ''it's not the end of the world.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/busin.main_headline: Bonuses Slide at Ford; Those at G.M. Just Slip
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/busin.print_headline: Bonuses Slide at Ford; Those at G.M. Just Slip
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/busin.body_text: **********The country's two largest auto companies released their annual proxy statements today and both showed declines in executive bonuses for 1989, although at markedly different levels. **********Bonuses paid to the top executives of the General Motors Corporation, declined by less than the overall drop in profits in 1989, while the bonuses paid to the Ford Motor Company's top two executives fell further than the percentage decline in profits. **********''In theory, the bonus should be more volatile than the underlying profits themselves, rising faster than the rise in profits, and falling further when profits decline,'' said Graef Crystal, a compensation expert and professor at the University of California Business School in Berkeley. **********''You can see that principle at work to some extent in the Ford plan,'' Professor Crystal said. ''G.M.'s situation is more nearly what you find at other companies, which is to say when the profits drop, the bonus is cut by some token amount.'' **********Profit Sharing Fell More **********The bonuses of Ford's top two officers declined 32 percent and 40 percent respectively. The company's net profit fell 27.6 percent. **********At G.M., the bonuses for the top two executives fell by 6.6 percent and 4.5 percent, respectively, compared with a 13 percent drop in earnings. **********While bonuses paid to Ford's hourly workers under the profit-sharing plan fell 64.1 percent, the combined bonuses of Ford's top two executives fell only 34.8 percent. **********A Ford spokesman said the discrepancy between hourly profit sharing and executive bonuses resulted from the formula used to calculate profit sharing, which is based on the profit performance of Ford's domestic automotive business. Profits from the American business declined more than Ford's overall profits. **********At G.M., the bonuses paid to the corporation's top two executives declined 5.8 percent, compared with a drop of 80.3 percent in the profit-sharing payout last year to hourly workers, who each received $50. **********Donald E. Petersen, who was chairman and chief executive of Ford until he retired in February, received total compensation of $6.57 million by exercising stock options worth $3.52 million in 1989. Mr. Petersen collected $10.49 million the previous year, when he exercised options worth $7.15 million. His salary rose to $1.53 million, from $1.14 million, and his bonus fell to $1.5 million, from $2.2 million. **********Harold A. Poling, the new chairman of Ford, received total compensation of $2.93 million in 1989, including the exercise of stock options worth $786,094. His bonus payments fell to $960,000, from $1.6 million in 1988. **********Roger B. Smith, chairman of G.M., received total compensation of $2.49 million, including a salary of $1.09 million and a bonus of $1.4 million in the form of restricted stock. His salary in 1988 was $983,000 and his bonus was $1.5 million, again in the form of restricted stock. **********Robert C. Stempel, the current president of G.M. who is to take over as chairman and chief executive on Sept. 1, was awarded total compensation of $2.1 million, including the exercise of stock options worth $321,820. His salary in 1989 was $725,000 and his bonus was $1.05 million. In 1988, his salary was $633,000 and his bonus was $1.1 million in restricted stock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/17/busin.main_headline:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Loews New President Made Movies a Career
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/17/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Loews New President Made Movies a Career
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/17/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: ''I go a long way back in the popcorn business,'' Robert Smerling says with a laugh. **********''I go a long way back in the popcorn business,'' Robert Smerling says with a laugh. **********The 55-year-old executive, who has worked in the motion picture theater business for more than 30 years, is the new president of the Loews Theater Management Corporation. The movie theater chain, a subsidiary of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., operates 850 screens at about 220 theaters in 16 states. **********Mr. Smerling reports to A. Alan Friedberg, who was named chairman of Loews in May by Peter Guber and Jon Peters, the co-chairmen of Columbia. While Loews officially announced Mr. Smerling's arrival yesterday, he has been on the job for more than a month, Columbia said. **********Mr. Smerling started in the movie business after leaving the University of Florida in the 1950's. **********''My family owned some drive-in theaters in northern New Jersey,'' he said in a telephone interview yesterday. ''I worked there as a young fellow until around 1960, when General Cinema took them over, and I went to work for them.'' **********Mr. Smerling's father had entered the drive-in business after helping to found the ABC Vending Corporation, a company that sold candy, popcorn and other treats at ball parks, theaters and other venues. ABC is now part of the Ogden Corporation, based in New York. **********In 1966, after working for General Cinema for several years, Mr. Smerling started Cinema National, a movie theater company that grew from several screens in Fairfield County, Conn., to nearly 100 before its sale in 1986 to USA Cinemas. At USA, Mr. Smerling became senior executive vice president under Mr. Friedberg, who was the president. **********From 1975 to 1986, Mr. Smerling was president of American Theater Management, a film-buying service that arranged bookings. **********In 1988, when USA Cinemas sold out to Loews, Mr. Friedberg left to tend to his own investments, including a number of theaters he owned in partnership with General Cinema. **********''I'd always been an entrepreneur,'' Mr. Smerling. ''But in today's climate and with the exhibition business in consolidation, opportunities are limited. It's a wonderful thing to come back and be part of the management team at Loews.'' **********Mr. Smerling, who recently remarried, has two grown children from a first marriage. He lives in Boston but is relocating to New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Underwriting Fees Decline Sharply
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/busin.body_text: **********The squeeze on Wall Street profits grew tighter in the last quarter, as fees for underwritings of securities fell by more than half, to their lowest levels in six years, and corporate America began to pull back from raising money in the capital markets. **********The bad news for the third quarter ended yesterday was reflected in most types of securities issued. Corporations issued a total of $72.6 billion, down from an anemic $73 billion issued in the third quarter of last year, according to the Securities Data Company. **********The poor showing for the quarter did not drive the underwriting results for the year to date below those for the period last year. Securities Data reported that $238.09 billion has been raised by corporations so far in 1990, compared with $217.18 billion in the first nine months of 1989. **********Investment bankers said that the bad results in the third quarter were caused largely by the world events that have thrown the financial markets into turmoil. **********''This quarter the new-issue market clearly has been dominated by the events in the Persian Gulf, the increased prospects for a recession and, more recently, problems in the banking system,'' said Mark A. Seigel, a managing director with Morgan Stanley & Company. **********Industrial Companies Active **********Wall Street analysts also said that most issuers were large industrial companies. ''The industrials were the bulk of the issuance,'' said Edson Mitchell, managing director at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. ''The financial issuers were not active.'' **********In some ways, the appetite among the industrial companies for debt issuance reflected the difficulties of the ''junk bond'' market, which virtually collapsed over the year, underwriters said. With hostile takeover bids financed by junk bonds becoming more a memory than a threat, the investor interest has focused again on investment-grade debt, they said. **********Reflecting that change, the demand for private borrowing through the bond market climbed slightly in the third quarter. According to Securities Data, $68.55 billion in debt was issued during the quarter, up from $63.36 billion in the period last year. **********But corporations have been much less able to issue debt that is not secured by assets. Only $19.76 billion in unsecured debt was issued in the third quarter, compared with $27.81 billion a year earlier. **********That drop has been made up in part by mortgage and asset-backed debt. Such securities were the strongest element of the debt market in the third quarter, with $46.95 billion being issued, compared with $33.64 billion in the period last year. **********New Stock Issues Drop **********The issuance of common stock, which had been growing popular throughout the year, also plunged sharply in the third quarter. Only $3.3 billion in stock was issued in the period, compared with $6.1 billion a year earlier. **********Indeed, the difficulties in the financial markets have slowed the trickle of initial public offerings to a near standstill. In the quarter, only $1.55 billion was raised by companies going to the capital markets for the first time, compared with $3.76 billion a year ago. **********The difficulty in underwritings has increased the competition among investment banks, helping to drive down fees. The disclosed fees in the third quarter were less than half those a year earlier, with firms getting only $339 million from underwritings, down from $785.6 million. **********For the first nine months, Merrill Lynch Capital Markets ranked as the leading underwriter of domestic issues, with $37.5 billion in securities, or 15.8 percent of the total market. It was followed by Goldman, Sachs & Company, with $32.08 billion, or 13.5 percent of the market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/world.main_headline: Agents Explain Why C.I.A. Planned for a Resistance in Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE; Agents Explain Why C.I.A. Planned for a Resistance in Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/world.body_text: **********Retired and still active intelligence officers here sought today to place in perspective the "stay behind" program of armed resistance groups organized 40 years ago by the Central Intelligence Agency in Western Europe to fight on if the Soviet Union invaded and occupied their countries. **********The existence of such groups and their secret arms caches has been disclosed in news accounts published in Italy, Germany, France, Sweden and Belgium over the last few weeks. **********A former senior C.I.A. officer, Ray S. Cline, said in an interview that the operations "made some sense then," referring to the post-war period when the Soviet menace loomed large in the minds of American policymakers and when Western military forces were weak in Europe. **********Although the agency declined to comment on the operations today, older officers recalled that there had been a real concern about a Soviet invasion of Western Europe at the beginning of the 1950's. Described in Colby Memoir **********The "stay behind" operations are briefly but precisely described in a 1976 Senate document and also in a 1978 memoir, Honorable Men, by William E. Colby, who became director of the C.I.A. in 1973. The recent West European press reports have provided details about the continuance of the "stay behind" networks in some West European countries well into the 1970's and in some cases beyond. **********At the time the "stay behind" program was begun late in 1950, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was only a year old and could field few troops. "N.A.T.O. was pretty feeble," Mr. Cline said. **********The Greek civil war had recently come to an end, as had the Soviet blockade of Berlin. North Korean troops backed by the Soviet Union and China had invaded and occupied most of South Korea. The Truman Administration was living through what it officially called "a war scare." **********"The possibility that the Soviets would overrun Western Europe was there," Mr. Cline said. "I never thought they would, but the possibility was there."  Matching Wartime Maquis **********The idea was to create units like the French wartime Maquis and have them in place before and after a Soviet takeover, he said. Then, according to the plan, American teams would parachute in to establish liaison and help activate the resistance groups armed from caches already in place. He said the program was designed in the context of psychological warfare operations to "stiffen the spines" of Western Europeans by showing that the United States was resolved to defend and assist them. **********The American liaison concept had been developed by the Office of Strategic Services in the latter stages of World War II. It was successfully practiced in the 1944 invasion of France when some 90 teams of three men each parachuted in with two-way radios to operate with Maquis units in blowing up German rail lines and ambushing convoys. Mr. Colby was a member of one such team. **********In November 1950, he was mobilized by the C.I.A. to develop "stay behind nets" in Scandinavia to fight in the event of a Soviet invasion. After training in clandestine skills, he was posted to Stockholm. His was part of a program that also built such nets in France, West Germany, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Belgium and Italy. **********The program had its origin in policy discussions in the late 1940's involving Roscoe Hillenkoetter, the first C.I.A director, Secretary of State George Marshall and George Kennan, the State Department's Soviet affairs specialist, according to Senate documents. It was implemented by the agency's next director, Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, under an April 1950 policy directive. Former Director Had a Role **********The "stay behinds" were organized under the agency's Office of Policy Coordination, as the covert operations branch was then known, and directed by Frank G. Wisner. Mr. Wisner was assisted by Richard Helms, who later became a director of the agency. **********In 1976, the Senate select committee that had investigated American intelligence activities published a short history of the C.I.A. which contained the following passage: "Until 1950, O.P.C.'s paramilitary activities (also referred to as preventive direct action) were limited to plans and preparations for stay behind nets in the event of a future war. Requested by the Joint Chiefs of Staff, these projected O.P.C. operations focused once again on Western Europe and were designed to support NATO forces against Soviet attack." **********The budget for the Office of Policy Coordination's worldwide operations, including the European "stay behinds," rose from $4.7 million in 1949 to $82 million in 1952, while its personnel increased from 302 to 6,954 in that period. **********As the C.I.A. station chief in Bonn in the mid-1960's, Mr. Cline, among others, recommended that the program be phased out. By Then, 'Men Too Old to Fight' **********He recalled that by the time he had come in contact with the stay behind operations in West Germany "they were just a list of names," which he said might have numbered a thousand but "more likely were in the hundreds." **********"What I discovered was no organization, but a lot of men too old to fight," he said. "A lot had already died or were in work where they wouldn't conceivably want to be in the Maquis. A lot of guns and ammunition were in the depots for a long time and there probably weren't any more people to use them. It was scaled way back." The small arms and munitions were drawn partly from United States Army stocks and partly from European weapons depots, he said. **********Mr. Cline, whose highest post with the agency was Deputy Director for Intelligence, said he was under the impression that his recommendation for phasing out the stay behind program had been accepted by Richard Helms, then the head of the agency. He said he was somewhat surprised to learn from press reports this week that elements of the program had survived for another decade or longer. **********Mr. Helms said he did not want to talk about the program, partly "because I can't remember anything about it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/23/busin.main_headline: Tektronix Head Ousted; Poor Earnings Are Cited
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/23/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Tektronix Head Ousted; Poor Earnings Are Cited
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/23/busin.body_text: **********Three years after his surprise promotion to president and chief executive of Tektronix Inc. over higher-ranking colleagues, David P. Friedly resigned on Friday at the request of the company's board. Tektronix said a search for a new president and chief executive had begun. **********On an interim basis, Robert W. Lundeen, Tektronix's chairman, will serve as chief executive, and William D. Walker, a director, will serve as president and chief operating officer. Gary Arnold, the former chief financial officer of the National Semiconductor Corporation, was named to that post at Tektronix on April 12. **********None of the company's executives were available to comment, but a spokeswoman said that Mr. Friedly's departure was tied to the company's continuing disappointing revenues and earnings. ''A lot of good steps have been taken, but obviously our financial results have not been good,'' said Jeannine Navarra Jensen, the spokeswoman. ''The board decided it was time for a change.'' **********Tektronix, which led in the growth of the high-technology community near Beaverton, Ore., is the largest private employer in the state. In the 1960's and 1970's, the company's electronic instruments did well, but its computer products have had a harder time competing. In the last four quarters, the company has reported losses in three and a tiny profit in the other. **********When Mr. Friedly was named chief executive in 1987, over several more senior candidates, he was expected to shake the company loose from the gentlemanly ways of its founders and make it a tougher competitor. But despite shake-ups, restructurings and layoffs, Tektronix has continued to report weak results. **********Mr. Friedly, who is 50, came to Tektronix in 1974 after being with the Genrad Corporation for 12 years. He rose through the Tektronix ranks to vice president and general manager of the communications group before he was named president. He is a graduate of Cornell University.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/14/busin.main_headline: Two U.S. Companies Plan to Sell Soviets 34 Billion Cigarettes
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/14/busin.print_headline: Two U.S. Companies Plan to Sell Soviets 34 Billion Cigarettes
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/14/busin.body_text: **********To ease a worsening Soviet cigarette shortage, America's two largest tobacco companies said yesterday that they would sell 34 billion cigarettes to the Soviet Union, or more than a month's supply. **********Philip Morris, the nation's largest tobacco company, plans to sell more than 20 billion cigarettes to the Soviets, and RJR Nabisco, the second largest, plans to sell 14 billion. **********The move comes none too soon for Soviet smokers. The shortage has led to street demonstrations and reportedly to riots in some cities. Philip Morris's shipments will begin as early as the end of this month, and RJR Nabisco's may begin by the first week of October. **********The American cigarettes are destined for the Russian republic, which has half the Soviet population, but presumably that would free scarce domestic cigarettes for the rest of the Soviet Union. **********Cigarettes are sold for widely varying prices in different countries and are heavily taxed. But if the two companies' shipments were valued at 1989 United States prices, excluding taxes, the cigarettes to be sold to the Soviet Union would be worth about $1.9 billion, or a little over a dollar a pack. **********It is an indication of the Soviet Government's strong desire for the cigarettes that it has agreed to pay in scarce hard currency and ''counter-trade items'' that can easily be sold for cash. A Philip Morris spokesman declined to say what those items were but said the company was ''very comfortable with the items because they are readily and clearly marketable.'' Oil is one possibility, because the Soviet Union is a large producer of oil. It is unclear why the Soviets could not sell the items in question for the needed cash. **********Neither the Philip Morris Companies nor RJR Nabisco would disclose all the terms of the transaction, partly because the Soviet Union is still negotiating with other tobacco companies in the United States and other countries. But Philip Morris said it planned to ship Marlboros, the world's best-selling brand, as well as a selection of its other brands yet to be determined. RJR Nabisco plans to sell Winstons and other brands. **********The Tobacco Merchants Association, a trade group, estimated that Soviet consumption totaled about 418.5 billion cigarettes in 1989, or about 80 percent of the 524 billion smoked in the United States. **********Raymond J. Pritchard, chairman and chief executive of Brown & Williamson, the nation's No. 3 cigarette maker, said the Soviet shortage could be equivalent to a shortfall of perhaps 200 billion cigarettes a year. He said he had learned while traveling in Bulgaria that 11 of 20 Soviet cigarette plants had been shut down for repair or maintenance. ''It was a major bureaucratic screw-up,'' he said. **********Problem in Bulgaria **********In addition, Bulgaria, which provided nearly all of the 55 billion cigarettes the Soviet Union usually imports, started experiencing shortages of cellulose acetate, a material used for cigarette filters, because of a lack of hard currency. ''The imports from Bulgaria dropped very dramatically, worsening the shortage that was already apparent in the Soviet Union,'' Mr. Pritchard said.  Brown & Williamson, a unit of B.A.T. Industries of London, is also negotiating with the Soviet Union for a large order of cigarettes but will probably sell the less expensive cigarettes known as generics. The company said that by yesterday it had not received word on its bid. **********The shipments by Philip Morris and RJR Nabisco, which are the largest single export orders ever for both companies, may take as long as two weeks to ship to ports in Europe like Antwerp, Belgium. It may take another two weeks for land transport to the Soviet Union. Both companies are considering air freight for speedier shipment. **********Worldwide exports for Philip Morris are about 360 billion cigarettes and about 101 billion for RJR Nabisco. **********U.S. Production Capacity **********The Soviet order will tax Philip Morris's production capacity in the United States because demand is already high for many of its brands, especially Marlboro, said John A. Dollison, a company spokesman. The cigarettes produced for Russia will be made in American factories, and an undetermined number of Philip Morris factories in other countries. **********''We will be looking to do deals with other republics of the Soviet Union,'' Mr. Dollison said. ''We are only too keen to talk.'' **********The Philip Morris cigarettes will be sent between late September 1990 and December 1991 and the RJR cigarettes between October 1990 and September 1991. **********Philip Morris also announced that it planned to sell cigarettes to the Soviet Union over the long term as well. It said that it signed two agreements with the Soviet Government. One provides for ''the continuing supply of significant quantities of cigarettes'' to the Russian republic between 1992 to 1995. The second agreement provides for Philip Morris to provide technical assistance to modernize antiquated Soviet cigarette factories. **********RJR Nabisco is also close to signing similar agreements, said Brenda H. Follmer, an RJR Nabisco spokeswoman. The company may produce Winston cigarettes at the existing Uritsky cigarette plant in Leningrad and may help with the modernization of other cigarette factories, Ms. Follmer said. **********No Health Warning **********While Phillip Morris and RJR Nabisco said the cigarettes destined for the Soviet Union will be identical in every way to American cigarettes, they acknowledged that the cigarettes would lack the Surgeon General's health warning about cancer and other diseases linked to smoking. ''We put whatever labels are required by local government authorities,'' Ms. Follmer said. **********It is unclear how much the American cigarettes will sell for, but there were reports that a pack of Marlboros were selling for up to 20 rubles, or $32, on the Moscow black market. The average monthly wage for a Soviet worker is 240 rubles. **********Earlier this summer, the cigarette shortage added to public outrage over shortages of basic foodstuffs. Last month, state-run newspapers said that Soviet authorities were cracking down on black marketeers hoarding cigarettes and that a Moscow factory was running overtime to produce 45 million cigarettes in 24 hours. **********Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov sought to assure the Soviet Union's 70 million smokers that more cigarettes - both domestic and imported - would be available soon. **********But street demonstrations have grown in Leningrad and especially in Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/19/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Changes to Cut Pillsbury Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/19/busin.body_text: **********In a move to improve the operating efficiency of its Pillsbury Inc. division, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. today announced a $140 million plant modernization program that will result in the elimination of up to 1,300 jobs as outdated production operations are closed. **********The move is intended to modernize and consolidate Pillsbury's outmoded manufacturing and distribution system. **********The need for such a large-scale revamping ''points out just how far behind Pillsbury was in making themselves an efficient operation,'' said L. Craig Carver, an analyst with Dain Bosworth Inc., an investment firm in Minneapolis. **********Pillsbury plants will be closed in Terre Haute, Ind., and Fridley, Minn., resulting in the loss of 800 jobs. An additional 200 jobs will be lost when a food production line in Springfield, Ill., is shut down. Grocery product lines will be moved from several locations to a refurbished plant in Murfreesboro, Tenn. **********Pillsbury's Wellston, Ohio, operation will be the leading beneficiary of the expansion program. Construction will begin later this month on a 160,000-square-foot frozen food distribution center that will eventually employ 500 workers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/busin.main_headline: From Morgan To Milken: Two Drexel Legacies
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH;   From Morgan To Milken: Two Drexel Legacies
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/busin.body_text: **********It was front-page news, but the collapse of the House of Drexel, ending a saga that ran from J. Pierpont Morgan to Michael R. Milken, was greeted with a yawn in the financial markets. **********The Dow Jones industrial average dipped Monday as rumors of Drexel's problems spread, but the market's moves were gentle thereafter, and the Dow ended the week down just 12.61 points, to 2,635.39. It was news that Drexel would no longer be a player, but it was already clear - since the Campeau bankruptcy, if not before - that the game had changed. **********Some good news on the economic front may have helped share prices, as retail sales rebounded and business inventories fell, reversing trends that had sparked recession worries. And the trade deficit shrank in December. **********In a volatile financial world, few firms could claim a longer history than Drexel, dating from 1838, when Francis M. Drexel of Philadelphia began dealing in currencies issued by state-chartered banks. Just twice in that history, each time under the guidance of a dynamic young financier, did Drexel become a major power on Wall Street. The difference in directions taken in those two eras helps to explain why Drexel's current problems proved fatal. **********J. P. Morgan joined Drexel in 1871 at the age of 34, and the New York outpost of the Philadelphia firm was renamed Drexel, Morgan & Company. Railroad bonds were that era's financial craze, and many defaulted. In helping to get the rails reorganized, and the investors protected from rail bosses whose ethical standards earned the epithet ''Robber Barons,'' Mr. Morgan gained wealth and fame. **********In 1969, 23-year-old Michael Milken was hired as a bond analyst by Drexel, Harriman, Ripley, the firm that had evolved from the Philadelphia Drexel firm after it separated from Morgan. **********Mr. Milken, too, was confronted by bond-market disasters, and he concluded that the ''junk bonds'' of his era were trading too cheaply. He was right, and for a time he and his customers prospered. **********From his experiences, Mr. Morgan concluded it was essential for a company to be financially secure, with enough resources to withstand a ''panic,'' as depressions were known in those days, and for it to have an unquestioned reputation for honesty. In 1907, both the Government and Wall Street relied on Mr. Morgan to stem that year's panic. **********Mr. Milken learned a different lesson. Having seen that companies in trouble could survive and meet their obligations, he became an evangelist for debt, arguing that both borrowers and lenders would prosper as billions in new low-grade bonds were issued. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., as the firm became known, followed his lead. Its profits were spent, not saved, and corners were cut in ways the Government concluded were illegal. **********By 1990, the lessons of Morgan had been long forgotten. When the junk bond panic arrived, the lenders vanished and Drexel, with no financial cushion, could not stay in business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/09/busin.body_text: **********Ex-isting house sales declined 1.6 percent in the first quarter, a real estate trade group said today, as mortgage rates anchored themselves in double digits and prices in many areas continued to rise. **********The National Association of Realtors said sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.81 million units in the period, down from 3.87 million units in the fourth quarter and 3.90 million in the first quarter of 1989. **********At the same time, the survey showed the median price of existing houses rose 5.2 percent, to $95,900, up from $91,200 in the corresponding period of 1989. The median price means half of the homes cost more and half cost less. **********Mortgage rates also rose from 9.83 percent as the year began to 10.22 percent as the quarter ended, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Association. **********The survey covered sales of existing single-family detached houses, town houses, apartment condominiums and cooperatives. **********By region, the West posted a 3 percent sales increase, followed by the South, which was up seven-tenths of a percent. **********The Northeast has the largest decline, down 5.5 percent, and sales were down 4.9 percent in the Midwest to 980,000 units. **********The West also experienced the sharpest gain in median prices, up 7.6 percent, to $143,700. It was followed by the Midwest, where costs rose 6.9 percent, to $74,200. Prices advanced 2 percent each in the Northeast and South. The median price in the Northeast was $146,200, while it was $85,800 in the South.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/busin.main_headline: Mood Swings Set the Tone On the Street
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH;   Mood Swings Set the Tone On the Street
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/busin.body_text: **********If psychiatrists, rather than economists, were the specialists that Wall Street relied upon, they might have a simple explanation for the way the stock and bond markets have moved this year. ''Manic-depressive'' would be the diagnosis. One moment all is well; the next brings obvious and overwhelming reasons for fear. **********Consider the stock market. Less than two months ago, the newsletter writers surveyed by Investors Intelligence of New Rochelle, N.Y., saw a bright future for stocks. Now the proportion of bears has more than doubled. The economic outlook really hasn't changed much over that stretch, but weakness in stock and bond prices proved terrifying to that band of gurus. **********When opinions are that widely held, they often end up being wrong. So it may be no surprise that stocks have stopped falling and started to recover. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 45.50 points, to 2,648.20 last week, its second gain in as many weeks, as long-despised technology stocks led the way up. **********The real stars so far this year, however, have been energy stocks, a group out of favor for a decade. They held up well when most stock prices fell in January, and are drawing in more cash from buyers now. ''It's a major shift in market leadership,'' said Ken Spence, Salomon Brothers' chief technical analyst. ''It's an environment similar to the late 1970's.'' Recalling how most shares performed then, it is to be hoped Mr. Spence is wrong. **********In the bond market, managers entered the year in a euphoric mood that vanished when prices stopped rising. By the time last week's Treasury refunding approached, there was fear of blood on the Street. But the auctions went reasonably well, and a spirit of joy returned, at least in the Treasury market. ''Junk bonds'' still suffer from a dearth of buyers. **********Many of the trends and facts that engulf Wall Street go almost unnoticed on Main Street, where most people spend their days far away from a Quotron terminal, blissfully unaware of the nuances of the latest changes in producer prices or German interest rates. When they make investments, it is not with a view to scalping a quick profit before lunch. **********It was the public that snapped up Thursday's issue of 30-year bonds, while the pros were cautious. Bids that did not set a rate - the so-called ''non-competitive tenders'' that are the hallmark of individual investors - bought 9.6 percent of the bonds, which will pay 8.5 percent interest. Not since the double-digit interest-rate days of the early 1980's has the public been that enthusiastic. Some of those tenders may have been from small banks, buying Treasury bonds because they don't have many attractive loan opportunities, but a big part of the demand came from individual investors. **********Wall Street would like everyone to believe that the public is always wrong, the better to persuade investors to hand over their cash to a professional. But year after year the typical money manager underperforms market averages. Somebody else must be outperforming the averages.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/23/world.main_headline: U.S. Said to Weigh Multi-Front Attack To Divert Iraq Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/23/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   U.S. Said to Weigh Multi-Front Attack To Divert Iraq Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/23/world.body_text: **********Contingency plans drafted by top Army and Marine Corps officers call for a multi-front ground attack against Iraq to prevent the massing of elite Iraqi troops to guard against a possible American invasion of Kuwait, The Washington Post reported in its Sunday editions. **********The Post account, attributed to unnamed military sources, said the plan was drafted for President Bush in the event that the United Nations trade embargo fails and he decides to pursue a military option. Under the plan, United States troops would mount ground assaults from as many as four directions, including through the Jordanian desert and the Turkish mountains, the paper said. **********The multiple assaults would force President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to disperse his 140,000-member Republican Guard if the United States decided to launch an invasion against Iraqi troops in Kuwait, the Post said. **********A week ago the Post quoted Air Force Gen. Michael J. Dugan as saying that American air attacks, including a massive bombing campaign against Baghdad that specifically targeted President Hussein, were the only effective option to dislodge the Iraqi troops in Kuwait. General Dugan was dismissed the following day by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. **********The Post said it could not determine whether the Bush Administration had approached Turkey or Jordan about the sensitive question of securing attack corridors through their countries. **********King Hussein of Jordan has strongly opposed the deployment of American forces in the region. President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, who is to visit Washington next week, has said he would not allow Turkey to be a staging area for offensive military operations against Iraq, the Post said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/busin.main_headline: Bridge Loans Cast Shadows On the Street
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH;   Bridge Loans Cast Shadows On the Street
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/busin.body_text: **********Engineers demand firm foundations on both sides of a bridge. Investment bankers don't have engineering degrees. Shaky bridge loans these days have more than a few Wall Streeters quaking, and played a role in Friday's stock market tumble. Rising interest rates and worries over inflation also played a role, as producer prices were reported to have risen 4.8 percent in 1989, the largest annual gain since 1981. The interest-sensitive Dow Jones utilities average has fallen 6.1 percent so far in 1990, its worst fortnight since the 1987 crash. But fear that easy takeover financing is at an end may be the biggest reason that the Dow Jones industrial average ended the week down 84.04 points, to 2,689.21. **********The most prominent bridge loan is the $400 million that the Campeau Corporation owes to First Boston, Paine Webber and Dillon Read. That loan, which helped Campeau spend too much in buying Federated Department Stores, got lots of press last week as Campeau teetered on the edge of bankrupcy. **********But First Boston and its friends are not alone on high bridges. As Shearson Lehman Hutton prepares to sell stock to raise capital, one money manager confesses to finding the shares cheap but adds that he is worried about Shearson's $500 million bridge loan to Prime Computer. **********A bridge loan is supposed to tide over an acquirer until permanent financing is arranged. Once it seemed like a great way to make money. Now it seems like a financial form of Russian roulette, in which the investment bank makes a little money if all goes well. If not, it loses a lot more than it can afford. **********Some on the Street blame Michael Milken for bridge loans. Not that Drexel Burnham Lambert pioneered them, but the competing firms needed a way to assure clients that they could complete offers, as Drexel was able to do with its letters saying it was ''highly confident'' it could sell junk bonds to finance deals for its clients. So bridges were built. **********When the music stopped at the takeover tango, Drexel had egg on its face as it was unable to raise cash it promised for some deals. Its competitors have black holes on their balance sheets. Egg is better. **********The question now is whether the dance is over, or just waiting for the band to finish its break.''I think we're getting a permanent disappearance of the junk bond market'' as a takeover tool, said John Paulson, a partner in Gruss & Company. Gruss used to concentrate on speculating in takeover stocks. Now it plans to focus on trading bonds of troubled companies. ''We think that will be the great opportunity of the 90's,'' said Mr. Paulson. **********Even a decline in interest rates might not help the takeover market now, since the credit cutoff reflects default fears, not Federal Reserve tightening. But the Fed is probably less likely to lower rates with inflation fears again rising, and with interest rates climbing around the world, higher rates in this country may be needed to protect the dollar. A month ago, almost everyone was bullish on bonds, but the bullish case now looks as shaky as the Federated bridge.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/18/busin.body_text: **********The Ashton-Tate Corporation, a computer software company based in Torrance, Calif, said today that it had returned to profitability after a long string of losses. **********The company attributed the improvement to strong sales of the updated version of its core product, dBase IV. The company began shipping the 1.1 version of dBase IV on July 31. **********For the third quarter, Ashton-Tate had earnings of $1.1 million, or 4 cents a share, compared with a loss of $19.2 million in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenues rose 12 percent, to $60.4 million, from $53.9 million in the third quarter of 1989. **********In the quarter, the company announced a program to repurchase up to three million shares of its common stock; it has already repurchased 1.7 million. **********''We are very pleased with the progress we've made on dBase IV version 1.1,'' Bill Lyons, Ashton-Tate's president, said in a statement. ''We have shipped more than 350,000 units, including free upgrades.'' Ashton-Tate's sales had slipped because of defects in an earlier version of the product. **********The company's stock rose 12.5 cents today, to $6.875, in over-the-counter trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/busin.main_headline: Belgians To Write Off Drexel Stake
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/busin.print_headline: THE DREXEL COLLAPSE;   Belgians To Write Off Drexel Stake
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/busin.body_text: **********Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, a Belgian holding company that owns 26 percent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., announced today that it would write off its entire investment, which it valued at $92 million. **********Trading in the shares of Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, the second-largest company in Belgium after Societe Generale de Belgique, was suspended on exchanges here today before the announcement. Yesterday, on early news of Drexel Burnham's bankruptcy, the Groupe's shares had fallen 6 percent, to 4,070 Belgian francs (about $116). After trading resumed today, the price dropped to 3,940 Belgian francs. The stock's high this year was 4,640; last year it reached 5,050. **********Analysts said the Groupe's stock had largely been discounted in the last two years, reflecting the American firm's legal troubles and in anticipation of Drexel Burnham's losses. Through the mid-1980's, Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, whose total portfolio is valued at $3.46 billion, had gained as much as 40 percent of its net profits from Drexel Burnham. **********Major Force in Belgium **********The group has extensive holdings in Belgian banking, insurance and utilities and owns a stake in hundreds of companies through a network of subsidiaries. Together with Societe Generale it probably controls half this country's economy. **********In today's announcement, Groupe Bruxelles Lambert said its administrators ''consider it prudent'' to recommend to the board of directors that it write off Drexel Burnham as a total loss. The effect on net asset value, the administrators said, would be 165 Belgian francs a share. For 1989, the announcement said, the group's consolidated profit would be 4.1 billion Belgian francs, or 210 Belgian francs a share. **********Without the Drexel Burnham write-off, the group said, its profit would have been 380 Belgian francs a share, up from 333 Belgian francs a share in 1988. Nonetheless, the company said, it intended to recommend to the directors a dividend of 182 Belgian francs a share for 1989, compared with 173.3 Belgian francs the year before. **********Groupe Bruxelles Lambert is the result of the merger of two 19th-century trading houses dominated by French-speaking aristocrats. In 1986, the chairman of the group, Baron Leon Lambert, died at the age of 58 after liquidating his highly prized collection of modern paintings the year before. In the last years of his life, the baron lived in a penthouse suite above the headquarters of Banque Bruxelles Lambert, which is 12 percent owned by the group. **********A Reclusive Chairman **********By the time the baron died, the main control of the group had passed to Albert Frere, now 64, who had taken over his father's hardware store in the grimy provincial city of Charleroi after World War II and, through investments in steel companies, had made a fortune. Mr. Frere is now the chairman of Groupe Bruxelles Lambert but in recent years has rarely appeared in public to comment on the company's affairs. **********Groupe Bruxelles Lambert has extensive holdings in companies that deal in its stock, including 46 percent of Dewaay Sebille Servais, one of the country's largest stockbrokers. Banque Bruxelles Lambert, which under Belgian law is allowed to deal in stock including that of its owners, issued a recommendation to its customers last month to buy Groupe Bruxelles Lambert shares. **********Such an investment, the bank's research department said, would enhance a ''quality portfolio'' and should appreciate ''over the long term.'' When the recommendation was made, the stock was trading at 4,640 Belgian francs a share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/18/busin.main_headline: Bunnies Diaper Maker To End Benefit Claim
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/18/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;   Bunnies Diaper Maker To End Benefit Claim
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/18/busin.body_text: **********New York and nine other states reached an agreement with American Enviro Products Inc., makers of Bunnies Biodegradable Disposable Diapers, in which the company will stop its advertising claims that the product benefits the environment. The company will also pay a $50,000 penalty and has created a product that is less harmful to the environment because it is lighter and would take up less room in a landfill, said Edward Barbini, a spokesman for New York's Attorney General, Robert Abrams. **********The company had made claims that the diapers played ''a vital role in the disposal of plastic waste.'' **********''Green marketing is the consumer's battleground for the 1990's, and we're very pleased with the results of this suit,'' Mr. Barbini said. In green marketing the environmental advantages of a product are made part of the sales approach.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/15/busin.body_text: **********Shanghai's largest and most elaborate hotel and office complex opened on Friday after nearly five years of delays, cost overruns and political turmoil. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East;   21 Ex-Policemen Put On Trial in Romania In Timisoara Deaths
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East;   21 Ex-Policemen Put On Trial in Romania In Timisoara Deaths
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/world.body_text: **********The long-awaited trial of 21 former secret police officers charged in connection with scores of deaths in the December revolution began today in Timisoara, the western city where the revolution took form. **********In opening statements, the chief prosecutor, Col. Vasile Kozma, said 94 people had died in the Timisoara violence, 300 were wounded and 20 were missing. Early in the revolution, reports from Timisoara spoke of up to 4,000 people dying there. **********As the trial began 180 miles west of here, the Justice Minister announced in Bucharest that the chief of the military tribunal that condemned Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife to death had committed suicide. **********In Timisoara, armored personnel carriers and soldiers surrounded Casa Tineretului theater, now converted into a courtroom. The proceedings are the first against those suspected of trying to crush the uprising before it spread across the country. #7 Charged With Genocide The defendants, headed by Maj. Gen. Emil Macri, sat glumly in their striped-brown prison suits as the indictment was read. General Macri and six others are charged with genocide and face life in prison if convicted. The 14 others face up to 20 years in prison if convicted on lesser charges stemming from the shootings of unarmed civilians who took to the streets of Timisoara in December to demonstrate against Mr. Ceausescu. **********The death of the chief judge in the Ceausescu trial was announced here at a news conference by Justice Minister Teofil Pop, who said the official, Maj. Gen. Gica Popa, 57 years old, shot himself in the head with his pistol on Thursday in his Justice Ministry office. **********Mr. Pop said General Popa was taken to the Bucharest military hospital, where he died two hours later with his wife and daughter by his side. The general left a suicide note that asked forgiveness, but did not explain the motive for his act, Mr. Pop reported. **********But General Popa's wife, Eleonora, said her husband had been receiving anonymous threats since Dec. 25, the date of the trial and execution of Mr. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena. **********The Justice Minister said the general's voice was the one heard on the video recording of the trial. The recording was broadcast repeatedly on Romanian and international television. **********General Popa was reportedly the official who announced that the Ceausescus would be executed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/17/world.main_headline: Liberian Rebel Leader Hurt in Crash
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/17/world.print_headline: Liberian Rebel Leader Hurt in Crash
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/17/world.body_text: **********The leader of one of Liberia's rebel factions, Charles Taylor, was injured in an automobile accident today while traveling to meet a group of West African leaders to discuss a cease-fire in Liberia's civil war, a rebel spokesman said. The talks were postponed. **********''He was incapacitated, but it's not life-threatening,'' said the spokesman, Tom Woweiyu, adding that he did not know how or precisely where the accident occurred or the nature of Mr. Taylor's injuries. said, The incident occurred early this morning in northern Liberia when several vehicles in a rebel convoy crashed on their way to an airport here, the spokesman said. Mr. Taylor was scheduled to meet later today with President Dawda Jawara of Gambia, the leader of a group of five West African nations that are preparing to send troops into Liberia to force a truce in the conflict. **********Sketchy reports reaching Man, which is about 250 miles northeast of Monrovia, Liberia's capital, said Mr. Taylor and several members of his group were hurt in the crash. **********Trip Is Canceled **********Mr. Woweiyu said that on the advice of a physician traveling with the rebels, Mr. Taylor canceled his trip to Banjul, Gambia, to meet with Mr. Jawara, and was returning to rebel headquarters on the outskirts of Monrovia. But the reports of the incident could not be independently confirmed. **********Last week, a supply convoy destined for Mr. Taylor's group, the National Patriotic Front, was reportedly attacked by troops loyal to Prince Johnson, the leader of a rival rebel group. The attack also occurred in northern Liberia, near the Ivory Coast border, but Mr. Woweiyu said he was certain that Mr. Johnson's forces had no role in the accident today. **********''It was just a car pile-up,'' Mr. Woweiyu said. **********But the incident today will probably delay deployment of the joint army, naval and airborne force that is mobilizing in neighboring Sierra Leone. The force was expected to move into the besieged Liberian capital later this week. **********Evacuation Plan **********Leaders of the 16-member Economic Community of West African states, which is sending the international force, have said they intend to evacuate foreign nationals and, if necessary, impose a cease-fire. They have talked of establishing an interim government and supervising elections. The five-nation peacekeeping force of about 3,000 includes soldiers from Nigeria, Guinea, Ghana, Gambia and Sierra Leone. **********In Banjul a statement released by the West African group said the meeting was rescheduled for Aug. 20. **********In another statement, the group ansaid a conference of Liberian political parties would be held in Banjul to establish an interim government. The statement added that among those invited to attend were representatives from President Samuel K. Doe's political party, as well as those from the two rebel groups. **********President Doe and guerrillas led by Mr. Johnson have said they would cooperate with the West African peacekeeping effort, but Charles Taylor has opposed foreign intervention in the conflict and has threatened to attack any troops sent to Liberia. Mr. Johnson's forces now reportedly control most of Central Monrovia and Mr. Taylor controls the rest of the country.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Sigma Upgrades Standard Monitors
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/23/busin.body_text: **********Sigma Designs Inc., a computer peripheral maker based in Fremont, Calif., said yesterday that it would offer special circuitry, designed to reduce electromagnetic field radiation emissions from cathode ray tube-based monitors and display systems, as a standard feature in all of its monitors for I.B.M. PC-compatible and Apple Macintosh systems. **********The company has been offering the ircuitry, originally developed in Sweden, as a $200 option with its monitors.
