The company said that the circuitry could reduce radiation by as much as a factor of 10.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/24/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Baker Snaps at Critics Of Moscow Arms Deals
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/24/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Baker Snaps at Critics Of Moscow Arms Deals
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/24/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today defended his handling of arms control negotiations with Moscow, saying that those who have accused him of giving too much to the Soviets are people who were never interested in arms reduction agreements with the Kremlin in the first place. **********Mr. Baker, smarting at suggestions that he had been snookered in his talks last week with the Soviets, used a White House briefing about the coming summit conference to try to smother a brushfire of criticism from conservative columnists and the Republican right that he was too generous with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********Defending the compromises he struck in Moscow last week in order to conclude a treaty limiting long-range strategic nuclear missiles, Mr. Baker said they had the full support of the United States military. **********In addition, he said, the compromises came after a series of concessions by the Soviets that will force them to cut their heaviest missiles by 50 percent and will allow Washington to protect its most valued programs, like cruise missiles and ''Star Wars''. **********Moscow Delays a Vote **********Mr. Baker also announced that he had just learned that the Supreme Soviet has not scheduled a vote for May 31 on a pending bill codifying freer emigration. When he was in Moscow last week, Mr. Baker was told that the bill would be on the calendar for that day, causing a bit of consternation in the White House. **********At the Malta summit meeting in December, President Bush promised that as soon as this bill was passed he would waive the Jackson-Vanik trade restrictions, thereby allowing the Soviet Union to export products to the United States at the lowest tariff rates possible. Since then, however, the situation in Lithuania has arisen. **********While Administration officials have declined to say so publicly, they have concurred that until the tension between Mr. Gorbachev and the Baltic states is clearly on the road to resolution, it would be preferable for the President not to waive the Jackson-Vanik provisions, no matter what happens with the Soviet emigration bill. **********Administration officials are concerned that President Bush will waive the Jackson-Vanik restrictions and that the Soviet leader will crack down on the Baltics a short time later, leaving the White House looking foolish. In addition, officials believe that even if the President wanted to waive the trade restrictions, he could run into serious opposition in Congress as long as the Baltic situation is in turmoil. **********Administration officials were therefore dreading the idea that the Soviets would pass the bill on the second day of the summit meeting. Mr. Gorbachev would then ask President Bush to fullfill his Malta promise and the President would be forced to say no. Officials said they still have not been able to sort out whether the postponement of the vote in Moscow was purely a scheduling matter or a decision by Mr. Gorbachev to avoid an embarrassing situation. **********White House on Defensive **********But it was on the question of his handling of arms control negotiations, not trade, that Mr. Baker was most animated. The criticism of his negotiating strategy, symbolized in today's issue of The Washington Times with the banner headline: ''Baker 'Sellout' in Arms Talks Feared,'' has put the Secretary of State and the White House somewhat on the defensive a week before Mr. Gorbachev's arrival. **********Answering a question about the compromise he struck in Moscow last week in an effort to close a treaty limiting strategic long-range nuclear weapons, Mr. Baker said with a jab at some of his Reaganite critics, ''First of all, let me say that I don't think you should look just at one negotiating session.'' **********''We've had a number of negotiating sessions on Start, going back into the Reagan Administration,'' he said, referring to the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty. **********There is, he added, ''very strong support for this agreement among the military leadership of the United States of America - support for it as a good agreement that is very much in the national security interests of the United States. And it would appear to me at least that most of the criticism is coming from those who in the past, from time to time, have simply rejected the concept of arms control generally.'' **********The Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, Mr. Baker said, ''is shaping up largely on original United States concepts and original United States proposals.'' **********'All the Other Way Round' **********''It's been quite some time, I think, since anyone would even argue that we've made concessions,'' he said. ''It's been pretty much all the other way around. **********''Let me remind you that this treaty will achieve a 50 percent cut in SS-18's, the heavy missiles that the Soviet Union has and that we don't have. They've got 308 of them and they'll only have 154 after this treaty, and that's very important from the standpoint of the United States. And it will represent a 50 percent cut in Soviet ballistic missile warheads as well. **********''You may have forgotten,'' Mr. Baker continued, that at the Wyoming United States-Soviet ministerial meeting last September the American side convinced Moscow to drop its demand for a formal link between a strategic arms treaty and one that would limit the United States Strategic Defense Initiative, or ''Star Wars,'' program. **********''People said in the aftermath of that meeting, 'Gosh, that couldn't be true, it's too strongly held a position by them, and the two sides were at loggerheads,'' Mr. Baker said. ''And yet they came to our position. You may have forgotten the Krasnoyarsk radar, which was a stumbling block for a number of years and which the Soviets agreed here in one of our negotiating sessions not long ago was indeed a violation and they said they'd take it to the ground.'' **********''And perhaps you've forgotten,'' he continued, that differences over air-launched and sea-launched cruise missiles ''hung this treaty up for so many years, and we've got what we want, and we've got a treaty that protects us on'' both nuclear-tipped and conventionally armed cruise missiles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/world.main_headline: BUSH GAINS TIME AS MOSCOW DELAYS LAW ON EMIGRATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   BUSH GAINS TIME AS MOSCOW DELAYS LAW ON EMIGRATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/world.body_text: **********A conflict between the White House and Congress over the trade accord signed at the Washington summit meeting was averted today when the Soviet Parliament said it would probably not take up a new law permitting unfettered emigration until September. **********Because passage of the Soviet law is a condition for expanding trade ties with Moscow, the White House said today that President Bush would not submit the accord that he signed on Friday with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the Senate until September at the earliest, assuming that the Soviet legislature, the Supreme Soviet, acted then. **********Political Breathing Space **********The likely delay will give the White House political breathing space to shore up support for the trade agreement. Presidential aides greeted the news from Moscow with obvious relief. **********As the results of the summit meeting were tallied, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union announced today at a meeting of foreign ministers in Copenhagen that the Soviet Union would withdraw a small number of its short-range nuclear weapons from Central Europe. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d lost little time in dismissing the military significance of the Shevardnadze announcement. [Page A10.]  Soviet officials said the decision to postpone the vote on the emigration bill could conceivably be changed, but the legislation was not on the agenda of the Parliament's current session, which ends on June 14. The Parliament does not convene again until September. **********On the trade treaty, some American officials said the Administration was aware before it signed the accord that the Soviet Union, which delayed passage of the emigration bill before, could well do so again. That would give Mr. Bush time to deal with Congressional opposition to the treaty. **********But Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said this consideration ''didn't have any influence'' on Mr. Bush, who he said had ''no idea'' beforehand that the vote would be delayed until September. ''We didn't have any indication of a timetable,'' he said. ''We assumed it was totally unpredictable, just like our own Congress.'' **********At a meeting today with Congressional leaders, Mr. Bush defended his decision to sign the trade treaty. He has been criticized by some lawmakers for not linking the signing of the treaty to a resolution of Moscow's struggle with Lithuania over its declaration of independence. Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, accused Mr. Bush of ''abandoning Lithuania.'' **********Several of the lawmakers who met with Mr. Bush said they warned him that the treaty would not go through the Senate as long as Moscow's dispute with Lithuania was in a stalemate. **********''Even after they codify their emigration practices, if the Lithuania or Baltic problem is not resolved, then I think it will become a matter of great concern in the Congress,'' said Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader. **********Administration officials said they saw the Soviet Parliament's action today as a temporary reprieve from the political battle over the trade agreement and expressed hope that Mr. Gorbachev might be able to make progress toward resolving the Baltic dispute by the time the Soviet Parliament votes on the new emigration law. **********The news today from Moscow on the Parliament's agenda was the latest twist in the tortuous history of the treaty, which sets rules for Soviet-American commerce, establishes protections for American companies doing business in Moscow and would increase the volume of trade by leading to the lifting of longstanding barriers, including higher tariffs and restrictions on Soviet access to American financial markets. **********Officials said that Mr. Bush warned Mr. Gorbachev five weeks ago in a letter that the proposed treaty was a political land mine because Congress was unlikely to approve it without a resolution of the Lithuanian situation or at least a lifting of Moscow's economic sanctions against the Baltic republic and the start of negotiations. The sanctions were imposed after Lithuania declared independence on March 11. **********An Implied Warning **********The letter's implied warning that no trade agreement would be signed at the Washington summit meeting was made explicit just before Mr. Gorbachev arrived, the officials said. Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, the Soviet Ambassador to Washington, was told last Wednesday that the treaty would not be among the documents Mr. Bush was willing to approve at a signing ceremony with Mr. Gorbachev that was scheduled for Friday, an official said. **********But there were sentiments within the Administration that the treaty should be signed, and even as Mr. Bessmertnykh was given the warning, the Administration was considering the option that was finally adopted - signing the treaty but holding up Senate consideration until the new emigration law was adopted, officials said. **********''There was a sense that not to sign it at all would be a rebuke to Gorbachev at a time when we are trying not to show a loss of support for perestroika,'' an official said. Then, over two days of talks with Mr. Bush, Mr. Gorbachev made the trade agreement a personal issue between the Presidents, officials said. **********Members of the Soviet delegation threatened, meanwhile, to scuttle a long-term grain agreement if the overall trade accord were not signed, officials said. **********Mr. Fitzwater said of the delay of the emigration law: ''That may not be bad in the sense of it gives them a little time'' to work out the Lithuanian dispute and issues related to emigration. These include Mr. Gorbachev's suggestion that he might consider delaying Soviet Jews' emigration visas unless Israel guarantees that they will not settle in the occupied territories. **********Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Gorbachev's warning is ''contrary to our policy'' and added that Mr. Bush told Mr. Gorbachev that the United States wanted to see unfettered Jewish emigration. **********During a discussion on human rights, Mr. Bush also expressed concern about what he perceived as rising anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union, officials said. He suggested that both leaders ''speak out against it,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. **********''President Gorbachev said he would look for an opportunity to do that, but that was it,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/busin.body_text: **********West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's call last week for talks with East Germany on creating a single German currency was a bold political maneuver - plus a daunting economic and financial challenge. And the challenge of putting the proposed monetary union in place, of making the West German mark the official currency of East Germany, would land on the doorstep of the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank. **********Karl Otto Pohl, the 60-year-old president of the Bundesbank, seems to be a reluctant conscript in Mr. Kohl's drive for a monetary union, which would sharply accelerate the pace of economic reunification of East and West Germany. When the Chancellor announced his proposal on Tuesday, Mr. Pohl branded it ''a very fantastic idea.'' **********Indeed, even before Mr. Kohl's announcement, Mr. Pohl and other Bundesbank directors had cast doubt on the merits of monetary union in the near future. First, Mr. Pohl said, East Germany needed to build its economy up to a level closer to the West's; he had doubts that shifting to another currency alone would solve East Germany's problems. For Bonn, he warned, a rapid currency union involved serious risks of rising inflation, higher interest rates and deepening budget deficits. **********Abrupt Change of Rhetoric **********But Mr. Pohl, a central banker of proven political skills, having risen in the Government ranks as a protege of Helmut Schmidt, changed his rhetoric abruptly after the West German Cabinet backed Mr. Kohl on Wednesday. The Government set up a ''German unity'' committee to pursue negotiations with the East German Government on monetary union. Afterward, Mr. Pohl explained pointedly that his differences with the Kohl Government were mainly over matters of timing, not substance. **********''One must not look at currency union with a shopkeeper mentality,'' Mr. Pohl said in a radio interview. He called Mr. Kohl's plan ''a historic decision that could not be approached with a faint heart.'' **********Mr. Pohl's changed tone is largely a compromise with reality. Established in 1957 and modeled closely on the United States Federal Reserve System, the Bundesbank has, by law, a high degree of independence, but it is required to support the general economic policy of the Government. **********Besides, any move to create a monetary union would be a political decision for East and West Germany. The Bundesbank could not veto the move, regardless of the qualms of its top officials. Indeed, though Mr. Pohl sat in on the Wednesday Cabinet meeting, no Bundesbank representative will be on the Government's ''unity'' committee, set up to map out all aspects of reunification, beginning with monetary union. **********'Really Irresponsible' **********The Bundesbank, economists say, now finds itself in a difficult position. ''What the Bonn Government has done is really irresponsible,'' said Jonathan Hoffmann, an economist with Credit Suisse-First Boston in London. ''Having an independent central bank gives them the opening to make an extravagant political promise, and then step back and leave it up to the Bundesbank.'' **********Still, reservations about the proposed monetary union extend well beyond the Frankfurt headquarters of the Bundesbank. Many crucial particulars have not yet been discussed, notably the appropriate exchange rate. Beyond that, serious questions remain about how it will work and if it will have the desired effect of shoring up the East German economy enough to stop the steady drain of its citizens to the properous West, at the rate of nearly 2,000 a day. **********The thinking behind the proposal is that monetary union would restore the flagging confidence of East Germans that their economy would be formally integrated into West Germany, giving the East Germans reason to stay home. **********In East Berlin, there are clearly misgivings about a rapid monetary union. The economic integration that comes with the shift to a single currency, for instance, may bring widespread layoffs and higher prices as inefficient East German state industries fall by the wayside and subsidies are trimmed. For East Germany, a monetary union would amount to giving up its economic sovereignty. **********'Social Consequences' **********With an eye on the March elections, the Economics Minister of East Germany, Christa Luft, said ''a union has such huge economic and social consequences that a Government with only a few weeks left in office understandably cannot give its blessing.'' **********''Politically, the proposal could be a solution, but economically, I have my doubts for both sides,'' she said. **********For the Bundesbank, the main worry about a rapid monetary union - and the economic reunification that would inevitably accompany it -is that it poses a severe inflationary threat. The most obvious, but less significant, source of inflationary pressure associated with monetary union would be the printing of more West German marks to exchange for Ostmarks. **********Until a rate of exchange is decided, it is impossible to say how much additional money supply will be created. But it would not seem to be a big problem for the Bundesbank. For example, if one West German mark was issued and exchanged for five East German marks, the addition to the nation's money supply would be about 3 percent, by some estimates. **********''The financing problem is manageable,'' Mr. Pohl said last week. **********Larger Inflation Threat **********But the larger inflation threat linked to monetary union would be posed by the huge amount of spending required to lift the East German economy toward the standards of the West. The forecasts are guesses at best, analysts admit, but the numbers range up to more than $600 billion over the next several years. Most of that money would presumably come from West Germany, through some combination of private and Government investment. And the higher spending, particularly by the Government, could well fuel inflation. **********For an institution that has been called ''the world's financial conscience on inflation'' - fighting it even when there is none - the genuine prospect of inflation is a chilling matter. **********Like other central banks, the Bundesbank is charged with regulating the amount of money in circulation and of credit supplied to the economy with the aim of maintaining the value of money. The Bundesbank takes its marching orders seriously indeed, helped by a powerful anti-inflation consensus in West German society. **********Here, the word ''inflation'' has a tenacious grip on the national psyche. Many German families still have some memory of the hyper-inflation of the 1920's - the wheelbarrows full of currency that bought a loaf of bread or bowl of soup. That clearly colors the thinking of the Bundesbank policy makers, and even modest upturns in inflation are viewed with alarm. **********In the late 1970's, West Germany's trading partners, particularly the United States, urged Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic Government to act as an economic locomotive to pull Europe out of recession. While economic growth rose, so did inflation. By 1981 it was running at a 6.3 percent annual rate. **********Playing on Fears **********A year later, Mr. Schmidt was gone, replaced by Mr. Kohl and his center-right coalition, which made effective use of inflation fears in its election campaign. **********That lesson was not lost on Mr. Pohl, a Social Democrat who was appointed president of the Bundesbank in 1979 by Mr. Schmidt. During the 1980's the Bundesbank kept its monetary policy fairly tight. Inflation dropped steadily, and in 1986 West Germany actually had deflation of two-tenths of 1 percent. During Mr. Pohl's tenure, West Germany has had the lowest inflation of any industrialized nation, and it is now running at a modest annual pace of about 3 percent. **********Because of its success in limiting inflation, the Bundesbank is held in high esteem by most Germans. **********Accordingly, its critics have been almost exclusively foreigners. For example, James A. Baker 3d, when he was Treasury Secretary in the Reagan Administration, would often accuse the Bundesbank of being obsessed with inflation, undermining the world's economic growth. The French Government has also pricked the Bundesbank from time to time about slow growth. In the French view, inflation of up to 8 or 9 percent is a sign of a robust economy. **********Moderate to Rabid **********Within the Bundesbank's 19-member central bank council, the views seem to range from moderately to rabidly anti-inflationary. Helmut Schlesinger, vice president of the Bundesbank, is often singled out as a true hard-liner. Mr. Baker once accused him of leading a cadre of inflexible monetarists on the Bundesbank's council that would fight inflation at any cost, including economic growth. **********The council meets every two weeks at Bundesbank headquarters in Frankfurt to set monetary policy. It is headed by either Mr. Pohl or, in his absence, Mr. Schlesinger, and consists of the 8 bank directors and the presidents of the 11 state central banks, for a total of 19 members. **********The composition is intended to represent fairly the federal structure of West Germany. Decisions are made by a simple majority of the votes cast. While the state central bank presidents usually take their cues from the Bundesbank directors, there have been instances in which the council went against their wishes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/world.main_headline: LITHUANIA OFFERS TO DISCUSS A VOTE ON ITS SOVEREIGNTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   LITHUANIA OFFERS TO DISCUSS A VOTE ON ITS SOVEREIGNTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/world.body_text: **********Leaders of this republic's embattled independence government sent a signal of compromise to the Kremlin tonight, saying they were ready to discuss the difficult issue of a referendum on secession if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev agreed to talk with them. **********The Lithuanian President, Vytautas Landsbergis, conceding that the Kremlin had greeted his pleas for negotiations with a ''concrete wall,'' appeared to be searching openly for a conciliatory note that might entice Moscow to the negotiating table. **********''There are no questions that cannot be discussed except the question of Lithuanian independence,'' Mr. Landsbergis said at a news conference. ''The problem of the referendum could also be discussed.'' **********Meeting Gorbachev's Complaints **********The republic's Parliament declared Lithuania independent of Soviet rule 18 days ago without holding a referendum among Lithuanian citizens. This has been a particular complaint of Mr. Gorbachev as he continues to denounce the republic's secession as illegal and therefore nonnegotiable. **********Mr. Landsbergis had previously belittled the referendum issue. He has said that Lithuania is not seeking permission to secede, but rather reclaiming the independence it lost 50 years ago when it was forcibly annexed by Stalin as a result of a Soviet nonaggression pact with Hitler. **********An additional suggestion of compromise today was the outright endorsement of an independence referendum by Algirdas Brazauskas, the leader of the Lithuanian Communist Party, which broke away from the Soviet Communist Party in December. Mr. Brazauskas, also a Deputy Prime Minister of Lithuania, is viewed by the public as one of the few accomplished politicians here capable of dealing with the Kremlin. **********'An Additional Ace' **********''A referendum would be an additional ace in our negotiating position,'' said Mr. Brazauskas, who appeared at the Lithuanian President's side to propose that the independence issue be put to the voters. **********Moscow is drafting a law on procedures for secession by Soviet republics. It includes requirements like a referendum, a five-year waiting period, satisfaction of economic claims and approval by the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies. The Baltic republics have said the draft law is unacceptable. **********There has been no sign that Moscow is entertaining the notion of compromise as the dispute over sovereignty continues. But Mr. Brazauskas noted that in his last visit to the Kremlin, on March 13, Mr. Gorbachev argued that Lithuania's failure to put the independence issue directly to the voters further weakened its position. **********Buying Some Time **********''He was insisting on the necessity of a referendum,'' Mr. Brazauskas said. While a vote might not change Mr. Gorbachev's opposition, the Lithuanian party chief said, it would make the republic's case much more emphatic. **********Lithuanian leaders have repeatedly said that a referendum would show overwhelming support for independence. About 80 percent of the republic's people are of Lithuanian heritage, and the only real opposition to independence comes from non-Lithuanians. A referendum might give Mr. Gorbachev a bit of time and perhaps a chance to preserve the illusion that Lithuania is following Moscow's rules, as other independence-minded republics anxiously watch the struggle. **********The political chemistry at the press conference was interesting. Mr. Brazauskas, a bluff party careerist, showed a positive zest for political detail and speculation. **********Mr. Landsbergis, a music professor who came to politics by way of the independence drive and prevailed over Mr. Brazauskas when a president was selected, maintained an icy, untrusting reserve toward the Kremlin. He reiterated that the Soviet authorities were waging a war of nerves in the republic, and he assailed the arrests of young Lithuanians who had deserted the Soviet Army in the name of patriotism. **********Party Chief Projects Confidence **********Mr. Brazauskas talked confidently of approaching Moscow with ''a certain compromise, a certain firmness.'' **********''I do not think Mr. Gorbachev has a very bad attitude toward Lithuania,'' he said. He said that despite the recent harassment of Lithuanians by the Soviet military, the Soviet President was ''seeking a way out.'' **********The joint press conference raised the question of whether a new strategy was being attempted by the Lithuanians. **********Was Mr. Brazauskas, with his timeworn party credentials and populist appeal, finally assuming the role of realistic broker in the standoff between Moscow and Vilnius? **********Deferring to Mr. Landsbergis, the party chief said he had his own government portfolio, the economy, not the role of political negotiator with Moscow. Mr. Landsbergis left the issue unresolved, lightly replying that Mr. Brazauskas was ''not my employee.'' **********Even so, Mr. Brazauskas's presence at the head table was certain to shore up popular enthusiasm for the hard-pressed independence drive, whatever the reaction from the Kremlin. **********Soviet Army Offers Amnesty **********During the day, the Government-controlled press in Moscow maintained its heavily propagandistic coverage of Lithuania. The reports emphasized calls for direct rule by Moscow from officials of the loyalist, rump Communist party, which was discredited in recent republic elections. **********Moscow also offered amnesty today to Lithuanians who had deserted from the Soviet Army, pledging that they would not be punished if they returned to their units and resumed service. Those who do not return will be ''searched out, detained and be subject to criminal punishment in accordance with current law,'' the Soviet press agency Tass quoted Defense Ministry officials as saying. **********Hundreds of Lithuanian deserters have been in hiding in the republic. Noting that such soldiers are being taken into custody at the rate of 7 to 10 a day, Lithuanian officials said that Moscow's offers of amnesty rang hollow. **********In some cases, the Lithuanian officials charged, Soviet patrols have been breaking into family homes to search for soldiers. Tass reported today that 51 Lithuanians had been sent back to their units, although it did not specify whether their return was forced or voluntary. **********Asked how long Lithuania could reasonably hold out as the Kremlin ignores pleas for talks, Mr. Landsbergis cited polls demonstrating the popularity of the independence drive. **********Mr. Brazauskas offered a more detailed reply, reporting that there had been ''no deterioration in the supplies of gasoline or oil'' provided by the national Government. He said the republic was managing despite banking restrictions imposed on the republic's accounts under a Moscow mandate. **********Prague Offers to Mediate **********PRAGUE, March 29 (Reuters) - In a message today to Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Landsbergis, President Vaclav Havel said the Czechoslovak Government was prepared to act as a mediator to help solve the Lithuanian standoff.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/19/busin.main_headline: Madison Avenue, Where Humor Can Get Some Respect
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/19/busin.print_headline: Madison Avenue, Where Humor Can Get Some Respect
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/19/busin.body_text: **********Humor on Madison Avenue is no longer a laughing matter. It has evolved from whimsical fad into an established marketing tool that is now taken very seriously, something akin to product demonstration, celebrity endorsement, the sexual tease or the adorable child. **********''It has become part of the repertoire,'' said Clay S. Timon, vice president and director of worldwide advertising at the Colgate-Palmolive Company. Indeed, consumer surveys show that comedy is now a common element in a majority of the most popular advertising campaigns, including the Energizer battery-powered bunny who bursts unannounced into other commercials and the ''Bo Knows'' commercials for Nike shoes, whichcarry Bo Jackson's athletic prowess to ridiculous extremes. **********This is so despite the negative reputation comedy has had among advertisers in past years, when it was accused of making people laugh but also of making them forget the product they were supposed to buy. The case against it was perhaps made strongest by David Ogilvy in his influential 1963 book, ''Confessions of an Advertising Man.'' ''People don't buy from clowns,'' Mr. Ogilvy said. **********But humor is getting respect now because of a growing need to stand out from the crowd. Advertising executives concede that they have created an enormous clutter of ads. There seem to be few media untouched by commercial messages (though in one promising development a Chicago company, the Viskase Corporation, found no takers for its offer to print edible-ink ads on hot dogs). **********Humor helps ads break out of that clutter, especially in giving a new or obscure product quick recognition. When ASI Market Research recently compared the viewer recall of several types of television commercials, those with humor were remembered by 17 percent more viewers than the average commercial. Two years ago, when Video Storyboard Tests asked viewers what kind of commercials they found persuasive, 58 percent chose funny ones; 44 percent named the nearest competitor, those with children. **********The reasons for comedy's success are many. Carol Moog, a psychologist and advertising consultant, offers this theory: ''Humor gives people a way to vicariously express their aggression. It reaches them above the base consumer level. It appeals to their intellect, and makes them feel bright.'' **********There is, however, a risk. A failure, like the ''Herb the Nerd'' campaign that Burger King launched in 1985, can subject a company to ridicule. What follows is a look at some creators of funny advertising whose work ranks among the most successful. **********Cliff Freeman has used humor to lift several clients from obscurity. Of course, his famous slogan did not make Gary Hart laugh during his first Presidential bid, which Walter Mondale derailed by asking, ''Where's the Beef?'' But when uttered by the grouchy Clara Peller, the line written by Mr. Freeman as a copywriter for Dancer Fitzgerald Sample vaulted Wendy's into the upper echelon of fast-food chains. **********The campaign is one of several from Mr. Freeman - now chairman of Cliff Freeman & Partners, a division of Saatchi & Saatchi - that have worked for underdog clients. Advertising from the nation's largest corporations, like McDonald's and General Electric, tends to be sentimental, as a way of reinforcing good will accumulated over years of market leadership. But upstarts cannot afford to play safe. ''With a limited media budget,'' Mr. Freeman says, ''we have to do advertising that has a tremendous impact immediately.'' **********Thus, when Philips Lighting sought to break General Electric's stranglehold on the light bulb market, it turned to Mr. Freeman. The Philips ads show the perils of life with shorter-lived light bulbs (like making a pass at the wrong person in a dark elevator - the dumpy cigar-chomper instead of the beautiful woman.) As for the criticism that the viewer may remember the joke but not the product, Mr. Freeman says the problem is solved by repeated showings, and that it is humor that makes this bearable. With a less engaging commercial, ''you could mention the name of the product 20 times, but no one would want to watch.'' **********JO SEDELMAIER, a 57-year-old Chicago director, is the man from whom Mr. Freeman says he learned the most about comedy. They have collaborated on several commercials, including ''Where's the Beef?'' and, for the Little Caesar's fast-food chain, ''Masseuse'' in which roly-poly men compare pizza prices while being kneaded and slapped about like so much dough. **********Mr. Sedelmaier, who is currently spoofing airline foibles - like the trays that dump food on your lap - for Alaska Airlines, made his reputation through commercials for Federal Express, notably ''Fast Paced,'' which stars an executive whose manic speed-talking symbolizes the pace of business that requires the speed of Federal Express. **********The director is no fan of emotional advertising. ''So much of what I see embarrasses me,'' he said. ''It's mawkish. There's not that much to be serious about.'' What must be serious to him are the facial expressions of his characters. ''You play everything straight,'' Mr. Sedelmaier said. And he tends to cast quirky people, like Clara Peller, rather than glamorous ones. In one slapstick spot for the drink Tang, a slight man tangos with an enormous woman, played by a man, whose weight sends the couple crashing through the floor. **********Mr. Sedelmaier concedes an element of meanness in some of his work. But, he said, ''I hear the same criticism of Chaplin. I'll stand in that company.'' **********Ask people in the advertising business to name their all-time favorite commercials and odds are they will mention Roy Grace's ''Spicy Meatball'' commercial for Alka-Seltzer. In it, an actor filming 60 takes of a spaghetti-sauce commercial needs relief. And they will probably cite Mr. Grace's ''Gorilla'' commercial for American Tourister luggage about the ape who hurls a red suitcase around his cage Mr. Grace, an art director who with Diane Rothschild runs Grace & Rothschild, made the classic ''Spicy Meatball'' and ''Gorilla'' ads two decades ago while at Doyle Dane Bernbach. He said of ''Spicy Meatball,'' given the heightened sensitivity about the portrayal of ethnic groups: ''You'd have a problem with that now. There's nothing mean-spirited about it, but it is a stereotype.'' **********The 53-year-old Mr. Grace remains committed to humor, but of a more urbane sort. For a print campaign for J&B Scotch, he and Ms. Rothschild have illustrated a series of straightforward headlines with visual puns. In ''A J&B Toast,'' the red letters of the logo pop out of a toaster. An upcoming ad for Range Rover parodies the infamous Infiniti ads that showed lots of pretty scenery but no car. In the spoof, with a similarly beautiful pastoral scene, a voice asks quietly: ''What more could you ask for?'' A British voice answers: ''quite a bit actually,'' and a Range Rover bursts into view. Mr. Grace admits that he is nervous about the ad, but says humor is worth the risk: ''When it works, there is nothing as sweet.'' **********Working through her own company, Joy Radio, Joy Golden, who is 60, has become a pre-eminent radio copywriter and producer. Her best-known campaign was for Laughing Cow cheese, a client of TBWA Advertising. In one ad, a woman tells this story: ''I went home and said, 'Look, Stuart, I brought you a little Laughing Cow in a red net bag freshly wrapped in wax with an easy-open French zipper.' He said, 'Enid, don't talk naughty to me.' Then he ate all 10 mini-cheeses and said they were the best treat he ever had in bed. So I smacked him.'' **********''Good comedy,'' Ms. Golden said. ''You take on an affinity for the product.'' **********TRANSLATING QUINTESSENTIAL BRITISH HUMOR FOR AMERICANS **********While most Americans say they dislike advertising, polls show that the British seem to enjoy it. One reason, advertising people say, is the higher portion of humor and the softer sell in British ads. **********Among the most popular figures in British advertising is a comic actor well-known to Americans: John Cleese, who is the spokesman for Schweppes soft drinks in the United States and Britain. Neither campaign bears any resemblance to the ads featuring the dignified, bushy-bearded Commander Whitehead; they were developed by David Ogilvy in the United States in the 50's and ran for 18 years. **********The new, self-deprecating campaigns accept the notion that advertising is inherently silly. The British ads, which Mr. Cleese co-wrote for Saatchi & Saatchi, begin with a voice-over in which he talks about the haggling that went on over his contract. He then appears on a beach flexing his biceps, in a parody of typically exuberant soft-drink commercials. **********One of Schweppes's American ads, created by Ammirati & Puris, mocks British and American stereotypes. Mr. Cleese plays a stuffy British aristocrat who sips Schweppes by his fireplace and pontificates indecipherably. Then, dressed in shorts and a Hawaiian shirt, he takes on the Americans. He bursts through a Schweppes poster at a beach and lip-syncs to an ebullient voice-over that exhorts the viewer to ''Buy a truckload today!'' **********This final version is more hyperactive than the original, Mr. Cleese says; in testing, American audiences did not recognize the parody. **********''In England,'' Mr. Cleese saids, ''having someone scream out to buy something would be considered rude, and a bit vulgar.'' Advertising, he said, has its limits: ''You can't sell in an advertisement. You can interest someone in a product by giving them a favorable association.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/21/busin.main_headline: Proxy Firm Founder Pleads Guilty to Theft and Fraud
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/21/busin.print_headline: Proxy Firm Founder Pleads Guilty to Theft and Fraud
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/21/busin.body_text: **********Donald C. Carter, who turned the prosaic business of proxy solicitation into a tool for corporate takeover battles, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Manhattan today to stealing $1 million from clients and filing false New York State income tax returns. **********He was subsequently dismissed by the owners of the Carter Organization, the company he founded. **********Justice George F. Roberts set May 2 for sentencing and said that the 41-year-old former analyst would receive 16 months to four years in prison and would be fined $2 million. Mr. Carter agreed to establish a $1 million escrow fund to make restitution to victims of the theft. **********Ronald Goldstock, director of the New York State Organized Crime Task Force, said in a news conference at his office here that Mr. Carter could have served up to seven years for grand larceny and up to four years for evading personal New York State income taxes and falsifying his 1986 return. **********Fake Documents Used **********Mr. Goldstock said the investigation established that Mr. Carter ''routinely billed his clients for nonexistent or inflated expenses, then supplied fraudulent documentation to justify the false invoices.'' The victims included Union Carbide; Shell Oil; Caesars World; UNUM, an insurance company, and MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings, the owner of Revlon. **********Mr. Goldstock said Mr. Carter ''charged hundreds of thousands of dollars of personal expenses, including renovations to his apartment at 120 East End Avenue, as business expenses of the Carter Organization. **********James W. Wetzler, commissioner of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance, said, ''The tax frauds to which Mr. Carter pleaded are in many ways very similar to that to which Leona Helmsley was recently convicted in Federal court, namely using the corporations for paying your personal expenses and then claiming them as business deductions.'' **********He was referring to the former hotel executive who was convicted of Federal tax fraud. She was sentenced to four years in Federal prison and fined $7.1 million but is appealing the verdict. **********Mr. Wetzler said he did not know how much Mr. Carter owed, ''but it could run from five to seven figures.'' He said, ''There will be a discussion between our auditors and his accountants about just how much the tax deficiency is.'' Mr. Wetzler said Mr. Carter and Mrs. Helmsley ''paid substantial amounts of tax, but committed fraud by not paying the full amounts.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/28/world.main_headline: Changes in Eastern Bloc Heighten Nationalist Yearnings of Basques
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/28/world.print_headline: Changes in Eastern Bloc Heighten Nationalist Yearnings of Basques
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/28/world.body_text: **********Never in need of much encouragement to proclaim their separate identity, nationalist groups in the Basque country and Catalonia are using events in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union to justify calls for regional self-determination in Spain. **********The resulting debate has quickly become lost in semantic arguments over the meaning of self-determination as opposed to self-government and autonomy, the concepts that were incorporated in the 1978 Constitution as a way of accommodating Spain's regional groups. **********The suspicion that the ultimate objective of Basque and Catalan nationalists is independence has been enough to prompt King Juan Carlos and Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez to reiterate that Spain is an indivisible and indissoluble union. **********Even in the Basque country and Catalonia, opinion polls show that only one in four people favor independence. But the intensity of feeling on all sides of the issue has underlined how regionalism continues to trouble Spain after more than a decade of democracy. **********E.T.A. Poses Biggest Problem **********The most acute problem is posed by the Basque separatist guerrilla group known as E.T.A., which began fighting for independence during the long, highly centralized rule of Gen. Francisco Franco and has continued its terrorism since the dictator's death in 1975, causing more than 600 deaths in 21 years. **********Support for E.T.A. and its methods has waned since the new Constitution allowed the Basque country to negotiate a high degree of autonomy, including the right to raise its own taxes, create its own police force, speak its own language and elect its own parliament. Yet nationalist sentiments remain strong. **********The current debate began last month, when a standing committee of Catalonia's local Parliament approved a resolution that endorsed self-determination. The sponsors noted that only days earlier the 12-nation European Community, including Spain, called for ''self-determination'' in East Germany. **********Jordi Pujol, the conservative nationalist who is President of Catalonia and whose party backed the resolution, subsequently played down its importance. ''I never talk of self-determination,'' he said. ''I talk of nation and state, of autonomy and independence, which are clearer concepts. We don't ask for independence but greater autonomy.'' **********But the issue was quickly taken up in the Basque country, where the local Parliament is to vote next month on two competing draft resolutions proclaiming the right of the Basque people to self-determination. The debate gained momentum from Lithuania's demands for independence from the Soviet Union. **********More Than a Semantic Dispute **********The more moderate of the two resolutions, sponsored by the right-of-center Basque Nationalist Party and the Basque Left, emphasizes that self-determination is ''a dynamic, gradual and democratic'' process and calls for revision of the autonomy agreement with Madrid. **********The other measure, backed by the centrist Basque Solidarity party as well as by E.T.A.'s political wing, known as Herri Batasuna, or People's Unity, goes much further. It affirms the Basque nation's right to ''territorial political unity'' in four northern Spanish provinces and three provinces in France's Basque region. **********Government officials said that while the more radical resolution was not likely to be approved, the political agitation stirred by the debate in Madrid and in the provinces had made it impossible for the Government to accept even the notion of constitutional reform. They argued that Basque nationalists were playing into the hands of E.T.A. extremists. **********Prime Minister Gonzalez asserted that with Europe moving toward greater unity, it was ''nonsense'' to talk of self-determination in Spain. ''On this I will be inflexible, whether in government or opposition,'' he said, ''because when you reach a certain age it is difficult to change convictions and I am convinced that Spain's unity cannot be questioned.'' **********Yet with the issue of nationalities dominating headlines in Europe, the debate seems likely to continue. Pasqual Maragall, the Mayor of Barcelona, the capital of Catalonia, went so far as to declare: ''I do not consider myself Lithuanian. I do not consider myself in the same political situation as a Lithuanian who is oppressed from a national point of view.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/busin.main_headline: Value of a USX Spinoff Is Disputed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Value of a USX Spinoff Is Disputed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/busin.body_text: **********The USX Corporation's sprawling plant along the shore of Lake Michigan here is the foundation of what many consider to be among the most efficient steel operations in the United States. **********Yet some analysts say the nation's largest steel producer would have difficulty continuing to outperform the industry as an independent company, spun off from USX as proposed by Carl C. Icahn, its largest shareholder. They also doubt that a spinoff would make each existing USX share worth $48 - 40 percent more than the current price - as Mr. Icahn stated in proxy material sent to shareholders early in April. **********''If the value of the company were $48 with a spinoff of steel, the stock price would reflect a value closer to that,'' said Jeffrey Miller, an analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. **********Shareholder Vote Set **********Shareholders will vote at the company's annual meeting on May 7 whether to spin off at least 80 percent of the steel business into a separate company called the U.S. Steel Corporation, the name used by USX for 85 years until 1986. Under Mr. Icahn's plan, each existing USX share would be replaced with two types of shares - one representing the steel company and the other an energy company composed of USX's large oil and gas holdings. Management would be under no obligation to carry out the plan if it was approved. **********Mr. Icahn, who urged management to put his proposal to a vote in lieu of his waging a proxy fight, is eager to rid USX of the steel business, which accounts for one-third of the company's sales and earnings. During a down cycle, he argues, the lagging steel unit could weaken the earnings of the energy subsidiary. **********He believes the market would value a pure energy and a pure steel stock higher than it now does a hybrid USX, which he contends is trading at less than its fair value because few analysts understand the intricacies of both businesses. **********Mr. Icahn has valued a separate steel company at $9 a share and the energy company at $39 a share. [Shares of USX closed on the New York Stock Exchange Monday at $34.50 each, up 37.5 cents.]  But some analysts believe the stock is already overvalued, run up by the presence of Mr. Icahn, who owns 13.3 percent of USX. And most say the value and virtue of spinning off the steel group depend on how certain issues regarding taxes and retiree benefits are resolved. **********Other analysts agree that steel should be sold, but question the timing of a sale. They say the unit would bring a higher price if the steel market were healthier. Some believe that Charles A. Corry, chairman and chief executive of Pittsburgh-based USX, opposes Mr. Icahn's proposal because he would rather sell steel when the market improves. **********While shareholders are expected to defeat the spinoff proposal by voting with management, as they usually do in these situations, Mr. Icahn could get support from some institutional investors. Like Mr. Icahn, some of these investors are irritated that USX's stock has risen only 8.4 percent in the last 15 years, lagging behind the 308 percent increase in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index during the same period. **********They contend that a restructuring undertaken by USX in 1987, after Mr. Icahn proposed taking over the company, was not radical enough, and welcome his latest threat as a much-needed catalyst for change. Under the restructuring, which management promised would raise the value of the stock, the company repurchased shares and placed its faltering Texas Oil and Gas unit up for sale. That unit is still unsold. **********Earnings Improve **********But management argues that the company is healthier than it has been in years. It earned $965 million last year on sales of $18.7 billion, up from net income of $756 million on sales of $16.8 billion in 1988. **********Also, since Mr. Icahn began to invest in USX three years ago, the company's stock price has increased 66 percent, compared with the 37 percent rise in the Standard & Poor's 500 during that period. **********And the oil and gas business, entered into in 1982 with the purchase of the Marathon Oil Company to protect against the cyclicality of the steel sector, now accounts for nearly two-thirds of USX's sales and earnings, up from 58 percent in 1988. **********Operating earnings of Marathon, the centerpiece of USX's energy holdings, have climbed significantly since 1987, to $862 million last year. They should continue to grow with the anticipated improvement in oil production and demand, analysts said. **********''Marathon is a valuable energy company with significant growth potential,'' said Rolf Wagner, an analyst at Scott & Stringfellow in Richmond. ''If the steel business were separated, none of that would change.'' **********The steel business has also staged a turnaround. After losing more than $2 billion during the four-year industry slump that began in 1983, the company became profitable in 1987 -helped by widespread layoffs, new equipment, improved demand and Federal restrictions on imported steel. It earned $432 million in 1989. **********Evidence of Revival **********Here in Gary, it now takes only 3.5 hours of labor to produce a ton of steel, down from 10 hours 10 years ago and significantly less than the domestic industry average of 6.6 hours. USX has pruned its work force to about 20,000 people, from 75,000 a decade ago. And by next year, Gary's output will be produced entirely by continuous casters, the equipment that casts steel far more efficiently than the old method, in which ingots were used. Now, more than 60 percent is continuously casted. **********But management calculates that operating the steel group as a stand-alone company could cost an additional $100 million to $200 million a year. Without the energy assets, analysts said, the steel company would have more difficulty raising the equity and debt capital it needs to keep pace in technology and modernization. It likely would also be saddled with more than $1.5 billion in debt at a time when steel earnings are expected to fall. **********Management is also concerned about losing $900 million in tax-loss carry-forwards. In the proxy materials, Mr. Icahn said USX's tax carry-forwards could be used up by the end of this year, before the spinoff. **********Question of Pensions **********But Mr. Icahn did not address several other concerns, such as how the steel company could cover its enormous retiree and medical benefits. Last year alone, the company paid $972 million in pension benefits. **********''It may be necessary for USX to create a trust fund, or to make a commitment to fund retiree benefits beyond the time of a steel spinoff,'' said John C. Tumazos, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ''That would have some impact on the results for the energy segment's performance.'' **********What is more, while issuing stock in the entity would invite an acquisition, top management and analysts say the steel business might be worth more in the second half of this year, or in 1991, when auto demand is expected to pick up and the steel market, which began to soften in the last quarter, bounces back. **********Based on their longstanding interest in the United States steel industry, Japanese steel companies are among the most likely acquirers, according to analysts. Japanese steel companies have ownership stakes or joint ventures with all of the large, integrated steel producers in the United States, including USX. **********USX officials say that Japanese companies have expressed interest in acquiring the company's huge plant here. But Mr. Corry has opposed a piecemeal divestiture. **********Interest From Europe **********Company officials say there is also growing interest from steel companies in Europe. That was underscored last month when the LTV Corporation, the nation's third-largest steel producer, said it was talking about a possible sale of part of its steel unit to Groupe Usinor-Sacilor, the giant French steel company. **********Hans Mueller, an industry consultant and professor of economics at Middle Tennessee State University, in Murfreesboro, Tenn., said candidates for a purchase or joint venture include Thyssen Stahl A.G., the large West German steel company, and British Steel P.L.C. **********However, several European steel officials say that the smaller, specialty steel companies in the United States are more likely targets than companies like USX, because their margins are higher. ''It seems that an investment in a large, integrated steel producer in the United States is not the best way to make money,'' said Heinz Kriwet, chairman of Thyssen. **********Still, some foreign steel companies say that USX's mill here would be a significant foothold in the United States market. ''The Gary facility,'' said a senior official at another West German steel company, ''is now something to look at seriously, considering the activity of Carl Icahn.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/14/busin.main_headline: Lockheed Shares Rise But Far From $40 Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Lockheed Shares Rise But Far From $40 Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/14/busin.body_text: **********Shares of the Lockheed Corporation increased $2 today, to $31.75, on the New York Stock Exchange after the investor Harold C. Simmons expressed interest on Monday in acquiring the company for $40 a share. **********The fact that the stock traded well short of $40 reflected a lack of confidence by investors in the proposed offer, analysts said. **********On Monday after the New York exchange had closed, Mr. Simmons proposed that Lockheed join him in offering investors $40 a share to take the company private, placing the value of Lockheed at about $2.5 billion. **********Mr. Simmons, a Dallas financier, has a history of taking large stakes in companies while keeping arbitragers and other investors in the dark about his ultimate intentions. Sometimes he has sold out his holdings, and other times he has succeeded in taking over the target company. **********Mr. Simmons controls 19.8 percent of Lockheed's 63.1 million shares. He bought the shares at prices well above the current price. He has been pursuing Lockheed for some time and lost a proxy fight for control of the company last spring. **********Lockheed responded cautiously today to the offer. A spokesman said company executives would be willing to meet with Mr. Simmons to obtain additional details. No meeting was set, however. **********Some analysts dismissed Mr. Simmons's offer as being too low. "I believe the $40-a-share offer is inadequate," said Lawrence M. Harris, an analyst with Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards in Los Angeles. "I would place a value on Lockheed as a takeover candidate at $55 per share." **********Gary J. Reich, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., said Mr. Simmons "is trying to create an environment where people think the company is for sale or where management is about to put itself on the block." **********Mr. Simmons has said he will be unable to finance a deal without Lockheed's help. His company, NL Industries, has about $430 million in cash but also more than $1 billion in debt. **********Mr. Reich said the missiles and space systems division of Lockheed alone was worth at least $5 billion, or more than twice what Mr. Simmons is offering for the entire company. **********The missiles and space group, which accounted for about 50 percent of the company's $9.89 billion 1989 sales, has a strong business as one of the nation's largest producers of spy satellites.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/01/busin.main_headline: Finance/New Issues;   Fannie Mae in Pricing Of Mortgage Securities
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/01/busin.print_headline: Finance/New Issues;   Fannie Mae in Pricing Of Mortgage Securities
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/01/busin.body_text: **********The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, priced a total of $1.25 billion in new securities yesterday. **********Fannie Mae sold $825 million in real estate mortgage investment conduit securities in three separate transactions. Through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, the Government agency priced $300 million of the Remics, which are backed by 9 percent Fannie Mae mortgage-backed securities that in turn are backed by 30-year fixed-rate mortgages. Yields ranged from 8.48 percent to 10.5 percent, with spreads over Treasury securities ranging from 50 to 200 basis points. The range on the average life of these securities run from one year to 20 years. **********In another $300 million Remic offering, through J. P. Morgan Securities Inc., the similarly backed securities were priced to yield from about 8.44 percent to 10.15 percent, while the spread over Treasury securities with a similar maturity ranged from 52 to 188 basis points. The range on the average life of the securities runs 2.35 years to 23.16 years. **********Also the Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette Securities Corporation priced $250 million of the Remics, which are backed by 9.5 percent Fannie Mae mortgage-backed securities. Yields on this issue ranged from 8.60 percent to 10.5 percent, while the range on the average life of the securities runs from 1.14 years to 23.8 years. Yield spreads over Treasury issues go from 50 to 200 basis points. **********Freddie Mac, meanwhile, priced $400 million in 10-year subordinated debentures, which carry a coupon of 9.15 percent and are priced at par. The offering is being made through the agency's regular selling group.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   Nortek Settles Complaint Of Lying on Stock Purchase
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   Nortek Settles Complaint Of Lying on Stock Purchase
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/busin.body_text: **********A longtime corporate raider, Nortek Inc., was accused yesterday of lying to the Securities and Exchange Commission in a filing regarding its efforts to acquire another company. **********Nortek and top executives including Ralph R. Papitto, its chairman, consented to an injunction and said the company would pay back the amount the S.E.C. says it made as a result of lying in 1987 about when it acquired stock in a company it was trying to take over. Those who acquire more than 5 percent of a company's outstanding shares are required to disclose their holdings within 10 days by filing Form 13-D with the S.E.C. **********The S.E.C. action may do little to deter other potential violators. If the S.E.C. charges are valid, Nortek is no worse off economically than it would have been had it complied with the law. It will pay $503,000, plus interest, with at least some of the money going to investors who were hurt by the inaccurate disclosures. **********The S.E.C. charged that Nortek lied in early 1987 about when it purchased a block of shares in the Rexham Corporation, a maker of machines for the paperboard industry. By misstating the date of purchase, it was able to delay the 13-D filing and keep accumulating stock without tipping its hand and sending up the price of the shares, the S.E.C. said. **********There was, of course, no way to learn of that from reading the S.E.C. filing; that required an investigation. Since Nortek filed lots of 13-D's, involving holdings in many companies, one might have expected the agency to begin an inquiry to see if there had a pattern of violations. But while S.E.C. officials would not comment yesterday on whether such investigations had been made, one said that they would amount to ''piling on'' and be pointless. **********The most the S.E.C. could hope to get, he said, was an injunction against violating the law, and now that such an injunction has been filed there is no point in investigating previous cases. If the company violates the law in the future, however, a contempt citation could be sought. **********Nortek's chairman, Mr. Papitto, issued a statement saying the company agreed to the judgment without admitting the charges ''in order to bring an end to the continuous drain on management time and to avoid incurring additional legal fees.'' Mr. Papitto, along with Richard L. Bready, Nortek's president, and Richard J. Harris, its treasurer, were ordered not to violate securities laws in the future. Company officials declined further comment. **********Nortek acquired a reputation in the 1980's as a small-scale conglomerateur, buying and selling subsidiaries at a rapid pace. But it seemed that for every company it bought, there were several in which it took only a stake. **********Its run at Rexham ended in April 1987, when Nortek, having offered to buy the company for $43 a share, agreed to sell its stock back to Rexham at $42 a share. **********The S.E.C. said the $503,000 Nortek is to pay is equal to the profit it made on the 62,950 shares of Rexham it purchased after it was required to disclose its holdings, but before it did so. Rexham's share price shot up after Nortek filed its 13-D. Investors who sold Rexham shares from Jan. 27 through Jan. 30, 1987, will be eligible to claim part of the payment, the S.E.C. said. **********The S.E.C. accused Nortek of concealing the facts regarding its purchases by having a subsidiary hold shares and then having it sell the shares to the parent company. By not reporting the subsidiary's transactions, the filing appeared to be in compliance, the S.E.C. contended. **********In another aborted takeover try in 1987, Nortek aroused the ire of many takeover speculators, but did not provoke S.E.C. action. In that case, involving Stanline Inc., Nortek's S.E.C. filing said it held more than 5 percent and was considering a takeover. But Nortek did not report that the day before the filing, Stanline's president had told Mr. Papitto in a phone call that Stanline would resist a takeover attempt. **********As arbitragers leaped in to buy Stanline shares after the filing was made, Nortek was the principal seller, a fact it disclosed a few days later, along with the statement by Stanline's president. Mr. Bready later told a reporter that Mr. Papitto had failed to mention the phone call to other company officials, so the company did not know of it when the original S.E.C. filing was made. **********Nortek, a maker of building products and aerospace components, has not done all that well in recent years. Earnings per share reached a high of $2.87 in 1985, and the share price peaked in early 1986, about the time those figures were announced, at $19.25. It reported losses equal to $1.23 a share for the first nine months of 1989, but has not yet released fourth-quarter figures. **********The company's share price fell 37.5 cents yesterday, to $3.375, in New York Stock Exchange trading. Its low trade of $3.25 a share was its lowest since 1978.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/18/busin.main_headline: Careers;   Gulf Crisis Stirs Interest In Geology
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/18/busin.print_headline: Careers;   Gulf Crisis Stirs Interest In Geology
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/18/busin.body_text: **********SMALL liberal arts colleges like Wooster, in Wooster, Ohio, report growing student interest in geology as a major, as do engineering schools like the Colorado School of Mines. **********This might be an obvious outcome of the Persian Gulf crisis, but the news comes with a twist because there is already a shortage of geologists. **********Many geologists work for small environmental companies and local and Federal governments instead of for oil companies. Shortages are certain to increase as the oil industry's need for geologists, especially those with master's degrees, grows. **********Samuel Root, professor of geology at Wooster, said there was increased interest by students in the environment and such problems as water contamination and waste handling, both of which require geologists' skills. **********''There is a tremendous increase in the numbers of geologists working on cleanups,'' he said. ''Many recent grads work with small environmental companies. Now, with the oil situation, we will need even more.'' **********He said that when he first joined the Wooster faculty in 1983 there were 20 to 25 geology majors. ''That dropped to 7 after a couple of years and now it has almost doubled, to 13 this year,'' he said. The liberal arts college has 1,800 students. **********''Students find out from friends about good jobs and they get excited and declare a major,'' he said. **********Today's geology majors, Dr. Root stressed, ''need a lot more chemistry, several courses in computer science as well as a course in the flow of fluids.'' **********Professors of geology also need to take more courses, he said, especially refresher courses, which are often given by professional associations. **********''I now teach a hydro geology course,'' he said, ''Next week I am going to a three-day program in Sarasota, Fla., given by the National Water Well Association on the subject of contaminated waters and how to clean them up. I will work the material into my course. **********''With the gulf crisis and higher oil prices, I think we are looking at a long-term need for more geologists. We will need more research and development in other energy areas -coal production, for example.'' **********Dr. Root has an academic as well as a corporate background. He received a master's degree from the University of Manitoba, Canada, and holds a doctorate in geology from Ohio State University. For several years, he worked for Exxon, mostly in South America. **********''Students often ask what I did working for a large corporation and what interesting assignments I had,'' he said. **********Samuel S. Adams, professor of geology and geological engineering at the Colorado School of Mines in Denver, says that students make up their minds about majors while they are in high school and even grade school these days. **********''Students catch on quickly to economics and it filters down through high schools,'' he commented. For example, he said that in his department, before retrenchment by the oil companies and low oil prices in the mid-80's, there were 60 geology majors in each of the junior and senior classes, but that there were now about 15 majors in each of the classes. Students generally do not declare majors until the end of their sophomore year in college. **********He explained that during that retrenchment, young people in Colorado watched their fathers and other relatives lose jobs in the oil industry, and turned away from the idea of becoming geologists or petroleum engineers. **********But he says those effects are starting to wear off. ''Even without the gulf crisis we have turned the corner,'' he said. ''Geology majors now are getting jobs, research funding is moving up, interviews on campus are increasing.'' **********Mr. Adams explained that environmental issues had ''opened up jobs for our students, all of whom are also trained as engineers.'' **********''The word is getting around,'' he said. Aided by a grant from Amoco, he had brochures printed explaining careers in geology that his undergraduate students are handing out at Colorado schools. ''They are also giving talks,'' he said. ''Very young people don't want to listen to a gray-haired old fellow like me. My students are almost their peers.'' **********He likened the differences between geologists and petroleum engineers to the differences between linguistic experts in Romance languages and Slavic languages. **********But geologists and petroleum engineers can work together effectively through computer graphics, he explained. ''We geologists are detectives and historians,'' he said. ''I can represent my views graphically by computer and the petroleum engineers can overlay their ideas on it, also graphically.'' **********Dr. Adams, who received his doctorate from Harvard, explained that cooperation between these professionals had become much easier because of $2 million in computer hardware and professional help provided by the International Business Machines Corporation to establish the I.B.M. Center of Geo-science Computing on campus.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/01/world.main_headline: Battle Against Cocaine Traffic Is Languishing in South America
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/01/world.print_headline: FALTERING DRUG WAR: THE FLOW FROM LATIN AMERICAN - A SPECIAL REPORT;   Battle Against Cocaine Traffic Is Languishing in South America
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/01/world.body_text: **********Despite some seemingly spectacular successes, the drug war in South America is not going well. Critics say the American military attack on Panama, justified in part as an anti-drug initiative, has only fragmented what is already a largely ineffective effort. **********Despite the lack of sympathy for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama, Latin America was clearly shaken by the latest case of United States military force in the region. Peru dramatized that reaction by pulling out of an Andean summit meeting on drugs with President Bush, set for February, and briefly halting an anti-drug effort with the United States. **********Because Peru grows 70 percent of the coca plants processed into the cocaine that is smuggled into the United States, its withdrawal from the summit talks dashed hopes for a start on a cohesive regional plan. **********Peru Could Become Sanctuary **********Colombia and Bolivia, the other two major cocaine producers in South America, say they still plan to meet with President Bush in February. But without Peru's cooperation, narcotics experts say, the drug war cannot succeed, because the country would become a huge sanctuary for growers and drug traffickers pursued by the two neighboring countries. **********Trying to knock Panama off the cocaine-distribution map by taking out General Noriega, who has long been linked to the drug traffic, was not a fair trade for the alienation of Peru, critics say. Panama's importance in the drug trade was waning as tension between General Noriega and the United States grew and drug traffickers and money launderers left for more tranquil points in the Caribbean, Mexico, Canada, Europe and Asia. **********Mr. Bush's campaign to stop cocaine at its source in the Andes, part of a broader drug strategy announced in September, includes $2 billion in economic aid to Peru, Bolivia and Colombia over four years and $261 million mainly in aid to the military and police in those countries. **********But four months into the campaign, the picture is bleak. **********Cocaine is flowing as freely as ever to the United States, where the appetite for crack remains ravenous, and it is becoming increasingly clear that for the Andes nations themselves, cutting cocaine production and exports is by no means the No. 1 priority. **********Colombia has embarked on a campaign to arrest its major traffickers and seize their assets, but for every trafficker who falls, another replaces him, overseeing the processing of the coca leaf at jungle laboratories and arranging for the shipment of cocaine to North America. And the coca plant continues to be cultivated in Peru and Bolivia, where poor farmers have discovered its value as a cash crop. **********In an interview, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, characterized the Administration's campaign as ''little more than a paper initiative.'' **********''The United States,'' he said, ''must launch a genuine plan for the Andes, not just a laundry list of disjointed initiatives.'' **********The Administration's response is that the problem of cocaine smuggling from Latin America has been building since the early 1970's, and that it will take time to solve. ''We can show some little successes, but over all it's going to take several years,'' said a United States official in Peru. ''We're just getting into the ballgame, just starting to get the resources we need.'' **********Some Administration officials working on drug issues in Washington say they do not expect to see any measurable effect on the flow of cocaine into the United States until late 1990. ''That's just a realistic assessment of how long it takes government to work,'' one said. **********Some Bush aides acknowledged that the Panama invasion has not been a plus for the drug war, and one said it was ''catastrophically negative'' and indicated that Washington was holding out hope that Peru would ultimately decide to join in the Andean summit meeting now that it has resumed its anti-drug program with the United States. Colombia One Kingpin Down, But Many to Go One of the most notable successes in the drug fight came in mid-December, when Colombian security forces chased down and killed Jose Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a powerful and violent leader of the Medellin cartel, which controls much of the world cocaine market. It was a major accomplishment for Colombia, and it bolstered public support after drug bosses had repeatedly escaped police raids and terrorized the capital, Bogota, with nightly bombings. **********In the last two weeks drug terrorism has dropped significantly. And there is some evidence that drug-ring leaders are now fighting each other. But the American and Colombian authorities say Mr. Rodriguez Gacha's death will have little effect on the export of cocaine because someone will win the battle to succeed him and simply pick up the slack. **********And Colombian traffickers, who control most of the cocaine industry worldwide, are moving their jungle factories, where paste from the the coca leaf is processed into powder. The refineries are being set up in Peru and Bolivia and even along the frontiers of Brazil and Ecuador, which until now had been relatively free of drug traffic. **********Scores of smaller Colombian drug processers and shippers and some of the major traffickers who have operated quietly and without violence have been left alone by the Government. Should the level of terrorism remain low for an extended period, some Colombian experts predict, the Government will declare victory and permit the peaceful drug traffickers to go about their business. **********In Colombia, as in Peru and Bolivia, political power and economic conditions are more important concerns. **********''We are fighting two wars in Colombia,'' Carlos Lemos Simmonds, the senior member of President Virgilio Barco Vargas's Cabinet and the President's chief political adviser, said in an interview, referring to the war against drugs and the war between drug traffickers and the nation's leaders. **********''The deadlier war is the one of the drug barons against our own politicians, our judges, our journalists,'' he said. ''They want to be the ones who govern the country. They want to make Colombia into a narco-state, so they can handle their business more easily. Both wars are urgent. But we have to stop these people from killing other Colombians. This has priority.'' Peru and Bolivia A Profitable Habit Hard to Break Presidents Alan Garcia of Peru and Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia argue that the solution to the drug problem lies not in force but in broad economic development - road building, electrification, agricultural services, the introduction of industry - along with price supports to make other crops more attractive than coca. **********The high profits from cocaine have made the Bolivian and Peruvian Governments reluctant to move against it, and few farmers have been willing to switch to other crops. Some Bolivian farmers have taken United States and Bolivian money, offered as an inducement for destroying coca plots and cultivating other crops, and moved to remote fields to plant more coca.
