In Peru, the Upper Huallaga Valley is the world's most fertile ground for the coca plant, and farmers there have virtually halted the cultivation of any other crop. **********The $2 billion in economic aid pledged by President Bush to Peru, Bolivia and Colombia over four years works out to about $166 million a year for each of the countries, an enormous jump. But Mr. Garcia and Mr. Paz Zamora are talking about $500 million a year and more. **********For Peru, the gravest concern is the Shining Path, a Maoist guerrilla movement that has been terrorizing the country for nearly 10 years. Mr. Garcia argues that pressure on coca farmers only provides recruits for the guerrillas, who exploit the cocaine trade by protecting the farmers and then ''taxing'' both them and those whom the Shining Path permits to export the drug. **********Bolivia's economy has forced many workers to protest conditions. The nation is under a state of siege, imposed after teachers began demanding raises that would have upset a long-range restructuring of the economy away from central controls. **********Colombia says it needs good prices for its main legitimate export, coffee, and fewer restrictions on its exports to of freshly cut flowers and textiles to the United States. But under pressure from American coffee makers for more advantageous prices and different mixes of beans, the United States has walked away from an international coffee agreement on price supports. **********World coffee prices have plunged, and Colombia says it will lose about $500 million a year unless the agreement is restored. Administration officials say they are trying to find a way for Colombia to recoup its loss, but the talks involve dozens of countries and are going slowly. **********Senator Biden proposes that to assist the drug-producing nations in reorganizing or bolstering their economies, a ''debt for drugs'' swap should be made. The United States would pay off the big foreign debts of the cocaine-producing countries under the plan in exchange for a program of coca-crop eradication and encouragement of alternate crops. United States Lack of Agreement And Coordination In the United States, the Bush Administration is confronted by competing interests among Washington agencies. Some, like the Commerce Department, show little active interest in the South American drug problem, despite the coca crop's inevitable intertwining in Andes economics and trade. Some, like the Pentagon, are not in agreement on the wisdom of the United States involvement in the Andes drug problems. **********Critics say the Administration's efforts are disjointed. At least six United States Government agencies, including the Central Intelligence Agency, the Drug Enforcement Administration and the State Department, are working against drugs in the three countries. **********Each agency has its own procedures and intelligence sources. Theoretically, the United States ambassador coordinates the drug war in his country. But in practice, central direction is weak and each agency goes its own way. **********''We are far from having a strategy,'' said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics. **********William J. Bennett, the nation's drug-policy director, has been criticized by politicians and experts in drug treatment for failing to take his advisers' counsel and take charge of an overall drug plan. A Government expert said, ''Bennett has done fine on the bully pulpit talking about the drug problem, but he seems unwilling to seize the power needed to really do anything.'' **********Donald R. Hamilton, the chief spokesman for Mr. Bennett, said the director had exerted sweeping influence on how the United States is dealing with drugs. ''He has good access to the President and when he's gone to the President he's gotten his way almost every time.'' **********Within the United States armed forces, opinion is divided over whether the military should be involved in the drug war in South America. Many officers, remembering Vietnam, worry that the military will be drawn into an unwinnable war. **********''We will be down there 20 to 40 years,'' said a senior planning officer in the United States military headquarters in Panama. **********Some officers think the armed forces could become a scapegoat if the anti-drug war fails. ''It is easier for politicians to shift the burden to the military than to get tough with their own drug-using constitutents,'' said a Pentagon officer who bitterly oppposes using servicemen in the drug war. **********Despite the misgivings, the Defense Department has ordered stepped-up training, reconnaissance, intelligence sharing and logistical support in the three Andean countries. The Andes The Divisive Issue Of Who Will Fight Mainly because of unextinguishable bad memories of gunboat diplomacy, the leaders of Colombia, Bolivia and Peru oppose the presence of American combat troops on their soil, and they want strict limits on any American military presence. **********Of the three countries, only Colombia has been willing to mount a real armed offensive of its own. Peru and Bolivia continue to equivocate on waging any kind of warfare on an industry that provides an income for hundreds of thousands of peasants. **********A key to the United States strategy is to engage the armies of all three countries in the drug war, but these forces have historically insisted that drug trafficking is a criminal matter for the police to confront. Friction between the police and the armed forces runs deep; they seldom work together, and when they do they blame each other for what goes wrong. **********In Peru the army actually prevents the police from operating in the Upper Huallaga Valley. Disturbing the coca farmers, the army says, would help the guerrillas by driving the farmers into rebel ranks. But tantalized by the potential of as much as $40 million in United States military hardware for an anti-drug campaign, the army now contends that through its war with the guerrillas it should be regarded as actually fighting cocaine. **********While drugs have been a police concern, most police officers have been assigned to other duties. Of the 80,000 members of the police in Colombia, for example, only about 3,500 are assigned to anti-drug units. In Peru, there are about 500 anti-narcotics police officers, and in Bolivia there are 700 to 800. Mexico New Way Stations South of the Border A United States official in Bogota who specializes in narcotics estimated that cocaine shipping from Colombia was still down about 25 percent from what it was before the Government of President Barco declared war on the drug traffickers last August. **********But he said new processing centers in Peru and other countries, especially Mexico, may have lifted the region as a whole back to where it had been. **********As United States patrols and radar networks have slowed traffic in the Caribbean, cocaine smugglers have been funneling their goods into the United States through Mexico. The Colombian cartels have formed alliances with Mexican smuggling gangs that have long dealt in marijuana and heroin. ''You have organizations on both sides of the border who have been involved with smuggling for decades,'' said a United States official in Mexico. **********Drug Enforcement Administration officials estimate that 50 percent to 70 percent of all South American cocaine entering the United States goes through Mexico, as opposed to 30 percent only a few years ago. **********Nearly 300 planes were seized in the raids in Colombia, but American officials say the traffickers have replenished their fleet by buying and stealing replacements all over the hemisphere. One of the most popular smuggling planes, the officials said, is the Gulfstream Aerocommander 1000, a twin-engine turboprop plane that can carry up to 2,000 pounds of cargo. **********Most of Mexico does not have radar coverage. Planes land at hundreds of dirt airfields and often keep one engine running as the cocaine is unloaded. Usually, the drug is hidden at the airfield for a few days, then smuggled across the border by truck. **********The United States has been putting up a barrier of radar balloons along the Mexican border; seven are to be up within weeks. The balloons can detect a plane as far away as 150 miles. **********In all three Andes countries and in the United States, politicians as well as scholars and economists talk of what they regard as the impossibility of significantly reducing the production and export of cocaine as long as demand remains strong. **********The most optimistic analysts estimate 5 to 10 years of heavy spending and perhaps much bloodshed, not to eliminate cocaine in South America but to contain it until consumption falls. **********''We're buying time,'' said one United States Embassy official here.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/01/busin.main_headline: Company News;   Pic 'N' Save Corp. In Buyback Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/01/busin.print_headline: Company News;   Pic 'N' Save Corp. In Buyback Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/01/busin.body_text: **********The Pic 'N' Save Corporation, which has been under pressure from an investment group that has sought control of its board, announced a plan to repurchase as much as $150 million of its stock and scale back operations. **********The company said it would also replace its president and chief executive. Pic 'N' Save, a retailer based in Dominguez, Calif., said that after a two-month search, it had not received any satisfactory purchase offers. Pic 'N' Save had been searching for a buyer after being pressured by Girard Partners, a La Jolla, Calif., investment firm that owns 6.6 percent of the company. On Monday, Girard said it did not believe it could raise the cash to buy Pic 'N' Save.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/05/busin.body_text: **********In trying to force the European governments to cut the generous subsidies paid to their farmers, the United States is allied with the 70 developing nations represented at this week's trade talks. **********Among the industrial nations, the Europeans give farmers by far the largest subsidies. The International Monetary Fund estimates that halting the industrial world's farm subsidies could raise third world farm exports by $50 billion a year. **********American officials are delighted that many third world nations have made reducing farm subsidies their principal goal in the trade negotiations. Brazil, Argentina, Chile and several other third world nations have been at Washington's side in putting pressure on the European Community to slash farm subsidies. **********But that support has its price. The developing nations have stressed that without a liberalization of farm trade, they will resist dropping barriers to protect their nascent service industries, which might be hurt by efficient competitors from industrialized countries. **********"Without a significant result in reducing agricultural protection, our country cannot accept the other results of this round of talks," said Domingo F. Cavallo, Argentina's Foreign Minister.  Rejoicing Over Fiber Accord **********On the one hand, third world ministers are eager for the industrial world to agree to slash protection in trade in textiles and farm products. Asian, African and Latin American officials say protection in these two areas robs them of vital export markets and slows their economic growth. **********At the same time, officials from many developing nations are uneasy about proposals to liberalize trade in services and curb government subsidies to industry. They fear, for example, that if Western or Japanese banks and insurers gain the right to operate freely in their countries, that could hold back development of their small financial services sectors. **********Officials of third world nations are rejoicing that negotiators are near agreement on phasing out the multi-fiber accord, which rich nations long used to restrict imports of third-world apparel. **********They are also optimistic about winning far lower tariffs on tropical products like bananas, peanuts and cocoa. Lower tariffs should help raise trade in third world farm commodities battered by low prices. **********Many officials of developing countries are less than enthusiastic about liberalizing trade in services. Fearing that Western corporations may completely dominate their service sectors, they are asking that along with liberalizaton, the industrialized world provide aid to help develop the third world's service sector. **********There is also ambivalence about the West's push to win more protection for intellectual property, including patents and copyrights. Some third world officials fear that this could slow much-needed innovation and the development of small business. One Indian official said that granting patents to Western pharmaceutical companies could aggravate problems in his nation where cheap medicine is needed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/28/world.main_headline: To Many in Panama, the New President Is an Enigma Wrapped in a Smile
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/28/world.print_headline: To Many in Panama, the New President Is an Enigma Wrapped in a Smile
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/28/world.body_text: **********To many people who know him only from afar, Guillermo Endara Galimany, a 53-year-old lawyer with a dimpled smile and a quick laugh, is something of an enigma. **********Unlike many of his predecessors in the 21 years of military rule, Panama's new civilian President, who sometimes jokes about his weight problem, often seems altogether too guileless and self-effacing to believe. **********Although many Panamanians think he is the perfect man for the job, others wonder if he has the political skill to rebuild the devastated economy, create an effective police agency to replace the Panamanian Defense Forces and still generate the popular support that his Government will need when the euphoria over the ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega subsides. Among other things, the circumstances under which Mr. Endara and his two vice presidents took power - as the invasion by United States troops began last month - is certain to be used against them as Panama's traditionally anti-American nationalism reawakens. **********In a particularly complex Panamanian play of race and caste, Mr. Endara is also likely to find himself denounced as the leader of the privileged few against the vast ranks of the poor. **********On the Night of Dec. 19 **********But there are aspects of the new President's personality and career that suggest that he may be able to rally the country in what many agree will be the difficult months of reconstruction ahead. **********Mr. Endara said that when American officials told him late on Dec. 19 that the invasion was imminent and that they wanted him to take the oath as President, ''I felt like I had been hit in the head with a sledgehammer.'' **********''It would have been very easy for me to say, 'I'm not going to take this job under occupation by American forces,' '' Mr. Endara said in a recent interview in his office overlooking the Pacific. ''But I knew that I couldn't do that. I had to assume the responsibility of Government - the people chose me to be President. I couldn't simply tell the U.S.: 'You pick the Government. You are the occupying power and you do what you want.' '' **********''History may speak horribly of me,'' he said of his decision. ''I certainly knew that Latin Americans weren't going to be very fond of me. But morally, patriotically, civically, I had no other choice. I had to do it.'' **********A Reputation As a Great Lawyer **********A year ago, before he agreed to run as the civilian coalition's nominee for the presidency against General Noriega's candidate, Mr. Endara was virtually unknown as a political commodity, except for two things. **********Political insiders knew him as the longtime behind-the-scenes secretary for his idol, Dr. Arnulfo Arias Madrid, the charismatic, Peron-like figure whose presence and views - a curious mix of socialism, fascism, racism, mysticism and resistance to United States domination of the Panama Canal - dominated Panamanian politics for half a century. **********But in the capital's financial center, bankers, businessmen and would-be businessmen knew Mr. Endara in a more pragmatic incarnation, as one of the best corporate lawyers in town, smart and well-connected. **********Both pursuits seem to have taught him the fine art of quiet compromise, a skill he has reportedly put to use in recent weeks settling differences between himself and his First Vice President, Ricardo Arias Calderon, leader of the formidable Christian Democratic Party; and the Second Vice President, Guillermo (Billy) Ford of the Nationalist Liberal Republican Party, a splinter group known by the Spanish acronym of Molirena. Under a pact said to have been signed Dec. 21 by the three men, decisions are being made not by Mr. Endara alone, but by consensus of all three. **********Some politicians say the country is apparently being run by a less-than-efficient junta, not a president. ''They're trying to play the piano with six hands,'' complained one critic, Carlos Ivan Zuniga, an opposition politician who heads a small, conservative political party known as Papo. **********But others are hopeful about Mr. Endara's skills at conciliation. **********''Over the years, I've seen him act many times as a bridge between competing groups,'' said Fernando Manfredo, who began serving this month as the first Panamanian administrator of the Panama Canal Commission, although in an acting capacity. In 1983, Mr. Manfredo recalled, Mr. Endara, representing Dr. Arias's Authentic Panamanian Party, managed to get a roomful of bitter political adversaries, including a Communist group, to agree on a complex change in the Constitution. **********Brilliance at School, Success at the Office **********Mr. Endara, an only child, was born May 12, 1936, to upper-middle class parents in the capital. By all accounts a brilliant student, he attended secondary schools in Argentina and a now-defunct military academy in Los Angeles, Calif., eventually graduating first in his law class at the University of Panama. **********He also studied law for a time at New York University, returning home to open a law practice in 1963 with an older lawyer, Galileo Solis. Mr. Endara was 27 at the time. **********The firm, now called Solis, Endara, Delgado & Guevara, had always specialized in corporate work, although in its early growth years, ''they took on just about anybody who walked in the door,'' said a Panamanian lawyer familiar with the firm. **********Solis Endara was thus well-positioned to take advantage of the explosion in commercial activity in Panama that occurred after the military coup of 1968, which toppled President Arias on his 11th day in office; it was the third time he had been deposed by the military since 1941. **********Much of the success of Panama's financial center in the 1970's and 80's, Mr. Endara readily acknowledges, was a result of the Latin American drug cartels, which brought billions in cocaine and marijuana profits to be laundered in Panama. But the President says that neither he nor his law partners ever knowingly worked with drug traffickers or accepted their money. **********In the interview in his newly renovated office at the presidential palace, which only a month ago had been occupied by American combat troops, Mr. Endara also dismissed press reports in the United States that Second Vice President Billy Ford's brother, Henry Ford, was associated with a Miami accountant who was convicted of laundering money for the Medellin cartel. **********Others familiar with Mr. Endara and Billy Ford, from childhood friends to longtime political adversaries, say that whatever their faults, they are not corrupt. **********''I know Billy Ford since we were 10 years old,'' said I. Roberto Eisenmann Jr., a businessman and publisher of the fiercely anti-Noriega newspaper La Prensa. ''I know basically everything he's done in his professional life, including all the temptations he has had, and I know he has never broken under them.'' **********Mr. Endara said of his own law firm: ''We did legal work under the dictatorship without any help from the Government, but we have done no business with narcotraffickers or anything like that that we know of.'' **********''But,'' he said, ''like any lawyer, I cannot vouch that every client who comes through our doors is a saint. **********''Like many other law firms in Panmama, we are often asked to do company work, such as incorporating companies,'' he went on. ''It's possible that we might help someone incorporate a company - and then maybe they would use the company for something else. **********''The fact is, I'm not sure of everybody I do legal work for, but I do try to avoid shady characters.'' **********According to a presidential spokesman, Louis Martinez, Mr. Endara remains a partner of the firm, but suspended his working relationship at the beginning of the political campaign last year. ''He will not be returning until he leaves public office,'' the spokesman said. **********A Close Friend And an Atlanta Arrest **********Mr. Endara said he remained ''close friends'' with Carlos Eleta, a wealthy Panamanian businessman who was arrested in Atlanta last April on charges that he conspired to set up a major cocaine smuggling ring. He was released on bail pending his trial. **********People here who know Mr. Eleta remain puzzled by his arrest, saying that the idea of drug smuggling seems totally out of character for him. Some Panamanians, like Guillermo Sanchez Borbon, political columnist for the daily La Prensa, suggest that he may even have been set up by General Noriega or people close to him. **********''Carlos Eleta is a friend, but we have nothing in common with him in the sense that we are not partners with him in anything, anything that I know of,'' Mr. Endara said, ''although he may have shares in some company that I might have shares in. **********''He's a friend, but I have many friends in Panama.'' **********The law firm's current clients, Mr. Endara said, include a cross-section of major Panamanian companies. **********''We're not a big firm,'' Mr. Endara said. ''In addition to the partners, we have another lawyer and some secretaries. In all, 12 people working in the office.'' **********Asked whether he had felt apprehensive about being offered the presidential nomination last year, Mr. Endara sighed heavily. ''I was not apprehensive, I was surprised,'' he said. ''I had not sought this nomination. **********''A group of politicians felt that somebody representing Dr. Arias - his prestige, his authority with the masses - should be on the ticket.'' **********Nearly two years after his death in Miami at the age of 86, Dr. Arias - or simply ''Arnulfo,'' as Panamanians commonly refer to him - still exerts an eerie gravitational pull on public life here. **********After Dr. Arias's young widow, Mireyea, turned down repeated offers that she run for the presidency as the candidate of the National Civic Crusade, Mr. Endara said, the job was thrust upon him. He says he accepted it philosophically. **********''I remember Dr. Arias always saying to me and to others that responsibilities for the country were things that came upon oneself by force of destiny. **********''It's sort of like karma. You know about karma? I'm not an Orientalist, I'm not a Buddhist, I'm not anything like that. But I've read books, and I learned that karma was something that you have to accept. I was surprised, but I felt an obligation to do my best, to finish the work of my teacher, my maestro, my mentor. And that is still my thought here.'' **********Mr. Sanchez Borbon of La Prensa said he believed that whatever his political skills, Mr. Endara's easy-going ways might be exactly what the country wanted right now. **********''After all the horror we've had, I think he is a good choice,'' Mr. Sanchez Borbon said. ''He's a very humble man, very placid - anything but charismatic. But he may surprise people.'' **********A New Friendship And a New Life **********Some would say he already has. A few weeks ago, Mr. Endara was observed in a booth of the Marriott Hotel coffee shop with a dark-haired young woman who, reporters agreed, was definitely not Marcelita, his 26-year-old married daughter. **********Soon after the much-talked-about sighting, Mr. Endara announced that he was dating the woman, 24-year-old Ana Mae Diaz. He has been a widower since June, when his wife, Marcela, died of a heart attack, a month after the abortive May 7 elections that were followed by street clashes in which her husband was beaten by paramilitary toughs. **********Mr. Endara and Miss Diaz had met in September, when she went to visit him during his two-week hunger strike against the Noriega Government. At the time, Mr. Endara, who says he lost 30 of his 265 pounds on the liquid-only diet, was usually flat on his back on a hospital bed in the window of a downtown office building, where skeptics could see for themselves that he wasn't eating. **********''We're still getting to know each other,'' the President was quoted as saying of Miss Diaz this week. **********That is a good description, many Panamanians say, of the relationship between Mr. Endara and the people of this close-knit country of 2.4 million as it struggles to reconstitute itself as a independent civilian democracy. **********''In essence, I really don't care what reputation I acquire,'' President Endara said, sounding a bit like his beloved mentor. ''What is important to me is to do my duty to the Panamanian people, to act in their interest and according to their will.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/09/world.main_headline: Serbian Voting Today Could Signal A Major Turn in Yugoslavia's Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/09/world.print_headline: Serbian Voting Today Could Signal A Major Turn in Yugoslavia's Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/09/world.body_text: **********Voters will cast ballots on Sunday in Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, to deliver a verdict on a government whose raw blend of old-style one-party rule and aggressive nationalism has made it a central issue for the country's uncertain future. **********The vote in Serbia completes a year of free elections held throughout Eastern Europe on the ruins of now-defunct Communist systems. With the exception of Albania, this Balkan republic of 9.5 million will be the last not only in the region but in Yugoslavia itself to undertake the initiation into democracy. **********The Serbian election comes at a time when the survival of Yugoslavia is increasingly in doubt. Slovenia, a republic that borders Italy and Austria, has set Dec. 23 as a date for a plebiscite on whether to break loose and become fully independent. A recent poll in the republic shows 80 percent of potential voters favoring the move. **********The Yugoslav Army has announced that next week it will reassert control over territorial defense in paramilitary units now under republican command in Slovenia and Croatia.  Election Could Be Decisive **********With signs pointing to a showdown in Yugoslavia's protrated crisis, the Serbian elections could prove decisive, given the instigating role played by Belgrade, capital of the republic, in disputes between the country's hostile nationalities. **********Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, who rose to head of the Communist Party in 1987 and has since built up considerable popularity as spokesman for a resurgent Serbian nationalism, is considered the favorite for re-election, although his party -- now renamed Socialist -- may not win a majority of the seats in the 250-seat Parliament. A second round of voting is set for Dec. 23, the same day as the plebiscite in Slovenia. **********Mr. Milosevic's main rival is Vuk Draskovic, head of the Serbian Renewal Movement, which staked out an extreme nationalist position early in the campaign. Recently, however, Mr. Draskovic, a 44-year-old novelist whose shoulder-length hair signals a provocative style, has toned down his jingoist language, some say as a prelude to a possible coalition with other opposition forces against Mr. Milosevic in the second round. **********Mr. Draskovic and other opposition candidates have turned the election into a frontal attack on the Communists, ignoring the Socialist Party's claim to having reformed itself. In a televised speech this week, Mr. Draskovic said the campaign was "a battle between the Cross and the Red Star." At a rally here Thursday, he vowed "to stop the Bolshevik powers and their tanks and guns with the election ballots that are the bullets of democracy."  Ex-Communists Defeated **********Although former Communists have been voted out of office in elections held in every other Yugoslav republic this year, some political analysts wonder whether Serbia may not have more in common with its Balkan neighbors, Bulgaria and Romania, where the old ruling parties were kept in power by a conservative electorate. **********In the campaign, Mr. Milosevic has tried to portray the Socialist Party as the bulwark of stability in a changing and turbulent time. "A Socialist defeat could unleash dark forces from the country's past," said Mr. Milosevic, who has also warned of the possibility of a civil war. **********Economic uncertainty, which in much of the rest of Eastern Europe followed political change, is already a real specter here. Although Serbia has so far resisted the painful aspects of economic reform, some observers predict that industrial workers will look to the former Communists for protection against market forces. **********Mr. Milosevic may have a powerful ally in the Yugoslav Army, which is dominated by a Communist-indoctrinated officer corps, 70 percent of whom are Serbs. In an interview this week, the Defense Minister, Gen. Veljko Kadijevic, said, "The future, historically speaking, belongs to the idea of socialism, and the experience of developed nations shows that it is one of the most civilized achievements of the contemporary epoch." Scattered Violence **********The Serbian elections are taking place in an atmosphere of controlled tension, amid scattered incidents of violence, some within the republic's borders, other in clashes involving ethnic Serbs in neighboring republics, particularly Croatia. Opposition spokesmen blamed politics for the shooting death of one Serbian Renewal campaign worker in southern Serbia this week, although others have played down the significance of the incident. **********National hostility -- between Serbs and Croats, Serbs and Albanians, Macedonians and Serbs -- have flared up throughout Yugoslavia in recent months, partly as a result of fears that Serbs, who dominated the Yugoslav state between World War I and World War II, are once again bent on asserting their power as the country's most numerous group. **********Kosovo, a region inside Serbia that has been the most troublesome of Yugoslavia's hot spots, has been quiet recently. Albanians, who make up more than 90 percent of the population there, are boycotting the election in protest against the Serbian government's move to strip the region of its political autonomy. **********In the debate over Yugoslavia's future, the Serbian government has opposed proposals by Croatia and Slovenia for a looser confederation, arguing instead for a strong federal system that would keep all the Serbs in Yugoslavia -- inside and outside the republic -- in a single state. In his interview this week, Defense Mininster Kadijevic supported a strong federal Yugoslavia, saying "the people will not accept recipes" for the breakup of the country "from self-styled messiahs and political adventurists." Calls for Negotiations **********The Reform Party, founded by federal Prime Minister Ante Markovic as a counter to the nationalist and Communist parties, is making a pitch to Serbian voters' Yugoslav sympathies and calls for negotiations between the national groups, including Albanians. **********But with the exception of Vojvodina, a region populated by a mixture of ethnic groups, the Reform Party has failed to pick up wide support in Serbia. Nationalism has proved to be too powerful a lure -- which explains why other opposition groups, including those with liberal, pro-Western platforms like the Democratic Party, have supported the Milosevic government's position on Kosovo. **********Since Mr. Milosevic finally agreed this year to open Serbia to the democratic process, the opposition has complained that it has had to compete under unfair conditions. Much of the mainstream press -- including the once-respected daily newspaper Politika -- and the television in Serbia have remained firmly under government control, although competing candidates were alloted time for a televised presentation of their views. **********In recent weeks, Mr. Milosevic has chosen to stay out of the limelight, declining for instance to take advantage of his one-hour television time. Although widely criticized throughout Yugoslavia as having been the first to ignite national rivalries, Mr. Milosevic has portrayed himself in the campaign as a voice of moderation and a peacemaker in comparison with his rivals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.main_headline: Envoy Besieged in Spying Inquiry Is Called Security Risk and Ousted
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Envoy Besieged in Spying Inquiry Is Called Security Risk and Ousted
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.body_text: **********Felix S. Bloch, the American diplomat who came under intense Federal investigation last year when officials said he was photographed with a Soviet spy, was told today that he was being dismissed because he is a national security risk, the State Department said. **********The action came after six months in which Mr. Bloch was publicly identified as a suspected Soviet intelligence agent, besieged by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and reporters, and barred from his Washington office, but never charged with a crime. **********Mr. Bloch has been on leave with pay from the State Department's bureau of European and Canadian affairs since June 22. Today, the department removed him from its payroll and said he would be dismissed in 30 days. **********The State Department announcement leaves Mr. Bloch with the choice of accepting his dismissal, and implicitly conceding guilt, or contesting it without guaranteed access to details of the allegations that led to his ouster. Under Federal laws governing dismissal of employees suspected of being security risks, the State Department is required to submit a summary of charges ''stated as specifically as security considerations permit.'' **********Under the law Mr. Bloch can contest the decision through administrative hearings at the State Department, including an appeal to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. Should he fail, he would then have the option of taking the matter to Federal court. It was unclear today what Mr. Bloch would do. Mr. Bloch's lawyer, John M. Bray, said his client had no comment. Mr. Bloch did not answer the telephone at his home near downtown Washington. **********Trail Growing Cold **********The State Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that the inquiry into allegations of espionage by Mr. Bloch remains active. Officials have conceded, however, that they so far lack the evidence to make a court case against their target and that his trail grows colder each day. **********Federal officials denied that a motive in dismissing Mr. Bloch was the hope that the move would produce additional evidence of wrongdoing through administrative hearings, court battles or other steps he might take to contest the action. Dismissal is the strongest action that can be taken against Mr. Bloch short of filing criminal charges, which the available evidence does not support, law enforcement officials say. **********It is ''farfetched indeed'' to think Mr. Bloch's dismissal is a Federal ploy to force the disclosure of new evidence against him, Michael Schatzow, a Baltimore lawyer who prosecuted John A. Walker, the master Soviet spy, said in an interview. Indeed, he said, the Government has abandoned similar proceedings in other cases to avoid disclosing classified evidence. **********''In these proceedings the burden usually goes the other way,'' he said, meaning the Government must show that its actions are justified. ''Mr. Bloch obviously has a good lawyer. He's not going to stick his foot in his mouth now.'' **********An Eerie Composure **********For the State Department, Mr. Bloch's dismissal was also dictated by financial considerations. Officials noted that Mr. Bloch receives an $80,000-a-year salary for a job he is barred from performing. **********Through it all, the balding, 54-year-old bureaucrat has maintained an eerie composure, repeatedly declining opportunities to deny that he was a spy and challenging investigators to find enough evidence to prove otherwise. **********A State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, today refused to describe the specific allegations of wrongdoing that led to the decision to dismiss Mr. Bloch, saying those charges are confidential under privacy laws. **********The Federal law covering Mr. Bloch's case allows the removal of employees ''in the interests of national security.'' An Administration official said today that the State Department had not previously used the law, and that its last known use, in 1983, was by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. **********State Department lawyers have been studying the agency's options under the law since at least last autumn, an Administration official said today. **********''It's a pretty complicated legal issue because it involves balancing the national security and due process,'' the official said. ''We do feel like we moved promptly in terms of the work that had to be done, but cautiously.'' **********Mr. Baker decided last week to invoke the Federal law, and the agency's Under Secretary for Management, Ivan Selin, ordered the dismissal. **********If Mr. Bloch is dismissed next month, the State Department would consider taking action under another law to reduce or eliminate his pension, the Administration official said. **********Mr. Bloch was the second-ranking American diplomat in Vienna during much of the Reagan Administration. In that job, he effectively ran day-to-day embassy affairs in a city that is a center for sensitive arms negotiations and other strategic matters. **********Charges Go Back to 70's **********Since 1988, he had worked in a Washington office that deals with European economic relations and restrictions on technology exports to the East bloc. **********American officials have said they believe that Mr. Bloch began spying for Moscow in the 1970's, when he was an officer at American embassies in West and East Berlin. But officials said he came under F.B.I. scrutiny only last spring, when he turned up in a secret videotape of a known Soviet agent whose European movements were being followed. **********Mr. Bloch was immediately placed under heavy surveillance, and his automobile and telephone were wiretapped. Officials said the automobile wiretap later recorded Mr. Bloch telling his wife, Lucille, that he had accepted money from the Soviet Union. **********Numerous news reports said the inquiry also turned up evidence that Mr. Bloch had spent large sums of money, well beyond the means of a mid-level diplomat, for a prostitute's services during much of his stay in Vienna. **********The Soviet agent appears to have cryptically told Mr. Bloch in a telephone conversation last May that he was under surveillance by the F.B.I. Shortly after the tip, the State Department suspended Mr. Bloch. **********Last July, reporters detected the heavy surveillance, and a horde of writers and photographers joined Federal agents in a round-the-clock siege of Mr. Bloch's home.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/02/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East;   Moscow Sends Armored Vehicles Through Tense Lithuania Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/02/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East;   Moscow Sends Armored Vehicles Through Tense Lithuania Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/02/world.body_text: **********The Kremlin sent a column of armored personnel carriers through the Lithuanian capital today, strengthening both the Soviet military presence and the psychological pressure on Lithuania to retreat from its claim of independence. **********The latest move in the war of nerves over the republic's sovereignty occurred in midafternoon, a day after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appealed to Lithuania to ''annul'' its declaration of independence as the price for negotiation or invite ''grave consequences'' on both sides. **********Other Issues Are Open **********Officials in Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, reiterated today that while a retreat from independence was out of the question, all other issues were open for negotiation. **********The two sides remained far from a common path toward talks, with the situation remaining tense but somewhat fluid. **********Officials of the Lithuanian government avoided hard-edged oratory today and again admitted to the theoretical possibility of a referendum on independence, a referendum that Mr. Gorbachev has insisted is a minimum condition of his negotiating on the issue. **********At the same time, a commentary on Vremya, the Soviet Government's main television news program, suggested tonight that the time had come for talks and that they did not have to be arranged on a presidential level but rather might begin at the level of legislative deputies. **********Such nuances of possible moderation, however, tended to be lost in the sound once again of Soviet armor moving through the tense republic. **********Witnesses in Vilnius said that more than two dozen tank-treaded armored personnel carriers proceeded noisily through the city from the railroad depot to the main Soviet military base on the northern edge of the capital. Earlier, about 3:30 A.M., other armored troop movements awoke residents of some city neighborhoods as leaders of the heavy Soviet military presence made further adjustments in deployment, officials of the Lithuanian government said. They could offer no detailed description of the vehicles or their mission. **********Before Lithuania's Parliament declared independence on March 11, an estimated 30,000 Soviet troops were normally stationed in the republic. But the contingent has been reinforced with an undetermined number of troops from neighboring republics as the crisis has continued, even though officials in Moscow insist they do not intend to use force as long as Soviet lives are not threatened. **********Significantly, perhaps, the Lithuanian President, Vytautas Landsbergis, made no comment on the latest troop movements. Other officials also appeared to be focusing on whatever promise of negotiation might evolve from Mr. Gorbachev's Saturday statement rather than on denouncing the latest Soviet pressure in the streets. **********''This army has been imposed on us, and no one knows how large it is or what its movements will be,'' Deputy Prime Minister Kaziemir Motieka said. ''This situation must be changed through the process of negotiations.'' **********While the troop movements once again served to highlight the standoff, various political factors were more quietly a part of the sovereignty crisis. **********Chief among these was the fact that Soviet officials are to travel to Washington this week to prepare for the coming summit meeting of Presidents Bush and Gorbachev. Any stepping up of Soviet military action in Lithuania would seem likely to threaten the summit meeting. **********An additional political factor is the resumption on Monday of the Parliament session in Tallinn at which Estonia has been charting its own, more cautious approach to independence, a slower pace that legislators deny is related to Mr. Gorbachev's pressure on Lithuania. **********Estonia Parliament to Meet **********The Estonian Parliament is to take up a resolution of support for Lithuania and condemnation of the Gorbachev Government. Any hedging in its language would be closely studied for its effects on the Lithuanian crisis and on Mr. Gorbachev's attempts to contain it and prevent its becoming a precedent for other separatist republic movements in his troubled nation. **********President Landsbergis already has found his appeals for official recognition ignored by the major democracies, which have, however, been admonitory over the Soviet troop forays occurring almost daily in Vilnius. **********Many potential flash points remain to be weathered if the crisis is ever to reach some stage of conciliation. One of them looms in the form of the spring draft of young Lithuanian men into the Soviet Army, a drawn-out process that begins this month. **********Lithuanian officials suffered a setback earlier when young Lithuanian men heeded the separatist movement's call to republic patriotism and deserted the Soviet ''army of occupation.'' The army has since been arresting many of them, with the Lithuanian government unable to make good on promises to protect them. **********The Soviet authorities continued to try to restrict information about the republic, with Western journalists removed and individual foreign volunteers beginning to receive notice that they must leave. William J. H. Hough 3d, a lawyer from New York City who had been advising the Landsbergis government, said he had been informed by the Soviet authorities that he must leave by Monday because of his activities. **********Troops Avoid Key Bastions **********Soviet troop initiatives have been the main factor in rising tensions in the republic, with a half dozen buildings in Vilnius seized in the last week in unresisted nocturnal paratroop forays, which have thus far avoided the key independence bastions of the Parliament and the television center. **********Troops moved into the republic prosecutor's building on Friday, and the situation there remained confused, said Aidas Palubinskas, a spokesman for the republic. He said the soldiers had been unexpectedly admitting justice officials of the pro-independence government, and a more accurate picture should emerge this week of whether the Gorbachev Government will try to take over the courts. **********Likewise, the effect of the troops' seizure of the main printing plant should be made clearer on Monday, with officials wondering whether the main pro-independence newspapers will be interfered with. Normally they do not publish on the weekend. **********In commenting on the referendum issue, Mr. Motieka said the republic's strong support of independence had been made clear enough in the recent elections, in which the separatist candidates of the Sajudis national front scored the heaviest in favoring immediate independence. The position of the breakaway Communist Party, which placed second, was that a slower pace should be taken toward independence with the republic's economy treated as a critical factor. **********Mr. Motieka noted that current law allows for referendums, providing that 300,000 voters request one. The Sajudis movement had such a petition under way earlier and collected 400,000 signatures, he said, before the elections forced the pace of independence. **********Mr. Gorbachev has made this a special point of complaint in dismissing the republic's declaration of independence three weeks ago as illicit. He says the troop movements are part of the national Government's duty to preserve law in what remains a Soviet republic. Self-determination, he says, is an issue to be settled by mutual agreement under pending constitutional provisions. **********As they are being shaped by Gorbachev officials, however, these provisions threaten to add years of political hurdles to Lithuania's course. **********Lithuanian officials insist that their sovereignty is unchallengable by Soviet authority because it amounts to a restoration of the independence lost 50 years when the Baltic republics were forcibly annexed by Moscow as part of a secret pact between Hitler and Stalin.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/06/world.main_headline: U.S. Military Cancels Leave After Slaying in Philippines
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/06/world.print_headline: U.S. Military Cancels Leave After Slaying in Philippines
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/06/world.body_text: **********The United States military canceled off-post leaves today for American servicemen in the Philippines after a Marine was shot and killed outside the Subic Bay naval base. Officials said that Communist rebels probably were responsible for the slaying. **********Gunnery Sgt. John S. Fredette, 34, of Buena Park, Calif., was wounded late Friday when five gunmen approached him in the nightclub district of Olongapo, 50 miles west of Manila, and shot him in the neck, the police said. He died an hour later.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/12/world.main_headline: Sri Lanka May Move Tamils From a Region
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/12/world.print_headline: Sri Lanka May Move Tamils From a Region
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/12/world.body_text: **********President Ranasinghe Premadasa is weighing a plan to evacuate one million Tamil civilians from the line of fire before the army mounts an assault on the rebel-held Jaffna peninsula in northern Sri Lanka. **********Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne told Parliament on Friday of a proposal to move civilians to temporary camps south of Jaffna, ''and then clear the north'' of Tamil guerrillas. **********The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam have held a 200-man army garrison under siege in Jaffna since June 11, when they broke a 13-month-old cease-fire and resumed a seven-year war for Tamil independence. **********At least 14,000 people have been killed since the Tamil war began, many of them civilians. **********Military officials said today that eight Tigers had been killed a day earlier in clashes with the army in the eastern and northern regions of this Indian Ocean island. One soldier also died in a rebel ambush. **********Mr. Wijeratne did not say when the evacuation might begin or how many people would be moved. Government census figures show one million Tamils living on the Jaffna peninsula, but thousands have fled across the Palk Straits to southern India.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;   Treasury Securities Up Slightly
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/busin.body_text: **********Prices of most Treasury securities inched higher in thin, volatile trading yesterday, as traders nervously reacted to sudden shifts in the foreign exchange and petroleum markets as well as a potpourri of rumors. **********Tough talk from President Bush about the Middle East dampened hopes for a quick settlement of the crisis. **********Traders in various markets reacted to the President's comments by selling fixed-income securities and the dollar and pushing up oil prices. **********But the downward trend in Treasury prices was later reversed, as oil prices came off their highs and the dollar firmed. A rumor that a Japanese investment bank was placing very large bids for bonds also helped the recovery. **********''Trading is very thin, people are uneasy about taking positions, and in that environment it doesn't take much to push the market around,'' one government bond trader said. **********Even with the swings, the Government's long bond ''is locked in a trading range of 8.87 percent on the high side and 8.70 on the low side,'' the trader said. ''And until we get further information about the budget, about oil and the Middle East and on the economy, we are likely to stay mired in it.'' **********'No Clear Direction' **********Analysts at MMS International, an economic information service and forecasting company, said in their daily commentary, ''The constant flow of headlines about the gulf crisis, seesawing oil prices, a weak dollar, and a ballooning budget deficit have left the market with no clear direction.'' **********In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the benchmark 8 3/4 percent bonds were offered at a price of 99 30/32 in late trading, up 5/32, to yield 8.75 percent, compared with 8.78 percent late Tuesday. **********Among notes, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 25/32, up 3/32, to yield 8.63 percent. And the 8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/8, unchanged on the day, to yield 7.92 percent. **********Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed. **********By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.44 percent, up one basis point, or a hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bills rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 7.33 percent. **********The Treasury said yesterday that beginning with the three-month and six-month bill auctions on Nov. 5 it will move up its deadline for receipt of noncompetitive tender offers by one hour, to noon. The move is intended to speed the release of auction results, the Treasury said. The deadline for competitive tender offers will remain at 1 P.M., the Treasury said. **********The Treasury said the change should help it meet a goal of regularly releasing auction results by 2 P.M. **********Until last week's quarterly refunding auctions, when release of the results was moved up by half an hour, the Treasury had tried to inform investors of the results by 3 P.M. **********Corporate Bonds **********In other developments, Southern California Edison offered $100 million of first and refunding mortgage bonds at competitive bid in the investment-grade corporate bond market yesterday. **********The securities, which mature Aug. 15, 1993, were won by a bid from a group led by Morgan Stanley & Company. **********The 8 1/4 percent bonds were priced at $99.80, to yield 8.325 percent, 25 basis points above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent three-year notes at the time of pricing. **********The issue is rated AA-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, dealers said prices of most widely quoted issues rose by one-quarter of a point to three-eighths of a point in dull trading. **********In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most issues were unchanged to up an eighth of a point, market participants said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   In Israel, the Feeling That It's Best to Use Force Without Delay
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   In Israel, the Feeling That It's Best to Use Force Without Delay
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/world.body_text: **********Israeli political and military leaders are saying that time is not on the side of the United States in the Persian Gulf crisis, and that it should act now. **********Late last week, in private discussions, Israeli military officials suggested that, if they were calling the shots, they would order a full-scale air assault on Iraqi military targets before Iraq had a chance to place hostages in sensitive locations. These views are now being openly expressed. **********After a briefing from military officials before Parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee, the acting chairman, Benyamin Ben-Eliezer, of the Labor Party said: ''If the Americans are waiting to amass a land force before attacking, they are making a mistake.'' **********At the same time, Israeli leaders continued insisting that they believe their country would be dragged into war with Iraq. During a Cabinet meeting on Sunday, military intelligence analysts told Government officials that there was a ''high probability'' of a military confrontation between the United States and Iraq that would quickly involve Israel, as well. **********Partly as a result, a public row broke out today over whether the Israeli military should distribute gas masks to the public. **********For the last two weeks, the army has said it has enough masks for everyone but does not want to pass them out now, for two reasons. First, it said, people might not take care of them properly. And second, it might send a signal to Iraq that Israel intends to launch an attack. **********Today, however, Foreign Minister David Levy demanded that masks and suits be immediately distributed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/07/world.main_headline: Cuban Communist Party Is Moving to Slash Its Bureaucracy by Half
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/07/world.print_headline: Cuban Communist Party Is Moving to Slash Its Bureaucracy by Half
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/07/world.body_text: **********Cuba's ruling Communist Party has moved to streamline its bloated bureaucracy, slashing national and provincial party posts by 50 percent and reorganizing the powerful Central Committee Secretariat. **********In an announcement on Friday, the Communist leadership also said it would introduce direct, secret voting and multiple candidates in coming elections for municipal and provincial party committees. The usual procedure in the past had been for candidates to be officially recommended and then elected by open vote. **********A statement published on the front page of the official newspaper, Granma, said the leadership under President Fidel Castro felt that it should not wait for the coming fourth party congress, due to be held in the first half of 1991, to introduce the changes. **********But while calling for national debate on ways to improve Cuba's one-party system, Mr. Castro has made clear that he does not intend to join the Soviet Union and former allies in Eastern Europe in embracing multi-party politics or a market economy. **********Reducing Paperwork **********The statement said the aim of the changes was to reduce paperwork and bureaucracy and end what it called ''hypertrophy'' in the Government and the party, making them more flexible and efficient and freeing individuals from time-consuming party business so they could use their experience in other tasks. **********It said the Secretariat of the Party Central Committee, the main body of bureaucracy that serves the leadership, would be cut back by more than 50 percent. Similarly, the size of provincial party committees would also be reduced by half, in part by eliminating many secondary and deputy posts. **********''The party should in this way be an example of rigorous application of the principle of not using a single employee more than is strictly necessary,'' the statement said. **********The existing 19 departments of the Secretariat are to be cut back to 9, headed by three secretaries working under First Secretary Castro. His brother, Raul, is Second Secretary of the Central Committee. **********In elections for municipal and provincial party committees due to be held between November and February, the leadership proposed that voting should be by direct, secret ballot and that the number of candidates should exceed the number of posts to be filled by at least 20 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/25/busin.main_headline: Business Graduates: Shying Away From Wall Street
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/25/busin.print_headline: Business Graduates: Shying Away From Wall Street
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/25/busin.body_text: **********In September 1987, as the bull market still raged and few guessed that a crash was but a month away, there was a huge waiting list for the investment banking course at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management. **********At the same time, management, marketing and even corporate finance classes, geared toward training the next generation of chief financial officers or controllers, went begging for students. **********''It had reached the point where we were wondering whether we shouldn't let some of our nonfinance faculty go,'' recalled Edmund J. Wilson, Kellogg's associate dean for master's degree programs and student affairs. **********Then the market crashed, and campus interest in Wall Street crashed along with it. In 1988, investment banking classes barely filled up. Corporate finance, by contrast, became the hottest ticket on campus, and marketing and management were getting hefty signups as well. **********By this past September, things had finally settled down. Investment banking was hot again, but not nearly so hot as in precrash days. And the corporate finance class, the management courses and other non-Wall Street classes all filled up. **********''We are finally seeing an equilibrium of interest,'' Mr. Wilson said. ''And in that sense the crash was a disguised blessing for the schools, for the students, for industry, for the whole profession of management. Students are finally paying attention to what they really want to do, not just to high salaries and prestige.'' **********It is a sentiment echoed on business campuses across the country, as schools try to assess the impact of the October 1987 stock market crash and many of Wall Street's other recent trials and tribulations on the latest generation of M.B.A.'s. **********The impact on students already in school when the market crashed has been well documented: Wall Street went from the hands-down employer of choice to an unsafe career bet. Wall Street recruiters spoke to half-empty rooms in the spring of 1988, as job-seekers flocked to presentations by management consulting firms, computer companies and consumer product corporations. **********Since then, the market, this past October's blip notwithstanding, has recovered. The hoopla over the decade's many insider trading scandals has died down. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., of course, has collapsed, but its long identification with well-publicized gambles in the ''junk bond'' market make it a special situation. And, even though some other beleaguered firms are still laying off people, the investment banks and brokerage houses have, for the most part, returned to a semblance of stability. They have even been recruiting actively on campus again. **********Yet academics and recruiters alike report that students, much like small investors, have shown a real reluctance to return to the markets. **********Indeed, the current crop of M.B.A. candidates, recognizing the insecurity involved in many high-profile financial jobs, is far less swayed by the promise of immediate six-figure incomes that lured many of their predecessors to Wall Street. Industrial corporations, meanwhile, have jumped into the breach with more aggressive recruiting programs, aimed at persuading M.B.A. candidates that there is as much glamour - and, for those who make it to the top, almost as much money -in managing a best-selling brand or opening a Hong Kong office as there is in doing mergers. **********Increasingly, the students are listening to the corporations' pitch. **********The implications for industry, and for the schools, can be huge. For more than a decade, business schools have found themselves competing for an ever-dwindling number of professors, as more and more of the best students were lured away from pursuing doctorates by high-paying job offers from Wall Street firms. Manufacturing companies all but stopped trying to recruit M.B.A.'s into line management jobs, and increasingly turned to in-house training programs and continuing education courses to develop manufacturing managers or internal finance specialists. Even management consulting firms, which once were the M.B.A. employers of choice, were having a hard time recruiting. **********Now the pendulum is swinging back - if not all the way to corporate America's side, then at least to a middle ground. Kellogg, Columbia, Cornell, Wharton, a whole host of business schools report that interest in industrial or academic careers is again at an all-time high. Courses in manufacturing, production and particularly international affairs have replaced investment banking as first-choice signups, they report. **********''The hard-core investment banking students, the ones who have it in their blood, have not changed their minds,'' said Lee Junkans, director of placement at Duke University's Fuqua School of Business. ''But the casual shoppers, the ones still looking for a career, for the most part are ignoring Wall Street, and listening to what the corporations have to say.'' **********Many educators guess that the shift in interest is permanent. ''Wall Street has finally lost its luster, and today's students want to know more about how you really operate a company, not just how you make deals,'' said John O. Whitney, who teaches management of organizations at the Columbia Business School. **********For the most part, the students know exactly what they are running from. On most campuses, the average age of an M.B.A. candidate is at least 26, which means that most have returned for their degree after several years of work experience. Many students spent those years on Wall Street - just in time to experience the depressed morale caused by the scandals, and the panic and subsequent doldrums caused by the crash. **********Then too, once-revered figures like Michael Milken and Ivan Boesky have been mired in scandal, tarnishing the Wall Street prestige. ''Now that some of the big names have been tarnished, being hired by Wall Street doesn't feel so much like earning a merit badge anymore,'' said Mr. Wilson, the Kellogg associate dean. **********And many of today's students do not relish the idea of putting in the 100-hour weeks that many investment bankers and brokers have endured to command their vaunted salaries. The aversion to the Wall Street grind is increasingly widespread, said Laurie Foltman, director of career services at Cornell University's Johnson Graduate School of Management. ''Students in general are now more concerned with life style, with balancing work and family,'' she said. **********Professors also say that today's M.B.A. students seem less selfish in their career aspirations. ''There is a lot more interest in corporate America now, as well as in not-for-profit and government, because students are looking more at what they can offer back, not just how much money they can make,'' said Thomas R. Dyckman, a Cornell accounting professor. **********Other industries, meanwhile, are offering more challenges. Companies of all kinds have been slashing management layers for a decade - for middle managers, a disastrous trend for middle managers, but for young M.B.A.'s, a quicker chance at a job with meaningful responsibilities and less competition for the top spots. **********Simultaneously, companies have been expanding their international operations at a rapid rate, opening branch offices, subsidiaries and manufacturing facilities around the globe. This has put young managers trained in business practices of different cultures on the fast track -a fact that has not gone unnoticed by ambitious business students. **********''Until recently, all we could do is talk about the glamour of an international job,'' said Gerald J. Mussari, a sector personnel manager at Procter & Gamble who has helped the company recruit international students at Cornell for several years. ''Now we can bring back the Cornellians we recruited three, four years ago and let them tell first-hand about the challenges and the glamour and the excitement. We have the credibility of a track record.'' **********WHAT STUDENTS ARE SAYING **********Among the 67,000 students who garner degrees from the nation's business schools each year - a total that has remained fairly constant in recent years - a shift in sentiment away from Wall Street and toward corporate America is evident. **********''Investment banking isn't a high-profile choice among any of my friends,'' said Samuel O. Sheagren, 25, a second-year management student at Kellogg. ''For one thing, Wall Street still seems too unstable. And for another, many of us want to analyze businesses and then do something about their problems, not just concentrate on making markets.'' **********Jane Gerb, a 26-year-old operations major at the Columbia Business School, is similarly impervious to Wall Street's allure. She expects to work for the General Motors Corporation when she graduates in June. ''Finance is still where the big money is and there are still students going into it because of that,'' she said. ''But increasingly, students and companies are recognizing that there are other lucrative and satisfying careers that M.B.A.'s can pursue.'' **********Often experienced in the workplace, M.B.A. candidates bring special insights to career choices. ''I've worked on trading floors, and yes it can be exciting when things are fast, but it is boring and depressing when things are slow,'' said Cynthia Merrick, a 26-year-old student at Fuqua who worked with Merrill Lynch for four years before going for her M.B.A. ''For me, now, brand management sounds a lot more exciting.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/28/busin.body_text: **********The Bank of New England Corporation yesterday announced a loss of $46.6 million for the quarter ended March 31, compared with a profit of $42.3 million, or 60 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago. **********The company, which lost $1.1 billion in 1989, continues to be troubled by bad real estate loans in a weakening New England economy. **********Earnings were hurt by the need to add $151 million to its reserves for loan losses in the first quarter, up from a $108 million increase a year ago. **********Earnings were also hurt by the need to pay higher interest rates on deposits to attract funds in the midst of its financial trouble. **********Losses were partly offset by gains of $173 million from the sale of various assets, including its credit card business. **********Following guidelines set by **********Federal regulators, Bank of New Engalnd is in the midst of a reorganization and trying to raise more capital. As part of that plan, the company has contracted to about $24.9 billion of assets from $32.6 billion a year ago. **********The company's stock slipped 12.5 cents a share yesterday, to $3.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/28/busin.main_headline: Stock Buyback Plan Announced by Carbide
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/28/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Stock Buyback Plan Announced by Carbide
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/28/busin.body_text: **********The Union Carbide Corporation said today that it would take several steps to strengthen its businesses and increase its flagging share price, including a substantial stock buyback and the sale of some businesses. **********Carbide's shares rose 62.5 cents today, to $14.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Union Carbide said it would begin a self-tender offer on Monday to buy back 20 million shares of common stock, or 14 percent of the shares outstanding. Pricing details will be announced Monday. **********The company also said it was in talks with unidentified parties to sell up to 50 percent of its UCAR Carbon business, which had 1989 sales of $802 million. The unit, a maker of graphite electrodes and other carbon products, is the smallest of Carbide's three main business units. **********Carbide said the sale was expected to be completed in the first quarter of 1991 and the cash would be used to repay debt. **********In addition, Carbide said it would establish an employee stock ownership plan, complete the reorganization of its retail packaged gases segment and sell its 50 percent interests in the Kemet Electronics Corporation and Lincare Inc. **********Investors have been hoping for a takeover, sale or spinoff of some of Carbide's assets to increase shareholder value. Carbide shares have been trading recently at near 1990 lows and at less than half of the 1989 high of $33.25. **********Carbide said today that its goal was to establish itself as a leading global chemical company. **********''We will have the best olefins chain petrochemicals and industrial gases businesses in the world, augmented by high-quality specialty businesses,'' the company's chairman, Robert Kennedy, said in a statement. Olefin chain petrochemicals are used in paints, plastics, synthetic fibers and other materials. **********Carbide is also a major producer of ethylene, the most important commodity chemical in the world and the basic building block of most plastics.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/03/world.main_headline: Saudi Urges Iraq to Quit Kuwait To Bolster Claims of Palestinians
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/03/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Saudi Urges Iraq to Quit Kuwait To Bolster Claims of Palestinians
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/03/world.body_text: **********Saying the world is ''teetering between the drums of war and the bells of peace,'' the Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia urged Iraq today to give up Kuwait to strengthen the right of Palestinians to claim a homeland in Israeli-occupied territory. **********In an address to the General Assembly, the Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, sought to improve Saudi relations with the Palestinians, which have been severely strained as a result of Saudi anger over the early support that Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, gave to President Saddam Hussein. **********In Jordan, where many Palestinians live, the Palestinians have been openly supporting the Iraqi leader. Speaking in Arabic and wearing a traditional Arab headdress and a robe edged with gold, the Saudi Foreign Minister told the Palestinian people, ''Your cause is our cause.'' **********The Saudi ''commitment toward the Palestinian people,'' he said, ''was not born today nor yesterday.'' **********''It was born with the first heartbeat of the cause,'' he added. **********Implicit Warning to Palestinians **********The Prince accused Iraq of undermining the Palestinians' right to a homeland by invading and annexing Kuwait. ''It is for Palestine that Iraq should withdraw from Kuwait and adhere to international legitimacy,'' he said, ''so that we can mobilize international legality to realize for the people of Palestine what will be realized for the people of Kuwait.'' **********His remarks also had an implicit warning to Palestinians and the P.L.O. that they would destroy their own case in the eyes of the world if they supported an Iraqi occupation of Kuwait that resembled the Israeli occupation of territories claimed by the Palestinians. **********''We say to them, 'Support legitimacy, for it is the basis of your cause, the cause of all Arabs, and the base that guarantees your legitimate rights in liberating the land and establishing the state,' '' Prince Saud al-Faisal said. **********He also seemed to criticize Jordan for its efforts to mediate between Iraq and those opposing the invasion of Kuwait. **********''There is no need for vacillation between word and deed or contradictions between declaration and implementation,'' he said. ''There is no place for alternative proposals, or for circulating initiatives that belong to the arena of wasted time.'' Denial From the P.L.O.  Reactions among Arab and other delegates focused mainly on the Prince's firm stand against Iraq and on the olive branch he offered the Palestinians by depicting Mr. Hussein as the real enemy of their cause. **********''Saudi Arabia is trying not to let the Palestinian cause get decoupled from general gulf concerns,'' said Clovis Maksoud, who resigned last month as the observer from the Arab League at the United Nations, citing the disarray in Arab attitudes toward the crisis. ''The Prince wants to show that Arab concerns are constant, but that primacy must go to resolving the immediate Kuwaiti issue.'' **********The senior P.L.O. official in charge of foreign policy, Farouk Kadoumi, did not make himself available for comment, although he is attending the General Assembly. A member of his delegation, Shafik Hout, said any suggestions that the P.L.O. supported Iraq were exaggerated rumours. **********He said the P.L.O. favored the withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait and of all foreign forces from Saudi Arabia, which should make it possible to resolve the dispute ''under an Arab umbrella.'' **********'To Climb Back on the Fence' **********Last week the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, told a news conference that the P.L.O. had made a serious mistake by showing support for the Iraqi invasion, but said, ''Some of Mr. Arafat's lieutenants are now trying to climb back on the fence.'' **********In his address, Prince Saud al-Faisal sought to counter Mr. Hussein's calls for a holy war against the non-Muslim forces in his country, as well as his contention that the annexation of oil-rich Kuwait was a blow on behalf of poor Arabs from lands without oil. He stressed that his speech was also a message from ''the custodian of the two holy mosques, King Fahd bin Abdul Aziz.'' The text had many references to Islamic ideals. **********The Prince avoided any reference to the nationality of the foreign forces in Saudi Arabia, saying just that they were from ''sisterly countries.'' He promised that they would withdraw as soon Kuwait was freed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/busin.main_headline: Chrysler Pact With Honda To Sell Jeeps
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/busin.print_headline: Chrysler Pact With Honda To Sell Jeeps
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/busin.body_text: **********The Honda Motor Company Ltd. has agreed to make part of its dealer network in Japan available to the Chrysler Corporation to sell two Jeep sport-utility vehicles, the companies said today. **********Chrysler will become the first company to offer vehicles through Honda's Japanese dealers. Sales will begin this fall with 1991 models of Jeep Cherokees and Wranglers. **********For years, Chrysler's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, has bemoaned his company's inability to penetrate the Japanese car and truck market deeply either because of Government regulation or dealer resistance. **********The Chrysler-Honda deal is expected to more than double the number of cars Chrysler sells in Japan compared with last year. **********Chrysler markets cars and Jeeps in Japan through a distribution network called Chrysler Japan Sales Ltd., a joint venture between Chrysler and J. Osawa & Company. A Chrysler spokeswoman, Karen Stewart, said about 1,500 Chrysler vehicles were sold in Japan last year. **********The General Motors Corporation sells vehicles in Japan through the Suzuki Motor Company dealers. And the Ford Motor Company uses the Mazda Motor Corporation's 290-dealership Autorama network to sell Ford- and Mazda-made vehicles under Ford nameplates in Japan. Ford expects to sell about 100,000 cars and light trucks through Autorama, including a mini-sport-utility vehicle, this year. **********Under the agreement, about half of Honda's Primo dealer network, a collection of 1,755 businesses that market family-oriented cars, will distribute Cherokee and Wrangler vehicles. About 2,000 vehicles will be sent to Japan during the 1991 model year, the companies said. **********Honda sells its own sporty cars through its Verno dealerships, and luxury cars through its Clio dealerships.
