In all, Honda has about 2,500 dealerships in Japan. **********Dealers with more than one brand of car or truck in Japan are extremely rare. **********''There is an incredible amount of dealer loyalty to their companies'' in Japan, Mary Anne Sudol, an auto analyst at Fitch Investors Services Inc., said today. ''It's a nice little breakthrough for Chrysler.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/busin.body_text: **********The European Community's Competition Commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, said today that Britain had met the conditions for becoming a full member of the European Monetary System. **********''The way is now open for the Government to start looking for an early date for full E.M.S. membership,'' Sir Leon told the Overseas Banking Club here. **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, under pressure to link the pound to the system's exchange rate mechanism, which is intended to stabilize the currencies of member countries, laid down stringent conditions in June. Among those were stipulations that France and Italy abolish controls on the flow of capital and that Britain lower its inflation rate, now nearly 8 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/09/world.main_headline: BUSH SENDS NEW UNITS TO GULF TO PROVIDE 'OFFENSIVE OPTION'; U.S. FORCE COULD REACH 380,000
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/09/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; BUSH SENDS NEW UNITS TO GULF TO PROVIDE 'OFFENSIVE OPTION'; U.S. FORCE COULD REACH 380,000
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/09/world.body_text: **********President Bush today ordered more than 150,000 additional American ground, sea and air forces to the Persian Gulf area, saying they were needed to provide "an adequate offensive military option" to drive Iraqi troops from Kuwait. **********The move would nearly double the size of the American land and naval combat units in the area and give the United States a numerical advantage over Iraq in the most up-to-date tanks. **********In making his announcement, Mr. Bush said the reinforcements were intended to increase pressure on President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to withdraw his troops from Kuwait, and to lay the foundation for an American attack should he continue to refuse. The Military Option **********"I have today directed the Secretary of Defense to increase the size of U.S. forces committed to Desert Shield to insure that the coalition has an adequate offensive military option, should that be necessary to achieve our common goals," Mr. Bush said at a White House news conference.  [ Excerpts, page A12. ] **********"I think Saddam Hussein should fully without condition comply to the U.N. resolutions. And if this movement of force is what convinces him, so much the better," he said. **********Before President Bush spoke, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union delivered Moscow's most explicit warning yet to Iraq, saying today in Moscow that the use of force to end the Persian Gulf crisis ould not be ruled out if diplomatic means fail.  [ Page A13. ] 380,000 by Early Next Year **********The Pentagon declined to say exactly how many additional troops were being sent, but one Administration official estimated that the additional reinforcements would number more than 150,000. That would bring the total American force in the gulf region to about 380,000 by early next year. **********Mr. Bush said he did not need United Nations approval to launch a military action against Iraq, but he indicated the Administration would seek out that support. **********"Yes, we have the authority but we've been great believers in going to the United Nations," Mr. Bush said in a question-and-answer session after his announcement. Virtually all of Washington's partners in the anti-Iraqi coalition have said that any military action should be undertaken under the umbrella of a Security Council resolution. **********The Security Council has adopted 10 resolutions against Iraq since Mr. Hussein's forces invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. One of the earliest measures, now three months old, provided for a comprehensive trade embargo and the blocking of all Iraqi assets abroad. **********Mr. Bush refused to say when force might be used, but he indicated agreement with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who said on Wednesday in an interview that two to three months more should be given to allow the sanctions against Iraq to work. If the sanctions fail, Mr. Mubarak said, war would be inevitable. **********The new reinforcements mark the largest military deployment since the Vietnam War, in which American troops stationed in Vietnam reached a peak of 543,000, excluding naval forces offshore. The deployment is also large by NATO standards, roughly equivalent in number to the American forces stationed in Western Europe during the cold war.  3 Aircraft Carriers **********The additional forces -- which include three and one-third Army divisions, three aircraft carriers, another battleship, a large Marine expeditionary force of more than 30,000 men and more Air Force units -- would join more than 230,000 American soldiers, Marines, sailors and airmen in the region. **********Although Administration officials previously outlined plans to send additional forces to the gulf area, saying two weeks ago that as many as 100,000 more troops might be sent, the decision today involves more troops and more armored units than expected. It is also the first time that Mr. Bush has explicitly threatened to to take offensive action against Iraq. **********The decision appears to have the dual purpose of escalating the pressure on Mr. Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait and increasing military forces in the region to a level at which an attack against Iraqi troops would be more feasible.  1,200 More M-1 Tanks **********The Army divisions being sent will add more than 1,200 modern M-1 tanks to about 800 American tanks already deployed in Saudi Arabia. The new tank deployments would give the United States an advantage in the number of top-of-the-line battle tanks, although Iraq, which has thousands of old tanks, would still have an overall advantage in tanks. **********The three aircraft carriers that are being sent will bring the total number of carriers in the region to six. The Navy has a total of 14 aircraft carriers. **********Mr. Bush has also ordered that an additional battleship, the Missouri, join the Wisconsin in the Persian Gulf. With their 16-inch guns and land-attack cruise missiles, the battleships will figure significantly in the impressive American firepower in the region. **********"There will probably be additional Air Force units also," said Mr. Cheney, adding that the precise units to be sent have not been determined. The United States has already stationed about 500 Air Force and Marine bombers, antitank aircraft and fighters in Saudi Arabia and other gulf nations, including a squadron of F-117 Stealth fighters, several dozen F-111F bombers in Saudi Arabia and about 20 B-52 bombers on the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia. Rivaling Cold War Numbers **********With the dispatch of the additional divisions, the United States will have about as many troops in the Persian Gulf as it maintained in Europe for about 40 years to oppose the Soviet military. Even with the warming in American and Soviet relations the United States kept some 305,000 Army and Air Force troops in Europe. **********General Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said at the news conference that two and a third of the Army's four and a third divisions in Western Europe were being sent to Saudi Arabia. **********The decision to send large reinforcements to the region suggests that the Bush Administration wants to leave a credible threat that it will force a resolution of the crisis, either by coercing President Hussein to withdraw his troops from Kuwait or by launching an attack with its allies to do so. **********President Bush asserted that the United States is receiving strong support from Western European, Arab and other members of the anti-Iraqi coaltion. Iraq has sought to divide the coalition, by releasing French and German hostages, for example, and some specialists question how long the alliance can hold. Waiting for Cool Weather **********Some military specialists say that if President Bush wants to use military force it would be preferable to begin in the cooler winter months, before the Muslim holy visits to Mecca in the spring. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney declined to say what role weather or political considerations played in the decision to send large reinforcements now instead of waiting to see if the economic sanctions work.  No Upper Limit Yet **********Mr. Cheney declined to rule out sending still more troops, saying that no upper limit had been set on American deployment in the gulf. He said Congressional leaders had been notified of the additional reinforcements today before the announcement. Congress has insisted that it be consulted before force is used in the gulf, but the Administration did not seek to explain the scope of its planned reinforcement before lawmakers adjourned late last month. **********While military officials say that a buildup would be needed to win a decisive victory and to limit American casualties in the event of war, some specialists said the new deployment would increase the risk of war. **********"It is too big a force to sit on," said Thomas McNaugher, a military specialist at the Brookings Institution, suggesting that the United States would be unlikely to tie down such a force for a lengthy period. **********The Administration's decision to continue the American buildup follows Iraq's move to expand its force in southern Iraq and Kuwait to some 430,000 and build elaborate fortications along the coast of Kuwait and the Saudi border. **********In addition to more than 230,000 American forces deployed in the region, allies of the United States have stationed well over 100,000 troops in the area, and more forces, including an Egyptian armored division and a Syrian armored division are being sent. **********The deployment of the three and a third Army divisions -- two and a third divisions from Germany and one from Fort Riley, Kansas -- is a major addition to United States armored capabilities in Saudi Arabia. Army figures show that the new units collectively have about 1,240 M-1 tanks, 750 of them new M1-A1 tanks, which have better guns and protection against chemical and biological attack. **********The American expeditionary force currently has about 800 tanks. This includes about 700 Army M-1 tanks, some 150 of which are M1-A1 models, and 120 Marine M-60 tanks. **********Mr. Cheney said the decision to add more forces was based in part on the assessment by the commander of American forces in the gulf region, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, of what would be needed to launch an offensive against Iraqi troops. **********"The additional military capability that's now being added clearly will give us the ability to conduct offensive military operations, should that be required in the months ahead," Mr. Cheney said. He said it would be early next year before all of the forces activated today were sent to the Persian Gulf and were combat-ready. **********The Pentagon is considering a plan to rotate fresh troops into the gulf region every six to eight months, but Mr. Cheney said a final decision had not yet been made on the policy. The 82d Airborne, which was deployed early in the conflict to get troops on the ground in a hurry, is expected to return to the United States so that the Army will have a quick reaction force for other possible crises and so the unit can continue its training. No announcement was made about the future of the 82d Airborne today. **********In addition to adding more active-duty forces, Mr. Cheney also called up the first Army combat reserve units, about 15,000 men. The Marine Corps has mobilized about 700 reservists this week for combat roles. Three Army National Guard brigades from Georgia, Mississippi and Louisiana were called up and will be sent to train for several weeks at the Army Training Center in Fort Irwin, Calif. **********Once the units have completed their training, Mr. Cheney said, the Pentagon will decide if they are ready enough to be sent to join front-line troops in Saudi Arabia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/17/busin.main_headline: Investment Banks' Ties To Pretoria Draw Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/17/busin.print_headline: Investment Banks' Ties To Pretoria Draw Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/17/busin.body_text: **********Some of America's biggest investment banks, vying for lucrative contracts to handle New York City's bond issues, now find themselves embroiled in disputes about ties to South Africa. The bankers' predicament is the result of a curious blend of Wall Street rivalries and racial politics that is increasingly a feature of public finance in American cities. **********The main target of anti-apartheid advocates - and a quiet campaign by its competitors on Wall Street - is the First Boston Corporation. First Boston has received particular scrutiny partly because one of its executives, Ronald Gault, is a friend and tennis partner of Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York. Mr. Gault, who is a director in the bank's public finance division, the unit seeking New York City's bond business, also served as co-chairman of a search committee for members of the Mayor's administration. **********The Mayor's office and the office of the New York City Comptroller will soon choose the three Wall Street firms that will manage the underwriting of city bonds over the next few years, a business that will generate a total of about $180 million in fees. **********Rival firms, concerned that Mr. Gault's friendship with the Mayor will give First Boston an advantage in winning one of the lead manager positions for the city's bond business, have emphasized First Boston's purported links to South Africa to anti-apartheid groups, investment bankers said. **********First Boston's major shareholder is CS Holding, a Swiss holding company that owns Credit Suisse, a Zurich-based bank with operations in South Africa. Other American investment banks also have large foreign investors, like Japanese banks and insurance companies that have operations or holdings in South Africa. **********Somewhat Tenuous Links **********In all cases, the links to South Africa are somewhat tenuous. The American investment banks do not have offices or direct investments in South Africa, the usual target of anti-apartheid protests. The advocates seem to have concentrated on First Boston because, with most American and British banks having pulled out of South Africa, Credit Suisse's presence there looms larger. **********The focus in New York on investment bankers' links to South Africa follows similar debates during the last year in Los Angeles and Oakland, Calif. As in New York, First Boston was the main target. Last year, Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles sent a letter to the City Council urging rejection of First Boston as underwriter for a $350 million financing. The firm eventually withdrew from the competition before the City Council ruled. **********In Oakland, First Boston's Credit Suisse connection was reviewed by the City Council, after Mayor Lionel Wilson publicly raised the question, but the firm was found to be in compliance with the city's regulations that prohibit hiring companies that have operations or business links to South Africa. **********In New York, local anti-apartheid groups held a news conference last week to criticize First Boston publicly and pressure the city government to bar the firm from being part of the underwriting group that will raise about $20 billion in short- and long-term financing by selling bonds for New York over the next several years. **********An Increasingly Political Business **********The business of public finance in America is highly political and has become increasingly so in recent years. The banking firms competing for the underwriting business of major cities often make political contributions, and they often hire former city officials or people close to city politics to help bring in business. **********During the 1980's, the rise of minority politicians and women on local and state levels added another highly politicized dimension to the business. Many cities and towns have since adopted ordinances requiring the inclusion of minority groups at every level of municipal business. Thus, the bankers that compete for public financing deals have come under substantial scrutiny from local governments all across the country. **********For black mayors - and the investment bankers pursuing the financing business of their cities - the matter of ties to South Africa by companies that deal with those cities has become a sensitive issue. **********Policy of Mayor Dinkins **********Mayor Dinkins's office has consistently said that firms selected as members of the city's underwriting group would be chosen based on their professional qualifications. The competing firms have been asked to provide information about any business connections to South Africa, direct or indirect, as a matter of routine. And a spokesman for the Mayor's office said that Mr. Gault's longtime friendship with the Mayor would make no difference in how the city selects its underwriters. **********For his part, Mr. Gault said that he hoped his friendship with the Mayor as well as First Boston's role as financial adviser to New York from 1982 to 1989 would have some influence on the city's selection of lead underwriters, but mainly in the sense of underscoring First Boston's qualifications and demonstrated expertise. **********''Dave and I have been friends for about 20 years,'' Mr. Gault said. ''I supported him spiritually and I supported him financially in two failed races. Will it make a competitive difference? I sure hope so.'' **********Anti-Apartheid Advocates' Stance **********Anti-apartheid advocates are vigorously pushing the city to exclude First Boston because it is 44.5 percent owned by CS Holding. And they have clearly tried to embarrass Mayor Dinkins on the issue. **********''There is an obvious contradiction between posturing to be anti-apartheid and then allowing a bank 44 percent owned by Credit Suisse's parent, a major supporter of apartheid, to make millions of dollars if it gets this contract,'' said the Rev. Lawrence Lucas, the pastor of the Resurrection Roman Catholic Church in Harlem, in a reference to the Mayor. **********Local anti-apartheid groups contend that although they are working against First Boston now, they will soon start to protest against some of the other investment firms. **********''Our interest is to expose all of them,'' said Elombe Brath, head of the Patrice Lumumba Coalition, one of the advocate groups. **********Position of First Boston **********First Boston finds itself in the uncomfortable position of having to defend itself for something it has little control over. **********''The issue has been framed so that First Boston seems to be a firm that sympathizes with apartheid,'' said Carl M. Eifler, a managing director and the head of First Boston's public finance department. **********''We have no ties with South Africa itself, and we have no ties coming from South Africa, but we are being held to a different standard than everyone else because of political pressures and base competitive reasons,'' Mr. Eifler. **********Nearly all major investment banks have been criticized for some kind of connection to business in South Africa. **********Variety of South African Links **********Depending on the criteria used, few investment banks can claim to have no links whatsoever. For example, Goldman, Sachs & Company is partly owned by Sumitomo Bank Capital Markets, a unit of Sumitomo Bank Ltd., which has business ties to South Africa. Goldman also has a small, indirect interest in the Bucyrus-Erie Company, a firm that does business in South Africa. **********Kidder, Peabody & Company is a subsidiary of the General Electric Company, which has ties to South Africa. Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.'s parent, the American Express Company allows its credit card business to operate in South Africa, and Shearson is partly owned by the Nippon Life Insurance Company, a large Japanese insurer with significant business interest there. Many other large investment banks also have ties to to South Africa or do business with companies that have ties there. **********In 1985 the New York City Council adopted an anti-apartheid law that restricts companies that do business with the city from having any business connections with South Africa. City officials said that the Dinkins administration is working to tighten the city's anti-apartheid law and that a bill to accomplish that end is under consideration. **********Firms' Exemption May End **********Financial firms have been exempt from the city's anti-apartheid regulations since the late 1970's, when the city was near bankruptcy and badly needed the bankers' support, but city officials said that might change. **********New York City's Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, said that at least 52 firms had applied to be part of the city's underwriting syndicate and that about 30 were still in the running. **********''We have a considered and deliberative process that we intend to follow through,'' Ms. Holtzman said. She refused to say whether possible South African business connections would be taken into consideration, but a spokesman in her office confirmed that they would.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/25/busin.body_text: *********** Acustar Inc., Troy, Mich., the parts unit of Chrysler Corp., said it would invest $31.9 million in its McGraw Glass and Detroit Axle operations. *********** Compaq Computer Corp., Houston, has announced a 2-for-1 stock split for shareholders of record on June 29, bringing the number of shares issued to about 78.1 million. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.main_headline: Profits Down at Digital and Apple
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.print_headline: Profits Down at Digital and Apple
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.body_text: **********The Digital Equipment Corporation and Apple Computer Inc. reported yesterday that their earnings had fallen in the latest quarter. Digital's earnings plunged nearly 83 percent, while Apple's were down just under 39 percent. **********Digital's results were at the high end of Wall Street expectations. Some analysts had predicted it would break even or have a loss. Apple's decline was anticipated as the company slowed production of older models to prepare for the introduction of new lower-priced Macintoshes on Monday. **********Following are details of the companies' results: **********Digital **********For its first quarter, Digital posted net income of $26.2 million, or 21 cents a share, compared with $150.8 million, or $1.20 a share, a year earlier. Revenues for the quarter ended Sept. 30 were flat, slipping a little more than 1 percent, to $3.09 billion, compared with $3.13 billion for the 1989 period. **********The company's stock rose $4.25 yesterday, to $51, on the New York Stock Exchange, after opening trading was delayed because of an order imbalance. **********Digital said that the results were ''not satisfactory'' and that the company would continue to cut expenses. For the fiscal year ended June 30, Digital took $550 million in charges to pay for voluntary severance packages. Last year, the company reduced its work force by 1,800. It said yesterday that it was still seeking to reduce its work force of 123,500 by as many as 6,000 employees before next July. **********John F. Smith, senior vice president of operations for Digital, which is based in Maynard, Mass., said the company was also consolidating operations, cutting discretionary spending and increasing automation. **********''They would like to become less capital-intensive,'' said Jay P. Stevens, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds. **********Digital's growth has slowed in recent years as the company has shifted to high-volume, lower-priced work stations from higher-margin minicomputers. **********Mr. Stevens said Digital should take more aggressive steps to reduce its work force. ''They tend to move slowly on staff reductions,'' he said. **********Digital had long resisted layoffs, but Mark Steinkrauss, a Digital spokesman, said, ''We can't rule out any line of thinking'' if too few employees accept voluntary severance. **********There were several bright spots in Digital's first-quarter results, including the company's worldwide services business, which grew 8 percent. Digital also shipped more than 75 of its new VAX 9000 mainframes. **********Digital's sales for the rest of the year are expected to get a lift from several new products scheduled to come out next week, including a midrange computer, the VAX 6500. **********The company also said that during the first quarter, it had repurchased 3.7 million of its shares for $241 million, completing a 5-million-share buyback its board authorized in April. **********Apple **********For its fourth quarter, Apple reported earnings of $98.5 million, or 81 cents a share, down from $161.1 million, or $1.24 a share, in the period a year ago. Revenues fell a little more than 2 percent, to $1.35 billion, from $1.38 billion in the fourth quarter of the 1989 fiscal year. Fourth-quarter 1989 earnings included 37 cents a share from the sale of common stock in Adobe Systems Inc. **********Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., announced its results after the stock market's close. Apple shares gained $2 yesterday, to $28.50, in over-the-counter trading. **********Apple predicted that it would return to strong revenue and earnings growth in the 1991 fiscal year. There are, however, some lingering doubts about how the new products will affect Apple's profit margins. **********For the fiscal year, Apple earned $474.9 million, or $3.77 a share, up 4.6 percent from $454 million, or $3.53 a share, in the 1989 fiscal year. Revenues rose more than 5 percent, to $5.56 billion, from $5.28 billion the previous year. **********''While we experienced significant revenue and unit growth in our Apple Macintosh computer modular products during fiscal 1990, sales of some of our more established product declined,'' John Sculley, Apple's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. However, ''gross margins improved dramatically from the prior year due to lower cost components and the favorable effect of a shift in our product mix to higher-margined products.'' **********While the three new Macintosh models all have lower profit margins than Apple products historically have had, the company expects to make up some of the difference through increased sales, continued strong sales of its more expensive, modular models, and continuing efforts to reduce operating expenses. Mr. Sculley, nevertheless, said he expects that ''gross margins will fall somewhat from the unsustainably high level of 53 percent of sales acheived in fiscal 1990.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/04/world.print_headline: Philippine Hotel Seized By a Rebel Governor
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/04/world.body_text: **********A suspended provincial governor backed by hundreds of armed men seized a hotel in the northern Philippines after a gunfight today, taking a general and several other people hostage, witnesses said. **********Rodolfo Aguinaldo had been suspended as Governor of Cagayan province and charged with rebellion and murder in connection with the attempted military coup last December against President Corazon Aquino. His forces today took over the Hotel Delfino in Tuguegarao, the provincial capital, 220 miles north of Manila. **********Witnesses said several soldiers were among his supporters at the hotel. Cagayan is the home province of Juan Ponce Enrile, the former Defense Minister who was arrested on Tuesday in Manila on charges of involvement in the December mutiny. **********Mr. Aguinaldo and his men captured Brig. Gen. Oscar Florendo, his driver and at least four civilian members of the general's staff after taking over the hotel in central Tuguegarao. **********One of Mr. Aguinaldo's men was killed earlier in a brief gun battle at a military checkpoint as his group drove in convoy to the hotel, witnesses said. **********Mr. Aguinaldo was slightly wounded when a window of his car was shattered by gunfire during the shootout, witnesses said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.main_headline: Big 3 of Long-Distance Slug It Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.print_headline: Big 3 of Long-Distance Slug It Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.body_text: **********The nation's three big long-distance telephone companies have sharply increased spending on advertising and marketing this year and are going after one another this fall with television and print campaigns whose tone is becoming nastier. **********None of the three, A.T.&T., MCI and U S Sprint, disclose advertising or other sales and marketing spending for competitive reasons. But according to Leading National Advertisers, a research company specializing in advertising spending, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's ad budget soared 40.2 percent in the first six months of this year, to $148.1 million. That was up from $105.6 million in the period last year. **********The MCI Communications Corporation, the second-largest long-distance carrier after A.T.& T., raised its advertising budget in the same period by 23.4 percent, to $25.4 million. No. 3, the U S Sprint Communications Company, increased its spending by 46.6 percent, to $27.5 million, according to Leading National Advertisers. **********'Smacking Each Other' **********''Almost any day of the week, you can pick up your newspaper and look at the back pages and see one of us smacking the other,'' said Joseph P. Nacchio, A.T.& T.'s vice president of marketing for business communication services. **********In another indication of how the marketing war has become more heated since the middle of the year, U S Sprint has transferred hundreds of employees into sales and marketing positions where they deal personally with business and residential customers, said Ronald T. LeMay, the company's president. But partly to allow it to do so, Sprint laid off nearly 1,000 of its 20,000 employees in the last three months. And A.T.& T. is adding 2,000 people just to its sales and marketing staff for long-distance business communications. **********The similarity of the many advertisements, with little-known actors and actresses promising better long-distance phone service and lower prices, prompted U S Sprint to start a new advertising campaign yesterday featuring a celebrity, the actress Candice Bergen. MCI began a new campaign in the last week that includes parodies of A.T.& T.'s ads. **********A.T.& T. touched off the current war of negative advertising several months ago with a series of commercials in which actors portrayed average consumers expressing exasperation at repeated sales calls from rival long-distance carriers. The people in the ads were invariably disillusioned with what was depicted as the scant savings and poorer service quality of the non-A.T.& T. carriers. **********One ad shows a young woman laden with shopping bags who races to answer the phone only to find that the call is a marketing pitch. ''I think it's him, but it's them,'' she says in disappointment and disgust. **********The A.T.& T. campaign seeks to make the company's customers more resistant to telemarketing by rivals by suggesting that the competitors be asked to ''put it in writing'' when they promise better quality and lower rates. **********Spoofing the Leader **********U S Sprint, facing a stagnating market share, has spoofed A.T.& T.'s advertising binge with an ad showing a nightmarish factory of the future with no people and lots of large machinery stamping out television sets displaying its larger rival's ads. And MCI has begun its own newspaper and television campaign stressing quality service and lower prices with lines like ''Has A.T.& T. been under a rock? Do they think they have a monopoly on operators, too?'' **********The marketing war reflects the fact that, much like sellers of toothpaste, A.T.& T., MCI and U S Sprint all now offer similar prices and products, having made most of the cost savings and network improvements that can be done readily, said Jack Grubman, a telephone industry analyst at Paine Webber. **********''This industry has evolved into another consumer nondurable industry, which is: you win market share points on marketing and advertising and not on pricing,'' he said. ''This is largely a commodity product and it really takes a lot of marketing and advertising to convince people otherwise.'' **********A.T.& T. has about two-thirds of the market, MCI 16 percent and U S Sprint about 10 percent. The rest is divided among several hundred small companies. The winners from this fall's marketing struggle will not be clear for several months. **********Little Effect on Profits **********The extra marketing spending is likely to cut profits, but not by much in an industry with $52 billion in annual sales, financial analysts say. Long-distance carriers are waging their marketing war because they are not satisfied with their market share, and the resulting campaigns are cheaper than cutting prices, Mr. Grubman said. **********The question is, can operating costs decrease fast enough to compensate for the extra marketing expenses, he added, estimating that the current marketing struggle could cost MCI about $25 million this year in foregone profits. **********The bitterness of the struggle for the long-distance market is clear from three details: Most of the advertising is aimed at taking customers from other long-distance carriers, instead of increasing overall demand; competition is driving up the cost of acquiring each new customer, and the nation's three leading long-distance carriers all say they are devoting a slightly larger percentage of their total revenues to sales and marketing this year, which has partly displaced spending on network improvements like new switching equipment and high-capacity fiber-optic lines. **********''It's going to, in effect, take money out of the pockets of the telephone industry and put it in the pockets of the advertising industry,'' although not to an extent that is likely to hurt the quality of service, said John S. Bain, a telephone industry analyst at Raymond James & Associates Inc., a brokerage in St. Petersburg, Fla. **********Greater Number of Services **********Increased advertising partly reflects the need to explain a greater variety of services, such as discounts for large volumes of calls to a given country or region overseas. Executives at all three long-distance carriers say that although total marketing spending for the year has increased faster than their revenues, the deluge of advertisements will not last. ''If it's there all the time, it tends to get stale,'' said Merrill R. Tutton, A.T.& T.'s vice president for consumer services. **********''Now it's the fall, so it's about time from a seasonal point of view to go back on the air again,'' said Kevin W. Sharer, the executive vice president for sales and marketing at MCI. **********The increased sales efforts are a rational response by telephone companies to a marketplace that rewards such spending, said Mr. Nacchio of A.T.& T. ''We must all be assessing that the incremental revenues are greater than the incremental costs,'' he added. **********The combative stance of the long-distance companies contrasts to most advertising by local phone companies, which enjoy monopolies. Their advertisements are aimed at persuading people to make more calls, a strategy that A.T.& T. also followed when it dominated the long-distance market. The Illinois Bell Telephone Company and the New York Telephone Company, for example, use the slogan of ''We're all connected'' set to feel-good music to try to stimulate demand for their services. **********The Buildup of 1989 **********MCI and A.T.& T. began to build up their sales and marketing staffs in the summer of 1989. **********U S Sprint did not immediately follow, and paid a price: On July 12, it announced a $42 million loss for the second quarter and blamed a lack of new residential and small-business customers. The stock of United Telecommunications Inc., which owns 80 percent of U S Sprint, quickly dropped by a third. **********Advertising campaigns by long-distance carriers are also particularly visible this autumn because residential consumers and small businesses represent the most hotly disputed corner of the market. But long-distance marketing moves in cycles. Large business customers, who are seldom the targets of television advertisements, may become the focus of attention again. **********''My competitors have, in my opinion, slid over'' to advertising for residential customers, said Mr. Nacchio, who oversees A.T.& T.'s large business accounts. ''If you would have looked at us six or eight months ago, you would have seen hand grenades going back and forth.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/world.main_headline: Flood of Foreigners Seeking Asylum Angers West Germans
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/world.print_headline: Flood of Foreigners Seeking Asylum Angers West Germans
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/world.body_text: **********With the 1990 figure for foreigners applying for asylum in West Germany passing the 100,000 mark this week, and hundreds of thousands of East Germans and ethnic Germans from farther east in Europe jamming into the country, feelings against non-Germans and non-West Germans are rising. **********You can hear it from some West German politicans and in Bonn's subways, where natives find themselves sharing space with Iranians, Sikhs, Arabs, Africans and Romanian Gypsies, all clearly identifiable by their chadors, turbans, djellabahs, veils and other native dress. **********The East Germans are not nearly so conspicuous. But the locals seem to recognize them instantly. A white-haired woman with a cane berated some noisy German youngsters in a subway car the other day, then turned to no one in particular and declared: ''I can't stand these people from East Germany! They should stay home. I never did like them.'' **********On the same line the next morning, an elderly German woman turned with a look of disdain away from empty seats adjacent to several dark-skinned passengers and sat down next to a white passenger. ''I despise these foreigners,'' she said. **********''But I am a foreigner, too,'' the seatmate said. **********''Yes,'' she said. ''But you are not dark skinned.'' **********That sentiment in a country where the population density is already one of the highest in Europe can be encountered in more intense forms in towns where asylum-seekers have been crowded into camps. **********One of those is in Lebach, a town of 7,200 in the Saar where there has been a reception center since 1958 for asylum-seekers and Germans from outside the country being resettled here. All went well with the foreigners until now. **********Curbs on Asylum Sought **********For weeks, the Lebach camp, with a capacity of 1,300, has been home to nearly twice that number, the majority of them Gypsies from Romania, and tensions with the townspeople have sharpened. **********After complaining of rampant shoplifting by the refugees, shopkeepers and bankers started closing their doors. Barbed wire was put around the town swimming pool to prevent camp people from bathing there. The police chief complained that Gypsies had entered his house and stolen property. **********Richard Dewes, Secretary for Social Affairs in the Saar state government, said he had encountred ''naked hatred'' when he tried to discuss the problems created by the asylum-seekers with Lebach residents last week. **********The situation in Lebach has prompted the Saar governor, Oskar Lafontaine, who is also the Social Democratic candidate for Chancellor of West Germany, to join politicians from other parties in proposing restrictive changes in the Federal Republic's laws on asylum. #41% Rise in Applications In principle, any foreigner may seek political asylum in West Germany, although currently about 97 percent of the applicants are considered to lack clear evidence of eligibility. But the law permits them to stay until their applications have been processed by administrative courts and other legal authorities, which can be a matter of months or even years. **********In July the number of applicants for asylum was 18,855, an increase of 41 percent over the number in June. **********Waves of asylum-seekers seem to be coming from ever new directions. In July it was the 3,200 Albanians who stormed into the West German Embassy in Tirana, subsequently obtaining free passage out of their Communist-ruled country. In August it seems to be people from Lebanon, Turkey and Bulgaria. **********The asylum issue is a difficult one, as Mr. Lafontaine learned when he proposed a ban on asylum seekers from European Community countries as the beginning of a restrictive list. He met a storm of criticism from his own party and from the Free Democratic Party. **********The issue conceivably could attract attention in the national election campaign that is just getting under way. But at the moment, Bonn politicians are so preoccupied with the unification of East and West Germany that the question has not attracted great controversy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/04/world.body_text: **********More than 100,000 people, most of them dressed in the mourning colors of white and black, took part today in a march to honor pro-democracy demonstrators who were killed in the army crackdown in Beijing last June 4. **********The march, under gray, rainy skies, drew the largest turnout here since the huge demonstrations in support of democracy in China last summer. The police estimated the crowd at 100,000, while organizers claimed 250,000. **********The size of the crowd, which stretched for more than two miles past the skyscrapers of Hong Kong's central business district, surprised even its organizers, whose original estimate of a turnout of 30,000 people was widely thought to be optimistic. Hong Kong, a British colony, reverts to Chinese control in 1997. **********''The vast numbers show that in spite of fears here - and many people do fear that the Chinese photograph these demonstrations and will later seek to punish those who took part - despite those fears, almost a quarter of a million people came out,'' said Martin Lee, a liberal lawyer and a leader of today's march. **********Intimidation Said to Fail **********Mr. Lee said the huge crowd ''proves that the Chinese policy of trying to intimidate Hong Kong over the past year has failed.'' He added, ''They need to recognize that fact and try to win us over, not frighten us.'' **********The crowds today, generally sad and solemn, followed a hearse, and where the Chinese traditionally place a picture of the dead, it carried pictures of the violence in Tiananmen Square last June. **********A Chinese father marching behind the hearse and carrying his young son on his shoulders said: ''I want him to remember this. I want him to understand we must never forget.'' **********Thousands of small white penants proclaimed, ''People Will Not Forget.'' The marchers, who sang ''China Shall Be Free'' to the American protest tune ''We Shall Overcome,'' also chanted for the downfall of Prime Minister Li Peng, and demanded the release of democracy advocates still in prison in China. **********The river of demonstrators was led by Mr. Lee and Szeto Wah, and a number of Hong Kong's most popular entertainers. The march was organized by the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of the Patriotic Democratic Movement in China, a group Beijing has labeled subversive. **********The march ended at the New China News Agency, China's de facto embassy here, and then dispersed quietly. The press agency's headquarters has traditionally been the focus of protests against China, and all day, passers-by had stopped to pay tribute to those who died in Beijing last June. **********Makeshift Altar Set Up **********Some bowed reverently before a makeshift altar that had been set up by student protesters outside the big marble and tile New China News Agency headquarters. Others lighted joss sticks, and still others brought small offerings of apples, oranges and biscuits they placed before the alter. The headquarters was heavily guarded by the police, its front door locked and barred. **********The crowds today were no match for the hundreds of thousands - some said up to a million - who took to the streets here last summer in support of the democracy movement in China. But today's turnout was nevertheless impressive for a colony that has grown increasingly reticent and fearful of China. **********One sign of the change of heart from summer to summer is the large Goddess of Democracy statue, put up by Beijing demonstrators, and copied here by local artists. The replica was displayed last summer in parks here, but was absent from today's tribute. **********The Goddess, stored for months by its creators, was finally buried in a garbage landfill after the Hong Kong Government refused to give it a permanent public home. Today, there was a smaller copy strapped to a bus, and there were a number of cardboard cutouts of the Goddess. **********Since last June, the Hong Kong government and political leaders here have taken pains to avoid angering or even displeasing the Chinese authorities, whose attitude toward the colony has been seen by many as intrusive and threatening. **********The military crackdown last year shook Hong Kong's very foundations, destroying in days the colony's essential confidence in itself, in its future under China. A local newspaper recently quoted expert psychologists as saying the level of stress in Hong Kong ranks behind only Beirut and Belfast. #1,000 Leave Each Week While China has promised to leave Hong Kong's social and economic systems largely intact and to maintain a policy of ''one country, two systems'' after 1997, few have faith in those pledges anymore. **********More than 1,000 people - educated, talented entrepreneurs and professionals - are leaving Hong Kong each week, creating serious shortages in key occupations. **********Economic performance has been lackluster, and more local companies here have moved their bases to Bermuda, and are looking for investments outside the colony. **********A Hong Kong Chinese banker said recently that political reforms here were no longer the answer. ''The only hope for us,'' he said, ''is a change of power in Beijing.'' **********Rallies in the U.S. **********By The Associated Press **********Demonstrations commemorating the first anniversary of the suppression of the democracy movement in China were held yesterday in New York, Washington, Chicago, Boston and Buffalo, among other cities. **********The rally in New York City drew about 1,500 people across the street from the Chinese Consulate in Manhattan. People inside the consulate's building at 45th Street and 12th Avenue were seen videotaping the rally from windows, and an older Chinese man yelled up several times in Chinese, ''Come Down! Come Down!''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/busin.main_headline: Paul Revere Insurance Gets a New President
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Paul Revere Insurance Gets a New President
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/busin.body_text: **********The leading disability income insurance company in North America, Paul Revere Insurance Group, will start the new year with a new president for the first time in 17 years. **********Charles E. Soule has been appointed president by the board of Textron Inc., Revere's parent company. Mr. Soule will replace Aubrey K. Reid Jr., 63 years old, who is retiring. **********Mr. Soule, 56, Revere's executive vice president for insurance operations, has spent his entire career at the company, beginning as a health insurance underwriter after his graduation from Dartmouth College in 1956. **********"I walked out of school one day and in here the next," Mr. Soule recalled in a telephone interview. "I was hungry then and I'm still hungry today." **********Through the years, Mr. Soule worked in most divisions of the company, which was founded in 1895 and is based in Worcester, Mass. He became a vice president in 1971, senior vice president in 1980 and executive vice president in 1983. **********Mr. Soule's predecessor, Mr. Reid, was also a lifelong Revere employee, starting in 1949 as a claims examiner. **********Although Revere writes life insurance, group health and medical insurance policies, disability income insurance has provided the bulk of the company's business. Today, about 70 percent of Revere's more than $750 million in annual sales comes from disability operations. **********Revere became a part of Textron in 1984, after Textron acquired Revere's parent, Avco Inc., for $1.4 billion. Textron, based in Providence, R.I., is a multi-industry company with the bulk of its business in aerospace technology, commercial products and financial services. **********Mr. Soule, who has written a textbook on disability insurance, said one of his goals as president would be to expand Revere's disability insurance business. To that end, he has appointed the company's first vice president for customer service and strategic development, Gerald M. Gates. **********"Customer service is taking a much bigger role in the insurance business than it had in the past," Mr. Soule said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;   Chile Allows Drug Patents To Outsiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/busin.body_text: **********In what was probably its last important legislative act, the military Government has adopted a law granting patent protection to foreign pharmaceutical companies whose products are copied and sold in Chile. **********Although the legislation does not provide as much protection as had been sought by the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association and the United States Trade Representative, Carla A. Hills, Chile is believed to be the first Latin American country to recognize the patent rights of laboratories that develop drugs. **********The law provides 15 years of patent protection for drugs, counting from the date of the beginning of the development of the drug. The law is not retroactive. **********Trade Sanctions **********American drug companies and the United States Government have sought protection in Latin American countries for years, and the issue led to trade sanctions against Brazil four years ago. United States law permits the restriction of imports from a country violating patent rights equal to the estimated amount of loss suffered by the drug companies. **********Latin American Governments have long ignored the pirating of drug formulas by laboratories in their countries, saying they were trying to provide medical care as cheaply as possible to their people. **********The four-man military junta that has served a legislative role in Chile for the last 10 years adopted the legislation on Jan. 30, at the request of the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. It was under pressure from the United States to adopt the protection before handing over power to the elected Government of Patricio Aylwin on March 11. **********Opposed by Local Groups **********The measure, which had been under discussion by Chilean and United States authorities for five years, has been strongly opposed by the local pharmaceutical organization and by political and consumer groups demanding cheaper and better medical care. **********Such groups depicted the pressures from the United States as an intrusion into Chilean sovereignty by a rich and powerful country and its business interests. **********But organizations of exporters and leading business figures argued that the legislation was necessary to protect Chile's own growing position as an export nation. When it filed its complaint with the United States trade representative in early 1988, the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association contended that its members had suffered losses in Chile of $87 million. Some European countries, including West Germany and Switzerland, could also claim losses. **********Foreign Minister Hernan Felipe Errazuriz, who played a role in bringing about the law, said he felt that ''if a country wants to have access to world trade it has to respect the rules of free trade.'' **********''Many only want free trade from the angle that serves their interests,'' he said. **********Politically Unpopular **********He also said that those in the United States wanting the stronger protection this law provides did not understand how politically unpopular that stanceis here. **********Members of Mr. Aylwin's Government have tacitly accepted the patent legislation as necessary to protect the country's trade position.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/world.main_headline: Berlin, the Capital, Fears for Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/world.print_headline: Berlin, the Capital, Fears for Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/world.body_text: **********Nearly a month after unification, this sprawling city of more than three million people is still struggling to become the united Germany's capital in more than name alone. **********The problem arises because the treaty uniting the Germanys declared Berlin the capital, but ruled that only the all-German legislature that will be elected in December could decide where to locate the ministries and bureaucrats. No decision is expected before the spring. **********Berliners appeared in need of reassurance this week. First, the present Bonn Legislature named Frankfurt, not Berlin, as the permanent seat of the Central Bank on Tuesday. **********Earlier, Bonn bureaucrats had leaked a report complaining about the way Berlin had handled Unification Day ceremonies on Oct. 3, calling them chaotic. And Bonn's arbiters of finance let it be known that they favored the immediate abolition of state subsidies that now pay about half of Berlin's annual budget of more than $17 billion. Arguments on Two Levels **********Heinrich Albertz, a former Mayor, appeared to stroke Berliners' sensibilities when he warned today that "Berlin has to be the true capital of a united Germany." If Berlin had only the title of capital, and the ministries and their bureaucrats stayed in the distant Rhineland, the 75-year-old politician said in a speech, then a united Germany was "in danger of listing westward." **********The arguments over Berlin are made at two levels. **********On the one hand, there is the cost of shifting ministries, financing accommodation for officials and their staffs, and reorganization. **********East Berlin's former Mayor, Tino Schwierzina, now the Deputy Mayor of all the city, warned recently of crushing unemployment in Berlin if the federal ministries stayed in Bonn, given the loss of roughly 180,000 jobs in the now dissolved bureaucracy of the former East German Communist Government. Berlin's jobless rate, he said, could rise as high as 25 percent. **********Berlin's government spokesman, Werner Kolhoff, argues that without Berlin as a locomotive the economic prospects of the five new states carved out of the region that used to be East Germany are bleak. 'On the Razor's Edge' **********"What other city can be the motor for the region?" he asked recently in the city's bright and trim town hall. "Our theory is that the integration of the new states has to happen through Berlin, or it will happen very fitfully, or not at all." **********"Berlin is on the razor's edge," Mr. Kolhoff said. "It can be a great metropolis, or it can be a poverty zone. Both are possible." **********But the other argument is over the symbolism and the political effects of the move. For most Germans, Berlin stands for recovery and reconstruction and the defiance of the Soviet attempt to starve the city out of its freedom with the 1948 blockade. Berlin also recalls the flight to freedom of millions of East Germans that provoked construction of the Berlin wall. **********But from a historical perspective, it also stands for Prussian militarism and failed empires, and the failed democracy of the Weimar period with the hyperinflation, disorder and decadence out of which Nazism arose. **********"Many Germans never liked Berlin," said Joachim Trenkner, a television producer who has seen Berlin through thick and thin. "They regard it a little the way the rest of America sees New York. Basically an evil place, even if lively and interesting. They go there to amuse themselves, but they don't really like it or trust it." The Political Element **********Partly, this is political, he admits. Berlin is run by a coalition of Social Democrats and a leftist grouping called the Alternative List that is often at loggerheads with the conservative Bonn Government. When Chancellor Helmut Kohl rushed to Berlin last November at the opening of the wall, the excited crowds booed him. **********There is a strong anarchic scene, and the city is perceived by many in the west as overrun by foreigners. Polish moonlighters and Soviet Jewish immigrants abound, and a large Turkish population remains from the effort to hire workers from Turkey to offset a labor drain caused when working-class families fled the city's isolation after the wall went up. Now the crumbling Kreuzberg district is sometimes called Little Istanbul, Turkish newspapers are edited here and there are two Turkish television stations. **********Boosters of Berlin like Mr. Kolhoff like to point to surveys like one taken recently in what used to be East Germany showing that 87 percent of the population there favor Berlin as capital. But there are dissenters. **********"I feel I am an East European," said Stefan Ret, a writer in what used to be East Berlin. **********Berlin is 50 miles from Poland, nearly as east as Prague, and the cobbled streets and crumbling buildings of the Prenzlauer Berg neighborhood where Mr. Ret is opening a publishing business remind one more of Warsaw or Bucharest than Paris or London. **********"The question of the capital is more urgent for West Berlin than for us," said Mr. Ret, who was born 34 years ago near Leipzig and wants to print young German and East European authors. "People there are afraid they will go under with the east. If the people in Bonn feel more comfortable there, let them stay there then."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/17/world.body_text: **********Israel's new Foreign Minister, David Levy, has apparently suffered a slight heart attack, doctors reported today. Mr. Levy, a 52-year-old Likud bloc member who is seen as a possible successor to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, arrived at a hospital in northern Israel on Thursday from his home in Beit Shean. He was placed in the cardiac intensive care unit, and his condition was described as good.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/22/busin.main_headline: Minutes From Fed Meeting Show Backdrop of Rate Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/22/busin.print_headline: Minutes From Fed Meeting Show Backdrop of Rate Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/22/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve set the stage for its recent interest rate reductions at a mid-November meeting of its monetary policy committee, according to minutes of the meeting released today. **********The central bank has permitted four reductions of its Federal funds rate since October and on Wednesday it dropped the discount rate from 7 percent to 6 1/2 percent, the first decline in four years. **********The decline in the Federal funds rate on Oct. 29, to 7 3/4 percent, from 8 percent, was in response to the Federal budget-cutting agreement between the Bush Administration and Congress. **********But the Federal Open Market Committee noted weakening economic activity at its Nov. 13 meeting and agreed to another "slight reduction." **********The move, the minutes said, was intended to "provide some insurance against a deep and prolonged recession without incurring a substantial risk in current circumstances of fostering intensified inflationary pressures." **********And, the minutes said, the committee agreed to give weight "to potential developments that might require some slight further easing" until the next meeting. That meeting was held Tuesday and was followed by the cut in the discount rate. The Federal funds rate is also closer now to 7 percent. **********Between the meetings, the Federal funds rate fell to 7 1/2 percent on Nov. 16 and to 7 1/4 percent on Dec. 7. The rate is the interest banks charge each other for overnight loans. The discount rate is the interest the Fed charges on loans to banks and other financial institutions. **********The minutes show that the committee members were concerned about "the growing signs of a softening economy, the related vulnerability of many business and financial firms to added financial strains and the increased reluctance of institutional lenders to accommodate less-than-prime business borrowers."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/08/world.main_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Reporter's Notebook;   For Speed Ball Bush, On to Helsinki
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/08/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Reporter's Notebook;   For Speed Ball Bush, On to Helsinki
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/08/world.body_text: **********All over the world last Saturday, phones began ringing. Christer Haglund, the press attache of the Finnish Consulate in New York, got a call from the Foreign Ministry at his summer home in the archipelago 35 miles east of Helsinki, putting him in charge of the 2,000 journalists descending on the capital. **********Sig Rogich, the President's summit planner, was spending Labor Day weekend hiking in the Virginia mountains when he got word that his presence was required in Finland. **********Wendy Walker, a producer at Cable News Network, was whacking the ball on the fifth hole of a golf course in Kalamazoo, Mich., when her bosses tracked her down with orders to catch the next plane to Helsinki. **********Only six days later in Finlandia Hall, where the Helsinki Philharmonic can usually be found rehearsing, the American networks have produced an instant electronic village, with four metal anchor booths rising from the lawn like miniature rock-concert stages. **********The Finns, who pride themselves on an industrious temperament and state-of-the-art technology, have outdone themselves. **********In Finlandia Hall, there are ''Helsinki, 9/9/90'' briefcases, umbrellas, T-shirts and hologram stickers, press packets in eight languages and brochures listing other events in the city: a production at the National Theatre of ''En Ole Herra Rappaport'' (''I'm Not Rappaport''), the Finnish Grand Prix in Body Building at the Ice Rink, a fish festival at the Baltic herring market, and ''Lapland Ahoy,'' a tourist and trade event aboard the Arctic icebreaker Sampo. **********One downtown shop sought to capture the zeitgeist of the East-West summit with a window display featuring a pouty cutout of Marilyn Monroe wearing an ''All We Need is Glasnost'' T-shirt with a hammer-and-sickle design. **********A Race With Television **********At CNN headquarters, Ms. Walker was overseeing the installation of 41 telephones, 40 television monitors, 15 trash cans, 10 clocks, 8 computers, 8 typewriters, 6 microwave dishes, 2 satellites, 2 fax machines, 1 photocopying machine and 1 refrigerator. **********At the request of the White House, she also had to have the Government guest house where Mr. Bush is staying wired so he can receive CNN. **********Next door at CBS, Susan Zirinsky, an inspiration for the producer in the movie ''Broadcast News,'' was ordering up shots of local statues and ''nice angles'' of the Presidential Palace, where the two leaders will meet Sunday for five hours, and have lunch with their wives and the President of Finland, Mauno Koivisto. **********Ms. Zirinsky was simultaneously arranging for Dan Rather's hotel room and scheduling coverage of a Sunday event with Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev, a tour of the University of Helsinki Library's rare map and book collection. **********Ms. Zirinsky said President Carter was also fast, recalling that he rushed off one morning from his house in Plains, Ga., so fast he left behind in his driveway the military attache with the bag of codes that can blow up the world. But she said Mr. Bush is the champion speed demon. **********''The President loves the game of 'Bet you can't keep up with us,'' ' she said. ''And, since television is crisis-oriented, we love the game of 'Oh, yes, we can.' '' **********Of Saunas and Summits **********Unofficially, it is being called ''the reindeer summit'' or ''the sauna summit.'' **********Finnish officials proudly point out that Mr. Bush, on a trip here as Vice President, enjoyed a traditional Finnish sauna bath. It may have been hard to avoid. According to ''A Businessman's Guide to the Finnish Sauna,'' the country has 60,000 lakes and 1,200,000 saunas, one sauna for every four Finns. **********But while the Finns may be trumpeting the Helsinki summit meeting, Bush officials here insist it is not a summit, but a meeting. **********That semantic downshift is consistent with the Administration's earlier reluctance to call the hostages in Iraq ''hostages'' or the blockade of the Persian Gulf a ''blockade.'' **********The use of the word ''meeting'' and the choice of less-than-exotic Helsinki are also consistent with Mr. Bush's desire to demystify contacts with the Soviet leader. The President wants his relations with Mr. Gorbachev, by phone and in person, to seem more routine and less dramatic. **********In order to avoid the use of the dread ''s'' word, White House officials arranged with Soviet officials for the background sign for the joint news conference to read: ''Bush -Gorbachev. Helsinki, Finland. September, 1990.'' **********Unlike Hollywood agents, who fight to the death over which star gets top billing, the American and Soviet advance teams did not wrangle about which President would be listed first. **********The summit planners for East and West, who also planned the sessions at Malta and Camp David, have become so friendly that they now call each other by their first names and exchange gifts. The Soviets offer caviar, and the Americans give Presidential cufflinks. **********Asked why Mr. Bush gets top billing, Mr. Rogich replied with the grace of a seasoned diplomat, ''Probably just alphabetical.'' **********Spotlight on the Gray **********Tourism in Iceland and Malta may never recover from the summit pictures beamed around the world, showing those countries looking wet and gray and windy. **********But the countries that play host for Soviet-American summit meetings always begin their endeavors with great optimism that they will be able to show off their charms and correct all misperceptions abroad. **********Even though it is raining and gray and windy here today, the Finns are buoyant about their turn in the spotlight. **********Ralf Friberg, the director general of the culture department of the Foreign Ministry, said the summit meeting might help debunk Finland's international reputation as a laggard ''in terms of bold diplomatic initiatives and strong phrases.'' **********''They characterize Finland as a waiter at the table of international diplomacy, or at most, a maitre d','' Mr. Friberg wrote in a statement on the summit titled, ''Why Helsinki?'' **********But he predicted that the meeting would be such a success that Finland will be able to sit down at the diplomatic dinner table. ''All 500,000 residents of Helsinki are eager to do their part,'' he said, ''be it only to applaud at black motorcades rushing by or to watch the performance on television.'' **********He also noted that security - always the top concern of host countries - would not be a problem. ''How safe is Helsinki as an international meeting place?'' Mr. Friberg asked. ''A Finnish policeman would answer this question with two words: safe enough.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/17/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   How Ayer Views Talks With Dentsu
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/17/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   How Ayer Views Talks With Dentsu
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/17/busin.body_text: **********JERRY J. SIANO, the chairman and chief executive of Ayer, wants to set the record straight. **********Contrary to recent reports in the trade press and some newspapers, Ayer is not on the verge of signing a deal to sell a minority stake to Dentsu, the Japanese agency giant, he said. **********''We've had a relationship with Dentsu for seven years, working together for clients like Toshiba, and recently we've had talks with Dentsu about forming a bigger relationship,'' Mr. Siano said in an interview on Friday. ''But nothing explicit has been agreed on, and no specific deal has been forged.'' **********Mr. Siano said he had had informal discussions with a number of agencies, including some from France that he would not name, that are attracted by Ayer's roster of blue-chip clients. These include A.T.& T., J. C. Penney, Procter & Gamble and General Motors. **********It is likely that Ayer will strike a deal at some point to sell a minority interest to a foreign agency, he said, because he wants to establish a solid presence in East Asia. To that end, Dentsu would be a likely choice, but Ayer could easily strike a deal with some other foreign agency. Ayer also needs an infusion of capital to continue its aggressive expansion in Europe and the United States. **********''If we want to grow further we have to look outside the agency for the money to invest,'' Mr. Siano said. Expansion in Europe is especially important, he said, because it now accounts for nearly 40 percent of the agency's business. **********Mr. Siano said Ayer needed to invest substantially in building up its European network if it wants to compete with well-established agencies like Young & Rubicam and J. Walter Thompson. ''It took us a long time to go international,'' he said. ''Now we have to play catch up.'' **********While the agency is profitable, Mr. Siano said, revenues have been shrinking, in part because of the decline in the industry in the United States and the loss of two big clients, Burger King last year and Continental Airlines earlier this year. **********One option for raising money that Mr. Siano said he would not pursue is going public. ''There is no reason for us to go public,'' he said. ''I don't want to spend my time thinking about the agency's bottom line, instead of our clients' business.'' **********Mr. Siano said going public would destroy the company culture of the private agency, which was founded 121 years ago. Many large publicly held agencies have been forced to make drastic cuts in their work forces to improve profits; Ayer, which is known for its paternalistic attitude toward employees, is reluctant to consider such layoffs. **********Mr. Siano has made significant changes at the agency. Since he took over the helm in January from Ayer's former chairman, Louis T. Hagopian, Mr. Siano has substantially changed the agency's management, appointing younger people to key positions. ''I want a more aggressive attitude,'' he said. **********In the past, Ayer has been viewed as an old boys' club that was slow to change. **********The agency has also begun to promote itself more heavily. ''We had been in the closet,'' Mr. Siano said. ''Now I want the agency to be more open.'' To that end, he has brought in consultants to teach Ayer executives how to communicate effectively with the press and clients. **********Of course, Ayer's staff can always learn to be innovative by example. In the lobby at the entrance to the agency's executive offices there are two huge artworks by Mr. Siano. **********''I think it helps to motivate people if there is a creative person at the head of the agency,'' said Mr. Siano, who was an art student in college. ''I know what it takes to nurture creative people. I set the tone by telling people you have to believe in advertising in order to create it well.'' **********And, in case any executives at Ayer forget that message, there is a piece of video art just down the hall from Mr. Siano's office that acts as a constant reminder. Four television sets continually play a fast-paced montage of scenes from programs and commercials over which is superimposed this message: ''We create your needs; we create your desires.''
