https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/world.main_headline: Soviet Debate: Do Party Cells Have a Place?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   Soviet Debate: Do Party Cells Have a Place?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/world.body_text: **********From the press gallery of the cavernous Kremlin hall where the Communist Party is holding its 28th congress, it is clear that this is not an ordinary political convention. **********The view to the right takes in rows of ivory-colored summer uniforms of the Soviet Navy. Below are the bemedalled khakis of army officers. Here and there amid the civilian business suits are the white blousons of the Interior Ministry and the blue epaulets that distinguish troops of the K.G.B., the internal security agency. **********The symbiosis of security forces and the Communist Party, so conspicuous at this party gathering, has become the target of mounting pressure both inside and outside the party, as Communists cope with the new world of political pluralism. **********In recent weeks, a wide range of elected officials, Communist insurgents, independent worker committees and rival political groups have demanded that the party give up its influential network of party cells in the army, the police and the courts. **********The campaign has encountered fierce resistance from top military leaders, who contend that the removal of party cells could lead to a dangerous collapse of discipline. **********But ''departization,'' as the movement is called, has won considerable support in the law enforcement agencies, where many judges and police officials say the taint of party influence undermines their credibility. **********And there are signs that in the army and the K.G.B., as well, a younger generation of officers consider the party cells an impediment to professionalism. **********''Knowing the mood of the majority of the officer corps, I can say that they are for expelling all party organizations from the army,'' Col. Vladimir S. Smirnov, deputy commander of an air force unit in Akhtubinsk, wrote in a letter this week to Moscow News. **********'Vacancies in Kindergartens' **********''There are no organs in the armies of democratic countries that implant the ideology of a single party,'' the colonel wrote, ''that rule the army on behalf of the party, that distribute housing, goods, vacancies in kindergartens and so on.'' **********At the party congress, where nearly 300 officers of the military, K.G.B. and police are among the 4,700 delegates, the calls to get rid of party organizations have been firmly rejected by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov, and the K.G.B. chairman, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov. **********Georgi K. Shakhnazarov, an adviser to Mr. Gorbachev, said in an interview that depoliticization was inevitable sooner or later, but that for the moment the party structures were a guarantee of stability. **********''If they cease to exist, it will mean that another support is knocked out from under Gorbachev, which is quite risky,'' he said. **********Loyalty to the State **********The issue is an important one for liberals, because they foresee a prolonged power struggle between elected government bodies and the party, and they want to make sure the military and law-enforcement agencies have clear loyalties to the government. **********Forty-seven liberal politicians and scholars asserted in a letter Wednesday to the daily newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda: ''The fact that the army has been used more than once for purposes for which it was not intended raises a serious question: which side will it take in the event of new collisions in our society?'' **********The Parliament of the Russian republic, headed by Boris N. Yeltsin, has already voted to outlaw party organizations in the military, law enforcement agencies and industry as part of a new constitution to be enacted later this year. Coal miners have added such a move to their list of demands. **********The party's influence in government agencies varies widely, and has declined as Mr. Gorbachev has tried to shift power from the old party patronage network to newly elected government councils. But the party still maintains political watchdog committees throughout the society, and their work is regarded with special suspicion when it comes to security agencies. **********Voting Irregularities Charged **********Since the outset last year of competitive elections, challengers in several cities have charged voting irregularities in precincts dominated by the military. **********The K.G.B.'s links to the party have come under strong attack recently following charges by Oleg D. Kalugin, a recently retired K.G.B. counterintelligence officer, that the agency is essentially a tool of Communist political control. **********''While the Interior Ministry is more or less accountable to the Council of Ministers, the K.G.B. has never been and is not accountable to anyone except the Politburo,'' said Mr. Kalugin, who was stripped of his rank of Major General for saying similar things in the Soviet press. He advocates making the K.G.B. exclusively answerable to the state, but adds, ''The K.G.B. is so much interwoven with party apparatus it is very hard to change.'' **********Anatoly A. Sobchak, the chairman of the predominantly non-Communist city council in Leningrad, said the K.G.B. chief in that city continues to send intelligence reports to the head of the Leningrad Communist Party organization, but not to him. **********Party Role in Justice System **********The party's role in law enforcement became a national scandal last year when two maverick federal prosecutors charged that the party had squelched their investigation of corruption reaching into the Politburo itself. A parliamentary inquiry found that much of the prosecutors' evidence was inconclusive, but it also confirmed that the party had meddled. **********In the courts, judges say political influence is minimal, especially now that such overtly political crimes as ''anti-Soviet propaganda'' have been expunged from the legal code. **********But judges still sometimes get calls from party headquarters urging that particular cases be handled with particular care. And the party's influence can still make or break a judge's or prosecutor's career, especially in the provincial cities where democracy has not yet penetrated. **********''We all agree that depoliticization is necessary,'' said Vladimir I. Kononyenko, the chief judge of the Peoples Court in the October District of Moscow. ''Because judges, in their role as arbitrators, have to take into account the interests of all sections of society, and they must be fully trusted.'' **********Overseeing the Police **********At the Interior Ministry, which oversees the police nationwide, sentiment for depoliticization is also said to run high. **********Grigory Y. Omelchenko, a police major and a delegate to the party congress, said Interior Minister Vadim V. Bakatin met with the ministry's party delegates last month and strongly endorsed the abolition of party committees. **********Police officers say the political committees often become way stations for aging party functionaries, who are assigned to the Interior Ministry a few years before retirement so they can retire with an Interior Ministry pension. **********''The operational workers, investigators, commanding officers and so on, they are all for elimination of these organs,'' said Mr. Omelchenko, who teaches at a police academy in Kiev. ''We must work only strictly under the law, and not in accordance with any political trends or movements or parties.'' **********There is little of that talk from the army generals and colonels who congregate in corridors between sessions of the party congress. More than a million Communists serve in the armed forces, and party members form virtually the entire officer corps. **********Morale Function in Military **********The top military brass argue that the political officers and party organizations in every military unit serve the function of morale officers, keeping spirits and standards high and combatting ethnic conflict. **********''Now, when our political system is unstable, there must be certain guarantors of stability,'' said Lieut. Gen. Yuri I. Pankratov, chief of political administration in the Carpathian Military District, with headquarters in Lvov. ''And the armed forces is a guarantor, not from the viewpoint of opression of any internal resistance, but it gives the capability of defence from an outside threat if necessary.'' **********Mr. Shakhnazarov, the Gorbachev adviser, said: **********''I would say our political officers in the army play the same role as chaplains in the armies of other countries. Their role is moral, patriotic education in the spirit of dedication to the country and the party. If all these functions are taken away from the army it will be very dangerous. **********''In due course, in a law-governed state, we must have guarantees that all law enforcement bodies must stand apart from any political partiality and work for the benefit of the entire society. **********''The question is, whether it should be done now. The danger is that if it is done now, as some demand, if political bodies start being disbanded in the army, this may lead to very dangerous results.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/busin.main_headline: World Markets; Coping With the Threat of Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/busin.print_headline: World Markets; Coping With the Threat of Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/busin.body_text: **********With the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait and the possibility of a war afterward staring them in the face, you might expect portfolio managers and market analysts to be beside themselves with anxiety. So why are they so calm? **********The answer is that since last August, when the Persian Gulf crisis began, they have become adept at coping with uncertainty about war. And when they look at the larger global picture, they see other factors clouding the outlook for the coming year far more than the situation in the Persian Gulf. **********These managers point to the decline in world economic growth, with the United States, Britain, Canada and Australia in recessions, the problems with banking systems in America and Japan and the high level of interest rates in Europe and Japan. **********"To an extent, it is still the same question," Martin Paling, international strategist for James Capel Inc. in London said about the uncertainty of war. "The deadline does not necessarily say that you will have a war after the Jan. 15, even if the United Nations requirements are not met. We have no idea what is going to happen." **********"I do not treat lightly the possibility of hostilities," added Lawrence W. Harris 3d, a director of Lombard Odier International in London. "But this is the most prepared for war portfolio managers have been in my lifetime." **********That does not mean that a war would not send stocks down sharply in markets around the world. This would be the likely immediate reaction, especially because some markets have rallied a bit since the lows reached in the fall. But these managers and analysts believe that a war could be quick and that markets would rebound. **********In fact, one portfolio manager stands ready with cash to leap in and buy when stocks drop if there is fighting. Another is already putting some cash back into stocks in case there is a negotiated settlement. **********Mr. Harris knows a long conflict is possible, but he is counting on a negotiated settlement or quick war that would do no long-term damage to oil production. **********"I am convinced there is so much oil out there that it is hard for me to believe that the price of oil would go up very much," he said. Earlier this year, the uncertainity for stock markets caused him to keep 30 percent of the Worldwide Value Fund in cash. He has cut that to 18 percent so he can buy back some stocks, on the theory that there will be a settlement or quick war followed by an equities rally. **********Mr. Paling of James Capel agreed. "We feel that the impact of a war on the medium-term economic performance would be limited," he said. Asked about the threat of a war, he answered, "The real question is what is happening if peace breaks out." **********Sander Cseh, who runs Cseh International in Philadelphia, has about 10 percent of his small fund in cash. He expects the drop in stock prices to be so shortlived if war breaks out that he is ready to snap up stocks should it happen. **********Such strategies reflect the view that a war will not mean a long-term jump in oil prices, an analysis based on the recent sharp increase in oil production in Saudi Arabia and other oil-producing countries. **********But beyond that, analysts and portfolio managers fall back on fundamentals -- the outlook for the world economy and interest rates in general. And although they are generally positive that global stock markets will rise moderately in 1991, after the sharp declines of 1990, there are seeds of doubt. "The main thing that worries me is the possibility that the deterioration in the economy is worse than I thought," said Mr. Harris. **********Madhav Dhar, a global strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York who is much more bearish, believes that stock markets are too anxious for a rally, which he said means they are ignoring the shakey economic fundamentals. **********Finally, there is the problem of the Soviet Union, the wild card in everyone's analysis. It is a country whose problems could send stock markets around the world reeling if something went seriously awry. "With Russia about to implode, that just adds to the risk premium," said Mr. Dhar.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/02/busin.main_headline:
Theater;
The Board Is Talking Center Stage
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/02/busin.print_headline:
Theater;
The Board Is Talking Center Stage
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/02/busin.body_text: **********AT 8:15 ON A SEPTEMBER MORNING, the executive committee of the Manhattan Theater Club has gathered for a breakfast meeting in the downstairs lobby of New York's City Center -- and Lynne Meadow, the M.T.C.'s artistic director, is late. Michael H. Coles, the president of the board of directors, briskly calls the session to order. The former chairman of Goldman Sachs International doesn't like to be kept waiting. The co-chairmen of the M.T.C. board, Paul B. Kopperl and Edwin C. Cohen, offer a few remarks. Cohen is in midsentence when he realizes that he's lost his audience. Fifteen heads have turned toward a rustling noise at the top of the nearby staircase. **********There stands Lynne Meadow -- tall with raven-black hair, her deep tan set off by strawberry-pink lipstick. Framed by gleaming brass banisters, grinning and waving in an impromptu imitation of Miss America, she starts her descent to the laughter and applause of the executive committee. **********Finally reaching the conference table, Meadow begins her presentation with theater gossip: the guest list at the recent birthday bash for a prominent British director, tidbits from a weekend spent at the home of a famous playwright. Then she gets down to business. "There is a play that I have in mind," she says, "but we'll have to discuss it financially." Pause. "It has 16 characters." Necks stiffen around the table. "And a swimming pool." Pause. "On the stage." She smiles hopefully. "That people **********swim **********in." **********Silence. Coles scowls. Kopperl looks nonplused. Cohen fiddles with a carton of fruit juice. John W. Spurdle Jr., the treasurer, utters a loud, disbelieving guffaw. Yet Lynne Meadow will probably get her expensive play, 16 characters, swimming pool and all. Somehow, the members of the board will find the money. **********During the years they have worked together, the directors of the board of the Manhattan Theater Club and Meadow have forged a remarkably close working relationship. At heart, it rests on the shared conviction that their nonprofit theater represents something special in the cultural life of New York and the nation, an institution that nurtures the serious, sometimes demanding works that so seldom make it to Broadway these days. **********"The M.T.C. is known for doing a lot of new plays," says Benjamin Mordecai, the managing director of the Yale Repertory Theater. "When you do that, you have a lot of 'critical' failures. It takes great courage. The top critics come. If the play gets blasted, it's done across America." **********For all its achievements, the theater club is not immune to the ailments afflicting the theater in general. Federal grants are static, and state and corporate support is waning. Like many urban producers, the M.T.C. faces an aging audience base. Last year it had a $250,000 deficit. Yet the theater club has devised a daring long-range solution that calls for an array of new programs and a major increase in its budget. At a moment when the local and national economies are stagnant, the M.T.C. is about to undertake its largest-ever capital funds drive. **********For many upwardly striving business people, membership on the board of directors of an arts institution is perceived as a way to join the company of the rich and famous. Not at the Manhattan Theater Club. The 31-member board has some high-net-worth individuals, but it includes neither Fortune 500 C.E.O.'s nor headline-grabbing socialites. For example, Coles, 58, is a limited partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company; Kopperl, 57, heads his own corporate financial advisory boutique of Delano & Kopperl; Cohen, 48, is managing general partner of General Atlantic Partners, a small private-investment firm; Spurdle, 53, is a retired managing director of J. P. Morgan & Company. **********What the theater club offers its board is a chance to help launch the careers of such actors as Holly Hunter and Amanda Plummer and to provide a stage for the work of such playwrights as Alan Ayckbourn, Beth Henley and Terrence McNally. To a degree that is unusual on most nonprofit boards, the top directors of the M.T.C. board treat that responsibility as a full-time job. **********It was the board that prodded Lynne Meadow and Barry Grove, the managing director, to confront the theater's long-term economic problems. The M.T.C.'s traditional artistic risk-taking, the board decided, would now have to be matched by a significant business risk. But the decision was not made quickly or easily. In his soft-spoken way, Kopperl reflects the board's deep concern. "I **********believe **********in what we're doing," he says. "I don't think we're being irresponsible. I don't see it as growth just to be big. I see it as a case of survival." **********EACH SEASON, THE M.T.C. presents nine plays at its two theaters in City Center, five of them finished works on Stage I; the others, on Stage II, sometimes works in progress being rewritten even as they are shown. The theater also sponsors 12 readings a year at the center by novelists and poets. **********But the soul of the Manhattan Theater Club can be found some two miles south of City Center's midtown neighborhood in a rundown area of the Chelsea district. Up a narrow, dark flight of stairs in what was once a longshoremen's hiring hall are the administrative offices and rehearsal rooms. **********The linoleum-tiled hallway is crowded with actors. Some are headed for rehearsals, others mumble their lines as they wait to audition. From behind a closed door comes the clicketyclack of tap dancers; in the ladies' room a singer practices her scales. **********In cluttered offices, desks are piled high with scripts. The walls are papered with photos of theater greats -- actors such as Glenn Close, Tim Curry, Colleen Dewhurst and Sam Waterston who have graced the M.T.C. stages. In part, the lure has been the theater's reputation for producing challenging, quality plays -- "Statements After an Arrest Under the Immorality Act," Athol Fugard's 1977 anti-apartheid work, for example, or the 1986 revival of "Loot," Joe Orton's farce that lacerates the church, the police and the medical and legal professions. **********The other attraction has been 44-year-old Lynne Meadow. She has been selecting the theater's plays for 18 of the M.T.C.'s 20 years, and she is well known in theatrical circles for her willingness to take chances and her perfectionism. In one case, unhappy with the director's work, she stepped in and restructured a play the night before it was to open. **********Her opposite number, Barry Grove, 39, has run the business side since 1975. An incisive, logical man who favors conservative attire, he stands in marked contrast to the flamboyant Meadow, but they have maintained what is probably the theater world's longest-running amicable partnership. "Barry anticipates," says Meadow, grinning at Grove as she sums up their relationship. "I worry." **********The M.T.C. started in 1970 as a neighborhood group that offered after-dinner play readings in the Upper East Side living rooms of its members. By 1971 it had grown large enough to have its own space, a complex of rooms at the National Bohemian Hall where the company began to win local and then national recognition. In 1985, after much dispute with the hall's owners, in and out of the courts, the M.T.C. completed the relocation of its theater operations to City Center and its headquarters to Chelsea. **********That same year, the board asked Lynne Meadow to map out her vision of the theater's artistic future -- "as if," Grove says, "the restraints of money were taken away." The board found her ambitions financially sobering: the M.T.C. had been sliding in and out of operating deficit from one year to the next. Clearly, it was time for the board of directors to think hard about reorganizing the theater. **********LYNNE MEADOW, A DRINK IN hand, looks on approvingly as her board members chat with a handful of actors and directors. On this September evening, the board is gathered for its first social event of the season in a Fifth Avenue art gallery owned by a fellow member, Edward R. Roberts, a limited partner at Goldman, Sachs. "They love this sort of thing," Meadow says. **********Board members attend readings and rehearsals; they dine with playwrights and actors. "There is an obligation," says Jim G. Kilpatric, a senior vice president at A.T.&T.;, "to keep yourself conversant with the theater and to have ideas." Meadow recalls talking to Kilpatric about a play in rehearsal. There were rough spots in the early version of the script, says Meadow, "and Jim had the most insightful, intelligent and **********radical **********idea of how to make it better." **********Says Meadow, laughing, "Some of the people on the board who you think would have the most conservative tastes in theater are the funkiest." Ed Cohen scouts out new writers, and recommends scripts to Meadow that are often very daring; Meadow produced one that was, she says, "a very difficult play" -- in other words, a box-office flop. Paul Kopperl has been known to attend some shows as many as eight times. **********During one board meeting, Meadow was discussing the rehearsal of a well-known playwright's work when Michael Coles interrupted. "He said it very innocently, but he asked how many rewrites the playwright had done," she says. "What he wanted to know was whether I was being as tough on an established writer as I would be on a new one." **********The commitment of the board's leaders to the M.T.C.'s mission was dramatically tested last season when some corporate donors, uncomfortable with the content of a proposed theater club show, refused to back it. The play, "The Art of Success," by Nick Dear, dealt in graphic detail and language with the debauched life and controversial art of the 18th-century artist, William Hogarth. Coles, Roberts and Cohen took out their checkbooks and underwrote a large part of the production. "The Art of Success" opened last spring to critical acclaim. **********THE THEATER CLUB'S move to City Center in 1985 had catapulted the M.T.C. onto a bigger stage. As the business people on the board thought about reorganizing the theater, they turned for help in a familiar direction. In 1987, the management consulting firm of McKinsey & Company began to study the theater on a pro bono basis. **********According to a McKinsey partner, "We told them you can't just admire your pretty baby anymore; it's now a growing child." Among the consultants' recommendations: cutbacks in staff, increased computerization, the appointment of marketing specialists to the board and the expansion of the board to include some heavyweight corporate executives with good contacts. **********The recommendations were approved by the board in June 1988, with one notable exception. Most of the directors were deeply concerned that the addition of prominent executives could alter the chemistry, destroying the teamwork developed over the years. Although the proposal to expand the board was defeated, the issue would later come back to haunt them. **********The consultants also urged that the M.T.C. develop a long-term strategic plan. The board soon called in Lynne Meadow for another look into the future. This time, though, it was not to be just a wish list but a detailed report on where the theater should go and how to get there. **********The draft that emerged painted a dreary picture. Promising playwrights were being lost to television and movies, and so were budding actors. The number of Broadway producers willing to invest in risky plays was shrinking rapidly, leaving more and more of the burden for producing serious shows on the backs of nonprofit theaters in general and M.T.C. in particular. **********There was more. About 60 percent of the $5 million operating budget was covered by ticket sales, mainly among the 13,000 people who buy season subscriptions. Now that market was saturated: the M.T.C. had reached "maximum subscription potential." Meanwhile, government support for the arts was at a low ebb and corporations were hunkering down for a recession. If these trends continued, the theater could face an earnings gap of $2 million by 1994. **********The assumption was that the M.T.C.'s major donors would hold fast -- institutions such as the Shubert Foundation and the Eleanor Naylor Dana Charitable Trust, corporations such as Philip Morris and A.T.&T.; But these patrons were not likely to make up the looming shortfall; new sources of income would have to be found or the scope and mission of the theater would have to be curtailed. It was a familiar dilemma for a business under pressure: cut costs or boost revenues. **********Meadow and Grove had no doubt about which of the two routes to follow, but their ideas for boosting revenues carried big price tags. For example, they asked for a $405,000 "artistic safety net" to cover the losses on risky plays. To strengthen the M.T.C.'s "product," they also sought money to beef up the script department and additional funds to option important new works and commission plays. To create the M.T.C.'s future audience, they proposed an education program that would bring high school students into the theater. To nurture new acting talent, they proposed setting up internships and master classes at the theater. **********One $600,000 item in the plan called for a fund to finance the transfer of successful M.T.C. plays to other theaters in New York and around the country. Because of its tight production schedule, the theater cannot extend the run of a hit play by more than a week. If a play is picked up by another producer, the M.T.C. may receive a royalty ranging from 0.5 percent to 5 percent of the weekly gross. But if the M.T.C. finances the move, the theater club winds up with the lion's share of the profits -- or losses.WHEN THE BOARD began to review the draft of the Meadow-Grove long-range proposal in the spring of 1989, the leadership was enthusiastic about many of the ideas. Several board members, for example, welcomed the idea of a safety net for risky plays. "I am not a proponent of comfortable theater," says Roberts. The option of cutting costs to solve the theater's fiscal problems was not seriously entertained; the board members felt they had cut as much as they could after the McKinsey report. **********As the directors tested the numbers against economic projections and devised a time frame for raising funds, they looked for ways to give Meadow what she asked for. "We didn't sit around and say, 'You guys are out of your minds' -- the way you would in a business budget meeting," recalls Spurdle. "Bond traders are replaceable. The Lynne Meadows are not." **********Herbert Weissenstein, a consultant to nonprofit groups who has helped design the M.T.C.'s fund-raising campaign, talks about the "magical balance" on arts boards between the business members' impulse to apply tough financial standards and their recognition that too much intrusiveness will backfire. "You have very little grasp over the product," he says. "The art belongs to the artist. It would be like telling an orchestra that was losing money: cut your string section in half, get rid of three flutes and two oboes -- and just play louder." **********Throughout April and May of this year, Kopperl, Coles, Grove, Meadow and Weissenstein met with small groups of board members over breakfast at the Princeton Club to discuss the draft of the long-range plan, and its financial consequences. Finally, on a June morning, the full board met in a conference room at Chase Manhattan Bank's Park Avenue offices to vote on the package. What the members of the board had before them was a proposal for a four-year campaign to raise a total of $9.8 million -- $3.4 million of that would represent the initiatives of the long-range plan, while the rest would fund programs already in existence. **********Before the vote, Coles warned his colleagues that approval would require that each of them donate a substantial, additional sum of money. The vote in favor was unanimous. **********Board member Gary Knisely, 48, who is managing director of Johnson Smith & Knisely, an executive search firm, recalls: "When I came home that night and told my wife, she said: ' **********What **********did you **********do **********?!' " **********THE MEMBERS OF THE Manhattan Theater Club board are expected to give, or to get from other sources, a minimum donation of $15,000 a year. What Knisely and his colleagues had "done" was to commit themselves to at least another $2,500 a year over the next four years. **********But that extra $2,500 a year would be the bare minimum. "If everybody gave that, we'd be in trouble," says Coles. At the June meeting, he announced that the leadership of the board had pledged "northward" of $500,000 to the campaign. The five leaders were Coles, Cohen, Kopperl, Roberts and Bonnie Sacerdote (an arts consultant and chairman of the membership committee whose husband, Peter, is a partner at Goldman, Sachs). **********During the following months, those five, long the club's biggest individual donors, solicited pledges from the other members of the board, armed with an estimate of how much money each member could afford to give. Their manner was delicate, but also direct. "I asked for a number," says Coles. "I said I may have asked for too much. But I may also have asked for too little, in which case, I hope you'll remedy that." They hope to raise $250,000 from their peers. **********In addition, the M.T.C. has applied for a three-to-one challenge grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. Under the grant, the N.E.A. would give the theater $750,000 over the next four years, on the condition that the M.T.C. attracted new or increased contributions of $2.25 million. As of the first week of November, the N.E.A. had not announced a decision. **********"Raising the rest of the money is going to be tough," says Roberts. "It's bad times." The M.T.C. has some novel ideas, including asking individual donors to commission plays. Subscribers now donate a total of about $200,000 a year, but the M.T.C. wants more; Coles, for example, is hoping to organize post-performance cocktail parties to knit subscribers into fund-raising teams. **********The capital campaign, scheduled to go public next month, has also reignited an earlier debate: Does the new M.T.C. require a more powerful and socially prominent set of directors -- people such as James D. Wolfensohn and Sanford I. Weill, the two well-connected investment bankers who helped put Carnegie Hall's 1985 campaign over the top? Or would such heavyweight donors overwhelm the board and interfere in artistic decisions? **********"I think we'd love to be seen as a high-profile prestige board to be on," Michael Coles says, "but it might mean a fundamental change in who we are." Coles would never think of changing the theater's artistic director, for example; the board's association with her, he says, "has the mark of a very personal relationship as opposed to an institutional one." Gary Knisely, on the other hand, says: "At some point we will have to be able to be in a position to tell Lynne to leave. Not because she isn't doing a great job, but because that is what the board of a major institution should be **********able **********to do." **********Earlier this year the board asked Knisely's firm to conduct a pro bono search for new board candidates. By fall, he had several candidates on his string, including the vice chairman of a New York bank and a senior partner at a Wall Street law firm. **********For some board members, such developments can be disconcerting. "We've all taken a big gulp," says one of them, who suspects that some of the things she loves most about the theater and its board may soon pass. Knisely talks openly about the possibility that a prominent new board member might take over Kopperl's role as the more active of the two co-chairmen. **********Generally speaking, Lynne Meadow contemplates the prospect of change philosophically, recalling the ups and downs of the Manhattan Theater Club's progress from living room readings to star billing as one of the most important companies in the nation. "Every year we've lost something," she says, and then adds, with a smile: "Take the day I stopped pouring drinks at the bar to help pay the rent."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;   Eric Mower To Buy Firm
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/busin.body_text: **********Eric Mower & Associates, a marketing communications agency based in Syracuse, has reached an agreement to acquire Levy, King & White, an advertising and public relations firm based in Buffalo. **********The Buffalo agency will now be called LKW/Eric Mower & Associates. The new two-office network will have about $75 million in billings, with a third coming from Levy, King & White. **********The purchase price, which was not disclosed, will be based on a percentage of the billings of the Buffalo operation during its first year. **********Eric Mower's clients include **********Agway, Alcoa and Nutri/ System. Levy, King & White's clients include the Buffalo Sabres hockey team and Ellio's Frozen Foods.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/busin.main_headline: A Turnaround Manager To Head Jos. A. Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   A Turnaround Manager To Head Jos. A. Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/busin.body_text: **********Timothy F. Finley, a turnaround manager, has been named president and chief executive of Jos. A. Bank Clothiers Inc., which operates 40 retail clothing stores throughout the United States and is known for its American-made men's suits. **********Mr. Finley, 47, formed the Finley Group in 1985 to provide management to troubled companies. His main responsibilities at Jos. A. Bank will be to cut its debt from a leveraged buyout that was financed by Drexel Burnham Lambert in 1988. The company, based in Baltimore, went private in the buyout. **********Jos. A. Bank, which he called a ''middle-priced Brooks Brothers,'' has a substantial mail-order catalogue sales operation. It plans to expand in the Northeast, where it has stores in Stamford, Conn., and Summit, N.J., but none in New York. **********Mr. Finley described himself as ''a rather unstructured, fancy-free kind of guy who's not great at running a company in the long term.'' **********Eight associates share the management responsibilities of the Finley Group. Mr. Finley's average stay at a company is one to two years. **********Mr. Finley has been president for two years of Baddour Inc., a 200-store chain in Memphis that operates under the name Freds Super Discount Store. It had $250 million in revenues last year. **********He was chief operating officer of Castleberry Foods, a family-owned canned-meat company based in Augusta, Ga., from 1986 to 1988. Mr. Finley was an executive vice president of Cannon Mills, a leading towel maker based in Kannapolis, N.C., from 1981 to 1985. Before that, he was a partner at the Charlotte, N.C., office of the accounting firm Deloitte, Haskins & Sells, which has since merged with Touche Ross to form Deloitte & Touche. **********''There is a general slowdown in the economy and the apparel industry that has contributed to the problems at Jos. A. Bank,'' Mr. Finley said. **********Mr. Finley succeeds David R. Waters, 59, who resigned after two years to begin his own consulting business. Mr. Waters will continue on the company's board. **********Jos. A. Bank had revenues last year of $150 million. The company, which has 1,700 employees, has corporate headquarters and three manufacturing centers in Baltimore. **********Mr. Finley was graduated from Ohio University with a degree in commerce and now lives in Charlotte, N.C., with his wife, Dolly. They have a daughter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/25/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; Iraq Bolsters Force, Saudi Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/25/world.body_text: **********Iraq has increased its forces in southern Iraq and Kuwait, amassing as many as 500,000 soldiers there as well as hundreds of anti-aircraft missiles and several thousand armored units, a senior Saudi official says. **********Saying this represented an increase over forces monitored there a few weeks ago, the Saudi official also said Saudi Arabia has confirmed reports that armed Palestinians from the Abul Abbas organization have entered Kuwait and are helping Iraqi troops on internal security and border patrols. The group, which carried out the Achille Lauro hijacking in 1985, is affiliated with the Palestine Liberation Organization and is now based in Iraq, **********He said other Palestinian groups are also believed to have sent armed units into Iraq to work with the Iraqi Army. **********The official, who spoke on the condition that his name not be used, also said that Saudi Arabia has intelligence reports asserting that North Korea is negotiating the supply of arms to Iraq. He declined to elaborate. **********The most recent previous Saudi estimate of Iraqi troops in Kuwait and southern Iraq was about 350,000; the Pentagon's current estimate is 430,000. **********The official said a significant amount of information on Iraqi troop movements originates with Iraqi soldiers who are continuing to defect to Saudi Arabia. **********"We continue to get defectors," the official said, briefing reporters in Jidda on Tuesday. "They come across by foot or by trucks. It is not as many as before but I can say they several hundreds have come over." **********The official said that "there is no question the embargo is taking its toll." **********The official said that by all accounts, the Iraqi Army in Kuwait is poorly supplied with essentials like food and cigarettes, and that Saudi Arabia has information of food riots that have taken place inside Iraq in Mosul and Najaf.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/world.main_headline: Bulgaria's Renamed Communists in Disarray After Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   Bulgaria's Renamed Communists in Disarray After Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/world.body_text: **********Despite their solid victory in elections to Parliament last month, Bulgaria's renamed Communists are acting like a party in disarray. **********Now known as Socialists, the Bulgarian Communists were the only ones in Eastern Europe to emerge from elections more or less intact after the upheavals that have swept away one totalitarian system after another. **********But political commentators and foreign diplomats described the party as a ship without a captain, lacking clear direction or initiative. **********In the three weeks since the election, they say, the Socialists have done little more than react fitfully to public demands for swifter democratic change and cleaner breaks with the Stalinist past. **********In the process, there are increasing signs of splits between conservatives and reformers allied with Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov, who said changes must come faster to rescue Bulgaria from a worsening economy. **********The Socialists' troubles were underscored and intensified by the resignation Friday night of President Petar Mladenov, who engineered a palace coup last November that toppled the country's hard-line leader of 35 years, Todor Zhivkov. **********Mr. Mladenov gave way to student strikes and other protests as he lost all credibility because of a comment last December that tanks should to be called in to crush anti-Communist demonstrators. **********Now, an unexpected priority for the new Grand National Assembly, which convenes on Tuesday, is to find a successor to fill the largely figurehead presidency. The Socialists lack the two-thirds majority to do it by themselves. Speculation ran high today that they might support a non-Socialist candidate. **********Opposition Is Wary **********Thus far, the main opposition group, a collection of former dissidents known as the Union of Democratic Forces, has resisted attempts to lure it into a coalition. The Socialists continue to try, however. **********Mr. Lukanov says a broad consensus is essential to deal with pressing national problems. But the tasks ahead are so daunting that some political specialists are convinced that the Socialists want to be able to share the blame should things go wrong. **********''I think they're scared to death of holding power by themselves,'' a Western diplomat said. **********If the ruling party had hoped that the Mladenov resignation would end the protests that have filled Sofia streets for weeks, they were disappointed. The protesters, almost giddy over a victory that would have been unthinkable a few months ago, started to raise new demands. **********The agenda includes calls for the resignation of Mr. Lukanov and other officials and members of Parliament regarded as tainted by their Communist Party past. In addition, protesters insist that a date be fixed for a public trial of the 79-year-old Mr. Zhivkov, who is reportedly in a prison hospital while the commission investigates corruption and abuse of power charges. **********Today, the Government sought to meet this demand by announcing that the inquiry would end on July 18 and that an indictment would be drawn up over the next month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/01/busin.main_headline: Wells Fargo Official Is New First Bank Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/01/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Wells Fargo Official Is New First Bank Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/01/busin.body_text: **********After a four-month search, John F. Grundhofer has been named chairman, president and chief executive of the troubled First Bank System Inc. of Minneapolis. Mr. Grundhofer, 51, had been a vice chairman of the Wells Fargo Bank. **********Analysts praised First Bank's board for selecting Mr. Grundhofer, an outsider, to try to restore the bank to profitability. On a per-share basis, the bank has lost money the last two years. ''I am surprised and impressed,'' said Thomas K. Brown, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc. ''I don't think they could have done a better job.'' **********In addition to 30 years of banking experience, Mr. Grundhofer brings with him the Wells Fargo reputation. ''He comes from the right place,'' Mr. Brown said. ''Wells Fargo is proving to be a great training ground for the United States banking industry.'' Senior executives at the BankAmerica Corporation of San Francisco and the Ameritrust Corporation of Cleveland are former Wells Fargo officials, Mr. Brown said. **********Wells Fargo & Company, the bank's parent, is considered to be among the best in the banking industry at controlling costs, a big concern at First Bank, which in the middle of a cost-cutting program that could bring as many as 1,700 layoffs. **********Darrell G. Knudson will remain as First Bank System's vice chairman and a director. Mr. Knudson, a candidate for the top job, had been serving as acting chief executive since D. H. Ankeny Jr. resigned in September 1989 after the disclosure of unexpected losses in the bank's loan portfolio. **********Mr. Grundhofer joined San Francisco-based Wells Fargo in 1978. Most recently, he oversaw the bank's operations in Southern California. He is a California native with an master's degree in finance from the University of Southern California. **********Mr. Grundhofer's brother, Jerry A., was recently named president and chief executive of Security Pacific National Bank of Los Angeles. **********Wall Street reacted positively to the appointment, with First Bank's stock closing at $15, up $1.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/13/busin.body_text: **********Japan's trade surplus edged up 3.7 percent in August, to $3.49 billion, from $3.37 billion a year earlier, the Finance Ministry announced today. It was the third time this year that the surplus had widened compared with a year earlier. The surplus had declined for 11 consecutive months until March. Imports in August rose 2.4 percent from a year earlier, to $18.9 billion, but exports climbed 2.6 percent, to $22.39 billion. The surplus with the United States, Japan's largest trading partner, shrank 6 percent, to $2.83 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/04/busin.main_headline: Rebates Are a Reason for Vehicle Price Increases by Big 3
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/04/busin.print_headline: Rebates Are a Reason for Vehicle Price Increases by Big 3
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/04/busin.body_text: **********With sales sluggish, the Big Three domestic auto makers recently announced midyear price increases, a move that illustrates the curious economic logic that governs the pricing strategy in Detroit these days. **********Even though the market for new cars is weak, Ford, General Motors and Chrysler have all opted to entice customers through continued rebates. Extra revenue from price increases is used to offset the costs of cash rebates and discount financing. **********''The pricing strategies of the Big Three are largely fictitious,'' said Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst with Dean Witter Securities in San Francisco. ''They raise the price on a vehicle by $50 or $60 one week, and increase the incentive by $100 the next.'' An Inescapable Cycle?  In fact, for the Big Three, the cycle appears to have become inescapable. Consumers now seem to require rebates before they will buy. **********On Monday, the General Motors Corporation raised prices between $66 and $165, and increased the destination charge by $10. The Chrysler Corporation's price increases, which also took effect on Monday, range from $60 to $160. Both companies followed the Ford Motor Company's move on June 18 to raise prices between $58 and $134. **********The increases on most cars and trucks sold by Ford, G.M. and Chrysler may eke out a little more revenue from a weak market. Raising prices now may also blunt the effect of higher prices when new cars are introduced in the fall, analysts say. **********Imports Take Same Course **********Although higher prices on imported cars probably will not show up until fall, several Japanese and European auto makers have begun offering rebates of their own and have followed - in some cases, even exceeded -the Big Three's price increases. **********The cycle of higher prices to offset rebates does not necessarily harm the competitive position of the auto companies, industry experts and economists say, since competitors are doing the same thing. But car dealers say many customers are baffled by the array of rebates and financing incentives. **********''Rebates have muddied the waters and made determining the true price of a car incredibly complex,'' said Lance Ealey, an automotive specialist with McKinsey & Company, a consulting firm. **********Customers Seem Hooked **********Chrysler was the first to offer rebates on cars, in the early 70's. The plan was viewed by analysts and competitors as a shrewd marketing move, and other companies soon followed suit. But by the mid-80's, analysts say, customers were hooked and the car companies saw their sales fall off sharply whenever rebates ended. **********''The consumer very quickly learns to look for rebates, and it doesn't take long to see demand dry up between one rebate period and the next,'' said James R. Taylor, a professor of marketing at the University of Michigan Business School. **********Car companies, fearful of losing customers to rivals, are unlikely to break the rebate habit soon. **********''Even if auto sales boom next year, we'll still have incentives,'' Mr. Glantz said. ''There are three dozen auto manufacturers out there, and unless they all go cold turkey I don't see how they can give up incentives.'' **********The manufacturers do have ways to raise revenues without adding significantly to a vehicle's base price. One pricing game Detroit plays involves making popular options standard equipment, which lifts the manufacturer's revenues on a vehicle. Customers are compelled to buy the special packages, while the manufacturers use the base price - minus the equipment - to promote their new models as only slightly more expensive than last year's versions. **********As a result of this trend, pursued throughout the 1980's, the least expensive cars now carry significantly more equipment than they used to, and they cost more. **********Japanese Prices Up, Too **********While the American car companies have historically moved first to raise prices, the Japanese have generally followed suit in the last few years, keeping their car prices within one or two percentage points of competing American models. The Toyota Motor Corporation, the Honda Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company typically limit themselves to lifting prices once a year, usually in the fall when most new models are introduced. Sometimes they delay price increases until the end of the year, seeking the promotional advantage that comes from comparatively low sticker prices in the first months that new models are on sale. **********In the past, the Japanese had shown a willingness to limit increases, with the objective of grabbing a larger share of the market. The most notable instance was the mid-1980's, when the value of the Japanese yen rose against the dollar, making goods produced in Japan more expensive in the United States. **********Opportunity to Gain Share **********While the Japanese did raise prices, they resisted pressure to keep up with the strengthening yen, even though their profits suffered. **********Some analysts contend that domestic auto makers, by failing to cut their prices then, passed up an opportunity to improve their competitive position. **********''The mid-1980's was a unique period in time when the domestic auto makers could have seized a gigantic comparative advantage,'' said Maryann N. Keller, an analyst with Furman Selz Mager Dietz & Birney in New York. ''The opportunity was there to open up a price differential so big that the issue of higher Japanese quality could have been obliterated by the vastly lower price of most American cars.'' **********Oldsmobile Rebates **********LANSING, Mich., July 3 (Reuters) - The General Motors Corporation said today that its Oldsmobile division would offer a $1,500 rebate to buyers of 1991 Oldsmobile 88 models in certain areas of the United States. The areas include New York, New England, Washington, Chicago, Minneapolis, St. Louis, San Francisco and Los Angeles. The program runs from Wednesday until Aug. 2. The new incentive is in addition to a rebate of $1,000 on the Cutlass Ciera, $2,500 on the Toronado and $1,000 on the Silhouette mini-van. These incentives are available nationwide through Aug. 2.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/17/busin.main_headline: Your Money;   How to Choose A Filing Status
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/17/busin.print_headline: Your Money;   How to Choose A Filing Status
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/17/busin.body_text: **********When selecting a filing status for income tax returns, the best choice can be less obvious than it seems, tax professionals say. **********The great majority of couples choose ''married filing jointly,'' knowing that is likely to mean lower taxes and less paper work. Few realize that in some cases it is advisable to file separately, either to avoid liability or to allow one partner to claim deductions they cannot claim together. **********Similarly, many single people simply check ''single,'' unaware either that they may qualify for the more beneficial ''head-of-household'' status or under tax law may not be single. **********''Once two people have signed a return, the law says they are jointly and severally liable,'' Richard J. Stricof, a partner with BDO Seidman in New York, pointed out. That means that if the Internal Revenue Service discovers that one spouse had substantial unreported income, it can hold both responsible for the taxes, interest and penalties. **********Often, if that happens, the ''innocent spouse'' defense is used. The other spouse denies knowledge of the undeclared income. But it is far from clear that that defense will succeed, Mr. Stricof said. **********He pointed to conflicting court decisions in such cases. The tax court denied relief to a man who failed to prove that he did not know of his wife's omissions of funds she had embezzled. He had accompanied her to a lawyer's office after a police investigation had begun, the court noted. Nor was innocent-spouse relief granted to a wife who had often spoken with her husband about his gambling activities. She hired an accountant and supplied him with the financial data to prepare the return and took care of the family's bank deposits, the court noted. **********But relief was granted to the wife of a man who had established a successful medical practice and concealed his illegal activities and omitted the income. The court said ''she completely trusted her husband owing to religious principles.'' **********Mr. Stricof advised anyone who had reason to believe that a spouse was concealing income -whether cash payments from legitimate business activities or money from gambling or illegal activities - to file separately to avoid future liability, even though such a filing will generally result in higher taxes. **********Also, when a marriage is in trouble and the partners are arguing over money, it may well be advisable to file separately, he said. Later, if they are divorced and the I.R.S. discovers a problem, it could hold a spouse liable who no longer has access to the relevant records. **********Happily married couples whose finances are aboveboard may also have reason to file separately. Sidney Kess, a New York lawyer and certified public accountant, pointed out that sometimes one spouse qualifies for deductions based only on his or her income, but that the couple would not qualify if they filed jointly. **********That is because the Tax Reform Act of 1986 allows deductions for unreimbursed medical expenses only to the extent that they exceed 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income, miscellaneous itemized deductions only above 2 percent and casualty losses above 10 percent. **********Whether it is advantageous to file separately will depend on a number of factors, including the size of the deductions and the amount of income and consequent bracket. To make sure, the return should be calculated both ways. **********Mr. Kess cautioned that taxpayers eligible for credits for earned income, child or dependent care or retirement must file jointly to claim them. Another consideration is that half of any Social Security benefits may be taxable for married people filing separately. For married couples filing jointly, half the benefits become subject to taxation only after income exceeds a base amount of $32,000. **********''A lot of people assume that if you are separated, you are single,'' Mr. Kess said, but for tax purposes a court decree for separate maintenance must have been in effect at the end of the year. There is an exception for legally abandoned spouses, he added. **********Separated or unmarried people may qualify for ''head-of-household'' status, which has more favorable tax treatment than ''single'' status, if an unmarried child, grandchild, foster child or other dependent relative lived with them more than half the year or if they provided more than half the cost of maintaining a household for such a person. **********A single person whose dependent parent is in a nursing home may also qualify for head-of-household status, Mr. Kess added, as may a married person whose spouse is a nonresident alien. He cited as an example a Pakistani taxi driver whose family still lives in Pakistan. **********There is one other category: surviving spouse. Those whose spouses died during the tax year may file a joint return if they have not remarried, and generally a surviving spouse with dependent children is entitled to file a joint return for two years after the year in which the spouse died.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/18/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Usinor-Sacilor Plans Purchase of Edgcomb
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/18/busin.body_text: **********France's biggest steel company, the state-owned Usinor-Sacilor S.A., said today that it planned to acquire the Edgcomb Corporation, a privately held United States steelmaker. No price was given for the acquisition, which must be approved by Federal authorities. **********The French company said the purchase depended on Edgcomb's current owners buying up all of the outstanding debt, which it put at about $100 million. Usinor-Sacilor became the world's second-biggest steel producer last year through the acquisition of the ailing West German steel company Saarstahl A.G. **********Since then, it has sought to build its United States presence through acquisitions and partnerships. It has two steel service centers in Chicago, and became one of the biggest United States producers of stainless steel following its acquisition of three producers earlier this year. **********The purchase of Edgcomb would strengthen Usinor-Sacilor's market position in the United States, especially in the East and Southeast. Edgcomb, which has 18 operational units on the Eastern Seaboard, has 1,600 employees and had 1989 sales of about $600 million. About 45 percent of its sales are in flat products, and it also sells stainless steel, long products and aluminum. **********A leveraged-buyout fund of the Blackstone Group, a New York investment bank, paid $8 a share for Edgcomb last year. It paid about $100 million for the company and refinanced about $200 million in existing debt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/busin.main_headline: Deal Is Set For L.I. Papers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/busin.print_headline: Deal Is Set For L.I. Papers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/busin.body_text: **********The former owner of Chanry Communications, a financially troubled chain of free weekly newspapers on Long Island, has agreed in principle to buy back the chain from E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company. **********Stan Henry, who founded **********Chanry in 1979, said he had agreed to repurchase the company because he expects the slumping Long Island economy to recover in the next few years, restoring the papers to profitability. **********The deal comes less than two weeks after Warburg became the sole proprietor of Chanry as part of the breakup of Warburg's partnership with Ralph McA. Ingersoll 2d, who bought the chain in May 1987. **********Warburg swapped its interest in the partnership's English and Irish papers for Mr. Ingersoll's interest in various United States papers, including the Chanry chain. **********Mr. Ingersoll reportedly paid about $25 million for the 82-paper chain, which had circulation of 1.15 million and revenues of about $38 million. A person with knowledge of the Chanry operation, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said it had profits of about $3 million when sold to Mr. Ingersoll. **********Mr. Henry would not confirm any numbers but said that revenues had ''significantly'' declined since he sold it and that the operation was no longer profitable. He declined to disclose the purchase price, but said the company was worth less than in 1987.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/03/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Meeting Sought On Nekoosa
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/03/busin.body_text: **********The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said today that it had solicited enough approval by shareholders of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation to call a special meeting to consider replacing Nekoosa's board with nominees who support its takeover offer. **********Georgia-Pacific sweetened its bid to $63 a share, or $3.6 billion, in November after Nekoosa rejected an offer of $58 a share, or $3.19 billion. **********Georgia-Pacific said the holders of more than 27.7 million, or 50.4 percent, of Nekoosa's shares had called for the meeting. Only 33.3 percent was needed, the company said. **********Nekoosa has rejected the latest bid and has begun a legal fight to prevent a takeover. **********Georgia-Pacific said **********Nekoosa must schedule the meeting within 15 days. It must take place within 60 days. **********Nekoosa's stock closed up 25 cents today, at $61.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Georgia-Pacific's rose $2, at $50.50.
