https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/26/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Reebok Expects Drop in Earnings
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/26/busin.body_text: **********Reebok International Ltd., the nation's second-largest footwear company after Nike, said yesterday that it expected its third-quarter earnings to be in the range of 33 cents to 35 cents a share, off from 44 cents in the corresponding period a year earlier. **********Reebok's shares closed at $9.125 yesterday, down 75 cents on the New York Stock Exchange, after hitting a 52-week low of $8.875. Three months ago, Reebok was trading near $19 a share. **********The company, based in Stoughton, Mass., also said that it expects fourth-quarter earnings to rise from last year's level of 30 cents a share. Reebok was not more specific, except to say that full-year profit ''should approximate 1989's level of $1.53 a share.'' It expects an improved performance in 1991. **********Reebok attributed the expected third-quarter decline mainly to lower United States sales of its Reebok brand and to higher marketing expenses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/29/world.main_headline: Fraud Alleged in Vote for Gorbachev Aide
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/29/world.print_headline: Fraud Alleged in Vote for Gorbachev Aide
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/29/world.body_text: **********Opposition members of the Congress of People's Deputies today produced what they called clear evidence of voting irregularities in the second-round election of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Vice President on Thursday. **********Brandishing a smoking gun that consisted of two apparently excess ballots, the opposition legislators charged that the voting in the Congress had been falsified to insure the victory of Mr. Gorbachev's candidate, Gennadi I. Yanayev. **********Arkady N. Murashev, a leader of the opposition Interregional Deputies Group, told reporters that the incident could be likened to the "Vatergeitsky skandal" -- the Watergate scandal -- although he emphasized that there was no evidence to implicate Mr. Gorbachev. **********"Generally speaking, it is a serious state crime, cheating in the results of voting for Vice President," he said. "In a civilized state, the fate of the present leadership would be determined" by such a scandal. **********Mr. Yanayev, criticized as a lackluster Communist Party functionary, failed to win election on the first ballot Friday morning, although he was the only candidate. He fell 31 votes short of the required 1,120, a majority of the 2,239 eligible members of the Congress. **********The official results of the second ballot, taken after Mr. Gorbachev refused to propose another candidate, were announced Friday evening. Of the 1,828 legislators who took ballots, 1,237 voted for Mr. Yanayev, 563 voted against, 23 ballots were returned blank or defaced, and 5 ballots were not returned.  7 Ballots Held Back **********But the opposition legislators said they decided to put the paper ballots in their pockets rather than vote, as a check on the fairness of the election. Today they displayed seven paper ballots, two more than the number listed as missing in the official count. **********"That means that on top of the number of ballots officially distributed, ballots were given out unofficially and placed in the ballot box," Mr. Murashev said, suggesting that the incident may indicate other forms of tampering. **********"I think they really over-insured themselves so that Yanayev would win," he said. "We want to underline that the important thing is not whether Yanayev won or not, but that the authorities can do whatever they like to achieve their goals, any kind of falsification, any kind of dirty tricks." **********The Interregional Deputies Group, a radical bloc that claims 229 members of the Congress, said it would present its evidence and demand an investigation, but with little hope of satisfaction. **********"I think they will never admit to fraud," Mr. Murashev said. "The most we can hope for is that they will admit to miscounting, or say that the chairman of the counting commission had a slip of the tongue when he announced the results."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/11/world.main_headline: Israel Picks Panel to Investigate Killing of 21 Arabs
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/11/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS;   Israel Picks Panel to Investigate Killing of 21 Arabs
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/11/world.body_text: **********The Government appointed a high-level commission today to investigate the violence in Jerusalem's Old City on Monday in which soldiers shot and killed at least 21 Palestinians. **********The commission is to be directed by Maj. Gen. Zvi Zamir, a reserve officer and a former head of the Mossad intelligence agency; Yaacov Neeman, a prominent private lawyer, and Chaim Kubersky, a former head of the Interior Ministry. It was given no deadline to complete its work. **********Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's office said it would seriously consider the committee's conclusions but would not be bound by them. Israel radio reported that the panel would not have the power to subpoena witnesses. **********The decision to appoint a commission came after Police Minister Roni Milo informed Mr. Shamir that he did not feel comfortable conducting only an internal police inquiry, as had been planned. Whatever a police inquiry's outcome, Mr. Milo said, his office would be open to challenges that the investigation had not been thorough. **********Police Are Defended **********But even as the commission was named, Government officials stuck to their assertion that the police had done nothing wrong, despite the worldwide condemnations pouring in today. **********Mr. Shamir's office insisted that the American decision to sponsor a United Nations resolution condemning Israel for excessive use of force had no bearing on the decision to open an investigation, though only an internal police inquiry had been planned before. **********''We don't need a probe by international factors,'' said Yossi Ahimeir, the Prime Minister's spokesman. He described the question of whether excessive force was used as a ''marginal point.'' **********Other than that, Israeli officials made no public mention of the planned United Nations action today, the eve of a major public holiday. Officials said today that they did not want to ''take a bad situation and make it worse,'' as one senior official said, by trading charges wth Washington. **********More Nations Join in Criticism **********Today the Governments of Spain, Greece, Turkey, Zimbabwe as well as the Vatican and the International Committee of the Red Cross added their public criticisms to those from a long list of other nations. **********The Red Cross said it ''urgently appeals to the Israeli authorities to put an end to the use of live ammunition against civilians.'' **********The opposition Labor Party, which had been silent about the incident, issued a statement today criticizing the Shamir Government not for the high number of Palestinian casualties but for what it called ''a lapse in security that endangered the lives of Jews at the Wailing Wall.'' **********The Western Wall, the last remaining remnant of the Second Temple, destroyed in A.D. 70 by the Romans, is sometimes called the Wailing Wall. Policemen opened fire on the rioting Palestinians after they had begun hurling rocks and bottles down on the heads of thousands of Jews praying at the wall. **********Detentions Are Extended **********This afternoon, a Jerusalem court extended the detention of Faisal al-Husseini, considered the most senior local Palestine Liberation Organization leader, and Sheik Mohammed Said Jamal, Jerusalem's deputy mufti. He is the city's second highest Islamic religious leader. **********Both are accused of inciting the riot on Monday, a charge both men vigorously deny. They are 2 of the most prominent of 77 Palestinians arrested for involvement in the rioting. The court said all of them could be kept in jail 10 more days before any formal charges are filed. **********Although there were scattered demonstrations today in the occupied territories, East Jerusalem and several Arab towns inside Israel, the army and police reported that most communities were calm. **********Israel's Ministry of Religious Affairs, meanwhile, published large advertisements in several newspapers urging religious Jews to turn out for services at the Western Wall on Thursday, the last day of the weeklong Succoth, or Feast of Tabernacles. **********Orthodox men celebrate the occasion by dancing with biblical scrolls, and most years thousands of them dance in front of the Western Wall. The Government said worshipers should not be deterred by ''the malicious attempt to desecrate the joy of our holiday beside the remnant of our holy temple,'' and promised ample security.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/world.main_headline: Palestinians' Support for Iraq Tempered by Kuwait Horrors
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; Palestinians' Support for Iraq Tempered by Kuwait Horrors
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/world.body_text: **********Thousands of Palestinians have fled Kuwait in the wake of the Iraqi invasion, and their stories of brutality have weakened Palestinian support for Saddam Hussein and produced a change in the political mood in Jordan. **********The Palestinians are torn on one hand by sympathy so many feel for Mr. Hussein, the Iraqi President, as a leader who might be strong enough to challenge the military might of Israel, and on the other by bitterness so many harbor toward Iraq. They remember the cruelty they endured or witnessed under Iraqi occupation in Kuwait and the loss of their livelihoods and, for thousands, their life's savings. **********According to official estimates, more than 180,000 of the 450,000 Jordanians in Kuwait, many of Palestinian origin, have returned to Jordan since the invasion on Aug. 2. The stories they have been telling about Iraqi occupation are quietly undermining the unquestioning support for Iraq that initially prevailed here after Iraqi forces invaded Kuwait.  Pro-Baghdad Rallies Stop **********While most Palestinians and Jordanians continue to express sympathy for President Hussein as a symbol of Arab strength and the potential liberator of Jerusalem, the rallies for him have stopped, official statements defending him have declined or become far more nuanced and the photos of a smiling King Hussein alongside President Hussein, his namesake but no relation, have all but vanished. **********"The whole town is whispering," said Sulaiman al-Fassam, Kuwait's Ambassador to Amman. "There's a lot of questioning going on. Before, Jordan was not neutral territory for us. Now they're heading for neutrality." **********A Palestinian university professor who taught in Kuwait and recently returned to Amman commented, "The honeymoon between the Palestinians and Iraq is definitely over." **********The clearest indication of the tensions among Palestinians -- and the divergent signals being sent out by factions within the Palestine Liberation Organization -- was a brief announcement on Nov. 8 from the P.L.O. headquarters in Tunis that a senior Palestinian official would visit Kuwait to try to help the 250,000 Palestinians who have remained there. Reuters reported that Yasser Abd Rabbo, a member of the organization's executive committee, would travel to Iraq and Kuwait to discuss ways to help the Palestinians. **********A senior Jordanian official, who like almost everyone insisted on anonymity when discussing this politically sensitive topic, said Mr. Rabbo had met last week with Iraqi officials to request that the P.L.O. be permitted to station its own military men in Kuwait to safeguard the Palestinians. The Iraqis refused, the Jordanian said. **********The organization, while denouncing Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, has maintained that the presence of American forces in the region poses a greater threat to stability than Iraq's seizure and occupation of Kuwait. This stance has substantially diminished sympathy in the United States and in Europe for the Palestinian cause and for the suffering that many Palestinians have endured in Kuwait. P.L.O.'s Pro-Iraqi Stance **********In interviews, Palestinians said the organization's pro-Iraqi stance reflected widespread despair that their plight would ever be addressed successfully through diplomatic channels. **********Because of the sympathy expressed here for Iraq by King Hussein as well as the P.L.O., most Palestinians who have returned from Kuwait, many desperate and suddenly destitute, have no way of publicly expressing the rage they feel. Once again, they say ruefully, the Palestinians are among the principal victims of a crisis not of their making. **********Interviews with more than a dozen returning Palestinians and a visit to the Bakaa refugee camp on the outskirts of Amman underscored the suffering many had incurred as a result of the crisis. Consider Mohammed Seif, 25 years old, now the head of his household at the Bakaa camp. **********"Overnight, we lost everything," Mr. Seif said with a sigh of resignation. His father, a journalist with the newspaper Al Enbaa, sent his family back to Jordan after the invasion. But he stayed in Kuwait to try to protect their villa and possessions. **********Mr. Seif's mother, 21-year-old brother and three sisters -- Arwa, 18, Ghada, 12, and Fidda, 10 -- have rented a semi-finished concrete house that has neither windows nor heat.  'It's So Cold' at Night **********At night, the biting desert air permeates the house, making the cement and tile floor so cold that after a few minutes the soles of one's feet feel like ice. The dampness is abated only by a tiny electric heater placed amid four paper-thin mattresses that the family members share to sleep. There are no blankets to cover them at night, and not a chair to sit on during the day. A blue plastic bag of onions and three round loaves of bread was the family's dinner that night. **********"It's so cold," Mr. Seif said. "The entire family is sick. We went to Kuwait to find a better life; we had a good life there. But now people are being killed there. There's no bread. Everyone is scared. There is no life." **********His brother had to quit the university because the family no longer had money for tuition, and Mr. Seif has not been able to find work. **********The plight of the highly educated professionals who have returned from Kuwait with their household possessions but not their savings -- which became almost worthless when Iraq converted Kuwaiti dinars into much less valued Iraqi dinars -- is a hot topic of conversation in many homes in this very social capital. Business Looted by Iraqis **********Esmat Khatib, a formerly wealthy Palestinian who went to Kuwait in 1963, made his fortune in office equipment. His entire family and his four brothers are now living in their father's house in Amman. Mr. Khatib took with him his household furniture, his wife's couture dresses -- stuffed into plastic garbage bags -- and the key to his $5 million factory and warehouse, which was looted by the Iraqis. **********"They took the fax machines, typewriters, all the computers and even the chairs," Mr. Khatib said. "I later saw the Iraqis sitting on my chairs at their checkpoints." **********As luck would have it, he had recently given his daugher $100,000 to buy an apartment in Boston, where she was studying. "Now she's sending money home to us," he said. **********Other Palestinians, who spoke on condition that they not be identified, told of human rights abuses they witnessed under Iraqi occupation. **********A professor at the University of Kuwait, which is now defunct, said he rapidly lost his sympathy for the Iraqis when he was stopped along with a dozen other cars at an Iraqi checkpoint in Kuwait City. **********"They pulled a young Kuwaiti out of his car and made the rest of us get out," the professor said. "Then they shouted at us, 'Does anyone know this dog?' " The professor said the Iraqis shot the young man in the head and left his body lying in the road for several hours as a warning. Collaboration Is Denied **********All of those interviewed denied that Palestinians were collaborating with Iraq in its occupation. The P.L.O. faction headed by Mohammed Abbas, also known as Abul Abbas, who masterminded the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro in 1985, sent Palestinians to help the Iraqis soon after the invasion, but even they have left, the Palestinians asserted. **********"Kuwaitis who have remained in Kuwait no longer believe that the Palestinians are collaborating with the Iraqis," said Khalid al-Rashed, a Kuwaiti journalist with the newspaper Al Khaleej, now published in the United Arab Emirates. "They know that both Kuwaitis and Palestinians are now being killed there." **********Despite their tales of atrocities, of growing hunger and theft in Kuwait and of lost fortunes, most of the Palestinians interviewed said they would not criticize President Hussein publicly, nor did they want to see Iraq's military power destroyed. "The Americans must leave the gulf, and Israel must leave our land," one professor said. **********They insisted that the P.L.O. was still the "sole and legitimate voice" of the Palestinian people. But almost all criticized its leadership, saying their leaders had not tried hard enough to protect the Palestinian community in Kuwait and the gulf. **********"For the past 10 years I happily gave the P.L.O. five percent of my paycheck from Kuwait to support my people," one Palestinian said. "Where are they now that we need them?" **********Mohammed Milhelm, a P.L.O. official in Amman, dismissed reports that the organization had billions invested in banks in London and elsewhere overseas. The organization itself, he said , has been hard-pressed for funds since the invasion. Angered by its pro-Iraq stance, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, which used to supply $8 million a month, stopped their payments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/04/world.body_text: **********Nelson Mandela expressed optimism today about the prospects of narrowing his differences with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher over economic sanctions against South Africa, and backed off from comments that had suggested that Britain should negotiate with the Irish Republican Army. **********On the first day of a two-day official visit, Mr. Mandela met Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd for lunch to discuss the prospects for resolution of South Africa's racial conflict. After the meeting, Mr. Hurd told reporters that he had emphasized to Mr. Mandela that Britain was ''anxious to do everything we could to help without interfering in South Africa's affairs.'' **********Mr. Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, said, ''I stressed the historical ties between Britain and South Africa and expressed the hope that these ties would be strengthened.'' **********A Strenuous Tour **********The congress leader, nearing the end of a strenuous tour that has covered Western Europe and the United States, said he was ''optimistic'' about his talks with Mrs. Thatcher, scheduled for Wednesday. They are expected to discuss at least two issues - the congress's refusal to renounce the use of force against the Government and the continuation of international economic sanctions against South Africa, backed by the congress as a means to press the Government to end apartheid. **********Britain has condemned the use of violence and been criticized by Mr. Mandela for easing some sanctions, including a ban on new investment in South Africa, in the belief that President F. W. de Klerk should be encouraged to reach a settlement. **********Mr. Mandela suggested that there was a possibility of narrowing the gap between the two positions and said: ''There are some points of difference. That does not worry me.'' Controversy Over I.R.A. **********But the issue of economic pressure was overshadowed today by the controversy surrounding remarks Mr. Mandela made in Dublin on Monday that appeared to suggest that Britain should open unconditional talks with the Irish Republican Army, which has been trying to force Britain out of Northern Ireland. Britain has said that it would not consider talks until the group lays down its weapons. **********In reply to an I.R.A. question at a news conference, Mr. Mandela said: ''People are slaughtering one another when they could sit down and address the problems in a peaceful manner.'' **********Mr. Mandela said later that he had been misinterpreted after criticism from all of Britain's main political parties and both liberal and conservative newspapers. In a meeting today with 150 British Members of Parliament, he insisted that he had been speaking about conflict in general and not specifically about Northern Ireland. **********$7 Million Raised in U.S. **********By The Associated Press **********Nelson Mandela raised more than $7 million for the African National Congress in his eight-city tour of the United States, according to figures provided by tour organizers. **********Organizers said most of the cash should reach the congress because many meeting places and equipment used by the tour were donated or supplied at a discount. Expenses have not been subtracted from the income. **********In Boston, planners raised about half their $1 million goal. But in New York, fund raisers said between $1.75 million and $2 million had been raised, about double their goal. **********In Atlanta, projections were for roughly $400,000, while about $300,000 was raised in the Miami area. In Washington, about $150,000 was raised. Income in Detroit was estimated at $1.4 million, and preliminary numbers from Los Angeles were $1.7 million and from Oakland, Calif., $900,000. **********The proceeds are to be deposited in a fund for the congress controlled by the American directors of the tour, led by Roger Wilkins, a professor at George Mason University and the trip's chief planner. The money will be used to finance 14 offices in South Africa for the African National Congress, a spokeswoman said. The remainder will go toward housing and education.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.main_headline: Gandhi's Security Is Anything but Secret Now
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.print_headline: Gandhi's Security Is Anything but Secret Now
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.body_text: **********Long a closely guarded secret, expensive security measures for former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and other politicians are being openly discussed here under the new Goverment of Prime Minister V. P. Singh. **********Mr. Gandhi has moved from the Prime Minister's official residence, surrounded by high blast-proof walls and, until recently, hundreds of grim security guards, to a smaller bungalow, with fewer guards but high walls, about two miles away. **********Mr. Singh still lives in a small house elsewhere in the capital but is expected to move to the official residence later this month. With the official residence vacant, the road outside the sprawling row of British-built bungalows was opened to traffic on Friday for the first time in six years. **********Measures to protect top Indian officials, especially Mr. Gandhi, were kept secret in the years after Sikh guards assassinated Mr. Gandhi's mother and predecessor in office, Indira Gandhi, in October 1984. The assassination, which occurred at her official residence, was apparently intended to avenge an Indian Army raid on the Golden Temple, the holy Sikh shrine, at Amritsar earlier that year to crush a Sikh revolt. **********But after the defeat of Mr. Gandhi in last November's elections, the cost and number of security personnel and bulletproof cars given to him and his family are being reported extensively and discussed in television and radio reports, newspaper articles, letters and editorials. **********Other politicians, also on a purported ''hit list'' of extremists, have complained that security measures for them have been reduced by the new Government. For its part, the Government says it is giving them adequate protection. **********The open talk of the details of Mr. Gandhi's security has angered officials in his Congress Party. ''This is the first time that a leader's life is being measured in rupees,'' said M. J. Akbar, a spokesman for the party, who is a member of Parliament. ''He is just extremely vulnerable.'' 7.5 Million Rupees a Year In a letter to a Congress Party leader Friday, Mr. Singh estimated the cost of Mr. Gandhi's security at 7.5 million rupees a year, or about $450,000. The letter, which was published in newspapers here and shown on the state-controlled television, said 150 guards, most from the New Delhi police, would be assigned to protect the former Prime Minister. He would have the use of four bulletproof cars. **********Mr. Akbar, who was editor of the influential Telegraph of Calcutta before being elected to Parliament, critiziced the new security measures. **********''In the United States, a former President continues to get the protection of the Secret Service, not of the local sheriff,'' he said. ''This is not to question the competence of the sheriff but it's not really his job and the Delhi police are simply not equal to the job.'' **********Mr. Singh was quoted by a spokesman today as saying that he was increasing the spending for security for Mr. Gandhi to about $600,000 and that crack members of the Special Protection Group, set up for the Prime Minister's own security, would be deployed for the opposition leader when he is in the capital. But state governments will be responsible for his security during travels across India. **********Security officials also are reportedly reviewing protection for Mr. Singh, who favors an open form of Government and less personal security. **********''It is not a question of an open Government,'' Mr. Akbar said. ''The reason why Rajiv Gandhi needs the security is because he is the target, not V. P. Singh.'' He pointed to a statement by a Sikh leader who demanded the withdrawal of security for Mr. Gandhi, saying he had ''committed genocide on the Sikhs.'' **********A shake-up in the security and intelligence services followed Mrs. Gandhi's death and a new residence, considered easier to protect, was selected for Mr. Gandhi. His mother's death also prompted savage anti-Sikh rioting in New Delhi and elsewhere in northern India, in which more than 3,000 Sikhs were killed. Sikh militants blame Mr. Gandhi for not curbing the violence in time after he succeeded his mother.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/12/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;   Chrysler Eases Attack On Japanese
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/12/busin.body_text: **********''Everything from Japan is perfect,'' he said. ''Everything from America is lousy.'' **********Japanese car makers were also mentioned in other ads in the series. **********In the new campaign, the Japanese are never directly mentioned, although some of the ads make comparisons between Honda and Chrysler models. One spot begins by praising Honda: ''A good car the Honda Accord; no doubt about it,'' the announcer says as a beautiful shot of the car is shown. **********But the commercial quickly turns into the expected pitch for Chrysler as a Plymouth Acclaim pulls in front of the Honda. ''Compared to the Plymouth Acclaim, it has less interior room, a smaller engine, no air bag and costs $1,300 more,'' the announcer says. ''Now, we're not saying the Accord is second rate, merely second best.'' **********Some auto industry analysts were not surprised that Chrysler changed its anti-Japanese stance. After all, it has not significantly helped Chrysler's sales, which have been in a slump. ''The Japan-bashing obviously was not working well,'' said Tom Healy, an analyst with J. D. Power & Associates, an automobile marketing company. ''A 'Made in Japan' label is not necessarily a turnoff to many car buyers.'' **********Chrysler was also criticized for attacking Japanese car makers because it imports vehicles made by Mitsubishi in Japan and sells cars made in a joint venture with Mitsubishi in Illinois. **********For its part, Chrysler, which spends about $700 million a year on advertising, said it had decided to modify its approach in part because research found that American consumers do not like to see other cultures criticized. **********The company also decided to concentrate on ads that compared some Chrysler cars with Honda models, which it has done previously, because it found the tactic effective. Even though Chrysler's overall sales have been falling, Mr. Damoose said sales of Plymouth Acclaim have improved significantly since last spring, when ads comparing it with the Accord began to run. **********The commercials are also more humorous than those in the past. ''It takes the edge off the criticism of Japanese cars,'' said David Bell, the president of Bozell, the agency that created both campaigns. **********The agency also decided to give the ads a ''hip'' look to try to change some consumers' perception that Chrysler has not been moving with the times. **********''We've found that a lot of people still associate Plymouth with an old-fashioned attitude,'' said Bert Gardner, an executive creative director at Bozell. ''We wanted to create a more contemporary image.'' **********To direct the commercials, Bozell hired Lol Creme, a former rock musician who now produces music videos. The sets on which the cars are photographed look like Broadway stage sets - they feature abstract representations of skyscrapers, mountain peaks and trees. The music sounds like a synthesized blend of Big Band tunes set to a rap music beat. **********One spot features a group of dancers in clothes reminiscent of the 1960's, moving to a groovy beat as they cross the set to a 20-year-old Honda. The announcer tells viewers that Americans were once attracted to Honda because it was a well-made, less-expensive alternative to American cars. **********The music and the clothes change to a 1990's version as the same group boogies back to a pack of new Chryslers and the announcer says that car buyers are now looking for well-made American alternatives to Honda. **********Mr. Iacocca appears in only one commercial, for Chrysler's mini-van. Acting like a tour guide at a Chrysler factory, he explains how the mini-van has been redesigned. **********In another spot about the design evolution of the mini-van, the agency used innovative computer-generated graphics that show the dashboard being reconfigured, the engine growing larger and the chassis changing shape. **********It was an expensive and time-consuming commercial to create, but agency executives said it was necessary. ''The most convincing way to illustrate to consumers that the mini-van had drastically changed,'' Mr. Gardner said, ''was to show them the metamorphosis happening before their eyes.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/17/busin.body_text: **********The Aluminum Company of America, citing a softening in aluminum prices and lower income from the company's affiliate in Brazil, yesterday reported a 43 percent drop in second-quarter earnings. **********The Pittsburgh-based company, the world's largest producer of aluminum, said that its earnings fell to $161.9 million, or $1.86 a share, compared with $285.2 million, or $3.21 a share, in the second quarter of 1989. Revenue fell to $2.73 billion in the second quarter from $2.82 billion in the 1989 period. **********Alcoa said that the lower earnings were primarily a result of a 24 percent decline in the price of aluminum ingot on world markets. Also, the company said that earnings at Alcoa Aluminio, the Brazilian affiliate in which Alcoa holds a 59 percent stake, dropped to $6 million in the first half of the year, compared with $61 million in the comparable period last year. The decline was attributed to actions taken by the Brazilian Government to improve that country's economy. **********Peter Anker, a metals analyst with the First Boston Corporation, said that the results were generally in line with expectations. ''They did a little better in Brazil than we had expected,'' Mr. Anker said. ''We had been expecting them to break even in the operation in Brazil, but it looks like they made $6 million.'' **********Other analysts said that the company's results reflected declining prices for fabricated aluminum products, adding that the prices of aluminum sheets for beverage cans had declined. **********On the New York Stock Exchange, Alcoa shares rose 50 cents yesterday, closing at $69.25.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/world.main_headline: Donors Plead for Ethiopian Truce To Prevent Starvation in the North
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/world.print_headline: Donors Plead for Ethiopian Truce To Prevent Starvation in the North
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/world.body_text: **********A group of Western countries appealed today to the Ethiopian Government and its rebel opposition for an immediate cease-fire and the reopening of the Red Sea port of Massawa to allow food shipments to avert starvation in the country's northern region. **********The United States, Canada, the 12 European Community countries and Norway, Sweden and Switzerland called on all parties involved in the civil war to stop fighting and guarantee safe passage for emergency food to prevent a repetition of the famine that killed hundreds of thousands of Ethiopians in 1984. **********Speaking for the European Community, the Irish Foreign Minster, Gerard Collins, said at a news conference that the Ethiopian Foreign Minister, Tesfaye Dinka, appeared to reject the appeal at a meeting here Monday. The official reportedly said that his Government was committed to recapturing Massawa from the rebels. **********Mr. Collins said the Ethiopian Minister first tried to persuade the donor countries to delay issuing the appeal. He then asserted that Massawa's port was out of operation, a statement that the food donors dispute. Finally, the Ethiopian official said that enough food to prevent famine could be brought by road from the port of Assab if the donors provided another 100 trucks. But Mr. Collins expressed skepticism about that assessment. **********The Eritrean People's Liberation Front, which captured Massawa in February, has offered to declare the port an open city and to guarantee free passage for food if the Mengistu Government will guarantee the safety of relief workers by calling off plans to recapture the port. **********European and Canadian diplomats called the rebels' offer opportunistic, and said the movement was more interested in military victory than in averting famine. **********Although the Soviet Union has told the Mengistu Government that it will not renew their joint accord on military cooperation when it expires next year, European diplomats said today that Israel had begun supplying arms to the Ethiopian Government in exchange for permission to evacuate the country's tiny Jewish population.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/busin.main_headline: Apple's Profits Rebound on Strong Foreign Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/busin.print_headline: COMPANY EARNINGS;   Apple's Profits Rebound on Strong Foreign Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/busin.body_text: **********Driven by strong international sales, Apple Computer Inc. today reported unexpectedly strong sales and earnings for its second quarter. The Cupertino, Calif., company had notified analysts on March 15 that results would be better than expected after a disappointing previous quarter, but today's numbers exceeded even the most bullish of revised estimates. **********In advising analysts today, however, Apple warned about the second half of the year. Some products are not selling as well as expected, domestic sales are down and the savings from lower component costs and reduced operating expenses have largely been realized, analysts said. Analysts said they were told to expect revenue growth of 7 percent to 10 percent in the second half, about the same as in the first. **********'Marked Improvements' **********For its second quarter ended March 30, Apple earned $131.8 million, or $1.04 a share, more than twice the $56.4 million, or 44 cents a share, it reported for the period a year ago. Sales rose 8 percent, to $1.35 billion, from $1.25 billion in the second quarter of its 1989 fiscal year. International sales were 47 percent of net sales during the second quarter of fiscal 1990, compared with 40 percent in the period a year ago. **********Apple released its results after the close of the stock market, and its shares were unchanged today, at $43.25, in over-the-counter trading. **********''We are experiencing marked improvements in our gross margins as a result of lower component costs and strong sales of the computers we introduced a year ago,'' John Sculley, Apple's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. ''At the same time, we continue to focus on managing the growth in our operating expenses.'' **********During the quarter, the percentage of Apple's revenues coming from outside the United States reached a high point, compensating for essentially flat domestic sales. Profit margins are typically higher on foreign sales as well, contributing to Apple's stronger than expected earnings. **********'Cautious' About U.S. Growth **********''This performance is a result of our efforts over the past few years to build a strong international presence and of the relatively higher growth rates the industry is experiencing in markets outside the United States,'' Mr. Sculley said. ''As we enter the second half of fiscal 1990, we are optimistic regarding the level of international demand, while we remain cautious regarding growth in the United States.'' **********While Apple's international sales grew 27 percent from the quarter a year ago, domestic sales were down 4.7 percent year-to-year and off more than 24 percent from the first quarter, said Steven L. Ossad, an analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. **********Also reporting unusually strong results today was Silicon Graphics Inc., a Mountain View, Calif., maker of computer work stations. Silicon Graphics reported earnings for its third fiscal quarter ended March 31, of $8.7 million, or 45 cents a share, more than twice the $3.1 million, or 18 cents a share, it reported in the comparable period a year ago. Revenues rose 61 percent, to $110 million, from $68.3 million in the third quarter of the 1989 fiscal year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/16/busin.body_text: **********With its ancient copper mash vats, ponderous oak barrels and age-old beer-making techniques, this city's famed Pilsner Urquell brewery long took a back seat to other enterprises as Communist central planners invested massively in favored industries like machinery and steel. **********But now that Czechoslovakia has thrown off Communist rule, workers and managers here are eager to transform their 158-year-old brewery into a dynamic, modern operation. **********For the 2,000 managers and workers here at the nation's largest brewery, 55 miles southwest of Prague, the dawn of capitalism means a series of needed reforms, led by a vigorous international marketing campaign. Indeed, company officials believe that Pilsner Urquell, perhaps more so than any other operation in Czechoslovakia, can be turned into an export powerhouse - and a large producer of hard currency. **********A Much-Imitated Pioneer **********The ambitious goal is mainly an effort to exploit the Pilsner Urquell brand, renowned among the beer-quaffing cognoscenti. Pilsner Urquell, which is German for ''Original Pilsner,'' was a 19th-century pioneer, creating a new beer category that was then widely imitated. Today, the ''pilsner'' name is attached to beers throughout the world, meaning a pale gold-colored beer with a strong hops taste. **********The end of Communism has produced a whirl of talk at Pilsner Urquell about the need to do business differently: establishing its own marketing arm, finding a foreign partner, modernizing its equipment, increasing exports and setting up an employee ownership plan. **********''We realize that we're sitting on a gold mine - the old Government failed to appreciate that,'' said Jaroslav Pesler, production manager at the brewery, a 130-acre jumble of dark, sprawling structures. ''The Government looked at us as an interesting oddity that happened to produce hard currency.'' **********Effect on Workers **********Although the brewery has an extraordinary reputation and product, it is typical of many Eastern European enterprises in the excitement and anxiety its employees are experiencing as the region divorces itself from Communism. **********For the workers, there is reluctant recognition that the advent of capitalism will probably mean tougher management, less slacking off and perhaps some layoffs, especially among the 400 administrative workers who spend much of their time doing paperwork for Prague's central planners. At the same time, despite all the talk nowadays about learning how to survive in the more competitive capitalist era, brewery workers seem supremely confident that their famed beer will withstand the heat. **********''There is more pride here than at other Czechoslovak companies,'' said Josef Krysl, a talkative 35-year-old who manages the dank, dimly lit beer cellars, where the beer ages slowly in large oak barrels. ''There are not many Czechoslovak products that command such respect and can be sold so easily on Western markets.'' **********Bid to Recapture Past Glory **********Managers are confident that by making the brewery into a market-oriented enterprise, Pilsner Urquell can recapture its past glory. The beer's popularity spread throughout Europe soon after the brewery opened in 1842, when Pilsen's small breweries pooled their resources to form one giant brewery. It married some then-new technology with traditional ingredients and patience to produce its distinctive brew. **********While other 19th-century beers were often murky, Pilsen's bottom-fermented beer grew famous for its golden clarity and assertive, somewhat bitter taste. Soon dozens of imitators sprang up throughout the world, and thus the family of pilsner beers was born. **********For a century after the Pilsen brewery was founded, Pilsner Urquell was hailed as one of the world's great beers. Its popularity stumbled after World War II, however, partly because of heavy bombing damage during the war and partly because of the Communists' half-hearted efforts to export it. **********Hopes to Raise Exports **********Soon after last December's peaceful revolution pushed out the Communist Government and created the prospect of economic changes, the brewery's managers set up their own exporting arm to put an end to the indifferent marketing. For decades, the brewery had to rely on Koospol, the state food- and beverage-export monopoly. **********A third of the brewery's annual production of 40 million gallons is exported. Brewery managers say that with some sophisticated marketing they can almost double exports so they represent 60 percent of production. **********American beer drinkers consumed about 470,000 gallons of Pilsner Urquell last year, not enough to make the beer one of the 50 best-selling imported beers in the United States. **********When a journalist visited one recent week, the brewery's general manager, Vaclav Spalek, was traveling in West Germany to meet with officials from a half-dozen beer companies that have offered to buy a stake in Pilsner Urquell or to enter into a marketing and distribution agreement with it. One German brewery has offered $70 million to buy a controlling stake in Pilsner Urquell, while several British and Australian companies have also made offers to acquire a stake. **********For the most part, brewery managers and employees want to remain independent, saying it would be better for a foreign partner to buy just a small stake. **********''We wouldn't like a foreign partner to obtain a majority,'' Mr. Pesler, the production manager, said. ''We'd like it to buy maybe a 25 percent stake.'' **********There is widespread agreement that an injection of foreign capital could be used to help finance a more modern, less labor-intensive pumping system to transfer the beer between mash vats, barrels and bottling plant. **********''We are profitable enough to pay for it out of our own earnings, but we can do it much faster with foreign help,'' Mr. Pesler said. **********Many employees are frustrated that the slow pace of legislating economic reforms on foreign investment and in other areas is keeping the company from selecting a partner and making other key decisions. ''We're eagerly waiting for the new laws to see what all the changes mean for us,'' said Jaroslav Hodan, the brewery's chief microbiologist. **********At the moment, the brewery's management is talking far more about finding a foreign company to cooperate with than about privatizating the company. There is some discussion about changing Pilsner Urquell's legal structure into that of a shareholding company, which would remain majority state-owned, at least for now. Many managers say the employees should be allowed to buy 10 or 20 percent of the shares to create more incentives for the workers. **********The end of Communism is likely to have a less welcome effect on the workers. ''One thing is for sure, they'll want us to work harder,'' said Jirina Slepichova, a 19-year-old brewery biochemist. **********Conditions Under Communism **********Karel Jilek, the 59-year-old brewmaster, recalls that the brewery's work ethic was far stricter in 1946, when he joined and the brewery was still privately owned. **********''The brewery workers haven't had to work so hard under Communism,'' said the round-faced, white-haired brewmaster. **********Vaclav Havel, the playwright who is now President, depicted conditions in a Czechoslovak brewery in his satirical autobiographical comedy ''Audience.'' The brewery Mr. Havel had worked for was not Pilsner Urquell, however, but another in Bohemia, said an official at the Czechoslovak Embassy in Washington. **********Mr. Pesler, the production manager, said that after management dismissed two workers for stealing from the brewery, the Civic Forum union threatened to go out on strike. Civic Forum was the umbrella group of pro-democracy forces, led by Mr. Havel, that toppled the Communist regime last December. **********Mr. Pesler, who was recently promoted to production manager thanks to the support of Civic Forum, persuaded the union not to strike, arguing that the workers must recognize that the rules have changed in post-Communist Czecholslovakia and that workers will be disciplined for stealing, slacking off and other infractions. **********''They don't realize sufficiently that they will have to work more and work more efficiently,'' he said. ''The pressure will have to come from management, and we have to accept that we will not be so popular.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/30/busin.body_text: **********Aancor Holdings Inc., including the National Gypsum Company, a wholly owned subsidiary, has sought protection from creditors, officials said today. **********The privately held Aancor filed the voluntary petitions in United States Bankruptcy Court on Friday. **********National Gypsum was taken private in April 1986 in a $1.64 billion leveraged buyout led by management. The company subsequently has reduced the face value of its debt from about $2 billion to about $1 billion, said Peter C. Browning, president and chief executive of both companies. **********Contributing to the company's debt level were a drop in gypsum wallboard prices to their lowest levels in a decade and declines in housing starts, he said. National Gypsum had 1989 sales of $1.36 billion. **********Aancor's debt reduction remains ahead of schedule, Mr. Browning said, but the company's efforts to reduce its debt further and insure necessary liquidity had not been sufficient. **********The Austin Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of National Gypsum, will be excluded from the filing, company officials said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/17/busin.main_headline: Norton Gets BTR Bid; Stock Soars
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/17/busin.print_headline: Norton Gets BTR Bid; Stock Soars
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/17/busin.body_text: **********In its most ambitious attempt to expand into the United States, BTR P.L.C., the British conglomerate whose holdings include Dunlop and Slazenger sporting goods, made an unsolicited $1.64 billion offer today for the Norton Company, a leading maker of abrasives, ceramics and other industrial materials. **********Norton is taking the $75-a-share offer under consideration, Francis J. Doherty Jr., a Norton spokesman, said in a telephone interview from company headquarters in Worcester, Mass. Norton's stock price soared today, closing at $74.875 a share, up $16.625. Last Friday, before takeover rumors began to circulate, the stock closed at $54.875. **********Later today, the company said it was urging shareholders not to tender their shares to BTR until Norton's board advises them of its position. It promised a report by the end of the month. **********About two-thirds of Norton's sales come from abrasives used primarily in factory tools and machines. Norton is the world leader and the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company is its biggest competitor. The rest of its sales come from technologically advanced ceramics, plastics and chemical-process products. **********BTR, Britain's ninth-largest company based on market capitalization, is one of this nation's most acquisitive. It comprises more than 100 companies, making valves and meters, automotive and aerospace components, construction materials and packaging. **********The acquisition of Norton would be BTR's biggest. The British company has more than 60 businesses in the United States. Last year these concerns generated a pretax profit of more than $250 million on sales of $3 billion. BTR has bought 12 American companies in the last 15 years at a total cost of about $1.2 billion. The other operations either came with foreign acquisitions or were started by BTR. **********The company's $438 million purchase last year of a valve and meter business from the Rockwell International Corporation was BTR's biggest in the United States. **********BTR, originally the British subsidiary of the B. F. Goodrich Company, is very different from another big British acquirer, Hanson P.L.C. **********Hanson has made a name for itself by buying companies that have diversified, then selling everything but the profitable core operations to get back most of what it paid. **********Pursues Global Expansion **********BTR usually keeps what it buys. It has a long history of acquiring industrial companies that make high-quality products for niche markets, investing heavily in them to lower their costs and helping them expand throughout the world. It is also known for getting the highest-possible prices for its products. **********''BTR has been an extremely good performer over the years,'' said Andrew C. Mitchell, an analyst at the Smith New Court Agency, a London brokerage. ''They have taken businesses that on the surface wouldn't be very exciting and produced very good results with them.'' **********BTR's worldwide operations had a pretax profit of nearly $1.74 billion on sales of $11.31 billion in 1989. The company's pretax profit grew more than fifteenfold in the last decade, while sales increased nearly as much. **********Confident on Financing **********BTR stressed that the bid for Norton would not be a leveraged buyout, whereby BTR would load Norton up with debt to finance the acquisition. BTR said it was confident of getting bank financing to buy Norton stock. Dillon, Read is the investment bank advising BTR. **********At a news conference, John C. Cahill, BTR's chief executive, noted that Norton had ''a mixed profit performance'' in the 1980's, when its earnings grew very little. **********Last year, Norton earned $105.1 million ($85.8 million before a tax-loss carry-forward) on sales of $1.53 billion. Norton had an operating margin of 9.6 percent, while BTR's was 17.6 percent. **********''If you combined the technology excellence of Norton with the operating excellence of BTR, you'd improve the key ratios significantly,'' Mr. Cahill said. ''BTR can provide the global scope, the financial resources and the management tools to allow Norton managers greater success in the 90's.'' **********Some Say Price Is High **********Mr. Mitchell and some other analysts said BTR was offering a relatively high price for Norton and would have to work hard to make the acquisition pay off. ''This will be one of their tougher challenges,'' Mr. Mitchell said. **********At least one analyst, James Wei of Merrill Lynch, said he thought that another company could bid for Norton and push the price above $80 a share. BTR officials said they had already paid $15 million, or about $50 a share, for a 1.6 percent stake in Norton. Analysts also said that unless Norton capitulated, BTR faced several obstacles: two anti-takeover laws in Massachusetts and a Norton plan that gives shareholders the right to buy shares at a bargain price if a hostile bid is made. **********BTR intends to has filed challenges to the laws and the plan in a Federal court in Boston, said Robert Delamter, a lawyer at Sullivan & Cromwell, the New York law firm representing BTR. **********Acting on the suit, Judge Joseph Tauro issued a 10-day restraining order barring the state or Norton from invoking the law or carrying out any other legal action to fight the tender offer until he hears further arguments on March 26. In addition, Mr. Wei noted that Norton, like others in its industry, was hit hard in the 1980's when many industrial customers substituted plastic parts, which did not require grinding, for metal parts, which did. **********Stock Buyback Under Way **********John M. Nelson, Norton's chairman and chief executive, seems to have been aware that his company was vulnerable to a takeover bid. Norton is in the process of selling its drilling-bits business for $550 million in cash and securities and said it would use the proceeds to buy back up to 15 percent, or 3.1 million, of its shares. It has already bought a million. **********BTR's shares closed today on the London Stock Exchange at $:4.37, or $7.10, up 20 pence, or 32.5 cents. **********The main architect of BTR's expansion strategy has been Sir Owen Green, BTR's chairman, who was chief executive until three and a half years ago. Before succeeding Sir Owen as chief executive, Mr. Cahill, who is 60 years old, ran the United States operations for seven years. He continues to live in America, and has homes in Providence,R.I., and in Longboat Key, Fla. **********How does he run a London-based company from America? ''I live in an airplane,'' he said. He quickly added it was not a BTR-owned craft. ''We have no corporate jets, no hunting lodges and only 49 people in our corporate headquarters'' in London, he said. ''We're not an extravagant company.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/31/busin.body_text: **********Many Eastern Airlines maintenance supervisors, including those indicted last week on charges of falsifying records, were trapped between the airline's aggressive management and its militant unionized workers, interviews with people at many levels of the airline show. **********On one side, management created enormous pressure to avoid delays caused by maintenance and keep the planes flying even as it laid off workers and cut back on the ready availability of parts, according to an Eastern executive, leaders of the airline's unions, and pilots and mechanics interviewed over the weekend and yesterday. **********On the other side, some unionized mechanics and pilots insisted on following rules to the letter to disrupt the airline's flight schedule as part of a bitter battle with management. **********Incentive Program Instituted **********The airline instituted an incentive program in which managers and supervisors got extra pay for keeping cancellations and late flights at a minimum. Those supervisors with poor records of keeping flights on time were often transferred, demoted or dismissed. The supervisors thus often had to choose between keeping their jobs and falsifying records, these people said. **********''With management at the top directing and pushing and the employees resisting, the line supervisors were caught directly in the middle,'' said John Bavis, a former leader of the pilots' union. ''If the performance of the airline was off, who did management go to? The line supervisors.'' **********Karen Ceramsak, a spokesman for Eastern, said that the incentive program was intended to reward people for performing work properly and keeping on top of maintenance, not just to keep planes flying on time. There was increased pressure on the supervisors to manage, she said, ''simply because they were managing under a difficult environment. The pressure was never to disregard legitimate safety conerns.'' **********Ms. Ceramsak said that all parts of an airline, including catering and luggate-loading, contributed to on-time performance, but ''that on-time performance does not come at the expense of safety.'' **********A former Eastern foreman pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of ignoring repairs and falsifying records. He told the court that the fraud was orchestrated by his superiors. **********Eastern and nine of its maintenance supervisors and executives were indicted last week on charges that important maintenance work was routinely ignored at some airports where the carrier operates and records were then falsified to make it appear as if the work had been done. The indictment covered the period from July 1985 to October 1989. Eastern has said that it has since taken action to insure that its operations are safe. **********The Eastern employees described a situation in which top Eastern executives thought that mechanics and pilots were using complaints about maintenance and malfunctions as another way of waging their war with management. Thus the executives put enormous pressure on supervisors to keep planes flying despite complaints, and instituted the incentive program. **********Complicating the jobs of the supervisors was the fact that pilots and mechanics sometimes did use the rules to fight back. In 1987 the pilots' union even began to refuse to fly planes on which a large number of maintenance items had accumulated. **********A series of layoffs and cost-saving drives during the period covered by the indictment often left supervisors with fewer workers to handle the same number of flights. **********Report Expected **********The practice of falsifying records was apparently allowed to continue in some areas because the Federal Aviation Administration took inadequate action. A Federal prosecutor in New York is expected to issue a report criticizing certain F.A.A. officials for not acting on complaints by Eastern mechanics and pilots that repairs were being forgone and maintenance records falsified. The report will say that these officials did not act because they attributed the problems to the labor dispute at the airline and did not want to get involved, according to several people with knowledge of the report. **********The unusual report stems from the grand jury investigation that produced last week's indictment. It has been prepared by the staff of Andrew J. Maloney, the United States. Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, in Brooklyn. **********Mr. Maloney and his staff would not comment. But the existence of the report was confirmed by a member of Mr. Maloney's team and a top official of the F.A.A., according to Mike O'Connell, the president of Local 1894 of the International Association of Machinists. Mr. O'Connell had presented some of the evidence that led to the grand jury investigation. **********Fred Farrar, a spokesman for the F.A.A., said the agency did not know of the report and would not have a response ''until we find out what the man said.'' He was referring to Mr. Maloney. $12 Million in Fines The F.A.A. has repeatedly investigated Eastern for maintenance, safety and recordkeeping violations over the last three years and has imposed fines totaling more than $12 million. Mr. Maloney commended the efforts of some of the staff of the F.A.A.'s Eastern regional office at Kennedy in his investigation. **********Most of those interviewed agreed that the practices mentioned in the indictment spread across many parts of Eastern's system. **********The indictment involved Eastern's operations at Kennedy International Airport, La Guardia Airport and Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta. **********The supervisors and executives are charged with what is called ''pencil whipping'' in the industry. The indictment says they signed their own names on records for work that was not accomplished, forged the names of other employees and used fictitious names. **********Conflict With Unions **********The period in which the practices went on coincided with a period of escalating conflict between Eastern's management and its three unions -the pilots, machinists and flight attendants. It covers the last year when Frank Borman, the former astronaut, was chairman and the three years when Frank Lorenzo controlled Eastern as chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, now called Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. The airline, which filed for protection of the bankruptcy court in March 1989, was placed under the control of a court-appointed trustee, Martin Shugrue, in April. **********After a period of good relations and some profitable quarters in 1985, Eastern by early 1986 had begun to lose money and was coming under pressure from its banks, which held about $2.5 billion in debt, to win union concessions and become profitable. **********While Mr. Borman was able to secure deep cuts from the flight attendants and pilots, he failed with the machinists. The company was sold to Mr. Lorenzo's company in 1986. **********Lorenzo Team Brought In **********By October 1986 Mr. Lorenzo had taken over as chairman and brought in his own management team, including Phil Bakes, the former head of Continental Airlines, as president. **********One former Eastern pilot who monitored what happened in maintenance but did not want to be identified said that Eastern executives installed a carrot-and-stick approach. For example, a manager of maintenance at Kennedy who met the company's goals for getting airplanes out on time would get extra money. **********If the supervisors and managers failed, the pilot said, they would face enormous pressure from above, including the threat of a transfer. **********An inspection of Eastern records in Miami by a team of F.A.A. investigators that found that Eastern managers ''were allowing aircraft to be moved without adequate corrective action'' concluded that the incentive program was partly to blame. **********Guilty Plea Entered **********By The Associated Press **********A former Eastern Airlines foreman pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he ignored vital maintenance and safety repairs and then falsified records to make it appear the work had been done. **********Elia Dragone, 29 years old, of Jersey City, was the first employee of the troubled airline to plead guilty in a broad scheme that allegedly allowed unsafe airliners to fly. **********Mr. Dragone, who worked at Kennedy Airport, told a Federal District Court judge in Brooklyn that the fraud was orchestrated by his superiors at the airline. **********Named in 20 Counts **********Mr. Dragone, named in 20 counts of the indictment, pleaded guilty before Judge I. Leo Glasser to two counts -conspiracy and obstructing a Federal Aviation Administration investigation into the airline. He faces five years in prison and a $250,000 fine on each count at sentencing Oct. 17. He was allowed to remain free on his own recognizance. **********In exchange for cooperating in the investigation, the Government will dismiss the other charges against Mr. Dragone and recommend leniency in sentencing, Charles W. Gerber, an Assistant United States Attorney, said. **********According to a four-page plea agreement signed on June 18, Mr. Dragone will testify at trials against Eastern and its employees. He will also cooperate in investigations of the airline by the F.A.A. and other Government agencies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.main_headline: Asarco Fights Sale Of Freeport Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Asarco Fights Sale Of Freeport Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.body_text: **********Asarco Inc. challenged the proposed sale of the Freeport-McMoran Inc.'s gold mining subsidiary to South African-controlled Minorco S.A. In a lawsuit filed in New York Supreme Court, Asarco said its interest in a joint venture with the Freeport-McMoran unit could be violated by the sale. **********Asarco, based in New York, asked the court to halt the sale until its interests had been protected. Minorco's $17-a-share, or $705 million, offer expires on March 23. Asarco and the Freeport-McMoran unit each have a 50 percent interest in a copper mining project in Arizona. Freeport-McMoran, based in New Orleans, said it would contest the suit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   H.I.P. Uses Light Touch In Campaign
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   H.I.P. Uses Light Touch In Campaign
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/busin.body_text: **********FACED with increasing competition, the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York has begun its first television campaign in three years, an effort aimed at dispelling what it says are some common misconceptions about health maintenance organizations. **********''A lot of people think we don't offer health care that is as up-to-date and convenient as service offered by other organizations,'' said Victoria Wicks, the senior vice president for marketing at H.I.P., a nonprofit organization that provides health care through its medical centers and hospitals for a set fee. ''We want to dispel those misconceptions and give people a new image of the organization.'' **********Ms. Wicks said consumer research had found that many people thought H.I.P.'s centers were like state-run clinics, which many associated with poor medical care. Other complaints have focused on the costs of the program and an inability to choose doctors. **********One commercial uses a stylistic trick to make a point about how much money the organization has invested in improving operations. A spokeswoman is shown on half of the television screen, while the other half pictures nothing but static, as if the videotape had been cut in half. **********As she alternately disappears into the static and reappears on the good half of the commercial, the spokeswoman tells viewers that ''H.I.P. has spent so much money, $170 million buying medical equipment and beautifying our offices, we only had enough money left for half a commercial.'' **********H.I.P. hopes the campaign will attract new members and keep current members from switching to other plans. Autumn is a critical period for health-care concerns because during this period many companies offer employees the opportunity to choose a new provider. **********The job of getting and keeping members has gotten harder. For one thing, far more competition exists; the number of health maintenance organizations has risen substantially since H.I.P. went into business more than 40 years ago. More than 600 such plans are competing in the $28 billion-a-year prepaid health-care industry. **********In the last 15 years, membership in these organizations has grown rapidly. About 30 million Americans are now enrolled in these plans. But primarily because of the rising costs of the plans, enrollment has slowed significantly in the last two years. **********For the most part, the campaign created by TBWA Advertising in New York relies on humor to demonstrate to consumers that they may have the wrong impression of what H.I.P. has to offer. **********Research found that most consumers were concerned about the kind of doctors who would treat them. ''The biggest problem most people had was the fear that they would get a lousy doctor,'' said Murray Gaylord, an executive vice president at TBWA. **********One commercial, called ''Night Golf,'' shows a frustrated-looking man teeing off at night with only the headlights from his cart to light the golf course. The announcer explains, ''Doctors at H.I.P. are so dedicated to the practice of medicine, their work comes before play - but at least they can have the golf course to themselves.'' **********Another addresses the concern among consumers that they would not be allowed to choose their doctor. The spot features a man adamantly shaking his head as the announcer says, ''If your doctor at H.I.P. isn't one you like, you can choose another, or another, or another until you find a doctor you do like, for whatever reason.'' The commercial ends with the man shaking the hand of a physician who looks just like him. **********The organization took the uncharacteristicly humorous approach because the advertising for competing health-care and insurance companies usually relies on a straightforward rundown of program benefits. ''Most advertising in this category gives consumers the serious treatment,'' Ms. Wicks said. ''We're hoping this will set us apart from the competition.'' **********Ms. Wicks said she did not worry that the commercials would give viewers the false impression that H.I.P. was a frivolous organization. ''Even though we're using a lighter tone,'' she said, ''we do not treat medical care lightly.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/world.main_headline: In Desert, G.I.'s Find a Welcome Oasis: The PX
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/world.print_headline: STANDOFF IN THE GULF; In Desert, G.I.'s Find a Welcome Oasis: The PX
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/world.body_text: **********It was as if Pfc. Jason Mink had never seen a fruit cocktail before. **********"You think about fruit a lot," said Private Mink, who carried a red plastic shopping basket overflowing with more than 30 cans of fruit salad. After four months in the Arabian desert, he had clearly been left without much taste -- make that any taste -- for freeze-dried Army rations. "You dream about fruit." **********Private Mink, a lanky 20-year-old from Palatine, Ill., waited patiently in the checkout line Sunday morning, relishing his first visit to what, for the hundreds of thousands of American soldiers in Saudi Arabia, is the next best thing to a ticket home: the post office and PX, or post exchange.  'Really Gets Boring Here' **********"It just breaks the monotony," says Specialist 4 Ron Power, a 22-year-old soldier from Chandler, Ariz., who said he tries to get to the PX as often as he can to stock up on shaving supplies and Tiparillos. "It gets really boring here, just waiting for something to happen." **********The Defense Department has established several of American post exchanges across Saudi Arabia, each one part supermarket, part restaurant, part entertainment center, part town square. A small canteen that sells hamburgers and french fries is run from a trailer nearby. **********For American soldiers and airmen who are deployed here, a visit to the PX is just about the only chance they have to pretend they are someplace other than in the middle Saudi Arabia, waiting for a military clash with Iraq. **********Many travel hundreds of miles by bus to this PX in eastern Saudi Arabia. The exact location cannot be identified under military reporting rules. 'Break From the Routine' **********"So many of these men and women are restricted to their camps and aren't allowed to go into town," said Dan Bouchard, a PX manager, who arrived here recently from San Antonio. "We're their break from the routine. We're the place they come to get their beanie-weenies and a can of Coke." **********Private Mink, who said he has been in the army for "two years, one month, 15 days and a couple of hours," made it clear that his visit to the PX was among the most pleasant occasions of his stay in Saudi Arabia. **********"I'm part of an engineering unit and we're building roads and helicopter pads way out there in the desert," said Private Mink, his face a reddish brown from days under the searing sun. "You need this sort of break." **********Inside the PX, the look is distinctly that of a K-mart or a Kroger, and these shoppers clearly appreciate the comforting familiarity of American brand names, everything from Oreos to Cheez Ums, from Milky Ways to M & M's, from Gatorade to Pepsi, from Johnson & Johnson baby powder to Noxzema skin cream.  Previous Use Unclear **********Military officials say they are not quite sure what the building was used for before it was turned into a PX last summer -- perhaps a small warehouse or a factory. The building appears to be reasonably new and is perhaps a quarter of the size of a traditional American supermarket. **********"I'll have to tell my dad about this," said a young airman, pointing to a shelf jammed with hundreds of blue cans of Spam. "He used to eat this stuff in Korea. I guess it's my turn now." **********The store is decorated for the holidays, with green-and-red foil garlands drawn across the ceiling and a nearly life-size stuffed Santa Claus placed near the entrance. **********A display of Christmas cards includes a specially designed card featuring a drawing of an Army M-1 tank parked on the Saudi desert under a palm tree decorated with Christmas ornaments.  Christmas Cards for Home **********Senior Airman Michelle Argabrite, a 21-year-old from Long Beach, Calif., was picking out a Christmas card for her 11-year-old sister from a more traditional selection of cards an aisle away. "For Christmas presents I've already gotten everybody Desert Shield T-shirts," she said, referring to the Pentagon's code name for the Saudi operation. "My parents are into that stuff." **********The PX selection of T-shirts, the preferred souvenirs for the soldiers, is vast. One shirt features an American flag and the words, "These Colors Don't Run." Another describes the deployment of hundreds of thousands of American soldiers and sailors to Saudi Arabia as the "U.S. Armed Forces Summer Tour." **********Soldiers here say often that, until and unless there is a fight with Iraq, their chief adversary is unrelenting boredom. **********The PX reports that among its fastest-selling items are tape players and radios. "Anything electronic that can keep people entertained," Mr. Bouchard said. "We just keep jamming these radios and boom boxes onto the shelves as fast as we can."  Romance by Cassette **********One customer, Specialist 4 Montegus Price, a 21-year-old soldier from Roanoke, Va., said he fills long hours of idle time by making romantic tape recordings for Cheryl, his girlfriend back home. **********"Today I'm going to buy maybe three 90-minute tapes for her," he said, reaching for a handful of blank cassettes. "I talk to her on the tapes and play some songs dedicated to her -- you know, soft music, love songs." **********Around the corner from the PX, in an adjoining warehouse, is one of the 12 regional military post offices set up by the Defense Department to handle the deluge of mail to American soldiers stationed here. **********At this post office alone, "we're handling about 100,000 pounds of mail a day," said Larry Bullock, who in civilian life directs a vocational training center in Montgomery, Ala., but who, because of his enlistment in the National Guard, now finds himself as a sort of military postmaster for a large stretch of Saudi desert. **********"Short of bullets flying, mail is the most important thing going on here," Mr. Bullock said.  Complaints About the Mail **********Unhappily for Mr. Bullock, his job may be one of the most thankless ones in the military. Soldiers complain incessantly that letters are lost or misplaced. **********"It's tough," Mr. Bullock said of the complaints. "They're all talking about the one piece of mail they're missing and I'm trying to talk about the hundreds of thousands of pieces of mail I have to deal with." A letter or parcel mailed in the United States will take an average of about two weeks to reach a soldier in the field, he said. **********Military postal workers also complain about their problems. For several weeks last summer, for example, soldiers tried to mail Saudi sand home as a souvenir. **********"They just put it in an envelope, and the envelope would somehow open up and the sand was getting all over the place," said Sgt. Marvin Thomas, a 23-year-old National Guardsman from Selma, Ala. "It was a mess." **********Pvt. Christa Barclay, a 22-year-old Army supply specialist, said as she stood in line to mail a package that she had heard rumors that part of the reason for the mail delays was the flood of letters sent from the United States marked "Any Soldier."  Letters From Schoolchildren **********Many schools in the United States have encouraged students to write to "Any Soldier," and the Pentagon also initially encouraged the letters. **********"It's a nice idea, and we've got some people in our unit who don't have much family and don't get much mail," she said. **********But Private Barclay wondered whether a nice idea was getting out of hand. "I answered one of the 'Any Soldier' letters from a school kid in Indiana, and the next thing I knew I heard back from kids in four different classes in the same school," she said. "You write one letter and next thing you know you've got nine pounds of mail." **********"You feel obligated to write back to all the kids who write you," she said. "But it's impossible. We've got work to do."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/27/world.main_headline: Iraq's Aim: High Toll for G.I.'s
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/27/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; Iraq's Aim: High Toll for G.I.'s
