https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/27/world.body_text: **********The Iraqi Government has stepped up its efforts to raise the cost in casualties of any attack on its armed forces, United States military and intelligence specialists say. **********The broad outlines of Baghdad's preparations on the battlefield have emerged from the information gathered by analysts who have studied Iraqi military performance over the last decade and more recently monitored the around-the-clock satellite imagery, radar surveillance and electronic data emanating from the Persian Gulf. **********The announcement last week that Iraq is sending 250,000 more troops to join the 430,000 already deployed in Kuwait and southern Iraq is an unambiguous signal from the Baghdad Government, these specialists said, that it is determined to deter a United States-led attack by fielding a numerically superior army whose total defeat can be accomplished only through a punishing and unpredictable conflict. **********The message seems clear, they said: liberating Kuwait by force would entail a casualty count high enough to drain away support in the United States for the war. **********American military officials are counting on the technological superiority of their air and ground forces to avoid a high-casualty slugging match with Iraqi troops. And they say Iraqi soldiers' morale is open to question. **********The most recent Pentagon estimates of casualties in a full-scale conflict with Iraq over several weeks indicate that American forces could suffer several thousand dead and many times more wounded, according to Bush Administration officials. **********These sobering figures come from Pentagon and intelligence-agency reviews of Iraq's military potential and its ability to respond to an attack. **********Iraqi forces are preparing the ground in Kuwait and southern Iraq to lure United States and allied attackers into killing zones of concentrated firepower. They are erecting multiple defensive barriers to make it difficult to sweep around their forward positions and attack their elite units. They are protecting their air forces from pre-emptive strikes by hiding planes in fortified bunkers, and they have shown the ability to augment Soviet-style armored attacks with unconventional tactics and weapons.  Iraq's Military: How Strong? **********As the brinkmanship between President Saddam Hussein and the American-led international coalition demanding his unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait becomes more tense, American analysts say the key to the Iraqi leader's strategy and perhaps his political survival rests with the million-member military establishment he has ruled with uneven success since coming to power in 1969. **********"As a general statement, they are some of the Arab Middle East's best-educated troops," said Lieut. Col. Douglas V. Johnson 2d, co-author of a recently published study of the Iraqi Army for the Strategic Studies Institute of the Army War College. "They are doctrinally inclined to fighting a set-piece battle, seeking to lure enemies into prearranged killing zones." **********Iraq now has the sixth-largest military force in the world, and with this week's call up of reserves, the total of men under arms could reach as high as 1.5 million, nearly 10 percent of the country's population of 16 million. **********The Iraqi military goes to the battlefield as a Soviet-equipped ground army whose fighting ability may be retarded by declining morale among the front-line infantry troops along the border with Saudi Arabia, half of whom are poorly paid reservists who can expect to bear the initial brunt of United States and allied firepower. **********Of the 430,000 troops Mr. Hussein has now fielded, about 230,000, organized in nine divisions of mixed Army and Republican Guard forces, are elite forces whose training, readiness and motivation approximates those of first-line American combat troops, according to Defense Department officials. **********Pentagon officials said the addition of 250,000 more Iraqi troops to Mr. Hussein's combat ranks in the war zone might only add to his burden of feeding and provisioning them as a result of the United Nations trade embargo.  New Chief of Staff Draws the Plan **********A major element of Mr. Saddam's plan fell into place this month when he installed a new armed forces chief of staff, Gen. Hussein Rashid al-Wendawi, who has been credited with dramatically reversing Iraq's fortunes during the eight-year war with Iran by combing flexible defenses with innovative offensive attacks. **********Under his leadership, Defense Department officials say, well-fortified Iraqi forces today are preparing to lure American and allied attackers into killing zones in Kuwait and southern Iraq where Baghdad's firepower is concentrated. **********Mr. Hussein's relationship with his officer corps has at times been stormy and marked by mutual distrust, frequent purges and centralized control. But the failure of Iraq's war strategy against Iran five years ago convinced the Iraqi leader to cede greater authority to his field commanders, whose initiative today may reflect a willingness to accept Mr. Hussein's interpretation of the Persian Gulf conflict as a struggle between Arab nationalism and foreign imperialism. **********Iraq's battle plan, like so many in the past, may not survive contact with the enemy. **********United States and allied forces will seek to exploit Iraqi weaknesses, American officials say, by relying heavily on United States air power, night combat ability, electronic warfare and superior battlefield intelligence to surprise, stun and then encircle Iraq's Army while avoiding its heavily defended sectors as much as possible to minimize casualties.  Tactics and Arms Are Unconventional **********In recent years, Iraqi commanders have improved their Soviet-style armored attacks with more unconventional tactics. Increasingly, they have also used unconventional weapons, like chemical warheads, fuel-air explosives and medium-range ballistic missiles to terrorize their enemies. Fuel-air explosives spread a highly concussive cloud of vapor. **********Mr. Hussein has also devoted billion of dollars to a domestic arms industry. **********"The Iraqis are formidable in defense, but we must also remember that their experience is against masses of fanatical light infantry which had limited artillery or armor support and almost no air support," the authors of the Army War College study said in an unclassified summary, referring to the war against Iran. **********With an air force of about 600 modern aircraft, Iraq is the largest Arab air power, but it committed its aircraft sparingly and often ineffectively in combat during much of the war. Iraqi pilots were notorious for dropping their bombs blindly from 20,000 feet over Iranian cities to avoid air defenses. **********Still, Iraq's air commanders, equipped with some of the latest Soviet- and French-made fighters, scored some spectacular successes. On one mission in 1988, an Iraqi formation flew the length of the gulf to execute a surprise low-level bombing raid that resulted in the largest one-day toll of Iranian shipping of the war. **********The widely held view that the Iraqi Air Force will be taken off the board in the opening hours of any conflict has been questioned by senior United States Government analysts, who see Mr. Hussein as marshaling his air forces in protected bunkers and sending them aloft only to take advantage on any opportunity to surprise or pre-empt United States forces. **********"I don't think they will lose all of their airplanes right away," a Government analyst said. "They will hide in their armored shelters and we will have to keep hitting the air bases all the time." What Will Victory By the Allies Cost? **********Still, American military officials appear confident that they can defeat the Iraqi military. The question is at what cost. **********"Very few people are predicting that they are capable of defeating the United States," said a United States Government specialist on Iraq who has been advising Defense Secretary Dick Cheney since the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. "The key question is how much are they going to hurt you, and there are a lot of us who believe they could hurt us quite a lot." **********American military and intelligence analysts say Iraq is preparing for a war in which it will try to force United States and allied ground troops to fight their way through multiple defensive barriers before reaching 9 to 10 divisions of combined army and Republican Guard troops. **********These mobile forces represent the core of Iraqi military power, experts say, and Mr. Hussein will probably seek to protect them from an opening round of bombardment while drawing American ground forces deep into Kuwait and southern Iraq for what could develop as a final climactic battle. **********Iraq's military commanders understand from Western press reports that an attack will most likely be preceded by a huge bombing campaign followed by major allied ground forces attacks and amphibious landings by United States marines. American air superiority will be an key factor. Iraqis Emphasizing Defensive Barriers **********In response, the Iraqis are placing strong emphasis on static defense barriers to protect their infantry and armored divisions from air strikes. They have established forward depots well stocked with ammunition to sustain them for weeks of fighting. **********Iraq's combat engineering battalions, working with priority support from the high command, are more than eight weeks into one of the most extensive military excavation projects undertaken in desert warfare. They have erected berms, tank and artillery emplacements and dug anti-tank ditches along nearly 200 miles of border between Kuwait, Iraq and Saudi Arabia. **********The defensive line, which includes mine fields and fiery napalm traps, now extends westward beyond the Hafr el Batin area in Saudi Arabia, which is the kingdom's main military base and staging area. The extension of this modern-day Maginot Line, much like the one France built to prevent a direct German attack in World War II, will make it more difficult for United States and allied forces to sweep around Iraq's forward positions, because of the desert's expanses and poor terrain. **********Iraq's front-line forces are backed up by a formidable rear guard of mobile tank divisions. **********"The Republican Guards are very clearly the key to the battle," said the specialist advising Mr. Cheney. "You have to go to them, but first you have to break through the defenses, then you have to fight your way through the intermediate reserve before you even are ready to take them on." **********"By then you are a long way from your supply bases," he said. "They are clearly preparing for that kind of battle." **********"Will this be enough to win? No, but they don't think that either. But they sure as hell can make us pay, and they hope they can outlast us. And after they tear us up, after we have 200,000 prisoners of war, how much will we be willing to continue?"

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/27/busin.body_text: **********Unable to recover from the setbacks it suffered after taking over the Zayre discount department stores in 1988, Ames Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that it had filed for bankruptcy under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. **********Ames, the nation's fourth-largest discounter after the K Mart Corporation, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Target Stores Inc., said a sharp drop in sales in recent weeks had left it short of cash. Retail analysts said most of the drop had occurred at the nearly 400 Zayre stores. **********Ames, with 680 stores, all east of the Mississippi, was already experiencing an inventory shortage because many suppliers had balked at making new deliveries until they were paid for earlier ones. The company said that when it could not reach a new lending agreement with its banks, it decided that the most sensible next step was to seek creditor protection while it sought to reorganize itself. **********Late Wednesday Filing **********The actual bankruptcy filing took place late Wednesday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, but it was not until yesterday morning that Ames, based in Rocky Hill, Conn., outside Hartford, disclosed that it had sought protection. **********''The Chapter 11 petition will give our suppliers the assurance they need to resume the steady flow of merchandise into our stores,'' said Peter B. Hollis, Ames's chief executive. **********Trading was halted on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in Ames's stock, which rose 12.5 cents, to $1.50, on Wednesday. Last year, Ames traded at a high of $20 a share. **********Ames also said yesterday that Chemical Bank in New York had agreed to provide $250 million in interim financing. While the retailer did not say so explicitly, the indications were that Ames would use the money to get new merchandise and to meet expenses like payroll, rent and utilities. **********By meeting those daily obligations, the analysts said, Ames could continue operating all its stores while it began the arduous process of working with creditors to restructure its finances. **********''It will be business as usual,'' said a banker who has done business with Ames. ''They will pay their employees and open the registers.'' **********The Zayre troubles were also a big reason for Ames's announcement several weeks ago that it expected to report a loss of $228 million for the fiscal year that ended on Jan. 27. **********As retail experts told it yesterday, that announcement touched off a chain of events. First, Ames's lenders declared the retailer in default on certain debt covenants. Next, so-called retail factoring companies, which guarantee a merchant's payments, stopped extending credit to Ames. Finally, many suppliers stopped making shipments, fearful that they might not be paid. **********In fact, the bankruptcy will leave several well-known suppliers with unpaid bills. Among them are American Yard Products Inc., the big lawn-mower company, which is owed $7.6 million; the Thermos Company, owed $5.2 million; the Sara Lee Corporation, due $3.9 million; Rubbermaid Inc., owed $4.5 million, and the Gitano Group Inc., the sportswear maker, due $5.3 million. **********Gitano, based in New York, said it would reduce its first-quarter earnings by about 10 cents a share in anticipation that it would not be paid for the Ames shipments. **********But retailing experts said big changes loomed for Ames, which with $4 billion in sales was once regarded as one of the best-run retailers in America. **********Kurt Barnard, an industry consultant who also publishes a retailing newsletter from New York, predicted yesterday that Ames would seek to undo its October 1988 acquisition of Zayre. He said Ames might sell off hundreds of the Zayre stores and refocus on the Ames discount stores, which had been performing well. **********Mr. Barnard said that possible buyers for the Zayre stores included Target, a division of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, and Wal-Mart. **********''A Target might pick up a store here or a store there,'' he said. ''But a discount-department operation will not reach out and buy the whole cluster. It's too risky.'' **********Quick Sales Seen **********Howard Davidowitz, the chairman of Davidowitz & Associates, another New York-based retailing consultant, said Ames would move even more quickly than Mr. Barnard suggested. **********He said the company might close 200 to 300 stores with going-out-of-business sales. That would allow Ames, he said, ''to get out of bad stores and to have less funding requirements because they won't have to finance the inventory in these bad stores.'' **********Ames's troubles seem easily traced to its $778 million purchase of Zayre, its largest acquisition. Although the takeover appeared to be a good fit, because Zayre had a good name and excellent locations that had little overlap with Ames, the retail experts said Ames managed to make a weak chain even weaker by committing several strategic blunders. **********For example, Ames sharply reduced the number of weekly Zayre mail circulars to which shoppers were accustomed. Ames changed the name of the Zayre stores to Ames, even though Ames is not well known outside its New England base. Ames also redirected Zayre's merchandise toward basic apparel rather than the inexpensive but fashionable clothing that had always been a draw for Zayre customers. **********The results were disastrous. Under Ames, sales at individual Zayre stores fell by 15 percent last fall from a year ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/23/busin.main_headline: Mutual Funds;   Cleaning Up on the Ground Floor
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/23/busin.print_headline: Mutual Funds;   Cleaning Up on the Ground Floor
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/23/busin.body_text: **********If Donna Dempsey Calder were to crack open a Chinese fortune cookie, the message would probably read, ''Get in on the ground floor.'' That's how she managed her career, and how, as manager of the $55 million Oppenheimer Discovery Fund, she picks her stocks. **********Ms. Calder, a rising star among fund managers, has built a spectacular record since 1986, when she took over the Discovery Fund, an aggressive growth fund investing mainly in small-company stocks. She beat Standard & Poor's 500-stock index by 2 to 8 percentage points from 1987 to 1989, no mean feat in a time when the volatile small-company sector mostly lagged the market. **********Things have soured a bit in 1990 - so far this year, the fund is down 13.8 percent while other small-company growth funds have declined 11.3 percent. But given the sector she manages, some slippage was inevitable. It has not tarnished her solid reputation. **********''It's too early to say that she's another Peter Lynch, but she's definitely on the short list,'' said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc., Chicago-based mutual fund consultants, referring to the legendary, recently retired, Fidelity money manager. **********Although she usually keeps just 5 percent of her holdings in cash, her bearishness has pushed that up to 32 percent, making cash the largest single holding in her portfolio. She has not bought any stocks since June - she believes the market has not yet bottomed out - and has whittled down her holdings to two main groups: energy (20 percent) and biotechnology (14 percent.) Another big part of her portfolio - 25 percent - is in special situation stocks, which she thinks will shine because of unique circumstances. Her other holdings are a mix of stocks. **********From her paper-strewn office in the World Trade Center, the 39-year-old Ms. Calder also manages Oppenheimer's $300 million Time Fund, which invests mainly in large-capitalization growth stocks. In both, she looks for companies that are ''relatively undiscovered by Wall Street, that have a new product or niche, or a special franchise that lets them grow at double-digit rates.'' She often shops at initial public offerings. **********''I watch speculative demand surge and then wane; when it gets excessive, I try to get out of the way before the crash,'' she said. She likes to buy stocks with a price-earnings multiple equal to or less than three-quarters of a company's growth rate. **********The sector she finds most exciting is biotechnology. She said that investments made by the industry in the 1980's are now bearing fruit, and the economic downturn has not yet affected stock prices. She particularly likes Home Nutritional Services, a Parsippany, N.J.-based health-care company, which she expects will grow 30 percent annually over the next two to three years. She also likes the Chiron Corporation, of Emerysville, Calif., which develops diagnostic tests and vaccines. **********Her other big emphasis - energy - hurt the fund in early 1990, but it should help now. Favorites include McDermott International, in New Orleans, and Snyder Oil, in Fort Worth. **********In her ''special situation'' category, she likes the Adolph Coors Company. It had trouble bringing its beer to the Northeast last year, but has succeeded with its new, nationally marketed Keystone beer, Ms. Calder said. She predicts its stock price will rise to $30 in the next year from the low $20's now. **********Ms. Calder's road to Wall Street was anything but direct. She alternated college semesters with forays through Europe and the American West, graduating at the age of 24, with a degree in education, from the University of Vermont. Although she received job offers from several New York City private schools, the low salaries turned her toward Wall Street and she become a secretary to a money manager at Mitchell Hutchins, later acquired by Paine Webber. **********Her on-the-job training there led her to apply for a money manager's job at E.F. Hutton. Told she didn't have enough experience, she challenged Hutton to try her out - and it did. A year later, she moved to Oppenheimer and worked her way up from research assistant to portfolio manager. **********She consults with three outside technical analysts weekly, studies stock charts and analyzes trends. When the story is sweet but the charts are sour, she holds back. And she's not afraid to bail out. But she has had bad calls, such as Tandem Computer this year. ''I got blasted,'' she said. She held a big chunk of Tandem stock but did not foresee sharp earnings shortfalls. **********What will she do when the market turns? She plans to stick a strategy that has held her in good stead over the years: ''I try to identify groups or sectors that will do well over the next 18 months to two years, and then pick the best four or five companies in the group.'' **********AVOIDING THE 12b-1 PENALTY **********Tired of paying 12b-1 fees? Shop around. **********According to Lipper Analytical Services Inc., 41.1 percent of the money in mutual funds this summer was subject to 12b-1 fees. Those fees are skimmed off fund assets each year to pay for marketing expenses. **********Some fund categories are more likely than others to levy 12b-1 fees, so pick carefully. The taxable bond group, for example, has more assets subject to 12b-1 fees than other fund groups. That's because starting a fund - and building a 12b-1 fee into it - is easier than asking shareholders to approve new fees. And many of the new funds on the market are taxable bond funds, which are being sold by big brokerages, said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper. Big brokerages often rely on 12b-1 fees to pay brokers to push funds. **********Least likely to charge 12b-1 fees are tax-free bond funds. For years, they have been sold by independent mutual fund companies rather than by large brokerage firms.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/05/busin.body_text: **********The Government announced today that it had reached an agreement with the major creditors of Charles H. Keating Jr.'s American Continental Corporation on a settlement that would provide for partial payment of claims by some holders of the company's subordinated debentures, as well as removal of senior management, including Mr. Keating. **********The proposed settlement pertains to the lawsuit surrounding the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing by American Continental, which sought protection from creditors in April of last year in Phoenix. Until then it was the parent company of Mr. Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. Lincoln was taken over by the Government shortly after American Continental's bankruptcy filing last year. Mr. Keating remains chairman of American Continental. **********Government officials said the proposed settlement does not affect their billion racketeering and fraud case against Mr. Keating and other American Continental officials. It also does not affect the court challenge by Mr. Keating of the Government's takeover of Lincoln. **********Today's action does allow the Government direct management over almost a dozen of Lincoln subsidiaries that were put into bankruptcy by Mr. Keating last year, effectively keeping them out of the hands of regulators.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/22/busin.main_headline: Wall Street;   The Dubious Profits in Patriotism
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/22/busin.print_headline: Wall Street;   The Dubious Profits in Patriotism
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/22/busin.body_text: **********PATRIOTISM may be the last refuge of scoundrels, but it is often the first choice of companies seeking the ear of the investing public. Consider the case of American Spirit Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif. **********American Spirit is a tiny over-the-counter company that is affiliated with the American Spirit Foundation, a nonprofit organization whose stated goals include the commemoration of America's political heritage. **********The corporation's principal tangible assets are two original bronze monuments, weighing a total of nearly 30 tons, that commemorate the bicentennials of the United States Constitution and the American Presidency. It also owns the copyrighted etchings used to produce exact bronze replicas of the Constitution itself, suitable for mounting in schools and libraries. American Spirit, in short, is a company whose products conjure up phrases like ''We, the people'' and ''E pluribus unum.'' **********A more apt phrase for investors might be ''caveat emptor.'' According to audit reports on file at the Securities and Exchange Commission, this company - whose shares are quoted by brokers at $3.75 if you want to buy them and $3 if you try to sell - is so short of capital that its survival is in doubt. And its chief assets, those two bronze monuments, have been pledged as collateral for loans due at the end of this month. **********As S.E.C. documents go, the filings by American Spirit are in a class by themselves. The catalog of exhibits include cameo appearances by President Bush, who signed a letter last November endorsing the display of the bronze documents in schools; former President Reagan, who dedicated one of the company-owned monuments at a ceremony in 1987; and former Chief Justice Warren Burger, the chairman of the Commission on the Bicentennial of the Constitution, which has extended its official recognition to certain projects of the affiliated American Spirit Foundation. **********Among the leading players is Brett-Livingstone Strong, the Australian artist who created the plaques and statuary. (Mr. Strong is perhaps better known for his portrait of the performer Michael Jackson and his bust of John Wayne, chisled into a Malibu Beach boulder.) The company's chairman and largest shareholder is Jeffory Fairbrother, an Australian businessman. Over the last year, Mr. Fairbrother has been involved in a series of deals that left his new company with these new art works and him with four million restricted shares of the company's stock, for which he paid $800, or one-fiftieth of a cent per share. **********The corporate assets have already had a slice of stardom. A four-page bronze replicaof the Constitution rode on floats in the Rose Bowl Parade, the Liberty Day celebration in Philadelphia, and the P. T. Barnum Festival parade, reported Peter F. Paul, the president of the American Spirit Foundation. And the Constitution memorial was the centerpiece at the inaugural ball for Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia in January. **********The nonprofit foundation, Mr. Paul said, was formed in May 1989. Its relationship with the publicly traded corporation is a little vague: The company's S.E.C. filing shows that it pays for Mr. Paul's salary and the foundation's office space, while Mr. Paul described the company simply as ''one of our sponsors'' and ''the exclusive supplier'' of the bronze plaques that figure in one of the foundation's projects. **********On Friday, Mr. Fairbrother said the company's report to the S.E.C. was ''not exactly accurate. We make a nominal and regular contribution to the foundation,'' he said, ''but we don't pay directly any salaries. They are independent. There will be an amendment to that effect, in due course.'' **********The plaque project calls for the foundation to enlist donors whose tax-deductible contributions - $6,000 per Constitution - will be used to place these bronze replicas in schools and other public locations. Then the foundation will buy the plaques from the corporation for $4,000 per set, or about $2,300 more than the plaques cost the company to produce. Proceeds from plaque sales are envisioned as the company's chief source of revenue. **********Aside from plaque sales, the company's only other source of income is the sale of stock through the exercise of warrants, which Mr. Fairbrother said has produced ''at least $300,000'' in fresh cash from investors since the date of the S.E.C. report last March. Although plaque sales have been skimpy so far, great things are promised by Mr. Fairbrother in recent company news releases. **********Meanwhile, the company's assets, while carried on the books as of March 16 at $8 million, are obviously not very liquid. (It is true that other epic works by Mr. Strong have found buyers - his portrait of Michael Jackson was sold recently to a Japanese tycoon for $2.1 million. But Mr. Paul said the foundation has ''equitable'' rights that prevent the company from selling the bronzes to the highest bidder. The plan, he said, is for the foundation to find donors to buy the bronzes and donate them to the American people.) The company's obligations, however, appear pressing. It owes $850,000 to the National Australia Bank, secured by the Presidency monument, and an additional $110,000 to a Los Angeles lawyer named Jerome Wank, a company shareholder. That note is secured by the Monument to the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution. Both loans are due on July 31, and, as of the company's March report to the S.E.C., the company did not have the money to repay those loans. **********Mr. Fairbrother insists that the monuments are not at risk, however. Mr. Wank agreed on Thursday to extend his note, the chairman said, and the company is now negotiating with the bank. Besides, he said, ''These are magnificent works of art and there is no way that the bank or Mr. Wank would set about trying to collect on them.'' **********Accepting collateral that one would never dream of seizing to satisfy a unpaid debt would seem to defeat the purpose of having collateral at all. But Mr. Fairbrother is confident that these credit problems will soon be history. ''This is a wonderful project,'' he said. ''We've got great prospects.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/busin.main_headline: Sound Becomes the New Frontier for TV Ads
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Sound Becomes the New Frontier for TV Ads
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/busin.body_text: **********A new Coca-Cola commercial probably has some television viewers thinking they are hearing things. At one point during the spot, chirping birds seemingly can be heard flying overhead while the wind whistles through the living room. **********The illusion in the Coke spot is created by a new three-dimensional stereophonic technology called Q-Sound, which makes recorded sounds seem to be coming from different parts of a room. Coke is the first to use it and is one of a growing number of advertisers relying on sound to make their commercials stand out. **********''Sound is the new creative frontier,'' said Paul Cappelli, a group creative director for McCann-Erickson Worldwide, which created the Coke spot. ''The visual part of commercials has reached its creative limits.'' **********Creative Innovations **********New sound technology is now being used to make creative innovations in commercials much the same way that advertising agencies made use of new videotaping and editing techniques developed for music videos in the early 1980's. **********Increasingly, commercials are using special effects created by computerized sound synthesizers, electronic musical scores and other sound enhancers. Some commercials have even made the sound the star -with not a single word from an announcer. **********''As consumers become increasingly sophisticated, it becomes harder to keep them entertained,'' said Gordon Bowen, a creative director at Ogilvy & Mather. ''Sound is the newest way to get them to pay attention.'' **********As a result, business is booming for sound production houses. There are now 200 production companies, most of which are in New York. About 10 years ago there were only several dozen. A sound specialist's handiwork can cost as little as $1,500 for a simple treatment or more than $25,000 for elaborate effects. And for new techniques like Q-Sound, experts say the price will be even higher. Ahead of Its Time?  But Q-Sound may be ahead of its time. The impact of the new Coke commercial was limited because the effect of 3-D sound can only be heard by people with stereo televisions; only 19 percent of American households have such sets. **********Q-Sound, which was developed by Canadian-based Archer Communicaions Inc., is a computerized sound-mixing process in which the voices, instruments and other elements of a recording are separated and then programmed to be heard from various locations. **********For example, the roar of a jet can be made to sound as if it is coming from above the listener and the babble of a brook as if it is at his feet. **********Like regular stereo, 3-D sound has its limitations. To get the desired effect, the listener must be sitting directly in front of the speakers. Nonetheless, Mr. Cappelli said, the agency intends to use Q-Sound in more commercials. **********Virtually Limitless Uses **********In contrast, the use of synthesized sound is virtually limitless. By using a computerized synthesizer, a sound engineer can recreate thousands of sounds, from the blare of a trumpet to the crash of two cars colliding. **********Synthesized sound has become commonplace in commercials during the last few years. ''You don't have to send out for the real sounds of the instruments or the voices you need,'' said John Silverman, president of J.S.M. Music, a production company. ''The computer has a library of thousands of sounds.'' **********The process is also less expensive than hiring musicians, and a musical score can be quickly changed. ''I was recently in the middle of finishing a sound track when the agency called and changed everything,'' said Don Piestrup, who heads Piece of Cake, a music production company. ''Within 20 minutes, I'd completely changed the sound track.'' **********Synthesizers have enabled advertising agencies to create commercials with startling effects. A spot for Goodyear Auto Services, for example, featured a series of quick shots of people having car trouble, accompanied by a raucous chorus of anvils, bells, drums and even the pneumatic wrench used by auto mechanics. **********The intensity of the sounds was multiplied by the synthesizer so that even though it was not any louder than the usual commercial, it would startle an unsuspecting audience. **********In another spot, for Levi Strauss, synthesized human voices were used like a musical score. Michael Montes, a sound engineer at J.S.M. Music, used a computer to slow the voices down, speed them up and stretch words out to impossible lengths as they sang the praises of jeans. **********Sound as the Focal Point **********In some recent commercials, the sound has been the focal point. A recent spot for Volvo, for example, zeroed in on the eerie synthesized version of the sound the car made as it sped along the highway. **********''You can only catch people's attention by creating something their ears aren't accustomed to,'' said Jeanne Neary, a partner at Look & Company, a sound production house. **********For all its flexiblity, the sound of computer-generated musical instruments can not match the quality of the real thing. So some sound specialists are adding real instruments to synthesized scores. **********''The actual sound of a violin or a saxophone is the only way to get the right emotional impact from music,'' said Scott Elias, the founder of Elias Associates, a production company. **********A Silent Commercial **********Someone, of course, always goes against the trend. For example, Bartle, Bogle, Hegarty, a London advertising agency, decided that less sound equals more impact. It recently created a commercial for a Sony compact disk player in which the only sound is the ring of a doorbell. **********In it, a man on a bare white set performs a pantomime. Soon after his imaginary girlfiend arrives at his apartment, they begin to dance and then romance. The imaginary girlfriend finally pulls the man off into the bedroom. **********''It's meant to be odd - to make people stop, look and try to listen,'' said Oliver Lewis-Barclay, an account executive at the agency.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/busin.body_text: **********A top Federal regulator ordered commercial bank officers today to correct promptly ''a significant number of fundamental deficiencies'' in their real estate lending operations. **********The Comptroller of the Currency, Robert L. Clarke, in a strongly worded memorandum addressed to board members and chief executives at 4,200 nationally chartered banks, pointed to three areas for criticism. **********First, ''basic lending principles have been ignored or compromised to increase volume and achieve higher levels of interest and fee income,'' Mr. Clarke said. In particular, banks are not requiring borrowers to invest enough of their own money in real estate projects. **********Second, ''too many banks have failed to obtain accurate, independent and timely appraisals'' of the real estate projects to which they are lending, he said. **********Also, some banks are engaging in practices that make it difficult to determine when a real estate project is going bad, he said. These were said to include inflating the loan amount so borrowers can cover the interest payments in the early years of the loan and operating with incomplete or nonexistent foreclosure policies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/28/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Avon Calls Off Adviser Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/28/busin.body_text: **********Avon Products Inc. said it was no longer negotiating with John P. Rochon, who had been chosen by an investor group that owns about 17 percent of Avon to study the cosmetic company's operations. Earlier this year, Avon avoided a proxy fight with the investor group, Chartwell Associates, by agreeing to form a special committee of its board that would hire Mr. Rochon as a consultant. **********Mr. Rochon said Avon wanted him to report to James E. Preston, its chief executive, rather than to the committee. Chartwell says that arrangement is unacceptable. Mr. Rochon is vice chairman of the Mary Kay Corporation, which is both an Avon competitor and a member of Chartwell. John F. Cox, Avon's senior vice president of communications, said, ''The agreement for Mr. Rochon to serve as a consultant was conditioned on his severing all his ties with Mary Kay.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Emigres;   Armenians in U.S. Say the People of the Homeland Are in Danger, but What Can Be Done?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Emigres;   Armenians in U.S. Say the People of the Homeland Are in Danger, but What Can Be Done?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/world.body_text: **********Khachatur Nagapityan, a track and field coach, came here from Soviet Armenia just two years ago, but he is ready to return whenever he is needed to fight for what he sees as his people's survival. **********''It happened once before, in 1915, and now history is being repeated,'' he said, referring to the mass killings of Armenian civilians by the Ottoman Turks during World War I. Now, like many other Armenians and Armenian-Americans here, he was showing his helplessness and frustration after scores of his countrymen were reported killed last week in a dispute with Soviet Azerbaijanis. **********''I am always calling but always it is busy, busy,'' he said. ''I am ready to help any way I can and if necessary of course I'll go.'' **********Word of Pogroms **********Mr. Nagapityan was discussing the news from home with other Armenians gathered around the counter at Taslakian's pastry shop, one of a cluster of Armenian shops and offices here. **********Hollywood and nearby Glendale have become the fastest-growing Armenian communities in the country, fed by immigration from the Soviet Union. Altogether, more than 200,000 Armenians are believed to live in the Los Angeles area, the greatest concentration outside Soviet Armenia. **********Other major centers are Fresno, in central California, and Watertown, Mass., as well as dozens of other communities scattered across the country. **********In all of them, said Garen Yegparian, a leader of the Armenian National Committee, a sense of desperation and helplessness has grown since the Soviet Government reported last week that anti-Armenian pogroms in the Azerbaijani capital, Baku, and clashes elsewhere in Azerbaijan had claimed scores of lives. **********A People in Danger **********The subsequent Soviet crackdown to restore order, in which scores of Azerbaijanis have been killed, has not eased the Armenians' fear that their people and nation are in danger. **********''I'm telling you, it's perceived as a matter of national collective survival,'' Mr. Yegparian said. ''We are facing the most important moment since 1915.'' **********It is a sentiment echoed by many Armenians here, including a leading historian, Richard G. Hovannisian, professor of Near Eastern and Armenian history at the University of California, Los Angeles. **********For the past two years ethnic violence has troubled Azerbaijan, which borders the republic of Armenia. Thousands of Armenians have recently been evacuated from Azerbaijan, fueling a sense here that Armenians are being progressively driven from their homes. Medicine or Guns?  ''There is a tremendous sense of frustration,'' said Mr. Yegparian, whose organization handles external relations for a leading Armenian political group, the Armenian Revolutionary Federation. ''Everyone wants to do something but it is not clear what we can do to help.'' **********''We are getting dozens of calls every day,'' he said. ''The community newspapers are getting calls. Let's do a demo. Let's do this. Let's do that. Everybody has an idea but nobody knows how we can be most effective.'' **********Osheen Keshishian, editor of The Armenian Observer, based in Glendale, said he was host of a telethon last month to raise funds for Armenia, where a devastating earthquake struck in December 1988. ''We got a lot of calls saying, 'Instead of sending food and medicine, let's send guns and ammunition,' '' he said. **********''We don't know what to do. It's awful.'' **********Both he and Mr. Yegparian said there was talk among young men of going to join the fight but little sign here that such talk might be turning serious. **********First the Quake, Now This **********They said, however, that an Armenian organization in France had sent word that a group of men were leaving this week to join the fight. **********Armenians are already involved in relief efforts as a result of the 1988 earthquake, which left as many as a half million people homeless. Now, said Professor Hovannisian, ''thousands of refugees from Azerbaijan are coming in and straining resources even more.'' **********Standing amid stacks of sticky pastries, sweet halvah and multi-tiered wedding cakes, the men and women gathered at Taslakian's pastry shop spoke of home in a patchwork of English, Armenian and Russian. **********On the street outside, alongside Yerevan Travel, Arakelian's Grocery and the Dr. Abdoyan Family Dentistry, were signs of the American patchwork these immigrants now inhabit: the Manila Philippine Barber Shop, the Chan Chao Thai Restaurant and the Panderia Salvadorena. **********A Crossroads People **********In their homeland, the mix and clash of cultures has much deeper roots. **********Armenia, regarded by historians as the first state to become Christian, has been a crossroads for the world's great powers including the Greeks, Persians, Romans, Arabs, Turks and Russians, Mr. Yegparian said. **********The mainly Shiite Muslim Azerbaijanis are the descendants of Turks who entered the area about 1,000 years ago, and the current conflict involves long-running nationalist, religious and territorial disputes. **********''God grant that it will not be war,'' said Stepan Kotugyan, a television editor who recently moved here from Armenia, standing with a small parcel in the pastry shop. **********''Yesterday I got a call from Yerevan saying everything is O.K.,'' said Lusik Apikyan, who has been here seven years. ''But then we hear on the news it is not O.K. When people listen every day they are crying. They want to go back and fight.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/05/world.main_headline: Soviet Union;   In Minsk, the Candidates of Dissent Stand Up to a Bare-Knuckled Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/05/world.print_headline: Soviet Union;   In Minsk, the Candidates of Dissent Stand Up to a Bare-Knuckled Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/05/world.body_text: **********The candidate had been well smeared by broadsides stuffed at the last minute into the mailboxes of the tenement warrens of Communism in the dawn of Election Day in Byelorussia. **********As he raced floor to floor through the tenements, trying to set the record right, Gennadi I. Grushevoy rang doorbells, begging surprised, suspicious people at their partly open doorways to ask him questions about the truth. **********''I've come to tell the truth, comrades,'' he said, frantically trying to protect his reputation from the handbills' allegations of Nazism, and to shield his insurgent's campaign from defeat at the hands of the local Communist Party. **********For all the Soviet political dissidents' pain and struggle, this Election Day was encouraging for them in making clear the party's deepening desperation in its attempt to stay alive and dominant. **********Fears of Trickery **********In the Byelorussian republic, run by perhaps the most resistant and formidable party machine, voters could witness fledgling, stunted democracy forcing a perversely encouraging phenomenon into Soviet politics: the opposition was putting poll watchers on guard in large numbers against widely held fears of vote corruption by the government itself. **********''We expect the party is resorting to widespread fraud,'' said Zyanon Paznyak, a leader of the insurgent Popular Front of Byelorussia, who likened the party to a cornered animal thrashing dangerously. **********''These fights can only make us stronger,'' he said, accusing the provincial police and others of trying to interfere with the poll watchers. But he said they were determined to witness any shaved totals, invented voters, even ballots cast from the graveyard - the nefarious stuff of established democracies that heretofore had been unnecessary in the 98-percent landslides of the party's old monopoly victories. **********'The Power of Words' **********''We are just learning what democracy is,'' said Mikhail Tkachev, a candidate and deputy chairman of the Popular Front. ''We are fighting for it against a bare-faced 'partocracy,' and believe me, it is not easy. But we are doing it without bloodshed. We believe in the power of words.'' **********As voters went to the ballot box across the Slavic heart of the nation in the Ukraine and Russian republics as well as here, no Communist Party was putting up a more head-on fight, declining to pander to or flirt with the opposition as in other regions. In the last two months the bosses of the Byelorussian machine used every rule and more in the party-scripted official election law to try to keep serious challengers from the voting lists. **********For weeks, patronage loyalists in government jobs repeatedly ruled opposition candidates in violation for the size of their crowds, the form of their nominations, the provenance of their pamphlets. Dozens of volunteers distributing opposition platforms were arrested. **********Moves and Countermoves **********But the opposition was only more emboldened. The Popular Front, denied republic registration to print its own pamphlets, trucked in anti-party tracts printed in the more sympathetic Baltic republics. Imaginative young nationalists wheeled a funeral urn right up to the government center as a convenience into which loyalists were invited to face the future and ''throw away your party cards.'' **********The party finally reacted to such stings by having its stalwarts in the republic parliament pass an outright ban, two days after the ballots were set, on voters' selecting any candidates of the most challenging insurgent groups running under the banners of the Popular Front, the Society for the Byelorussian Language and the Ecological Union. **********At this, the public rebelled and demonstrated peacefully a week ago, even spontaneously seizing broadcast time on the party-controlled television station to accuse the party of gross abuse of the democratic process. The party finally retracted the ban after the opposition prepared to complain directly to the United Nations. **********'The Big Cheeses Must Hide' **********''Now the big cheeses must hide in the farthest boondocks,'' exulted Valery Saveklov, a worker at the Popular Front, referring to the fact that the republic's embattled party chief, Yefrem Sokolov, and others have shied from a city candidacy to run for the parliament in an obscure, supposedly safer rural district. The government gave two new tractors to the local farm collective, but the insurgents were saying the bribery was no match for their corps of poll watchers dispatched to the village for the occasion. **********Ivan I. Lipsky came into the front's headquarters Friday night with a black eye, a swollen nose and a big smile, certain that the thugs who had set upon him as he campaigned were emissaries from a desperate party apparat. **********''The party has ignored all the laws about fairness and packed the press with lies,'' he said, describing the insurgents' handicaps. ''All the party people in my neighborhood were given a day off to deliver pamphlets while the rest of us had to work. You cannot have true pluralism until we have a fair election law.'' **********A Legacy From Chernobyl **********The party has denied the charges of pervasive fraud and claimed its practices were fair and according to law -a law dictated by the party through the Communist-dominated republic parliament, the 360-member chamber the insurgents are challenging in today's vote. **********''Only people with strong nerves, the fighters, made it this far,'' said Pyotr v. Sadovsky, a candidate, Popular Front leader and author of some of the most articulate demands aroused by the Byelorussian public's escalating fears about the Chernobyl nuclear plant explosion four years ago. **********Most of the radiation clouds drifted onto Byelorussian farm communities, and the villages are still being haphazardly evacuated, residents complain, by an all too secretive Government. **********''A year from now we will have caught up with the democratic progress of the Baltics,'' Mr. Paznyak contended, noting that the popular front was less than a year old and was proscribed by the government, yet was giving the party a fight in which, by some estimates, insurgent candidates might take half the seats in the parliament. **********An Insurgent Agenda **********Mr. Paznyak looked ahead to an insurgent parliamentary agenda that will include the thorough disestablishment of the party from government, a move to a market economy rather than the dictated plan of the national government, and the first steps toward an economic confederation of like-minded reform governments that insurgents say will sooner or later come to power in the Soviet Baltics and the Ukraine. **********Such plans seemed well beyond the tenement horizon as Mr. Grushevoy anxiously rang voters' doorbells to respond to the handbill that smeared him as a Nazi sympathizer. Listeners at the doorways soon were agreeing that he was the victim of another ham-handed Communist tactic. **********''Seventy years of Communism and we're still standing on our knees,'' one pensioner boomed out as other apartment dwellers watched more silently, unused to such uninhibited cries of foul on a Communist election day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/04/busin.body_text: **********Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the British information services company, said on Monday that it would seek shareholder approval to buy back up to 10 percent of its stock and increase its borrowing power. **********Reuters said shareholders will vote on the proposals at a special meeting to be held immediately after the annual shareholders meeting April 26. **********The company said the approval to buy up to 10 percent of its stock will expire at the 1991 annual shareholders meeting. Reuters has 431.1 million shares outstanding. **********It is seeking to increase its borrowing power to 2.5 times its adjusted capital and reserves, up from 2 times capital and reserves. The company would effectively be raising its borrowing limits to $:1.02 billion, or $1.7 billion, from $:817 million. **********The Reuters chairman, Sir **********Christopher Hogg, said the company had surplus cash and no significant long-term debt. **********He said there were no plans for major acquisitions or borrowings, but that the ''authority to increase borrowings is desirable to enable Reuters to take full advantage of major investment opportunities that might arise.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/28/busin.body_text: **********The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday reduced the debt ratings of two large military contractors, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the General Dynamics Corporation. Moody's Investors Service also cut the ratings of McDonnell Douglas. **********Citing potential cost overruns on certain McDonnell Douglas projects, S.&P. lowered the company's senior debt to BBB+ from A-, its subordinated debt to BBB from BBB+, and its Rule 415 shelf-registration senior debt to preliminary BBB+ from preliminary A-. **********Debt ratings of the McDonnell **********Douglas Finance Corporation remain on Creditwatch with negative implications. McDonnell Douglas and its subsidiary have a combined debt of about $5.2 billion. **********Moody's lowered the commercial paper of McDonnell Douglas to Prime-3 from Prime-2, its senior debt rating to Baa-3 from Baa-1, and its subordinated debt rating to Ba-2 from Baa-2. Moody's said it had cut the ratings because of the contractor's ''difficulties in its commercial aircraft operations, and the deteriorating outlook for its defense business.'' **********S.&P. cut the senior debt of **********General Dynamics to A, from A+, and its subordinated debt to A-, from A. About $610 million of long-term debt is affected. S.&P. cited potential cost overruns and cutbacks on the company's projects as the reason for the reduction.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/16/busin.main_headline: G.M. to Export Cars to Yugoslavia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; G.M. to Export Cars to Yugoslavia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/16/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation will begin exporting a small number of Chevrolet, Pontiac and Cadillac cars to Yugoslavia beginning early next year, the auto maker said. The initial order is for 450 1991 Chevrolet Corsica, Cadillac Sedan DeVille and Pontiac Grand Prix and Bonneville cars. The order was to be signed on Friday in a ceremony at G.M. headquarters here. **********G.M. also has agreements to establish vehicle and component assembly operations in other Eastern Euopean countries, including Hungary, Czechoslovakia, the Soviet Union and the former East Germany. The Yugoslavian-bound cars will go to Y.K., a vehicle distributor located in Sarajevo. "Our target is to sell 1,000 vehicles next year from the Sarajevo dealership," said Y.K. president's, Sead Dizdarevic.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/01/busin.body_text: **********Northwest Airlines, the carrier owned by NWA Inc., said it would invest $422 million in the next five years to upgrade its service. Frederic V. Malek, president of the carrier, which was acquired last year by a group headed by Alfred A. Checchi, said four areas would be worked on: performance, cleanliness, trouble-free customer experience and employee attitude. It is generally accepted that Northwest's service suffered greatly after it merged with Republic Airlines several years ago. The carrier has been working to recover from that image since then.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/19/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   3 Admit to Vandalism At a French Cemetery
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/19/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   3 Admit to Vandalism At a French Cemetery
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/19/world.body_text: **********The authorities said today that three neo-Nazi skinheads had admitted to desecrating a Roman Catholic cemetery near Rennes in western France last Wednesday night. **********Law-enforcement officials said the skinheads had painted slogans to foment anti-Jewish sentiment by making it look as if Jews were getting even for the desecration of graves in a Jewish cemetery at Carpentras last week. The slogans included ''Carpentras Will Be Avenged'' and ''Death to Le Pen,'' a reference to Jean-Marie Le Pen, leader of the far-right National Front. **********Law-enforcement authorities said they had no strong leads about who committed the desecrations at Carpentras, where a corpse was dug up and mutilated. Prime Minister Michel Rocard said he had ordered 60 extra detectives to work on the case. **********The police in Montpellier, in southern France, said they had arrested two young men for drawing racist slogans and swastikas on posters advertising marches to protest anti-Semitism.
