https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/18/world.main_headline: Iraqi General Says a U.S. Attack Is Doomed to Fail
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/18/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; Iraqi General Says a U.S. Attack Is Doomed to Fail
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/18/world.body_text: **********A top Iraqi general said today that the American-led military force in the gulf would face "uncalculated developments" if it launched an attack to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait -- developments that would doom the attack to failure. **********The warning came from Maj. Gen. Mundhir Abdul-Rahman, a missile expert and the head of the Iraqi Army's morale and guidance department. **********It was difficult to determine whether the general was speaking in his capacity as a specialist in long-range weaponry or as the chief booster of military morale. **********In an article in Al-Qadissiya, the army's daily newspaper, General Abdul-Rahman questioned the value of Western air superiority if the aim was to take Iraqi territory. He said his country was prepared to defend itself despite plans by the United States to increase troop strength.  Report on Superguns **********The general's warning came as the British newspaper Independent reported today that Iraq is believed to have assembled three so-called superguns able to fire shells a distance of more than 450 miles. **********United States intelligence officials were quoted as saying they believed that the guns, largely assembled from British-made components, may have been delivered to Iraq before production of the weapons was discovered earlier this year. **********In his article, General Abdul-Rahman wrote, "The surprise element by Iraq will make the American aggression face uncalculated developments and unexpected results in reaction, which would make their execution of aggression according to its plans impossible." **********Iraq could come up with a military surprise that would prevent the United States to "manage the crisis the way they like," the general said. Forces Roughly Equivalent **********The increase in American troop strength announced this month would raise the level of United States forces in the region to 430,000 soldiers, sailors, Marines and air force personnel -- believed to be about equivalent to the number of Iraqi forces in Kuwait and their strategic reserve in southern Iraq. **********President Bush said the extra forces were needed in case it became necessary to launch a military strike to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait. Iraq overran the emirate on Aug. 2. **********General Abdul-Rahman questioned the efficacy of a surgical air strike by the forces arrayed against Iraq. Military experts say Western air power is technologically superior to Iraq's air strength of around 500 combat jets. **********The combined air power of the United States, Britain, France and their allies in the gulf region now totals more than 1,000 fighters and attack aircraft. **********"Never in the past was the air force able to end war," General Abdul-Rahman said, a point on which some Western analysts agree. **********The general said the balance in ground forces was in Iraq's favor because of "numerical superiority, war-tested experience" and support weaponry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY EARNINGS;   Profit Lags at Caterpillar
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/21/busin.body_text: **********Caterpillar Inc. announced today that it had put into effect a white-collar hiring freeze after the company's profit fell short of last year's performance for the second consecutive quarter. **********Despite record sales, Caterpillar earned $99 million, or 97 cents a share, in the first three months of 1990, a 29.8 percent drop from last year, when the first-quarter profit was $141 million, or $1.39 a share. **********Revenue for the Peoria-based Caterpillar, the world's largest manufacturer of earth-moving equipment, was up 9.1 percent, to $2.87 billion for the quarter, the second-best quarter in Caterpillar's 75-year history. The company's revenue was $2.63 billion in the corresponding quarter last year. The all-time high for revenue was $3.04 billion in the second quarter of 1989. **********The hiring freeze applies to all management or salaried employees, said Len Kuchan, Caterpillar's treasurer. **********He said a company reorganization, which created profit-driven management centers, had resulted in a reduction of middle-management jobs and some salaried workers. **********Mr. Kuchan said no layoffs of blue-collar workers is expected in 1990, although they could occur if the nation's economy sinks into a recession. **********Mr. Kuchan attributed the low profit level to increased costs resulting from soaring health-care expenses, plant modernization programs, higher material costs and trouble in key markets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/25/world.main_headline: Yugoslavia Police Deployed to Quiet Unrest
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/25/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Yugoslavia Police Deployed to Quiet Unrest
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/25/world.body_text: **********The Government sent soldiers across the province of Kosovo today to restore order after renewed unrest touched off by a mysterious illness affecting hundreds of ethnic Albanians. **********At the same time, the Serbian republic announced that it was assuming direct control of Kosovo's police, a move that could increase tension. **********The police force is dominated by ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of Kosovo's population. **********The minority Serbs and Montenegrins have accused them of failing to provide adequate protection to minority groups in Kosovo, a province within Serbia. **********More than 60 people have died in ethnic violence in the province in the last year. **********The latest unrest was set off by an illness that hospitalized about 1,000 people, most of them ethnic Albanian children and teen-agers, last week. **********The victims suffered lung and skin irritation, and there were allegations by the Albanians that they had been poisoned. **********Most of the patients had been released by today, but a few were still arriving for treatment. The cause of the illness had not been determined. **********Today, a dozen tanks were on the outskirts of Podujevo, 20 miles north of the province capital, Pristina. Troop movements were also reported at Pec, Vucitrn, Titova Mitrovica, Djakovica and Prizren, the Belgrade radio said. **********Podujevo is a hotbed of the Albanians' struggle for the autonomy that Kosovo lost when Serbia assumed direct control of its judiciary and education a year ago. **********A Western journalist who asked not to be identified said he saw police headquarters in Podujevo surrounded today by at least 40 officers in battle gear. He said policemen carrying submachine guns were all over the city. **********Jim Fish, a British reporter for the BBC, said he was detained by the police for two hours and questioned when he returned to Podujevo after a visit to a nearby village. **********He said he passed a column of tanks outside town. **********A French medical team was reported on the way to Kosovo to try to determine the cause of the illness.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/18/world.main_headline: Mandela's Group Begins a Recruiting Drive
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/18/world.print_headline: Mandela's Group Begins a Recruiting Drive
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/18/world.body_text: **********A middle-aged white couple recently walked into the old Arthur Murray dance studio for a rehearsal and found the last waltz saved for the African National Congress. **********Since their previous visit, the premises had been rented to the Congress for its regional headquarters in the Eastern Cape. The dancers were urged to rehearse in what remained of the ballroom, disregarding the militant slogans and political bustle. **********"The poor white man and lady ran away," said Mike Xhego, the Congress's regional spokesman. **********Had they stayed, the couple might have found themselves invited to join the African National Congress, which has started a nationwide drive for members since its emergence last February from 30 years as an outlawed organization.  100,000 Join Congress **********The results have been modest so far. As of Sept. 12, 100,000 South Africans had joined the Congress, it says. Latest estimates put its membership somewhere between 120,000 and 150,000. By contrast, the Zulu political movement Inkatha, which was never banned, asserts it has 1.7 million paid members, though opinion polls show Inkatha with only a fraction of the Congress's national public support and virtually none in the Eastern Cape. **********The population of South Africa, including the nominally independent ethnic homelands, exceeds 37 million, of which a little more than 5 million are white. **********In Cape Province's eastern region, where more than 1 million South Africans live, the African National Congress maintains it has enlisted more than 30,000 members. Its goal is to sign up 50,000 members by mid-December and ultimately 10 times that many. "This was the cradle of the revolution in the 1950's, even in the 1980's," said Benson Fihla, a former political prisoner who is chairman of the African National Congress's branch in the Eastern Cape.  Big Crowds for Mandela **********The Congress traditionally found its strongest support here. When Nelson Mandela visited Port Elizabeth shortly after his release from prison, he drew a crowd that organizers put as high as 500,000. The opening this month of the Congress's regional branch here attracted up to 50,000 people. **********The roadside tables in the membership drive are usually set up on weekends and at the end of the month, when those with jobs have just been paid. Recruiters have also gone door to door. **********But many people say they cannot afford the Congress's modest annual membership fee of 12 rand, or about $4.75. Port Elizabeth and the surrounding area suffer from an unemployment rate believed to exceed 50 percent, partly because Ford and General Motors shut down their automobile assembly plants in response to overseas pressure to disinvest.  Congress's Competitors **********The African National Congress also found itself competing around Port Elizabeth with the more militant Pan-Africanist Congress and with the Labor Party, whose leader, the Rev. Allan Hendrickse, lives in nearby Uitenhage. **********"People are resenting the Labour Party," said Mr. Xhego. He discounted the Labour Party's appeal because of its participation in the segregated Parliament. The Pan-Africanist Congress, formed in 1959 by breakaway A.N.C. members, claims to have more support than the African National Congress. Bloody fighting between adherents of the rival organizations broke out around Uitenhage last February. **********The African National Congress has encountered the biggest resistance in rural areas of the Eastern Cape, not just from white farmers but also from intimidated black farm workers. **********"It's very difficult to reach the farms because the farm worker will tell you that if the master knows he is in the movement, he will lose everything -- his house, his school, everything," Mr. Xhego said. **********"We need to convince those farmworkers it is not criminal to join the A.N.C.," he said. "In fact, it is their right."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/world.body_text: **********China expressed deep concern tonight over political battles in Taiwan that are taking place in advance of the presidential election there later this month, and strongly condemned the governing Nationalist Party for ''creating political and social instability.'' **********The Chinese statement, attributed to ''an authoritative source in Beijing'' and distributed by the official New China News Agency, seemed to display indignance and bewilderment about the furor in Taiwan in recent days. **********Taiwan's National Assembly is scheduled to choose a president on March 21, and until recently it was all but a foregone conclusion that the incumbent, Lee Teng-hui, would be re-elected. But politics in Taiwan have been thrown into an uproar by the unexpected candidacy of a rival ticket backed by some elderly officials who are suspicious of Mr. Lee's program of rapid change and of his identity as a native Taiwanese with few links to the Chinese mainland. **********While President Lee has 80 percent approval ratings in public opinion polls, it is the 752-seat National Assembly that will choose the president and vice president. Most of the assembly members are aging Nationalist officials who were elected on the Chinese mainland before the 1949 Communist Revolution. **********It is not clear if the rival ticket has any chance of unseating Mr. Lee. So far about 200 assembly members have shown support for the rival ticket, which proposes Lin Yang-kang, the popular chief of Taiwan's judiciary, for president and Chiang Weigo, the sole surviving son of the former Nationalist leader, Chiang Kai-shek, for vice president. **********Unification With Mainland Urged **********The statement by Beijing blamed the Nationalist Party for ''political irresolution, economic disorder and deteriorating social order,'' and reiterated the mainland's long-held view that Taiwan should take steps toward unification with the mainland. **********In the last few years, as Taiwan has moved rapidly toward greater democracy, the mainland has appeared increasingly uncomfortable with the hurly-burly of free speech and political campaigns there. Beijing apparently feels that while Taiwan's former authoritarian rulers - Chiang Kai-shek and his son, Chiang Ching-kuo - were fervent anti-Communists, at least they believed that Taiwan should be part of China.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/world.main_headline: Raids Reported at Radio Stations As Crackdown Goes On in Haiti
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/world.print_headline: Raids Reported at Radio Stations As Crackdown Goes On in Haiti
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/world.body_text: **********The military Government continued its crackdown on dissent today with police raids that halted broadcasts by three independent radio stations in the northern port of Cap-Haitien, a witness said. **********The witness, an employee of Radio Citadelle, said armed plainclothes officers burst into the station shortly after a 1 P.M. news broadcast that reported on weekend arrests, beatings and the exiling of political campaigners. **********The news staff fled before the raid and no one was arrested, said the employee, speaking on condition of anonymity. He said similar raids occurred at Radio Voix du Nord and Radio Cap-Haitien during newscasts, which also were suspended. All three stations are privately owned. **********Radio is the main source of news in impoverished Haiti, and the raids underscored the determination by the Government of Lieut. Gen Prosper Avril to suppress dissent in what critics say may be a move toward re-establishing a dictatorship in Haiti, which shares the Caribbean island of Hispaniola with the Dominican Republic. **********Deadly Elections in 1987 **********General Avril rose to power in a revolt that ousted Lieut Gen. Henri Namphy, who took over the country after the fall of the Duvalier dictatorship in 1986 and oversaw elections in November 1987, which were canceled when at least 34 voters were shot and hacked to death by thugs working in collusion with soldiers. **********In its toughest crackdown on the opposition since taking power in a September 1988 barracks revolt, the Government arrested seven prominent opposition political leaders on Saturday and Sunday and forced them into exile. Dozens of others were arrested but were thought to have been released. **********The Government declared a state of siege and launched the crackdown on Saturday, a day after unidentified gunmen killed an army colonel, his wife and their servants. **********Of the six main radio stations in the capital, Port-au-Prince, only the Roman Catholic Radio Soleil, the Protestant Radio Lumiere and the Government-run National Radio broadcast news today. **********'Rubbish of the Constitution' **********Speaking on Radio Soleil, Bishop Willy Romelus denounced the Government's action over the weekend. ''They have made rubbish of the Constitution,'' the cleric said of General Avril and his associates. **********Radio Soleil said Frank Senat, co-leader of the radical Jean-Jacques Dessalines Group, was arrested on Monday on unspecified charges. The co-leader of the party, Sylvain Jolibois, was among those reportedly forced into exile on Sunday. **********In announcing the state of siege on Saturday night, the Government said it was necessary to banish political dissents to prevent an upsurge of ''terrorism.'' Critics accused General Avril of moving toward re-establishing a dictatorship despite his pledge to turn over power to a civilian government in elections scheduled for October. **********The United States said today that it ''deplores the actions taken by the Government of Haiti'' last weekend. **********U.S. Expresses Regret **********''While we regret the recent incidences of violence in Haiti, we believe that the actions taken by the Government of Haiti are not an appropriate response,'' said the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler. **********Under the state of siege, the Government suspended a law forbidding forced exile and renewed an entry-visa requirement for Haitians returning from abroad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/27/busin.main_headline: Debate on Phone System: Is U.S. Falling Behind?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/27/busin.print_headline: Debate on Phone System: Is U.S. Falling Behind?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/27/busin.body_text: **********In Congressional hearings and a closed-door conference of top Federal and state regulators this week, a bitter debate has flared over whether the nation's telephone system is being modernized quickly enough. **********Arguing that it is not are the seven regional Bell operating companies, which provide four-fifths of the local telephone service in the United States. On the other side is an unlikely combination of consumer groups, big businesses and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. **********The Bell companies say that Japan, France and even Singapore may have telephone systems as good as or better than those in the United States by the mid-1990's unless state and Federal regulators give them more incentive to invest in new fiber-optic cable and digital switches that transmit voice, computer data and images faster and more cheaply than existing copper cables and analog switches. **********They want state public service commissions to let them include in their rate bases the cost of early replacement of older equipment. And they want Congress to reverse a court-ordered bar on their entry into telephone equipment manufacturing, as well as into information services like electronic shopping and cable television programming, which will insure adequate demand for the new technologies installed. **********Big Public Relations Campaign **********''If you like being No. 2, you'll love America's telecommunications policy,'' reads one of the large advertisements placed by the Bell companies in newspapers and magazines. The ads are part of a $21 million public relations campaign on the subject. **********Consumer groups dispute these assertions, and estimate that accelerated investment could add as much as $11 to monthly telephone bills within a dozen years. A.T.&T. is vigorously opposing any relaxation of rules that now bar the Bell companies from manufacturing telephone-system equipment, one of its biggest businesses. **********And 14 large corporate users of telephone services, including the International Business Machines Corporation, have accused the Bell companies of exaggerating the threat to competitiveness. **********Federal regulators and members of Congress have expressed concern over whether investment in the telephone system is adequate to prevent an erosion of the competitiveness of American goods. Advocates of more investment in fiber optics and digital switches say these are essential to bringing high-quality facsimile machines, faster computer communications and video telephone service into American businesses and homes. **********For example, the Sharp Corporation may sell its recently announced color facsimile machines only in Japan, partly out of concern that too few American businesses will have the especially advanced type of high-speed digital telephone lines to handle efficiently the high volume of data needed, said Joseph F. Cosgrove, Sharp's national facsimile marketing director. **********F.C.C. Conference **********Alfred C. Sikes, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, convened a conference Wednesday and yesterday to review the technological development of the nation's telephone system. It was attended by the heads of most of the nation's state regulatory agencies. No broad policy initiative was announced or agreed upon. **********The Senate Subcommittee on Communications held hearings Wednesday on the health of the nation's telephone system, as it began consideration of a bill to allow the Bell companies to develop and manufacture telephone equipment. The House Subcommittee on Telecommunications is reviewing slightly broader legislation. **********Spending Elsewhere Cited **********To bolster their case, the Bell companies point to heavy spending by other nations on their telephone systems. **********But some industry and Government experts say that extra spending in the United States would be expensive and unnecessary because local telephone companies are already making digitally switched, fiber-optic telephone lines available as fast as their customers demand it. **********Some Government officials also suggest that advocates of regulatory change may be exaggerating the immediate threat to American competitiveness to stampede the Government into action. ''Those who believe the policies are bad might have a reason to manufacture a crisis,'' Mr. Sikes said in an interview. **********The United States still has the world's best telephone service, Mr. Sikes said, adding that any erosion of its lead was not significant so far. But he added that there were grounds for concern that the nation was developing two forms of telephone service, as large corporations install the latest technology while smaller businesses and individuals continue to rely on a public access network that receives limited investment. **********Rise in Investment Urged **********Mr. Sikes said that since the beginning of the year he had called in the chief executives of each of the seven ''Baby Bells'' to encourage more research and investment. Annual investment in local telephone exchanges stagnated in the 1980's at about $20 billion, according to the United States Telephone Association, an industry group in Washington. But over the same period, local telephone companies' revenues rose 55.9 percent, to $91.7 billion last year. **********Even among some Baby Bell executives, some question exists over the extent to which loosened regulation would stimulate investment in the public access network. Richard K. Snelling, the executive vice president responsible for the network of Southern Bell, which provides nearly a tenth of the nation's local phone service, said that regulatory changes would be unlikely to prompt substantial changes in his company's plans to install fiber-optic cables and other high-technology equipment. **********He said Southern Bell would install fiber-optic cable regardless of regulatory changes because it was now as cheap as copper cable and getting cheaper. BellSouthd (Southern Bell)

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/09/world.print_headline: WITH DEATHS TIED TO SALVADOR ARMY, AID FIGHT IS LIKELY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/09/world.body_text: **********Responding to a Salvadoran statement that military men were involved in the killing of six Jesuit priests in November, Administration officials acknowledged today that future aid to El Salvador would hinge on satisfying Congress about the progress of the investigation. **********But the Administration said it did not think that aid to El Salvador should be directly tied to the inquiry, setting the stage for a battle with Congressional Democrats, many of whom insist that the case serve as a test of whether the United States should support the rightist Government in San Salvador. **********U.S. Pressure Called Factor **********In a televised announcement Sunday night, President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador said ''some elements of the armed forces'' were behind the killings, which took place on Nov. 16. A Congressional critic of United States policy in El Salvador and officials of the Bush Administration said today that American pressure was partly responsible for that announcement. **********Administration officials said they kept pressure on El Salvador to investigate the killings in part to forestall efforts by Democrats in Congress, who want to halt American aid to the Salvadoran military, which has long been tied to human rights abuses. **********Obstacles to Prosecution **********The White House officials also said they genuinely wanted those responsible brought to justice, but diplomats and lawyers in San Salvador said today that there would be many obstacles to a successful prosecution. [Page A10.]  A housekeeper and her daughter were also killed in the attack, which came six days before Congress adjourned. Legislators expressed deep outrage at the time, and there were unsuccessful attempts in the Senate and the House to restrict aid. **********Many legislators expressed concern that the killings were ''most likely carried out with American-supplied weapons,'' in the words of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York. **********Representative Joe Moakley, Democrat of Massachusetts, who leads a committee investigating the killings, said in an interview today that he was ''very happy about the announcement'' by Mr. Cristiani because it suggested that the Salvadoran Government was making a diligent investigation. The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, appointed the committee. **********Mr. Cristiani ''knows that Congress is serious about reviewing American aid if these killings are not solved, with the right people indicted and sentenced,'' Mr. Moakley said. ''Many people will make up their minds on further aid to El Salvador based on the way this case is handled.'' **********Mr. Moakley, who is chairman of the House Rules Committee, has been a critic of American policy in El Salvador for a decade. He said that Mr. Cristiani was ''cooperating fully'' with Congressional efforts to monitor the investigation. **********''The Speaker's involvement put additional pressure on El Salvador,'' Mr. Moakley said.  Closer Review Called Necessary With most members of Congress out of town, it is difficult to determine whether Mr. Cristiani's announcement will stave off new Congressional restrictions on American aid. While pleased with the investigation so far, members of Congress said they needed to review the inquiry more closely before deciding whether to restrict aid. **********The Bush Administration said today that Mr. Cristiani showed ''great courage'' in declaring that military men were responsible for killing the priests. Mr. Cristiani is the leader of a rightist alliance that has been accused of backing paramilitary death squads. **********Administration officials said the vigor of the official Salvadoran investigation showed that there was no reason for the United States to reduce or restrict aid to El Salvador, as some Democratic members of Congress have demanded. **********Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said the Administration hoped that the future of American aid ''would not be linked'' to the investigation. **********''While identifying these alleged individuals is a decisive and necessary first step, the Salvadoran Government must now take actions to prosecute'' those responsible for the crime, Miss Tutwiler said. ''I have no reason to believe'' that El Salvador will not fully investigate the ''horrendous murder'' of the priests, she said. **********'Salutary,' Rights Group Says **********Americas Watch, a human rights group, said, ''The Cristiani Government's admission of military involvement is an important and salutary development.'' But noting that there have been no indictments or arrests, the group said the Bush Administration must ''maintain sufficient pressure to see that all those responsible are tried and punished.'' **********Miss Tutwiler said she did not know the rank of the Salvadoran soldiers suspected in the killings. **********Mr. Moakley said his independent inquiry strongly suggested that ''the responsibility goes extremely high'' in the Salvadoran armed forces. **********The Federal Bureau of Investigation is providing laboratory services to the Salvadoran Government to help with the inquiry. F.B.I. officials declined today to give details of the bureau's help. Mr. Cristiani asked for such help in a letter sent to President Bush on Nov. 19. **********El Salvador received $298 million in economic aid and $80 million in military assistance from the United States last year. In the last eight years, Washington has provided more than $3.2 billion of aid to El Salvador, about $1 billion in military equipment. The Government has been fighting a civil war against leftist rebels for more than a decade, and the priests' killings came during a rebel offensive in the capital. A strict curfew was in place at the time, during which only the military was allowed to move freely. #47 Are Confined to Base Just after the killings, the Bush Administration adamantly opposed Congressional efforts to curtail aid to El Salvador, even though it now appears that such efforts were partly responsible for the Salvadoran Government's professed commitment to investigate. **********Members of the elite Atlacatl battalion are among those suspected of being involved in the killings. Col. Rene Emilio Ponce, the head of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in El Salvador, said on Sunday that 47 members of the battalion were being confined to their base even though they had not been arrested or formally charged. **********Many members of the battalion have been trained by the United States. But an American official said, ''Just about every battalion in El Salvador has received U.S. training of one type or another.'' **********Anne Manuel, the research director of Americas Watch, said the Atlacatl battalion was implicated in the 1981 massacre of more than 700 peasants in the Salvadoran province of Morazan. It has also been accused in the killings of at least 68 people in Cabanas province in 1984 and the massacre of at least 50 in Chalatenango province in 1984. **********Its record cast doubt on ''the theory promoted by successive U.S. administrations that U.S. training brings about improved human rights behavior,'' she said. **********Without naming those responsible for killing the priests in November, Miss Tutwiler said, ''We are pleased that the Salvadorans have made this important breakthrough in identifying alleged perpetrators of the despicable slayings of the Jesuit fathers.'' **********Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said the White House had no independent information about who carried out the slayings. **********''Cristiani has shown great courage,'' he said. ''We asked that the investigation be thorough and the prosecution move ahead, and it looks like that's the course he is on. He deserves a lot of credit.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.body_text: **********The Government of Brazil is expecting monthly inflation to fall below 10 percent in October after prices did not rise in the final week of September, the newspaper O Globo reported on Saturday. **********Brazil, plagued by hyperinflation until March of this year, has no official inflation figure. But O Globo said economists had presented data on Friday to the Economy Minister, Zelia Cardoso de Mello, showing price increases were slowing. **********President Fernando Collor de Mello has made the fight against inflation his No. 1 priority since taking office nearly seven months ago. **********A strong economic package took a third of Brazil's money out of circulation overnight and forced price rises down to about 7 percent a month in May, but inflation crept to more than 10 percent in July and stayed near 12 percent in August and September.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/busin.body_text: **********William H. Donaldson, one of the three founding partners of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., was named chairman of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. He will replace John J. Phelan Jr., who will retire in January. **********Richard A. Grasso, now president and chief operating officer of the exchange, will be promoted to executive vice chairman, succeeding Richard R. Shinn. **********The appointment of Mr. Donaldson, whose selection had been expected on Wall Street, comes as the exchange is being challenged on many fronts as the central arena for trading shares in American companies. Although it has lost volume to regional exchanges, to overseas markets and to new products traded on the nation's futures exhanges, it remains the world's largest exchange. **********Series of Challenges **********In a news conference, Mr. Donaldson said his biggest challenges will be meeting international competition and ''restoring public confidence'' to an exchange where trading is perceived to have become increasingly volatile since the October 1987 crash. **********''We are in an extremely competitive marketplace,'' Mr. Donaldson said. ''That competition never rests, and opportunities for improvement are never exhausted.'' He added that as capitalism spreads, the exchange must ''explore the boundaries'' of competition and must keep abreast of technological innovations to make trading more efficient. **********The selection of Mr. Donaldson, who is 59 years old, brings to the exchange a man with broad experience. After graduating from Harvard Business School, he and two classmates founded Donaldson, Lufkin in 1959. In 1973, when the firm was the 10th largest on Wall Street, he left to become an Under Secretary of State and, later, a White House special counsel. **********Mr. Donaldson became dean of the Yale Graduate School of Management and is executor of the estate of Henry Ford 2d. He now heads Donaldson Enterprises, a private venture capital firm but will sever his ties with the firm in January. **********Mr. Donaldson has close ties to the Bush Administration and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. He was recently selected by the President to join business leaders and Cabinet members on a visit to Poland. At Yale, Mr. Donaldson was a member of the Skull and Bones Society, with George Bush and was also a classmate of Mr. Bush's brother, Jonathan. **********Benjamin F. Edwards 3d, chairman of A. G. Edwards, a St. Louis brokerage firm and an exchange director, said Mr. Donaldson brings ''enthusiasm, a quick mind and some experience in the business.'' **********Mr. Edwards said he felt Mr. Donaldson's biggest challenge will be ''to listen to the exchange's customers and to maintain its position as the world's best marketplace. **********''They can't do that by living in yesteryear,'' he said. ''They may have to be more competitive.'' **********Arthur Levitt, former chairman of the American Stock Exchange, said he suspected that the selection of Mr. Donaldson means that ''having a voice in Washington and in the financial community is the exchange's most important priority right now.'' **********Mr. Levitt added that one ''serious problem'' facing Mr. Donaldson will be dealing with the ''pressures being brought to bear on the specialist system,'' which is the heart of the exchange's trading process. The specialists, who trade securities on the exchange floor, are often strained for capital at times of heavy volume. Their jobs are being threatened by computerized trading systems used in the over-the-counter and other markets. **********Issue of Program Trading **********In other issues, Mr. Donaldson declined to take a position on program trading, which some blame for increased market volatility, saying that he needed to research the subject. Still, he said market volatility was ''of great concern'' to him. **********Mr. Donaldson also is credited with participating in a transformation of the capital structure of the financial-services industry. In 1969, Donaldson, Lufkin was the first firm to go public, a trend that others followed to help bring fresh pools of money to support Wall Street firms. **********Mr. Grasso, 44, has had a two-decade career within the exchange, and recently has been instrumental in introducing more automation to the exchange floor. Mr. Grasso said he was ''delighted and honored'' by the exchange board's ''vote of confidence in me.'' **********Mr. Phelan recently became chairman of the board of the Aspen Institute and, in two years, will become the new head of the International Federation of Stock Exchanges.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/09/busin.body_text: **********The chief regulator of nationally chartered banks said today that a significant number of consumer loans made by commercial banks were turning sour. **********''We are concerned about a significant rise in nonperforming consumer loans at banks around the country,'' Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency, told the Institute of International Bankers in New York. In his speech, which was released in Washington, he said his agency had not determined how widespread the problem was. **********''We are analyzing the data and trying to determine precisely what this implies for the overall condition of the national banking system,'' he said. **********On other topics, Mr. Clarke predicted the trend toward bank consolidation would continue. He said there would be about 11,000 banks by 1993, compared with 12,600 now and 14,400 in 1980. He also said more banks would be owned by foreigners. **********The American Bankers Association, a trade group representing commercial banks, reported last month that the number of consumers 30 days or more behind on their loans soared to a 10-year high in the third quarter. **********Nationally, 2.88 percent of the loans surveyed at 800 banks were delinquent on Sept. 30, compared with 2.30 percent three months earlier. The delinquency rate was more than 4 percent in four states: Connecticut, 6.05 percent; Vermont, 5.35 percent; Massachusetts, 4.80 percent, and New York, 4.44 percent. **********While consumer lending is becoming more chancy, statistics from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the agency that guarantees bank deposits up to $100,000, show that banks are becoming more involved in such lending. **********Loans to individuals grew by 5.2 percent from the third quarter of 1988 to the corresponding period of 1989, according to the F.D.I.C. At the same time, all bank asset grew 4.2 percent, but real estate loans grew 13.1 percent. **********Loans to individuals represented 12 percent of banks' $3.2 trillion in assets at the end of the third quarter. However, consumer loans made up only 5.9 percent of all bad assets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/28/world.main_headline: Moscow Journal;   matchmaker's Dream: From Russia With Love
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/28/world.print_headline: Moscow Journal;   matchmaker's Dream: From Russia With Love
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/28/world.body_text: **********Alla R. Tambovtseva says she was impressed by the frequent smiles and ''positive emotions'' of the American tourists she used to meet before she lost her administrative job at an Intourist hotel here. **********So when she saw an advertisement in the newspaper Moskovsky Komsomolets - one promising to help find ''lifetime companions'' in the United States - she quickly sent a letter, four photographs and a fee of 50 rubles, or about $80 at the official exchange rate. **********''I think that there's a better chance with an American to have a good family and to have stability,'' said Miss Tambovtseva, a 30-year-old Russian, who is divorced and has no children. **********Miss Tambovtseva also cited some more unexpected reasons for seeking an American husband - among them, the possibility of civil war in the Soviet Union and a concern about pesticide residues on Soviet food. **********And, Miss Tambovtseva said, reflecting a common fear about the lack of single-use medical equipment here, ''If I have children, I do not want them to have AIDS.'' **********Not so long ago, the appearance of the first American-Russian matchmaking service might have been viewed as one of the more frivolous byproducts of warming superpower relations. **********Escape From a Harsh Society **********But for Soviet clients, the decision to sign up with a joint venture in international matchmaking is a very serious affair. **********Marriage to an American has always been a tantalizing route to upward mobility for some Russians. But the risks were great - the loss of a job, and the strong possibility that the state would not let a Soviet citizen join a spouse in America. **********Those risks have nearly evaporated under new emigration policies. The desire to leave has spread through all layers of Soviet society, as more and more people seek ways to escape a country that they believe can no longer protect them from food shortages, anti-Semitism and other problems. **********''Many people want to leave this country now because of the economic situation, the difficulties of life,'' said Galina I. Bashayeva, 20, a student at the Foreign Languages Institute in Moscow. **********They Want Love (but in the U.S.) **********Miss Bashayeva and other clients of the venture, called American-Russian Matchmaking, do say they are looking for love. **********''Like every Jew in the Soviet Union, I want to emigrate,'' said Svetlana L. Gartman, 23, who said she was rejected for postgraduate study at a Moscow institute last year because she is Jewish. **********Miss Gartman described her anxieties about rising anti-Semitism during a break in a video session in a shady park by Moscow's famed, and faded, Bolshoi Theater. **********Clients of American-Russian Matchmaking took turns strolling past the park's fountain and purple pansy beds, while Jacob Cantor recorded their moves with his video camera. **********Mr. Cantor was born in the Soviet Union but left with his family 17 years ago when he was 2. His father, Gene, is the American partner in the matchmaking firm. **********More Women Clients Than Men **********Gene Cantor said he hopes to start making matches for Miss Gartman and perhaps 700 other Soviet citizens when he returns to Los Angeles this week, laden with photographs, videotapes and biographies of his new clients - three-quarters of whom are women. **********Mr. Cantor plans to open a matchmaking bureau in California to advertise his Soviet clients and set up initial mail contacts with interested single Americans. **********American-Russian Matchmaking will also arrange tours for any Americans who want to meet their Soviet pen pals. These tours, complete with ''candlelight and chandelier dinners'' in the Soviet Union, would be the source of any profits the service might make. **********Escape From Ethnic Violence **********The firm's marketing plan reflects some hard-nosed business sense. Besides Moscow and Leningrad, the country's two biggest cities, American-Russian Matchmaking's partners in the Soviet Union have placed advertisements in hot spots like Armenia, where tens of thousands of refugees from ethnic violence are looking for a new life. **********Ads were also placed in Lithuania, where many Russian residents began searching for a way to get out after the Parliament declared independence on March 11. **********Gene Cantor said he does not expect many people to emigrate through his matchmaking service. Americans may be drawn to the service by curiosity, but the huge geographic and cultural gaps are likely to limit the number who actually propose marriage. **********Among those most likely to wed one of his Soviet clients, Mr. Kantor said, would be Jewish emigres to the United States. **********''They feel a lot of cultural deficiencies in America,'' he said. ''They are kind of nostalgic. It would be nice to meet a girl from the old country.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/15/busin.main_headline: Mutual Funds;   Variations on the Index Game
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/15/busin.print_headline: Mutual Funds;   Variations on the Index Game
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/15/busin.body_text: **********With all the brouhaha about index funds these days, something important is slipping by. Tracking Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is not the only way to go - or perhaps the best. **********There are two other smart ways that investors can index their portfolios: they can bet on small-company or international stocks. Although the choice of index funds specializing in these areas is rather limited - there are only about a handful on the market - there are at least four new ones in the works, according to Wayne S. Huff, an associate with Charles E. Simon & Company, a Washington-based research firm. **********One reason they look so good is that the S.&P. 500 is likely to give up its position as the best-performing index in the next five years, analysts say. Joe Mansueto, president of Morningstar Inc., a Chicago-based mutual fund consulting firm, predicted that the Wilshire 4500 or the Russell 2000 will take the top spot. Investors who agree can get into funds that mimic those indexes. **********The plain-vanilla S.&P. 500 index funds already have lost much of their luster. The stocks in the S.&P. 500 had a spectacular run-up during the 1980's, but times have changed. Pension money is moving into small-company stocks because they are relatively inexpensive, and the ''junk bond'' market that financed corporate buyouts - and helped send big-company stock prices heavenward - has collapsed. **********Small-company stocks turned in a dazzling performance for the first half of the year. These long-neglected cousins of the S.&P. 500 are coming into their own after lagging the market for seven years, market observers say, and index fund investors can tag along for the ride. **********There are three small-stock index funds to watch. Vanguard's $184 million Extended Market Portfolio, which tracks the Wilshire 4500 Index, includes more small-company stocks than the funds that track the S.&P. 500. Financial stocks, mainly small- and medium-sized banks, make up 22 percent of its portfolio, versus only 9 percent for the S.&P. 500; 7 percent is invested in energy stocks, versus 13 percent for the S.&P. 500. **********Unlike most Vanguard funds, this one carries a one-time, 1 percent upfront charge to defray higher transaction costs stemming from trading requirements in the over-the-counter market, said Brian S. Mattes, a spokesman. **********As for performance, the past 12 months have been a period with market averages all over the lot. The fund rose 4.4 percent for the year ended June 30, according to Morningstar. Meanwhile, two traditional measures of small-company performance moved in opposite directions. The Nasdaq index rose 6.2 percent for the year ended June 30; the Value Line index dropped 5.4 percent. **********Vanguard's $47 million Small Capitalization Fund tracks the Russell 2000, which includes more small-company stocks than the Wilshire 4500. The average market capitalization of the Russell stocks is $170 million, versus $1 billion for the Wilshire 4500, and the fund's portfolio focuses more heavily on the technology and consumer discretionary sectors. So the fund, with a 1 percent one-time upfront charge, is a more pure small-company play - and thus more volatile. It was up 1 percent for the year ended June 30. **********The most expensive of these three funds is Colonial's Small Stock Index Fund, which tracks the smallest 20 percent of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange, and has a 4.75 percent upfront charge. It rose just three-tenths of a percent for the year ended June 30.  One reason expenses are so critical with index funds is that they create tracking errors that can cause a fund to underperform the index it is supposed to duplicate. With the Vanguard funds, for example, expense ratios - the gauge of those expenses - are razor thin, which lets those funds track the indexes very closely. **********On the international side, there are several index funds worth considering. Colonial's International Equity Index Fund, which has a hefty 4.75 percent upfront sales charge, weights its portfolio by the gross national product of each country in the Morgan Stanley Capital International E.A.F.E. index. As a result, the Japanese portion of Colonial's portfolio is lower and the European portion is higher. The fund rose 15.8 percent for the year ended June 30, versus a 19.2 percent rise in all international stock funds. **********Vanguard's International Equity Index Fund, which began investing just last month, has garnered $70 million in assets in ''one of the most successful new fund launches that we've ever had,'' Mr. Mattes said. It has two portfolios that investors can buy separately. **********Its $53 million European Portfolio tracks the Morgan Stanley Capital International Europe Index, made up of about 600 companies in 13 countries; about two-thirds of the portfolio is invested in Britain, West Germany and France. The Pacific Portfolio mimics the Morgan Stanley Capital International Pacific Index, with tracks stocks mainly from Japan (91 percent of its weighting) and Australia, New Zealand, Hong Kong and Singapore. **********THE 12B-1 DISADVANTAGE **********The 12b-1 fees levied by mutual funds usually lower net returns to investors, according to a new study conducted for the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********Proponents of the fees - named for S.E.C. Rule 12b-1, which allows funds to use shareholder money for marketing expenses - claim 12b-1 plans improve fund performance. They say higher marketing spending brings in shareholders, and as funds grow, costs drop because expenses are spread over a bigger base. **********Not so, says Charles Trzcinka, an associate professor of finance at the State University of New York at Buffalo, and Robert Zweig, a financial analyst with the S.E.C.'s division of investment management, who studied 612 stock and bond funds. They found that the larger the 12b-1 fee, the larger the fund's total expenses - and, in general, the lower the net returns. The advice from Mr. Trzcinka: ''Investors should put no more money into 12b-1 funds unless they are sure that the service they get from their broker is worth the fee.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/busin.main_headline: World Markets;   Volatility in South Africa's Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/busin.print_headline: World Markets;   Volatility in South Africa's Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/busin.body_text: **********Humphrey Borkum, a director of South Africa's largest brokerage house, wasn't surprised by what Nelson Mandela said when he was released last week from prison after more than 27 years. But other players in the South African stock market apparently were. **********After Mr. Mandela restated his support for the African National Congress's long-held policy of nationalization of some key industries, like gold mines, the Johannesburg Stock Exchange Overall Index plummeted 7.5 percent in just three days. It recovered a bit at the end of the week, but still finished 6 percent down. ''I didn't expect him to come out after 27 years and say, 'I changed my mind,' '' said Mr. Borkum of Davis Borkum Hare. ''Everyone here thinks he is doing no more than staking out his position from where he will negotiate.'' **********But that didn't deter the selling, which was accelerated by a concomitant sharp decline in the financial rand, the special investment currency foreigners must use to buy South African stocks. Kloof Gold, a gold-mining company, fell from 42.75 rand on Feb. 9 to 37.75 at its low on Wednesday; and the drop of the financial rand increased the loss when translated into other currencies. **********The fall was just as scary for Americans who invest dollars in gold funds concentrated in South African shares. International Investors Inc. is the largest gold fund and has 56 percent of its investment in South Africa. It fell from $18.18 on Feb. 9 to $15.75 Wednesday, a 13.4 percent decline, compared with a 11.6 percent decline in the South African gold index. A sister fund, Gold Resources, which does not invest in South Africa, was down only several pennies, to $5.42 on Wednesday. **********Mr. Borkum and Niall Brown of Simpson McKie, another big South African brokerage firm, attributed the sell-off to speculative foreign investors who had already pushed the the market up 3.2 percent after South Africa's President, F. W. de Klerk, promised two weeks ago that Mr. Mandela's release was imminent. ''It is a case where people are behaving more on sentiment than fact,'' Mr. Brown said about both the run-up and the fall. **********David Poole, chief economist at International Investors Inc., said a correction was due anyway because of the large rise in gold-share prices. The fund has risen 73.6 percent since last May; the South African gold index has risen 44.7 percent. **********Most Americans who invest in South Africa do so through funds, like International Investors, that buy gold stocks in South Africa, the United States, Canada and Australia. But opposition to apartheid has deterred many investors. According to Davis Borkum Hare, Americans held only 3.9 percent of the South African gold shares that are traded in American Depository Receipts in the United States at the end of last year, down from 13.8 percent at the end of 1987. **********Last week's decline in the South African market means investors will have more volatility to contend with. It is likely that every hiccup in talks between the A.N.C. and Pretoria could move the market quickly in one direction or another. And as in the case of the plunge last week, these moves may not seem logical. **********There is, of course, a risk that talks won't get off the ground. But Mr. Mandela's release and Mr. de Klerk's willingness to negotiate are real reason for optimism. And they give investors, for the first time in years, several positive factors with which to balance South Africa's risks. **********One is that South African gold stocks are already some of the most attractive in the world and would be more so with a new government. In the last year, they are up 72 percent in dollar terms compared with 27 percent for gold shares in the United States. **********And investors can look forward to the lifting of sanctions, which is now a real possibility and would bring in floods of new money. **********But after all this, there is still one other variable to contend with: the price of gold, which colors the atmosphere on the exchange. Warren Myers, vice president of Merril Lynch Capital Markets in New York, predicts a continued rise, which should push up the price of gold shares. But Mr. Brown thinks gold will not rise much this year, ''so gold shares are not too exciting.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.body_text: **********The Toronto police said last Friday that they had cracked an international high-technology credit card fraud ring that uses electronically doctored credit cards. **********The Hong Kong-based scheme involves copying electronic information from a genuine card and attaching it to a stolen one. **********The seized cards were stolen and doctored in Hong Kong and the four men caught using them were Chinese nationals who had immigrated to Canada, said Roy Teeft, detective inspector of the Toronto Police Department's intelligence services. The scheme affects all major credit cards. **********When the theft of a credit card is reported, the issuing company makes the card worthless by invalidating its two built-in safeguards - information recorded on a magnetic stripe and the multi-digit number. **********In the case of the cards seized by the Toronto police, the last four digits of the number had been reimbossed and a special $1,200 coding machine, attached to a home computer, was used to alter the stripe. Both stripe and number then corresponded to data attached to valid cards. **********Mr. Teeft said the fraud artists would need someone inside a bank, credit card company or a business accepting cards to pass on information about valid cards.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/world.main_headline: Wukeshu Journal;   The Perfect Union Still Eludes a Checkered China
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/world.print_headline: Wukeshu Journal;   The Perfect Union Still Eludes a Checkered China
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/world.body_text: **********Bi Shucai furrowed his brow into a hundred wrinkles as he tried to think of the differences between himself, a member of the ethnic Sani minority, and the Han Chinese people who rule the country he lives in. **********He slurped from a bowl of rice soaked in potent wine, and a few drops fell on the bright, blue-bordered, woven-hemp vest that is part of the Sani costume. **********''The only difference is the clothes and the food,'' said Mr. Bi, a 44-year-old rice grower whose family has its roots in this small village, which means Five Tree Village in Chinese. ''We Sani people cook our meat with pig bones in it. But the Han people don't.'' **********Mr. Bi is one of 80 million members of ethnic minorities whom the Communist leadership is trying to assimilate peacefully into Han Chinese life. China's minorities represent only 8 percent of the country's population, but there are 55 different groups, and 24 of them live here in the country's southwest. **********Distinctions Are Blurring **********Many of the minority groups live in mixed-tribe communities that are often hotbeds of dispute. But at least in this province of Yunnan, the younger generations are beginning to marry across ethnic lines and blurring the distinctions between peoples. The Communist leadership hopes this trend will diminish the chances of conflict. **********In any event, chances of an uprising seem slim. In Yunnan, for example, the minority groups make up one-third of the whole, but any effort to organize would be difficult because they are fragmented and scattered throughout the province's sprawling red-clay hills and rice-paddied valleys. Rifts often occur between neighboring tribes over land and resources, rather than between a minority and the Han Chinese. **********''The minorities here have always lived under some form of Chinese rule, be it the Communists or the emperors,'' a Muslim student said. ''In Yunnan, they are not united. They don't have the sense of having their own nation as do the Tibetans or even the Mongolians.'' **********But the recent upheavals in the Soviet Union's minority regions have raised concerns about prospects for stability here. Prime Minister Li Peng recently called for greater emphasis on minority relations, and the Government is planning to increase tax benefits to certain minority areas. **********Some Extra Benefits **********A Government official said that Yunnan spends the equivalent of $43 million on supplements to minorities, although there are many other benefits that are not captured in that amount. For instance, the minority people here are not subject to China's one-child policy, but are permitted to have two children, and in some cases more. **********Minority students applying for college may be admitted with lower exam grades than Han Chinese, and minority families get a certain priority in allocation of housing. Two of the poorest minority areas are also exempt from taxes, and the Government says it is doing its best to encourage a business mentality among some traditionally oriented societies. **********''The Government gives investment money and sends intellectuals and technicians to help the minorities develop their local economies,'' said Shen Qirong, an official at the provincial Minority Nationalities Affairs office. ''We also have minority swat teams who go to the minority areas to settle any conflicts.'' **********Still, officials acknowledge that in Yunnan there is still a gap in average incomes: Han Chinese earn the equivalent of $85 per year, while minority people earn $64. **********Religious Differences **********The tensions here are not as sharp as in the neighboring province of Tibet, where violent clashes have led to the declaration of martial law in Lhasa, the capital. In Yunnan, religious differences are a source of minority friction, and relations between the Han Chinese and Muslim groups are still somewhat strained. **********The 400,00 Muslims in Yunnan, members of the Hui minority, still recall the conflict in 1974, near the end of the Cultural Revolution, when the army invaded an area in Yunnan's southwest, called Shadian, to crush a rebellion by Muslims. Communist officials had been forcing the Muslims, who do not eat pork, to raise pigs, and the defiant Muslims armed themselves with knives and guns, both Muslim and Chinese officials say . The clash apparently left several hundred dead. **********In recent months, some Muslim nations were reported to have offered money to pay for students to study in their countries, but the Chinese Government has refused to allow the money to be disbursed directly to Muslim groups in Yunnan. The offer has renewed the discomfort on both sides. **********''Everything seems fine on the outside, but underneath there is still tension,'' a Chinese worker said. **********More Privileges Promised **********Officials say the Communist Party has helped raise the standard of living for many of these societies and weaned them from their traditional way of life. **********Ma Yisheng, a senior research official at the small museum at the Yunnan Institute of Nationalities, said some societies used slaves until a few decades ago. He said that the Yi minority, the largest in Yunnan and an umbrella race for Sani people like Mr. Bi, would punish its slaves by binding their feet to a horse who would gallop around, dragging the face and body on the ground. **********''In the future, there will be more privileges,'' Mr. Ma said. ''The Government is worried that the minorities aren't developing as fast as the rest of China.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/world.main_headline: Punished by Bucharest, City's Choice Was Revolt
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: ONE TOWN;   Punished by Bucharest, City's Choice Was Revolt
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/world.body_text: **********The man described his day. He wakes. He goes to buy milk for his children. For the babies, there is no formula to buy. He goes to work. The bus line is long and slow. It is cold at work. There is no heat, no equipment for proper work. He finishes work and goes to buy something to eat. But there is no food to buy. The next day, it is the same.  Thus did Victor Carauscu, a 28-year-old research engineer, describe the small and grinding deprivations that led him, on the night of Dec. 22, 1989, to take up arms against tyranny in the revolution that toppled Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife, Elena. **********His story, recounted to a reporter today, might be repeated by men and women across the land. But for the residents of this snowbound Transylvanian city cradled by pines and mountains, it was not the first time they had taken to the streets. **********'He Never Returned' **********In November 1987, workers from what used to be called the Red Flag Truck Factory went on strike to demand bread and money. Baton-wielding police officers charged and scattered the strikers when they tried to storm the Communist Party headquarters. One day later, the strike leaders, identified from security police videotapes of the protest, were rounded up. Some vanished.  Mr. Carauscu, who joined the 1987 demonstration, said about 60 people were formally tried on charges of terrorism and hooliganism and sentenced to two-year jail terms. **********Hundreds more, he said, were evicted from their homes, sent to other towns and made to work there. Still more, according to several residents here, who asked not to be identified, met a harsher fate. **********''They brought the son's clothing home in a cardboard box,'' a hotel employee said, describing what he said was an incident he had witnessed. ''The clothing was covered in dried blood. They did not explain to the parents what had happened to the son. But he never returned.'' **********Concessions, Then Punishment **********For a brief moment, the authorities offered concessions. Wages were increased. Food supplies began to arrive. Then, according to Mr. Carauscu and others, the food supplies ran out. ''We had less than before,'' he said. ''The whole city was being punished for the strike.'' **********That deepened the discontent that Rumanians used to discuss only among their closest friends, never knowing when they might be denounced by informers for doing so. **********''We thought that some of the leaders in Bucharest might do something,'' said Mr. Carauscu, who works at the factory's research department and of late has become a leader in the revolutionary committee here. ''But nobody did anything. We hoped the army might do something. But they didn't. We even hoped that Gorbachev might help us. But he didn't. The only way that remained was to fight and we fought.'' **********''The situation could not survive forever,'' he said, even if other Eastern European countries had not first thrown off Communist rule. He continued, ''In other countries it was changed peacefully. But that was not possible here.'' **********'Then We Knew he Was Weak' **********Yet, in conversations with him and with students who took part in the demonstrations that overthrew the Communist Party in this city, 100 miles north of Bucharest, one thing seemed clear: Without the clues provided by the capital's television and radio stations, the lesser revolutions around the country would not have charted their courses so easily. **********The first and overriding sign, said Julia Gavril, a 26-year-old drama student, was a broadcast of a speech in central Bucharest by Mr. Ceausescu on Dec. 21, during which the crowd booed him down and the television station, then in the hands of his regime, froze the transmission. **********''Then we knew he was weak and scared,'' she said. ''The whole country saw him frightened. This was a very important moment.'' **********The display of vulnerability spurred between 3,000 and 4,000 people to demonstrate outside the local party headquarters here, she said. Workers from Brasov's factories, including the Red Flag Truck Factory, came to protest. **********Protest at Central Square **********Already, she said, people had been angered by the accounts from foreign radio stations of the bloody suppression of protest in the western town of Timisoara. But the army and the police, not yet ready to switch allegiance, guarded the Communist Party headquarters, fired into the air and turned water cannon on the demonstrators. **********The next day, according to several accounts, thousands of people converged on the central square outside the Communist Party headquarters. They listened for news relayed by others watching the television, now in the hands of those who had forced the Ceausescus to flee Bucharest. **********About noon, the television broadcast the news of Mr. Ceausescu's helicopter flight from the Central Committee Headquarters in Bucharest. About 2 P.M., the army units guarding the local party headquarters in Brasov withdrew and the demonstrators poured into the local party building. **********Army Hands Out Guns to Rebels **********''People embraced, soldiers and workers,'' said Miss Gavril. ''Old men cried. I even saw an army officer with tears on his face.'' But the ordeal was not over. **********From Bucharest, on the television, came images of Mr. Ceausescu's Securitate, the secret police, counterattacking, opening fire on the crowds celebrating the new and still undefined order. **********''We thought the same thing could happen to us,'' said Mr. Carauscu. ''So we asked the army to come back and defend us.'' He said he had joined the core of those who made decisions without time for reaching a consensus, and was one of those at the local party offices when the army handed out the guns to the revolutionaries to fire on the Securitate units around them. **********About 2 A.M. on Saturday Dec. 23, the fighting in Brasov started, with pro-Ceausescu forces firing on the crowds and the army firing back. **********Counterattack by Securitate **********It took two days of swirling, ill-defined conflicts, scares and alarms for the fighting to die down. There were panics and rumors and confusions. **********Two of the supposed revolutionaries to whom the army had given guns in the party headquarters turned out to be Securitate infiltrators, who then turned their guns on the revolutionaries and were shot down. **********There was a counterattack on the security police headquarters against army units holding it. By the end, 64 people had been killed, Mr. Carauscu said. The national death toll is estimated by Western diplomats at 7,000. **********The fighting subsided when the television broadcast news of the execution of Mr. Ceausescu and his wife on Dec. 25, Mr. Carauscu said. **********''This was very good,'' he said, offering a view that has become controversial and has divided Rumanians. ''If he had remained alive and his forces had continued to fight for him, then all the country would have been transformed into a bloodbath. But this execution saved thousands of lives.''
