https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/17/busin.print_headline: Citicorp to Cut 215 Jobs at Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/17/busin.body_text: **********Citicorp said today that it would cut 215 jobs in a reorganization of its money-losing Citicorp Scrimgeour Vickers equities unit. **********Citicorp said up to 140 employees would be laid off while another 75 are being transferred within the organization, which will be integrated more closely with Citicorp's pan-European capital markets group. **********Citicorp Scrimgeour Vickers will be left with a total of 110 employees, it said. The banking company said Scrimgeour Vickers would cease to deal in fixed income securities, equities and related products.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Kohl Will Meet Gorbachev Today in Moscow on Unity
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Kohl Will Meet Gorbachev Today in Moscow on Unity
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl will fly to Moscow late Saturday for some personal diplomacy with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, hoping to convince the Soviet leader to drop his remaining objections to German unification within NATO, West German officials said today. **********Mr. Kohl will arrive just after a visit to Moscow by the NATO Secretary General, Manfred Worner. The session will be the first high-level West German-Soviet talks since February, when Mr. Kohl went to Moscow and convinced the Soviet leader to agree in principle to German reunification. **********Officials involved in the preparations said that among the issues that Mr. Kohl was prepared to discuss on Sunday and Monday was a ceiling on the strength of the united German armed forces. A Western diplomat said he believed that the Germans were prepared to set an all-German limit ''in the high 300,000's.'' That number would be about 100,000 below the oveall troop strength of West Germany last year. **********A Visit to the Caucasus **********Because of Mr. Gorbachev's preoccupation with the 28th Communist Party Congress, West German officials said, the details of the program are tentative. After talks in Moscow on Sunday morning, Mr. Gorbachev plans to fly with his guest to Stavropol, the city in the northern Caucasus where the Soviet President spent his childhood and began his Communist Party career. **********A visit to Mr. Gorbachev's native village, Privolnoye, is possible before the two leaders part at Mineralniye Vody, a northern Caucasus spa resort, on Monday afternoon, German officials said. **********While West German officials view the personally escorted sightseeing on Mr. Gorbachev's home turf as a significant personal gesture, there was a distinct shift in tone today in the way the officials discussed concrete prospects for the visit. **********Earlier, the public line was that Mr. Kohl, who had been pushing his allies at the recent summits of NATO, the European Community and the Group of Seven industrial democracies for a multinational economic aid package for the Soviet Union, would not go to Moscow with empty hands. Today, officials said he would not be offering any more money this weekend. **********Guaranteeing Bank Loans **********The officials said Mr. Kohl would point out that he had gotten his partners to agree to consider the possibility of effective assistance programs while Moscow worked out its plans for change. West Germany had shown its good faith, they said, by agreeing to guarantee $2.9 billion in bank loans and to pay the Soviet Union $781 million this year to cover the cost of stationing its 360,000 troops in East Germany. **********Finance Minister Theo Waigel and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher will also be in the delegation, and the Economics Minister, Helmut Haussmann, has drafted a comprehensive plan for expanding German trade, increasing oil and gas imports from the Soviet Union and broadening technical assistance for Soviet economic changes. Mr. Kohl will carry the plan in his briefcase in Moscow. ''There will be no further financial offers,'' an official said. **********The officials said that Mr. Kohl would also point out the political gestures that West Germany and its allies had made to allay Soviet fears about unification. Mr. Kohl plans to be the first NATO government head to explain to Mr. Gorbachev the implications of the London summit's decisions to transform NATO from a military to a political organization, invite the Soviet Union and other members of the Warsaw Pact to sign nonaggression pacts and to ask Mr. Gorbachev to address them at NATO headquarters in Brussels. **********A Meeting in Paris **********Will all this, and whatever Mr. Kohl whispers in private in Mr. Gorbachev's ear, be enough to get the Soviet Union to agree to the idea of a united Germany within NATO? One European diplomat said on the eve of the talks, ''If the Russians are capable at all of rational decision-making at the moment, they probably will fall into line,'' but he did not expect this to happen quite yet. **********Mr. Genscher and his Soviet counterpart, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, will meet in Paris again next Tuesday, with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Foreign Ministers of Britain, France and East Germany, for the next round of six-power talks on unification. **********In the Paris talks, Poland is expected to push for a commitment by the World War II Allies not to give up their residual occupation rights after unification until a united German government negotiates and ratifies a treaty guaranteeing the integrity of the postwar Polish-German border, along the Oder and Neisse Rivers several hundred miles to the west of the prewar line. **********West Germany, whose Parliament agreed with the East German Parliament to attain such a treaty, will argue in Paris that the promise is sufficient and that Germany should regain full sovereignty and unification after the all-German elections tentatively set for Dec. 2, officials here say. The United States will also reject the Polish demand, according to an American diplomat here. **********Mr. Kohl will discuss concrete measures to improve the lot of the estimated two million ethnic Germans in the Soviet Union, officials said, in hopes of reducing the flow of refugees coming to West Germany. Noting that 66,000 have arrived in this country so far this year, one official said, ''We want to put measures in place that will prevent a massive exodus.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/18/world.main_headline: Thailand Tells U.N. to Stop Aiding Burmese
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/18/world.print_headline: Thailand Tells U.N. to Stop Aiding Burmese
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/18/world.body_text: **********The Interior Ministry has threatened to expel United Nations or other refugee officials who assist Burmese dissidents living in Thailand, newspapers reported today. **********Thailand has close ties with the military Government in Myanmar, formerly Burma, which brutally crushed a student-led movement for democracy two years ago. Thousands fled the suppression and joined armed rebel groups in areas bordering Thailand and India. **********The Bangkok Government began reconsidering the status of Burmese asylum seekers after two Burmese students hijacked a Thai airliner flying to Myanmar last Saturday. Two other Burmese students had hijacked a jetliner to Thailand a year ago. **********The Nation newspaper said Chamnarn Potjana, deputy permanent secretary of the Interior Ministry, on Friday warned international organizations to stop helping Burmese students. **********If they did not, "no matter whether they are officials of the U.N.H.C.R. or other United Nations agencies, we will ask the Foreign Ministry to expel them from the country as persona non grata," Mr. Chamnarn was quoted as saying. U.N.H.C.R. stands for the United Nations High Commissioner forRefugees. **********The Bangkok Post quoted Mr. Chamnarn as saying that Burmese students were also thought to be responsible for a recent minor bombing of Myanmar's embassy compound in Bangkok. **********He said Thailand would deport violators of its laws. **********Mr. Chamnarn spoke after a Cabinet committee meeting. He said it had recommended the establishment of a holding camp for Burmese dissidents on the Thai-Burmese border. **********The private United States Committee for Refugees estimates that there are 2,000 Burmese students in Bangkok. Another 2,700 are on the Thai-Burmese border, said the All Burma Students' Democratic Front, the main group of exiled students. **********Thailand considers the students illegal immigrants subject to detention, fines and deportation. The students depend on the assistance of private relief groups and grants from the High Commissioner for Refugees ranging from $40 to $120 a month. **********The Nation quoted Mr. Chamnarn as saying that the High Commissioner's office should use the $120,000 monthly allowance it had for Burmese students to establish the border camp. **********The United States Committee for Refugees said Thailand has repatriated more than 5,200 Burmese, many of them students, since 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.main_headline: House Votes To Override Amtrak Veto
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.print_headline: House Votes To Override Amtrak Veto
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.body_text: **********The House of Representatives today overrode President Bush's veto of legislation continuing the Federal subsidy of Amtrak, the passenger rail line, but Senate action was delayed until next week as Republicans attempted to rally support for the veto. **********The contest was notable for its political symbolism, because it was this year's first veto confrontation between the Bush Administration and Congress, which is dominated by Democrats. **********President Bush vetoed the bill last month because of a provision that he contended would impose unnecessary new regulations on the railroad industry. The provision would expand the regulatory authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission, letting it review proposed takeovers of railroads by investors who are not already in the rail business. The commission already reviews acquisitions between railroad companies. **********Amtrak's nationwide passenger service will continue to operate under separate legislation even if the veto is sustained, lawmakers said. But new commuter rail service between Washington and its outer suburbs in Virginia would be stymied, and other minor provisions of the bill would not take effect. **********House members overrode the veto in a 294-to-123 vote, brushing aside the President's offer to approve similar legislation without the regulatory provision. **********Last year, Mr. Bush's first in office, he returned 10 bills to Congress and none of those were overridden. **********Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the committee that drafted the legislation, said he would oppose efforts to enact a substitute bill swiftly. He said the House had too much other pressing business to consider. **********Those arguing in favor of an override said the Administration was masking the veto's true objective -to undermine Federal support for rail passenger service. **********Both the Bush and Reagan administrations have opposed the Amtrak subsidy, which under the current bill would amount to almost $700 million in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. But the President's veto message did not mention the subsidy, concentrating instead on the provision that would require I.C.C. approval of all proposed acquisitions of railroads by companies that are not already in the rail business. **********In the Senate, where the Amtrak measure passed last month on a voice vote, the prospects for an override were considered too close to predict. Several Republicans were absent today, improving the Democrats' chances of getting the two-thirds majority needed to override the veto. **********But Republican leaders refused to bring the issue to a quick vote, and under Senate rules they were able to postpone consideration until next week. **********Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, was clearly annoyed at the failure to decide the matter today. **********''What should take an hour takes a day; what should take a day takes a week, and progress is painfully slow,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.main_headline: Dow Falls 12.16 Points in Light Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.print_headline: Dow Falls 12.16 Points in Light Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.body_text: **********Stocks slumped in light trading yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 12.16 points, to 2,674.55, in the wake of a rise in bond yields. **********Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 145.44 million shares from Monday's abnormally low 114.8 million, with 913 issues falling and 36 hitting new lows. An additional 557 stocks advanced, with 22 touching new highs and 36 hitting new lows. **********Traders attributed the jump in rates to strong retail sales so far this year, which in turn revived fears of inflation. **********The Dow transportation index rose 10.85 points, to 1,155.76, with Merrill Lynch & Company upgrading all five airline stocks on the S.&P. 500 -AMR, Delta, Pan Am, USAir and UAL - partly because energy prices are down. **********The approach of the so-called triple witching hour on Friday, when stock index futures, index options and equity options all expire, made traders particularly nervous, market analysts said. **********Upgrading of Airline Stocks **********Charles I. Clough, chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, said he had told the brokerage firm's sales force that it was upgrading the recommended weighting of airline stocks from one-half of 1 percent of an investment portfolio to three-quarters of 1 percent. Not only have fuel costs fallen, he said, but ''the takeover fluff is gone'' and ''it looks like the industry has another round of consolidation'' to come. Mr. Clough said Merrill Lynch was ''pulling back a little'' on capital goods stocks, like Caterpillar, because ''they have gotten ahead of themselves.'' **********UAL rose 3 3/8, to 139, on heavy volume. Traders said they had heard talk that the carrier's pilots would meet shortly, ostensibly to discuss a possible bid. Some analysts seemed skeptical. **********AMR rose 1 3/8, to 64 7/8, with over million shares changing hands, while Delta rose 1 5/8, to 71 3/4, also in brisk trading. Pan Am remained unchanged at 3 1/8, and USAir rose 1/8, to 30 1/4, both in heavy trading. **********Caterpillar fell 1, to 60 1/4; Clark Equipment 1 1/8, to 43 1/4; Martin Marietta 1 1/8, to 42 5/8, and McDonnell Douglas 1 3/8, to 55 7/8. **********Hugh Johnson, head strategist for the First Albany Corporation, argued that the broad market decline came in response to the strong retail sales picture for the first two months of the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/10/busin.body_text: **********The director of the Defense Department program that monitors the advanced technologies of America's foremost economic competitors has resigned, saying he has become frustrated by the Bush Administration's refusal to support plans to assist the nation's high-technology industries. **********Michael C. Sekora, a 33-year-old physicist who has directed the program, known as Project Socrates, in the Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency, said yesterday in an interview that he had submitted his resignation on April 20. **********Also on that day, Dr. Craig I. Fields, another leading advocate of assisting high technology, was removed from his position as director of the Defense Advanced Projects Agency. **********Mr. Sekora's resignation was independent of Dr. Fields's transfer, but the two men shared professional frustrations. **********Dr. Fields's removal last month has heightened an already-bitter controversy over what the Federal Government's role should be in support of critical high-technology industries. Advocates of a national industrial policy have argued that the Government should step up its efforts to bring the United States back as a major player in the consumer electronics industry and in defending industries like semiconductors and computers that are threatened by foreign competitors. **********But Administration officials have argued against any coordinated attempt to spend heavily on particular technologies, saying it is impossible to pick ''winning'' technologies. **********Others have suggested that the recent cutbacks are more likely to be related to across-the-board reductions at the Pentagon than to ideological issues. ''A lot of this may have little to do with ideological issues,'' said Gary R. Saxonhouse, professor of economics at the University of Michigan. ''They are cutting everywhere in the Defense Department. They have to make hard choices.'' **********Reasons for Resignation **********Mr. Sekora said he resigned because he thought he would be more effective doing similar research working with private corporations outside the Federal Government. He said that his resources had recently been cut at the Pentagon and that Defense Department executives had been stalling on legislation that would have combined his agency with a second group, the Defense Industrial Network, to create a stronger organization to collect information for industrial planning. **********''All the initiatives that were started under Reagan are taking hits from the Bush Administration,'' Mr. Sekora said. Project Socrates was created in 1988 and it was intended to build an accurate data base of many of the world's most advanced technologies to help planners assess the status of American high-technology efforts compared with those of foreign competitors. **********Mr. Sekora said he had set up a private company, Technology Strategic Planning Inc., and planned to work with corporations to provide assessments of foreign technology. **********In setting up Socrates, Mr. Sekora had been successful at gathering experts who could be called on to gauge competitive foreign technologies. **********'A Network of People' **********''What he's put together is a network of people in all of the major labs that we have both corporate and government,'' said Dr. Roy L. Beasley, a Defense Department consultant who is a specialist in military manufacturing technologies. ''They were all willing to work together to determine the status of the United States technology in any area.'' **********Mr. Sekora said information-gathering operations like Socrates were essential because the United States is no longer the unilateral leader in all advanced technologies. **********''Technology is becoming uniformly distributed around the world,'' he said. ''The way Socrates addressed technology was to say that every technology in the world is simulatneously a threat and a resource. The most advanced technology is now found in third-world countries or even small countries in the East bloc.'' **********The Socrates program in the Defense Intelligence Agency focused on tracking advances in microelectronics, exotic structural materials, superconductors, high-performance computers, high-definition television and a number of classifed technologies, he said. **********Project's History **********Project Socrates was part of a strategy advanced by Robert B. Costello, the former Under Secretary of Defense for acquisition during the Reagan Administration. Mr. Costello, who is now a research fellow at the Hudson Institute in Indianapolis, had established a number of programs to bolster economic competitiveness. **********Mr. Costello called the cutbacks unfortunate. ''They're terminating the only data base on industrial policy that the nation has,'' he said. ''I don't see how they can do this. You have to have this kind of information to even know how lay out your research and development money.'' **********Project Socrates is currently in the midst of a detailed evaluation of technologies that are critical for high-definition television, an advanced version of television that offers far sharper pictures than today's commercial television.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   To Albanians, 'Ciao Italia!' Means Haven
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   To Albanians, 'Ciao Italia!' Means Haven
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/world.body_text: **********Tattered, penniless and weary, but jubilant just the same, thousands of Albanian refugees sailed today into Western Europe and, they were certain, to a better life. **********The largest contingent - 3,915 men, women and children - crossed the Adriatic Sea in the dead of night aboard four ships, and celebrated the new day in this creaking port on the heel of the Italian boot. About 550 others journeyed on a separate ship to Marseilles. **********They are a ragtag bunch, unwashed, unshaven and ill-clothed after up to two weeks of shelter in Western embassies in Tirana, the Albanian capital. Some hobbled off the ships, and a few had to be carried off because of injuries suffered when they clambered over walls and smashed through gates in trucks to get onto embassy grounds. **********Newborn Among the Refugees **********One of the first to be brought off the ships was a baby born five days ago in the West German Embassy compound. Fourteen others spent their first day in the West in a Brindisi hospital, with an assortment of stomach and kidney problems and broken bones. **********But they had spanking new red passports in their pockets and promises of safe passage from Italy, West Germany, France and Greece. That, along with pluck, was all they needed to form the largest exodus from the last Stalinist stronghold in Eastern Europe. **********''Ciao Italia,'' they shouted, cheering and waving from the top deck as they glided into Brindisi aboard the Espresso Grecia, a cruise ship normally used to ferry backpacking European youths to island vacations in Greece. Today, the Espresso Grecia carried the blue flag of the United Nations, which supervised the evacuation by bus from Tirana and then the ship-boarding in the Albanian port of Durres. **********A 5-Hour Voyage **********On arrival in Brindisi, the refugees sipped milk and mineral water and ate cakes provided by the Italian Red Cross. Most tore eagerly at packages of clothing and shoes handed them to supplement the meager bundles they had carried, if they managed to bring even that much. **********There were unconfirmed reports that scuffles had broken out in Durres when other Albanians tried to force their way onto the ships. But Claudio Luksich, chief engineer of the Espresso Grecia, said ''everything was calm.'' To avoid provoking the Albanian authorities, he said, the refugees had heeded requests to remain quiet as they embarked on the five-hour, 85-mile voyage. **********Overwhelmingly, the new arrivals were in their 20's and 30's. Mr. Luksich said older people who appear to have been dispatched by the Albanian Government went to Durres to beckon the young people to stay. **********Among those who ignored the plea was Eno Vaso, a 27-year-old college graduate, who stood barefoot, having lost his shoes during his escape into the West German Embassy. **********''I want to change my life,'' Mr. Vaso said in Italian, which he said he learned in part from watching Italian television. ''I want to lead a better life. I don't want Communism.'' **********Australia a Destination **********Like many of the refugees, he said he hoped ultimately to reach Australia, where an uncle lives. Others gave the United States and Canada as their havens of preference. A few, among them Rodolf Hadhami, insisted that they would return home ''when Albania is free,'' which Mr. Hadhami predicted would be within two years. **********Several said that through Italian and Yugoslav television they were well aware of the changes that had swept other corners of Eastern Europe, and they also knew of the similar flight to freedom by foreign embassies that East Germans had made a year ago. **********For now, the Albanians will stay in the countries whose embassies had given them shelter, and for most that means West Germany. **********About 3,050 of them boarded three long special trains that came from Germany to carry them north. It was not clear where they would wind up, but a West German diplomat, Friedrich W. Catoir, said they would be housed for a while in six reception centers. **********An Abandoned Army Depot **********Brindisi's prefect, Giuseppe Mazzitello, said 29 people who had fled into the Greek Embassy were to be flown to Greece, while 841 more refugees would stay in Italy while they figure out to do next. Italy has an ethnic Albanian population of about 150,000, concentrated in the hardscrabble South, and some of those communities have offered to shelter their compatriots. **********The Italian group was taken to an abandoned army depot outside Brindisi, where they will stay in old buildings equipped in the last few days with cots, kitchens and portable toilets. On Thursday soldiers hacked away at weeds and tore down rolls of barbed wire, which were seen as an unseemly early sight for people seeking freedom. **********In the long term, the Albanians' future is less clear, for it is uncertain if they will be deemed political refugees or simply emigrants in search of better living conditions. The decision could have a significant effect on whether they will be allowed to resettle in their chosen countries. **********'Came Here to Find Work' **********''Life in Albania is very difficult,'' said Ganti Borova, a 23-year-old architecture student. ''We came here to find work.'' **********That point was echoed by many of the new arrivals. **********But others asserted that they and their families had spent years opposing the Communist Government and that their flight was purely political. Nevres Tabaku, a woman in her 50's, said that her parents had been jailed as dissidents and so had her brother, Iuli, who stood by her today and who, she said, had been imprisoned for 27 years. **********''This is a family that has spent a hundred years in prison,'' she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/15/world.main_headline: Both Kabul and Rebels Report Battle Gains
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/15/world.print_headline: Both Kabul and Rebels Report Battle Gains
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/15/world.body_text: **********Muslim guerrillas said today that they had captured strategic security outposts and killed more than 200 Afghan troops in their latest attempt to capture the capital, Kabul. **********The Afghan Government said in a broadcast on state radio that its soldiers had killed 177 guerrillas who were trying to overrun the city and had destroyed a huge cache of arms. **********Claims by the guerrillas and the Kabul Government are often exaggerated and difficult to verify. **********Midia, the press agency of the guerrillas' leadership in Pakistan, said rebel fighters had captured 16 outposts in intense fighting south and east of Kabul and had chipped away at the security belt surrounding the city. It said 16 guerrillas were killed in the latest battle to unseat the Soviet-backed Government. **********But the official Kabul radio, monitored in Islamabad, said the guerrillas had suffered heavily losses in their two-pronged attack. The radio said that sporadic clashes continued in several places near the city, but that the worst fighting had ended. **********Fighting between the Islamic fundamentalist rebels and Government troops usually intensifies from late September to early November, before winter snowstorms blanket the mountains that ring the capital.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/11/busin.body_text: **********The stock of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation fell $2 today, to $72, on the New York Stock Exchange in the wake of what analysts described as a lackluster presentation by the company at a meeting on Tuesday. Traders said that a relative lack of enthusiasm by Paul Lego, Westinghouse's president and chief operating officer, at a session with securities analysts had had a negative effect on the stock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/03/busin.main_headline: German Union Instills Vision Of a Great Continent Reborn
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/03/busin.print_headline: German Union Instills Vision Of a Great Continent Reborn
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/03/busin.body_text: **********When European business leaders describe their vision of Europe, they usually talk of building a bigger, more united, more dynamic continent. German unification fits neatly into that vision. **********Chief executives at several of Europe's largest corporations said, in a series of interviews, that the unification of West Germany and East Germany would be the crucial first step toward a merging of Western and Eastern Europe that could result in a family of nations larger and more dynamic than today's Western Europe. **********''The European challenge is to restore the Europe of 1914, when Europe was the biggest economic power in the world and had the best-educated population, one that is twice the population of the United States and four times the population of Japan,'' said Hans-Jorg Rudloff, chairman of Credit Suisse-First Boston, a leading investment bank in London. **********But German unification may hurt some countries and companies, the European executives warn. As investment money flows into East Germany, it might be harder for struggling African and Latin American nations to attract funds for development. **********Similarly, the stream of West German capital that has poured into factories in southern Europe may largely be rechanneled toward the East, halting the investment benefits enjoyed recently by Spain and Portugal, for example. **********Still, the executives view German unification as a welcome prospect in general. After complaining for years about slow European growth, a malady they called Eurosclerosis, executives say a greater Europe will provide vast opportunities for growth. It will also give European companies a stronger foundation for competing against American and Japanese corporate giants. **********West Germany is expected to spend hundreds of billions of dollars to rebuild East Germany and bring its living standards up to the much-envied levels of the Federal Republic. That will require stepped-up production by West Germany's potent industrial machine; ''the locomotive of Europe'' will have to pull all of the continent to faster growth. **********Some Western European business leaders worry that unification will make West German companies even more formidable competitors. Titans like Siemens, Daimler-Benz and Deutsche Bank will expand their reach, and British, French and Italian executives say their companies will have to work hard to stay in fighting trim. **********These business executives assert that German unification should in no way slow the European Community's plans to drop all internal trade barriers by late 1992, creating a single central bank and currency for the 12 nations. **********Instead, they say, European unification should be accelerated so that a united Germany is created under a large, watertight European roof. **********Rather than gloating at the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, some of the eight modern knights of capitalism interviewed say it is a time of unusual responsibility for the West. **********''We have to pay the bill,'' said Carlo de Benedetti, chairman of Olivetti, the Italian company that makes office automation equipment and personal computers. ''The bill has to be paid by the ones who have the money and not the ones who don't have the money.'' A Bigger Market Open to Everyone LARS RAMQVIST Recently chosen chief executive of Ericsson, the Swedish telecommunications company. **********German unification is bound to be the first step toward building a great, united Europe, East and West. This united Europe will be 700 million people, according to the old definition of Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals. **********In the beginning, it will be tough to do business in East Germany, but long-term it will be a bigger market that will open up to everyone. What's important in all this is that it is the first step in a bigger Europe, and that will be positive for Swedish industry. Running 'Like Mad' To Stay Competitive SIR DENYS HENDERSON Chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries, Britain's largest chemical company. **********There is a pent-up demand to improve standards of living, not just in East Germany but in the East bloc as a whole. There is a somewhat naive view that it is going to create a massive new market overnight in the East bloc. My view is that it's great, but you are not going to switch overnight from a totalitarian economy to a market economy. **********In the short term, it might make it slightly easier to compete against German industry. The Germans are committed to achieving unification and there will be a cost to that absorption. If their capital priorities are directed toward the East bloc, it might mean some distractions about what they hope for in other parts of the world: Asia and the United States. **********In the long term, it will make German competition tougher because the German market will be an even bigger market. In a decade when demography is going to be a problem in terms of getting new skilled workers into the economy, it will give the Germans access to a very skilled work force. After the absorption period has gone through, that will put German industry in a very strong position. We will have to run like mad to improve our productivity, our technological base and international presence to compete satisfactorily. **********The negative part is that it is just possible that West Germany's absorption of East Germany's ostmark may produce higher inflation in West Germany, which will undoubtedly produce higher interest rates. This will be matched in other parts of the world, and that means the United States and Japan. That could produce a slowdown in growth. Solving the Problems Left by Communism CARLO DE BENEDETTI Chairman of Olivetti, the Italian office machine and computer company. **********The real unification in terms of willingness and spirit is a fait accompli. The consequence of this is that we are at a turning point for Europe. **********I think we should negotiate politically with Germany that it is in the best interests of all of the community's partners to speed up the process of European integration before a negative climate appears in other European countries that Germany is too powerful, too arrogant. **********We couldn't be more happy seeing the total and irreversible collapse of Communism, ideologically and practically. Communism has failed because it hasn't been able to solve the real problems of those countries in terms of democracy, economic freedom, social structure, consumer satisfaction. **********The real news is that we have to be the ones who will be in charge of solving those problems. The challenge for the Western world, for the capitalistic world and specifically for Western Europe, will be to help solve those problems. Renewing a Nation In Need of Repair PERCY BARNEVIK Chairman of Asea Brown Boveri, a Swiss-Swedish company that is Europe's largest electrical engineering group. **********During a short-term transition period, German unification could create some problems, such as higher inflation and, consequently, higher interest rates. **********Medium-term, the reconstruction of East Germany represents enormous business opportunities. We estimate that 600 billion Deutsche marks will be needed for housing, 40 billion for new power plants, 8 billion for new telephone lines and 100 billion to 150 billion marks to renew the transportation system. This means larger markets for both West Germany and the European Community. **********Industry and governments have to act quickly to support East Germany to build an adequate industrial infrastructure. Only this will keep the East Germans there. A mass migration could thus be avoided. **********Environmental issues are a top priority. East Germany urgently needs new equipment to reduce toxic emissions. Its power plants are 35 percent less efficient than those in the West. **********At first, West German companies will be more absorbed with East Germany and thus have to slightly reduce capacity available for other markets. At the same time, suppliers from other Eastern European nations will have a harder time supplying East Germany as their trade system changes to hard currency dealings. Product quality will play an increased role. **********In the second phase, the position of West German industry will be improved because of the larger market and better production-sharing possibilities with East Germany. This will create tougher competition for non-German companies. **********There is a real risk that West German interests are, for the moment, somewhat diverted toward East Germany. As a result, some people in Brussels are afraid of a slowdown in the integration process. This need not be the case if the other European Community members insist strongly enough. West Germany has the capacity to go both ways at the same time. Balancing Emotions Against the Realities MICHEL FRANCOIS-PONCET Chairman of Compagnie Financiere de Paribas, a French banking group. **********German unification is a complex and a not-so-complex situation. East Germany is about 10 percent of West Germany in terms of gross national product, but it's at least 25 percent in terms of population. It is one-fifth in terms of productivity ratios. Therefore, you have a set of problems balancing the political emotions and the consequences on East Germany of issues like unemployment. **********German unity will mean a different economic balance in Europe. It will become a country of 80 million people, and the game will not be exactly the same. **********For some French companies, there is already a certain feeling of inferiority. It varies from one company to the next. Unification will create a larger market for industrial companies in Germany; it gives them a more powerful base. French companies will have to maintain their cool and not hesitate to take chances. More Consumption And a New Impetus JEAN-LOUIS BEFFA Chairman of Saint-Gobain, the Paris-based glass and packaging company. **********German unification is a very positive development. It expands the market. It's going to be a new impetus for economic demand. **********When the Common Market was formed, everyone worried about what would happen to French industry as opposed to German industry, but basically it was a positive factor. It will be the same now. It will be good for the good companies, whether German of French. The dynamic companies in France are already reacting and signing agreements. **********If all goes quickly and in the right direction, the so-called German question will be solved and we will be in a position to integrate Europe and more quickly. I am in favor of not slowing down European integration and support pushing for German reunification within the European Community. **********When a country like East Germany starts growing, its people will improve their housing, buy cars, buy packaging, and all that is going to help us. Showing Willingness To Transfer Wealth HANS-JORG RUDLOFF Chairman of Credit Suisse-First Boston, a London-based investment bank. **********If what the Germans have is economic and monetary union, then it will be nothing else than a huge investment program. A lot of money will have to be invested in industrial stock, streets and railways. **********Germany being a first-class borrower, if it starts borrowing heavily, whether for companies or government, it will clearly divert investment money from other areas. What we will see is a competition for capital all around the world. All this will happen when monetary policy all over the world is very tight and when there is a huge debt burden out of the 1980's to pay off or refinance. It will create a big competition for savings. **********I'm not talking about East Germany alone, but the entire East, and that includes the Soviet Union. If you divert huge streams of capital to these areas, wherever these funds are diverted from will have to tighten their belts. **********Will unification be inflationary? My answer is no. The Germans have a superb tradition of handling inflation. They are always willing to make the sacrifice to avoid inflation. **********Will it be impetus for growth? Yes. But will that additional growth be negated by less growth in other areas of the world? That could very well be. **********No one should have the illusion that it is good enough to applaud the liberation of 120 million people from 40 years of dictatorship, praising our own system and how we proved beyond any doubt that the capitalistic liberal system is superior in economic terms to the 80-year-old Marxist system. To applaud that is not good enough. Now we have to help these people who aspire to the same living standards that we have. We have to show that we're willing to transfer some of that wealth. New 'Marshall Plans' To Prime the Pumps CORNELIS VAN DER KLUGT Chairman of Philips N.V., the international electronics group based in the Netherlands. **********German unification is inevitable. It will strengthen Germany, and therefore it will also strengthen the European Community. Everyone is hell-bent to make sure that it doesn't slow down European integration. We should never slow down European integration - it's already 30 years late. But it might slow down if everyone places their priorities elsewhere. **********There is no longer an Eastern bloc. Some countries will move fast, like Hungary. Others will move almost as fast, like Czechoslovakia, and then there is the next layer: Poland, the Soviet Union, Romania, and Bulgaria, countries that will come later. In countries where there is so little and such low purchasing power, the interest for business will be the initial infrastructural projects, which will be done with money from our side. **********These improvements will bring these countries to a higher productivity, which will give them possibilities to export to Western Europe and to increase their material well-being. This is a long-term process, with the initial business based on a Marshall Plan-type of approach.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/19/world.main_headline: Soviets Said to Withdraw Fighters and Bombers From Vietnam Base
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/19/world.print_headline: Soviets Said to Withdraw Fighters and Bombers From Vietnam Base
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/19/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union has withdrawn all of its MIG-23 fighter planes and about half of its TU-16 bombers from its base at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam, Pentagon officials said today, in a move the officials said would reduce Soviet military abilities in Southeast Asia. **********But Pentagon officials added that there were no indications that the Soviet Union planned to shut down the base, which is used to refuel Soviet ships on their way to the Indian Ocean. **********Cam Ranh Bay, which was built by the United States in the Vietnam War, is the largest Soviet naval base outside of the Soviet Union. For years, the Pentagon has described the base as a threat to the United States and Southeast Asian nations. **********Cam Ranh Bay ''extends the Soviet wartime reach over East Asia's sea lines of communication in the South China Sea and poses a challenge as well to the U.S. military presence in the Philippines,'' the Pentagon said in its 1988 Soviet military power report. **********Squadron of Fighters **********The 1988 report said that the Soviet Union maintained a squadron of 14 MIG-23 fighters at the base to defend the installation from attack and to escort other planes. It added that Moscow had 16 Badger bombers, 10 of which were capable of carrying anti-ship cruise missiles. **********While the Pentagon said in its 1988 report that Soviet planes and ships at Cam Ranh Bay could be destroyed in a global war with ''relative ease,'' it said that such an action would divert American forces from other missions. **********But today a Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, Vadim Perfilyev, said that the Soviet Union had withdrawn MIG-23 fighters and TU-16 bombers from the base. Mr. Perfilyev said 6 to 10 Soviet aircraft remained, but he gave no details. The withdrawal of the planes was disclosed this week in a report by The International Herald Tribune. **********Pentagon officials familar with intelligence reports offered their elaborations today on the withdrawal of the aircraft. **********They said the only squadron of Soviet MIG-23 fighters at Cam Ranh Bay, about 12 planes, had been taken apart and shipped back to the Soviet Union. **********Described as 'Junkers' **********About half of the Soviet Union's force of TU-16 bombers had flown back to the Soviet Union, Pentagon officials added. The remaining half a dozen or so bombers were described as ''junkers'' by one Pentagon official. ''They are the sort of planes that nobody ever expects will fly again,'' the official said. **********While the withdrawal significantly reduces the Soviet Union's capability to attack ships in the area, the Russians still have TU-95 Bear long-range reconnaissance planes at Cam Ranh Bay. A Pentagon official said that about four of these planes were based there. **********The number of Soviet ships stationed at the base has declined since 1988, when the Pentagon said the Soviet naval presence at Cam Ranh Bay included about 25 ships, including 2 to 4 submarines. **********Pentagon officials said today that Moscow now had fewer than 20 ships at Cam Ranh Bay, including one submarine. The ships there are small fighting and support ships. **********Soviet Cut in Spending **********Pentagon officials said that the declining Soviet military presence at Cam Ranh Bay is part of the larger Soviet effort to cut military spending. **********Some Western and Asian diplomats in Southeast Asia have suggested that the move is also designed to improve relations with China and to increase pressure on the United States to reduce its military presence in Asia and the western Pacific, in particular at its bases in the Philippines. **********But Pentagon officials asserted that there were no indications that Moscow intended to abandon the Cam Ranh Bay base. **********''The ships have not left,'' said one Pentagon official, who did not wish to be identified. ''The people have not left. Strategically, it is still pretty important to their deployments in the Indian Ocean. There is no sign that they intend to leave.'' The official said that while the withdrawal of the Soviet planes was welcome, the United States would not have had much difficulty ''neutralizing'' the aircraft in a war. **********'Purely Defensive Structure' **********Mr. Perfilyev, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, said the withdrawal of the planes was part of a move to a ''purely defensive structure in the Asia-Pacific region'' and was being carried out in consultation with the Vietnamese. **********He added that ''the Soviet side hopes that these actions will help to defuse military-political tension'' in the region. **********In 1988, the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, offered to abandon Cam Ranh Bay if the United States did the same with its six military bases in the Philippines. American officials dismissed the offer, saying that the United States needed to maintain naval bases in the Pacific to support its worldwide operations. **********The State Department said it welcomed reports that Soviet planes had been withdrawn from Cam Ranh Bay. ''We anticipate that less Soviet military involvement in southeast Asia would contribute to regional stability and to efforts to achieve a comprehensive political settlement in the Cambodia conflict,'' a State Department spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/05/busin.print_headline: MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Macy's Ad Assails Financial Rumors
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/05/busin.body_text: **********Frustrated by the continuing speculation about the financial stability of R.H. Macy & Company, Edward S. Finkelstein, its chairman and chief executive, took a full-page advertisement in a leading retailing trade paper yesterday to respond to "unfounded rumors and misinformation, which serve no one." **********In the advertisement, which appeared in Women's Wear Daily at a reported price of about $15,000, Mr. Finkelstein leveled an attack on what close associates say is a pet peeve -- the growing conviction among suppliers and creditors that Macy's future is staked to sales performance this Christmas. **********"No 'miracles on 34th Street' are required this Christmas," he stated in the advertisement, a reference to the holiday movie that is centered on Macy's flagship store on 34th Street in Manhattan. "The season will not make or break Macy's. We expect it to be slow and we are prepared for it." **********The ad, which some in the industry say only lends credence to the rumors, was in the form of a letter from Macy's and signed by Mr. Finkelstein. It begins, "Dear Friends: It has become fashionable of late for uninformed outsiders to speculate about Macy's status and future." **********The letter was also distributed to Macy's employees earlier this week, a company spokesman said. **********Mr. Finkelstein declared in the ad, "We have $650 million less in inventory this Christmas season than last, so there is no need to resort to last year's level of markdowns, regardless of what others may do." **********He added: "Our gross margins this Christmas quarter will be superior to last year's. We are focusing on profitability, not volume, and are committed to preserving traditional gross margins." **********Mr. Finkelstein is said by people close to Macy's to have been especially irritated by recent news reports about the sharp increase in its losses, which rose to $66 million in the first fiscal quarter, ended Oct. 31, and by other articles suggesting that Macy's may face what Federated Stores confronted last January: a bankruptcy filing. **********Last Thursday the Standard & Poor's Corporation said it was reviewing for a possible downgrading the speculative-grade rating for Macy's subordinated debt. The rating agency said the action reflected Macy's continuing weak retail sales in the context of the company's highly leveraged capital structure. Macy's is about $5 billion in debt from a 1986 leveraged buyout led by Mr. Finkelstein and a 1988 acquisition of the Bullock's and I. Magnin retail chains in California. **********In the advertisement, Mr. Finkelstein tried to address the ramifications of some of these issues. "Macy's has ample liquidity to meet all of its obligations under any economic scenario we can foresee," he said. "In fact, even after making our $68 million debt principal payment later this month, we will be cash positive and have $475 million of excess bank borrowing capacity." **********The advertisement drew mixed reactions. **********"It's certainly a gamble that by running the ad he is reinforcing the rumors," said Bud Konheim, president of Nicole Miller Inc., a dress and sportswear maker. "It's obvious that Mr. Finkelstein is frustrated because no one is telling the story the way he wants it to be told. He probably feels embattled on several fronts. He used to make himself available to the media, but now he has other people doing it for him. But, in my opinion, he is doing well coping with all his problems." **********Others doubted that the advertisement made a convincing case. "It's a bold move for Macy's to make considering that neither they nor anyone else knows that the retail business will be better in 1991 than it was in 1990," said David Rachman, professor of marketing at Baruch College in New York. "Ed Finkelstein must also be feeling pressure from suppliers. But if I were doing this, I would have my favorite banker also writing a statement in the ad or appearing with me on the six o'clock news." **********He said the advertisement might have been a ploy to buy time. "I suspect that he may be in the midst of making a major or otherwise important deal and ran the ad to buck up the morale of factors and creditors until the deal takes place," Professor Rachman said. **********In the ad, Mr. Finkelstein also stated: "Any comparison between Macy's and the situation in which Campeau Corporation (now Federated) found itself last winter is simply wrong. Campeau didn't have ample cash to meet its obligations -- we do; Campeau had huge, ballooning debt and interest payments to meet in a very short time frame -- we don't; and Campeau wasn't run by merchants who have seen hard times before and know how to plan for them -- we are." **********Federated Stores, which owns Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus, declined to comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/09/busin.main_headline: Top Officer Retiring From Amstar Sugar
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Top Officer Retiring From Amstar Sugar
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/09/busin.body_text: **********The Amstar Sugar Corporation, makers of the Domino brand, said yesterday that William C. Shanley is retiring as president and chief executive effective on Oct. 1 and will be succeeded by Jack F. Lay, who is now senior vice president. **********Amstar is a subsidiary of Tate & Lyle P.L.C., a British concern that is the world's largest sweetener company, making corn sweetener, beet and cane sugar and awaiting government clearance for an artificial sweetener. Mr. Shanley, 65 years old, will become president of Tate & Lyle Inc., a United States subsidiary of Tate & Lyle. He described the post as a part-time one in which he will deal with legislative and Wall Street issues. **********''Neil asked me to take the job since I've been in the business for 40 years,'' Mr. Shanley said, referring to Neil M. Shaw, chairman and chief executive of the London-based Tate & Lyle. **********Mr. Shanley pointed out that 40 percent of the parent company's assets are now in the United States. They include, in addition to Amstar, the A.E. Staley Manufacturing Company, a major producer of corn sweeteners and starches; the Western Sugar Company, which operates seven beet sugar factories in the Western United States, and the Pacific Molasses Company. **********Mr. Shanley is being replaced by another longtime executive of the sugar industry, Mr. Lay, 60. He joined Amstar in 1952, three years after Mr. Shanley did so. He became plant manager at the company's packaging facility in Philadelphia, supervised the construction of a new packaging plant in Charleston, S.C., and managed the Brooklyn refinery after moving to New York in 1965. An industrial engineering graduate of Johns Hopkins University, Mr. Lay was named a senior vice president of the company in 1986. **********Mr. Shanley is a graduate of Cornell University with a degree in electrical engineering and holds a master's degree in chemical engineering from Columbia University. **********Mr. Shanley has led Amstar for the last 10 years, a period that saw the company change hands in two mangement-led leveraged buyouts before its sugar unit was bought by Tate & Lyle in 1988 for $305 million. **********''Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts bought us first,'' he said, ''and then Merrill Lynch. We finally got owned by a sugar company instead of a financial company, and everyone in Amstar was delighted with that.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.main_headline: American Wins Friends and Influence at the U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.print_headline: American Wins Friends and Influence at the U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.body_text: **********When Thomas R. Pickering, the United States representative here, started whispering into a portable phone during the Security Council debate on Panama last month, he reinforced the split image that many people have of him after his first year on the job. **********As usual, he strode quickly into the Council session, his great height and gold glasses giving him an earnest air. And the cordless telephone he carries almost everywhere is his personal contribution to the job of representing the United States at the United Nations. **********At one level it seems to symbolize the professionalism that he is credited with bringing to the post. But by suggesting that Mr. Pickering is kept on a short leash by his superiors, the phone is a reminder that he is a rarity, an American permanent representative to the United Nations who does not have a seat in the Cabinet, and only the second career diplomat to hold the job. The first was Charles W. Yost, who served under President Nixon. **********Bush's Old Stamping Ground **********Just why President Bush downgraded a post that he once held is unclear. Some say Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d insisted on it after hearing of the difficulties that former Secretaries had with past representatives. Others say Mr. Bush wanted to prevent Ronald Reagan from lobbying for the job for his daughter Maureen, who took part in the General Assembly session in 1988 as a member of the American delegation, and who was reportedly interested in the post. **********Nevertheless, President Bush's choice of Mr. Pickering is seen as encouraging at the United Nations. **********By giving the post to a respected Foreign Service professional, President Bush seemed to end the ideological confrontation of the Reagan years and to accept that the United Nations could play a useful role in global problems now that cold war tension is fading. **********Mr. Pickering is praised for his mastery of the issues, his energy and his openness. ''When you deal with him even as a small country you find he has done his homework,'' said Dr. Chan Heng Chee, Singapore's representative. Yves Fortier, the representative from Canada, said, ''He often doesn't need to open his briefing book.'' **********'Pinching and Pushing' **********''Pickering is on top of the United Nations agenda,'' said Prof. Lincoln P. Bloomfield of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ''He understands the tricky problems it can help with.'' Professor Bloomfield, Director of Global Issues on President Carter's National Security Council, added, ''but he must keep pinching and pushing Washington to keep the faith.'' **********Such praise implies unhappiness with Mr. Pickering's predecessor, Vernon A. Walters, now the United States Ambassador in Bonn. Mr. Walters spoke a half-dozen languages, but was not thought to be a master of detail and traveled often on Presidential missions. ''Either he wasn't there or you saw your precious half-hour wasted on jokes and anecdotes,'' a United Nations representative recalled. **********But while many welcome Mr. Pickering's technocratic approach, some regret the loss of that prestigious Cabinet seat and wonder whether he can do enough ''pinching and pushing'' in Washington without it. **********'Pickering Is Terrific' **********Edward Luck, president of the United Nations Association of the United States, shares that view. ''We think Pickering is terrific,'' he said. ''But we still want the Cabinet seat restored because it gives him more authority within the State Department.'' **********In particular, Mr. Luck thinks that a Cabinet seat strengthens the representative's hand in dealings with the Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, the State Department official directly in charge of United Nations matters, and the official to whom Mr. Pickering reports. **********''Traditionally the Republicans have used this job to pay off the extreme right, which doesn't like the United Nations,'' Mr. Luck said. ''That's why Pickering needs extra authority.'' **********John R. Bolton, the current Assistant Secretary, is a conservative who once worked for Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. Mr. Bolton praises many aspects of the United Nations, and last year the Bush Administration asked Congress to send the organization its full funding and to start paying off Washington's huge backlog of dues to the United Nations. Congress refused to do so. **********No Suite or Limousine **********While Mr. Pickering is praised by colleagues at the United Nations, they also note that he has suffered embarrassments in recent months at the hands of Washington's power brokers. **********The State Department acknowledged his reduced status by removing the impressive sixth-floor office suite that his predecessors were given in Washington, as well as the personal limousine. **********Mr. Pickering shrugs off the loss, although those close to him say he fought to retain the Washington office and car. **********Sitting recently in the United States Mission on First Avenue, in a sunny room across from the United Nations, Mr. Pickering played down the loss of the Cabinet seat. ''The President told me he thinks I can do what he wants done here,'' he said. ''So I have his confidence. And when U.N. matters are discussed he invites me to the Cabinet, so what do I lose?'' **********A Staff Shortfall **********Mr. Pickering failed to win Congressional backing for the higher pay and perks that he says the Mission needs to attract quality officials to New York. Washington's United Nations office is about 25 percent understaffed. **********On two occasions, Mr. Pickering's advice has been rejected by the Administration. Although he predicted that the Palestine Liberation Organization could be stopped from winning recognition as a state, as it was seeking at last year's General Assembly session, the State Department weighed in with a threat to bankrupt the organization if the P.L.O. was admitted as a nation. The Arabs nations decided eventually not to press the issue. **********Soon after, Vice President Dan Quayle demanded the repeal of a General Assembly resolution equating Zionism with racism, although Mr. Pickering, like other Western diplomats, judged this effort difficult without a Middle East breakthrough. **********Both episodes angered America's allies because they showed the United States in an arrogant light, trying to impose conditions even while owing the organization a half-billion dollars in dues. But many experts say a Cabinet seat and a big office in Washington would not have made much difference. **********Bush Under Nixon **********After all, George Bush was cast in the role of straw man by President Nixon, who left him struggling to keep China out of the United Nations in the early 1970's while Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger was secretly negotiating its admission in Beijing. **********And Daniel Patrick Moynihan, now the Democratic Senator from New York, had no illusions about his importance as a Cabinet officer when he served here under President Ford. **********He began ''A Dangerous Place,'' a book about his spell as United States permanent representative, by recalling the fate of many of his predecessors. He wrote: ''I had seen Stevenson humiliated. Goldberg betrayed. Ball diminished. Wiggins patronized. Yost ignored. Bush traduced. Scali savaged.'' **********''A man of Tom Pickering's experience knows his way around Washington and can get his views across effectively,'' a senior American diplomat said. ''But he is still basically an ambassador who most of the time carries out orders made by others.'' **********A Visible Post **********A direct, open man, Mr. Pickering always seemed assured of success. Born in 1931, he was educated at Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Me., before attending the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University and winning a Fulbright Scholarship to study in Australia. After State Department posts in intelligence and arms, he served as Deputy Chief of Mission in Tanzania and as special assistant to William P. Rogers and Mr. Kissinger when they were Secretary of State. **********He was Ambassador to Jordan, Assistant Secretary of State for Oceans and International Environment and Scientific Affairs, and Ambassador to Nigeria, El Salvador and Israel before taking the United Nations post. **********Despite its curtailed privileges, the United Nations job remains a singularly prestigious and visible post, one that involves dealing with 158 foreign governments at once. The job brings a rambling apartment at the top of the Waldorf Towers where Mr. Pickering lives with his wife, Alice, and their two children. The apartment costs the Government about $250,000 a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/24/busin.main_headline: Milken Plea Is Said to Be Set for Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/24/busin.print_headline: Milken Plea Is Said to Be Set for Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/24/busin.body_text: **********Michael R. Milken, who created the high-yield ''junk bond'' market that financed many of the big corporate takeovers in the 1980's, will plead guilty today to violating a series of regulations governing securities transactions, people who have been briefed about the plea agreement said. **********The violations will include aiding in the false filing of information with the Government, assisting in the violation of net capital rules for a stock trading firm, conspiracy and other crimes. **********After Mr. Milken reportedly agreed on Friday to plead guilty to six felonies, it was rumored among securities lawyers and on Wall Street that he would admit to widespread wrongdoing, including crimes involving a number of takeovers and dealings with the nation's savings and loan associations. **********Plea Is Narrower in Scope **********But the plea, which will be entered in Federal District Court in Manhattan, is much narrower in scope, the people who had received the briefings said yesterday. **********Mr. Milken, the former head of the junk bond division at the defunct Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., will plead guilty to aiding Ivan F. Boesky, the former stock speculator, in filing false documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission, these people said. Mr. Boesky, who settled charges of insider trading in 1986 and paid $100 million in penalties, provided essential testimony for the Goverment's case against Mr. Milken. **********Mr. Milken will also plead guilty to aiding and abetting Mr. Boesky in violating the net capital rules that governed the Seemala Corporation, Mr. Boesky's stock trading firm. Net capital rules set a minimum on the amount of liquid capital a securities firm must hold. **********Although the identity of the stock that was used in the net capital violation could not be determined, Mr. Milken was charged by the S.E.C. with agreeing to buy stock in the Phillips Petroleum Company from Mr. Boesky in an effort to reduce Seemala's net capital deficiency. **********In addition, Mr. Milken will plead guilty to aiding David Solomon, another former junk bond trader and founder of Solomon Asset Management, in filing a false income tax return. Last year, Mr. Solomon resigned from his job and agreed to provide evidence for the Government in the Milken case. **********Mr. Milken will also plead guilty to two other charges, including providing a customer with a guarantee against a loss in a securities transaction. Such an agreement would amount to illegal parking of securities, because the market risk would have been removed from the deal. **********Conspiracy Charge **********In addition to the regulatory violations, Mr. Milken will plead guilty to conspiracy to violate the securities laws. **********Mr. Milken however, will not plead guilty to rackteering, insider trading, obstruction of justice, or any of the other more serious charges that some had thought he would face. **********Because participants in the junk bond market had been expecting some settlement of the Government's investigation, the proposed deal with Mr. Milken was treated almost as a non-event, many traders said yesterday. **********''It's totally anticlimactic,'' said Mark Durbiano, a portfolio manager at Federated Securities in Pittsburgh. **********Officials from the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan declined to comment on the Milken case, as did S.E.C. officials. A spokesman for Mr. Milken would not comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/21/world.body_text: **********Bulgaria has become the breeding ground of some of the world's most lethal computer viruses, programs that are maliciously designed to spread through computer memories and networks and at times destroy valuable stored information like bank and medical records. **********"We've counted about 300 viruses written for the I.B.M. personal computer; of these, 80 or 90 originated in Bulgaria," said Morton Swimmer of Hamburg University's Virus Test Center, who specializes in diagnosing and curing Eastern European computer viruses. "Not only do the Bulgarians produce the most computer viruses, they produce the best." **********One Bulgarian virus, Dark Avenger, has infected American military computers, said John McAfee, who runs the Computer Virus Industry Association, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., and tracks viruses for computer hardware and software companies. **********"I'm not saying that any super-secure computers have been infected," he said. "But the U.S. Defense Department has about 400,000 personal computers, and anyone who has that many machines has a 100 percent probability of being hit." **********"It is causing some people in sensitive places a lot of problems," a Western diplomat here said, "and they are very reluctant to admit they have them."  Many Bulgarian Viruses **********"I would say that 10 percent of the 60 calls we receive each week are for Bulgarian viruses, and 99 percent of these are for Dark Avenger," Mr. McAfee said, adding that the virus has also attacked computers belonging to banks, insurance and accounting companies and medical offices. **********Several experts say the spread of the Bulgarian viruses is a consequence of having developed a generation of young Bulgarians whose programming skills found few outlets. **********A decade ago, this country's Communist leaders decided to make Bulgaria an Eastern-bloc Silicon Valley, Vesselin Bontchev, a Bulgarian computer specialist, said. **********Bulgarian factories began turning out computers, and the Government put them in workshops and schools. But many computers stood idle because people did not know how to use them or lacked an economic interest. **********"People took office computers home, and their children began playing on them," he said. **********These children quickly acquired software-writing skills, but had little or no chance to apply them constructively, he said. They began bootlegging copyrighted Western software, especially computer games, by overriding devices written into the software to prevent it from being copied. Then they started altering the operating systems that drive the computer itself.  Dozen Youths Are Blamed **********Mr. Bontchev estimated that there are only about a dozen young Bulgarians who have written the viruses that have caused all the trouble. **********"Computer hackers here write viruses to show who is who in computer science in Bulgaria, to find a place in the sun," said Slav Ivanov, editor of a Bulgarian computer magazine. **********One virus designer acknowledged that revenge was also a factor. **********"I designed my first computer virus for revenge against people at work," said Lubomir Mateev, who helped write a nondestructive virus known as Murphy. "Our first virus made all the computers at work send out a noise when they were switched on." **********Mr. Mateev, who is 23 years old, said he collaborated with Dark Avenger's designer last spring on a new virus that is harder to diagnose and cure because it is self-mutating. **********Attempts over several months to get in touch with Dark Avenger's creator proved fruitless. **********For now, Bulgaria's computer virus designers can act with legal immunity. "We have no law on computer crime," said Mr. Ivanov, whose magazine offers free programs that cure Bulgarian viruses. "The police are only superficially interested in this matter."  Government Not Suspected **********Bulgaria's secret-police computers have also been infected, said a well-placed Bulgarian computer expert, who spoke on condition of anonymity and refused to elaborate. **********Dark Avenger has also spread to the Soviet Union, Britain, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary, Mr. Bontchev said, adding, "I've even had one report that it has popped up in Mongolia." **********Mr. Bontchev said he was almost certain Bulgaria's Government was not involved with Dark Avenger. "A computer virus cannot be used as a weapon because it cannot be aimed accurately and can return like a boomerang," he said. "It can be used only to cause random damage, like a terrorist bomb." **********Unlike less infectious viruses, Dark Avenger attacks computer data and programs when they are copied, printed or acted on in other ways by a computer's operating system, Mr. Bontchev said. The virus destroys information every 16th time an infected program is run. **********A virus can spread from one computer to another either on floppy disks or through computer modems or computer networks, he said. Many viruses are spread at computer fairs and through computer bulletin-board systems using telephones. **********"Things may get much worse before they improve," Mr. Bontchev said. "The first law of computer viruses is that if a virus can be made, it will be. The second law is that if a computer virus cannot be made, it will be anyway."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/23/busin.body_text: **********The Circle K Corporation has appointed as its new chairman a Cincinnati lawyer who is a partner with the law firm representing the company's largest shareholder. **********Circle K, the nation's second-largest convenience-store chain after the 7-Eleven stores, named Bart A. Brown Jr. its chairman on Thursday, replacing Karl Eller. Mr. Brown is a senior partner in the law firm of Keating, Muething & Klekamp. The firm represents the American Financial Corporation of Cincinnati, Circle K's largest shareholder. **********Mr. Eller resigned as chairman and chief executive officer on May 7. The post of chief executive remains vacant, the company said. **********Mr. Brown, 58 years old, was chosen because of his expertise in acquisitions, dispositions and debt restructuring, a spokesman for Circle K said. **********Circle K filed on May 15 for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, listing more than $1 billion in debt. **********Circle K operates about 4,600 stores in 32 states.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/busin.main_headline: New Drumstick Said To Be Easier to Control
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/busin.print_headline: PATENTS;   New Drumstick Said To Be Easier to Control
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/busin.body_text: **********David Hughlett, a professional drummer in Dallas, patented a drumstick this week that he said was faster, more powerful and easier to control than conventional sticks. **********The new stick is made from ordinary wood, but its center of balance has been shifted backward by a weight mounted in its butt end. Mr. Hughlett, the author of a book entitled ''Understanding Drum Techniques,'' said most drumsticks had a center of balance 42 percent to 46 percent of the distance from the butt end. The new stick balances at its center of rotation, which is 35 percent to 41 percent from the butt end, he said. Mr. Hughlett said his sticks were somewhat heavier than usual, but their balance made them feel lighter and bounce off a drum head more rapidly. **********Mr. Hughlett and the co-inventor, Jimmy R. Evans, a technician, have formed R. B. Percussion in Dallas and plan to begin manufacturing the sticks in several weeks. **********They received patent 4,905,566.
