https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/12/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: The Nissan Motor Corporation yesterday named Thomas D. Mignanelli president and chief executive of its American sales and marketing subsidiary, making him the first American to hold such a position at a Japanese auto maker. Effective July 1, Mr. Mignanelli replaces Kazutoshi Hagiwara, who will return to **********The Nissan Motor Corporation yesterday named Thomas D. Mignanelli president and chief executive of its American sales and marketing subsidiary, making him the first American to hold such a position at a Japanese auto maker. Effective July 1, Mr. Mignanelli replaces Kazutoshi Hagiwara, who will return to Tokyo to assume a new position at the parent company. **********As head of the Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A., which is based in the Los Angeles suburb of Carson, Mr. Mignanelli assumes responsibility for product planning, financial, legal and public affairs and human resources. He was already in charge of sales and marketing in his previous position of executive vice president for operations. **********While the naming of Mr. Mignanelli is a significant step in what the Japanese call the ''Americanization'' of their operations here, analysts see no shift in the balance of power between Americans and Japanese. **********At Nissan, ultimate responsibility for long-term strategy and vehicle design remains in Japan. Mr. Mignanelli will report in the United States to Yoshikazu Hanawa, president of Nissan North America Inc., which coordinates all Nissan's activities here. **********''What this does do is give Mignanelli more control over what's going on in the organization without having Japan checking every move that's made,'' said George Peterson, an industry analyst. **********Mr. Mignanelli said that while Nissan's strategy of giving foreign subsidiaries more autonomy made the naming of an American president inevitable, the decision was made years sooner than expected. **********''It's a big departure,'' he said in an interview. ''The tactical decisions -day-to-day operations, budgeting, anything that has to do with running the business - will no longer be made by a Japanese.'' **********Thomas O'Grady, president of Integrated Automotive Resources, industry consultants, said he expected Nissan's Japanese executives to monitor American operations closely. **********Despite introducing a number of new cars, sales for the first five months of 1990 are off 11.4 percent. While Nissan's market share increased in May over last year to 4.2 percent from 3.9 percent, it has declined in recent years because of competitive pressures and what analysts view as a number of marketing missteps, including dropping the Datsun name and introducing modern styling too slowly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/29/busin.main_headline: The Executive Computer;   Liberating Machines From Keyboards
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/29/busin.print_headline: The Executive Computer;   Liberating Machines From Keyboards
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/29/busin.body_text: **********One big obstacle to a wider adoption of computers is the keyboard. ''I had not even touched a computer before I came here, because I never learned how to type,'' confessed a man recently hired as a senior marketing executive by a large computer company. He has now learned to type - and to use a computer. **********It is not just executives who shy away from keyboards. Factory workers, sales representatives, police officers, construction supervisors and millions of other nonoffice employees who might benefit from computer automation are left out because they cannot, or will not, use a keyboard. And even the willing find it hard to use a computer if they have to work standing up. **********Recognizing this, computer companies including the International Business Machines Corporation, Apple Computer Inc. and the smallest Silicon Valley newcomers are racing to develop notepad computers - lightweight machines that can be operated with pen-like styluses, using a flat screen as the writing surface. **********As the user writes on the screen - or, at least for now, carefully prints block letters or numbers - the computer converts them eletronically. Some software will also allow the user to employ the stylus for operations that do not involve handwriting. In much the way one works with a mouse, the user might drag symbols around on the screen, indicate choices from a menu, or put a check mark in a box on a form. Census takers, inventory clerks and workers at fast-food restaurants, among others, might well find the machine appealing. **********Apple's former head of product development, Jean-Louis Gassee, said earlier this year that stylus technology would eventually replace the Macintosh's famous mouse, which is more of a pointing device than a writing tool. **********Although the technology is still relatively crude, and for the time being useful only in narrow applications, electronic notepads have created a great deal of excitement in the industry. Grid Systems Inc., a division of the Tandy Corporation, has brought a notepad computer to market. And earlier this month, I.B.M. announced that it had entered into a joint venture with the fledgling Go Corporation of Foster City, Calif., to develop pen-based computers. **********''We see stylus-based systems as one of the most important applications to come along since the original PC in the 1970's,'' said Timothy P. Bajarin, executive vice president of Creative Strategies Research International, a consulting and market research company in Santa Clara, Calif. ''For the first time, it makes me believe that the PC can be used in a broad-based, Everyman-type situation. You've got so many people who don't use desktop computers or keyboards, and yet everyone uses a pen and writes.'' **********Other analysts, including a number of people who are in the business of developing stylus-based computers, say a little caution is appropriate. Vern Raburn, an industry veteran who is chairman of a notepad software development company called the Slate Corporation, in Scottsdale, Ariz., recently told PC Week magazine: **********''I don't want to see what happened to artificial intelligence and multimedia happen here. The biggest concern we have is overexpectation - that people are going to look at these machines and say, 'Wow! Magic Paper!' Will this be the machine that unlocks the world of computers for the great unwashed? No, nothing is.'' **********One problem is that handwriting recognition technology is still in its infancy. The Gridpad computer, which sells for $2,370, can recognize only carefully printed numbers and block-letter capitals, for example. Given the complexity of the algorithms needed to accomplish even that task, the prospect of developing a computer that can read most people's handwriting is daunting. **********I.B.M. researchers at Yorktown Heights, N.Y., last month announced that they had developed a system that could recognize many handwritten characters, including those that touched or overlapped. The I.B.M. system, called the Paperlike Interface, is said to ''read'' the handwriting immediately, with a high degree of accuracy, and convert it to computer text. **********The company's partnership with Go, which is developing both the hardware and the operating system for a stylus-based notepad, creates a formidable alliance. **********Other major companies, including the Japanese electronics giants Sony and Canon, are also pursuing the market. Sony, for example, recently introduced a palm-sized device called the PTC-500 which recognizes the Kanji characters used in Japan. There are no plans to introduce the machine in the United States, a Sony official said. **********Of course, drawing is not the primary issue with notepads; writing is. However, some people contend that even writing may be too hard for some users, or not sufficient for some tasks. They point to speech recognition technology as the eventual ways to open the doors to such people. But on a technical level, that is even more difficult than handwriting recognition. **********Other companies are exploring other input technologies, including but not restricted to styluses. The details of such research are closely guarded. The Momenta Corporation of Mountain View, Calif., for example, describes its as-yet-unannounced notepad machine only as radical and ''non-keyboard.'' **********Of the notepad computers already on the market, the best known is the Gridpad, from Grid Systems. The Gridpad proved to be a handy tool for such applications as filling out a traffic accident report or writing a sales ticket. It is not intended to be a general-purpose computer, although it is MS-DOS compatible and can be connected to a desktop PC in a variety of ways. **********The Gridpad is a 4.5-pound, 9-inch by 12-inch computer that looks, in the words of a Grid official, like a black ''Etch-a-Sketch'' toy. The machine has straps on the back that can hold it on the user's forearm. They are handy, because the computer can get awfully heavy at the end of a long shift. The straps also make it easier to hold the computer and write on it at the same time. **********The machine is not flawless. In tests it flubbed some characters and the screen image was quite dim. But this technology will surely improve. The larger test is whether software will be developed that will make the machine popular. **********Users will want highly specialized applications, and even entering a business form into the Gridpad requires an advanced programmer. Right now, there seems to be no way to use handwriting to enter data into Lotus 1-2-3, dBASE or other standard business applications. **********Other companies developing notepad products include Data Entry Systems Inc. of Huntsville, Ala., which sells a $1,595 machine, and Superscript Inc., of Cambridge, Mass., which is developing software. **********Are pen-based computer pads likely to have a substantial impact on the broader base of desktop personal computers in the next few years? ''It's very questionable at this point,'' said Michael S. Swaveley, president of the North American operations of the Compaq Computer Corporation. ''The technology is moving forward but it is far from 100 percent perfect.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/31/world.main_headline: Baker's Tone on Jerusalem Settlement Softens
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/31/world.print_headline: Baker's Tone on Jerusalem Settlement Softens
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/31/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, in an apparent softening of United States opposition to Israeli settlements in Arab East Jerusalem, has said that Jews have the right to live in all parts of the city. **********Mr. Baker's statement on Jerusalem, which was markedly different from the tone struck by the Bush Administration last month, came in a letter dated March 16 to Representative Mel Levine, Democrat of California. **********In the letter, Mr. Baker stated: ''I am also very aware of the great significance which Jerusalem has for the Jewish people as well as for people of all religions. Clearly, Jews and others can live where they want, East or West, and the city must remain undivided.'' **********Previously, a Blind Eye **********President Bush touched off a debate last month by stating his opposition to Jewish settlements in East Jerusalem as well as in the occupied territories. His remark helped cause a political crisis in Israel which led to the fall of the Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. **********Successive United States administrations had for years turned a blind eye to the densely populated Jewish suburbs that have sprung up in East Jerusalem since Israel captured it from Jordan in the 1967 war. **********Mr. Bush was pressed by American Jews to reverse himself, but refused. The most he would say was that ''Jews and others have the right to live there in the context of a negotiated settlement.'' **********The disclosure of Mr. Baker's letter came as a senior United States official said that Washington was pushing for a reversal this year of the 1975 United Nations General Assembly resolution equating Zionism with racism. Assistant Secretary of State John Bolton told a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee today that the United States was working through diplomatic channels to reverse the resolution. **********Some Nations Indicate Switch **********''We believe that there is strong opposition to the resolution by a large and growing number of U.N. member countries,'' Mr. Bolton said. ''With this in mind, we are taking action and will intensify our efforts during the 1990 session of the General Assembly.'' **********He said all 35 nations that opposed the resolution in 1975 still did so and some nations that had supported it then, like Mexico, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, had indicated they would oppose it now. Others seemed likely to abstain. **********Israel was eager to see the resolution revoked but did not want a vote unless victory was assured, Mr. Bolton said. **********He indicated that attempts by Washington to agree on a joint strategy with the Soviet Union had failed to produce agreement so far, but that the dialogue continued with Moscow sending encouraging signals indicating it no longer accepted the premise of the resolution.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/02/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: At the Wall;   100 Injured as Video Screen Falls On Revelers at Brandenburg Gate
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/02/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: At the Wall;   100 Injured as Video Screen Falls On Revelers at Brandenburg Gate
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/02/world.body_text: **********A giant video screen collapsed onto a crowd early this morning and injured more than 100 people during wild New Year celebrations at the Berlin wall, the police said. **********The police also said they had found a 24-year-old West German dead along Unter den Linden boulevard in East Berlin, but his death did not appear to be connected with the collapse. **********During the celebration, a total of 300 people were injured, and 80 of them were taken to hospitals in East and West Berlin with cuts, broken bones and head wounds, the West Berlin police said. **********The death and injuries darkened the most exuberant celebration at the wall since Nov. 9, when East Germany's Communist leaders threw open the borders after a wave of unrest swept away Erich Honecker, the Communist Party chief, in October. #400,000 at Brandenburg Gate East Germans clambered onto the wall that hemmed them in until just seven weeks ago, drinking, shouting and kissing their fellow Germans from the West. **********At the stroke of midnight, champagne and fireworks rained down on the crowd of 400,000 thronging the Brandenburg Gate, the 200-year-old symbol of German unity that was sealed to the public for 28 years until its reopening 10 days ago. **********Some, defying police orders, managed to climb to the top of the imposing gate, on scaffolding supporting the video screen. Just after 1:30 A.M., the scaffolding gave way. **********Red Cross workers struggling through the crush and the carpet of broken glass found scores of injured. **********East German guards immediately closed border crossings at the Brandenburg Gate, bringing an abrupt halt to the celebrations. **********East German television today reported that vandals had seriously damaged the Quadriga statue atop the gate. The copper statue represents the goddess Nike in a chariot drawn by four horses. **********Anarchists Riot in Hamburg **********In Hamburg, West Germany, 10 policemen were seriously wounded and a patrol car was destroyed when masked anarchists rioted during a New Year's march, the police said. **********The rioters stole a submachine gun and ammunition from a patrol car, which they pushed over and set on fire. The fighting was eventually broken up when 100 policemen arrived and threw tear gas into the crowd. Two members of an anarchist group, the Autonomes, were arrested, the police said. **********At the wall, even the East German border guards, who only a few weeks ago stood dour-faced in their watch towers and shot at anyone trying to cross to the West, have been in a mood to celebrate. **********One, offered a bottle of champagne, looked at it carefully and then took a cheery swig. **********''It's New Year, it can't do any harm,'' he said, adding that it might not be a good idea to publish his name.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/18/busin.main_headline: G. E. Lawyer to Join Morgan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/18/busin.print_headline: G. E. Lawyer to Join Morgan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/18/busin.body_text: **********Philip A. Lacovara, a former Watergate prosecutor, is leaving the General Electric Company to become general counsel and secretary of Morgan Stanley Group, the Wall Street firm said yesterday. **********Mr. Lacovara, 47 years old, will also be a managing director and member of the management committee of Morgan Stanley & Company. **********''We are creating a new postion which will have responsibilities for our legal and government relations activities and contribute broadly in areas of strategy and policy,'' said S. Parker Gilbert, Morgan Stanley's chairman, of Mr. Lacovara's post. **********Mr. Lacovara joined G.E. in 1988 as Benjamin W. Heineman Jr., the company's general counsel, recruited some Washington lawyers to the corporate world. Mr. Lacovara was G.E.'s senior counsel for litigation and legal policy and a vice president. **********Before joining General Electric, Mr. Lacovara was partner in charge of the Washington office of Hughes, Hubbard & Reed. Earlier, he had served as counsel to the Watergate special prosecutor, as Deputy Solicitor General and as special counsel to the New York City Police Department. He is immediate past president of the District of Columbia bar. **********Mr. Lacovara, who grew up in New York City, is a magna cum laude graduate of Georgetown University and summa cum laude graduate of the Columbia University Law School.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/23/busin.body_text: **********Two New York investment partnerships, West Associates and KD Associates I, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that they planned to register to sell 1.51 million common shares of the Danaher Corporation, lowering their holding in the Washington-based manufacturing concern to 3 percent from 8.2 percent. The two groups acquired their Danaher shares in August 1987 for $8.33 a share. Danaher fell 12.5 cents today, to $20, on the New York Stock Exchange, giving the company a current market value of $582 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/10/busin.body_text: **********A small but growing number of American towns, no longer able to prosper from the industry, mining or farming that once defined them, are using imagination and ingenuity in hopes of snaring some of the tourist dollars that usually flow to big metropolitan hot spots. **********Some of these communities are spending millions of dollars on sometimes offbeat and risky ventures that often have little relation to their history or image. **********Chicopee, Mass., wants to turn its Connecticut River waterfront into an Amazon jungle, complete with monkeys and exotic birds. Kemmerer, Wyo., plans to become a virtual J. C. Penney theme park. Gary, Ind., is promoting casino gambling. And places that do not already have football field-sized aquariums are quickly drawing plans for them. **********Officials of these towns say they hope that a metamorphosis that involves revamping their downtowns and imposing new building codes will create places that people will drive out of their way to visit and to spend money. **********''It's happening overnight,'' said David Edgell, director of policy and planning for the United States Travel and Tourism Administration, an agency of the Commerce Department. ''What people are doing may seem unbelievable.'' But, he added, many communities had proved that tourism can rebuild economies that might have otherwise faded with the paint on the town hall. **********Already there is a Swedish theme town - albeit with palm trees - in California, and Bavarian-style towns are springing up across the West. Festivals that were once held annually for just the local community have expanded into gigantic productions that celebrate everything from squid to Shakespeare. **********Behind these changes is the recognition that tourism is the third-largest retail service industry in the United States, employing six million people. In 1989, travelers in the United States spent more than $330 billion on goods and services, according to a Commerce Department study. **********That study said spending by visitors was becoming an increasingly effective economic development tool for rural areas. Tourism can replace agriculture and industry as a community's livelihood, the study said. **********''One of the major changes in thinking is tourism,'' said Matt Kane, a policy analyst for the Northeast-Midwest Institute, a economic research group based in Washington. ''Before it was part of a diversified approach. Now everybody is putting their eggs in one basket.'' **********May Be a Fad **********But Mr. Kane, the author of ''Economic Development: What Works at the Local Level,'' warned that tourism might be a fad. ''In the 70's, you saw the building of industrial parks. In the 80's, it was the microchip industry. The major push now is tourism.'' **********Mr. Kane said tourism could be part of a good strategy, but it could be disastrous for towns to rely on tourism alone. ''Tourism is very seasonal and very cyclical,'' he said. ''When the economy flattens and people have less money to spend, just watch what happens to all the fancy hotels that have been built.'' **********Still, there are some long-term success stories. One is Leavenworth, a town in the mining and logging area of central Washington state, about 120 miles from Seattle. Leavenworth is often lauded as the oldest and most successful example of a dying town that was resuscitated by tourism. **********Leavenworth's downturn, which began in the early 1940's, followed the pattern of many other communities hit hard by a changing manufacturing base and the resulting unemployment. By the end of World War II, Leavenworth's timber and mining industries had pulled out, stores were boarded up and more than half its population had moved. The final blow came when the railroad stopped serving the town, which is in a valley of the Cascade Mountains. **********In the late 1960's, after two decades of economic decline, the town of 1,600 people emerged as a Bavarian village, even though it had no real ethnic German community. Today the town, framed by mountains and waterfalls that inspired the Bavarian theme, is a picture postcard of prosperity. **********The boarded-up storefronts have been replaced by antique shops and beer halls. Chalet-style motels cannot be built fast enough to keep up with demand. Retailers, many of whom dress in Lederhosen year round, say that 1989 was their best year. **********''It was pretty scary going in,'' said Laura Jobin, director of the Leavenworth Chamber of Commerce, who grew up in the town. ''People said the idea would never work, but we had hit rock bottom. What were our choices?'' **********Leavenworth transformed its face in less than five years, and by 1970, tourism was the town's major industry. Even though the nearest large city, Seattle, is two hours away, a million people a year visit the town. Leavenworth officials get 50 to 60 inquiries a year from as far away as Japan asking how they did it. **********Massachusetts Rain Forest **********On the East Coast, Chicopee, a Western Massachusetts industrial city of about 50,000 just north of Springfield, has seen scores of manufacturers pull out since the 1970's. Officials paid a design firm, Cambridge Seven Associates in Cambridge, Mass., $75,000 to come up with an idea to attract new business using an abandoned electrical plant where toxic wastes are stored. **********The first idea was to build an aquarium large enough to gain national recognition, but too many other places, including Baltimore and Mystic, Conn., already had them. So the design firm proposed turning the aging plant on the muddy Connecticut River into a $25 million Amazon rain forest. **********''It's a very ambitious concept,'' acknowledged Thomas Haberlin, Chicopee's community development director. But he said feasibility studies had shown that projected economic growth would justify the conversion. **********''With the state government turning from poor to terrible, we've had some doubts expressed,'' Mr. Haberlin said. ''But there really aren't any alternatives.'' **********Cambridge Seven is involved in other town projects. It designed a $30 million freshwater aquarium on the banks of the Tennessee River in Chattanooga, Tenn. That city, like many of the firm's other clients, is economically depressed and hopes tourism will help. ''It's like changing a city with one building,'' said Peter Chermayeff, the firm's founder and vice president. **********Homage to J. C. Penney **********Not all places have the aspiration or can raise the millions of dollars needed to bring large projects to life. But the economic development offices in towns even as small as a few thousand are scurrying for a niche that might tap new sources of revenue - sometimes with quirky ideas. **********Unemployment and an exodus of young people have plagued Kemmerer, Wyo., home of the nation's largest open coal pit. That moved Kemmerer to try to capitalize on its place as the home of the original J. C. Penney store. **********The southwestern Wyoming town, which is near the Utah border, already has a J. C. Penney museum and a J. C. Penney boardwalk. There are now plans to restore the original store and the boarded-up downtown area, all using the J. C. Penney theme. ''People get real excited about J. C. Penney here,'' said Steve Golnar, the city's administrator. He said the project had prompted interest from top Penney executives. **********Thomas Griffo, a J. C. Penney Company district manager whose territory includes Wyoming, emphasized that the company was not behind Kemmerer's plan. But he added that J. C. Penney ''may be spending some monies to bring in some of the old look'' of the original store. **********Indiana Casino Plan **********Not all of the places taking bold steps are rural. Gary, Ind., a city of about 130,000 in the Chicago metropolitan area, has lost a third of its population since the steel industry collapse. It is counting on the Indiana Legislature to approve the construction of five casino hotels along Lake Michigan. The city's Economic Development Office projects that the hotels will generate $800,000 million in gaming revenues annually and employ thousands. **********''Nobody else is going to employ 25,000 people off the bat,'' said Karen Williams, a city spokeswoman. ''Casinos have the most impact in the shortest amount of time. We simply can't wait 10 or 15 years.'' **********Though some projects may appear frivolous, some say it may be more foolish not to try. **********''Structurally, the economy has changed so much that the economic conditions that created these towns 100 and 200 years ago just aren't there any longer,'' said B. J. Reed, an associate professor of public administration at the University of Nebraska in Omaha, who advises community and business leaders in dying towns. **********''In the long run, it is desperate,'' Mr. Reed said. ''Unless these towns can find a viable economic base or just retain what they have, they simply have no justification to exist.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Lionel Is Urged To Sell Big Stake
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/busin.body_text: **********An investment group led by a Florida brokerage, which controls a 5 percent stake in the Lionel Corporation, has asked the New York toy retailer to set up a committee to consider the sale of a large stake in the company. **********The brokerage, Trendex Capital Management, said that after a New York investor, Robert I. Toussie, dropped his $95.4 million bid to acquire Lionel in January, half of his shares were acquired at a premium by a group linked to Lionel management. Michael J. Vastola, Lionel's chairman and chief executive, was unavailable for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/busin.main_headline: Dow Rises 20.72 Points in Brisk Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/busin.print_headline: Dow Rises 20.72 Points in Brisk Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/busin.body_text: **********Stocks advanced briskly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 20.72 points, to 2,689.64. **********Prices rose despite growing sentiment that the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates to cool off the economy. Program traders, moreover, were noticeably absent. **********Volume fell to 141.6 million shares, from 149 million on Tuesday, with 864 issues rising and 612 declining. **********If the Fed increases rates, that will almost certainly lure investors instantly away from the stock market to the higher returns of bonds and money market funds. The bellwether 30-year Treasury bonds, meanwhile, remained steady at 9.02 percent. **********The traders said many investors largely ignored new data showing that the economy was expanding because many had already adjusted to the strong possibility that interest rates would be going up. **********When asked why the market was so strong, one trader noted that ''The 1990 Stock Traders Almanac,'' published by Yale Hirsch in Old Tappan, N.J., said that for the last 40 years, stock prices have risen 72.2 percent of the time on May 2 - the highest percentage in May. **********In Old Tappan, Mr. Hirsch said, ''The market tends to be strongest on the last, first, second, third and fourth days of the month.'' **********The market could advance again today, the analysts said. **********In an announcement that came as a relief to stock and bond traders, the Treasury said well after the end of the trading day that it would raise $30.5 billion next week. **********The analysts said that they had expected the total to be that high but that the markets would have been under pressure if the refinancing had been much higher. **********In one of the biggest developments of the day, American General, the big Houston insurer, jumped 7 1/2, to 47 5/8, with 7.1 million shares changing hands - by far the most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange. The company said it would put itself on the block. **********Among the Dow industrials, I.B.M. rose 1 1/8, to 109 1/8; Primerica 1 1/8, to 30 1/8; USX 7/8, to 34, and Westinghouse a point, to 73 5/8 - all in strong trading. Chevron rose 5/8, to 66 1/8, and Texaco 3/8, to 59. Other oil stocks gained, with Royal Dutch/ Shell up 7/8, to 73 3/4; British Petroleum a point, to 61 1/4, and Amerada Hess 7/8, to 47 1/4. **********The Dow transportation stocks rose only 1.78, to 1,138.69, with Union Pacific up a point, to 68 7/8, but UAL down 2 1/4, to 151. **********In a move that generally follows the end of an offer to buy a company's stock, Rorer, the drug company, fell 5 1/4, to 64 1/2, with Rhone-Poulenc's offer expiring tomorrow. **********Among the indexes, the Standard & Poor's 500 gained 2.23, to 334.48; the Nasdaq composite 1.73, to 423.58, and the American Stock Exchange's market-value 0.91, to 344.23.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.main_headline: Session Called on Soviet Chief's Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: SOVIET UNION;   Session Called on Soviet Chief's Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.body_text: **********Leaders of the Soviet legislature voted today to convene an extraordinary session ''in the nearest future'' to expand the powers of the Soviet presidency, a post now held by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********The idea of endowing the President with new emergency powers was proposed last week by Mr. Gorbachev and endorsed by the Central Committee of the Communist Party amid claims that the current system was too slow in dealing with outbreaks of ethnic violence and economic crises. **********The official Soviet press agency Tass said tonight that the 41-member Presidium, or executive committee, of the legislature had met today with Mr. Gorbachev presiding and voted unanimously to press quickly for constitutional changes to create ''a democratic presidential power.'' **********A special session of the full 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies would also have the authority to abolish the Communist Party's constitutional monopoly on political power and open the way to a multiparty system, steps endorsed in the new Communist Party platform adopted last week. **********Sweeping Powers Suggested **********The party platform, which Tass published tonight for the first time, did not specify what new powers should be given to the President, but the wording suggested that it should be sweeping. **********The platform declared: ''A President is needed to maintain the country's stable development, to speed up perestroika, to guarantee its irreversibility, to insure the normal and effective functioning of all state and public institutions in the process of democratization, to insure law and citizens' security, to protect the Soviet Union's interests and to represent our state in the international arena.'' **********The idea of creating a stronger chief executive appears to have widespread support here, but critics say Mr. Gorbachev should not be given the new post without facing a direct, competitive nationwide election. **********While legislative leaders moved quickly to execute the party's proposals, there were signs that Mr. Gorbachev's blueprint for the country was arousing dissatisfaction among the military leadership. **********General Mikhail A. Moiseyev, the armed forces chief of staff, said in a weekend interview with the military newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda that the party platform ''contained too many generalities'' and ''belittled'' the army. **********Morale Problems in the Military **********General Moiseyev's unusually critical comments included charges that the party had ignored deep morale problems in the military brought on by draft evasion, desertion of ethnic minorities and the slashing of the professional officer corps because of troop withdrawals in Eastern Europe. **********The general disclosed that in last fall's call-up, 6,000 young men had resisted the draft, often with the cooperation of local Communist Party and Government agencies. The opposition was strongest in the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia and other regions pressing for independence from Moscow. **********In the southern republics of Azerbaijan and Armenia, General Moiseyev added, 1,200 deserters had fled the army, many of them to join up with ethnic commando units. **********The party platform published tonight is a draft to be presented at a nationwide Communist Party congress in the summer. It is clearly a compromise document, bowing simultaneously to Mr. Gorbachev's program and to familiar basics of Communist doctrine, leaving individual Communists broad leeway for interpretation. **********Soviet legislators seeking the guidance of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union on the issue of whether to allow private property will not find those words in the text, but they will find this: ''The C.P.S.U. believes that the existence of labor-individual property, including ownership of the means of production, does not contradict the modern stage in the country's economic development.'' Which Means of Production?  Soviet economists sometimes use the phrase ''labor-individual'' property to mean the things workers use in their jobs. An orthodox economist would conclude that individual farmers could own their own tractors, but not entire farms. But ''ownership of the means of production'' might be interpreted to mean private farms and factories. **********The draft platform calls for elections to become ''an honest competition'' open to all ''public organizations and movements.'' **********''The development of society does not preclude the possibility of forming parties,'' the draft says. ''The procedure for their formation will be established by law and reflected in the constitution of the U.S.S.R. **********''The formation and activity of organizations and movements that expound violence and inter-ethnic strife and that pursue extremist, unconstitutional aims should be prohibited by law.'' **********The platform promises to submit an amendment to Article 6 of the Soviet Constitution, which establishes the party as ''the leading and guiding force'' in Soviet society. **********The party's ''role is to be a democratically recognized political leader acting through Communists and not seeking advantages nor establishing a privileged status for itself in the U.S.S.R. Constitution,'' the text says. **********The proposal to create a strong presidential government has arisen repeatedly in the soviet press, sponsored in some cases by writers with close ties to the party leadership. **********Although Mr. Gorbachev is already head of state, chairman of the legislature and leader of the Defense Council, advocates of a new system contend that he lacks the flexibility to take rapid executive action, like sending troops to trouble spots or imposing emergency economic measures. **********A Major Overhaul **********Creation of a presidential government would mean a major overhaul of the parliamentary system enacted less than a year ago. **********The current system includes the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies, which selects from its own ranks a 542-member standing Parliament, called the Supreme Soviet, and its executive committee, called the Presidium. The chairman of the Presidium is generally referred to as President, but in domestic affairs he is in theory required to consult with the rest of the Presidium. **********Yuri N. Afanasyev, a historian and leader of the parliamentary opposition, has strongly opposed the proposed revamping of the system. **********''We are witnessing the creation of authoritarian-totalitarian power headed by the initiator of perestroika,'' Mr. Afanasyev warned on Saturday. Other advocates of more far-reaching change said they supported the notion but felt that before getting new powers, Mr. Gorbachev should run in a nationwide election. **********Neither the party document nor the announcement today indicates how the President would be selected. Party leaders have indicated that they hope to have the Parliament appoint Mr. Gorbachev to the new post for the duration of his current term - until 1994 -and begin popular elections to the post after that. **********Tass said the parliamentary leaders had also sent the legislature draft laws creating procedures for a republic to secede from the union. **********Two Baltic republics, Lithuania and Estonia, have approved laws challenging their forced 1940 incorporation into the Soviet Union, setting the stage for a showdown this year over their quest for independence. **********The reports tonight provided no details of the proposed legislation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/busin.body_text: **********The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced a total of $1.3 billion in four-year and 10-year debentures through its regular selling group of securities dealers. **********Because of the Fourth of July holiday tomorrow, the Government agency moved up its debenture offering a day. All the debentures are priced at par and all are callable. **********For the $700 million in debentures due 1994, the interest rate is 8.65 percent. The yield at a price of par is about 32 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. These securities are callable by the agency on or after July 11, 1992. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/24/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   Wall St. Volatility Reflects Larger Economic Worries
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/24/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   Wall St. Volatility Reflects Larger Economic Worries
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/24/busin.body_text: **********A sharp fall in stock prices yesterday reflected growing worries over the health of the economy, especially the erosion of corporate profits, as well as a stock market that has grown increasingly fragile, some traders and analysts say. **********The rapid plunge in prices, which sent the Dow Jones industrial average down more than 100 points in little more than an hour of trading, only to stabilize and end the day down by 56.44 points, or 1.9 percent, at 2,904.70, came after a series of disappointing earnings reports from companies as diverse as Texas Instruments, the electronics company, and McDonald's, the hamburger chain. **********The selling extended to virtually all stocks, with six stocks falling in price for every one that rose. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell by 6.30, or 1.7 percent, to 355.31. [Page D1.]  Growing Apprehension The profit disappointments came at a time of growing apprehension about the health of the financial system -many large bank stocks are trading at their lowest levels in two years - that had generally not hurt the stock market up to now. While share prices were not as expensive, measured against such indicators as earnings and interest rates, as they were in the summer of 1987, they were approaching that level, according to many analysts. **********''The market had reached overvalued levels, the economy is sluggish, and corporate profits, while they are not horrendous, are well below the levels of expectations that were built into prices,'' said Abby Joseph Cohen, the chief American strategist for Barclays de Zoete Wedd Research. **********The Federal Reserve lowered interest rates slightly two weeks ago, providing some help for share prices, but worries that interest rates would not fall further, and might rise, have grown. Those fears intensified yesterday after rates in Japan rose overnight, and share prices declined in Tokyo, with the Nikkei 225-stock index off 1.6 percent. But in early trading today the Nikkei's losses were trimmed. At the close of the morning session, the average was down by 67.66 points, to 31,827.13, a decline of about two-tenths of a percent. **********Rates Quickly Turn Down **********Interest rates were up in early New York trading yesterday, but quickly turned down after stock prices cracked, as traders seeking safety bought Treasury securities. **********The suddenness of the plunge stunned many traders, recalling the 190-point fall on Oct. 13, 1989. But while there were a pair of causes that touched off that slide - including the collapse of financing for a takeover of United Airlines and a Washington setback to efforts to lower capital gains taxes - there were no such ready explanations yesterday morning, although some pointed to the continued rise of oil prices and to the fact that McDonald's, a consumer growth stock and market leader up until now, reported poor earnings late Friday. The company fell $1.50 that day and another $3 today, closing at $33 a share. **********The plunge may have been accelerated by the fact many brokers had built up inventories of shares in recent weeks as the Dow neared 3,000, a point at which it was hoped that buyers would come flooding in. Last week, the average traded over that level on three days, but never closed there. In addition, there had been a widespread expectation on Friday that prices would rise in late trading as the scheduled expiration of a stock index futures contract in Chicago touched off a wave of buying. Instead, the buying from that was minor and was overwhelmed by late selling from other areas. **********Some analysts said the decline was exaggerated by changes in the securities industry in recent years. With commission rates on stock trades falling steadily, the big brokerage houses seem less willing to risk their own capital to buy stocks that institutions are selling. Without that buying support, the volatility of stock prices is increased. **********With buyers returning in the afternoon, the day ended as only the third worst decline of the Dow in 1990, and there were indications that some buyers were betting that the market would bounce back quickly. **********Robert Farrell, the chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch, said that it appeared more retail customers at his firm were inclined ''to want to buy something'' rather than to ''panic and sell.'' **********Impact of 'Circuit Breakers' **********The ''circuit breakers'' in effect at futures exchanges - most importantly the one at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which trades contracts on the Standard & Poor's 500 index - seem to have had a dual impact. They may first have accelerated the drop, but then stabilized the market. **********The rule on the S.&P. provided that if the September futures contract fell 12 points - about 3.3 percent - there could be no trading below that level for 30 minutes. When prices began to near that amount just after 10:30 A.M., there appeared to be a ''magnet effect,'' in which they fell to the level. Prices in the stock market at first continued lower, but then rallied, helping the futures quotes recover. **********In the afternoon, when the market again sagged, S.&P. futures prices fell even lower. There was no circuit breaker then, and there would not have been one unless prices fell 20 points, but the market nonetheless rallied. **********Rules Proposed by Exchange **********The New York Stock Exchange has proposed rules to halt stock trading for 30 minutes if the Dow falls 100 points in a day, but they are awaiting approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission and by other exchanges, and were not in effect. **********The Big Board did, however, put into effect a ''side car'' rule in which some program trades related to index arbitrage were delayed for five minutes after the futures circuit breaker was set off. The immediate effect of that was to cause some program trades to be executed at a loss, some traders said. **********In recent weeks, as the Dow rose while many stocks were weakening, traders had increasingly focused on two groups: computer stocks, which were market stars early in the year, and companies that were thought to have consistent growth in profits, whatever happened to the economy. It was in that context that disappointments in such companies as McDonald's and Texas Instruments may have demoralized money managers, and made them hesitate to buy when prices tumbled yesterday. **********Volume yesterday, at 209 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange, was heavier than usual, but by no means as heavy as in previous big drops. That fact served to reinforce the feelings of some traders that the markets have become more fragile, able to plunge with only limited selling pressure. **********Reports from some brokerage houses yesterday said there was only limited selling of stocks by institutions. But there seems to have been more selling of stock index futures in an effort to hedge portfolios against further losses. That selling was then translated back to the stock market through index arbitrage, in which traders sold stocks while buying the futures contracts. **********The Big Board asked that brokers refrain from some forms of index arbitrage after the large fall in the morning, but some of it continued, traders said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/busin.body_text: **********For M. Stuart Millar, a man once heralded as the savior of the struggling small-airplane industry, the dream has run into the reality. **********A World War II fighter pilot with a passion for aviation and a solid track record in business, Mr. Millar set the industry on its ear in 1987 after acquiring the troubled Piper Aircraft Corporation, a company whose name has long been synonymous with small private planes. **********In a business where liability insurance is the safety net against the huge lawsuits resulting from crashes, Mr. Millar decided to forgo it. When rising prices were the norm, he slashed his own by 20 percent, offering a plane for as little as $45,000 when the cheapest model from other companies cost twice as much. And when it was still unclear whether demand for small planes would grow, he cranked up Piper's production line and introduced new designs. **********Mr. Millar has indeed raised Piper's sales and orders strikingly. But recently it has become evident that his daring plan has begun to unravel. Industry analysts said Piper's woes could be traced to underfinancing and an unrealistic business plan under which the company, hoping to build a loyal customer base, sold hundreds of discounted planes at a loss. **********A Two-Week Furlough **********To deal with what Piper executives described as a cash flow problem, the company last month furloughed nearly all of its 1,600 employees for two weeks. Rumors circulated that the Vero Beach, Fla., company, in debt to many vendors, was preparing to file for bankruptcy protection. **********Piper executives say their problems are only a temporary setback. They are quick to point to the company's large backlog of orders for Piper planes ranging from the $45,000 single-engine trainer to a twin-engine turboprop model that costs several million dollars. Meanwhile, Mr. Millar has been talking to domestic and foreign corporations in hopes of attracting investors. **********Mr. Millar's task will not be easy; he is trying to succeed at the low end of the market, where giant competitors like General Dynamics, which owns Cessna Aircraft, and Raytheon, which owns Beech, have failed. Both companies are no longer making planes that sell for less than $100,000, citing a decline in the number of private pilots to buy the planes and the cost of liability insurance to protect themselves against large lawsuits. They have moved toward selling larger jets - a business that Piper is not in. **********Last year, the general-aviation industry sold 1,143 planes, down from nearly 18,000 in 1978. General-aviation planes range from single-engine propeller planes like Piper's to $23 million business jets. **********The sales decline of the 1980's was evident at Piper. In 1987, when it was owned by Forstmann Little & Company, the New York buyout firm, Piper was building fewer than 300 airplanes a year - less than a tenth of its peak in the late 1970's. The company, which employed more than 8,000 people in the late 1970's, had only 750 on its payroll. **********The company's troubles attracted the attention of Mr. Millar, then a computer entrepreneur, who owned a Piper plane. ''I was shocked at what I saw,'' Mr. Millar, now 65 years old, said of a visit to the Piper factory. ''I hadn't realized that the industry for small aircraft had dropped so precipitously.'' **********In 1987 he bought the failing company from Forstmann Little for what aviation industry executives estimated was $6 million. Terms of the deal were never disclosed, but it was clear that the low price was partly due to the fact that the buyer was assuming potential liability for every plane made by Piper since 1937 -more than 100,000 airplanes. **********By daring to expand production to 14 models from just a few, and marketing more aggressively, Mr. Millar breathed new life into Piper. Airplane sales rose to $90.5 million last year from $50.7 million in 1988. The company's backlog grew to $175 million from about $8 million. At the same time, amounts paid out in lawsuits dropped by a third. The number of workers doubled. Morale rose for the first time in years. **********One of Mr. Millar's first moves as the company's new owner, president and chairman was to resurrect the Piper Cub, an airplane in which thousands of pilots have learned to fly since the 1940's. ''It was one of the great utility airplanes,'' Mr. Millar said. ''Alaska wouldn't be a state if it wasn't for the Piper Cub.'' **********Piper sold more than a hundred of the spartan Cubs to doctors, lawyers and airline pilots who were willing to pay $50,000 to taste a simpler era of flight. Although the Cub had new radios and instruments, it was basically the same plane that carried Mr. Millar aloft on his first flight in 1940. **********Sensing a growing market for the training planes used primarily by flying schools - to replace a fleet whose average age is more than 20 years - Mr. Millar stripped down a Piper model and created a no-frills training plane called the Cadet. Piper was determined to build a loyal customer base by luring people into aviation, and the company sold hundreds of the planes. Mr. Millar ''became an industry spokesman for the downtrodden masses who previously couldn't afford flying,'' an industry executive said. **********But, priced at $45,000, the plane was a money loser. Piper could cover only labor and material, not overhead or dealer discounts. **********''We're a victim of our own success,'' said C. Raymond Johnson, who was recently appointed president of the company. **********Credit Stretched **********But critics have argued that Piper is actually a victim of poor planning and inadequate financing. Airplane companies are more assemblers than manufacturers, relying on as many as 400 vendors to supply the parts, engines and radios that make a plane. In its headlong rush to regain its former glory, Piper had stretched its credit with those vendors to the limit. **********''He was depending on the munificence of his suppliers,'' said James Holahan, editor of Aviation International News, an industry publication. ''They finally lost patience.'' In deciding to forgo liability insurance, Mr. Millar chose to do battle in the courtroom. Employing a staff of what Mr. Johnson called the ''meanest bunch of junkyard-dog lawyers,'' the company refuses to settle a case out of court if it thinks its plane was not at fault. ''We refuse to pay extortion money,'' Mr. Millar said. **********For the most part, the strategy has paid off, Mr. Millar said. Awards against the company dropped to $8 million last year from about $30 million a year when Mr. Millar bought the company. **********Piper can take such a risky strategy because its corporate pockets are not nearly as deep as those of a company like Raytheon or General Dynamics. Still, losing one huge lawsuit could mean the end of Piper. **********The strategy has backfired on at least one occasion. In 1988, Piper was sued for an accident involving a twin-engine model called Aztec. Arthur Wolk, the plaintiff's attorney, offered to settle the case for $800,000. Piper declined. A jury awarded the plaintiff $4.7 million. **********Mr. Millar has taken other unconventional steps that have made him something of a folk figure in the industry. When one of his most popular models, a high-performance six-seat plane that sells for about $350,000, developed an engine problem, Mr. Millar promptly grounded the fleet and provided free first-class airline tickets to owners until the defect had been repaired. All told, 893 people took him up on the offer, which cost the company $2 million. **********Ultimately, Piper's biggest challenge may be a lack of customers. The number of pilots in the United States has dropped by about 15 percent in the last eight years. Industry analysts trace the decline to the rising cost of flying and the decline of the industry itself. **********Meanwhile, Mr. Millar said he hopes to arrange additional financing within 60 days, using the company's $50 million in real estate assets as leverage. But the search for backers has not been easy. ''There are few banks that will lend money to an airplane company,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/world.main_headline: Draft of U.N. Resolution On Lands Held by Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/world.print_headline: STANDOFF IN THE GULF; Draft of U.N. Resolution On Lands Held by Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/world.body_text: **********Following is the draft United Nations Security Council resolution proposed to the United States today by the representatives of Malaysia, Colombia, Cuba and Yemen:  THE SECURITY COUNCIL, **********REAFFIRMING the obligations of Member States under the United Nations Charter, **********REAFFIRMING FURTHER the principle of the inadmissability of the acquisition of territory by war as reiterated in Security Council Resolution 242 (1967), **********HAVING RECEIVED the report of the Secretary General submitted in accordance with Security Council Resolution 672 (1990) on ways and means for insuring the safety and protection of the Palestinian civilians under Israeli occupation, **********CONSIDERING it necessary to increase the impartial international presence in the occupied territories, **********GRAVELY CONCERNED at the dangerous deterioration of the situation in the Palestinian territories occupied by Israel since 1967, including Jerusalem, **********STRESSING the need for negotiated settlement of the Middle East conflict, with the objectives of ending Israeli occupation of the Palestinian and other Arab territories, security for all states in the region, including Israel, and fulfilling the legitimate political rights of the Palestinian people, **********1) EXPRESSES its appreciation to the Secretary General for his report contained in document S.21919; **********2) DEPLORES the rejection by the Israeli Government of Security Council Resolutions 672 (1990) and 673 (1990); **********3) URGES the Government of Israel to accept the de jure applicability of the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949 to all territories occupied by Israel since 1967, including Jerusalem, and abide scrupulously by the provisions of the said Convention; **********4) CALLS UPON the High Contracting Parties to the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949 to insure respect by Israel, the occupying power, for the Convention under all circumstances, in accordance with Article 1 of the Convention; **********5) WELCOMES the idea of convening a meeting for the High Contracting Parties of the Fourth Geneva Convention, and requests the Secretary General in cooperation with the I.C.R.C. to invite the High Contracting Parties to discuss possible measures to be taken at that meeting by them under the Convention and report to the Council; **********6) REQUESTS the Secretary General to monitor and observe the situation in the occupied territories on an urgent basis, using the United Nations personnel stationed there and appointing the necessary staff to accomplish this task, and to keep the Security Council continuously apprised; **********7) CONSIDERS that the convening at an appropriate time of an international peace conference on the Middle East, properly structured with the participation of the parties concerned, would facilitate the achievement of a comprehensive settlement and lasting peace in the Middle East; **********8) REQUESTS FURTHER the Secretary General to report on the fulfillment of the above provisions, and decides to reconvene as necessary to consider the situation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/01/busin.main_headline: Bankrupt Ames Hires A Turnaround Expert
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/01/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Bankrupt Ames Hires A Turnaround Expert
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/01/busin.body_text: **********Ames Department Stores, the discount retailer that filed for bankruptcy last Wednesday, yesterday named a retailer and turnaround expert to help solve its financial problems. **********Stephen L. Pistner, a former chairman of the McCrory Corporation, will become the chairman and chief executive of Ames immediately. Mr. Pistner, who had also previously served as chairman and chief executive at Montgomery Ward & Company, will replace Peter B. Hollis, whose resignation was announced yesterday. **********Suffering mostly from an inability to digest its 1988 acquisition of 390 Zayre stores for $778 million, Ames filed for protection under the Federal Bankruptcy Code when merchandise suppliers began to sharply cut shipments to the store. Outward signs of Ames's insolvency appeared for the first time several weeks ago when the company, based in Rocky Hill, Conn., said it expected to report a $228 million loss for the fiscal year that ended Jan. 27. Ames became the nation's fourth-largest discounter with the acquisition of the Zayre stores. **********In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Pistner, 58 years old, said he had been given a three-year contract. ''I am hardly familiar enough at this stage with Ames's problems, but I am sure, given Ames's strong assets and market position, we will be able to return Ames to profitability,'' Mr. Pistner said. **********While Mr. Pistner declined to comment on salary, estimates by industry executives put his salary at more than $1 million a year. **********Edward Johnson, an analyst for Prescott, Ball & Turben, said, ''The Pistner name and reputation could help Ames. Besides, Ames needs drastic medicine and he knows how to prescribe it.'' **********Since leaving McCrory in 1988, Mr. Pistner has been a consultant. Before Montgomery Ward, where he worked from 1981 to 1985, he was president of the Dayton Hudson Corporation. He was appointed to that post after turning around the Target discount-store division of Dayton Hudson. **********Mr. Pistner began his career as a salesman of Electronics Associates in St. Paul, where he later became president. He renamed the company Team and sold it in 1970 to Dayton Hudson. **********Known as a demanding and authoritative executive, Mr. Pistner received a multimillion-dollar salary as McCrory's chairman. But within three years, he had policy differences with Meshulam Riklis, chairman of the parent, Rapid-American Corporation, and departed. **********Mr. Pistner, who lives in Florida, is married and has three children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/28/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   BellSouth Plans Paging Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/28/busin.body_text: **********BellSouth Enterprises and the Celltelco Nationwide Paging Partnership announced plans today to begin a joint nationwide paging service. **********The agreement between Mobilecomm, a BellSouth subsidiary, and Celltelco is subject to regulatory approval. The operation would be managed by a committee including representatives of the two companies and would be marketed by Mobilecomm. The deal calls for Celltelco to contribute its license for a nationwide paging system in return for a 50 percent stake in the partnership. **********Mobilecomm would provide network facilities and capital in exchange for the remaining 50 percent. **********Mobilecomm said it would also offer to buy an equity interest in Celltelco when the deal is completed. The amount of that purchase was not disclosed. **********''This joint venture with Celltelco will allow BellSouth to be a major participant in the development of the national paging industry,'' said Earle Mauldin, group vice president for mobile systems at BellSouth Enterprises, a management division of the BellSouth Corporation, the regional telephone company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/busin.main_headline: Delay Sought In Meeting Of OPEC
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/busin.print_headline: Delay Sought In Meeting Of OPEC
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/busin.body_text: **********Iran's oil minister, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, whose country said it would not support an accord proposed by a majority of the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise output, asked today that the OPEC meeting be postponed a week to consider alternative courses. **********But one senior OPEC official who insisted on not being identified, said, ''I think the accord we have stands and will most probably be adopted tomorrow morning.'' **********The Iranian oil minister also suggested that a joint group of OPEC and the Paris-based International Energy Agency, which comprises 21 industrialized nations, meet to decide on joint action to be taken to tackle the oil price crisis. [Reuters reported that Venezuela's Minister of Energy and Mines, Celestino Armas, said that he still expected the OPEC talks to end Wednesday with an accord to raise output. Mr. Armas said that OPEC would have to discuss Iran's proposal for a week's postponement to meet with the International Energy Agency, but that he did not think it would delay the accord beyond Wednesday. The I.E.A. said it would reject talks with OPEC, Reuters also reported.]  The proposal is in line with previous requests from Libya and Iran, which have both opposed any output increase from OPEC, that both oil companies and industrialized nations release their stored oil to relieve the pressure on prices and make up for any shortage of oil exports. **********Shortfall Projected **********Oil analysts project a shortfall of 4 million barrels a day, as a result of the embargo of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil mandated by the United Nations after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and the United Arab Emirates could raise their total output by 3.2 million barrels a day, but prefer to do so under what they call the OPEC umbrella, rather than on their own. Various other OPEC members together could add some 400,000 barrels. **********Mr. Aghazadeh said Western nations should first draw on oil stocks to help meet the crisis. ''It is not the responsibility of OPEC only,'' he said. ''For this reason, I cannot support an increase in production.'' **********Several OPEC officials dismissed the proposal as ''far fetched'' saying it is not likely to dissuade the group'smembers who can increase output from doing so immediately. **********Only Iraq, Iran and Libya oppose the accord, which has the support of 10 OPEC members and could be adopted by a simple majority on Wednesday. **********''On the face of it, meeting with the I.E.A. may not be a bad idea,'' the senior OPEC official said, but he added, ''This is not the time to stop everything and explore this very complicated arrangement.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/world.main_headline: Son of Ex-President of Costa Rica Claims Victory in National Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/world.print_headline: Son of Ex-President of Costa Rica Claims Victory in National Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/world.body_text: **********The 40-year-old son of a former president claimed victory in presidential elections today in Latin America's oldest democracy. **********Rafael A. Calderon Jr., the candidate for the Social Christian Unity Party, was leading with 20 percent of the vote counted. **********''It's a victory for all of us,'' he said, ''everybody who believes in Costa Rica.'' **********The governing party's candidate, Carlos Manuel Castillo, a 61-year-old economist, conceded defeat in a statement at the National Liberation Party's election headquarters. But early returns showed it was one of the closest elections in the 100-year history of Costa Rican democracy. **********The winner is to succeed President Oscar Arias Sanchez, who won the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize for his peace efforts in Central America. Mr. Arias is prohibited under the Constitution from seeking a second term. **********Voters were also electing new members of the 57-seat National Assembly and 1,000 municipal officials. The departing President has said he plans to write a book and spend a year teaching at Harvard University after the inauguration of the new government in May. **********The Turnout Is Heavy **********The turnout was heavy, as is traditional here. Although the campaign frequently was criticized as dull, preliminary figures showed that more than 80 percent of the 1.6 million registered voters cast ballots. **********Both major parties mobilized nationwide transportation networks to take their supporters to the polls. As caravans crisscrossed the country, voters hung out the vehicles' windows waving their parties' multicolored flags. **********Rival supporters blasted each other with horns, beeped in unison to the rhythm of their candidate's name. Hour after hour, wave by pounding wave, the strident battle swept across San Jose. **********The Government gave 10,000 children, some only 4 years old, their first taste of the political process by helping them to register and vote. Like most other Costa Ricans, they went through the cumbersome balloting procedure today. But unlike the ballots of anyone 18 or older, theirs did not count. **********''Castillo's more qualified, but he's older,'' Antonio Baleibanu said in explaining why he voted for Mr. Calderon. The 10-year-old had dressed up for the occasion, choosing a red Washington State Huskies T-shirt and painting war stripes on his face in the red and blue of Mr. Calderon's party. **********The presidential election, the third in the last year in Central America, underscores an ideological shift in the region. President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador and President Rafael Callejas of Honduras, who were elected last year, are both more conservative than their predecessors. **********Both major candidates here are more supportive of United States policy in the region and more critical of Nicaragua's Sandinista Government than Mr. Arias. That is likely to provide critics of the Nicaraguan Government a solid majority in any future regional summit meeting. **********The platforms of the two candidates are distinguished largely by nuance, although their styles could not be more different. Mr. Calderon is the more charismatic. He has avoided direct attacks on President Arias, who has a better than 80 percent approval rating, but has charged that the governing party is corrupt and is trying to perpetuate its power. **********Wholesome Image Is Aim **********Mr. Calderon's advertising campaign has tried to portray him as a social populist and foreign policy conservative and has focused on his handsome family, apparently in an attempt to give him a wholesome, neighborly image. Mr. Calderon is the son of Rafael Angel Calderon, who was president from 1940 to 1944 and who tried to nullify results of the 1948 elections when his party lost. **********Mr. Castillo has emphasized his experience. His campaign slogan, ''We can trust him,'' is a thinly veiled attempt to play on the perception that the opposition destroyed the economy when it was in power eight years ago. **********But he appears austere and uncomfortable in public and has been unable to attach himself to President Arias's coattails.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/03/busin.body_text: **********The number of working United States oil and gas rigs made a turnaround last week, increasing by 53, to a total of 946, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The week's increase reversed a downward slide in the rig count - a historical occurrence in the first three months of the year. Baker Hughes's rig count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of wells in production. A year ago, the rig count totaled 779.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/busin.body_text: **********South Korea's fledgling second airline, Asiana, made its inaugural international flight today when a Boeing 737-400 flew to Tokyo from Seoul with 147 passengers, a company spokesman said. The private airline, competing with Korean Air Lines, also privately owned, will fly to Tokyo four times a week. Asiana began domestic flights in December 1988 and now serves 10 domestic routes. The airline is owned by the Kumho Group, which also operates a road transport network.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/26/world.main_headline: Bush Visit to Highlight Caracas Chief's Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/26/world.print_headline: Bush Visit to Highlight Caracas Chief's Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/26/world.body_text: **********If there is a world leader who works the international telephone operators harder than President Bush, it is President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela. **********The two have little else in common. One is a blue-blood Republican, the other a charismatic Social Democrat. But their instinct to reach for the Rolodex when crisis strikes has helped make them uncommonly close allies. **********Administration officials say Mr. Bush's visit to Caracas on Dec. 7 as the final leg of his South American tour will highlight Mr. Perez's central rolein Latin American politics. The two leaders plan to discuss how to reinvigorate the stalled Salvador peace negotiations, how to insure that the coming elections in Haiti are peaceful and fair, and how to cushion the international oil market from the gyrations of the Persian Gulf crisis. **********Mr. Bush's talks with Mr. Perez, a State Department official predicted, "will have a nice personal glow." **********Their relationship blossomed two days after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, when Mr. Bush called Mr. Perez on the telephone to express his concern that an explosion in oil prices could destabilize the Western economy.In a formal note delivered to Mr. Perez by Vice President Quayle four days later, Mr. Bush asked Venezuela, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, to increase its oil exports. Without hesitating, Mr. Perez said he would expand production as quickly as possible, and with the help of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia he lobbied for weeks to persuade OPEC members to sustain production levels. **********"He's a real operator," said a White House official, who noted that Mr. Perez's promise to help ease the oil crunch was "the first bit of really good news the Administration had received internationally after the invasion.""His word was his bond," he said. "He delivered." **********Venezuela, which has the largest oil reserves in the Western Hemisphere, has increased its production since the invasion from 2 million to more than 2.4 million barrels a day. The nation plans to boost production by 100,000 barrels more by January. **********"I have told President Bush, and I think he understands, that the potential reserves of Venezuela can take care of all the energy needs of the hemisphere for the forseeable future," Mr. Perez said in a telephone interview. **********What makes the emerging close relationship between the two Presidents all the more remarkable is Mr. Perez's populist record from his first term as President in the 1970's. Then he used his country's oil wealth to expand the role of the state in the economy and tohelp finance and arm the Sandinista revolution in Nicaragua. But today a mellower Mr. Perez is a promoters of a more conservative school of thought that seeks to encourage private enterprise and foreign investment. 'Clear Latin American Lead' **********"Venezuela and Carlos Andres Perez have taken the clear Latin American lead," said Michael M. Skol, the American Ambassador in Venezuela. "Venezuela has influence and has used it responsibly." **********Recognizing Venezuela's role as the most influential nation in the Caribbean basin, Mr. Bush urged Mr. Perez at their last meeting in September to keep a close eye on the Haitian presidential campaign. The Venezuelan needed little encouragement, and in loose coordination with Washington, hehas pursued an aggressive policy to insure that elections next month are fair. **********Mr. Perez said Venezuela was sending 15 military advisers to help insure the security of the balloting in Haiti, and is sending 300,000 barrels of oil at preferential rates during the campaign to ease the country's import burden. Venezuela is also sponsoring seminars for all seven presidential candidates to teach them how to campaign and get out their supporters on election day. **********Mr. Perez said he had spoken with Mr. Bush on the telephone twice in recent weeks about developments in Haiti, Nicaragua and El Salvador. In those conversations, he said that he had also proposed that Venezuela, the United States, Mexico and Spain join in developing an economic aid package for Central America, and that Mr. Bush agreed that it would be a good idea.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/04/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;   Young & Rubicam Quits T.W.A. Account
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/04/busin.body_text: **********Young & Rubicam Advertising, New York, resigned yesterday as agency of record for Trans World Airlines. The account billed $45 million. **********''We could not agree on an acceptable level of compensation for our services,'' said Joseph E. De Deo, the agency's president and chief executive. ''It would not have been possible for us to continue to service their business without sustaining unacceptable losses. It is not a happy moment for us. We wish T.W.A. well.'' **********T.W.A. could not be reached for comment late yesterday when the announcement was made.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/busin.main_headline: Fed Nominee Backs Policy On Inflation
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/busin.print_headline: Fed Nominee Backs Policy On Inflation
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/busin.body_text: **********David W. Mullins Jr., the Bush Administration's first nominee to the Federal Reserve Board, testified today that he supports the central bank's current strategy of fighting inflation by keeping interest rates high. **********''I would not disagree with the current policy,'' Mr. Mullins told the Senate Banking Committee at his confirmation hearing. ''The current policy has relatively high real rates. I think that is having a moderating effect on inflation, and I hope that will lead to lower rates.'' **********Mr. Mullins, 43 years old, has played a central role in the Bush Administration's economic policy as the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance. **********View of Fed-Treasury Conflict **********In his testimony, Mr. Mullins said recent reports that the Treasury had been unhappy with the Fed policy, preferring lowering interest rates to stimulate economic growth and bring down the value of the dollar, had been exaggerated. **********''Fundamentally there is no conflict between growth and reducing inflation,'' Mr. Mullins said. ''Reducing inflation is an important prerequisite for maximizing growth.'' **********Mr. Mullins's hearing lasted for more than two and half hours, unusually long for a nominee who is facing little or no opposition. **********Several senators questioned whether Mr. Mullins would be an independent voice on the Fed board or simply a voice of the Treasury. **********Questions on Greenspan Article **********Other questions centered on a recent article in The Los Angeles Times suggesting that Mr. Bush did not intend to reappoint Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve when his term ends in 17 months. **********Mr. Mullins said he had met privately before his nomination in December with Richard G. Darman, the head of the Office of Management and Budget; Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff. But he said that he was unaware of any displeasure in the Administration toward Mr. Greenspan and that he would be an independent voice at the Fed. **********A former professor at the Harvard Business School, Mr. Mullins is a specialist in banking, capital markets and corporate finance.
