Aside from what he said today, his overall economic and monetary policy views are little known. He first gained national recognition when he served as an assistant on the report on the market crash of October 1987 conducted by Nicholas F. Brady, who is now Treasury Secretary. **********When Mr. Brady came to Washington, he brought Mr. Mullins with him to help draft the Bush Administration's savings and loan bailout legislation. Mr. Mullins had primary responsibility for guiding the measure through Congress last year. **********Defends Bailout Estimate **********He testified today that ''convincing and compelling evidence'' was still lacking that the $50 billion bailout was seriously underfinanced, as L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and many critics have argued. **********Mr. Mullins was nominated to fill the remaining six years of the term of H. Robert Heller, who resigned his Fed seat to become executive vice president of Visa International, the credit card company. **********Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, the chairman of the Banking Committee, said he would support Mr. Mullins's nomination. A vote on the nomination could come as early as next week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/29/world.main_headline: Ethnic Strife Goes On In Pakistani Province
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/29/world.print_headline: Ethnic Strife Goes On In Pakistani Province
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/29/world.body_text: **********Renewed fighting between ethnic groups in Sind province killed at least 15 people today. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan criticized the police for their role in unrest, in which at least 152 people have died in three days. **********The violence in Sind, the home province of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, increased domestic pressure on Ms. Bhutto as she tries to deal with a dispute with New Delhi over a Muslim revolt in India's disputed Kashmir state, political analysts said. **********In a statement, President Ishaq Khan denounced the police for an ''ill-planned'' operation and ''indiscriminate firing'' in the ethnic violence ravaging Karachi, Pakistan's largest city, and nearby Hyderabad. **********Mr. Ishaq Khan, quoted by a spokesman in Islamabad, the capital, called for a judicial inquiry into the actions of Sind policemen in Hyderabad. His strong remarks were unusual, since administration is considered the Prime Minister's responsibility. **********The army brought relative calm to Hyderabad, where 99 people were killed Sunday in clashes between security forces and rioters. **********Fifteen people were killed in Karachi, where the victims included a pro-Government member of Parliament, Senator Mohsin Siddiqi. He was shot while driving through the riot-devastated central district, the police said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/busin.body_text: **********If the Pentagon follows its plan to shut the M-1 tank program in a budget-cutting move, the impact will not end with the General Dynamics Corporation, the big weapons maker that assembles the tank at factories in Ohio and Michigan. **********It would also be a big setback for the tiny Lakewood Manufacturing Company in Westlake, Ohio, which makes fenders and other metal parts for the tank, and for Cadillac Gauge Textron Inc. in Warren, Mich., which makes the aiming system for the tank's gun. **********Scores of other companies would also lose large amounts of business, in some cases enough to endanger their survival. In a recent survey of 120 of its M-1 subcontractors, General Dynamics found that 15 percent would have to close a plant if production of the tank program was ended. **********A Ripple Effect **********The M-1 program is just one example of how the coming Pentagon budget cuts would ripple through thousands of subcontractors in all 50 states. Such smaller companies heavily dependent on military contracts are particularly vulnerable to the upheaval and accelerated consolidation that awaits the military-supply industry as it enters the post-cold war era. **********Lakewood, for example, derives more than 50 percent of its $6.5 million in annual sales from subcontracting work for General Dynamics on the M-1 and employs half its 95 employees on the program. Its executives are already preparing for the changes ahead. **********''We're aggressively trying to diversify into commercial markets, and we think we'll be able to replace some of the M-1 work, but we'll be hurt,'' said Richard C. Peplin Jr., the company's owner. ''Some people will be laid off, and the company will go backward to some extent.'' **********While the ranks of subcontractors include large corporations like Texas Instruments Inc. and the General Electric Company, most lack the size, the name recognition and the political influence of prime contractors like General Dynamics. But the business of supplying nuts and bolts, wing sections, radar equipment, microchips and other components is an immense enterprise that cuts across regional economies and industry lines. **********On most arms programs, roughly half the budget ultimately flows to subcontractors. Last year, for example, when the Pentagon awarded $120 billion of prime contracts, more than $56 billion was farmed out to subcontractors, many of which rely on yet another tier of suppliers for the parts they need. 5 Percent Cuts Ahead Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is lobbying Congress to limit cuts in the Pentagon's $300 billion budget to about 2 percent a year through 1997. But Congress seems certain to insist upon deeper cuts, probably in the range of 5 percent a year after accounting for inflation. **********Cuts of that magnitude would reduce the size of the United States military force by as much as 25 percent. They would also mean canceling, delaying or scaling back most big weapons programs. In addition to the M-1 tank program, Mr. Cheney has already recommended cuts in other high-profile systems like the B-2 Stealth bomber being built by the Northrop Corporation and thousands of subcontractors. **********The weapons industry is not the only one in which subcontractors are put at risk when the business cycle turns down, as suppliers to the automobile industry have long known. But analysts and industry executives think the current political atmosphere will mean a permanent reduction in the size of the military contracting industry. **********A Decade of Pressure **********The last decade has left many military subcontractors battered by foreign competition and squeezed by new Government rules that lowered the allowable profit margin on contracts and raised the costs of dealing with the Pentagon bureaucracy, which stepped up its oversight and demanded more paperwork. A half-dozen Government and private studies now conclude that further weakening could imperil national security. **********''If present trends persist, the once-mighty arsenal of democracy could become little more than an electronic laboratory, perhaps even incapable of manufacturing the materiel required for deterrence or for protecting U.S. national interests around the globe,'' said a report issued last year by the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a nonpartisan research group in Washington. **********A Faster Exodus **********The center estimated that the number of companies doing military contracting work decreased to fewer than 40,000 in 1987, from 138,000 in 1982. Government officials and private analysts say budget cuts will only speed that exodus. ''There is no question that we have already lost a significant number of subcontractors and suppliers,'' said Senator Jeff Bingaman, the New Mexico Democrat who is chairman of a subcommittee on the military contracting industry, ''and budget cuts are one additional element that will adversely affect them.'' **********Michael Quinn, the director of marketing and program operations at Cadillac Gauge Textron, a division of Textron Inc., said that if the M-1 program ended, the company would probably have to lay off at least half of its 65 skilled engineers and hundreds of production workers. **********''The state of the art would stop advancing and our ability to remain competitive internationally would erode,'' Mr. Quinn said. ''More important, when there's a new generation of technology, we'll be starting over with amateurs. If suddenly the Russians weren't withdrawing or some other threat appeared, it would be at least four years until we could support a tank production effort.'' **********The same types of issues are already facing other subcontractors across the country. Texas Instruments said earlier this month that it would eliminate 1,000 of the 22,000 jobs in its military systems division, reflecting declining demand for its military electronics products, which are used in scores of weapons systems. The P.V. Tool Company in Westbury, L.I., a precision-tool maker that gets 80 percent of its business from the nearby Grumman Corporation, has seen annual revenues fall by almost 40 percent as Grumman programs like the F-14 Navy fighter plane and the A-6 attack plane are scaled back or canceled. **********Paring Back Suppliers **********Even where programs have not been canceled, the prospect of budget cuts is squeezing subcontractors, as prime contractors pare back the number of suppliers they deal with, seeking to give their business to those who consistently deliver the best price and the best quality. **********''The aerospace industry is cutting back its supplier base, and it's doing it by selecting those suppliers that are improving their operations,'' said Ted Tiaga, the owner of Golden Eagle Manufacturing, a metal-working company in San Dimas, Calif., which makes parts for missiles and torpedoes. **********The prime contractors, seeking to keep their own plants and personnel busy, are also starting to do some work themselves that they formerly would have subcontracted. ''When the defense budget is growing, it's easier to farm the work out,'' said William B. Burnett, a vice president at the consulting firm Charles River Associates. ''When the budget is shrinking, the primes are more likely to keep the work in-house.'' **********Competition Intensifies **********The battle to get business from prime contractors has become increasingly intense. In some cases, suppliers are cutting their prices significantly, seeking to win enough business just to keep operating. **********Lamsco West Inc. in Santa Clarita, Calif., recently bid for some additional work making portions of the outer skin of the B-2 Stealth bomber, offering to do the work at its cost. The company lost out to another subcontractor that was willing to do the work for even less. **********''Some of these small shops almost have to take business at less than cost in order to at least meet their overhead expenses,'' said Gladden Baldwin, the general manager of Lamsco West. **********More Nonmilitary Work **********Many subcontractors are looking for more nonmilitary work. Golden Eagle Manufacturing, which relies on military business for 95 percent of its revenues, wants half its business to be commercial, Mr. Tiaga said. It has already had some success making parts for the water-purification industry and for medical instruments. **********But most commercial markets are already highly competitive, and many subcontractors admit they are likely to have only limited success with diversification. Moreover, for many companies, nonmilitary business is not a realistic option. **********''Everything we do is designed for the life-and-death defense situation,'' said Mr. Quinn of Cadillac Gauge. ''If we were to build a commercial product it would probably be overpriced by five or six times.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/12/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   PEREZ DE CUELLAR VISITS ALBANIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/12/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   PEREZ DE CUELLAR VISITS ALBANIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/12/world.body_text: **********Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations flew here today for talks with Albania's Communist leaders. The Albanians see the visit as an opportunity to advance the opening of their isolated and restricted country. **********It was the first visit here by a Secretary General, who came at the invitation of President Ramiz Alia's Government. Thousands of Albanians lined the narrow road from the airport and thousands more stood along the streets of this capital of 300,000 people to glimpse the cavalcade of eight cars carrying the hosts and guests. **********The crowds were silent as the cars passed along streets normally crowded with pedestrians, horse carts and ancient trucks or buses. But they stared intensely at the passing parade. **********Touring Eastern Europe **********The widely publicized visit of Mr. Perez de Cuellar, who has been touring Eastern European countries in a United Nations jet, was celebrated in the Albanian press, as was the presence of a dozen journalists representing publications from the United States, Spain, Brazil, France, Portugal, China, Japan, West Germany and Italy. **********Mr. Alia is apparently using the presence of the United Nations chief and the non-Communist journalists in his effort to push back what is believed to be opposition to his ''democratization'' policy from powerful Stalinist elements in the sole political organization, the Party of Labor, as the Communists are called here. **********Mr. Alia has been in power since the death in 1985 of his predecessor, Enver Hoxha, but only recently has he moved to change the authoritarian policies of the man who ruled Albania for four decades. **********Albanian Government officials and journalists said as much, and Ismail Kadare, the country's leading novelist, remarked in a brief interview today that the Mr. Perez de Cuellar's visit could be viewed as ''part of the process of democratization in Albania.'' **********''There is joy among the people these days about these developments,'' he said. **********Fundamental Change Sensed **********There is a sense here that for the first time since World War II Albania is undergoing fundamental change from a rigid Communist police state to a more participatory society and the introduction of elements of democracy. **********The visit started with traditional airport protocol. The Secretary General shook hands with the ambassadors from Eastern and Western nations who reside here. **********The accents in the welcoming remarks of Foreign Minister Reis Malile reflected Albania's new attitude. **********Petraq Pojani, the Foreign Ministry's spokesman, said Mr. Malile spoke of Albania's desire to ''strengthen cooperation with the United Nations and to make every effort to contribute to the work of the U.N.,'' where Albania has long been a relatively inactive member. **********Mr. Malile emphasized that Albania was ''a small country.'' Its population is 3.3 million. But he said that henceforth Albania intended to take part more actively not only in the United Nations but also in the 6-nation Balkan cooperation talks that began two years ago in Belgrade and in the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. **********Issue of 6 in Italian Embassy **********For his part, Mr. Perez de Cuellar praised Albania's ''strong commitment to independence.'' **********While his talks dealt in the generalities of international affairs, there is expectation that the Secretary General may be confronted with a specific issue. **********Six Albanians have been taking refuge in the Italian Embassy here since December 1985 and have refused to leave even with a promise of Albanian exit visas. This has not changed, although Parliament this week passed a law permitting all Albanians to travel abroad. **********According to Albanian officials, Mr. Perez de Cuellar may be asked to provide a diplomatic means for the six Albanians to leave under United Nations auspices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/01/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Hun Sen expressed concern today that Khmer Rouge forces were coordinating military operations and strategy with non-Communist guerrilla armies supported by the United States, and he said the Khmer Rouge had obtained weapons from the non-Communist factions. **********In an interview, the Prime Minister said Khmer Rouge guerrillas had received American-made antitank weapons from the non-Communist forces despite Washington's assertion that such arms transfers had not occurred. **********The Cambodian Government is fighting a three-party coalition made up of the Communist Khmer Rouge and two non-Communist guerrilla groups led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Son Sann, a former Prime Minister. **********Displays M-16 Rifles **********Mr. Hun Sen displayed M-16 rifles and grenade launchers that he said had been seized from Khmer Rouge guerrillas during fighting in October. He said that the guerrillas had obtained the weapons from Prince Sihanouk's army. **********There was no way to verify the source of the weapons independently, and Mr. Hun Sen did not say how many weapons the Khmer Rouge had obtained from the Sihanouk army. **********Cambodian officials and foreign diplomats said the war was confined mainly to three provinces along the Thai border and appeared to be at an impasse. **********The 38-year-old Prime Minister said that Cambodia would hold national elections by early 1991 regardless of whether his Government reaches a negotiated political settlement with the guerrilla forces. **********The Prime Minister said he hoped to achieve a political settlement of the civil war so the United Nations could send experts to Cambodia to ''organize the elections.'' Opposition candidates, including Prince Sihanouk, could then take part in the voting, he said. **********International Observers Invited **********In the absence of a political solution, Mr. Hun Sen said, Cambodia plans to organize elections by itself and invite international observers to monitor the vote. His comments were the most explicit statement by any Cambodian official of the Government's intention to hold elections monitored by international observers. **********Gen. Peng Path, a Vice Minister of Defense, said in an interview that the tactics of the Khmer Rouge were more clever and sophisticated than those of the non-Communist factions. The Khmer Rouge forces, led by Pol Pot, save their ammunition and quietly send infiltrators deep into Cambodia while allowing the non-Communist forces to assault Cambodian Government positions near the border, he said. If the guerrilla coalition starts to prevail, the Khmer Rouge would be the first to arrive in Phnom Penh and would be in a better position to seize power, he said. **********Thus, he concluded: ''The most dangerous enemy is Pol Pot. The Khmer Rouge is more patient, more persistent, and can endure more'' than the non-Communist factions. **********Mr. Hun Sen said, ''U.S. arms that were provided to the other side could not fail to fall into the hands of the Khmer Rouge.'' **********Artillery Support Cited **********Khieu Kanharith, editor of the weekly newspaper Kampuchea, said the Khmer Rouge had provided artillery support to the guerrillas. **********Gen. Peng Path said that Phnom Penh had received most of its weapons from Moscow and that there had been no change in the level of arms shipments in the last six months. **********Mr. Hun Sen said the date for elections would be set by the National Assembly. Several Cambodian officials said they were considering dates in the first half of 1990. **********''If there is a political solution, we would organize elections within the framework of that solution,'' Mr. Hun Sen said. ''If there is no political solution, we would have to organize elections on a unilateral basis. One way or the other, elections will be held.'' **********The United States and most Western countries have refused to recognize the current Phnom Penh Government, saying it is illegitimate because it was installed by Vietnamese invaders in January 1979. **********The Khmer Rouge ruled Cambodia from 1975 to January 1979. It presided over a brutal restructuring of society in which more than a million Cambodians were killed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/27/busin.main_headline: Toyota Plant Is Expected For Kentucky
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/27/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Toyota Plant Is Expected For Kentucky
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/27/busin.body_text: **********The Toyota Motor Corporation is expected to end months of speculation on Tuesday by announcing that it will build another automobile assembly plant near its existing factory in Georgetown, Ky. **********Toyota needs the additional production capacity to meet rising demand for its vehicles in the United States. In the last year, Toyota's American sales have risen 13.7 percent. **********In contrast, the Big Three car makers have posted sales declines, which they have attributed to a soft market. The declines have led to plant shutdowns and the temporary layoffs of more than 40,000 workers. **********A Toyota official said six states had been under consideration for the new plant, which the company had said would be situated within a few hours' drive of Georgetown. Sharing Some Operations **********A Toyota spokesman in Georgetown declined to name the states under consideration. But, he said, "Kentucky received first consideration because of the success we have had here so far." **********Analysts said that situating the new plant near an existing one would enable the two factories to share certain manufacturing operations, saving millions of dollars. **********Analysts expect the new plant to cost somewhat less than the $1.1 billion that Toyota has invested in its Georgetown factory, which began producing Camry automobiles in May 1988. Stamped metal parts and engines, for instance, might come from the existing factory. **********Although Toyota has not said what it plans to produce at the new plant, a likely candidate would be the subcompact Corolla, as well as additional production of the Camry. Both models have been selling well in the United States. **********But many industry analysts have also been speculating that Toyota might begin manufacturing a full-size pickup truck, breaking into a niche that remains the Big Three's exclusive domain. **********"I keep thinking this will be the long-awaited pickup truck plant," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton. "There is a lot more profit in those than in the compact pickups." **********Toyota currently operates a joint venture with the General Motors Corporation in Fremont, Calif., which is scheduled to begin producing compact pickup trucks in August. The joint-venture plant also makes Corollas and a similar model, the Geo Prizm, for G.M. A Toyota plant in Canada also makes Corollas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/17/busin.main_headline: Northwest and Delta Match $12 Surcharge for Fuel Cost
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/17/busin.print_headline: Northwest and Delta Match $12 Surcharge for Fuel Cost
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/17/busin.body_text: **********Northwest Airlines and Delta Air Lines matched American Airlines yesterday in adding a $12 surcharge on every round-trip ticket to help cover the rising cost of fuel. **********The surcharges apply to tickets bought on Feb. 9 or later. The surcharge will be quoted separately from the fare by travel agents and airline reservation agents. It will also be listed as a separate charge on the ticket. **********Other airlines are expected to match the increases, even if the higher fares cost them some passengers at a time of year when fares usually go down as traffic slows. But if even one big airline refuses, the increases would probably be withdrawn by the rest of the carriers. **********The increases come on top of a 4 percent rise in fares that some airlines began several weeks ago, also to cover fuel costs, which have risen to 90 cents a gallon and higher, from 60 cents only last month. Supplies of jet fuel have tightened as refiners have switched more production to heating oil during the unusually cold weather of recent months. **********Underestimated Fuel Cost **********Donald J. Carty, senior vice president of finance and planning at the AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, said the nation's largest carrier had expected that fuel would cost about 65 cents a gallon in January. **********''Somehow the airlines are going to have to get more for their product than they have been getting to ameliorate this fuel price increase,'' he said. **********Fuel is one of the largest costs for airlines, ranging from 30 percent of operating costs for carriers with older fleets to 20 percent for carriers with newer, more fuel-efficient fleets. **********The price in jet fuel is still rising even though prices for heating oil, which surged in December, have begun to fall. Heating oil, at $1.10 a gallon in the last week of December, has been selling for about 70 cents a gallon for January delivery in the New York area. **********Oil analysts said the increase in the production of heating oil to meet the high demand caused by cold weather in recent months is one cause for the low inventories of jet fuel. **********'The More Pressing Need' **********''Supplies are tight due to the fact that refineries maximized output of heating oil,'' said Robert Boslego, an oil consultant. ''That was the more pressing need. That's where they make their money.'' **********He said another reason for tighter supplies was that many refineries on the Gulf Coast had to cut production because the cold affected equipment. **********He said supplies of jet fuel were the lowest in some time, with the supply at 24 days now, compared with 28 days a year ago and 34 days in 1988. **********At the same time, demand for fuel among the airlines, many of which have expanded routes and taken delivery of new planes, has risen by 7.8 percent in the last three months, Mr. Boslego said. **********Mr. Carty said the airlines could do little about the price because most do not have the capacity to store fuel. **********Carriers like American, which has been buying more fuel-efficient airplanes, can better absorb a fuel price rise than carriers like Trans World Airlines and Pan American World Airways, which have older fleets. Pan Amd (pan american) NWAd (northwest airlines)

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/23/busin.main_headline: Monsanto Shares Up Sharply On Hopes for Fat Substitute
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/23/busin.print_headline: Monsanto Shares Up Sharply On Hopes for Fat Substitute
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/23/busin.body_text: **********Even though frozen desserts made with Nutrasweet's new fat substitute will be in grocers' freezers this summer, the Monsanto Company subsidiary is unlikely to find itself gorging on profits for years. **********As with any new product, it might take several years for Simplesse, as the ingredient is called, to recoup the money it took to develop and market it, food industry analysts say. This is particularly true in this case, because for now the Food and Drug Administration has approved the product for use only in ice cream-like desserts. **********Even so, Monsanto stock, listed on the New York Stock Exchange, rose by $4.375 a share today to close at $112.25, with some analysts predicting an immense demand for Simplesse products, given the growing national concern for healthy diets. In 1989, Nutrasweet had $869 million in sales for its artificial sweetener aspartame, accounting for just 10 percent of Monsanto's sales and 16.7 percent of the company's net operating profits, analysts at Salomon Brothers said. Monsanto, based in St. Louis, makes most of its money selling industrial and agricultural chemicals. $500 Million in Sales Possible While many analysts were reluctant to guess the potential market for fat substitutes, some said that within five years Simplesse could generate $300 million to $500 million in sales. **********David L. Morley, group vice president of the Simplesse group, declined to disclose any projections for the product. He also declined to disclose the advertising budget for Simplesse. **********Still, Simplesse is Nutrasweet's long-awaited second act. Until now, the company's sole product had been the highly successful aspartame, which has found wide acceptance in soft drinks and foods since it was introduced in 1981. There had been mounting pressure on Nutrasweet to develop another product because the exclusive patents it holds on aspartame will start to expire around the world in 1992. **********At a news conference in New York,the company said it would follow the same ''branded ingredient'' strategy that helped make Nutrasweet, itself a substitute ingredient, a household name. The company said the line of Simplesse frozen desserts, called Simple Pleasures, would be marketed through a newly formed subsidiary, the Simplesse Company, based in Skokie, Ill., a few miles from Nutrasweet's Deerfield headquarters. **********Little Immediate Impact **********Despite the jump in Monsanto's stock today, Leonard Bogner, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Research, said Simplesse would have little immediate impact on Nutrasweet. ''In terms of financial impact, near term, there's not going to be one,'' he said. Simplesse will lose money this year because of the cost of introducing the product, he said. **********Nutrasweet officials said Simplesse had a wide variety of potential applications. The low-calorie fat substitute, made from cooking and blending milk or egg-white protein, is intended to replace fat in salad dressings, mayonnaise, yogurt, butter, cheese and other dairy products. Simplesse is one of many fat substitutes being developed around the nation. But unlike a potential competitor, Procter & Gamble's Olestra, which is still awaiting approval, Simplesse breaks down when exposed to high temperatures and therefore cannot be used in cooking or baking.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/11/world.body_text: **********Barring a collapse brought about by the wave of political violence now afflicting Guatemala, the general elections on Sunday and the inauguration of a President in January should mark a democratic watershed: the first transfer of power from one elected civilian to another in the country's history. **********That would be a significant step for the United States-backed effort to end a tradition of military dictatorship and build a working democratic system. **********But Western diplomats say the political violence illustrates President Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo's failure to gain control over the armed forces and end the institutionalized terrorism that limits political expression to the right and the extreme right. **********"The only left here is in the mountains," said Juan Francisco Alfaro, secretary general of the Confederation of Guatemalan Union Groups, the largest labor organization in the country, in referring to a three-decade-old guerrilla movement. Only Hints at Reform **********Most leading candidates have announced ambitious programs to stabilize the foundering economy. But they have not dared to do more than hint at plans for demilitarization, agrarian reform, population control or land redistribution. Such programs would address the problems most often cited as the causes of the pervasive poverty and political repression that have led to two decades of war and bloodshed. **********The results have been growing apathy and hopelesses in the face of growing violence, a resurgent guerrilla movement and corruption by the ruling Christian Democrats. Increasingly, Guatemalans equate democracy with anarchy and yearn for the strict hand of military government. **********"People are asking themselves: Is this what we wanted? Is this the system we fought for?" said Edmond Mulet, a senior opposition deputy. "There's enormous frustration. In only five years the whole system is besieged. Whatever happened to our dreams?" **********In a startling turnaround from the national jubilation that greeted Mr. Cerezo's 1985 election, polls now find a five-point preference for military regimes over democratic governments. But the army, which squashed two right-wing coup attempts against Mr. Cerezo, is expected to accept any of the three leading candidates. A Wealthy Front-Runner **********Polls show that the front-runner is Jorge Carpio Nicolle, a wealthy newspaper publisher and founder of the National Center Union. In an effort to broaden his appeal in the private sector, he enlisted as his running mate Manuel Ayau Cordon, a businessman who started as a presidential candidate of the far-right National Liberation Movement. **********Senior members of the National Center Union have acknowledged that it was unlikely that the ticket could win the absolute majority needed to avoid a runoff in January. That has made the campaign into a scramble for second place between Alvaro Arzu, the wealthy former mayor of the capital and the ex-president of the National Liberation Movement, and Jorge Antonio Serrano, an evangelist and the president of the council of state during the regime of the dictator Gen. Efrain Rios Montt.  The General's Reputation **********Mr. Serrano has benefited from the collapse of the general's own candidacy, which ended last month when the Supreme Court upheld the constitutional provision barring former dictators from power. In the most obvious sign of the country's disillusionment with democracy, the general was until then the front-runner, even though thousands of civilians were killed during his rule in the early 1980's. But his 16-month tenure is now remembered more for stability than for bloodshed. **********The national dissatisfaction seems to have buried the chances of Alfonso Cabrera Hidalgo, the candidate of the ruling Christian Democrats, who by law may not renominate the President. Mr. Cabrera's campaign has faltered since he was stricken with pancreatitis earlier this month. **********Mr. Cerezo spent his first two years as President pushing demilitarization and Guatemala seemed to be fertile soil for democracy.  But Guatemalan politicians say their President appeared to give up and became content to finish his term. He stopped going regularly to his office, and his aides were replaced by girlfriends who surrounded him in what has been described as "a thicket of pretty legs." **********Violence began to mount. In the first nine months of this year, there were 276 political murders and 145 disappearances, according to the congressionally appointed Human Rights Ombudsman. **********Mr. Cerezo has described the human rights abuses as the final spasms of a dying era. But many Guatemalans blame the President, saying he allowed himself to become a captive of the army. They note the military staffs his country estate, providing even the servants. When aides went to see him there earlier this year, they said they were required to park their cars and ride the last two miles on Army buses. **********"He became the caged pet of the army," Jorge Skinner Klee, a senior opposition Congressman, said. **********But some diplomats say Mr. Cerezo came to rely on the army because it is the only bureaucracy that works. He asked civilian aides two years ago to prepare his position papers for a summit meeting in Mexico. They never produced. Finally, he turned to the army. It had a series of detailed plans on his desk within a week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Coca-Cola to Raise Dividend by 18%
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/busin.body_text: **********The Coca-Cola Company, enjoying a strong global beverage business, raised the quarterly dividend on its common stock by 18 percent and said its board would recommend a 2-for-1 stock split at its annual meeting. Coke's shares rose sharply in on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $69.50, up $2.375 each. **********The dividend increase, to 40 cents a share from 34 cents, is the largest percentage increase in the company's quarterly dividend since 1960. The new annual rate is $1.60 a share. The higher dividend is payable on April 1 to shareholders of record on March 15. If the stock split is approved by shareholders at the April 18 meeting, the additional shares would be distributed about May 11.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/18/busin.body_text: **********The New York developer Donald J. Trump said yesterday that he had met the interest payment deadlines on two high-yield, or "junk bond," issues sold to finance two Atlantic City casinos. **********Mr. Trump paid about $18.4 million in interest to bondholders of the Trump Castle Hotel and Casino and approximately $16 million in interest to the bondholders of the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino. **********The developer said yesterday that the payments were with funds from within the Trump Organization, his main corporate entity, and not with money borrowed from financial institutions. Mr. Trump is said to have arranged a line of credit with a foreign lending institution. **********Although yesterday's Trump Plaza payment had been expected, some uncertainty had arisen over whether Mr. Trump would be able to pay the $18.4 million of interest on the Castle bonds. The Castle remains the weakest performer among Mr. Trump's three Atlantic City casinos. **********Next June, the developer faces a much larger principal and interest payment on the Castle bonds, and it is expected that he will continue to try to resolve some of the Castle's debt problems before then. **********For most of this year, Mr. Trump has been locked in negotiations with bankers, bondholders and other creditors as he has tried to reschedule more than $3 billion in debt and win more lenient repayment terms. **********Last month, he escaped having his prize Atlantic City property, the Taj Mahal casino, forced into bankruptcy by giving 50 percent of his equity in the casino to bondholders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/world.main_headline: Big Christian Battle Taking Shape Along Highway North From Beirut
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/world.print_headline: Big Christian Battle Taking Shape Along Highway North From Beirut
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/world.body_text: **********Civilians in Christian East Beirut who spent six days and nights sheltering from fighting between warring Christians took advantage of a lull today to look for food or flee to safer ground. **********Large crowds gathered outside bakeries and groceries early today to try to stock up in anticipation of the next battle, which broke out in the afternoon despite a promise by the combatants to observe a truce. **********Police and hospital officials say 260 people have been killed and 1,200 wounded in the week since ferocious battles broke out between Christian troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun and militiamen of the Lebanese Forces, a Christian militia headed by Samir Geagea. Among the dead are 25 people who were killed in Muslim West Beirut by artillery shells fired from the Christian side. **********After the six-hour lull was broken, civilians rushed back to their cold and dark shelters. All of Beirut has been without electricity and water since the latest round of fighting began. **********At the coastal town of Dbeiye, five miles north of East Beirut, witnesses said Mr. Geagea's forces remained in partial control. The militia has admitted that General Aoun's troops advanced about one mile up the coast in a 12-hour battle on Sunday involving thousands of troops and militiamen. **********General Aoun's troops in Dbeiye faced militia tanks and artillery guarding a tunnel at Nahr al-Kalb, a strategic spot on the coastal highway leading to the militia-held port of Junieh, 13 miles north of the capital. Both sides brought reinforcements to the tunnel to prepare for the next round. **********In the capital, the fighting has turned into a real urban warfare, with tanks and artillery firing into residential quarters in East Beirut and its suburbs, with the areas under the control of one side or the other resembling a patchwork. **********General Aoun's army now controls a strip of territory extending from the general's bunker beneath the presidential palace in suburban Baabda in the southeast to Dbeiye, including some neighborhoods of East Beirut. **********Mr. Geagea says his men are in solid control of two Christian districts to the north, Byblos and Kesrouan. **********The leading Beirut daily, An Nahar, said today that the two men were locked in a struggle to the finish. ''If Aoun backs down now, he would lose, and Geagea must keep up the resistance,'' it said. **********The Christian battles began when General Aoun moved to disarm the 10,000-strong militia, which was sharing power in the Christian enclave with the general's 15,000-man force.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/21/busin.main_headline: Sears Certificate Offering Is Aimed at Small Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/21/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;   Sears Certificate Offering Is Aimed at Small Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/21/busin.body_text: **********Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, yesterday priced a $250 million issue of pass-through certificates that are being aimed at retail investors rather than the institutional buyers who normally dominate the asset-backed market. **********The offering is being done through an underwriting group led by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., a Sears unit. **********The certificates are backed by receivables from the Sears credit card. The giant retailer, through its Sears Receivables Financing Group subsidiary, sold a portion of its credit card accounts-receivable portfolio to a trust that issues certificates. The trust for this issue is Sears Credit Account Trust 1990-B, and these certificates represent an undivided ownership interest in the receivables owned by the trust. **********Underwriters gave the certificates, which have a scheduled maturity date of March 15, 1995, an 8 3/4 percent coupon and priced them at 99.70 to yield 8.90 percent, or about 43 basis points more than the when-issued five-year Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********The certificates are expected to be rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/28/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Top West German Anti-Terrorist Is Slightly Wounded in a Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/28/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Top West German Anti-Terrorist Is Slightly Wounded in a Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/28/world.body_text: **********West German terrorists set off a bomb by remote control next to a busy highway today just as Bonn's top anti-terrorist official was driving by. The official was slightly wounded in the neck and arm. **********The official, Hans Neusel, state secretary in the Interior Ministry, was on his way to his office at 7:30 A.M. and had taken the highway exit to the ministry, in northern Bonn, when an electric-eye bomb went off just as his Government car went by. **********The bomb was said to have been concealed in the guard rail on the right side of the road. Witnesses said the explosion tore a three-foot-deep hole in the roadway and badly damaged the car and the guard rail. **********The attack followed a series of extraditions of West German terrorist suspects recently found to have been hiding in East Germany. **********Ex-Lebanese Seized in '86 Blast **********Disclosures by a former East German Communist secret police officer have also led to the arrest of a former Lebanese citizen on charges of organizing the 1986 bombing of a West Berlin discotheque, in which two two American soldiers died. The West Berlin authorities said today that the former Lebanese citizen was believed to have been following orders from a Libyan terrorist. **********The bombing led President Ronald Reagan to order the bombing of the Libyan cities of Tripoli and Benghazi that year. **********The police said a letter from the West German terrorist group known as the Red Army Faction had been found at the scene of the attack in Bonn. The letter reportedly said a group named for a Spanish terrorist who died in May had carried out the attack, and demanded among other things that all ''revolutionary prisoners'' be allowed to serve their sentences together. **********The West German authorities said they assumed that the attackers were among the 15 to 20 active Red Army Faction members who were also believed to have killed the chairman of the Deutsche Bank, Alfred Herrhausen, in his car last Nov. 30. He was killed by an electrically triggered remote control bomb similar to the one used in today's attempted assassination of Mr. Neusel. **********''They tried to kill me,'' he told reporters at the scene. ''It's a risk in my job, but even if they had killed me someone else would take my place.'' **********Looking intact but shaken, Mr. Neusel spoke to reporters at the Interior Ministry a few hours after the attack and appealed to the terrorists, who began their actions in Germany in 1968 under the leadership of Andreas Baader and Ulrike Meinhof, to give up their ''criminal and destructive plans.'' **********Groups in Italy and France **********He said terrorist groups in Italy and France as well as Spain and West Germany were trying to form a ''West European guerrilla front.'' **********The West Berlin authorities today identified the man they had arrested on charges of organizing the 1986 discotheque bombing as Ali Mansur, and said he was a West German citizen of Lebanese origin. He was arrested in his apartment on Wednesday on suspicion of murder, a spokesman for the city's justice department said. **********The spokesman said that Mr. Mansur, who is 32 years old, was identified after a former member of the now disbanded East German State Security Ministry's secret police confirmed evidence found in the ministry's files that the East German Communist authorities knew that Libyan terrorists and diplomats had planned the attack on La Belle discotheque. Besides the Americans, a Turkish woman was killed, and 229 people were wounded. **********President Reagan asserted at the time that the Libyan Embassy in East Berlin had planned the attack and he ordered the raids on Tripoli and Benghazi 10 days later. The first evidence confirming the Libyan connection began emerging last month from East German files released last month by Peter-Michael Diestel, the anti-Communist Minister of the Interior., Five Other Suspects The West Berlin spokesman, Cornel Christoffel, said the West Berlin police also had warrants for five other suspects, all of Arab origin, whose names also emerged from the East German files. Another suspect being held in a West Berlin jail on a different charge, Fauor Daher, has not been charged with direct complicity in the discotheque attack, Mr. Christoffel said. **********Other disclosures from the secret security ministry files in East Germany in the last month led to the arrest and extradition to West Germany of five Red Army Faction terrorist suspects, who have all said they fled to the East to avoid reprisals for their efforts to give up violence. **********Erich Mielke, the Communist former chief of the secret police, was arrested by the democratically elected East German Government on Thursday on charges of having illegally sheltered the terrorists, who were on all the international most-wanted lists, and of plotting to set up internment camps for East German dissidents. **********A West German prosecutor, Alexander von Stahl, told a Bavarian newspaper, Passauer Neue Presse, that the bomb attack on Mr. Neusel's car in Bonn was a long-planned operation. ''It could not be a reaction to the extradition of former terrorists to West Germany,'' he said. **********Jose Manuel Sevillano, the Spanish terrorist in whose name the letter said the Red Army Faction had carried out the attack, was a member of the Spanish left-wing guerrilla group Grapo. He died in a Spanish jail May 25 after a 177-day hunger strike. **********He was demanding that 66 jailed Spanish terrorists serve their sentences together. In West Germany, approximately 40 convicted members of the Red Army Faction staged a hunger strike with a similar goal in early 1989.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/26/world.body_text: **********With thousands of angry nationalists besieging its building, the Slovak Parliament approved a bill tonight to make Slovak the official language of the Slovakia republic. **********The new law allows the 600,000 ethnic Hungarians in Slovakia, one of two Czechoslovak republics, to use Hungarian in all official business in communities where they make up at least 20 percent of the population. It was adopted by a vote of 82 to 51, with 10 abstentions. **********The nationalist opponents argued for no exceptions to the language law. **********In the view of the bill's proponents, a law with no exceptions would put Czechoslovakia in violation of the European Convention on Human Rights and block the country's hope for being admitted to the Council of Europe. Prague bases considerable hope on this admission as a step toward membership in the European Community.  'There Is Mob Pressure' **********The coalition government, which supports the bill, holds 86 seats in the 150-seat Parliament. But several coalition deputies said they might be swayed by the radicals outside the gates. **********"There is mob pressure on Parliament," said Peter Tatar, the floor manager for the bill. "The deputies are afraid of their voters and the mob." **********But there were only four defectors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/world.main_headline: Diplomacy Resumed by U.S. and Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/world.print_headline: STANDOFF IN THE GULF; Diplomacy Resumed by U.S. and Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/world.body_text: **********After a week of silence, diplomatic contacts have resumed between the senior United States envoy in Baghdad and Iraqi officials, but no progress has been reported toward resolving the Persian Gulf crisis. **********Meeting ith Western reporters, the American envoy, Joseph C. Wilson 4th, the deputy chief of mission, said, "I have not given up hope on the diplomatic process." **********Secret consultations continued today in the Iraqi capital involving senior Iraqi officials and 20 to 25 Iraqi Ambassadors who have been summoned from Western and other foreign capitals before the Jan. 15 deadline in the United Nations Security Council resolution demanding that Iraq withdraw its occupation army from Kuwait or face eviction by force. **********Foreign Ministry officials have declined to comment on the consultations and have told foreign journalists that they would not be available for the rest of the week. Western officials said they regarded the gathering as an extraordinary session that could signal a new diplomatic initiative by Iraq, probably after the New Year.  Some 'Room for Diplomacy' **********A United States official here said he could not confirm "at this point" an Israeli newspaper report that American and Iraqi officials had discussed or agreed on a date for Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to meet in Baghdad with President Saddam Hussein as part of an effort to avert war. **********The official, whose comments on diplomatic progress were generally positive yet also ambiguous, said, "What you should take from this is that so long as there is some sort of diplomacy to be conducted we are going to conduct it." **********"I think and I hope there is some more room for diplomacy," the official said. Later the official said, "Obviously we're not sitting on our hands here." **********The United States and Iraq remain deadlocked over dates for an exchange of high-level visits proposed by President Bush in an attempt to avert war over Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.  Hints of Compromise Dates **********The United States has insisted that it will send Mr. Baker to Baghdad no later than Jan. 3, but Mr. Hussein said he was not available until Jan. 12, three days before the deadline. The White House has said that date is unacceptable because it is too close to the Jan. 15 deadline and thus the Iraqis would be able to say after such a meeting that they had not had enough time to consider any American offer or to pull out of Kuwait. **********Officials in Washington and Baghdad have hinted at compromise dates between Jan. 5-8 for the Baker meeting, but the United States official here discouraged any suggestion that the Bush Administration had relented on its position that the Baker meeting must occur no later than Jan. 3. **********The Israeli newspaper report said a date of Jan. 9 was agreed on as a date for Mr. Baker's visit. But a State Department spokesman in Washington denied the report. Western officials here said a meeting as late as Jan. 9 was plausible, because many Western governments estimate that Iraq could withdraw its forces in the five to six days remaining before the deadline after such a meeting took place. **********Western embassies here said they had noted the strong resurgence of rumors that Mr. Hussein's Arab Baath Socialist Party is making plans to set off national demonstrations about Jan. 10 that would create the impression that the Iraqi people would rather pull out of Kuwait than go to war. Avoiding Look of Stubbornness **********There have been similar suggestions that Mr. Hussein would submit the question of a pullout to his National Assembly, a consultative body that is controlled by Mr. Hussein's one-party apparatus. **********As with all rumors in the Iraqi capital, Western diplomats say it is difficult to determine whether the current rumor has official sanction or reflects popular sentiment. **********The resumption of diplomatic contacts between the United States Embassy and the Iraqi Foreign Ministry might have been compelled by leaders on both sides who wished to avoid any accusations of stubbornness in working out a compromise on the dates. **********As recently as Monday, the United States official had made a point of telling reporters here that there had been no diplomatic contacts between the United States Embassy and the Iraqi Government for a week.  'You Know Our Position' **********In the last meeting between Mr. Wilson and Nizar Hamdoon, an undersecretary of the Iraqi Foreign Ministry, Mr. Wilson read from an aide memoire that recounted the history of the dispute over the dates, but proposed no compromise, while Mr. Hamdoon listened and then said, "You know our position," Western officials said. **********Today, a United States official said he meant to convey a new impression about the resumption of diplomatic contacts. To demonstrate that contacts had resumed, the official picked up the telephone and dialed the Foreign Ministry. It is believed from his comments on the telephone that he spoke to Mr. Hamdoon, who is a former Ambassador to Washington. **********Also today, Mr. Wilson made arrangements to send a bottle of California wine to Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, as a Christmas gift. Mr. Aziz is a Christian. **********On Christmas Day, Mr. Wilson received a cake in the shape of a Yule log from Mr. Hussein as well as a floral arrangement of purple and lavender zinnias.  Reports on U.S. Readiness **********In an editorial on Tuesday, the state-controlled Baghdad Observer posed the question of whether "time is running out," for diplomacy and then replied, "Who says so?" **********"Peace can always be saved but all it needs is courage," the newspaper said, insisting that Mr. Hussein has the right to chose his own date in January to receive Mr. Baker. **********"This is the idea," the editorial said, "but if the U.S. wants to keep insisting on its own terms, then it will be closing the door to peace." **********Mr. Hussein and other Iraqi officials continued their warnings about the consequences of war in the region, but thus far there has been no official reaction to reports from Washington that the dominant view of the United States military leadership is that American forces in Saudi Arabia might not be prepared for offensive action by mid-January. **********Still, some Iraqi officials have greeted that assessment with skepticism, pointing out that United States and allied air forces in the Persian Gulf have been prepared for some time to carry out offensive operations against Iraq's armed forces. **********"I don't believe this report," said an Iraqi Government official. "They could send 1,000 airplanes tomorrow to bomb us."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/14/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   A Friendship Outlasts A Partnership
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/14/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   A Friendship Outlasts A Partnership
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/14/busin.body_text: **********TOD SEISSER lighted a candle on Saturday at the bar mitzvah of Jay Taub's son - an act demonstrating that in advertising, friendship can outlive partnership. **********Mr. Taub and Mr. Seisser were the vice chairmen of Keye/Donna/Pearlstein, New York, and, like Michael Steadman and Elliot Weston, the fictional copywriter and art director on the television series ''Thirtysomething,'' they saw their agency close after an account defected. Both life and art reveal the capriciousness that rules the advertising industry, where dreams of success can be snuffed out at random. **********But while the television program highlights the self-doubts of two ad men thrust from their entrepreneurial cocoon, reality underscores other traits of advertising people, especially the ones who revel in creativity: their toughness and resilience. **********''I don't want to do 'Mr. Whipple,' '' Mr. Seisser affirmed from his freelancer's desk at Backer Spielvogel Bates. **********Mr. Taub, from his freelance outpost at Ogilvy & Mather, was equally emphatic. ''I don't want to do 'Ring around the collar,' '' he said. **********Last year, after winning the Playboy magazine and Bridgestone tire accounts, the two men were filled with jaunty bravado. Keye/Donna/ Pearlstein's New York office, which was founded on May 16, 1988, was finally establishing itself as a creative force in the ingrown advertising industry. **********But disaster crept slowly upon them. Shortly after the office was formed, Consumer Reports magazine reported that the Samurai, a four-wheel-drive vehicle made by the American Suzuki Motor Corporation, had a tendency to flip over when rounding corners at high speeds. After trying public relations strategies and new advertising themes to limit the damage, Suzuki, the largest client of Keye's home office in Los Angeles, took a step common among threatened clients: It dismissed its ad agency. Pressed for cash, the agency closed its New York branch in March. **********''It's my theory,'' said Mr. Seisser, an art director, ''that somebody at K/ D/P did something in a previous life to deserve the rotten luck that came their way in '89.'' **********The men admitted to brief bouts with depression, but they did not engage in two pastimes that might have been expected when a business goes belly up: rancor and second-guessing. Instead, they concentrated on what they might do next. **********For Mr. Taub, who is 39 years old, the question was solved quickly. A call from Ogilvy came in even before the doors were locked on Keye's New York office. He began freelance copywriting there the day after his agency closed, becoming part of the team that drew the Eastern Airlines account to Ogilvy in May. He has also served part time at Backer Spielvogel Bates, working with the 32-year-old Mr. Seisser in a partnership that is now nine years old. **********Both men said they were freelancing by choice. ''It's like where you get divorced and want to date but don't want to get married right away,'' Mr. Taub said. **********Ah, but whom to marry, when the time arrives? Friends, like Neil Drossman of Campbell-Mithun-Esty, Mr. Taub's mentor, called with solace and advice. Jerry Della Femina, at whose agency Mr. Seisser and Mr. Taub met, entered into negotiations with them that led nowhere. **********The greatest profusion of inquiries came from people who wanted to start agencies and thought Mr. Taub and Mr. Seisser knew the secret. ''Starting an agency is kind of a tough thing to do, getting your ducks in a row,'' Mr. Seisser said. ''A lot of people calling us were looking for a short cut. They wanted to know how tied in we were into the existing business, to use it as a foothold for a new agency.'' **********The offers were all unappealing. ''When things are going good and you want to leave a place, you make it happen, but when someone's courting you and you're not sure where you are in your life, it's hard to say, 'This is what I want and need,' '' Mr. Taub mused. **********Both men said it was irrelevant whether they worked together again. ''Tod and I started out as business partners, but now we're friends who happened to work together,'' Mr. Taub said. And both said their goal was simply to do ''great work,'' which Mr. Seisser defined as advertising that sells products while allowing him to sleep at night. **********But asked to pinpoint the perfect situation, Mr. Seisser waxed a bit nostalgic. ''The ideal?'' he asked. ''If I could invent one?'' he asked again. ''Keye/Donna/Pearlstein,'' he concluded. ''With a vehicle that doesn't flip over.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/01/world.main_headline: Jamaica and Barbados Offer Force to End Trinidad Unrest
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/01/world.print_headline: Jamaica and Barbados Offer Force to End Trinidad Unrest
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/01/world.body_text: **********Jamaica and Barbados have offered assistance to the Government of Trinidad to help it restore public order after the widespread looting and violence produced by an attempted coup. **********On Monday, 120 soldiers of the 2,500-member Jamaican Army were dispatched to Barbados and kept on standby at the Grand Island Cay airport pending a request for assistance from Trinidad. Similarly, the Barbadian Government placed its approximately 1,000-member armed forces on alert should they be needed in Trinidad, 200 miles to the south. **********Jamaican and Barbadian officials said that as of late today, Trinidad had made no request for military assistance, but that discussions about assistance were being held. **********''Our troops will remain there until Trinidad says they are needed or not needed,'' Hartey Nieta, the spokesman for Prime Minister Michael N. Manley of Jamaica, said in a telephone interview from Kingston. ''Rather than have them on standby in Jamaica, we thought it would be better to have them ready for service in Barbados, which is only a half an hour away in case there is more looting and arson.'' **********A Common Anxiety **********The show of regional solidarity reflects a common anxiety over abrupt political crises that can disrupt small island republics. By virtue of its relatively large population and its strong cultural influence, much of the English-speaking Caribbean looks to Jamaica for such leadership. **********In another reflection of concern over events in Trinidad, most speakers at the opening session of a three-day summit meeting of Caribbean leaders this morning added the theme of regional security to the scheduled topics of economic integration and cooperation. **********One leader, Prime Minister Erskine Sandiford of Barbados, called for the creation of a new regional security arrangement, an idea that was subsequently added to the summit agenda. **********If troops are requested by Trinidad, participants at the Caribbean Community meeting, being held in Kingston, said that those sent would most likely limit their role to helping police the streets and restore law and order. **********Grenada a Precedent **********The United States invasion of Grenada in 1983 was the first major precedent for regional security intervention. Troops from Jamaica, Barbados and other islands were flown in after United States forces had arrested leaders of a violent coup on that island. **********After the departure of the American forces, limited numbers of soldiers and police from neighboring islands stayed on to help keep the peace and train a new police force. **********A United States intervention in the violence in Trinidad has all along been considered unlikely, officials say. **********Officials of Barbados say there is already a security arrangement, known as the Regional Security System, linking the small islands of the eastern Caribbean which would provide a legal framework for any security assistance offered Trinidad by her neighbors. **********UNEVENTS can get lost, if needed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/22/busin.main_headline: Rift Ends for Spanish Bank Over Who Will Be Its Head
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/22/busin.print_headline: Rift Ends for Spanish Bank Over Who Will Be Its Head
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/22/busin.body_text: **********A bruising five-week leadership struggle at Spain's largest private bank ended Saturday when the board of the Banco Bilbao Vizcaya approved the appointment of a Basque financier, Emilio Ybarra Churruca, as its chairman. **********The dispute began after the sudden death of one of the bank's co-chairmen, Pedro Toledo, on Dec. 12 and underscored the internal tensions that continue to plague the huge bank formed in October 1988 by a merger of the Banco de Bilbao and the Banco de Vizcaya. **********So deep was the split among the bank's 38 directors that last week they took the unusual step of asking the head of Spain's central bank, Mariano Rubio, to help find a solution. Mr. Rubio's compromise was eventually accepted. **********Jesuit-Trained Economist **********The new chairman, a 53-year-old Jesuit-trained economist from a prominent Basque family, comes from the ranks of the Banco de Bilbao. But his nomination was also approved by board members formerly linked to the Banco de Vizcaya. **********The board accepted Mr. Rubio's suggestion that the B.B.V., as the bank is known here, should be run by a single chairman in order to encourage its internal fusion. **********Under the original merger accord, the chairmen of the two merging banks, Mr. Toledo of the Banco de Vizcaya and Jose Angel Sanchez Asiain of the Banco de Bilbao, were to serve as co-chairmen for four years. After Mr. Toledo's death, the Banco de Vizcaya proposed Alfredo Saenz Abad as his successor, while Mr. Sanchez Asiain made a bid to become sole chairman. **********As the deadlock continued over the year-end holidays, Mr. Sanchez Asiain offered to step down as co-chairman if agreement could be reached on a single successor. His resignation was accepted Saturday. **********New Questions Raised **********The questions now being asked in financial circles here are how much damage has the conflict caused the B.B.V.'s reputation and will the bank being able to overcome its problems. **********The Banco de Bilbao came to merge with the Banco de Vizcaya in 1988 after it was rebuffed in its attempt to fuse with the Banco Espanol de Credito, known as Banesto. While the Bilbao bank was larger and older than its new partner, the Banco de Vizcaya was widely viewed as more modern and agile. **********The Socialist Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez also strongly encouraged the merger on the grounds that, without a rapid process of consolidation and reorganization, Spain's banking and financial sector would be highly vulnerable to takeovers in the integrated European market that will exist after 1992. **********But financial experts said the good will that preceded the merger was quickly strained by squabbles over the size of offices assigned to the new co-chairmen. **********'Overcoming the Past' **********Many of the suggestions put forth by Mr. Rubio for the B.B.V. focus on how the bank should prepare for the future, starting, as he put it, with ''overcoming the past.'' **********''The only way the bank can begin a new era of progress is to heal the wounds, which requires everyone to forget what has happened these recent weeks,''he said. **********One of his ideas for streamlining the bank's operations involved setting an age limit of 70 years for board members. This was accepted on Saturday, along with his suggestion that 10 board members be immediately retired and replaced by only 5 members. **********The B.B.V., which still has its roots in the Basque country thanks to tradition and shareholders, now operates throughout Spain and increasingly elsewhere in Europe. Its pretax profits during the first six months of 1989 were around $590 million, although they may have been hurt during the rest of the year by a Government-imposed credit squeeze.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/03/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East;   Hungary and Soviets See Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/03/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East;   Hungary and Soviets See Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/03/world.body_text: **********After months of discussions, the Governments of Soviet Union and Hungary said today they had agreed to draft an accord quickly on a full withdrawal of Soviet troops. **********The plan was announced after two days of talks between a delegation led by a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Ivan Aboimov, and Hungarian officials led by Ferenc Somogyi, Secretary of State at the Foreign Ministry. **********The two sides said that Soviet troops would be withdrawn ''on the basis of an intergovernmental agreement to be concluded within the shortest possible time.'' A timetable has not been set, but Hungarian officials said they wanted all Soviet forces to be removed this year or in 1991 at the latest. **********An estimated 50,000 Soviet troops are stationed in Hungary. The Soviet military has maintained a constant presence there since World War II that is usually remembered for the suppression of a 1956 uprising. About 10,000 Soviet soldiers left Hungary under a partial withdrawal last year. **********An article on Tuesday in Krasnaya Zvezda, the Soviet Defense Ministry's newspaper, asserted that Hungary was demanding too rapid a withdrawal. Warning of a potential disruption in military security, it said that a military threat in Europe gave Soviet troops sufficient reason to remain. **********The Hungarian Foreign Minister, Gyula Horn, said in an interview published today in the Socialist newspaper Nepszabadsag that such views were ''one-sided'' and ignored reality. **********Mr. Horn also welcomed a proposal by President Bush for deep cuts in Soviet and American forces in Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;  $202 Million Issue By Port Authority
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/busin.body_text: **********A $202.07 million tax-exempt debt offering by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on behalf of Continental Airlines and Eastern Airlines for a new passenger building at La Guardia airport was well received and was immediately oversubscribed, the underwriters, led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said. **********The special project bonds, which are not rated by Moody's Investors Service or the Standard & Poor's Corporation, include $51.18 million in securities due 2006 that are priced to yield 9.375 percent, $30 million in securities due 2010 priced to yield 9.50 percent, and $120.9 million in securities due 2015 at a priced to yield 9.625 percent. Underwriters said the bonds were subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax for certain investors. **********The project, primarily for Continental, is expected to be completed in early 1992.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/05/busin.main_headline: Mergers Up In Europe as Barriers Fall
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/05/busin.print_headline: Mergers Up In Europe as Barriers Fall
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/05/busin.body_text: **********The lure, and the fear, of 1992 are continuing to drive the pace of mergers and acquisitions in Europe, and more and more they are opening doors that had been closed in the past. **********In the first quarter of this year, 357 European companies were acquired by concerns from Europe, the United States or Japan, according to data released this week by Translink's European Deal Review, an organization that monitors such activity. The total value of the deals in which a price was reported was $15.4 billion. The value of 55 percent of the deals was not reported. **********The number of deals was just below the record of 371 in the third quarter of last year but above the quarterly average of 317 for all of 1989. The total value was below the third quarter's $21.7 billion but above the other three quarters, Translink's said. **********American Acquisitions Slowed **********While European companies were very active, acquisitions by American concerns slowed significantly, Translink's reported. **********In the first quarter, American companies were involved in 37 deals, with a total reported value of $747.8 million. This compares with 53 deals, with a reported value of $4.2 billion, in the fourth quarter of 1989 and a total of 182 deals, with a reported value of $15.2 billion, in all of 1989. **********The continued high level of acquisitions seems to reflect that the barriers to acquisitions, within the 12-nation European Community and elsewhere, are coming down. The pressure to build ties is forcing an easing of obstacles to takeovers in countries like France and Sweden that have long been hostile to such purchases. **********The trend demonstrates that business and economic decisions have moved ahead of politicial or regulatory ones. That is comparable to what happened in the United States in the 1970's as financial markets left regulators breathlessly trying to catch up with their innovations. **********''Everyone is bringing down their defenses so that they can buy in the European Community,'' said Mark Dixon, the editor of Translink's European Deal Review. This easing, he said, should make more acquisitions possible and should make more logical business alliances easier. **********France and Sweden Rank High **********France, a member of the European Community, and Sweden, which is not, were No. 1 and No. 3, respectively, in net acquisitions last year. This means that French and Swedish companies bought much more abroad than foreign companies bought in France and Sweden. France's surplus was $6.1 billion and Sweden's was $1.3 billion. The No. 2 position was held by West Germany. **********But in the first quarter of the year, France and Sweden were the top targets for acquisitions. In part, this reflects the cross-ownership merger between Volvo A.B. of Sweden and Renault S.A. of France. **********French and Swedish companies were also the targets of other deals. France was No. 1 in the number of deals, with 53. Sweden, with 12, tied for ninth with Norway. But that is already more than a third of last year's total acquisitions by foreigners in Sweden. **********In another measure of the change in positions, the value of the companies that outsiders bought in France equaled 82 percent of acquisitions by French companies abroad, compared with 43 percent in all of 1989. In Sweden, the ratio rose to 72 percent in the first quarter, from 15 percent in 1989. **********Active Outside Home Nations **********Even with this new spurt of foreign acquisitions in France and Sweden, the two were also first in acquisitions abroad in the first quarter, again helped by the the Volvo-Renault deal. Along with Britain, France and Sweden are spending much more to acquire foreign companies than to buy at home. **********For Sweden, it seems the economic ties to the European Community will be well established before the politicial decision is made over whether to apply for membership in the community. But the mood in Sweden -and the economic moves already made - seem to narrow the question to when will Sweden apply, not whether it will do so. **********The slowing pace of acquisitions by American companies in the first quarter does reflect a change in attitude about the need to get a foothold in Europe, Mr. Dixon said, describing it as a natural slowing after the activity last year. And he notes that while the deals declined, dropping the United States to fifth in the first quarter from first in 1989, many companies making acquistions were medium sized. **********These acquisitions, Mr. Dixon contends, reflect a growing and broader commitment to a role in Europe that goes beyond what huge multinational companies like the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation have already done. **********McGraw-Hill Moves Quickly **********One American company that bought in Europe, and elsewhere, in the first quarter was McGraw-Hill Inc., whose Standard & Poor's Ratings Group bought financial ratings services in Britain, France, Sweden and Australia. **********Standard & Poor's wants a foothold in Europe and Australia to take advantage of the growing international market, its president, Leo O'Neill, said. Capital markets outside the United States are growing faster than in the country, and so is the ratings business, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/23/busin.main_headline: Du Pont to Construct Plants For Ozone-Safe Refrigerant
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/23/busin.print_headline: Du Pont to Construct Plants For Ozone-Safe Refrigerant
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/23/busin.body_text: **********Du Pont announced yesterday that it would design four plants to produce refrigeration chemicals that do not endanger the earth's ozone layer, but said it was continuing to delay a commitment to produce another family of compounds that would have a different use. **********The company said the decision to build the plants put it among the leaders in the production of environmentally friendly refrigerants. ''These commercial facilities would be among the first to produce world-scale quantities of non-ozone depleting alternatives,'' said Joseph P. Glas, director of the Freon Products division of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. Freon is Du Pont's trade name for current refrigeration compounds. **********Both groups of chemicals are intended to replace the most widely used refrigerants, known as chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's. The chlorine in CFC's that escapes to the atmosphere has been identified by scientists as the principal agent responsible for the thinning of the ozone layer. **********Because the ozone shields the earth from harmful solar rays that can cause skin cancer and disrupt the food chain, most industrial nations have agreed to phase out the use of the CFC's by 2000. More than two billion pounds of the chemicals are used annually worldwide, a third of them in the United States. They are also used in insulation and as cleaning agents in electronics. **********The company said the new plants would produce four types of hydrofluorocarbons, or HFC's, for use in automotive air-conditioners, home refrigerators and commercial refrigeration equipment.
