The new compounds contain no chlorine and are therefore not expected to pose a threat to the ozone layer. **********When they become operational, between 1992 and 1995, the plants will have the capacity to produce 140 million pounds of refrigerants annually, which the company said ''could supply most worldwide refrigeration needs through the end of the century.'' **********The plants will be in Corpus Christi, Tex.; Louisville, Ky; Dordrecht, the Netherlands, and Chiba, Japan. **********Du Pont said it was holding back on plans to expand production of a third group of chemicals, known as hydrochlorofluorocarbons, pending passage of the revised Clean Air Act. HCFC's, as they are known, have been scheduled to replace CFC's in the roughly 75 percent of applications where HFC's are not suitable. **********Among the CFC applications where HFC's will not work are as refrigerants in large industrial chilling equipment and in the production of insulating foams, Du Pont officials said. **********HCFC's have much less ozone-depleting potential than CFC's, but they do contain chlorine. As a result, some environmental advocates have called for their use to be phased out soon after CFC's are eliminated in the next century. Big producers like Du Pont have said the HCFC ban should not take effect until 2030, to allow it and makers of equipment using the chemicals to recoup their investments in equipment to make and use the compounds. **********But an amendment to the Senate version of the Clean Air Act revision would ban their use by 2015. Mr. Glas said large chilling units that cool office buildings and hospitals have an economic life of up to 40 years. Anyone buying equipment designed for HCFC's could face a shortage of refrigerant long before the equipment was scheduled to be retired. **********Chemical industry executives have argued that the use of HCFC's is necessary for a quick phasing out of CFC's. And they have warned that if HCFC's are banned too soon, developing countries may continue to use the more dangerous CFC's, to the detriment of the ozone layer, until environmentally benign alternatives are found. **********Redesign Necessary **********Phasing out CFC's means redesigning all equipment that uses them as a refrigerant fluid. None of the proposed alternatives can be used in machines designed for CFC's. **********Mr. Glas said Du Pont, which is one of the world's largest producers of CFC's, is working with manufacturers to assure that substitute fluids deliver adequate performance. He said domestic automobiles with non-CFC air-conditioners would probably be available toward the end of next year. The substitute would be an HFC compound designated HFC-134a. **********Du Pont said that by the end of the year it will have invested $240 million in research and capital spending on CFC replacements. It said total expenditures by the end of the century could total more than $1 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/05/busin.main_headline: World Markets;   The Unsettling Iraq Factor
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/05/busin.print_headline: World Markets;   The Unsettling Iraq Factor
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/05/busin.body_text: **********SADDAM HUSSEIN, the President of Iraq, bet that Kuwait was vulnerable and it was. So were most of the world's markets, which tumbled dramatically after Iraq's invasion of the emirate last week as the outlook clouded for oil prices, inflation, economic growth and the balance of power in the Middle East. . **********The markets had been under stress before the invasion. Interest rates around the world are high. Many economies are slowing or are growing more slowly than anticipated. Earnings reports are coming in lower than expected - and the prospect is for less to come. **********The Amercan stock market was weakening and Japan's was already reeling. West Germany's market was worried by higher interest rates and, again, the cost of German unification. Italy has problems with its coalition government. Britain is near a recession. **********Hong Kong, which had been reaching new heights regularly, was stunned by the invasion, which sent the Hang Seng index tumbling by 111.69 points or 3.4 percent. Oil-rich Norway, whose all-share index had been propelled to new highs four days last week by rising oil prices and the expectation that they would rise further after the invasion, fell 1.6 percent Friday under the weight of inflationary fears. **********''We've been skittish on these markets anyway,'' said Madhav Dhar, global strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. ''This was not a healthy environment. We expected markets to roll off anyway. And this will aggravate that.'' **********Cliche though it is, the only certainity now is uncertainity and it alone is enough to roil stock markets. The unknown - what the Iraqi leader might do next - kept traders and analysts close to their computer screens Friday and responding - by buying dollars as a safe haven or dumping stocks because of inflationary and interest rate fears - to bulletins like ''State Department says Iraqi troops within six miles of Saudi border'' or ''Shevardnadze says U.S.S.R. 'has been assured' Iraq to pull out soon.'' **********But about as fast as the Iraqi forces moved into Kuwait City, economists and analysts around the world were examining the longer-term impact, pushing numbers through their black boxes and churning out estimates of the inflationary, interest rate and economic growth consequences both of the invasion and of higher oil prices. These scenarios, none of them very good, will be digested by investors this week and should add to the downward pressure on markets. **********Kieth Skeoch, chief economist at James Capel & Company in London, estimates that with a $25 per barrel price for oil, inflation in the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada could be five-tenths of 1 percentage point higher in the next year. And economic growth could be cut by as much as four-tenths of 1 percentage point from what it might have been. For the United States and Britain, whose economies could be near the brink of a recession already, this not comforting. **********Guy Rigdon, director of strategy at UBS Phillips & Drew in London, said he expected interest rates in Europe will be pushed up about half of a percentage point. And in Japan, he said, the oil price rise (he is also assuming $25 a barrel) will insure that the Bank of Japan will raise the official discount rate, now 5.25 percent, and keep interest rates higher longer. **********He estimates that, based on this rise in interest rates, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index, which fell 4.4 percent last week to close at 29,515.76, should drop below 28,000, the low it reached during the market collapse in the first quarter of the year. In Europe, he expects that markets could fall 10 percent to 20 percent from where they were. **********Last week, West Germany was down 4.1 percent; Britain, whose decline was somewhat offset by the positive effect of higher oil prices on its North Sea oil production, fell 2.0 percent; France, 4.9 percent, Spain, 5.5 percent, and Italy, 4.7 percent. **********Merrill Lynch, according to its chief international equity strategist, Thomas Robinson, has already changed its investment levels in several markets, cutting them in Japan and the United states and raising them in the few countries that will beneift from higher oil prices, like Norway, or are not as dependent on oil, like Switzerland.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/busin.body_text: **********Czechoslovakia signed a trade and economic cooperation accord today with the European Community that its Prime Minister called an important step toward full membership by the year 2000. **********The agreement replaces a commercial accord signed in December 1988 and will give Czechoslovakia better access to markets in the 12-nation alliance, officials said. **********The Czechoslovak Prime **********Minister, Marian Calfa, said at a meeting of the community nations that the pact demonstrated his country's commitment to democracy and a market economy. **********Separately, the community endorsed extending a 24-nation Western aid plan for Poland and Hungary to five other countries: Bulgaria, East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Romania and Yugoslavia. **********The community's two-way trade with Czechoslovakia now totals about $2.4 billion a year. **********The new 10-year accord covers trade in industrial and agricultural goods and will remove quantitative trade restrictions. **********The agreement is the fourth the community has signed with an East European country after Poland, Hungary and the Soviet Union. The community expects to sign similar accords with Bulgaria and East Germany on Tuesday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/21/busin.main_headline: Patents;   A Method to Improve Flowering of Fruit Trees
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/21/busin.print_headline: Patents;   A Method to Improve Flowering of Fruit Trees
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/21/busin.body_text: **********A team of Canadian and Australian agricultural researchers has patented a method for helping fruit trees bear flowers more consistently. **********Some trees tend to produce a glut of fruit one year and little the next, an irregularity, known as ''biennial bearing.'' To prevent it, the patent says, fruit growers should coat leaves of the tree in late spring of the first year with compounds known as gibberellins, a class of substances produced by a fungus. They are known to promote the growth of plant shoots. **********Patent 4,941,908 was issued to Richard P. Pharis, a researcher at the University of Calgary in Alberta; Norman E. Looney, a researcher at the Agricultural Canada Research Station in British Columbia, and Lewis N. Mander, a researcher at Australia National University in Canberra.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/world.main_headline: A CONSPIRACY LINK IN PRIESTS' KILLING
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/world.print_headline: A CONSPIRACY LINK IN PRIESTS' KILLING
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/world.body_text: **********A United States Special Service officer told the F.B.I. in an affidavit he later retracted that he had prior knowledge of plans to kill six Jesuit priests but made no effort to stop them. **********The American psychological operations specialist, Maj. Eric Buckland, testified that the top Salvadoran military commander, Col. Rene Emilio Ponce, knew of the army's plans to kill the priests at least 10 days before the slayings last Nov. 16 and ordered Lieut. Col. Carlos Aviles to try to stop them. **********"They want to handle it the old way by killing some of the priests," Major Buckland testified he was told by Colonel Aviles after a meeting with a leader of the plot, Col. Guillermo Benavides. "Aviles told me that Benavides was old school and was still the 'hammer.' And Aviles added that there was some talk about death squads which were run out of the military school." Solid Link to Conspiracy **********Though it was retracted, Major Buckland's testimony is the most direct evidence to emerge so far linking the killings to a broader armed forces conspiracy. The affidavits cast doubts on continuing assertions by American and Salvadoran officials that the Jesuits were killed on orders from a single commander who cracked in battle. **********But Colonels Aviles and Ponce, the armed forces' chief of staff when the killings occurred, denied the allegations on Monday and dismissed Major Buckland as "emotionally unstable." **********"It's the biggest lie I've ever heard," said Colonel Ponce, now the Defense Minister. "It's completely false." **********The officers said that a demonstrable error discredited the affidavits. The documents say that Colonels Aviles and Benavides met here "approximately 10 days prior to the killings." But Colonel Aviles was in New Orleans at that time. In another affidavit, however, Major Buckland says the meeting "probably occurred in late October." **********A week after testifying he had advance knowledge of the plot, Major Buckland recanted. "The statements I made all seemed real to me at the time, and I was convinced I had not thought of them earlier because I had suppressed them," he said. "Upon reflection of those statements, I know that they are not true." 'Indications of Deception' **********But polygraphers for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said that while one lie-detector test taken by Major Buckland was "inconclusive," another found signs that his original assertion was true. When he denied having prior knowledge, "there were indications of deception," the examiner, Special Agent Paul Cully, said. But there were also signs that he made up information. **********In his report, Mr. Cully said Major Buckland admitted he had advance knowledge of the plot. "Major Buckland became aware of this information several weeks before the Jesuits were murdered," Mr. Cully wrote. "He was also advised on the afternoon of Nov. 16 that the operation would take place." **********Major Buckland said he decided against advising his superiors before the killings because "the U.S. would mishandle the situation," the agent added. American officials, who originally sought to blame leftist guerrillas for the killings, say the Major did not inform them about the army's involvement until six weeks after the murders. Impediment to Discussions **********Judicial authorities say the contradictions in the affidavits make them pratically useless in court. But Major Buckland's charges are likely to impede negotiations between the Government and the rebels and to strengthen Congressional resolve to slash American military aid, which pays for the entire Salvadoran military budget except salaries. **********"If they're still killing priests after 10 years of involvement, you have to ask if the U.S. should still be here," an American diplomat said recently. **********The affidavits, whose sketchy details have been leaked in recent days, have already infuriated leading members of Congress. They charge that witholding the testimony demonstrates that the State Department has failed to cooperate with the investigation fully, but stopped short of accusing the Bush Administration of participating in an effort to obstruct justice. **********Administration officials said the affidavits were withheld because they are unreliable. They said that United States officials were at first convinced that it would be more fruitful to pursue other leads. Major Buckland's testimony, they added, seemed irrelevant once Colonel Benavides was charged. **********Salvadoran officials say they resent the failure to credit the army for cooperating. They say its help was critical to the arrest of Colonel Benavides, the highest-ranking officer charged with a human rights abuse, and a praiseworthy step toward ending the military's tradition of immunity in rights cases. 'I Did It' **********Major Buckland also testified that Colonel Aviles told him in mid-December that Colonel Benavides had admitted his role in the killings to the officer in charge of a special commission investigating them. **********"I did it; what can you do to help me?" Colonel Aviles quotes Colonel Benavides as saying, according to the affidavits. But Colonel Benavides was not arrested until almost a month later. **********Major Buckland said that a week later, he asked Colonel Aviles who else knew about the plot to kill the Jesuits. Colonel Aviles said he wasn't sure. **********"Does Colonel Ponce know yet?" Major Buckland said he pressed. **********"I don't know," he said Colonel Aviles responded. "I don't know who knows. What if a higher-up ordered this thing?"

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/04/busin.body_text: **********A group led by Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor who is proposing to spin off the steel holdings of the USX Corporation, said yesterday that such a separation would yield about $48 a share for stockholders. **********Pittsburgh-based USX, the nation's largest steelmaker, has vast energy holdings. A nonbinding vote is scheduled for the company's annual meeting on May 7. USX's management called the proposal unnecessary and unwise. **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the company's stock rose $1.50, to $37.125.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/08/world.main_headline: In Turkey, Iraqi Deserters Tell of Brutality in Kuwait
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/08/world.print_headline: STANDOFF IN THE GULF; In Turkey, Iraqi Deserters Tell of Brutality in Kuwait
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/08/world.body_text: **********For a month now, 130 Iraqi Army deserters and civilian refugees have been holed up in this eastern Turkish city, where they tell of having left behind troops demoralized by meager food rations and terrorized by threats of hanging. **********Some who were sent to Kuwait in the early days of the Iraqi invasion say they saw summary hangings of soldiers and the rape of young women in the streets. A few admit that they themselves had joined in the plunder of gold and cash from Kuwaiti houses, but insist that they had no choice but to take part. **********To a man, they say that if war does break out in the Persian Gulf, there will be an exodus of deserting Iraqi soldiers and frightened civilians into neighboring countries. Like this group, hundreds of other Iraqis are reported to have already fled into Saudi Arabia, and some others to have trickled into Syria and Iran. **********"More than half a million would come now if the way was easy," a private said. "But it is dangerous. If they catch us, they hang us."  Most From Minority Groups **********Nearly all the refugees here belong to minority groups in northern Iraq that are not disposed, even in good times, to kind thoughts of President Saddam Hussein. **********But they say their escape into Turkey across the rugged, mountainous border was spurred not by deep-rooted ethnic animosities but rather by Mr. Hussein's bellicosity. **********"Our problem is Saddam," said an enlisted man from the northern town of Erbil, who like others declined to give his name out of fear of possible reprisals against family members back home. "In Iraq, the war is never over." **********They are mostly a mixture of ethnic Turks, Kurds and half a dozen Christians, held under guard at a spare hotel in this remote eastern city until the Turkish authorities can figure out what to do with them. Only five are Arab Muslims. **********Most are single young men who deserted from the Iraqi Army, but a few managed to bring their families along. There are seven children in the group, including a baby born to a Kurdish couple during their flight. They named the child Hakkari, after a border town 80 miles south of here that was their first way station in Turkey.  A Hard, Risky Journey **********For all, it was an arduous, risky journey out of Iraq, made individually or in small groups. **********A 25-year-old enlisted man said he had paid 1,500 Iraqi dinars to a Kurdish guide to help him through mountains that straddle the paths across the border. At the official exchange rate, that is equivalent to $4,500, although black-market prices would reduce that figure considerably. **********The man said he had been assigned to combat duty in Kuwait, and decided to desert after being allowed to return home to northern Iraq to obtain food. Like most of the others, he left with only the clothes that he wore, resting by day and walking after dark on his three-day journey into Turkey. **********A month ago -- roughly eight weeks after the first of them left their country -- the Iraqis were moved to the Bayram Hotel in Van. As the weeks pass the new arrivals complain that they feel less like refugees than prisoners.  Willingness to Talk Fades **********Three weeks ago, the Turkish Government arranged for them to meet with a group of journalists, and they talked willingly about brutalities they had witnessed in Kuwait and about the fading supplies of food and water on which they said Iraqi soldiers subsist. One said at the time that officers in his company had raped 20 women, then had them shot. Another said Iraqi soldiers had looted a hospital of medicine and equipment, including an incubator. **********But they said atrocities in Kuwait were concerns for Americans. What they want to know is when they can leave for preferred destinations in the United States, Canada and Western Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/18/busin.body_text: **********Zenith Electronics and A.T.& T. said today that they were jointly developing an all-digital high-definition television system. It replaces Zenith's proposed Spectrum Compatible system, a high-definition technology that is partly digital, and will be one of six competing systems evaluated by the Federal Communications Commission. The tests will begin in April and extend through the fall. **********The Zenith Electronics Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are the third group to announce an all-digital system, which would broadcast entirely in the 1's and 0's of computer code. Such a system could offer improved reception, and give television sets much of the capability of computers to store, retrieve and manipulate images. It could also cost less because the memory requirements would be lower. **********Although broadcast experts have said that fully digital television could not be developed in time to compete in the race for a standard for the technology, known as HDTV, the General Instruments Corporation announced its digital system in June, followed by a consortium formed by NBC, Thomson S.A. of France, Philips N.V. of the Netherlands and the David Sarnoff Research Center in Princeton, N.J.  Preparing for the Test **********"The powerful combination of Zenith's and A.T.& T.'s digital high-definition technologies will mean a terrestrial broadcast HDTV system for the U.S. that can outperform all others in the world," Wayne C. Luplow, Zenith's executive director of advanced research and development, said in a statement. "We're moving ahead full force on the digital system and, together, are preparing for the scheduled F.C.C. test period next fall." **********Zenith is responsible for the system definition and transmission technology, AT&T Bell Laboratories for the design and implementation of a new video compression system, and AT&T Microelectronics for the semiconductor technology. Digital television signals must be "compressed" to fit within the bandwidth of a normal TV channel. Simulcast HDTV would be broadcast on currently unusable channels now left vacant because of interference. **********While both video compression and the prevention of interference are more challenging in a digital system than in analog, the advantages of the digital format are believed to outweigh the difficulties. The system proposed by Zenith and A.T.& T. incorporates a new software algorithm to accomplish the necessary data compression and digital filtering technology to prevent high-powered conventional signals from interfering with the HDTV channel.  Lower Cost Expected **********The system that Zenith and A.T.& T. are announcing "is better than most of the other proposals in terms of image quality," said James I. Magid, an analyst with Needham & Company in New York. In addition, "although they don't tell you in the release that they will be cheaper, the cost should be about a tenth of the Japanese system," he said. HDTV sets went on sale in Japan earlier this month for $34,000 each. **********A number of technology analysts have suggested for some time that embracing an all-digital format would be one way for the United States to overcome the lead taken by Japan in the HDTV race. To date, the Japanese have not shown a digital system. One major advantage of a digital system is that there would be no loss in signal quality through the broadcast process. **********"At the receiver end, so long as you had a certain level of signal, what you would see on the screen would be in effect a clone, a perfect replica of what came out of the studio," said Alex D. Felker, a technology and engineering consultant with the Washington-based firm of Wiley, Rein & Fielding. The disadvantage is that should the signal fall below a certain level, there would be no picture at all, not just a deterioration of the image as with conventional sets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/busin.main_headline: Profits at Anheuser-Busch Rise by 2.1% in Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/busin.print_headline: Profits at Anheuser-Busch Rise by 2.1% in Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/busin.body_text: **********The Anheuser-Busch Companies, the country's largest brewer, said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 2.1 percent and that its profit for the year was up 7.2 percent. **********The quarter's results confirmed that Busch's more aggressive price-cutting policy, announced in October, hurt earnings. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, the company earned $128.1 million, or 45 cents a share, compared with $125.5 million, or 44 cents a share, a year earlier. **********Sales in the fourth quarter grew 5.5 percent, to $2.31 billion, from $2.19 billion a year ago. **********For the full year, profit rose to $767.2 million, or $2.68 a share, from $715.9 million, or $2.45 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 6.3 percent, to $9.48 billion from $8.92 billion. **********Effect of Pricing Policy **********Last October, in announcing a 5 percent earnings gain for the third quarter over the similar period a year earlier, to $238.3 million, Busch said it would match any price cuts by rival brewers instead of trying to raise prices. The policy, it said, would hurt earnings in the fourth quarter and in 1990 but would help build Busch's already dominant market share. **********''They just wanted to scare the other guys,'' said William Leach, an analyst at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, referring to principal Busch rivals, the Miller Brewing Company and the Adolph Coors Company. **********Analysts said the net effect of Busch's policy for the industry was to restrain prices, rather than actually cut them. Earlier this month, Busch announced its regular annual price increase, about 3 percent, which is equal to its increases in 1989 and 1988. But Busch made it known, analysts said, that it would offer discounts of 1 percent to 2 percent. That would add less than a dime to the $3.30 wholesale price for a six-pack of beer. **********Market Share Edges Up **********Busch said yesterday that it had increased market share by one percentage point, to 42.1 percent, for the year. It reiterated its goal of reaching 50 percent within the next five years. **********In the fourth quarter, the number of barrels of Busch beer sold - which includes Budweiser and Michelob -rose 1.1 percent, to 18.3 million, from 18.1 million the year before. For the year, barrels sold rose 2.8 percent, to 80.7 million from 78.5 million. **********Mr. Leach, the analyst, said the fourth-quarter performance was in line with analysts' expectations. While Busch is a well-run company that diversified into other operations like amusement parks, he said, it is still dependent on one business and essentially one brand, Budweiser. ''Anheuser-Busch is the world's biggest one-product company,'' he said. **********In 1988, beer accounted for 77 percent of its sales and 92 percent of its pretax operating income. Busch does not break out results for particular brands. **********Per-Capita Consumption Off **********Industry sales have been flat since 1986; per-capita consumption is down in the United States over the last 10 years, mainly because of health concerns over alcohol and a trend toward lighter beverages, such as bottled water. Brewers sold about 182 million barrels last year, about the same as the year before. Americans drank about 23 gallons of beer in 1989, compared with 26 gallons a decade before. **********Despite being the largest company in the beer business, Busch does not enjoy the profit advantages of, say, tobacco companies. Unlike makers of cigarettes, which have also generated health concerns and are showing declining sales, brewers cannot as easily raise profit margins through manufacturing efficiencies or regular price increases. Brewers are already quite efficient and their customers often balk at raising prices. Nonetheless, Busch is spending more than $1 billion on plant modernization to become more efficient. **********Busch's share price rose $1 yesterday, to $37.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/world.main_headline: Israeli Court Delays a Plan For V.O.A. Station in Desert
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/world.print_headline: Israeli Court Delays a Plan For V.O.A. Station in Desert
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/world.body_text: **********The Supreme Court of Israel issued a temporary injunction today against construction of a Voice of America relay station in a southern desert. **********The injunction was requested by the Nature Preservation Society, which contends that the station could interfere with bird migration routes and cause environmental damage. **********The National Planning Board initially voted that construction of the project should be delayed for two years to allow for a study of bird migration. **********But the board reversed itself last month after an appeal by the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/14/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East;   New Soviet Threat 'Disturbing' to Bush
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/14/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East;   New Soviet Threat 'Disturbing' to Bush
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/14/world.body_text: **********Speaking with unusual force about the Lithuanian crisis, President Bush said today that he and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain found reports of a Kremlin ultimatum to the Baltic republic ''deeply disturbing.'' Mr. Bush said imposition of economic sanctions against Lithuania would violate Moscow's stated policy of seeking to resolve the stalemate over Lithuania's desire for independence without force. **********''Now is no time for escalation; it's time for talks,'' Mr. Bush said, speaking for himself and for Mrs. Thatcher at a news conference here. **********Mrs. Thatcher added: ''We've come a long way in relations between the Soviet Union and the free world. We wish that improvement to continue, but it could not continue if the Soviet Union were to resolve this by force.'' **********Neither the President nor Mrs. Thatcher would say what they would or could do if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev carried out a threat to suspend shipments of vital supplies, possibly including oil and natural gas, to Lithuania if certain laws are not rescinded in two days. The two leaders also tried to couch their remarks as diplomatically as possible. **********Still, their statements after talks represented a marked change by Mr. Bush, who has carefully avoided commenting on developments in the Soviet Union in recent weeks. Mrs. Thatcher has also been restrained in her public statements about Lithuania, restricting herself to calls for peaceful dialogue that she and Mr. Bush repeated today. **********The two leaders said they were basing their remarks on a news report about Mr. Gorbachev's threat and declined to go into much detail on the development. **********Mr. Bush said the two had learned of the ultimatum only moments before their news conference began and added that their Governments had not yet independently confirmed the details. But United States officials said the White House had in fact learned of it 90 minutes earlier and that Mr. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher had been handed the dispatch about 30 minutes before they emerged from their private conversations to take questions. **********The fact that the intensely cautious Mr. Bush, acting for himself and Mrs. Thatcher, chose to bring up the news report at the outset of the news conference, before they were asked about it, illuminated the alarm with which the two leaders viewed the Kremlin's ultimatum more than their words did. **********On Germany and NATO **********Mr. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher said the Lithuanian question, as well as broader issues of German unification and reorganization of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, occupied much of their four hours of talks at the cream-colored stucco colonial palace that is Hamilton's Government House. **********Since the news report from Moscow was given to the two leaders toward the end of the talks, it was not clear how much time they could have devoted to discussing Mr. Gorbachev's demand that Lithuania rescind a series of laws its Parliament has passed since the declaration of independence. **********''Obviously, there has been no time to look into this matter in detail or determine all the facts,'' Mr. Bush said. ''But we have been calling on Moscow publicly and privately for avoiding escalatory measures in favor of dialogue.'' **********Mrs. Thatcher said that she and Mr. Bush had agreed in advance on what he would say about Mr. Gorbachev's threat. **********Reluctant at First **********At first, Mr. Bush was reluctant to characterize the ultimatum or say whether it violated Mr. Gorbachev's promises not to use force to keep Lithuania within the Soviet Union. But he later said: ''Am I concerned about the report? If it proves to be accurate, the answer is yes, because it goes against the policy of dialogue and a no-coercion dialogue that will result in peaceful evolution of democracy and self-determination. **********''So I'm concerned about the report. I'm concerned about the timing. But I just don't want to comment any further.'' **********Mrs. Thatcher bristled when asked about reports that Mr. Gorbachev had told a delegation of United States senators in Moscow this week that he did not want ''lectures'' from the West on how to handle Lithuania. **********''We're just not lecturing anyone, but we're entitled to express a view,'' she said. **********The Prime Minister added: ''We've frequently expressed it. This is not a problem that should be solved by force and which cannot be solved by force. It therefore must be solved by discussion. We had a duty to say what we think. We still think that way and we still think that is the only way to go.'' **********Mr. Bush has said the use of force in Lithuania would set back Soviet-American relations at a time when arms control and other issues appearing to be moving forward relatively smoothly. A major dispute in the relationship could also jeopardize the summit meeting planned in the United States for May 30 to June 3.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/busin.body_text: **********Amid a mixture of glitz and uncertainty, Comdex/Fall, the world's largest annual exposition of computer products, opens here Monday for a weeklong trade show expected to attract 100,000 buyers and sellers, nearly a fifth from overseas. **********The glitz, impressive even by the standards of this neon-washed desert city, is provided by 1,800 companies, from the International Business Machines Corporation to tiny start-ups hoping for a big break. The First Interface Group of Needham, Mass., which produces the Comdex shows, said the exhibitors will fill more than a million square feet of display space and will demonstrate an unusually large number of new products. **********The uncertainty arises from how well those new products will sell if the economy falters, as many people here expect.  'Like Christmas Shopping' **********"From a product standpoint, this is the most interesting and exciting Comdex in several years," said Lissa Morgenthaler, senior analyst for the California Technology Stock Letter in San Francisco. "It's a little like Christmas shopping for me, but the companies will be feeling a fair amount of trepidation." **********"Excitement isn't always what a company wants," she noted. "Certainty is sometimes better." **********Among the new products are miniature portable computers that match the power of desktop PC's, software applications designed to take advantage of the Microsoft Corporation's DOS-Windows operating system, storage devices that can hold billions of characters of data, and powerful Unix-based work stations, which will compete with both conventional PC's and more costly minicomputers and mainframes. **********Dealers at the show will be wrestling with fundamental changes in the way businesses now shop for PC's. As small computers become more powerful and complex, and as networked PC's become more important, the traditional retail channels are being squeezed by specialized dealers and warehouse-style discounters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/23/busin.main_headline: Intergroup to Consider Sale of Foxmeyer Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Intergroup to Consider Sale of Foxmeyer Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/23/busin.body_text: **********National Intergroup Inc. said today that it would ''entertain and evaluate proposals'' for the sale of its Foxmeyer Corporation drug distribution subsidiary. National Intergroup said several potential buyers had indicated they were interested in the unit. **********The announcement represents a shift by National Intergroup, which had said earlier that it would not sell Foxmeyer. **********Shares of National Intergroup jumped $1.50 on the announcement, closing at $16.125 on the New York Stock Exchange. Foxmeyer is the nation's fourth-largest distributor of pharmaceuticals and health and beauty products, with $3 billion in sales. National Intergroup, a drug and metal company based in Pittsburgh, acquired Foxmeyer in 1986 for $600 million. **********Today's announcement is the cornerstone of an agreement between National Intergroup and Centaur Partners L.P., a New York investment partnership, which earlier this month won three seats on National Intergroup's board in a proxy battle. **********A central issue in that fight was whether to sell Foxmeyer. Centaur advocated selling all of National Intergroup's assets, including Foxmeyer, and distributing the proceeds to shareholders. **********Before today's announcement, National Intergroup had been opposed to selling Foxmeyer and had advocated a plan to sell all of its nondrug distribution assets, change its name to Foxmeyer and move its headquarters to Dallas, where the Foxmeyer unit is based. **********Analysts said a sale of Foxmeyer, in essence a move to liquidate National Intergroup, would mean National Intergroup's stock would be worth from $25 to $28 a share. Most of its other assets are metal companies. **********But Gregory Drahuschak, an analyst with Butcher & Singer in Pittsburgh, said the latest move meant that National Intergroup would study offers but was not committed to sell Foxmeyer. ''They are not hanging a for-sale sign from the door,'' Mr. Drahuschak said. **********With the announcement, National Intergroup, formerly called National Steel, ended all litigation resulting from its proxy battle with Centaur. Under the agreement, National Intergroup will pay Centaur $4.2 million. In exchange, Centaur agreed to refrain from seeking further changes in the board until next July. **********National Intergroup also announced that Buck Mickel, the chairman and chief executive of the RSI Corporation, an outdoor-equipment and office-supply distributor, had been named chairman of National Intergroup, replacing Howard M. Love, who had resigned after Centaur won its proxy fight. Mr. Mickel has been a member of National Intergroup's board since 1983.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/10/world.main_headline: Sea Blockade Spurs New Carnage Between the Lebanese Christians
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/10/world.print_headline: Sea Blockade Spurs New Carnage Between the Lebanese Christians
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/10/world.body_text: **********Twelve people were killed today as warring Christian forces fought savage artillery duels today, bringing most of Lebanon's Christian enclave under shellfire in a new flare-up of the four-month Christian conflict, hospital officials said. **********Nineteen people were wounded in eight hours of bombardment of territory from East Beirut to the mountain peaks in the Christian heartland 18 miles to the northeast, the hospital officials said. **********Forty-five people have been killed in the last three days. More than 1,000 people have died in the warfare between Christian factions, with the number of wounded more than 3,200, and property damage running in the millions of dollars. **********All of the divided Lebanese capital reverberated to the din of exploding howitzer shells, with several slamming into Muslim quarters close to the Green Line that separates West Beirut from Christian East Beirut. **********The new fighting between Lebanese Army troops loyal to the Christian commander, Gen. Michel Aoun, and militiamen led by Samir Geagea came after General Aoun declared the 28-mile Mediterranean coast off the Christian enclave a war zone, and warned that ships sailing there would be attacked ''irrespective of their type or cargo.'' **********His purpose is to blockade militia-run harbors. The restricted zone is between Beirut harbor and Madfun, north of the ancient port of Byblos. **********The blockade was declared in retaliation for a siege the militia imposed against a makeshift sea outlet that General Aoun's forces had established at Antilias, a northern suburb of East Beirut. Lebanese Forces naval craft had twice intercepted ships bound for Antilias and forced them to return to the Mediterranean island of Cyprus. **********Within hours of General Aoun's action, the militia diverted its sea traffic to Byblos. General Aoun's small navy was dispersed when he lost the naval base at Junieh shortly after the inter-Christian warfare resumed at the end of January. **********While Christian areas were battered by shellfire today, Lebanon's President, Elias Hrawi, and Prime Minister Selim al-Hoss drove to the Syrian capital, Damascus, and met for the second time in six months with President Hafez al-Assad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/21/busin.main_headline: The Executive Computer;   A Notebook That Can Provide Desktop Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/21/busin.print_headline: The Executive Computer;   A Notebook That Can Provide Desktop Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/21/busin.body_text: **********Reinforcing its reputation as the personal computer industry's technolog leader, the Compaq Computer Corporation has become the first company to fit the full power of a desktop PC into a laptop small enough to carry in a briefcase. In doing so, Compaq has come close to creating a single computer that can meet the needs of an executive both in the office and on the road. **********The Compaq LTE 386s/20 laptop weighs 7.5 pounds. At 11 inches wide, 8.5 inches deep and 2.2 inches tall, it is roughly the size of a middleweight telephone book. Compaq refers to its new machine as a notebook PC, but it's well beyond the five-pound limit that many people assign to that classification. **********Regardless of the nomenclature, the LTE 386s/20 is a champion in its weight class. It boasts an Intel 386SX microprocessor operating at 20 megahertz, two megabytes of system memory, a high-capacity diskette drive, a choice of 30- or 60-megabyte hard disk drive and VGA graphics. No other portable of comparable size can match its features. Epson America Inc. is the only other computer maker to have announced a 386SX-based notebook machine, and at 5.8 pounds it is closer to being a true notebook. But the Epson uses a slower, 16-megahertz chip, and it will not be available until the end of the year. Compaq officials say their machine is on its way to the stores. **********As with most Compaq computers, the LTE 386s/20 carries a premium price: $6,499 for the 30MB model, $6,999 for the 60MB model. An optional desktop ''docking'' station that surrounds the LTE and adds two expansion slots, two more drive bays and the ability to use standard keyboards and monitors, is $1,499. Compaq officials said the expansion base allows the LTE 386s/20 to be used as the executive's primary desktop machine. For life on the road, the LTE slips out of the docking station. **********Frank J. Michnoff, senior research analyst for Meta Group Inc., a market research company in Westport, Conn., said the pricing was ''somewhat in line'' with his expectations. ''Compaq doesn't want to cannibalize any other existing models,'' Mr. Michnoff said, referring to the larger and less expensive 386SX-based SLT computer. He said that if Compaq follows past custom, it can be expected to reduce the price of the new model after the competition arrives. That competition is already on the horizon. According to Compaq, notebook computers are expected to account for 50 percent of all portable sales by 1992. **********''By the end of the year, I think you'll see a whole roster of similar products, some in the six-pound range,'' said Bruce A. Stephen, director of PC hardware research for the International Data Corporation of Framingham, Mass. ''There will be lighter machines, and products that will cost less.'' **********In return for so much money, the user can expect premium laptop performance. The 386SX processor is not the only feature that sets the new LTE apart from other small laptops, including Compaq's earlier LTE and LTE/286 models. The LTE 386s/20 has a 9-inch, edge-lighted display that offers the full 640 by 480 dots of VGA resolution. In contrast, the other Compaq LTE machines have CGA screens with 640 by 200 resolution, which causes graphics to be flattened; a pie chart, for example, would show up on a CGA screen as an oval instead of as a circle. The new VGA screen can display a perfect pie in up to 16 shades of gray. **********Many small computers achieve their size by jettisoning either the diskette drive or a hard disk. Compaq has consistently vowed not to make that compromise. The standard 3.5-inch, 1.44-megabyte diskette drive serves mainly to move data and applications to and from the hard disk, which does most of the work, and it is much more convenient than using cables or modems. And while other notebook computers offer no more than 20 megabytes of hard disk storage, Compaq's goes well beyound that. The 30- and 60-megabyte choices are rugged, 2.5-inch hard drives made by Conner Peripherals Inc. of San Jose, Calif. **********Another reason Compaq was able to pack so much into such a small package, the company said, was its use of a technology called Regal Flex, which has also been used in cruise missiles and the Stealth fighter. Regal is an acronym for rigid epoxy glass acrylic laminate, which describes the machine's single circuit board. The flex part is just that: once the board is printed and packed with circuitry, it literally folds over on itself, much like a trifold wallet. Besides the savings in space, the design eliminates the need for many of the cables normally found in component electronics. **********Compaq is justifiably proud of its ability to produce the LTE 386s/20 in an 8.5- by 11-inch form. The technical breakthroughs required for such miniaturization are impressive. However, is there really a compelling reason for requiring computers to conform to standards set years ago for business stationery, briefcases or, in the case of the two-pound marvel built by the Poqet Computer Corporation of Sunnyvale, Calif., the inside breast pocket of a man's business suit? **********The drawback - albeit a small one in the case of the overall impressiveness of the LTE 386s/20 - is that Compaq's decision to limit the width of the computer to precisely 11 inches demands that the keyboard be miniaturized. It has all the standard keys, but they are scrunched together. And some keys are oddly placed. Function keys are half-size. Relaxing the standard by as little as half an inch would have allowed Compaq to use full-size, fully spaced keys. **********The optimal keyboard size is determined not by stationery or luggage but by ergonomics - specifically, the size and dexterity of the operator's fingers. We can condense keyboards, but we cannot shrink our fingers. (This writer has learned to type fairly well on the 8.5-inch Poqet keyboard, but the process invariably brings to mind the image of an elephant tap-dancing.) A standard legal pad measuring 8.5 by 14 inches is quite convenient and also fits neatly into a briefcase. As long as the overall heft of the unit could be kept low, a laptop computer that is 14 inches wide, coincidentally the same width as a standard desktop keyboard including a separate numeric or cursor keypad, would not seem to cause a great hardship. After all, if one is going to spend nearly $7,000 for a laptop computer, it seems silly to worry if it will fit in a $100 briefcase. **********Advanced Micro Devices Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., recently condensed a full AT-class motherboard to a single chip; Conner has built a 60MB hard drive the size of a pack of cigarettes; the power supply of the new Compaq machine is the size of a package of chewing gum. At this rate, it may soon be possible to design a ''smart'' standard keyboard that contains a computer and a disk drive, with a flip-up screen. We may be entering the age of the mouse-driven graphical user interface, but the keyboard is still important to many people.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;   TREASURY ISSUES CONTINUE TO GAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/busin.body_text: **********The credit market rally continued yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates dipped in moderately active trading. For the first time this week, dealers said, retail customers were significant buyers of securities. **********Traders said that there likely was further room for improvement. **********''For now the market is under the trance of a budget accord,'' one Government bond trader said, ''and there is nothing of substance to get in the way of that feeling until we get to the employment numbers a week from Friday.'' **********Most market participants remain skeptical that Congress and the Bush Admnistration will come up with a meaningful package to reduce the Federal budget deficit. Nevertheless, President Bush's statement earlier in the week that tax revenue increases will be needed as part of a comprehensive effort to cut the deficit is still ringing in Wall Street's ears. **********Afraid Not to Believe **********''Whether traders believe what Mr. Bush said or not is not the issue,'' said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets. **********''At this juncture, they are afraid not to believe it. There is a clear nervousness about selling securities right now, especially when they are holding meetings in Washington to look for ways to cut the deficit.'' **********Yesterday's price rise began in London, where traders said a Japanese account bought large amounts of securities. **********That purchase, plus a successful auction of new one-year Treasury notes in the early afternoon, bolstered prices further. **********''The market is firm and the tone is positive,'' another trader said. ''Despite the auctions this week, it doesn't seem like the Street has many securities on its books.'' **********At yesterday's auction, the new one-year bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.52 percent, down from the average rate of 7.65 percent on the one-year bills auctioned on May 31. **********Savings Bailout Bonds **********In addition to the successful bill auction, traders were also heartened by the Resolution Funding Corporation's announcement yesterday that early next month it will sell an unspecified amount of 30-year bonds. **********Earlier this year, Resolution Funding, the entity established to finance the bailout of troubled savings and loan associations, made two offerings of 40-year bonds that were poorly received. But traders said issues with maturities of 30 years are far easier to sell. **********The size of the new bond offering will be announced next week. **********In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered in late trading at a price of 103 13/32, up 15/32, to yield 8.43 percent, compared with a yield of 8.47 percent late Wednesday. **********Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 27/ 32 late yesterday, up 3/8 of a point, to yield 8.44 percent. **********Prices of the two note issues auctioned earlier in the week also improved. **********By late in the day, the 8 1/2 percent four-year notes auctioned on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.38 percent. And the 8 3/8 percent two-year notes sold on Tuesday were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 8.27 percent. **********Short-term Treasury bill rates dipped slightly. **********In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.73 percent, down 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.61 percent. **********Corporate Issues **********In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the American General Finance Corporation offered $150 million worth of four-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers Inc. **********The 9 1/4 percent notes, which mature on July 1, 1994, were priced at $99.55 to yield 9.387, 97 basis points more than the prevailing when-issued yield on the 8 1/2 percent four-year Treasury notes auctioned on Wednesday. **********The issue, which is noncallable for life, is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********Also in the corporate market, Texaco Capital Inc., a financing subsidiary of Texaco Inc., offered $150 million worth of debentures. **********The 8 5/8 percent debentures have a final maturity of June 30, 2010, but holders may redeem the securities in three years by exercising a put option at 100. The debentures were priced at $99.85 to yield 8.682, 30 basis points more than the prevailing yield on the 8 5/8 percent three-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing. **********Morgan Stanley & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is also rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P. Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was slow, dealers said. Prices of most actively quoted issues were unchanged to up 1/8 of a point. **********The tone was somewhat firmer in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds. **********According to municipal bond traders, prices of most issues improved by 1/4 of a point to 3/8 of a point. **********In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended June 18. The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction of one-year Treasury bills: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) **********Average Price.......... 92.376 **********Discounted Rate.......... 7.52% **********Coupon Yield.......... 8.09% **********High Price.......... 92.365 **********Discounted Rate.......... 7.53% **********Coupon Yield.......... 8.10% **********Low Price.......... 92.386 **********Discounted Rate.......... 7.51% **********Coupon Yield.......... 8.08% **********Accepted at low price.......... 2% **********Total applied for.......... $31,662,840 **********Accepted.......... $10,263,830 **********N.Y. applied for.......... $27,657,715 **********N.Y. accepted.......... $9,572,115 **********Noncompetitive.......... $834,280< **********The one-year bills mature July 5, 1991.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/world.main_headline: Sudan's Harvest Even Poorer Than Expected
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/world.print_headline: Sudan's Harvest Even Poorer Than Expected
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/world.body_text: **********The official assessment on grain supplies in the drought-ridden Sudan by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations shows that the harvest now being collected is even poorer than the early calculations of most Western donors. **********The Food and Agriculture Organization told the ambassadors of the Western nations in Khartoum, the Sudanese capital, on Sunday that the Sudan had a shortage of 1.2 million tons of grain. In some areas of the country's north, which is controlled by the Islamic fundamentalist junta of Lieut. Gen. Omar Hassan Ahmed al-Bashir, there was no harvest at all, the report said. **********The United States has been predicting that the grain shortage would be one million tons, putting eight million to nine million people at risk of hunger. **********The official figure from the United Nations is important because the Khartoum Government has been insisting that it would not make an appeal for food until the United Nations report was completed. **********But even now and with a grimmer picture than expected, officials of the United Nations said the Sudanese leadership, which has become militantlyanti-Western, was unwilling to ask for aid. **********The British Ambassador in Khartoum, Allan Ramsey, visited General Bashir today and was told by the President that the Government would deal with the situation in "our own way," a United Nations official here said. A rough estimate of covering the cost of purchasing the grain, transporting it and then trucking it inside the country is $500 million, the official said. **********Western donors, unhappy with the Sudan over its sympathetic attitude to Iraq, its human rights violations and its bombing of civilian targets in the southern part of the country, have saidthey would provide food but only if they can be assured that it will get to the people in need. **********So far, the United States, traditionally the largest food donor to the Sudan, has said it will provide 100,000 tons for humanitarian relief on such conditions. But where the rest of the grain will come from is unclear. **********With a 1.2 million-ton grain shortage, the Sudan would need about 500,000 tons in aid for people unable to afford to buy food, Vincent O'Reilly, the director of the United Nations Operation Lifeline Sudan said in Nairobi . The remaining 700,000 tons would be needed for the commercial markets, but the Khartoum Government is bankrupt. **********"It is a very, very bleak situation to say the least," Mr. O'Reilly said. **********Adding to the hopeless economic standing of the Government, Westernfood experts doubt the capacity of the Sudan, where roads are often nonexistent and trucks in poor repair, to transport and store and distribute 1.2 million tons of imported grain. Big Need by May Seen **********The food will start to be really needed by April and May, with June and July the critical months, the experts said. The Port of Sudan can unload only 150,000 tons of grain a month, and by the middle of next year the needs will be about 250,000 tons a month, officals at the World Food Program said. **********Further complicating the dire needs in the Sudan are the food shortages in neighboring Ethiopia, which is experiencing its second year of drought. **********The Port of Sudan is the unloading place for the grain that is donated byWestern governments to the rebels in the northern Ethiopian province of Eritrea, the worst drought area in Ethiopia. Ethiopia, which has a more and efficient professional transportation system than the Sudan, has requested more than 800,000 tons in international aid for next year. **********But United Nations officials are worried that with such critical shortages in the Sudan, the Sudanese will either hijack grain intended for Ethiopia or give priority to the grain intended for the Sudan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/14/busin.main_headline: Integrated Resources Files for Chapter 11 Protection
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/14/busin.print_headline: Integrated Resources Files for Chapter 11 Protection
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/14/busin.body_text: **********After months of trying to reach an out-of-court understanding with its creditors, Integrated Resources Inc. sought voluntary protection yesterday under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. **********The New York-based company, once a high-flying real estate syndicator, has suffered financial setbacks since the Tax Reform Act of 1986 made it virtually impossible for the company to sell its most popular tax-shelter products. **********The company has since diversified into other areas of financial services like mutual funds and aircraft leasing, but at great cost to its profits. With the jittery market for high-risk debt securities and Integrated's mounting problems, the company was unable to extend its short-term borrowings that came due last June and ended up defaulting on $1.6 billion in debt. **********Yesterday, however, the company's top management said it was driven to make the filing because certain dissidents broke ranks with the company's other creditors. **********''We are disappointed by the fact that a few recalcitrant creditors could derail this process,'' said Stephen D. Weinroth, the company's chairman. He cited First Fidelity Bank N.A., New Jersey, in Newark in particular for forcing the company to make the filing in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York. **********About three weeks ago, First Fidelity had gone to New York State Supreme Court to recover $11.6 million that it had lent to various partnerships that are guaranteed by Integrated. Last Thursday, Judge Beatrice Shainswit signed an order that would have allowed the bank to place liens on Integrated's assets. **********''This was incredibly foolish on their part,'' Mr. Weinroth said, adding that Integrated could not appeal the decision without paying the entire $11.6 million in advance. ''We told them if they did that, we'd have no choice but to file.'' **********'Independent Matters' **********But a First Fidelity spokesman, who asked not to be identified, disputed Mr. Weinroth's assertions. ''We feel that the bankruptcy filing by the company is not related in any way to the judgment which we received, and that these are entirely independent matters,'' he said. **********Integrated has relied heavily on Drexel Burnham Lambert for financing and advice, and Mr. Weinroth left the investment house to take the post at Integrated last August. But there is a limit to the help Drexel could offer now, given its own fragile financial condition. **********Indeed, analysts attributed the sharp drop in price on Integrated bonds yesterday not so much to the company's filing as to the separate announcements by Drexel in recent days indicating that it needs an infusion of capital to survive. **********''This paper has Drexel's imprint all over it, and people are afraid that there is not going to be liquidity in anything Drexel underwrote or is associated with,'' said Leigh Walzer, an analyst with R. D. Smith & Company, a research boutique that specializes in distressed securities. He noted that investors were particularly concerned that prices might deteriorate further as Drexel liquidates its own ''junk bond'' holdings to satisfy its debts. **********Securities Decline **********Prices of Integrated's securities could not fall much further. The company's stock, once trading as high as $40 a share, fell about 8 cents, to 17 cents yesterday. Integrated's senior bonds traded yesterday between 13 cents and 17 cents on the dollar, while the company's subordinated bonds traded between 1 and 2 cents on the dollar. **********A plan that Integrated presented to its creditors last month shows that the company believes its assets are worth slightly more than $700 million and put its debts at $1.6 billion. **********The company said its biggest creditors are Manufacturers Hanover, which it owes $55.8 million, and Chemical Bank, which it owes $51.6 million. The two banks' actual exposure is probably less, however, since the bulk is owed by Integrated's sponsored partnerships - none of which have filed for bankruptcy. **********Executive Life Insurance owns about $48.8 million of high-yield bonds and is the third-largest creditor, followed by the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, which owns about $45 million of another high-yield bond issue, according to Integrated. **********Drexel, which has been helping Integrated to restructure and sell various asssets up until this week, is believed to be the fifth-largest creditor, with about $41.1 million in debts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/busin.main_headline: Stocks Climb Sharply as Dow Gains 29.28
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/busin.print_headline: Stocks Climb Sharply as Dow Gains 29.28
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/busin.body_text: **********Stocks fought off a general malaise yesterday, advancing sharply on slow volume in a rise that analysts said was helped along by computerized program trading. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, off 10 points earlier in the day, recovered toward the end of the session, advancing 29.28 points, to 2,736.94. **********By the end of the day, 889 issues were up and 569 were down. **********Activity rose to 131.6 million shares, still the fifth-slowest day of the year. The 116.1 million level the day before was the second slowest. **********Volume in the Nasdaq market fell to 81.01 million shares, or 61.5 percent of Big Board trading - a sign of heavy speculative activity that some analysts argued could mean more bad news ahead. **********Joseph A. Feshbach, chief technical analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities, said that despite yesterday's showing, last week was the third in a row that volume among less seasoned, speculative stocks in the over-the-counter market approached 90 percent of the volume on the New York Stock Exchange. **********If the high ratio of Nasdaq trading to Big Board activity continued for another week, Mr. Feshbach said, ''it typically means the market's not far from a selloff.'' **********Hugh Johnson, head strategist for the First Albany Corporation, said that the market was ''directionless and featureless'' for most of the day but that program trading in the final half-hour helped the professionals ''lock in a meaningful profit.'' **********Laszlo Birinyi, head of the research firm of Birinyi Associates, said that a 12-minute ''sell'' program in the morning brought the market down 4.5 points but that four ''sell'' programs lifted the market sharply. One 12-minute program near 2:30, he said, pushed up the Dow 15 points while an 11-minute program at the day's end lifted it another 11 points. **********Most Active Stock **********American Express topped the Big Board's most-active list, falling 1/4, to 26 5/8, with 2.5 million shares changing hands. It said it had reached agreement to buy the Shearson shares it does not yet own. Shearson, the brokerage firm, rose 1 1/4, to 12 1/2. **********Drug stocks were among the best gainers, with Pfizer up 1 1/4, to 60 1/4; Merck up 1 5/8, to 71 3/8; Lilly 2, to 64 7/8; Johnson & Johnson 1 1/4, to 57 1/8; American Home Products 1 1/8, to 100 3/4; Warner Lambert 1 7/8, to 105; Schering-Plough 1 5/8, to 80 1/4, and Beckman Instruments, the lab equipment company, up 1 5/8, to 18. Steven G. Einhorn, chairman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs, reiterated his ''buy'' recommendation for drug stocks. **********The Dow transportation average rose 16.72 points, to 1,192.57, with UAL, up 3 1/2, to 161 1/2, on continued takeover sentiment; AMR up 1 1/2, to 67; Delta Air Lines 1 3/8, to 74 3/4; USAir 1 1/8, to 31 1/2; Norfolk Southern 1 1/4, to 39 1/4, and Union Pacific up 1 1/2, to 70 7/8, after it said its oil and gas output would rise sharply this year. **********Morrison-Knudsen, the construction company, fell 1 1/8, to 52 3/8. The company said new notes could discourage a hostile takeover because in such an instance investors could demand immediate payment. **********Archer Daniels Midland rose 1 1/8, to 22 7/8, in heavy trading after William Leach, food analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, estimated its profits would rise because of price increases on corn sweeteners. **********In the wake of continued weakness in Japanese stocks, ''put'' warrants on the Nikkei stock average in Tokyo advanced in heavy trading on the American Stock Exchange - further evidence that American buyers are betting Japanese stocks will continue to decline. **********Japanese Stocks Drop **********TOKYO, Wednesday, March 28 (Reuters) - Japanese stock prices fell sharply again today as the dollar rose to its highest point against the yen in three years. **********The Nikkei 225-stock index dropped 562.39 points, or 1.77 percent, to close at 31,263.57. At one point, the Nikkei was down more than 700 points. **********The dollar traded as high as 158.75 yen today, one yen higher than its close in New York on Tuesday. The Bank of Japan intervened in the market, however, and by midafternoon it was selling dollars for around 158.40 yen, dealers said. **********The dollar has not traded above 158 yen in Tokyo since Jan. 12, 1987.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/busin.main_headline: Rates Move Up as Oil Prices Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;   Rates Move Up as Oil Prices Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities yesterday continued to move in tandem with world petroleum markets, as a small rise in oil prices prompted credit market participants to sell notes and bonds, lifting interest rates. **********Once again, trading was thin, although a second videotaped message from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq did prompt a flurry of activity early in the afternoon, less than an hour before the 1 P.M. auction of $11.5 billion of new two-year Treasury notes. **********Mr. Hussein's message appeared conciliatory - he said that foreign women and children taken hostage by Iraq were free to leave and that he was willing to talk to President Bush about ending the crisis in the Persian Gulf. But the videotape, which was broadcast on the Cable News Network, did not soothe raw nerves in the credit markets. **********Traders and analysts noted that Mr. Hussein's statements stood in contrast to steps taken earlier in the day when Iraq declared that Kuwait was its 19th province. **********But the major factor influencing trading decisions, market participants agreed, was movements in oil prices. **********Uncertainty Over Oil Supplies **********''Uncertainty associated with future oil supplies is still the dominant factor,'' said Joe Liro, a vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc. ''We had a very good price bounce on Monday, but with oil prices rebounding, the market couldn't do any better.'' **********Nevertheless, traders said that bidding at the two-year note auction was strong. **********Bids on the notes produced an average yield of 8.19 percent, up slightly from the 8.07 percent average yield at the last two-year note sale on July 25. **********Late yesterday, the notes were offered on a ''when-issued'' basis at a price to yield 8.20 percent. **********''Demand for the two-year was respectable,'' another trader said, ''and most important, the auction was not disruptive to the market.'' **********Today the Treasury is expected to sell $8.5 billion of new five-year notes. The securities were offered on a when-issued basis in late trading yesterday at a price to yield 8.61 percent, compared to 8.54 percent late Monday. **********In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 97 1/32 late yesterday, down half a point, or $5 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 9.03 percent, compared with 8.99 percent late Monday. **********Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent ten-year notes were offered at 98 30/ 32, down 10/32, to yield 8.91 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent seven-year notes were offered at 98 13/32, down 10/32, to yield 8.81 percent. **********Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed. **********In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.47 percent, unchanged on the day. And six-month bill rates dipped by 2 basis points, or hundreths of a percentage point, to 7.45 percent. **********While developments in the Middle East could quickly energize the markets, analysts said that activity is likely to remain subdued for the next week or so. **********''For the most part, people will be waiting for the release of the August employment report on Sept. 7,'' said Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. **********''And if the employment report is poor or indicative of soft economic growth and the situation in the Middle East is pretty much unchanged, I would expect the Federal Reserve will move to ease monetary policy,'' he said. **********In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, demand for a $700 million general obligation bond issue from the State of California was strong, dealers said. By late yesterday, roughly $28 million of the securities remained unsold, investment bankers said. **********In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely-quoted issues were unchanged in sparse trading, dealers said. **********Corporate bond traders said that prices of most investment-grade corporate issues were unchanged to down 1/4 of a point. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction of $11.5 billion of two-year Treasury notes: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures)           Average Price   99.882        Average Yield   8.19%        Low Price   99.864        High Yield   8.20%        High Price   99.900        Low YieldY$8.18%        Accepted at low price   56%        Total applied for   $28,547,955        Accepted   $11,557,490        N.Y. applied for   $25,511,035        N.Y. accepted   $10,189,695        Noncompetitive   $1,372,000        Interest set at   8 1/8% **********The two-year notes mature August 31, 1992.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/28/busin.main_headline: Offering by Massachusetts Has Maximum Yield of 8%
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/28/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;   Offering by Massachusetts Has Maximum Yield of 8%
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/28/busin.body_text: **********The Commonwealth of Massachusetts, whose fiscal stability is under siege from a weakening economy, various legal challenges and a tax-cut proposal to be voted on in November, came to market yesterday with a $1.3 billion offering of fixed- and variable-rate securities through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. **********Proceeds from the sale will be used to clear the state's accumulated deficit of $1.3 billion. **********The sale involves four series of bonds, three of which are secured by letters of credit. **********The $1.025 billion series A portion includes serial bonds priced to yield from 7.25 percent for an issue due in 1992 to 7.95 percent in 1996. There are also term bonds due in 1997 priced to yield 8 percent, and zero-coupon bonds, which pay no interest but if held to maturity in 1997 yield 8 percent. **********The series A bonds are rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation and they are secured by a portion of the state's personal income tax revenue that is deposited monthly in a special trust fund and would be insulated from any effects of passage of the tax-cut proposal that the group Citizens for Limited Taxation put on the November ballot. **********Underwriters said the series B, C, and D bonds were being issued as commercial-paper-type instruments, with yields ranging from 6.15 percent to 6.75 percent, and maturities running from October 1990 to July 1991. **********The variable-rate issues backed by letters of credit are rated accordingly. About $125 million of bonds secured by a letter from National Westminster Bank and short-term ratings of Aaa/VMIG-1 by Moody's and AA+/A-1+ by S.&P. The $100 million of bonds backed by a letter from Union Bank of Switzerland's New York branch are rated Aaa/ VMIG-1 by Moody's and AAA/A-1+ by S.& P. The remaining $50 million in bonds is secured by a letter from Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank Ltd. and is rated Aa-3/VMIG-1 by Moody's and A+/A-1+ by S.&P.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/03/busin.main_headline: Satellite TV Battle Ends in Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/03/busin.print_headline: Satellite TV Battle Ends in Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/03/busin.body_text: **********After battling for several months, British Satellite Broadcasting and Rupert Murdoch's Sky Television said yesterday that they would merge. The archrivals had waged a bitter war for dominance over a new British television market and in the process had accumulated losses of more than $1.5 billion. **********Terms were not disclosed. But analysts said the deal included a substantial payment to Mr. Murdoch, alleviating a severe cash squeeze at his international media conglomerate, the News Corporation, which is about $8.7 billion in debt. **********In return, Mr. Murdoch agreed to share equally a market he now dominates, and to give the chairmanship of the joint venture to an executive associated with British Satellite.  Source of Big Losses **********The surprise merger of the four-channel Sky service and the five-channel British Satellite also appears certain to stanch a big financial drain for the News Corporation. Sky, started in February 1989, has piled up losses of more than $600 million. It was not expected to break even until 1993, had the fight with its rival continued. **********There has been wide speculation in recent weeks that Mr. Murdoch might be forced to sell some properties in the United States. These include the HarperCollins publishing house, a host of magazines including New York and Mirabella, the 20th Century Fox movie studio, and the fledgling Fox broadcasting company. **********That speculation may now abate somewhat. "This has got to be very good for Murdoch," said Carla Tammenoms Bakker, a media analyst at Morgan Stanley. "I would guess that News Corporation's stock is going to move."  Stock Price Has Plunged **********In the last three months, the company's stock price has plunged to $7, from $19, on the New York Stock Exchange. The shares gained 12.5 cents each yesterday, to $7.125. The announcement was made after the close of trading. **********If Mr. Murdoch stands to gain, one conspicuous loser may be Hollywood studios, which had made substantial amounts by profiting from the rivals' bidding war for movies. **********A statement from the companies said the merged operation would be formally called British Sky Broadcasting but would adopt the Sky brand name. It will consist of five channels, including two that will show movies. **********The News Corporation will control 50 percent of the merged company, and shareholders of British Satellite will control the other half.
