British Satellite's stock is primarily held by communications companies including Pearson P.L.C., Reed International P.L.C., Granada Television and Chargeurs S.A. of France. **********Ms. Tammenoms Bakker said that because Sky was far bigger and moresuccessful than British Satellite, Mr. Murdoch would not have agreed to a 50-50 venture unless he had received a substantial payment. Fiona Waters, a spokeswoman for Sky, said no financial terms were being disclosed. **********Sky's service, received through dishes that pick up signals from a satellite called Astra, is received in just over a million British homes, while British Satellite is in an estimated 117,000 homes. **********After repeated technical problems, British Satellite began its service in April, just over a year after Sky. It was thus only on the air as an independent concern for six months -- a hugely disappointing performance for a consortium that had raised $2.4 billion in capital and had vowed to blast Mr. Murdoch out of the sky. Analysts believe the service has lost about $900 million.  Total of $2.5 Billion **********The statement said the combined investments in the two satellite television ventures had amounted to $2.5 billion. **********Sky comprised channels featuring entertainment, news, movies and sports. British Satellite also had movie, sport and entertainment channels, as well as a rock-music channel called Power Station and a catch-all channel called Now, featuring everything from gardening shows to business reports. Apart from the two movie channels, it was not clear what the three other channels on the new merged service would be. **********When they were started, the services represented a gamble that people in Britain were fed up with the state-owned BBC and the independent ITV. **********The merger of the two operations comes at a time when it seems clear that there is indeed an appetite for new stations. But several analysts had expressed doubts that the appetite was large enough to support both British Satellite and Sky. **********The companies operated with different and incompatible technology. The statement suggested that the merged company would primarily rely upon Sky's Astra system and suggested that British Satellite's technology might be phased out. **********The chairman of the new British Sky Broadcasting board, to include an equal number of representatives of Sky and British Satellite, will be Ian Irvine, the deputy chief executive of Reed International. The managing director will be Sam Chisholm, now chief executive of Sky television.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/05/busin.main_headline: Elite Magazines Compete for a Place at Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/05/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Elite Magazines Compete for a Place at Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/05/busin.body_text: **********Home is where the heart is, to be sure. But home may also be where the money is these days, as Americans put away their dancing shoes and come back home again. **********At least, that is what publishers of the elite home-design magazines are betting on. These sumptuous publications, which are to home decorating what haute couture is to sewing, include Knapp Communication's Architectural Digest, standard-bearer for the category; Conde Nast's HG, known until two years ago as House & Garden; Hearst's House Beautiful, granddaddy of them all at 94 years old; Meredith's Metropolitan Home, and Hachette's stylish newcomer, Elle Decor. **********As advertising pages continue to decline while the economy deteriorates and with marginal magazines struggling for their lives, the industry is bracing for a shakeout in categories with too many similar magazines. On the theory that a reader might be hard pressed to differentiate between, say, House Beautiful and HG, these magazines would appear to be prime candidates.  Hard Cores of Readers **********But media directors and advertisers think differently. They say that despite similar demographics and the same kinds of lavish layouts, each magazine has an individual appeal and its own hard core of readers. **********"Certain ads will draw better in one magazine than another," said Michael Dugan, the president of Henredon Furniture Industries. "House Beautiful seems to have carved out an editorial niche that emphasizes the country look. HG has a more urbane, elegant look. Elle Decor is visually terrific and may have appeal to the younger reader. Met Home has a very clear identity and a lot of reader interaction. Architectural Digest is the best magazine we advertise in." **********Nonetheless, the home furnishings market is down and many department stores are feeling the pinch. **********Cheryl Smith, media director at William B. Johns & Partners, a New York ad agency, described the home furnishing market as "a little bit flat right now," but said advertisers with the most expensive goods were the least affected by the economic slump. **********"If you continue advertising and stay visible, you can gain market share," she said. "Recession or not, you have to remain visible." **********Recession or not, the magazines are now edited for readers who are scaling back. They are running more service pieces, more articles on how to refurbish existing interiors instead of redecorating from scratch, more features on less-expensive items. **********In the first nine months of the year, advertising pages fell 9 percent in House Beautiful and 8 percent in Metropolitan Home, while Architectural Digest posted a 4 percent increase and HG a stunning 10 percent gain. Elle Decor began publication in March so no comparative figures exist, but its publisher, Polly Perkins, said the nine 1990 issues had a total of 468 advertising pages, well above the projected 350 pages. **********The circulation leader is House Beautiful, with 932,377 subscribers last year, followed by Metropolitan Home at 701,015, Architectural Digest at 632,302 and HG at 619,920. Ms. Perkins said Elle Decor's circulation, as yet unaudited, was 200,000. **********All five magazines have a lustrous quality about them. With their depictions of perfectly appointed rooms, designer furniture, elegant gardens and oh-so-handsome couples presiding over impeccable preserves, the publications present a world that is more fantasy than reality.  Ultimate Voyeur Experience **********Architectural Digest, edited by Paige Rense, is considered to be the dominant magazine. Its critics call it pretentious, but with four-color issues of more than 300 pages each and more than 1,800 ad pages last year, it is the ultimate voyeur experience into the houses of the rich and famous. **********"A couple of hundred years from now, if you want to get a sense of how affluent America lived in the latter half of the 20th century, you could do no better than a copy of A.D.," said Thomas P. Losee Jr., the publisher. **********Or any of its competitors, for that matter. Nine-year-old Metropolitan Home likes to distance itself from the others with its motto, "Journalism, Not Voyeurism," although it, too, runs its share of glamorous homes. **********For instance, one article entitled "Why You Can't Buy a Sofa in America" examined why most good furniture is sold "to the trade only" and must be purchased through decorators. The piece also explained how to read the price code that hangs off sofas. As a result of this article, Metropolitan Home was barred from a major furniture show.  Bare-Knuckled Competition **********Although the magazines eye each other warily, there has not been the kind of bare-knuckled competition that occurred in the mid-1980's when Conde Nast brought in Anna Wintour, the British editor, to reposition House & Garden. The result confused readers, alienated advertisers and brought a flood of criticism. Under the editorship of Nancy Novogrod, HG has settled down and is back in favor with advertisers. **********House Beautiful, which manages to be both elite and mainstream, probably carries the most consumer articles. Tony Hoyt, its publisher, describes the magazine as "very 203," the area code for Fairfield County, Conn., one of the wealthiest suburbs in the United States. **********The industry is watching Elle Decor, the latest entrant. Modeled after the hugely successful French magazine Elle Decoration and riding on the name recognition of its sister Elle, the magazine has succeeded in attracting coveted younger readers. **********Whatever their individual drawing cards, the magazines are hoping that the 1990's will be the decade of the home. "There are going to be millions and millions of couch potatoes, and you're going to need lots of couches," says Theodore V. Kruckel, Elle Decor's marketing director.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/24/world.main_headline: Anger in Congress Over Aquino's Snub
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/24/world.print_headline: Anger in Congress Over Aquino's Snub
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/24/world.body_text: **********President Corazon C. Aquino's refusal to meet with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney during his visit to the Philippines this week has stirred anger among Democrats and Republicans in Congress and accelerated proposals for moving American forces from that country to other locations in the Pacific region. **********At a White House meeting this week, Congressional leaders from both parties expressed their dismay to President Bush over the diplomatic snub, echoing in more subdued terms some of the angrier comments expressed by legislators in floor speeches and comments over the last several days. Members of the House were particularly sharp in their criticism of Mrs. Aquino, and some suggested that cutbacks in American aid to the Philippines might also come. **********Representative Toby Roth, a Wisconsin Republican who serves on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, noted that the United States had given hundreds of millions of dollars in aid to the Philippines and that Mr. Bush had assisted Mrs. Aquino's Government in December by calling in American fighter planes to help put down a coup attempt. **********''I have a solution to the problem,'' he said. ''Let them keep their bases. We do not want them, we do not need them. They are only an albatross around the neck of the American people.'' **********Domestic Needs Cited **********Mr. Roth said there were plenty of domestic needs for which money now going abroad could be used. **********''We like the people of the Philippines, but it is incumbent upon us to send them a strong message,'' he said. ''America is a strong horse willing to pull a heavy load, but we are not a dairy cow to be milked.'' **********The Subic Bay Naval Station and Clark Air Base are the principal American military installations in Southeast Asia and among the largest outside the United States. There are about 18,000 American military personnel in the Philippines, and 20,000 dependents. The United States is one of the major employers in the country. **********In recent years, rising nationalism in the Philippines has made the bases a political target of rebels on the left and of more moderate opposition members who believe Mrs. Aquino is too close to the United States. **********The 1947 lease covering six American installations including Clark and Subic Bay is scheduled to expire in 1991 unless the two nations can negotiate a new agreement. **********Lawmakers in the United States are irritated at the direct linkage the Philippine Government appears to be making between the bases and increased economic aid. ''There has always been Congressional concern that we are paying rent through foreign aid even though those bases are supposed to serve mutual security interests,'' said a foreign policy aide to Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who heads the Senate Appropriations Subcommitee on Foreign Operations. **********Inaccurate News Reports Charged **********A week before Mr. Cheney's visit, Mrs. Aquino announced that she would not meet with the Defense Secretary, saying American news reports had inaccurately characterized her discussions with other American officials who had visited recently. **********Mrs. Aquino also complained that Washington had failed to live up to a 1988 aid agreement covering the last two years of the bases agreement because this year's allotment had been reduced by $96 million. Still, the Philippines ranks among the top five recipients of American aid. **********Mrs. Aquino's complaints about the cuts in aid were generally supported by politicians in the Philippines, and some lawmakers here said they understood Mrs. Aquino's political need to demonstrate her independence from Washington. But even those most sympathetic to her said she had gone to far in refusing to see Mr. Cheney. **********''I think that Mrs. Aquino's action was regrettable because the United States has been a great friend to the Philippines,'' said Representative David R. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the House Appropriations subcommittee responsible for making foreign aid allocations. **********Mr. Obey said the Philippines received $289 million in assistance last year and $467 million this year. ''If that's a loser, I'd hate to see a winner,'' he said. ''I think it comes with ill grace to the Philippine Government to object to a 62 percent increase over last year.'' He said this was the largest increase for any country in the foreign aid bill. **********The Administration has already been reviewing alternatives to the Philippine bases. According to Congressional officials, Guam and Singapore have been examined as possible relocation sites for some installations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/14/world.main_headline: Pakistan Reports Clash With India in Kashmir
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/14/world.print_headline: Pakistan Reports Clash With India in Kashmir
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/14/world.body_text: **********Indian soldiers tried to capture a mountain outpost, starting a firefight with Pakistani soldiers along the cease-fire line dividing the disputed region of Kashmir, Pakistan said today. **********India denied that a battle had taken place. **********The Pakistani Defense Ministry said the attack on a remote outpost in the Himalayas occurred Sunday, the day after talks on easing border tensions had adjourned. It said there were Indian casualties, but did not say how many. **********Earlier today, a Foreign Ministry spokesman reported no progress in the talks, which adjourned without a date for resumption. **********India, a predominantly Hindu country, and Pakistan, which is Mulsim, have been uneasy neighbors since the 1947 partition that ended British colonial rule. **********Tensions have been heightened by a Muslim separatist uprising in India's part of Kashmir. **********''The war threat has never receded,'' said an official of Pakistan's Defense Ministry, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. ''This could be an isolated incident, or it could lead to escalation.'' **********Indian soldiers used artillery, antitank guns and mortars in attacking the outpost in the Kel sector, 60 miles northeast of Muzaffarabad, capital of Pakistan-controlled Kashmir, and were driven off with mortar fire after about an hour, the Defense Ministry said. **********''Our forces repulsed the attack and inflicted casualties on the intruders,'' an official said. **********In New Delhi, an Indian Government spokesman said: ''It's not true. We have not attacked. We have not used any artillery. We have not suffered any casualties.'' He also cannot be identified under briefing rules. **********Skirmishes and small-arms fire are frequent along the United Nations-monitored cease-fire line in Kashmir, over which the two nations fought wars in 1948 and in 1965. **********The attack was reported to United Nations military observers in New Delhi and Islamabad, the Pakistani Defense Ministry said. **********India accuses Pakistan of arming, training and harboring Muslim militants fighting in Indian Kashmir, which the Pakistanis deny. Pakistan contends that India is using brutal force to crush an indigenious independence movement. **********The uprising has cost more than 950 lives since Indian forces cracked down in late January. Tensions increased last spring in the dispute over Kashmir, a former princely state that both nations claim.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/busin.print_headline: MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; DDB to Work On McDonald's
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/busin.body_text: **********The McDonald's Corporation, has returned to DDB Needham with part of its reported $300 million account, giving the agency a reported $55 million chunk of the business that had been handled by Leo Burnett. The agency handled McDonald's entire account until 1981, and it will rejoin the fast-food chain with various promotional work aimed at young audiences. **********The Leo Burnett Company, which took the account away from DDD Needham, continues as McDonald's main agency. "We don't like to lose any assignments, but over all our win/loss record is pretty good," said Hall (Cap) Adams Jr., chairman of Leo Burnett. "It's not the first time and it probably won't be the last." Mr. Adams said he did not anticipate that most dreaded and common result of a big account loss: layoffs. **********"It's a matter of workload," said Charles Rubner, vice president of communications for McDonald's, explaining why DDB was chosen. "We're simply saying that we'd like some additional creative resources and diversity." **********Mr. Rubner denied industry speculation that McDonald's was reacting to the lukewarm reception of Burnett's recent "Food, Folks and Fun" campaign. Some viewed it as an anticlimactic follow to the popular "Good Times, Great Taste" theme of the earlier Burnett days. "Not at all," Mr. Rubner insisted. "We are pleased with all the work Leo Burnett is doing."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation, which has lost several top executives in recent weeks, suffered another big disappointment today as an international joint venture with Renault, the French auto maker, fell apart. **********Chrysler and Renault announced that they had jointly decided not to cooperate on a $500 million project to build a mini-Jeep to compete with the Suzuki Motor Company's Sidekick and Samurai and the General Motors Corporation's Geo Tracker. The vehicle would have been sold in Europe and the United States. **********The two companies had considered assembling the vehicle in the United States and Europe and sharing the cost equally. Although no manufacturing site had been chosen in the United States, the partners announced in February, a year after the preliminary pact was signed, that they would build the vehicles at a vacant Renault plant in Valladolid, Spain, about 100 miles north of Madrid. **********Chrysler declined to elaborate on the reasons for the termination except to say that both sides believed it ''is no longer economically attractive.'' Chrysler said a distribution agreement under which Renault sells Jeep vehicles in Europe would not be affected. **********A spokeswoman for Renault confirmed that a study by the two companies had concluded that an alliance was ''not feasible.'' **********It was not clear whether Renault's increasing involvement with Volvo A.B., the Swedish auto maker, affected the decision to drop the mini-Jeep project. Since the agreement with Chrysler was made, Renault and Volvo have agreed to a large-scale joint venture to build trucks in Europe. **********Chrysler said it plans to continue with the project, code-named JJ for ''junior Jeep,'' and ''is reviewing various implementation alternatives,'' including a different partner. Chrysler has been negotiating with union and city officials in Toledo, Ohio, where it operates an assembly plant for full-size Jeeps, to build mini-Jeeps. **********Chrysler and Renault had originally talked of starting production of the mini-Jeeps in 1992. **********For Chrysler, pressing on alone with the project would be likely to raise the company's capital costs significantly at a time when the No. 3 auto maker's financial resources are already stretched. The company's sales have been soft and its market share in the United States has declined in the last year. **********The company has also been jolted by a series of executive changes. Two weeks ago, Gerald Greenwald, vice chairman and heir apparent to Lee A. Iacocca, the company chairman, announced his resignation. The departure of Mr. Greenwald, who left to run UAL Inc., the parent of United Airlines, followed the defection of a vice president in charge of international business and the resignation of Chrysler's treasurer. **********And on Monday, Bennett E. Bidwell, the chairman of Chrysler's automotive subsidiary, confirmed that he would retire at the end of the year for health reasons. **********After Mr. Greenwald's announcement, Mr. Iacocca told Chrysler's board that he would stay on as chairman indefinitely and would begin working on a succession plan. His current management contract expires at the end of 1991. **********Like its competitors, Chrysler has tried in the last two years to build a presence in Europe to balance its heavy reliance on the United States auto market. The Ford Motor Company and G.M. have recently had trouble making a profit in their United States operations, but have managed to balance those results with strong earnings in Europe. **********Chrysler sold off its European operations more than a decade ago to raise cash. But it has an agreement with Steyr-Daimler-Puch A.G. to build mini-vans in Graz, Austria, beginning in 1991. **********When Chrysler first announced the venture with Renault, Mr. Iacocca projected eventual sales of 100,000 mini-Jeeps a year in the United States and 50,000 in Europe. **********''It's a wild car,'' Mr. Iacocca had said when the joint venture was first announced. ''It's a youth-oriented vehicle that will have appeal in many countries. Russian kids will like this, too.'' **********At the time, Mr. Iacocca had said the vehicle would be assembled using an innovative manufacturing technique, but he had declined to elaborate. Today, a spokesman said Chrysler is aiming to have its suppliers assemble parts into large subassemblies, which Chrysler workers would put together to create a whole vehicle. This modular-assembly process would require far fewer workers, perhaps as few as 300, compared with a few thousand in a conventional assembly plant, a spokesman said. **********But so far, the sales of competitive vehicles suggest that the entire mini-Jeep market might not be as big as Chrysler had projected. ''Chrysler's goal of selling 100,000 was way too ambitious,'' said Christopher Cedergren of J. D. Power & Associates, a market research firm. ''The mini sport utility market is pretty dead right now. **********''Most of the vehicles - the Suzuki Samurai, Geo Tracker and Suzuki Sidekick - are not suitable as a primary means of transportation. Even young people are reluctant to buy them for their primary car, because they're not very comfortable for long periods of time.'' **********Two years ago, the Suzuki Samurai was branded as unsafe by Consumer Reports magazine, a contention that Suzuki denied, and sales of the Samurai fell sharply. Since then, Suzuki and G.M. have teamed to build similar vehicles, the Sidekick and Tracker, that the companies say are inherently more stable than the Samurai because of their dimensions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/world.main_headline: Panel Hears How Federal Aid Profited a Savings Institution
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/world.print_headline: Panel Hears How Federal Aid Profited a Savings Institution
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/world.body_text: **********A Senate subcommittee was told today that a Texas savings and loan association made up of 15 failed institutions earned huge profits as a result of Government subsidies, but made only four new loans in 1989. **********The panel is looking into how an Arizona insurance executive with legal and regulatory problems was able to acquire the savings and loan from the Government with borrowed money. **********According to testimony by regulators and documents made public today by the Senate Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Antitrust, Monopolies and Business Rights, irregularities continued after James M. Fail took control of the revamped institutions. **********Loans to a Lobbyist **********New questions were raised about loans of more than $500,000 last year from Mr. Fail's companies to Robert J. Thompson, a former Congressional liaison aide to George Bush when he was Vice President. **********The Bluebonnet Savings Bank, made up of the 15 savings and loan associations that Mr. Fail took over in 1988, made one of the loans to Mr. Thompson last year. **********Mr. Thompson, now a Washington lobbyist, helped Mr. Fail, who has had legal and regulatory problems, quickly win approval for the takeover of the 15 institutions and for $1.85 billion in Federal aid from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. **********In addition, insurance regulators from Arizona and Illinois told the subcommittee about violations or possible violations by insurance companies used to finance Bluebonnet's acquisition. **********The circumstances of Mr. Fell's acquisition of the insolvent institutions, as detailed in Government documents, were reported Sunday by The New York Times. The hearing today produced new information about how Mr. Fail was hastily selected as the winning bidder, often with missing or inaccurate information, according to testimony by two low-level regulators and supporting documents. **********Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, and the panel's chairman, said the hearing was part of an inquiry into whether the 1988 bailout of the industry was ''simply an exercise in throwing good money after bad'' that involved ''deals set up by the well connected and the high rollers.'' **********Mr. Metzenbaum wants to undo or renegotiate some of the 1988 deals. The competitiveness and cost of these sales are currently being reviewed by the Resolution Trust Corporation under the legislation authorizing the rescue of the savings and loan industry. **********Mr. Fail was invited to the hearing but did not appear. Instead he submitted a statement that referred in general to his record in managing newly acquired insurance companies that had experienced past difficulties. **********''My ability to handle these difficult problems has benefited the public, the policy holders and the employees of the company,'' it said. **********Stanley M. Brand, a Washington lawyer representing Bluebonnet, also issued a statement questioning the subcommittee's tactics and jurisdiction, and suggested the inquiry was politically driven. **********Argument Over the Blame **********The subcommittee inquiry is likely to heighten the argument between the Bush Administration and Democrats in Congress over who is to blame for the savings debacle, one of the nation's costliest. **********Many invited witnesses did not appear today, including Mr. Thompson, the former Bush aide, and former top officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board who were in office at the time of the Bluebonnet acquisition and other deals that critics contend were rushed through in the last days of the Reagan Administration. **********Mr. Thompson also declined to be interviewed or to respond to questions about the loans submitted in writing last month. **********Senator Metzenbaum said the subcommittee might vote to issue subpoenas to resolve many of the unanswered questions. **********New information made available by the subcommittee today showed that Federal regulators concluded that Bluebonnet's profitability last year - it was the most profitable large savings and loan association in the nation - was ''solely due to the extensive assistance provided by (the) Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.'' **********Other information introduced at the hearing showed that one of the new loans made by the Dallas-based institution was a $356,000 mortgage for Mr. Thompson's Washington home. The loan represents more than 25 percent of the new mortgage loans made last year. Information was not disclosed on the other three loans. **********Insurance Problems **********The Phoenix-based Farm and Home Life Insurance Company, one of Mr. Fail's life insurance companies, is the owner of a $150,000 loan to Mr. Thompson. Susan Gallinger, Arizona's director of insurance, told the panel that her department had questions about the transaction, which was made last year. **********Last week, her department suspended Farm and Home's authority to operate. In a regulatory order, the department found, among other things, that an investment reported by Farm and Home in Bluebonnet did not comply with state code. **********State and Federal regulators involved in overseeing Mr. Fail's financing of his Bluebonnet acquisition told the committee that they had been unaware of key details at the time. **********Zack Stamp, the director of insurance for Illinois, said his agency had begun investigating a $25 million loan to Mr. Fail from a Chicago company, the Bankers Life Insurance Company, used to help buy Bluebonnet. **********Rob Roe, a former bank board official, who now works for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, also testified that he was unaware of key details about Mr. Fail's financing, including the sources and timing of Mr. Fail's $70 million capital contribution, $10 million of which was late. **********Mr. Roe, who was designated by his superiors to negotiate the Fail deal in late 1988, told the panel that he believed Mr. Fail was the low-cost bidder to the Government. But documents released by the subcommittee showed that another bidder had sought $97 million less from the Government, and that Mr. Roe was present when the board was told that Mr. Fail's group was the ''second lowest bidder.'' **********Wayne G. Frena, the analyst at the Federal Home Loan Bank in Dallas who reviewed Mr. Fail's background, testified that that he had not been given adequate time and information to do the review. He and other members of the Dallas bank raised objections to Mr. Fail's acquisition because of Mr. Fail's past legal problems, but were overruled after a phone call from Washington. **********Mr. Brand, the attorney for Mr. Fail and Bluebonnet, said that his clients' actions ''were entirely proper and in full compliance'' with Federal law and that Mr. Fail had ''engineered a remarkable turnaround'' in Bluebonnet.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/04/world.main_headline: In Thatched Roofs of Argentine Poor, an Insect That Saps Health of Millions
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/04/world.print_headline: In Thatched Roofs of Argentine Poor, an Insect That Saps Health of Millions
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/04/world.body_text: **********Ruben Juarez, a Government sanitary agent, stopped at the thatched-roof home of Luisa Chavez, opened two simple cardboard devices hanging on the bedroom walls and found what he feared. **********Out of the accordion-pleated ''sensor'' tumbled a live vinchuca, the blood-sucking insect that carries a disease that often brings early death to the rural poor of Latin America. **********It is known as Chagas's disease, named for the Brazilian doctor who identified it in 1909. The victims, most of whom are initially infected as children, usually recover from the first stage of Chagas's after infection, perhaps suffering a period of fever and a swollen eye. But starting 15 or 20 years later, as many as a third of them will suffer heart disease or digestive complications that can result in sudden death or a long, slow decline. **********The vinchuca, which ranges from the size of a fly to several times larger and carries a deadly parasite called the Trypanosoma cruzi, is drawn to the heavy grass and twigs that many poor farmers in the hottest parts of Latin America use to make roofs over houses known as ranchos. Sometimes the walls are made of adobe, and the vinchuca may hide in the cracks, and sometimes the sides of these houses are open to the air. **********Parasite Drops Onto Skin **********The vinchuca usually drops onto sleeping children at night. It passes along the parasite not through its bite, but when it defecates almost simultaneously and deposits the parasite on the skin surface. If the victim scratches the area of the bite later, the infection enters through the slightly opened skin. The infection can also enter directly into the eye if the bite occurs on the lid, a common occurence. **********Mr. Juarez, riding a bicycle along the dusty, rutted roads here in the western part of the province of Santiago del Estero, visits each home in his territory at least once every three months. When he finds signs of vinchucas he sprays and fumigates with insecticide, the most effective way known to prevent the disease. **********International health officials estimate that 20 million people, living in every mainland country south of the Rio Grande, are infected with some form of Chagas's, but it is in the impoverished north of Argentina and across the border in Bolivia that the infection is believed to be most widespread and to occur in its most serious form. **********Dr. Elsa Segura, who directs the Chagas's institute of the Argentine Health Ministry, said in an interview in Buenos Aires that blood transfusions were the second leading way of transmitting the disease but that only a fraction of the infections in Argentina occur that way because all blood donations in the country are tested for Chagas's. **********Some Congenital Cases **********In some cases, infected mothers pass the disease to their babies at birth. Chagas's experts say that in the north of Argentina, congenital infections occur in about 3.5 percent of all births by infected mothers, and that the figure is as high as 10 percent in some areas of Bolivia. **********''Here in the province of Santiago del Estero, we have the sad privilege of being the most infected area in the nation and one of the worst in Latin America,'' said Dr. Oscar S. Ledesma, who directs the Chagas Diagnostic and Treatment Center at Independencia Hospital in the provincial capital. **********In a 16-bed corner ward of the rundown hospital, children suffering from acute Chagas's infection in its initial form come to be treated with a drug called Benznidazol, which is often successful in killing the parasite. Most carry the telltale sign of one eye nearly swollen shut and have come here by battered bus from as far away as 100 miles after local nurses suspected they might have Chagas's. **********Just a few days before Dr. Ledesma led a visitor into the ward, one of the patients, a 6-month-old girl, died of heart disease after being diagnosed with Chagas's. Hers was one of the rare cases of death occuring during the initial stage of the disease instead of years later. **********Severity of Symptoms Varies **********Dr. Humberto S. Lugones, a pioneer in the treatment of Chagas's in the province who is 75 years old and now semi-retired, estimated that 25 percent of the 650,000 people in Santiago del Estero were infected with Chagas's. Although that is down a few percentage points from earlier years, he and Dr. Ledesma said there had been a rise in acute cases in the last three years. **********Nationwide, about 2 million Argentines in a population of 33 million are infected, and 400,000 to 500,000 of them are believed to suffer some form of heart disease as a result. The only area of Argentina completely free of vinchucas is south of the 42d parallel in cold Patagonia. **********Most people are unaware at the time they become infected because early acute symptoms show up in fewer than 5 percent of the cases. Others may suffer only a slight fever that passes in a few days, or they may have no symptoms at all. **********If the infection is noted at the time and treated with Benznidazol, experts say there is often no long-term effect. But since most infections go untreated, about a third of the infected people in Argentina begin to show signs of heart disease starting 12 to 15 years after infection. In Argentina, cardiologists say, many in that group will die between the age of 30 and 50 as a result of what is called Chagasic myocarditis. The other two-thirds will probably live out their lives normally. **********'The Disease of the Poor' **********Once the Chagas's patient develops symptoms of heart disease, he undergoes the same treatment as other heart patients and his survival chances depend upon the kind of heart disease, the treatment and whether he alters his lifestyle. Chagas's experts say they have no figures on the actual death rate from heart disease among Chagas's victims. **********Although researchers are working on a vaccine to prevent Chagas's infection, its use on humans is thought to be years away. **********''This is the disease of the poor, of underdevelopment,'' Dr. Lugones said. ''It affects the areas with the lowest socio-cultural level, where people have little education, don't practice hygiene and have precarious housing. **********''The quickest way to reduce Chagas's in Santiago del Estero would be to replace all the ranchos with decent housing,'' he said, ''but there are 50,000 ranchos in the province and there is no money to replace them.'' **********Doctors dealing with the disease say that because Chagas's affects mainly the poor, it is a low priority in the Argentine national health budget and for international organizations that finance medical research.

A Unisys spokesman, Peter Hynes, said the company was disappointed by the downgrade by Moody's Investor Services Inc. of about $5.2 billion worth of securities. **********Mr. Hynes cited the decision by the company last week to suspend the common stock dividend as evidence of its efforts to maintain credit quality. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/busin.main_headline: The T-Shirt Industry Sweats It Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/busin.print_headline: The T-Shirt Industry Sweats It Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/busin.body_text: **********Their appeal transcends income, education and taste. While other fashions have come and gone, the lowly T-shirt keeps selling. But even this garment's sales may be vulnerable to a recession. Indeed, a surge in domestic capacity and the flow of imports have made T-shirt marketing a sweaty contact sport. Analysts are expecting cutbacks in domestic T-shirt output to continue in 1991. **********"The T-shirt market this year is soft due to too much capacity and the erosion in general economic conditions," said Robert Blanchard, president of the National Knitwear Manufacturers Association, of Morristown, N.J. "Retailers knew that they can always get the supply they need and are controlling their inventories." **********Because T-shirts are relatively cheap and readily available in a wide range of styles and designs, they appeal to many different people. For example, wearing a T-shirt is a way to assert one's identity or or back up a boast, whether it be about surviving the New York Marathon, visiting Dolly Parton's Dollywood in Tennessee or proclaiming an allegiance to Calvin Klein. "Over the last five years, demand for T-shirts has been very strong," said Deborah Bronston, apparel analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., in New York City. **********Meeting the demand can yield stunning profit margins. Start with a simple white cotton or cotton-polyester shirt, dye it in the factory or run it through a screen or thermal printing machine. With little added expense, a basic $3-wholesale shirt can emerge as a garment that sells for several times more. **********This year, about a billion T-shirts have been made for the United States market, or four for every back. Domestic mills produced about 609 million outerwear-style T- shirts and produced another 300 million meant to be worn as underwear. About 108 million shirts have been imported. **********T-shirts are the only clothing sold not just in stores, but also on the street, in gasoline stations, bowling alleys, movie theaters and zoos. A single shirt can fetch as little as $5 or as much as $150 when sold in boutiques. Even better, in Manhattan's Times Square, three shirts can sell for as low as $10. **********Large makers like Fruit of the Loom Inc. and the Hanes division of Sara Lee Corporation, together account for more than 50 percent of the domestic outerwear T-shirt market, with Fruit of the Loom having a somewhat higher share than Hanes. But retailers buy only about 15 percent of their shirts directly from the manufacturers. The rest filter through wholesalers who either print T-shirts themselves or sell to independent, entrepreneurial style printers. **********Some executives and analysts forecast continuing strong sales. Millions of young and older Americans constantly add to their T-shirt wardrobes -- attesting to the enduring American passion for the casual. "T-shirts and jeans naturally go together, since each seems to be just right for the other," observed Richard Ruster, the president of the Tee Corporation of America, a producer and importer in New York City. "They're the leisure wear for the 1990's." **********Few fashions are so adaptable. What began as outerwear for the fitness craze has become an all-purpose garment for the home and many work places. Indeed, the greatest growth in T-shirt sales has been in outerwear. Jack Hershlag, executive director of the National Association of Men's Sportswear Buyers, speaks of "the two worlds of T-shirts." **********One, he said, is the world of fashion T-shirts, proprietary creations marketed by companies or designers, usually as part of coordinated wardrobes. The other includes the blank shirts that are printed with cartoon characters, team names, product logos, special events, political slogans and jokes. "Bart Simpson is probably outselling any other cartoon character," Mr. Hershlag said. "It's a case of the product creating its own market, and the more bright ideas there are, the bigger the market will be." **********Some analysts say that fashion and novelty will continue to fill T-shirts and T-shirt demand. "Even though some see an oversupply, I see a continuing, solid trend because of the tie-ins with popular movies or television shows," said Arthur Britten, a New York retailing and apparel consultant. "The 'Dick Tracy' and now 'The Simpsons' shirts have had sales in the millions." **********As demand grew in the late 1980's, factories expanded more than 10 percent a year but still ran at capacity. Domestic outerwear production boomed from 382 million shirts in 1986 to 648 million in 1989. Output fell closer to 600 million this year as the manufacturers, fearing oversupply, cut back. **********Importers have had to retreat as well. The biggest source of imported T-shirts is Pakistan, followed by China, Hong Kong and the Philippines. While the foreign flow increased from 14.9 percent of the outerwear market in 1986 to 18.2 percent in 1989, it has slowed this year, dropping an estimated 6 to 8 percent through June, Mr. Blanchard said. **********Domestic T-shirt makers have depended on automation to fend off the imports that have inundated many other types of apparel companies. T-shirts are made from knit jersey, either an all-cotton or polyester blend, by high-speed knitting machines that, in a plant with 500 employees, turn out 17 million shirts a year. But lower fiber costs help keep the price of imported shirts a dollar or two below the cost of domestic products. **********Some American companies are trying to compete by shifting their production overseas. Mr. Ruster said that imports are more likely to thrive in 1991 than domestic production. His three-year-old T-shirt company produces all its garments from abroad. Foreign makers often pay more for import rights -- which, under national quotas, can be bought and traded -- than for actual shirt production. In Mr. Ruster's view, "That shows the demand still exists for the import." **********For manufacturers like Mr. Ruster, T-shirts will never go out of style. "It's still a very hot business," he said. "The T-shirt business is at its peak and everyone still wants to be in it."  DESIGNER T-SHIRTS' TRUE WORTH **********Nobody would price a Claude Monet painting by totaling the value of its canvas, pigment, frame and labor, as well as the retail markup. Likewise, the Monets of the fashion world insist that standard accounting fails to capture their creations' true worth. Far from treating T-shirts as designer doodlings, clever retailers promote them as essential elements in wardrobes. **********Earlier this year, at the Claude Montana boutique in Beverly Hills, Calif., $150 bought a white T-shirt with a big M on the front. However, the French designer will no longer produce these shirts, because, as the boutique manager said, "We do not renew last season's styles." **********Those in the business stress that the finished masterpiece justifies a shirt's high price. "The designer who decides to do a T-shirt will design it totally, from the fabric, construction, shape and trim," said Jack Hershlag, of the National Association of Men's Sportswear Buyers. "Basic T-shirts are mass-produced and chopped out in standard shapes. But the designer might want his creation longer, shorter, fuller or deeper, or with a higher neck." **********Not that this effort is always evident. "You are paying for the designer's name, which is usually on it, and for the pleasure of the reaction you get," Mr. Hershlag said. "It's a matter of fashion appeal and probably snob appeal. Is it better made? Yes, but probably not much more than the best-made, moderate-priced T-shirt." **********Mr. Hershlag said that consumers will never tire of letting designers advertise on their chests. "Not one bit," he said. "People want that name on their jeans or their T-shirts. Manufacturers are falling all over themselves to get the permission of designers to use their names on the products they make."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/15/busin.main_headline: WORLD TRADE BODY IS EXPECTED TO LET SOVIETS HAVE ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/15/busin.print_headline: WORLD TRADE BODY IS EXPECTED TO LET SOVIETS HAVE ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/15/busin.body_text: **********In an initial step linking the Soviet Union more closely to the global economy - a goal urged by the Bush Administration - Moscow is expected to be granted observer status this week in the organization that oversees world trade. **********Observer status in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a 97-nation organization based in Geneva, would for the first time bring the Soviet Union into the international organizations that have helped shape the postwar world economy. The move is expected to be approved by the GATT Council at a regular monthly meeting scheduled for Wednesday. **********An Administration official said today that President Bush wanted a favorable decision before his meeting in two weeks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as ''a tangible sign of American interest in bringing the Soviet Union into the world economy.'' **********U.S. Opposition Ends **********When Mr. Bush last met the Soviet leader at Malta last year, he pledged to remove American obstacles to Soviet participation in GATT. But the plan at that time was not to allow Moscow in until early next year. **********During most of the last decade, the United States had flatly rejected the idea of granting the Soviets observer status at GATT, considering it politically undesirable and economically impractical. Europeans, on the other hand, felt there would be little harm in letting the Soviets in. **********Earlier this year, the Administration decided to speed up the process started at Malta. **********Torie Clarke, an aide to the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said, ''This decision stands today.'' **********No Guarantees **********''The United States has let it be known that if agreeable to all other GATT members, we would have no problem with observer status, but we have made it clear that this does not guarantee full membership,'' Ms. Clarke said. **********Observer status, said David Woods, head of information at the GATT headquarters, means the Soviets would be able to attend the monthly meetings of the GATT Council and participate in standing committees, like the Committee on Trade and Development, which works with the third world. **********In addition, the Soviet observers could speak at meetings, if invited, usually after the full members. They would receive all documentation. **********But the Soviets would not be able to vote. Neither would they be permitted to observe nor attend meetings related to the Uruguay Round, the GATT-sponsored effort to get rid of barriers to trade in services and farm products and providing better protection for patents, copyrights and other intellectual property. The Uruguay Round, which began at a negotiating session in Punta del Este, Uruguay, four years ago, is due to be concluded at the end of this year. **********While observer status does not guarantee full membership, it does provide experience in the workings of the trading system. To make the transition to full membership, an applicant nation must enact policies to open its economy to competition and foreign goods. There is a no set list of measures that must be adopted for membership, such as moving to a convertible currency, but the overall drift of the nation's policies must be seen as a clear move toward more liberal trading practices. Full membership in GATT usually insures lower import duties on the products of a member country. **********The move from observer status to membership can take several years. For example, China has been an observer for the last three years. It was moving to satisfy the membership requirements until it crushed student demonstrations last June. The membership talks have been suspended since. **********Some Dispute in Congress **********The decision to back an early approval of observer status for the Soviets could be contentious, because it comes as the Soviets are cracking down economically on Lithuania. **********President Bush announced on April 24 that for the time being he would not order American sanctions against Moscow, but the conflict over Baltic independence is having a significant impact on Washington. **********A resolution calling on the President not to support observership so long as the economic blockade of Lithuania remains has been introduced in the Senate. **********Japan has also used the issue of GATT observer status for the Soviets as a vehicle for underlining its differences with Moscow. Signaling its displeasure over continued Soviet occupation of four Japanese islands off Hokkaido seized in 1945, the Japanese Government asked for a delay last month when the GATT Council first took up the Soviet issue. **********Japan has set the unconditional return of the islands as a condition for concluding a peace treaty and establishing full-fledged economic ties with Moscow. **********But Japanese officials, who want to see the Soviet Union move toward a market-oriented economy, say they do not plan to use the island issue to keep the Soviets out of the GATT. **********''We are coordinating our position with the U.S. and the European Community,'' said Shataro Yachi, political counselor at the Japanese Embassy here. He said the GATT and island issues ''are not directly linked.'' **********Mr. Gorbachev is expected to visit Japan next year, and many Japanese expect that he will try to resolve the territorial problem in return for Japanese economic assistance. **********GATT is important for both the Soviet Union and China as they seek to normalize commercial relations with the rest of the world. Membership protects a nation's trade interests from the discrimination against nonmembers. **********For example, had the Soviet Union been a full member of the GATT, it would have been much more difficult for the United States to deny so-called most favored nation status to Soviet imports, a situation that imposes 10 times higher duties on imports from the Soviet Union than other countries. **********Under a Soviet-American agreement that both sides hope to have ready by the time Mr. Gorbachev meets with Mr. Bush, the Soviets could be accorded lower tariffs. **********GATT membership is also important as a sign of legitimacy and acceptance by the world community. **********Mr. Woods, the GATT official, said membership would involve significant commitments to economic change. ''It cements the reform process that governments wish to pursue,'' he added. **********Mexico and Morocco, two of the newest members, for example, have undertaken significant trade liberalization as a result of their accession. **********The Soviets have been interested in other international economic organizations besides the GATT. **********A $12 billion European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which is expected to open later this year, includes the Soviet Union as well as the United States. **********Moscow has long expressed interest in two important postwar institutions, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The Soviet Union participated actively in the 1944 conference at Bretton Woods, N.H., where these organizations were born. Yet the Soviet Union decided not to join, foreshadowing the cold war. **********The Soviets have not applied for membership in either of the Bretton Woods twins, and it is considered unlikely that Moscow would join, at least until the mid-1990's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/17/busin.body_text: **********The nation's trade deficit narrowed sharply in December to $7.2 billion, the smallest gap in five years, the Commerce Department reported today. **********The latest figures brought the full-year deficit to $108.6 billion, a reduction of $9.9 billion from the 1988 total. This improvement, however, was far less than the $33.6 billion reduction achieved in the preceding year. **********And while the December performance was considerably better than expected, most private analysts said that the deficit would likely widen again in coming months unless the economy sinks unexpectedly into recession. **********Trend for '90 **********''I think the trend is for little, if any, improvement'' for 1990, said Gary E. Schlossberg, an economist and trade specialist at Wells Fargo Bank. **********Just over three-quarters of the December narrowing was the result of lower imports, a phenomenon that is mostly welcomed but that also implies a weakening domestic economy. This was quite consistent with the department's report last month that gross national product in the fourth quarter grew by a skimpy five-tenths of 1 percent. **********The remainder of the December improvement reflected higher exports, but these were largely the result of a rebound in aircraft sales after the 48-day strike at the Boeing Company was settled Nov. 21. **********Export Momentum Slows **********''Export momentum continues to decline'' after helping to pace economic expansion for much of the past three years, said Bruce Steinberg, senior economist at Merrill Lynch, . **********Currency traders focused on the sluggishness suggested by the decline in imports and the dollar fell against most major currencies. [Page 44.]  The report had little impact on the credit or stock markets. [Page 38.]  A number of analysts, however, took some heart from the December trade figures. The $3.1 billion drop from November's $10.3 billion deficit was significant, said Jerry J. Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, precisely because - not in spite of - the drop in imports. **********''For the first time there are clear indications that in the face of slowing domestic demand, imports of manufactured goods are declining,'' he said. ''The drop in imports of capital equipment at a time when exports of capital goods and machine tools are rising was particularly noteworthy.'' **********Mr. Jasinowski said he disagreed with those who are predicting little further improvement in trade this year. In addition to the gains made by American producers competing with imports, he cited a ''massive boom'' in European demand for American goods and a declining dollar that he expected would bring sustained increases in exports. **********Michael R. Darby, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, called the report ''quite encouraging'' while cautioning that trade figures are subject to especially large short-run gyrations that make it hard to spot emerging trends. **********Deficit With Japan **********The latest figures show, for example, a second straight sizable decline, to $3.5 billion, in the American deficit with Japan, but analysts remained wary of concluding that this represents fundamental improvement. They noted that the declines of 12 percent in December and 18 percent in November were preceded by a 19 percent jump in October. Imports of Japanese cars rose in December to $1.9 billion, from $1.6 billion in November, the report showed. **********For the year, the United States deficit with Japan totaled $49 billion, down 11.6 percent from the 1988 total of $55.4 billion. **********The trade balance with Western Europe swung in December to a $550 million surplus, from a $750 million deficit, with $100 million of the improvement accounted for by a smaller trading imbalance with West Germany. **********There was some further shrinkage in the American deficit with the newly industrialized countries of the Far East - Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore. The combined deficit was $1.4 billion in December, down from $2.1 billion in November and $2.8 billion in October. Lower imports accounted for somewhat more than half the December improvement. **********Bill for Oil **********The nation's bill for imported oil eased $300 million, to $4.1 billion, in December, as a 27-million-barrel reduction in volume more than offset a 64-cent price increase. This occurred despite record December cold, suggesting that refiners drew down inventories during the month. Analysts expect a huge January increase in the oil bill, which during December represented 56.9 percent of the total trade deficit. **********For the year, oil imports surged 27.2 percent, to $48.94 billion - the highest amount since 1984, when the bill for oil was $52.4 billion. **********December's exports rose 2.4 percent, to $31.1 billion, while imports fell 5.9 percent, to $38.3 billion, the report showed. The $7.2 billion deficit was the lowest since the $6.8 billion posted in December 1984. **********November's deficit, initially reported at $10.5 billion, was revised to $10.3 billion but remained the worst deficit of 1989. **********Capital goods accounted for the biggest changes on both sides of the equation for December - a $1 billion increase in exports, three-quarters of it aircraft, and a $1.1 billion decline in imports. **********Without seasonal adjustment, the deficit dropped even more - to $6.4 billion from $10.6 billion, the report also showed. The three-month seasonally adjusted moving average now stands at $9.2 billion, down from $9.7 billion in November and from $10.2 billion in December 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/world.main_headline: U.S. INVITES IDEAS FROM THE SOVIETS ON STRATEGIC CUTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/world.print_headline: U.S. INVITES IDEAS FROM THE SOVIETS ON STRATEGIC CUTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/world.body_text: **********In a shift of position, the Bush Administration has told Moscow that it is now prepared to receive Soviet proposals about reductions in long-range nuclear arms that go beyond the emerging strategic arms treaty, Administration officials disclosed today. **********Until recently, the Bush Administration has rebuffed Moscow's suggestions that the two sides open discussions on a possible second arms treaty that would make deeper reductions in long-range nuclear weapons, like ocean-spanning ballistic missiles, cruise missiles and bombers, than does the arms treaty now under negotiation. **********But Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told Soviet leaders in Moscow last week that the Administration is now ready to entertain new Soviet ideas on what sort of subsequent reductions in long-range nuclear arms should be carried out after the current Strategic Arms Reduction Talks are concluded. **********Thinking of 'Next Phase' **********''Up to now we have not been willing to discuss the Soviet ideas on Start-2 on the ground that we still have work to do on Start-1,'' said a senior Administration official. ''Now we are saying you can raise your ideas if you want to. We are getting to the point where we need to think a little bit about the next phase.'' **********The question of whether to seek further reductions in long-range nuclear weapons after an agreement is reached has been a contentious one for the Bush Administration. Some Administration officials, like the White House national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, have argued that reductions in nuclear weapons should not be pursued for their own sake, and the Administration has yet to formulate a basic position of what additional cuts in long-range nuclear arms, if any, might be sought. **********The treaty currently under negotiation would cut the number of nuclear weapons carried by long-range missiles and bombers by about 30 percent. A second treaty, if it were negotiated, would make deeper cuts, although officials said it was too early to determine what the extent of its reductions might be. **********Seed for a Second Treaty **********Administration officials said Mr. Baker's invitation to the Russians to present their ideas did not commit Washington to presenting its own proposals for a new treaty. Nonetheless, some officials said Mr. Baker's move was potentially significant because it would force the Bush Administration to define its thinking on future arms cuts and could initiate a process that would lead to talks on a second treaty. **********''The major impact is likely to be on the process back home,'' one Administration arms control specialist said. ''Bureaucratically, it will stimulate us to think about what happens after Start, if only to have something to say to the Soviets.'' **********Another official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the likely effect of the Administration's decision would be to encourage the initiation of talks on a second arms treaty. **********''The willingness to hear the Soviet ideas on Start-2 does not mean that there might not be a pause after Start,'' the official said. ''But the general direction is not in favor of a pause.'' **********Still, the course of strategic arms control policy in the Bush Administration is far from clear. Mr. Scowcroft said after the Malta summit meeting in December that the two sides should pause after the first treaty is completed before deciding whether to begin talks on a second. **********Some officials who remain wary of promising deeper strategic arms cuts say the Administration's new willingness to listen to Soviet ideas does not necessarily commit the United States to negotiating a second treaty. Given the differences among American arms control specialists, the presentation of new Soviet ideas could prompt heated debate within the Bush Administration. **********Administration officials said the Soviet proposals would be presented in Geneva to Richard R. Burt, the chief American strategic arms negotiator, by Yuri Nazarkin, the top Soviet negotiator on long-range nuclear weapons. **********Several Reasons Cited **********Administration officials cited several reasons to receive Soviet ideas. By taking up such proposals, the Bush Administration may be able to influence Moscow's new five-year program to develop strategic weapons and further reduce the Soviet nuclear threat to the United States, said one senior official. **********Another official said talks on a second treaty could be a useful ''dumping ground for hard issues that could slow down Start-1.'' **********Mr. Scowcroft, for example, has reportedly expressed interest in far-reaching strategic arms measures, like a ban on all multiple-warhead land-based missiles. But some officials say the introduction into the current talks of major new proposals like that would prevent President Bush from meeting his timetable of completing a strategic arms treaty this year. **********Such innovative proposals might have a place in negotiations for a second treaty, officials say. If such talks were opened, the United States might want to negotiate an entire new treaty or simply prepare amendments to the first document, officials said. **********No Harm in Listening **********Beyond that, some Administration officials say there is no harm in listening to new Soviet ideas now that an initial treaty appears to be within reach. **********An official, who noted that there are differences within the Administration over whether to proceed with a second treaty, said: ''Discussing Start-2 is something the Soviets clearly want to do. We will let them present their ideas and try to clarify what they mean. That does not commit us to a full-fledged discussion.'' **********The Administration's new willingness to hear Soviet ideas follows reports of important headway being made in the Moscow talks on conventional arms and strategic weapons issues. **********But despite that progress, officials expressed disappointment with the Soviet reaction to new proposals by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on cutting aircraft. American officials said Moscow was still resisting strict limits on its training and interceptor planes, among other problems. **********Administration officials also said today that it was unlikely Mr. Baker would be able to respond to a new proposal by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for troop reductions in Europe during a meeting of foreign ministers from NATO and the Warsaw Pact that opens Monday in Ottawa. They said that American officials are divided over the plan and that Washington will need time to consult with other NATO nations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/18/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Ashland in Deal With Occidental
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/18/busin.body_text: **********Ashland Oil Inc. said it had agreed to buy the Occidental Petroleum Company's Appalachian natural gas properties for about $107 million. Ashland said it would acquire about 550,000 acres, primarily in West Virginia and eastern Kentucky. Production from the properties averages about 16 million cubic feet a day. **********Occidental, based in Los Angeles, said separately that gas production from the properties was about 2 percent of its domestic gas output. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, Occidental's shares rose 12.5 cents, to $27.25, while Ashland's shares finished unchanged, at $37.375.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/16/busin.main_headline: A Chip Maker's Profit on Patents
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/16/busin.print_headline: A Chip Maker's Profit on Patents
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/16/busin.body_text: **********Texas Instruments Inc. has become, in the eyes of its competitors, the schoolyard bully of the electronics industry. **********The Dallas-based semiconductor company, a co-inventor of the integrated circuit and a pioneer in computer memory chips, has been requesting unusually high royalty payments from companies that it contends are using its patented technologies, and has been suing those that fail to comply. In the process, it is turning patents into a major profit center. **********But rival semiconductor and computer companies are rising up in anger, saying that Texas Instruments' demands have become excessive, threatening to stifle innovation and to entangle the industry in wasteful lawsuits. They see Texas Instruments' actions as part of a demoralizing trend in the United States in which companies are becoming more competitive in the courtroom as they become less competitive in the technological marketplace. **********'Getting Everybody Mad' **********They see in Texas Instruments' crusade not a legitimate desire to protect crucial technology but a desperate move by a company that can no longer compete in the marketplace and is seeking instead to live off payments from inventions, many of them unimportant, that it made 10, 20 or even 30 years ago. **********''They are riding on their position from the past,'' said Wilfred Corrigan, chief executive of LSI Logic, a Silicon Valley semiconductor company that has been sued by Texas Instruments. **********''They are getting everybody mad at them,'' Mr. Corrigan said, predicting that companies would retaliate by seeking higher royalties on their own patents. ''The intellectual property weapon is a little bit like poison gas or an atom bomb,'' Mr. Corrigan said. ''Before you throw it, you'd better make sure it doesn't bounce back on you.'' Other executives say Texas Instruments risks losing business from companies it antagonizes. **********Even some executives who have not been sued and who favor tough protection of patents think Texas Instruments might have gone too far. **********''I think they got carried away; I think it's a little abusive,'' said W. J. Sanders 3d, chairman of Advanced Micro Devices Inc., another semiconductor company, who nevertheless said Texas Instruments' intentions are ''fundamentally sound.'' **********Richard J. Agnich, general counsel for Texas Instruments, denied that the company had become uncompetitive or was resting on its laurels. Texas Instruments ranked 17th in the number of patents received in 1989, he said, and some of the patents involved in negotiations with Japanese companies are based on developments in the last decade. Moreover, he said, the company is continuing to fight in the memory-chip business. **********Mr. Agnich said that charging royalties for patent use was another way for a company to earn a return on its investment in research and development, supplementing the traditional way of selling products developed from the research. **********The other companies are reacting as a person would if he were told he would have to pay to use a lawn mower he had been borrowing from a neighbor for years, Mr. Agnich said. The person would get angry, but no one would question the right of the lawn mower owner to ask for payments or stop lending the mower. **********''When people look back 10 years from now, they'll say, 'Those guys were just the first of what has become the norm,' '' he said. Other companies are indeed moving toward more aggressive use of their patents, though none have gone as far as Texas Instruments in making patents a large source of income. Royalty rates, like real estate prices in the 1980's, have been rising sharply. **********Gaining an Edge **********Historically, electronics companies liberally licensed their patents, with royalties of no more than 3 percent, or never even bothered to obtain patents. The ethic was to outrun the competitors, not block them. By the time a patent was issued, it was thought, the technology would be obsolete. **********But as the industry has become more competitive, companies have tried to use every asset at their disposal to gain an edge. The creation in the early 1980's of a special Federal court for handling patent appeals also contributed to stronger enforcement of patents. **********Companies including the Intel Corporation and Apple Computer Inc. have become more diligent in protecting their intellectual property. **********In a more general sense, American companies are relying more on their technological inventions and less on their manufacturing prowess in competing with Japanese companies, which can afford to invest more in plants and equipment. Many newer American semiconductor companies design chips but let others manufacture them, in a sense earning their return on their intellectual work. **********'A Profit Center' **********But Texas Instruments has taken the concept of intellectual property as a source of revenue to a new level. **********''T. I. is one of the first companies that very publicly decided to make its intellectual property a profit center,'' said Robert P. Merges, a professor at Boston University Law School. ''For most firms, patents still occupy the traditional role of being partly a strategic weapon to slow down competition and partly a bargaining chip to negotiate with competitors.'' **********While Texas Instruments' patent policy has the support of the top executives at the company, it is being spearheaded by Mr. Agnich, Mel Sharp, the highest patent attorney at the company, and Richard Donaldson, who is in charge of patent licensing. For its litigation the company has relied on the Cleveland-based law firm Jones Day Reavis & Pogue. **********One reason Texas Instruments stands out, lawyers say, is that few other companies have a patent portfolio as strong. And two that do, I.B.M. and A.T.&T., have been reluctant to press their hands for fear of antitrust lawsuits. **********Suits in Far East **********Texas Instruments first struck five years ago, suing eight Japanese and one Korean semiconductor company, accusing them of infringing semiconductor patents. The settlements have yielded Texas Instruments more than $600 million in payments since 1986. **********Now, Texas Instruments is becoming even more aggressive, pursuing payments on three fronts. **********In Japan, where most of the 1986 licensing agreements are coming up for renewal, the company has been seeking royalties as high as 10 percent on the price of chips, triple the usual level, Japanese press reports say. Texas Instruments' hand was strengthened last year when it finally received a Japanese patent for the invention of the basic integrated circuit by Jack Kilby in 1958. **********If all its demands are met, which is unlikely, Texas Instruments' royalties from Japan could jump to between $500 million and $2 billion a year, from more than $150 million now, according to various estimates by Wall Street analysts and the Japanese press. Japanese companies, calling the demands outrageous, have vowed to resist. **********Texas Instruments is seeking royalties from more than 30 makers of personal computers for use of patents covering how a microprocessor connects with other parts of the computer, work that dates back to the early 1970's. The company has already sued Zenith Data Systems, Samsung, Daewoo and Dell Computer over these patents. **********Lawyers say Texas Instruments is seeking royalties of 2 to 3 percent on the sale of each personal computer, or about $50 for a $2,000 machine. Such royalties could earn the company as much as $100 million a year for five years, said Stuart Lubitz, a Los Angeles patent attorney who is following the case for several clients. **********Smaller computer companies worry that such high payments will put them at a disadvantage compared with some large companies that can use Texas Instruments' patents without paying in exchange for licensing their own technologies. The Tandy Corporation filed an antitrust suit last month accusing Texas Instruments of seeking excessive royalties for invalid patents. **********Dispute Over a Process **********In the American semiconductor industry, Texas Instruments sued five smaller companies last year for infringing a patent, also dating from the early 1970's, that covers a process for encasing a computer chip in plastic. Four of the companies, including LSI Logic, have joined to fight the suit. They argue that the process for which Texas Instruments has a patent is just one step out of hundreds in making a chip. If each of several hundred companies demanded a similar royalty for use of their process, the payments would far exceed the price of the chip, they say. **********Some people support Texas Instruments. Rajiv Chaudhri, semiconductor analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company, said profit margins in the pharmaceutical industry were three times those of the semiconductor industry, largely because drugs have stronger patent protection than semiconductors. The result, he said, is that while drug companies can sustain themselves, American semiconductor companies, as a group, are not generating enough cash from operations to survive over the long run. **********Texas Instruments needs all the patent royalties it can get. Unlike most American chip companies, it is still in the dynamic random access memory chip business, which requires large investments and is dominated by the Japanese. **********Moreover, its other businesses are hurting. Its computer business has never been very successful. Its semiconductor business is considered to have a lackluster product line and has recently fallen into the red. The company has been sustained through semiconductor slumps by its military electronics business, but that business is now likely to be hurt by Federal budget cuts. **********Mr. Chaudhri of Goldman, Sachs estimates that the company will make no profit on its operations in 1991, but will record after-tax earnings of $333 million, or $4 a share, strictly from royalties, assuming it is successful in getting what it is demanding from Japanese companies. **********Threat From the Japanese **********The threat to Texas Instruments is that companies will find a way to fight back. Japanese companies are among the leaders now in obtaining United States patents for their own technologies, putting them in a position to turn the tables. **********Hitachi showed just how effective this tactic can be after it was sued by Motorola for infringing Motorola's microprocessor patents. Hitachi managed to find one of its patents on which Motorola infringed. Motorola was ordered to halt shipments of its flagship product, the 68030 microprocessor. The companies negotiated a settlement last week that will allow both to continue shipping products. **********In the case of the plastic packaging and personal computer patents, the company's opponents dismiss the patents as old and unimportant and will seek to invalidate them.
