https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/06/busin.print_headline: CONSUMER RATES;   Fund Yields Are Mixed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/06/busin.body_text: **********The new data will take into account the Middle East crisis, and the analysts said they should show that the economy was weaker and close to a recession. **********Managers of tax-exempt funds repositioned themselves this week and increased the number of days that securities are held in portfolios by 2, to 59. **********Assets fell by $812 million, to $79.9 billion, while the average seven-day, tax-exempt, compounded yield increased 9 basis points, to 5.43 percent, and the 30-day average yield rose 4 basis points, to 5.29 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********For investors in a 28 percent tax bracket the equivalent taxable, seven-day compounded yield is 7.54 percent; it is 8.10 percent for investors in the 33 percent bracket. **********Among tax-exempt funds with assets of better than $100 million survyed by IBC/Donoghue's, the Spartan New Jersey Municipal Money Market Portfolio showed the best return for the week, with a yield of 6.14 percent. The fund is distributed by the Fidelity Distributors Corporation of Boston. **********Of the funds investing primarily in New York securities, the Spartan New York Municipal Money Market Portfolio, also distributed by Fidelity, showed the best return with a yield of 6.02 percent. **********Meanwhile, assets of taxable funds declined by $2.1 billion, to $398.8 billion. Analysts said that among the possible causes were the settling down of the bond and stock markets and the cash settlement on Treasury notes bought at auction last week. Institutional assets declined by $900 million, to $84.1 billion, while consumer funds fell by $1.2 billion, to $314.7 billion. **********The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios increased by one, to 46. **********Donoghue's said the seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money-market fund fell a basis point, to 7.75 percent, while the 30-day average yield fell a similar amount, to 7.77 percent. **********Of the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million, the Dreyfus Worldwide Dollar Money Market fund had the best return for the second week. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/17/busin.main_headline: Farley Sale Of Cluett To French
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/17/busin.print_headline: Farley Sale Of Cluett To French
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/17/busin.body_text: **********In another setback in his attempt to acquire all of West Point-Pepperell Inc., the Chicago industrialist William Farley agreed today to sell the textile giant's Cluett, Peabody division, maker of Arrow shirts and Gold Toe socks. **********Mr. Farley already owns 95 percent of West Point. But the sale of the division is at such a low price that analysts said the deal would be likely to hurt Mr. Farley's position, making it harder for him to line up financing for the rest of West Point. The buyer is the Bidermann Group, a French apparel maker, which will pay $350 million in cash and give a $60 million promissory note to acquire Cluett. **********'A Long Way to Go' **********''Farley still has a long way to go,'' said Kenneth Karwowski, an analyst at Duff & Phelps Inc., an investment research firm based here. He is far from out of the woods.'' **********Mr. Farley's company, Farley Industries, best known for its controlling stake in Fruit of the Loom underwear, announced last spring that it would pay $3 billion for West Point, one of the nation's leading makers of bath towels, sheets and raw fabric. To complete the merger, the industrialist set up a special company, the West Point Acquisition Corporation, which raised $2.9 billion, or roughly 95 percent of what was needed, from banks and private investors. But it was then unable to raise more money. **********For Mr. Farley, selling West Point assets became immediately necessary for two reasons: first, to pay off large portions of the bank debt, and second, to persuade investors to finance his purchase of the remaining 5 percent of West Point. Mr. Farley had said that to make the takeover a success he would need to raise at least $1.3 billion through asset sales. **********Loans in Trouble **********Now that Mr. Farley has succeeded in selling one of West Point's biggest assets, but at a price far lower than he had forecast last year, analysts say that both his bid and the bank loans he took out to finance the first part of the takeover are in trouble. **********In particular, Mr. Farley told investment professionals late last spring that Cluett would command anywhere from $700 million to $750 million, Mr. Karwowski said, adding that ''back in September they still were looking at $600 million.'' As re-cently as January, however, after West Point said it had reached an agreement in principle with Bidermann for Cluett, word began circulating in the investment community that the sales price for Cluett was continuing to drop. One person close to the talks said at the time that a $500 million price was likely. **********Analysts gave two possible explanations for why the price came in even lower. One possibility is that Bidermann reviewed Cluett's fourth-quarter operating results and found them to be worse than expected. The other is that Bidermann drove the price down by exploiting Mr. Farley's inability to raise money in other ways - through, say, the sale of high-yield ''junk bonds.'' **********The sales price for Cluett was ''below our estimate, which in turn was below Farley's projections,'' said Josie Esquivel, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ''It may have been a matter of Bidermann's knowing that Farley was up against a wall.'' **********Effect of Drexel Bankruptcy **********Indeed, now that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., one of Mr. Farley's lead financiers in the past, is in bankruptcy and the junk bond market he had hoped to tap has dried up, Mr. Farley has little choice but to sell assets to meet his obligations to his bankers, analysts said. In fact, even if Mr. Farley could tap the junk-bond market, he would still have to sell assets, the analysts say. **********''If this deal was going to work, it would be because assets could be sold at high prices,'' said James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, a financial newsletter. ''It was not going to work because West Point produced sufficient sales and earnings to cover the debt. This was to be a leveraged liquidation.'' **********For Mr. Farley's bankers, the lower-than-expected price tag on Cluett makes it less likely that they will be repaid the roughly $1 billion they lent him in the form of a bridge loan to acquire 95 percent of West Point. But analysts said bankers were eager to avoid forcing West Point into bankruptcy, since that would mean that the banks might not get paid for years. As evidence, the analysts pointed to the banks' decision, announced Wednesday, to extend the bridge loan to 1994. **********Some analysts have begun to wonder whether Mr. Farley may be facing a cash squeeze himself. Although he has turned around Fruit of the Loom, bonds of his main operating company, Farley Industries, have been coming due. To meet interest and principal payments on these bonds, Mr. Farley has been selling other assets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/05/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Statesman Elected in Greece
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/05/world.body_text: **********Parliament elected Constantine Karamanlis as President today, making the 83-year-old conservative elder statesman the head of state for the next five years. Mr. Karamanlis mustered the support of 153 of the 300 deputies in Parliament - 2 more than the required minimum of 151. His New Democracy Party, now led by Constantine Mitsotakis, won a thin working majority in Parliament in elections last month. This is Mr. Karamanlis's second time as President, a post that under the Greek Constitution is largely ceremonial.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/23/busin.main_headline: The Executive Computer; On Electronic Bulletin Boards, What Rights Are at Stake?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/23/busin.print_headline: The Executive Computer; On Electronic Bulletin Boards, What Rights Are at Stake?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/23/busin.body_text: **********THE Prodigy network, which provides information and consumer services to several hundred thousand computer users, says it has only acted as any responsible publisher would in deciding which messages to publish on the electronic bulletin boards that it provides. That has placed the company, a joint venture of Sears, Roebuck & Company and the International Business Machines Corporation, at the center of a debate about the nature of electronic mail and electronic forums. The stakes are large. Because Prodigy is owned by two formidable companies, and because the service is rapidly gaining customers, the issues raised in the Prodigy debate could have implications for other on-line services. **********Yet Prodigy says there is nothing to debate. In these pages last week, Geoffrey Moore, the company's director of market programs and communications, said: "The First Amendment protects private publishers, like The New York Times and Prodigy, from Government interference in what we publish. The Constitution bestows no rights on readers to have their views published in someone else's private medium. What the Constitution does give readers is the right to become publishers themselves." **********Not everyone sees the issue in those terms.  While Prodigy refers to itself as a private carrier and to its customers as members, it is a public service in the sense that it is open to anyone who pays a monthly fee. Among its services are electronic mail, in which computer users can exchange private messages, and public forums, in which members can post messages on what is, in effect, an electronic bulletin board. And Prodigy is alone among the major on-line information services in screening all messages before they are posted to the public forums, rejecting any that run counter to what Prodigy executives deem appropriate. **********Millions of personal computers users use various on-line messaging services. In the office, such systems are typically private, but these private office mail systems are increasingly being linked to public carriers, allowing a worker to send E-mail, facsimile, telex, digital pager and regular postal messages to workers in other offices or to anyone else linked on the worldwide telecommunications networks. **********Many companies have a formal policy on the use of such systems; those that do not should probably get to work on one immediately. "Logical policies should be taken for the benefit of both employers and employees, and the policies should be made known," said Michael F. Cavanagh, executive director of the Electronic Mail Association, a trade group based in Arlington, Va. "It's less clear whether or not there should be one policy for all companies. You run into a range of different interests and concerns." **********The debate about Prodigy began when some subscribers protested its policy to impose a surcharge on heavy users of its E-mail service. The protest was expressed mainly by posting electronic messages on the service -- certainly one of the first on-line consumer protests. But some of the protesters contacted Prodigy's advertisers through private electronic mail. (Prodigy is also one of the few on-line services that includes paid advertising on every computer screen.) According to Prodigy executives, the advertisers complained and sent them copies of the protesters' private messages. The executives then banned the most vocal protesters and closed the public forum in which the rate increases were being discussed by members. Prodigy has since invited some of the banned protesters to reapply for membership. **********There is no evidence that Prodigy executives read the private mail of the protesters, and they insist that all E-mail is private. However, they acknowledge that they routinely monitor messages sent to the public areas of the network. "Members agree not to submit, publish, or display on the Prodigy service any defamatory, inaccurate, abusive, obscene, profane, sexually explicit, threatening, ethnically offensive, or illegal material," the Prodigy membership agreement states. **********The agreement, to which all Prodigy applicants must agree before they are given access to the system, adds: "Prodigy reserves the right to review and edit any material submitted for display or placed on the Prodigy service, excluding private electronic messages, and may refuse to display or remove from the service any material that it, in its sole discretion, believes violates this agreement or is otherwise objectionable." **********Other on-line information services have similar restrictions against libelous, obscene or otherwise offensive material and will remove posted messages that violate those rules. At Compuserve Inc., whose claimed customer base of 740,000 users makes it the country's largest on-line information service, the policy is to allow all messages to be posted, and then to intervene only if other users complain. In most cases the offending messages are removed and the user is warned by electronic and postal mail. In worst cases the subscriber is kicked off the service. **********Ten users have been terminated from Compuserve in the last three and a half years, said Dave Kissler, a Compuserve spokesman. "There are two key rules that we enforce strictly," he said. "One is not to use the system to be abusive to others or to lessen the favorable experience of others using the service." The other, he said, is not to solicit members to leave for rival services. **********"We have 240 forums, containing hundreds of thousands of messages at any time," Mr. Kissler said. "Forums are central to the nature of the on-line environment, really the lifeblood of what the communications service provides. Part of that is the lively exchange of opinions on a variety of topics." **********The lines get fuzzy when, in the course of that lively exchange, the sender's language or sentiment gets overheated. **********"There is some debate in legal circles on the extent to which videotex service providers must screen publicly posted messages," said Benjamin Wright, a lawyer in Dallas who specializes in electronic communications law. "If the law sees the provider as more like a newspaper, then the duty to screen is higher. But if the law sees the provider as more like a telephone company, a communications common carrier, then the duty is lower." **********"However," Mr. Wright said, "I believe it will be very difficult for anyone to argue that a service provider cannot set ground rules for its service, such as no profanity, no drug deals and even no political messages to advertisers." **********Some critics say the Prodigy ground rules are excessively broad, permitting the service to ban items on the basis of content (such as a protest against Prodigy policies). For example, Prodigy closed a public forum that featured a debate between homosexuals and fundamentalist Christians. Prodigy officials cited lack of general interest in the forum, while critics cited censorship.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/busin.main_headline: ALL ABOUT/Minivans;   Zippy Hybrids Win a Place in the Family Driveway
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/busin.print_headline: ALL ABOUT/Minivans;   Zippy Hybrids Win a Place in the Family Driveway
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/busin.body_text: **********For sheer inventiveness, there is little in the automotive world to rival theVoyager III, the Chrysler Corporation's vision of the ultimate minivan. As a whole, it resembles a bulbous, stretched-out van. It has two engines and four rear wheels. With the flip of a few switches and levers - voila! - the van separates into two parts: a three-seat urban commuter car and a rear module that can be parked until needed. Chrysler suggests the rear module might be used for camping or carrying passengers. **********''Very silly,'' said a viewer last week at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit. ''It just goes to show that Detroit still can laugh at itself.'' Chrysler acknowledges that Voyager III isn't likely to be for sale in the next decade. But this multimillion-dollar project is hardly a stab at humor. Voyager III allows Chrysler engineers, designers and marketers to explore how minivans may evolve, to test consumer reactions and to signal competitors that Chrysler intends to remain pre-eminent in a market segment that it invented in the early 1980's and continues to master. **********With competition increasing, Chrysler may have trouble maintaining minivan dominance. Even as minivan sales rise - and station wagon sales stagnate - the auto companies' market forecasters agree that the United States minivan market can't expand beyond one million to 1.5 million sales annually, compared with 835,000 (including cargo, not just passenger, minivans) in 1989. Minivans range in price from about $12,000 to $18,500 and more for deluxe models. **********Automakers are trying to lure minivan buyers with more sophisticated designs and hotter performance. While other minivans have sliding doors, the Mazda MPV, introduced earlier this year, sets itself apart by introducing an oversize side door that swings open. **********Innovations and new designs are evidence that automakers are pouring money and manpower into crossbreeding cars and trucks. The popularity of these hybrids reflects the more active, family-oriented lifestyles of customers and their demand for space without sacrificing comfort. **********Second Try Toyota Redesigns Its American Entry **********The Toyota Motors Corporation stumbled in its first attempt to crack the American minivan market. Now, the biggest Japanese automaker is ready for an ambitious second try. Toyota's original van, a model popular in Japan, failed to capitalize on a strong market in the United States because the design was awkward for Americans. With the front seats located forward of the front axle, passengers had to climb over the front wheel to get in. ''The Japanese are a bit smaller physically, and it wasn't as much of a problem for them,'' said John Koenig, Toyota's product planning manager in this country. **********Later this year Toyota will introduce the Previa, an import from Japan that it boasts is ''a completely fresh approach to passenger transportation.'' Toyota said its engineers evaluated competitor's minivans and concluded that engine and transmission layouts wasted interior room. **********Toyota designed its 2.4-liter, four-cylinder engine to sit at an angle so it fits precisely in the center of the vehicle, under the floor. This layout, Toyota claims, gives the Previa more length and cargo volume than the stretched version of Chrysler's minivan. Toyota added special rear seats that almost completely fold out of the way. Rear-wheel drive is standard, four-wheel drive optional. Mr. Koenig stressed to Toyota designers in Japan that Previa must be wide enough to carry standard-size plywood or dry wall sheets flat on the floor. To make sure Japanese engineers got the point, Toyota's United States planners bought some plywood and shipped it to the home office in Nagoya. **********New Production Automakers Hedge Their Bets **********No automaker wants to arrive at the minivan party with a new model just as the music stops. With plenty of new models on the way, automakers are wary of losses after a binge of enthusiasm and overinvestment. **********The General Motors Corporation has dedicated only one assembly plant, in North Tarrytown, N.Y., to building front-wheel-drive minivans. Production of the Chevy Lumina, Pontiac Transport and Oldsmobile Silhouette minivans, featuring futuristic designs and plastic body panels, began in November and is increasing slowly. **********Last year Chrysler, which was operating minivan plants on two shifts with overtime in St. Louis and Windsor, Ont., agonized over whether to add a third plant before deciding it was too risky. The cost of a new plant would have required the No. 3 automaker to sell more than 700,000 minivans annually, up from almost 500,000 now (24.4 percent of the cars and light trucks Chrysler builds). Instead, Chrysler tried to wring an additional 50,000 units from the St. Louis plant by adding a third shift and asking employees to work four 10-hour days. The workers refused because they couldn't agree with Chrysler on overtime pay. **********Ford Motor Company and Nissan Motor Corporation, both eager to enter the minivan arena, decided to reduce their risk by collaborating. Ford already builds the Aerostar van, smaller than a full-size van but not a true mini. Nissan sells the Axxess station wagon, which has some minivan qualities. Together, they will build a new front-wheel-drive minivan at a Ford plant in Lorain, Ohio, probably beginning in 1992. Early speculation was that it would be a luxury model.  The Honda Motor Company spent heavily to develop its own minivan. But a Honda spokesman said the company concluded there are so many competitors that Honda could not make a profit. So the company decided to buck the trend and bring out another type of utility vehicle that G.M., Ford and Chrysler are turning away from: a station wagon, in a new Accord model. Honda will begin building the wagons at its plant in Marysville, Ohio, later this year. The plant will export to Japan and possibly to Europe. **********Minivan Safety Federal Regulators Tighten the Rules **********As minivans and other truck hybrids become more popular for toting passengers, they face more scrutiny from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. When minivans first appeared in the early 1980's, some car safety rules didn't apply. Minivans weren't required to have head restraints, roofs that could pass crush tests, sides reinforced against impact or shoulder harnesses for rear passengers. Truck safety requirements have been less stringent since they have been used primarily for cargo. **********Federal regulators now are moving to require minivans, utility vehicles (passenger vehicles built on truck chassis) and pickup trucks to comply with the rules for cars. Proposed crushing and impact standards are under discussion. In 1991, all light trucks must have head restraints and rear passenger shoulder harnesses. On January 4, the N.H.T.S.A. proposed a requirement for front-seat passive restraints - automatic seat belts or air bags - for the 1994 model year. **********Even without meeting federal standards, minivans have a good safety record. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety says that minivans have proportionately fewer fatalities than all but the biggest cars. **********THE GENDER FACTOR **********Auto executives hate to characterize a vehicle type as the province of one gender - why alienate 50 percent of the public? - but if there ever was a ''man's car,'' they say, the four-wheel-drive utility vehicle is it. **********Utility vehicles, or passenger vehicles built on truck chassis, were inspired by Jeeps, pickup trucks and even British Land-Rovers. Although minivans also qualify as truck hybrids, few buyers consider them as alternatives to utility vehicles. Each has its own strong market, much influenced by gender. **********Utility vehicles are tougher to control but better at handling rough roads. They have a bumpier ride and cabins high off the ground. Minivans handle more like cars, with cabins low enough to enter easily when the rider is wearing a skirt. ''You make a different statement about yourself with a utility vehicle than with a minivan,'' said Joseph Cappy, the Chrysler vice president of brand development. ''One is a macho, daring bon vivant. The other is Joe Family.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/busin.main_headline: Ex-Im Bank Resumes Aid to China
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/busin.print_headline: Ex-Im Bank Resumes Aid to China
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/busin.body_text: **********The Export-Import Bank, an agency of the Federal Government that provides credit to the customers of American exporters, has made its first loan to China since the military crackdown against pro-democracy demonstrators in June, bank officials said today. **********The loan is believed to be the first to China by any Western lending agency since June. **********The $9.75 million loan to the China National Offshore Oil Corporation was signed in Washington on Friday. Wary of criticism by those who believe its China policies have been too lenient, the Administration did not announce the action. **********Last month, Beijing lifted martial law, and the Bush Administration responded by easing some sanctions against China, including ending its blanket opposition to World Bank loans to China. **********Bank officials said the loan, which is for 10 years at an annual interest rate of 8.3 percent, had been approved after a determination by the bank's board that the American company would lose the contract without the Government financing. Administration proposals to reduce the operations of the bank have drawn criticism from business leaders who are concerned about the loss of such export sales. [Page D8.]  The new loan will enable the Chinese oil company to finance engineering services for a gas processing plant that the Chinese state enterprise is buying from McDermott International Inc. The plant is near the Bohai Gulf. **********McDermott, based in New Orleans, has annual revenues of $2.4 billion and employs 2,800 workers, selling, among other things, oil and gas equipment and services. Much of its business is overseas. **********World Bank officials said their board will take up two China loans on Thursday, one for $60 million for agricultural projects in Jiangxi province in eastern China, and one for $30 million for earthquake reconstruction in Shanxi and Hubei provinces in north China. **********The actions of both the Export-Import Bank and the World Bank come against a backdrop of sharp Congressional criticism of the Administration's policies on China. Congressional critics argue that the Administration has been too willing to ease sanctions in the absence of significant improvement of human rights policies by Beijing. **********Some officials said today that the United States might approve only the earthquake reconstruction loan because this would have the least political repercussions. **********The Export-Import Bank makes loans at subsidized interest rates to foreign customers of American companies. It also guarantees export loans that commercial banks may make. For most of its loans, the bank looks for a guarantor, in case the money is not repaid. The guarantor usually is the national bank of the country receiving the goods. **********In this case, the guarantor is Mitsui & Company, a giant Japanese trading concern that has close commercial relations with the Chinese oil enterprise and with McDermott. **********Bank officials said a guarantee by a commercial enterprise in a third country was unusual but not unprecedented. ''Mitsui offered the guarantee, and it certainly has the money,'' one bank official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/03/busin.main_headline: Southland Reports Loss Of $1.01 Billion in Period
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/03/busin.print_headline: Southland Reports Loss Of $1.01 Billion in Period
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/03/busin.body_text: **********The Southland Corporation, the owner of 7-Eleven convenience stores, said today that it had lost $1.01 billion in the fourth quarter of last year and that it might seek bankruptcy if it could not restructure its debt. **********Analysts said the loss was likely to hurt the proposed financial rescue of Southland, the world's largest operator of convenience stores. **********In a bid to end its debt troubles, the company last month said it would sell 75 percent of its business to the Ito-Yokado Group of Japan for about $1 billion. Ito-Yokado already controls 7-Eleven Japan. **********Chairman's 15% Stake **********John P. Thompson, Southland's chairman, will hold 15 percent of the remaining company and ''junk bond'' holders will own the remaining 10 percent. **********''This appears to me to kill the whole deal,'' said William Eddleman, the director of bond research at Barre & Company in Dallas, referring to today's announcement. **********Southland said its revenues totaled $2.06 billion in the last three months of 1989, including a non-cash write-off of $947 million of goodwill stemming from a 1987 leveraged buyout that took the company private. It lost $1.31 billion, on sales of $8.35 billion, for all of last year. **********The company said it expected its earnings to fall short of projections this year, initiating default provisions under debt covenants with its banks. **********''The company believes that if it is unable to consummate a restructuring, it would ultimately have to seek relief under the United States Bankruptcy Code,'' Southland said. **********Southland said its independent auditors had ''substantial doubt about Southland's ability to continue as a going concern.'' $4.9 Billion in New Debt The company took on $4.9 billion in debt in a 1987 leveraged buyout, and growing competition has since cut into its revenues and earnings. **********Southland owns about 6,900 7-Eleven convenience stores and has licensees or affiliates operating another 5,900 stores in the United States and in 21 foreign countries. **********Under an agreement with its banks, Southland faces a May 1 deadline to submit a debt restructuring plan and must complete the approved bank plan by Dec. 1. The restructuring and sale to Ito-Yokado is contingent upon consent by two-thirds of its preferred stockholders and the tender of 95 percent of the outstanding principal on five high-yield bond issues.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/24/busin.body_text: **********The Italian Government today renewed its decree for a capital gains tax, an issue that helped to provoke a stock traders' strike earlier this week, but it postponed putting the tax into effect for two months. **********The Cabinet's action put off the tax until Feb. 15. It had to renew the decree because without action, the decree would have expired after Parliament's failure to approve it within a two-month period. **********The capital gains tax applies to small investors. Companies and institutional investors already have to include capital gains on stock trading in their corporate earnings. But individual investors are not required to include capital gains on their income tax filings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/14/busin.main_headline: East Europe Deals For Control Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   East Europe Deals For Control Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/14/busin.body_text: **********The Control Data Corporation said it had received a $9 million letter of intent from Poland to buy a computerized energy management system. The system, expected to be financed by the World Bank, may not require an export license because of an easing of export restrictions agreed to by the United States and its allies in Paris last week, said Dieter Porzel, vice president of Control Data's central Europe region. **********Control Data said it was also expecting approval to export a six-computer, $32 million system to the Soviet Union for nuclear-power safety. It said it already had United States approval for a $6 million sale of three smaller mainframes for oil exploration. A separate deal with East Germany calls for the installation of mainframes at five universities and government agencies in partnerships with existing West German customers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/02/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Prague;   Havel Tells Festive Czechoslovaks That Honesty Is Key to Recovery
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/02/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Prague;   Havel Tells Festive Czechoslovaks That Honesty Is Key to Recovery
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/02/world.body_text: **********President Vaclav Havel told the citizens of Czechoslovakia today that their Communist leaders had lied to them for 40 years, that their country was in a serious economic and environmental crisis, and that only a return to the values of honesty, decency and mutual respect could lead to recovery. **********''For 40 years you have heard on this day from the mouths of my predecessors, in a number of variations, the same thing: how our country is flourishing, how many more millions of tons of steel we have produced, how we are all happy, how we believe in our Government,'' the author and playwright began, wearing glasses and reading from a manuscript. ''I assume you have not named me to this office so that I, too, should lie to you. **********''We have become morally ill because we are used to saying one thing and thinking another,'' Mr. Havel said. His televised message seemed to be aimed at sobering a people who spent the New Year's holiday in delirious celebration of his election and the new freedom that it symbolized. [Excerpts from Mr. Havel's speech appear on page A13.]  A Sadness 'Inflicted on Ourselves' **********But in an allusion to widespread Czechoslovak resentment of the Soviet Union, he said, ''It would be very unwise to think of the sad heritage of the last 40 years only as something foreign, something inherited from a distant relative.'' On the contrary, he said, ''it is ''something we have inflicted on ourselves.'' **********Mr. Havel, who was elected by the national Parliament on Friday, repeatedly called in his 40-minute address for mutual respect among the Czechs, Slovaks, and other nationalities in this Central European country, without directly comparing ethnic tensions with similar problems in the Soviet Union. **********He announced an amnesty for thousands of prisoners who have been protesting overcrowded conditions, poor food, and the lack of rehabilitation in more than a score of jails across the country. **********He also called for trials to assess responsibility for the Stalinist style of repression in Czechoslovakia over the past 40 years; said he hoped that diplomatic relations could soon be restored with the Vatican and Israel; and invited Pope John Paul II and the Dalai Lama, the winner of last year's Nobel Peace Prize, to visit Czechoslovakia. **********Amnesty for Lighter Offenses **********Mr. Havel is to visit East Germany and West Germany on Tuesday. ''I want to contribute to the cause of peace,'' he said, ''by my short visit tomorrow to our two mutually related neighbors: the German Democratic Republic and the Federal Republic of Germany.'' **********''I have decided to proclaim a relatively broad amnesty,'' he said of the prison inmates, ''but I appeal to the prisoners to understand that 40 years of degraded justice cannot be done away with all at once. By uprisings they will help neither the republic nor themselves.'' **********He urged Czechoslovak citizens ''not to be afraid of released prisoners, but to help them in a Christian spirit after their return among us, to find in themselves what our prisons could not instill: repentance and a desire to lead a good life.'' **********Officials said later that the amnesty would free all prisoners serving sentences of two years or less and reduce longer terms by as much as one half. It would not affect people convicted of terrorism, murder, robbery, rape or other sexual abuse, or misuse of public office. The country's jails hold about 50,000 people. **********Ex-Party Chief in Custody **********The highest-ranking Czechoslovak official known to have been taken into custody on charges of abusing his office is Miroslav Stepan, who was the head of Prague's Communist Party organization when the police in the capital moved in to repress demonstrations on Nov. 17. He was arrested on Dec. 23, the Government press agency said. **********Mr. Havel also replaced the Prosecutor General and the Interior Minister today, continuing a shake-up in response to the Nov. 17 crackdown. **********In a series of prison terms beginning in 1977, Mr. Havel served more than five years for refusing to surrender his conscience to the dictates of the Communist state. **********He told his listeners today that he would be ''a President that would speak less but work harder, who will be permanently present among his fellow citizens and listen to them well.'' **********He said that the most difficult work, of insuring that freedom will last, was only beginning, like the cleanup of champagne bottles and broken streamers from Wenceslas Square, Prague's main gathering place. **********From Revelry to Reflection **********The cobblestones were literally wet with champagne Sunday night as tens of thousands of people came out to celebrate the New Year with whatever beverage came to hand, often sparkling wine made in the Soviet Union. Friends and lovers embraced on the square, firecrackers exploded in salutes and the crowd burst into song, marking the end of a year that also brought new freedom to Poland, Hungary, East Germany and Rumania. **********''You have had freedom always,'' said a gray-haired man, Jaroslav Baraban, amid the din, ''but we have only known it for a month.'' **********Like many who filled the vast square, half a mile long and 200 feet wide, between midnight and dawn this morning, the man was nearly weeping. He joined in the repeated chants of ''Havel, Havel,'' ''Long Live Havel'' that demonstrate how much of a symbol the new President has become. **********The celebrations turned more solemn and dignified today as church bells pealed from the medieval towers and baroque domes of the golden city. The gilded baroque interior of the Church of St. James filled with worshipers who flocked to hear a high mass and a performance of Mozart's Coronation Mass by a choir and orchestra. Tonight Mr. Havel and his wife attended a concert of Dvorak's Slavonic Dances in the Municipal Building, where the independence of Czechoslovakia was first proclaimed in 1918. **********A Farewell to Cynicism **********''Everywhere in the world,'' Mr. Havel told the nation in his address this afternoon, ''people were surprised at how these malleable, humiliated, cynical citizens of Czechoslovakia, who seemingly believed in nothing, found the tremendous strength to cast off the totalitarian system in an entirely peaceful and dignified manner within a few weeks. **********''Humanistic and democratic tradition slept on after all somewhere in the unconscious of our nation and national minorities,'' he said. **********But Czechoslovakia also owed its freedom, Mr. Havel said, ''to the courage of those in the Soviet Union, East Germany, Hungary and Poland who had fought for theirs.'' **********''All human suffering concerns each human being,'' he said. He acknowledged that without recent political changes in the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia's revolution would have suffered the same fate as the Prague Spring of 1968, the reform movement that was cut short by a Soviet-led Warsaw Pact invasion. **********Mr. Havel ended his speech with a double echo of Czechoslovak history. He recalled that Thomas G. Masaryk, Czechoslovakia's first President, had taken a prayer by the 17th century Moravian churchman, John Amos Comenius, and paraphrased it: ''Your Government, my people, has returned to you.'' **********The crowd in Wenceslas Square last night also echoed Comenius, breaking into a song made popular by the artist Marta Kubicova during the brief Prague Spring. ''May peace be with this land,'' they sang. ''Let hate, envy, fear and conflict pass. May they pass, may they pass.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/28/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Wal-Mart Net Jumps By 31.8%
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/28/busin.body_text: **********An article in Business Day yesterday about the earnings of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. misstated the 1989 net income for Sears, Roebuck & Company's merchandising group. It was $646.9 million. **********Wal-Mart Stores Inc. continued its rapid growth in the fourth quarter, with profits rising by 31.8 percent to $425.9 million, or 75 cents a share, compared with $323.2 million, or 57 cents in the year-ago period. Sales in the quarter rose by 24.6 percent to $8.1 billion. **********Analysts said Wal-Mart, currently ranked No. 3 among the nation's mass merchandise retailers, should overtake the struggling Sears, Roebuck & Company and the K Mart Corporation in merchandise sales volume in the United States this year. Wal-Mart, based in Bentonville, Ark., plans to open more stores in 1990 than in any previous year. **********For all of 1989, Wal-Mart's profits exceeded $1 billion for the first time in the company's history, rising by 28.6 percent to $1.08 billion, or $1.90 a share. A year ago, Wal-Mart earned $837.2 million, or $1.48 a share, in 1988. Sales in 1989 rose by 25.2 percent to $25.8 billion. **********''It clearly was another outstanding year, and another outstanding quarter,'' said Dennis Telzrow, retailing analyst with Eppler, Guerin & Turner Inc., in Dallas. Wal-Mart shares rose $1.375, to $43.25, in active trading today on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Wal-Mart's revenue total for 1989 was more than triple the $8.5 billion in revenue it posted in 1986. Net income increased at about the same rate, from $327 million in 1986. **********Analysts said Wal-Mart's stunning growth probably would continue. Daniel D. Barry, retailing analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company, in New York, said sales should reach $31.6 billion this year. He estimated net income would rise to $1.3 billion, or $2.30 a share. **********David Glass, president and chief executive, said in a news release that Wal-Mart anticipated ''an intensely competitive environment'' this year. He added that the company had ''a great opportunity'' to grow ''in a manner consistent with prior years.'' **********The retailer plans to open Wal-Mart stores for the first time in California this year, in the state's Central Valley. It also is expanding broadly in Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin and, also for the first time, in Pennsylvania. Its stronghold remains the rural and suburban South and Southwest. **********In the 12 months through the end of January, the company increased its number of Wal-Mart stores by 143 to 1,402, and opened 28 new Sam's Wholesale Clubs, for a total of 123. It also owns three large Hypermart stores, which combine grocery and discount retailing. **********Mr. Barry said Wal-Mart should exceed Sears, Roebuck & Company and K Mart in domestic merchandise sales this year. Sears's merchandise sales in the United States were $27.5 billion last year. including income from credit-card finance charges. Sears' total merchandising sales were $31.6 billion, including $4.1 billion from operations in Canada and Mexico. **********K Mart will report its 1989 results next week. Mr. Barry estimated that K Mart's domestic merchandising sales last year matched Sears's total, at $27.5 billion, with total merchandising sales at $29.3 billion. K Mart has 118 of its 2204 stores in Canada. **********Wal-Mart would need another year to overtake K Mart and Sears in total merchandising sales, if current sales trends continue, Mr. Barry said. He estimated that K Mart would post $32 billion in total sales this year, with Sears rising to about $33.2 billion. **********In profits, Wal-Mart is already the group leader. It passed K Mart in annual net income for the first time in 1988, with $837 million to K Mart's $803 million. Analysts said K Mart is likely to report net income of less than $200 million for 1989. **********K Mart announced on Monday that it would take a $640-million charge against its fourth quarter earnings in an effort to speed up its $2.3 billion program to modernize its stores. Sears net income from its merchandising group in 1989 was $292 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/busin.body_text: **********DESPITE the largest introduction of computer systems in the company's history, shares in the Hewlett-Packard Company continued to drift downward yesterday. They closed at $47, down 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Analysts said the new products were impressive, but they were disappointed by projected delivery dates, which stretched to the end of the year. And several analysts criticized the company for providing insufficient detail in its announcement. **********In a generally weak market for computers, analysts who have been neutral on Hewlett-Packard said they saw no reason to change that recommendation; others lowered their rating. **********Hewlett-Packard introduced 24 computer systems for a wide range of commercial and technical applications. The systems all feature Hewlett-Packard's Precision Architecture, a design based on reduced instruction set computing, or RISC, a technology increasingly used to provide faster performance at lower prices. **********The announcement included Hewlett-Packard's first multiprocessor machines, which are intended to compete with large mainframes from the International Business Machines Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation. These computers, which are four times faster than the company's previous top-of-the-line model, will not be available until the end of the year. **********''It's a good direction, a positive announcement, but the timing is distasteful,'' said John B. Jones Jr., an analyst with Montgomery Securities. The end-of-the-year delivery ''implies to me that they're having more difficulty producing those machines than we anticipated,'' he said. **********He said the late delivery would ''have a dampening effect on the stock.'' **********Information about the announcement began leaking out last week when Hewlett-Packard briefed computer industry consultants, and ''the share price has been drifting down because of it,'' Mr. Jones said. On Jan. 2, the stock's closing price was $49.375. **********John Dean, an analyst with Salomon Brothers in San Francisco, said he was disappointed by the late delivery of the high-end machines, particularly because Hewlett-Packard's RISC architecture was designed with multiple processor versions in mind from the start. **********''The question you have to ask is why is it taking so long when it's a basic part of the architecture,'' he said. He had expected the machines to be shipped by midyear. **********Taking a more positive view, Russell Crabs, an analyst with the Soundview Financial Group, complimented Hewlett-Packard for the quantity and quality of the equipment announced. ''The real exciting thing in a technology sense is the new CMOS implementation of the Precision Architecture,'' he said, referring to the use of chips based on CMOS, a type of silicon that operates more coolly and allows more devices on a chip than conventional materials. **********Using CMOS allowed Hewlett-Packard to offer a machine with mainframe-level performance at a far lower price, which will open up a new product category and expand the market for the company's computers, Mr. Crabs said, adding that he was not concerned by the end-of-the-year delivery date. **********''The sales cycle on the high-end systems is so long that if they announce them now it will take that long to close business,'' he said. **********Soundview has had a long-term buy recommendation on Hewlett-Packard shares. Strategically, the company ''is doing all the right things,'' but they are ''still working against a weak computer environment,'' right now, Mr. Crabs said. ''Our approach on the stock is you buy it on weakness,'' he said, adding that it was not a buy at today's price. ''I would rather get the first fiscal quarter behind us.'' **********Peter D. Schleider, an analyst with Wessels, Arnold & Henderson in Minneapolis, is also taking a wait-and-see approach. He said he had hoped to see the CMOS devices in a desktop machine rather than only at the mainframe level but was impressed by the company's aggressive pricing of the new computers. **********The company still ''has a lot of wrestling to do within its customer base,'' he said, as it moves from computers based on its own proprietary software operating system to machines that run Unix, an industry standard system developed by A.T.& T. Customers will not want to make that move until it is clear they can move their data from the proprietary machines to the Unix-based computers, he said. He rates the stock a hold. ''It's a good company, and well managed, but it's still in a transition mode,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/02/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   Ship Companies 'Born to Die'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/02/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   Ship Companies 'Born to Die'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/02/busin.body_text: **********IN the late 1970's, after spending much of his career in real estate, Michael S. Hudner turned his attention to shipping, an industry that had suffered several protracted downturns but that he believed was due for a recovery. In an attempt to persuade skeptical investors, he constructed a new investment vehicle, whose management would not be allowed to invest in new ships or other ventures once it had spent the original amount raised in a public offering. **********The goal of this enterprise, now commonly known as a self-liquidating company, was not to grow and become a shipping company over the long term. Instead, it would buy ships, run them for a time and distribute the profits. It would sell off the ships at opportune times or when their useful years began to wane. **********''They were born to die,'' said James J. Dowling, a shipping analyst with Furman Selz Mager Dietz & Birney, one of the largest financial and investment companies catering to the shipping industry. **********Mr. Hudner's idea was to reduce the chance that managers would spend the company's profits on more ships or some other venture without the approval of stockholders. **********''To make this industry attractive you had to eliminate some risks that burned investors in the past,'' said James L. Winchester of Mabon, Nugent & Company, which managed some of the offerings. **********Investors had been through the latest downturn from 1982 to 1986, when many shipping companies had again overexpanded. Tankers were scrapped and large shipping companies suffered huge losses. Some went bankrupt. **********Since 1987, Mr. Hudner and Arvid Bergvall, who has spent most of his career managing vessels and investments in shipping, have put together three companies whose management is limited in what they can do. **********The three, formed with public offerings, were B&H Bulk Carriers, B&H Maritime Carriers and B&H Ocean Carriers. **********Other investors followed the trend, forming companies with similar structures, like MC Shipping, Global Ocean Carriers and Nortankers. **********As shipping has recovered in the last two or three years, most of these companies have done well. The ships they bought early in the recovery have increased in value. As shipping rates have risen they have made money and paid dividends at a rate of 13 to 15 percent a year. **********Still, the performance of their stocks has been mixed, with shares of some companies trading below the price at which they were issued. One important reason is that companies that have paid out dividends at the promised rates and have paid off the original investment of stockholders began to pay a substantial amount of the proceeds - from about 25 to 50 percent - to management. **********Thus when a company nears the point of having to pay management a good part of the returns, the stocks have generally dropped, because the amount left over for the stockholders drops. B&H Bulk Carriers, for example, was formed in June 1987. It raised $20 million that September through an offering priced at $10 a share. With the money it raised, the company bought nine ships. **********Early last year, the management decided to sell two of the ships, which had gone up in value, and paid a dividend of $7.60 a share. **********After the big payout, the stock price dropped to $9 a share, and it has recently traded at $5. **********He believes that such self-liquidating companies should trade at a discount to the value their ships would bring if they were sold. **********Mr. Winchester said some of the companies are undervalued, since the liquidation value was about $13 a share. Combined with the fact that management would get half the proceeds, this would make the price about $6.50 a share. **********Such companies have aroused the ire of several of the older, better-established shipping concerns. In their view, the self-liquidating companies are taking advantage of a short-term recovery of the industry but are not taking the risk of building for the future. **********But others in the industry see entrepreneurs like Mr. Hudner as a welcome addition. In the past, ship owners raised some of their financing with government help and built their ships with state subsidies. They often ended up overexpanding, which helped bring on the industry's deep slumps. **********Basil Papachristidis, the head of a major shipping company, recently estimated that in the last two and a half years about $650 million had been raised by such firms through private and public offerings. **********S. E. N. Pollock, chairman and chief executive of BT Shipping Ltd., a conventional shipping company, said the protections were needed to reassure investors at the time these companies were formed. ''The self-destruct mechanism was the way people saw things in those years,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.main_headline: Foreign Investors Held $2 Trillion in U.S. in '89
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.print_headline: Foreign Investors Held $2 Trillion in U.S. in '89
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.body_text: **********Foreign investment in the United States rose to a record total of $2 trillion in 1989, up 12 percent from $1.786 trillion in 1988, according to preliminary statistics released today by the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis. **********About a third of the $214.6 billion increase, or $72 billion, was in direct investments. These include foreign spending on factories, real estate, corporate takeovers and ownership of 10 percent or more of an American company. **********The remaining two-thirds of the increase in foreign holdings came from so-called portfolio investments, which include purchases of American corporate securities and Government bonds. Foreign investment now plays a very large role in financing the huge Federal budget deficit. **********Fourfold Increase **********Since 1980, foreign investment in the United States has increased fourfold, the report noted. **********''Until the budget and trade deficits are brought under control, the U.S. will continue to rely on foreign capital,'' said Elliot L. Richardson, chairman of the Association for International Investment, which represents foreign investors. **********Brad Larschan, a spokesman for the group, warned that today's report could ''exacerbate concern about foreign investment in the Congress and with the public generally.'' **********Three bills pending in Congress, including one proposed by the Bush Administration, would increase Government surveillance of foreign investments. **********A recent report by the General Accounting Office has raised questions about the effect of foreign investment on national security. ''The basic question, as many have posed it, is whether the U.S. defense industrial base is being gradually 'hollowed out' as foreign investment takes place,'' the report said. **********Supporters of foreign investment say that it provides the money needed to finance the deficit and support the stock market and that it provides jobs, management skills and technology. They say the ability of the United States to attract foreign investment reflects its strength in the global economy and improves Americans' understanding of foreign cultures. **********Critics contend that the United States has become overly dependent on foreign capital, which could lead to an erosion of political and economic independence as decisions affecting Americans are increasingly made abroad. In addition, they say some foreign investors buy American companies to acquire their technology and damage their competitors. **********Pat Choate, a vice president of the military contractor TRW Inc. and a leading critic of foreign investment, said the report showed that ''bit by bit we're surrendering control of our economy.'' **********While foreign direct investment increased by 22 percent in 1989, according to an analysis of the Commerce Department data by the Association for International Investment, American investments abroad increased by 9.7 percent, or $31.7 billion, raising its value to $358.6 billion. **********British Remain in the Lead **********The British continued to be the largest direct investors in America, with the Japanese remaining in second place. They were followed by the Dutch, Canadians, West Germans and French. **********British investment increased by $20.2 billion, or nearly 20 percent, for a total of $122.1 billion, accounting for 30.5 percent of all direct foreign investment in the United States, according to the analysis of the Commerce Department data by Mr. Richardson's organization. **********Japanese investment increased by $17.3 billion, or 32.4 percent, for a total of $70.6 billion, or 17.6 percent of all foreign direct investment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   A Sloganeer Strikes Out On His Own
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   A Sloganeer Strikes Out On His Own
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/busin.body_text: **********HE wrote ''Come to think of it, I'll have a Heineken'' and ''She's very Charlie'' for Revlon. Now, after nearly 40 years of boosting beer and blush, Malcolm D. MacDougall is building his own brand image by putting his name on the door of a new company. **********Mr. MacDougall, who is 60 years old, announced on Friday that he was leaving the Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor advertising agency, where he is vice chairman, to start a creative consulting firm called the MacDougall Company. He said he intends to work directly with consumer-product and service companies to find creative solutions to their advertising and marketing problems. **********''There are 850 marketing consultants out there,'' said Mr. MacDougall, who admitted he fabricated the number for effect. ''But nary a one that can sit eyeball-to-eyeball with a marketing director and solve his No. 1 problem, which is creative execution.'' **********In a lesser man, such braggadocio would be ignored or scorned. But Mr. MacDougall is one of advertising's better liked and more successful creative executives, a slightly rumpled Ivy Leaguer with an open face and disarming grin whose sloganeering for a variety of American companies has earned him widespread repute. **********Mr. MacDougall, who is known to all as Mal, inspired the Diet Coke anthem ''Just for the taste of it.'' For Good Housekeeping magazine, he invented ''the New Traditionalist,'' helping raise the self-esteem of modern mothers. His words sold lipstick (''Revlon lips never lie'') and ball peen hammers (''Stanley helps you do things right.'') Mr. MacDougall once commented: ''I'm never surprised when the gods of advertising remind me once again that there is nothing permanent in the business but change.'' That is an apt theme for his life of profesional wandering. After stints as associate creative director of BBDO in New York and creative director at BBDO in Boston, Mr. MacDougall, a Harvard graduate, formed Humphrey Browning MacDougall in 1970, igniting an advertising renaissance there that was joined by Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, an agency he later served as New York president. **********In between the two, he worked at SSC&B, now called Lintas, rising to president and director of creative services. He joined Jordan in 1987. **********He maintained that he was not bored in his current position and simply wanted to open his own creative consulting operation to expand the number of product categories in which he might work. As Patrick J. McGrath, Jordan, McGrath's president, said, ''I hate to admit it, but there are a lot of areas we're not represented in.'' **********For Jordan, McGrath, the defection of Mr. MacDougall would normally be considered a serious loss but for one factor: the agency has signed on as the MacDougall Company's first client. This will enable him to continue to work creatively for at least three of his top accounts there, Good Housekeeping, Milton Bradley toys and games, and Rockport shoes, for which he recently wrote the slogan, ''Rockports make you feel like walking.'' **********Mr. MacDougall said he would take no agencies other than Jordan, McGrath as clients, nor will he accept clients that conflict with the agency's current accounts. He is even maintaining an office at Jordan, McGrath. **********''One reason,'' said James J. Jordan Jr., the agency's chairman, pointing to a room filled with storyboards, books and mementos, ''is he's accumulated so much junk it's impossible to move.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/world.main_headline: C.I.A. Fears Iraq Could Deploy Biological Arms by Early 1991
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   C.I.A. Fears Iraq Could Deploy Biological Arms by Early 1991
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/world.body_text: **********Iraq has developed biological weapons that will be able to deliver significant quantities of the deadly agents on the battlefield by early next year, according to American intelligence reports. **********The intelligence reports were described to reporters today by Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who chairs the House Armed Services Committee, and were confirmed by Administration officials. **********Until recently, Administration officials said that Iraq had only gone so far as to conduct research on biological warfare and had not developed biological weapons. **********But William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, said in a little-noticed section of a speech last week that ''Iraq has a sizable stockpile of chemical and biological weapons.'' **********Anthrax Among Weapons **********That was the first time any Administration official had publicly asserted that Iraq had succeeded in developing biological weapons. **********Mr. Aspin told reporters today that American intelligence reports say that by early next year, Iraq will have the capacity to deliver a significant amount of biological weapons, including anthrax. An aide to Mr. Aspin told reporters that the Iraqis would have the capability to deliver the biological agents by bombs, short-range rockets and possibly by Scud surface-to-surface missiles. **********Biological weapons, unlike chemical weapons, are based on living agents like viruses and bacteria. They can be used to spread deadly diseases, like typhoid, chlorea and anthrax. **********Iraq has repeatedly denied that it has biological weapons, unlike chemical weapons that it used in its war with Iran and that it has threatened to use against Israel if attacked. **********Key Plant Near Baghdad **********''We have no biological weapons, but we do have chemical weapons,'' President Saddam Hussein of Iraq told Senator Bob Dole and other visiting Senators in April, according to an official Iraqi transcript of the meeting. **********Experts outside the Government have said a key Iraqi biological weapons installation is at Salman Pak, about 18 miles southeast of Baghdad. **********Mr. Aspin said the developing Iraq biological-warfare capability was one of several factors that could encourage the Bush Administration to take military action against Iraq before next year. **********But some experts outside the Government played down the threat posed by biological weapons. **********''It would be suicidal for Iraq to use biological weapons on our forces,'' said Elisa Harris, an expert on chemical and biological weapons at the Brookings Institution. **********The Risk of Response **********''They would risk infesting their own troops with whatever weapon they used and they would certainly unleash a devastating response on our part if they were to do this,'' she said. **********Ms. Harris also said that American soldiers could be inoculated against anthrax and that the chemical protective grear provided to the troops could be used to protect against biological agents. **********But an Administration official said that the Pentagon was taking the Iraqi biological-warfare capabilities seriously and was giving renewed attention to ways to protect American troops. The official declined to be specific, saying that discussions on the matter were classified. **********A Pentagon spokesman declined to say what if any steps the American military was taking in response to the latest intelligence reports, saying the question had been referred to the United States Central Command in Saudi Arabia. **********Chemical Weapons Noted **********Mr. Webster spoke sparingly last week about Iraq's means of delivering biological weapons, citing the need to protect classified information. **********When a questioner asked if Mr. Webster was suggesting the Iraqis had armed surface-to-surface missiles with biological weapons, the Director said, ''The development of these indigenous capabilties does not mean that in every case and for every type of B.W. [biological weapon]  capability they currently have the corresponding delivery systems with which to be effective.'' **********''The answer is not so important at the present time because of the size of their chemical-warfare capability, with which they can do substantially everything they can do with B.W. capability,'' Mr. Webster said.
