https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/world.main_headline: Cambodia Talks Quickly Collapse With Boycott by the Khmer Rouge
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/world.print_headline: Cambodia Talks Quickly Collapse With Boycott by the Khmer Rouge
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/world.body_text: **********A new round of talks on Cambodia lasted only 25 minutes today after the Khmer Rouge guerrillas complained about their representation here and boycotted the session. **********The Khmer Rouge boycott annoyed their Japanese hosts, who are engaged in regional peacemaking for the first time since the end of World War II. **********But Japanese officials said discussions were under way to salvage the talks, which were intended to formalize a symbolic agreement already initialed by all four Cambodian factions. **********The talks went into recess after the representative of the Khmer Rouge, Khieu Samphan, did not show up for the morning session, which was opened by the Japanese Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, and run by the Foreign Minister, Taro Nakayama. **********Demands for Equality **********While the Japanese Government had made it clear from the start that these discussions were between the two rival governments in Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge suddenly complained in a statement that it wanted to take part as an equal in four-party talks. **********Prince Norodom Sihanouk is the leader of a Cambodian coalition government in exile consisting of the Khmer Rouge and two non-Communist factions, his own and that of a former Prime Minister, Son Sann. **********Prince Sihanouk had agreed to represent his side, with Mr. Khieu Samphan and Mr. Son Sann as part of his delegation, while Prime Minister Hun Sen represents the Vietnamese-installed Government in Phnom Penh. **********Mr. Khieu Samphan's agreement to attend as only part of Prince Sihanouk's delegation was considered a significant concession by the Khmer Rouge and their Chinese allies. **********It pleased the Americans, too, because it made the Khmer Rouge, who dominate the battlefield against Mr. Hun Sen, seem subsidiary to the non-Communist Prince Sihanouk. **********But the Khmer Rouge clearly have had second thoughts. **********Japanese Visibly Upset **********The Japanese diplomat in charge of Southeast Asian affairs, Masaharu Kohno, said tonight that he was not entirely surprised by the Khmer Rouge boycott, ''since they have done similar things on other occasions.'' But the Japanese were visibly upset. **********By recreating difficulties thought to have been resolved, the Khmer Rouge insure that they are not forgotten. They also put Prince Sihanouk into a difficult situation, highlighting the weakness of his position. If he proceeds, as promised, to continue talking to Mr. Hun Sen and to sign the agreement already worked out, the Khmer Rouge say they will not abide by it. But if he does not proceed, he displays how much he is beholden to them. **********That is why, in previous conversations with Mr. Hun Sen, the Prince has stressed that he was acting for his own faction only. Here, however, he is supposed to be representing his coalition. **********Mr. Kohno said he could not predict whether Prince Sihanouk would return to the talks or sign an agreement, worked out by the Thai Defense Minister, Gen. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, that calls for an immediate cease-fire. **********National Council Proposed **********The agreement also calls for the establishment of a supreme national council to represent Cambodian sovereignty after a settlement and before new elections. In the agreement, the council is two-sided, with six members each for the two rival governments, rather than equal representation for all four factions. **********Washington is said to want modifications to the initialed text calling for a comprehensive settlement and a stronger role in monitoring a cease-fire and cessation of foreign military aid by the United Nations. But there was little discussion of any changes today. **********As Japanese, Thai and even Chinese Embassy officials tried to persuade the Khmer Rouge to return to the talks, Prince Sihanouk said he was not returning to them himself because he agreed with the proposed text and had ''nothing to discuss.'' **********''The problem is with the Khmer Rouge,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/27/world.main_headline: Communist Laos Mixes Strict Political Dogma With Capitalist Economics
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/27/world.print_headline: Communist Laos Mixes Strict Political Dogma With Capitalist Economics
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/27/world.body_text: **********Fifteen years after the Communist victory in this smallest of the three countries of Indochina, Laotian leaders continue to profess rigorous political dogma, but they have openly returned to capitalist economics. **********After nearly a decade of ideological orthodoxy in all fields, the ruling party has officially delayed the transition to socialism. Laotian peasant farmers once again till lands that are their own, and commerce in this virtually unindustrialized country has largely returned to private hands. **********During a two-week stay in a country that has severely limited press access since the Communist takeover, the bustling commercial life of this capital and the major provincial towns of Savannakhet and Luang Prabang stood in sharp contrast to the political monotony. Where a decade ago the markets were almost as bare of variety as the political scene, they now look virtually as they did under the old Government. **********Bicycles, which then had the streets virtually to themselves, are contending today with motorcycles. Cars have reappeared, and not all the European luxury cars belong to diplomats or international officials, as they did earlier. Gasoline is once again in adequate supply. **********In his first interview with an American reporter, Kaysone Phomvihane, Prime Minister and General Secretary of the Communist Party, expressed the guiding policy. **********He said the country was faced with the realities of an underdeveloped economy and the heavy destruction of war. ''We could not afford to work subjectively and in a rush to attain socialist goals, but must strive to surmount the difficulties caused by this backwardness for several more decades,'' the Prime Minister wrote in reply to questions submitted before the interview. Political Freedom Is Not in the Cards Sisana Sisane, himself a longtime party leader, who holds Cabinet rank as chairman of the Committee for Social Sciences, said socialism might take a century to achieve. ''We don't have the basis for building a socialist economy,'' he said. **********Mr. Kaysone rejected any borrowing from present developments in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, particularly tendencies to political pluralism or challenges to the sole party's ''leading role.'' **********''The Laotian people have faith in and agree with the People's Revolutionary Party's leadership, since the party belongs to the people, originates from the people and serves the people,'' the General Secretary said. ''Our Laotian party does not yet see any need for establishing other political parties.'' **********Acting President Phoumi Vongvichit explicitly condemned political freedom in an interview. ''If everyone speaks in his own way, I consider that anarchy rather than democracy,'' he said. ''We compare this to a cart drawn by several buffaloes - one pulls to the right, one to the left, another remains standing. Can that cart advance?'' **********A senior Communist diplomat said: ''I prefer not to talk about politics, because anything I'd say would have to be critical. There is no true democracy in this country.'' **********Laotian and foreign residents reported that after a gradual beginning in the mid-1980's, commercial prosperity appeared to take a sharp upward turn only last year. Since 1988, business freedom appears to have known no limits, and a new foreign investment code was adopted to make Laos attractive to investors. **********Almost no figures are available to document what an observer sees. ''There is no hard information whatsoever,'' a Western Ambassador complained. **********A senior international official said: ''No one knows anything. There's not a single statistic that can be checked.'' Control of Economy Is Decentralized A main reason is that in an exception to the practice in other Communist countries, the central leadership has allowed considerable authority over economic life to devolve to the provinces. They are free to conclude trading agreements not only with private companies but also with neighboring countries. Laotians with links to the power structure said Mr. Kaysone allowed this decentralization to take the sting out of power rivalries that might otherwise have weakened his rule. **********As in the pre-Communist past, free trade in Laos amounts to an invitation to Thai business to extend its markets and economic influence. The other neighbors - China, Vietnam, Cambodia and Burma - are too hampered by poverty and state-controlled economies to take advantage of the opportunity. Moreover, Thailand has always been the main route of international access to this landlocked country. **********Thai consumer goods dominate retail trade, from foods, toiletries, medicines and cheap textile goods to television and video sets, motorcycles and cars. What mystifies foreign observers is how Laotian importers and consumers pay for these goods. Exports of hydroelectric power and timber, overflight rights and remittances from refugees abroad are this country's main sources of foreign earnings. A factory producing toothpicks is believed to be the only source of manufactured export goods. **********Laotians and foreign residents suspect that considerable quantities of timber are exported illegally. Even less verifiable is a widespread suspicion that the smuggling of opium and heroin, of which Laotian mountain tribesmen are major producers, also finances consumer imports. **********Communist leaders concede that official corruption and profiteering are on the rise. ''At the beginning, party workers served the interests of the people well,'' Mr. Sisana said. ''Then errors were made. There are now many illnesses among Communists - omissions and corruption.'' **********''Graft is growing and beginning to show,'' a United Nations official said. ''People are showing wealth.'' In a country where Government ministers earn less than $50 a month and lower-level civil servants between $10 and $20, moonlighting jobs and the small shops or market stands that supplement family incomes are not sufficient to explain a recent spurt of home-building and imports of new cars. The Mass Culture Comes From Thailand The flood of Thai goods, and even more the far-reaching penetration of Laos by Thai television and the pop culture that it transmits, have gone a long way to undo the puritanical Communist ways that Laos sought to install when the revolution was young. Tight jeans, which 15 years ago were cause enough to deport young people to harsh labor camps, raise no eyebrows. The state has allowed restaurants that it owns to be turned into discos. **********The prevalence of Thai pop music, posters of Thai pop stars and similar signs of an energetic mass culture spreading across its borders have aroused unhappiness among educated Laotians. A Foreign Ministry official angrily insisted in a hotel bar that the waitress replace a tape of Thai music with Laotian songs. **********Mr. Kaysone said in the interview that the danger of Thai economic dominance ''creates many difficulties for us.'' He did not elaborate on the theme. **********Speaking of the attitude of Laotians in general, a long-serving Western Ambassador said, ''They would rather be robbed blind by the Thais than be a colony of Vietnam.'' **********While Mr. Kaysone and other leaders interviewed affirmed that Vietnam, which played a dominant role in achieving the Communist victory here, continues to hold a special relationship, Vietnam's own economic and political difficulties have clearly diminished its former role of tutellary power. The 50,000 Vietnamese troops stationed here since 1975 were withdrawn by 1987, the Government asserts. **********Vietnam's role as this frail country's ''senior partner,'' succeeding the United States, which followed France, seems to have been assumed by a flourishing international and bilateral aid community. The number of United Nations agencies, national assistance projects - particularly Swedish, Japanese and Australian - and private relief groups like the American Quakers and Mennonites surpass, in the view of some of their representatives, this Government's absorptive capacities. **********''Laos is 'in,' '' said a visiting official of an international lending institution. Diplomats and international officials fear that such pressure will keep Laos from standing on its own feet. ''In the early 1980's there was a greater feeling of a striving for self-reliance,'' a senior aid representative said. **********A Communist Ambassador estimated that Laos received about $130 million yearly in foreign aid, of which $50 million comes from the Soviet Union. Most goes into infrastructure projects in a country that lacks above all roads, transport and communications. Consequently, little immediate effect is felt by the large rural population, the vast majority in a country of less than four million people. **********Basic Services Seen as Neglected Laotians and international officials said basic human services, especially public health and education, were grossly neglected. Many exist on paper only. A United Nations official who travels widely said most of the village schools he sees in the mountain regions are unused, deteriorating buildings. Low pay, often many months in arrears, obliges teachers to find other ways of earning a living. **********In the painfully underequipped province hospital of Savannakhet, the country's second-largest town, the chief physician, Dr. Siheng Sayasene, said firmly that patients were dying for lack of equipment and medicine. Furthermore, the limited number of medical personnel in the country, as well as transport difficulties, are thought to keep the majority of those requiring treatment from receiving it. **********At a large party on Saturday night, at which President Phoumi was the guest of honor to celebrate the birthday of a wealthy businessman from the pre-Communist regime, a former Government official commented sadly that the gathering seemed to sum up Laos today. **********Once again, the official said, the political and business elites live privileged lives, irrespective of what separated them in the past, and the bulk of the Laotian people stand outside looking in.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/busin.main_headline: Business Scene;   Reviving a Role For Apprentices
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/busin.print_headline: Business Scene;   Reviving a Role For Apprentices
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/busin.body_text: **********ACROSS Europe, apprenticeship programs train millions of young people for skilled jobs. In the United States, where millions of young people leave high school without much hope of entering skilled, well-paid trades, apprenticeship programs barely exist. **********Logically, this ancient form of job training seems due for an American revival, given the rising demand for skilled workers to master the complex computerized machinery and the new technologies that are constantly changing work practices. An effort is afoot to give apprenticeship in America a shot in the arm. For teen-agers who do not go on to college, becoming an apprentice would be a middle ground between high school and full-fledged work. **********The Commission on the Skills of the American Work Force, a panel of business and union leaders, is issuing a set of proposals today that asks Congress to create a nationwide government-regulated apprenticeship program, financed partly through a payroll tax. Separately, the Labor Department has created the Office of Work-Based Learning to support pilot apprenticeship projects. And the Secretary of Labor, Elizabeth H. Dole, is recruiting 25 industry, government and labor leaders for an advisory group that will suggest ways to expand apprenticeship training. **********''We are actively promoting school-to-work programs, but we are not calling them apprenticeship,'' said James D. Van Erden, administrator of the Office of Work-Based Learning. ''The word carries connotations of the union movement and we don't need this negative baggage.'' **********Apprenticeship means learning a trade, over three or four years, through a combination of classroom study and on-the-job training. Most of the nation's electricians, carpenters, plumbers and ironworkers acquire their skills this way, but outside the construction industry, apprenticeship programs exist only sparsely, for some auto and aircraft workers, machinists, mechanics and a few others. **********The Fitzgerald Act, passed by Congress in 1937 to correct abuses inflicted on apprentices, empowered the Labor Department to register the programs and to set standards, like a minimum of 144 hours a year of classroom training. Nevertheless, only 300,000 people are in registered apprenticeship programs, roughly unchanged since 1950. Most programs are the fruit of union agreements, although the military trains 50,000 of the apprentices as an inducement to re-enlist. **********From colonial times until well into the Industrial Revolution, being an apprentice was standard job training. With the advent of the assembly line, millions of jobs were limited to two or three simple, quickly learned tasks. As a result, apprenticeship training retreated to crafts like carpentry and electrical work, which still required complex skills. But now, with the rise of a flexible workplace -one that requires ingenuity and complex skills to carry out a variety of tasks - apprenticeship training is coming back into vogue. **********Reacting more quickly to the change, West Germany, Sweden, France and other European countries are well ahead of the United States in government-sponsored apprenticeship training, often financed through special taxes. ''You can sustain profits in two ways in the international arena,'' said F. Ray Marshall, a Labor Secretary during the Carter Administration. American companies opted for cost-cutting through layoffs and limits on wage increases, he said, while other industrial nations sustained wages, but trained workers so they could produce more. **********Lately, however, some big American companies, like Motorola, Ford, General Electric and American Express, are spending tens of millions of dollars on job training that resembles apprenticeships. They are, in effect, beginning to adopt the European approach. But from a corporate executive's viewpoint, incorporating this individual company training into a national apprenticeship program has two big drawbacks as well as one big advantage. **********The advantage is that the companies could pay a training wage with Government sanction. Ironworker apprentices, for example, currently start at between 35 percent and 50 percent of a journeyman's wage, moving up each year toward full pay. One drawbacks is that companies would have to comply with Federal regulations, particularly rules that insist upon minority hiring for the programs. And they would have to issue nationally recognized certificates to newly graduated apprentices, who could then depart with their licenses for new jobs, just as journeymen carpenters move among employers, offering their licenses as proof of their skills. **********Whatever the pros and cons, other leading industrial nations are moving to train their workers and increase their productivity. ''We do this for college-educated people,'' Mr. Marshall said. ''But we do virtually nothing for people who don't go to college.''

Your Own Account;
The Discounters' Advantage
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/18/busin.print_headline:
Your Own Account;
The Discounters' Advantage
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/18/busin.body_text: **********A BEAR MARKET and a recession shouldn't drive you to drop your investment program. But they could encourage restructering a portfolio, and certainly encourage an attitude of thrift. With that in mind, a discount broker may be the answer. **********These brokers will trade stocks, bonds, mutual funds, precious metals or options for commissions that can be as much as 90 percent below what you would pay a full-service broker, said Mark D. Coler, whose book "Investing at a Discount" was published last month. **********Discount brokers offer no investment advice. But unless you require considerable hand-holding before you make a trade, that shouldn't be an obstacle. "For most investors who know what they're doing and are seeking execution at the lowest price, discount brokers make sense," said John Markese, research director at the American Association of Individual Investors in Chicago. **********Discounters offer a couple of other advantages over full-service brokers. One is that you can buy a variety of securities, including mutual funds, from several different companies and yet receive a single, consolidated statement listing all of these investments. Many financial planners recommend discounters to their clients precisely for that reason, even if the client's entire portfolio consists of mutual funds. **********You can, of course, buy no-load mutual funds -- those without a sales commission -- direct from the company. But if you buy them from several different companies, you will receive a stack of statements, making it difficult to monitor your portfolio. **********"Financial confusion is at the root of many peoples' investment problems," said H. Lynn Hopewell, a financial planner in Falls Church, Va. "People make big-buck mistakes from confusion." **********For example, Jonathan D. Pond, a Boston financial planner, says he recently acquired a new client who was "a superb investor." But she "must have had 25 mutual fund accounts." The only way to roll them into one and get a consolidated statement was to use a discount broker, he said. **********Another advantage is that discount brokers do not have the potential for conflict of interest that full-service brokers do. A full-service brokerage house serves many different clients -- from corporations that issue securities to retail customers.  So it may commit to buy a big block of securities from a major client, planning to funnel some of it to you, whether it's right for your particular portfolio or not.  Brokers may also have a larger stake in selling you mutual funds or other products managed by their employer, on which commissions are greater. **********If you decide to use discounters, how do you evaluate them? Consider commission, of course. If you want just the lowest commission, look for what Mr. Coler calls the "deep discounters." When he prepared an index comparing 20 trades of about $9,000 per trade, he found that the typical full-service broker charged around $206 per trade. The largest discount brokers charged around $92 for the same trade, while the "deep discounters" charged $53. On higher-volume trades, the discount could be as much as 90 percent. **********Mr. Markese suggests that you "come up with what is likely to be your normal trade." Then get price quotes from several discounters. One percent or less of the price of the securities "is truly discount," he said. "If you're paying 2 percent, you're paying full-service rates." **********There are both national discounters and regional discounters. If you use a regional broker, you should get a referral from friends or colleagues who are active investors and use discounters, according to Meloni Hallock, a senior manager in personal financial services for Price Waterhouse in St. Louis. "I wouldn't just look them up in the phone book," she said. **********Think about how you plan to use your broker. Some discounters offer additional services, for a fee, of course. For example, Charles Schwab & Company, the largest discount broker, offers research on companies at $7.50 per company, according to Mark Goines, vice president of marketing. You get a report compiled by Standard & Poor's, current news headlines from Dow Jones and a consensus of analysts' outlooks. **********If you plan to use a discount broker for your mutual fund portfolio, you'll want to know which mutual funds are available. Jack White & Company, one of the oldest discount brokers, offers 1,300 mutual funds, which Mr. White, the company's president, claims is the largest list available. The firm, which is located in San Diego, also offers competitive trading prices, financial planners say. **********If you trade stocks, you need a broker good at executing trading orders. This is important if you want to trade at a particular price. For example, you might want a minimum of $31 a share. If the stock trades in a range of $30 to $32 that day, the broker may not sell at $31 if he or she doesn't act quickly. **********"If you save something on the trade, but they don't trade quickly and the stock is moving around, you might lose it on the price," Ms. Hallock said. This can happen occasionally with any broker, she said, but if it happens to you frequently, you should take your business elsewhere.  When to Go Full Service **********DISCOUNT brokers offer advantages for many investors but they are not for everyone. Here are some things you're more likely to get from a full-service broker: *********** New investment ideas. "There are a lot of people who need a nudge to think about their portfolio," said Meloni Hallock of Price Waterhouse. *********** Seminars and research reports. *********** Negotiated commissions. "If you like to bargain and negotiate, you won't get it from a discount broker," Ms. Hallock said. Even a beginning investor can negotiate some sort of deal from a full-service broker if he or she asks, although it would not be as good as one available from discounters. "It's very common to get a discount of 20 percent from a regular brokerage firm," she said. "That won't happen with discounters because their margin is too thin." *********** Personal attention. **********Some investors use both a discounter, for simple stock trades, and a full-service broker, for more complicated trades, like buying options. If you do use both, however, don't take your broker's ideas and execute them through a discounter; a broker who discovers you doing this will cut you off.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/busin.body_text: **********Even though Super Bowl XXIV was the lowest-rated football championship in two decades, advertisers may still have scored well. **********''This is the best way to reach the biggest television audience,'' said Bill Katz, senior vice president at BBDO/New York, which created four minutes of advertising for Pepsi during the Super Bowl. ''We're delighted that so many people hung in there to watch.'' **********The game, in which the San Francisco 49ers crushed the Denver Broncos, 55 to 10, was seen by 63 percent of those watching television during the the broadcast and had a 39 rating, the A. C. Nielsen Company reported. Each rating point equals 921,000 homes with televisions. **********It is the only Super Bowl that has dipped below a 40 rating since 1970, when the rating for Super Bowl IV was 39.4. **********The Super Bowl's poor showing does not mean that the 21 advertisers who paid $700,000 for each 30 seconds of commercial time will receive so-called make-goods, free advertising time given by the network when a program fails to deliver a guaranteed audience. **********Such make-goods are unlikely, said executives of agencies that bought time on the Super Bowl, because CBS sold advertising for the game with no guarantees on how large the viewing audience would be. **********But several advertisers said that they were not unhappy and that the game's relatively weak ratings would not discourage them from advertising during next year's game. **********''It's no deterrent for buying time on future Super Bowls,'' said Joel M. Segal, executive vice president for national broadcasting at McCann-Erickson, which produced three minutes of Coca-Cola commercials broadcast during the game.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/busin.main_headline: Mitsubishi Trust in U.S. Options Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/busin.print_headline: Mitsubishi Trust in U.S. Options Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/busin.body_text: **********Eager to give its corporate clients worldwide an opportunity to deal in futures and options, the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation of Japan said today that it would form a venture with the Chicago Research and Trading Group Ltd., one of this country's leading traders of options and futures. **********A spokesman for the 50-50 venture, Michael Weiser, said that broadly speaking Chicago Research would contribute expertise, Mitsubishi Trust would contribute most of the $150 million in start-up capital and both organizations would contribute personnel. But all the terms of the joint venture, which will focus on futures and options contracts in interest rates and currencies, were not disclosed. **********Changes for Both **********The deal will enhance Mitsubishi Trust's ability to compete globally with other banks that already offer futures and options, and at the same time will make Chicago Research a different sort of firm. Until now a proprietary firm - that is, one that traded principally for its own account - Chicago Research, after the joint venture, will be working with outsiders, chiefly corporations and other institutional investors. **********Malcolm Hanney, a Chicago Research executive vice president, added that the deal ''will provide Chicago Research serious access to the Japanese market and corporate business in Japan.'' **********The joint venture appeared to be unusual in a number of ways. **********Although Japanese financial institutions have entered into business arrangements with United States financial institutions in the past - Sumitomo Life, for instance, owns part of Goldman, Sachs; Nippon Life owns part of Shearson Lehman Hutton, and Yasuda Life owns part of Paine Webber - the Japanese have been passive investors in those deals. Similarly, in a highly publicized joint venture operating in Japan, Wells Fargo is a passive investor in a money management joint venture with the Nikko Securities Corporation. **********Active Japanese Involvement **********In the Chicago Research-Mitsubishi Trust joint venture, by comparison, both partners will have exactly 50 percent ownership. Moreover, the Japanese are expected to send representatives to Chicago to be actively involved in policy making. **********Additionally, this appeared to mark the first time that the Japanese were formally joining forces with an American firm that dealt strictly in futures and options in this country. Another major futures and options trading firm based here, O'Connor & Associates, a direct competitor of Chicago Research, has a link with the Swiss Bank Corporation. **********For its part, Mitsubishi Trust has been eager to learn more about and participate in the options and futures fields. Many of its corporate clients do business globally and would like to use futures and options for protection against swings in interest and currency rates. But Mitsubishi Trust does not own a seat on either the Chicago Board of Trade or the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the two principal futures exchanges here. Mitsubishi Bank, which does own a seat on the Mercantile Exchange, is a separate organization. **********'Seeking Out Expertise' **********''They are seeking out expertise, and this will significantly enhance their ability in these areas,'' said Mr. Hanney, the Chicago Research executive vice president, referring to Mitsubishi Trust. **********The joint venture will solidify what has been an informal but increasingly close-knit relationship between Mitsubishi Trust and Chicago Research. The two first started talking about doing business together in April 1987, when Mitsubishi provided Chicago Research with $37 million in capital by purchasing subordinated bonds. Those bonds were rolled over last year, when Mitsubishi increased its money outstanding to Chicago Research to $45 million. **********A Mitsubishi Trust official in New York, Makoto Oikawa, referred requests for comment to Mitsubishi Trust's headquarters in Tokyo. Because the announcement was made in the middle of the night in Japan, there was no answer there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/17/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East;   17 Nations Plan to Relax Rules on Exports to East
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/17/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East;   17 Nations Plan to Relax Rules on Exports to East
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/17/world.body_text: **********A watchdog group including Western nations has agreed to begin relaxing controls on the export of advanced technology to Eastern Europe, but the United States has insisted that some of the concessions not yet apply to the Soviet Union, Western officials said today. **********Since the 17-nation group known as Cocom makes its decisions by consensus, the officials said, Washington was also able to block proposals by Western European countries for greater flexibility towards the entire East bloc during a two-day meeting here. **********Some Western European officials complained privately that Washington still views East-West trade through a cold war prism and ignores the needs of emerging Eastern European democracies for modern technology. They argued that a ''two speed'' approach limiting concessions to the Soviet Union would be impractical and bureaucratic. **********Although numerous Western European countries are already scrambling to take advantage of the new business opportunities opening up in the East, the United States seems determined not to be rushed. **********Unable to agree on most specifics, the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls decided instead this week to set political guidelines for the future, including plans for a major review of the products subject to its export controls. **********But Cocom, which is made up of 14 Western European countries, the United States, Japan and Australia, did reach these three basic agreements: *********** To reduce from 12 weeks to 8 weeks the time that Cocom takes to review requests by Western companies for permits to export sensitive items to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. *********** To ease curbs on the sale of computers, precision machine tools and telecommunications equipment to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Such goods account for about half of the 1,500 or so items whose export is controlled and for about 80 percent of the license applications. *********** To examine requests by Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia for preferential treatment in exchange for pledges and verification mechanisms to insure that technology with potential military applications does not reach the Soviet Union. **********Western officials said that several Western European governments, notably West Germany and France, had argued in favor of a more ambitious across-the-board reduction of Cocom's list of sensitive items. France was also rebuffed in its bid to have controls relaxed on the export of civilian aircraft, they said. **********''We reached agreement on a basic approach,'' one United States official said. ''This will enhance access to Western technology for legitimate civilian purposes for the regimes of Eastern Europe which have embarked on a democratic reform process.'' **********In Washington, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Deputy Secretary of State, told listeners today at the United States Chamber of Commerce that ''the Government understands Cocom has to adjust.'' **********But some industry spokesmen expressed disappointment that more was not achieved this week. **********''It appears the net effect is we have the same restrictions that existed last Monday,'' said Willard A. Workman, Director of Foreign International Policy and Programs at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. ''There is no change.'' **********''I think the United States defused a potentially explosive situation,'' said Debra L. Waggoner, manager of international trade policies at the American Electronics Association. ''But it is still moving too slowly and runs the risk of causing serious deterioration to Cocom.'' **********Awaiting Free Elections **********The results of the review to be carried out by the United States are to be presented to Cocom here in June. By then several Eastern European countries theoretically will have held free elections, and efforts toward German reunification may have set the stage for a change in East Germany's status. **********''At the moment, East Germany is still a a separate entity and a proscribed destination,'' a senior State Department official said in Washington. ''What it will be in three months, I don't know. I don't have the gift of clairvoyance.'' **********As in the past, secrecy characterized the Cocom meeting this week. Government delegations refused to say where the conference was being held, no public statement was issued on the results, and official briefers insisted that their names not be published. **********But while Cocom has played a central role in the West's strategy towards the Soviet bloc over the past 41 years, political experts predicted that the organization would face growing pressure to change - not only from Eastern European governments, but from Western companies anxious for profit. **********Among the major corporations already making bids or seeking opportunities in telecommunications, where Eastern European countries are dramatically behind, are American Telephone and Telegraph, Ericsson of Sweden, Siemens of West Germany and Alcatel of France. **********Until now, the only significant relaxation of controls by Cocom involved exports to China since 1985, a move that was backed by the United States. The looser export policy has allowed many American companies to play an important and lucrative role in development of the Chinese economy. **********Several Western European Governments are hoping that Eastern European countries will soon be given even more flexible treatment than enjoyed by China, officials said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/busin.print_headline: Six Accused In $3.7 Million Insider Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/busin.body_text: **********Government lawyers in New York and Washington yesterday accused a former associate at a prominent New York law firm, his sister and four others of earning at least $3.75 million from illegal insider trading from 1984 to 1988. **********Prosecutors said the conduit for the confidential information was Steven L. Glauberman, a 39-year-old associate of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. Mr Glauberman resigned last month from the law firm, where he specialized in mergers and acquisitions. **********He purportedly traded and passed information on 29 takeovers and corporate restructurings of some of the firm's most notable clients, including Morgan Stanley, the Hospital Corporation of America, Bristol-Myers, National Gypsum, Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., the Allied Corporation and the McKesson Corporation. **********Civil Charges Settled **********William R. McLucas, head of the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said that Mr. Glauberman had settled civil insider trading charges. He is said to be cooperating with Federal prosecutors in Manhattan, who yesterday filed four criminal counts against him. **********The charges were a further embarrassment to Skadden, Arps, which is New York's largest law firm and one of the nation's most prominent takeover players. In recent years, it has seen several of its employees leave after the Government found they had traded on confidential client information. **********''We feel we're a victim,'' said Earle Yaffa, the managing director at Skadden, Arps. ''It's impossible when somebody who is trusted and relied upon to work on these things misuses the information at his disposal.'' **********Government lawyers said the bulk of the trades occurred after Mr. Glauberman sold the information to his broker, Eben P. Smith, who was then at the Stamford, Conn., office of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. Mr. Smith is accused in the case of buying the information for $50,000. Government officials said the two men had long had a close friendship. Mr. Glauberman is the godfather of one of Mr. Smith's children. **********The S.E.C. complaint said that Mr. Smith had set up a special account for Mr. Glauberman that was liquidated a day after Mr. Glauberman received a subpoena from the agency. **********Mr. Smith's lawyer, Robert Anello, declined to comment yesterday on the charges filed by the S.E.C. and the seven-count indictment against his client. Mr. Anello said that Mr. Smith had left Smith Barney in 1988 and gone to Gruntal & Company, where he recently resigned. **********Data Passed to Others **********Prosecutors said Mr. Smith traded on the information and also passed it to Peter H. Jeffer, an independent arbitrager, in exchange for Mr. Jeffer's business with Smith Barney. Mr. Smith was also accused of passing the information to Stanley Patrick and Anthony Correra, two of Mr. Jeffer's employees, who used it to trade for themselves and their clients. **********Mr. McLucas of the S.E.C. said Mr. Jeffer and Mr. Correra had also settled civil charges filed in New York by the commission. The S.E.C. said it had waived financial penalties against Mr. Jeffer, his company and Mr. Glauberman because they did not have the money to pay. The two men have agreed to be permanently barred from working in the securities industry. **********Sister Settles Charges **********Mr. Glauberman also purportedly shared the information with his sister, Lori Glauberman, an associate director in the preferred stock department at Bear, Stearns & Company. She has settled S.E.C. charges that she used the information in at least 11 instances, realizing profits of $19,135.92. Under the settlement, she will pay fines and disgorgement of $38,271.84 and be barred from the securities industry. **********Mr. Jeffer is expected to plead guilty to one criminal count of wire fraud that was announced yesterday by Federal prosecutors in New York. **********The prosecutors said that a grand jury had handed up indictments against Mr. Smith on seven felony counts of conspiracy and securities fraud and against Mr. Patrick on four similar counts. Mr. Patrick's lawyer, Robert L. Ellis, was on vacation yesterday and could not be reached for comment. **********Each of the criminal counts carries a maximum prison penalty of five years and a fine of either $250,000 or twice the illegal profits earned through the scheme.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/17/busin.body_text: **********Hanson P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed with Sir James Goldsmith to swap its 49 percent interest in the Newmont Mining Company for Cavenham Forest Industries. Cavenham, a large United States forest products company, is controlled by the British-French financier. **********Hanson, the giant British conglomerate, said that under the agreement it would sell its stake in Newmont to companies controlled by Sir James for $1.11 billion in cash and $189 million in notes. Newmont is the largest gold-mining company in North America. Sir James, in turn, is to sell Hanson two companies, General Oriental Securities Ltd. and Hornwood Barbados Ltd., whose principal holding is Cavenham, for $1.3 billion in cash. **********''Cavenham is a $100 million pretax earner, and it is a good, steady earner,'' said David Clarke, president of Hanson Industries, the United States arm of Hanson. ''It has very good management and large and well-groomed assets. This is a win-win situation. Now Newmont has a stable shareholder who is a passive investor.'' **********Hanson had long sought to distance itself from Newmont, which it acquired as part of its $6.5 billion purchase of Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. in August 1989. Hanson has sought to dispose of its Newmont shares to reduce the debt it took on in the Consolidated Gold Fields acquisition. **********Six weeks ago Hanson announced that Hanson Industries planned to sell 8.4 million of its Newmont common shares and 4.2 million Newmont warrants. Newmont at the time said it planned to sell 3.6 million new common shares in a public offering. The company said yesterday that it was terminating that offering, which analysts had expected to run into trouble because of unfavorable market conditions. **********Last week, Hanson said it had decided not to set a price for its secondary offering of Newmont because of the decline in Newmont's stock price. The stock, which traded early last week at $40, closed at $34.75 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, down 25 cents. Hanson's stock closed at $18.50, down 25 cents, on the Big Board. **********Under the terms of a standstill agreement, Hanson said Newmont had the right of first refusal to match a cash offer for Hanson's stake within 60 days. **********Cavenham was acquired by Sir James as part of the 1986 purchase of portions of Crown Zellerbach. The forest products concern is now the sixth-largest private owner of timberland in the United States and the nation's 12th-largest lumber producer. 1.7 Million Acres Owned Cavenham has 1.7 million acres of timberland, principally in Oregon, Washington, Mississippi and Louisiana. The company also operates five timber sawmills, as well as oil and gas properties in Louisiana. The company reported sales of $275.5 million and pretax profits of about $97 million for the fiscal year ended March 31. General Oriental and Hornwood had combined net assets of about $1.6 billion at the end of September. **********Hanson will remain in the gold business, through its interest in Gold Fields Mining, a major gold company based in Denver. It has mining properties in Nevada and California. **********People close to Sir James said yesterday that the financier was attracted to the deal because he wanted to place his assets in a more liquid holding and that he considered that the gold mining industry offered such an opportunity. **********Hanson's holdings in Britain include Imperial Tobacco, Ever Ready batteries and London Brick. In the United States, Hanson's interests include the SCM Organic Chemicals Corporation, Peabody Coal, Jacuzzi whirlpool bath products and Farberware cookware.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/30/busin.main_headline: A Chip Patent Is Granted That May Rewrite History
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   A Chip Patent Is Granted That May Rewrite History
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/30/busin.body_text: **********In a shock to the computer industry, a virtually unknown California inventor has been issued a patent that he says covers a fundamental development of the computer revolution - the microprocessor. **********After a 20-year struggle, Gilbert P. Hyatt, an inventor in Southern California, was granted a patent for a design for building a computer on a single chip. Mr. Hyatt filed for the patent in 1970 based on work he started in 1968. **********Attorneys and computer companies were studying the patent today to determine its significance, which could turn out to be far less than Mr. Hyatt hopes. But lawyers said Mr. Hyatt could collect millions of dollars of royalties over the next 17 years from manufacturers of the chips. **********The development could also entail rewriting the history books of the electronics industry. Credit for inventing the microprocessor has generally been given to Ted Hoff, who developed the first such chip at the Intel Corporation in 1971. Texas Instruments Corporation, however, also has a fundamental microprocessor patent issued in the early 1970's. **********The ability to cram the basic functions of a computer onto a single chip gave rise to personal computers and allowed programmable features to be added to electronic devices ranging from microwave ovens and videocassette recorders. A chip is typically a piece of silcon that contains microscopic electronic circuits that are the building blocks of computers and other electronic devices. **********''It looks to me that it's broad,'' said Gary Hecker, a Los Angeles patent attorney who has seen Mr. Hyatt's patent. ''It could be sufficiently broad to cover basic microprocessor design.'' But he added that there appears to be plenty of areas where the patent could be challenged. **********Michael Slater, editor of Microprocessor Report, an industry newsletter, said he did not think the patent covered microprocessors but other chips known as microcontrollers. **********Mr. Hyatt's patent, Mr. Slater said, is for a chip containing both the processor and memory needed for a computer. Microcontrollers have both these features and are used in a variety of electronic appliances. Microprocessors generally only contain the processor, not the memory. **********Big Markets Involved **********Microcontrollers represent a larger market than microprocessors. Worldwide sales this year of microcontrollers will be about $3.4 billion and sales of microprocessors about $2.1 billion, according to Dataquest, a market research firm. **********Intel and Motorola Inc. are the leading microprocessor manufacturers. Motorola is the leading maker of microcontollers. But numerous other semiconductor companies make one or both types of the chips. It is also possible that Mr. Hyatt's patent would entitle him to collect royalties from users of such chips, like personal computer manufacturers. **********Spokeswomen for Intel and Motorola said their attorneys were reviewing the patent and that they did not yet have any comment. The patent was issued in July, but not publicized until this week. **********Mr. Hyatt, who is 52 years old, said he began work on the computer chip in 1968 when he started a company called Micro Computer Inc. He said the company closed in 1971 because of a dispute with its venture capital investors before he could make such a chip. Since then, he said, he has been supporting his work as an inventor by consulting for aerospace companies. **********''I always had confidence that we would set history straight,'' he said. **********Mr. Hyatt, who lives in La Palma, outside Los Angeles, said he hoped to license the patent at reasonable rates to provide financing for his research. He said he was negotiating a joint venture with a ''major manufacturer'' that would license his patents and would then try to license them to others. ''Nobody is interested in litigation,'' he said. **********Analysts said if Mr. Hyatt set his rates low enough, he might get what for him would be significant revenue without hurting chip companies. But if he asks for large amounts, he will no doubt be challenged. **********Susan Nycum, a computer attorney in Palo Alto, Calif., said the new patent appears to predate Texas Instruments' patent. That could weaken the hand of the Dallas company, which is now seeking royalty payments from many personal computer companies, based in part on its microprocessor patent. **********In relation to this effort, Texas Instruments has sued Zenith Data Systems and two Korean personal computer manufacturers, Samsung and Daewoo, for patent infringement. A Texas Instruments spokesman said the company didn't think the Hyatt patent would affect its litigation. **********Long Wait for Patents **********Attorneys said it was unusual but not unprecedented for a patent to take so long to issue. Gordon Gould was issued a patent in 1977 for a laser he invented as a graduate student in the late 1950's, and has since been pursuing royalty collection. And the Japanese patent office in November finally issued Texas Instruments a patent for the integrated circuit it had been seeking since 1960. **********Other inventors have also waged long struggles. Only last month, Robert W. Kearns won a $5.2 million jury verdict against the Ford Motor Company, related to Mr. Kearns's development of intermittent windshield wipers about 20 years ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.main_headline: Iacocca Says He Will Stay At Chrysler's Helm Past '91
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.print_headline: Iacocca Says He Will Stay At Chrysler's Helm Past '91
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.body_text: **********Seeking to allay concerns among investors, dealers and employees that a leadership vacuum could develop at the Chrysler Corporation, Lee A. Iacocca said today that he would stay on as chairman beyond December 1991. **********The 65-year-old executive had previously said he would make a decision on his retirement by the end of 1991, when his current contract expires. **********Mr. Iacocca's decision to stay came at Chrysler's regular monthly board meeting today in New York. No retirement date was set, and a spokesman for the company said board members had not yet negotiated a new contract with Mr. Iacocca. **********Automotive analysts expressed dismay last week when Chrysler's vice chairman, Gerald Greenwald, resigned. Mr. Greenwald signed a five-year contract to become chairman and chief executive of UAL Inc., which owns United Airlines, if financing can be lined up for the proposed employee buyout of UAL. **********Two other top Chrysler executives, the corporate treasurer and an executive vice president, announced plans in recent weeks to leave. While Chrysler appeared to handle those departures in stride, Mr. Greenwald's decision seemed to rattle Wall Street, and some analysts expressed concern that the company's management lacked depth and experience. **********''Clearly there is a crisis of confidence among the white-collar rank and file, dealers and, to some extent, investors,'' said Joseph S. Phillippi, an automotive analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton. **********Robert M. Barboza, who owns a Chrysler-Plymouth dealership in Raynham, Mass., said: ''It's good that he isn't leaving with auto business tough as it is, because he is a seasoned auto pro. There are people who can do Mr. Greenwald's job, but Mr. Iacocca is very essential for us to keep selling cars.'' **********''With Iacocca at the helm, we feel kind of stable,'' said Aaron Taylor, president of Local 7 of the United Automobile Workers union, which represents 3,500 unemployed hourly workers whose hope for the future depends on an unfinished Chrysler plant in Detroit. **********In a statement issued by the company, Mr. Iacocca, who earned $1.4 million in salary and bonus last year, said one of his primary responsibilities would be to arrive at an orderly succession plan. ''We're going to do that according to our own timetable, and it won't be driven by a big X on a calendar,'' he said. **********Chrysler wasted little time dividing Mr. Greenwald's management duties among other ranking executives. But today's announcement is likely to go further in calming the jitters of nervous investment analysts, many of whom said last week that they had hoped for a signal from Mr. Iacocca that he would stay past 1991. **********More Competition Expected **********''I think this is an indication that Iacocca will be more of a hands-on manager than he has been in the last few years,'' said David Healy, an auto industry analyst for Barclays Bank in New York. ''He has said the 90's are going to be so highly competitive. I think he still wants to be there to run the show.'' **********In the current competition for American car and truck buyers, Chrysler has been bloodied more than its rivals. Chrysler's market share for the first five months of the year stands at 8.9 percent, nearly two full points below the 10.7 percent market share it posted through May of last year. **********The company's decision to drop its subcompact Omni and Horizon models and reduce sales to rental fleets accounts for a portion of the decline in market share. But Chrysler has also been losing ground in the remainder of its car models. Even more worrisome to Chrysler is the new competition to its mini-vans and Jeeps, which have been vital sources of profits. **********Chrysler stock has seesawed in the week since Mr. Greenwald made his departure official, trading between $15.375 and $16.625 before losing some of its price at the end of the week. The shares rose 12.5 cents each today, closing at $16.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/25/world.main_headline: Unrest in Ivory Coast's Capital Turns to Violence
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/25/world.print_headline: Unrest in Ivory Coast's Capital Turns to Violence
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/25/world.body_text: **********A week of growing anti-Government protests turned violent today for the first time as fierce confrontations erupted between crowds of youths and heavily armed police officers and soldiers. **********Witnesses said the crowds attacked vehicles and blocked streets in protest against hardships they say have resulted from President Felix Houphouet-Boigny's economic measures. Some of the protesters here reportedly carried placards with Mr. Houphouet-Boigny's photo and distributed leaflets accusing him and members of his Government of corruption. **********Several hundred youths also marched through the central Boulevard de la Republique, chanting ''Liberty!'' and ''Free our comrades!'' and demanding the President's resignation. In particular, some of the protesters said they wanted a multiparty democracy. **********On Friday afternoon, about 200 students reportedly held a peaceful sit-in at St. Paul's Cathedral. The police responded early this morning with tear gas and rubber truncheons. **********The wave of criticism directed at Mr. Houphouet-Boigny is an extraordinary blow to a man who since 1960 has personally engineered the Ivory Coast's ''economic miracle.'' **********The President is relatively robust at what he says is the age of 84. But many people insist that he is closer to 90 years old. The nation shares borders with five countries, every one of them ruled by a military or authoritarian Government; a sudden void of leadership here could prove convulsive. **********Worse May Lie Ahead **********For now, whether the protests will continue and perhaps even spread seem inextricably linked to Mr. Houphouet-Boigny's economic program. And in the short term, Western diplomats and Ivory Coast analysts say they believe that further strains from the austerity measures seem certain. **********Less than a decade ago, the picture was much different. When prices of the country's main exports, coffee and cocoa, soared to record highs, the Ivory Coast used its surplus earnings to build the largest road network, the most reliable telephone system and the most skilled and educated work force in West Africa. **********But after four years of slumping commodity prices, this nation of 11 million has been plunged into its worst recession in more than 30 years. **********Discontent with the Government's economic program has been exacerbated by anomalies of prosperity and want. Some of the protesters complained about Mr. Houphouet-Boigny's decision to build a multimillion-dollar Roman Catholic basilica in his hometown, Yamoussoukro. **********The President has declined to say how much the basilica cost, insisting that he paid for it with family money. Some reports, however, have estimated that it cost as much as $200 million, and protesters said the money could have been better spent on health care and housing. **********Criticism Through Channels **********There have been other grounds lately on which Government policy has been questioned. In recent weeks, Mr. Houphouet-Boigny has refused to even consider the increasing calls for a multiparty democracy, insisting that this would endanger national unity. **********At the same time, he has said that Government critics are free to voice their opinions within the existing political structure. **********But for now, the state-controlled newspapers and radio stations have completely blacked out news of the protests, which began Monday. Student protesters say this amounts to censorship, and is an apt illustration of why they are trying to open up the political process.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/busin.body_text: **********Attracted by the hope of bargains, real estate investors and prospective home buyers are jamming the phone lines of the Government agency that this week began selling billions of dollars' worth of properties owned by failed savings institutions. **********But it is questionable whether the program, which promises to be the largest real estate sale in the nation's history, will result in as many bargains as buyers might hope, real estate experts and Government officials said yesterday. The program will bring thousands of houses, condominium apartments, office buildings, shopping centers and other properties onto the national market, perhaps further depressing prices in already glutted markets like the Southwest. **********But Government officials say they are determined to make sales in an orderly manner. And they note that they must sell each property for at least 95 percent of its appraised value, as the bailout bill requires. **********Where Opportunities Are **********''There are going to be opportunities, but they aren't going to be in buying at a deep discount,'' said Stan Ross, the co-managing partner of Kenneth Leventhal & Company, a real estate consulting firm in Los Angeles. ''The opportunities are going to be in the ability of buyers to sort through and identify properties that they can work on and create more value.'' **********Real estate executives said, however, that many properties would prove unattractive to potential buyers, particularly apartment complexes and small office buildings, and that the Government may be unrealistic in believing that it can command full price for them. **********'Aren't All Cats and Dogs' **********''The properties aren't all cats and dogs,'' said David W. Gleeson, the president of the Lincoln Asset Management Company, one of the largest real estate concerns in Dallas. ''But it is going to be difficult to find investors. It will be a rude awakening for the Government to find that they have to lower prices.'' **********Under the program, the Resolution Trust Corporation is offering for sale residential and commercial buildings and undeveloped land owned by hundreds of insolvent savings and loan associations that have been seized by the Government. The properties are available for sale to anyone interested, from individual home buyers to huge real estate companies. **********Most of the residential properties will be listed by local realtors, which will handle them just as if they were privately owned. The commercial properties will generally be sold through regional offices of the Government agency, through the savings institutions themselves or through brokers hired by the trust agency. **********On Tuesday, the trust agency published an inventory of the more than 30,000 properties it had taken control of through Sept. 30. Since then the agency has been besieged with phone calls - 8,000 on Wednesday alone, with 200 callers on hold at any one time - as people scrambled for information on what many perceived as a fire sale. **********Texas has by far the greatest number of properties for sale - 15,750. Its neighbors in the oil patch also had high totals, with 1,575 in Oklahoma and 2,434 in Louisiana. The only other states with more than 1,000 properties on the lists are Florida, with 1,288, and Arizona, with 1,711. **********In contrast, New York had only 12, New Jersey, 11; Connecticut and Delaware, 2 each, and New Hampshire, 1, while several states had none -Maine, North Dakota, South Dakota, Vermont and West Virginia. **********Desire for a Bargain **********''There's a lot of desire out there to get a bargain,'' said Stephen Katsanos, a spokesman for Resolution Trust. ''There's a feeling that if they don't get in there now, they may miss an opportunity. But people may be disappointed when we don't accept an outlandishly low offer.'' **********The residential properties on the list encompass everything from a $4 million mansion in Malibu, Calif., to a 500-square-foot house in poor condition in Louisiana. The commercial properties include office buildings, shopping centers, hotels, stables and even boat slips. **********Mr. Katsanos said the Government's inventory of properties was continuing to swell as more institutions were taken over by regulators. He said the properties on the current list were probably less than half of what the Government would ultimately possess. **********The inventory list published this week has only skeletal information about the properties offered for sale, including a brief description of size and location. Asking prices are included for some properties, although the values have yet to be set for many of them. Most listings include the name and phone number of someone to call about purchasing the property. The others include information about which savings institution had the property and how to reach that institution. **********Toll-Free Number **********To take orders for the inventory list, the trust agency has set up a toll-free telephone number: (800) 431-0600. The complete inventory of 26,813 residential properties, 2,516 commercial properties and 794 land parcels is available for a charge of $50. The volumes containing the commercial and land properties can be purchased separately for $10 each, and separate sections listing just single-family or multifamily housing are $15 each. **********In addition to selling properties through local realtors and brokers and consultants who specialize in distressed property sales, the trust agency is also considering a number of unconventional approaches, including displaying some of the properties on cable television programs and working with a company that sets up international auctions by satellite. **********Residential properties listed by local realtors will not be distinguished from other homes and condominiums. ''In a lot of cases the buyer may not even know this is a Government property they're dealing with,'' Mr. Katsanos said. Some real estate experts are skeptical of the Government's ability to manage such a huge undertaking efficiently. ''The first piece of advice I'd give to investors is that they should go into the process with a lot of patience,'' said James W. Field, a liquidation expert at Coldwell Banker, the real estate company. ''It's going to take a lot of time and you're going to have to learn to deal with the foibles of the bureaucracy.'' **********Volume Seen Causing Chaos **********Perhaps more important, some real estate professionals said that the Government will never be able to develop a firm grasp on the value of the properties it is selling, and that the sheer volume of the properties it puts up for sale will inevitably cause chaos in the marketplace and drive prices down in some areas. **********Almost by definition, the greatest concentration of properties the Government is now trying to peddle are in those regions hardest hit by economic downturns and falling real estate prices. As a result, finding buyers for a greater number of properties without pushing prices down may be impossible, some experts said. **********For those who are interested in the properties but do not want to buy the books, the lists are also being distributed to 1,400 libraries across the country.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/19/busin.main_headline: Times Co. Profit Dropped in the 2d Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/19/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Times Co. Profit Dropped in the 2d Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/19/busin.body_text: **********The New York Times Company reported yesterday that income in the second quarter fell to $26.8 million, or 35 cents a share, down 35.1 percent from net income of $41.3 million, or 53 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1989. **********Second-quarter profits were down 31.6 percent from income from continuing operations of $39.2 million, or 50 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. **********Times Company revenues rose 1.9 percent in the quarter, to $468.9 million, from $460.3 million in the comparable period last year. **********The company said the main reasons for its lower profits were lower advertising lineage at The New York Times, which reflected continuing weakness in the New York region's economy; a reduction of 7 cents a share as a result of acquiring McCall's magazine in July 1989, a deal structured to maximize cash flow, and a reduction of 8 cents a share because of higher depreciation and interest expense related to construction. The company completed the building for The New York Times's new color production and distribution plant in Edison, N.J., and it built a plant for The Gwinnett Daily News in Georgia, one of its regional newspapers. **********Eric Philo, a publishing analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said the earnings were a little better than expected in part because of the performance of the regional newspapers. But he said economic weakness was spreading to other parts of the country, and he does not expect the regional papers to show the growth in the second half that they showed in the quarter. **********Two Special Items **********The Times Company said that except for the acquisition of McCall's and the construction expenses, second-quarter earnings would have equaled the results from continuing operations a year earlier. **********The company said operating profit in this year's second quarter for the newspaper group declined to $50.1 million from $67 million in the second quarter of 1989. The group consists of The New York Times, 35 regional newspapers and a one-third interest in The International Herald Tribune. **********Advertising volume at The New York Times declined 13.4 percent, to 24.7 million lines, in the second quarter. Average circulation for The Times in the first half reached new highs of 1,133,400 copies on weekdays, up 45,700 copies, and 1,713,200 on Sundays, up 65,100 copies. **********Advertising volume for the 35 regional newspapers increased 2.5 percent, to 9.7 million inches, in the second quarter. Circulation also increased at the regional newspapers, to 880,200 copies on Sundays, up 16,900 copies, and to 901,700 copies on weekdays, up 19,700 copies. Circulation was 77,400 for the non-dailies, up 1,000 copies. **********Profits from the company's Magazine Group were down because of the acquisition of McCall's, while results from the Broadcasting/Information Service Group held even and earnings in the Forest Products Group declined, reflecting softness in the newsprint market and unfavorable Canadian currency exchange rates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/04/world.main_headline: Beijing Journal;   A Mystical Art, but Can It Make the Lame Walk?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/04/world.print_headline: Beijing Journal;   A Mystical Art, but Can It Make the Lame Walk?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/04/world.body_text: **********Craze Sweeps the Country **********Qi gong (pronounced chee gong) is a mystical traditional art that is based on breathing exercises but extends far more broadly and is sometimes compared to a religious cult. A qi gong craze has swept China in the last few years, and more than 5 percent of China's population is now said to practice the art. Then there are thousands of qi gong masters who claim to be able to heal the sick, hold light bulbs and make them glow, turn wine into water and increase crop yields. **********As the movement has spread, with some qi gong masters gaining thousands of disciples and asserting that they can transport themselves instantaneously around the country, or that they cannot be harmed by bullets, the Government has become apprehensive. This summer the authorities instituted new restrictions on qi gong clinics, and there has been a sharp cutback on vast assemblies in which qi gong masters transmit their qi upon the multitude and cause the audience to writhe, cry, laugh or otherwise lose control. **********Qi is a vague concept that can refer to air or gas or a vague spirit or life force. Some Chinese believe that qi gong masters emit qi in the form of invisible radiation; others believe that they radiate nothing more than self-confidence. **********''It's classic end-of-dynasty stuff,'' said Geremie Barme, an Australian scholar who recently visited Beijing. ''It's superstitious, spiritual, religious, to give people an alternative to replace the structure collapsing around them.'' **********Mass Fads of the Past **********As Mr. Barme noted, China has experienced similar mass fads in the past. In the middle of the last century, for example, a Chinese with a notion of Christianity pronounced himself the brother of Jesus and led a rebellion that was crushed only after 14 years of civil war and 20 million or more deaths. **********Qi gong researchers in China estimate that the number of practitioners has soared from about 260,000 a decade ago to 60 million today. That is more than the number who practice the somewhat similar but better-known taijiquan exercises. Many Chinese begin each day with qi gong breathing exercises to relax, and such personal exercises are much less controversial than the emergence of qi gong masters with vast followings. **********However strange its variants, qi gong is not a joke: it is taken very seriously here, and some foreign experts believe that the enthusiasm for qi gong masters could pose a political challenge for the Government. The crackdown now under way may be an indication that the leadership agrees, and in July the police in Shanghai detained Zhang Xiangyu, a 47-year-old actress who was treated as a messiah by her thousands of followers. **********Miss Zhang reportedly asserted that the heavens had endowed her with what she called ''natural central qi gong'' to heal the sick, predict the future, see beneath the earth and save her disciples from natural disasters that would engulf the world. Miss Zhang earned the equivalent of hundreds of thousands of dollars by charging people to attend rallies. **********'A Modern Sorceress' **********''Natural central qi gong drips with blood, for it has driven people crazy and even sent them to their deaths,'' the official Health News declared. ''The masses know that Zhang Xiangyu is a modern sorceress who has cheated people of their money.'' **********Despite the crackdown, qi gong is still very much alive in China. Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, is said to have summoned a qi gong master to transmit qi and improve his health. The Beijing Military Region operates a qi gong clinic. **********There are various views about the effectiveness of qi gong. Some Chinese intellectuals are openly skeptical, but most Chinese seem to believe that there is something to it. **********''There is definitely something there, but we don't know what it is,'' said Lin Zhongpeng, who helped launch the ''qi gong fever'' with the establishment of a Qi Gong Study Center in 1979. Yet Mr. Lin believes that most qi gong masters are simply showmen, and he says he once pretended to transmit qi to an audience in the southern city of Guangzhou. **********''Everybody jumped around and laughed and cried,'' Mr. Lin recalled. ''And then I told them I hadn't done anything, and that they had responded simply because they believed in me. Eighty percent of those big meetings is simply psychology.'' **********A Relaxation Response **********Herbert Benson, an associate professor at Harvard Medical School who has visited China for research in this area, said by telephone that he believed that qi gong could have medical effects but that these did not necessarily have anything to do with qi. He said that for many ailments and pains, the body responds well to relaxation and a reduced metabolism. **********Qi gong tends to elicit this relaxation response, Dr. Benson said, and so tends to be helpful. But he said there are many other ways to achieve this relaxation, including meditation, prayer, taijiquan and yoga. **********''Of course qi gong works,'' he said. ''But there's nothing unique about it.'' As for the masters who claim to transmit qi, Dr. Benson is skeptical. He said that benefits may be the result of a placebo effect derived from the belief that the treatment will work, and the patient may also gain by relaxing during the treatment. **********''It may be that nothing is transmitted more than faith,'' he said.
