https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/busin.body_text: **********Despite the swift demise last week of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the ''junk bond'' market seems certain to survive, money managers, analysts and traders said. But the form that it will take is not clear, they said, and in the short term, as the Drexel network of lenders is dismantled, some highly leveraged companies will have to scramble to find new sources of financing. **********Over the next year, there will be new jolts and more volatility in the market for high-yield, high-risk securities, the experts said, as more companies default on their debts, major participants exit the market and the troubles on Wall Street curb the willingness of dealers to trade in these risky securities. **********''Once this current frenzy settles down, it could take six months to one year'' to restore order, said Peter Nadosy, managing director and head of the asset management division at Morgan Stanley & Company. **********All this, of course, means that the few companies that can raise money in the public markets will have to pay dearly for it, while financing for many other low-rated companies may be almost impossible to obtain, bankers say. Indeed, things may get much worse if the credit contraction spreads to other corners of the financial world. **********For now, many companies are considering the following alternatives to junk bonds: debt from the private placement market, which is dominated by insurance companies, equity from venture capital investors and a reduction of debt in exchange for equity. **********''Anybody who's got a bridge loan that's hung up is looking at a number of alternatives,'' said Raymond J. Lemanski, co-head of junk-bond trading at the Prudential-Bache Securities Corporation. **********That would include companies like West Point-Pepperell, Grand Union, Prime Computer and Ohio Mattress, which all used short-term ''bridge loans'' to finance takeovers and other restructurings and now need to refinance those loans. **********The experience at Morningstar Inc. is indicative of the problems these companies face. In recent weeks, bankers at B. T. Securities Inc. have been trying to restructure the finances of Morningstar, the dairy company that B. T. Securities and a group of investors acquired from the Southland Corporation in 1988. Last October, the turmoil in the junk market forced them to postpone a $150 million bond offering. **********Consequently, almost every available source of financing is being considered to help repay the bank debt. Indeed, bankers at B. T. Securities already have made a short-term bridge loan to Morningstar, are proposing a sale of some of the company's assets, are looking for potential equity investors and are trying to replace the bank debt with private financing from insurance companies, said Charles Quattrochi, a managing director at B. T. Securities. **********Whether they will be able to secure such financing and at what additional cost is not clear, said Mr. Quattrochi. ''It's a terrible time,'' he said about the markets. If the bankers and investors had known that they could not tap the junk market at the time they made the acquisition, he said, the original investment ''would have been done with a different capital structure.'' **********Because of the junk market's turmoil, many bankers expect that other low-rated companies like Morningstar will rush to the market of privately placed debt, where the current average interest rate is about 12 percent. While the cost of financing is lower than in the public market, these lenders have generally provided financing only to the strongest companies, or have exacted stiffer terms from the weaker issuers. **********Thus, investment bankers stress that many of the companies that are unable to raise money in the junk market should not expect to find credit in the private-placement market. Only the top tier of these low-rated companies will be able to raise money, they say. And these companies will have to be prepared to include stock or equity-like features as part of the transaction. **********''The marginal deal is shut out,'' said Ralph H. Fletcher, a managing director in the private finance group at Salomon Brothers. **********And after almost a decade of replacing stock with debt, some financiers now see equity as the way to save some of these over-leveraged companies. Forstmann, Little, one of the largest leveraged buyout firms, is in the final stages of raising money from its partners to invest in companies that it believes will fail from the crush of debt. **********For the companies that are able to raise money in the public junk market, the cost is already higher and likely to increase. Junk-bond investors are screening out the weaker companies and lending money only to the so-called quality junk issuers. If this flight to quality junk continues, it will be in stark contrast to the past two years, when easy credit was made available to finance poorly structured deals like Federated and Allied Stores. **********Over the past two years, one popular credit standard used by junk-bond investors - the ratio of a company's cash flow to its interest expense - fell below 1 in many offerings. But investors say that these so-called coverage ratios already are being raised as investors become more demanding. ''You won't see any more deals done at 1,'' predicted Barry G. Coffman, a portfolio manager of junk bonds at Fidelity Investments in Boston, one of the largest investors in junk bonds. ''Investors will be skeptical of deals below 1.5.'' **********But even the stronger companies face higher costs for borrowing in this market. Despite the fact that Sullivan Graphics, which recently sold $100 million in 10-year notes, had an interest coverage ratio of 1.8, its securities were priced to yield 15 percent. And the bondholders demanded restrictions on the company's ability to pay dividends or issue more debt in the future. **********''The rate was higher than we thought,'' said Nicholas Daifotis, a director at Merrill Lynch, the company's underwriter. **********And companies will no longer be able to issue any of the ''gimmicky'' securities, like the so-called deferred interest bonds that littered the junk-bond market in the past few years, market experts say. In recent years, corporate raiders used securities like zero coupon bonds and pay-in-kind bonds that either pay no current interest or pay the investor more securities instead of cash to finance their acquisitions. **********Investors now laugh when these securities are mentioned. ''Those things are out the window,'' said Mr. Nadosy of Morgan Stanley. ''You're going to have to pay real money when you do an acquisition.'' While the new caution is welcome, few on Wall Street say they believe that this purge marks the end of speculative lending. The history of markets and credit has demonstrated too clearly that speculative excesses are part of the human condition. **********The renewed emphasis on higher standards is only a small step on the ''trek to reality,'' and credit standards ultimately will slide again, said Michael C. Aronstein, chairman of Comstock Partners, a New York investment firm. Conceding that he sounded like a character in a ''bad Western,'' he added, ''Wherever a man walks, greed lives.'' **********COWARDLY FUND MANAGERS? **********In the glory days of the ''junk bond'' market, the network of investors, issuers and intermediaries celebrated their power and influence with back-slapping camaraderie at the annual Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ''predators ball'' in Beverly Hills. **********But, like Drexel, those days of bonhomie and good will are history. Two weeks ago, at a junk-bond conference hosted by Merrill Lynch & Company in Phoenix, many portfolio managers were shocked by what they described as the ''condescension'' and insults of Henry Kravis, founding partner of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company. **********Mr. Kravis's leveraged-buyout firm has used billions of dollars in junk securities to help finance the acquisitions of RJR Nabisco and other companies. **********In an after-dinner speech, Mr. Kravis accused the money managers of following a ''herd mentality'' by selling their bonds in recent months. He said that his firm and the bondholders were ''partners'' and that they should hang together during this period. **********Many in the audience inferred that Mr. Kravis was accusing them of being cowards who were swept along in a panic created by the news media. **********They also deeply resented being called partners of Mr. Kravis. As managers of other people's money, they are required to fight for the rights of bondholders. And in recent months that has placed them in an adversarial relationship with Mr. Kravis and other stockholders of highly leveraged companies. **********In ''exchange offers'' proposed by Mr. Kravis's companies, like SCI Television and Hillsborough Holdings, bondholders have been asked to swap securities with high-paying coupons for ones with a lower interest rate. Some bondholders are balking. **********Mr. Kravis's remarks may make his future dealings with investors more difficult, some people who attended the conference said. Mr. Kravis declined last week to comment. **********''That speech may come back to haunt him,'' said J. Michael Pokorny, a senior portfolio manager at Delaware Management, a Philadelphia investment firm that manages more than $3 billion of junk bonds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/21/world.main_headline: Canada Moves Closer to Pact, but Barriers Remain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/21/world.print_headline: Canada Moves Closer to Pact, but Barriers Remain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/21/world.body_text: **********Canada cleared one obstacle toward approval of the Meech Lake constitutional accord today when the Manitoba legislature began debate on the issue, but the prospects that the accord will be ratified before the deadline of midnight on Saturday appeared to be slim. **********In Winnipeg, the Manitoba capital, the Cree Indian legislator who had barred any legislative action on the accord for eight days ran out of ways of keeping the issue from debate. **********But with more delaying tactics expected in the legislature, and with more than 3,000 witnesses waiting to testify at public hearings that must be held before the pact can be approved under Manitoba law, the accord was increasingly being viewed across Canada as doomed. **********If either Manitoba or Newfoundland fails to ratify the accord before the Saturday deadline, the pact, and the provision it makes for special constitutional status for Quebec, will automatically lapse. **********Many Canadians are concerned that failure to adopt the pact will push the Quebec government into measures designed to placate the rising tide of popular support for independence in the province. At the least, the collapse of the pact is expected to set back, possibly for years, the effort to gain Quebec's formal commitment to remain a part of the Canadian confederation. **********For several days, Gary Filmon, the Manitoba Premier, has been saying that the blocking tactics of Mr. Harper, the Cree Indian, have made it impossible for the province to approve the accord before the deadline. That has appeared to leave only one alternative, an extension of the Saturday deadline. **********But constitutional experts have said that giving the two holdout provinces more time would take a constitutional amendment, passed by the national Parliament and all 10 provinces, again by Saturday midnight, to suspend a requirement in the Constitution that sets a three-year limit for approval of measures like those included in the Meech Lake pact. **********Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, who was the principal architect of the constitutional accord when it was drawn up in June 1987 has shown strain as the deadline approaches. On Monday, he sent an emissary to Winnipeg in an attempt to persuade Indian leaders that the grievances underlying Mr. Harper's blocking actions could be met through the appointment of a royal commission of inquiry, and by future constitutional measures on behalf of the country's 525,000 Indians. But the initiative was rebuffed by the Indian leaders, who said that they wanted immediate action. Today, Mr. Mulroney asked the House of Commons in Ottawa to pass a resolution urging Manitoba and Newfoundland to ratify the accord. He noted that eight provinces representing 94 percent of Canada's 26 million people have already endorsed the pact. **********''Quebec in confidence and understanding has chosen to return to the Canadian constitutional family,'' he said. ''If we do not seize this glorious chance now, who can say when it will come again?'' **********Premier Robert Bourassa of Quebec appeared equally concerned as he left a meeting on Tuesday between New England governors and eastern Canadian premiers in Mystic, Conn. Mr. Bourassa said Manitoba's leaders should meet the deadline if they wanted to keep the country united.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/20/world.main_headline: Poland's President to Step Down, Clearing Way for Free Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/20/world.print_headline: Poland's President to Step Down, Clearing Way for Free Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/20/world.body_text: **********President Wojciech Jaruzelski notified Parliament today that, as expected, he would step down shortly, paving the way for general elections to choose his successor. **********Technically, the general, who is in the second year of a six-year term, merely asked the lower house to set the date for ending his term. The lower house is expected to respond later this week. **********Though the voting procedures have yet to be determined, politicians from all factions have repeatedly said the elections could take place this fall, thus replacing the only Warsaw Pact leader besides Mikhail S. Gorbachev still in office a year after the Berlin wall was opened. **********On Monday, Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity trade union movement and challenger of Communist rule, announced his candidacy for President. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who had been nominated to his post as head of government by Mr. Walesa, is understood to be nearing a decision that would have him run against his former patron for the Presidency. **********As General Jaruzelski was, in effect, submitting his resignation to Parliament, political leaders from the factions backing Mr. Walesa and Mr. Mazowiecki completed discussions at which they agreed to press jointly for what was described as the first fully democratic ballot in postwar Poland. According to legislation to be presented in the next few days these would involve balloting for a new parliament as well as the direct election of a president. **********When General Jaruzelski won the presidential office in July 1989, he was elected by a vote of a Parliament in which only a third of the seats in the lower house were openly contested, with the rest reserved for Communists and their allies. At the time, candidates backed by Solidarity won all but one of the races in which they were permitted to run. **********Seeks to 'Promote Democracy' **********In his letter to the Speaker of the lower house of Parliament, Nikolai Kozakiewicz, General Jaruzelski said he was motivated to step down by ''concern to prevent undesirable public sentiment'' and to ''promote democracy'' in Poland. He asked Parliament to end what has turned out to have been a largely ceremonial and transitional stewardship by mandating the election of a president by universal vote, something that will require a change in Poland's Constitution. **********The move came on the eve of a session of Parliament called to discuss constitutional changes. Bronislaw Geremek, speaker of the largest bloc in Parliament, said at a news conference that Parliament would be asked to vote on measures to set the presidential election for sometime later this year, perhaps as early as November, and to set a date for fully democratic elections for a new parliament ''probably in the early spring.'' **********On Tuesday, General Jaruzelski met for a day of talks on the political situation at the residence of the Polish Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, with senior political leaders including Mr. Walesa and Prime Minister Mazowiecki. **********First of Soviet-Bloc Countries **********Though Poland in 1988 was the first of the Soviet-bloc countries to turn its back on Communism, with the appointment of Mr. Mazowiecki to head the first non-Communist government in Eastern Europe since the early postwar years, the nation's Parliament, unlike similar bodies in Hungary, Czechoslovakia and East Germany, has never been elected in fully free voting. Instead, seating in the lower house, on which Mr. Mazowiecki's authority rests, springs from an agreement reached in April 1988, when Solidarity and the governing Communist Party reached a pact at arduous round-table discussions on dividing up the seats in Parliament. **********Mr. Mazowiecki's policies, particularly on the economic front, are facing a serious test. The Persian Gulf crisis, with its upward thrust on energy prices, has upset the reckoning of Government economists. Moreover, two days of talks with visiting Soviet trade officials this week disclosed that future economic relations with the Soviet Union, Poland's largest trading partner, will be increasingly difficult as both countries move toward putting their trade on a hard-currency basis. **********This week's events were forced in large measure by Mr. Walesa, who led the industrial strife in 1988 that led to relegalization of his trade union, which had been crushed by martial law under General Jaruzelski, and forced the Communist leaders to the bargaining table. In recent months, Mr. Walesa, from his union stronghold in Gdansk, on the northern Baltic sea coast, has grown critical of Mr. Mazowiecki's Government, attacking its severe economic austerity program for not moving fast enough in some areas and not protecting workers sufficiently. **********At his news conference, Mr. Geremek advocated that elections for Parliament be held in the spring after the Presidential balloting since that would allow Mr. Mazowiecki and his team of economic advisers to put the main elements of economic policy in place, including the formulation of a 1991 budget.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Executive Raises Stake in Ultimate
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/busin.body_text: **********Norman Elowitz, a New York fashion executive, has raised his stake in the Ultimate Corporation to 8.4 percent from 7.2 percent. Between May 1 and June 5, Mr. Elowitz bought 64,500 shares for $5.25 to $7.125 each. The company's stock slipped 25 cents today, to $6.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Elowitz, the chief executive of Honey Fashions Ltd., reiterated his earlier statement that he was ''contemplating making another offer to Ultimate.'' The executive offered to acquire Ultimate in February for $10 a share, or $94.9 million, but the management of the computer concern, based in East Hanover, N.J., rejected the bid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/busin.body_text: **********Oil prices approached $40 a barrel and gasoline and heating oil topped $1 a gallon yesterday in sometimes frenzied futures trading. **********Traders scrambled to buy supplies after President Saddam Hussein of Iraq threatened on Sunday to order attacks on oilfields in Saudi Arabia, other Arab countries and Israel unless a United Nations embargo against his country was lifted. **********Crude for November delivery traded as high as $39.20 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange before retreating in the afternoon to settle at $38.25, up $2.82 for the day. It was one of the largest single-day increases in seven and a half years of trading on the exchange, and marked the ninth straight trading day that the November contract had risen, for a total rise of $8.38. **********Impact on Other Markets **********The jump in oil prices had an impact on other financial markets, with the Dow Jones industrial average off by nearly 60 points. Also, gold prices were up sharply, and long-term interest rates rose to their highest levels in 18 months. [Pages D16 and D17.]  Increasingly hawkish statements by Iraqi leaders on Thursday, Friday and Sunday have sent oil prices spiraling upward after about two weeks of relative stability and small daily increases. **********Sunday's announcement particularly alarmed the many traders and brokers who had assumed that Iraq would go to war only if attacked, said Virginia Wiater, an energy futures broker for United Energy Inc., a New York brokerage. ''That just made everybody completely cuckoo,'' she said. **********About $39 in Informal Deals **********In a further sign of price pressure, traders making informal oil deals after the close of trading on the mercantile exchange were agreeing to prices of about $39 a barrel, said Robert F. Murphy, an energy futures broker at Lehman Brothers Inc. ''Even without war, and without the destruction of the oilfields, we could reach $40'' in trading today, he added, declining to speculate on how high prices might go if war did break out. **********Comparing current prices with those prevailing during the oil shocks of 1973 and 1979 is difficult because most oil was then shipped under long-term contracts rather than being traded on markets, and because prices in general have risen in the last decade. **********The highest price paid for comparable oil was $39.80 on March 29, 1980, said Peter C. Beutel, an oil price analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., a consulting firm in Hoboken, N.J. Adjusted for inflation over the last 10 years, that is comparable to nearly $65 now. **********Heating oil for October delivery rose yesterday by 6.71 cents a gallon, to $1.0392, on the mercantile exchange, while October gasoline rose 6.78 cents a gallon, to $1.0423. The contracts for crude oil delivery in December through March all rose the limit of $1.50 a barrel, while heating oil and gasoline contracts for November through March all rose the limit of 4 cents a gallon. **********Jet fuel prices set a record of $466 a metric ton in deals struck yesterday in Europe, far surpassing the previous mark of $420 a ton, set on Jan. 3, 1980, said John H. Kingston, the managing editor of Platt's Oilgram Price Report, a daily New York newsletter. Jet fuel is traded in direct deals between refiners and airlines rather than on a commodity exchange, and jet fuel has been in particularly short supply for the last month because a large refinery in Kuwait was one of the world's main producers. **********Quick Effect Expected **********The recent sharp increase in oil prices is likely to affect consumers quickly, although the direct effect on politically sensitive gasoline prices may be muted. Oil companies are marking up the prices of jet and diesel fuel and heating oil quickly, while accepting much-reduced profit margins on sales of gasoline, said Theodore R. Eck, the chief economist of the Amoco Corporation in Chicago. **********Rising jet and diesel fuel prices are passed on to consumers by airlines, in the form of higher ticket prices, and by trucking companies that must charge more for transporting food and other goods to stores. **********The price of a standard 42-gallon barrel of crude oil has risen from 40 cents a gallon to 91 cents since July 1, including yesterday's sharp increase, said Neil T. Geary, a spokesman for Amoco. During the same period, Amoco has increased the average price it charges to service stations and wholesalers by 21.5 cents a gallon for gasoline and 27.5 cents a gallon for heating oil, he added. Amoco's jet fuel prices have typically climbed about 37 cents a gallon, although increases for specific airlines have varied widely depending on whether they had long-term contracts. **********But Edwin S. Rothschild, the energy policy director at Citizen Action, a consumer group based in Washington, said that oil companies could afford to increase gasoline prices slowly now because they raised them slightly during the first six months of this year, when crude oil prices fell $5 a barrel. ''They're already ahead of the game,'' he added. **********Changes in Payment Practices **********Rises in crude oil prices have affected consumers more quickly in recent years in part because of changes in the payment practices of oil companies. Imported oil meets about half of the needs of the United States, and most of this oil is now paid for by the companies when it arrives at an American port, instead of when it is loaded aboard tankers at jetties in the exporting country. **********As a result, four-fifths of the imported oil pumped at Amoco service stations has belonged to the company for only the five to seven days that it takes to refine the oil, ship it by pipeline and truck to the dealer, and store it in the dealer's tank until sold to American drivers, Mr. Eck said. In the early 1980's, Amoco paid for oil when it was loaded and owned the shipment during the tanker trip to the United States, which lasts four to six weeks for journeys from the Middle East.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/20/world.main_headline: Canadians In Kuwait Quit their Embassy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/20/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS;   Canadians In Kuwait Quit their Embassy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/20/world.body_text: **********Canada announced today that its five remaining diplomats had abandoned the country's embassy in Kuwait and had arrived in Baghdad. **********The action left the British, French and United States embassies as the only ones still open in Kuwait, in defiance of Iraq's annexation and order that all embassies in Kuwait be shut down. Iraqi troops have deployed around the missions, and water, electricity and food have been cut off. **********A spokesman for Canada's External Affairs Department said that its diplomats had only enough fuel to run a generator several hours a day and that their food was virtually exhausted. **********External Affairs Minister Joe Clark said in a statement, ''It is no longer feasible for them to remain given available supplies, which are nearing exhaustion, and to stay would jeopardize their health.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/26/busin.main_headline:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

Car Makers Push Fuel Efficiency
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/26/busin.print_headline:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

Car Makers Push Fuel Efficiency
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/26/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: LIKE tentative swimmers, Cadillac and Chrysler are testing the waters of public concern about fuel economy by modifying their advertising to promote the fuel efficiency of their cars. **********LIKE tentative swimmers, Cadillac and Chrysler are testing the waters of public concern about fuel economy by modifying their advertising to promote the fuel efficiency of their cars. **********Cadillac, a division of the General Motors Corporation, and the Chrysler Corporation have added some new taglines and titles in television and print ads that had been completed before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and the price of oil and gasoline surged. **********Chrysler's changes are designed primarily to attract buyers looking for the most fuel-efficient cars and trucks made by an American auto maker. Cadillac's changes are aimed at reassuring prospective customers who may be having second thoughts about buying a large car. **********But the two auto makers have been reluctant to push the theme too hard because they are concerned a more vocal approach could backfire and end up heightening fears of impending gasoline shortages. And that could hurt sales even more. **********So Chrysler has added one line at the bottom of its ''Advantage: Chrysler'' ads calling attention to its corporate average fuel economy, which is higher than either G.M.'s or that of the Ford Motor Company. **********''That line was in response to the perception that there was going to be a fuel shortage,'' said Tom Houston, a spokesman for Chrysler. **********Cadillac has revamped some of its television and print ads to play up the Environmental Protection Agency's certification that 1991 Cadillacs can go a little more than 26 miles on a gallon of gas under highway driving conditions, an improvement of one mile a gallon over last year's models. Cadillac's six models get 16 miles a gallon in city driving, unchanged from last year. **********Cadillac executives seized on the highway mileage improvement, accomplished largely by adding smoother-shifting transmissions and new fuel-injection systems, to update their pitch for big cars. A new tagline about the Cadillac being ''as responsible to own as they are responsive to drive'' was patched on to some of the division's television commercials, intended to reassure prospective buyers that they would not be out of step with the times by purchasing a Cadillac. **********''Availability and price of gas doesn't affect luxury car buyers much in their purchasing decisions,'' said Peter R. Levin, director of advertising for Cadillac. ''But many still had memories of previous oil crises, and they did not want to project an image of being irresponsible by purchasing a luxury car.'' **********Cadillac's changes were made based on a survey of luxury car owners in seven major cities a week after the Iraqi invasion. **********''Initially, our 1991 product advertising focused only on the performance aspects of our new engines,'' Mr. Levin said. **********But, he added, ''We don't want to overdo the message about fuel economy because that might cause a sense of panic or discourage people from deciding to buy a luxury car altogether.'' **********Most car companies say they are content to run commercials developed before the Persian Gulf crisis drove up the price of gasoline by more than 20 cents a gallon. With the American appetite for big, less-efficient cars, pickup trucks and mini-vans as keen as ever, auto makers apparently do not risk being penalized in the marketplace for pushing the performance, styling and reliability of their vehicles. **********Some Japanese manufacturers say they are already well positioned with cars that are at least widely perceived as being fuel efficient. **********''There's no need for us to shift our advertising,'' said David W. Danzer, corporate marketing manager for Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A., ''because our customers tell us that fuel economy is already one of their highest considerations in choosing a Toyota.'' **********Still, the overall fuel economy of many Japanese manufacturers' fleets has slipped in the last two years as the cars they sell in the United States have grown larger and heavier. **********Mr. Levin said Cadillac did not plan to redo its ad campaign for 1991, but it might tinker further with the fuel economy theme if war broke out in the Persian Gulf and fuel prices soared. **********''In normal times, a V-8 engine is a key signal to luxury car buyers,'' said the Cadillac advertising manager. Cadillac now promotes itself as the only luxury car line besides Rolls-Royce to offer V-8 engines as standard equipment in all of its models. **********''But if the situation worsened, we might not want to emphasize that,'' Mr. Levin said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/24/world.body_text: **********On the day this week that the spiritual leader of thousands of Kashmiri Muslims was shot dead by unknown assassins, India's special minister for Kashmir, George Fernandes, was on his way to Cairo to deliver a letter to President Hosni Mubarak. **********Mr. Fernandes arrived on the heels of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, who has just completed an eight-nation tour of the Islamic Middle East. She was asking for Islamic solidarity against India. **********An Indian-Pakistani diplomatic war, fought by envoys from Washington to Beijing, has been gaining intensity over several months. But so far it has been a war of accusations rather than a debate over objectives. What each side wants, and why, is not always clear to governments outside this region, diplomats say. A Campaign of Repression?  Islamic Pakistan asserts that India has unleashed a military campaign of repression against the Muslim majority in the Kashmir Valley, where alienation from New Delhi has been growing for three years and where many people want to exercise the right, denied them for 40 years, to choose whether they want to be part of India. **********This week those charges were intensified as Indian paramilitary forces fired into a crowd of mourners carrying the body of the slain Muslim cleric, Maulvi Mohammed Farooq, from the hosptial to his religious headquarters in Srinigar, the capital of Kashmir, on Monday. Dozens of people died. **********In Srinagar today, witnesses told reporters that there had been no exchange of fire between troops and militants, as Indian authorities have insisted in describing the troops' action as self-defense. **********In New Delhi, officials regard the question of Kashmir's future a matter over which there can be no debate. The problem, they say, has become simply one of Pakistani support for armed militants. They say that until Islamabad stops that support, there can be no hope of negotiations inside Kashmir or with Pakistan. **********Three Border Wars **********But beneath the surface, politicians on both sides of the border say, there are other motivations and other reasons for the standoff between two countries that have fought three wars along the Kashmir border. **********In Pakistan, resentment has festered for nearly 20 years over India's support for a Bengali Muslim independence movement that in 1971 - with the help of the invading Indian Army -created Bangladesh out of what had been East Pakistan. **********Over the last decade, not only Pakistan, but also Bangladesh, Nepal and Sri Lanka have watched as India backed other guerrilla armies in the region, most prominently the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam in the Sri Lankan Northeast. Indian intelligence agencies have also supported guerrilla groups in the Chittagong Hills in Bangladesh. Pakistan fears Indian influence in its already troubled province of Sind. **********A Chance for Revenge **********''So here in Kashmir, Pakistan has the perfect opportunity to pay us back,'' an Indian politician said. ''They have only to give enough support to keep an insurgency running for a long time.'' **********For India, the Kashmir situation is fraught with so much potential danger that the Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh seems unwilling or unable to gamble on bold political moves - including opening the border between Indian Kashmir and the Pakistani part of the region or talking with Islamabad about how to build a new political entity in Kashmir that would satisfy both countries. India seems intent on crushing the revolt by force before looking for the roots of the problem. **********The Singh Government is supported by a Hindu-based party that includes people willing to press a case against Muslims anywhere. **********The Kashmir Valley is only about a third of India's Jammu and Kashmir state, and the only Islamic area -Jammu is largely Hindu and Ladakh is Buddhist. But Kashmir's population is large enough to make Jammu and Kashmir the only Indian state with a Muslim majority. It is important to India's image as a secular nation with religious freedom to have a predominantly Muslim state. **********Furthermore, in India, religion is an explosive subject even in normal times. There is always the danger that the crisis in Kashmir will set off conflagrations elsewhere. Several thousand people died at the hands of Hindu mobs last fall in several Indian states because of a dispute over a mosque in Ayodhya over which Hindus wanted to construct a temple. **********Economic and Political Issues **********Kashmiris argue, however, that their problems with India are not religious, but economic and political. They and their supporters in Pakistan accuse India of emphasizing their religion in order to undermine their cause in the West, where Asian Muslims often believe there is a prejudice against them. **********The Kashmir Valley, which India had been developing as one of its prime tourist areas, suffered from a low investment level in industry, gorwing unemployment, poor communications, limited air services and inadequate roads connect it with to the rest of India. People here have come to believe that the produce of their orchards and farms might move more quickly through Pakistan. **********Buddhists Ladakhis have similar complaints. Apricots not available anywhere in Indian cities ripen and rot on Ladakhi hillsides for lack of refrigerated airfreight services. **********Under Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and her son and successor, Rajiv, New Delhi began interfering with Kashmir's internal politics, ultimately dominating the National Conference, the last Kashmiri party with any claim to Kashmiri nationalism. As a result, many Kashmiris were pushed outside mainstream politics. A 1987 state election, which more or less everyone admits was rigged in favor of Mr. Gandhi's Congress Party and its National Conference allies, provided recruits for new militant groups. **********An Indian attack on Pakistan will not solve these problems, say citizens groups here and in Islamabad who are beginning to fear an accidental war that neither side wants. Both sides accuse each other of massing troops. Both fear the coming of summer, when snows melt in the border mountain ranges and a season conducive to both military maneuvers and guerrilla infiltration begins.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/busin.main_headline: Continental's Risks in a Chapter 11 Filing
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/busin.print_headline: Continental's Risks in a Chapter 11 Filing
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/busin.body_text: **********The words "Chapter 11" have never helped a company's public image. The question facing executives of Continental Airlines is just how serious the damage will be. **********In filing for bankruptcy protection yesterday, Continental has taken great pains to reassure its customers and travel agents that it will be business as usual for the nation's fifth-largest airline. While many travelers say they will indeed continue to fly the carrier, some remember Continental's bankruptcy filing eight years ago, when some flights were canceled and some passengers were left with worthless tickets. **********One travel agent said yesterday that he had temporarily stopped booking tickets on Continental.   A 'Dangerous' Move **********"In this environment, it's dangerous to go into Chapter 11," said Raymond Neidl, an analyst with Dillon, Read & Company. "Other airlines will pounce on you and try to steal customers and scare travel agents." **********Hollis H. Harris, Continental's chairman, said yesterday that the airline would continue to fly its normal schedule, would honor its contracts with travel agents and other airlines and would refund money to any customer who wanted it. **********"The travel agent and consumer can book Continental Airlines with absolute confidence," said Ned Walker, a Continental spokesman. He said that of the airline's approximately 1,400 scheduled flights yesterday, not one was canceled because of Continental's financial condition. Of 4,600 calls to its reservations line surveyed by the company, only nine cancellations were reported, which was a lower rate than average, Mr. Walker said. **********But the real test of consumer confidence, industry analysts said yesterday, will come early next year, when demand for travel historically falls off. By filing for bankruptcy protection in the midst of the busy holiday travel period, Continental has cushioned itself against, or at least delayed, any consumer backlash. **********"They picked a good time," said John Pritchard, a New York lawyer specializing in bankruptcy law. "No judge is going to want to strand these people." A bankruptcy judge has broad powers in deciding how a company would operate and could, as a last resort, call for liquidation. **********With flights already booked through the end of the month, most Continental ticket holders have few options. **********Ron Smith, the executive vice president of the American Society of Travel Agents, said the trade group was telling its members to book customers on Continental. "We're telling people to hang loose and keep booking them," he said. **********To some, the stigma of Chapter 11 may not be as strong as it once was. "The public is more callous about these things," said Russ Thayer, the senior vice president of Airline Economics, a consulting firm in Washington, noting that at least three well-publicized airline bankruptcy filings have occurred in the last decade. In only some of the cases did the airlines stop flying altogether. **********Travelers flying Continental from Newark International Airport yesterday had mixed reactions to -- and varying degrees of understanding about -- the filing. "I hope it doesn't go through for at least five days because that's when our flight home is," said Leo Bergeron of San Francisco. **********Others showed greater loyalty. "It's a temporary setback," said Gene Carter of Columbia, S.C. "It's a great airline." **********But some travel agents are suggesting that their clients not fly Continental, at least for now. "We are suggesting alternative airlines until the smoke clears," said David Perelman, the owner of the D.M.S. Travel Group in New York. "In the past, the passenger and travel agent have been left holding the bag," he said. **********In recent years, the travel industry has been seeking greater protection for itself and its clients, should an airline stop flying. The industry has been pushing for a small "default" fee to be collected on each ticket, with the amassed funds to be used to reimburse passengers and travel agents should a carrier stop flying. **********The law currently affords passengers little protection. "Passsengers are unsecured creditors who go to the end of the line," said Cornish Hitchcock, legal director of the Aviation Consumer Action Project, a group based in Washington.  'Put Me on Someone Else' **********Other travel agents said they were informing passengers of Continental's financial situation when making reservations. Thomas Nulty, the president of Associated Travel in Santa Clara, Calif., said that after being told of the filing, "every single person said put me on someone else." **********Most of Continental's 37,000 employees learned of the filing from the news media. One pilot, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said he was not concerned about his job security, but he added, "It's aggravating to have it hanging over our heads all the time."

**********Consumers were scaling back borrowing in the July-September quarter as the economy appeared to be headed toward a recession, a banking group said Monday. **********The percentage of consumer loans 30 or more days delinquent was a seasonally adjusted 2.56 percent at the end of the third quarter, virtually unchanged from the 2.55 percent rate at the end of the April-June period, the American Bankers Association said. **********The rate was 2.46 percent at the end of the first quarter and 2.64 percent at the end of the fourth quarter of 1989. **********"Consumers are well aware of the slowing economy and are making efforts to consolidate and repay debts, rather than take on new ones," said Robert H. Dugger, chief economist of the trade group. **********Government data show consumers are taking fewer loans, he said, while anecdotal evidence from bankers indicates financially strong households may be taking out less expensive and longer-term home equity loans to pay off other consumer loans and reduce their monthly payments. **********Mr. Dugger said he expected the number of consumers behind on loan payments to be higher when figures are reported for the final three months of this year. **********Michael K. Evans, a Washington economist and consultant, said consumer loan delinquencies generally did not rise significantly until well into a recession. **********The lack of movement in the national delinquency rate masks sharp variations among regions. Consumers were hit hardest in the Northeast and least in the West and Midwest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/busin.main_headline: Talking Business; with Krief of Bernard Krief Associates;   Consultant's Bid For Saatchi Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/busin.print_headline: Talking Business; with Krief of Bernard Krief Associates;   Consultant's Bid For Saatchi Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/busin.body_text: **********For more than a year, Bernard Krief, a French management consultant, has been trying to buy the Hay Group, Saatchi & Saatchi's consulting arm. The path has not been smooth. First Saatchi said Hay was not for sale; then it said the group was worth triple the $100 million to $200 million Mr. Krief was offering; then Mr. Krief refused to sign a confidentiality letter that Saatchi wanted before it would show him its books. Now several Hay managers are trying to buy Hay for about $90 million. Still, Mr. Krief, whose 150-person Bernard Krief Associates is a fraction the size of Hay, which has a staff of more than 2,000, is persevering. **********Q. Why do you want Hay so badly? **********A. We are only in four countries - France, the United States, Russia and Belgium. Hay would give us instant entree to 32 countries. **********Q. Couldn't you spread out yourself? **********A. Consulting start-ups are difficult, because so much depends on your image. In Germany, for example, it would take years to establish the Krief name, while the Hay name is already known. **********Q. If this merger means so much to you, why would you not sign the letter of confidentiality? **********A. I had to promise not to meet with the Hay consultants, and not to participate in any tender offer anyone might make for Saatchi. That is asking too much. If you go into a store to buy six shirts, no one should tell you you can't see the shirts first, and that you must promise you'll never cooperate with anyone who buys the store. **********Q. Some Hay managers are trying to buy the company themselves. Aren't you afraid they will quit if you outbid them? After all, the only assets a consulting firm has is its people. **********A. That's one reason I wouldn't sign that letter. About 150 people are the leaders at Hay. I want to sit down with them and see if they want me. If they don't, I'll walk away. But I think many of them will be interested in what I have to offer. **********Q. And what is that? **********A. I offer them participative management, and a willingness to spend a lot of money on research and development. I'd ask them to buy 10 percent of the company at first. I'd offer them stock options for another 30 percent down the road, as well as financial incentives to help them buy stock. **********Q. But why would people who want to own the business be happy with a minority stake? **********A. Not all of them are interested in the buyout. But if they wanted to eventually own 80 percent, that would be fine, too. **********Q. Actually, you are like the little fish trying to swallow the big fish. If you got Hay, wouldn't its sheer size undermine Krief Associates? **********A. It would be perfectly O.K. if they absorbed me. I'd even be willing to move to the States. What's important is that there be cross-fertilization, not only between Krief and Hay, but between the Hay operations in the different countries. **********Q. Still, how many Hay consultants could you lose and still feel you made a good deal?. **********A. It's not a question of numbers, but of names. I would need to hold on to most of the 150 top people. I would treat them like partners, not employees. **********Q. But don't you feel that their corporate culture would overwhelm yours? **********A. I'm not an autocrat, I'm a team worker. I would want the 150 top people to sit on a strategy committee, to help with planning. I don't think they have that with Saatchi, but that would fit right in with the culture of our company. **********Q. What happens now? **********A. I'm expecting a more normal letter of confidentiality any day now. If I get it, I will sign, and start meeting the consultants. **********Q. And what if you don't land Hay? Do you have other plans for growth? **********A. I just signed another letter of confidentiality this week. I have other negotiations going on, and I'm open to the idea of joint ventures with consulting firms from other countries, either to help us get into countries we're not in or to help us get into consulting areas like logistics in which we have no expertise.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/04/busin.body_text: **********The Cigna Corporation said today that its earnings fell by half in the first quarter, partly because of large claims resulting from severe winter storms in Europe. The big insurance company said profits fell to $42 million, or 54 cents a share, from $85 million, or $1.02 a share, in 1989. Revenues fell slightly, to $3.8 billion, from $3.6 billion. Net income for the 1989 quarter included $13 million from operations that have been sold or discontinued.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/20/busin.body_text: **********The Perkin-Elmer Corporation yesterday took the first step toward spinning off its troubled semiconductor business by selling its electron-beam-technology division. The buyer is a management team backed by six United States corporations, including I.B.M. and Perkin-Elmer itself. **********The deal, in which the California-based division is being sold to a newly formed company known as the Etec Corporation, does not include the optical lithography operations group, which has been the focus of nationwide concern since Perkin-Elmer announced last April that it was withdrawing from the semiconductor equipment business. **********There were reports earlier this year that the optical lithography business was on the verge of being acquired by the Nikon Corporation of Japan, because of a lack of American bidders. That group manufactures the equipment that imprints electronic circuit patterns onto silicon wafers, a process known as photolithography. **********Another Sale Expected **********Industry analysts said Perkin-Elmer is expected to announce soon that it will sell its optical lithography group to the Silicon Valley Group of San Jose, Calif. Executives of Perkin-Elmer and the International Business Machines Corporation said they could not comment on those talks. **********The electron-beam group is the other half of Perkin-Elmer's semiconductor operations, and analysts say it has been the leading maker of electron-beam machines in the United States. This technology permits semiconductor makers to create crucial components of the chip-making process known as masks. The machines are also used - like ultra-thin pencils - to write circuits directly onto silicon wafers. **********''It's a super technology, and it will give the U.S. an edge,'' said Harinder Kohli, a technology analyst at Sutro & Company in San Jose. ''There is no question that there is a future for this technology, but Perkin-Elmer couldn't do it alone.'' **********Perkin-Elmer executives said the sale was part of a strategic shift. ''We have decided on a corporate focus on material sciences and the analytical instruments business,'' said Horace G. McDonell, the chairman. ''These are growth businesses. They are less volatile and more consistent than the semiconductor business.'' **********Terms of the sale were not disclosed, but executives said the management group, which will be led by Charles E. Minihan and Thomas Halloran, both former Perkin-Elmer employees, would have the largest share in the new company, to be based in Hayward, Calif. The six corporations, which also include Du Pont, Grumman, Micron Technology and Zitel, will have smaller equal shares. **********Analysts said the company was probably sold for $30 million to $40 million. The company manufactures only a handful of the multimillion-dollar machines each year. **********Worries About U.S. Role **********American semiconductor executives and analysts had worried that Perkin-Elmer's departure from the business was another sign of the industry's deterioration in the face of tough Japanese competition. **********I.B.M., which has invested heavily in helping Perkin-Elmer develop a next-generation optical-lithography machine, called Tool X, has been particularly concerned about losing vital portions of the semiconductor business to foreign competition. Computer makers like I.B.M. rely on state-of-the-art semiconductors to build their most advanced models.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   200 Pilots Included In USAir Layoffs
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/14/busin.body_text: **********USAir Group Inc., the owner of the nation's seventh-largest airline, whose profits have been hurt by industry fare cuts, said it planned to lay off 200 pilots and an unspecified number of other workers. The company, which has hubs at Pittsburgh, Philadelphia and Charlotte, N.C., said it would announce the layoffs to employees on Tuesday. **********USAir's earnings have suffered in weak pricing environment. Eastern Airlines is still discounting aggressively to regain market share after being virtually shut down last year. USAir posted a loss of $76 million in 1989, its first loss in 14 years, and had a first-half 1990 loss of $113.1 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   U.S. Turns Down MCI's Complaint
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/02/busin.body_text: **********A Federal appeals board rejected the MCI Communications Corporation's challenge to part of the multibillion-dollar Government contracts that have been awarded to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and U S Sprint. Washington-based MCI's complaint involves changes in a contract to redesign and provide voice, data and video telecommunications networks, a project that could total $25 billion over 10 years. **********The General Services Administration is permitting U S Sprint to make changes in toll-free services. MCI had complained that the modifications were outside the the contract and that competition was required for the work. The G.S.A appeals panel's ruling was on Wednesday. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/16/busin.body_text: **********The National Broadcasting Company sued the Sony Corporation and its Columbia Pictures subsidiary today, charging that Columbia had sabotaged a joint venture with NBC to distribute home videos. **********The suit, filed in state court here, contends that Columbia, which is working to build a competing home-video operation, is undermining the operations of RCA/Columbia Home Video. NBC charged that Columbia's actions were hurting the joint venture's profitability and were reducing its value to any potential acquirer. **********NBC is seeking at least $250 million in damages. **********'Sony Will Not Be Intimidated' **********A spokesman for Columbia said the company had not yet seen the lawsuit. ''We are surprised to hear about the litigation since we have enjoyed a mutually beneficial relationship with them,'' he said. **********Sony also issued a statement saying that it had not seen the suit, but added, ''We can state now that Sony will not be intimidated.'' A Sony spokesman declined to elaborate. **********NBC, which is owned by the General Electric Company, and Columbia established the home-video joint venture in 1982. NBC said it had become one of the largest and most successful video distributors. Last year RCA/Columbia Home Video had revenues of $470 million and profits of $74 million, the suit said. **********Sony bought Columbia for $3.4 billion last year in the first major acquisition of a Hollywood studio by a Japanese company. After that acquisition, NBC said in its suit, Columbia decided to establish its own video-distribution operation, despite the success of the joint venture, Terms of the Joint Venture The partnership agreement extends for 10 years, ending in June 1992. When the agreement expires, The companies can extend the venture, have one partner buy out the other or sell the entire operation to a third party. NBC estimated that the company would be worth $1 billion were it to be sold. **********''In our view, both parties are obligated to build RCA/Columbia to the maximum of our capabilities throughout the 10-year term,'' said Richard Cotton, NBC's general counsel. **********Sony has long said that it wants to increase its control of ''software,'' or entertainment programming, in order to help its sale of ''hardware,'' or the televisions and videocassette recorders on which the programming is played. **********The suit said Sony and Columbia had improperly prevented RCA/Columbia Home Video from acquiring video rights to films to be released by the Orion Pictures Corporation and had then made their own separate deal for the rights. **********Deteriorating Relationship **********The suit also said Sony and Columbia had improperly taken information from the joint venture and were using it to establish their own home video operation. **********The suit is indicative of the deteriorating relationship between the television networks and the major studios. The networks are seeking the repeal of Federal rules restricting their ownership of television programs. They would like to profit from the syndicated sale of reruns, but the major studios bitterly oppose them on the issue. **********NBC has been out in front on this issue and has been particularly critical of the acquisition of studios by foreign companies while the networks are barred from owning studios and the programming they produce.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/20/world.main_headline: Bangalore Journal;   Christians Revel in Conversion Back to Indianness
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/20/world.print_headline: Bangalore Journal;   Christians Revel in Conversion Back to Indianness
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/20/world.body_text: **********They gathered at dusk beside the woods, a band of several hundred Christians who had come to consecrate an empty field where they envisioned a church would one day stand. When the deed was done, the Mass said and the Archbishop gone, they spread carpets over the dusty earth and settled down to watch a priest dance. **********The Rev. Francis Barboza, an ordained member of the Roman Catholic Society of the Divine Word and a classical Indian dancer, is also a leader among those who want to de-Westernize Christianity in India. He incorporates religious themes in his performances of the Bharatanatyam dance forms of South India, where he was born. **********''My main purpose is to understand Christ within my culture,'' he said as he prepared to perform on Monday evening. **********With the rise of Hindu militancy all over India, and the success of Islamic fundamentalists in Kashmir, India's Christians have reason to take stock of their position and ask questions about their future as a religious minority. **********Indianness of Christianity **********Christianity, some of its adherents say, must prove its Indianness not only to avoid becoming a target of the Hindu revival but also to make itself credible as an alternative to other religions in a materialistic age. Rising islands of urban affluence in a sea of rural poverty disturb many Indians, who are searching for responses. **********''The Christian has something to offer,'' said George Ninan, who gave up a career in advertising to devote his life to the Assemblies of God, an evangelical church. ''I think that what India needs is more of an awareness of the other person, a concern for the neighbor.'' **********The roots and beliefs of Christianity are about to get their first national public airing this year, when the Government television network, Doordarshan, begins broadcasting stories from the Bible. Most of the filming is being done along India's southern coasts, where studio crews have built large models of Noah's Ark and the Tower of Babel. **********Indian Christians say their earliest churches were founded in the region by St. Thomas the Apostle in the first century A.D. Although there are no written records, Indians believe St. Thomas was martyred in South India and buried in Tamil Nadu. Over the centuries, other branches of Christianity were brought by European colonizers and American missionaries. **********Christian Sense of Community **********In Bangalore, a city of churches as well as the capital of Indian science and research, nearly all the country's diverse Christian communities are represented: the Roman Catholic Church; the ancient Syrian Church of Kerala, well established by the sixth century A.D.; its reformed counterpart, the Mar Thoma church; Protestants from the Church of South India, which groups Anglicans, Lutherans and other older denominations, and newer evangelical groups with links to the United States. **********There are thought to be up to 24 million Christians in India, only 3 percent of a national population now above 810 million. But their influence has been strong, particularly in education. In areas where their numbers are significant, literacy rates and the status of women are generally very high, and birth rates are lower. **********Leela Rao, a professor of film at Bangalore University's Central College and a Hindu Brahmin who has taken part in seminars on communications in India organized by Mr. Ninan, said in an interview that Hinduism, India's majority religion, was essentially a self-centered but not selfish creed. Christian churches seemed to have more of a sense of community, she said. **********''As a Hindu, you go to the temple only as a means to your own salvation,'' she said. ''No one can do anything for you, and you can't do anything for anybody. Spiritual salvation is never for a community. The universe is one. You find yourself and become part of that universe.'' **********Agents of Foreign Influence **********But the Christian churches often have problems putting across their message of social justice and good works because of their shortsightedness or because the Hindu establishment casts them as agents of foreign influence, Mr. Ninan said. **********He drew attention to a Christmas Eve program broadcast on Indian television that featured a talk by the American evangelist Billy Graham. **********''Billy Graham is great,'' Mr. Ninan said. ''As an evangelical Christian, I couldn't have thought of anyone better. But not for India.'' **********''People have been putting out the idea that Christianity is a foreign religion, and here you have this white man talking,'' he said. ''It stuck in the minds of people.'' **********'Self-Appointed Saviors' **********A religious experience as a young man ultimately led him into an evangelical church, he said, but he has been disturbed by its links to evangelists in the United States who think ''writing a big check'' is serving God. **********''There are a lot of people who have become self-appointed saviors of India,'' he said, recalling an American preacher who came to India seven years ago and saw a film he thought had the power to convert the country if it could be widely distributed. **********Returning to the United States, the evangelist raised money for the project. ''He is thought to have collected millions of dollars,'' Mr. Ninan said. ''Indians got none of it.'' **********Mr. Ninan, like Father Francis, said he believed that Indian forms of communication like music, dance and drama - frowned on as immoral and all but obliterated by 19th-century and early 20th-century missionaries - needed to be revived to tell the Christian story. **********Mr. Ninan's wife, Pamela, and two other writers are now adapting for young Indian readers the English-language Good News Bible for Children. The adaptation, to be published by the Bangalore-based Bible Society of India, hopes to replace drawings like those of a slim, blond Eve and a Tarzan-like Adam with more appropriate Indian illustrations. **********Father Francis also performs essentially Hindu dances because, he said, the arts are are a way to bring people from those different cultures closer together. **********''That's what the arts are for,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/world.main_headline: Walesa's Rival to Open His 'Black Bag'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/world.print_headline: Walesa's Rival to Open His 'Black Bag'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/world.body_text: **********For the last week, Stanislaw Tyminski has been coyly hinting about documents in his "black bag" that would harm Lech Walesa, his rival in the Polish presidential race. **********Tonight, he called a crush of Polish and foreign reporters to his headquarters for a news conference, kept them waiting an a hour and half, and then announced that he would make his purported evidence public on Friday, shortly before the noon deadline set by Polish law for all campaigning to come to a halt. Under the rules, Mr. Walesa will not be permitted to respond before the voting begins on Sunday at 6 A.M. **********"I was hit a thousand times and there's a saying, you have to fight fire with fire," Mr. Tyminski said, his face breaking into a grin. "I was hit below the waist. This is one of my points of control. I have no access to radio or television. I cannot supervise that the votes are counted properly. What I can show is proof." 'A Joke of History' **********Asked why he would not release his purported material immediately so it could be verified, he replied, "It's a political decision." **********The tumultuous session with reporters reflected the increasingly bitter tone of Poland's first presidential campaign. This week, Mr. Tyminski has been pummeled by every major institution in Poland. **********The Roman Catholic Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, said in an interview published today that Mr. Tyminski was "a joke of history"; the state-run television broadcast a report that accused him of wife-beating and abusing his children; the Interior Minister today all but called him a liar about his purported travels in Libya in the 80's; United Press International obtained documents from Government officials showing that Mr. Tyminski had been denied entry into the Polish Army because of "reactive psychosis." Casts Himself as Underdog **********Mr. Tyminski has denied all the charges and threatened to file lawsuits. He is casting himself as the beleaguered underdog challenger beset by a cabal of Polish media and Government agencies. Tonight, Mr. Tyminski's staff permitted supporters to push their way into the news conference and shout abuse at the reporters crowding into his small offices. **********In speeches and public appearances this week, Mr. Tyminski has asserted that Poland was under threat from election fraud, that people close to Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki had tortured a Catholic bishop in the 50's, and that senior Solidarity officials had been secret police agents. **********Mr. Walesa declined today to take part in a televised debate tonight with Mr. Tyminski, saying in a statement that he had violated "the elementary rules of political culture." The televised meeting of the two had been proposed for Dec. 2, but Mr. Tyminski insisted that it take place on the last evening of the campaign. **********"The presidential post requires that the contenders behave in a dignified way," Mr. Walesa's statement said. "One can tolerate slips on the road to democracy, but one must not make our country become the laughingstock of the world." Tyminski Held Accountable **********Mr. Walesa, for his part, has added somewhat to the sharp tone of the campaign. In an interview with the Government newspaper Rzeczpospolita, for example, he reaffirmed his commitment to take Mr. Tyminski into an unspecified type of custody if he wins the voting this Sunday. **********"I want to ask all the services concerned," Mr. Walesa said. "Tyminski must not be let out of the country. He must account for everything that brought Poland harm, and for abusing Poland's good name in the world." **********Polish television aired a broadcast this week that quoted a neighbor of Mr. Tyminski in Toronto as saying he beat his wife and abused his children. The report provided no documentary support for the charge and Mr. Tyminski replied with a letter to Polish television that threatened a lawsuit against the head of Polish television. He said the woman making the accusations "had done so under the influence of her alcoholic husband." **********Polish television also broadcast, without comment, tape of Mr. Tyminski's assertion that he had caused Jeffrey Sachs, the economist, to lose his temper during a discussion the two men had on the ABC News program "Nightline." A tape of Mr. Tyminski's making this remark at a news conference was followed by a shot of Mr. Sachs showing the American economist speaking in a completely calm tone of voice. **********Today, Interior Minister Krzysztof Kozlowski held a news conference at which he said the intelligence agencies of Canada and the United States were looking into Mr. Tyminski's backgroud.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/04/busin.body_text: **********The House of Representatives passed a bill today that would place new restrictions on companies that provide long-distance telephone service to hotels, hospitals and college campuses. **********The legislation, which was passed earlier this week by the Senate, is meant to address complaints about overcharging for calls placed through ''alternative operator services.'' **********Such companies lease long-distance lines and provide service to people staying in hotel rooms, for example, but their prices have often been far higher than those charged by conventional long-distance services, like A.T.&T., MCI or U S Sprint. **********The bill would require such services to let customers reach their own long-distance carriers, using their long-distance calling cards. **********It would also require that alternative operator services identify themselves to customers and provide information about their prices upon request.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/18/world.print_headline: Fighting Erupts in the Salvadoran Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/18/world.body_text: **********Fighting broke out between leftist guerrillas and Government troops in San Salvador tonight and loud explosions were heard in several sections of the city. **********The authorities said that a number of people were wounded. **********Witnesses said they saw army helicopters dropping flares and firing with automatic weapons at suspected guerrilla positions near the Ilopango air base, a few miles east of the capital, and at other points in the city. **********Reporters said they heard a number of loud explosions, apparently caused by bombs in the poor neighborhood of Soyapango on the city's east side, and in Delgado to the northeast. **********A Red Cross spokesman, who insisted on anonymity, said in a telephone interview that there was fighting in the southern part of the city. **********The armed forces press office said it had no immediate details. **********''We know there have been explosions, but we don't know where,'' a military spokesman said in a telephone interview.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/11/busin.body_text: **********The Knoxville News-Sentinel and The Knoxville Journal agreed last week to dissolve their four-year-old joint operating agreement by the end of 1991, ending a lawsuit. **********The News-Sentinel asserted in its lawsuit that The Journal's owner, the Persis Corporation, violated terms of the agreement when it bought The Daily Times in Maryville in neighboring Blount County in December. The News-Sentinel, owned by the E. W. Scripps Company of Cincinnati, considers The Daily Times a direct competitor. **********As part of the termination arrangement, The News-Sentinel will pay Persis $40 million. **********A statement said that after the agreement ends, The Journal would publish separately and in competition with The News-Sentinel. Currently, The News-Sentinel provides sales, production and distribution for The Journal. The news departments are separate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/busin.body_text: **********In an effort to offset rising fuel costs, Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it would add an $8 fuel surcharge each way on all of its domestic tickets. **********The move is a direct result of the invasion of Kuwait by Iraqi troops on Thursday, said Robert Gibbons, a Northwest spokesman. The airline's fuel costs have risen 8 cents a gallon since Wednesday, he said. **********''We, as an airline, are just as much a victim of what is going on in the Middle East as the consumer at the gas pump,'' Mr. Gibbons said. **********The surcharge, which will be added to tickets purchased starting next Thursday, will appear as a separate item on tickets. Mr. Gibbons said the airline had not yet decided whether to extend the policy to its international flights as well. **********No other airlines matched Northwest immediately. Tim Smith, a spokesman for American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, said the airline would decide Monday whether to add a fuel surcharge. **********Fuel accounts for about 15 percent of an airline's operating cost. Last winter, many airlines added fuel surcharges, typically about $5, when fuel prices rose sharply as a result of a heating-oil shortage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/30/world.main_headline: Pope Criticizes Settlers in the Old City
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/30/world.print_headline: Pope Criticizes Settlers in the Old City
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/30/world.body_text: **********In an implied criticism of Israeli policies, Pope John Paul II expressed ''profound concern'' today over the recent attempt to create a Jewish settlement in the Christian quarter of the Old City of Jerusalem. **********The Pope also seemed to suggest that Israel needed to be more sensitive in this matter, pointing out that Jerusalem was sacred to three religions - Judaism, Christianity and Islam - and that their rights should be respected. **********With his appeal, made at the end of the Mass celebrated in St. Peter's Square, John Paul thus publicly entered the dispute that erupted this month when 150 Jewish settlers occupied a four-building complex owned by the Greek Orthodox Church. **********The Israeli Government, after earlier denials, acknowledged that it had contributed $1.8 million to help establish the settlement in the Christian quarter, a disclosure that has touched off strong criticism both in Israel and abroad. On Friday Christian leaders added their protests by closing churches and shrines throughout Israel and the occupied territories for the day, including the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, which is near the settlement and is where Jesus is said to have been entombed after the Crucifixion. **********Last week, the Israeli Supreme Court gave the settlers until Tuesday to leave the site, although it granted permission for 20 guards and maintenance workers to remain while a lower court hears further evidence in the tenancy case. **********Addressing pilgrims gathered in the vast square, the Pope said today, ''I want to invite you now to be, along with me, spiritually close to our brothers in East Jerusalem, especially those responsible for the venerable Christian churches.'' **********''The grave incidents that have occurred recently in the Holy City and that led to the sorrowful decision to close holy places temporarily, and particularly the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, are a cause also for me of suffering and profound concern,'' he said. ''Let us pray that everyone will have at heart the search for solutions inspired by justice and respect for rights.'' **********Listening to him were thousands of Spanish pilgrims attending a beatification ceremony for 11 priests, nuns and friars killed by left-wing Republican forces in the Spanish Civil War of the 1930's. According to ANSA, the Italian news agency, the crowd also included - unusually - senior officials from Arab countries. Among them were the representative in Italy of the Palestine Liberation Organization and the Ambassadors of Iraq, Lebanon, Algeria, Southern Yemen and the United Arab Emirates. **********The Vatican has no diplomatic relations with Israel, and disapproves of Israel's insistence on regarding Jerusalem as its capital. Instead, the Holy See wants Jerusalem to be declared an international city. **********It is hardly the first time that the Pope has made comments likely to displease at least some Israelis. Officials in Israel have criticized him for having met three times, and as recently as several weeks ago, with Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. leader. John Paul has insisted repeatedly that Palestinians have the same right as Jews to a homeland.
