https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/busin.body_text: **********The Atari Corporation has begun talks to acquire computer chips from the Soviet Union. Gregory Pratt, Atari's chief financial officer, said the company had obtained and tested dynamic random access memories, or D-RAM's, produced in the Soviet Union. The chips can store 256,000 bits of information. **********Mr. Pratt said Atari's main goal was to sell computers in the Soviet Union. But knowing that the Soviet Union has little currency to pay for products, the company is looking for something to trade for.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/07/world.main_headline: Archie Bunker's South African Cousin Has TV Debut
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/07/world.print_headline: Archie Bunker's South African Cousin Has TV Debut
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/07/world.body_text: **********The plot would seem familiar to American television viewers: an amiable white bigot in a working-class neighborhood finds his complacent prejudices under assault when a family of color moves in next door. **********The theme, explored years ago in the American situation comedy ''All in the Family,'' has emerged in a South African incarnation, ''People Like Us,'' which premiered on Dec. 23. **********The taping of the 26 half-hour shows was completed in 1987. The series has since been on the shelf at the state-run South African Broadcasting Corporation, which spent 1.7 million rand, currently about $680,000, to make the series but was too nervous to show it until now. **********In the interim, John Cundhill, who wrote the series five years ago, emigrated to Australia. The plot is dated by anomalies like houses selling for 32,000 rand, at $13,000 today, a fraction of their current price, and by quips about the old liberal Progressive Federal Party, which died last April when the new Democratic Party was born. **********Saturday Night Time Slot **********In the Johannesburg suburb of Mayfair, on which the show's fictitious neighborhood of Randjiesuitsig is said to be based, racial mixing no longer raises eyebrows. And President F. W. de Klerk has embarked on a policy of evolutionary change that includes formal recognition of a handful of multiracial neighbors, despite the existence of legal residential segregation. **********The South African Broadcasting Corporation is showing ''People Like Us'' at 10:25 on Saturday night to avoid inciting or offending whites. The late time slot reportedly was chosen because the majority of viewers at that hour are black, and impressionable children of any race are usually in bed. One television reviewer, Richard McNeill, accused the corporation of cowardice and said the series should be shown on prime time weekdays so more whites would watch it. **********South Africa's answer to Archie Bunker is Barney Bosman, a municipal building inspector who argues that just as antelopes stick to antelopes and giraffes to giraffes, so people should not deviate from their own kind. Barney, played by Michael Brunner, does not confine his intolerance to non-whites; he does not like Jews, Portuguese and Greeks either. And his insistence that a lioness does not attempt a lion's work makes clear where he stands on feminism. **********''A lot of things have changed since Dr. Vorster,'' Barney Bosman tells his son-in-law, Biff Britz, alluding to John Vorster, South Africa's Prime Minister in the heyday of apartheid. ''But that's not to say we can't change them back again.'' **********A Mixed-Race Doctor **********But Barney's life is changed when Glen Kinnear, a white upper-class property developer, renames the neighborhood Honeysuckle Heights to lure Johannesburg yuppies and begins buying up houses. The developer, who runs short of cash, sells his own house in the wealthy northern suburb of Bryanston and moves in next to the Bosmans in Randjiesuitsig, to the mortification of his snobbish wife, Tessa. ''I saw a woman on the street with her hair in curlers,'' she says of their new Afrikaner neighbors. ''Imagine the accents.'' **********Biff Britz, who lives with his father-in-law, quietly buys the other house next door, and resells it to Ben Paulsen, a mixed-race doctor. Dr. Paulsen and his wife are implausibly upscale - she owns a fashion boutique - but his surly kid brother, Russell, on probation for car theft, readily stoops to the occasion with Barney. **********The characters include a British immigrant couple who moved to South Africa, they announced, ''to get away from the blacks.'' But the series gives short shrift to the country's black majority. The only blacks in the first two episodes walked on as construction workers and a gardener. **********Yet ''People Like Us'' conveys with some poignancy the desperation of mixed-race South Africans who yearn for the things whites take for granted. ''I want to own a house, Ben,'' pleads Dr. Paulsen's wife, despite the fear that Randjiesuitsig will not welcome them. **********Abusive Phone Calls to Actors **********Though ''People Like Us'' confronts racism on tiptoe, Tanya Logan, who plays Barney's liberated tomboy daughter, Barbie, said in a newspaper interview that she and her husband had received dozens of abusive telephone calls, and the other actors have braced for a backlash. But they said they considered the series relevant for South Africa. **********''It is not a series that hammers any messages or that will radically alter anyone's viewpoint, but rather tries to show that change doesn't signify the end of the world,'' Gray Hofmeyr, the director, said in an interview with The Johannesburg Star newspaper. ''It's a series that will develop the ability of South Africans to laugh at themselves.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/30/busin.snippet: LEAD: What do Merv Adelson, former chairman of the Lorimar Telepictures Corporation, former Postmaster General Preston Robert Tisch and Stephen Wynn, the chairman of Golden Nugget Inc. in Las Vegas, have in common?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/30/busin.main_headline:
The Executive Life;

For the Cognoscenti, Anything Custom-Made
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/30/busin.print_headline:
The Executive Life;

For the Cognoscenti, Anything Custom-Made
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/30/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: What do Merv Adelson, former chairman of the Lorimar Telepictures Corporation, former Postmaster General Preston Robert Tisch and Stephen Wynn, the chairman of Golden Nugget Inc. in Las Vegas, have in common? **********What do Merv Adelson, former chairman of the Lorimar Telepictures Corporation, former Postmaster General Preston Robert Tisch and Stephen Wynn, the chairman of Golden Nugget Inc. in Las Vegas, have in common? **********Several times a year each of these busy executives can be found standing in a small, wood-paneled room lined with mirrors on West 57 Street, as William Fioravanti, a custom tailor, hovers around them with a measuring tape and a loaded pin-cushion. For what seems like an eternity, Mr. Fioravanti pokes and prods, looking for the errant bulge or the unseemly high waist; the flat or curved seat; the barrel chest or the bow-legged stance. His mission: to camouflage any particular flaw beneath the seams of a well-cut suit. The price of his craft? Upward of $3,000 per suit.  Recession or not, the custom-made traditional men's suit is back in the executive suite in a big way. After years of dabbling in the flashier duds of European designers like Giorgio Armani and Gianni Versace, male executives are returning to the more conservative, somberly patrician look of a Savile Row suit. **********Of course, some, most notably bankers, never left that look. But for those who did stray, the reasons for a return are many, not the least of which is the instant aura of Old World money that custom suits bestow on their owners. It was no coincidence that Oliver Stone, the director of ''Wall Street,'' starring Michael Douglas as the ruthlessly ambitious arbitrager Gordon Gekko, allowed the camera to linger on his star's elegant, custom-made English suits. **********There are also some practical reasons for the renewed popularity of these suits. ''The English suit is very flattering to the person,'' noted Henry Stewart, another leading New York custom tailor. ''The Italian and French suits are not at all flattering. They're too tight in the wrong places: they remind me of a tight-fitting lady's dress.'' **********Added Mr. Fioravanti, ''Our client wants to look no-nonsense and efficient. He doesn't care to look like a kid in a disco.'' **********But coming up with the $3,000 to finance the purchase of one of these gems is only the beginning. There is serious suit etiquette among the executive cognoscenti; and violators quickly become the subject of scorn, regardless of how powerful or successful they are in business. Simply put, there are rules to dressing like Cary Grant or Prince Charles, and they must be followed if an executive is to look at all comfortable - at all natural - in one of these power outfits: *********** Buttonholes: Always insist that buttons on a jacket sleeve are unbuttonable. Never, however, stoop to the obvious ploy of leaving the top button nonchalantly unbuttoned, thereby alerting the world to the fact that you've paid extra for real buttonholes. This practice, particularly popular among ambitious young Wall Street investment bankers, is an instant sign of clod-like naivete. *********** Monograms: A bad idea. ''Monograms are for the most affected jerks,'' snorted one partner at a prominent Wall Street law firm. ''They also suggest, at the very least, that you can't remember what the hell your name is.'' *********** Baggy trousers with narrowed ankles: Too trendy. As Mr. Fioravanti explained, ''When I see a very pegged leg with a wide knee, well, this is not attractive.'' *********** Custom-made shirts: At $150 a pop, these are perhaps the ultimate luxury in custom tailoring. A noted New York tailor, John Reyle, said: ''The custom-made shirt fits. Some of the commercial-made shirts are so blousy around the waist, it's disgusting. Brooks Brothers shirts, for example, I abhor. They must make them for a 44-inch waist.'' Most top executives, however, go through shirts like water and so tend to rely on less expensive, off-the-rack makes from Turnbull & Asser and The Custom Shop. Remember to keep the collar small and narrow. *********** Ties: Hermes or, better yet, custom-made. *********** Shoes: Again, if you can afford $2,500 for custom-made shoes, by all means do so. Serious executives used to make a trans-Atlantic trek to the London shop of the shoemaker George Cleverley, before he retired. Mr. Cleverley would cut a last for you from which he could fashion a lifetime of shoes - usually about eight pairs. In his absence, lace-up oxfords from Church's or loafers from Bally do nicely. Minimize purchases of Gucci loafers: they're starting to look very Wall Street-Hollywood. **********It all seems like a lot of fuss. Yet aficionados of power dressing claim they really spend less time on their clothes this way than if they shopped at a store. ''I'm not a fast thinker when it comes to clothes,'' explained Mr. Tisch, the president and co-chief executive of the Loews Corporation. ''With a Fioravanti suit, my wife goes with me once to pick out the fabric, I go alone for the fitting, and it's done. They know my taste, my size, and there's no pressure to buy. They also shorten my wife's skirts at the same time.'' **********But perhaps the most important reason top executives favor custom-made conservative suits is the image they convey. Supple lapels, minimum shoulder padding, high-cut arm holes and dark wools: they whisper quiet prosperity and success, and for many men that is worth any price. Barry Slotnick, a New York criminal lawyer, explained, ''I have only two requirements in my Fioravanti suits: They must be of traditional style and they must be navy blue. I have at least 15 custom-made navy blue suits. Why? Because there have been studies showing that juries think navy blue looks more lawyerly.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/03/busin.main_headline: Company News;   Japonica Accepts Plan on Allegheny
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/03/busin.print_headline: Company News;   Japonica Accepts Plan on Allegheny
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/03/busin.body_text: **********Japonica Partners agreed with creditors of Allegheny International Inc. to take control of the bankrupt appliance maker on Aug. 15. The partnership, based in New York and Rhode Island, has been pursuing Allegheny for about a year. Allegheny, which filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors in February 1988, owns the Sunbeam Corporation, maker of Sunbeam and Oster appliances. **********Japonica will name the new concern the Sunbeam/Oster Companies, with headquarters in Pittsburgh. William Webber, a former executive of Sunbeam, will be president, and the chairman will be Paul Kazarian, a Japonica principal. Japonica will own about 90 percent of the stock, and creditor banks will receive $127 million for Allegheny stock they own. Unsecured creditors and equity shareholders will receive $7 a share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/22/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Japan Chooses G.E.-Made Engine
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/22/busin.body_text: **********The Japan Defense Agency selected an engine made by the General Electric Company to power the FS-X fighter jet in a deal worth at least $100 million, G.E.'s Aircraft Engines division announced. The F110-GE-129 engine is to be used aboard the FS-X aircraft, which are modeled after the General Dynamics Corporation's F-16 fighter jets. The first production versions are to be completed by 1999.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/03/busin.main_headline: Patents; Talking Book Made With Bar Codes
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/03/busin.print_headline: Patents; Talking Book Made With Bar Codes
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/03/busin.body_text: **********BAR code labels, those familiar if inscrutable blocks of black and white stripes, have long been used to store prices on groceries as well as information for such things as shipping orders and even business forms. Now, Matsushita Electric Works Ltd. of Japan has received an American patent on a way to use bar codes to create talking books and labels. **********In the new system, the phonetic elements of a word are stored as a bar code symbol, which can be read by a light-sensitive device similar to those used to read price tags. The information is then relayed to a voice synthesizer and converted into a spoken word. A student learning the word "breakfast," for example, would wave a bar-code reader over a code next to the written word and hear it pronounced a moment later by the voice synthesizer. In one proposed version of the invention, people studying a book would wear a tiny bar code reader on their index fingers. **********As envisioned by the company, the invention would make it easy to print talking dictionaries so that people learning a language could hear how words are pronounced. It could also give the blind a way to obtain important information from labels and other written material that does not come in Braille. **********The key to the invention, according to the patent, is the use of a simplified approach to reconstructing words from code. A Matshusita spokesman said the company was not marketing the product yet. **********Four Matsushita researchers, Hiroharu Kunizawa, Noboru Ueji, Akira Yamamura and Hiroshi Itoyama, received patent 4,964,167.

Merrill Lynch Capital Markets acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated AA-2 by Moody's and AA by S.& P.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/world.main_headline: Baker and Shevardnadze Plan Talks in Houston
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE; Baker and Shevardnadze Plan Talks in Houston
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, announced today that they would hold a ministerial meeting on Dec. 10 and 11 in Houston, Mr. Baker's hometown, apparently to pave the way for a summit meeting in Moscow this winter. **********Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze made the announcement after a two-and-a-half-hour meeting at the Soviet Mission to the United Nations in New York, where the two men discussed last-minute details before Thursday's Security Council vote. It is expected to authorize the use of force against Iraq if Iraq continues to refuse to withdraw from Kuwait. **********The Baker-Shevardnadze meeting in Houston will be the second time that the two men will have met in the United States outside Washington. In September 1989, Mr. Baker invited his Soviet counterpart for a ministerial meeting in Jackson Hole, Wyo. **********After meeting with Mr. Baker, Mr. Shevardnadze will fly to Washington to confer with President Bush.  Persian Gulf Crisis on Agenda **********Besides setting a date for a summit meeting between Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush, the Shevardnadze trip is also expected to try to resolve outstanding differences that have been holding up completion of a strategic arms reduction treaty. **********Speaking to reporters today, Mr. Shevardnadze said that in his talks with Mr. Baker they also would take up the issue of the prolonged crisis in the Persian Gulf "in a very serious and substantive way." **********"There is still hope there will be a peaceful resolution of this conflict," Mr. Shevardnadze said after meeting with Mr. Baker at the Soviet Mission. **********The Security Council on Thursday is expected to pass a resolution allowing the use of force against Iraq if it does not pull its forces from Kuwait by Jan. 15. Presumably the Shevardnadze talks will provide a final check on the situation before that date. Hoping to Complete Arms Treaty **********Mr. Bush had hoped to go to Moscow to see Mr. Gorbachev and sign a new strategic arms limitation treaty in December. But several unsettled issues, including the kinds of tests the Soviets will be permitted with long-range SS-18 missiles, have slowed completion of the accord. **********Asked if the summit could now be held in January, Mr. Shevardnadze said: "I don't know if January or perhaps a little later. To a large extent this will depend on what we will be able to do with the Start treaty." **********He said the two sides were "quite realistic about being able to complete it" and said, "There is a lot of work we will have to do." **********The treaty would cut United States and Soviet arsenals of long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines by about 30 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/world.body_text: **********Japan and the Soviet Union, in their most intense round of diplomatic activity in recent years, tried and failed this week to narrow their differences on a 45-year territorial dispute that has stood in the way of improved relations. **********Nonetheless, negotiators in Moscow cleared the road for a visit to Tokyo in September by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the first visit by such a high-level official since the end of World War II. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is due in Japan next year. **********It was a week in which Mr. Gorbachev met with no less than three delegations from Japan, and officials here said afterward they had the impression that the Soviet leader was focusing personally on improving relations with Tokyo for perhaps the first time since taking office. **********Looking for a New Attitude **********''We have the impression that Gorbachev would like to his devote more time now to Japan-Russian relations,'' a senior Japanese official said. **********Many Japanese say they are hopeful that the Soviet Union will eventually have to adopt a more conciliatory attitude to Tokyo if it wishes to tap Japan's financing and technological expertise to improve its economy. So far, they acknowledge, this has not happened. **********In official talks in Moscow, Japan and the Soviet Union agreed to begin discussions on Tokyo's offer of technical assistance to improve the Soviet economy. Also slated are talks on improving the environment and on Japan's offer to help victims of the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear plant accident. **********Still, Mr. Gorbachev was quoted as expressing frustration over Japan's refusal to make concessions on the territorial matter, saying that it might not be worth his visiting Japan if Tokyo kept insisting on its way. **********Moreover, Mr. Shevardnadze complained that he was ''profoundly saddened'' by recent comments from Japan's Foreign Minister, Taro Nakayama, that giving economic assistance without major changes in the Soviet economy would be like ''throwing money down the drain.'' **********''This means that our nearest neighbor has no understanding of perestroika,'' Mr. Shevardnadze was quoted as telling a delegation of politicians from Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party. **********The root of the main dispute is Japan's claim to the tiny islands off its northern coast that were seized by the Soviet Union in the final days of World War II. Moscow maintains a historical claim to the islands, but Tokyo views the Soviet move as an example of cold war ''expansionism.'' **********As cold war sentiments have lifted, Japan has fallen short of its goal of ''internationalizing'' the issue. The major industrial democracies at the Houston summit meeting in June, for instance, took note of Japan's claim but termed it a bilateral dispute, not a major international issue. **********Rejecting a Compromise **********From time to time, some Japanese commentators and politicians suggest there may be room for compromise, that the Soviet Union might be willing to give up two of the four islands and declare the whole area a demilitarized zone that could be visited freely by Japanese. **********Japanese officials always reject such suggestions. Most recently, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has said Japan could not settle for anything less than return of all the islands. Absent such a settlement, he said Tokyo would not take part in any proposed economic aid program for Moscow. **********As seen here, Mr. Gorbachev sent mixed signals on the islands this week. First, he told the Speaker of Japan's lower house of Parliament that the Soviet Union was not occupying anyone else's territory, saying with some impatience: ''I repeat again today: we do not have a territorial issue.'' **********But later he was said to have told Daisaku Ikeda, leader of a Buddhist sect known as Soka Gakkai, that ''large concessions'' would be necessary if relations were to improve. Mr. Ikeda said afterward that he understood this to be a reference to Soviet concessions in the territorial dispute. **********In the meeting with Mr. Ikeda, Mr. Gorbachev was quoted as sounding both conciliatory and perhaps wistful. ''The fact that we have no dialogue with our neighbor country Japan is not a normal situation,'' he was quoted as saying. **********Then, when told that the springtime cherry blossom season would be a good time to schedule his visit next year, the Soviet leader added: ''That is what I would like. Spring is the symbol of my existence.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/12/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Memories Goes Beyond Newsstand
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/12/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Memories Goes Beyond Newsstand
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/12/busin.body_text: **********MEMORIES magazine will soon be hard to forget. The name of the publication born two years ago as a newsstand test product is about to turn up in all sorts of unlikely places. **********For starters, in October Memories will become a monthly. Its rapidly growing circulation rate base will jump to 800,000 for 1991, from 600,000 this year and 450,000 in 1989. **********But it's the appearance of Memories in media other than print that is causing advertisers to take notice. For Diamandis Communications Inc., a unit of Hachette S.A. and the magazine's publisher, these multimedia deals mean, at the least, circulation-building publicity. **********For advertisers, the mainstreaming of Memories may be the ultimate in ''added value,'' as the magazine industry calls support for advertisers that transcends the printed page. **********The magazine's first venture beyond print began eight months ago with the Satellite Music Network, a division of the ABC Radio Network. Some 500 radio stations across America now play daily ''A Memories Minute,'' celebrity profiles or miniature histories ''from the pages of Memories magazine,'' as the announcer says. **********In the late fall, Doubleday will publish the ''Memories Magazine Yearbook,'' a collection of photographs of celebrities drawn from their high school annuals, packaged and produced by the magazine. And last week, the magazine concluded a deal with Polygram Records to create a Memories record label, to be applied to compilations of old songs. **********At Diamandis, executives are using the same term for Memories that baseball teams apply to a superstar in his prime. They are calling it ''the franchise.'' **********The relationship involving Memories, NBC News and LBS Communications, a syndicator of television shows, promises the most. The three companies have created a weekly television series, called ''Memories . . . Then and Now,'' which will feature yesterday-and-today footage of famous people, places and events. NBC is paying the magazine a small licensing fee, and using its own video archives to produce the show; LBS is finding the stations and selling the advertising. **********The partners expect the show, which makes its debut in the fall, to reach 85 percent of the country. Seventeen of the top 20 television markets are already covered. In New York and Los Angeles, the program will be broadcast from 7 to 7:30 on Saturday nights. **********The most unusual aspect of the venture is the effort by LBS and Diamandis to sell print and broadcast advertising jointly. A marketer committing to one commercial each week on the television show would pay $2.34 million. If the advertiser separately buys two pages each month in the magazine, it will pay $369,000. But an advertiser buying print and television together will receive a 2.5 percent reduction on the television spots for the first year. The advertiser will be guaranteed a television rate increase of no more than 5 percent for the second year, will receive a 30 percent discount on the 1990 print ad rates and no print rate increase in 1991, despite the planned growth in circulation. **********Other benefits the magazine says it can toss into the package include free commercials on ''Flashback,'' a radio series that LBS syndicates, and free commercials on the Nostalgia Channel, a cable network. What is more, because the show will include features drawn from the magazine's pages, like the yearbook photos, some advertisers will be offered coincidental print and television positioning for their ads. **********''In an environment where the word 'synergy' is overused, I believe we are offering a real opportunity to make one plus one equal three,'' said Gergory C. Coleman, the magazine's publisher. **********Last week, LBS and Memories signed their first joint advertiser: the Andrew Jergens Company, the maker of hand lotion and soaps. Dawn Sibley, the media director of Ally & Gargano, Jergens's agency, said, ''The cross of both media will give us a better result than just a scattered print and television buy.'' **********''You can use TV to seed an image and use print to go for the buy,'' she said. ''This way, we can go for both.'' Ms. Sibley said the agency was considering creatively coordinating the print and television ads.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/04/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Stock Options At Chrysler
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/04/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation has granted some top managers stock options to keep their compensation packages competitive, a company spokesman said on Monday. **********The nation's No. 3 auto maker granted the options last week to about 1,800 executives. **********''People were moving on because their package was noncompetitive,'' the spokesman, Lee Sechler, said. **********Since May 1, Gerald Greenwald has quit as Chrysler's vice chairman and Michael Hammes has resigned as vice president for international operations. Frederick W. Zuckerman, vice president and treasurer, is expected to leave later this summer, and Bennett E. Bidwell, the chairman of Chyrsler Motors, is expected to take early retirement at the end of the year. **********Company officials declined to disclose the number of options granted or their price. **********The United Automobile Workers union criticized granting the options. ''This violates the spirit of camaraderie and the sharing effort that they've been talking about,'' said Aaron Taylor, president of Local 7, which represents laid-off workers at the company's closed Jefferson Avenue assembly plant. **********Chrysler and the union will begin contract negotiations July 20 to replace an agreement that expires Sept. 14.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/busin.main_headline: Tartikoff Show Goes On, But Its Script Is Changing
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: TELEVISION;   Tartikoff Show Goes On, But Its Script Is Changing
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/busin.body_text: **********JUST before Brandon Tartikoff faced the press for the last time as NBC's chief programming executive, he strapped on a mobile microphone and headset, a la Madonna, and sang a two-minute rap number with the network's newest star, Will Smith - also known as the Fresh Prince. **********No other television executive would have dared try the stunt, let alone bring it off, as Mr. Tartikoff did last week. But Mr. Tartikoff is a showman by every possible definition. **********The Tartikoff show is going to continue at NBC, but not as before. And if NBC does not show Mr. Tartikoff something that he wants to see, the show might not run too long. **********What Mr. Tartikoff wants to see is that NBC is serious about expanding in directions that will alter the entire concept of a network. **********Mr. Tartikoff has been president of NBC Entertainment for more than 10 years, longer than anyone else in the business. Last week, though, he announced that he was giving up day-to-day control of NBC's programming department and becoming chairman of a newly created entity, the NBC Entertainment Group. **********Several NBC executives described the move not as the end of an era at the network, but rather as a shifting of priorities. The succession of Warren Littlefield, Mr. Tartikoff's chief programming lieutenant, as entertainment president assures a smooth transition, the NBC executives said. **********But it will still be a transition, and that has inescapable implications for NBC. Mr. Tartikoff has been the most successful television executive in a generation, leading a department that climbed from laughingstock to television supremacy, pulling in up to $500 million a year in profits. **********He has been closely associated with NBC's hits over the last decade, from ''Cheers'' and ''Hill Street Blues'' to ''Cosby'' and ''Golden Girls.'' **********But those shows have made their creators and studio owners far more money from syndication profits than Mr. Tartikoff or NBC earned from selling the commercial time in them. Now, Mr. Tartikoff said, with the economics of television in upheaval, it is possible for such hits to become ''loss leaders'' for a network while they continue to make their owners rich. **********As he see it, there is a need for a a new form of television network, resembling a large Hollywood studio. **********The word studio is much on Mr. Tartikoff's lips these days. The new opportunity he most wants is to run a movie studio that NBC's parent company, the General Electric Company, would buy for him. **********The network put in a determined effort to keep Mr. Tartikoff, who said he had communicated for seven months his ''diminished interest'' in several aspects of the programming job. Mr. Tartikoff has frequently been wooed by studios, most recently this last March when he declined a feeler to take over the troubled Orion studio. **********Mr. Tartikoff called a studio a ''big toy to play with.'' He does not necessarily expect G.E. to run out and buy him one. But, he said, ''I don't rule it out either.'' He has told associates that he would like to see NBC move to buy a studio by January, especially if the networks win a ruling in December from the Federal Communications Commission authorizing them to take some profits from programs sold into syndication. **********As long as the networks are excluded from those profits, owning a studio makes less sense. But Mr. Tartikoff believes that such a move is necessary - both for NBC and his own personal growth. **********A small studio, he said, could provide the network with the packaging, experience and distribution to make middle-budget movies, those costing $12 million to $14 million. **********But, he added, he can see NBC moving to a higher level by taking advantage of its assets, including its large news and sports staffs and the production abilities of its local stations. **********Even if the studio does not work out right away, Mr. Tartikoff sees other ''sparkling opportunities.'' He has ideas for working inside NBC in a separate production unit, spinning out international co-productions and other creative programming deals. **********The arrangement calls for Mr. Tartikoff to explore these areas, while maintaining ultimate authority over his previous empire, the NBC programming division. **********But Mr. Littlefield says he will be running NBC Entertainment, using Mr. Tartikoff as a consultant. **********Mr. Littlefield participated in developing virtually every NBC show now on the air and is respected in Hollywood for his programming talent, if not his rap singing. **********In an interview last week, Mr. Littlefield acknowledged, ''Brandon casts a very large shadow.'' **********So despite the carefully muted talk of the end of the Tartikoff era in network programming, the evidence is growing that the shadow has moved on to a position in front of a different set of spotlights.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Japan Putting Limits on Aid To Nations Hurt by Embargo
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Japan Putting Limits on Aid To Nations Hurt by Embargo
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/world.body_text: **********Japanese officials attached new conditions today to the financial aid pledge Japan made last week to help Middle Eastern countries hurt by the trade embargo on Iraq. **********The shift is likely to slow the rate at which the support is delivered and make it contingent on contributions from other countries, principally the United States. **********''Japan should make a significant contribution in this field, but there is a limit to what any one country can do,'' a senior Finance Ministry official said at a briefing here today for foreign reporters. **********''An international network of support might be necessary,'' said the official, who insisted that he not be identified. **********He said that meant that Japan would try not to act on its own, but would seek to be part of an aid consortium that would include the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the United States and other industrial nations. **********No 'Cash Dispenser Machine' **********The comments marked a change in tone from last week, when Government officials said Japan was preparing to move swiftly to offer the equivalent of billions of dollars in financial support to nations that were taking part in the embargo on Iraq and were suffering economically because of it. Principally, the Government was focusing on Jordan, Egypt and Turkey, neighbors of Iraq and Kuwait. **********The remarks thus appeared to be an attempt to temper global expectations about how much Japan would contribute and the terms under which it would make loans, grants or other forms of aid available. Japan has initiated programs to help recycle the vast trade surpluses achieved in recent years, but it has fought against developing an image as a ''cash dispenser machine'' for aid, as one official here put it. **********Japan's Constitution restricts its use of military forces in international disputes, and the Government has been engaged in a fierce internal debate over how it can directly take part in the embargo without changing the law or jeopardizing political support at home. **********A number of officials had seized on financial aid to the ailing Middle Eastern countries as a form of support not restricted under the law, but which would mark a positive Japanese contribution. Those officials had said that a package of low-interest loans and other forms of aid would be announced shortly to demonstrate Japan's commitment. **********Scaling Back Expectations **********On Wednesday, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is expected to disclose his long-awaited package of measures for bolstering the multinational forces opposing Iraq. But a number of officials have said it would be just a preliminary step, and would include little of the financial aid pledged earlier. **********Press reports here have said the other measures are expected to be: sending medical personnel to the Persian Gulf region, refugee aid and transportation equipment, perhaps chartered jets and ships. The second part of the package, the financial measures, is now expected to be incomplete and contingent on talks with other countries. **********Japan is more dependent on Middle Eastern oil than any other industrialized nation, getting slightly more than 70 percent of its crude from the region. Shortly after Iraq invaded Kuwait, Japan froze the assets of the two countries and decided to join the trade embargo. Getting beyond those initial steps has proven difficult. **********The note of caution sounded by the Finance Ministry official today irritated some in the Foreign Ministry, who had hoped for a quicker and more decisive response to promote Japan's image as a leading player in international issues. **********''If we miss this wave, the wave will be gone,'' said a Foreign Ministry official, who backed a swifter commitment by the Government. ''This is frustrating for us.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/13/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Rumanian Leaders Outlaw Ousted Communist Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/13/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Rumanian Leaders Outlaw Ousted Communist Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/13/world.body_text: **********Bowing to demands of thousands of irate demonstrators, leaders of Rumania's governing Council of National Salvation agreed tonight to outlaw the Communist Party and to hold a national referendum on restoring the death penalty. **********An estimated 5,000 people joined the rally, the first public demonstration against the new leadership that took power last month in the revolution against the Communist Government of President Nicolae Ceausescu. **********Rumania is the only country in the Eastern Bloc to have outlawed the Communist Party, the only party it had before the revolution in December. But the country's new political picture is by far the most chaotic, with a hastily organized Government that has not been elected and almost no organized opposition. **********Appearing increasingly shaky in their three weeks of rule, the Council's chairman, Ion Iliescu, and Prime Minister Petre Roman also agreed to appoint a commission to receive complaints from the public. **********Council Seems to Lose Ground **********The Council of National Salvation appeared to have lost ground in a number of Rumanian cities. There were reports tonight that local governments affiliated with the Council had been ousted in Timisoara, Brasov, Iasi and other major cities. In at least one of those cities, Iasi, the army was reported to have taken control. **********The demonstration in Bucharest began at noon as a commemorative ceremony in Palace Square to mourn the thousands of Rumanians killed in the uprising against Mr. Ceausescu. **********The crowd grew, and soon there were cries for the ouster of Silviu Brucan, a veteran Communist who was held under house arrest by the dictatorship until Mr. Ceausescu's fall. Mr. Brucan, a senior member of the Council of National Salvation, said on Thursday in an interview that he remained a convinced Communist. **********''Out with Communists!'' the crowd chanted as it moved to Victory Square. The shift in mood seemed spontaneous; there were no placards or banners to suggest that the anti-Government outburst had been planned. **********When Mr. Iliescu, Mr. Roman and others tried to address the demonstrators this evening, they were often shouted down. **********There were chants demanding that Mr. Iliescu, who is also considered to have been an anti-Ceausescu dissident, step down, and Mr. Roman with him. **********'Death to Loyalists!' **********By 8 P.M. the demonstrators turned their fury on Ceausescu loyalists. ''Death to Ceausescu's people!'' they cried. ''Death to loyalists!'' Then there were shouts demanding restoration of the death penalty, which the Council abolished after ordering the execution of Mr. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, after a secret military trial. **********''Death! Death! Death!'' shouted the crowd. **********''All right, we will hold a referendum on the death penalty,'' Mr. Iliescu said. **********''Try all his chief aides!'' the crowd shouted. ''We're not leaving!'' **********The crowd then demanded that the Communist Party be outlawed. The party collapsed with the ouster and subsequent execution of Mr. Ceausescu, but the protesters evidently feared that it could be reorganized. **********''The Rumanian Communist Party is outlawed, considering that it is against the national spirit and our ancestors' law,'' Mr. Iliescu said in remarks broadcast live on state radio and television. **********That seemed to satisfy most of the demonstrators, who chanted, ''Victory! Victory!'' and began trickling home. But a core of protesters were still gathered in Victory Square after midnight, chanting anti-Communist slogans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/busin.main_headline: A Fervent Advocate Of the Proxy Battle
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/busin.print_headline: A Fervent Advocate Of the Proxy Battle
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/busin.body_text: **********Robert A. G. Monks has a resume that might endear him to any corporate board: a Harvard-educated lawyer who made his fortune as an industrialist; former chairman of a leading Boston investment firm; two-time Republican candidate for the United States Senate in Maine. And, he held top positions in the Reagan Administration. **********In this case, appearances are deceiving. Mr. Monks is the scourge of many executive suites for his outspoken - and influential - views on corporate proxy battles. From a Georgetown office, Mr. Monks, 56 years old, heads a consulting business that for a fee advises more than 100 institutions, including the mammoth employee pension funds of New York City and California, on how to vote their proxies. And he has been a behind-the-scenes player in recent proxy contests, with victories at the Lockheed Corporation and Honeywell Inc. **********For Mr. Monks, shareholder activism is a calling and he minces no words on its behalf. ''American chief executives are close to becoming the absolute monarchs that we saw in the 18th century,'' he said in an interview. ''Managements of large American corporations are only accountable to themselves. The words I use may be of governance and process, but what is really being said in a masculine, emotional way relates to power. In a psychological sense, it's like I'm gelding these guys.'' **********First-Hand Knowledge **********What sets Mr. Monks apart from other proxy advisers is that he used to run companies himself. Nor does it hurt that he has enough wealth to pursue his interests. He took over a family coal and oil business that was eventually split and sold in 1972. He successfully speculated in oil during the energy squeeze in the mid-1970's and was chairman of the Boston Company, an investment firm, until it was taken over by American Express. **********And while he has attacked corporate boards, he has sat on a few himself - not without criticism over possible conflicts of interest. Because of such questions, he recently decided to leave the board of Jefferies & Company, the Los Angeles brokerage that has advised corporate raiders. But he still holds paid advisory positions at Lambert Brussels Associates, which held a 33 percent stake in Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., and is an adviser to the American unit of Mitsubishi of Japan, though he says he may terminate these relationships. **********He approaches corporate governance with a born-again fervor, gained during his years of Government service. He came to Washington in 1981 as a director of the ill-fated Synthetic Fuels Corporation and became, in 1984, head of the Labor Department's pension and welfare benefits program. Soon, he began to exhort pension fund managers to flex their power over intransigent corporate managers. **********''I got the idea that stock ownership was a responsibility,'' he said. ''Before, I just wanted to trade.'' **********His 1984 speech ''The Institutional Investor as a Corporate Citizen'' set Labor Department policy that has encouraged proxy activism by pension funds and is considered a seminal work by shareholder activists. After leaving Government, he began, like a well-heeled Paul Revere, to travel the country, meeting pension-fund managers and spreading his views. **********Passion Into Business **********A passion turned into a business, and Mr. Monks's vehicle was Institutional Shareholders Services, a company he founded to analyze proxy questions and make recommendations - for a $10,000 annual base fee. His timing was right. Institutional funds were growing, and few had the in-house expertise, or willingness, to analyze complicated proxies, which meant that they often automatically sided with management. And, senior Labor Department officials had begun to put pressure on large institutions, which own nearly half of all corporate equities, to consider voting their proxies as a fiduciary duty. **********''One of the major criticisms of institutional investors is that they own stocks but don't know enough about the companies they own to make an informed proxy vote,'' said John Wilcox, a managing director at Georgeson & Company, a New York proxy solicitor. ''It's a perfect situation for them to seek assistance, and Bob Monks has taken advantage of that.'' **********In running his business, Mr. Monks has walked a tightrope - between conflicts in his business activities and between promoting his own ideas and the interest of his clients. **********Eyebrows were raised when Mr. Monks served as an unpaid adviser to the Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons, who led a proxy battle for control of Lockheed. Mr. Monks took pains to disclose that relationship because his firm was recommending that institutions side with Mr. Simmons. But Mr. Monks did not make similar efforts to disclose that he was a director at Jefferies, which was advising Mr. Simmons. Mr. Monks has since left the Jefferies board but still holds an equity stake in that firm. (His one remaining corporate directorship, is at Tyco Laboratories, a New Hampshire concern,) Others are concerned that Mr. Monks's zealousness for shareholder rights makes him recommend proxy-contest positions that are sometimes not in his clients' economic interests. Lilli A. Gordon, a managing director of the Analysis Group, a rival consulting firm based in Boston, pointed to the recent proxy bid by Torchmark, an insurance company with steller earnings, for American General, an insurance company with a weak stock performance. Mr. Monks recommended that his institutional clients oppose Torchmark because it has anti-takeover provisions in its own bylaws. **********''When he gives advice that could potentially decrease value for the shareholders, he's ultimately not serving his clients,'' Ms. Gordon said. **********To Mr. Monks, however, corporate governance leads to superior corporate performance. ''I'm not interested in having the world's most successful consulting firm, but in promoting my own agenda,'' he said. **********So far, that agenda has led to major shareholder victories at Honeywell and at Lockheed. In both cases, he was instrumental in connecting with a well-known investor willing to foot the bill to wage a proxy battle -which can cost between $1 million and $5 million. **********The 1989 Honeywell battle grew out of conversations Mr. Monks had with the Texas investor Richard E. Rainwater, once a financial adviser to the Bass brothers of Texas. Mr. Rainwater and other Texas investors owned 4.4 percent of Honeywell. Mr. Rainwater's group was unhappy with the company's stock performance and upset that Honeywell was asking shareholders to approve two anti-takeover measures. **********If Mr. Rainwater's group would lead the proxy battle, Mr. Monks would rally the pension funds. After a one-week blitz, their side won. The effort was remarkable because the group worked without a complete list of Honeywell shareholders. They bypassed small shareholders and relied almost exclusively on institutional votes. ''This said institutions could ignore all other shareholders and still block management initiatives,'' said Mr. Wilcox, the proxy solicitor. **********Another deep pocket for Mr. Monks was Mr. Simmons, chairman of NL Industries, who was willing to spend $11 million to take on Lockheed, in which NL had a $500 million stake. Even though Mr. Simmons did not succeed in ousting Lockheed's board, the company agreed to add three shareholders' representatives to its board and enacted three shareholder-rights measures that Mr. Simmons had proposed - overturning Lockheed's ''poison pill,'' opting out of anti-takeover protections provided by incorporation in Delaware, and confidential proxy votes. **********New Plans Afoot **********With these victories, Mr. Monks is plotting again. He wants to oppose management initiatives to issue ''sweetheart'' stock to thwart takeovers. He also wants corporations to create shareholders' advisory committees for their boards and opt out of Delaware's anti-takeover protection, if incorporated there. **********In the current USX Corporation proxy battle, he has sided with the investor Carl C. Icahn, who wants to split the company. **********Not all his clients follow his bidding, however. Paul Quirk, head of the Massachusetts Public Reserves Investment Management Board, said Mr. Monks's views are ''very refreshing'' but not always followed by his group. And Robert C. Pozen, general counsel at Fidelity Investments, terms Mr. Monks's opinions ''useful, but one of many views.'' **********Still, Mr. Monks thinks he's working on their behalf. ''It's difficult for many of my clients to take a high-visibility position,'' he said. ''I'm saying that I'll be the lightning rod.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/03/world.main_headline: Polls in Peru Show a Tight Race Shaping Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/03/world.print_headline: Polls in Peru Show a Tight Race Shaping Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/03/world.body_text: **********Peru's presidential race nears the runoff vote on June 10 with a near-tie in the polls between the two candidates: Mario Vargas Llosa, the novelist, and Alberto Fujimori, an agricultural engineer. **********The race may tip decisively on Sunday night as Peruvians watch the only scheduled television debate between the candidates. **********Because of a slow vote count from the first-round election, the national election board in mid-May moved the date from June 3 to June 10. **********The debate may favor Mr. Vargas Llosa, a free-market advocate, who enjoys a slight lead in the polls in Lima, home to one-third of Peru's 22 million people. Mr. Fujimori, leads in the interior, which is mostly without television. **********Mr. Fujimori, who surprised many Peruvians with his strong showing in the first round of voting on April 8, has subsequently been hurt by opposition charges that he cheated on his taxes and that his economic program is sketchy. In addition, Japan's Government rejected assertions by Mr. Fujimori, the son of Japanese immigrants, that his election would unleash an avalanche of Japanese aid and investment. Bolstering Mr. Fujimori and his Change 90 movement has been the official support of Peru's established left and center-left parties. **********Stung by charges that he ran an elitist campaign, Mr. Vargas Llosa has rolled up his sleeves and campaigned heavily in Lima's shantytowns. **********Mr. Vargas Llosa may also be helped by what Lima's popular press calls Peru's ''holy war.'' **********Concerned about strong evangelical Protestant support for Mr. Fujimori, the Roman Catholic hierarchy has campaigned openly for Mr. Vargas Llosa. **********Oddly enough, Mr. Vargas Llosa, the son of Catholics, is an agnostic, and Mr. Fujimori, the son of Buddhists, is a Catholic. Only about 5 percent of Peruvians are Protestant. The rest are Catholics, by practice or by tradition. **********In an ''open letter to Peruvian Catholics,'' Lima's Roman Catholic Archbishop, Augusto Vargas Alzamora, denounced an effort ''to destroy the Catholic Church'' and ''an insidious campaign against our faith.'' **********On Tuesday night, an earthquake registering 6.3 on the Richter scale, shook Peru's Amazon, killing 137 people, injuring hundreds and leaving thousands homeless. **********Public anguish over the earthquake may have swelled the religious processions, which drew about half a million people into the streets of Lima. In a country with deep spiritual roots, many people noted that the Amazon shook on the 20th anniversary of an earthquake that killed 70,000 in the north. **********After processions, Peru's Government placed Lima and the neighboring port of Callao under a 30-day state of emergency. A similar state of emergency, which gave broad powers to the police and military, was decreed before the first round of voting in an attempt to prevent attacks by the Shining Path guerrilla organization. **********The violent Maoist-line group has reportedly suffered a split and in recent weeks it has carried out only sporadic actions against the elections. **********Last week, the Shining Path killed two of Mr. Vargas Llosa's political supporters, including a former state governor. On Thursday, the police said guerrillas killed eight people in three towns near the city of Huancavelica in Peru's southern highlands.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/30/busin.body_text: **********Soaring oil prices pushed West Germany's inflation higher in August, but economists said the rate for the year could still be kept near the 3 percent level. The Federal Statistics Office said today that West Germany's cost of living rose four-tenths of 1 percent in August, for a rise of 2.9 percent over the last 12 months. It was the highest year-on-year rise since December 1989, when prices rose 3 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/05/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Soviets Suggest Conference Combining Issues of Mideast
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/05/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Soviets Suggest Conference Combining Issues of Mideast
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/05/world.body_text: **********Longtime Source of Contention **********The Kremlin's proposal for an international conference was long a cold-war bone of contention, with Israel maintaining strict opposition to such a forum as a means of addressing the Palestinian question. **********President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has been denounced by the United States for saying that consideration of a military retreat from Kuwait must be contingent upon an Israeli withdrawal from territory occupied in previous Middle East wars. **********In his speech, Mr. Shevardnadze gave no indication whether President Mikhail S. Gorbachev might pursue this point at his summit meeting with President Bush in Helsinki on Sunday. **********''Presumably, Israel's agreement to its convocation could exert a positive influence on the overall situation in the Middle East and on efforts to defuse the crisis,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said, renewing the proposal for an international meeting on the Middle East. **********''For its part, the Soviet Union would not leave without response an Israeli move along these lines and might take a fresh look at the issue of Soviet-Israeli relations,'' he said, apparently referring to the question of restoring Moscow's diplomatic links with Israel. Relations were severed after the 1967 war in the Middle East. **********Support for U.N. Effort **********The move to link the conference proposal to the Kuwait crisis was something of a surprise, coming as it did only five days before the one-day Helsinki summit meeting, which is expected to emphasize Moscow-Washington agreement over how best to press Mr. Hussein to retreat from Kuwait. **********Mr. Shevardnadze stressed that the Soviet Union felt ''duty bound'' by the United Nations Security Council resolutions condemning Iraq and pressing for a diplomatic settlement. **********''Even hypothetically we should not acquiesce in any option that would fall short of restoring the sovereignty, territorial integrity and legitimate Government of Kuwait,'' he said, urging political approaches to ''remove the military presence of other countries.'' **********In the last week, a few Soviet officials have departed from the Kremlin's quiet tolerance of the Bush Administration's military buildup in Saudi Arabia, saying the buildup could continue after the crisis and jeopardize Soviet-American progress in disarmament. **********But Mr. Gorbachev has made a point of saying before the summit meeting that the White House moved at the invitation of Saudi Arabia and in conformity with the United Nations Charter, and that there has been no flagging in Soviet-American cooperation. **********List of 'Interlocking Problems' **********Mr. Shevardnadze said the ''complex interlocking problems'' included ''the Arab-Israeli conflict, the fate of the Palestinians and the tragedy in Lebanon,'' all of them aggravated by ''critically high'' amounts of arms. **********''Quite a few extraregional states, including the great powers, have contributed to that situation,'' he said. **********''After one more look at the situation we still have come to the same conclusion,'' he said, saying that the Gorbachev Government feels the need to increase pressure for an international conference on the Middle East ''without deferring for a subsequent period'' the United Nations' efforts to bring about a comprehensive settlement. **********Diplomatic efforts ''unquestionably'' deserve priority in tackling the Kuwait crisis, Mr. Shevardnadze said, while adding: ''The course at a peaceful settlement should in no way imply that the aggressor has nothing to fear.'' **********Predicting that the summit meeting in Helsinki would ''mark a major milestone on the road toward resolving the crisis,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said the Soviet Union was convinced that the sanctions against Iraq would work. **********Baker Cool to Conference **********WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (Special to The New York Times) - In an interview with NBC News, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d appeared today to dismiss the proposal by Mr. Shevardnadze to convene an international conference. **********Mr. Baker said that an ''extraordinary degree of international consensus'' already existed for dealing with Iraq and that considering all the actions taken by the United Nations so far ''we almost have an international conference.'' **********In what seemed to be a polite way of dismissing Mr. Shevardnadze's proposal, the Secretary said, ''We would like to see a little bit more of what the Soviets have in mind.'' **********Shevardnadze Arrives for Talks **********TOKYO, Sept. 4 (Special to The New York Times) - Foreign Minister Shevardnadze arrived here tonight to begin three days of talks that Tokyo hopes will thaw decades of frigid relations before next year, when President Gorbachev becomes the first Soviet leader to visit Japan. **********Both Japanese and Soviet officials here played down the likelihood of any major progress on the one issue that has kept Japanese money and technology out of Mr. Gorbachev's reach: the continuing dispute over four northern islands that the Soviet Union claimed in the last days of World War II. But the tempo of discussions about the islands has accelerated recently. **********On Monday Ivan Frolov, a Politburo member and chief editor of the newspaper Pravda, said Mr. Gorbachev would bring with him ''something historic'' in his visit to Tokyo, scheduled for next spring. But Japanese officials say there has been little indication that the Soviets have any inclination to return the islands.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/22/busin.main_headline: Disney Files Antitrust Suit Against Fox
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/22/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Disney Files Antitrust Suit Against Fox
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/22/busin.body_text: **********The Walt Disney Company filed an antitrust lawsuit today against Fox Inc. in a case that illustrates the awkward role Fox faces in trying to be a television network and a programming supplier. **********Disney said it had filed suit in Federal District Court here, accusing Fox of trying to prevent affiliates of the fledgling Fox network from carrying afternoon cartoon programming from Disney's syndication unit, which is called Buena Vista Television. Disney said Fox was putting pressure on the 126 affiliates to carry Fox's cartoon programming instead. **********A spokesman for Fox, a subsidiary of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, said the company does not comment on lawsuits. Kevin O'Brien, the general manager of KTVU-TV in San Francisco and president of a Fox affiliate's oversight committee on children's television, said these charges ''are so absurd they're comical.'' Request to F.C.C.  Disney also asked the Federal Communications Commission today to reject Fox's recent request to be granted a waiver of restrictions on the activities of networks. Starting in the fall, Fox will be considered a network under Federal rules, after it begins broadcasting more than 15 hours of programming a week. **********Fox wants exemptions from rules that bar networks from syndicating programs. **********Trying to reconcile its roles as owner of a studio and a network, Fox has increasingly been caught in the middle of the long-running dispute between program producers and ABC, CBS and NBC over whether the networks should be allowed to own stakes in entertainment shows and to profit from their syndication. **********Fox, the parent of the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation and Fox Television, broke ranks with the other studios last month by asking the F.C.C. to relax its current rules. The rules limit the involvement of networks in the production, ownership and distribution of programming. **********Fox also asked the agency to reconsider its definition of a network and requested a waiver of limitations on network activities until the F.C.C. completed the process of drawing new rules. **********The Disney suit asserts that Fox has threatened to end its affiliation agreement with any station that agrees to carry Disney's afternoon block of cartoons. Fox is offering its stations a half-hour ''Peter Pan'' cartoon show in the fall and eventually plans to develop a two-hour cartoon block similar to Disney's. **********Disney is seeking unspecified damages from Fox and a court order barring Fox from what Disney calls anti-competitive practices.
