https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/23/busin.main_headline: Eastern Pilots Accept Pact With Wage Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Eastern Pilots Accept Pact With Wage Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/23/busin.body_text: **********Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it had reached an interim agreement calling for wage and benefit cuts by members of its pilots' union, but that the cost savings would be less than half the amount needed to allow the airline to emerge from bankruptcy court protection. **********Under the agreement, the wages of pilots will be reduced by 25 percent and the amounts paid by Eastern into a retirement plan will be cut. Pilots will also contribute to medical and dental insurance plans. **********The agreement did not cover about 1,500 to 2,000 pilots who have not been recalled to work even though the union ended its sympathy strike last November. **********The pilots honored picket lines set up when the Eastern machinists' union went on strike a year ago. Eastern hired new pilots during the strike and cut back routes. It says it does not need to recall the strikers. **********The wage cut under the new agreement applies to the Eastern pilots who are still being paid at the pre-strike wage rate. Replacement pilots have been hired at lower pay. **********The wage-and-benefit cuts would remain in place until July 1 unless the two sides reach a new agreement, or the United States Bankruptcy Court requires even-harsher cost reductions, or the National Mediation Board declares a 30-day cooling-off period. **********Labor disputes in the airline industry are settled under the Railway Labor Act, which provides for intervention by the National Mediation Board. **********Eastern, which is owned by the Texas Air Corporation, has been seeking to to emerge from bankruptcy by early summer. The interim agreement with the pilots is expected to help Eastern get its reorganization plan approved by Judge Burton R. Lifland of the United States Bankrupty Court in Manhattan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Navistar International Names New Officers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/09/busin.body_text: **********The Navistar International Corporation, maker of heavy trucks and diesel engines, yesterday announced a new management lineup, with John R. Horne as president and chief operating officer. **********Also promoted was Robert C. Lannert, who will be executive vice president and chief finnacial officer. Both men were named directors. **********Mr. Horne, 52 years old, and Mr. Lannert, 50, will join a newly formed office of the chief executive with James C. Cotting, 57, chairman and chief executive. The office will be responsible for the overall results of the corporation and its strategic direction, Navistar said. **********Mr. Horne succeeds Neil A. Springer, 52, who left the company last month after a 30-year career there. **********The company, which is based in Chicago, and was formerly International Harvester, is "doing well given an abominable truck market," said John E. McGinty, analyst at the First Boston Corporation. The market is at its lowest level in a decade, he said, adding, however, that Navistar was in a sound financial position. "The only unknown is its unfunded past medical costs, and the company won't comment on that," he said. **********Another analyst, Eli S. Lustgarten of Paine Webber, noted that Mr. Cotting had a financial background and said he was glad to see him expand managment with an operations man. Mr. Horne has been group vice president and general manager for engine and foundry operations. Daniel C. Ustian, 40, was named to succeed him in that post. **********Mr. Horne oversaw product advancements in diesel engines, including a new "smokeless diesel" that already meets 1994 Federal emissions standards, Mr. Cotting said in a statement. **********Mr. Horne joined the company in 1966 as an engineer in the diesel engineering center at Melrose Park, Ill. He was named group vice president earlier this year. **********Mr. Lannert has been vice president and treasurer of Navistar. The post of chief financial officer is a new one at the company. Mr. Lannert joined International Harvester as a trainee in the treasury department in 1963. Mr. Cotting cited his "major contribution" during Navistar's financial restructuring in the 1980's after it came close to bankruptcy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/25/busin.main_headline: Talks End; Charges Seen At Eastern
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/25/busin.print_headline: Talks End; Charges Seen At Eastern
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/25/busin.body_text: **********Eastern Airlines has failed to reach a plea-bargaining agreement in a Federal investigation of past maintenance practices, and a grand jury is expected to indict the carrier this week on criminal charges, Eastern's court-appointed trustee and Federal officials said yesterday. **********The indictments, expected to include charges of conspiracy to falsify maintenance records, would mark the first time an airline has faced criminal charges for faulty maintenance. If found guilty, Eastern faces large fines, and some current or former executives face possible imprisonment. **********Current Practices Not at Issue **********Any indictments would involve practices that are said to have occurred in early 1989, and Federal aviation officials say the airline now complies with all regulations. Still, industry analysts said yesterday, the indictments would deal another blow to Eastern, which has been losing more than $1 million a day since a strike by its machinists began in March 1989. The carrier is operating under bankruptcy protection. **********But some of the analysts said yesterday that Eastern's image could not be blemished much further than it already had been. ''It'll be like beating a dead horse,'' said Kevin Murphy of Morgan Stanley & Company. **********The pending indictments are not expected to sidetrack negotiations with Northwest Airlines this week about a possible takeover of Eastern, Mr. Murphy said. **********For about 10 months, a grand jury has been investigating Eastern's maintenance practices during the early part of last year at Kennedy International Airport and La Guardia Airport in New York and at Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta. At least seven current and former Eastern employees, including vice presidents of the company, are expected to be named in the indictments, which may have already been voted upon and could be announced as early as today, a Federal official familar with the case said yesterday. **********No accidents occurred as a result of the purported violations, and Eastern's current maintenance practices are not under investigation, the Federal officials said. **********Martin R. Shugrue Jr., Eastern's court-appointed trustee, described the purported violations yesterday as ''ancient history'' and said all the problems had been corrected. ''Eastern has many problems,'' he said. ''Flying a safe airline is not one of them.'' **********But Mr. Shugrue acknowledged that in some cases ''routine work that was supposed to be accomplished was not.'' **********Impasse Over Conspiracy Charge **********Talks between Eastern's lawyers and Andrew J. Maloney, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, broke off last night over an impasse on the conspiracy charges being considered against the carrier, Mr. Shugrue said. He said the airline was unwilling to agree to a conspiracy charge of falsifying maintenance records because he would not admit to a ''systemic problem at the airline.'' **********Mary Jo White, a spokeswoman for the United States Attorney's office in Brooklyn, declined to comment. **********Mr. Shugrue said earlier this month that all of the people being investigated had left Eastern or had been assigned to other departments. **********Kennedy Practices Most Serious **********The most serious of the charges involve Eastern's maintenance operation at Kennedy Airport in New York, where supervisors purportedly falsified records, a Federal official familiar with the case said yesterday. In some of the cases, Eastern supervisors purportedly signed off on repairs even though they were never made. **********Eastern closed its base at Kennedy last year after the Federal Aviation Administration fined the carrier $893,000 for ''faulty maintenance,'' Fred Farrar, an F.A.A. spokesman, said yesterday. An investigation by the agency of Eastern's maintenance practices at other cities found no problems, he said. **********The possible criminal indictments against Eastern are also expected to include fraud, obstruction of justice and making false statements. **********No Criminal Charges Ever **********The F.A.A. regularly fines airlines for maintenance practices, but never have criminal charges been filed. The agency has faced a shortage of inspectors in recent years and has been criticized by some consumer groups and members of Congress for not scrutinizing airlines carefully enough. **********One aviation expert said yesterday that the expected indictments were meant as a deterrent to other carriers. The message to the airlines is: ''You better be honest or you will be charged with a criminal act,'' said John Galipault, the president of the Aviation Safety Institute, a research group based in Worthington, Ohio.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/busin.main_headline: A 'White Knight' Draws Cries of 'Patent Blackmail'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/busin.print_headline: A 'White Knight' Draws Cries of 'Patent Blackmail'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/busin.body_text: **********Most people who have heard of Eugene M. Lang know him as the New York philanthropist who struck an imaginative deal with a class of Harlem sixth graders: If they finished high school, he would pay their college expenses. The idea, which has been widely copied, brought Mr. Lang national celebrity. **********Mr. Lang's for-profit company, the Refac Technology Development Corporation, is far less famous, and is drawing far less favorable reviews from some quarters. Based in New York City, Refac promotes itself as a ''white knight'' for small-time inventors who lack the resources to fight their own legal battles. But critics - and there are many - angrily charge that the company makes millions of dollars through ''patent blackmail'' and the cheeky manipulation of weaknesses in the legal system. **********What has prompted their outrage is Refac's use of patent infringement suits; it has filed against 2,000 companies so far and has threatened to file against more than 1,000 others. Among the targets are manufacturers like International Business Machines and Eastman Kodak; retailers like R.H. Macy, Sears and Radio Shack, and scores of small importers and distributors. Critics say Refac is, in effect, practicing a form of litigation extortion. They charge that the company merely acquires obscure patents that have little real value and do not hold up in court and uses them as weapons to create enough fear and and confusion to force settlements. **********''They are trying to live off industry by using fear and intimidation. It's a disgrace of the legal system,'' said Bernard E. Appel, president of the Tandy Corporation's Radio Shack retail chain, which Refac has sued more than once. Surjit P. Soni, a lawyer for electronics importers in Pasadena, Calif., who recently succeeded in getting a Refac suit thrown out of court, said: ''I believe this has been a scheme from day one, a concerted plan to extort money through the abuse of the legal system.'' **********Not true, responded Mr. Lang. ''We prefer not to litigate,'' he said. ''Our interest has always been in representing small companies or individuals who do not have the experience or expertise to represent their own interests effectively. Philosophically, my basic interest has always been to represent the little guy. I am a little guy myself.'' **********If the volume of Refac's activity seems audacious, the scope of its technological claims is truly breathtaking. Among other things, it claims ''basic'' patents in the following: *********** Liquid crystal displays, for virtually any digital readout found in a watch, electronic calculator, consumer appliance or automobile dashboard. *********** Automated teller machines, present at bank branches around the country. *********** Credit card verification systems, like those used by retailers to automatically check Mastercard and Visa numbers. *********** Bar code scanning systems, such as those used in stores and factories to read price tags and shipping labels. *********** Videocassette recorders, audiocassette tape players and camcorders. Refac says its patent covers the method of threading tape used by all manufacturers. *********** Electronic keyboards. Refac is demanding royalties from every major manufacturer of electric pianos and organs. *********** Spreadsheet software. In its biggest splash yet, Refac filed suit during the summer against five top companies in the $700 million to $800 million market, including the Lotus Development Corporation, over its Lotus 1-2-3 program. **********Refac's philosophy has paid off handsomely. The company's revenues, mostly from royalties, have surged from $3.2 million in 1985 to $10.2 million in the first nine months of last year, and Refac enjoys a robust, 25 percent after-tax profit margin. If its current claims prove even marginally successful, moreover, these sums will be just pocket change. **********Yet the most striking feature of Refac's performance is the contrast between its success in obtaining royalties and its failure to win court cases. The company has not won any lawsuits, although it has benefited hugely from fundamental laser patents obtained and defended in litigation by the laser pioneer Gordon Gould. Several Refac cases have been thrown out of court on summary judgment, often amid scathing criticism by Federal judges of Refac's tactics. **********But even Refac's angriest detractors agree that it is simply the most aggressive example of a much larger trend. Court awards in patent suits have been skyrocketing since the early 1980's, as a new Federal appeals court has begun enforcing patent claims much more rigorously. **********The courts have also allowed juries to handle more decisions, and many have proven eager to side with inventors against large companies. The upshot is what one expert calls a ''judicial lottery,'' an often unpredictable system that can yield huge rewards for those who are sufficiently aggressive. An important indicator of the lucrative new opportunities, however, is that high-powered patent law firms are now agreeing to gamble with millions of dollars worth of their time by representing lone inventors on a contingency-fee basis. Until recently, most refused to do that, because the cases are so time-consuming and the prospects so uncertain. **********That is changing. In November, for example, an independent inventor in Princeton, N.J., Jerome Lemelson, won an award of $25 million after fighting a 12-year case against Mattel Inc. over its line of Hot Wheels toys. **********This month, an even bigger case, not related to Refac, is being tried in Detroit. The seemingly improbable suit, brought in 1978 by Robert Kearns, an independent inventor, against the Ford Motor Company, claims rights to the intermittent windshield wiper and could, if successful, cost automobile makers as much as $1 billion in royalties. The battle is being waged on a contingency basis by one of the most respected patent firms in the country, Houston-based Arnold, White & Durkee. **********Refac was founded in 1952 by Mr. Lang, and for most of its years was a fairly quiet licensing company that achieved modest success by skillful negotiation. Typically, Refac acquired a patent in exchange for assuming the burden of negotiating for royalties or, if need be, litigating. In most cases, the company then split the profits from any license fees with the inventors. In almost all cases, said Mr. Lang, Refac owns the technology and acts as a principal, not as an agent for the inventor. **********Even today, Mr. Lang said, there are some technologies that do not require litigation on Refac's part. Still, the most lucrative of those account for less than 15 percent of Refac's revenues. **********The moving force behind Refac's legal strategy was Philip Sperber, who, until his death in a Dec. 13 automobile accident, was the company's vice president and lead litigator. A strong believer in litigating as a negotiating tool, he was instrumental in transforming Refac from a mere licensing company to a litigation factory. **********Mr. Sperber developed a basic strategy of suing great numbers of companies at one time, and not only the manufacturers alleged to be infringing, but distributors, retailers and customers as well. **********Refac's aggressiveness has sometimes gotten it in trouble. When the company pressed claims against makers of automated teller machines, United States District Judge Nicholas Politan in New Jersey dismissed the case as frivolous and lectured Refac on its tactics, saying Refac had ''unnecessarily contacted and harassed'' customers of Diebold Inc. **********Suing retailers and customers is perfectly legal, however, and Mr. Lang defended the practice as the only way to identify the manufacturers. ''How are we going to reach the manufacturers if they're in Hong Kong?'' he asked. **********But lawyers for retailers and customers charged that Refac was exploiting the fact that such companies are simply more likely to settle because they have less stake in the issue. ''It's patent blackmail,'' added Harold Wegner, a Washington lawyer whose firm has defended numerous small companies. ''Refac coerces manufacturers to settle for high license fees, because if they don't, the retailers and distributors will go to their competitors.'' **********Despite its track record in court, Refac hasn't stopped seeking royalties or threatening new lawsuits. In October, the company notified some former defendants in California that it was offering a 50 percent discount from Refac's normal royalty rates while it appealed. **********In the meantime, Refac reminded them by letter, ''you may be at risk'' of suits in other jurisdictions ''regardless of what happens on appeal in this case.'' **********HELPFUL HINTS FOR LITIGATORS **********The man most responsible for transforming Refac from a licensing company to a litigation factory is Philip Sperber, who was vice president and lead litigator until his death in an automobile accident last month. Mr. Sperber often wrote about licensing, and was forthright about his fondness for suing. **********''While no one can replace him,'' Eugene M. Lang, the president of Refac, said of Mr. Sperber, ''we are in a position, happily enough, to pick up the pieces.'' **********The following examples of Mr. Sperber's thinking have appeared in Les Nouvelles, the journal of the Licensing Executive Society: **********On the cost of litigation: ''It only makes sense to view the cost of litigation as bargaining leverage to force a settlement on terms favorable to the party that can litigate the matter to death without worrying about the cash flow.'' **********On jury trials over arbitration: ''If patent validity or infringement is questionable, why take a chance with an arbitration expert who will know exactly how weak the patent is and how dubious infringement is? It makes sense to take one's chances with a judge inexperienced in the technical and legal aspects involved. If the infringer is much bigger than the patentee or an entire industry has copied the patent, a jury trial would be much more beneficial than arbitration because of the sympathy and deep-pocket doctrine that can be played to the hilt.'' **********On suing retailers and customers as well as manufacturers: '' . . . Retailers and users sued for patent infringement frequently establish a policy of buying only from suppliers licensed by the patent holder. This results in manufacturers, importers and foreign exporters voluntarily asking for a license. This industrywide litigation strategy also has a synergistic effect that encourages settlement on the part of infringers.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/busin.main_headline: U.S. Treasury Charges Discrimination by Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/busin.print_headline: U.S. Treasury Charges Discrimination by Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/busin.body_text: **********In a tough new report on the slow opening of Japan's financial markets, the United States Treasury Department said today that foreign banks and securities firms were still blocked from competing on equal terms because of legal and informal hurdles, despite Tokyo's emergence as a major financial center. **********The Treasury study conceded that some of the blatant discrimination against foreigners, such as a lack of seats on the Tokyo stock exchange, have been eliminated in recent years. But in a slight shift of focus in Washington's efforts to open Japan's financial markets, it added that some of the worst impediments faced by foreign firms were informal barriers, or unwritten business and government practices. **********An example of this sort of barrier has cropped up recently in what is becoming one of the most closely watched confrontations between an American securities house and Japanese ways in years. **********Salomon Brothers Inc. appeared to have staged a coup recently in breaking the lock grip that big Japanese brokerage houses have on underwriting the yen securities of Japanese companies. It won the mandate to be the lead manager on two big offerings of convertible bonds in the Euromarkets for Oji Paper and Fujisawa Pharmaceutical.  'Like Exporting AIDS' **********But just 10 days later, Japan's biggest broker, Nomura Securities, protested vehemently against what it described as the unsound way Salomon planned to trade the bonds after they were issued, a complex technique that is common in the more innovative New York markets. The yen-denominated securities were going to be swapped into dollars, combined with options and sold to American insurance companies as private placements instead of publicly listed securities. **********"It's like exporting AIDS from Wall Street," Tadashi Takubo, an executive managing director at Nomura, was quoted as saying in the Japan Economic Journal, the country's leading business newspaper. "We have to protect the soundness of the Tokyo market from the U.S. threat." **********Asked about the story, Fujisawa Pharmaceutical said yesterday that it had not decided who would underwrite its convertible bonds and Oji Paper said it would neither confirm nor deny the reports. **********But Salomon officials insisted the Big Four securities houses had intimidated the companies into backing away from using an American lead underwriter, in spite of the better terms Salomon was offering.  Importance of Cultural Factors **********"We offer good technology and some good market opportunities, but how a Japanese company comes to a decision on its underwriter is the critical question at the end of the day," said Kunihiko Kumagai, a managing director at Salomon Brothers. "The cultural, or invisible factors can be the most important part of doing business." **********He added, "We need to learn a lot more about how to persuade a Japanese company." **********Earlier this year, Salomon sailed into another controversy when it stunned the Big Four by underwriting some dollar-denominated bonds for Mitsui Toatsu, a big chemical company. Shortly afterward the Japanese newspapers were filled with complaints from the big Japanese brokerage houses on how Salomon's program trading was behind a steep slide in share prices. **********The report issued today is a so-called national treatment study, intended to determine whether American financial institutions are permitted to compete on an equal footing with Japan's own banks and securities firms within Japan. The latest report, the fourth in the last decade, repeats the conclusion that Japan still restricts the operating ability of foreign bankers and investment bankers. **********According to Treasury estimates, foreign banks have actually been losing ground here. **********Foreign banks' share of total lending has tumbled from 3.5 percent in March 1983 to 1.7 percent at the end of last year. By contrast, Japanese banks have taken more than 25 percent of the lucrative California banking market. **********No Japanese bank has been acquired by a foreign bank and foreign banks must pay much higher rates to borrow yen and acquire funds to operate in Japan, the report says. **********Specifically, the Treasury contends that despite several important openings since 1986, keiretsu, or big groupings of industrial companies and banks, exclude foreign banks. Relatively inexpensive short-term loans from the Bank of Japan are difficult for foreigners to obtain. Japan's short-term money markets remain underdeveloped. And many regulations continue to be delivered orally or in ways that are difficult for foreign banks to obtain and cary out. **********On the securities side, the report argues that foreign firms are still excluded from the underwriting business. They are still not free to trade in foreign currencies. New financial products are accepted here only after substantial delays. And foreign firms still face major obstacles in breaking into the lucrative business of managing pension funds and investment trusts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/30/busin.main_headline: Stanhome's New Chief Began With Summer Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/30/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Stanhome's New Chief Began With Summer Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/30/busin.body_text: **********Alejandro Diaz Vargas, who first worked for Stanhome Inc. in a summer job in a distribution center in Puerto Rico, has been named the company's chief executive, arriving at the top post at the age of 45. **********Stanhome, based in Westfield, Mass., and once known as Stanley Home Products, makes and distributes home and personal care products, imports and distributes porcelain figurines and other giftware and sells giftware and collectibles. **********The company, with virtually no long-term debt, has had a return on equity averaging well over 25 percent in the last four years, a recent Standard & Poor's report noted. Stanhome expects this year to be another profitable one; in the last five years the annual rate of growth in earnings per share has been 23 percent. **********Mr. Diaz, who is known to his associates as Alek, has been president since 1988 and added the title of chief operating officer in 1989. He is now taking on the chief executive post as well, succeeding H. L. (Bill) Tower, 58, who held the post for 12 years. Mr. Tower remains the chairman. **********Mr. Diaz said on Friday that he made it to the top ''by working very hard.'' After graduation from the University of Puerto Rico and a stint in the Army he was ready to find a job and remembered his summer employer, Stanhome. ''I decided to make a phone call,'' he said, and got an interview in Westfield, in western Massachusetts. **********Mr. Diaz apparently made a good impression. He was named assistant to the president of the international division, a job he held for six months before being assigned to two other vice presidents and moving to Europe, where he stayed for seven years, working in Britain, Spain, Portugal and Italy. He returned to the international division in Westfield and about five years ago was made president of the division. **********The company sells its home and personal care products wholesale to independent dealers who in turn sell them to consumers at home gatherings. Stanhome sells its giftware and collectibles through its Enesco giftware group and sells collectibles directly through advertisements in magazines by its Hamilton group, a recent acquisition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/20/busin.body_text: **********Increasing consumption and growing imports pushed Japan's trade surplus down in December, the Finance Ministry said today. It was the eighth consecutive monthly decline from levels a year earlier. **********The trade surplus, calculated on a customs-clearance basis, shrank 36.3 percent, to $6.19 billion, from a year earlier, when it registered $9.72 billion, the ministry said. **********The trade account for all of 1989 was in surplus by $64.43 billion, compared with $77.56 billion in 1988. Ministry officials attributed the paring of the trade surplus to higher personal consumption and import growth. In December, they said, high oil prices also pushed up the value of imports. **********In December, exports totaled $24.59 billion, off 6 percent from a year earlier, while imports were up 11.8 percent, at $18.40 billion. **********The monthly trade surplus with the United States dropped 24 percent, to $3.83 billion, the report said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/busin.main_headline: Poland Applies Shock Treatment to Revive Its Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/busin.print_headline: Poland Applies Shock Treatment to Revive Its Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/busin.body_text: **********Poland's crash economic plan is intended, in short, to jump-start the nation's jalopy-like economy. But critics ranging from free-market economists to doctrinaire Communist leaders fear that the plan's high-voltage jolt can cause the rusting, brittle economy to explode before it heaves forward. **********No one denies that Poland's pioneering program to move toward capitalism, which includes painful steps like removing price controls and ending most subsidies to consumers and industry, is fraught with risks. The biggest risk is that the plan's painful results, including a spike of inflation, high unemployment and numerous bankruptcies, will provoke a wave of strikes or other unrest that can drag the economy further into the mud. **********Fears of such unrest did not diminish in January, when prices rose about 70 percent, far above the 45 percent forecast by the Government. At the same time, the purchasing power of an average family plunged an estimated 30 percent in January alone, because of strict wage controls. The Government had predicted that its shock program, which began on Jan. 1, would push down family incomes 20 percent over several months. **********Desire for Capitalism **********For critics of the plan, many of whom share a desire to transform Poland into a capitalist economy, January's unhappy statistics bear out their fears that reformers tried to do too much too quickly. The critics argue that prices will rise more, and purchasing power will fall faster, than the Government predicted. In their view, the Polish economy was too rigid to adapt as quickly as the Government had hoped. **********The critics said, for example, that the Government was too optimistic about inflation because, in their view, it paid too little attention to monopolies. Single enterprises have controlled many industries here for 40 years, and many of those companies raised prices substantially after price controls were lifted and they were told they must become self-supporting in the new ''sink or swim'' era. **********''Any well-trained economist knows that if you apply market mechanisms to an economy with no market infrastructure, you're not going to be able to achieve what you want,'' said Jan Vanous, research director of PlanEcon, a Washington-based consulting group that monitors Eastern Europe. ''It could be an utter disaster.'' **********Possible Social Unrest **********One thing on which the plan's architects and critics agree is that there may be social unrest if inflation continues to rage in February and wages remain far behind. The fear is that there could be dozens of strikes instead of the half dozen that took place in January. **********Nonetheless, Government officials defend their plan, saying a ''big bang'' was the only way to awaken Poland's prostrate economy and bring down the inflation rate, which was more than 500 percent last year. These officials say it is better to take very bitter medicine for a short time, in the hope of regaining economic health, than to suffer severely for a long time with no hope of a cure. **********Polish officials point to some evidence that the plan is starting to work. Prices rose more slowly at the end of January than at the beginning of the month. They note that the price of milk, meat and some other items even fell after rising steeply. **********Success on Currency **********What is more, the Government's efforts to create a convertible currency appear successful. Finance Ministry officials are pleasantly surprised that the zloty's official exchange rate remains stronger than the black-market rate. A stable currency helps bring down expectations of inflation. The Government hopes that after the January burst of price increases, inflation will fall to a monthly rate of 4 percent or less this spring, and the economy will start to grow again after a decade of stagnation. **********Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz insists that the plan is the best one for Poland. ''A gradual program can work when you have minor inflation,'' he said. ''I would prefer a gradual approach if I knew it would work. But if you want to get rid of hyperinflation, you have to accept a crash program.'' **********The biggest test of the Balcerowicz plan will be getting inflation under control as soon as possible. The plan limits monthly wage increases to 30 percent of inflation, which aims to check inflationary pressures and help shell-shocked companies stay in business. In January, prices jumped 70 percent and wages rose 21 percent, meaning a 30 percent loss in purchasing power. If inflation remains strong in February, the wage controls could mean a cumulative drop in purchasing power of 40 or 50 percent. **********In January, the Government conceded modest wage increases to striking coal miners, but did so in a low-key way. In addition, after farmers protested that they were being driven out of business, the Government quietly increased subsidies to buy tractors. **********Some economists say a wiser approach for Eastern European nations moving away from Communism would be to take a series of preliminary steps to increase competition before lifting price controls. That is the path Czechoslovakia has chosen. **********Although there is disagreement about prices, everyone agrees that removing price controls is essential to encourage companies to produce more and to give them a true measure of profitability and efficiency. **********Timing Mistake **********''The mistake is to begin price reforms with a monopolistic structure,'' said Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus of Czechoslovakia. **********Czechoslovak officials say that before lifting price controls, they want to break up monopolies and encourage start-up businesses. In Poland, a tight credit policy is intended to squeeze out inflation. **********In addition, Czechoslovak officials say they want to allow more imports, to increase competition from abroad, before freeing prices. To help preserve hard currency and prevent domestic bankruptcies, the Polish Government has imposed high duties on imported cars and electronic products. **********Mr. Balcerowicz, the Finance Minister, admits that Poland's plan has some imperfections. But he has repeatedly said that Poland's economy was disintegrating too quickly for the Government to have the luxury of taking months to hammer out an ideal program. In his view, the problem of hyperinflation was paramount, and Poland could not devote a year or two to gradual competition-creating policies before lifting price controls. **********''No one has ever stopped hyperinflation with a gradual approach,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/16/busin.body_text: **********The Polaroid Corporation's stock tumbled more than 20 percent yesterday, as investors showed their disappointment in the news late Friday that the company would receive hundreds of millions of dollars less in damages than had been expected from the infringement of its instant photography patents by the Eastman Kodak Company. **********Analysts said that Polaroid's third-quarter earnings, announced yesterday, also contained enough bad news to contribute to the slide, although overall earnings and sales were higher than a year earlier. Polaroid reported that net income increased 5 percent, to $31.3 million, or 42 cents a share, from $29.9 million, or 40 cents a share, in 1989's third quarter. Worldwide sales climbed 6 percent, to $463.7 million from $437.7 million. **********Polaroid's shares fell $6.50 yesterday to close at $22.75, making it the second-biggest loser on the New York Stock Exchange. Kodak's shares, however, rose $3.25, to $37.875. Kodak was the second-most-active issue on the Big Board, with 2.7 million shares traded, and Polaroid was the sixth-most-active, as nearly 2 million shares changed hands. $909.4 Million Award The decline in the stock price was largely attributed to Polaroid's experiences in court. On Friday, after the market had closed, it was announced that Judge David Mazzone had awarded Polaroid $909.4 million, but that was about $600 million less than Wall Street had expected. **********The key to the ruling was Polaroid's failure to convince Judge Mazzone that Kodak had intentionally and willfully trampled on Polaroid's instant photography patents. Many analysts expect Polaroid to appeal the ruling. **********The earnings reported yesterday by Polaroid were helped by a sharp 27 percent increase in overseas sales and lower taxes. However, some of the foreign increase was attributable to the decline of the dollar, which increases the value of overseas sales. **********Domestic Sales Decline **********Offsetting the unexpected good international news was Polaroid's report that domestic sales had declined 6 percent from a year earlier. That marked the fifth consecutive quarter of decline. In addition, operating margins have continued their slide from a peak of 18.9 percent in the second three months of 1989, to 12.9 percent in the recently completed quarter. **********I. MacAllister Booth, president and chief executive of Polaroid, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., said yesterday that the earnings reflected heavy investments in marketing and new product development to make the company more competitive. But he also warned that the investment needs and the weak business climate in the United States might lead to further earnings disappointments. **********With the damage award out of the way, analysts are once again focusing on Polaroid's sales and earnings. And some are skeptical. **********''It's hard to figure out what they can do to really turn around earnings in the long run,'' said B. Alex Henderson, who follows Polaroid for Prudential-Bache Securities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/08/world.main_headline: De Klerk and Mandela Plan May Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/08/world.print_headline: De Klerk and Mandela Plan May Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/08/world.body_text: **********The South African Government will hold its first formal meetings with the African National Congress on May 2, 3 and 4, the Government announced today. **********The meetings are the rescheduling of a session planned for April 11. Giving three days for the encounter, which will involve senior officials on both sides, suggests that the participants may try to accomplish more than their original one-day agenda envisioned. **********A week ago, the African National Congress insisted on a postponement in protest over the shootings of demonstrators in a black township, Sebokeng, on March 25. Conflicting reports say that 11 to 17 people died after the police opened fire, and that more than 400 people were wounded. **********Three Hours of Talks **********After three hours of talks on Thursday in Cape Town, President F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela, the deputy president of the African National Congress, announced that the meeting would go ahead. The congress consented after Mr. de Klerk told Mr. Mandela that he would ask his Cabinet to approve an independent judicial inquiry into the deaths in Sebokeng. **********The announcement of the agreed date was withheld until today because Mr. Mandela said approval was needed from the African National Congress's national executive committee, which remains in exile in Zambia. **********The congress said previously that at the meeting it planned to press its demands that the national state of emergency be lifted, that an unconditional amnesty be extended to all political prisoners and exiles and that political trials end. It said those steps were needed to create a climate that would permit the Congress to join the formal negotiations that Mr. de Klerk has proposed on the country's future. **********Mandela to Visit Zambia **********In Lusaka, a congress official, Steve Tshwete, was quoted by Reuters today as saying that Mr. Mandela would arrive there on Sunday to consult with the organization's leadership in exile. Mr. Tshwete, who sits on the group's national executive committee, said Mr. Mandela would brief it on his meeting with Mr. de Klerk and his visit earlier this week to townships in Natal that have been caught in fighting between rival black factions. **********Tonight, Mr. Mandela was scheduled to meet with a delegation from the Azanian People's Organization, a black consciousness movement, in what he indicated earlier was an effort by the African National Congress to build alliances with rival black organizations. **********''We are considering the question of pooling our resources with all anti-apartheid forces,'' Mr. Mandela said Thursday. The Azanian People's Organization has refused to join the negotiations proposed by Mr. de Klerk, that are intended to lead to a new constitution for South Africa giving political rights to the black majority. **********Mandela to Move to Mansion **********The African National Congress also announced today that Mr. Mandela would immediately move into the 15-room mansion in Soweto that his wife, Winnie, had built for him while he was in prison. A statement issued from Lusaka by Alfred Nzo, the organization's general secretary, said the decision was based on Mr. Mandela's personal requirements and his obligations to the congress. **********The mansion reportedly cost 500,000 rand, or about $200,000, to build. Some Sowetans nicknamed it ''Winnie's Palace'' and ''Winnie's Folly'' because it stood out from the surrounding poverty of the black township. **********Mr. Mandela once said he would not live there, and after his release from prison he went back to the four-room matchbox of a house where he lived before his 27 1/2 years of confinement. **********The old house has proven inadequate for Mr. Mandela. In the two months since his release from prison, he has received journalists and other visitors in his front yard or cramped living room. **********The poor security of the house, with Mr. Mandela's bedroom visible from the street, is believed to have motivated the decision to move into the new two-story house, which sits behind a high wall.
