https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/world.main_headline: U. S. EASING CURBS AS CHINA DECLARES MARTIAL LAW OVER
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/world.print_headline: U. S. EASING CURBS AS CHINA DECLARES MARTIAL LAW OVER
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/world.body_text: **********China lifted martial law in Beijing today, and within hours the United States announced that it was easing its blanket opposition to World Bank loans to China. **********Prime Minister Li Peng, who announced the lifting of martial law in a nationally televised speech, warned against unspecified foreign and domestic ''hostile forces'' that he said were working to subvert Communism in China. But he said that by and large, China had returned to normal. **********Despite the official end of martial law, the Chinese authorities retain the ability and apparently a desire to suppress any signs of political unrest, experts on China said. [An article and excerpts from Mr. Li's speech are on page A10.]  Administration's China Policy Vice President Dan Quayle said the lifting of martial law vindicated Mr. Bush's efforts to re-establish normal diplomatic ties with China. But experts on China challenged the Administration's assertion that Mr. Bush's policy had helped persuade China to lift martial law. **********The Chinese action did not quell Congressional anger over the crackdown, in which hundreds of Chinese civilians were killed. Nor did it seem likely to mute Congressional criticism of President Bush's policy, which many lawmakers consider excessively sympathetic to the Chinese leadership. **********The White House and the State Department praised China's decision to lift martial law as ''a positive step.'' Neither publicly acknowledged that strict laws banning dissent remained in force in China. **********The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said that in ''a partial change of policy'' the United States would examine loans on a case-by-case basis. **********Support for 'Human-Needs Loans' **********Proposals for seven loans totaling $780 million have been held at the World Bank since the beginning of the crackdown in June. **********Mr. Bush does not want economic sanctions to ''hurt the Chinese people,'' Miss Tutwiler said.  ''Our view is that basic human-needs loans - for instance, earthquake relief - should be permitted periodically to go forward,'' she said. **********Miss Tutwiler said the United States' revised position had been under consideration for months and was ''not connected'' to the end of martial law. The timing, she said, ''is sheerly, honestly coincidence.'' **********Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, said the lifting of martial law was ''an empty gesture.'' **********''Beijing can lift martial law because it does not need martial law to crush dissent,'' she said, noting that China had adopted a series of measures outlawing anti-Government demonstrations and authorizing security forces to stop protests. **********Mrs. Pelosi is the author of a bill that would prohibit the United States from sending Chinese students back to China. Mr. Bush vetoed it on Nov. 30. Congress is likely to override the veto soon after it reconvenes on Jan. 23. Congress is also likely to approve a package of economic and military sanctions banning arms sales to China and suspending Federal insurance for private investments in the country. **********Quayle Sees Policy 'Dividends' **********Martial law was imposed in parts of Beijing on May 20, after more than a million people filled the streets of the capital to support demands for greater democracy. **********Sweeping restrictions were imposed, including total bans on rumor-mongering, boycotts of classes, petitions, meetings and anything else that was deemed threatening to what Beijing called ''the normal order.'' **********After the June 3-4 military crackdown on the democracy movement, the Government banned all dissident organizations and gave the police the right to shoot demonstrators. Thousands of arrests and scores of executions followed. **********It is not clear if China made a commitment to lift martial law when Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, visited Beijing last month. **********Mr. Quayle said today that the lifting of martial law illustrated the ''dividends from the President's policy toward China.'' A White House spokesman, Roman Popadiuk, said the Administration would like to think that the trips to China by Mr. Scowcroft, in July and December, ''played a part'' in China's decision to lift martial law. **********Repression Said to Continue **********But outside experts expressed doubt. A professor of Chinese history at Boston University, Merle Goldman, said ''the Chinese have been suffering economically'' and need financial assistance from the World Bank. **********''The lifting of martial law is essentially a cosmetic or symbolic gesture to show that things are back to normal and to impress the outside world,'' she said in a telephone interview. **********If China released student leaders, intellectuals and workers imprisoned in the crackdown on the demonstrators in Tiananmen Square, that would provide tangible evidence of political liberalization in China, Mrs. Goldman said. **********Senator Claiborne Pell, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said the lifting of martial law was ''a small step in the right direction.'' **********But Mr. Pell, a Rhode Island Democrat, said, ''It does not change the fundamental circumstance of repression in China or the many serious issues that remain - human rights and freedom for arrested students and workers, human rights and an end to martial law in Tibet, and a halt to Chinese arms for Pol Pot and the murderous Khmer Rouge in Cambodia.'' **********Mr. Popadiuk said: ''We are pleased with the lifting of martial law and see it as a positive step.'' **********He said that the lifting of martial law was ''another in a series of positive steps'' by China. In the last few weeks, he said, the Chinese Government has readmitted a reporter from the Voice of America, has discussed renewal of a student-exchange program suspended since June and has curtailed criticism of the United States in Chinese newspapers and broadcasts. **********Mr. Popadiuk also said the Chinese had ''announced that they would not be selling medium-range missiles to the Middle East.'' **********But an Arabic-language newspaper published in London said this week that Syria had ''officially received assurances from the Chinese Government of its commitment to military cooperation between the two countries.'' The report said that China had rejected American pressure to stop selling weapons to Syria. **********Pledge to Halt Missiles Sales **********Chinese officials concluded that they needed to maintain the military capabilities of Syria and Israel's other Arab neighbors because ''Israel is being armed with the most technologically advanced weapons,'' the report said. **********Asked about that report, Miss Tutwiler affirmed that China had announced that it ''would not be selling medium-range missiles to the Middle East.'' She said she did not know if the Administration was monitoring China's adherence to its pledge. **********It was not immediately clear what types of World Bank loans would be acceptable to the United States. Miss Tutwiler said that though Washington might support some ''basic human needs loans'' to China, it would continue to discourage ''project loans.'' A spokesman for the Asia division of the bank, Pastor B. Sison, said the distinction was not obvious, because loans for specific projects could also serve basic human needs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/14/world.main_headline: On the Ethiopian Front, Rebel Confidence Rises
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/14/world.print_headline: On the Ethiopian Front, Rebel Confidence Rises
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/14/world.body_text: **********On the peak of this stone-laden mountain, a wiry guerrilla fighter ducks and weaves along a waist-high trench. Through binoculars he peers at the enemy trenches of the Ethiopian army, an ocher ribbon carved around the hill several hundred yards in front. **********In the distant valley, the 32-year-old guerrilla, Michael Abraham, picks up a glistening patch where the early sun catches a mosque, a church and a moving car, a sign that the Ethiopian town of Keren, 12 miles away, is coming awake. **********This is the front line in Africa's longest-running civil war, a battle almost three decades old, being waged between Eritrean rebels, who want independence from Ethiopia, and the Ethiopian Army. It is a match pitting a flinty, well-organized guerrilla force estimated at 30,000 strong against an Ethiopian force thought to number 230,000 and backed by almost as many militia. **********A little more than a decade ago, the guerrillas barely knew how to operate artillery. Today with divisions' worth of sophisticated Soviet equipment captured from the Ethiopians, a Soviet diplomat concedes that the Eritreans fight better with it than the Ethiopians. [In its most daring assault in the war since 1977, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front attacked the Red Sea port of Massawa last Thursday, and claimed to have captured it. The rebels mounted an almost simultaneous offensive on the Keren front, north of Massawa. The Government acknowledged that its army and navy had taken ''big sacrifices'' in heavy fighting.]  War, Devastation and Drought As the cold war recedes and the superpowers disengage from proxy wars elsewhere, the Ethiopian civil war shows no sign of a peaceful solution. At the same time, the war is compounding the devastation caused by yet another Ethiopian drought that is evident everywhere in the bare, dusty brown hills and the stark silhouettes of dying baobab trees that lead the way to the front line here. The United Nations says the failure of last season's rains threatens more than four million Ethiopians with starvation in coming months. **********The civil war spread beyond Eritrea last year as another rebel group, the Tigrean People's Liberation Front, helped in critical battles by the more experienced, technically superior Eritrean forces, scored big victories against flagging Government troops. The Tigrean rebels, fighting for the overthrow of the Ethiopean Government but not secession, pushed the army out of the entire province of Tigre, which has at its heart the venerated 2,000-year-old historical capital, Axum. That new alliance between the previously quarreling rebel groups has put even more pressure on the increasingly strained Ethiopian leader, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam. After taking Tigre, the rebels, still assisted by the Eritreans, pushed farther south, occupying large hunks of the provinces of Wollo and Gondar and even penetrating well into Shoa province. In December, they took towns only 100 miles north of the capital, Addis Ababa. **********New Element: Israeli Aid **********The Soviet Union has encouraged its shaky Ethiopian client to settle with the Eritrean and Tigrean rebels at the negotiating table. But Western military analysts say the Soviets pumped high levels of equipment into Ethiopia last year. More than $800 million of Soviet military hardware, including new generation T-62 tanks and B-24 multiple-rocket launchers, arrived in Ethiopia by ship and plane last year, far surpassing the supplies of the previous year, those analysts say. **********Since its military commitment in 1977, when the Soviet Union and the United States switched clients in the Horn of Africa - the United States dropped Ethiopia for Somalia and the Russians dropped Somalia for Ethiopia - the Soviets are estimated by Washington to have sent $11 billion of arms to the Ethiopians. **********The United States has stayed out of the Ethiopian war in the last dozen years, disliking the hard-line Marxist-Leninist Government of Colonel Mengistu that overthrew Washington's old ally, Emperor Haile Selassie. Washington was also unimpressed with the Marxism espoused until recent years by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front. But despite its distaste for Colonel Mengistu, the United States along with most Western powers and all African states, has agreed with the Ethiopian Government's argument that the Eritreans should not be allowed their goal of separating the Eritrean province from Ethiopia and creating an independent state. **********The arrival of Israel on the side of the Addis Ababa Government has added a new, potentially highly charged element to the civil war. Western and Eastern-bloc diplomats say they don't yet know the magnitude of Israel's military assistance. But they say that whatever the size of the Isreali help, it is bound to generate more supplies for the Eritreans from Arab countries. **********'The Generals Are New Generals' **********In a narrow riverbed valley behind Giguru mountain, Halibai Fesshae, a 35-year-old division commander on the Keren front, exuded quiet confidence that the Eritreans would prevail militarily. He was relaxing just before 3 P.M. The next two hours would be the danger zone, when Soviet MIG's of the Ethiopian Air Force often fly over this region of Eritrea. **********''I have learned that deploying a lot of force doesn't give you any priority,'' Mr. Halibai said in his rarely practiced but proficient English. **********''Without troop morale, air and military weapons can't mean anything. A major factor is morale. Theirs is totally flat, zero.'' **********He was dismissive of the Ethiopian Army's command. Since the failed coup of May last year, he said, ''Most of the generals are new generals.'' **********The Role of Morale **********''They were serving 10 to 15 years in social-service agencies,'' he said, referring to Colonel Mengistu resorting to old trusted allies pulled out of military retirement to take the place of officers assassinated or imprisoned after the failed coup last year. **********Mr. Halibai - there are no military titles of rank in the Eritrean front -said he had seen the bad morale at close quarters. Last March, the Ethiopians started an offensive to dislodge the Eritreans from their Mount. Giguru trench lines, he said. The battle lasted eight days with the Eritreans holding their ground. ''Their new recruits don't have enough food or medecine,'' he said. ''They are not well trained. Even physically they are underaged, they cannot fight. Of 60 prisoners of war taken at the battle last year, 80 percent were under the age of 16.'' **********Like many of the senior commanders in the Eritrean front, Mr. Halibai left high school in Asmara, the capital of the province, in the mid-1970's, when persecution against Eritreans by the Government was particularly strong. He has seen the guerrillas grow from an inexperienced, somewhat factionalized group to a formidable fighting force. **********As Mr. Halibai spoke under the shade of a thorn tree, a shiny Soviet jeep was parked nearby, a minor prize from the battle of Afabet two years ago when the Eritreans captured scores of tanks and a number of rocket launchers. **********Western military analysts say the vast majority of the military equipment comes, as the Eritreans assert, from the Ethiopian Army. Some supplies come from Arab countries, they say. **********Fleet of Speedboats **********The Eritreans are not Arabs; indeed the leadership of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front is largely Tigrean-speaking Christians. But about half of the 2.5 million population of Eritrea is Muslim, a factor that helps account for sympathy from Arab countries who also don't like the idea of a strong, united Ethiopia on the Red Sea. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front keeps offices in a number of Arab countries, including Kuwait and Abu Dhabi, where there are large numbers of wealthy Eritrean businessmen who give generously to the front. It also has offices in Syria and Libya. **********The rebel leaders refuse to say where they got their newly acquired naval force, a fleet of high-powered speedboats that patrol their Red Sea coast and were definitely not captured from the Ethiopians. The rebel front has put new emphasis on the Red Sea, the main delivery artery for Soviet, and now it appears, Israeli equipment. ''We can't control the coast,'' Mr. Falahai said. ''But we can reduce the total transportation on the sea.'' **********Wherever a visitor travels in the rocky terrain of northern Eritrea, the cult of the Kalishnikov is pervasive, hardly surprising among a young adult generation that has known nothing but life at war. In a school room in Orota, for example, where the children of fighters played in a basement classroom on shiny new Yamaha violins donated from Norway, a Kalishnikov assault rifle was slung against a window. It belonged to the teacher, who like all teachers in the countryside - the rebels hold very few towns - are considered fighters, an escort from the rebel front said. **********The escort was Girma Asmaron, the head of information for the front's foreign ministry, who graduated from Bowdoin College in Maine in the early 1970's. He wore a Soviet Red Star pistol on his waist, along with a hand grenade, a pack of bullets and a flashlight, all neatly held in a specially tailored, Eritrean made, leather belt. It was not that he expected trouble as he traveled through the rebel-held area, he said, ''But I carry it so you get used to the idea of carrying a gun.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/04/busin.body_text: **********Rising oil prices helped push up the value of orders to factories for manufactured goods by 1.8 percent in August, the Government reported today. Analysts said the oil-inflated rise disguised the weakness in the industrial sector. **********''To me, the number excluding petroleum is consistent with our view that the economy is sliding and slipping into a recession,'' said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist with the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. **********Bruce Steinberg, senior economist with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, added: ''It continues to show the industrial sector is going nowhere and may be sinking a little bit. There's nothing in the report to say we're not having a recession.'' **********The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and nondurable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $244.6 billion, but added, ''Most of the increase is attributed to the petroleum refining industry. Excluding petroleum, orders increased 0.6 percent.'' **********Mr. Sohn said ''energy prices went up even more dramatically in September and orders then will be even more exaggerated.'' He suggested the reports should be examined excluding petroleum costs and ''my expectation is that orders will continue to soften.'' **********Nondurable Goods Orders **********Overall nondurable goods orders, which include petroleum, advanced 4.4 percent, to $117.1 billion, in August including a $3 billion rise in the petroleum and coal category. Nondurable orders had edged up just two-tenths of 1 percent in the month before the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. **********Orders for durable goods - big-ticket items expected to last more than three years - fell five-tenths of 1 percent, to $127.5 billion, after rising 2.7 percent in July. The drop in August orders was a slight downward revision from the eight-tenths of 1 percent decline first reported last week. **********The often-volatile military orders also jumped following the Iraqi invasion, up 14.4 percent, to $8.6 billion, after declining 5.1 percent a month earlier. Excluding the military, orders were up 1.4 percent. **********But orders for nonmilitary capital goods, a barometer of business plans for expansion and modernization, indicated a cautious investment attitude. Orders plunged 10.2 percent, to $35.8 billion, erasing a 10.1 percent advance in July. **********Among durable goods, electrical machinery orders were up 2.9 percent, to $20.9 billion, after rising 1.5 percent in July. Transportation orders rose 1.8 percent, to $35.4 billion, after a 4.6 percent gain a month earlier. Excluding transportation, orders were up 1.8 percent. **********''Within transportation, increases in motor vehicles and parts and shipbuilding and tanks more than offset a decline in aircraft and parts,'' the report said. **********Registering losses were non-electrical machinery, down 5.0 percent, to $21.4 billion, following a 3.5 percent gain, and primary metals, which fell 2.3 percent, to $11.5 billion, after a 2.7 percent rise.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/10/busin.main_headline: Market Place; A Way of Betting On a '95 Oil Price
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/10/busin.print_headline: Market Place; A Way of Betting On a '95 Oil Price
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/10/busin.body_text: **********WHILE the world pays close attention to daily changes in the price of oil, a deeper question for the oil industry and the economy is the long-term outlook for prices. What will a barrel of oil cost in five years, after the Persian Gulf crisis has presumably been resolved and any war damage has been repaired? **********A relatively new financial instrument, the Salomon Phibro Oil Trust, represents a sort of popular projection of the 1995 oil price. Four units of the trust represent one barrel of West Texas Intermediate oil -- or, more practically, the price of one barrel -- in September 1995. At that time, Phibro will acquire four million barrels, auction them and split the proceeds among the holders of the 16 million units. **********When the trust came on the market on Aug. 24, three weeks after Iraq invaded Kuwait, units sold for $4.65 each. On Friday, they closed at $3.25, down 12.5 cents, on the American Stock Exchange. **********Philip C. Verleger, the commodities market expert at Charles River Associates, a consulting firm based in Boston, pointed out recently that buyers of the units do not expect a price per barrel of four times the share price (or $13 on Friday); they are expecting a gain, in exchange for the use of their money for the intervening years. Assuming a cost of money of 12 percent, the share price implies a 1995 price in the neighborhood of $24 a barrel. Such a figure, Mr. Verleger said, would be "strikingly low," especially since it represents the price after inflation has taken its toll. Many other oil experts agree, although with global production capacity and inventories rising, a price crash after the crisis is resolved could also be envisioned. **********Anyone with a little cash on hand who thinks theprice in mid-decade will be above the mid-$20's could place a bet by buying units of the Phibro trust; if the sale price in 1995 exceeds $24, the buyer's return would exceed 12 percent. An investor who wanted to place the opposite bet, that prices would be even lower, might buy stock in a company that prospers when prices are low, like a refiner and marketer of petroleum products. **********In the oil markets, five years is almost forever. In 1981, for example, when oil prices were near record highs after the revolution in Iran, almost no one foresaw the price collapse of 1986. And no one was predicting that year that Iraq would invade Kuwait in 1990, causing oil prices to double in a few weeks. **********Before the invasion, oil analysts pointed out that the world's surplus capacity lay almost entirely within OPEC's control and was dwindling as demand rose. This situation was a recipe for significant price increases in the mid-90's, they said. **********The chief economist of the Amoco Corporation, Theodore Eck, predicted before the events of the last five months that oil would sell for $25 in the mid-1990's. "I don't see that anything's happened to change that forecast," he said last week. **********Independent of Saddam Hussein, he said, the world's largest and third-largest producers (the Soviet Union and the United States) are going through rapid declines in production, and the Persian Gulf (home of the second-largest, Saudi Arabia) still has the great bulk of the known, easy-to-pump oil. "Price is going to continue to be a function of the leading countries in OPEC: Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Iran and Iraq," he said. "Thosefour determine what the price is." **********Those countries were successfully raising prices before the invasion, he said. And if the crisis over Kuwait has had any effect, it is to raise the revenue requirements of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Iraq; Iran was already hard pressed for money. **********At the First Boston Corporation, William Randol, who follows the oil market and oil stocks, said that the recent price shock had helped slow the economies of various nations, depressing demand, but that overall demand was still growing. He predicted a price above $30. Last month, Texaco Inc. predicted prices rising two to three percentage points above inflation; inflation of 4 percent, Mr. Randol said, would yield a price of $27.75 in 1995. **********Norman P. Higby Jr., an analyst in Menlo Park, Calif., laid out a different projection. Saudi Arabia, already a partner with Texaco in a joint venture for refining and marketing that covers the Eastern United States, would expand that effort nationwide and provide gasoline cheaply, to gain market share. Others, he said, would have to follow with low product prices to stay competitive, lowering the value of crude. Prices would be volatile, he said, ranging from $15 to the high $20's or $30. **********Thomas R. McHale, an energy economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said he saw China becoming an importer instead of an exporter, and Soviet production falling sharply. Outside the Middle East, he asked, "where else do we have any great potential for expansion of oil production?" **********His forecast implies a higher price, but he added that many analysts underestimate the long-term capacity of countries facing higher prices to use less. He would not speculate on a 1995 price. **********And the completely unforeseen is always a possibility. At Bear, Stearns & Company, William E. Byers, a futures expert, warned that in oil, copper, soybeans or any commodity, projections made by extrapolating current conditions and inflation rates are seldom accurate. His bottom line on 1995 has a ring of sincerity to it. "I have no clue," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/15/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation said today that Kirk Kerkorian, an investor with a history of corporate deal making, had acquired 9.8 percent of its common stock for $277 million. **********The news surprised many analysts, who regard Chrysler's pension liabilities, modest cash flow and relatively weak prospects as impediments to investors seeking quick returns. **********Chrysler's board responded this morning by reducing to 10 percent, from 20 percent, the amount of its shares that a hostile investor can amass before the company's "poison pill" anti-takeover provisions kick in. **********In a statement, the Tracinda Corporation, Mr. Kerkorian's investment company, said: "We were surprised by the action of the Chrysler board, especially since Tracinda's purchases are for investment. It is hard for us to see how the steps taken by the board today are in the best interests of all the shareholders." **********Last month Mr. Kerkorian sold the MGM/UA Communications Company to an Italian financier, Giancarlo Parretti, for $1.3 billion.   Disclosure Statement Planned **********Tracinda, which is based in Los Angeles, said it would file a disclosure statement on Monday, giving further details, with the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********Chrysler declined to speculate on Mr. Kerkorian's motives, but it did say that Mr. Kerkorian had met at its request with Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of Chrysler, in New York on Dec. 7. The meeting was called after Chrysler became aware that Mr. Kerkorian, whom Mr. Iacocca knows socially, had amassed about 5 percent of its stock, a spokesman said. The company said Mr. Iacocca sought an agreement that would have capped Tracinda's investment at 5 percent, but Mr. Kerkorian declined. **********The spokesman said Mr. Kerkorian had told Mr. Iacocca and Robert S. Miller Jr., the auto maker's vice chairman, that he considered himself a passive investor, that he supported management and that he thought Chrysler's shares were undervalued.  Advisers Retained **********Chrysler has retained the First Boston Corporation and the Blackstone Group as financial advisers. **********Chrysler's executives and directors remained wary, judging from the action taken today by the board to amend an anti-takeover provision that was adopted in 1988. As amended today, that provision entitles all common stockholders except those with a stake of 10 percent or more to purchase common stock at half price, once an investor has amassed a 10 percent stake. Such an action would require Chrysler to issue a significant amount of new stock. **********Also today, the board approved a second option enabling the company to give an additional share to every holder of one share -- except a holder of 10 percent or more -- effectively cutting in half the holdings of any hostile suitor. **********Mr. Kerkorian is now the largest Chrysler stockholder. According to Chrysler's 1989 proxy statement, Windsor Funds Inc. holds 8.68 percent of its shares and Sanford C. Bernstein & Company has 6.22 percent. **********News of Mr. Kerkorian's stake had little effect on Chrysler's stock, which closed unchanged today on the New York Stock Exchange at $12.25. It was the sixth-most-active issue, with more than 1.5 million shares changing hands. **********While most auto analysts say Chrysler may eventually need a big partner to compete globally, several expressed doubt that such a linkup was imminent. Chrysler and Fiat recently ended negotiations after nearly a year of talks. **********Some analysts suggested that Mr. Kerkorian might have begun to acquire his shares earlier this year on the assumption that Chrysler and Fiat would make a deal.   Stock Has Been Stable **********Other analysts said they thought Mr. Kerkorian had amassed his holding over the last month or so, which would help explain why Chrysler's share price has remained relatively stable while those of General Motors and Ford have fallen. In any case, the Los Angeles investor has roughly doubled his stake in the last week. **********Another strategy that Mr. Kerkorian may be considering, analysts said, was to find someone else interested in buying his holding, possibly Chrysler itself. Mr. Healy raised the possibility that Mr. Kerkorian might seek a premium price from the company for his stake, a practice known as "greenmail." **********Ann Knight, an automotive analyst with Paine Webber in New York, said, "Generally, auto makers don't attract this kind of attention, because they are deeply cyclical, capital-intensive companies."  Deals Involving MGM **********Because so many of Mr. Kerkorian's interests are privately held through Tracinda, it is difficult to assess his wealth. But several bankers who have followed his dealings say it probably exceeds $1 billion. **********In 1969, he bought 45 percent of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for $82 million, and in 1980 split it into MGM Grand Hotels and the MGM Film Company. The film company in turn bought United Artists a year later. **********Tracinda began shedding those assets in 1986, selling MGM Grand to the Bally Manufacturing Corporation and then MGM/UA to the Turner Broadcasting System for $1.5 billion. As a 51 percent owner, Mr. Kerkorian kept $765 million and bought back some of the assets for $480 million, selling part of that company to the public. Earlier this year, Mr. Kerkorian sold that stake to Mr. Parretti for $1.3 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.main_headline: Company Profits Down; G.N.P. Growth at 1.1%
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.print_headline: Company Profits Down; G.N.P. Growth at 1.1%
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.body_text: **********Profits of American companies fell by 3.2 percent in the final three months of 1989 mainly because of rising labor costs, the Commerce Department reported today. **********For the full year, corporate profits from current production dropped by 8.3 percent; in 1988 they rose by 10 percent. The decline was the first significant drop since a 20.2 percent decrease in 1982, the most recent recession year. **********While profits from current production are the purest gauge, the Commerce Department reports other measures of profits. Current-production cash flow - the internal funds available for investment - fell by three-tenths of 1 percent after rising by 1.9 percent in the third quarter. Profits before taxes eased by five-tenths of 1 percent after a 7.1 percent decline, and profits after taxes rose by 2.8 percent, the first quarterly gain in a year. **********Calculation of Growth **********The profits report accompanied the department's latest calculation of the pace of economic growth in the fourth quarter, now put at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.1 percent. **********This suggested that the economy was slightly firmer than shown in last month's estimate of nine-tenths of 1 percent. The first estimate, in January, had said the gross national product expanded at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the quarter. **********The figures on corporate profits, although not unexpected, reinforced the worries of some analysts that corporations would not have the means or the incentive to invest in new plant and equipment during 1990. **********Not a 'Painless Landing' **********''This shows that a 'soft landing' is by no means synonymous with a painless landing,'' said Robert G. Dederick, a former Commerce Department official who is now chief economist for the Northern Trust Company of Chicago. ''One of the key questions now is whether this year is going to be dragged down by businesses responding to last year.'' **********A ''soft landing'' refers to the effort of policy makers, so far fairly successful, to restrain the economy enough to keep inflation under control without tipping the economy into a recession. **********Profits are a principal source of money for expansion, the other being loans. Many lending institutions have, however, been tightening credit standards recently, with lending to smaller companies seeming to be the most seriously affected. **********Higher Final Sales **********The latest revision of the G.N.P. growth figure reflects higher final sales for most major components partly offset by a $4 billion downward adjustment in the growth of inventories. The gross national product measures the output of goods and services, and production adds to the G.N.P. even if the goods pile up on dealers' shelves. The latest data were considered something of a plus for the business outlook because it means inventories are under good control and production will not need to be scaled back to bring them into balance with sales. **********The rise in the G.N.P. fixed-weighted price index, a measure of inflation, remained at 3.6 percent, up from 2.9 percent in the third quarter. **********The 3.2 percent quarterly decline in profits reflected a fall-off of $9.5 billion, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $285.7 billion. Profits would have been far worse had it not been for a sharp increase in earnings abroad. **********The foreign component jumped $9.7 billion, up from $2.1 billion in the third quarter. This represents the amount by which dividends paid to United States residents and reinvested earnings of foreign affiliates of American companies exceed corresponding amounts paid to foreign residents. **********Domestic Profits Down **********Domestic profits of nonfinancial corporations skidded by $13.9 billion, far more than the $3.8 billion decline in the preceding three months. Gross corporate product rose while profits per unit of real product fell; lower unit profits reflected difficulty in raising prices combined with higher costs. **********Kenneth A. Petrick, a Commerce Department specialist, said much of the narrowing of profit margins reflected higher labor costs as companies appeared to hold on to workers in hopes that the economy would regain momentum. **********Mr. Petrick also said the net interest costs of nonfinancial corporations seemed to have leveled off, suggesting diminishing pressure on profit margins this year. He acknowledged, however, that some of the interest reduction figure could be a reflection of defaults on debt. **********Domestic profits of financial corporations fell by $5.2 billion during the quarter, less than half the third-quarter drop of $10.8 billion, which reflected large costs incurred by casualty insurers because of hurricane and earthquake damage. The fourth-quarter decline reflected the problems of banks and savings and loan associations. **********Data included in the revision of the gross national product for the fourth quarter of 1989 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   30,000 Jam New Las Vegas Casino
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/20/busin.body_text: **********Thirty-thousand people today stormed a drawbridge that does not raise, ignored security guards in medieval costumes and raced to the gambling tables at the opening of Excalibur, which is billed by its owner as the world's biggest casino hotel. **********Under 10-foot heraldic banners and giant iron chandeliers, customers gambled in a casino four football fields long, with 100 gaming tables and 2,600 slot machines. **********The $290 million Excalibur, with 4,032 rooms priced from $45 to $65 a night, is owned by Circus Circus Enterprises, which also owns the Circus Circus casino in Las Vegas. **********The name of the casino comes from the English Arthurian legend. Excalibur was the name of King Arthur's sword. At the casino, customers who prefer not to gamble can shoot electronic crossbows for prizes or watch jousts. **********Excalibur is the latest ''theme resort'' to open in Las Vegas, part of a trend by giant casino operators to create a family atmosphere. **********Industry analysts say the resorts are aimed at people who spend between $100 and $200 a day on entertainment and gambling. **********Las Vegas is one of the fastest-growing American cities, and planners estimate it will have 75,000 hotel rooms by the end of this year, nearly a 20 percent increase over two years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/23/world.print_headline: CHANGE IN BRITAIN; 'I'll Miss Her,' Bush Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/23/world.body_text: **********President Bush said today that he would miss Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's friendship and counsel but that he expected to continue working closely with her successor as head of the British Government. **********"You know of my high regard for Prime Minister Thatcher," Mr. Bush said after a Thanksgiving visit to American forces in Saudi Arabia. "We will obviously work with the next Prime Minister." **********He added: "I would send my best to her at this difficult time. She has been a staunch friend and ally. She's a woman of principle. She stood for what she believed. You always know where she was and what she believed." **********Mr. Bush said he was certain that Britain would remain a firm American partner. "But on a personal level I'll miss her because I value her counsel. She has been an outstanding Prime Minister for the United Kingdom and an outstanding friend for the United States."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Centaur Loses Court Ruling
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/busin.body_text: **********National Intergroup Inc. announced this evening that the Delaware state court had upheld the company's contention that the Centaur Partners Group needs the votes of 80 percent of National Intergroup's shareholders to force the election of the majority of the company's board at its annual meeting in July. **********The ruling is a blow to Centaur's consent solicitation efforts. Centaur had argued that it needed only a simple majority of shareholders for its proposals to succeed. **********Centaur, a New York partnership led by Abbey J. Butler, a New York money manager, and two Washington financiers, Melvyn J. Estrin and Charles P. Abod, has amassed a 16.5 percent stake in the company. In a prepared statement, Mr. Butler and Mr. Estrin said they would appeal the decision to the Delaware Supreme Court.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/26/busin.body_text: **********The Bush Administration said Friday that it would not retaliate against the 12-nation European Community and South Korea over trade barriers imposed against United States telecommunications companies. **********The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said that instead the Administration would extend for a year the current round of talks aimed at settling the dispute. **********South Korea and the European Community were accused by the Administration a year ago of erecting unfair barriers that discriminate against the sale of United States telecommunications products and services. **********Under the 1988 trade law, American negotiators had a year to try to get the other countries to remove the offending barriers. If the talks proved unsuccessful, the Administration could then have retaliated by imposing higher tariffs on imports from the European Community and South Korea. **********Mrs. Hills said the Administration had decided to exercise the option to extend the negotiations for another year on the ground that substantial progress had been made in the talks. She cited several areas where both the European Community and the South Koreans had liberalized their trade laws governing telecommunications equipment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/05/busin.main_headline: Holiday Inn Adds To Y.& R. Billings
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/05/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;   Holiday Inn Adds To Y.& R. Billings
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/05/busin.body_text: **********Executives at Young & Rubicam can breath a little easier about the agency's decision on Wednesday to resign the $45 million Trans World Airlines account. Yesterday, Y.& R. retained the $25 million Holiday Inn account for its domestic business, which was in review, and the agency also added Holiday Inn's international business, which will double the account's billings to about $50 million. **********''We've made up an awful lot of the T.W.A. loss in one day,'' said Joseph E. De Deo, the agency's president and chief executive. ''We're just delighted.'' **********Other agencies in the review were Ogilvy & Mather and Grey Advertising. **********Hamish Swan, vice chairman of Holiday Inn Worldwide, said, ''We took a look at a number of agencies and decided we liked Y.& R.'s approach to our global challange the best.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/23/world.main_headline: Baker Reports a Pledge by de Klerk
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/23/world.print_headline: Baker Reports a Pledge by de Klerk
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/23/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa had told him that his Government was on an irreversible course toward creating a nonracial democracy. **********Addressing reporters in Cape Town after a one-hour meeting with Mr. de Klerk, Mr. Baker gestured toward the South African President and said: ''May I repeat what you told me at the conclusion of our meeting? 'That we are engaged here in South Africa in an irreversible process that we will follow to its logical conclusion.' '' **********Mr. de Klerk's use of the word ''irreversible'' was clearly not accidental. Leading American proponents of continued economic sanctions against South Africa like Representative William H. Gray 3d, Democrat of Pennsylvania, have repeatedly said that these punitive measures must not be ended until apartheid is on an irreversible track toward dissolution. South Africans said that only lately has Mr. de Klerk begun to use this expression in his public statements. **********Baker Deeply Impressed **********After the talks in Cape Town today -Mr. Baker also met with black opposition leaders and with Foreign Minister R. F. Botha - reporters traveling on Mr. Baker's plane were told that the Secretary of State was deeply impressed by Mr. de Klerk's stated commitment to end in the very near future the state of emergency declared in 1986. **********As impressed as Mr. Baker was Wednesday by the black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela, he was said to be no less taken with Mr. de Klerk in their first meeting. **********The reporters were told that Mr. Baker, a novice in African diplomacy, might be somewhat naive in his assessment, but nevertheless felt that Mr. de Klerk was ''absolutely serious.'' **********The reporters were told that in the view of those aboard the plane the South Africans are committed. and that changes that were taking place in other parts of the world were likely to be repeated in South Africa. **********Two Sides Still Far Apart **********On April 11, Mr. de Klerk and the African National Congress will begin talks on removing obstacles to formal negotiations on power sharing - obstacles like the state of emergency and the continued confinement of political prisoners. Both sides have been making conciliatory statements, but they remain far apart on what a ''new South Africa'' should look like. **********Mr. Baker's visit was the first by an American Secretary of State to South Africa since Cyrus R. Vance came in 1978. Mr. Baker left reporters with the impression that the visit signaled the beginning of a new relationship, on a much higher level, between the Bush Administration and South Africa provided that Mr. de Klerk continues moving forward. Mr. Baker and Mr. de Klerk discussed a date for his proposed visit to Washington. The final announcement will be made after consultations with the White House. **********Mr. Baker was understood to have told aides that when Foreign Minister Botha told him at a meeting in Rome in February 1989 that a de Klerk Government would be committed to ending apartheid and instituting majority rule, he did did not believe the South African. Reporters were told today that Mr. Baker ''believes them totally now when they say they have made a commitment and will follow through on it.'' **********Mr. Baker was said to have told Mr. de Klerk that the South African's moves - releasing Mr. Mandela, legalizing the African National Congress and agreeing to open talks with the it -were ''courageous in light of the obvious political pressures he is subject to.'' **********Earlier today, after talks with leaders of the African National Congress, Mr. Baker held an impromptu news conference accompanied by the black nationalists. A senior official of the congress, Govan Mbeki, used the opportunity to criticize the Secretary of State for meeting Mr. de Klerk on South African soil, echoing criticisms made by Mr. Mandela on Wednesday in Windhoek. **********''We are not happy that he has come here to consult with the South African Government,'' Mr. Mbeki said, adding that such a move would only ease pressures on Mr. de Klerk before he has made any real changes in the system of apartheid. **********Mr. Mbeki said that the African National Congress's message to Mr. Baker, the American Government and the American people was that they ''should continue to impose the pressures which they have been on the South African Government and not relax them at all until such times that positions will have been made clear.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/25/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;   Giving Polystyrene Another Chance
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/25/busin.body_text: **********The machinery is deafening, the floors are messy, and the pungent air is thick with flies on a summer day inside the Plastics Again polystyrene recycling plant here, an hour's drive west of Boston. But the scene is enough to delight a plastic manufacturer. **********The two-year-old plant is the world's first large-scale operation to reclaim polystyrene from the cafeterias and fast-food chains that use it in plates, cups, utensils and food packaging. **********Managers of the plant, which is now operating at half capacity, expect it to begin processing new types of used polystyrene, like packing material, in coming months. Its general manager, Thomas Tomaszek, said the plant should break even next year and eventually produce a 25 percent return on investment. **********Moreover, it has become a valuable proving ground for a new generation of larger plants that its owner, a consortium of polystyrene producers known as the National Polystyrene Recycling Company, expects to be even more profitable. **********''This is the first plant to demonstrate that it's viable to recycle food packaging with today's technology,'' said E. J. Schneiders, president and chief executive of National Polystyrene. The company, based in Lincolnshire, Ill., which was founded last year by the eight largest polystyrene manufacturers to lead a nationwide recycling effort, bought Plastics Again in October from the Mobil Chemical Company and Innopac Inc., a Canadian packaging firm. **********National Polystyrene hopes not just for profits, but also to take the steam out of drives in a growing number of communities to ban polystyrene packaging. Often known as Styrofoam - the trade name of Dow Chemical's foamed polystyrene -polystyrene is also commonly used in denser formulations to make packaging products like the clear-clamshell food containers used at salad bars and items like toothbrush handles. Studies show that polystyrene accounts for less than 1 percent of the solid wastes pouring into the nation's landfills, but it makes up a very visible part of litter, and many people see it as a symbol of wasteful consumption. **********Based on the experience of Plastics Again and a handful of smaller operations, National Polystyrene has set a goal of recycling 250 million pounds a year by 1995, which would be about 25 percent of all polystyrene used in food packaging. **********Other Plants Are Planned **********In recent months, National Polystyrene has also purchased a small recycling operation in Brooklyn, lent $400,000 to upgrade a privately owned plant in Portland, Ore., and pursued plans to open recycling plants by the end of the year in the Philadelphia, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Chicago areas. The new operations are planned to be roughly four times the size of Plastics Again, which at full capacity can process about three million pounds of polystyrene annually. **********Last week, the Dart Container Corporation announced plans to set up operations at its factories in Mason, Mich.; Leola, Pa.; Plant City, Fla., and Campbellford, Ontario, to reclaim between one million and three million pounds annually of foamed polystyrene coffee cups and packing materials. Unlike the National Polystyrene plants, Dart's will not accept materials that must be washed. **********One thing that may help is the growing number of programs to recycle other products. Plastics Again, for instance, has benefited from bottle recycling that began when Massachusetts passed a bottle-deposit law. The reason: New England Crinc, a company that had established an extensive bottle hauling-business, was able to collect polystyrene as well at a reasonable price. **********Plastics Again pays 5 cents a pound for deliveries that are at least 98 percent polystyrene by weight. For now, at least, it also takes less clean supplies, which may be contaminated by a wide variety of foods, textiles and metals, but it charges a fee of up to 24 cents a pound for a fast-food restaurant that has done little sorting. **********Clean and Serene Appearance **********These days, a truck pulls up every three hours or so to the back of the grass-verged plant, which looks serene and spotless from the outside. The polyethylene bags are pulled out, cut open so their contents can be poured onto conveyor belts, and set aside to be baled and sent to a polyethylene recycler. **********Bags filled with relatively large pieces move down a conveyor belt, where two workers quickly separate other types of waste before the polystyrene feeds into a shredder. The contents of the other bags, most of them from McDonald's or a handful of other fast-food restaurants, ride a separate conveyor up to a hopper that relies on vibration to sort out waste like cans and loose change. Both streams are then washed and fed into a high-speed grinder. **********The next stage is rinsing, followed by a spin dryer and then a screw-dryer that wrings more liquid from the polystyrene shreds before feeding them into an oven dryer. The shreds emerge from the oven stuck together like caramel corn and must be reground before being sent by vacuum tube to the extruding system. **********Another machine stuffs the shreds into the extruder, which presses the plastic through screens that remove residual wastes like bits of aluminum, bone, stone and fiber before it is chopped into small, round pellets. Colors, modifiers like rubber that make the plastic more resilient, and chemicals to make it more resistant to ultraviolet light can be added during extrusion. **********Combs and Cafeteria Trays **********The end product is then cooled in a water bath and packaged in 1,100-pound boxes. The boxes are sold by the truckload to processors that make the polystyrene into products including reusable cafeteria trays, insulation, egg cartons, office products, combs, tape-cassette cases and flower pots. Water used in the plant is recycled and a scrubber system cleans the air, which is changed six times an hour. **********Samples of the pellets are run through standard tests in a nearby room to establish the key characteristics of each load, like the melting point, density, and how easily it will flow as it melts. **********''You don't need a master's of science to run this system,'' Mr. Tomaszek said. **********Flies and Low Wages **********One does, however, need a fair number of workers who will accept low wages and put up with unappetizing conditions. Plastics Again relies largely on Vietnamese immigrants supplied by an employment agency at $7.50 an hour. Mr. Tomaszek said he was working hard to improve conditions, including getting rid of the flies without using pesticides. But the long-run need is more automation, particularly at the messy front end of the process. **********National Polystyrene plans to break initial processing down into three separate systems in its new plants, each handling a different kind of polystyrene waste, said James H. Browne, a process engineering expert at Law Environmental Engineering, a Kennesaw, Ga., consulting firm hired to oversee National Polystyrene's programs to locate, design, secure permits, buy equipment and build plants. **********The key equipment in the new design is a $500,000 twin-screw extruder, made by Werner-Pfleider of West Germany. The extruder is more energy-efficient than single-screw devices and better suited for adding compounds that can increase the value of the recycled polystyrene. **********Sorting Is Important **********To take full advantage of it, National Polystyrene will probably have to require those sending polystyrene to its plants to do a better job of sorting. Polystyrene makes up about 80 percent of the material arriving at Plastics Again. George Mackey, the Dow Chemical executive who is chairman of National Polystyrene's technical committee, says the newer plants will probably specify 95 percent purity. **********''You don't want to put valuable additives into the product until you are confident that you have consistent quality,'' Mr. Mackey said. **********Unless coloring is added, the pellets produced at Plastics Again emerge looking like green BB's. Virgin polystyrene can be clear and thus has more potential markets. Plastics Again's products sell at a 20 percent discount to standard polystyrene, but National Polystyrene wants to close the gap. ''I believe that someday, good-quality recycled polystyrene will sell at the same price as virgin,'' Mr. Mackey said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/world.main_headline: Tokyo Opposes Cuts in U.S. Forces in Asia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/world.print_headline: Tokyo Opposes Cuts in U.S. Forces in Asia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/world.body_text: **********Reacting to the cutbacks announced in President Bush's proposed military budget, a senior Japanese Government official argued today against any reduction in the United States' military presence in Japan or the rest of Asia because of a continuing Soviet menace. **********''The situation in Europe is one thing and the situation in Asia is another,'' a senior Foreign Ministry official said. ''We support the U.S. forces staying in Japan.'' **********The official, who briefed reporters on condition that he not be identified, characterized the proposed American military reductions as the product of budgetary constraints rather than strategic considerations. In fact, he applauded the Bush Administration's attempts to reduce the budget deficit, a policy that Japan has been pressing the United States to undertake in trade negotiations currently underway. **********But he was unwavering in reiterating Japan's hard-line military stand against the Soviet Union, a longstanding policy that has not been affected by the developments in Eastern Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/18/busin.body_text: **********Whittle Communications, a specialized media company based in Knoxville, Tenn., said yesterday that it had named Gerry Hogan, the president of Turner Entertainment Networks, as a vice chairman. **********The change moves Mr. Hogan, who announced his resignation from Turner yesterday, from cable television to what Whittle calls place-based and private media. Whittle's projects include various formats - television, books, magazines and wall posters -which include advertising. **********''Cable is a maturing industry,'' Mr. Hogan said yesterday, ''and I see this private media and place-based media as in the same spot cable was 10 years ago. This is an opportunity to break new ground.'' **********Mr. Hogan, a 44-year-old graduate of St. Ambrose College in Davenport, Iowa, joined the Leo Burnett Agency in Chicago after college and worked there for three years, leaving as an account executive handling Procter & Gamble. After joining Turner in Atlanta in 1971, he eventually became responsible for the TNT cable channel, the TBS Superstation and Turner Pictures. **********Whittle, which is 20 years old this year, employs 1,000 and has annual revenues of $230 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/25/world.main_headline: U.S. Joins in 2d Vote At U.N. to Criticize Israel Over 21 Slain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/25/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; U.S. Joins in 2d Vote At U.N. to Criticize Israel Over 21 Slain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/25/world.body_text: **********The United States voted with the rest of the Security Council tonight to deplore Israel's refusing to cooperate with an investigation of the killing of 21 Palestinians in a clash with Israeli security forces two weeks ago. **********The unanimous council vote, the second to criticize Israel in 12 days, had been postponed for 24 hours at the request of the United States so that President Bush could send an appeal to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to reconsider his Government's refusal to cooperate with the United Nations inquiry into the Oct. 8 killings. **********Israel rejected the appeal today, and after promising members to make "another serious attempt" at changing Israel's position, the United States representative, Thomas R. Pickering, returned to the council chamber empty-handed. **********Diplomats said that as with the earlier council resolution against Israel Washington's vote was largely influenced by its desire to preserve the international coalition opposing the seizure of Kuwait by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. **********On Oct. 12, the Security Council voted unanimously to approve a resolution condemning Israel for using excessive violence four days earlier in suppressing stone-throwing demonstrators at Al Aksa Mosque in the Old City of Jerusalem. **********The new resolution "deplores" Israel's refusal to receive an investigative team that Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar planned to send to Jerusalem at the Security Council's behest. The mission was to report on the Oct. 8 incident and suggest ways to protect Palestinians in the occupied territories from further violence. **********The new resolution urges Israel to reconsider its refusal and "insists that it comply fully" with the Oct. 12 resolution, which authorized the inquiry. **********Last week, the Israeli Government said that although the United Nations investigators could come to the country it would not receive them or give assurances that its members would be able to meet Palestinian leaders. Mr. Perez de Cuellar responded by saying that he would not send the team.  U.N. Role on Israel Seen **********The resolution adopted today instructs the Secretary General to submit his report by the end of the month as planned even though his team will not be visiting Israel. The council "affirms its determination to give full and expeditious consideration to the report." **********This means that later this month the Security Council will begin discussing possible new ways that the United Nations could help protect Palestinians against Israeli mistreatment. **********Though it voted for the resolution tonight, the United States has said that in its view the process outlined by the Security Council does not give it the right to involve itself in the quest for a permanent peace settlement in the area. **********But most other members see the Secretary General's report as opening the door to precisely such United Nations involvement. Some are likely to argue that the best way to protect Palestinians from further violence is to summon an international conference under United Nations auspices to settle the Palestinian question -- a gathering the Israeli Government has long opposed. **********While irritation with the present Israeli Government's policies may partly explain the Bush Administration's endorsement of two anti-Israeli resolutions this month, diplomats believe another powerful factor is the need to preserve the unity of the moderate Arab coalition Washington has built up against the seizure of Kuwait by Iraq. **********An American veto would embarrass the Arab states by casting the United States in the role of Israel's protector. It would also allow President Hussein to present himself as the true ally of the Palestinians. **********As a result, the Security Council's campaign to oust Iraq's forces from Kuwait is becoming linked with the Palestinian question in the minds of most council members. They accept the Arabs' contention that the council cannot preserve its credibility if it punishes Iraq's aggression while turning a blind eye to Israel's continued occupation of Arab lands. **********In a bitter address tonight, Israel's acting representative, Johanan Bein, accused the Palestine Liberation Organization of deliberately sidetracking the council from the Persian Gulf crisis by involving it in the Palestinian question. "It appears Saddam Hussein has been let off the hook," he said. **********But Yemen's representative, Abdullah Saleh al-Ashlaf, the council's only Arab member, said the council should impose trade sanctions on Israel if it continues to disobey its orders just as it imposed them against Iraq. **********The P.L.O.'s acting observer, Nasser al-Kidwa, also asked the Security Council to institute a stronger link between its handling of Iraq and Israel, saying it should be prepared to impose economic sanctions on Israel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/world.main_headline: Lesotho Army Ruler Declares Exiled King to Be Dethroned
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/world.print_headline: Lesotho Army Ruler Declares Exiled King to Be Dethroned
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/world.body_text: **********The military ruler of the southern African nation of Lesotho today declared the exiled King, Moshoeshoe II, dethroned and stripped him of his title of head of state. **********Maj. Gen. Justin Lekhanya, chief of the governing military council, said he was retracting an invitation issued on Oct. 24 for Moshoeshoe to return from exile in London. The former King set unacceptable conditions for his return, including dissolution of the Government, General Lekhanya told the National Constituent Assembly. **********King Moshoeshoe was forced into exile in March after disagreements with General Lekhanya, who came to power in a 1986 coup that ousted Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/04/world.main_headline: With Baltic Aid, Rival Republics Agree on Truce
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/04/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   With Baltic Aid, Rival Republics Agree on Truce
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/04/world.body_text: **********Separatist leaders of several republics in the Soviet Union succeeded today in circumventing the Kremlin and negotiating a cease-fire in the explosive border violence between Armenia and Azerbaijan. **********The new challenge to Moscow's authority resulted in a communique that was signed in the Latvian capital by nationalist leaders from the two feuding southern republics, who agreed as well to the exchange of dozens of hostages and the creation of a council to work directly on the turmoil in the Transcaucasus. **********The communique was also signed by separatist leaders from the three Baltic popular fronts, which sponsored the unusual talks. The talks were intended to demonstrate the eroding political influence of the central Government in Moscow as much as to calm the regional crisis. **********Decentralized Populism Gains **********By creating this new sort of political initiative, leaders from the separatist movements of the two warring republics and of the Baltic lands, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, feel that they have considerably advanced the cause of decentralized populist politics now challenging the Communist Party's authority in major parts of the nation. **********''This was historic and shows how strong these movements truly are -not for the Government but for the people,'' said Anda Anspoka, a spokeswoman for the Baltic Council. That is an alliance of the powerful popular fronts in Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia that have been crafting peaceful initiatives to secede from the nation in the face of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's objections. **********''Until yesterday we were not sure that the two sides would ever agree to even meet in the same room with mediators,'' Miss Anspoka said, noting the long history of enmity between the Azerbaijanis and Armenians and the current spate of violence that has posed a critical problem for the central Government. **********No Reaction From Gorbachev **********The five popular fronts made a point of not inviting Kremlin officials to the talks, held in Riga, Latvia's capital, aiming to show that they had the people's confidence while the Government did not. Mr. Gorbachev has offered no reaction to the two-day meeting, which was mentioned briefly in Soviet news accounts with no reference of the Baltic sponsors. Miss Anspoka said the talks that produced the agreement lasted from 6 P.M. Friday until 3 A.M. today. She added that the negotiators from the Armenian National Movement and the Azerbaijani Popular Front were so involved that they had asked for an additional session this afternoon limited to themselves without Baltic Council mediation. **********''Who would have imagined these hot-blooded people finally talking directly this way,'' she said. **********One factor was the decision to exclude from the agenda the most delicate of their differences, the ethnic turmoil around Nagorno-Karabakh, an enclave within Azerbaijan but populated mostly by Armenians who prefer allegiance with the neighboring Armenian republic. The two sides even ventured to raise this issue before the final session ended this evening in Riga, Miss Anspoka said. But they reported no progress after restating their fimiliar differences over the communal violence, which began two years ago and in which scores of people have been slain. They did agree that their dispute was rooted in territorial and political issues, not in the religious differences between the Islamic Azerbaijanis and the Christian Armenians. **********Under the terms of the communique, the popular front leaders agreed to return to their people in Armenia and Azerbaijan to explain the agreement and to effect an end to all border violence no later than Feb. 15. They also agreed to investigate all hostage-takings in the region by that date and to effect an exchange no later than March 1. It is believed that 18 Armenians and 47 Azerbaijanis are being held as hostages from the numerous village raids and reprisals. **********Before leaving the negotiating table at the Latvian Writers' Union, the two sides also jointly condemned the Kremlin's sending of emergency troops to the region, and contended that the ethnic violence could be better contained by earlier and more accurate and credible investigations of tensions by popular front representatives rather than Communist Government officials. **********Local Party Is Displaced **********The popular unrest in the republics has increasingly revealed the local Communist machines as being out of touch with the new wave of politics being brandished by the popular fronts. In Azerbaijan, the party apparatus was routed by popular front leaders. In the Baltics, local party leaders have been joining the secessionist challenge to central authority to win popularity. **********The Riga talks came about after Mr. Gorbachev declared a state of emergency and sent troops into Baku, the Azerbaijani capital, on Jan. 20 to reclaim civil authority from the Azerbaijani Popular Front. He also sought to stop maurauding gangs of Azerbaijanis who killed dozens of civilians from the Armenian minority in a week of insurrection. **********At least 100 more people were killed in the troops' storming of Baku. The Soviet leader said the move was needed because popular front ''extremists'' were on the verge of fully displacing local Communist authority. **********But the popular front's contention, endorsed by the signers of the Riga accord, was that the Government had fomented ethnic violence as a pretext for imposing martial law so as to head off a devastating defeat for the Communists by the popular front in coming local elections.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/busin.main_headline: Saudi Oil Minister Predicts A 'Sellers' Market' in 90's
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/busin.print_headline: Saudi Oil Minister Predicts A 'Sellers' Market' in 90's
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/busin.body_text: **********The Saudi oil minister, Hisham M. Nazer, said yesterday that he did not anticipate an oil crisis in the 1990's but added that ''the market will slowly but steadily turn into a sellers' market.'' **********He predicted a 20 percent increase in oil demand in this decade, which other experts said would be a continuation of the trend in recent years. That increase would come with world economic growth of 3.2 percent, he said. **********The Saudis' own growth rate would also be about 3.2 percent, he said, which some experts describe as a modest figure. **********Mr. Nazer would not make specific predictions about oil prices. But he said, ''We do not think higher prices will sustain economic growth.'' Conversely, he said, lower prices would not ''maintain the proper stability in producer countries.'' Saudi Arabia has run a budget deficit in some years recently because of lower oil prices. **********Asked whether his country would make further investments in refining and marketing operations in consumer countries, Mr. Nazer said such expansion was ''an important ingredient of stability'' in the industry. His country already owns half the Texaco marketing and refining network in 23 Eastern states, including three refineries and thousands of gasoline outlets. **********Mr. Nazer spoke at a conference on the Saudi economy at the Kevorkian Center for Near Eastern Studies at New York University. He arrived in New York on Wednesday, when he helped open a 65,000-square-foot exhibit on Saudi history and culture at the Passenger Ship Terminal, Pier 88. The exhibit runs through March 17 and then moves to Los Angeles. **********Would Lease Oil **********In response to a question yesterday, Mr. Nazer said his country would be interested in leasing oil to the United States for storage in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. An Energy Department report recently endorsed the idea of filling the reserve caverns, mostly in Louisiana, with oil that was leased instead of purchased, to lower the cost. Mr. Nazer said, ''We're interested in the strategic reserve simply because we're interested in penetrating the American market.'' **********Some American analysts suggested that leasing could be a way for a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to earn extra oil revenue without violating the group's quotas, which cover sales and do not anticipate leasing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/12/busin.body_text: **********Rise for Three-Month Bill **********The average discount rate for a new three-month bill rose by two basis points, to 7.41 percent, while the six-month bill rate fell by two basis points, to 7.34 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********In the weekly survey of New York area banks and savings institutions done by The Bank Rate Monitor, the average yields were down. At commercial banks, the average money market account was down by a basis point, to 6.21 percent, while yields on three-month certificates and six-month certificates fell by five basis points each, to 7.60 percent and 7.69 percent, respectively. **********Yields at savings institutions, which remain higher than those offered by commercial banks, were also down. The average money account declined by two basis points, to 6.39 percent, while a three-month certificate was unchanged at 7.92 percent. For a six-month certificate the yield fell by five basis points, to 7.96 percent. **********Money Market Yields Down **********Outside the New York market and among 20 large banks nationwide, the average yield for a money market account slipped by a basis point, to 6.25 percent, while a six-month certificate of deposit fell two basis points, to 7.53 percent. **********Among some of the country's large credit unions this week, where yields have been mixed for the last month, the average yield on a money market account was unchanged at 6.54 percent, while the average yield on a six-month certificate was down by two basis points, to 7.87 percent. **********For the longer one-year and two-and-a-half-year certificates, the average yields dropped by a basis point, to 8.04 percent and 8.17 percent, respectively. And for a five-year certificate, the yield was up by a basis point, to 8.30 percent.
