https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/04/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene;   Cellular Phones: Room for Three?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/04/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene;   Cellular Phones: Room for Three?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/04/busin.body_text: **********EVER wonder why cellular mobile telephones, the communications miracle of the 1980's, cost so much to use? One corporate maverick, Federal Digital Cellular, claims to know the answer: monopoly power. It is asking Federal regulators to make room for a third cellular phone competitor in each city. **********There is, however, a giant catch: The slice of the airwaves the company wants is already being used by GTE Mobile Communications to operate air-to-ground pay phones on domestic airliners. **********Putting this piece of radio spectrum up for grabs would put GTE's Airfones out of business. Perhaps more significant politically, it would threaten the interests of established cellular telephone companies, whose lock on mobile communications is now valued in the tens of billions of dollars. **********In the mid-1970's A.T.&T. estimated that by 1990 just 100,000 Americans would be willing to shell out $100 or more each month for the luxury of phones in their cars and briefcases. Competition-minded policy analysts thus thought they had scored a victory in convincing the Federal Communications Commission to make room for second cellular systems, independent of the local phone company, in every metropolitan area. **********But the cellular phone has proved to be the biggest electronic hit since the Walkman. The investment firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette now predicts that the current army of 3.5 million cellular subscribers will mushroom to 26 million by 1998. Cellular phone companies must race to keep the supply of circuits ahead of demand. **********It is not surprising then that franchise holders are not competing on the price of calling time. According to Paul Kagan Associates, a consulting firm, mature cellular systems enjoy a 60 percent profit margin on sales - five times the average margin for regulated public utilities. **********Cellular franchises, by custom freely tradable once they have been assigned, now change hands for about $200 per resident. This figure implies that the right to run one of the two cellular systems in every big city is worth a staggering $37 billion. **********One way to prevent consumers from being gouged would be to regulate rates. But the F.C.C. is loath to extend its reach in an area of rapid innovation and productivity improvement. **********The alternative, Federal Digital Cellular argues, is to carve out enough room on the airwaves for a third competitor in each market. Little space would be needed, the company asserts. While the two current systems take up 50 megahertz of spectrum, a third using new digital technology could be squeezed into four megahertz. **********As a practical matter, however, the only chunk of spectrum available is the one used for air-to-ground phones. In April 1988 the commission proposed to convert GTE's experimental license, issued in 1984, into what would amount to a permanent entitlement. Federal Digital Cellular is now petitioning to reopen the proceedings. **********Some members of the commission staff are reported to be reluctant to undo a completed deal. And no one is eager to penalize GTE for its innovation in air-to-ground communications, or disrupt Airfone service to consumers. But a number of considerations may yet convince the regulators to think again. **********Even by GTE's optimistic revenue projections, the potential value of a third cellular franchise in major markets is at least five times as great as the value of Airfone service. Air-to-ground service, moreover, could be accommodated on higher radio frequencies by using satellites. Indeed, one company, the American Mobile Satellite Corporation, is already licensed for the service and expects to be in operation this year. **********Federal Digital Cellular's real ace in the hole, however, may lie in the White House. The Bush Administration has taken no public position on how best to allocate the contested chunk of spectrum, and is not likely to do so. **********But as part of the effort to meet the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction targets in 1991, Administration budgeters projected $3 billion in revenue from a new system of auctioning communications rights to the highest bidders. And it is virtually inconceivable that the goal could be met without earmarking the most desirable portions of the unallocated spectrum to cellular phones. **********A reopening of the proceedings would not necessarily mean victory for proponents of the third cellular option. But it would give them a chance to make their case - and perhaps make a side deal with GTE to drop out of the contest. After all, if additional cellular service is so much more valuable than current air-to-ground service, there ought to be some way to compensate GTE for its loss of the franchise and still come out ahead.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/world.body_text: **********In an atmosphere of rising ethnic tension, Serbs in the Yugoslav republic of Croatia today declared the republic's predominantly Serbian-populated counties to be autonomous. **********The declaration, based on the results of a vaguely worded referendum on Serbian autonomy conducted throughout Yugoslavia over the last two months, was signed by Milan Babic, a local politician who heads the Serbian National Council, a Yugoslav press agency report said. **********More than 99 percent of the approximately 750,000 participants in the referendum voted for autonomy, the report said. Serbs officially account for 11.5 percent of Croatia's 4.7 million people, but any Serb born or living in Croatia was allowed to vote. **********The autonomy declaration comes after a weekend of unrest in Croatia's Serbian-populated counties that has set off a storm of criticism across Serbia. Extreme nationalist opposition political figures in Serbia threatened today to form paramilitary units ''to defend'' the Serbs in Croatia if the Yugoslav Government does not do so. **********The unrest began after special Croatian police units began confiscating arms and ammunition from police stations in Serbian-dominated areas and from weapons depots belonging to units of Yugoslavia's territorial defense organization, a kind of national guard. **********On Friday night, a group of Serbs broke into an arsenal in a police station in the town of Glina and made off with weapons. **********Croatian riot policemen using tear gas clashed with the crowds in several predominantly Serbian-populated towns on Saturday. A police officer and a civilian suffered gunshot wounds. **********Late Sunday night, an anonymous group based in Knin, an almost completely Serbian-populated Croatian town, blocked area roads and rail lines in reaction to the police detention of Serbs for illegal weapons possession and disorderly conduct, a press agency report said. In a statement released today, the group gave the Croatian authorities an ultimatum to release the detainees, the report said. Barricades still blocked several main roads tonight, radio reports said. **********Croatia's government has repeatedly said that the Serbs' referendum is illegal and asserted that the actions of the republic's Serbian minority are an effort to undermine Croatia's democratic order and deflect attention from Serbian police repression against ethnic Albanians in that republic's Kosovo region.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/02/busin.main_headline: Media Critics Are Seeking To Turn Talk Into Print
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/02/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Media Critics Are Seeking To Turn Talk Into Print
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/02/busin.body_text: **********About 18 months ago, J. Anthony Lukas, Ken Auletta, Frances FitzGerald and a clutch of other famous journalists began exploring the possibility of starting a magazine that would rip the hide off the media industry. **********Some wanted to call it ''Tell,'' others preferred ''Gadfly'' or ''Media Watch.'' No one was really wild about ''Mercury'' - as in messenger of the gods - but that name was selected as everyone's second choice. **********Now, Mercury has evolved from a dinner conversation to a refined concept that its backers say will be tested for audience appeal this September through a $150,000 mail promotion. **********Fair Game for Criticism **********As envisioned, Mercury would consider everyone fair game for criticism, including its celebrated backers, and would ruthlessly scrutinize communications in the broadest sense: print and broadcast, public relations, advertising and Hollywood. **********''I don't see it as ideological,'' said Mr. Lukas, who added that the magazine would lay bare how the media influences politics and vice versa. **********If response to the mailing is encouraging, October will be devoted to an attempt to raise the $6 million needed to begin the magazine sometime next year. **********But those involved say they are not kidding themselves. **********''This is going to be a hard sell,'' said Arthur M. Dubow, a venture capitalist who is leading the financial side of Mercury's evolution, echoing concerns about today's depressed magazine market. **********The idea for Mercury began when John Scanlon, a public relations man known for his relationships with celebrity journalists, spoke to Mr. Auletta about the need to revive something similar to More magazine, an aggressive, liberal journalism review in the 1970's. The new magazine is to be broader in appeal and focus. **********Inner Circle of the Project **********The group expanded to include Mr. Lukas, Ms. FitzGerald and Mr. Dubow, who have formed the inner circle of the project, with Mr. Auletta. **********Others also became involved, including David Halberstam, Bill Kovach, Roger W. Wilkins, Robert A. Caro, Richard M. Clurman, Bill Moyers, Rea S. Hederman, Joan Ganz Cooney and Richard Pollak. **********Mr. Scanlon eventually dropped out, agreeing that only journalists should be involved. **********Jonathan Alter, the press critic of Newsweek, was invited to prepare a proposal for Mercury and it is his vision that is being followed, though Mr. Lukas said that the question of who will be editor will not be resolved until, and if, one is needed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/04/busin.body_text: **********When makers of personal computers and work stations talk about mainframe computers, they often call them dinosaurs. **********The implication is that these huge machines laboring away in glass-walled rooms surrounded by white-coated technicians are the industry's past; powerful desktop computers are its future. And in fact, more and more tasks that once required a mainframe are now being tackled by the PC or its more powerful desktop sibling, the work station, strung together on a network. **********But far from killing the mainframe, in many businesses work station networks have fostered a complex computing environment that plays to the mainframe's strengths. Mainframe revenues are still growing at a little more than 10 percent a year, which off a base of more than $14 billion in 1989 is hardly indicative of a moribund industry. As one industry executive puts it, if these are dinosaurs, they are an awfully frisky breed. **********Indeed, the three mainframe makers with the fastest growth are each preparing to introduce a new generation of machines. Hitachi Ltd., which has historically been a distant third to the International Business Machines Corporation and the Amdahl Corporation, tried to gain an advantage in June when it announced its next-generation mainframes well in advance of those two rivals, which are not expected to announce until sometime next year. **********But analysts said the impact of the Hitachi announcement was lessened somewhat by delivery dates so far in the future - the second quarter of 1991 - that they will not predate the new I.B.M. or Amdahl machines by much. **********Industry executives and analysts say the mainframe business has averaged about 10 percent growth a year for the last 20 years and could well continue at that rate for the next 10. But this is revenue growth, driven by existing customers upgrading to new and ever-larger machines. Unit growth, created by sales to new customers or new sites, is only in the low single digits and is not expected to accelerate, analysts say. **********Analysts also say the growth is limited to I.B.M., which has 83 percent of the market, and to the so-called plug-compatible manufacturers, which make mainframes compatible with I.B.M.'s. These are Amdahl of Sunnyvale, Calif., and Hitachi of Japan, which resells its machines in the United States through Hitachi Data Systems Inc. in Santa Clara, Calif. **********Two emerging trends in computing are expected to drive demand for mainframes and work stations simultaneously. **********One is ''enterprise wide'' computing, where all the computers in a company are connected on a series of networks, a task of such complexity that it could be managed only by a mainframe. The other is ''client-server'' computing, where tasks are divided between the client - a work station or PC - and the server - a larger computer elsewhere on a network. While most work station companies also make machines they call servers, on complex installations the server is likely to be a mainframe. **********''Legitimately, some work has gone from big machines to small machines, and it was the right place to go,'' said John C. Lewis, Amdahl's chairman and chief executive. ''That will continue, but what I think is going to happen is that customers are going to find that the best technical solution is a combination of centralized computer server capability and decentralized work stations,'' he said. **********While work stations are increasingly used for personal productivity - design work in engineering or producing presentations and reports in the commercial world - data and applications crucial to a business are still likely to reside on the mainframe. When it comes to managing all of a bank's automatic teller machines, or coordinating reservations for airline seats, the mainframe's robustness and ability to process huge amounts of data are key. **********''There are quite a few Fortune 500 companies whose health of the business is based on the ability of these monsters to keep running,'' said John B. Jones Jr., an analyst with Montgomery Securities. **********Many companies have begun to use their large computer systems as an offensive weapon. Aided by a software technology called relational data base management, which is adept at processing complex requests and breaking down vast amounts of information in many ways, these companies constantly review their internal data, looking for ways to drive down the time to market of new products, cut inventories and improve manufacturing efficiency. **********''People find as they start doing that, it gets complicated,'' said M. Bernard Puckett, the president of I.B.M.'s data systems division. ''The thing that mainframes remain good at is managing that complexity.'' **********As the ability of networks to move data has improved, companies are also finding that their efficiency is improved by having fewer mainframe sites. Organizations that used to have many data centers, each with their own modest-sized mainframe, are now consolidating those operations, which has driven demand for the very largest mainframes. **********So while having the most powerful mainframe on the market has always been important for a manufacturer's bragging rights, it may now give a significant competitive edge, said Stephen Cohen, an analyst with the Soundview Financial Group in Stamford, Conn. **********In the past, I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., was able to offer the biggest mainframes. I.B.M. did not get as much power from a single computer processor unit as did Amdahl or Hitachi, but it was able to couple six processors while its competitors were limited to four. **********Compatibles Gain Market Share **********In the next generation of mainframes, which could ship in late 1991 or early 1992, Mr. Cohen expects the compatible manufacturers to still have the largest single processors, but that all three companies will reach parity at eight processors coupled together. ''I think I.B.M. will end up losing share in the marketplace,'' he said. Hitachi and Amdahl ''will have product equal to if not superior to I.B.M.,'' he added. **********The plug-compatibles have been gaining share from I.B.M. for several years. Like the Compaq Computer Corporation in the PC business, they have done this by offering lower prices, superior performance or new features in advance of I.B.M., while remaining scrupulously compatible. Amdahl, for example, was the first to offer a complete mainframe version of Unix, the industry standard operating system software popular on work stations. **********Gary Moore, president and chief executive of Hitachi Data Systems, said the company's early announcement of its new mainframes had more to do with allaying customer worries than getting a jump on the competition. ''We were seeing concern from our customers - 'What are you going to do next?' '' he said. ''A lot of customers do planning nine to 12 months out; you don't just go out and buy a $14 million computer.'' **********Maintaining customer loyalty is difficult in the mainframe business because compatibility allows different manufacturers' products to be mixed and matched within a single installation. Customers know that buying a single piece of Amdahl or Hitachi equipment will improve their bargaining power with I.B.M. on the next sale, and analysts say discounts as deep as 45 percent are not unheard of. **********I.B.M. Dominates Software **********While some analysts worry about the growing power of the Japanese in the mainframe business - Amdahl is 44 percent owned by, and gets key components from, Fujitsu Ltd. -others say I.B.M. will remain dominant because it sets the software standard to which I.B.M., Amdahl and Hitachi must adhere. **********''The operating system and related data base software are so important that just because the Japanese can produce faster processors before I.B.M. - in the eyes of the customer that doesn't mean that much,'' said Ulric Weil, an analyst with Weil & Associates in Washington. ''On the software side, the Japanese simply are not able to solve that riddle.'' **********And despite its forays into PC's, work stations and minicomputers, I.B.M. remains very bullish about the mainframe. ''If it were going to go away, we would need to be the first to know,'' Mr. Puckett said, noting that I.B.M. budgets new mainframe developments seven to 10 years ahead of their appearance in the market. **********Mr. Puckett said the mainframe market was at the front end of a new demand cycle as more companies used the big machines to improve their own efficiency. And each year, he said, the dinosaur ''rattles its tail and lumbers forward for a few billion dollars more in revenues and profit.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/busin.main_headline: Good Profit Margins Shown At Saks and Marshall Field
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/busin.print_headline: Good Profit Margins Shown At Saks and Marshall Field
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/busin.body_text: **********Prospectuses for Saks Fifth Avenue and Marshall Field show that both companies have produced profit margins about twice the norm for department stores catering to higher-income clientele. **********The 46 stores of Saks, which is based in New York, are somewhat more profitable than the 24 stores of the Chicago-based Marshall Field, according to the documents. **********Both chains have been put up for sale by their British owner, B.A.T. Industries, which is selling assets in an attempt to thwart a hostile takeover bid from Sir James Goldsmith. **********The confidential prospectuses, which were sent out by investment bankers this week, show that Saks's operating profit rose 7.9 percent in 1989 from 1988, while Marshall Field had a decline of seven-tenths of 1 percent in income before depreciation, interest and taxes. **********Saks's revenue in 1989 rose 7.1 percent, to $1.24 billion, from $1.16 billion in 1988. Same-store sales were up 6.1 percent, with the Minneapolis store, which opened in August, accounting for the difference. The company's Midwest, Southern, Western and Texas regions had the best gains, the prospectus reported. **********Operating income at Saks rose to $94.1 million in 1989, or 7.6 percent of revenue, compared with $87.2 million, or 7.5 percent of revenue, in 1988. The gain came from higher sales and higher gross margins. **********Marshall Field's sales grew by 6.86 percent in 1989, to $1.09 billion, from $1.02 billion in 1988. Its estimated income before depreciation, interest and taxes declined to $90.75 million in 1989, from $91.4 million the year before. **********Several Bidders Drawn **********Saks Fifth Avenue and Marshall Field are expected to draw a number of bidders. For Saks, the known bidders are a management group led by Melvin Jacobs, Saks's chairman, and Joseph E. Brooks, chairman of the Ann Taylor stores, in conjunction with Merrill Lynch Capital Partners. The General Cinema Corporation, which owns almost 60 percent of the Neiman Marcus Group, is said to be a potential bidder for Saks. Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., is the investment bank handling the sale. **********Bidders for Marshall Field are reported to be a group led by Philip B. Miller, chairman of Field; the May Department Stores Company, St. Louis; Dillard Department Stores, Little Rock, Ark., and the JMB Realty Company, Chicago. Goldman, Sachs is handing the sale of Marshall Field. **********Although the unsettled conditions in retailing might force offering prices down, many retail and financial executives expect Saks to draw bids in the $1 billion area and Marshall Field to attract a wider range of prices, perhaps from $600 million to under $1 billion. **********Led by New York City **********According to the prospectus, Saks's sales in New York City were the highest in the chain in 1989, totaling $277 million, up 3.1 percent for the year. The second highest in sales was the West Coast region, where they were $203.6 million, up 3.6 percent. **********Saks told prospective bidders that it had budgeted $435.5 million for capital expenditures from 1990 through 1994. The company plans to open 10 stores and to replace its existing stores in Chicago, Phoenix, White Plains, and La Jolla, Calif., and to renovate 37 others. **********The expansion of the New York City store will cost about $25 million, or 5.7 percent of the budget. B.A.T. has already supplied $27 million from 1986 through 1989 toward the New York City expansion. **********In its five-year plan, Saks said it expects to have sales of $1.385 billion in 1990, which should grow to $1.855 billion in 1994. Gross profit is projected to grow from $593.8 million to $795.4 million in the period, with operating income rising from $106.3 million to $154.4 million.

Robbins manager of its new Troy, Mich., office, McCann/SAS, which it opened to serve the GMC truck division of the General Motors Corporation. Ms. Robbins had managed truck advertising at the Chevrolet division at G.M. **********"Why Candace?" said John J. Dooner, president of McCann, North America. "That's simple. She's known to be one of the best in the advertising business as it relates to trucks through her work at Chevrolet." **********The deal was worked out with G.M. as part of the agency's effort to have a "partnership" relationship with the auto maker. **********"She's not really leaving G.M., she's being given the opportunity to manage a complete operation," Mr. Dooner said. "Everyone here is a winner."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/08/world.main_headline: A HOSTAGE RELEASE PREDICTED BY IRAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/08/world.print_headline: A HOSTAGE RELEASE PREDICTED BY IRAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/08/world.body_text: **********The official Iranian press agency reported today that a Western hostage held in Lebanon, probably a European, was expected to be released shortly. **********The report by the Islamic Republic News Agency was thought by Western diplomats here to be highly significant because Lebanese kidnappers who hold European and American hostages have broad ties to Iran's Government. **********The press agency said in a brief report from Teheran that well-placed informants had been unable to name the hostage to be freed but that ''he is most probably a European.'' The report said it was unclear where or exactly when the release might occur. **********Earlier Prediction Was Accurate **********Earlier this year, the news service accurately predicted the release of two American hostages, Robert Polhill, and Frank Herbert Reed, who were freed by the their captors in April. **********Mr. Polhill was freed on April 22 after 39 months in captivity, and Mr. Reed was freed on April 30 after more than 43 months. Six Americans are among the 16 Westerners still held hostage in Lebanon. [The Associated Press reported that a person close to the Syrian Army command in Lebanon said that if any hostage was released, it probably would be Brian Keenan, an 39-year-old Irishman who taught English at the American University of Beirut and was abducted in April 1986.]  [Prime Minister Charles Haughey of Ireland said Saturday that he he was aware of renewed hopes for Mr. Keenan's release and that His Government was ''making a total all-out effort, constantly using every means at our disposal, our embassy and friends,'' Reuters reported.]  Iran was said to have been instrumental in the release of Mr. Polhill and Mr. Reed, and the freeing of another hostage in Lebanon would almost certainly signal the continued desire of President Hashemi Rafsanjani to improve ties to the West. **********It might also again demonstrate how Mr. Rafsanjani has gained the upper hand against extremists in his Government who are said to see the hostages as important bargaining chips who should remain in captivity. **********Earthquake Relief Assistance **********In the last two weeks, in the wake of the devastating earthquake in Northern Iran, Mr. Rafsanjani has made what seems to be a bold break with past practice by agreeing to accept humanitarian assistance from the United States and other nations long considered to be enemies. **********The freeing of additional hostages could help Iran put an end to trade embargoes by the United States and European Community nations whose citizens are held captive in Lebanon. **********While other Iranian officials have said publicly that Iran can do little more to help free Westerners in Lebanon, diplomats here have said that Iran still holds significant sway over the pro-Iranian kidnappers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/world.print_headline: GORBACHEV CALLS ON PARTY TO FORGO POWER MONOPOLY; MEETS HARD-LINE OPPOSITION
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called on the Communist Party today to forswear its constitutional monopoly on power and to accept the prospect of rival political parties. **********Speaking to the party's governing Central Committee, the Soviet leader vowed that the Communists would give up ''any legal and political advantages,'' apparently including the party's nearly unlimited power to fill important jobs in government, industry, news organizations and other major social institutions. [Excerpts, page A16.]  Mr. Gorbachev immediately encountered fierce opposition from hard-liners who warned that political pluralism would lead to the extinction of the Communists. **********Vast Changes in Party Sought **********In his opening speech to the two-day gathering, the Soviet leader urged that a nationwide congress on the future of the party be moved up to next summer, because the party is in danger of losing its initiative. **********He also proposed, in a draft of a party program, the most sweeping internal reorganization of the party structure since Lenin's day. And he urged the party to consider broader but unspecified powers for the recently created post of presidency. **********Mr. Gorbachev had argued until recently that it was too early to abolish the party's constitutional monopoly. He had said that only the party could unify the country during a difficult period of transition. But there have long been hints that he was open to establishing a multiparty system eventually. And he has gradually given way to critics who view the party's constitutional guarantee of power as a hallmark of authoritarian rule. **********Approval of Proposal Is Seen **********The meeting of the 250-member Central Committee is to approve a party platform for final action at the party congress. Mr. Gorbachev's draft has not yet been made public, but details have emerged in his speech and the discussion, as well as in press reports over the weekend. **********Participants leaving the session tonight said Mr. Gorbachev's draft seemed likely to pass. But excerpts of the debate published by Tass included blistering attacks from hard-liners unwilling to forsake the party's leading role. **********Valentin K. Mesyats, the old-guard party boss of the Moscow region, declared that he had been sent to the Central Committee meeting to stand up for the leading role of the party. He warned that Mr. Gorbachev's program ''is leading to a point where the party as such is falling by the political wayside.'' **********On the other flank, Boris N. Yeltsin, the feisty opposition member of the Soviet Parliament, proposed a more far-reaching party program, including direct election of top party leaders by the rank-and-file. **********Mr. Gorbachev's centrist and sometimes fuzzy draft, he said, ''gives the impression that it was written with two hands, left and right.'' **********The party congress, originally scheduled for the spring of 1991, has already been advanced to October amid signs of the party's declining authority. Today Mr. Gorbachev said the need for revamping the party was urgent and proposed that the meeting be moved up to June or July. **********Gorbachev's Argument **********The debate today focused on Mr. Gorbachev's call on the party to relinquish its ruling position, guaranteed by Article 6 of the Constitution, and to recognize the tumult of new political forces unleashed by several years of liberalization. **********''The party in a renewing society can exist and play its role as vanguard only as a democratically recognized force,'' he said. ''This means that its status should not be imposed through constitutional endorsement. **********''The Soviet Communist Party, it goes without saying, intends to struggle for the status of the ruling party,'' he continued. ''But it will do so strictly within the framework of the democratic process by giving up any legal and political advantages, offering its program and defending it in discussions, cooperating with other social and political forces, always working among the masses, living by their interests and their needs. **********''The extensive democratization under way in our society is being accompanied by mounting political pluralism. Various social and political organizations and movements emerge. This process may lead at a certain stage to the establishment of parties.'' **********Time Frame Uncertain **********The Soviet leader was vague about when new parties would materialize. Two Soviet republics - Lithuania and Estonia - have already legalized competing parties and have begun officially registering rivals like the Social Democrats, Christian Democrats and Greens. In these and other republics, popular fronts that combine members of various parties - including the Communist Party - and others have challenged the party's power. **********If enacted, Mr. Gorbachev's recommendation on pluralism would make the Soviet Union the last Communist country in the Soviet bloc to relinquish its legal guarantee of power. **********The formal Communist monopoly dates to Stalin's 1936 constitution, but in practice there have been no multiparty elections here since shortly after the Bolsheviks seized power in 1917. **********Mr. Gorbachev's remarks drew a wary response from Communist Party insurgents, who on Sunday organized a march of 100,000 people through Moscow to demand more democracy. **********Vasily S. Shakhnovsky, a leader of an alliance of Moscow Communist clubs that sponsored the demonstration, said a constitutional amendment would be an important symbol, but no assurance of political freedom. **********''Power will still remain in the hands of the party apparatus,'' he said tonight. ''It's more an emotional thing, and it will depend on whether he really wants to give the power away.'' **********Shift of Power May Be Goal **********Mr. Gorbachev's speech today seemed to confirm what many think is his overall strategy: a transfer of responsibility and power from the party machine to the presidency and the elected Parliament. **********Many say they think that if this is accomplished he will surrender his position as party leader to focus on his term as President, which continues until 1994. **********The Soviet leader seemed to side with those who contend that the President, like chief executives in the United States or France, should have more power. **********Critics of the current system say Mr. Gorbachev is too hemmed in by the fractious Parliament, which prevents him from responding quickly to ethnic disorders or economic crises. **********Mr. Gorbachev today said that ''the question has arisen'' of equipping the President ''with all the necessary powers to implement the policy of perestroika.'' **********''The draft platform naturally speaks about this concisely, stressing the need to act without delay,'' he said. ''I think this idea deserves discussion by this plenum.'' **********Mr. Gorbachev asked the Central Committee to endorse a major reorganization of the party, creating a chairman with two deputies in place of the current General Secretary, and streamlining the Central Committee to 200 members. **********He called for ''rethinking the principle of democratic centralism,'' the policy of centralized discipline that requires all party members to follow the line decreed from above. **********Disappointed Consumers **********Mr. Gorbachev grimly admitted the failure of his program to produce tangible results for Soviet consumers, describing the national mood as ''social tension and anxiety'' mixed with ''apathy and disappointment.'' **********He passionately defended his decision to send the army last month to the embattled southern republic of Azerbaijan, asserting that if a state of emergency had not been imposed ''the blood of not dozens but of thousands upon thousands of people would have been shed.'' **********The intervention, he said, headed off a coup by nationalists who ''sought to establish a dictatorship - not a democracy - by naked force and through militant nationalism.'' **********Although his draft platform reportedly called for lifting the party's categorical objection to private ownership of industry and farmland, his speech did not touch on this point and it did not figure in the debate excerpted tonight by Tass.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/04/busin.main_headline: Precious Metals Are Down While Crude Oil Prices Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/04/busin.print_headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS;   Precious Metals Are Down While Crude Oil Prices Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/04/busin.body_text: **********Precious metal prices continued to fall yesterday, largely on the firmness of the dollar and the belief that the Federal Reserve will not reduce interest rates because of recent signs of economic improvement. **********Prices of crude oil continued to soar on the willingness of many refiners to pay more despite production problems at several Southern refineries. Much of the buying reflected strong prices for heating oil and the unusually tight gasoline supply for the season. **********''The precious metals market, led by gold, again ignored the rising energy prices and their impact on inflation and focused instead on the recent firmness of the dollar and indications that the economy was not as weak as had been thought,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, a precious metals specialist at Prudential-Bache Securities. **********Among the recent bullish economic signs, she said, is the upturn in sales of new homes and construction starts in real estate. The strong equities market has also prompted many investment fund managers to switch out of gold mining shares. **********All this comes at a time when the precious metals markets are unusually thin, Ms. Raptopoulos said, ''because many of the important participants, particularly those in Asia and Europe, have closed shop for the Christmas and New Year's holidays.'' **********On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the spot January gold delivery settled at $394 an ounce, down $5.60 on the day. The closing gold price was the lowest since mid-November. The spot Comex silver contract settled at $5.151 an ounce, down 3.2 cents. It was the lowest spot silver price since mid-October. **********The spot January platinum delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange settled at $469.80 an ounce, off $4.40. That was the lowest level since last September. **********Peter C. Beutel, an energy analyst at Elders Futures Inc., said ''that despite refinery production problems, much of related to the uncommonly cold weather along the Gulf and other parts of the South, refiners continue to be the big buyers of crude.'' **********The refiners have sharply increased their buying of crude because of the soaring demand and prices of heating oil, as well as unleaded gasoline, Mr. Beutel said, adding that ''some of the refinery problems have been in the plants that produce gasoline.'' **********At the close of the New York Merc, the spot February crude oil delivery settled at another contract high of $23.68 a barrel, up 79 cents on the day. The spot February unleaded gasoline contract climbed 1.54 cents a gallon, to 67.23 cents, and the spot February heating oil delivery rose 0.81 cent a gallon, to 78.20 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/05/busin.main_headline: Higher Fares On Foreign Flights Due
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/05/busin.print_headline: Higher Fares On Foreign Flights Due
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/05/busin.body_text: **********Some Sample Fare Rises **********Under the British Airways increases, the one-way business-class fare from New York to London has gone up to $1,802, from $1,700, while the full one-way coach fare during midweek travel has gone to $578, from $546. The one-way business-class fare from Los Angeles to London is now $2,424, up from $2,287, while the one-way full coach fare has gone to $792, from $747. **********Prices for jet fuel in the United States have risen from about 55 cents a gallon before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 to as high as $1 a gallon and have recently fluctuated between 70 and 80 cents. **********A spokesman for Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it would match the British Airways increase, effective tomorrow. **********Other leading carriers on the routes are expected to match the increase or to put through their own increases soon. **********Decision Made at Meeting **********The decision to seek the higher fares, the first for quickly rising fuel prices since the early 1980's, was made at a gathering of representatives of 200 airlines of the International Air Transport Association in Geneva last week. **********The group, a worldwide trade association for international airlines, decided to seek increases of 5 percent to 8 percent. Most of rises are expected to be about 7 percent, with fares to some areas of the world going as high as 8 percent. **********While the increases are subject to approval by the governments of the nations where a carrier flies, such approval is expected quickly. **********The carriers in the United States are expected to seek antitrust immunity from the Transportation Department to consult with one another and raise their fares. **********A Strong Case **********The airlines have a strong argument in seeking the higher fares, since increased fuel prices quickly affect the cost of an airline's operations. Fuel makes up 20 percent to 30 percent of an airline's operating cost, depending upon the age of the fleet and the length of the carrier's routes. **********Carriers have little capacity to store fuel and therefore have little choice but to pay market prices, which have risen recently. **********Dennis Eklof, a senior consultant at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Cambridge, Mass., said yesterday that Kuwait had invested heavily in sophisticated refining capacity and had become a big supplier of jet fuel. **********The loss of the capacity, along with the added demand for jet fuel created by the military buildup of the United States in the Middle East, he said, was ''severely straining the capacity to make jet fuel on a worldwide basis.'' **********Thus the pressure on prices for jet fuel have been greater than other products like gasoline, which is in less demand after the peak summer driving season. **********Rises May Not Be Enough **********Edward J. Starkmann, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc., said yesterday that the latest increases would not cover the airlines' added costs and that they might have to seek additional increases if the crisis in the Middle East persisted. **********Mr. Starkmann said that the fare increases on international routes tended to be more ''monolithic'' and that they would be felt by the business traveler as well as vacationers paying discount fares. **********The increases would also come during a slow period of travel for the industry but one during which most travelers are going on business. Such fliers generally have less ability to put off or cancel a trip. **********The trade group represents most of the world's primary international carriers except Northwest Airlines. **********International passengers made up about a fourth of the 1.1 billion passengers carried by airlines in 1989. Of the 260 million international passengers carried that year, about 230 million traveled on airlines that are part of the trade group. **********More World Travel **********International travel has also been growing faster than travel to most domestic markets, by 7 percent in 1989 over the previous year. **********Increases of 8 percent are being sought on flights from Canada to the rest of the world, flights between destinations in the southwestern Pacific, and those from the southwestern Pacific to North and Central America and Europe. Fares on international flights within Africa and to the outside will also rise by 8 percent. **********International flights within Europe would go up by 5 percent. Also international flights in Venezuela to North and Central America, the Caribbean and Europe would go up by 3 percent. International flights to Libya would not go up at all. **********Fare increases on flights between Japan, the southwest Pacific and the United States are to be decided at another conference of the association, to be held by Oct. 15.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/11/world.main_headline: BUSH DISTRESSED AS POLICY FAILS TO MOVE CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/11/world.print_headline: BUSH DISTRESSED AS POLICY FAILS TO MOVE CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/11/world.body_text: **********President Bush and many officials in his Administration say they are deeply disappointed by the failure of the Chinese Government to relax its repressive rule in response to numerous conciliatory gestures by Mr. Bush. **********The American officials explained that divisions within the Chinese leadership, compounded by fears about a resurgence of the democracy movement in China after the rapid democratic change in Eastern Europe, have made it difficult for Beijing to respond as the President had hoped. **********Those concerned about the meager results so far include the architects of Mr. Bush's policy and some who carried it out, like Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger. He acknowledged in recent Congressional testimony that the repression continued after his visits to China, that there has been no ''rapid payoff'' from Mr. Bush's policy and that China has no plan to lift martial law in Tibet. Mr. Eagleburger secretly visited Beijing with Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, in July and December. **********Getting Worse, Not Better **********Administration officials say the crackdown has become harsher in the last few months, with more surveillance of dissidents, more political education classes for students, more restrictions on overseas study and more persecution of the Roman Catholic Church and other religious groups. **********In addition, the officials said, the Government has recently purged or punished many Chinese journalists and police officials who expressed support for the democracy movement or did not take a firm stand against it. **********Administration officials said they hoped that, by openly expressing their disappointment with China, they could coax Beijing to end the abuse of human rights. **********In a surprise to the Administration, trade with China was booming even as repression increased there. Commerce Department data show that Chinese exports to the United States rose 42 percent last year, to a total of $12 billion. Much of the increase occurred in the second half of 1989, despite the killings in and near Tiananmen Square early in June. The Beijing authorities have been hard pressed to obtain convertible currency to pay off foreign-debt obligations. **********Personal Embarrassment to Bush **********For Mr. Bush, these developments represent a special problem because he invested a lot of political standing in defending his China policy and risked his reputation as someone knowledgeable about the country, where he served as chief of the United States mission in 1974 and 1975. **********Mr. Bush now voices such disappointment, sometimes even irritation, but has no new policy. In an interview with NBC News last week, he acknowledged that ''there hasn't been much'' give yet by the Chinese, and he said, ''I wish there would be more.'' **********His criticism of China is far milder than that in the State Department's annual report on human rights, which sharply assailed Chinese abuses. ''I believe I know how to go about trying to see things move forward again,'' Mr. Bush said. ''Some think isolation -bring them to heel by publicly slapping people. I think I know China well enough to know that this isn't the way to do it.'' **********Beijing vilified Mr. Bush for allowing the State Department to issue the report. It further strained relations with Washington this week when it expelled an American businessman, John P. Cragin, on a charge of conducting ''illegal religious instruction.'' China said he had done ''missionary work under the guise of holding English-language- training courses in Tianjin since October 1989.'' **********How State Dept. Sees It **********A State Department official said: ''We hoped there would be more of a response to the President's overtures. We are still hoping. The people in power in China today fear that if they do the things we would like them to do to heal the wounds of last June, they will jeopardize their own personal positions.'' **********The increase in trade between China and the United States would have been impossible if Congress had imposed stiff economic sanctions, as many lawmakers advocated last summer. Mr. Bush persuaded Congress to hold off, arguing that commercial contacts were good because they ''have led, in essence, to this quest for more freedom'' in China. **********''The Chinese are desperately trying to increase exports,'' said Jan M. Whisler, an economist at the United States International Trade Commission. ''China must now depend almost entirely on export revenues for the hard currency needed to service its foreign debt of nearly $40 billion.'' Major payments on the debt are due this year. **********A new fight looms in June over trade benefits. China's most-favored-nation status, which generally guarantees the lowest possible tariffs on exports to the United States, is scheduled to expire July 2. Administration officials say Mr. Bush will seek a regular annual extension of that status for China. Many in Congress are already gearing up to resist. At least six bills have been introduced to suspend or terminate China's status as a most favored nation. **********Use of 'Forced Labor' **********Senate Republicans are collecting evidence to show that some of China's exports, particularly textiles, were produced in prisons and labor camps. Federal law prohibits the importing of any goods produced in a foreign country by ''forced labor'' or ''convict labor.'' Textiles accounted for $3.2 billion of the $12 billion in Chinese exports to the United States last year. **********Roger W. Sullivan, president of the United States-China Business Council, a trade association of 300 American companies doing business there, said there would be ''a very strong challenge by Congress to renewal of most-favored-nation status for China.'' **********Although quick to acknowledge that Mr. Bush has not achieved his objectives, White House officials are sensitive to criticism of the President's China policy. **********Mr. Scowcroft complains bitterly that his toast ''to U.S.-Chinese friendship,'' at a banquet in Beijing on Dec. 9, has been misread as an endorsement of the military crackdown. Likewise, Douglas H. Paal, the senior specialist on China at the National Security Council, severely criticized a report on China issued last month by Asia Watch, a human rights group. When Is Ferocity Restraint?  Mr. Paal marked up a copy of the report with marginal commentary, like a professor's comments on a student's essay. Asia Watch said that the Chinese People's Liberation Army had shown ''ferocity'' in suppressing the democracy movement. **********Mr. Paal wrote: ''Some of the P.L.A. actions were indeed ferocious - other units at other times did show great restraint.'' **********Asia Watch said that thousands of peaceful dissenters were being detained in China without trials. Mr. Paal wrote, ''The very fact that so many detainees have not been tried indicates some degree of restraint.'' **********People who originally backed Mr. Bush's policy say they, too, have been disappointed. A. Doak Barnett, professor emeritus of Chinese studies at Johns Hopkins University, said he supported Mr. Bush's effort to ''halt the downward spiral in our relations with China'' by sending Mr. Eagleburger and Mr. Scowcroft to Beijing in December. **********''That mission had valid objectives and was worth trying,'' said Mr. Barnett, who has been studying China for more than four decades. ''But the Chinese have not responded sufficiently to indicate a reversal of repressive trends or to have a significant impact on American public opinion or Congress.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/18/busin.main_headline: CBS Records Chief Seen In 2-Year Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/18/busin.print_headline: CBS Records Chief Seen In 2-Year Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/18/busin.body_text: **********Walter R. Yetnikoff, the 56-year-old chief executive of CBS Records, has signed a new contract under which he will remain as chief executive for two years and then become a consultant to the company, several top-level industry executives said. **********Mr. Yetnikoff spearheaded the sale of CBS Records to the Sony Corporation of America, a unit of the Sony Corporation, in 1988 and was given a $20 million multiyear contract. **********A spokesman for the Sony Corporation of America said the company would neither confirm nor deny Mr. Yetnikoff's employment arrangements, which were reported in The Wall Street Journal yesterday morning. Mr. Yetnikoff was on vacation and did not return telephone calls. **********Several record industry executives at other companies said that they believed that Mr. Yetnikoff's current salary was about $3 million and that it was likely he would get at least a comparable salary in his new contract. **********These executives added that Mr. Yetnikoff's relations with some of CBS's most widely known performers, including Bruce Springsteen, had deteriorated in recent months. **********Neither Mr. Springsteen's manager, John Landau, nor his lawyer, Allen Grubman, returned telephone calls yesterday. **********The executives also added that Michael Jackson no longer worked with his former manager, John Branca, who was close to Mr. Yetnikoff, and that Mr. Branca's departure could affect the nature of Mr. Jackson's relationship to CBS. Mr. Jackson has recently brought in a new team to handle his affairs. **********''That matters because these singers are legends in the industry,'' said one record industry executive who strongly declined to be identified. He added that news that Mr. Yetnikoff would relinquish the leadership of the company would make him virtually a lame duck for the next two years. **********Reason for Contract Unclear **********Mr. Yetnikoff built the company, and his reputation, in part on his relationships with his superstar talent. But what precisely prompted the restructuring of his contract was not clear. At least one record industry executive said he believed that Mr. Yetnikoff was not unhappy, at least with the financial arrangements of the deal. Michael Shulhof, the head of the Sony Corporation of America, was away and did not return telephone calls. **********Mr. Yetnikoff had long chafed at working for CBS, under both its current chairman, Laurence A. Tisch, and its former president, Thomas H. Wyman. He was outspoken both in his criticism of those executives and in his desire to accumulate capital in any sale of CBS Records. **********The natural successor to Mr. Yetnikoff would be Tommy Mottola, whom Mr. Yetnikoff brought in to replace his longtime associate, Alvin N. Teller, as head of the domestic record company. Under Mr. Mottola, the company has promoted a number of new performers, including New Kids on the Block. **********Record industry executives said that CBS had somewhat recovered from a tough period it suffered last year, when its market share tumbled compared with that of its giant rival, Warner Brothers Records Inc. But Sony does not break out the figures for its record company publicly. Nevertheless, CBS's international businesses are believed to be doing well. And over all, Sony is considered to have made a smart purchase in buying CBS Records. **********Peter Guber, the co-chairman of Sony's Columbia Pictures unit, said yesterday that he knew nothing about Mr. Yetnikoff's plans for departure. But there was speculation yesterday that Mr. Guber and his partner, Jon Peters, would assume overall responsibilites for Sony's record operations as well.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/11/busin.main_headline: BMW, the Motorcycle, Gears Up for a Big Run
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;   BMW, the Motorcycle, Gears Up for a Big Run
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/11/busin.body_text: **********TURNING attention to its neglected stepchild, BMW is trying to pep up its motorcycle division by hiring a new advertising agency, raising ad expenditures tenfold and adding cheaper entry-level vehicles to its high-performance line. With new management from Germany in place, the company's American division is introducing a new ad campaign later this month by Burkhardt & Christy Advertising Inc. of New York. **********BMW's ad spending on motorcycles shriveled last year to only $200,000, as the company's market share dwindled to 2.2 percent. The company expects its sales to increase this year by 30 percent. **********But the Munich-based BMW, or Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G., still has a long way to go to catch Harley-Davidson Inc., the sole American maker of motorcycles, which dominates the market for the powerful large-engine motorcycles known as ''hogs.'' **********Harley, based in Milwaukee, had 59 percent of the market last year. The four large Japanese manufacturers - including the overall industry leader, the American Honda Motor Company - had more than 38 percent of the market. About a third of the 260,000 motorcycles sold last year were these big bikes, according to the Motorcycle Industry Council, a trade group based in Irvine, Calif. **********The motorcycle business foundered in the 1980's as the population aged, depriving the industry of many of its traditional young customers, and because the average price of a motorcycle rose sharply, to about $4,000. **********Harley, whose powerful bikes can cost double or triple the average, benefited in part from a high tariff on similar Japanese motorcycles. But it also successfully marketed its born-in-the-U.S.A. and ''Born to be Wild'' images to an older, tamer consumer. Some in the industry called these college-educated, affluent new Harley buyers ''Attila the Stockbroker.'' **********BMW says some of these older consumers may not be attracted to Harley's image. ''Harley triggers more of a machismo thing, a wild outlaw image,'' said Ron Burkhardt, a principal with Burkhardt & Christy, which BMW hired last year. ''BMW has a more conservative, more serious high-tech image.'' **********Hans Koudella, who became the director of marketing for BMW of North America's motorcycle business last October, says it somewhat differently. ''Harley's success is based on a mixture of American pride and interest in a classical, but not high-tech, motorcycle,'' he said. ''We are not selling a hot bike; we are selling technical proficiency.'' **********Mr. Koudella, the parent company's former worldwide marketing manager for motorcycles, also knew that BMW's reputation in building high-performance cars would help in the marketing for the company's motorcycles. **********But first, Burkhardt & Christy had to convince people that BMW made motorcycles in the first place. It was an embarrassing lapse for a company whose first business was motorcycles and considers the United States its most important foreign market. **********Where BMW once advertised only in motorcycle enthusiast publications, like Cycle magazine, it now advertises in ''life style'' magazines, like Skin Diver and Yachting. In marketing lingo, the potential BMW customer was an ''outdoor energetic.'' **********Mr. Burkhardt said, ''Our whole strategy was to get the doctor, the lawyer and the other professionals who would be interested in BMW motorcycles, if they only knew that BMW made motorcycles.'' **********The agency also had to address the high price of BMW cycles - $6,000 to $13,500. With the increasing value of the German mark lifting the lofty price of BMW's, the company saw its motorcycle sales plunge from a peak of 5,000 in 1986 to just 2,600 last year. **********This year, sales are expected to reach 3,380 and approach 4,000 next year. Customer traffic at BMW's 180 dealers - Harley has more than triple the number - has risen by as much as 40 percent. **********The agency devised a slogan that addressed the high price tag as one of value: ''Worth the obsession.'' **********In advertising that began this month, BMW is putting new emphasis on the motorcycle rider. Previous ads emphasized the sleek aerodynamic lines of the motorcycle. ''The old ads were all right, but they seemed somewhat aloof,'' Mr. Koudella. One new ad says: ''Remember adrenalin? BMW has never forgotten.'' Most importantly, BMW offered what amounts to a budget motorcycle, the K75 series, for less than $6,000. It also did not pass along as much of the rise in the German mark as might be warranted. This year, for example, the mark rose about 10 percent against the dollar, but BMW raised prices only 3 percent. **********''We call it market-conscious pricing,'' Mr. Koudella said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/17/world.main_headline: Poland's Foreign Lenders Accept Unusual Extension of Payments
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/17/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Poland's Foreign Lenders Accept Unusual Extension of Payments
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/17/world.body_text: **********The United States, West Germany and other major Polish creditors showed support for the Solidarity-led Government today by extending the payment deadlines for $9.4 billion of Poland's hard-currency debt on unusually lenient terms. **********Polish officials rejoiced at the unprecedented relief granted by the Paris Club, a group of 17 creditor nations, which declared that easing Poland's hard-currency debt burden would help the country endure the strong and bitter economic medicine that it is taking to revive its prostrate economy. **********''We're delighted the debt was rescheduled,'' Henryk Wozniakowski, a Government spokesman, said at a news conference tonight. ''It will be a great benefit to us.'' **********The agreement, signed in Paris today by Polish officials and the nation's government creditors, would stretch the payments of interest and principal over 14 years. **********''It's the most extraordinary agreement we have ever had,'' said Jean-Claude Trichet, the chairman of the Paris Club and head of the French Treasury. ''It indicates the confidence that the governments have in Poland.'' **********The Paris Club has rescheduled the payment of debt for many nations, mostly in Africa, Asia and Latin America. But the Polish accord involves the largest amount of debt ever rescheduled by the club. **********'An Exceptional Case' **********Obviously aware of the reaction their generous decision might bring in other debt-troubled countries of Eastern Europe and South America, Poland's Western creditors said in a communique that they were ''convinced that Poland was an exceptional case'' and were impressed by its ''very courageous'' economic program. **********Poland has leapt ahead of other Eastern European countries in seeking to transform its economy from Communism to capitalism and has taken painful steps like allowing layoffs and bankruptcies, lifting price controls and slashing subsidies to industry and consumers. [A watchdog group including Western nations has agreed to start relaxing controls on the export of sophisticated technology to Eastern Europe, but the United States has insisted that some concessions not yet apply to the Soviet Union, Western officials at the meeting said. Page 9.]  All told, Poland has $40 billion in foreign hard-currency debt, with $27 billion of that owed to Western governments. West Germany is the largest creditor; the United States ranks behind Britain and France. Most of the rest of the $13 billion in foreign hard-currency debt is to private interests. **********Terms of the Agreement **********Under today's agreement, the payment of $3.4 billion overdue at the end of last year will be rescheduled, as will all the interest and principal repayments due until the end of March 1991. Polish officials said the agreement allows this $9.4 billion to be repaid over 14 years, with an eight-year grace period on the payment of principal. **********One Polish official estimated that this would reduce Poland's annual debt repayments to about $1.1 billion. Poland's debt service has amounted to about $3 billion a year, but in recent years the country has fallen behind and paid only about half that amount annually. **********Officials also said that under the agreement Poland would repay no money at all during the next 12 months. **********A Plea to Bank Creditors **********Mr. Trichet called on commercial banks that are also creditors of Poland to follow the lead of the Paris Club and offer similarly generous debt-relief measures. The club wants the commercial banks to postpone all interest payments that Poland owes them for an extended period. **********Last week, Poland's Prime Minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, sent a letter to the heads of government of the creditor nations asking that all of Poland's debt repayments be postponed this year and that the creditors work to reduce Poland's debt through forgiveness or other means. **********Poland's Vice Minister of Finance, Janusz Sawicki, said the agreement was a vote of confidence in Poland, but he said the problem of reducing Poland's debt remains. **********At his news conference today in Paris, Mr. Trichet also said, ''We have already decided that we have a moral commitment not to leave Poland without a good new agreement after March 1991.'' **********Mr. Trichet said a task force was being formed to study means of debt reduction as well as future debt rescheduling. **********The agreement announced today comes on the heels of other major Western assistance efforts for Poland. The International Monetary Fund has pledged $713 million in aid to Poland, while the World Bank has pledged $360 million this year as part of its $2.5 billion three-year aid package. **********Mr. Sawicki, the Vice Finance Minister, said the agreement showed that creditors recognize that Poland's debt was inherited from a Communist regime that had mismanaged the economy and poorly invested the money it had borrowed. **********The Paris Club's communique states that the creditors recognize the ''historic significance of the great transformations now under way in the Polish economy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/19/world.main_headline: 3 Rebel Organizations in India Link Activities
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/19/world.print_headline: 3 Rebel Organizations in India Link Activities
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/19/world.body_text: **********Three well-armed leftist insurgencies in India's strategic and oil-producing northeast have agreed to coordinate their militant activities, the first such move in the troubled region in more than 30 years. **********Officials familiar with the area said the three groups are based in northwestern Myanmar, formerly Burma, and eastern Bangladesh and have close relations with insurgent groups in Myanmar. That is confronting the Indian Government, struggling with militant revolts in Kashmir and the Punjab, with another major crisis in a region that has international borders with China, Bangladesh, Bhutan and Myanmar. **********The insurgents were identified as the United Liberation Front of Assam, the National Socialist Council of Nagaland and the United Liberation Front of Manipur, which have agreed to work together for independence, saying the ''people of this region belong to the same racial and cultural group.'' **********India's northeast is a melting pot of ethnic, linguistic and religious groups. It is also rich in oil and gas reserves, tea and jute, and has extensive forests. **********The highly organized movement by the United Liberation Front of Assam, which seeks independence, is the fifth violent agitation in the last 11 years by different groups, including the Nagas, in the ethnically diverse region that is home to more than 23 million people. **********The National Socialist Council of Nagaland is the oldest and largest of the movements and continues the Naga revolt of the 1950's. **********The Mizo tribe insurgency of 1966 ended in 1985, an insurgency in Manipur state is still active, while a rebellion in Tripura by tribespeople seeking to protect their identity ended in 1988. **********Earlier this summer, a bearded young leader of the Assamese front spoke with a visitor in a village near the main Assam city of Gauhati about its goals. **********''We will not settle for anything less than independence,'' said Siddharth Phukan, the spokesman of the organization. ''India has exploited us for too long.'' Officials say the group virtually runs a parallel administration in parts of the state. **********The group has extorted large funds from businessmen and tea plantation companies, seized licensed weapons and regularly takes away private vehicles for its operations. Businessmen and others speak of a ''fear psychosis'' and there is little new investment. **********State authorities say they believe there are at least 400 armed fighters in the group. There are thousands of more workers in an efficient, secretive network of informers and supporters across Assam. **********Widespread violence is anticipated during state elections, which could be held in November. More than 4,000 persons were killed in Assam in ethnic and inter-group fighting in a 1983 ballot. **********The police stepped up a campaign against the organization in recent weeks after gunmen from the front killed a number of prominent businessmen, politicians and others. **********Many of its members have scattered and Mr. Phukan said he never stays in one place for more than one night. ''Constant vigilance, constant mobility and constant mistrust are the keys to survival,'' the 30-year-old said. **********An important element in the front's clout is the involvement of members of the governing Assam Gana Parishad, a regional ally of Prime Minister V. P. Singh.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/world.main_headline: 2 Dead as Typhoon Hits Micronesia Homes
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/world.print_headline: 2 Dead as Typhoon Hits Micronesia Homes
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/world.body_text: **********A typhoon with winds of 125 miles per hour raked Micronesia today, killing two men and leaving more than 1,000 people homeless, officials said. **********The two men were killed in the capital, Pohnpei, when they were electrocuted by downed power lines, said Tony Palomo, a representative of the Guam Department of the Interior. **********Early reports estimated that well over 1,000 people were left homeless, said Ismael Dobich, public affairs director of the state of Chuuk. The storm, with gusts of 155 m.p.h, battered the state's outer islands of Pulap, Ruo, Nomwin, Fananu, Murilo and Tamatam. Each island has about 500 residents. **********Micronesia is in the western Pacific Ocean, north of the Equator. The principal island groups include the Caroline Islands, Nauru, the Gilbert Islands, the Northern Mariana Islands and the Marshall Islands. **********The typhoon destroyed nearly every home on Pulap and Ruo, Mr. Dobich said. The entire banana, coconut, taro and breadfruit crops were destroyed on Ruo, he said. **********"In Pulap, all of the homes were destroyed with the exception of one concrete structure," Mr. Dobich said. Most of the homes were made of wood and tin.
