https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;   U.S. Bond Auction Goes Poorly
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Government's first auction of 40-year bonds since the mid-1950's went poorly yesterday, as investors demanded higher-than-expected interest rates on $5 billion worth of bonds issued by the Resolution Funding Corporation that will be used to finance the bailout of insolvent savings institutions. **********The higher-than-expected interest rates will cost the Government more than $200 million over the life of the bonds. **********Bids on the securities produced an average yield of 8.60 percent, about 10 basis points, or hundredths of a point, above where the bonds had been offered in when-issued trading earlier in the day. **********And after the results were announced, the price of the bonds slipped further. By late in the day the securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.66 percent. **********Other Signs of Weakness **********The interest rates were not the only sign of weakness. **********Demand was tepid, with $8.16 billion worth of bids received. By comparison, the last Treasury auction of 30-year bonds, in November, brought $20.4 billion in bids for the $10 billion in bonds that were sold. **********And the Resolution Funding Corporation's first sale of $4.5 billion of 30-year bonds in October generated $12.9 billion in bids. **********Moreover, the bids on yesterday's issue covered an unusually wide range. **********Nearly 60 percent of the bids were at a price to yield 8.65 percent, while the low bids came in at a price to yield 8.55 percent. In most Treasury auctions, the difference between high and low bids is generally 1 to 2 basis points. **********''This is a lot worse than expected,'' a trader who deals in Government agency issues said. ''It's very ugly.'' **********Officials Satisfied **********Still, officials at Refcorp, as Resolution Funding is known in the credit markets, said they were satisifed. **********''We shaved 12 basis points off the bonds sold in October,'' said William S. Jasien, a spokesman for the agency, which was established by Congress to oversee the savings bailout. ''That was our objective. Unfortunately, it happened at a time when the market was not hospitable.'' **********The auction results also produced a sharp selloff in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds. Prices of most issues, which had risen earlier in the day, plunged after the results were announced late in the day. **********Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on activity in the foreign exchange and fixed-income markets, said the high bids showed that ''a small percentage of dealers wanted to be darn sure they got these bonds,'' adding, ''As far as the rest of the investor community is concerned, they were not interested in bonds at these yield levels.'' **********Japanese Not Involved **********The investors in the 40-year bonds apparently did not include the Japanese. **********The Japanese ''prefer 30-year bonds,'' said William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc. **********Mr. McCarthy and others said the lack of Japanese participation at the auction raised questions about whether Japanese investors would be active buyers at the Treasury's quarterly refinancing auctions in February. **********But Mr. Brachfeld commented, ''I don't think it says anything about how the refunding auctions will go.'' **********The 8 1/8 percent Refcorp bonds sold in October were trading at a price to yield 8.77 percent late yesterday. The auction of the 40-year bonds marked the first time the Government has sold securities with such a long maturity since 1955. **********Reduce Financing Costs **********''One of the purposes of Refcorp is to reduce financing costs, and they accomplished that,'' Mr. McCarthy said. ''But you can safely say that the Treasury will not issue a 40-year bond to replace the 30-year bond.'' **********The price of the Treasury's outstanding 8 1/8 percent bond of 1919 pl,mmeted after the results of the auctiowewere annncnced. **********In le e tradin t the clo 1/4,ly watched issue was offered at a price of 97 3/32, down nearly a full point, or almost $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.39 percent. **********Treasury note issues also took a beating, especially intermediate- to long-term issues. **********By late in the day, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 96 30/ 32, down half a point, to yield 8.33 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 97 7/8, down 3/8 of a point, to yield 8.25 percent. **********Interest rates on the $10 billion worth of two-year notes to be sold at auction today also rose. **********The notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.17 percent late yesterday, up from a late offered rate of 8.10 percent on Monday. Treasury bill rates inched higher. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.67 percent late yesterday, up 3 basis points. And six-month bills were offered at 7.59 percent, also up 3 basis points. **********Kodak 'Step Down' Notes **********In the corporate bond market, the Eastman Kodak Company priced $500 million worth of ''step down'' floating-rate notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. **********The notes, which mature Jan. 20, 1993, carry their name because interest rates on the securities decline at specified times in the course of the loan. **********The notes, which were priced at par, or $100, are noncallable for one year. **********For the first year, rates on the notes will be the one-month commercial paper rate plus 30 basis points. In the second year the spread, or difference, over one-month commercial paper shrinks to 25 basis points. And in the third year the spread over one-month commercial paper falls to 20 basis points. **********The commercial paper rate is set the third Wednesday of each month, with the first rate set on Jan. 29. **********The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********Investors in the tax-exempt municipal bond market snapped up an $837 million issue of general revenue bonds from the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority. **********The negotiated issue consists of serial and term bonds. Coupons on the serial bonds range from 6 percent on bonds maturing in 1991 to 7.50 percent on bonds that mature in 2004. **********Merrill Lynch Capital Markets acted as lead manager for the transaction, which is rated A by Moody's and A-minus by Standard & Poor's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/world.main_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;   GORBACHEV HINTS HE WOULD ACCEPT MULTIPARTY RULE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;   GORBACHEV HINTS HE WOULD ACCEPT MULTIPARTY RULE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/world.body_text: **********In his most conciliatory comments to date on the prospect of a multiparty system, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that ending the Communist Party monopoly on power in the Soviet Union would not be a ''tragedy.'' **********Mr. Gorbachev was speaking at the end of a tense three-day visit to defiant Lithuania, where despite warnings from Moscow the parliament has legalized rival political parties and where the Communist Party has declared itself independent of the national party in Moscow. **********''I don't see any tragedy in a multiparty system if it arises and actually answers the interests of society,'' Mr. Gorbachev said in response to a question at an often stormy meeting with several hundred Lithuanian Communists. **********'Should Not Be Afraid' **********''We should not be afraid of it, the way the devil is of incense,'' he said, adding that a multiparty system ''should not be artificially imposed.'' **********Mr. Gorbachev has strongly opposed efforts to end the Communist Party's constitutionally guaranteed domination, arguing that the party is the only force capable of uniting the country in a period of political and economic crisis. **********Lithuania has been a persistent political problem for the Soviet leader, and people here have increasingly called for independence from Moscow. After three days of travel and meetings in the republic, Mr. Gorbachev failed to persuade Communists here to reverse their decision last month to break with the central party in Moscow or to reconsider their calls for an independent Lithuanian state. **********Election Due Next Month **********The Lithuanian Communists' decision was made after the party's prestige and membership began to drop sharply as Lithuanians calling for greater freedom saw the party as a tool in Moscow's hands. The party suffered widespread defeats in elections last March to a new Soviet Parliament and made the break from Moscow partly in an attempt to prevent similar embarrassments in elections next month for the republic's legislature. **********Today's meeting with members of the breakaway party and Communists who chose to remain loyal to Moscow was Mr. Gorbachev's final attempt to convince people of the dire consequences of secession from the Soviet Union. **********While acknowledging, as he has several times these last few days, that each republic has the constitutional right to secede, Mr. Gorbachev warned that the republic was ill-prepared for such a course. **********'Think a Thousand Times' **********''Think a thousand times before embarking on an independent drift, without a compass, without a map, reserves of fuel and a competent crew,'' he said. ''You cannot drop people on an iceberg and say, 'Let them swim.' '' **********At today's meeting, which was broadcast live on Lithuanian television and radio and was reported as the main item on the national evening news from Moscow, Mr. Gorbachev reflected the various postures he has taken during his trip, organized as a fact-finding mission after the Communist Party's Central Committee failed to agree on a response to the Lithuanians' defiant split. **********Mr. Gorbachev joked with the people in the hall, chastised them, appealed to them and lectured them. In one of his most fervent pleas to the listeners to abandon their drive for independence, he said, ''There is no absolute freedom, and you will not find absolute independence anywhere even with a high-powered telescope.'' **********This was far from a passive audience, and even before Mr. Gorbachev began his address speaker after speaker told him firmly that they remained convinced of the correctness of their choice despite the intensive visit by Mr. Gorbachev and a 40-member Moscow delegation. **********''Maybe we are taking a risk,'' said the party chief from the port city of Klaipeda, ''but we cannot just sit on our hands.'' **********Worker Criticizes Gorbachev **********Although the purpose of the trip was to assess the mood among Communists in the republic, to understand better why so many chose to reject Moscow's control, the focus became the popular movement in the republic toward secession. **********A factory worker sharply criticized Mr. Gorbachev for spending his time in Lithuania lecturing people rather than listening. **********''We know your ideas,'' he said. ''You should have listened to our ideas.'' **********''I already know your opinion,'' Mr. Gorbachev snapped back. **********Vladislav Sved, the temporary leader of the party's pro-Moscow faction, called the decision by his former colleagues ''illegitimate'' but said it was a reality the party leadership had to deal with. **********'Psychological Pressure' Cited **********One speaker said the pro-independence forces in the party applied ''psychological pressure'' in Lithuania, preventing people from comfortably disagreeing with them. **********''If this is where freedom and independence begin,'' he said, ''then excuse me, where are we going?'' **********Mostly the speakers today chiseled away at arguments Mr. Gorbachev presented in trying to make a case for pursuing the goal of independence through a radically restructured Soviet Union. **********Kazimiera Prunskiene, deputy prime minister and a leader of the newly independent Lithuanian party, said Lithuania had to make decisions based on current realities, not on a promised federation that does not yet exist. **********''If our arguments about the secession of Lithuania from the Soviet Union under today's conditions and the independence of the Communist Party of Lithuania are not convincing,'' she told Mr. Gorbachev, ''then think how skeptical we are of a new union whose plan we have never seen.'' **********Little Party Change Seen **********Algirdas Brazauskas, the leader of the breakaway Lithuanian party, explained that it had split with Moscow because the Communist Party as a whole ''had changed little'' in the last few years when Mr. Gorbachev began directing a restructuring of the country's economic and political life. **********''Time waits for no one, as life shows,'' Mr. Brazauskas said, adding, ''Different times require different decisions.'' **********In his speech, Mr. Gorbachev rebuked Mr. Brazauskas, saying, ''If nothing had happened in the party, we would not be speaking today about this subject.'' **********He also challenged Mr. Brazauskas to say how the Moscow authorities had interfered with his work in Lithuania. **********Mr. Gorbachev and the Central Committee delegation have apparently decided to hold off on any decision about the party's relationship with the Lithuanian Communists. Mr. Gorbachev said they would see each other at the 28th party congress in October, adding, ''I hope we have laid the foundation to continue this dialogue.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/world.body_text: **********Soviet Jews could begin to fly to Israel next week from an airport in Finland, the Foreign Minister has said. The operation would make Finland the fourth major route for Jews emigrating from the Soviet Union, along with Hungary, Romania and Poland. **********Finnish and Israeli officials confirmed plans last month to transfer thousands of Soviet Jews to Israel through a small airport near the Finnish-Soviet border. Then the plans appeared to stall because Israel refused to guarantee that the immigrants would not be settled in occupied territories. Israel later said it would not settle Soviet Jews in the occupied lands. **********At a news conference after a Cabinet meeting on Tuesday, Foreign Minister Pertti Paasio said Finland would allow one transit flight a week until Oct. 24.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/25/world.main_headline: Militant Muslims Grow Stronger As Algeria's Economy Weakens
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/25/world.print_headline: Militant Muslims Grow Stronger As Algeria's Economy Weakens
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/25/world.body_text: **********Shifting his feet nervously, Nasreddin stands in a busy alley, scanning the crowd for a plainclothes policeman who might arrest him or a customer who might buy the decrepit portable cassette player that he is peddling. **********This is the Aguiba market in downtown Algiers, one of the busiest trabendos, as the black markets are called in French-Arabic slang. The opposition Islamic Salvation Front adopted the trabendos, organizing relations between buyers and sellers. **********So it is no surprise that Nasreddin, who would not give his full name, is one of nearly six million Algerians who voted on June 12 for the fundamentalist Islamic Front in Algeria's first free elections since the nation won independence from France in 1962. **********An Unexpected Victory **********Sweeping aside predictions that it could win no more than 30 percent against the ruling National Liberation Front, the Islamic Salvation Front, known by its French initials, F.I.S., received almost 65 percent of the popular vote. It won 55 percent of 15,000 municipal posts throughout the country and took control of Algiers and 32 of the country's 48 provinces. The ruling party was a distant second, and the eight other parties hardly made a mark. **********''I voted for the F.I.S. out of revenge,'' said Jamal Merouane, an electrician in his mid-30's who left his Government job three years ago to drive a taxi because his salary was too low, inflation too high and promotions given only to those connected to the ruling party. **********''In this country, if you are a young man like these kids at the trabendo markets, you only have four choices: you can remain unemployed and celibate because there are no jobs and no apartments to live in; you can work in the black market and risk being arrested; you can try to emigrate to France to sweep the streets of Paris or Marseilles, or you join the F.I.S. and vote for Islam,'' Mr. Merouane said over a cup of coffee in a neighborhood cafe. **********A week after the elections, the growing consensus of Algerians and foreign diplomats here is that the fundamentalist triumph is only the beginning of a long period of severe social unrest as secular Algerians and fundamentalists battle for the hearts and minds of the people of this North African country. **********'The New Generation' **********''God rest the soul of the National Front for the Liberation of Algeria,'' said Yousfi Abdelbaqi, a former National Liberation Front supporter and veteran of the war for independence from France, led by the front, known as the F.L.N., from 1954 to 1962. ''The Islamic movement is the true heir of the F.L.N. This is the new generation, which has had enough of the parasites that demolished the F.L.N. I wish them luck, but it really does not matter, because they are here to stay.'' **********The Islamic Front has been vague about its policies. What is clear so far is that it has struck an alliance of sorts with Algeria's merchants and seems to espouse a free market. Some of its leaders, describing a woman's primary role as rearing a family, have suggested that women limit themselves to jobs like nursing or teaching. **********But whether they agree with the Islamic Front or not, most Algerians are thrilled and proud of the difference the free ballot has made in their lives. In this capital, there is a sense of excitement that can only be experienced in the aftermath of a genuine revolution. **********Even educated, cosmopolitan Algerian women, who are the first to argue that Islamic fundamentalism represents a direct threat to their future, do not regret the outcome of the elections. **********''The most important thing is that people are free to talk, to express their views,'' said Dalida Ramadani, a 24-year-old chemistry student at Houari Boumediene University who voted for the National Front. ''The fear has gone.'' She vowed to fight any fundamentalist attempt to force her to wear a veil or stay at home. **********''I want to see if the F.I.S. will respect the freedom of others, if they can rebuild the country's economy,'' she said in the midst of a heated conversation with supporters of the Islamic Front and other parties. ''If they can do it, why not support them? We are all for a good, honest administration and for democracy.'' **********Algeria's President, Chadli Benjedid, is under mounting pressure to dissolve Parliament, which is exclusively made up of National Front members and has little claim to legitimacy in the aftermath of the vote. But many opponents of the Islamic Front say Parliament should not be dissolved for at least six months, to allow secularists to reorganize. **********No matter what happens next, everyone agrees that in today's Algeria the only organized political force is the Islamic Front, which draws on a network of 9,000 mosques across the country. **********''For the next five years there is no alternative to the fundamentalist movement in Algeria,'' said Ammar Ben Hemmer, an editorial writer for the National Front's newspaper. ''The only thing we have to do is make sure that Islam does not turn to fundamentalist militancy, because in this country Islam has always been a tolerant religion.'' **********For West's Leaders, A Grave Quandary **********For the West, the events of Algeria pose a grave quandary. The Mediterranean countries of Western Europe, particularly France, are already struggling to absorb the estimated four million legal and illegal Arab immigrants from North Africa. Now they worry about another huge influx, this time of Algerians fleeing Islamic fundamentalism. **********''For France, Algeria is already what Mexico is to the United States,'' a senior Western diplomat said. **********Western envoys concede that the democracy movement, something they have championed in Eastern Europe and Latin America, is producing something quite different in North Africa -a virulent brand of anti-Western Muslim fundamentalism. **********Many said the momentum gained by the Islamic Front and similarly militant Islamic movements already active in other North African countries like Tunisia, Morocco and Egypt may be unstopable. **********''Islamic fundamentalists are the primary political force in the Arab world today,'' said Francois Burgat, who has written a book on Islam in North Africa and who came here to observe the elections and analyze their aftermath. ''Islamic discourse has become the only nationalistic discourse today.'' **********But a senior West German diplomat said, ''The point is that they have had absolutely free democratic elections here, even though the party benefiting from this does not believe in freedom.'' **********Strikes and Lines: A Bitter Economy **********Monday, noon: As the hot sun bakes Algiers, the smell of uncollected garbage is getting stronger. Sanitation workers have been on strike for more than a week, demanding higher wages. There have been no newspapers for days because drivers and deliverers have also been on strike. Long lines of cars are lined up at the few gasoline stations still working; most workers at the Government oil monopoly, Naftal, are on strike too. And at hospitals only urgent cases are treated, because doctors have been striking. **********If not for the trabendos, most Algerians could not get everyday items -including spare parts, batteries, cooking oil and light bulbs - that are legally obtained only by the ruling elite. **********''The Government has nothing in the stores,'' said Nasreddin, the merchant in the Aguiba market. ''You cannot find a razor in Algiers, and they arrest us for selling things people need. You just wait. This place is going to blow up like Ceausescu. It is going to be another Romania here.'' **********With $27 billion in foreign debt, Algeria is spending nearly 70 percent of its estimated $10 billion annual oil revenue to pay off the debts and interest, leaving precious little to pay for new housing, schools and jobs. **********''The country is falling apart,'' said Larbi Alilat, a winning candidate from the secular Rally for Culture and Democracy, which is vehemently opposed to both the ruling National Front and the fundamentalists. ''I think Chedli and his ministers would like nothing better now than to leave, provided there is no accounting for their past mistakes.'' **********''What we need now is a government of transition, made up of acceptable figures from several parties, that will normalize the situation and stabilize democracy,'' Mr. Alilat said. But on Monday his party rejected an invitation from the National Front to join its ranks. **********Is Running Algeria Simply Impossible? **********But a Government minister who declined to be identified thinks that the fundamentalists will fail, too. ''Of course allowing the F.I.S. to go ahead and institute its social program in the municipalities will be controversial and very messy,'' he said. ''But the question is, Can they pick up the garbage? Can they create housing? Is their anti-French rhetoric going to pay our debts to France? Our best estimate is that they simply cannot run the country, because they have no programs, no experience and no easy solutions to the lack of money and jobs. It is better to open the abscess now and clean it up rather than to sit on millions of people who believe, rightly or wrongly, that Islam is the answer to everything.'' **********In Islamic fundamentalist circles, word has gone out in several neighborhoods to pitch in and pick up the accumulated garbage. And just to make sure that they are not blamed for the economic mess, many Islamic Front candidates are demanding audits of the bankrupt municipal governments they are about to inherit from the National Front. **********On Friday, in an address to a huge flock of the faithful who came to celebrate their victory at the Abelhamid Ibn Badis mosque in Al Kuba, a fiery leader of the Islamic Front, Ali Belhaj, cautioned his followers not to be too confident of victory until more battles were won. **********''We have won the votes, but can we win in the field?'' he asked. ''Votes come and go, but deeds and proper behavior are never overlooked or forgotten.'' **********An eventual Islamic triumph here still depends on many factors. **********Many Algerians who opposed the Islamic Front say they are confident that Algeria's army, silent so far, will act if necessary. If secularists fail to stop the Islamic wave, it is said, the army will stage a coup, forcibly suppressing fundamentalists and reinstituting a military dictatorship. **********In October 1988, Algeria's generals supported the Government and faced hundreds of thousands of youths who took over the streets of all major cities and towns for the better part of 10 days protesting against the country's drifting policies. Thousands were wounded and at least 100 were killed. Will the army do it again? ''Absolutely not,'' said Tomasz Wojewoda, a counselor at the Polish Embassy here, who said he spoke with the experience of his own country in mind. ''The time for this kind of thing has passed, not only here but in the whole world.'' **********The Government minister said a coup would be pointless, partly because there was nothing the army could do about the disastrous economic situation. Besides, he said, it is too early to pronounce Algeria an Islamic republic. **********''We don't want a blood bath here,'' he said. ''At what price should we deny democracy in Algeria?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/08/busin.main_headline: Your Money; Returning to Cash In Uncertain Time
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/08/busin.print_headline: Your Money; Returning to Cash In Uncertain Time
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/08/busin.body_text: **********For uneasy investors, it may make sense to lighten up on portfolio holdings before the end of the year, combining tax and market strategies. **********"With the continued uncertainties over war and recession and job stability, a lot of people are interested in cash right now," said George E. L. Barbee, executive director of personal financial services for Price Waterhouse. "We're finding that mindset." And comments from market professionals show there is good reason for that view. **********Edward A. Taber 3d, director of T. Rowe Price's taxable bond division, said at his firm's briefing this week on the 1991 investment and economic outlook, "The more risk you took, the less reward you got" in 1990, and that could continue early next year. So far this year money market funds have had a 6.5 percent return, he noted, while high-yield funds have lost 11.5 percent, and long Treasury funds have returned only 1.3 percent. **********Paul W. Boltz, the firm's economist, saw a mild recession, beginning in this quarter and lasting two or three quarters, with a slight drop in short-term interest rates. He expects the Fed to tighten credit as recovery sets in, but he sees an outside possibility of a severe recession, should war break out in the Persian Gulf or a major bank fail. **********John H. Laporte, president of Price's New Horizons and New America Growth funds, concurred, saying, "We think the bear market has farther to go." But he added, "The stock market as usual will begin to recover well before the economy." He added that small growth stocks, which have been battered this year, could lead a cyclical recovery in 1991, so he advised investors to focus on growth companies with high financial returns and assured earnings growth. **********Investors should inventory their portfolios,determining paper losses and gains, and identify candidates for sale, Mr. Barbee said, and then decide whether to move into a cash position like a Treasury bill or C.D. or to reinvest in the market. **********If a portfolio has both losses and gains, an investor can use the losses to offset the gains, so that cash is raised without incurring tax liability on the gains. Also, net capital losses of up to $3,000 can offset ordinary income, so from a tax standpoint, he said, "it makes sense to admit to yourself you were wrong and sell." **********"It is paramount to run some calculations before the end of the year and see if there is an A.M.T. situation," Mr. Barbee added, referring to the alternative minimum tax, which is intended to make sure that no taxpayer with substantial income avoids taxation. **********The rate is 21 percent, compared with a normal 28 percent or 33 percent, but a number of tax breaks that are allowed in regular tax calculations are taken away. As a result, those who are snared have a larger taxable income and fewer deductions than they would have under regular rules. **********The reason to see if there is an alternative tax liability is that the three things most likely to subject a taxpayer to it are commonly considered inyear-end planning. They are: sizable state and local taxes, the exercise of incentive stock options and the donation of appreciated property to charity. The timing of these items is often the opposite for regular taxpayers and those subject to the alternative tax. **********For regular taxpayers, appreciated securities, for example, may be deducted at market value -- and making such a contribution at year-end can be an effective way to help a favorite charity and lower one's tax bill. But for those subject to the alternative tax, the deduction is based on the original cost. Therefore, if a taxpayer were to be subject to the alternative tax this year but not next year, it might be a good idea to delay the donation until January. **********As for gifts of valuable artwork, the new tax law provides a one-year window in 1991 in which donors will not be subject to the alternative tax. **********Sam Radin, president of the National Madison Group, which advises lawyers on tax and estate planning, noted that for regular high-income taxpayers it might be advisable to wait until early January to fulfill a 1990 charitable pledge because the deduction will be worth more in 1991, when it will be taxed at 31.93 percent after the phase-out of all exemptions, compared with 28 percent in 1990. **********"The value of a $100,000 charitable deduction in 1990 is $28,000; in 1991 it is $31,930," he said. The difference "represents a 14.04 percent net after-tax return -- with no risk."  'What If' Tax Strategies **********Probably the fastest way to try "what if" tax strategies is to use income tax software in a personal computer. Turbo Tax from Chip Soft, which has been the best-selling program for I.B.M. and compatible machines in recent years, has also introduced a Macintosh version this year. **********Headstart versions are now on retail shelves. A big plus for this program is that it has 1991 tax rates as well as 1990's, so that in the planning mode users can see what the effect would be of recognizing income or taking a deduction this year versus next year, for example.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/15/world.main_headline: Albania Reportedly Sends Troops to Halt Riots
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/15/world.print_headline: Albania Reportedly Sends Troops to Halt Riots
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/15/world.body_text: **********Albanian troops were sent into the central city of Elbasan today to halt a mob of about 1,000 as rioting continued in Albania for a second day, journalists said. **********Official Albanian radio confirmed the unrest in Elbasan, about 20 miles southeast of the Albanian capital, Tirana. The radio said six members of the security forces were injured by stones and that two were in the hospital. **********The Albanian news media also reported that 10 people were hurt, 30 were arrested and extensive damage occurred on Thursday in seven hours of vandalism and looting in the northern city of Shkoder. **********An editor of the Albanian A.T.A. news agency said that Elbasan, a city of about 80,000 residents with a giant steel mill, was quiet tonight after soldiers and security forces moved in. Government Concessions **********Albanian radio, monitored in London, said that residents sought to gather today in the main square of the central coastal city of Durazzo, but that security forces intervened and dispersed "these malevolent elements." **********The two days of rioting follow Government concessions that allowed the formation of Albania's first non-Communist party. This Balkan nation is ruled by the only hard-line Communist regime remaining in Eastern Europe. **********President Ramiz Alia decided this week to llow alternative parties, seemingly to avoid the sort of uprising over living conditions and repression that toppled other Communist Governments in Eastern Europe last year. On Wednesday, he appealed on national TV and radio for peaceful change. **********Journalists and intellectuals had said that Mr. Alia would meet today with leaders of the new Democratic Party of Albania as both sides appealed for calm and a halt to unrest in provincial cities. But an intellectual said later that the Government had decided no meeting was needed. **********Some intellectuals speculated that Mr. Alia's decision to allow alternative political movements had touched off resistance among conservative elements of the ruling Communists and the the secret police. **********The angry crowd in Elbasan stoned official buildings today, broke windows, looted shops and set fire to buildings and cars, said a journalist for the news agency A.T.A. who spoke on condition of anonymity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene;   If a Recession, How Serious?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene;   If a Recession, How Serious?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.body_text: **********IT is probable, but not yet certain, that the United States is in a recession. **********The highly regarded Research Seminar in Quantitative Economics of the University of Michigan, in a report issued last Friday, estimated that real gross national product declined at an annual rate of four-tenths of 1 percent in the July-September quarter. But this week the Federal Reserve Board reported that helped by a jump in auto sales, industrial production rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September, and it revised its figures upward for July and August, showing a slightly rising trend for the third quarter. **********The basic trend in the overall economy right now can be described as wiggling around zero. The consensus forecast of the 50 economists surveyed by Blue Chip Economic Indicators calls for real G.N.P. to decline six-tenths of 1 percent in the current quarter and one-tenth of 1 percent in the first quarter of 1991, which would technically make it a recession. But the consensus calls for recovery to start in the second quarter of 1991 and pick up gradually as the year wears on. **********There is still some chance, however, that we can pull ourselves out of the current morass. Most important, the Fed is likely to bring down interest rates once a budget agreement between the Administration and Congress is set. **********The Fed is worried about a credit crunch that could dump the economy into recession and crack its financial structure. In his Congressional testimony last July, Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, said: ''We have been closely watching various interest rate spreads and other indicators to determine if the pulling back of commercial banks to less lax lending standards is moving over the line, so to speak, and in effect creating a tightening in credit markets independent of actions by the Federal Reserve.'' His conclusion: a tightening ''of modest dimensions may be occurring.'' **********Since then, the danger to borrowers and banks alike has increased. As James J. O'Leary, economic consultant to the United States Trust Company of New York, puts it, ''Many commercial banks and life insurance companies, including many large ones, are seriously undercapitalized, raising the risk of insolvencies as large loan losses continue.'' Hard pressed for reserves, and nervous about nonperforming loans, many banks are turning down borrowers who once would have been considered creditworthy. **********A tightening of private credit has the same impact on the economy as a tightening by the Fed, as Mr. Greenspan has made clear. To prevent the system from seizing up, and falling, many businesses say, the Fed should make more reserves available and bring down interest rates. **********After the lending binge of the 1980's, the restoration of stricter lending standards is necessary and healthy. But the Fed is now worrying about signs that the banking system is contracting more than it should and endangering the economy. **********However, the Fed still believes that the money-supply indicator it watches most closely - M-2, which includes currency in circulation and demand deposits plus time and savings deposits - is growing adequately, within its 1990 target range of 3 to 7 percent. But M-2 is in the lower half of that range, and has been slowing. A more decisive move toward easing by the Fed may be needed to prevent a worsening credit crunch that would chop into the nation's money supply. **********The gulf crisis and the surge in oil prices have stirred both recessionary and inflationary fears. But higher oil prices have also spurred spending in the United States for oil drilling and production. And, assuming no further acceleration in oil prices or, preferably, a continuation of the decline that set in this week, the prospects of recovery in 1991 will be strengthened. **********The biggest risk to this forecast of sluggish growth or moderate recession through the rest of this year and early next year, followed by a gradual recovery, is the threat of a financial crisis that would result if several major banks were to go under. But it is unlikely that the Federal Reserve, Congress and the Administration would permit that to happen. A more likely outcome involves rescues and mergers of threatened major institutions. **********Another big risk is that of an outflow of foreign capital. Yutaka Yamaguchi, the chief representative in the Americas of the Bank of Japan, that country's central bank, said in an interview in New York that he was not greatly concerned whether the United States was in a slight recession or still growing slightly - it came to much the same thing. What he was worried about, he said, were ''external shocks that could have a negative impact'' on America's highly leveraged corporations and financial institutions. He expressed strong agreement with the Federal Reserve's policy, which he called ''very cautious.'' Too sharp a fall in United States interest rates, while foreign rates are rising, could increase capital outflow. **********This must be the best-advertised, most carefully watched financial contraction ever. That in itself may help to keep it from becoming an economic catastrophe like the one in the early 1930's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/world.main_headline: Press Reports Conflict on Albanian Turmoil
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/world.print_headline: Press Reports Conflict on Albanian Turmoil
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/world.body_text: **********Newspapers today quoted an Albanian border guard who fled the country as saying that the security forces had fired on protesters last week and that one city was in a state of ''revolution.'' **********But Yugoslavia's press agency said there was ''nothing unusual'' going on in Albania, just a day after reporting that the authorities there had imposed ''extremely strict'' security measures to prevent unrest. **********The official Albanian press agency also quoted an Italian diplomat as denying that there was unrest in the isolated country. Albania, situated between Greece and Yugoslavia, is the last bastion of Stalinism in Eastern Europe and is closed to most foreigners, so none of the reports could be independently confirmed. **********Daily newspapers in Greece on today quoted the border guard, Albert Tzeka, 20 years old, as saying that widespread protests had broken out in at least three cities in his country against the hard-line Communist leadership. **********''The people have risen up,'' Mr. Tzeka was quoted by the Greek daily Kathimerini as saying. ''The people and the students - especially in Shkoder, Korce and Sarande. In Shkoder, there is a revolution. The army and the security police fired on the people, and there are many dead and injured.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/29/busin.body_text: **********A COMMERCIAL version of the hit television show "America's Funniest Home Videos" has been created by J. Walter Thompson for its new client Toys "R" Us. **********The $15 million campaign, which begins tonight, features dozens of candid shots of children -- and adults -- playing with toys. The results are often amusing and a fascinating interpretation of the company's long-time theme, "I don't want to grow up; I'm a Toys "R" Us kid." **********One spot focuses primarily on adults, with people trying, and failing, to use the simplest toys. A man throws a small wooden glider and it immediately crashes at his feet, whereupon a disdainful child chases after him and kicks him in the shins. Badminton players get entangled in their net. And a woman riding a tiny tricycle pedals into a swimming pool. There also are, of course, the obligatory shots of hopelessly inept adults struggling with Hula-Hoops. **********What makes these commercials powerful is watching people make fools of themselves. **********In these commercials, the scenes were not staged. The agency cast about 200 non-actors, whom it found by advertising in local newspapers in the Long Island resort town of East Hampton. Children and adults picked their toys and set out to have a little fun. The goings-on were filmed by cameramen using telephoto lenses. **********"We had to make sure that people weren't aware they were being photographed," said Linda Kaplan, a group creative director at the agency. "Otherwise they would have been too self-conscious to have fun." **********The agency also did not tell people what to do or interfere once the action began. While the strategy paid off with some wonderful candid footage, it also made for a long, tedious production. "We filmed people for hours when essentially nothing interesting was happening," Ms. Kaplan said. **********After the two weeks of shooting for the commercial, many of the toys used were donated to children's hospitals and orphanages. **********This is Thompson's second go-around with Toys "R" Us. The agency lost the account six years ago and won it back in March. **********The television campaign is not intended to sell particular toys, said Ernie Speranza, the vice president of marketing and advertising at Toys "R" Us Inc., based in Paramus, N.J. "We leave that to the individual manufacturers." he added. "We want to create a brand-name image for the store as a fun place to go shopping for toys." **********With annual sales of about $5 billion, Toys "R" Us has a commanding lead in the $15 billion toy market, Mr. Speranza said. **********The company intends to use the commercials in other parts of the world. Toys "R" Us has been aggressively expanding in Europe and East Asia and plans to have 100 stores overseas by the end of this year. **********Toys "R" Us has also begun its largest print campaign, in which some popular items like Nintendo video games and Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtle toys are spotlighted. The company figures that when times get tough economically, it is the best time to take business from competitors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/07/world.main_headline: Attack on Israelis Upsets Palestinians in Egypt
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/07/world.print_headline: Attack on Israelis Upsets Palestinians in Egypt
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/07/world.body_text: **********The Egyptian authorities said today that the men they suspected of killing nine Israelis in a rifle and grenade attack on a tour bus near here on Sunday were Palestinians. That has come as no comfort to a dwindling minority of 40,000 Palestinians whose roots here, once firm, have weakened with time. **********''Many Palestinians who used to look at Egypt as the refuge feel some resentment at the loss of Egypt as that major haven of support,'' a senior Palestinian said. He said he feared that the Egyptian dragnet for the killers might draw in innocent people. **********The police say the hunt for those who killed the Israelis, who were slain on a main desert highway east of Cairo, has narrowed to a Palestinian who used a Jordanian passport to hire the car used by the assailants. Along with the 9 who died, 17 Israelis were wounded in the attack. A faction of the Islamic Holy War terrorist group in Lebanon took responsibility for the raid. **********Passport Is Discovered **********The passport was discovered in an apartment close to where the abandoned car was found, in a village just north of Cairo. The photograph in the passport has been circulated to the police, who have been ordered to check hotels, car-rental companies and apartment agencies. The driver of the bus was also a Palestinian, police officials said, and he has been detained for questioning about whether he cooperated with the assailants. A second attacker is being sought. **********The use of a Jordanian passport is seen by Western diplomats as significant. With Egypt, Iraq and Yemen, Jordan is a member of the Arab Cooperation Council, whose nationals are not required to have visas to enter the four countries. More than half of Jordan's population is of Palestinian origin. **********On Monday, when the Shiite fundamentalist group in Lebanon took responsibility for the attack, it used a Syrian radio station often associated with a Palestinian extremist movement, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command. **********For some of the Palestinians who live in Egypt and seek to avoid confrontation with the Government, the attack and the identification of Palestinians as the assailants is a burden. **********''We do not want to be singled out, either as a community or as individuals, as terrorists,'' said a Palestinian businessman who asked not to be identified. ''We don't want ordinary Egyptians to come to regard us as people who have brought bloodshed to their land.'' **********The Palestine Liberation Organization representative, Sayed Kamal, denounced the assault and reaffirmed P.L.O. policies prohibiting armed actions outside Israel and the occupied territories. But unease among other Palestinians reflects a sense that their position in Egypt has been eroded by economic pressures, as it has in other Middle Eastern countries. **********The contrast is particularly striking in Cairo. Under Nasser, the first wave of Palestinian refugees after the creation of Israel had special status. Many of the leaders of the P.L.O., including Yasir Arafat, the chairman, were educated here and began their political careers as students. Moreover, said Dr. Nabil Shaath, a prominent Palestinian, in an interview before the raid, Nasser gave Palestinians the same work, property and rights as Egyptians. **********''The community probably never exceeded 100,000, but its quality has deteriorated in terms of education,'' he said. At one time, 40,000 of the 100,000 Palestinians were in Egyptian universities. Now, he said, ''the majority are very poor and because they are uneducated have little mobility.'' **********''Many feel this is part of a much broader Egyptian problem, that Egypt is not in an economic condition that allows largess,'' said Dr. Shaath, a businessman and a member of the Palestine National Council, which the P.L.O. calls a parliament in exile. **********But some Palestinian institutions survive. In a Cairo suburb, 2,000 patients, half of them Palestinians, are treated at the Palestine Hospital, run by the Palestine Red Crescent Society, whose chairman is Fathi Arafat, the younger brother of the P.L.O. chairman. The hospital is in the same Cairo suburb, Heliopolis, as the Egyptian hospital where Israeli wounded were treated after the attack on the bus. **********List of Israeli Dead **********JERUSALEM, Feb. 6 (Special to The New York Times) - The authorities today provided this information on the identities of the slain tourists: **********BERDITCHEV, Leah, 57 years old, of Moshav Ein Vered, no occupation given. **********BERLINER, Ruhama, 48, of Mevasseret Zion, a botanist with Hebrew University. **********BINYAMINI, Issachar, 72, of Tel Aviv, a ceramic artist and construction worker. **********HOROWITZ, Shmuel, 57, of Har Adar, no occupation given. **********MEIRI, Aya, 66, of Tel Aviv, a retired statistician for the Ata Textile Company. **********MIRON, Eli, 39, of Bat Yam, tour guide. **********SCHUMERT, Zvia, 67, of Jerusalem, a retired chemist for Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem. **********SHIFTAN, Zeev, 70, of Jerusalem, a retired director of the Hyrological Department of the Tahal water planning company. **********WEISBARD, Eugenia, 72, of Tel Aviv, a retired technician with Ichilov Hospital in Tel Aviv.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/world.main_headline: Guatemala's Campaign Trail: Murder Shadows Candidates
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/world.print_headline: Guatemala's Campaign Trail: Murder Shadows Candidates
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/world.body_text: **********Celso Milagro, who was running for Mayor, died on a cobblestone street here, holding the hand of his 3-year-old daughter. **********Mr. Milagro, the popular candidate of the National Center Union, was killed while walking to market several weeks ago by a lone gunman who stepped out of the milling crowd and shot him four times in the chest. **********Revenge was apparently exacted 18 days later. This time Sebastian Morales, a regional director of the ruling Christian Democratic Party, who was backing Mr. Milagro's rival, was the victim. He was passing the small cemetery on his way home from an independence-eve party when he was ambushed and killed. **********The slayings in this hilltop town of 16,000 people 120 miles northwest of Guatemala City reflect the wave of political violence that has swept over Guatemala as it prepares for presidential, legislative and municipal elections in November. **********''Small town, big hell,'' Jorge Skinner Klee, a leading Congressman from the National Center Union, said in an interview in his book-lined Guatemala City study. ''Politics are so much more bitter at the local level. The confrontation is so much more immediate.'' **********The coming election is to lead to a democratic watershed for Guatemala: the first time in the country's history that power is to be transferred from one elected civilian to another. But despite new high-water mark for the democratic process, the campaign is focusing attention on what many here consider as the failures of President Vinicio Cerezo, Guatemala's first civilian President in almost two decades, to build a foundation for democracy. **********Law enforcement is often little more than a political tool. The chief of police in Quiche, the departmental capital, whose responsibilities embrace Jocopilas, said in an interview he had not bothered to open an investigation into the killings. He said he did not see any point in driving the 10 miles to the scene of the crime. **********''We only go to pick up cadavers,'' said a patrolman at police headquarters. **********The spiraling political violence and common crime has coincided with a drawn-out depression, which has left 7 in 10 Guatemalans struggling below the poverty line and aroused demands for political change. The front-runner, in most surveys, is the main opposition party, the National Center Union, an amalgamation of rightists led by Jorge Carpio Nicolle, a Guatemala City newspaper publisher. **********Spur to General's Campaign **********Increasingly, many Guatemalans have begun to equate democracy with anarchy and this is seen as favoring the law-and-order campaign of Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, a former dictator who ruled with an iron fist in the early 1980's, when thousands were killed in his campaign against a leftist insurgency. Among his supporters are many who remember his 16-month tenure not for the death toll or other violence, but for what they recall as its stability. **********''He's an order man, but not a lawman,'' Congressman Klee said in reference to General Rios Montt. **********Despite the polls showing Mr. Carpio to be in the lead, there are many election anaylsts who say it is conceivable that the general could win a majority in the first round of the balloting, provided he can get around a constitutional provision that bars former dictators from coming to power, though it does not keep them from running for office. **********The general's aides are hoping to stall the court response until after the elections on the assumption that the decision of the judges will be less meaningful than the mandate of the electorate. **********Meanwhile, the killings here - and the police chief's reaction - are by no means exceptional. At least one Congressman and several other municipal candidates have been slain as have a couple of prominent businessmen linked to President Cerezo and other leading politicians. **********Most of the victims tend to be far less well-known than the two men killed here. Their mutilated bodies are found in the morning by the roadside and quickly buried as ''XXs,'' a designation that after decades of political violence has become the Guatemalan equivalent of John Doe. **********This society first opened up to political debate and popular organizing in the days after Mr. Cerezo's 1986 inauguration. Increasingly, however, intimidation and fear spread, leading Guatemalans to avoid taking public stances or calling attention to themselves. Although Mr. Milagro was killed on a crowded market street in front of dozens - maybe even hundreds - of witnesses, not one has come forward to identify the killer. **********With real live and thus vulnerable candidates shrinking from public view, the violence has turned the campaign into something of a battle of the billboards, which bedeck almost every vertical surface in the capital and every utility pole in the countryside. **********Traveling With Protection **********Harris Whitbeck, the running mate of General Rios Montt, never travels without what he calls his ''tank'' - a blood-red jeep. Its inch-thick armor and bulletproof glass force him to use the air-conditioning whenever he is in the car and have given him a permanent cold. Congressman Klee, whose great-grandfather came here as a Prussian consul, notes that colleagues call him crazy for walking the couple of blocks from his law office to the legislature. **********''Under current conditions, there can be no democracy for the country -there can only be elections among a small privileged club,'' Philip Heymann, the director of the Center for Criminal Justice at Harvard Law School, said recently in testifying before the United States Congress about why he had decided to abandon a three-year-old effort to build a justice system in Guatemala. **********Here in Jocopilas, Mr. Milagro's murder had led to the near collapse of the Center Union campaign. What began as a serious challenge to the dominant Christian Democrats has turned into something of a beauty contest with one competitor. ''It should have been a civic festival,'' acknowledged Carlos Lopez Giron, the party's senior official in the department. ''But we're not ready. There are lies, rumors and attacks.'' **********Most polls show Mr. Cerezo's Christian Democrats as being widely unpopular. Its candidate, Alfonso Cabrera, handpicked as Mr. Cerezo's successor, is trailing badly. But in a largely illiterate country, the polls are considered little more than an indicator of sentiment in the capital, where about a quarter of the 3.3 million registered voters live. **********Many politicians and analysts predict that the governing party's organizational muscle in rural areas like Jocopilas could propel it into the January runoff, provided none of the 13 candidates receives a majority in the November balloting. **********Constitutional Hurdle **********But first, the country must overcome the looming constitutional crisis posed by General Rios Montt's challenge to the constitutional provision that would seem to preclude his assuming power. **********Mr. Whitbeck, the general's running mate, said their small army of lawyers is planning a barrage of motions to delay a court ruling until after the voting. **********Asked what would happen if the courts deny their petition to be on the ballot, he said: ''If they say no, they'll be saying no in February or March. By then, it will be the will of the people, not part of the politicians' game.'' **********Many Guatemalans fear that such a strategy represents a formula for political chaos. In a country where the recent history is a story of coups, there is widespread speculation about how much turmoil the divided, the politically powerful army would tolerate. **********''For the moment, we've got the devil bottled up in his barracks,'' Congressman Klee said. ''But who can say for how long?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.main_headline: 2 Army Women Being Investigated For Disobeying Order in Panama
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.print_headline: 2 Army Women Being Investigated For Disobeying Order in Panama
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.body_text: **********The Defense Department said today that it was investigating an incident in which two women in the Army refused an order to drive other soldiers into downtown Panama City early on Dec. 20, the day that United States troops invaded Panama. **********A public affairs officer for the Army said the Pentagon was considering bringing charges against the two women, who have not been identified except as truck drivers for the 193d Support Battalion. **********Asked about the episode, which was reported Friday by The Associated Press, the officer, Maj. David A. Georgi, said fatigue had apparently played a role in the drivers' refusal. **********Invasion Was 9 Hours Old **********''They had been driving for a long duration, and it was about nine hours into the operation,'' he said. ''The drivers' state of mind was such that they didn't feel they could endanger the lives of other soldiers, if they were to transport them into this part of the city.'' **********The area was dotted with snipers at the time, and the report by The Associated Press quoted unidentified ''Defense Department sources'' as saying that as a result the two drivers had also feared for their own lives. **********Federal law bars women from being sent into combat, but about 600 women were among the troops who invaded Panama, where they served with units assigned ''support'' functions, not front-line combat roles. **********Woman in a Firefight **********Nonetheless, some women did come under fire there. Among them was Capt. Linda Bray, who has received wide attention for leading a military police company that engaged in a firefight before capturing a barracks and a dog kennel belonging to the Panamanian Defense Forces. **********A Pentagon spokesman, Lieut. Comdr. Ken Satterfield, said that in the incident involving the two drivers they were replaced on the mission by soldiers assigned to the 193d Light Infantry Brigade and returned to their unit, where they ''performed other driver duties.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/14/busin.main_headline: Your Money;   I.R.S. Loses Cases On Home Offices
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/14/busin.print_headline: Your Money;   I.R.S. Loses Cases On Home Offices
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/14/busin.body_text: **********The Internal Revenue Service's tough stance against deductions for offices at home has been rejected in two recent Tax Court decisions. Now, accountants report, many clients are asking whether they can file amended returns. **********In one case, Nader Soliman, an anesthesiologist, worked in operating rooms at three hospitals, none of which provided him with office space. So he used one room in his three-bedroom home to keep patient and billing records, medical textbooks and journals, and a telephone and answering machine to keep in contact with surgeons and patients. **********The I.R.S., relying on its traditional test, asserted that the hospitals were the ''focal point'' of Dr. Soliman's business and denied a home-office deduction. The court, applying a new ''facts and circumstances'' test, said he had ''to perform two very different functions: to render medical services at hospitals and to care for administrative chores.'' It allowed the deduction, ruling that ''both functions were equally essential to a successful medical practice,'' and that the second required an office. **********In the second case, applying the facts-and-circumstances test, the Tax Court allowed a musician who earned his living performing in restaurants to deduct the expenses of a home office where he practiced, kept records and recorded music. **********John L. Norman Jr., national director of taxation for Pannell Kerr Forster in Washington, said: ''Quite a few clients heard about it. I think the medical grapevine has been working overtime.'' **********Many people may now qualify for the deduction, he said, like consultants and salespeople, as well as musicians and professionals. But those who take it should realize that ''there is a high probability the service will audit them,'' he said. The I.R.S. has asked the Tax Court to reconsider the decision. **********Still, he said, he advises those who have a reasonable case to take the deduction, provided they can document it and are willing to have their returns scrutinized and to litigate the matter. **********Tim Kochis, national director of personal financial planning for Deloitte & Touche in San Francisco, said, however, that given the I.R.S.'s ''unwillingness to abide by this decision, I wouldn't recommend that it would be a good idea to go back and amend returns with any expectation of success.'' **********Coopers & Lybrand, while noting that some people might be able to claim deductions on amended returns, cautioned clients in a recent newsletter that an office must be a principal place of business and used only for business to be deductible. **********''If you keep your books and records in a den, but the family watches TV there, too, in the evenings, you can't take the deduction,'' the firm said. **********Sidney Kess, a New York lawyer and certified public accountant, said, ''If the court decisions permit it, you should take it, if you qualify.'' As for amending returns, people might wait to see the outcome of the I.R.S. challenge, he suggested. There are ancillary benefits for those who can take the deduction, Mr. Kess said. Unlike commuting costs, transportation expenses between a home office and another place of business are deductible, and it may be easier to write off a computer. **********Fear of Filing **********Some people, overwhelmed because they owe taxes and do not have the money, think they have no choice but to delay filing. Meanwhile, they live in fear of the I.R.S. **********''The I.R.S. has done a very good job of scaring people,'' Mr. Kochis of Deloitte said. ''In some cases they are immobilized.'' **********But the worst thing to do is nothing. If possible, taxpayers should borrow the money and file either the return or Form 4868 for an automatic extension to file, he said. If no loan is available, they should still file and work out a late-payment arrangement with the I.R.S., he said. Form 1127 is used. **********Actually, the interest the I.R.S. will charge is generally lower than interest on personal loans, he added, but for peace of mind most people would rather borrow privately. Failure to file can bring heavy penalties, he noted, as can failure to pay taxes. **********''The overall key in dealing with the I.R.S. is communication,'' said Thomas P. Henry, an Ernst & Young tax partner in Hartford and a former I.R.S. agent. The service views failure to file and to communicate as irresponsible, he said, ''and they take that very seriously.'' **********But people who honestly do not have the money to pay can work out a payment schedule before the matter goes to the collection division, he said. He warned, however, that the I.R.S. would ''not believe a lot of hard-luck stories'' and would attach assets like C.D.'s, stocks or bonds, if they exist. **********''The I.R.S. has much more authority than any general creditor'' to attach assets, he added, and people who lie or try to hide assets can face severe penalties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Investor Seeks More of Henley
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/16/busin.body_text: **********Libra Investment Ltd., a Swiss investment firm controlled by the Lebanese investor Toufic Aboukhater, said it would seek Government antitrust clearance to raise its stake in the Henley Group Inc. to 49.9 percent from about 25 percent. **********In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Aboukhater said he had ''no present intention to seek or obtain control'' of Henley, a health and scientific, aerospace and specialty materials company in Hampton, N.H. He said he might consider such a move in the future. **********Mr. Aboukhater has been purchasing Henley shares since July, most recently raising his stake to 24.3 percent from 22.88 percent. He is blocked from acquiring more than 25 percent without Federal antitrust clearance. **********Henley has expressed confidence that Mr. Aboukhater would remain ''constructive'' in his relationship with management. A Henley spokesman said that position had not changed. Between Sept. 24 and Oct. 12, Mr. Aboukhater purchased 142,800 Henley shares on the open market for an average price of $15.60. The stock rose 25 cents today, to $15.25, in over-the-counter trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/03/busin.main_headline: Chief's Patient Vision Faces Test at Cummins
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/03/busin.print_headline: Chief's Patient Vision Faces Test at Cummins
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/03/busin.body_text: **********Henry B. Schacht, once hailed as the ''king of the Rust Belt'' for patiently trying to make the Cummins Engine Company as efficient as its Japanese rivals, is under fire. **********His ambitious and expensive five-year plan to revitalize Cummins, undertaken in 1982, has yet to yield any clear benefits for shareholders. And now, the engine maker's largest shareholder wants to know why. Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., which owns 14.9 percent, promises to challenge Mr. Schacht's management performance at the company's annual meeting here on April 3. **********''He's simply not delivered,'' said Bruce A. Hancox, the chairman of Brierley Investments Ltd., the New Zealand conglomerate that owns a majority of the Hong Kong-based Industrial Equity. ''We definitely will be asking some questions.'' **********Faced in the early 1980's with a slackening in demand for diesel engines and reports that the Japanese were about to introduce cheaper models that would compete with Cummins' most popular diesel engines, Mr. Schacht, the chairman and chief executive since 1977, mapped out the $1.1 billion revitalization program. Cummins, founded 70 years ago, is the world's largest independent maker of diesel engines. **********While the 56-year-old Mr. Schacht was lionized for his vision by the media and was added to large corporate boards like the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Chase Manhattan Bank, his plan, which called for new products, lower prices and streamlined production, has never delivered on its promise. **********Cummins shareholders have enjoyed almost no return on their investment in recent years. In fact, the company has essentially borrowed in 7 of the last 10 years to pay the dividend on its common stock, a situation that the balance sheet can support for only so long. **********''This company is under threat of takeover, not by me, but by the lenders,'' Mr. Hancox said. ''The lenders will own the company. It's being given to them bit by bit every day.'' **********Wall Street analysts agree. ''There's no doubt that the Cummins shareholders continue to be low on the scale of importance,'' said Eli S. Lustgarten of Paine Webber Inc. in New York. **********Neither is David G. Sutliff, a capital-goods analyst with S. G. Warburg & Company, also in New York, enamored of Mr. Schacht's performance. ''The job he's done has been all right, just all right,'' he said. **********Because of Cummins's lackluster performance, Industrial Equity is now questioning Mr. Schacht's level of commitment, given the chairman's involvement on numerous boards, and even the independence of the company's 13-member board, which includes several individuals who serve on other boards. $400 Million Is Too Much Mr. Hancox, for one, says the company's investment of about $400 million a year in research and development and on capital spending should be cut. [The investment works out to about $40 a share per year on what is now a $46 stock, its closing price Monday on the New York Stock Exchange after falling 62.5 cents a share.]  Cummins's anti-takeover tactics are another source of conflict. Though deemed as fair to the shareholders by the company's advisers at Morgan Stanley & Company, the $72 million deal that Cummins orchestrated last July to buy out an uninvited suitor, Hanson P.L.C. of Britain, placed burdens on the company's balance sheet and has been criticized in shareholder lawsuits as unfair. **********The dispute between Cummins management and Industrial Equity could be long and contentious. The Hong Kong company has been a powerful and persistent adversary. And when many corporate raiders have fled the United States, Industrial Equity has made more than 52 large investments in companies here in recent years and has sought to play a more active role in 21 of them, according to a confidential analysis circulated among members of the Cummins board. **********Board Request Is Denied **********But this time, Cummins has been forced to rely on conventional anti-takeover warfare. It has denied Industrial Equity's requests for a seat on its board. It has sued the Hong Kong company over what it contends is its disregard for American securities laws. It has also alerted regulators to possible violations in Industrial Equity's public filings. **********Cummins is unlikely to find an investor to help block a takeover as it did last summer. To thwart Hanson, three members of Cummins's founding family paid Hanson $72 million -paying a $5 million premium - for its 10 percent stake and immediately converted their entire holdings of 1.6 million shares into high-yielding Cummins securities. **********But largely for estate-planning reasons, the Miller family lacks the wherewithal to stage a second rescue. ''It is out of the question,'' said William I. Miller, 33, a spokesman for the family who is also one of Cummins' newest directors. **********Cummins's deteriorating balance sheet has also made it difficult to attract other ''patient investors,'' those whom Mr. Schacht describes as sticking with a cyclical company through its ups and downs. **********'Be Patient' **********Mr. Schacht, who graduated in 1962 with top honors from the Harvard Business School, calls many of Industrial Equity's allegations absurd, but he concedes that the next few months will test his credibility. ''The major responsibility falling on this management at this time is having said 'Be patient,' '' he said. ''We've now got to earn.'' **********He added, ''To the extent we're not able to do it, we'll not have met our responsibilities.'' **********Mr. Schacht insists that Cummins's poor performance is more the result of problems with implementation than with flaws in his vision. **********Mr. Miller, who did not sell his shares in the Hanson transaction, agrees. ''The board of directors has a lot of confidence in what he's doing,'' he said. ''It's been a long and painful implementation of strategy, not all of which has gone perfectly.'' **********Consider what happened last year. The company's sales and earnings in the first two quarters had risen over the previous year, an indication that Mr. Schacht's vision might finally pay off. Several months of modest price increases had generated an extra $80 million in sales volume, almost all of which was expected to fall to the bottom line. **********Big Drop in Sales **********But an abrupt downturn in heavy-duty truck orders hurt sales in the second half of last year. More troubling, Cummins's 1989 warranty expenses totaled $169 million, or 4.9 percent of sales, up from 2.9 percent in 1988 and 1.9 percent the year before. **********Mr. Schacht attributes the change to new technologies that Cummins developed to meet 1991 emissions requirements, design choices that have turned out to have unintended consequences. **********While it is possible that Cummins's competitors will wrestle with similar costs as they improve their own emissions performance, the $71 million increase in warranty expenses over 1988 wiped out most of the $80 million windfall from the price increases. Cummins finished the year with a $6.1 million loss, on sales of $3.5 billion. **********Mr. Schacht moved quickly to cut discretionary costs, and, along with other officers, took a 7 percent pay cut in the fourth quarter on his $450,000-a-year salary. **********Some Allies Bruised **********But the episode was enough to give even some longtime allies pause. ''Can I hold management responsible for the downturn in the heavy truck market?'' said Mr. Miller, the family spokesman who also sits on Cummins's technology subcommittee. ''No, that's not reasonable. Can I for the warranty payments? That's a gray area.'' **********Mr. Schacht cannot easily afford to misstep again. He lost a badly needed ally when the three Millers converted their holdings into nonvoting securities. Five institutional investors, including Industrial Equity, now control 45.6 percent of the Cummins stock, an extraordinary concentration of voting power. **********''As long as they're treated well by managements of the companies they invest in, they're very supportive,'' said J. Michael Short, an analyst with Wealth Monitors Inc., a brokerage in Kansas City, Mo., that specializes in tracking prominent investors. ''Where they have not been treated well, they become very aggressive. **********''They'll use the courts to the utmost, and they certainly don't let anyone push them around,'' Mr. Short said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Gorbachev Supporter Voted Russian Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Gorbachev Supporter Voted Russian Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/world.body_text: **********A national bureaucrat was elected Prime Minister of the Russian republic today, defeating an ally of the republic's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, the official press agency Tass reported. **********The new Prime Minister is Ivan S. Silayev, a Deputy Prime Minister in the national Cabinet of Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. **********The victory of a person with ties to Mr. Yeltsin's rival, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the national President, might make it more difficult for Mr. Yeltsin to pursue radical changes beyond Mr. Gorbachev's economic and social restructuring program. **********On Tuesday, the Russian Parliament, led by Mr. Yeltsin, took its first step on a path of more radical change by approving a resolution declaring that the republic's laws had primacy over Soviet laws. **********Mr. Silayev, 60 years old, won 70 percent of the vote in the Russian Parliament to defeat Mikhail Y. Bocharov, a leader along with Mr. Yeltsin in the bloc Democratic Russia. **********Mr. Silayev, an engineer, started his career at the Gorky Aircraft Plant. He moved up to Minister of the Aircraft Industry and then Minister of the Machine Tool and Instrument Industry.
