https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/27/busin.main_headline:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

Building An Image For Saturn
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/27/busin.print_headline:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

Building An Image For Saturn
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/27/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: SATURN, the new compact-car division of the General Motors Corporation, understood its mandate: manufacture cars that match the quality of Japanese imports. **********SATURN, the new compact-car division of the General Motors Corporation, understood its mandate: manufacture cars that match the quality of Japanese imports. **********General Motors built a high-technology assembly line in Spring Hill, Tenn., and has worked closer than ever with union officials to create an environment to achieve the best results. **********Now, it is up to Hal Riney & Partners of San Francisco, Saturn's advertising agency, to convince car buyers that General Motors' multibillion-dollar project was worth the effort. **********The first Saturn television campaign will make its debut early next month, right before the first of the cars are scheduled to be sold on Oct. 25. The half-dozen or so commercials offer a behind-the-scenes look at the Spring Hill plant and the workers who gave up jobs elsewhere and uprooted their families to join the Saturn project. The campaign is the first step - and the most logical, according to Riney executives and others in the industry - in Saturn's effort to create an image of an American-built car that is just as good as Honda's Civic or Toyota's Corolla. **********''We'd sell every Saturn built if we could bring everyone to Tennessee and show them the plant, let them touch the car, and let them sense the dedication,'' said Patrick Sherwood, senior vice president at Riney and the agency's director for the Saturn account, estimated to be worth $100 million yearly. ''We can't do that, but we can bring Spring Hill to Los Angeles, Portland or wherever.'' **********It is not entirely new territory for advertising. For years, Ford, fighting an early 1980's image problem, has promoted ''quality'' as its ''job one'' in commercials filmed on the assembly line. **********The Saturn Corporation also has a problem with its image: it does not have one. The number of people who know about the division is minuscule. So the most expedient way to build name recognition for Saturn and create the idea that the cars are different and even better than Japanese models, the agency says, is to focus on the mile-long assembly line, the entire manufacturing process and the workers. **********''We can't just say we've got the quality, we've got the quality,'' Mr. Sherwood said. ''We have got to demonstrate why people ought to look at our car. One way is to focus on the state of the art plant, but we can go way beyond that and show the commitment of our team members, the risk they are taking and how they chose to join.'' **********One 60-second advertisement gives a worker's view of the American auto industry, its early fascination with big cars and huge grilles, and then the sudden decline of the industry in the wake of the Arab oil embargo. The unidentified worker tells how he and his friends grew frustrated with Detroit's problems, and how he decided to join Saturn. **********A second advertisement focuses on Jim Peters, a Saturn executive who played a role in the plant's design and believes it was necessary for Saturn to start with a clean slate. **********There is no jingle and not much of a slogan. But all of the advertisements use a catch phrase: ''A Different Kind of Company. A Different Kind of Car.'' **********Each advertisement contains what is easily recognized as what has become known in the industry as the ''Riney touch,'' sentiment-laden messages replete with references to Americana and family. Other emotional Riney campaigns were created for Alamo rental cars and Gallo wines. **********The two commercials, which were shown to advertising executives yesterday at a luncheon in Los Angeles, involve montages containing scenes of that most American image: baseball. **********There are eight print ads that follow the same themes as the television campaign. All are based on hundreds of interviews Riney executives conducted with Saturn workers. **********Additionally, Riney created an eight-page magazine insert that is scheduled to run regionally when car introductions take place later in the fall. **********Saturn's lineup includes three cars, two sedans and a coupe. The cars, which will cost about $10,000 to $12,000, will be available first in California and parts of the Southeast and will be available nationally by early next year. **********Besides telling the story of one Saturn worker, the magazine insert contains a four-page spread of two of Saturn's cars. **********The campaign ''is really in tune with the times,'' said Jeremy Anwyl, president of USP Automotive Research, a market research firm in Irvine, Calif. ''Today people are concerned with high quality and the value element - 'I don't mind paying if it will hold up.' ''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/busin.main_headline: U.S. OFFICIAL CITES JAPAN'S PROGRESS ON OPEN MARKETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/busin.print_headline: U.S. OFFICIAL CITES JAPAN'S PROGRESS ON OPEN MARKETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/busin.body_text: **********Japan should not again be cited for unfair trading practices, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, told Congress today, disclosing that Washington and Tokyo had reached agreement on the last major item on their current trade agenda. **********Japan has ''moved further this year than any other country'' in opening its markets, Mrs. Hills said. Citing Japan under the ''Super 301'' provision of the tough 1988 trade law again would impede further progress, she added. **********The accord announced today, the culmination of a negotiating process set forth by that law, involved wood products and is expected to raise American exports to Japan by $1 billion a year. Under earlier accords, which are expected to increase annual exports by $700 million, Japan agreed to open its markets for American supercomputers and satellites. In Tokyo, the announcement was viewed favorably.  Ignoring of Law Seen The comments of Mrs. Hills before the Senate Finance Committee elicited challenges from most of the Senators present who contended that only constant pressure yielded results. **********Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the panel and was one of the sponsors of the 301 provision of the trade law, argued that the Administration would be ''ignoring'' the 1988 law and could ''poison the well'' for Congressional consideration of trade accords that it is expected to seek later with the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, China and members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a Geneva body that promotes trade liberalization and resolves trade disputes. **********Mr. Bentsen, who takes a hard line on Japan, issued an unusually stern rebuke, contending that the constitutional form of government ''cannot work if the Administration refuses to implement laws.'' **********On the other hand, both Senator Max Baucus, a Montana Democrat who heads the Finance Committee's trade subcommittee, and Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon termed the wood products pact ''significant.'' Because of the prominence of wood-producing industries in their states, both had taken leading positions demanding Japanese liberalization. The two Senators said they had spoken with industry representatives who welcomed the accord. **********Senator Packwood, the ranking Republican on the Finance Committee, was among the few Senators at today's session to speak out against citing Japan. **********President Bush has been caught between his reluctance to offend powerful lawmakers and his desire to reward his new friend, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan, whose undertakings at a meeting with the President last March in California have led to the spate of accords, including today's on wood. **********Change in Dynamics Seen **********In addition to the successful conclusion of trade agreements, the Administration's tilt against branding Japan results from changing political dynamics, many analysts believe. **********While many Americans still think that Japan does not play fair in world trade and is seeking commercial hegemony with its vast surpluses, the resentments are not as intense as last year, the analysts say. **********According to William T. Archey, vice president, international, of the United States Chamber of Commerce, ''What's different this time round is the political imperative doesn't have the same oomph.'' **********A declining trade imbalance with Japan and the fact that Japanese surpluses are financing American budget deficits are among attentuating factors. **********Cabinet Meeting Scheduled **********Later Mrs. Hills told reporters that the Administration had yet to make its final decision on whether to name Japan as an unfair trader. A first Cabinet meeting on the issue is scheduled for Thursday morning. But Administration officials said was unlikely that her position would be reversed. **********The law gives the Administration some discretion in naming countries that will be subject to Super 301 procedures. Congress can ''jawbone'' the President, but short of enacting new trade legislation it cannot overrule his decision. Among the criteria the President must consider is whether it is in the United States' overall interest to name a country. **********Already in Mrs. Hills's camp, Administration officials said, are Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d; Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; the head of the Office of Management and Budget, Richard G. Darman, and the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Michael J. Boskin. **********But Mrs. Hills insisted that ''we are not backing off, or taking the pressure off.'' She said that the talks aimed at overcoming the pervasive policy and cultural obstacles confronting foreign business in Japan, known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, had achieved significant preliminary results perceisely because they were proceeding outside the 301 process, which carries the threat of sanctions. **********''I must be given a small amount of discretion to be able to tell members of this committee where I think the tools ought not be used and where they should be used,'' Mrs. Hills said. **********She added that she wanted ''to very surgically use the tool of Super 301 in a manner that is so careful that in balance it does not cause a distraction or, in fact, a permament impediment to achieving our multilateral goal'' of opening markets. **********First Step in Process **********Citing a country is the first step in a process that could lead to reprisals in the form of 100 percent duties on a country's exports to the United States, if improvements in what the United States considers unfair trade practices are not made. **********Monday is the statutory deadline for citing countries for ''priority'' negotiations under the 1988 Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act, reflecting practices that pose, according to the law, ''significant'' barriers to American exports. **********Japan was named under the Super 301 law last year for its closed markets in satellites, supercomputers and wood products. Today's pact, under which Japan would alter product standards, building codes, product certification and tariffs in ways to accelerate the flow of wood imports, means that Japan has now reached agreements in all three sectors. **********The supercomputer and satellite agreements were both concluded within the last month. Under the supercomputer pact, which is expected to lead to increased sales of as much as $500 million a year, Japan would use practical benchmarks to select among machines, instead of the ''hypothetical'' standards used in the past to undercut American-made supercomputers. **********Open Process Required **********The agreement on satellites, which could increase exports by up to $200 million a year, requires the Government of Japan to buy all commercial and operational satellites in an open and competitive procurement process. It opens up the Japanese market to American commercial, communications and broadcast satellites and to non-research and development satellites. **********The accords have come against a backdrop of improvement in the American bilateral trade balance with Japan. In the first two months of this year, the American trade deficit was running at an annual rate of $35.8 billion, a 27 percent improvement over the $49 billion trade deficit for all of 1989. **********Reaction in Japan **********TOKYO, Thursday, April 26 (Special to The New York Times) - Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said today of the announcement by Mrs. Hills: ''It is good that we have settled the problems of our shared perceptions.'' He had no further comment. **********Earlier, a Foreign Ministry spokesman offered guarded support, saying Japan had always ''firmly believed our country will not be cited once again'' under the United States trade law known as Super 301.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/27/world.main_headline: Consuelito Journal;   Sugar Harvest's Bitter Side: Some Call It Slavery
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/27/world.print_headline: Consuelito Journal;   Sugar Harvest's Bitter Side: Some Call It Slavery
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/27/world.body_text: **********Just off National Highway 3, in the gently rolling green countryside best known for producing major league baseball players, thousands of dirt-poor Haitians work 15-hour days in vast sugar-cane fields. **********Because of their low wages, the tiny barrack rooms shared by as many as seven, and a diet often composed of little more than cornmeal and water, they have been likened to slaves by international human rights groups and by Dominican missionaries and other church workers. **********Lured by recruiters who promise decent wages and housing or impelled by the mean conditions in Haiti itself, the plantation workers - sun-wizened and hollow-mouthed old men and shallow-ribbed, glassy-eyed boys - cut and gather a ton of cane to earn the equivalent of $2. **********The wages are not paid to the workers directly in cash. Instead, they receive vouchers from the plantation owners, the State Sugar Council, which they are allowed to convert to cash at the plantation canteen only twice a month. In the meantime, they live on steep credit advanced by the canteens, helping to insure that they rarely accumulate any savings. **********Cutting Cane 'Is Slavery' **********''I've been here for 27 years, and as far as I am concerned cutting cane here is slavery,'' said Fines Herman, a 46-year-old Haitian, who crouched on the ground to relieve a persistent pain in his back. ''I don't have any way to get back home. I don't have any money. I don't even have any way of knowing how many tons I have cut. They decide everything here.'' **********Mr. Herman said that in nearly three decades of cane cutting he had never felt he had earned enough to try to make his way back to his country with his head high. **********While some workers have periodically returned home without major incident, many others who have sought to make their way back to Haiti had nothing but tales of woe. **********Cachena is a typical batey, or plantation village, strung along the road to San Pedro de Marcoris, the provincial capital 70 miles east of Santo Domingo made famous by its supply of players to American baseball teams, including George Bell and Pedro Guerrero. A newcomer there, Ceraphin Baillard, said he dreams about returning home. **********''When this season ends, I'm leaving and I won't be back,'' said Mr. Baillard, an illiterate Creole-speaking worker in ragged clothing who guessed his age as 20. ''See my ticket. I earned only 20 pesos for three days of work. That's nothing; I can't even eat well for a day with this.'' **********Gathered around their concrete barracks, where they sleep in bare rooms on metal-framed bunk beds without mattresses, others who had lived the bitter experience of being stopped on Dominican highways at police roadblocks, seemed almost to taunt Mr. Baillard for what they suggested was naivete. **********''You'll get home only if they don't rob you and send you back,'' an older worker said to the approving nods of the group. ''We would all go home right now if it were so easy.'' **********The State Sugar Council owns and manages 12 large sugar plantation factories, which were the property of the dictator Rafael Trujillo until his assassination in 1961. General Trujillo institutionalized the use of cheap Haitian migrant labor, signing an agreement with Haiti in 1952 for the provision of workers. By 1983, the Dominican Government was paying the Government of the Haitian dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier as much as $2.25 million a year under the arrangement. **********While the official exchange of workers for money lapsed when Mr. Duvalier was forced into exile in 1986, the State Sugar Council remains dependent on imported labor. To meet its demand, the council has stepped up the use of recruiters paid by the head to lure people from southeastern Haiti, a recent report by Americas Watch, the international human rights organization, said. **********The report said the recruiters travel to Haiti and promise well-paying jobs to young men, usually not mentioning that the work will be in the sugar industry. When the recruits arrive at the border, the report said, they are seized by the army and taken by truck to one of the 280 or so plantation villages that dot the Dominican countryside. **********About 40,000 workers are needed each year to harvest the crop. An undetermined number are recruited in this way. Many others, the report said, are simply rounded up from the large number of Haitians living within the Dominican Republic, who, because they are seen as illegal aliens, enjoy few rights. **********The State Sugar Council declined to make anyone available to discuss its labor practices. The Ministry of Agriculture also declined to comment, saying it had no oversight of the sugar industry. **********There was a widespread fear of speaking for the record about plantation conditions among missionaries and volunteer workers who in recent years have become involved in efforts to spread word about the bateys and have quietly petitioned the Government for changes. One reason for their fear, many said, was the threatened expulsion of people who had cooperated with groups like Americas Watch in the efforts to draw attention to the laborers' predicament. **********''In my view this is not slavery, it is something worse,'' said a Dominican who worked as an inspector for the Sugar Council before joining a philanthropic group's efforts to improve conditions. ''A slave is a form of capital. These Haitians don't receive the benefits one would accord to valued capital. Slavery doesn't capture what is going on here.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/27/world.main_headline: U.S. CARGO FLEET IS FOUND WANTING
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/27/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   U.S. CARGO FLEET IS FOUND WANTING
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/27/world.body_text: **********Nagging problems with the fleet of cargo ships designed to carry American military equipment in emergencies have forced the Navy to charter dozens of foreign vessels to help carry thousands of tons of supplies to Saudi Arabia. **********The troubles with the Ready Reserve Force, an armada of 96 retired commercial ships that wait in mothballs until summoned in a crisis, have drawn criticism from Congress and rekindled a simmering debate between lawmakers and the Administration over responsibility for maintaining the fleet. **********The commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, has complained that the breakdown of several ships carrying cargo and combat equipment has slowed the buildup, but added that the United States has still been able to mount a credible defense in Saudi Arabia against an Iraqi attack. **********At a hearing today of the House Merchant Marine Subcommittee, lawmakers repeatedly questioned senior officials from the Navy and the Transportation Department about the need for renting foreign ships at a cost of about $10,000 a day when comparable American vessels lay idle in East and Gulf Coast berths. **********Navy officials responded that foreign vessels have often been closer to loading ports and more ready to sail than ships in the Ready Reserve that need to be cleaned, inspected, refueled and equipped with a full crew. 14 of 41 Were on Time ''We needed to get ships on berth and get cargo moving,'' said Vice Adm. Francis R. Donovan, chief of the Military Sealift Command. ''We didn't want to wait for the Ready Reserve breakout and risk the possibility of a delay.'' **********The Navy's contingency plans for a major military sealift have always included chartering a small number of foreign vessels to supplement its transport fleet, Pentagon officials said. But the urgency of the Persian Gulf crisis forced Navy officials to rent more foreign vessels than planned. **********Ready Reserve ships are maintained by the Maritime Administration, a division of the Transportation Department, and are supposed to be ready to sail with civilian crews in 5, 10 or 20 days. Only 14 of the first 41 Ready Reserve ships, however, reached their loading ports on time, sealift officials said. Seventeen ships were one to five days late, six ships were six to 10 days late and four ships were 10 to 20 days late. **********The United States also owns eight faster transport ships, which are being used, but the vast amount of cargo headed for Saudi Arabia has required officials to rely heavily on the Ready Reserve vessels. **********Admiral Donovan said that chartered foreign vessels cost about $10,000 a day, roughly half the price of maintaining the Ready Reserve ships or renting American commercial ships. But he said that vessel availability, not cost, was the Navy's main consideration in deciding which ships to use. **********Blaming Each Other **********In addition to the 43 Ready Reserve ships that have been called up, the Navy has chartered 38 foreign vessels and 10 American commercial ships. **********Cargo planes delivered the first wave of supplies and virtually all American ground forces to the desert kingdom, but transport ships are carrying 95 percent of the military's cargo and equipment to the Middle East. **********So far, more than 750,000 tons of equipment and cargo have been delivered or are en route to Saudi Arabia, sealift officials said. **********Congress and the Bush Administration have blamed each other for the woeful state of the Ready Reserve ships, some of which had not been used in a decade. **********The Adminstration, for example, requested $239 million to maintain the fleet in the fiscal year that ends on Sunday, but Congress approved only $89 million. **********''Funding has been kept so low that the readiness status of many R.R.F. ships is not realistic,'' Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner said in a speech on Tuesday. ''Congress, in effect, is taking the 'ready' out of the Ready Reserve Force.'' **********Delays Have Been Cut **********Committee members accused the Bush Administration of failing to address the problem with anything more than piecemeal approaches. **********''I've yet to see any administration come through with a national maritime policy,'' Representative Helen Bentley, Republican of Maryland, said in an interview after the hearing. ''When this is all over, we'll have to restructure the whole thing.'' **********Admiral Donovan said in a brief interview during a break in today's hearing that the sealift operation was several days behind schedule, in part because of delays caused by the Ready Reserve Force, but that the gap was narrowing. **********He said that the delays had been whittled from 14 days a week ago to about six days now. **********Under Repair in Spain **********Admiral Donovan said that three ships had broken down and had to be towed, including one of the fast transport ships, the Antares, which is now under repair in Spain. Three other ships were forced to stop for repairs, causing minor delays of several days. **********Shipping specialists said the problems with Ready Reserve are no surprise. A Presidential commission warned in February 1989 that the United States was dangerously short of the transport ships it would need in a major war. The panel recommended a 10-year, $13 billion construction program to meet the shortfall. **********Pentagon officials have pointed out that the constituent ships within the Ready Reserve do not meet military requirements. **********Only 17 of the Ready Reserve's 96 ships are the so-called roll-on, roll-off freighters, the most efficient ships for transporting tanks, armored personnel carriers and other vehicles. As a result, the Navy has had to charter 17 additional freighters from American or foreign companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/17/busin.main_headline: 2 Guilty of Insider Trading In Case Involving Magazine
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/17/busin.print_headline: 2 Guilty of Insider Trading In Case Involving Magazine
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/17/busin.body_text: **********A former printing company worker and a stockbroker were found guilty of insider trading today for buying stocks based on advance knowledge of the contents of Business Week magazine. **********William N. Jackson, 34 years old, of Long Beach, Calif., a former quality-control analyst at a company that prints the magazine, faces up to $80,000 in penalties after the verdict by a civil jury. Brian Callahan, 30, of Anaheim, Calif., faces up to $110,000 in penalties. He had been a broker for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. **********Neither the printing company, R. R. Donnelley & Sons, nor Business Week, which is owned by McGraw-Hill Inc., were charged in the case. **********'Inside Wall Street' Column **********The Government said that Mr. Jackson reviewed a freshly printed copy of Business Week each Wednesday night, then phoned Mr. Callahan the next morning to buy stocks recommended in the magazine's ''Inside Wall Street'' column. **********The printing of Business Week begins on Wednesday nights, but the magazine does not reach newsstands until Thursday evening. **********The two men traded in 53 stocks between 1987 and 1988, the Government contended. Mr. Jackson made more than $19,000 for himself and two brothers, and Mr. Callahan made the same for himself and his clients and $8,000 in commissions, it charged. **********Assets Are Frozen **********The Securities and Exchange Commission said it would seek all the profits, plus interest, and triple that amount in penalties. After the verdict, Federal Judge Stephen V. Wilson froze the men's assets. **********An S.E.C. lawyer, Jeffrey Zuckerman, praised the jury for a ''quick and decisive verdict'' after the four-day trial. The jury deliberated about an hour. **********''I'm pleasantly surprised,'' Mr. Zuckerman said. **********The defendants' attorney, Joseph Connolly, had argued that the S.E.C. was ''stretching the securities laws almost beyond recognition'' and called the violations marginal. **********''These are a couple of guys who lost their jobs,'' he said. ''They're not wealthy, either of them.'' **********Mr. Jackson acknowledged that he bought stock but testified that he did not realize he was breaking the law or the confidentiality requirements of Donnelley. **********Mr. Callahan testified that he though Mr. Jackson got his tips from a computer program. **********Other Cases **********The conviction was the latest in the Government's investigation of insider trading related to Business Week. **********In January, John Joseph Lynch agreed to pay more than $44,000 to the S.E.C. to settle charges that he traded on confidential information from advance copies of the magazine. Mr. Lynch, who worked for the New Jersey company that typesets the magazine, neither admitted nor denied guilt. **********Previously, S. G. (Rudy) Ruderman, a former Business Week broadcast editor, and William Dillon, a former Merrill Lynch stockbroker, both pleaded guilty to trading on advance information and were sentenced to six months in prison.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/13/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Requiem for a Dictatorship, Sung Slightly Off-Key
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/13/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Requiem for a Dictatorship, Sung Slightly Off-Key
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/13/world.body_text: **********In many parts of this country, the popular uprising against Rumania's Communist Government was a scene of tragic bloodshed. But here in the heart of Moldavia, it has unfolded more like an operetta. **********As recounted by a number of people in Iasi who witnessed the events, there was no storming of the party headquarters as in Bucharest and other cities. There were no shots fired, and no deaths. **********Instead, they said, at about the time President Nicolae Ceausescu was fleeing his headquarters in Bucharest three weeks ago, the first party secretary of Iasi County hurriedly called her principal deputies together. **********''I am a niece of Ceausescu,'' the party chief, Maria Ghitulica, supposedly said. ''Take good care of this. I've got other things to do.'' Off in a Twinkling With that, the story goes, she was out the door and off in a limousine. The other Communist leaders followed pell-mell, as did the entire staff of the local detachment of the state security police from their nearby headquarters. **********Within an hour, thousands of Iasi citizens and units of the Rumanian Army who had been alerted to the events in Bucharest by radio reports. They gathered in front of the party and police headquarters, then simply walked in unopposed, said Luca Arbore, a journalist. The first several hundred inside the party headquarters proclaimed Doru Tigau, a 43-year-old philosophy professor, the head of the local branch of the newly formed Council of National Salvation. **********He and others addressed the crowds from the same balcony used by President Ceausescu when he last spoke in Iasi, on Sept. 15. Among the speakers was Pimen Suceveanu, vicar of the local archbishopric of the Rumanian Orthodox Church. **********''I spoke as a pastor,'' he said, ''to keep order and discipline and not to allow a hatred or wrath to boil over.'' **********As the speeches continued, army units tracked down Ms. Ghitulica, her deputies and the security police chiefs and placed them under house arrest, pending investigation by a still-to-be-appointed independent commission. **********Cranking Up the Marconi **********Over at Radio Iasi, which had been closed in 1985 along with four other regional stations on the order of President Ceausescu, Stefan Daraban, a technician, picked up Radio Bucharest's signal of the dictator's downfall. Within two hours he and a makeshift crew had cranked up the Marconi transmitter and put Grigore Ilisei, a former radio reporter, on the air. **********''Here is Radio Iasi,'' he proclaimed. ''Thirteen hundred kilohertz. After five years of silence, years of the dictator Ceausescu, you hear the voice of Radio Iasi in liberty.'' **********The station is now broadcasting eight hours a day, although so far no one on the staff has been paid. **********Iconoclasts Have Their Day **********All over Iasi, citizens have moved swiftly to eliminate reminders of Mr. Ceausescu - his photos, his books, his propaganda banners. **********At the huge Cultural Palace, which includes museums of history, ethnography and fine arts, staff members happily ripped down a giant tapestry picturing Mr. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena. The work been forced on the museum by the now-deposed Minister of Culture, Suzana Gadea. **********''We had been able to stall on having a section in the historical museum on the Ceausescu epoch,'' said Doina Lemny, an art historian, ''but not the tapestry.'' **********''Ceausescu didn't like Iasi,'' Ms. Lemny said. ''His last visit to Iasi was a fiasco. People stayed away. It was passive resistance.'' **********Iasi (pronounced yahsh), founded in the 14th century, was the capital of Stefan the Great, the ruler of Moldavia. It emerged as Rumania's leading cultural center in the 19th century. Its university, founded in 1860, is the nation's oldest, as is its fine arts museum, founded the same year. **********An Unsteady Hand **********It now appears, however, that the daring young men who took over the town and county government three weeks ago never really got a grip on things. **********A new mayor of Iasi was named Wednesday and ousted Thursday. In another incident last weekend, a rumor spread that Arab terrorists had attacked the post office. **********Mr. Tigau, receiving a warning Thursday while in the midst of aninterview, pulled a pistol and ordered the army to counterattack. The terrorists turned out to be some Yemeni exchange students who were simply trying to reach him by telephone. **********''My policy is nonviolence,'' said Mr. Tigau. He said that the closest Iasi came to real trouble was when two helicopters landed some elite police troops about 18 miles outside of the city. ''They vanished into the forest,'' he said. **********''A revolutionary has to know how to drive and how to use arms,'' Mr. Tigau said, his voice hoarse from chain-smoking. ''I thought I was apolitical. I suddenly discovered I was a highly political person.'' **********The Rewards of Vigilance **********With that he invited two foreign journalists to accompany him on a 50-mile drive northwest to the Cotnari Winery, where, he hinted darkly, there was a threat of violence in the vineyards. **********He took the wheel of a five-speed Dacia and drove at speeds of up to 80 miles an hour on the narrow highway, dodging horse carts, tractors, hikers, bikers, trucks, stray dogs and a pig. **********At Cotnari it turned out that all was well, and he settled in for a brief wine tasting. **********This morning, Mr. Tigau found himself out of the politics of the new Rumania. He and the entire leadership of the Iasi National Salvation Front were removed by army commanders, a highly placed official said. **********''Things were getting too chaotic under them,'' the official said. ''So the army will run things in the county until a new governing commission can be formed. The same thing is happening in some other counties.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/10/busin.main_headline: Adding Noise to Cut a Car's Noise
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/10/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;   Adding Noise to Cut a Car's Noise
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/10/busin.body_text: **********Automobile engineers seeking to make a car quieter have typically padded body panels with a bit of cloth or fiberglass and added rubber to motor mounts. Now, researchers at Lotus Engineering in Britain have devised a way to cut interior noise with microphones and microchips, a technique dubbed ''anti-noise.'' **********The basic principle of anti-noise -stifling sound by creating the acoustic mirror image of the unwanted noise - has been known for decades. But it is the recent use of specialized computer chips, called digital signal processors, that made it possible for Lotus to develop a lightweight noise-muffling gear that should add only about $150 to a car's price if the car already has a stereo. **********Lotus has tested its anti-noise device in a variety of vehicles and expects to produce the system commercially within two years. **********The engineers at Lotus, which is owned by the General Motors Corporation, have tackled one of the few areas of automotive technology that has improved little in recent years. Cars have become faster and more frugal with a gallon of gasoline, but most have not become quieter. And the smaller-engine models tend to be noisier than heavier cars. **********Indeed, the four-cylinder engines now commonly used are more economical, but have more inherent vibration than six- or eight-cylinder versions, and lightweight bodies are more resonant, amplifying engine vibration, exhaust and road noise into a constant drone of background noise. Traditional noise reduction techniques add weight and are only partly effective. **********Sound Is Analyzed **********So Lotus researchers turned to electronics. They mount microphones, which monitor noise, in the car's passenger compartment and feed the information to a small computer. The computer analyzes the sound and produces a signal, through the car's stereo speakers, that is identical in pitch and volume but reversed, so that the peaks of its sound waves coincide with the troughs of the original noise, effectively canceling most of what is known as the resonant boom. The anti-noise signal is not audible on its own and does not interfere with music reproduction. **********While the concept of reducing noise by producing twice as much of it seems odd, it is by no means new. **********''The first patent we dug up was filed in the U.S. in 1934,'' said Malcolm McDonald, general manager of noise, vibration and harshness for Lotus Engineering, the research and consulting unit of Group Lotus, the British sports car company. The procedure has been made possible recently by ''advances in digital signal processing and the modern digital signal processing chip,'' Mr. McDonald said. He added, ''We are using not just one speaker, but four or six and feedback from six microphones; it's the ability to process that all very rapidly which has made it possible.'' **********A Computer on a Chip **********Like the microprocessor at the heart of a personal computer, a digital signal processor is essentially a computer on a chip. But it is optimized for certain intense kinds of computation rather than the general purpose input and output functions of a standard microprocessor. Thus, digital signal processors, like the Texas Instruments Inc. chip used by Lotus, are extremely fast and can process several tasks at once. **********Digital signal processors are also relatively inexpensive, allowing Lotus to add an anti-noise system to a car already equipped with a good stereo system for about $150. Previous anti-noise systems, also known as active noise cancellation devices, have cost $18,000 to $25,000, limiting their use to aircraft cockpits and industrial installations. Mr. McDonald said the cost could drop as low as $15 in a few years. **********Mr. McDonald declined to name customers for the system as Lotus's consulting contracts are confidential. But he said the company was working with a number of auto makers around the world and had installed anti-noise devices in more than 30 cars. The greatest noise reduction was 27 decibels in a van; in typical cars, the noise level was reduced by 10 to 20 decibels. Every 10 decibels cut is half the noise, on a logarithmic scale. **********'It Gets Far Quieter' **********''It's quite dramatic,'' said Peter Egan, senior editor of Road & Track magazine, who drove several antinoise-equipped cars at Lotus's headquarters. ''You can get in a cheap little econobox car that's pretty noisy; flick the switch and it gets far quieter, much smoother sounding,'' he said. **********Mr. Egan noted that four to six pounds of anti-noise equipment could accomplish more than 100 pounds of sound-deadening material. ''I think there will be a lot of interest when people understand what it is and what it can do,'' he said. **********The Lotus anti-noise system is designed to curb mainly lower frequencies, where most ''booms,'' or crests of resonant background noise, occur. In addition, the Lotus unit cancels only constant noise, so sounds like speech and police sirens are not affected. But an advantage of the system over traditional methods is that it can simultaneously reduce noise from several sources, and at different points in the car. **********''When it was cut in at full boom, the noise-reducing effect of the system was immediately impressive,'' Steve Cropley, editor of the British magazine Car, wrote after driving an antinoise-equipped Toyota Celica. The magazine has often described this model as ''boomy'' at British freeway speeds. ''It wasn't that the engine itself seemed to get much quieter, but the oppressiveness of the boom vibration, which seemed to arrive at the ears from every direction, was simply eliminated,'' Mr. Cropley wrote. **********Starts Auto Vibration **********Booms are a problem to auto manufacturers because the insides of car bodies have a resonant frequency, much like the inside of a guitar. Noise that excites that resonance sets the car to vibrating, creating a standing wave of sound that is almost self-sustaining. But this same principle actually works for the Lotus system when anti-noise is applied. **********Because the boom is a resonance, ''You need very little power to excite it, very little to cancel it,'' Mr. McDonald said. The Lotus system uses only one watt of power to cancel a standing wave by 20 decibels, he said. In contrast, one headlight consumes 55 watts. This means the car need not have a huge stereo system to employ anti-noise devices. **********Lotus will offer anti-noise systems to all automobile manufacturers when the system is produced, within two years, the company said. But it has no plans to incorporate it in its own cars, neither the $80,000 Turbo Esprit nor the just-introduced $35,000 Elan. Part of the reason is that these cars are quite boom-free by design, Mr. McDonald said, but he added that part of the reason was that ''a sports car needs to sound like a sports car; it has to make a certain amount of noise.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/busin.main_headline: Industries In a Squeeze On Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/busin.print_headline: Industries In a Squeeze On Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/busin.body_text: **********Prices of oil, related products and some raw materials have been rising, but manufacturers across a wide spectrum of industries are having great difficulty passing along the higher costs to their customers. **********Because of the squeeze, profits of manufacturers have been tumbling for most of the year. Many manufacturers have cut back on their plans to modernize and have deferred plans to hire additional employees, and some have begun to lay off workers. **********On the other hand, resistance to price increases has created benefits for consumers, who have seen prices rise only moderately in the last few months. **********Examples of the squeeze on manufacturers are many. The nation's leading steel companies had originally planned on price increases of 8 percent at the beginning of next year but they have scaled that back to 4 percent, even as their costs of raw materials like zinc, coke and ferromanganese have increased at double-digit rates in the last two years. Higher Energy Costs **********At the same time, energy costs for steel makers and other manufacturers that are heavy consumers of power have climbed by as much as 50 percent since the Persian Gulf crisis began last summer. **********Big tire companies announced price increases of up to 5 percent in October, in an attempt to recover increases of as much as 19 percent since August in the cost of oil-related chemical products. Dealers have responded unenthusiastically and tire prices have remained substantially unchanged since the summer. **********The chemical makers themselves have been squeezed. Prices of two important petrochemicals -- ethylene and xylene -- have increased 46 percent and 70 percent, respectively, since July. Chemical companies have not recouped the higher costs of these petroleum-based chemicals in their efforts to pass along the price increases to manufacturers. As a result, the chemical industry will see its after-tax profits fall this year for the first time since 1985, to below $22.5 billion, from $24.8 billion last year, according to the industry's trade association. **********Similarly, machine tool makers complain that they cannot pass on the higher costs they have incurred this year for energy and electrical materials like wiring in making turning machines, which form cylindrical parts, and machining centers, which make parts with edges. Those costs have risen an average of about 10 percent this year, machine tool makers say. **********Indeed, manufacturers are meeting fierce resistance from their customers, who contend that they cannot pass along the costs to consumers. For example, the Ford Motor Company has asked its suppliers of plastics, steel and other products to cut their prices by 1 percent because of the auto maker's inability to pass along higher costs. **********While some of the higher costs of manufacturing are a result of higher energy prices, economists also point to higher labor costs. For example, contracts signed last year between the nation's large steel companies and unionized workers have caused wages and benefits to climb by 3 to 5 percent from their level of a year ago. **********Economists contend that the current situation is a hallmark of a recession. Demand for products is too weak for customers to pay more for products. At the same time, the levels of production of many manufactured goods are high and companies are eager to sell those products, often at prices too low to make a profit. Tight Rein on Inventories **********"It's a component of the recession that is now under way," said Jerry J. Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "This means that there is a very tight rein on inventories, and companies will avoid personnel increases. If things get worse, there will be cutbacks in the employment rolls to reduce overhead costs, and then research and development budgets get cut, along with capital spending budgets." **********Frantz R. Price, vice president of industry analysis with the WEFA Group in Philadelphia, said nearly all of the manufacturing industries are now having trouble passing along their higher costs. **********For example, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, like other tire producers, has had trouble getting price increases accepted by dealers. After a price increase of 2 to 5 percent in August, Goodyear was rocked by the increases in crude oil prices. The company's costs of synthetic rubber increased by as much as 7 percent. At the same time, the cost of carbon black, an important ingredient in tire making, increased 15 percent and the cost to Goodyear of butadienne, an important petrochemical component in tires, increased 19 percent. So in October, Goodyear announced another price increase of 2 to 5 percent to recover those higher costs.  Excess Tire-Making Capacity **********But analysts say that the October price increases are not holding firmly and that discounting is common. **********"The No. 1 problem now in the industry is the pricing issue," said Tom H. Barrett, Goodyear's chairman and chief executive. "With the automotive and truck industry down in the United States and Europe, there is some excess capacity available." **********Mr. Barrett noted that petroleum products were an important ingredient in tires -- the average passenger tire contains about five pounds of oil -- and that the company had been hurt by the higher price of oil. The company announced in August that it was cutting production and laying off about 800 workers at three North American plants. **********At Johnson Controls Inc.'s plastics group in Michigan, the higher cost of polyethylene terepthalate has made it more expensive for the company to produce plastic soft-drink bottles and food containers. With the cost of the petroleum-based chemical product rising more than 10 percent since the summer, Johnson Controls, like other makers of plastic bottles, has increased its own price to customers only marginally. Company officials say there is more than enough capacity to meet the current demand and that producers are eager to keep their customers' business. **********"We have a number of agreements with our customers that amount to being cost pass-through agreements," said Leonard Zabinko, a manager in the company's plastics technology group in Manchester, Mich. "But over time, you have competitive pressures counteracting those agreements. And, as a result, our own margins are squeezed." . **********Johnson Controls' plastics division has decided "not to hire people, and we are considering deferring some capital spending," Mr. Zabinko said. He added that because of the prospect of prolonged higher petroleum prices, "We're taking steps to make more permanent changes in our strategy in terms of capital spending." **********At Ford, said G. Leon Picuch, the director of supply policy and planning, "there is a lot of unused assembly capacity and that's going to create a continuing competitive market." **********. "The days of passing along costs to the consumer have gone," he said. **********In the steel industry, where producers have been forced to lower their price increases, pricing conditions will probably continue to deteriorate into next year, said John Jacobson, a steel analyst with AUS Consultants in Philadelphia. **********"The first quarter will be the worst for the industry," he said. He added that service centers, the smaller companies that cut and form steel into various shapes for customers, "report that a lot of their customers are now slower in paying their bills." **********"What this essentially means is that we're definitely in a recession," Mr. Jacobson said.  The Situation at Dow **********Executives of the Dow Chemical Company have been meeting with customers in an effort to persuade them to agree to higher prices. **********"We are re-examining our working capital, tightening inventories where appropriate and reconsidering our payment terms," said Harry W. Mohlmann, vice president of Dow's chemical and metals product department. "And we are reviewing our capital spending, to be sure it is in line with the new environment." **********When will manufacturers find it easier to raise prices to their satisfaction? In a recent survey of the nation's purchasing managers, the executives said they thought that economic conditions would pick up in the second half of next year, but that the first half of the year would be characterized by recession.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/23/busin.main_headline: Facts on File Sale Is Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/23/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Facts on File Sale Is Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/23/busin.body_text: **********Facts on File Inc., a New York book publisher and information service to libraries, is being offered for sale, publishing industry executives said yesterday, ''At this time we have no comment,'' said Thomas Conoscenti, the division vice president for North American and European publishing at Commerce Clearing House Inc., the Chicago company that owns Facts On File. **********Facts on File, which has more than 90 employees, had revenue of about $15 million last year, industry executives said, with the bulk of it from book publishing. It is also said to be moderately profitable. The investment banking firm of Goldman, Sachs & Company is said to be seeking buyers for the company. **********Its book publishing operation, which published more than 100 titles last year, specializes in nonfiction and reference books. Libraries are the most important customer for both the books and the information service, a digest of national and international news. **********Facts on File published only two books in the 1970's, but soon began building a substantial nonfiction list.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/busin.body_text: **********United Press International laid off more employees today, a day after company officials said the news service faced liquidation unless remaining workers accepted a 90-day pay cut of 35 percent. **********"There have been some further dismissals in various departments of U.P.I.," said a spokesman, Milt Capps. "They were in various places throughout the system. These dismissals have been effected over the past couple of weeks, some of those as late as today." He declined to give numbers. **********On Monday, U.P.I. officials said the 83-year-old news service would have to be liquidated Nov. 16 unless employees represented by the Wire Service Guild accept 90-day salary cuts. Managers and other non-Guild workers already had been told they must accept similar cuts. **********Company officials said pay concessions by the union-covered employees would provide more time to seek a buyer, although Pieter Vanbennekom, U.P.I.'s executive vice president, cautioned that approval of the pay cut would not "guarantee U.P.I. will be successfully sold." **********Mr. Capps said the company normally does not reveal plans for layoffs in advance but also said, "We do not anticipate many, if any, such moves during the balance of this interim plan that we have." **********U.P.I. has changed ownership three times in the last eight years. Its current owner is Infotechnology Inc.
