https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/26/world.main_headline: Gorbachev Sets Deadline for Militants to Disarm
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/26/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   Gorbachev Sets Deadline for Militants to Disarm
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/26/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev set a deadline today for the disarming of militant groups and warned that troops might be sent if such groups continued to endanger the lives of the civilian population. **********In a decree that was Mr. Gorbachev's strongest word in months on the rising violence involving separatist guerrilla bands and militant political groups, the Soviet leader ordered that the groups surrender their weapons and disband within 15 days. **********He referred to no particular organizations, but his order was apparently issued in response to recent weeks of armed raids on Soviet troops by separatist gangs in Armenia. The authorities in the republic have reported heightened attacks on Soviet military posts by gangs intent on gaining more weapons for the vendetta border battles occurring chronically with Azerbaijan groups, according to the Soviet authorities. **********Hundreds of people have died in those battles in the last two years, including casualties in conflicts with Soviet troops stationed there to try to keep order. **********Moscow's Eroding Power **********In the republic of Kirghizia, more than 200 people have been killed in two months of ethnic rioting involving the Kirghiz majority, the Uzbek minority and Soviet troops who have taken countermeasures in what have been described as some fierce clashes. **********For more than a year, central Government authority has gradually eroded in the outlying republics in the face of popular-front movements and the rise of separatist politics among a raft of ethnic groups. Local Communist and government officials have been drawn into those movements, increasing their distance from central Government control. **********The Kremlin has also become wary of using military force against separatist demonstrators after events like the slaying of unarmed civilian protesters by Soviet troops in Tbilisi in April 1989. **********But in his new edict, the Soviet leader said that the central troops of the army or the Interior Ministry can be sent ''if actions of these armed groups endanger the safety of the population and the state.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/busin.body_text: **********Textron Lycoming said today that it had signed a $1 billion contract extension with the Army to build more than 2,000 gas turbine engines for tanks. **********The contract calls for building 2,081 AGT-1500 gas turbine engines for the M1A1-M1A2 tanks, the company said. It also allows for an additional 308 engines to be built if needed. **********The contract runs from 1991 to 1994, the company said, and extends a contract Lycoming has now with the Army. **********The engine is produced specifically for main battle tanks and armored ground vehicles. With it, tanks can go from 0 to 20 miles per hour in seven seconds, and can travel up to 30 m.p.h. cross-country and 45 m.p.h. on paved surfaces. **********Textron Lycoming has built more than 9,000 AGT-1500 engines for the Army's fleet of Abrams tanks. **********The Stratford-based company is a subsidiary of Textron Inc., based in Providence, R.I., which has businesses in aerospace technology, commercial products and financial services.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/busin.main_headline: Military Role Is Urged for New TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/busin.print_headline: Military Role Is Urged for New TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/busin.body_text: **********An advisory panel to the Pentagon is preparing to recommend that the Defense Department vastly increase its efforts to help American industry develop high-definition television displays. **********The advisory group, known as the High Definition Systems Task Force, said that the Pentagon was in danger of becoming totally reliant on foreign vendors for such systems, posing ''unacceptably high levels of risk to our national security,'' according to a draft of the group's report, which has not yet been released. **********Such high-resolution television pictures could be used to display information on military aircraft, ships and vehicles, in intelligence systems, and for training and simulation devices. The group also recommended HDTV for related activities like sensors to capture high-resolution images and systems for transmitting such images. **********A Sharper Picture **********The report is the latest to call for an increased Government role in the development of HDTV systems, which display sharper pictures than today's television sets. **********Many industry executives, as well as the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors, have argued that development of HDTV is necessary to keep the American computer and semiconductor industries competitive. The new report, while agreeing with such arguments, bases its case for increased Federal support primarily on military grounds. **********The draft report also says that the study group had discovered ''credible indications'' that foreign suppliers, including Japanese, had been withholding advanced technology from the United States or putting pressure on American companies to buy foreign components instead of comparable United States parts. **********The report urges that an American intelligence agency conduct an investigation of this matter that would be classified to ''permit the participating U.S. corporate representatives to speak freely and without fear of reprisals from any foreign vendors.'' **********Diverse Members of Group **********The study group is made up of about 30 representatives of the electronics and television broadcasting industries as well as people from labor unions and universities. Its chairman is Alexander B. Trowbridge, former president of the National Association of Manufacturers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/busin.main_headline: Another Top Officer Resigns at Shearson
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Another Top Officer Resigns at Shearson
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/busin.body_text: **********Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., the Wall Street firm that recently announced a major restructuring in response to a serious contraction in its business, has lost another top executive. **********Stephen H. Silverstein, the brokerage firm's senior executive vice president in charge of real estate resigned last week. Although Shearson did not issue a news release, people inside the brokerage firm said Mr. Silverstein informed top Shearson officials last week that he would be leaving, most likely by the end of the month. **********Reached at his office at Shearson headquarters in New York, Mr. Silverstein confirmed the report. **********''The firm does not want to be involved any longer in real estate-related activities,'' Mr. Silverstein said. ''Therefore, it no longer makes sense for me to be here.'' **********At Shearson, the 41-year-old Mr. Silverstein had responsibility for all of the firm's activities related to real estate. These included not only Shearson's direct investments in real estate and certain real estate lending, but also real estate syndication as conducted through Shearson's Balcor Company. Before moving to New York to take his current post, Mr. Silverstein ran the Balcor group of companies from its headquarters in Skokie, Ill, outside Chicago. **********Mr. Silverstein said he made his decision to leave Shearson, a unit of the American Express Company, after the brokerage firm announced recently that it probably would sharply curtail Balcor's activities with an eye toward winding down its operations. He has spent the last few years attempting to recoup for Balcor investors losses they suffered from Balcor real estate partnerships that bought heavily into the depressed Southwest in the early 1980's. **********Notwithstanding the fact that Mr. Silverstein joined Balcor after the investments were made, he has taken a lot of heat from disgruntled investors. Still, he indicated that he remained interested in the field. **********''I would like to pursue real estate and other investment-related activities outside of Shearson,'' he said. **********In particular, Mr. Silverstein said that he and his family would likely return to Chicago, where during a 20-year career he served as senior vice president and chief financial officer of Playboy Enterprises Inc. and later as head of his own investment firm -the Robinwood Group. Mr. Silverstein said that while he would work with his contacts in Chicago to examine other career opportunities, he would probably end up managing Robinwood full time. **********Mr. Silverstein's resignation is the latest high-level departure at Shearson. In recent months, Peter A. Cohen, the firm's chairman and chief executive, resigned to pursue other interests, and Jeffrey B. Lane, the firm's president, resigned to join the Primerica Corporation, which owns Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. A Shearson spokesman said a successor to Mr. Silverstein would not be named.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/busin.main_headline: Mutual Funds;   When All Junk Is Not Equal
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/busin.print_headline: Mutual Funds;   When All Junk Is Not Equal
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/busin.body_text: **********As managers of ''junk bond'' funds scramble to recoup losses and pull investors back into their shattered business, one of the biggest losers in last year's market collapse has come up with a plan to separate the wheat from the chaff - or at least the blue-chip junk from the junky junk. **********The First Investors Corporation, a New York-based mutual fund group, plans to ask the Securities and Exchange Commission next week for permission to split its junk funds in half, with one group holding the highest-risk issues and the other, the lower-risk ones. It also wants to let investors move between them, and the plan is considered likely for approval. ''Investors will have more of a choice, and the funds can be more focused,'' said Glenn O. Head, the group's chairman. **********And not a moment too soon. Some critics see this as a way for First Investors to dig itself out of a mess it created when it took big risks with shareholder money in hopes of high returns. ''This may be a way of covering up this past mistake,'' said Don Phillips, editor of Mutual Fund Values, a fund advisory service in Chicago. **********First Investors' yields - which have been among the highest in the junk fund sector during the last four years - lured new investors into the company's $1.1 billion Fund for Income and $646 million High-Yield Bond Fund. ''The current high yields have been the funds' primary objective and that comes as a result of taking somewhat higher risks in some cases,'' said Mr. Head. **********But because First Investors' went for yield, its junk funds have much more lower-grade junk - and worse performance records - than similar funds. The Fund for Income, for example, had the worst 10-year record of all junk funds for the period ending March 31, 1990, according to Morningstar Inc., a Chicago-based mutual fund consultant. As for the newer, High-Yield Bond Fund, it lost 3 percent in the three-year period ended March 31, 1990, while all junk funds were up one-tenth of 1 percent. In 1989 alone, both funds lost 8.1 percent while the junk group lost an average 1.6 percent, Morningstar said. In the first quarter this year, the group lost 4.3 percent, but the Fund for Income lost 5.4 percent and the High Yield Bond Fund lost 6.1 percent. **********But maybe First Investors is on to something with its new plan. Contrarians believe the $26 billion market in junk bond mutual funds has sunk so low that a turnaround may be in the offing. If so, First Investors may be poised to take advantage of it, and may provide a model for others. Its proposal to split its funds is the first of its sort. **********The proposal is also a recognition that all junk is not equal. At first, the junk market consisted of a homogenous group - all the bonds were lower-grade or unrated issues - but the market's structure shifted in the last two years to a two-tier system. **********As the market deteriorated and investors grew more skittish about lower-grade issues, many fund managers started upgrading the credit quality of the bonds in their portfolios. By the time the market was knocked almost senseless by the Campeau bankruptcy, the downgrade of RJR Nabisco, and Drexel's demise, it was clear that funds loaded with junky junk were out cold but that the top tier of junk was affected modestly. **********To be sure, even as many investors grew scared and demanded higher quality bonds, there were still aggressive investors willing to trade lesser quality for higher yield. These two constituencies made it increasingly difficult for portfolio managers to strike the right balance between credit quality and yield. **********First Investors thinks that, with its new plan, it has found a solution to this quandary. The philosophy behind it, Mr. Head said, is that some people want protection from volatility while others prefer to take risks in return for possible big gains. **********Its plan works this way. The company's two junk fund managers will separate all the issues in each of their funds on the basis of credit quality, as measured by yield to maturity. Then they will split the list down the middle and create four funds: two in the higher-yielding, lower-quality issues, and two with higher-quality but lower-yielding issues. **********When the transaction is complete, current investors in a given fund will get shares of each new fund, but will be able to move from one to another whenever mood or market shifts. Note, however, that such shifts would be taxable. **********''Investors can choose what they want to do without the fund having to incur expenses to buy or sell issues,'' Mr. Head said. ''And it lets portfolio managers focus their energy and direction on the higher-yielding or higher-quality part of the market.'' He said he expected that when the High Yield Bond Fund was split into two, the conservative part would yield about 10 1/2 percent while the aggressive fund would yield about 16 percent. **********The proposal is on the ballot for shareholder approval in June. If approved, the new funds would begin operating this summer. **********WHO OWNS MUTUAL FUNDS? **********Investors earning less than $50,000 a year owned more than half the mutual funds held by households surveyed between May 1987 and May 1989, according to the Investment Company Institute, the industry trade group, which conducted the studies. **********But some trends suggest that wealthier investors are beginning to play a bigger role in the market. **********Baby boomers, who are entering their prime earning years, are moving into the market. Avi Nachmany, an analyst with Strategic Insight, New York-based mutual fund consultants, said that many stockbrokers are now pushing funds to their clients, rather than individual stocks, presumably to minimize the risk of their recommendations. Further, he said, treacherous markets have led more investors to shy away from direct ownership of stocks and to put more of their money in managed portfolios such as mutual funds. **********Already, he said, fund shares make up one-third of the average investor's portfolio.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/04/world.main_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: East Germany;   At House of Democracy, Some Pluralism for Berlin
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/04/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: East Germany;   At House of Democracy, Some Pluralism for Berlin
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/04/world.body_text: **********A single building, a solid five-story structure from the days of the last Kaiser, houses more political groupings today than this capital has known since Hitler came to power 57 years ago. **********A modest handwritten cardboard sign at the entrance names it the ''House of Democracy.'' It is the headquarters for most of the new parties and movements that will take part in elections on March 18, striving to seal the demise of the Communists, who ruled East Germany without opposition until last fall's peaceful popular rising. Until last month, the house was the headquarters of the Communist Party for the center of East Berlin. **********The party vacated the building in response to opposition demands for equality of chances in the voting for East Germany's first freely elected Parliament. **********Now, Democratic Reawakening, which describes itself as a conservative party, shares the house at 165 Friedrichstrasse with the Initiative for Peace and Human Rights, whose leaders do not bridle at the label of ''anarchists'' (although they say they wouldn't choose it for themselves) and the United Left, which puts itself left of the Communists. **********Green Party and Green League **********The Green Party keeps house next to the Green League, which refuses to become a party, and the Citizens Movement Democracy Now, which fuses Christian and Socialist ideas. Another group, the Independent Association of Women, unites women of many political tendencies who have put their differenes temporarily aside to unite for the defense of women's rights. **********A day inside shows the joys and growing pains of an infant democracy and its parents. **********The corridors swarm with people, mainly young, who want to join the movement, or at least pick up some of their mimeographed literature or ask them to send speakers to speak about the ideas they represent. **********Any door a visitor opens leads to men and women in deep discussion. Sometimes the subject is organization, because all the parties and movements are still in gestation; sometimes the conversation cuts across party lines, as representatives of different groups talk about election coalitions. But all doors appear to be open, and none seems to lead to the smoke-filled rooms of older democracies. **********Two Parties Stand Aside **********Only two of the new movements stand aside from this marketplace of the new politics. At separate headquarters are the Social Democrats, who in the consensus of the other parties have received so much assistance from their West German patrons that they feel sure they will emerge as the strongest party, and the New Forum, which was the most prominent organization in bringing about the downfall of the Communists but plans not to present candidates. **********Despite the multiplicity of views, most of the organizations in 165 Friedrichstrasse are on speaking terms. They agree on one issue: none seem to want to speak to Democratic Reawakening, which is said to be receiving almost as much help from the West German Christian Democrats as the Social Democrats get from their Western partners. **********''They have climbed on Kohl's lap and got their candy for it,'' says Vera Wollenberger, a leader of the Green Party, speaking of the group's links to Chancellor Helmut Kohl's party. **********'They Are Swallowing Us' **********Throughout the building, a feeling prevails that the Social Democrats and Democratic Reawakening, are not only like their West German counterparts but also the principal mechanisms for rapid reunification of the two states. Leaders speaking for the other groups unanimously expressed concern over what they consider the greatly quickening pace toward formation of a single Germany, entirely on West German terms. **********''They are swallowing us,'' is a phrase that sooner or later turns up in conversations throughout the day's chats in offices and corridors. **********''It may be going too fast,'' conceded Erhard Neubert, a theologian, sociologist and former evangelical pastor, who is deputy chairman of Democratic Reawakening. ''Unity will come de facto by public pressure.'' **********Mr. Neubert said he and others had hopes before the public pressure grew for reunification that the first three parliamentary votings would be contested by a coalition of all non-Communist forces against the ruling party. He said such a parliament would have been best able to deal with issues specific to a country that developed separately from the other Germany. **********Interest From West Germany **********''It has become impossible because of the massive West German intervention,'' he said. ''Now we have to orient ourselves along the West German political spectrum. Our own problems will receive short shrift. We cannot put the brakes on this process, but we must try to steer and shape it.'' **********Above all, Mr. Neubert said, the first non-Communist East German Government must control the influx of West German capital and see to it that the bulk goes to smaller enterprises and leads to the creation of a middle class in this largely egalitarian country. **********But Mr. Neubert said that not only was his party accepting material help from its West German sympathizers -as other groups do also in varying degrees - but also the services of 15 to 20 West Germans who cross daily. **********''We don't have organizational experience to build a party structure,'' he said. ''But we try to do all we can ourselves.'' **********''Of course, somebody from the East could do what I do,'' said Sven Leistikow, a West Berlin student volunteer. ''But somehow they are not here.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/17/world.print_headline: STANDOFF IN THE GULF; IRAQ IS DELAYING SOVIET DEPARTURE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/17/world.body_text: **********Despite a warning from Moscow, Iraq is delaying the departure of 2,300 Soviet advisers now working at oil and military installations, Eastern European diplomats said today. **********Soviet officials fear that the advisers could become targets in any attack on Iraq by the American-led forces in the Persian Gulf. **********Iraqi officials have told Moscow they will impose economic penalties if the Soviet Government walks away from the large oil, hydroelectric and military contracts that were employing about 7,000 Soviet technicians and other specialists when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. **********A high-level Soviet delegation arrived here tonight in the hope of negotiating a "temporary suspension" of Moscow's contracts with the Iraqi Government. That way, the envoys said, the agreements could be resumed without penalty after a resolution of the gulf standoff and the lifting of the United Nations trade embargo against Iraq. **********The dispute follows a strong warning to Baghdad on Nov. 30 by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, that Moscow would not hesitate to send military forces to the region to protect Soviet citizens whom Iraq prevented from leaving the country. **********On Dec. 4, Baghdad announced that all Soviet experts wishing to leave the country were free to do so as of the next day, but said it would hold the Soviet Government responsible "for reneging on contracts." **********About 80 of the Soviet specialists still here are working on military contracts, including agreements to maintain high-technology combat aircraft and air defense networks, diplomats said. **********"I can't say that the specialists make a substantial contribution to the military," a diplomat said. "But their advice may be valuable." **********The envoy added that acquiring spare parts was now more important to the Iraqis, but that expert Soviet advice could be important in helping the Iraqis devise methods to work around shortages of major components.  Retaining the Specialists **********"Maybe that is why they are trying to keep the specialists as long as they can," the diplomat added. **********So far, Soviet officials have made it clear to the Iraqi military authorities that as each contract expires, Moscow will not extend the term and will evacuate the Soviet specialists who were working under the contract. But Iraq has controlled the pace of Soviet evacuation by requiring that each specialist obtain an exit visa, which requires a letter certifying that the person has fulfilled all his contractural obligations. **********More than 300 Soviet technicians have left Baghdad in the last week. But even under this arrangement and the current pace of Soviet evacuation, there could still be a significant number of Soviet military technicians in Iraq on Jan. 15, the date after which the United Nations Security Council has authorized the use of military force to evict Iraq from Kuwait. Market for Soviet Arms **********If there is a war, the Soviets would try to find safe places for their people, the diplomat said, adding, "But it cannot be excluded that the specialists, because they are at some military installations, will not be under attack by Americans." **********Iraq is the largest third-world export market for Soviet arms and industrial projects in terms of hard currency earnings. These projects generate annual payments to Moscow consisting of $1.5 billion in oil and $200 to $300 million in cash, an official said. **********But after the Aug. 2 invasion and the United Nations trade embargo imposed on Iraq, Baghdad suspended payments on the approximately $700 million it still owed for 1990, a delinquency that worsens Moscow's already significant financial problems. **********The single largest Soviet project affected here is the $700 million Western Qurna oilfield development project north of Basra that employed 3,000 Soviet technicians. About 1,500 are still there, a knowledgeable diplomat said, and arranging their their departure is the most difficult aspect of the commercial dispute between Moscow and Baghdad.  Costly Equipment Breaks Down **********In July, the Soviet contractor for the Western Qurna project took delivery of more than $100 million worth of oilfield equipment from Italy. Soviet officials paid for this equipment in hard currency, and they now are concerned that they will not recover their investment from Iraq. Meanwhile, the equipment is corroding in the harsh sand and saltwater environment of southern Iraq. **********"I'm afraid this is a total loss," a diplomat said. **********The Iraqi authorities have told the Soviets that if they walk away from their projects in Iraq, all costs and losses associated with delays to the project will be deducted from Iraq's calculation of its debt to Moscow. Such a move could cost the Soviets several hundred million dollars, a diplomat said. **********About 500 Soviet technicians remain at Iraq's Diwaniya irrigation project in northern Iraq, and 300 more are still working on a hydroelectric project near Baghdad on the Euphrates River. **********"Some are going to leave after a while," an East European diplomat said. "The Iraqis want to prolong contracts to keep the specialists longer," But he added that "we made it quite clear" that Moscow intended to bring the experts home. **********The arriving Soviet delegation was carrying draft proposals for a document that could set terms for a temporary suspension of work. **********"The Iraqis have taken a very tough position that everything connected with cancellation -- any losses -- is the responsibility of the Soviet Government," the East European diplomat said. **********The Soviets have kept their dispute with Baghdad at a relatively low profile, and Soviet officials are clearly trying to preserve for the long term a strong trade relationship with Baghdad.  Greater Scrutiny in Moscow **********Diplomats said Soviet military sales to Iraq, which at their peak provided 70 percent of Iraq's arms needs, would in the future come under greater scrutiny by the Soviet Parliament and would be affected by any international agreement to curb sales of sensitive military technologies to Iraq after the current crisis is resolved. **********Among the sophisticated Soviet weapons sold to Iraq in the last decade are the MIG-29 and MIG-25 fighter planes and several other Soviet export models; the T-72 main battle tank and its predecessors, and a variety of anti-aircraft radar and missile systems.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/04/busin.body_text: **********The last few years have been trying ones for the independent movie studios as they struggled with the rising costs of making and marketing movies. But recently things have gone strikingly well for the New Line Cinema Corporation. Last weekend, ''Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' a film about the four turtles made famous in comic books and on television, opened to the ninth-biggest audience in history, grossing $25.4 million. **********At a time when many independent studios have failed, a handful have survived. Among the publicly traded companies, New Line and Carolco Pictures Inc. are perhaps the most prominent. Although their strategies are markedly different, their discipline in adhering to their niches has set them apart from their counterparts, many of which ran into trouble by trying to do too much too quickly. **********A Second Hit Film **********New York-based New Line makes inexpensive films aimed initially at specific audiences: youngsters in the case of ''Ninja Turtles'' and blacks in the case of ''House Party,'' a musical comedy about two black teen-agers that was released in early March. New Line spends most of its money on distributing its own films. On the success of ''House Party,'' which has so far pulled in $16 million, and in anticipation of a potential hit in ''Turtles,'' New Line's stock climbed to a high of $12.375 a share last week, after trading as low as $5 in the last 12 months. It closed yesterday at $11.50, up 25 cents, on the American Stock Exchange. **********In contrast, Los Angeles-based Carolco makes high-budget films. It spends its money attracting well-known stars whose films are highly prized by distributors, but Carolco wants no part of distribution. Carolco's stock has been relatively flat recently, closing yesterday at $11.50, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Its recent releases have not done as well as the ''Rambo'' series, featuring Sylvestor Stallone, on which the company's reputation was built. But analysts believe the star appeal of two films now under way, featuring Mel Gibson and Arnold Schwarzenegger, could result in big turnouts at the box office this summer. **********The vagaries of the movie business have made life erratic for both companies. New Line's 1989 profits fell to $664,241 from $4.6 million in 1988, although sales rose to $61.8 million from $57.1 million. The company said the decrease occurred because it released only one film last year, ''Nightmare on Elm Street V,'' which did not fare as well the other movies in that series. **********Carolco, which has a market capitalization of $360 million, more than four times that of New Line, has not announced its 1989 earnings but they are expected to be down from the 1988 figure of $35.5 million. Revenues are expected to rise slightly to about $145 million from 1988's $139.1 million. **********Thomas Levine, vice president for corporate development, said the decline was attributable to a lack of box-office hits last year and to the fact that Orbis Communications, its TV division, did not perform as well as anticipated. **********An Expensive Business **********The rising costs of the film business and the resulting consolidation into the hands of the major studios over the last five years have made it difficult for independents to survive. Today, advertising and marketing costs for a film average about $10 million. **********Where there once was a host of small film companies like Dino De Laurentiis Productions and New World Pictures, there are now only a few. Some of them, like New World, have stumbled despite their roster of popular films because they expanded too quickly and entered related businesses like television. **********''A lot of companies started with $3 million films and moved right into $10 million pictures,'' said Roy Furman, a partner at the Wall Street firm of Furman Selz Mager Dietz & Birney. ''As the costs of marketing rose, it became a brutal business. Maybe you could get back enough money to cover production expenses, but not distribution, too. In some cases, they simply tried to make too many movies. '' **********A Lawyer Who Loves Movies **********New Line has avoided some of those pitfalls. The company was formed in 1967 by Robert Shaye, a lawyer by training with a passion for film, who broke into the business by starting a company to distribute movies to college campuses. **********Mr. Shaye produces films that are inexpensive and have a narrowly focused appeal. ''That way we can market the films very carefully,'' he said. ''House Party,'' for example, cost less than $3 million to make. **********''We had a whole range of options for opening the picture,'' said Mr. Shaye, who is 51. ''We decided to go for the core audience and then to make it accessible to a broader audience. The movie has a core black audience, but it is funny enough to appeal to a wider audience.'' **********Though New Line now has teen-age films, a movie for blacks and one for children, the foundation of its success is the ''Nightmare on Elm Street'' series of five horror movies that began in the early 1980's. **********Although many independent companies have trouble competing against the major studios for screen time, Mr. Shaye believes that ''screens are a function of the films you have.'' **********''If you have the films people want to see, you will get the screens you want,'' he said. **********Big Spending on 'Turtles' **********Nevertheless, New Line spent $12 million on the movie prints and advertising for ''Turtles.'' It earns the standard fee of 30 percent of box-office sales for distributing the film and also recoups its print and ad costs. The balance goes to the producers, Golden Harvest Films, a unit of the Golden Communications Company. **********Mr. Shaye says he has no interest in diversifying New Line. In fact, the company's next release, due out this September, is another teen-age film, a comedy about growing up called ''Book of Love,'' in which Mr. Shaye will make his debut as a director. **********Carolco takes the reverse approach. The company steers clear of distribution because of the enormous cost of promoting a wide-release film and because one huge failure could be fatal. Instead, it concentrates on producing big-star action films that it hopes will have as much appeal abroad as they do in the United States. **********The company was formed in 1984 primarily to produce films starring Mr. Stallone. The worldwide appeal of Mr. Stallone enabled Carolco to build strong relationships, particularly with foreign distributors. Peter Hoffman, chairman of Carolco since 1986, hopes to use those relationships to build a broad-based entertainment company. **********Carolco's films typically feature big-ticket talent. The company can afford these stars because it presells distribution rights to its network of foreign distributors. For instance, even before filming began, foreign distributors agreed to buy the theatrical rights to ''Total Recall,'' starring Mr. Schwarzenegger, whose previous pictures, ''The Predator'' and ''The Terminator'' had worldwide appeal. Those commitments enabled Carolco to raise a large portion of the $50 million it needed to finance the movie. **********To lay off marketing risks, Carolco struck a deal in 1985 with Tri-Star Pictures, which now has exclusive rights to distribute all of Carolco's films in the United States. Tri-Star pays the print and advertising costs, and after recouping these expenses, it keeps an average of 35 percent of the film's net profits. **********Two New Entries **********Mr. Hoffman, who is 40, has also begun to diversify into new categories of films. Carolco's recent forays into categories other than action films include ''The Music Box'' and ''Mountains of the Moon,'' both released in the last six months. **********Neither has had much impact at the box office in the United States, but Carolco may be counting on the overseas market. ''The Music Box'' was directed by Costa-Gavras, whose work is highly regarded abroad. And ''Mountains of the Moon'' is about the expedition by Sir Richard Burton and Sir John Speke to discover the source of the Nile. **********Carolco has also bought control of what is now called Live Entertainment, a videocassette business; Orbis Productions, a television production company, and the Indieprod company, an independent movie concern that has produced hits like ''Footloose'' and ''Roxanne'' and is headed by Daniel Melnick. **********Mr. Hoffman defends his acquisitions of Live and Orbis, arguing that they will enable Carolco to keep the ancillary rights to its films. ''When companies sold off all the ancillary rights, they could only look to the theatrical business to recoup their investment,'' Mr. Hoffman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/18/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices regained some lost ground in afternoon trading here today, after falling to a new trading low for 1990. **********The 225-share Nikkei index closed at 23,884.82, down 480.78, or 1.97 percent. Early in the afternoon session the Nikkei had tumbled below its previous low of 23,405.71 set on Sept. 7, falling 963.64 points, or 3.95 percent, to 23,401.96. **********Stocks rebounded after a big trust fund moved in to support the market. ''Nobody wants the market to close at new lows today,'' one broker said. **********In early trading, the market was jarred by rising oil prices and talk of declining real estate values. ''Oil companies here decided to raise their gasoline prices yesterday, which psychologically was a big negative factor,'' a trader at a Japanese brokerage said. **********News of surging oil prices overseas contributed to the steep early slide. That was followed by selling related to futures arbitrage. **********A newspaper report that the **********Finance Ministry might increase regulation of real estate deals used as tax shelters spurred further selling of stocks. Brokers noted that the stock market here often moves in tandem with real estate prices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.main_headline: Busch Adds Officers In Broad Realignment
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Busch Adds Officers In Broad Realignment
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.body_text: **********The Anheuser-Busch Companies yesterday announced a management realignment that included an expansion of corporate personnel and a new president for its Anheuser-Busch Inc. beer subsidiary. **********August A. Busch 3d, chairman and president of the parent company in St. Louis, is relinquishing the presidency of the beer unit and will devote more time to corporate duties and working with other subsidiaries, the company said. **********Mr. Busch, who is 52 years old, will be succeeded at the beer unit by Patrick T. Stokes, 47, who will be moving from the bread and snacks operation. Since 1985 Mr. Stokes has been chairman and chief executive of Campbell Taggart Inc. and Eagle Snacks Inc., the company's two food subsidiaries. Campbell Taggart is a major national producer of baked goods and the largest Anheuser-Busch profit contributor after beer. **********''As president of Eagle Snacks, he has kept in close contact with hundreds of our beer wholesalers throughout the country who also handle our snack food line,'' Mr. Busch said of Mr. Stokes. **********One of the men most responsible for the company's top-ranked position in the beer market, Michael J. Roarty, 61, is moving from the beer unit to become executive vice president for corporate marketing and communications and chairman of the media group, which places all company advertising. **********Big Jump in Sales **********Mr. Roarty has been executive vice president for marketing of the beer unit since 1977, a period that saw the company's beer sales double, to 80.7 million barrels from 35 million, and market share go to 42.1 percent from 21 percent. ''It would be impossible to overstate the contribution Mike Roarty has made to the success of Anheuser-Busch,'' Mr. Busch said. **********Mr. Roarty and Mr. Stokes will join Mr. Busch and Jerry E. Ritter, 55, in the corporate office. Mr. Ritter, who has been vice president and group executive and a member of the corporate office since 1983, has been named executive vice president and chief financial and administrative officer. **********Mr. Busch said the changes were the result of a ''long-term management development plan that we put in place in 1974.'' In other moves, David C. Leavenworth, 52, president of Campbell Taggart, was named chairman and chief executive of Campbell Taggart and Eagle Snacks and was named to the parent company's policy committee. Kevin F. Bowler, 41, was named president of Eagle Snacks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/world.main_headline: PERES IN TROUBLE AS DEADLINE NEARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/world.print_headline: PERES IN TROUBLE AS DEADLINE NEARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/world.body_text: **********With Shimon Peres's deadline for forming a new Government just 24 hours away, the Labor Party appears to have given up hope that it can break the deadlock with Likud. **********This afternoon Mr. Peres, the Labor leader, and others around him were saying they still held out hope based on two slender threads that were dangled in front of them today. By evening, however, defeat was written across their faces too. **********It now seems likely that acting Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir will be invited to try to form a Likud-led Government on Thursday afternoon. **********Through the day today, at least two possibilities remained for Labor. A dissident member of a religious party who once supported Labor but switched his allegiance to Likud was ordered by a Rabbinical court this morning to abide by his agreement to vote for Labor. And Yitzhak Modai, a former member of Likud who has taunted both parties with the suggestion that he might support either one, flirted with Labor this evening before announcing in the end that he was going to support Likud. **********'This Unpleasant Fact' **********Chaim Ramon, who leads the Labor Party's Parliamentary faction said: ''The conclusion is clear. Apparently the mandate will go to Shamir. We must live with this unpleasant fact.'' **********Many in the Labor Party are now openly calling for another ''national unity'' government with Likud - exactly the situation that Labor declared intolerable when it brought down the last Government in March. **********But Tuesday night, acting Foreign Minister Moshe Arens of Likud said: ''We had a unity Government with Labor for a year and a half, and I think it's an understatement to say that it didn't work out. I think we have to learn from it, and I don't expect the Government that the Likud will establish will be a unity government.'' **********As the last several weeks of coalition negotiations have shown, however, anything is possible in the end. **********Likud Seeking Partners **********Mr. Shamir has already begun meeting with smaller rightist and religious parties, saying he wants to form a narrow, right-wing Government. With that in mind, Likud and the smaller parties are initialing coalition agreements. **********And as the pendulum swings toward Mr. Shamir, both the Likud and the smaller parties around it are beginning to shift positions, abandoning earlier statements of principle to take advantage of the new circumstances. **********The ruling issued today by Jerusalem's rabbinical court was against Eliahu Mizrahi, a member of the rigorously Orthodox Agudat Israel party. **********He and the other party members signed a coalition agreement with Labor last month. But at the last minute, just as Mr. Peres was about to present his new Government to the Parliament, Mr. Mizrahi and another party member, Avraham Verdiger, changed their minds and left the party, saying they would go with Likud. **********Rabbinical Court Ruling **********Last week, Mr. Verdiger changed his mind again and returned to Labor. The court decision today ordered Mr. Mizrahi to abide by the coalition agreement he signed and support to Labor. **********He has not made his intentions known and probably will not until he is forced to. On the day Mr. Verdiger announced his return to Labor, much of the country was asking what Mr. Mizrahi would do. So he called the phone company, had the number changed for his car phone and then drove around the country all day, to be sure that no one could reach him. **********If the mandate reverts to Mr. Shamir on Thursday, he will face the same 60-to-60 parliamentary deadlock that is thwarting Mr. Peres. Just as Labor has tried for five weeks to win over just one member of Parliament to break the deadlock with Likud, so Likud is now wooing individual legislators, including some from the Labor Party. In this circumstance, every one of the Parliament's 120 members potentially holds the Government's future in his hands. Every one can make demands and negotiate deals with Likud, just as several did with Labor. **********All this has so infuriated the public that citizen protesters say they have acquired 600,000 certified signatures from Israeli voters demanding a change in the nation's electoral system, meaning that more than one-quarter of the nation's voting age population has signed. **********Changes in Eletoral System **********Three weeks ago, Mr. Shamir let it be known that his goal was to form a short-term ''national unity'' Government with Labor for the sole purpose of changing the electoral system so that Israel would never again face the prolonged coalition-making process under way now. **********''People are fed up, fed up,'' Avi Pazner, Shamir's aide, said on April 5, when Labor appeared close to forming a Government without Likud. **********But as the Likud proceeded through its own coalition negotiations today, there was no public mention of a short-term, interim government, no talk of electoral reform. **********In fact, responding to a court order, both Labor and Likud made public their coalition agreements with smaller parties on Tuesday. And the newspaper Yediot Achronot reported this morning that Likud's agreement with the small religious party Torah Flag, a strong opponent of electoral reform, says Likud will not support changing the electoral system without the party's agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/30/busin.main_headline: Fed Acts To Lower Key Rate
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/30/busin.print_headline: THE CREDIT MARKETS; Fed Acts To Lower Key Rate
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/30/busin.body_text: **********Honoring a pledge it indicated would be fulfilled once Congress passed a new Federal budget, the Federal Reserve Board yesterday sent a clear signal that it had lowered interest rates. **********Analysts, however, said the drop was modest would do little to spur an economy many contend has fallen into recession. Additional evidence of economic weakness will be needed before the Fed acts again, they said. **********Some expect that those signs will emerge soon, though -- possibly in the employment report due out on Friday -- and that the Fed could push rates down again by as early as mid-November.  Action Was Expected **********Yesterday's action had been widely anticipated and fell on deaf ears in the credit markets. Prices of most Treasury securities fell and interest rates moved slightly higher. The move also appeared to have had little effect on the stock markets, where traders focused on the Middle East crisis and problems with the banking industry. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.94 points.  [ Page D8. ] **********The Fed sent its signal by adding money to the banking system in late morning, a time when it normally conducts business in the Treasury securities market. That action trimmed the Federal funds rate, the key short-term interest rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans, by one-quarter of 1 percentage point.  Below Target Level **********When the Fed entered the market, the overnight rate, which is the interest rate most directly controlled by the Fed, was trading at 7 3/4 percent. That was below the 8 percent level analysts said has been the Fed's target since mid-July, the last time the Fed chose to ease monetary policy and allow rates to decline. **********Through its action, the Fed added liquidity to the banking system, insuring that the supply of funds would exceed the demand and cause the funds rate to drop. The Fed often sends signals on the direction of interest rates by adding or draining reserves through its operations in the Treasury securities market. **********The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, had indicated publicly on many occasions during the past few months that the central bank would push the short-term interest rate lower once a "credible" Federal budget package had been passed by Congress. **********With a weakening economy, the Administration had been advocating lower interest rates for months. Inflation pressures, aggravated by the sharp increase in oil prices since early August, had, however, persuaded the Fed to resist those pleas. **********"This move was a quid pro quo for the budget package," said Alan Leslie, chief economist at the Discount Corporation of New York, a primary dealer in Government securities. "But it was also a step that had already been widely anticipated." **********Market participants, who often buy securities on rumors and then sell later when the rumors become fact, hewed to that formula yesterday. **********Even though traders had pushed short-term money market rates down considerably last week, before the Fed's move, traders cited additional reasons why they chose to sell securities yesterday.  Treasury Auctions Ahead **********Specifically, with the uncertainty about the budget now removed, dealers face a flood of new Treasury debt auctions, beginning with today's sale of a record $12 billion worth of two-year notes. On Wednesday, the Treasury is expected to announce the size of its quarterly refunding auctions. Analysts expect that the Treasury will need to sell around $34 billion of new securities at the refunding auctions, which will probably begin on Nov. 6. **********In addition, market participants were slightly unnerved when remarks by the Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, flashed across trading screens. **********In an appearance at Washington College in Easton, Md., Mr. Brady said that in the first nine months of the year, the economy grew at a 1.5 percent annual rate. The comments unsettled traders because they appeared to suggest that Mr. Brady had prior knowledge of a preliminary report, which is expected to be released by the Commerce Department today, on how the economy performed in the third quarter.  Higher Than Expected **********Given the 1.7 percent increase in the first quarter and a much more modest four-tenths of 1 percent rise in the second, the economy would have had to expand at 2 percent or more in the third quarter to make Mr. Brady's comments stand up. Most Wall Street analysts are forecasting the preliminary figures would show the gross national product grew by slightly more than 1 percent during the third quarter. **********A Treasury aide said later that Mr. Brady did not have advance knowledge of the third-quarter growth figures, but was merely making a general point that the economy was still expanding. **********Mr. Brady's comments did not help matters, but traders said the market was primarily focused on the upcoming auctions. In order to spur demand for the issues, dealers said interest rates will have to move higher. **********"The Fed can ease all it wants, but we still have to deal with record supply," one Treasury bond trader said.  Some Strong Demand **********While longer-term securities may require higher interest rates, demand for high-quality, short-term Treasury bills remains strong. **********At yesterday's weekly auction of three-month and six-month securities, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.12 percent, down from 7.2 percent at last week's sale. It is the lowest rate on a three-month bill since the auction of Aug. 15, 1988. **********Meanwhile, bids for the six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 7.13 percent, down slightly from last week's average rate of 7.16 percent. It is the lowest rate on a new six-month bill since the auction of July 25, 1988. **********In advance of the two-year auction, the securities were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 7.82 percent.  Long Issues Hurt **********In the secondary market for Treasury securities, longer-dated issues fared the worst. **********In late trading, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 99 1/8, down 21/32, to yield 8.83 percent, up from 8.76 percent late Friday. **********Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 14/ 32, down 11/32, to yield 8.67 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 31/32, down 1/8 of a point, to yield 8.24 percent. **********In other developments, the rate on $75 million worth of Citicorp 49-day auction-rate preferred stock was reset at 12.50 percent yesterday. **********That rate, while sharply higher than the one set at the issue's last auction in late August, was in line with a similar Citicorp auction held last Wednesday.  Alberta Notes **********Elsewhere in the corporate debt market, the Province of Alberta offered $300 million of seven-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. **********The 9.20 percent securities, which mature Nov. 1, 1997, were priced at $99.80, to yield 9.238 percent, which was 68 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, higher than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing. **********The securities, which are non-callable for life, are rated AA-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, dealers said that prices of most issues slipped by 1/4 of a point to 3/8 of a point in light trading. **********Municipal bond traders said that prices of most widely quoted secondary issues fell by about 1/4 of a point. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills: (000 omitted in dollar figures)               3-Mo. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/world.main_headline: Mongolia to Remove Its Last Stalin Statue
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Mongolia to Remove Its Last Stalin Statue
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/world.body_text: **********Mongolia's Communist Government has decided to remove the last statue of Stalin from the capital, signaling another concession to democratic demands, an official newspaper said today. **********The paper, Unen, said the decision to cart away a huge statue of the Soviet dictator was made by the Mongolian Politburo in consideration of the public's changing wishes. **********''The statue has received much displeasure from the public,'' the newspaper said, adding that it would be pulled down ''according to the principle of justice and democracy.'' **********The move was the latest in a series of concessions to a wave of popular demand for political and economic changes in Mongolia's 69-year Communist system. The country is a Soviet ally. A new Mongolian Democratic Association will hold its first congress on Sunday, at which 500 national delegates are expected to proclaim themselves Mongolia's first opposition party.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/world.main_headline: Shongweni Journal; Into the Valley of Death, Good Will Brings Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/world.print_headline: Shongweni Journal; Into the Valley of Death, Good Will Brings Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/world.body_text: **********This dirt-poor Zulu community sits at one end of the Valley of a Thousand Hills, as tradition praises the undulating green countryside. But the feuding that tore Shongweni asunder caused it to be nicknamed the Valley of Death. **********In one year, 150 or more inhabitants were shot, stabbed, hacked or burned to death in clashes between members of the Zulu political movement Inkatha and supporters of the United Democratic Front, an affiliate of the African National Congress. Hundreds of homes were burned down in Shongweni and thousands of families fled. **********The killing consuming Shongweni, about 20 miles west of Durban, was appalling even by the standards of other impoverished black communities across Natal, where 4,000 people have been killed in the last four years in fighting involving supporters of Inkatha and the congress. **********But then a miracle descended upon Shongweni. The fighting ceased and a fragile peace that passes understanding has held for the last 14 months.  Divine Intervention Seen **********Shongweni's inhabitants credit their deliverance to divine intervention. **********"It is difficult to say what ended it," said Elliot Madonsela, an old man who hid in the woods during the fighting. "I sincerely believe it was God." **********A few offer more mundane explanations. "Everybody was really exhausted, because we used to attack them and then they came and attacked us," said Thulani Sithole, a commander of the militants supporting the United Democratic Front. **********Everyone agrees that a local shopkeeper and a white riot policeman played an important role in stopping the fighting. **********John Mkhize, the shopkeeper, said the violence around his bustling general store followed a pattern common to that of other Natal townships. Inkatha started a drive in 1988 to sign up new members, he said, resorting to methods just short of coercion. In protest, local youths burned down the home of a municipal councilor who was active in Inkatha's campaign. Older Inkatha supporters retaliated, and a cycle of revenge prompted more battles.  Six Shops Are Burned **********As the war seesawed across the rolling hills, six shops were burned down, leaving Mr. Mkhize's store one of the last businesses still operating. **********"It was when they attacked the house across the road that I decided it was time for me to call it quits," Mr. Mkhize said. He told Thulane Zulu, the local leader of the United Democratic Front, and Victor Sibisi, the Inkatha leader, that he would close. **********Mr. Mkhize said: "My aim was not to talk peace to these people. After the brutal and gruesome deaths I had seen, I never cherished a hope that the day would come when these guys would talk about peace." **********"I asked them why they were fighting," Mr. Mkhize said. "They were fighting over nothing -- a meatless bone." **********Maj. Ray Harrald, then a captain in the South African Police, had arrived to command a nearby police unit trained in riot control. He greeted villagers in rudimentary Zulu, unlike the riot police officers who patrolled buttoned up in their vans. He helped an old man and his daughter build a fence around their home. When the local bus company withdrew service to Shongweni because of the fighting, Captain Harrald told his men to give rides to elderly residents in violation of police rules. **********"He completely changed the image of the police as we knew them," Mr. Mkhize said. "He was a high-ranking police officer who was prepared to stop and chat and extend his hand. He would come down to the level of the people in Shongweni. This meant quite a lot."  A 'Fantastic' Accord **********Major Harrald became so popular that Mr. Mkhize asked him to mediate the peace talks he was trying to start. Mr. Mkhize said of the policeman: "We have a roundabout way of expressing a very simple idea. He would sit and listen patiently." **********Major Harrald describes himself as a born-again Christian motivated by faith that blacks and whites are created in the same image. "As far as I was concerned, they were entitled to the same treatment as anyone in South Africa," he said of Shongweni's people in a telephone interview from Pretoria, where he has been reassigned after a promotion. **********On Aug. 29, 1989, after repeated quarrels and walkouts, the adversaries met under a scorching sun and pledged support for an unwritten peace accord. "It was fantastic," Major Harrald recalled. "There wasn't a weapon in sight. One of the most important things they came to realize was that the violence was getting them nowhere."  A Joint Feast Is Held **********In December, both sides gathered to apologize to their ancestors and to slaughter three oxen for a feast at which adherents of the United Democratic Front and Inkatha dined together. **********"We respect each other now," Mr. Madonsela said "The young people don't interfere with us. We can even walk about in the night." **********Shongweni's success has been studied elsewhere for clues to ending the fighting. "It should be done by local people because they have undergone the whole experience," Mr. Mkhize advised. **********A sympathetic police response also helped, but Major Harrald said Mr. Mkhize and the people of Shongweni had resolved not to let anyone disrupt their reconciliation. **********"It is by the grace of God that that peace has held," he said. "All I did was I got the ball rolling, and they took it from there."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/25/busin.main_headline: Vote Ends Wine Commission in California
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/25/busin.print_headline: Vote Ends Wine Commission in California
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/25/busin.body_text: **********The California Wine Commission was voted out of existence today, the victim of a rebellion by the state's small wineries. **********A state agricultural body that oversees the commission said that the vote, taken over several weeks, was 125 to 111 against a five-year continuation of the commission, which was created in 1985. The commission will end its term in June. **********The Wine Commission is a state-administered marketing group that assessed a tax on all wineries that crush more than 100 tons of grapes in a season. About 80 percent of the money collected was turned over to the Wine Institute, a San Francisco-based lobbying body for the California wine industry. **********Small wineries, however, complained that they were assessed disproportionately in their payments to the commission and that the institute failed to represent their interests in its promotions. **********''The rank and file out there knew that they were getting the short shrift,'' said Bill MacKiver, the co-owner of the Matanzas Creek Winery, a small producer of premium wines. He and Brice Jones, the owner of the Sonoma Cutter Vineyards, whose slightly larger wineries are in Santa Rosa, led the effort to end the commission. **********''The main industry body did not listen to its members,'' Mr. MacKiver added. **********Mr. MacKiver and Mr. Jones conducted a telephone and letter-writing campaign to other small vintners, pointing out that they were being assessed at up to $14 for a ton of grapes, while the E. & J. Gallo Winery in Modesto, Calif., the world's largest, was paying only $2 a ton. **********They contended that Gallo and Seagram's, another large wine producer, dictated the Wine Institute's policies and promotions and that those policies benefited the large wineries at the expense of the small premium producers. **********A Gallo spokesman said the winery's owners, Ernest and Julio Gallo, had no comment. **********The Wine Commission has 237 members, mostly small- and medium-sized vintners. The institute has about 550 members. **********Breakdown of Vote **********Mr. MacKiver said the 111 votes cast to continue the commission represented about 88.5 percent of the volume of wine produced by its members, while the 125 votes to end it represented 11.5 percent. **********Sam Folsom, a spokesman for the Wine Institute, said it would now revert to relying on voluntary contributions, as it did before the commission was created in 1985. **********''We're disappointed that the commission wasn't reapproved, but in terms of the overall picture and our continued existence, nothing changes,'' Mr. Folsom said. ''Now that the wineries are not going to be paying into the commission, we'll revise our dues structure'' to cover the shortfall in revenues, he said. **********Before the commission began, wineries that belonged to the institute paid dues of 7 cents a gallon. **********A possible problem for the institute is that multiple organizations now exist to represent the wine industry's interests, and some could siphon off funds that had been going to the institute. **********Some of the same vintners that have opposed the commission have formed the American Wine Alliance for Research and Education, a group also based in San Francisco that tries to present a positive view of wine's relationship to health and society.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.main_headline: Macy Will Report Deeper Losses for the Fourth Quarter and the Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.print_headline: Macy Will Report Deeper Losses for the Fourth Quarter and the Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.body_text: **********R. H. Macy & Company's fourth-quarter loss deepened to $80 million, from $57.3 million a year earlier, and its losses for the full fiscal year ended July 28 more than tripled, to $215.3 million, from $63 million the year before, according to statements relayed to credit agencies and confirmed yesterday by sources close to Macy. **********Macy, New York's biggest retailer and the operator of about 100 department stores in the East, South and West, had a sales gain of 2.5 percent in the quarter, to $1.63 billion, from $1.59 billion the year before. For the full year, Macy's sales rose 4.3 percent, to $7.27 billion from $6.97 billion. **********The preliminary figures for the year were published in The Wall Street Journal and Women's Wear Daily yesterday. The fourth-quarter results were extrapolated from the full-year results and those for the nine months ended April 28. Macy expects to furnish final results in a financial statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission late next week, One Measure of the Decline Earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation fell 22.1 percent, to $721 million, from $926.1 million the year before. The tax aspect does not apply to a company losing money. In the fourth quarter, earnings before inventory accounting adjustment rose 7.2 percent, to $179 million from $167 million. ''The drop in those earnings was due to higher inventory accounting charges, which reduced the income by $35 million,'' said one executive close to Macy. **********Macy is one of the nation's most highly leveraged retailers, following its 1986 leveraged buyout and its 1988 acquisition of the Bullock's and I. Magnin stores in California. In its regular, informal report to credit agencies, Macy said that its inventories were $560 million less than a year ago, which could be seen as an indication that Macy, along with most other retailers, does not expect a robust Christmas selling season. **********''I think Macy's primary markets in the Northeast and California suffered from very sluggish consumer buying,'' said Janet Mangano, research director for Jesup, Josephthal & Company, New York. ''That produced the kind of top line or sales that would affect any retailer leveraged or not. But then the high leverage makes weak results seem even weaker.'' **********'Macroeconomic Factors' Cited **********Ms. Mangano said that Macy had had a relatively good third quarter ended April 28 after two ''very weak'' quarters. But the improved trend waned in the fourth quarter ''probably due to the macro-economic factors,'' Ms. Mangano continued. ''But the fourth quarter may have implications for arranging future lines of credit,'' she added. **********Frank Basile, chairman of the CIT Group/Factoring, New York, which has been closely monitoring Macy, said yesterday: ''You can't help but be concerned when dealing with such highly leveraged companies as Macy. But it is actually doing better than most of the others. The company has sufficient resources and support to make it through the holiday, and they have a number of options they could take afterward.'' **********He said that the recent sale by Macy of its credit unit to the General Electric Capital Corporation ''will benefit Macy's earnings and allow it to cut its debt.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/busin.body_text: **********Imelda Marcos will testify with immunity this week in a Federal investigation of allegations that the Westinghouse Electric Corporation paid a $17.3 million bribe to the Philippine Government, her lawyer said. **********The lawyer, James Linn, said Mrs. Marcos had been assured of immunity by Theodore Greenberg, the deputy chief of the Justice Department's fraud division. Mr. Greenberg and a Westinghouse spokesman, Paul Jones, declined to comment on the grand jury proceedings. **********The panel is scheduled to question Mrs. Marcos on Tuesday. It is investigating allegations that Westinghouse bribed the Philippine Government to obtain a contract to build a nuclear power plant when Mrs. Marcos's late husband, Ferdinand, was President. **********Last week, Westinghouse said it had paid $17 million in commissions over 10 years to sales representatives who handled the reactor contract. **********Mrs. Marcos has been subpoenaed to bring all documents related to payments made to Westinghouse and Burns & Roe Enterprises of Oradell, N.J. Westinghouse built the $2.3 billion plant about 60 miles west of Manila in the early 1980's. Burns & Roe was a subcontractor. The plant has never been operated. **********Mrs. Marcos has no such records, Mr. Linn said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/17/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Executive to Oversee Fisher-Price Spinoff
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/17/busin.body_text: **********The Quaker Oats Company has named Ronald J. Jackson, a longtime executive in the toy industry, to oversee the spinoff of its troubled Fisher-Price business into an independent, free-standing company. Mr. Jackson, who is 46 years old, was named chairman, president and chief executive of Fisher-Price. **********The spinoff, announced last month, is expected to be completed by early next year. **********Mr. Jackson is particularly well suited for the assignment. In 1985, he administered General Mills Inc.'s spinoff of the Kenner and Parker Brothers toy operations into an independent company. **********''It is really the same situation,'' Mr. Jackson said in an interview. ''The key lesson is to size the business properly,'' he added. ''My agenda for the next couple of weeks is to spend a lot of time on volume forecasts.'' Accurate sales forecasts are vital, he said, to insure that the new company's expenses are not too high. **********Although one of the best-known brands in the toy business, Fisher-Price has recently suffered difficulties. Production problems and soft sales contributed to a lackluster Christmas season, and Quaker management expects the unit to show a loss for the year. **********Mr. Jackson came from the Stride Rite Corporation, where he was president and chief executive. In 1985, he left the same job to become president and chief executive of Kenner Parker Toys. **********''As a New York baseball player said, 'It's deja vu all over again,' '' said John J. Phelan, executive vice president and treasurer of Stride Rite, a shoe company. **********Mr. Phelan said Stride Rite's chairman, Arnold S. Hiatt, was shocked that Mr. Jackson was leaving a second time. Mr. Phelan said the chairman had called the news ''one of the most traumatic'' events of his business career. **********''I like Ron as a person, but he has twice impacted Stride Rite,'' Mr. Phelan said. ''We've spent six months getting him up to speed, and then he leaves.'' **********Mr. Phelan said that Mr. Jackson's departure would not have a significant effect on the company and that a search committee had been formed to replace him. **********Mr. Phelan said the parting of the ways was ultimately amicable, but he added, ''If you asked Arnold if he'd hire him back again, he'd probably say no.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/03/busin.body_text: **********Central American economic ministers agreed on Wednesday to a plan to eliminate gradually regional trade barriers and called for the creation of a Central American free-trade zone by 1992. **********''By 1992 bilateral treaties will have disappeared, and we will have a region of free trade,'' the Honduran minister, Ramon Medina Luna, told reporters. **********Central American countries have traditionally conducted trade among themselves under highly protectionist policies. **********Ministers from Guatemala, Costa Rica, Honduras, El Salvador and Nicaragua ended a one-day meeting called to develop an economic integration plan proposed by the five Central American presidents in June. Regional integration has been proposed in the past, but guerrilla wars and internal conflicts have prevented implementation of any plan. **********Mr. Medina Luna said ministers would meet in September to work further on the plan for the free-trade zone, which he said had already been agreed on in principle by the five countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/busin.main_headline: U.S. Supercomputer Makers Challenge Export Proposal
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/busin.print_headline: U.S. Supercomputer Makers Challenge Export Proposal
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/busin.body_text: **********United States manufacturers of the most powerful computers are challenging a Commerce Department proposal to relax regulations on exporting the machines. The manufacturers say the proposed change does not go far enough. **********Under the new proposal, makers of the powerful computers, known as supercomputers, would have to meet special Federal requirements to export machines with speeds of 300 million floating point operations, or calculations, per second to any of 23 United States allies. **********For most other countries, with the exception of Warsaw Pact nations, supercomputers rated at 150 million calculations per second would have to meet the requirements. The requirements could include inspections after delivery abroad, restrictions on the use of certain kinds of software, agreements by foreign governments to comply with restrictions on use, and audits of compliance. **********Export License Would Be Needed **********The proposal requires exporters of a computer with a speed of more than 100 million floating point operations per second (also known as megaflops) to obtain an export license. Supercomputers would remain embargoed to Warsaw Pact countries. **********The export of supercomputers troubles many experts concerned that the machines will be used to speed the design of nuclear weapons, ballistic missiles and other arms. **********In the past, supercomputer exports have been controlled by a complex licensing process on a case-by-case basis. The threshold for defining a supercomputer had been set at speeds above 100 million floating point operations. **********Industry executives argued that the new Commerce Department definition failed to account for rapid changes in technology. They said that by the end of this year even some desktop computers will fall under the proposed requirements. **********''I.B.M.'s strong objection to the 100-megaflops definition is that it would classify most of our commercial large-scale processors as supercomputers,'' said Irving Wladawsky-Berger, I.B.M.'s assistant general manager for the mainframe computer division. **********Alternate Plan Supported **********I.B.M. executives and other industry officials have said they support an alternative proposal of the American Electronics Association that suggests that the definition of a supercomputer falling under the rules be calculated by averaging the peak performance of the two most powerful commercially available machines in the world - a figure that could well reach into the thousands of megaflops, as opposed to the hundreds. **********Systems sold to Western industrial countries with more than 25 percent of the peak number would require a security plan. For countries outside the Western industrial world or those not signatories of the nuclear nonproliferation treaty, a security plan would be needed for all machines whose performance exceeds 10 percent of the average. **********The Commerce Department said it would hold a 45-day period for public comment before it issued a final rule. It held public hearings in Dallas on Monday and Santa Clara, Calif., yesterday. Hearings will be held in Boston tomorrow and in Minneapolis on Monday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   Xtra to Sell Itself And Avoid Proxy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   Xtra to Sell Itself And Avoid Proxy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/busin.body_text: **********RATHER than risk their removal in a bitter proxy vote, the top managers and directors of the Xtra Corporation said yesterday that they would put the company up for sale and would cancel the annual shareholders meeting originally scheduled for tomorrow. If the company is sold, the managers and board members are likely to reap a tidy profit themselves. **********Xtra, one of the nation's largest lessors of truck and rail trailers, has revamped its operations in the last few years. Unhappy with the performance of the stock, a dissident group that controls more than 21 percent of the company's common stock has taken aim at management. **********The dissidents, which include several investment partnerships and Gintel & Company, a New York securities firm, have been seeking to replace the board with its own committee of directors. The group contends that Xtra has been mismanaged, that much of its capital has been wasted and that its executives, particularly Charles F. Kaye, the chairman, have been excessively compensated even as they were running the company into the ground. The group filed complaints yesterday in Delaware Chancery Court to force Xtra's management to hold the annual meeting as soon as possible. The dissidents also said they did not believe management would be able to find a buyer for the company in its present condition. **********Xtra, which had been trading at close to its 52-week low of $23.50 for several months, shot up on the prospects of a sale. Xtra closed up $5.25, to $30, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The dissident shareholders are determined to unseat Mr. Kaye, whose compensation package has been continually sweetened in the last 10 years, despite the company's erratic earnings and stock performance. Indeed, Mr. Kaye has tied his bonus to cash flow rather than earnings at a time when he has sold off divisions, greatly adding to the cash flow.
