In addition, controlling Xtra's capital expenditures seems to be a problem that has bedeviled the company's management, although they have noted the need for this in public documents. **********''If you look back at the annual reports, you will find that they have been promising reduction of capital expenditures all along,'' said Lewis Rubin, a member of the executive committee established by the dissidents' group and the former head of two leading transportation leasing companies. **********Instead of reducing expenditures, Mr. Kaye has spent more than $600 million in three years for acquisitions that have not yet produced substantial bottom-line gains. **********''They have added nothing to free cash flow or profitability after spending more than $600 million,'' said John J. Lee, another member of the shareholder group's executive committee and a former president of Phibro Resources, a unit of Salomon Inc. ''You don't have to be a genius to see that the money has been misused.'' **********Xtra's stock has been remarkably sluggish despite the bull market of most of the 1980's. In 1980, the company had revenues of $179 million and earnings of $12 million. In the decade sales and earnings fluctuated widely, with earnings reaching a high of $26.6 million in 1984. In the fiscal year 1989, the company had $212 million in revenues, or a compounded annual growth rate of 1.8 percent over 10 years. Over the same period the company has spent more than $1.2 billion, about $190 a share, on various capital expenditure programs. **********But despite the sales of divisions, the one-time gains and the realignment of some of the company's business, the increased capital expenditures have apparently not helped Xtra's earnings. Last year sales fell some 5 percent and earnings dropped nearly 50 percent. Some of the shareholders are particularly piqued because despite the divestiture of several divisions, payouts to shareholders did not increase to reflect the gains. As for the stock, it ended the decade only 75 cents higher than it stood at the beginning of the 1980's. **********Moreover, according to the dissident shareholders' group, Mr. Kaye ''has reaped excessive personal benefits from the company in the form of bonuses and stock grants.'' They note that his compensation has increased 73.5 percent, while returns to shareholders fell 4.4 percent. **********Xtra's management has defended the compensation structure based on cash flow rather than the company's earnings. Although such a structure has resulted in higher bonuses, Mr. Kaye has said in letters to shareholders, an independent committee of directors had determined that it was a better measure of the company's performance. Mr. Kaye has declined to be interviewed. **********As for the underperformance of the stock, management has defended its leasing practices, which the dissidents have criticized, and argues that the market had not recognized that it is leasing a larger percentage of its trailers than in the past. They did not, however, explain the costs of these added leasing arrangements nor the nature of the contracts, both significant omissions. **********The dissident shareholders' group contends that it can reduce Xtra's operating expenses by at least $10 million and that it will sharply reduce capital expenditures. Unfortunately, it has not been specific about the cuts. It did not rule out sales of divisions, the entire company, or a move to take the company private.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/20/world.main_headline: Amid Sea of Difficulties, India's Prime Minister Welcomes a Small Victory
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/20/world.print_headline: Amid Sea of Difficulties, India's Prime Minister Welcomes a Small Victory
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/20/world.body_text: **********As his Indian Air Force jet climbed into a hazy morning sky over the Bay of Bengal, Prime Minister V. P. Singh was relishing a moment of triumph. **********Huge crowds at two huge rallies in Madras, the largest city in South India, had responded with happy enthusiasm to his affirmative action plan that would set aside 27 percent of Federal jobs for millions of disadvantaged Indians, in addition to 22.5 percent already reserved for outcasts and tribes. Posters welcomed Mr. Singh as the ''Savior of Backward Classes.'' **********Mr. Singh has found the going much tougher in recent weeks in North India, his political base. Not only are defiant upper-caste Hindus paralyzing campuses and city streets in violent protests against his promise to extend the share of Government jobs reserved for the poor and socially marginal, but a Hindu-Muslim confrontation also looms over a disputed holy site, and cracks are appearing in the fragile political alliance that keeps the Prime Minister in power. In the states of Punjab and Kashmir, dozens continue to die daily in clashes that pit separatists against the police. **********''I think there is a fair chance that these difficulties will be overcome,'' Mr. Singh said in his low-key style on Monday as the plane headed north toward the Vindhayas, the mountains that form India's psychological Mason-Dixon line. ''But certainly we cannot say we are out of all risk.'' **********Opening to Foreign Investment **********Moving aside two envelopes of files, Mr. Singh, a hard-working political loner, spoke about the frustrations he has encountered as he has sought new sources of investments abroad to hasten the development of India, campaigned to rid India of social inequities and worked to keep his minority Government in power through the time-consuming process of building consensus on every major issue. **********He said now that India was facing the loss of ''some of the comforts'' of its longstanding relationship with the Soviet Union, New Delhi had ''no option'' but to open the country to more foreign investment and seek to integrate itself into a fast-changing world economy. In his comments he echoes the view of many Indian officials who have been contending that Moscow, caught up in economic revolution, can no longer be counted on as an economic and diplomatic cushion. **********''Within certain national priorities, we do want foreign investments and technologies, which will go a long way toward strengthening our production base,'' Mr. Singh said, particularly those ''which will give a boost to our exports, or in frontier technologies for which we don't have the facilities for research.'' India, which has been historically protectionist, also needs investment in agriculture, he said. **********Quiet Negotiations **********''That's our biggest industry, our area where our employment generation need is largest,'' he said. **********But Mr. Singh said that to advance those plans, he was negotiating with the ''friendly parties'' that support him in Parliament though they remain outside his National Front coalition: the Left and the nationalist pro-Hindu Bharatiya Janata Party. **********Characteristically, the process goes on behind the scenes. Mr. Singh, who confides mostly in his wife, Sita Kumari, rarely thinks aloud. Cabinet leaks are almost nonexistent. When the Prime Minister feels the moment is right, he makes an announcement, sometimes to the surprise of his closest aides. On the question of investment, he evidently has yet to achieve consensus. **********''I do hope that there will be a movement forward,'' he said. ''But it cannot be a unilateral movement in the present political context.'' **********Wants 'Consensus Approach' **********Mr. Singh, whose Janata Dal Party includes politicians whose attitudes toward international corporations border on paranoia, wants to breach the wall of bureaucratic hurdles that drive away foreign and Indian investors. **********''People complain about our procedures,'' he said. ''So we are examining those procedures, and the Industry Minister would be announcing these policies. But certainly, we want to go with a consensus approach on this.'' **********Prime Minister Singh's minority Government, which he calls a ''unique experiment'' in India, survives on layers of agreements, each adding to the tradeoffs inherent in coalitions. **********At the heart of the Government is Mr. Singh's Janata Dal Party, where a wing led by an ambitious rival for party leadership, Chandra Shakhar, plots incessantly. **********Shoring Up Coalition **********Next is the National Front coalition, in which Mr. Singh's party shares Government power with several regional parties and splinter groups. Mr. Singh had been visiting Madras to shore up relations with one of his partners, the Dravidian National Party of Tamil Nadu's Chief Minister, Muthivel Karunanidhi. **********Still a minority in Parliament, the National Front relies on the two disparate voting blocks outside the governing coalition, the Bharatiya Janata Party, inspired by Hindu revivalism, and the left, including two Communist parties and other Socialist groups. **********Mr. Singh acknowledged that barely a month after consolidating his position within his party in August, when he dismissed his Deputy Prime Minister, Devi Lal, he faces ''an element of fluidity'' in his political position. **********Temple at Center of Conflict **********This time, the Bharatiya Janata Party is threatening to withdraw its backing because of the Government's opposition to the Hindu militants' plan to build a temple on the grounds of an old mosque in the northern town of Ayodhya, which they believe is the birth place of the god Rama. The issue, which has inflamed the conflicting passions of Muslims and Hindus, has been simmering for a year but is due to erupt again by Oct. 30, when the Hindus say construction will begin. **********The Bharatiya Janata Party - one of whose leaders has no objections to sati, the outlawed Hindu practice in which widows burned themselves on the funeral pyres of their husbands -also opposes any compromise on Punjab, where militants drawn from the Sikh religion are demanding more autonomy, and Kashmir, India's only Muslim majority region, where an independence movement is growing. Many Hindus would like India to declare itself a Hindu nation and abandon its secular political creed. **********Mr. Singh conceded that in an effort to build consensus, he had sacrificed his best opportunity to deal with Punjab, where nearly 2,000 people have died this year at the hands of separatists, security forces and common criminals taking advantage of a disruption in law and order. **********A Missed Opportunity **********''I ought to have gone for elections in Punjab in the first six months,'' said Mr. Singh, whose first bold act in office was to ride through the streets of Amritsar, the heart of Sikh separatism, in an open car. But influential members of his party, and intelligence agencies, argued against calling an election in the state, officials say. **********''The people of Punjab had great faith,'' Mr. Singh said. ''The Sikhs had great faith and confidence. There was an environment for elections, but somehow I couldn't get a consensus on it and I stalled. I have made a mistake and I will not forgive myself for it. It's a golden opportunity, which I missed. I shouldn't have listened to anyone.'' **********Asked about how to bring Kashmiri Muslims back from alienation, Mr. Singh asked how they got there in the first place. **********''The first target of the terrorist is the ballot box,'' Mr. Singh said. ''Their first target is to eliminate those who are in the democratic process, to disrupt all channels of normal political expression.'' In Kashmir, he said, separatists have created an atmosphere of fear by the ''systematic throttling of democracy.'' **********Pervasiveness of Politics **********''I think when the human-rights debate is raised, this debate should be raised along with it,'' he said, asserting that the separatists had adopted a deliberate policy of ''drawing out the state machinery'' and provoking it to ''come down heavily.'' **********Shifting into a broader philosophical look at India, Mr. Singh said one of its development problems was the pervasiveness of politics in Indian life. **********''Or you may say, that politics hogs too much attention, while efforts in other sides of life, contributions in other areas, do not find the recognition they deserve,'' he said. **********''The limelight the politician gets perhaps our artists don't get, our writers don't get, our scientists don't get,'' he said. ''And there are so many activities by voluntary organizations. I think we must correct this for a balanced life in our country.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Dubcek Rebukes Slovak Protesters Who Disrupted Speech by Havel
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Dubcek Rebukes Slovak Protesters Who Disrupted Speech by Havel
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/world.body_text: **********Alexander Dubcek, the hero of Prague Spring, shed his image of kindly geniality today to chastise a large crowd of his fellow Slovaks after some of them had disrupted a speech by President Vaclav Havel, who comes from the Czech part of this country. **********Mr. Dubcek's forceful speech largely silenced several hundred Slovak nationalists. **********''I know that you are drunk from freedom, but if this is the expression of democracy, we should be ashamed,'' Mr. Dubcek told an audience that numbered in the tens of thousands. ''We have not been fighting against one totalitarianism so that another can come in. It's not civilized to prevent Presidents from speaking.'' **********Mr. Dubcek was this country's leader when Soviet forces invaded in 1968 and ended a brief attempt to invent ''socialism with a human face.'' He spent much of the next 21 years in menial jobs, including as a clerk in the national forestry service. **********Much of the rally in the hot afternoon sun in Bratislava was consumed by shouting matches between the small group of nationalists and the much larger contingent of Havel partisans. The insults each side chose were revealing. **********Slovak Sentiments **********The nationalists chanted: ''This is our house,'' ''We want free Slovakia'' and ''Speak Slovak.'' In response, the majority of the crowd, their arms a milling sea of the two-fingered V-signs that symbolized the revolution here and in Poland, replied: ''Long live Havel,'' ''You are making us ashamed'' and ''United we stand.'' **********Mr. Havel reminded the crowd that he opposed the efforts of the Communists to stamp out Slovak nationalism, to create the illusion that this country had only one culture. He said that he rejected both this ''mirage of Czechoslovakism'' and the ''totally wrong notion of totally independent republics.' **********Elections for a national constituent assembly, which will take place on Friday and Saturday, have touched off a groundswell of nationalist sentiment in Slovakia, the eastern region of what is now called the Czech and Slovak Federative Republic. The Slovak Nationalist Party, which is separatist, is expected to get about 10 percent of the vote, while the Christian Democrats, who have been sympathetic to secession, command a more sizable following estimated at 25 percent of the electorate. **********Polls predict that the Civic Forum, the organization led by Mr. Havel, will come out ahead when all the votes are counted nationwide. The race in Slovakia is closely contested, with the counterpart to the Civic Forum there, the Public Against Violence, running even with the Christian Democrats. Six months after the revolution that toppled Communism, Mr. Havel remains a national hero, and even his routine trips through Prague are an occasion for crowds to surge toward his car. **********A Plea for Understanding **********Today on his last campaign swing through Slovakia before the election, Mr. Havel took his message of national unity and tolerance for minorities from the Hungarian border to Bratislava, the capital of Slovakia. He got a decidedly mixed reception. **********At two of the three appearances, his speech was accompanied by leather-lunged groups of protesters waving the signs of the Slovak Nationalist Party. He ignored the hecklers on his visit to Komarno, a tired shipbuilding town largely populated by Hungarians, but in Bratislava he looked up from his prepared text, peered over the rim of his gold reading glasses, and responded with some of the wryness that distinguishes his work as a playwright. **********''Where were you in November?'' he asked, referring to the month when the Czechoslovak revolution began last year. ''The most important thing we have to do is not submit ourselves to the voices of those who have appeared from nowhere,'' he continued, ''those who are fighters now but were servile to the former lords, those who are appealing to the basest of emotions.'' **********While Mr. Havel implored Slovaks to join in a national rebuildling effort, he made it clear that if the majority here decides to sever ties with the Czechs, the central Government in Prague will not stand in the way. ''It does not make sense,'' he said, ''to kick an open door.'' **********In Czech, With a Slovak Finale **********In Bratislava, Mr. Havel spoke in his native Czech, which is easily understood by Slovak speakers, but concluded with a sentence in Slovak. ''We are fellow citizens,'' he said. ''and I'm looking forward to my next visit to Slovakia.'' **********One sign of the rapid development of this country's political culture is that voters in Slovakia seem quite willing to separate their personal feelings for Mr. Havel from their inclination to vote for his party. **********When Mr. Havel spoke earlier in the day in Nitra, an agricultural center of Slovakia, the crowds were friendly and surged toward the stage, creating a crush of people chanting ''Long live Havel.'' **********Yet, Julius Petko, a mechanical engineer and a supporter of the Public Against Violence, said that most of the people in the crowd would likely vote for the Christian Democrats. ''Slovakia is very strongly Christian,'' Mr. Petko said of the Roman Catholic Church's role in the city's politics.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/14/busin.snippet: LEAD: Dependence on the automobile is usually unavoidable in new suburban developments, but a builder has tried to make car ownership optional for residents of a 167-unit condominium being built on Forest Avenue in Old Greenwich, Conn.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/14/busin.main_headline:
Connecticut Projects;

No Car Needed at This Suburban Condo
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/14/busin.print_headline:
Connecticut Projects;

No Car Needed at This Suburban Condo
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/14/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Dependence on the automobile is usually unavoidable in new suburban developments, but a builder has tried to make car ownership optional for residents of a 167-unit condominium being built on Forest Avenue in Old Greenwich, Conn. **********Dependence on the automobile is usually unavoidable in new suburban developments, but a builder has tried to make car ownership optional for residents of a 167-unit condominium being built on Forest Avenue in Old Greenwich, Conn. **********Still, it is unclear whether buyers leaving the city will be drawn to the more urban-style developments like this one. **********At the complex, called Old Greenwich Gables, a rear gate will lead directly from the condominium into the adjoining parking lot of the Old Greenwich train station, and shopping, houses of worship and a library are all within walking distance. **********Although suburban development more commonly occurs away from transportation, shopping and the workplace, the Regional Plan Association, an agency serving New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, has encouraged suburban developers to focus projects around railroad stations and other transportation hubs to reduce dependence on cars. **********The Collins Development Corporation of Stamford, Conn., which is developing Old Greenwich Gables, says that buyers, especially those from Manhattan, will want the conveniences the condominium offers. **********''We are so convenient that you could say we are Madison Avenue north,'' said Arthur Collins, president of the development company. ''It's like living near the subway while being in the country.'' **********But sales have been somewhat slow. Since the condominiums were put on the market 18 months ago, only 33 have been sold, and the developer has reduced the size of the rest of them in an effort to speed sales. **********Prices, which had ranged from $280,000 to $600,000 for 1,000-square-foot to 2,200-square-foot apartments, some of which had included duplexes, now start at $240,000 for a 900-square-foot one-bedroom apartment and range up to $370,000 for a 1,300-square-foot three-bedroom unit. Duplexes are no longer being built. **********The site's accessibility, however, has played an important role in the town of Greenwich's decision about what should be built on the property. The town of Greenwich includes Old Greenwich. **********The eight-acre parcel had been zoned for industrial use and was part of a 20-acre site on which stood a 425,000-square-foot Electrolux vacuum cleaner factory that closed in 1987. Collins had purchased the property in 1987 for $20 million and had originally proposed to build a 210,000-square-foot office building on the site. **********But the plan was rejected because of community opposition to a commercial project. To appease residents, the local Zoning and Planning Commission agreed to rezone much of the property for residential use. In 1988 it approved 24 single-family houses on six acres; a 167-unit condominium on eight acres, and 40,000 square feet of office space on two acres. Four acres were acquired by the town for municipal parking. **********The town might have required that the condominium be smaller to alleviate the potential traffic buildup in the area. But it allowed the condominium a higher density - of 20 units to the acre - than is permitted under the town's multifamily zoning because it assumed that its close proximity to shopping and transportation would minimize the use of cars by residents, said James G. Sandy, the town planner and zoning coordinator. **********The density also permitted the developers to build private recreational amenities that may well have been unaffordable to buyers if the number of units had been lower. **********Amenities will include a clubhouse, a health spa, saunas, an indoor squash court and an outdoor swimming pool. These will be shared by tenants of the adjoining office building as well as by the owners of the 24 single-family houses. Those two groups will contribute to the cost of operating those amenities. **********The three-story attached town houses, which have brick, stucco or wood frame exteriors, are being designed by Do H. Chung & Partners of Stamford. Each contains two or three apartments. Ground-floor units have private patios, and those on upper floors have balconies. The courtyards around which the units are grouped are landscaped with fountains and paved in brick. **********Design changes have been made on 134 apartments. Potential buyers have indicated that they prefer smaller, more affordable apartments, so sizes have been reduced. Walk-up apartments have been eliminated. An elevator will now serve every group of 12 apartments. **********There will be indoor and outdoor parking for 380 cars, with garage parking for 260 cars created from a section of the former factory building. Ninety apartments will be built on the garage roof, and these will overlook the Metro-North train tracks. **********The office building, completed six months ago, is fully leased, and 19 of the 24 three- and four-bedroom single-family houses, priced from $710,000 to $800,000, have been sold.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Muslims;   Islamic Population Gain A Challenge to Soviets
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Muslims;   Islamic Population Gain A Challenge to Soviets
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.body_text: **********Experts on the Soviet Union say they expect to see more violence in areas populated by Muslims, who account for a large, rapidly growing share of the Soviet population. **********The latest unrest in the southern Soviet republics, which pits Muslim Azerbaijanis against Christian Armenians, focuses new attention on the importance of Muslims in the Soviet Union. **********The seven biggest Islamic nationalities - Azeri, Tatar, Kazakh, Tadzhik, Kirghiz, Uzbek, Turkmen - account for a total of 51.6 million people, or 17.7 percent of the Soviet population, now estimated at 291 million. **********Those seven nationalities have higher birth rates than the Russians and account for a large proportion of draft-age men and new job-seekers. But together those nationalities are expected to account for about one-third of the total Soviet population in the year 2050, according to projections by the United States Census Bureau. #125.5 Million in 2050 The bureau estimates that the seven major Muslim nationalities will account for 125.5 million people, out of a total Soviet population that is projected at 386.5 million for the year 2050. **********Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, wrote in the winter issue of Foreign Affairs that there was a ''growing prospect of truly intense and potentially quite bloody international strife within the Soviet Union.'' **********''National passions are being unleashed'' in the non-Russian republics, and ''the national issue has become the central dilemma of Soviet political life,'' he said. ''The approximately 50 million Soviet Muslims currently produce as many babies per year as do the 145 million Russians.'' **********Paul A. Goble, deputy director of research for Radio Liberty, which broadcasts to the Soviet Union from Munich, said that the Azerbaijanis ''are vastly more educated and more urbanized'' than most Soviet Muslims and are mainly Shiites, whereas most Soviet Muslims are Sunnis. **********Russian Percentage Declining **********Shiites have a stronger sense of martyrdom and revolution and have displayed a greater desire than Sunnis to effect change through political activity. **********''The forces driving the unrest, demands and pogroms in Azerbaijan do not have exact equivalents'' in other Muslim areas of the Soviet Union, Mr. Goble said. ''I think we will see communal violence in Central Asia, but it will probably not be as intense or widespread as in Azerbaijan.'' **********The Russian population is just now falling below one-half of the Soviet total. Muslims account for a steadily growing proportion of the non-Russian population of the Soviet Union. **********W. Ward Kingkade, a demographic statistician at the Census Bureau's Center for International Research, foresees ''explosive growth'' of the population in Soviet Central Asia. But he said the Muslims ''are not going to be a majority'' of the total Soviet population at any point in the next 60 years. **********Religion Not Tabulated **********Soviet census takers do not ask questions about religion, so in the Soviet Union, as in many other countries, it is difficult to count the Muslims precisely. For the sake of convenience, many demographers assume that members of nationalities with an Islamic history or background are Muslims. Five of the seven biggest such nationalities -Kazakh, Tadzhik, Kirghiz, Uzbek and Turkmen - are in Central Asia. **********In a recent report, the Census Bureau said that those Central Asians account for 13 percent of the current Soviet population, but ''will contribute a disproportionate share of total population growth in the U.S.S.R.: roughly half of all growth through 2010 and nearly two-thirds of growth through 2050.'' **********Mr. Kingkade, the author of the study, said that Uzbeks alone, who represent only 6 percent of the current Soviet population, would ''account for roughly 25 percent of the population growth to the year 2000 and over 33 percent of the growth'' through 2050. **********The growth of the Muslim population is particularly notable among Soviet citizens 15 to 19 years old. In this age group, which includes military conscripts and people joining the labor force for the first time, the Russian population is leveling off and is expected to decline in the next 20 years, while the Muslim population is increasing rapidly. **********Foreign Policy Implications **********The Census Bureau estimates that the number of Russians in the 15-to-19 age group, now 10.3 million, will decline to 8.8 million by the year 2050. The bureau says that the population of the major Muslim nationalities in that age group, now 4.8 million, will probably reach 8.2 million by the year 2050. **********Some experts see the growing dependence on Muslim conscripts as a threat to the efficiency of the Soviet armed forces. Prof. Martha Brill Olcott, chairman of the department of political science at Colgate University, said, ''The Muslim population has deficiencies in Russian language training and technical education.'' **********In addition, she said, the growth of the Muslim population has implications for Soviet foreign policy. ''Muslim leaders of the world will mistrust Moscow if its own Muslim population is considered abused, especially in light of the unpopular Soviet occupation of Afghanistan,'' where Muslim guerrillas expelled the Soviet Army, she said. **********Demographers and political scientists generally do not expect Muslim-versus-Russian civil war in the Soviet Union. Nancy Lubin, a political scientist at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, said that historic feuds between Muslim groups in the Soviet Union made a pan-Islamic movement unlikely. For example, she said, there have been longstanding conflicts between Uzbeks and Tadzhiks over territorial and other claims in Central Asia. **********Fertility Rates Higher **********The Soviet Union is the world's third most populous country, and the Soviet census lists more than 100 nationalities. **********Fertility rates for the Central Asian nationalities of the Soviet Union equal or exceed the average for third world countries, while the rates for Russians and many other European nationalities in the Soviet Union are below the levels required to maintain the size of the population in the long run. **********The total fertility rate reflects the number of children a woman is expected to bear, on the average, over her reproductive life. For the Soviet Union as a whole, the fertility rate was 2.4 in 1983-84. The rate was 2.1 for Russians, 2.4 for Tatars, 3 for Azeris, 4 for Kazakhs, 5.7 for Uzbeks, 5.8 for Kirghiz, 6.1 for Turkmen and 6.6 for Tadzhiks. (For the United States it was 1.9.) In the last decade, fertility has declined among Soviet Central Asians, and in the last few years it has risen in the European republics of the Soviet Union. But large disparities remain. **********Interest in Islam Growing **********Most of the Muslim nationalities are concentrated in republics like Uzbekistan, where the name of the republic resembles the name of the nationality. The Tatars, however, are spread out. Their homeland is in the Crimea and the Volga region of European Russia, but they were forcibly resettled by Stalin in Central Asia. **********A revival of religious feeling in Central Asia may increase the potential for outbreaks of ethnic violence. **********Professor Olcott said that popular interest in Islam had increased since the mid-1970's. ''Intellectuals write more frequently about the Islamic past of their peoples, there is a new pressure from college-age youth demanding to learn Arabic'' and celebration of long-neglected celebration of long-neglected religious holidays is now popular, she said. **********A State Department official noted the construction of new mosques and said, ''There is a renaissance of religious feeling in Central Asia.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;   Keeping in Touch While Airborne
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/19/busin.body_text: **********Several companies are developing satellite-based systems that will enable airline passengers to make phone calls or send facsimiles from a plane flying virtually anywhere in the world, spawning what one company calls the ''office in the sky.'' Currently, passengers can make calls only when flying within about 100 miles of the United States, and the transmission quality can be poor. **********British Telecom, Comsat/GTE Airfone, a joint venture, and SITA, a Paris-based telecommunications consortium of 370 companies from 180 nations, are each working on satellite-based systems that they hope will be operating next year. **********The systems differ slightly, but each will use a network of satellites to bounce signals from the plane to ground stations, which are linked with normal telephone networks. Because the systems use digital technology, calls will be crisper than those made on today's airborne telephones, which use conventional radio technology. **********But the systems will not allow people on the ground to call airborne passengers, and one stumbling block remains: The airlines have yet to install the digital cockpit electronics needed. Five international airlines, however, - Cathay Pacific, China Airlines, Finnair, Qantas and Swissair - will soon install the electronics and have agreed to offer the SITA service on their flights, beginning next year. **********In addition to allowing passengers to make phone calls anywhere, some of the systems will enhance communication between pilots and air traffic controllers, because they will no longer need to rely exclusively on standard radios, which can be unreliable in remote parts of the world.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/world.main_headline: Blazing Trenches May Be Iraqi Means of Defense
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; Blazing Trenches May Be Iraqi Means of Defense
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/world.body_text: **********Fortifying its military positions in Kuwait, Iraq has dug trenches that might be set afire to defend against an American attack, Administration officials say. **********The Iraqi move is one of a series of steps that Baghdad has taken to strengthen its defenses along the Kuwaiti border with Saudi Arabia and along the Kuwaiti coastline, including minefields, barbed wire and sand barriers. **********American officials said that substances appear to have been placed in the trenches, which might be turned into flaming moats in case of an American attack. **********"The assumption is that the substance is some kind of petroleum product but we have not seen any tests where they set it ablaze," one Government official said. Oil for the Trenches **********In addition, Iraqi combat engineers have laid pipe that stretch from the trenches toward oil complexs in Kuwait, leading some officials to conclude that the pipes will be used to pour oil into the trenches to help create a fire barrier. There are no operating oil refineries in Kuwait, however, to produce refined oil, which is more flammable than crude oil. **********Administration official are also keeping a careful watch on three Iraqi oil tankers, which have anchored off the coast of Kuwait for about a month. A senior Administration official said Iraq's intentions in moving the tankers there are not clear. **********One line of speculation, reported today in The Washington Times, is that Iraq might disperse oil from the tanker and create a flaming oil slick in an effort to foil a Marine amphibious assault. Another line of speculation, officials said, is that the tankers are being used to store oil at a protected anchorage while the embargo is in effect. 3,500 Iraqi Tanks **********Iraq continues to maintain a force of 430,000 in Kuwait and in southern Iraq, according to the Pentagon figures released today. Iraq has 3,500 tanks in this region. The number of Iraqi armored personnel carriers in this region has declined to 2,200 from 2,500, according to the latest Pentagon estimates. The number of artillery pieces, meanwhile, has climbed from 1,700 to 2,200, according to Pentagon estimates. **********A Government specialist said the precise composition of Iraqi forces had fluctuated in recent week but there had been no basic changes in the Iraqi military strategy in Kuwait. **********"There have been no significant changes," a Pentagon spokesman, Bob Hall, said. "Their posture is primarily one of defense with the ability to go on the offensive quickly." **********A fourth American aircraft carrier, the Midway, arrived in the Persian Gulf region. Pentagon officials said the Midway was scheduled to to replace the Independence, which is deployed in the Arabian Sea and which is nearing the end of its scheduled sixth-month tour at sea. But until the Independence leaves the region the Pentagon would have the option of keeping a fourth carrier in the region.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/10/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;   N.A.S.D. Ruling on ASK
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/10/busin.body_text: **********ASK Computer Systems Inc. said today that it had been advised by the National Association of Securities Dealers that as a condition of its continued listing, the proposed sale of about 5.6 million shares of common stock to the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, a General Motors subsidiary, and the Hewlett-Packard Company would require shareholder approval. **********James P. Lennane, a holder of about 9.7 percent of the stock of ASK, has filed suit to block the proposed sale as well as the proposed acquisition by ASK of the Ingres Corporation. He contended in his suit that consummation of the sale without stockholder approval would violate N.A.S.D. rules. **********Mr. Lennane has also indicated that he will attempt to gain control of ASK's board through a proxy fight. **********ASK said that rather than submit the sale to a shareholder vote to keep its shares listed in the National Market System, it would allow its shares to trade on the Nasdaq over-the-counter market list. **********The National Market System reports each trade for a listed company, while the over-the-counter list is less detailed, containing the latest bid and asked prices. **********''We believe that completing the sales of shares to E.D.S. and H. P. and the acquisition of Ingres is in the best interests of the company,'' Sandra Kurtzig, ASK's chairwoman, president and chief executive, said in a statement. **********''We believed that a contingency such as shareholder approval of the sale of the shares as part of the financing for the acquisition would not have been acceptable to Ingres,'' she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/world.body_text: **********As far as Ali Ashour Daghir knew, the soft-spoken American with whom he met in London last September was the manager of export and finance for a company in San Marcos, Calif., not far from San Diego. Mr. Daghir and two Iraqi engineers were there to conclude a deal to purchase 85 special capacitors, 40 of them with specifications identical to those used in setting off nuclear weapons. They discussed how to disquise the objects to get them past United States Customs. **********In fact, the American was Daniel Supnick, a special undercover agent for the Customs Service. That encounter led to the arrest of Mr. Daghir and several other people in London today after a long and complex charade carried on by the British and American authorities. Officials said that an indictment charging conspiracy to export defense articles against a number of those involved, none Americans, is expected to be unsealed in San Diego on Thursday. **********Government sources familiar with the investigation gave this account of how it developed: **********It all began 18 months ago when the San Marcos company, CSI Technologies, received an inquiry from a company in Britain, Euromac (London) Ltd. in Surrey, about buying capacitors, which are common industrial devices that hold electrical charges. But the manufacturer became suspicious because the specifications - in size, inductance, resistance to stress and gravity - could have been only for military use, most probably to help detonate a nuclear warhead. As such, the item is listed on the State Department's munitions list, which bans its export to certain countries. The device is used in the Midgetman warhead. **********Cooperation Sought **********The Customs Service asked CSI and its president, Jerold D. Kowalsky, to go along with the prospective buyer, to try to get an order, and to offer a good price to keep the buyer from going to one of the other two suppliers, one in the United States, the other in France. But Euromac, which is listed in British corporate records as an importer of food, canceled the order last April soon after a story appeared in The Washington Post, quoting Israeli officials as saying that Iraq had started a program to build nuclear warheads. **********Two months later, however, Euromac renewed the inquiry and Mr. Supnick, a man with long experience in undercover detective work, was assigned to the case to try to figure out who was the real user of the product, and to get incriminating evidence. **********In September 1989, Mr. Supnick and Mr. Kowalsky went to London, where they met with Mr. Daghir, director of Euromac; Jeanine Speckman, Euromac's export manager, and two Iraqi engineers who identified themselves as representatives of Al Qaqaa, a rocket research arm of the Iraqi Ministry of Industry and Military Industrialization. **********The Iraqis said the capacitors were for laser research and applications. They also said they wanted high-speed switches of a type also used in nuclear weapons. When told by the Americans that the capacitor specifications were military, the Iraqis changed their story, saying they were for aerospace purposes. **********Dissimulation Is Urged **********A purchase order for $10,500 was signed at that time. The next day, Miss Speckman telephoned the Americans, suggesting they misdescribe the items as components of computer-room air conditioning units. The order was paid for with two money wires from the Iraqi Embassy in London. **********A few days after the London meeting, the Milan daily Corriere della Sera reported that the Italian office of Euromac, which stands for European Manufacturer Center, was an Iraqi front to acquire military equipment, including components for cluster bombs. The newspaper said Italian secret service investigators had linked the firm to a scandal in which a subsidiary of Ferranti, the British military manufacturer, had received credits from the Atlanta branch of Italy's Banca Nazionale del Lavora to finance Iraqi arms purchases. **********There followed months of confusing instructions from Euromac in Britain on how to ship the capacitors. At first, Mr. Daghir wanted them sent directly to Baghdad, the Iraqi capital. Mr. Supnick refused. Efforts failed to trick the Iraqis into coming to San Diego to inspect and claim the capacitors. **********Ultimately it was agreed that the order would be sent through Britain at the direction of Euromac and Mr. Daghir. Ealier this month, the Iraqis sent the ''end user certificate'' required for exports by the Customs Service. It was issued, falsely, in the name of the University of Technology in Baghdad, which said the capacitors were to be used for a carbon-dioxide laser system at the university's school of applied science. **********American and British Customs officials agreed that after the order arrived in Britain and was claimed by the Iraqis, a shipment of inoperable capacitors would be substituted by British agents. That was done and the arrests were made Wednesday in London.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   Moscow's Maverick With a Purpose
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   Moscow's Maverick With a Purpose
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/world.body_text: **********Boris N. Yeltsin, the virtuoso in the evolving Communist art of campaigning against Communism, is in the thick of it again with a bold election stratagem to craft a shadow presidency for himself, the better to challenge the nation's President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********Mr. Yeltsin, the former Moscow party chief who has become a leader of the Soviet Parliament's opposition, has been roaming the troubled heart of this nation, the Russian republic, campaigning for near-certain victory on Sunday as a candidate for the republic's parliament. **********He hopes to use this as a springboard to be chosen as republic president and chief executive of what he intends to turn into a showcase alternative to Mr. Gorbachev's foundering plan of national renewal. **********''This is a chance to form a core of legislators with a better, far different, more progressive outlook directed at the deeper life of Russia,'' said the ubiquitous politician, who has been pioneering a Western political touch, using his much-sought coattail power to travel around the republic and be photographed with like-minded candidates for their campaign pamphlets. **********Best-Known Candidate **********Delighted, he slaps his palm to symbolize the insurgents' collective handbill and pantomimes pasting the challenge squarely on a campaign wall, beaming as if at the Kremlin wall: Yeltsin redux. **********''I am undergoing personal perestroika,'' he declared with impish ebullience, appropriating Mr. Gorbachev's patented buzzword for change to describe his chesslike move at jumping from Moscow, where is currently a deputy in the national parliament, and challenging Mr. Gorbachev obliquely from the grass-roots. **********Mr. Yeltsin is perhaps the best-known candidate in the elections on Sunday, when the most populous republics, Russia, Byelorussia and the Ukraine, vote for local officeholders and members of republic parliaments. **********Mr. Yeltsin's choice is impressive, for Russia contains three-quarters of the land and almost half the population of the Soviet Union. It also includes more than a fair share of popular unrest over the failed economy and national anxiety over sagging morale. **********A New Flashpoint **********And his timing seems impeccable, for the change of Soviet politics begun by Mr. Gorbachev is fast coming to focus on a struggle for power between the traditional fortress, the central Government, and the separate republics epitomized by Russia, newly awakening to promises of some autonomy. **********Mr. Gorbachev himself has provided a new flashpoint for this issue by demanding the emergency creation of a popularly elected national presidency with greatly increased executive powers, a role tailored to his strategy of shifting his seat of power from the party to the Government. **********Mr. Gorbachev hurriedly moved the measure establishing this proposed presidency through the Supreme Soviet standing legislature this week. But the plan is being denounced by opposition critics, led by Mr. Yeltsin, as a betrayal of perestroika's promise of balanced self-government. **********''We must make Russia and all the republics more independent and at the same time give the center government a good push to become more progressive,'' said Mr. Yeltsin, an avid politician who garnered daredevil fame in 1987 by being cast from the ruling Politburo for criticizing the party establishment, a role he has since honed into an open challenge of his one-time mentor, Mr. Gorbachev. **********'Critical Mass Is Growing' **********''The critical mass is growing,'' said Mr. Yeltsin, who started his move from his old power base in Sverdlovsk, at the nation's working backbone in the Urals, where he first rose from factory worker to party prodigy. **********His strategy is to bring enough insurgents into the Russian parliament to stop the central party's anti-Yeltsin campaign there and guarantee his success in the deputies' election of one of their members as republic president. **********''It's not that I need a higher post,'' protested Mr. Yeltsin, looking delighted after a day at his current job as the unofficial opposition leader in the National Congress of Peoples Deputies. **********It was a day in which Mr. Gorbachev could not resist criticizing his chief antagonist by name for suggesting that some of the nation's many scattered, dispirited Russians, increasingly criticized in other ethnic republics, might want to come home to Mother Russia to create progressive new cities. **********'He Is Getting Very Nervous' **********''So far Mr. Gorbachev cannot easily pronounce the word 'opposition,' '' Mr. Yeltsin said of the Soviet leader's thin-skinned performance in pushing the presidency bill to initial passage. In that confrontation, Mr. Gorbachev dismissed the minority opposition as ''demagogues'' for having questioned his devotion to power sharing. **********''He is getting very nervous,'' said Mr. Yeltsin, who feels that Mr. Gorbachev's pride is getting in the way of democratization. ''I can read between the lines.'' **********The outlook is that Mr. Gorbachev will win approval of his enhanced presidency by mid-March, although Mr. Yeltsin is among those who argue that the alarmed dissenters in the 2,250-member national congress might prove large enough to stop Mr. Gorbachev short of the 1,500 votes he needs. **********If the Soviet leader prevails as usual, Mr. Yeltsin sounds hardly at a strategic loss. He is pointing to the ''last chance'' roundup for the Communist Party to reform itself and renounce its power monopoly in June at the critical party congress. **********And should that fall short? ''Then the party splits,'' said Mr. Yeltsin with a calmness resembling the sweet anticipation of a man who expects to be a kind of president in waiting by then.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/busin.snippet: LEAD: Say goodbye to the 40-slips-and-a-bait-shop days, the time when mom-and-pop marinas contributed a modicum of service to enhance, but not disturb, tranquillity at the water's edge.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/busin.main_headline: Turning Marinas Into the Holiday Inns of the Water.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/busin.print_headline: Turning Marinas Into the Holiday Inns of the Water.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Say goodbye to the 40-slips-and-a-bait-shop days, the time when mom-and-pop marinas contributed a modicum of service to enhance, but not disturb, tranquillity at the water's edge. **********Say goodbye to the 40-slips-and-a-bait-shop days, the time when mom-and-pop marinas contributed a modicum of service to enhance, but not disturb, tranquillity at the water's edge. **********Today marinas are a growth industry, with chains offering not only the predictable places to tie up but also burgers and swimming pools and, amazingly, the occasional tennis court. **********''We've changed marinas from boat garages into resort-oriented type facilities,'' said Charles Collett, president of Nautical Properties Inc. in Georgetown, Md. ''We believe the marina should be a place for people to enjoy, not just a place to keep the boat.'' **********The marina universe is limited, of course. Douglass Norvell, a professor at Western Illinois University in Macomb, Ill., who has written a number of books on the industry, estimates that there are only about 8,000 marinas in the United States. Full-scale operations with 200 or more slips number about 3,000. Subtracting municipal, resort and boat-dealer marinas, there are just 1,000. California-based Westrec Properties Inc., the industry giant, has just 17 marinas (actually 16 with 1 under construction) with capacity for 7,479 boats. **********The industry also faces formidable opposition in the form of environmental interests, fund-raising problems and some heavy skepticism about whether it can ever really be big business. And with the downturn in real estate, particularly in the Northeast and Southwest, the timing does not seem propitious. **********The hunger for marina properties, by saltwater or fresh, started sharpening in earnest in the late 1980's, as Westrec went on a buying spree and prices industrywide skyrocketed. **********The No. 2 company, Marineland, in New York City, boasts 15 marinas and ''dockominiums'' - the slips are on long-term leases. (No. 3 is Brewer Yacht Yards, of Mamaroneck, N.Y., with 11 marinas. Nautical Properties, with 7 marinas and a 1,311-boat capacity is No. 4.) It all adds up to a phenomenon that Neil Ross, president of the International Marina Institute, a nonprofit research and information clearing house, likens to the experience of the lodging industry in the 1950's. That was when lodging shifted from independently owned roadside cabins and courts to motels, like the Howard Johnson and Holiday Inn chains. **********The difference, Mr. Ross says, is that, just as lodging in the 50's could tap an almost unlimited supply of cheap land, so the marina industry, a fledgling, could do as it wished with marshes and swamps, then considered nuisance areas good for little save breeding mosquitoes. But now, those same marshes, swamps and coastal lands are fiercely defended by the government and all sorts of environmental groups. **********The result is that, to expand, marinas are tending toward acquisition, not development. ''You have to buy a chain; you can't build it,'' said Jerold Miles, a Westrec founder. ''New sites are extremely difficult to find. The environmental concerns will delay the project for years and years.'' **********None of this serves to dampen the enthusiasm of such marina visionaries as Bruce Blomgren of Boca Raton, Fla. Mr. Blomgren's Brandy Group has managed more than 25 marinas and waterfront properties over the past 13 years, but his real enthusiasm is poured into efforts to develop his own chain of marinas. **********In 1988, he formed the National Marinas Limited Partnership to raise $30 million for the purchase of marina properties. He only came up with $2 million. Mr. Blomgren blames not the concept, but the marketing; and it didn't help that that his partners had been associated with the scandal-plagued Southmark Corporation of Texas. **********Earlier this year, Mr. Blomgren appeared to have found a safer financial harbor. In January, he formed a partnership with the New York-based LCP Group with ambitious plans to raise up to $30 million and have 20 marinas operating in three years. With the Middle East crisis creating havoc in the financial markets, that plan may prove to be overly optimistic, but Mr. Blomgren's enthusiasm is not likely to disappear. **********Closest to Mr. Blomgren's vision of a great regional marina chain is Nautical Properties, with all seven of its marinas in the Chesapeake Bay area. The marinas have been standardized and loaded up with amenities like swimming pools, tennis courts and picnic pavilions. **********Mr. Collett of Nautical says that if the financing's there, he too wants to expand, acquiring additional properties around Chesapeake Bay, perhaps a project in Cape May, N.J., and eventually, down the coast to Florida. **********''Through the latter part of the 80's, I worked hard to beef up my corporate staff, so we have a team to support our individual marinas,'' Mr. Collett said. ''We've developed our own proprietary software so that we now have one centralized accounting office and I can control the cash flow at every one of my facilities.'' The marina industry, he says, is heading toward regional chains. How do you properly price a marina? Professor Norvell suggests a simple formula: Take the marina's net profit (averaged over a few years), multiply it by 10 and that's a fair price. **********As to what actually happens, Professor Norvell did a statistical analysis a few years ago of 66 Florida marinas that were for sale. Each acre of land was worth $200,000 and each boat slip, whether in the water or dry storage, was worth $9,000, he concluded. The marina permit was worth $1 million. **********For some companies buying marinas, the industry appears to be a logical extension of existing business. Aspen Wind, of Denver, Colo., a boat seller, last year raised about a half-million dollars in a public offering. It wasn't much, but it was enough to plunk down as a downpayment for a $3.1 million marina in Jacksonville, Fla. ''With our boat sales, it seemed like a natural fit,'' says David Nommensen, Aspen's chief executive. ''The economy has basically very little effect on whether or not a person uses his boat. The economy will obviously affect boat sales.'' It's a little harder to divine the rationale of Armada Group Inc. based in Amarillo, Tex., which does oil and gas syndications. It is attempting to raise $3 million to develop a marina on the south shore of Lake Superior and to acquire two marinas in eastern Oklahoma. **********''We are here to build a company,'' explains Larry Heimsoth, Armada's president, who was introduced to marinas by one of his partners. ''We want to become a marina company.'' **********Notable among the skeptics in all the big-business talk is Mr. Miles, an industry veteran who left Westrec to manage Seven Crown Resorts' seven marinas in California and Nevada. He also has a separate company that manages a marina in Arizona. **********''People all of a sudden got the impression marinas were an area where you could make a killing overnight,'' he said. ''They are finding that is not the case.'' **********His perception is that marinas have become just another real estate investment. ''People are buying on the bigger-fool theory,'' he observed. ''It takes a big fool to buy, but a bigger fool will come along and buy it from him.'' **********Others agree. ''A few years ago marinas were listed for sale at a price you couldn't possibly justify to an investor, but there were a lot of investors anyway,'' said Ronald Stroud, a marina consultant in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. ''Now the economy has turned and we have a lot of marinas for sale, but very few investors.'' As is the case with other inflated real estate, prices are coming down. **********Mr. Miles, despite his long commitment to the industry, has begun to doubt whether it's possible to build large chains. ''You can build uniformity from a standpoint of accounting. You can adopt uniform logos, but there is a major difference between a 1,500-slip marina in Atlanta and a 50-slip marina on the waterfront in Houston. Westrec will grow and eventually it may have 40 marinas, but the proposition that there are going to be very many others is not likely.'' Mr. Miles gets a lot of support from Professor Norvell.  Some companies will do well running two or three marinas, he says, but to make it go national there are two big problems: limited supply and the difference in markets. **********''The marina customer who owns a houseboat on Lake Lanier in Georgia and a marina customer that is a charter captain in Key West are two different people,'' said Professor Norvell. ''They don't even speak the same language.'' **********WHAT MAKES A CHAIN? **********The first major move in the formation of a marina chain came from Westrec Properties Inc. in Glendale, Calif. **********The company is an offshoot of Public Storage Inc., an operator of mini-warehouses that. As Peter Nelson, Westrec's chief financial officer, explains, Public Storage was looking for other properties. What it wanted was an industry with low operating costs relative to revenues. **********At first, Mr. Nelson said, Westrec viewed marinas as a simple real estate play. From 1987 to 1989, it raised $88 million from public and private sources for investment. Then it decided to commit to the long term. **********''All of our properties have restaurants, hotels and stores,'' Mr. Nelson said. ''We are really looking at all the revenue generators and trying to make them work and not just rely on boat storage, which is the easy part.'' **********Westrec has ended up with 17 marinas in California, Arizona and Washington. **********Its diversity sets it at odds with some other major marina promoters, including Bruce Blomgren, head of the Brandy Group in Boca Raton, Fla. **********''You can't create a chain unless you have some geographic logic to it,'' Mr. Blomgren says. ''One in Sacramento, one in Dallas and one in Atlanta is a little tough to relate to.'' **********Nevertheless, Westrec is currently scrutinizing properties on both coasts. **********Marketing methods also differ. Mr. Blomgren's plans rest on a sort of ''Holiday Inn concept, which is to give the user a brand name to go after.'' He has no patience with Westrec's ''loose connection of marinas.'' He would stress common advertising, common reservations and a user card that would be good for discounts throughout the chain. **********Mr. Blomgren said the Brandy Group concept is: ''We buy it and it becomes a Brandy marina.'' **********Westrec, by contrast, is taking an approach like that of the Best Western motel chain - each marina retains its distinctive name and the Westrec brand stays discretely in the background.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/busin.main_headline: The Justin Battle: A Waiting Game
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/busin.print_headline: MARKET PLACE; The Justin Battle: A Waiting Game
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/busin.body_text: **********A COUPLE of years ago, the battle for Justin Industries would not have seemed very odd. Now it seems extraordinary. **********Justin, based in Fort Worth, is a small conglomerate with its biggest interests in boots and bricks. It is run by John Justin, a 73-year-old former mayor of Fort Worth who has no desire to sell. **********Mr. Justin is busy fighting a tender offer to buy most of the company's shares at $18 each, well above any price at which Justin has traded. The offer came from a group led by two 32-year-old men, one of them a former aide to Asher B. Edelman, the corporate investor and chairman of the Datapoint Corporation. For much of the financing, they are relying on a commitment from Paine Webber Inc. to sell bonds. **********Before the "junk bond" market collapsed, such deals were common. But the conventional wisdom now is that they cannot be done, a belief that Mr. Justin has emphasized in letters to shareholders. **********Barry S. Rosenstein, the former aide to Mr. Edelman, conceded that the takeover market had changed and that he feels a bit lonely. "We're the only financial tender out there now," he said in an interview. "I feel like a dinosaur." But he said he was confident that financing could be completed. **********In fact, the tender offer, which has been pending since September, is little more than a sideshow. The real battle is likely to come at a shareholders meeting. Perhaps that will be in March, when the 1991 meeting is scheduled to be held. But it could be earlier, since a court may yet order a repeat of the 1990 meeting. **********Last week, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled that Justin had violated securities laws in failing to disclose before the 1990meeting that it had changed its bylaws to make it all but impossible for shareholders to throw out directors between annual meetings. That action, taken in November 1989 as the takeover effort was getting under way, was not disclosed until August. After a flurry of negative publicity, the board reversed its decision in September. Mr. Justin said that the failure to disclose was simply a "technical violation" of little importance. **********But the judges did not order a new meeting; they only told a lower court judge to consider that issue. When the company announced that the court did not order the meeting, the shares promptly fell to as low as $12. But they recovered after the insurgents emphasized that the court was explicit in saying securities laws had been broken. On Monday, the shares closed unchanged, at $13.25 each, in over-the-counter trading. **********Mr. Rosenstein's ally in the takeover attempt is Perry H. Sutherland, whose family controls the privately held Sutherland Lumber Southwest Inc., a Midwest retailer. The two men have acquired an 11.9 percent stake in Justin, just over one million shares, at an average price of more than $14. Mr. Rosenstein said they had spent another $2 million arranging financing and paying various fees, including legal fees. **********While bank financing for most of the purchase seems secure, Paine Webber's "highly confident" letter for subordinated debt gives the firm the option to walk away for a variety of reasons, including "market conditions." But Mr. Rosenstein said that the deal would not be highly leveraged and emphasized that it did not rely on selling major assets of Justin. He said he was confident the money could be raised when needed. **********Mr. Justin dismissed the $18 price as unreasonably low. "It is less than 1.5 times book value, and this company will sell for more than that," he forecast. He said that the Acme Brick business was doing well as the Texas economy started to revive, and that the boot business, based on the Justin, Nocona and Tony Lama brands, was "very good." In the first nine months of the year, Justin reported profits of $4.4 million, or 49 cents a share, on revenues of $208 million. **********The Tony Lama business was bought by Justin after the first approach from Mr. Sutherland and Mr. Rosenstein, and was denounced by them as a "scorched earth" acquisition that had forced them to lower the price they could pay. But Mr. Justin said it was working out well, in part because Tony Lama no longer offers unreasonable credit terms that had "destabilized" the industry. **********The tender offer is unlikely to go anywhere soon, if only because Mr. Justin, his board and his managers control 23 percent of the company, while an employee ownership plan holds 16 percent. That makes it almost impossible for the raiders to assemble the two-thirds of the shares they need to complete the deal. **********But at an annual meeting, the group would only need a majority of the shares voting to replace the board, and Mr. Rosenstein said that goal is possible, although far from assured. **********Anyway, he said, he and Mr. Sutherland are long-term investors who are prepared to wait and fight the battle with Mr. Justin over and over. "He can win 9 of 10 shareholder votes, and we win when we win that one," he said. "We've said to John, 'We've got 40 years on you. We can wait.' " **********That wait, warned Mr. Justin, could be a long one. Although Mr. Rosenstein described Mr. Justin as being "in failing health," Mr. Justin said he was in "as good health as can be" and had no intention of retiring.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/busin.body_text: **********Acting swiftly to capitalize on last week's Federal court ruling giving copyright protection to the set of computer commands used in its popular 1-2-3 spreadsheet program, the Lotus Development Corporation sued two California software companies yesterday, accusing them of copyright infringement. **********In his ruling last week, Judge Robert E. Keeton of Federal District Court in Boston wrote that Paperback Software International had infringed the distinctive command structure of the Lotus spreadsheet. Lotus officials said that they had waited for that court ruling before pursuing publishers that offered products with commands similar to those of Lotus 1-2-3. The suits today named Borland International and the Santa Cruz Operation as defendants. **********The 1-2-3 spreadsheet, which makes possible both simple budget tasks and complex ''what-if'' business models, has become the software industry's best-selling program since it was introduced in 1983. **********''The heart of our suit is that they are not allowed to copy the 1-2-3 menus,'' said Thomas M. Lemberg, Lotus's general counsel. ''It is not a defense to say, 'Gosh, I have a different appearance.' '' **********Borland executives argued that the Lotus suit was without merit because Borland's spreadsheet, Quattro Pro, does not mimic the Lotus command set; rather, it has its own distinctive menu system. However it is possible to configure the Quattro program so that it appears with ''1-2-3-compatible menu tree commands.'' The user must install special files for this option, which is detailed in the Quattro program guide. **********Lotus stock slipped 12.5 cents in Nasdaq trading yesterday, to $34.625 a share, while Borland's stock tumbled $4.375, to $17, as Nasdaq's loss leader. Santa Cruz is privately held. **********A Contentious Issue **********The issue of whether software publishers can copyright the unique appearance and function of their programs has become a contentious one in recent years. Before the advent of personal computers in the early 1980's, most programs running on larger systems had control systems known in industry jargon as ''command line interfaces.'' **********But with the advent of personal computers, programs have acquired elaborate on-screen menu systems to aid people in using programs. Customers who are trained using one program are often unwilling to invest the time to learn a new one. **********At the heart of the dispute over copyright infringement and the protection of intellectual property is a deeper argument over how to insure innovation in the computer industry. **********Some industry executives have argued that the industry leaders' reliance on legal defenses to protect their products from immitators would stall innovation. But others argue that the consequence of the Lotus lawsuit will be to clarify the ground rules under which competition can take place. **********''The uncertainty has been a killer,'' said Esther Dyson, a personal computer industry analyst who publishes Release 1.0, a newsletter. ''This clarifies who does the innovation. I see so many knock-offs of things that are really boring. Now, if developers know they can protect something, they will probably do a better job.'' **********Relief Is Sought **********Borland, of Scotts Valley, Calif., filed suit for declaratory relief in United States District Court in San Jose, Calif., last Friday seeking confirmation that its spreadsheet product does not infringe any Lotus 1-2-3 copyrights. **********Officials of the Santa Cruz Operation, which produces the SCO Professional program, said they would have no comment until they had read the Lotus complaint. **********Philippe Kahn, Borland's president, said that he believed that Lotus had chosen to sue his company because ''we're hurting them in the marketplace.'' **********According to the International Data Corporation, a Framingham, Mass., market research firm, 1-2-3 now has a 52 percent worldwide market share of spreadsheet units shipped for I.B.M. and compatible personal computers, while Quattro has an 8.4 percent market share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/busin.body_text: **********The Chicago Board of Trade acted within ethics rules when it declared an emergency and ordered traders to reduce soybean holdings last July, Congressional investigators said on Tuesday. **********The General Accounting Office was asked to investigate last summer's order to liquidate large stakes in the July futures contract. The controversy centered on Ferruzzi Finanziaria S.p.A., one of the world's largest soybean processors. **********Ferruzzi had gained a huge stake in the soybean contract and traders believed the company's position could lead to price manipulation. **********The board was widely criticized by farmers who saw the value of soybeans drop. They suggested that traders may have secretly learned about the emergency order before it was publicly announced on July 11. **********But the G.A.O. concluded that members of the board who held contracts did not participate in meetings that led to the emergency order. **********Between May 25 and July 11, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission asked Ferruzzi at least 10 times to reduce its large position in July soybean futures voluntarily. The board made the same request at least six times. Ferruzzi refused to honor the requests.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/13/world.body_text: **********For Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, even bad news brings some respite these days. **********Retail prices rose 9.4 percent over the 12 months that ended April 10, the Central Statistical Office reported on Friday. It was the highest rate of increase since the year that ended in May 1982. But since the figure was lower than the 10 percent forecast the previous day by the Bank of England, stock market prices rose on Friday, and the Government maintained that its anti-inflation policies were working. **********The Government has found other silver linings. Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative Party won only 27.9 percent of the vote in the nationwide elections for local councils on May 3. But it took majorities in several important London districts, which encouraged the Prime Minister to believe that her Government had finally turned the corner. **********But victories like these have not ended an incipient revolt by Conservative members of the House of Commons against her leadership of the party, several members of Parliament said in interviews this week. **********Backbench Conservative members of Parliament like Tony Marlow, who describes himself as a Thatcherite, and Barry Porter, also previously regarded as a loyalist, have been saying that it is time for her to make way for someone more popular. **********''The Iron Lady might be susceptible to metal fatigue,'' Mr. Marlow wrote in The Independent newspaper recently. This week he said he saw no reason to reconsider his words after the mixed results in the local elections. **********''Someone more popular'' is generally taken to mean Michael Heseltine, the former Defense Secretary who resigned from Mrs. Thatcher's Cabinet in 1986 after she refused to accept his advice to keep a British helicopter company in European hands rather than let an American company buy it. But as long as Mrs. Thatcher has shown a determination to brook no challenge to her leadership, Mr. Heseltine has not issued one. **********Some people thought he had done so in an article on Thursday in the Times of London. In the column, Mr. Heseltine spelled out ways that the Government could modify one of Mrs. Thatcher's most unpopular measures, the per capita community charge on local government services known as the poll tax. The tax, which is set at the same rate for dukes and dustmen by local government councils, was generally viewed as the cause of the Government's poor showing in the recent vote. **********Mr. Heseltine said he accepted the idea that everybody should pay a fair share of the costs of paving the streets and collecting the garbage, but argued that the tax should be modified so that the rich paid more than the poor. **********Pressed on Thursday night on a television broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation, Mr. Heseltine backed off from an open challenge. ''I think Mrs. Thatcher will lead the party into the next election,'' he said. ''I think the Conservatives will win it. That is my position.'' **********That view is held more firmly at 10 Downing Street, the Prime Minister's office. One official there said that public opinion polls, which had shown the opposition Labor Party leading by more than 20 percent in recent months, had begun to register a shift in support to the Conservatives in April. **********People close to Mrs. Thatcher said that she dismissed the opposition from Mr. Marlow and Mr. Porter as insignificant. A former minister suggested that her view was incorrect and that an open move to challenge her could be expected this summer, or by the autumn at the latest. **********Mrs. Thatcher does not have to call an election until mid-1992, and her close aides say that she will wait for inflation and 15 percent interest rates to decline before she puts her fate to the country. Others speculate that her husband, Denis, now 75 years old, might prevail on her to bow out. **********Both Conservative and Labor members of Parliament agree that public anger over the poll tax is fiercer than any discontent they have seen since Mrs. Thatcher first took office in 1979. **********''The pressure to do something about it will continue,'' one Conservative legislator said. ''I've got to worry about keeping my own seat in the next election, not just getting her re-elected.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/13/busin.main_headline: The Executive Computer;   Where the Libraries Are Leading the Way
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/13/busin.print_headline: The Executive Computer;   Where the Libraries Are Leading the Way
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/13/busin.body_text: **********Companies that are trying to figure out how they will manage the flow of information in the 1990's and beyond might begin their research with a trip to the library - not to take out a book but to study the ways in which libraries are preparing for the 21st century. In the vanguard of information technology, today's librarians are as likely to be experts in work stations, networking, communications protocols, electronic imaging and fiber optics as they are in books and manuscripts. The information technologies and techniques now being explored by libraries are likely to serve as models for businesses in the years to come. **********Information, rather than oil or steel, is likely to become the most precious commercial resource, and the company that can gather, evaluate and synthesize information ahead of its rivals will have a competitive advantage. Technology will also enable workers to collaborate on projects regardless of their physical locations, so the ability to exhange information on data networks is crucial. Libraries have addressed these issues for years. **********''With their mission of organizing information and serving users, libraries are an ideal platform for broad-based technology development and implementation,'' said Lloyd G. Waterhouse, vice president for academic information systems at the International Business Machines Corporation. And Richard M. Helms, I.B.M.'s chief architect for image systems management added, ''Librarians are working with standards ahead of everyone else.'' **********As those standards evolve, industry will be able to take advantage of them in a broad range of areas in information management. The libraries themselves are evolving, too, as computers, mass data storage and information networks erase the physical requirements of storing documents. Whether corporate or public, tomorrow's library will not necessarily be a place to go, some librarians said, but rather a focal point for a variety of services. Such ''libraries without walls'' are beginning to appear in schools and businesses, and the silent, musty stacks are giving way to high-technology centers, available to personal computers everywhere, that offer data, graphics, animated illustrations, video clips, recorded voices and compact-disk quality music. **********In nontechnical terms, ''libraries are getting funky,'' said D.
