Kaye Gapen, dean of the library system at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, echoing an observation made by one of my 10-year-old friends. **********Ms. Gapen is chairman of the steering committee of Informa, a group of academic, corporate, government and public librarians that assembled in Austin, Tex., earlier this month for a conference sponsored by I.B.M. The purpose of the conference was to give the librarians access to the expertise of I.B.M. managers. The conference also provided an opportunity for librarians to tell the company of their strategic needs. While the conference focused on I.B.M. technology, many librarians said they, like their counterparts in the corporate world, must deal with multiple, incompatible systems of hardware and software. The librarians also said they were often called upon to develop seamless computer systems linking many different departments, some of which might have set up their own information centers. **********''Our interests are the same,'' Ms. Gapen said of the academic libraries and the business world. ''They are able to move ahead in some areas because they have more dollars and because their applications are smaller. On the other hand, there is more momentum in the universities.'' She said the University of Wisconsin library system, with five million volumes distributed in 14 libraries, was planning to spend $50 million to $70 million on information systems in the next few years. **********Much of that investment will go into areas of interest to businesses. A major contribution, for example, will be in the definition of standards. Libraries are leading the way in creating the tools that will be used for information access in the years ahead, and businesses will benefit as they copy those standards within their own organizations. **********One area of particular interest is imaging, the general term for making electronic copies of physical documents. Just as some libraries have tens of thousands of older books printed on acidic paper that are now discolored and crumbling to dust, many companies have endless crates and filing cabinets filled with old documents. And just as some industries are buried each day by incoming paper forms and documents, some libraries are running out of room. Paper documents take up valuable space; they are virtually impossible to search with accuracy or speed, and yet they contain information that some day may turn out to be important. **********The problem is a familiar one to executives. Kathleen Wiegner, in a recent issue of Forbes magazine, recounted the story of the movie producer Sam Goldwyn, whose files were overtaking his office. ''Get rid of all this,'' Mr. Goldwyn ordered his secretary. ''I can't,'' she replied. ''Some of those are important papers.'' Mr. Goldwyn answered: ''All right, then. Make a copy of everything before you throw it out.'' **********Libraries cannot throw everything out, of course. To preserve old books and periodicals, libraries for years have transferred images to microfilm or microfiche. That solves the space problem. But those microfilm copies become so brittle and scratched from repeated use that some are unreadable, some librarians said. Another drawback of microfilm is that one needs a specialized machine to use it. Displaying the images on a computer screen would make them available to anyone who has access to a PC. In business, that's practically everyone. **********Libraries are under tremendous pressure to come up with a solution. At the University of Wisconsin, ''20 percent of the two million volumes in our main library are so embrittled that they will be endangered by their next handling,'' Ms. Gapen said. In other words, the books could fall apart the next time someone opens them. But until imaging standards are set that will guarantee that the images will be read by future technologies, libraries are reluctant to commit the vast resources the project will require. **********Optical technology is appealing; entire filing cabinets or shelves of books can be captured on a single compact disk. Because the disks are never physically touched, the image will never degrade. But before such tools can be widely used, standards must be developed in the software used to search and retrieve these images. Another advantage of electronic imaging is that, when coupled with data networks, it will make library resources available far beyond the library's immediate geographic area. Architects, for instance, could study plans in other cities, and in the business world, branch offices would be able to gain access to information regardless of where it physically resides.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/31/busin.body_text: **********Although a law that took effect on April 1 allows employers to hire teen-agers at less than the minimum wage of $3.80 an hour, few of them have elected to go below this level, an initial survey indicates. **********A survey of 167 fast-food restaurants by two university economists found that only three were using the sub-minimum wage, which ranges between $3.35 an hour and $3.80. Most of the restaurants, all part of the Burger King, Kentucky Fried Chicken or Wendy's chains, said they did not think they could attract acceptable workers at the new sub-minimum wage. **********They also expressed concern that paying some young employees less than others would be demoralizing and disruptive -- a criticism that leaders of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations have often leveled at the concept of two-tier pay scales. **********The behavior of the companies is in sharp contrast to the importance President Bush attached to the sub-minimum wage. When Congress passed a bill last year that raised the minimum wage to $3.80 on April 1, 1990, and $4.25 next April 1, Mr. Bush threatened a veto unless a sub-minimum wage was provided for teen-agers. Congress agreed to include that provision for three years. **********The President contended that companies would resist hiring and training disadvantaged teen-agers unless they were allowed to pay less than the new minimum for the first six months of the new worker's employment.  A White House spokesman, Stephen Hart, declined to comment today on the survey, which studied the 167 restaurants in Texas, where many fast-food outlets have historically paid young workers no more than Federal law requires. Fast-food companies had been among the supporters of the separate wage scale for teen-agers.  A Social Role **********Lawrence F. Katz, a Harvard Univerity labor economist, and Alan B. Krueger of Princeton University, the co-authors of the survey, said the response of the fast-food restaurants suggested that the minimum wage played a social role beyond the supply-and-demand laws of economics. The Federal minimum wage has come to be accepted by most employers and employees as a sort of guide to the least that should be paid for the most menial jobs, they added. **********Officials at the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics said they knew of no other study that had attempted to measure the use of the new sub-minimum wage. Indeed, future studies might turn up more use of the sub-minimum wage. But the bureau's wage and employment data tend to confirm the survey's findings. **********Month after month, for example, bureau data show that about 2 percent of the nation's employed workers earn less than the minimum wage, including 6 percent of the 16-to-19-year-old wage group, the one most affected by the sub-minimum wage. This 2 percent receives less than the legal minimum because of loopholes in the law or violations of it. And since April 1, the percentage has not risen. **********The bureau's unemployment data also fails to turn up evidence bearing out the Administration's concern that joblessness would rise among teen-agers without the sub-minimum wage to offset the April 1 rise in the minimum to $3.80 an hour, from $3.35. **********Although few employers appear to have resorted to the sub-minimum wage, the teen-age unemployment rate remained unchanged until late summer. Bureau officials and most private economists attribute the increase not to wage levels, but to the downturn in the national economy.  No Unusual Changes Reported **********Mr. Katz and Mr. Krueger, who presented their survey at the annual conference of the American Economic Association, which ended here today, found that the fast-food outlets they surveyed did not report unusual changes in employment levels and hours worked after the new minimum wage went into effect. **********Nor did they report cutbacks in fringe benefits, although a majority of the employees at fast-food restaurants work part-time and do not qualify for health insurance and other benefits. **********Still, some economists argue that the April 1 increase in the minimum wage put relatively little pressure on employer costs because the minimum had remained at the old level, $3.35 an hour, since 1981, and during that unusually long period many companies found themselves moving their wage scales above the minimum. In this view, the minimum might begin to hurt employers when it rises to $4.25 an hour on April 1. That might prompt more companies to resort to the sub-minimum, which will rise at that time to $3.80 an hour, some economists say.  Little Training Required **********Finally, most people earning only the minimum wage are in retail trades, with a heavy concentration among fast-food outlets. The jobs they occupy usually require only a few days of training to master. The sub-minimum wage provision, on the other hand, allows an employer to pay a teen-ager $3.35 to $3.80 an hour for the first three months on the job, even without offering training. To extend this special pay level pay for an additional three months, training must be involved. **********"The fact there is very little use of the sub-minimum means that employers are not chomping at the bit to train young people and being prevented from doing so by the minimum wage," Mr. Krueger said. **********Sixty of the 167 outlets surveyed had been paying the old minimum of $3.35 an hour and they reported jumping to $3.80 an hour on April 1. Most of the rest had been paying above the old minimum to teen-agers and they generally increased their wages by enough to keep their pay above the new minimum.  Upward Shift for Thousands **********The hourly wages of thousands of people earning just above the minimum shift upward when the minimum does. The Texas survey found this phenomenon and other studies, in the past, have also reported it. **********Mr. Katz and Mr. Krueger selected Texas because it is one of the 25 states that does not have a minimum wage law that could override the national minimum. **********The new sub-minimum wage scale replaces one that had been in existence since 1961 but was limited to full-time students who worked part-time. Studies showed that the only employers to use that wage were universities and movie-theater chains.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/world.main_headline: Israeli Camping Store Offers Tips From Afar
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/world.print_headline: Israeli Camping Store Offers Tips From Afar
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/world.body_text: **********At first glance, it looks like an ordinary camping store stocked with waterproof flashlights, down-filled sleeping bags and 12 brands of bug spray. But a schedule on the front window gives a hint of the shop's larger purpose. **********''Weekly advice to travelers to the Far East, Tuesdays, 4 P.M. - Free,'' it says. South American travelers, it says, should come ''Sundays at 4.'' **********Inside, a lecture is under way. Avi Lugassi, who has just returned from a trip in which he backpacked in India and Nepal, is offering advice to about two dozen young men and women sitting on the floor under the hiking-boot display. All of them are about 21 or 22 years old, meaning they have just been released from the army. **********As Mr. Lugassi talks about the importance of taking water purifiers and diarrhea pills - ''If you ever have to go into a Nepalese pharmacy, you'll understand why,'' he said - many of the young people look through loose-leaf notebooks holding thousands of handwritten letters from other young Israeli adventurers who have written back to the store with bits of travel advice. **********Looking over it all, the owner, Yuval Limon, 33, said ''A system like this could only work in Israel.'' **********Each year, more than 60,000 young Israelis pass through Mr. Limon's store. They listen to lectures and look through the notebooks, preparing for the trip to far reaches of the third world that has come to be a unique national ritual for Israeli youths just out of the army. **********Virtually all young people enter the army as soon as they enter high school and often come out several years later changed men and women. **********''All of us have to be in the army, and when we come out it has been very rough,'' Mr. Limon said. Many 19-year-olds are thrown into the occupied territories, fighting the Palestinian uprising, or into Southern Lebanon, where they find themselves in gun battles with Palestinian guerrillas. **********''You see blood, sometimes death,'' Mr. Limon said. ''When you get out, you have to get away.'' **********Mr. Limon suggests that many Israelis are not immediately driven by ambition into jobs since the socialist structure of this state makes incomes and living standards comparatively uniform. **********Instead of immediately jumping onto the professional ladder, tens of thousands of Israelis strap on backpacks and set off for India, Asia, South America or other places where travel is cheap. **********As a result, it is not at all uncommon to hike through a tiny Burmese village, for example, and find a restaurant menu written in Hebrew. And travelers to such places often report that the residents tell them they believe Israel must be the world's second largest nation, given the unusually high number of visitors. Only Germans seem to visit the third world more. **********Letters With Travel Advice **********Those remote places are seldom mentioned in formal travel guides. That is why Mr. Limon started what he calls the institute in his store. Israel's young travelers, thousands of them a year, are compiling an ever-evolving, Hebrew record for other young Israelis of the world's least-frequented travel spots. **********Before leaving, they spend hours in the store reading the letters and getting valuable advice. In the Burmese capital, one letter says, ''The driver in carriage No. 40 speaks good English.'' In the United States, says another, ''Be sure to join the American Automobile Association so you can get their travel 'Triptiks.' '' **********''The knowledge in these notebooks you could never find anyplace else,'' Mr. Limon said. Clearly, the store's services are not a purely altruistic enterprise. Although the lectures are free, and there is no charge for consulting the letters, many of the young people end up buying their camping gear from Mr. Limon's store, too. **********''We like to give people the keys,'' Mr. Limon said. ''In Israel, we are living something like the Vietnam War all the time. If you live in Israel, you've just got to get away sometime. You've got to get out and take a big breath.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/11/world.main_headline: Shiite Leader Said to Back Moves to Free Hostages
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/11/world.print_headline: Shiite Leader Said to Back Moves to Free Hostages
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/11/world.body_text: **********A key Lebanese Shiite Muslim leader said in remarks published today that he was ''encouraging elements'' that may lead to the release of Westerners taken hostage in Lebanon. **********Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, spiritual leader of the pro-Iran Party of God, had been asked by the Beirut newspaper Al Liwa if he thought the hostages would be released in 1990. **********''We believe there are encouraging elements regarding readiness to deal with the issue,'' he responded. **********On Feb. 23, after returning from a trip to Iran, Sheik Fadlallah had called for ''realistic and humanitarian means to free the hostages.'' The Party of God is believed to be an umbrella for groups holding some of the 18 Western hostages. **********Sheik Fadlallah's remarks were reported as an Iranian newspaper asserted that the American press was conducting a ''media blitz'' on the hostages to prepare the American public for a military mission to free them. **********The Iranian newspaper Kayhan International said in an editorial that an American military rescue mission involving Israel would ''end the so-called crisis with the death of at least the American hostages.'' **********The newspaper cited no source or facts to back its assertions. **********Kayhan International, which is often at odds with President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran, said, ''If the U.S. and Israel embark on military adventurism, the hostages will in fact be a pretext for crippling the Islamic movement.'' **********President Rafsanjani said earlier this week that the hostage issue was nearing a solution, and recent editorials in The Teheran Times have also said the hostages were near release. **********Kayhan's editorial today said the American press was focusing on the hostages in an effort to evaluate the reaction of Iranian officials and to put humanitarian pressure on Iran. **********It said another reason for the American ''hostage propaganda'' was aimed at positioning American companies to take part in rebuilding Iran. **********The newspaper said the reports on the hostages were part of ''a media blitz designed to create activity and certain conditions that at present are non-existent.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/21/busin.main_headline: Robert Mondavi Gives Winery Reins to Sons
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/21/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Robert Mondavi Gives Winery Reins to Sons
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/21/busin.body_text: **********Robert Mondavi, the man most often credited with putting California wines on the world map, said yesterday that he was turning over his executive responsibilities at the winery that bears his name to his sons, Michael and Tim. **********"At 77, the time has come for me to pursue my interests in wine and culture," Mr. Mondavi said in a statement. "Having worked with Michael, Tim, Marcia and our staff for the last 25 years, I feel very positive about this transition, which limits my direct involvement to serving as chairman of our board." Marcia Mondavi Borger, Mr. Mondavi's daughter, lives in New York City, where she heads the winery's East Coast marketing. **********The Robert Mondavi Winery was founded in 1966 in the Napa Valley after Mr. Mondavi left the Charles Krug Winery in a dispute with his brother Peter. From the beginning he was a tireless evangelist for California wines, promoting his own products as the equal of the best that France could offer at a time when most California vintners produced nondescript generics. **********Perhaps his ultimate vindication was Opus One, a joint venture initiated by the late Baron Philippe de Rothschild of Bordeaux to produce premium red wine in the Napa Valley. **********"He has probably been the most important figure in the wine industry in the last half of this century," said Paul Gillette, publisher of The Wine Investor, an industry newsletter. **********Though an aggressive competitor, Mr. Mondavi is well regarded by other wine makers because so many of his efforts promoted the industry as a whole. "He always sought to enlarge the pie rather than enlarge his piece at the expense of others," Mr. Gillette said. **********Most recently, he has mounted what he calls his "mission," a panel of doctors, clergy and educators that seeks to highlight wine's positive role in modern culture and defend the industry against the anti-alcohol lobby. While Ernest Gallo, the reclusive co-owner of the E.&J. Gallo Winery, the nation's largest, quietly urged wine makers to take a low profile rather thanface possible product liability suits, Mr. Mondavi spoke out in person and in labels on every bottle. **********Wine is "the temperate, sacred, romantic mealtime beverage recommended in the Bible," Mr. Mondavi once said in an interview. "It's a liquid food that has been praised for centuries by rulers, philosophers, physicians, priests and poets for life, health and happiness." **********R. Michael Mondavi, who is 47, and Timothy J. Mondavi, 39, have been named managing directors and will act jointly as chief executive. The two have been managing partners, with Michael having primary responsibility for administration and marketing, and Tim serving as winegrower, with responsibility for managing vineyards and wine making. **********If anything, the winery will become even more outspoken under the second generation's management, Michael Mondavi said in a telephone interview. "The industry can't just make no comment when people talk about the negative aspects of wine," he said. "We need to constantly talk about wine's proper, moderate use." **********Michael Mondavi began at the winery at its founding as vice president for production. He was responsible for wine making until 1974; from 1969 to 1978, he was also vice president of sales. Michael Mondavi is also the most recent past chairman of the Wine Institute, the California wine industry's lobbying organization. **********Tim Mondavi began working in the cellar and the lab at Robert Mondavi Winery while a student at the University of California at Davis, where he received his bachelor's degree in enology and viticulture in 1974. He became executive vice president in charge of production in 1975, and in 1976 was named the wine maker. In 1984 he became president of vineyard operations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/05/busin.main_headline: Seidman Vows to Set His Own Exit Date
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/05/busin.print_headline: Seidman Vows to Set His Own Exit Date
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/05/busin.body_text: **********The unusual public negotiations between L. William Seidman and the White House continued today, with the manager of the savings and loan bailout insisting that he would pick the time of his departure. **********In his first extensive public comments on the question, Mr. Seidman said that President Bush ''did not ask me to leave'' and ''did not encourage me to leave'' and that the timing ''is truly my decision.'' **********The remarks, seen as an attempt by Mr. Seidman to maintain his dignity while not defying the President, capped a week in which comments by White House officials and President Bush himself made it clear that the Administration would like Mr. Seidman to leave well before his term ends in October 1991. **********Mr. Seidman's comments came after his appearance before a House Banking Committee panel on the savings and loan bailout. As chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, he is also chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created by Congress to administer the bailout and spend at least $50 billion over the next two years. **********The F.D.I.C. chief, who is highly regarded in Congress both for his skill as a banking regulator and his candor about the size of the savings crisis, has frequently clashed with top officials at the Treasury and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff. Industry experts say Mr. Sununu and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady are leading the effort to force Mr. Seidman out. **********Mr. Seidman has been a thorn in the side of the Administration for some time. During talks over the bailout legislation, Mr. Seidman broke with the Administration by seeking added powers for his agency. In addition, he persuaded Congress to approve a measure that would prevent the President from arbitrarily removing the head of the F.D.I.C. Mr. Seidman has also been outspoken in saying that the Administration's estimates of the bailout's costs are low and that Treasury officials have intervened excessively in the day-to-day running of the bailout. **********On Thursday, President Bush, in an attempt to mute Congressional and industry criticism of the White House's increasing pressure on Mr. Seidman, both praised him and made his departure final by saying that he heartily agreed with Mr. Seidman's recommendation that his successor be the Federal Reserve Board's chief banking regulator, William Taylor. Mr. Taylor is on loan from the Fed to serve as chief executive of the oversight board of the Resolution Trust Corporation. **********Mr. Seidman said today that he would remain at least until the end of June, a date he has set to complete a plan by the trust corporation to sell or liquidate 141 ailing institutions at a cost to the public of almost $57 billion. But Mr. Seidman left open the possibility that he might stay longer. **********''President Bush did not speed up my decision,'' he said. ''I have been saying for several months that I planned to leave once the R.T.C. is up and running,'' but he added that he would decide when that time is. **********Until the so-called June 30 project is completed, he said, ''I will not think about what I am going to do.'' **********Praise From Panel Members **********In Mr. Seidman's appearance before the House panel, which has in the past received him warmly, the tone was somber. **********''One of the bright spots in this whole mess has been Mr. Seidman,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat from Brooklyn. ''The Administration should be on its hand and knees begging you to stay.'' **********Mr. Seidman cautioned the lawmakers against expecting quick results from the savings and loan rescue, saying that even a year from now the end will not be in sight. **********''Don't be impatient,'' he told lawmakers with a hint of nostalgia. ''This is a long, hard job. It isn't going to be accomplished anytime soon.'' **********Warning on Interest Rates **********Mr. Seidman pointed to a recent rise in interest rates as a double threat. **********First, the increased borrowings by the Treasury that are needed to finance the rescue push up interest rates, putting pressure on consumers and the economy. Then, higher interest rates generally translate into lower real estate values, which increases the bailout's cost to the taxpayer. **********''The real pain of what is taking place, on everything from increased Government borrowing to the effect on real estate markets, is still being felt,'' Mr. Seidman said. ''I think it is very important that no one expect by this time next year we'll all feel great.'' **********As he has in the past, Mr. Seidman stressed that the losses in the savings and loan industry, which are increasing at a rate of $28 million a day, will not be stemmed until all the real estate acquired by Resolution Trust has been sold to the private sector. **********Price Cutting Is Planned **********To speed up asset sales, the agency has significantly liberalized its sales guidelines to allow considerable markdowns on property that is not selling well. **********He reiterated that the bailout was almost certain to cost more than the Bush Administration has predicted. He took exception, however, to the estimates by Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher, who last month said the cost of the bailout, plus interest expenses on the borrowings, could be as much as $500 billion during a 30-year period. **********''It's like buying a $100,000 house and saying that it really is $300,000 because you are taking out a mortgage on it,'' Mr. Seidman said. **********At the hearing, lawmakers lavished praise on the F.D.I.C. chairman, gave cautious support to Mr. Taylor and asked Mr. Seidman what advice he had for Mr. Taylor. **********''The first thing I'd say is take a hard look before accepting the job,'' he said. ''And don't expect a lot of praise.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/13/world.main_headline: Unrest Reported in Muslim Areas of China; Foreigners Are Barred
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/13/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Unrest Reported in Muslim Areas of China; Foreigners Are Barred
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/13/world.body_text: **********Reports of unrest in Muslim areas of western China and of a ban on visits by foreigners to the area continued to circulate today, but the Foreign Ministry declined to comment. **********The reports of clashes come principally from foreign travelers who were not themselves witnesses. The descriptions are sketchy, but the Foreign Ministry seemed to give them additional credibility by failing to label them ''groundless,'' as it periodically describes Western reports about news in China. **********At the weekly news briefing, the Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, Li Jinhua, repeatedly evaded questions about the situation in Xinjiang. She said that she did not understand the situation there, and that in any case it was not the Foreign Ministry's responsibility to respond to queries about China's internal affairs. She said she did not know who could respond to such questions. **********There have been some reports of deaths, although it is not clear how reliable these are. In addition, troops are believed to have been sent to the area of the disturbances, around the legendary silk road city of Kashgar, not far from the border with Afghanistan and the Soviet Union. **********Increasingly Warm Relations **********For several months foreign correspondents have been refused permission to visit Kashgar, and now they are also turned away even from the provincial capital, Urumqi. Tourists and all other foreigners have also been banned from the area since last weekend, and so there is no dependable source of information about the unrest. **********Xinjiang Province, formally known as the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, has a large population of ethnic minorities including Uygurs, Kazakhs, Kirghizians, Tadzhiks, Uzbeks and others. Many are Muslims who have been enjoying increasingly warm relations with members of the same ethnic groups who live across the border in the Soviet Union. **********A European diplomat said the reports of disturbances in Muslim areas were of particular concern to China in the period leading up to the Asian Games, which will be held in Beijing in September. China has staked its prestige on the games, and on the willingness of Asian nations to take part despite the military crackdown last year. **********Ethnic Unrest and Protests **********With China's ties to the West now strained, its relations with various Islamic countries including Pakistan and Iran are more important than ever, yet the warmth of their friendship and their enthusiasm about participation in the Asian Games might be tested if China were thought to be repressing its Muslim population. **********China has already has experienced ethnic unrest and separatist demonstrations in Tibet. But Tibet is remote and isolated and by denying most foreigners permission to go there - and by maintaining martial law for more than a year in the Tibetan capital, Lhasa - China appears to have restored an uneasy peace as well as maintained a mostly successful news blackout about events in Tibet. Xinjiang is not quite so remote, and repression there would complicate relations with China's neighbors. **********''There's extra tension in Xinjiang every spring,'' said a diplomat from a country adjacent to China. ''But this year it's much worse than normal.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/11/busin.body_text: **********FASHIONABLE organizations today are flattening their hierarchies, streamlining operations and using the word "empower" a lot. The most adventurous increasingly rely on information technology to reshape themselves. They buy into the idea that network technologies will let them become lean and mean so they can do more work with fewer people. **********Unfortunately, the network to organizational hell is wired with good intentions. Many companies are learning the hard way that their networks are designed in ways that virtually guarantee the waste of money and time. **********We need to build tools, technologies and network environments that encourage productive relationships, not just productive individuals. Our design inspirations should be collaborative relationships like the Wright Brothers, Watson and Crick, who discovered the double helix shape of DNA, and Hewlett and Packard, the electronics pioneers. These collaborators succeeded not just because they were smart and dedicated but because they built and used their own collaborative tools -- models and prototypes. Unfortunately, most networks are designed with the goal of exchanging mail and messages rather than creating shared space where people can collaborate. **********It is the difference between infrastructure and architecture. Infrastructure means you have a resource; architecture means you have a design purpose. Today's networks are more like information pipes or data highways than places that people would want to live in every day of their working lives. No one doubts that the physical layout of an office plays a role in shaping how people interact. That's equally true for network architectures. Organizational networks need Frank Lloyd Wrights who are more concerned with the relationships these technologies create than in the information they carry. **********These architects don't yet exist but there are organizations that are exploring the relationship-driven -- as opposed to the data-driven -- approach to technology. Xerox PARC has its CoLab -- a meeting room where participants have their own computers linked to a giant screen. The screen serves as a shared space where ideas can be batted about. People can see and shape the flow of the meeting before their eyes. Similarly, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, a subsidiary of General Motors, has enjoyed great success with its Capture Lab in Ann Arbor, Mich. **********The difficult questions have little to do with technology and everything to do with how organizations choose to define themselves. The technology becomes a medium of organizational design. Organizations and the people who work in them would be a lot better off if they spent a little more time and thought about what really matters to them. Certainly, information matters. Quality relationships -- relationships that generate innovations and ideas -- matter more. **********Great collaborations have transformed the arts, sciences and business. Our network architectures should reflect that.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/03/busin.main_headline: German Company to Buy Fireman's Fund
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/03/busin.print_headline: German Company to Buy Fireman's Fund
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/03/busin.body_text: **********Allianz A.G., Europe's largest insurance company, announced yesterday that it would buy the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, the American property and casualty insurer, for $3.3 billion in cash. **********Fireman's Fund is the main subsidiary of the Fund American Companies, a holding company based in Greenwich Conn., and had premiums in 1989 totaling $3.2 billion. **********The deal, which has a number of conditions, would be one of the last big steps in Allianz's strategy to build a worldwide insurance network, people involved said. The company's European acquisitions in the last decade have made it the largest insurer in Europe, but it has not made any inroads into the American market. **********''This deal sort of completes the strategic global presence that Allianz has been seeking,'' said Dennis S. Hersch, a partner with Davis, Polk & Wardwell who worked on the agreement. **********The deal, which is subject to approval by Fund American shareholders as well as a number of state insurance commissioners, would also benefit the shareholders of the company, whose stock has recently been at levels close to what it was when the company went public in 1985. **********'A Little Victory' **********Referring to shareholders, John J. Byrne, the chairman of Fund American, said: ''My owners have been very patient.'' He added: ''This is a matter of great pleasure to hand those patient owners a little victory.'' **********After the complex deal is completed, Allianz, based in Munich, will acquire only the insurance operations of Fireman's Fund. After receiving the $3.3 billion, Fund American will pay Fireman's Fund, now owned by Allianz, $2.2 billion in cash for part of its investment portfolio, as well as for the mortgage company and other long-term investments. **********People who helped structure the deal said that the buyback of those assets was the result of discomfort on the part of Allianz with the equity holdings, as well as a lack of familiarity with the mortgage business. **********''Germans are risk-averse investors,'' one person involved in the agreement said. ''The portfolio consists of a large quantity of common stocks, and the German philosophy is to invest in debt securities.'' **********As a result of the transaction, Allianz will be able to use the cash to redirect the investment strategy of its new subsidiary. **********Win Some, Lose Some **********But the equities are of substantial value. As of May 31, which was chosen as the date to judge the value of the portfolio, the company held about $1.45 billion in common stocks and other securities. But company officials said a large percentage of those securities were in energy-related companies that experienced a rapid run-up in share price yesterday as a result of the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq. **********''Well, you win some, you lose some,'' Mr. Byrne, 57, said of the increase in the portfolio's value. **********As part of the deal, Fund American will also pay $434 million to repurchase the 300,000 shares of preferred stock held by Infint S.A., a Luxembourg corporation. **********The American Express Company, which once owned Fireman's Fund, will not sell the 342 million preferred shares it holds in Fund American as part of the deal, a spokesman for American Express said. **********The deal will leave Fund American with hundreds of millions of dollars in cash. Company officials said that after the acquisition is completed, Fund American planned either to buy back its shares, or to distribute cash to its shareholders in an amount estimated to exceed $800 million. **********After the distribution is completed, Fund American said that it expects to liquidate its remaining assets over three to five years. The top management of Fireman's Fund will continue to work with the insurer after the deal is completed. **********A Lengthy History **********The history of yesterday's agreement, which is expected to close in January, is lengthy. The management of Fireman's Fund, American Express and Allianz first held conversations about a possible purchase of the insurer by Allianz six years ago when American Express owned the company. Those talks, however, fell apart. **********Despite the public offering, American Express remained close with Fund American. James D. Robinson 3d, the chairman and chief executive of American Express, serves as an adviser to the board of Fund American, and Howard L. Clark Jr., the chairman and chief executive of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. serves on the board. **********By early June, executives at Lehman Brothers, the investment banking division of Shearson, thought that Allianz was ready to talk again, and approached Mr. Byrne about discussing a possible deal. ''Lehman Brothers gets the credit for getting us back together again,'' Mr. Byrne said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/busin.main_headline: Company News;   Court Backs Nintendo on Video-Game Suits
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/busin.print_headline: Company News;   Court Backs Nintendo on Video-Game Suits
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/busin.body_text: **********A Federal appeals court has ruled that Nintendo of America Inc. may sue retailers who buy unauthorized Nintendo video games from its competitors, strengthening Nintendo's dominant position in the industry. **********The decision goes to the heart of Nintendo's strategy of tightly controlling the quality of its video games as well as the supply. Nintendo game cartridges, which sell for $23 to $45 each, are some of the best-selling items in the toy business. Such leading retailers as Toys ''R'' Us and Wal-Mart Stores Inc. once carried unsanctioned games for Nintendo, but the company's lawyers successfully persuaded them to withdraw the products before filing a lawsuit. **********Nintendo, based in Redmond, Wash., had more than 80 percent of the $3.4 billion video-game business last year. **********The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington made the decision on March 7, but it was disclosed yesterday. The court voided a preliminary injunction stopping Nintendo from suing retailers for patent infringement when they carried unsanctioned games. **********The injunction stems from a lawsuit charging Nintendo with monopolistic practices. It was filed in December 1988 by the Atari Games Corporation, an arcade-game developer in Milpitas, Calif. In February 1989, Atari Games persuaded a Federal court in San Francisco to grant the injunction. **********Nintendo had developed a security system consisting of a ''master'' computer chip in the Nintendo game deck and a ''slave'' chip in the game cartridge inserted into the deck. Without both, the game cannot be played. But Atari Games developed a way to circumvent the Nintendo system, making possible the development of unsanctioned games. **********In its decision, the appeals court said that patents, like Nintendo's on its video games, were presumed to be valid and that the San Francisco court had erred in granting the injunction to Atari Games. **********The Atari Games lawsuit is scheduled for trial in the spring of 1991. Although Atari Games has not yet decided whether to appeal the appeals court ruling, it hinted at more litigation. Dennis Wood, the company's senior vice president, said the lifting of the injunction also allowed Atari Games to sue retailers carrying cartridges that infringed its own patents. **********Atari Games, a private company, and the Atari Corporation, a publicly traded home-computer maker based in Sunnyvale, Calif., are successor companies to Atari Inc., the maker of video games in the early 1980's. They are not affiliated with each other.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/16/world.main_headline: Outcry Over Visits From South Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/16/world.print_headline: Outcry Over Visits From South Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/16/world.body_text: **********Administration officials said today that they were considering ways to revise the schedule for the White House visits of President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa and Nelson Mandela because of protests that Mr. de Klerk's visit comes first. **********Officials said on Monday that the tentative schedule for the two groundbreaking visits had Mr. de Klerk coming to see President Bush on June 18 and Mr. Mandela, the leader of the African National Congress, on June 25. **********There was a sharp outcry from the planners of Mr. Mandela's trip to the United States, from June 20 to 30. They said scheduling Mr. de Klerk's visit before Mr. Mandela's was an insult to the 71-year-old black leader, who spent 27 1/2 years in prison. Indeed, they argued, Mr. de Klerk should not be allowed to come at all until he had made what they termed substantive progress toward ending apartheid. **********'It's Not Too Late' **********''It is a slap on the face,'' said Mendi Msimang, the African National Congress representative to Britain, who spoke at a news conference today giving the agenda for the Mandela visit. ''It is not too late for the Administration to take corrective measures.'' **********The Rev. Jesse Jackson pointed out that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d visited Mr. de Klerk in Cape Town in March despite Mr. Mandela's request that he not go. By inviting Mr. de Klerk to Washington, the civil rights leader said, Mr. Bush has ''given the apartheid regime a level of credibility that brings it back into the family of nations before apartheid ends.'' With Mr. de Klerk's visit first, Mr. Jackson argued, Mr. Mandela would spend his trip ''on the defensive answering the initiatives and gestures of de Klerk.'' **********But Ibrahim Gassama, the legislative director of TransAfrica, a planner of Mr. Mandela's visit, said that ''it is not just a question of sequence.'' **********''It is symbolically bad to have our President meeting with the head of an apartheid state,'' he said. ''There are still troops in the townships. The fundamental laws of apartheid are still on the books. The invitation is not justifiable by any means.'' **********Sandra Hill, the head of a coalition of anti-apartheid groups in Washington, said today that the groups would stage protests and try to rally support to force the White House to cancel the visit of Mr. de Klerk. **********Administration officials, who said the order of the trips had been decided simply by available dates and not by a desire to promote one leader over the other, said there was no chance of Mr. de Klerk's visit being canceled. President Bush decided on Feb. 1 to invite both men to the White House, as a way to encourage Mr. de Klerk to release Mr. Mandela from prison. **********An Attempt to Spur Talks **********After Mr. Mandela was released, the President extended the invitations, hoping to spur the talks between the two men to give political rights to South Africa's disfranchised black majority. **********''The protests of the A.N.C. and others compels us to discuss whether we should change the sequence of the visits,'' an Administration official said. ''But nothing has been set in concrete, and the dates might be switched for both. There's still a possibility that Mandela might come before de Klerk.'' **********But the official added that there was a strong possibility that the dates would be left where they were, since the White House felt that the anti-apartheid groups would protest Mr. de Klerk's visit no matter when it came. **********At the African National Congress news conference, the schedule of Mr. Mandela's 10-day trip was laid out. He will appeal to Americans ''to maintain the sanctions and intensify the sanctions,'' said Tebogo Mafole, the A.N.C. representative at the United Nations. **********He will receive a ticker tape parade in New York City, address a joint meeting of Congress, attend a gala held by the entertainment community in Los Angeles, receive an honorary degree in Atlanta from a consortium of black colleges, speak to trade unionists and meet with heads of American corporations to talk about their investment policies in South Africa. **********At the invitation of Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, Mr. Mandela will also visit the John F. Kennedy Library in Boston.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/09/busin.main_headline: Cable Bill Faces Hurdles, Despite Panel Approval
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/09/busin.print_headline: Cable Bill Faces Hurdles, Despite Panel Approval
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/09/busin.body_text: **********The likelihood that the cable television industry will undergo some form of re-regulation gained momentum this week as the Senate Commerce Committee approved a bill that would let the Federal Communications Commission set guidelines on the fees cable subscribers pay to receive broadcast and public access channels. **********The House of Representatives is scheduled to mark up its own draft of a re-regulation bill at the end of the month. **********Nevertheless, re-regulation faces some big hurdles, making passage of legislation this year uncertain. On Thursday, the National Cable Television Association said it would oppose the Senate's bill, which cleared the committee in an 18-to-1 vote on Thursday, because of its treatment of a key issue. **********Disagreement Develops **********James Mooney, the association's president, said the industry opposed the bill's requirement that cable system operators that also own programming services make their programs available to rival systems. **********Mr. Mooney contended yesterday that the bill did not reflect the industry's agreement with the Commerce Committee to allow companies like Time Warner Inc, which owns the Home Box Office programming service and also owns cable systems, to make exclusive distribution agreements with rival systems. **********Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, said the industry had sought special antitrust exemptions at the last moment. **********The Senate measure leaves open how programmers would charge rival services. **********Other factors also make passage of the legislation this year uncertain. The Senate committee agreed yesterday to have Senator Conrad Burns, Republican of Montana, hold hearings on a separate bill that would let telephone companies enter the cable industry. **********The move creates a situation in which the two bills could knock each other out, a telephone industry spokesman said. 30 Working Days Left All this comes when Congress has only 30 working days left before taking August off and adjourning early for elections. With so little time, it is uncertain whether either the House or Senate bill could be passed, and if both pass, whether they could be reconciled. **********Last month, a draft of the House's version of a bill to re-regulate the industry, which was deregulated in 1984, was disclosed. The House version was viewed as less objectionable to the industry than the Senate measure. **********Gene Kimmelman, legislative director for the Consumer Federation of America, said that the cable industry's decision yesterday to back out of the agreement had cost it some good will. **********Recently the industry, whose stocks had been battered by fears of re-regulation, agreed to compromise on re-regulation provided it did not face extensive fee reglation and the entry of the telephone companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/20/world.main_headline: Haiti Leader Faces Task Of Controlling Military
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/20/world.print_headline: Haiti Leader Faces Task Of Controlling Military
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/20/world.body_text: **********Since he was overwhelmingly chosen as Haiti's first democratically elected President last Sunday, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide has maintained strict public silence, gathering advice from his closest confidants as he awaits final election results that could be as far as a week away. **********While they await details of the 37-year-old priest's plans for governing, however, there is an emerging consensus among Haitian and foreign political analysts here on the challenges that the politically inexperienced Roman Catholic priest will soon face. **********First and foremost, many feel, will be asserting his control on an army that has proven stubbornly resistant to change as it clung to power for most of the nearly five years since the dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier fled the country in the face of a popular uprising early in 1986. **********Although the army exhibited strict neutrality during the election and has pledged to stay out of politics in the future, Father Aristide must quickly make good on his central campaign promise of "justice" by arresting several longtime leaders of the Tontons Macoute, the Duvalier family's feared militia of red-kerchiefed enforcers.  'First Thing He Has to Do' **********"The first thing he has to do is arrest some of these people and bring them to trial," a Haitian political scientist who spoke on the condition of anonymity said. "If he doesn't succeed in doing that, then he has really failed. And this is something he will have to do in the first week, not in the first 100 days." **********Father Aristide, who had long been a boldly outspoken enemy of the Duvalier dictatorships and the system of repression that followed the deposed rulers, entered the presidential race only after the return from exile and attempted candidacy of Roger Lafontant, a widely feared former Interior Minister under the deposed dictatorship. The current provisional Government of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot never executed a warrant for Mr. Lafontant's arrest on charges of treason. **********"The Duvalierists ruled this country twice as long as the Nazis ruled Germany," a foreign diplomat said, explaining the failure of the military to arrest Mr. Lafontant and other Tontons Macoute. "It is not easy for the army to bring itself to confrontation with them. There is a whole complex web of ties, from money spent here and there to long, compromised histories together that discourage them from acting." **********If the army command should balk at Father Aristide's order to arrest leading Duvalierist figures, the new President would be faced with his first serious crisis. **********A possible response would be to call the people into the streets to rout the Duvalierists. This violent purging first occurred after the fall of the Duvaliers, and was repeated after an attack on Father Aristide's congregation in 1988 in which 13 worshipers were killed.  Risk of Alienating U.S. **********Diplomats say, however, that a strategy akin to officially encouraged lynching would quickly bring international condemnation and end any fragile honeymoon that the President-elect may have won with the Haitian elite. It would also risk alienating foreign donors, including the United States. **********Father Aristide -- with what many feel is strong support among enlisted men, who share the same background of poverty as his most ardent followers, and a grudging respect for the group of mid-level officers who oversaw the election process -- might simply retire the senior officers who are products of Duvalierism. **********While diplomats here are not encouraging such a restructuring of the 7,000-man army, they say that as long as the rule of law is upheld and human rights are respected, the vocal disapproval of the United States and other major foreign partners of military coups makes a senior officer-led action against Father Aristide unlikely anytime soon. **********If arresting villains from past Governments provides a quick and relatively inexpensive way to sustain the enthusiasm in economic matters of those who elected him, experts say Father Aristide's task of bringing tangible improvements will be much slower.  Public Services Collapsing **********Since the departure of Jean-Claude Duvalier in 1986, Haiti's official economy has barely grown, and public services, never robust, have all but collapsed, giving way to widespread decay and corruption. **********"Nobody here is paying any taxes," said Leopold Berlanger Jr., president of a Haitian development institute. "Before they can do anything else, the Government is going to need some income." **********Fther Aristide's official campaign documents advocate a mixture of cooperative-style reorganization of the peasantry, streamlining but not privatization of state-owned corporations, with an emphasis on eliminating featherbedding and graft, and protection for important industries. **********Because of his commitment to protectionism, many analysts say a growing number of influential Haitian industrialists and entrepreneurs are willing to give the new leader a chance. **********"Most of the industrialists have already been reassured, except for those who will never agree with us," said George Anglade, a Haitian geographer at the University of Quebec who has rallied to the new leader's inner circle. "They know that it is time to stop the crony-capitalism, start paying taxes and make a break with the kind of business that depends on who you know." **********Even before any tax-collection effort can bear fruit, however, the new Government will be confronted with the problem of paying monthly petroleum bills of about $8 million. To avoid disruptions of supplies during the runup to Sunday's elections, the United States and other countries covered the costs of importing oil with low-interest loans and cash donations.  Currency May be Devalued **********To come up with the necessary hard currency, several Western diplomats said, the new Government will face the unpopular task of devaluing the local currency, the gourde, which has long been pegged to the dollar at a rate of five to one, or finding some other way to make consumers pay the real cost of imported oil. **********In agriculture, a centerpiece of campaign statements, Mr. Anglade, one of Father Aristide's closest advisers, said a major focus would be reorganization of the country's 7,500 rural communal gardens, which he said will be consolidated and made more productive through state financial assistance and extension services. **********State-owned land will also be distributed to peasants under the age of 35, and agricultural industries will be created or moved to rural areas to brake the flight of the population to the capital. The rural restructuring, which Mr. Anglade said would be "non-coercive," will also allow the new Government to gather masses of peasants for a major literacy drive. **********Western diplomats and Haitian analysts, while granting that the President-elect has strong popular support, say that almost no amount of domestic self-help by itself can create a modern economy capable of ending Haiti's poverty. This goal, they say, will require greater assistance from the outside and closer integration with the international economy. **********"If he does not have a liberal economic policy, he won't be able to produce the results his constituents want so badly," a Western diplomat who is not an American said. "Without international support, the whole thing will fall like a leaf from a tree."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/world.main_headline: Jiucun Journal;   In a Chinese Desert, Once-Barren Lives Bloom
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/world.print_headline: Jiucun Journal;   In a Chinese Desert, Once-Barren Lives Bloom
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/world.body_text: **********The soil is sandy in this unpretentious little village on the edge of the desert. The 40 homes are made of mud and have plastic windows, but they are buttressed by hope: a yearning by the peasants who come here that the village will mark an escape from the poverty that has been the lot of their families for scores of generations. **********Everyone here is a newcomer, a pioneer trying to forge a new life and wring crops from what is now desert. The migrants come from the impoverished hill country 200 miles south of here, where many people live in caves and lack enough to eat. The settlers are part of an ambitious Government program to resettle 210,000 poor peasants on land reclaimed from the desert with the help of Yellow River irrigation projects. **********''Of course it was sad to leave my old village,'' Chen Wenxue, a wiry 25-year-old man, said as he showed off the plain mud hut into which he moved a year ago with his wife and infant child. ''Even though it wasn't a good place, and it was poor, it was still home. But this is better for the child.'' **********A Better House Is Next **********A short walk way, the family of Yu Liujin is planting a vegetable garden and planning how to spend the money from this year's harvest. Should they save for a bicycle, a television, or a better house? It is a novel problem for a family that used to spend all its money to survive, but Mr. Yu, 34 years old, decides that the priority is to build a fancier house with plaster walls and a concrete floor. **********''After some others came here and found a good life, I made up my mind to move as well,'' said Mr. Yu, who arrived a few months ago with his wife and four children. (The last baby was unauthorized, but officials judged him so poor that instead of fining him they settled for sterilizing his wife.) ''I decided that our lives could be improved,'' he said. ''For now it's not much better here. But give us a few years, and things will get better.'' **********This faith that life will improve is nurtured by the experience of those who moved earlier to this valley about 25 miles southwest of Yinchuan, the capital of the Ningxia autonomous region in northwestern China. Some 160,000 people have been resettled in six years and 50,000 more are scheduled to move before the project is completed in 1992. **********Projects to relocate peasants from places of endemic poverty are under way in other parts of China, but this is one of the most ambitious. About 5 percent of Ningxia's population will be relocated. **********Yet migration to escape poverty is a Chinese tradition; most of today's migrants are descendents of peasants who fled war and turmoil in Shaanxi Province in central China in the 19th century. **********The resettlement programs may also be a test case for the removal of vast numbers of people if the Government goes ahead with a proposal to build a huge dam on the Yangtze River. Depending on the height of the dam, known as the Three Gorges Project, 200,000 to 1.4 million people would have to be resettled from low-lying farmland. **********A Hard Life at First **********In Ningxia, the new settlers initially face a hard life, but they are buoyed by the experience of those who came earlier - people like 23-year-old Ma Xiangmei, who came with her husband in 1985. **********The couple decided to migrate after hunger forced them to sell their wedding presents: one wristwatch and one bicycle. They packed their belongings in a pair of small orange overnight suitcases and climbed onto a truck that could fit not only nine destitute families but all their goods. **********''When we first came I wasn't used to it and I longed for my hometown,'' Miss Ma said as she tended the garden in front of her home. ''But now I like it and it's much more prosperous here. I won't go back.'' **********The couple's life is still hard, but now they have a bicycle as well as a watch each. They have even splurged on a black and white television set, which sits opposite the kang, the traditional Chinese platform bed that is heated by a fire beneath in winter. They can lie on the kang, lean back against the wallpaper (old copies of People's Daily), and feel that they are part of the modern world. **********Almost All Do Better **********Almost all of those who came in the early years seem have improved their lot. Ma Chunming, a muscular 29-year-old peasant, and his wife, Yu Ailan, 28, earned only about $50 a year in their old village and they say it was often a struggle to afford food and clothing. They still have not raised the money for a television set, but they have replaced their mud hut with a three-room house that has glass windows, a cement floor and plaster walls. **********Mr. Ma and Miss Yu moved in 1984, at the beginning of the resettlement program, and they acknowledge that at first they had doubts. At that time, many peasants in the poor areas refused to move. **********''They lived in the mountains and had closed minds,'' said Cao Zhesheng, a Ningxia official who has helped oversee the resettlement. ''They didn't know anything about the outside world. And they knew about dry farming, not about cultivating irrigated land.'' **********Now word has filtered back to the hometowns that the settlers have prospered and resistance to migration has turned into a waiting list to join the program. **********''At first, I was very sad to leave my parents and my ancestral home,'' Mr. Ma recalled. ''The old place was spectacularly beautiful with trees and grass, and it was tough to get used to the sand and the climate here. But then we saw that here it is much easier to make a living.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/11/world.main_headline: 21 South Africans Are Released Under Political-Prisoner Amnesty
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/11/world.print_headline: 21 South Africans Are Released Under Political-Prisoner Amnesty
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/11/world.body_text: **********The Government released 21 political prisoners today, and the African National Congress, while welcoming the move, responded by insisting that all political prisoners still behind bars be released immediately. **********The release of the captives was a consequence of President F. W. de Klerk's announcement on Monday that an indemnity against prosecution would be extended to political exiles and prisoners. **********At their first formal meeting in Cape Town from May 2 to 4, the Government and the Congress established a joint working group to define political crimes and work out conditions for an amnesty of those prisoners and exiles accused of committing them. The amnesty, which the African National Congress has set as a condition for its participation in negotiations on the country's future, was discussed in greater detail at a second round of talks in Pretoria on Aug. 6. **********Although the details have yet to be disclosed, the two sides are believed to have agreed upon a phased amnesty, beginning with cases of purely political offenses like treason and continuing later to cases involving violent crimes like murder. **********Political Trials to Continue **********Mr. de Klerk declared a cut off date effective on Oct. 8, the day of his announcement, after which offenses would not be covered. He also said the amnesty would not be automatic, meaning that prisoners or exiles would have to apply and that those facing trial for political crimes would have to go through the judicial system. **********The African National Congress said all political prisoners qualified for release under Mr. de Klerk's announcement and that all political trials should be halted. **********''What is the logic of determining a cutoff date and in the same breath pursuing legal processes or continuing to punish those whose only crime is their opposition to the criminal system of apartheid,'' the Congress said in a statement. **********The African National Congress estimated the number of political prisoners in South Africa at 3,500. **********Estimates of Political Prisoners **********It was not clear what the Congress is basing its estimate on. The Human Rights Commission, a body created nearly two years ago to monitor human rights from the perspective of the anti-apartheid movement, says it has counted less than 1,600 political prisoners in South African jails. It has speculated that others it does not know about could push the total as high as 3,000. **********One of those released today, Titus Hendricks, who spent four years in the maximum-security prison at Robben Island, said at a news conference in Cape Town that 200 ''comrades'' were still left on Robben Island. **********Fifteen of those released today came from Robben Island, traveling on a ferry across a half dozen miles of chilly Atlantic waters to Cape Town. Three others came from prison in Cape Town and one each from prisons in Pretoria, Johannesburg and Modderbee. **********They were serving sentences of 4 to 16 years on for offenses that included murder, arson, terrorism and treason committed in the course of their opposition to apartheid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/16/busin.main_headline: For Man With a Dream, A Humbling Nightmare
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/16/busin.print_headline: For Man With a Dream, A Humbling Nightmare
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/16/busin.body_text: **********The financial and legal troubles facing the Campeau Corporation's American retailing units are undoubtedly a personal humiliation for Robert Campeau, the French Canadian entrepreneur whose debt-burdened dream was to own a national chain of shopping malls housing prestigious stores. **********But what remains unclear is how much the difficulties of the company's American retailing business have or will affect Mr. Campeau's personal fortune, which just four months ago was estimated at more than $300 million. **********Much of the 66-year-old real estate developer's wealth was in Campeau stock, which is worth about a tenth what it was a year ago. The financial bind felt these days by Mr. Campeau was underlined earlier this month when he was forced to surrender about $100 million of his stock to the National Bank of Canada. He had to hand over the shares on Jan. 4, when he could not make payments on loans made to a pair of his investment companies. His Campeau shares had been put up as collateral on the bank loans. **********Chateau May Be for Sale **********In recent days, it has been rumored in Toronto that Mr. Campeau's mock 18th-century French chateau has been put up for sale. Yet with his far-flung real estate holdings and the investment companies he controls, his personal wealth remains difficult to measure, analysts say. **********Mr. Campeau is a classic outsider who flouted Canadian business and social conventions, and the view on Bay Street, Toronto's financial community, toward his fall is already apparent. Sympathy is scarce. **********''The attitude on Bay Street is that he went down to the United States and vastly overpaid for what he bought,'' said Porter Davis, an American who is an investor on the Toronto Stock Exchange. ''Now that it's caught up with him, I'd say that a lot of people up here couldn't be happier.'' **********Even before the recent troubles, Mr. Campeau's role in the affairs of his company had been drastically reduced. On Thursday, Mr. Campeau's fellow board members voted to remove him as chairman of the American operations. **********Elusive Figure in Recent Months **********In recent months, as Campeau's American retailing subsidiaries, Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores, have teetered on the edge of bankruptcy, Mr. Campeau has been an elusive figure. Company insiders were quoted in Canadian newspapers as saying that Mr. Campeau had played little part in the marathon board discussions in recent days, where the future of the company was being weighed. In the board room, one insider said, there was ''a tacit acceptance'' that Mr. Campeau was no longer a major force at the company he founded. **********For Mr. Campeau, it has been a precipitous fall from the heady days of March 1988, when his $6.6 billion takeover of Federated, following the $3.6 billion takeover of Allied in October 1986, created an impressive department store empire in the United States. Back then, he was on magazine covers in both nations, held packed news conferences and was at glittering parties that drew some of America's best-known names in business, fashion and entertainment. **********Some of the most lavish parties were held in the Campeaus' homes in Palm Beach, Fla., and in Toronto's rustic Bridle Path district, where Mr. Campeau and his German-born wife, Ilse, are said to have spent more than $5 million on a layout that includes a marble staircase, an Olympic-size indoor pool and a paneled library. **********Takeover Blocked in 1980 **********Mr. Campeau has had a longstanding feud with the Toronto business establishment. In 1980, it closed ranks to block his attempted takeover of the Royal Trust Company, one of Canada's largest finance houses. **********Mr. Campeau complained that he had been frozen out by Toronto's English-speaking banking and business elite because he is a French Canadian, and because he lacked the connections forged in expensive private schools and sporting clubs. After suffering what members of his family subsequently described as a nervous breakdown, Mr. Campeau returned to the fray determined to silence his Toronto detractors by plunging into the big leagues of American business. **********One of the more sympathetic verdicts on Mr. Campeau was offered by Peter Newman, a Canadian author. Writing in Maclean's magazine last fall, Mr. Newman said Mr. Campeau's had been ''the classic tragedy of a gutsy entrepreneur reaching beyond his means to grasp the social legitimacy that had always eluded him.'' Mr. Campeau, Mr. Newman said, chose ''to mortgage his soul to prove to Canada's elite just how big a deal he could pull off.'' In Canadian business, Mr. Newman concluded, ''he will not be missed.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/28/busin.body_text: **********Despite a rise in revenues, the profitability of the 20 largest United States oil companies fell in the first half of the year, the American Petroleum Institute said on Sunday. **********But the companies' prospects are likely to improve sharply in the second half because of the 50 percent rise in crude oil prices since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. **********The A.P.I., a trade group, said that profits as a percentage of stockholder equity fell to 13.2 percent in the first half, from 15.8 percent in the period last year. A spokesman said the decline was largely because of depressed oil prices early in the year. **********Operating income of the 20 companies for the first six months was $8.1 billion, compared with $8.9 billion in the comparable period in 1989, the A.P.I. said. It said operating income in the second quarter was $4 billion, compared with $4.5 billion a year earlier, an 11 percent drop. **********Total revenues for the companies in the first half totaled $194 billion, 6.4 percent higher than the $182.4 billion last year. Second-quarter revenue totaled $94.9 billion, 2 percent higher than the $93 billion last year. **********Soaring oil prices since the invasion of Kuwait are expected to raise oil company profits in the second half of the year, although the effects are expected to vary based on whether companies earn most of their money from pumping oil or refining it into petroleum products.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/busin.body_text: **********IT is no secret that one of today's overriding challenges is the need to make changes in graduate business schools. In fact, a recently published report, ''Leadership for a Changing World - The Future Role of Graduate Management Education,'' discusses some of the steps business school deans and business leaders consider necessary. **********John Rosenblum, the dean of the Darden Graduate School of Business Administration at the University of Virginia and a co-chairman of the academic commission that prepared the report, spoke about some of the more provocative ideas in an interview last week. **********One of the big concerns among the deans is how the already crowded M.B.A. curriculum will deal with a host of newly emerging topics, including ethics, the environment and international business. **********As one answer, Dr. Rosenblum and others have been discussing changes in the traditional two-year M.B.A. program, with many criticizing the European idea of an intensive 11-month program and the 15-month program offered at some American graduate schools. Dr. Rosenblum said there are some creative alternatives. **********''A few of us on the commission discussed a year program right after college, a second year about six years later in a person's career, followed by a two-month program in another six years,'' he said. ''I think the idea is worth considering. It would help free ourselves from the paradigm, or box, of the traditional two-year M.B.A. program.'' **********Such a plan would allow students to gain experience, while giving experienced managers an opportunity to continue their formal educations. ''Managers need to constantly reinvent themselves,'' Dr. Rosenblum said. **********Another concern has been that some business school professors spend too much time on research that is not helpful to business. In its report, the commission stressed that business schools had tended to concentrate on ''elegant, abstract models'' that seek to unify world economic systems rather than help students understand ''the messy, concrete reality of international business.'' **********The commission, while stressing the importance of ''effective scholarship,'' urged that professors acquire more business knowledge to ''relate their scholarship to problems facing business leaders.'' The report also noted that some knowledge and skills ''may be best provided by faculty with managerial experience.'' **********Dr. Rosenblum agreed wholeheartedly with that last point and said he had added experienced corporate managers to his faculty - not just as adjunct professors but as full players. **********''Faculty are enriched by diversity,'' he added. **********One of those managers is Thomas C. MacAvoy, 62 years old, a former president of Corning Inc., the upstate New York glassware company. **********''He is a chaired professor who teaches a course called 'Innovation and Technological Management,' '' Dr. Rosenblum said. ''And he has collaborated in the design of our new course in leadership, which will be given this fall for the first time.'' **********Another is Robert J. Sack, 56, who was a partner for 25 years in the former accounting firm of Touche Ross, which is now Deloitte Touche, and was also chief accountant for the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********''He has come here to teach international financial reporting and also a course on communicating corporate value,'' Dr. Rosenblum said. ''In both cases they are the kind of professionals that would fit well as members of the tenured faculty.'' **********Dr. Rosenblum also said that many graduate business schools should find niches. **********He applauded Rollins College's Roy E. Crummer Graduate School of Business, where the dean, Martin Schatz, hires only older, experienced professors with Ph.D.'s. **********Dr. Rosenblum noted that Rollins stressed teaching and course development over research. **********The campus at Winter Park, Fla., obviously also has an attraction for many older professors at a time when business school professors are in short supply. **********''The difference between a teaching faculty and a research faculty is in what the faculty publishes, rather than if the faculty publishes.'' Dr. Schatz said. ''We encourage our people to publish material that improves the teaching process. Unlike many other schools, we value the publication of textbooks.'' **********Dr. Rosenblum called this a powerful niche strategy. ''I think we should celebrate differences among graduate schools of business,'' he added. ''More schools need a self-identity. We hope that this booklet will be a catalyst to more creative thinking like this.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/world.main_headline: Hong Kong to Try 5 Beijing Foes; Charge: Illegal Use of Megaphones
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/world.print_headline: Hong Kong to Try 5 Beijing Foes; Charge: Illegal Use of Megaphones
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/world.body_text: **********In a few days, the British Government will put on trial five prominent pro-democracy campaigners accused of using hand-held megaphones without a permit at demonstrations here.
