Critics say that the move is an attempt to appease the Government in Beijing. **********In a similar case last Wednesday, Fung Chi-wood, who is an Anglican priest and well-known democracy campaigner, was convicted of another offense - not presenting his identification card to a police officer and collecting money without a permit. **********The issue has come up as the British authorities in Hong Kong face accusations of acting as Beijing's agent to suppress anti-Communists or pro-democracy activities in the territory during the approach to 1997, when London will return Hong Kong to Beijing. **********The Hong Kong authorities have already banned some prominent Chinese exiles from entering the territory, censored films critical of the Communists and turned away a radio ship funded by exiles who wanted to broadcast propaganda toward the mainland. **********Creating a Public Nuisance **********The ordinance under which the five democracy campaigners are being tried is a statute enacted in 1900 to punish people for a creating a public nuisance. **********The ban on megaphones has been applied only once before, the defense says, about three months ago, when another democracy campaigner used a megaphone to call people to a demonstration. **********The offenses for which the democracy campaigners are being tried took place when they were leading rallies in January and February related to the Basic Law, the document that will guide Hong Kong's future. Chinese officials criticized the protests. **********Since the crackdown in Beijing in June 1989, Hong Kong democracy protesters - students, scholars and professionals - have become much more active in the territory. Small demonstrations take place regularly. **********'Pressure From the Chinese' **********''I think it faced pressure from the Chinese,'' Mr. Fung said of the British Government about his prosecution and conviction. ''It wants to suppress the political activities of the democracy activists in Hong Kong.'' **********A spokeswoman at the attorney general's office would not comment on the cases. Still, Hong Kong officials deny that they are trying to suppress democracy, but say that they must preserve stability in the territory, and that the territory must live with the reality that it has a powerful northern neighbor, whom it will not help to offend. **********In May, leaders of Hong Kong's democracy movement were making plans to commemorate the first anniversary on June 4 of the suppression of pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing. Nearly 100,000 people took to the streets to commemorate that day. **********Two of the defendents, Albert C. Y. Ho and Yeung Sum, are vice chairmen of the United Democrats of Hong Kong, the territory's first political party, which was formed in April. **********On several days recently in the busy central district in Hong Kong, hand-held megaphones were seen used by tour guides, movie crews, and even a small group of demonstrators who said they knew nothing of a permit. **********Sought Megaphone Permit **********Mr. Fung sought a permit to use a megaphone but was told by the police that he could ''adequately pass on your views and opinions by speaking to people individually.'' **********In both cases, conviction carries a fine of less than $10 or three months in jail. **********What is unusual about the case of the megaphones is that the British Government had suggested earlier that the law being invoked contravened a Government-backed Bill of Rights that has been proposed for the territory, which will be voted on soon. **********In a letter to legislators on May 2, the Government included a list of Hong Kong laws that it said could be challenged as incompatible with the Bill of Rights. The law banning megaphones without a permit was among them. **********The Government has proposed a two-year freeze on the bill, after it is adopted so inconsistent laws can be revised to conform with the Bill of Rights. But the megaphone case has critics worried that the law might be applied through the period of the moratorium, even if the freeze were cut to one year. **********''I think it wouldn't be right for the Government to enforce that law,'' said Daniel R. Fung, who is leading the defense in the megaphone case. ''Because that would conflict with the Bill of Rights and be contrary to the spirit of the moratorium.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/01/busin.body_text: **********In increasing numbers Americans are being given the opportunity to control their own destiny through self-directed retirement plans, not only I.R.A.'s and Keogh plans for the self-employed, but also employer-sponsored 401(k) plans that offer a number of investment options. Typically participants can change their investment mix in December, and the right choice now can make a considerable difference at retirement time. **********"Many small companies no longer offer pension plans," said Charles H. Salisbury Jr., managing director of T. Rowe Price Associates, the Baltimore-based investment-management and mutual fund organization. "They do offer defined-contribution plans" in which the employee chooses how much is to be set aside in tax-deferred retirement accounts, he added. **********Data from the Social Security Administration show that the percentage of privately employed workers covered by employer-financed pension plans seems to have peaked. The portion rose from about 25 percent in the early 1950's to 50 percent in 1979, but fell back to 46 percent in 1988. **********To the employee this is a two-edged sword. It can mean that many are without the benefit of professional pension managers, although often the options include professionally managed mutual funds. The positive aspect is that it can also mean greater long-term rewards for those who are disciplined about putting money into the plans and taking time and effort in managing their accounts. **********The most popular investment choice for employees' funds is a guaranteed investment contract issued by an insurance company or a similar contract issued by a bank. These contracts earn a guaranteed rate of interest, generally a bit higher than short-term money market instruments. Some 60 to 75 percent of employees' own money is in guaranteed investment contracts, retirement experts say. **********Other popular investment choices include: short-term Treasury or money-market funds, employer stock, Government bonds or other fixed-income securities, balanced mutual funds and equity funds. In the majority of 401(k) plans employers match employee contributions to some extent, mostly in the company's stock. **********Donald R. Levy, a lawyer and consultant on retirement and benefit plans for Maxwell Macmillan, cited a number of reasons that employees choose guaranteed investment contracts. "Basically, the employee wants to be sure not to lose his or her own capital," he said. **********Nor is this employee conservatism wrong in Mr. Levy's opinion. "I would favor G.I.C.'s over bond funds because bonds can fluctuate in value." he said. "Employees should consider putting a goodpart in G.I.C.'s -- they're a good investment -- and for balance, consider equities and bonds." How much to put in each will vary. **********The first consideration, Mr. Levy said, is what the employer is putting in. Other considerations include the investment mix of any other retirement accounts that the person and his or her spouse have and their age and risk tolerance. **********Mr. Salisbury argues that younger employees in particular should "accept more volatility in the earlier years to build up more savings." **********"A 28-year-old or a 30-year-old should not have most of their money in guaranteed investment contracts," he said, adding, "Buy stocks now when they are cheap." During eight postwar crises including the Korean War, President Kennedy's confrontation with U.S. Steel, President Nixon's resignation and the 1987 crash, he noted, stock prices tumbled, but in each case within six months to a year they recovered substantially, in many cases more than making up what they lost. And over the long term, equities have outperformed other investments. **********As people get older, they can shift more money into fixed income, he said, recommending 10 percent in fixed income for every decade of age. **********One way people can make their own determinations of how much to set aside and how to invest it is with a retirement planning kit that T. Rowe Price offers free to those who request it by calling 1-800-638-5660. It includes a workbook developed with Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, with worksheets, and booklets on strategy and mutual funds. **********Another source of advice is the Price Waterhouse Retirement Planning Adviser, recently published by Pocket Books at $5.50. George E. L. Barbee, executive director of personal financial services for Price Waterhouse, advises people to make the maximum contribution possible to 401(k) plans both this year and next -- that's $7,979 this year -- "especially if there's a match."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/07/busin.body_text: **********The Government agency charged with selling failed savings and loan associations has adopted a policy requiring its employees to maintain a log of all telephone inquiries made by or on behalf of public officials. The Resolution Trust Corporation action was announced on Wednesday in response to policy directives in the savings and loan bailout legislation enacted by Congress last August. The action also calls for establishing a special committee to conduct formal reviews when Resolution Trust employees believe they have received inappropriate requests from public officials.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/world.main_headline: Syrian Official Says He Expects Release of Hostage
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/world.print_headline: Syrian Official Says He Expects Release of Hostage
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/world.body_text: **********A Syrian official said today that he expected an American hostage to be released Sunday to the United States Embassy. The embassy had no comment. **********Iran, Syria and the United States continued to stir hopes that an American hostage would be released in the next few days despite the absence of any evidence of progress in that direction. **********The Teheran Times, the English-language newspaper in the Iranian capital, urged Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine, a faction in Lebanon, to free an American hostage, as they had promised on Wednesday. **********The Teheran Times said in an article published today that ''hurdles there may be on the way, but it is our hope that despite all, the freedom of the hostages can become a reality materializing soon.'' **********The newspaper, known for its closeness to pragmatic figures in Teheran headed by Iran's President, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, said there was no need for the United States to dispatch senior officials to conclude a deal, asserting that the American Ambassador to Syria, Edward Djerejian, was capable to handling the situation. **********The kidnappers of the American hostages said Thursday that it was the refusal of the United States to send Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly to Damascus that had caused them to delay the promised release of an unidentified hostage on Friday. Mr. Kelly is a senior American Middle East policy maker. **********Two Syrian officials who asked not to be identified said in separate interviews today in Damascus that despite that setback, Syria had committed itself ''far too deeply'' to the release of an American hostage to let the endeavor fail. One official said he expected a hostage to be released on Sunday to the United States Embassy. American officials confirmed that Syria was making a vigorous effort to bring all parties involved in the kidnapping to the view that it is time to free at least one of the American hostages. **********The Syrians asserted that the United States had led them to believe that it was not opposed to sending Mr. Kelly to Damascus. **********But the two officials said that the issue should not in itself be an obstacle to what they asserted would be an eventual success of the Syrian efforts. **********A number of foreign diplomats here noted that the passage of time is adding more obstacles because it it allows the various parties to complicate the process. Among other things, those diplomats said today, the attack overnight by Israel on the training headquarters of the Shiite Party of God militias in a Bekaa village that killed six guerrillas is, in the words of an Arab diplomat who asked not to be identified, ''like breaking a bee hive open.'' ''It can only make the hostage takers angry,'' he continued. **********It also appears that the deteriorating security situation in Beirut, with intermittent fighting between the pro-Iranian Party of God militias and the pro-Syrian Amal militias, will make it more difficult to obtain the release of hostages presumbably held in the southern Shiite section of the city, diplomats here said. **********Syrian officials were also very critical of what they characterized as ''deliberate sabotage'' by the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********The P.L.O. has been the source of contradictory information, asserting that a deal had been worked out between Americans and Iranians.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.main_headline: Creditors to Fight Drexel's Plan for Revamping
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.print_headline: Creditors to Fight Drexel's Plan for Revamping
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.body_text: **********A committee of unsecured creditors of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that it would oppose the investment firm's reorganization plan. **********The committee said it had unanimously voted to propose its own plan, which calls for starting with a clean slate of directors and the replacement of Drexel's management team. The announcement sets the stage for a confrontation of the creditors and Drexel executives on Tuesday at a hearing in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. **********At the hearing, Drexel and two other court-appointed committees are expected to ask a Federal bankruptcy judge to extend the period during which Drexel has the exclusive right to formulate its own plan to emerge from Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The period expires on Wednesday. **********The action by the creditors' committee comes a day after Drexel presented an outline of the plan to creditors. The creditors' plan follows Drexel's in overall structure, but differs in significant detail. **********Three Funds Sought **********Under the creditors' proposal, Drexel would establish three funds. The first would consist of Drexel's portfolio of ''junk bonds,'' bridge loans and other assets that Drexel has valued at about $2 billion. Under the creditors' proposal, the fund would issue three types of notes, due in 18, 24 and 36 months. The notes would bear interest and could be publicly traded. **********Drexel's plan calls for the issuance of notes from a similar fund, but they would mature in six years, would not guarantee interest and would not be publicly traded for at least 30 months. **********The creditors proposed the establishment of a second fund based on a bankruptcy court's estimate of Drexel's legal liability arising from more than 400 civil lawsuits in which the firm is named as a defendant. **********A third fund would be financed mostly from the proceeds of lawsuits that Drexel may have against others, including present and former Drexel executives who received hundreds of millions of dollars shortly before the firm filed for bankruptcy in February. The fund's proceeds would be shared by Drexel's creditors and shareholders. **********Wilbur L. Ross Jr., a senior managing director and bankruptcy specialist at Rothschild Inc., which is advising the creditors' committee, said it had rejected the Drexel plan after concluding that it would pay ''substantially less than 100 cents on the dollar.'' He added that the committee's plan would provide for 100 percent recovery with interest over three years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   As Cold War Recedes, Radio Services Face Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   As Cold War Recedes, Radio Services Face Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/world.body_text: **********The worldwide information and broadcasting operations of the United States are facing reductions as the cold war era recedes and the Government budget shrinks, with the most painful cuts occurring at the United States Information Agency. **********Today, Bruce S. Gelb, the agency's director, was offered the option of eliminating the programs of the Voice of America for one day a week in all of the 43 languages in which it broadcasts as a means of dealing with a shortage of more than $1 million in the operating budget. **********The director chose to keep the Voice of America on the air seven days a week and to make up the deficiency by trimming other U.S.I.A. programs, perhaps in the cultural exchange area. The gap resulted from interim appropriations legislation approved by Congress a few weeks ago. **********The cuts are occurring as a debate gets under way over the Government's broadcasting operations, a corollary in some respects to the national debate over what is to become of this country's defense establishment. **********Already, the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe have begun emphasizing their roles in helping the countries of the former Soviet bloc to ''build democracy.'' The radio service executives hope this will convince Congress of their continuing value in the era after the cold war. **********An Unsurmountable Problem **********Directly at issue in the debate are the Voice of America, which broadcasts globally, and Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, which broadcast from Munich to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Eventually, the cultural exchange and information programs of the U.S.I.A. could also become subject to questions about whether they belong elsewhere in the bureaucratic scene, Government officials said. **********The Munich stations confront one unsurmountable problem. Created at the height of the cold war and clandestinely financed by the Central Intelligence Agency, their mission was mainly to provide alternative sources of news and commentary for listeners in countries controlled by Communist governments - and those governments have for the most part vanished. **********The two stations currently broadcast in 23 languages, although not in English. After the C.I.A. financing was disclosed in the early 1970's, the stations' budgets were directly appropriated by the Government. **********The Voice of America, on the other hand, was founded in 1942. While for decades it also delivered cold war messages, including to audiences in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, its mandate remained global. **********H. Stanton Burnett, a counselor of the United States Information Agency during the Reagan Administration, recalled that the agency ''used the cold war to sell its budget,'' leading him to surmise that it will now have ''a harder time selling the larger package.'' **********Competition Intensifies **********The debate comes when the longstanding competition between the two broadcasting operations for Government funds is intensifying. **********An interagency group working under the National Security Council has been evaluating the Munich-based stations as well as the Voice of America. Its review will be given this summer to a bipartisan commission that will be formed to make recommendations on the future structuring of the Government's broadcasting services. **********Those recommendations will probably figure in hearings early next year in the House and Senate that could lead to Congressional proposals or legislation on changes in American broadcasting and perhaps deal with the future of the United States Information Agency as well. Some on Capitol Hill, including aides of Senator Claiborne Pell, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, think other institutions should take over the agency's functions. **********As in the past, there is some interest in Congress in combining the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty into an independent public institution like the British Broadcasting Corporation. Mr. Gelb, the U.S.I.A. director, acknowledged in an interview that this is ''a possibility that has been discussed.'' **********Last month, the radio debate was sharpened when the Advisory Commission on Public Diplomacy, which is appointed by the President, issued a report urging ''planning now for the termination of Radio Free Europe's language services'' and eventual ''transfer of assets as appropriate to the Voice of America.'' **********That proposal was assailed by Malcolm S. Forbes Jr., chairman of the Board for International Broadcasting, which oversees the Munich-based stations. Mr. Forbes accused the commission of having a ''less than objective perspective'' and said that its recommendation ''must be questioned in the light of the commission's close relationship with U.S.I.A.'' **********In his response to the presidential panel, Mr. Forbes was careful to distinguish between Radio Free Europe, which is perceived as vulnerable, and Radio Liberty, which broadcasts exclusively to the Soviet Union and whose continued usefulness is not being questioned at this time. **********Speaking of Radio Free Europe's East European service, which claims virtually saturation listenership in five countries, Mr. Forbes asserted that it was ''premature to call for an end of R.F.E. broadcasts,'' describing them as ''a valuable trademark that must be preserved.'' **********Battle Lines Are Drawn **********But within the stations themselves the battle lines have already been drawn. **********A middle-level Government official bitterly compared the two operations to a thoroughbred and an underfed workhorse. The well-nourished thoroughbred is Radio Free Europe-Radio Liberty, which has broadcast to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union since the early 1950's. The workhorse is the Voice of America, which broadcasts globally in 43 languages, including English. **********''Both horses are sick,'' the official said, ''but the prize horse has a terminal disease'' because the cold war for which it was bred has ended. **********The official said that Voice of America, although it broadcasts in almost twice as many languages as the Munich stations, has a current operations budget of under $171 million compared with $190 million for Radio Free Europe-Radio Liberty. Next year's budget foresees $2 million less for Voice of America but no change for the Munich stations. **********''We are bleeding to death,'' said Robert T. Coonrod, Voice of America's deputy director, said. **********Budget constraints have meant that in Africa the Voice's network of part-time correspondents is drying up and in Warsaw funds stretch only for irrregular staffing of the Voice's bureau. One hour of Russian-language broadcasting had also to be cut.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/busin.main_headline: An Oil Dealer's Niche: The Man in the Middle
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/busin.print_headline: An Oil Dealer's Niche: The Man in the Middle
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/busin.body_text: **********Fred Allegretti, the head of a large New York heating oil delivery company, follows daily oil trading on the computer screen behind his desk. The ever-changing numbers directly influence the wholesale price he pays for oil and, in turn, what he ends up charging his customers. He doesn't like what he sees on his screen and his customers don't like what they see on their bills. **********In the last three and half months, Mr. Allegretti, president of the Bayside Fuel Oil Corporation in Brooklyn, has seen heating oil prices for residential customers soar to about $1.40 a gallon, following crude oil's rise to nearly $40 a barrel from $23. In the last few days, crude has come down to about $30 a barrel, and heating oil contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange are now about 86 cents a gallon.  Northeast Concentration **********The prices have been swinging back and forth because oil traders, like traders at the other futures and stock exchanges, have been basing many of their buy and sell decisions on news and rumors about Middle East tensions. **********Mr. Allegretti, 55 years old, has been following the markets long enough to know they respond to all kinds of forces, real and imagined. But he and other deliverers say they cannot help but feel exasperation at the unusual degree of market instability ever since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. **********Adding to their frustration, they say, is that heating oil stocks are plentiful and the weather in the Northeast has been unusually mild for most the heating season so far. Those factors normally would have prevailed to keep prices more stable and relatively low. **********Oil burners are used to circulate hot water or steam to heat 15 percent of the homes in the United States, but 44 percent of those in the Northeast, according to the Commerce Department. **********"All the people that sell me oil price their prices on the Merc," Mr. Allegretti said in his roomy split-level office overlooking Gravesend Bay in Bensonhurst. "But I think it's too speculative. It's the tail leading the dog." **********As a result, even before winter sets in, dealers like Mr. Allegretti are feeling the wrath of consumers who remember paying less than $1 a gallon for most of last winter. **********"They're angry as could be at us," Mr. Allegretti said. "I don't know if people are going to be able to swallow these price increases." **********Home heating oil deliverers who were feeling unjustly persecuted for the rising prices probably had "a legitimate beef" after the initial surge in August and September, said Chris Dyson, research director of Buyers Up, a Washington-based consumer organization. But recently, when the wholesale price fell, retail prices hardly dropped at all, he said, suggesting that some deliverers had kept prices higher than necessary. **********The dealers' price for heating oil in the Northeast fell 10 cents a gallon during the week of Oct. 23, he said, while the price they charged customers dropped only a penny. **********Mr. Allegretti said that when the wholesale prices were at their highest about six weeks ago, his profits actually decreased. He said that to give his customers a break he did not mark up his selling price as much as he might have, thus shrinking his profit margin. For example, when he was buying oil at $1.04 a gallon, he sold it at $1.35; yesterday, when he bought it at 84 cents he sold it at $1.30. On the day of the invasion of Kuwait he was paying 60 cents a gallon and selling it for 99 cents. **********The prices of home heating oil contracts on the Merc fell steeply for several days in mid-October, to 76 cents a gallon from a high of about $1.06. Then they picked again, although they have been falling this week to close at 84 cents yesterday for the December contract.   Role of Fantasy and Rumor **********Industry analysts say that if fighting starts in the Middle East, the prices will soar. "People are sophisticated enough to know that the Iraqi-Kuwait situation is the cause," said Robert Greenes, a director of the Metropolitan Energy Council, a trade organization that promotes the use of oil heat in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. **********"But human nature allows them to manifest their anger at the one guy they see," he said, "like the oil deliverer or the guy who runs the service station. They can't yell at the Exxons of the world, or the Saudis." **********He also said that heating oil deliverers were being unfairly blamed even when "the earlier price rise prompted by the Mideast crisis was based on fantasy and rumor" on the Merc. **********The dealers say they have little choice but to pay the refineries whatever prices result from Merc trading or risk being caught short of supplies. And they say that to stay in business they must pass the higher prices on to their customers. **********The more-than-adequate supply of heating oil now is in contrast to the situation last winter, when a record cold snap in December caused some shortages and briefly sent the price up to $1.60 a gallon. Heating-oil refineries have been operating at maximum capacity, partly in reaction to the dip in stocks last winter, and partly to build up new stocks as a safeguard against shortages that might be caused if the supply of crude oil from the Persian Gulf is cut.  Shortage Called Unlikely **********Mr. Allegretti, whose family has owned Bayside since 1933, generally buys and sells oil only as he and his customers need it. That means his company can be caught with little to sell if there is a nationwide shortage. He rarely sets fixed delivery prices for a full heating season, so his prices can fluctuate as much as the Merc, something his customers do not appreciate when the only direction of prices seems to be up. **********With 25,000 retail customers on Long Island and in the five boroughs of New York, and 125 smaller oil delivery companies as wholesale customers, Bayside is one of the largest suppliers in the metropolitan area. **********Most of the oil that fills Mr. Allegretti's 90 delivery trucks comes from the New Jersey refineries of large oil companies like Exxon, Gulf and Amoco. The oil gets to Bensonhurst by boat and truck. **********Phillip R. Chisholm, executive vice president of the Petroleum Marketers Association of America, a Washington-based industry group, said that because of the high output now the industry was unlikely to face winter shortages even under the worst circumstances -- a brutally cold winter, coupled with all-out war in the Middle East. **********Many consumers seem to be filling their tanks now instead of waiting for colder weather, hoping to beat further price increases.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/world.main_headline: German Greens, Still Fighting Each Other, Review Election Debacle
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/world.print_headline: German Greens, Still Fighting Each Other, Review Election Debacle
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/world.body_text: **********The moderates accused the radicals of living by "rejection." The radicals attacked moderates as "undertakers," and for good measure blasted a newly arrived eastern German member as a "reactionary." Petra Kelly blasted them all as "mullahs of the party factions who have coagulated in dogmatism." **********Beaten, battered and possibly destroyed by their drubbing in Sunday's election, the Greens were still at it, as if determined to go out with the same defiance, irreverence and chaos with which they first invaded the corridors of mainstream politics a decade ago. **********Meeting in the environmentally sound conference room they had built in the Parliament building eight years ago, the 46 departing western German Green members of Parliament seemed agreed on only one point: that if the movement did survive, it could not avoid the schism that has all but paralyzed the Greens in recent years. **********"The election result showed that the anti-party party project has failed," declared Wolfgang Ullmann, a pastor from Berlin who arrived in Bonn with the small group of eastern German Greens and civic-movement leaders to whom the mantle of left-wing protest now passes.  Only 3.9 Percent of Vote **********In Sunday's election, the western German Greens mustered only 3.9 percent of the vote, less than the 5 percent needed to secure a seat in Parliament and far below the 8.3 percent they won in 1987. That meant that all 46 western German members of Parliament, and their staff of about 260, would have to vacate their parliamentary offices and lose much of their income this month. **********The western Greens might have retained some seats if they had united before the elections with the eastern German Greens, since their combined vote would have nudged them over the 5 percent barrier. But because they were opposed in principle to the "colonialization" of the east, the Greens had postponed uniting their parties until after the election. **********The eastern German coalition of Greens and civic movements -- the remnants of New Forum and the other movements that arose during the 1989 uprisings -- won 6.1 percent of the vote in the east, enough, under the special rules for this election, to claim eight seats in Parliament. **********Whether the election really was the death knell of the Greens will become clear only at their next party congress in the spring, and before that they face elections in Hesse state on Jan. 20. But the election defeat seemed to sever the last fragile links between the bitterly divided factions in the movement.  'Realos' vs. 'Fundis' **********Leaders of the pragmatic "realo" wing, led by Joschke Fischer, declared that only by engaging in active politics could the movement recover. "You cannot keep ignoring the laws of political physics and reduce yourself to non-representation," he declared as he proposed changes to move the Greens to a more established leadership. **********From the radical "fundi" wing, whose members believed in keeping the Greens as a voice of radical opposition and permanent resistance, Jutta Ditfurth fired back that if the party went the way of conventional politics, she and her comrades would quit. **********"If they come through with what they just proposed, then it's over, the Greens are dead," she declared to reporters outside the hall where Mr. Fischer had just finished a news conference. "This is really a news conference of undertakers." **********Ms. Ditfurth rejected the notion that it was the public infighting that had damaged the movement. On the contrary, she declared, it was the realos' efforts to squelch debate that put people off. "The public loved the fights, against NATO, for social change," she said. "These were good fights. They raised consciousness." **********Somewhere between the two, Miss Kelly, 42 years old and a founder of the movement, declared that the party had committed suicide through its internal struggles. "Each side keeps telling the other to go home, but when they leave the roof caves in," she said. "In the end the voters never learned about the good things we were still doing, because all the media tuned into was the fight."  Bickering Over Reunification **********To outside commentators, the bickering that hurt the most came over German unity. Radical Greens rejected unity outright; others, including Miss Kelly, criticized it but accepted it; others supported it. In the end the party emerged without a position on the most fateful issue of the campaign. **********At the same time, the Greens' original cause, the environment, became a standard plank of the mainstream parties, especially in the campaign of Oskar Lafontaine, the Social Democratic candidate. **********Ultimately the bickering and the loss of strong issues were less direct causes of the Greens' loss than symptoms of the movement's middle age, of its doomed efforts to perpetuate the heady resistance of the 1960's. **********"We need a radical rejuvenation of our party," Mr. Fischer said. "The youth was our source of life. When we lost that, we lost the elections. The generation of the 1960's is now into parenthood and even grandparenthood."  Deputies Were Rotated **********Ever seeking to combat institutionalization, the Greens experimented with constant rotation of parliamentary deputies, with fuzzy lines of command and an antipathy to party discipline. The best known of the Greens faded into the background because of the mandatory rotation. **********The bulk of the party's losses were defections: 600,000 voters switched to the Social Democrats, 140,000 to the Christian Democrats. But equally painful was that 270,000 former Green voters simply did not vote. **********But however hard the blow, few Greens or political analysts were prepared to write off the movement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.main_headline: A Bomb Kills 4 in New Delhi On Eve of Independence Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.print_headline: A Bomb Kills 4 in New Delhi On Eve of Independence Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.body_text: **********A bomb killed at least four people in New Delhi on the eve of India's independence day celebrations, news agencies reported today. **********They said the bomb exploded just before midnight in a park in the northwest of the city where people were celebrating the birthday of Lord Krishna, one of the Hindu gods. **********The police were quoted as saying the bomb, which also wounded at least 20 people, was fitted with a timer and was probably planted by secessionist militants. Immediate suspicion fell on Sikhs fighting for an independent homeland in Punjab.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/20/world.main_headline: Social Democrats Quit East German Coalition
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/20/world.print_headline: Social Democrats Quit East German Coalition
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/20/world.body_text: **********East and West Germany stumbled again today over a partisan political obstacle on the path to unification when the East German Social Democratic Party quit the governing coalition in East Berlin, apparently denying the coalition, which is led by Christian Democrats, a ruling majority. **********The action put East Berlin's Social Democrats in the same situation as the Social Democrats in Bonn - as an opposition party in Parliament. But it did not seem likely to upset the timetable for unification and elections now envisaged by the two heads of German governments. **********The elections are set for Dec. 2. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany and Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere of East Germany, both Christian Democrats, have declared themselves in favor of a formal act of unification, probably with ratification of a treaty between the two German states, on Oct. 14. **********The Social Democratic walkout this evening in East Berlin, approved by 60 of the party's 88 deputies in Parliament, was touched off by Mr. de Maiziere's dismissal of two Social Democratic members of the Cabinet last Wednesday. **********Objections to Premier **********Wolfgang Thierse, chairman of the East German Social Democrats, said his party had quit the coalition with the Christian Democrats ''because of the behavior of de Maiziere.'' He was referring to the confusion created at the end of July when Mr. de Maiziere and Mr. Kohl tried to move the election date up to Oct. 14 in an effort to minimize the political damage from the increasing cost of reunification to West German taxpayers. Unemployment is heading toward one million in East Germany and cost estimates for bailing out East Germany's failing economy have risen into the scores of billions of dollars. **********The withdrawal of the Social Democrats apparently leaves the East German coalition Government with 192 votes in the 400-member Parliament -not enough to pass legislation to carry out unification. But it is unthinkable that the Social Democrats in East Berlin or in Bonn would vote against unification if it came to an up or down choice. **********The tactic chosen by the Social Democrats in both capitals is to say the sooner the better on unification, which could also be accomplished without a negotiated treaty. In this version, the East German Parliament would simply vote to approve the accession of East Germany to West Germany under Article 23 of the Bonn Constitution. The Social Democrats are suggesting Sept. 15 as unification day. **********Prime Minister de Maiziere says Sept. 15 would be too soon, and Chancellor Kohl apparently agrees.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/26/world.main_headline: Mexicans Hopeful as They Await Bush Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/26/world.print_headline: Mexicans Hopeful as They Await Bush Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/26/world.body_text: **********Seeking to capitalize on the warmest official American-Mexican relations in recent memory, Mexican authorities prepared for the arrival of President Bush here on Monday for a two-day state visit that is expected to focus largely on trade issues. **********The visit, which will be the sixth meeting between President Bush and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, is seen here as a confirmation of the good personal ties between the two leaders, who held their first talks even before Mr. Bush was sworn in as President.That theme has dominated descriptions of the meeting by aides to Mr. Salinas, who has staked much of his personal and political success on his ability to work as an equal with Mr. Bush in improving relations between the two countries. **********But officials familiar with the agenda said that the meeting would also include substantive talks, dominated by efforts to eliminate potential obstacles to a free-trade agreement that would link North American economies in a giant new trading partnership. **********They said the two leaders would also confront a variety of more divisiveissues, ranging from drug enforcement efforts to violence against illegal Mexican immigrants entering the United States near San Diego, where ethnic tensions have flared in recent months. Preventing Problems **********"This is not so much a meeting to solve problems as to prevent them," said a Mexican official involved in preparations for the visit. "We believe we have better relations with this Administration than with any other in years, and we don't want to lose the chance to keep things going forward." **********Preliminary discussions toward a Mexican-American free-trade agreement have been under way since the two Governments formally accepted the idea during a visit by Mr. Salinas to Washington in June. **********Since then, however, the environment for direct negotiations has been sharply affected by a series of international developments, ranging from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait to the stalemate of the Uruguay Round of international trade talks in Geneva. **********Among the major outstanding issues in the talks is the degree to which any free-trade agreement would cover Mexico's large oil sector, which Mr. Salinas has repeatedly said must be excluded from negotiation. American interest in that issue has grown with the potential for conflict in the Persian Gulf, but senior aides to Mr. Salinas asserted again last week that he would not accept oil as part of the trade package. **********Other concerns, officials said, include efforts in both countries to allay domestic opposition to the pact, which must overcome sharp differences in everything from wages to environmental restrictions. Diplomats and officials on both sides have also expressed worry over the potential political fallout from continued charges of fraud against Mr. Salinas's governing party, most recently during local elections Nov. 11 in the state of Mexico, just outside the capital. Canada's Role Is Issue **********The format of the trade negotiations themselves has also been thrown into question by the proposed participation of Canada, whose inclusion in any formal agreement would create a trading zone some 25 percent larger than theEuropean Community. **********A free-trade pact between the United States and Canada went into effect last year. But the announcement of negotiations toward a similar agreement between the United States and Mexico prompted immediate Canadian demands for some sort of participation or representation in the new talks. **********The idea of permitting a new participant at the negotiating table has been opposed by many proponents of the agreement, who have argued that it would slow the progress of the talks, which both sides hope to complete before the end of Mr. Bush's term in 1992. **********But senior Mexican officials now say that some degree of Canadian participation appears inevitable, if only in the form of an invited observer or other special status.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/22/busin.main_headline: Havel's Aides Meet U.S. Bankers On Investment in Czechoslovakia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/22/busin.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Havel's Aides Meet U.S. Bankers On Investment in Czechoslovakia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/22/busin.body_text: **********While President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia visited with President Bush and addressed Congress yesterday, his top economic advisers worked at cultivating investment for their country. **********Rather than meet directly with business executives, many of whom remain skeptical about investing in Czechoslovakia, the officials are trying to build a network of Wall Street advisers and investment bankers who would help the Czechoslovaks draw foreign investment. **********Two key architects of the evolving Czechoslovak economy are traveling with President Havel: Vladimir Dlouhy, the Minister of Planning, and Vaclev Klaus, the Minister of Finance. Both are strong advocates of foreign ownership of Czechoslovak companies to make them efficient and competitive in world markets. **********Party at the Guggenheim **********The two officials were guests in New York last night at a party at the Guggenheim Museum given by Salomon Brothers and at a private dinner at the home of William Luers, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a former United States Ambassador to Czechoslovakia. **********The dinner guest list included E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York; Anthony Solomon, the bank's former president and now an investment banker; Robert Hormats, an investment banker at Goldman, Sachs & Company, and Martin Feldstein, a Harvard economist who is advising the Czechoslovak Government. **********Rather than rely on foreign loans to modernize industry - loans that might result in a burdensome foreign debt -the Havel team would encourage foreign companies to put businesses in Czechoslovakia and also to purchase some major state-owned manufacturing operations. Josef Tosovsky, president of the State Bank of Czechoslovakia, said yesterday in Washington that President Havel is not seeking credits or loans during his visit to the United States. **********Legislation Planned **********The Havel Government is drafting legislation that would permit foreign ownership and make other changes favorable to foreign investment. Under current law, a foreign company can be only a minority partner in a joint venture. **********But anticipating that the necessary legislation will soon be adopted by Parliament, some big American companies are negotiating with state-owned Czechoslovak operations, particularly those manufacturers with products that could be exported to Western Europe, according to people involved in the discussions. **********The General Electric Company, for example, is holding talks with the Skoda Engineering Works, a manufacturer of power equipment and other machinery, in competition against Siemens A.G. The Chrysler Corporation has held talks with a separate Skoda company, the manufacturer of autos. One competitor is Mazda. The idea is to produce an American- or Japanese-designed car at a Skoda factory for export to Western Europe. The lures are Czechoslovak engineering and manufacturing skills and low wages. **********Talks on Glass Plants **********Numerous Western companies, including some from the United States, have also talked with the Czechoslovaks about investing in that country's famous glass factories, particularly those making auto glass, said Jan Vanos, president of PlanEcon, a Washington consulting firm that specializes in Eastern Europe. **********Smaller American companies have not gone beyond the inquiry stage, apparently preferring to wait until the new laws governing foreign investment are in place, said Fred Zeder, president of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a Government agency that insures foreign investment by American companies. **********Earlier this month, the Czechoslovaks asked Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, when he visited Prague, for help in forming a panel of American advisers. The group being formed includes Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve; John Whitehead, a former Deputy Secretary of State who is now an investment banker; Peter McPherson, executive vice president of the Bank of America, and Mr. Hormats. **********''The panel is mostly a way for the Czechs to strengthen their ties with the American financial community and with companies that are potential investors,'' Mr. Hormats said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/17/busin.body_text: **********Japanese financiers are making a strong push to expand their role in financing new office buildings in the United States just as American banks, dismayed by shrinking profit margins and loan losses from a glut of unoccupied buildings, are becoming more cautious and cutting back. **********The expansion by Japanese and other foreign banks into real estate lending led Citibank yesterday to announce a revamping of its real estate business to cut back on lending for large projects and concentrate on related fee-producting services. Bankers say they can often earn more from specialized transactions such as interest rate swaps than from direct loans. **********As the largest bank in the country, with the largest portfolio of real estate loans, Citibank has not avoided the losses from bad real estate loans that have hit many American banks over the last 18 months. In its annual report, Citibank said it expects the level of bad loans that are not currently paying interest to continue rising in 1990. **********Opportunity to Expand **********Already well known in real estate circles as buyers of prestigious office buildings, from Rockefeller Center in New York to the Arco Plaza in Los Angeles, Japanese bankers say they see an opportunity to expand their business and are busy hiring American experts in construction lending. **********Included among the new projects they are financing are buildings in Jersey City for Merrill Lynch & Company; an office tower next to Carnegie Hall in Manhattan, and the Park Hyatt Hotel in Santa Monica, Calif. **********''There is a real war going on for market share of first-class construction projects between foreign and domestic banks,'' said David Schulman, a real estate analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. ''The domestic banks have to decide if they want to fight for the large, high-visibility projects.'' **********Japanese bank executives recognize that real estate markets are slumping in many parts of the country. But looking ahead to better times, they want to become better established in real estate lending, particularly for new construction, because it can be much more profitable than other areas of bank lending. **********And to earn the greatest profits in the few good projects available, Japanese bankers want to take roles as lead banks, rather than continuing to be junior partners of American and other foreign banks. Executives at American and European banks and real estate developers say Japanese bankers will probably succeed. **********American bankers facing the stiffer competition from Japanese and other foreign banks say they are handicapped by fear of criticism from Federal bank regulators. Tougher standards by Federal bank examiners on real estate loans forced the Bank of New England Corporation to announce a $1.1 billion loss for 1989. **********And other banks around the country have pulled back from real estate lending until they know more about the new standards and there are more signs of stability in real estate prices. These new standards do not apply to branches of Japanese and other foreign banks, greatly improving their ability to attract developers' business. **********'Alternative Sources' **********Robert F. Upton, a vice president at the New York branch of the Mitsui Bank, said that the contraction of the savings and loan industry was also favoring expansion by Japanese bankers. **********''Developers who once worked with savings and loans who are no longer in business will now have to look for alternative sources of credit,'' said Mr. Upton, who joined the bank last October. Japanese banks are already active in making mortgage loans, he said, and are now hiring technical experts who can handle construction lending as well. **********Haruhiko Watanabe, vice president in the New York branch of the Fuji Bank, said that the Japanese bank could remain active in real estate financing during the slump because it was a conservative lender during the building boom of the 1980's and avoided the losses now hurting many American banks. ''Even though the market is bad, we think there can be good projects,'' he said. **********As Japanese banks gained experience, Mr. Watanabe said, they have received many loan requests from developers who were attracted by the lower interest rates available from Japanese banks. **********Henry Elghanayan, owner of the Rockrose Development Corporation, developer of a 60-story office building next to Carnegie Hall on 57th Street in mid-Manhattan, said that Fuji Bank's interest rate on a $125 million construction loan was a percentage point lower than that offered by American banks. ''And Fuji took the entire loan without it being conditioned on their being able to find other participants,'' he added. ''That's something U.S. banks don't do.'' **********For many years, American banks have welcomed the Japanese as junior members of the lending groups needed to finance large office buildings. Such sharing is likely to continue, bankers said, even though Japanese banks are now competing for the more profitable role of lead bank. **********Lower Rates for Juniors **********All junior members of lending groups for construction loans, not just Japanese banks, normally find themselves ''scalped,'' collecting a lower interest rate on their loan than the full rate charged to the borrower. The difference, typically five-hundredths to 25-hundredths of a percentage point, is pocketed by the lead bank. In addition, the lead banker usually keeps half or more of the loan commitment fee, which can equal about 1 percent of the total loan. **********Although the lead bank has more responsibilities and expenses, such as studying the feasibility of the project and monitoring construction so that money is not paid out faster than needed, the extra payments make the role of lead banker more profitable and very desirable. **********''As long as we were going to be involved and exposed to the risk of loss, we decided to do the business as a lead bank, in a way that gives us control over our destiny,'' said Yasuhisa Fujita, deputy general manager at the New York branch of the Tokai Bank Ltd. ''Japanese banks have been regarded as merely funds providers,'' Mr. Fujita said, ''but with the proper people, we can establish ourselves as professionals who can handle all aspects of the business.'' **********Mr. Fujita said Tokai planned to increase its American commercial real estate lending, including construction loans, by three or four times this year, but he declined to identify a dollar goal. **********Americans Hired **********To guide the expansion, the Japanese bank last year hired Kevin J. Mulvaney and Bruce F. Evans, two Americans with construction-lending experience at other banks. Among Tokai's early construction-lending efforts was co-managing with the Bank of Montreal a $180 million loan for an office building at 101 Hudson Street in Jersey City, where Merrill Lynch will move much of its back-office operations. **********Stephen W. Laver, a principal at the Trammel Crow Group, a real estate development firm, said Japanese lenders were involved to some degree in almost every Trammel Crow project. Rather than merely joining lending groups managed by others, he said, ''the Japanese banks are increasingly developing a direct-lending ability.'' **********One aspect where Japanese banks can be especially effective, he said, is in attracting money from other Japanese investors who want to own or make long-term investments in American buildings. Japanese regional banks, about three dozen of which have American offices, have money to invest but do not have the personnel to originate their own loans. They are prime candidates to participate in loans managed by larger banks like Tokai, Mr. Fujita said. **********Reputation for Price-Cutting **********In an effort to improve profitablity - an area where Japanese banks lag far behind competitors from other parts of the world - some Japanese bankers are trying to shed the image as price-cutters. **********''Profits in construction lending are already shrinking due to price competition, and we do not aim to aggravate that situation by competing for new deals on price,'' said Mr. Mulvaney of the Tokai Bank. ''Our pricing plan is to be the equal of American banks. We would rather do half as many deals if it meant the profit margins would be twice as high.'' **********As Japanese bankers push for more business, real estate experts are wondering if the Japanese can avoid the losses incurred by some savings and loan associations that reached for the profits of construction lending but ended up making too many bad loans. **********Japanese bankers vow that they will be cautious. But the real estate market has been treacherous, even for the most experienced American banks. **********''The near-term outlook for real estate is not positive,'' the Real Estate Research Corporation said in the 1990 edition of Emerging Trends in Real Estate. With domestic banks and insurance companies awash in bad loans, it said, ''increasingly active foreign banks might look at the carcasses before they try to pick up the slack.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;   U.S. Securities Narrowly Mixed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in a turbulent session yesterday, despite reports suggesting the economy is gathering strength and that inflation remains a real worry. **********The 6.7 percent rise in durable goods orders for March was much stronger than economists had projected. And the employment cost index, which rose by 5.5 percent from the first quarter of 1989 through the first quarter of 1990, was much worse in terms of inflation than market participants had hoped to see. **********Immediate market reaction to the numbers was negative, and yields on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 briefly touched 9 percent before a wave of buying ensued. Late in the day they yielded 8.95 percent, the same as Monday. **********Rumors that the Federal Reserve Board was about to tighten monetary policy pushed prices down again later in the day. Those declines were reversed when it became clear that the rumors were unfounded. **********After seven consecutive days of price declines, ''the upward bounce we got was strictly technical, because the news was awful,'' one Government bond trader said. ''The tone in the market is still the same,'' the trader added. ''It's terrible.'' **********Even though the reaction to the statistics was muted yesterday, Joe Liro, a vice president and money market economist at S.G. Warburg Securities Inc., said that ''in the long run, they were negative influences on the bond market.'' **********Durable Goods Figures **********The monthly durable goods figures are a ''wacko series in terms of their volatility,'' Mr. Liro added, but the March increase reversed a downtrend in orders that has been seen over the past few months. **********''I was not of the mind that we were having strong growth,'' Mr. Liro said. ''But the numbers are coming in a lot stronger than I had foreseen.'' **********After all its gyrations, by late in the day the Treasury's benchmark 8 1/2 percent bonds were offered at a price of 95 9/32, up 1/32. The minuscule improvement was the first gain registered in the last eight sessions. **********Prices were mixed In the secondary market for Treasury notes. **********In late trading the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 96 31/32, up 2/32, to yield 8.96 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 98 6/32, down 1/8 point, to yield 8.93 percent. **********Late yesterday the two-year Treasury notes expected to be offered at auction this afternoon were quoted at a price to yield 8.87 percent in when-issued trading, up from 8.83 percent on Monday. **********Treasury Bill Rates Mixed **********Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed. **********Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.74 percent late yesterday, down two basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates fell by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.88 percent. Meanwhile, one-year bill rates rose by two basis points, to an offered rate of 7.90 percent. **********An earnings report from RJR Nabisco that exceeded most analysts' expectations failed to have much impact on prices of the company's high-yield bonds. **********Prices of the company's payment-in-kind bonds jumped briefly after the report was released, but retreated later and closed little changed on the day. **********''I thought the numbers were positive, but they may already be reflected in the prices of the securities,'' said Dirk M. Van Doren, a senior analyst at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, a bond rating and research company. ''But the figures bode well for the future of the company.'' **********The report on RJR, a unit of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, was the highlight of an otherwise dull session in the high-yield market. Prices of most issues were little changed on the day. **********In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most actively quoted issues dipped by about 1/8 point. **********Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most issues fell by 1/4 point in quiet trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Document Processor Appoints a Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.body_text: **********Document Technologies Inc., a Palo Alto, Calif., company specializing in image processing products, named Dwight Ryan as chairman and chief executive yesterday. Mr. Ryan, 54 years old, is a 28-year veteran of the Xerox Corporation. **********Mr. Ryan succeeds Mark Potts, Document Technologies' founder, who will continue as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Potts will now focus on developing new business opportunities and concepts for the next generation of products. Mr. Ryan's priority will be on strengthening the marketing sales and customer support capabilities. **********''I've believed for some time that the electronic document imaging marketplace would be a major growth market for the 1990's,'' Mr. Ryan said in a statement. ''When I first reviewed the D.T.I. product family, I recognized technology that could indeed revolutionize the electronic document market.'' Image processing is based on converting paper documents into graphic images that can be stored and transmitted by computers. **********''It is exciting to be involved in an energetic start-up at this point in my career,'' Mr. Ryan said. ''D.T.I. has had excellent visionaries and technologists in the founders, great success with early customers, and now is poised to be a fast-paced growth company for the 1990's.'' Document Technologies began shipping production units for resale in the United States and Europe in 1989. **********Before joining Document Technologies, Mr. Ryan was president of the special markets group at Xerox. Other previous positions included vice president of marketing and president of the business systems group, and he was part of an executive team that redefined Xerox's major business strategies and reshaped the company into multiple business units in the early 1980's. **********Mr. Ryan received a B.S. degree in engineering from Cornell University and an M.B.A. from Rochester University. He is married, with three children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/30/busin.body_text: **********Three former employees of MAI Basic Four Inc. today settled Federal insider trading charges accusing them of buying Prime Computer Inc. securities after they learned that MAI Basic was planning to make a hostile bid for Prime in the fall of 1988. **********In a civil complaint filed in Federal court in Sacramento, Calif., the Securities and Exchange Commission had charged Dale T. Jabour, MAI's former director of accounting; Ronald Lee Thurman, the company's former director of financial planning, and Winston T. Cheong, described as a former staff business analyst. **********All three settled the civil charges without admitting or denying the allegations and were barred from further violation of Federal securities laws in the future. **********Betrand H. Weidberg, MAI Basic's general counsel, said Mr. Jabour had resigned from his position 18 months ago, after he informed the company about his purchases. **********Mr. Weidberg said an internal company investigation that followed Mr. Jabour's disclosure did not uncover the trades by Mr. Thurman and Mr. Cheong. They resigned only a short time ago, Mr. Weidberg said, after the company became aware of the S.E.C. investigation. **********Robert C. Rosen, a lawyer for Mr. Thurman and Mr. Cheong, criticized the agency for bringing the charges. **********As part of the settlement, Mr. Cheong and Mr. Thurman were ordered to repay $5,705 in profits from the trades. All three defendants were forced to pay penalties of a combined total of $27,505. The commission said that Mr. Jabour had already repaid $21,800 in profits to the people from whom he purchased call options on Prime stock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/busin.main_headline: JAPAN INVESTMENT IN U.S. PROPERTY OFF
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/busin.print_headline: JAPAN INVESTMENT IN U.S. PROPERTY OFF
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/busin.body_text: **********Japanese purchases of United States real estate fell 10.7 percent in 1989, with investment shifting from office buildings to hotels and resort properties, the real estate accounting firm Kenneth Leventhal & Company said today. **********The Japanese spent $14.8 billion on real estate in the United States last year, compared with $16.5 billion in 1988, the company's report said. **********Purchases of office properties fell about 60 percent to $3.3 billion in 1989 from $8.31 billion in 1988. Investment in hotel-resort properties rose to $4.16 billion last year, from $3.58 billion in 1988, a 16 percent increase. **********Over all, offices remain the favorite target of Japanese investors, said Jack Barthell, a Leventhal partner. Of the total $5.7 billion that the firm's data show as invested in United States real estate, 44 percent is in offices. **********The Japanese appear to be backing away from purchases of ''trophy properties,'' like Rockefeller Center, the study found. Mitsubishi Estate Company last year announced it was spending $846 million for a controlling interest in the compnay that owns Rockefeller Center, the New York office and cultural center. **********The study also noted that the Japanese still own just 2 percent of United States commercial real estate, far less than European investers. **********California was the leading state for the second year in a row, with 36 percent of the 1989 investment. Forty percent of the purchases were concentrated in the greater Los Angeles area. **********Hawaii was second and New York third, but interest among Japanese buyers in New York properties appears to be waning. **********''Most attractive properties have already been acquired, and the cost of acquisitions in Manhattan may cause investors to divert funds to other markets,'' Mr. Barthell said. **********The top three states accounted ofr 81 percent of the Japanese investment. **********Among the findings, investment in residential property jumped to 15 percent, triple the amount invested in 1988. Nearly two-thirds of that was in California, and 28 percnet in Hawaii. **********Leventhal said the size of Japanese deals is getting smaller as investment moves into smaller American cities, and that Japan's largest institutional investors are turning attention to Europe leading up to economic unification in 1992. **********Leventhal defines investment as both equity investment and convertible debt secured by United States real estate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/world.main_headline: Mandela and de Klerk Announce Agreement on New Date for Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/world.print_headline: Mandela and de Klerk Announce Agreement on New Date for Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/world.body_text: **********President F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela agreed today to reschedule formal talks between the Government and the African National Congress on a political settlement on South Africa's future. **********The talks, originally planned for April 11, were canceled by the African National Congress last week, after the police fired on anti-apartheid demonstrators. **********After three hours of unexpectedly amiable talks this evening at Tuynhuys, the President's office here, Mr. de Klerk told reporters that he and Mr. Mandela had settled on a new date, which he said would be announced ''fairly soon.'' **********'Cordial Nature' of Meeting **********Mr. Mandela said the date would be made public after it was cleared with the executive committee of the African National Congress, which remains in exile in Zambia. **********''The cordial nature of the discussions and the concessions that had been made by both sides gave us the impression that we are correct in sitting down with the Government,'' Mr. Mandela said at a news conference later. **********The breakthrough in the meeting occurred after President de Klerk promised an investigation of the police shooting of black protesters in Sebokeng, a township in the southern Transvaal, on March 26. **********De Klerk Orders Inquest **********At least 11 people were killed in the ensuing violence and more than 400 were wounded, many by shotgun pellets fired by the police. In protest, the African National Congress said last Saturday that it was pulling out of the April 11 talks. The two sides had been scheduled to discuss obstacles to the organization's formal participation in negotiations that Mr. de Klerk wants to hold on a new constitution that would extend political rights to the country's black majority. **********Some critics of the African National Congress suggested that it was stalling for time because it was unprepared to talk to the Government. Mr. Mandela reiterated tonight that the talks were suspended because of what he called ''the massacre of innocent and defenseless people in Sebokeng.'' **********President de Klerk said he had directed that an inquest into the deaths be carried out by a judge. He also said his Cabinet would discuss at its next meeting the appointment of a judicial commission of inquiry. **********''I have already given instructions for an in-depth investigation of what happened there,'' Mr. de Klerk told reporters after his meeting with Mr. Mandela and three other representatives of the African National Congress. **********Hopes for Talks With Pretoria **********Mr. de Klerk carefully avoided conceding that the police had been guilty of any brutality. ''They are there to protect life and property,'' he said. **********Mr. Mandela declined to appear with President de Klerk to talk to reporters after their meeting. But he said the ''cordial and pleasant atmosphere'' had resulted in a productive meeting. Mr. de Klerk, speaking separately, described their talks as not only ''very frank'' but also ''very fruitful.'' **********The meeting was the first between Mr. de Klerk and Mr. Mandela since the latter was freed after 27 1/2 years in prison. The two leaders met in December and in February, on the eve of Mr. Mandela's release. **********Tonight Mr. Mandela sounded more favorably disposed toward Mr. de Klerk than he had in his two months of freedom. He said his group was under the impression that the Government would address not only the incident in Sebokeng but also the broader issue of the surging factional violence afflicting the country, which he blamed on the deprivations of apartheid. **********Mr. Mandela said he was now hopeful that the full meeting scheduled between the Government and the African National Congress would be productive as well. Before it will enter negotiations, his organization is demanding that the Government declare an unconditional amnesty for exiles and political prisoners, including those accused of common crimes, lift the national state of emergency and end political trials. **********Mr. de Klerk also said the African National Congress's continuing endorsement of armed struggle would be one of the issues the Government would raise in the larger talks. **********Call for 'Credible Leaders' **********Mr. Mandela said he hoped that the government inquiry into the shootings in Sebokeng would also include blacks ''regarded as credible leaders'' by the community, a usual reference to those supporting the African National Congress and its allies. **********Earlier today, President de Klerk, who is trying to attract as many black leaders as possible to join the negotiations he has proposed, was to have met the leaders of the six self-governing ethnic homelands. But the only ones to appear were the Zulu leader, Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi and Cedric Mopedi, the leader of Kwa Kwa. Chief Buthelezi said he came in his capacity as head of the Zulu political organization, Inkatha, and not as the chief minister of Kwa Zulu, the Zulu homeland. **********The homelands, which Pretoria created to reduce the number of blacks living around urban areas reserved for whites, have been widely regarded as artificial entities and their leaders as puppets. **********South Africa's homeland policy suffered a further setback today when a military coup toppled the government of Venda, one of four other homelands declared independent by Pretoria. Transkei and Ciskei are now run by military governments following coups there. The South African Army in early 1988 crushed an attempted coup in Bophuthatswana, the fourth homeland.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/24/busin.body_text: **********The Education Department said today that it would try to resolve a financial crisis at one of the nation's largest guarantors of student loans. **********The Higher Education **********Assistance Foundation, a nonprofit corporation based in Overland Park, Kan., guarantees nearly $10 billion in student loans. **********The foundation told the department that it faced serious financial problems. **********Etta Fielek, a department spokeswoman, said Higher Education had asked Congress and the department to approve a federally assisted takeover by another guarantor, the Nebraska Student Loan Program. But Ms. Fielek said: ''There's a problem of scale. **********There's concern on the part of the department that Nebraska would be too small an operation to consume something the magnitude of H.E.A.F.'' **********According to The Wall Street **********Journal today, Higher Education expects a cash shortfall of $50 million to $100 million in the next 12 months. **********Separately, the Student Loan **********Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, does not expect problems at Higher Education to have any material effect on its earnings, a spokeswoman for Sallie Mae said. The foundation is a large guarantor of loans for Sallie Mae.
