https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/09/busin.main_headline:
Your Own Account;

Choices, Choices in the 401 (k)
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/09/busin.print_headline:
Your Own Account;

Choices, Choices in the 401 (k)
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/09/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: When employers began to introduce 401 (k) retirement plans nearly a decade ago, they billed them as an opportunity for employees to control their own retirement money. The employer offered a range of investment choices and employees could be as aggressive - or as conservative - as they wished. **********These plans allow employees to set aside a portion of their pre-tax salary. The 1990 legal limit is $7,979, although employers often impose lower limits. Employers typically match a portion of the contribution, from 25 cents on the dollar up to a full dollar. Earnings on the money grow tax deferred. **********A July survey of 313 employers by Foster Higgins found that 88 percent allow employees to choose among investment options. And improving a plan has typically meant more options, Mr. Ternoey said. ''The idea has been that choice is good,'' he said. ''What we've found is that if you don't spend time explaining investment concepts, more choice is of no use and can even be misleading.'' **********In fact, surveys show that a large percentage of 401 (k) money goes into the most conservative option - guaranteed investment contracts,or G.I.C.'s, which promise a specific rate of return. ''People invest for themselves in 401 (k) plans much more conservatively than their employers invest pension plan money,'' said Barbara J. Pope, director of personal financial services for Price Waterhouse in Chicago. **********Conservative investing doesn't vary much by industry, either. Christine Seltz, partner at Hewitt Associates, benefits consultants based in Lincolnshire, Ill., points out that ''If you look at a group of what we think of as high flyers, like investment bankers, they have the same pattern. The bulk of the money is going into G.I.C.'s.'' **********Keeping your money safe for retirement is an important goal, to be sure. But, these consultants point out, if you don't achieve a decent return on your money, you won't have enough. ''We haven't given employees a good enough idea of what they will need for retirement,'' said Marvin H. Greene, a consultant with Towers Perrin, New York-based benefits consultants. **********A couple of simple strategies can improve the 401 (k) performance, these consultants say. ''We're not talking about turning people into M.B.A.'s and Wall Street wizards,'' Mr. Ternoey said. ''If you just take some basic investment concepts and let them operate, you'll end up with a better account balance.'' **********Put some of your money into stock, these experts say, by investing either in an equity mutual fund or your company's stock. ''When you're looking at a long-time horizon - 15, 20, 30 years - a portion has to be in equities because over the long haul, that's where you'll get the best return,'' Ms. Pope said. And a difference of just 1.5 percentage points compounded over a working lifetime can make a huge difference, said Mr. Greene. **********Mr. Ternoey pointed out that 401 (k) plans provide an ideal opportunity to make use of an investment technique called dollar cost averaging because the money you contribute is deducted from each paycheck. Dollar cost averaging is a method of buying stock or mutual fund shares by investing the same amount of money on a regular schedule regardless of the market price. **********Your dollars buy more shares when the price is down, fewer when it's up. Studies show that investors who use this strategy pay less per share over time than those who make their investments in a lump sum. **********You should also diversify, and you should check the performance of your investments regularly. For example, Mr. Ternoey has just two options with his 401 (k) plan: a stock mutual fund into which he puts 75 percent of his money and a guaranteed investment contract, 25 percent. **********He also checks periodically to see if the two investments are still in balance. If the stock market is soaring, the portion in stocks might grow to 80 or 85 percent. Then he moves some back into the G.I.C. ''It's a passive way to buy low and sell high,'' he said. And he forces himself to rebalance his fund at regular intervals. ''As much as my guts tell me I want to do one thing, I've got my rule and I stick with it,'' he said. **********Another simple strategy is to hedge by putting your current investments into one account and directing new money to a different account, he said. For example, if you are nervous about the outlook for the stock market, you may want to move some of your accumulated money out of the stock fund to preserve gains. However, it makes sense to direct new money into the stock fund. ''If you really think the market's going to go down, why don't you hedge your bets by putting your money from the next few payroll deductions into the market?'' he said. ''If it does go down, you'll be buying at the bottom. If you're wrong, you haven't fully committed yourself one way or another.'' **********WHAT EMPLOYERS OFFER **********Nearly nine out of 10 employers allow employees to choose among investment options for their contributions to 401 (k) plans, according to a new survey by A. Foster Higgins & Company. **********The survey found that 59 percent allow employees to choose where all of their 401 (k) retirement money will go while 29 percent allow an investment choice only for some of the money. **********Of those employers who provide a choice, 26 percent provide two options; 39 percent give three options; 18 percent, fouroptions and 17 percent, five or more options, according to Foster Higgins. **********The most common option is a guaranteed investment contract, an insurance company product that offers a guaranteed return, and a similar product offered by banks. These products are offered by 88 percent of those surveyed. The survey found that 83 percent offer stock mutual funds; 42 percent, company stock, and 26 percent, a money market fund.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/03/busin.main_headline: Dow Slumps 34.66 Points, But Oils Soar
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/03/busin.print_headline: Dow Slumps 34.66 Points, But Oils Soar
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/03/busin.body_text: **********Inflation fears touched off by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait pushed most stock prices lower yesterday, including airlines and other users of petroleum products, but sent oil and oil-service stocks sharply higher. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which had sunk as much as 52 points around 11:30, closed at 2,864.60, down 34.66, or 1.2 percent. Trading activity soared to the highest level in nine months. **********Eight of the 10 most active issues on the New York Stock Exchange included some of the world's biggest oil companies. Leading the list, Chevron rose 1 5/8, to 80 3/8, with nearly 12 million shares changing hands, and reached a new high of 81 1/4 during trading. Texaco, No. 2, surged 2 5/8, to 66 5/8, on 6.2 million shares and also reached a new high, of 68 1/2, before falling back. **********Volume Up Sharply **********Volume jumped to 253.1 million shares from a strong 176.8 million the day before, but 1,211 stocks fell, 144 hit new lows and only 464 advanced. Activity was the heaviest since Oct. 16, when volume soared to 416.3 million after the previous session's slide. **********Although crude oil prices have been climbing, analysts maintained that the situation in the Middle East was so fluid that the direction of prices was uncertain and would continue that way for some time. Hugh Johnson, head strategist for the Albany Corporation, a brokerage firm, said, ''If oil prices stay high, it could endanger the economic recovery, which is closing in on its eighth anniversary.'' **********The oil price rise also ''darkens the outlook for the economies of West Germany and Japan,'' he said, noting that they rely more heavily than the United States on Middle Eastern oil. **********Saudi Reaction Awaited **********''The key economic question,'' said Peter J. Canelo, investment strategist for the Wall Street firm of Bear, Stearns & Company, ''is where does the price of oil go?'' The big consideration, he added, ''may prove to be what the Saudis do.'' **********He argued that it was in the interest of Saudi Arabia and most members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to maintain moderate prices. After consultation with Stephen A. Smith, the Bear, Stearns oil analyst, he described his idea of moderate as around $18 a barrel for Saudi crude and the ''low 20's'' for West Texas intermediate. **********''If Iraq really wants the price to stay high and cuts Kuwait's production, will the Saudis make up that shortfall?'' he asked. ''We believe the Saudis will increase production to achieve stability.'' **********Program trading - particularly program selling - helped push the market down sharply. Birinyi Associates, which tracks such activity, said the net effect of the buying and selling was to lop slightly more than 19 points off the Dow. **********Other Oil Stocks Up **********Among other oil stocks on the Big Board active list, Exxon rose 1 1/8, to 53 1/4, also reaching a new high of 55. Mobil rose 1 7/8, to 67 1/4, a new high. USX, which owns oil interests, rose 1/2, to 34 5/8. Phillips Petroleum rose 7/8, to 29 5/8, after a new high of 30 1/2. Unocal, the 10th-most-active stock, rose 2 1/8, to 33 1/4, with 3.2 million shares changing hands. **********Arco gained 5, to 135 1/2; British Petroleum 4, to 79 3/4; Oryx Energy, 3 3/8, to 52 1/4; Amoco 2 7/8, to 58 1/4; Amerada Hess 2 7/8, to 52; Union Pacific, which has oil and gas interests, 2 3/8, to 77 7/8 and Pennzoil 2 1/4, to 84 3/8. **********Companies that serve the oil producers also gained. Schlumberger rose 2 1/4, to 68 3/4, hitting a new high of 69. Dresser rose 2 1/8, to 55 1/2, with a new high of 55 3/4. McDermott International rose 2, to 34 1/2, yet another high. **********Mr. Canelo of Bear, Stearns argued that ''if the energy sector benefits from higher oil prices, other sectors will be forced to pay the cost.'' He mentioned consumer durables and particularly cars, airlines, some utilities using oil and energy-intensive industries, like steel and aluminum. **********Utilities Hold Up **********Ford fell 1 1/4, to 39 7/8; G.M. 1 1/2, to 43 7/8, and Chrysler 5/8, to 14 3/8. Except for UAL, which fell 5 7/8, to 130 on financing woes, airline stocks fell slightly. Utility stocks held up well. Reynolds Metals lost 1 1/4, to 65, and Alcoa 1, to 67 1/4. **********In response to a gold price rise, gold stocks advanced, with Newmont Mining, rising 1 3/4, to 51 5/8. **********Fund American, which is selling Fireman's Fund to Allianz A.G., rose 11 5/8, to 49 3/4. But with a drop in bond prices depressing insurance investments, insurance stocks fell. A.I.G., a market favorite, fell 3, to 71. **********Drug stocks fell in the wake of strong increases already made this year. Bristol Myers fell 2 3/4, to 62 1/4. Lilly 2, to 82 5/8, Merck 2 5/8, to 87 1/4 and Syntex 2 3/8, to 59 1/8.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/busin.print_headline: TALKING DEALS; Regulatory Pitfall In Telmex Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/busin.body_text: **********A HIDDEN regulatory pitfall may await the buyers in the Mexican Government's recent sale of the controlling stake in the country's telephone company. **********The Federal Communications Commission is considering regulatory changes that could sharply curtail Telefonos de Mexico's most profitable business, the handling of calls from the United States. The regulatory review has already put the GTE Corporation in an awkward position and may now create problems for the Southwestern Bell Corporation, which is part of a consortium that won the Mexican Government's auction on Dec. 7. **********Grupo Carso of Mexico, France Telecom and Southwestern Bell paid $1.7 billion on Dec. 20 to buy a controlling 20.4 percent stake in Telmex, which includes 51 percent of the votes in the company. **********France Telecom filed a brief statement with the F.C.C. during its two public comment periods in the fall saying that it was reducing the fees it collects in France for completing international calls, but Southwestern Bell filed no documents. Ronald W. Hall, a company spokesman, said that would change. **********"We will protect our interests," he said. "Now that we're certain we have it, we'll be much more interested in participating." **********Royce S. Caldwell, a group president at Southwestern Bell, said in an interview after the Telmex auction that the buyers intended to reduce international fees somewhat over the next few years anyway. **********Telmex's main source of profits lies in charging American long-distance companies for receiving more calls from the United States than it sends. Last year, these fees totaled $534 million for Telmex, or nearly a quarter of its revenues of $2.2 billion. Telmex collected more of these fees fromAmerican carriers than did any four other foreign telephone monopolies combined. **********The actual cost of handling incoming international calls is minimal because of technological changes. For example, operators are not needed for most international calls, but the fees include them. The F.C.C. proposed new rules for the fees last summer, in an effort to halve the price to consumers within three years, and it is asking foreign telephone companies to reduce fees voluntarily. **********James S. Kahan, Southwestern Bell's managing director of corporate development, told a recent meeting with Wall Street analysts that his company was counting on Telmex's fees from American long-distance carriers as a source of dollar-denominated revenues to protect it against changes in the exchange rate between the peso and the dollar. **********The F.C.C.'s interest in reducing these rates could put Southwestern Bell in the awkward position of deciding whether to defend the interests of its American customers, who would benefit from lower prices for international calls, or those of its Mexican customers, who are currently subsidized by profits from the international fees. Mr. Hall said that if the fees were entirely eliminated, which isunlikely, Telmex could raise local telephone rates an average of $100 a year, or about $8.30 a month, a move that would be unpopular in Mexico. **********Southwestern Bell was aware of the F.C.C.'s deliberations before it bid, said Patricia Diaz Dennis, a Washington lawyer and former F.C.C. commissioner who is advising Southwestern Bell in the deal. **********Telmex reached an agreement last year with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to reduce its fees by a third by 1999, which might lessen pressure from regulators, Mrs. Dennis said. But she added that the commission was likely to examine payments to Telmex anyway, given their size. **********Two groups of Latin American countries have filed documents with the F.C.C. opposing the proposed rule changes. They contend the changes would make it harder to turn their state-owned telephone companies over to the private sector, if there was a threat that the companies' international fee revenues would shrink soon. **********GTE has sided with them for different reasons. It owns the Compania Dominicana de Telefonos, better known as Codetel, which has a near monopoly on local telephone service in the Dominican Republic. GTE has filed two documents with the F.C.C. objecting to reductions in international rates, and earlier this month its officials began lobbying the commission personally, F.C.C. records show. **********The company contends in its filings that if the commission does act, countries receiving American foreign aid and buying large quantities of American-made telephone switching equipment should receive waivers. **********GTE makes telecommunications equipment in a joint venture with A.T.& T. And Codetel collected $75.3 million last year in international calling fees from American long-distance carriers, up from $8.2 million 10 years earlier. According to the F.C.C., only the much larger countries of Mexico, West Germany, the Philippines, South Korea and Japan received larger fees last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge is taking a constitutional challenge of President Bush's savings and loan association rescue program under consideration after acknowledging that a ruling against the Government could have a far-reaching impact. The Olympic Federal Savings and Loan Association of Berwyn, Ill., asked United States District Judge Royce C. Lamberth on Tuesday to block any Federal takeover of the weakly capitalized savings and loan association. **********Olympic is disputing the constitutional authority of the acting director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, Salvatore R. Martoche, as well as the director he replaced, M. Danny Wall. Its lawyers say that any move to seize Olympic would be illegal. **********Government lawyers disputed the argument but said that in any case the public interest in seeing the savings industry bailout progress overrode any points Olympic might win. **********Aaron B. Kahn, a lawyer for the Office of Thrift Supervision, said a decision favoring Olympic would open the floodgates to scores of similar suits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/05/busin.main_headline: Boesky Released on Parole, Ending 3-Year Prison Term
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/05/busin.print_headline: Boesky Released on Parole, Ending 3-Year Prison Term
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/05/busin.body_text: **********At 5:05 yesterday morning, Ivan F. Boesky became a free man. **********Mr. Boesky, who gained fame for his ability to pick stocks and infamy when he admitted in 1986 that his skill was based on cheating, signed papers for his release from a halfway house in Brooklyn, ending a three-year prison term that he began in 1988. He was paroled for good behavior. **********Mr. Boesky, 53 years old, was transferred to Brooklyn in December from a minimum-security prison in Lompoc, Calif., where he was serving his sentence for one count of securities fraud. But since Feb. 5, he has been required only to telephone the halfway house every day and to report in person twice a week. **********Robert McCaw, one of Mr. Boesky's lawyers, said yesterday that his client was ''in good spirits.'' Mr. Boesky, he added, had few long-term plans. **********Mr. Boesky must still report to a probation officer each month for six months. He must also continue to cooperate in the securities fraud investigation of Michael R. Milken, the former head of the high-yield ''junk bond'' division of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., whose parent company has sought bankruptcy protection. He is also expected to testify if the case goes to trial. **********When he pleaded guilty to the criminal charge in 1987, Mr. Boesky agreed to cooperate with the Government in the investigations of Drexel and Mr. Milken. Although the criminal case against Mr. Boesky has ended, he faces civil complaints from investors who say he defrauded them. **********While Mr. Boesky does have assets, his net worth, in large part because of loans, is virtually nothing, Mr. McCaw said yesterday. He will be living at his 75-acre estate in Westchester County, near the residences of several other Wall Street financiers and takeover artists who had once been the staple of his business. **********While at the halfway house in Brooklyn, Mr. Boesky worked as a consultant, earning about $200 a week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/14/busin.body_text: **********The National Association of Securities Dealers has fined the Stuart-James Company more than $2 million for overcharging companies. It is one of the largest fines ever levied against a brokerage firm by the N.A.S.D., which polices over-the-counter stock trading. **********The purported overcharges involved more than 4,000 stock transactions in 1988, the association said. Stuart-James is one of the nation's largest over-the-counter investment banking firms, with 40 retail offices nationwide and more than 1,000 brokers. **********The N.A.S.D. announced last week that as part of its settlement with the Englewood-based brokerage, it was fining Stuart-James $1.9 million; its president and owner, James Padgett, $105,000; its former chairman and co-owner, Stuart Graff, $25,000, and its head trader, Steven Pata, $30,000. **********Under the agreement, Mr. Padgett was barred from being involved in a supervisory capacity in the company's markup area for six months, Mr. Graff was suspended from acting as the company's principal for 60 days and Mr. Pata was suspended for 20 days. They agreed to the sanctions without admitting or denying guilt. **********The association said Stuart-James's markups ranged from 6.9 percent to 153 percent over their cost, when the firm dominated and controlled the trading of the securities. It cited low-priced and penny stocks. **********As part of the settlement, Stuart-James agreed to stop making markets in low-priced stocks and to send customers written confirmation of the highest ask and bid prices in certain securities at the time of sale. **********Last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission filed excessive-markup charges against the firm and also accused it of a number of other securities violations. Stuart-James, Mr. Padgett, Mr. Graff and other current and former executives of the firm are now on trial before an S.E.C. administrative law judge.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/world.main_headline: Ivory Trading Ban Said to Force Factories to Shut
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/world.print_headline: Ivory Trading Ban Said to Force Factories to Shut
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/world.body_text: **********Major ivory carving factories in Asia that produced jewelry, figurines and tourist trinkets have virtually closed down since a world ban on ivory trading came into force this year, says an expert in the trade who just finished a survey of the ban. **********The expert, Esmond Bradley Martin, who just completed a three-month inspection of the elephant ivory and rhinoceros horn trade for the World Wide Fund for Nature, said that in Beijing only 5 of 550 ivory carvers are still employed at the Beijing Ivory Carving Factory, which last year was the biggest in the world. **********In Hong Kong, one of the largest sellers of ivory, 75 percent of the craftsmen are out of business, he said. He estimated that sales of carved ivory in Hong Kong stores, which mostly are made to tourists, were down by at least half. **********The ban on international trading in elephant ivory, agreed to by more than 90 countries in October, came into force in January. **********Many African and Western governments, backed by international conservation groups, pushed for the ban as a way of preserving the African elephant. In the last decade it is estimated that rampant poaching in eastern and central Africa has reduced the elephant population from about 1.3 million to about 750,000. During that time the price of ivory soared. **********An official of the African Wildlife Foundation, which along with the World Wide Fund for Nature lobbied heavily for the ban, said Mr. Bradley Martin's findings showed that the ban was working. ''It's having a much greater effect in a shorter period of time than anyone expected,'' said the official, Mark Stanley Price, director of the African Wildlife Foundation office in Nairobi. Dr. Bradley Martin said the demand from tourists for ivory had not vanished. ''Europeans and Americans are still buying ivory, but small pieces,'' he said. These are easier to hide in pockets or luggage than the bigger items, he said. **********The ivory ban is to be reviewed in two years and there was hope in the carving industry that it would then be repealed, Mr. Bradley-Martin said. **********In Beijing and Canton, site of another large carving factory, the ivory carvers are being asked to stay home but are being compensated with 75 percent of their salaries by the factories, he said. At the Daxin factory in Canton, the second largest after Beijing, only one worker remains of the 400 who were there in June last year. **********In Japan, the largest consumer of ivory, Mr. Bradley Martin said the price of ivory tusks had risen because the country had agreed to abide by the international trade ban. About 100 tons of raw ivory were left in Japan at the time of the ban, about the amount that the country uses in one year. But Mr. Bradley Martin said Japan, unlike other countries, did not have a history of receiving smuggled ivory and it seemed unlikely that illegal African elephant ivory would find a market there. **********In two African countries where elephant poaching has been most severe, Kenya and Tanzania, poaching has declined since the ban. Stepped up anti-poaching efforts and a less certain market for new tusks in the wake of the ban seem to have curbed the slaughter, experts said. **********But two months ago, Richard E. Leakey, the director of Kenya's wildlife service, said 57 elephants had been killed in Tsavo National Park since January. He said 12 tons of tusks, many of them from freshly killed animals, had been intercepted in Kenya and Tanzania. **********He attributed this to Britain's decision to allow Hong Kong to sell a 670-ton stockpile of ivory, the biggest in the world. ''I don't think it is any coincidence, particularly when the people arrested said under interrogation that the ivory would be sent to Hong Kong for sale,'' Dr. Leakey said. **********Conservationists take heart, however, from the poor prices that poachers are getting for ivory within Africa. Ivory sold in Kismayu, a traditional transit point for ivory on the southern coast of Somalia, was being sold with difficulty this year for only $2 to $3 a kilogram.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/busin.main_headline: Decision Is Near on Bonwit's Fate
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/busin.print_headline: Decision Is Near on Bonwit's Fate
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/busin.body_text: **********Efforts to sell Bonwit Teller, the century-old retailer based in New York, appear to have reached an impasse yesterday, store executives and garment industry suppliers said, and speculation mounted that the 16-store chain may be on the brink of liquidation. But a spokesman for Sanford C. Sigoloff, chief executive of the L. J. Hooker Corporation, Bonwit's parent company, said the fate of the retailer would be decided next week. **********''No decision has been made yet, but we are close,'' the spokesman said. **********Both Bonwit Teller and B. Altman & Company filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in August, as did its parent company. All but one of the seven B. Altman stores have since been liquidated, including the Manhattan flagship store at Fifth Avenue and 34th Street. The B. Altman store in the Forest Fair Mall in Cincinnati remains open. Bonwit Teller was put up for sale. Bonwit, whose flagship store is in the Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue, lost $23 million in the last three years. Most of the stores are on the East Coast and in the Midwest, with two in Florida. **********Pyramid Offer Rejected **********Yesterday, Women's Wear Daily reported that an offer from the Pyramid Companies, a Syracuse mall developer, to buy some of the Bonwit stores had been rejected by the Bonwit Teller creditors' committee. In a Chapter 11 situation, any sale of assets has to be approved by a committee of creditors and, ultimately, by the court. **********Rumors swept Seventh Avenue that Bonwit would soon suffer the same fate as B. Altman and provide yet another body blow to the New York retail community during the Easter selling season. Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus are both struggling to survive the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing of the retail division of their parent company, the Campeau Corporation. Price-slashing from a Bonwit Teller liquidation would further complicate its spring business. **********Turnaround Specialist **********Mr. Sigoloff, a turnaround specialist hired to run Hooker, the United States division of the Hooker Corporation of Australia, declined to comment on the reports. **********But a spokesman for Mr. Sigoloff's company, Sanford Sigoloff Associates, in Santa Monica, Calif., said a decision had been expected yesterday but was postponed until next week. **********''Right now, there are a number of things on the table,'' he said. ''Pyramid is still involved in the discussions.'' **********He added that there were other ''entities'' expressing interest in buying the stores, but he would not name them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/busin.main_headline: All Nippon Is Planning $3.3 Billion Jet Order
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   All Nippon Is Planning $3.3 Billion Jet Order
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/busin.body_text: **********All Nippon Airways said today that it planned to buy about 30 medium-sized passenger jets for about $3.3 billion, substantially increasing its fleet. **********A company executive said a committee led by the company's vice president, Keisuke Inui, would take about three months to choose the aircraft. **********They aircraft under consideration are: the Boeing Company's 777, with a seating capacity of 407, which Seattle-based Boeing is developing with Japanese assistance; the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's MD-11, with a capacity of 380; Airbus Industrie's A330, with a capacity of 385, and the Airbus A340 with a capacity of 262 to 295. Boeing has still not announced whether it will build the 777. **********All Nippon will introduce the new planes in a four- or five-year period starting in 1995, the executive, who asked not to be named, said. **********The executive said the introduction of the aircraft is aimed at meeting passenger demand that is expcted to increase in the mid-1990's with the completion of three big Japanese airport projects. **********Japan's first airport for 24-hour operation is being built on a man-made island in Osaka Bay and is scheduled to open by 1993. Two more runways will be added at the New Tokyo International Airport at Narita. And Tokyo's Haneda Airport, used mostly by domestic carriers, will be expanded. **********All Nippon, formerly limited to domestic routes, has grown in recent years since the Ministry of Transport permitted it to fly some international routes. The company currently operates 105 aircraft. In 1988 and 1989, it ordered 46 planes, which are scheduled to begin flights this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/world.main_headline: Higher Incomes, U.N. Finds, Do Not Assure a Better Life
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/world.print_headline: Higher Incomes, U.N. Finds, Do Not Assure a Better Life
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/world.body_text: **********Challenging traditional ways by which the world has measured the growth of nations, a new report issued by the United Nations Development Program concludes that there is no automatic link between a country's per capita income and the well-being and progress of its people. **********The Human Development Report 1990, prepared by an international team under the direction of Mahbubul Haq, former Minister of Finance and Planning in Pakistan, is intended to touch off a debate in the last decade of this century over why some nations, however poor in resources, make life better and others fail. **********''People cannot be reduced to a single dimension as economic creatures,'' William H. Draper, administrator of the Development Program, says in an introduction. In an age of democratic urges, he says, factors like longevity, education, human rights and political freedoms must be part of growth. #15 Countries Are Cited The report singles out 15 countries that have achieved relatively high levels of development in democratic, or ''reasonably democratic,'' settings. These are Botswana, Colombia, Costa Rica, Jamaica, Malaysia, Mexico, Mauritius, Trinidad and Tobago, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Tunisia, Turkey, Uruguay, Venezuela and Zimbabwe. **********''Life does not begin at $11,000, the average per capita income in the industrial world,'' it adds. ''Sri Lanka managed a life expectancy of 71 years and an adult literacy rate of 87 percent with a per capita income of $400.'' **********In South Asia, Sri Lanka is the exception. The nations of this region - from Afghanistan through Pakistan, India, Nepal and Bhutan to Bangladesh - are all among the countries where human development is lowest, the report says. **********The findings confirm what is daily becoming more readily observable: that the Asian ''miracle'' is largely confined to Southeast Asia and East Asia, and that claims by India that it be included among newly industrializing countries cannot be justified in broader development terms. **********South Asia Lags in Vital Areas **********In plotting regional aggregates of human development over nearly 30 years, South Asia falls behind all other regions of the world except sub-Saharan Africa in improving calorie intake, life expectancy of children under 5, adult literacy and access to basic health care. **********Meanwhile, populations continue to grow at a very fast rate in an area where more than a billion people are already straining natural resources and where governments are spending large amounts of their revenues on the military and law enforcement. **********By virtually every measure of material human progress, China, the world's most populous nation, outstrips India, a democratic country whose leaders contend that the Chinese have been more successful only because they apply policies coercively. **********The report introduces a new measure of growth, the Human Development Index, based on a three-step calculation of deprivation measured in three basic variables: life expectancy, literacy and real disposable income. **********The report is published by the Oxford University Press in Oxford, England, and in New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/busin.body_text: **********The First Executive Corporation said today that it planned to refinance $275 million of bank debt, putting off large payments to lenders for several years to protect its capital base. Under the plan, dividend payments to common and preferred stockholders would be stopped. **********First Executive, an insurance holding company based in Los Angeles, had been considering such a restructuring for several months to postpone making the first of three large payment to lenders next year. Payments were coming due of $46.5 million on March 31, $184.5 million in 1993 and $44 million in 1995. **********While First Executive maintains that it could have made the $46.5 million payment due next March, a restructuring would prevent a further drain on company finances. **********Under the preliminary agreement, the company will make a $30 million payment to borrowers participating in the restructuring. Then about $245 million in new notes at a higher interest rate will be issued, coming due in equal installments in 1996, 1997 and 1998. **********First Executive also said it had told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it might restructure its preferred stock obligations. The company said there was no guarantee either restructuring would be consummated. **********First Executive has been hurt badly by losses of hundreds of millions of dollars caused by the declining value of the company's "junk bond" portfolio. **********The well-publicized problems caused concern among policy holders and for a time surrenders of policies were well above normal levels, though the company says that is no longer the case. In the wake of the crisis, the company's ability to borrow large sums has been shut off. **********Regulators in California, who are conducting a special review of First Executive's insurance activities, have prevented the company from transferring large amounts of money from its California subsidiary to the parent company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/25/busin.main_headline: Bankers Face Increasing Skepticism Among Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/25/busin.print_headline: Bankers Face Increasing Skepticism Among Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/25/busin.body_text: **********The high dividend that Citicorp was forced to pay today on a preferred stock issue served as a reminder that many investors are skeptical about the strength of large banks despite assurances by bankers and regulators that they are solvent. **********Bankers gathered here for a meeting of the American Bankers Association noted that data of the Federal Reserve through mid-October show that Citicorp and other large banking companies like Chase and Chemical have not been hit with enough deposit withdrawals to force them to borrow at the Fed's discount window. **********But problems with bad real estate loans and weak earnings at the large banks have made investors and depositors more nervous than at any time since the Federal deposit insurance program was created in 1933. **********Short-term deposit ratings for the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company are all lower than the highest grade assigned by Moody's Investor Services, which many investors require. Citicorp, however, still has a top Moody's rating.   Demanding Higher Yields **********In the financial markets, corporate treasurers are demanding high yields in return for taking the risk of holding bank securities, whose values might decline in the current weak banking climate. Still, analysts are not predicting that any large banks will become insolvent anytime soon. **********Corporate treasurers are not the only American financiers to feel uneasy about large New York City banks. The chief credit officer at one large regional bank with more than $15 billion of assets said he recently stopped making overnight and short-term loans to some New York banks and has sharply cut back lending to weaker New York banks with which he does large amounts of other business. "I don't get paid enough to take the risk," he said, adding that there are many lower-risk alternatives. **********Michael Esposito, chief financial officer at Chase Manhattan, said that "some lines have been cut," referring to credit lines from banks that in years past routinely lent their excess cash to Chase. In the Eurodollar market, where large New York banks are heavy borrowers from foreign institutions, Mr. Esposito said interest rates paid by Chase had moved up relative to that paid by some other banks. Things have jumped around for a month or two, he said, "but they will come back to normal." **********Bankers and regulators meeting here also expressed concern that talk about changing the Federal Deposit Insurance System could intensify the fears of depositors, possibly prompting them to withdraw their funds from banks. About 35 percent of the public believes that the banking system is unhealthy, according to a recent survey by the American Banker, the trade newspaper.  Regulator Calls for Caution **********"In this environment, we need to be awfully careful when talking about deposit insurance reform," said Robert L. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency, the top regulator for most of the nation's largest banks. "Let's not spook people, depositors, into making irrational decisions," he said in an interview here. **********Many recent proposals, like cutting the amount of deposits covered by insurance or requiring automatic losses for large depositors at failed banks, can be dangerous, Mr. Clarke said. "They all sound like a pulling away of the support system that traditionally existed for the banking industry," he said. **********Robert H. Smith, chairman of the Security Pacific Corporation in Los Angeles, said that "if there is change in deposit insurance, it is important that it be done with a great deal of caution, and over time." **********A key aspect of deposit insurance for large banks is the extent to which Federal insurance protects deposits above the ceiling of $100,000 per account. Last month, Federal Reserve officials urged the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to protect all foreign deposits at the failed National Bank of Washington. If those deposits were not fully protected, Fed officials said, foreigners might be prompted to withdraw a large part of the $380 billion they have on deposit in American banks.  Concern at Small Banks **********Smaller banks are also concerned that changes in deposit insurance could disrupt their business. "Deposit insurance is our biggest advantage when it comes to competing with the money market mutual funds," said Robert E. Marling, executive vice president at the Woodforest National Bank, Houston. **********Proposals to limit coverage to a total of $100,000 a depositor rather than $100,000 an account "would chase a lot of people away from the bank" to investments like Treasury bills, Mr. Marling said. **********David W. Mullins Jr., a Federal Reserve governor, said the Treasury might propose next year that bank customers be limited to no more than three insured accounts of a maximum of $100,000 each, rather than the unlimited number of $100,000 accounts at present.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/busin.body_text: **********The Paris sugar market this week moved its operations across the exchange in a bid to revitalize futures trading. The Paris futures exchange, Matif, moved the sugar trading floor 770 yards to the financial futures center, placing it next to the French Government bond pit, where Matif's most active contract is traded. The exchange hopes that traders in financial futures will be drawn to the unusual volatility of sugar prices. The Paris market lost more than one-third of its volume between 1986 and 1989, largely because of competition from the computerized London market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/16/world.main_headline: U.S. and Israel in Collision Over Reaction to U.N. Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/16/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS;   U.S. and Israel in Collision Over Reaction to U.N. Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/16/world.body_text: **********Israel and Washington appeared to be on a collision course today as President Bush declared that he wanted to see Israel drop its opposition to a United Nations mission being sent to Jerusalem to investigate the killing of 21 Palestinians last week. **********Speaking after the Israeli Cabinet's decision on Sunday to spurn the United Nations resolution condemning Israel for excessive use of force and ordering an inquiry in the Jerusalem slayings, Mr. Bush told reporters: ''We want to see that U.N. resolution fully implemented. We are a part of it and we think it's the right step.'' **********Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said: ''We are disappointed that the Israeli Government has decided not to cooperate with the mission. In fact, we think that a failure to cooperate denies Israel an opportunity to present its case to the Secretary General.'' **********Administration officials said they felt that Washington had expended a great deal of energy at the United Nations to defy allies and get the United Nations resolution watered down to its bare minimum. **********Administration officials spent the day telling Israeli Government officials that the longer Israel drags out this issue the more difficult it is going to be for the United States to push through any new resolutions against Iraq in the Security Council. That, they said, would not be in Israel's interest or Washington's. **********A Message from Baker **********The Americans said they have also warned the Israelis that by refusing to simply accept the United Nations mission and make the best of it, they are going to create a situation in the Security Council in which no action will be possible against Iraq without some parallel action on the Arab-Israeli issue. **********As one Administration official put it: ''This molehill is turning into a mountain.'' **********Ms. Tutwiler said that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d had sent a message to Israel's Foreign Minister, David Levy, over the weekend. **********Describing its contents, she said, ''While recognizing that Israel would have preferred no U.N. resolution, the U.S. voted for the Security Council resolution because we feel Israel should have been prepared to deal with violence and a riot without there being 21 dead and a 150 wounded and because Israel has accepted the Secretary General's representative as recently as June of this year and therefore this mission would not be precedental. **********''The Secretary's message,'' she said, ''made clear that our sense of concern over Israel's handling of the situation would have led us to support U.N. Security Council action regardless of the situation in the gulf. We would like to see this issue concluded and hope that Israel will find a way to work with the Secretary General's representatives.'' **********Administration officials said that what is at stake now is not simply another difference of opinion between Washington and Jerusalem over the Israeli-Palestinian peace process, but the United States's strategy for dealing with Iraq, which hinges on keeping an Arab and international coalition focused on rolling back the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. **********Jewish Organizations Split **********United States officials say that whatever the merits of Israel's case, if it is seen as upsetting the American strategy in the Persian Gulf, Israel is certain to pay a heavy price in its relationship with Washington. This is particularly unfortunate, officials said, since Israel and the United States share a common interest in undermining President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, in preventing any linkage between the gulf crisis and the Arab-Israel conflict and in keeping the United Nations Security Council out of Arab-Israeli diplomacy. **********American Jewish organizations have been far from unanimous in supporting Israel's decision to spurn the United Nations mission. Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, issued a statement today saying, ''Israel would be best served by making its case to the world community. To refuse to cooperate with the U.N. investigators on any level will not help Israel's longterm interests.'' **********Americans For Peace Now, which brings together an American Jewish and Israeli peace organizations, issued a statment saying: ''The United States is to be commended on the way it dealt with an extremely difficult situation. Israel is better off with a U.S. initiative than a resolution drafted by Israel's adversaries.'' **********But the American Jewish Congress declared: ''The reluctance of the Israeli Government to cooperate with the United Nations representatives is surely understandable given the U.N.'s record of one-sided pronouncements on virtually all questions pertaining to the Arab-Israel conflict.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/31/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene;   Thai Stock Boom Grinds to a Halt
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/31/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene;   Thai Stock Boom Grinds to a Halt
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/31/busin.body_text: **********BRASH and booming Thailand, which has been enjoying some of the world's highest growth rates in the last few years, has suffered something of a nervous breakdown this month, as the shock waves set off by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq have ricocheted around the world. **********After surging 85 percent in a year, the Thai stock market fell farther faster than any other market in the world. In the 17 trading days between Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait, and last Friday, the Securities Exchange of Thailand index lost 39.1 percent of its value, falling from 1,142.63 to 695.81, its lowest level since Oct. 31, 1989. **********The move was almost enough to stop the pile drivers that are forming the foundations of the condominiums and office buildings that are supposed to service Bangkok's boom. The biggest concern during the market's tumble, economists say, was that the real estate sector might collapse, leading to a larger loss of confidence. The sector is already regarded as a little too hot and speculative for anyone's good. **********The Government became so worried that it decided to intervene. It established a $195 million mutual fund, to which all brokers had to contribute, to buy shares and provide liquidity to the market. If necessary, officials said, the sum could be doubled. **********The fund, called Ruam Pattana II (''Joint Development II''), has a five-year maturity, and is modeled after Ruam Pattana I, set up after the stock market collapse of October 1987. The first fund was one-fifth the size, but seemed to help, prompting a rapid recovery of the market. **********Fund II seemed to help this time, too. The S.E.T. index, as it is called, made gains of some 60 points a day early this week, and there was a general easing of concern. On Thursday the index closed at 839.80.  Nevertheless, some economists contend that the Government intervened too quickly. ''I think the fund created an artificial bottom faster than necessary,'' said Chesada Loha-unchit, managing director of Tara Siam Business Information Ltd., a leading Thai research institute. ''The bottom was very near, but a lot of people with confidence in the market didn't want to buy before the bottom. I think the authorities were too nervous.'' **********Mr. Chesada, like most economists here, forecasts that the rise in oil prices will curb the growth of Thailand's economy, but says that Thailand is better positioned to adjust than it was during the last oil shock, in 1979. It is also probably better off than many of its neighbors, who depend more directly on exports to the United States, which seems to be veering into recession. **********But no one knows if there will be a war, or what the price of oil is going to be next year. Narongchai Akrasanee, vice president of the Thailand Development Research Institute, the country's leading institute, said he expected that if oil prices average about $25 a barrel, Thailand's growth in 1991 will slow to 5 percent or 6 percent from an initial forecast of 9.3 percent, while inflation will reach 7.5 percent, instead of 6 percent. **********Mark Greenwood, managing director of Asia Equity Thailand Ltd., said that with oil at $30 a barrel, inflation would be near 10 percent and growth would be cut to 6 percent. At $25 a barrel, he said both growth and inflation would be about 8 percent. **********The main worry, he said, is inflation in real estate, ''which has a lot of froth.'' But compared to 1979, he said, when imported crude oil filled 80 percent of Thailand's energy needs, the figure today, after natural gas development, is 40 percent, representing only 9 percent of total imports. **********Mr. Chesada agreed, saying that 1979 found a weak Government here with a large budget deficit and the baht tied to the dollar. Today, with a budget in the black and a floating baht, he said, Thailand has much more room to use fiscal policy. If there is a recession and a drop in exports, he said, the Government could put money into badly needed infrastructure projects - telephones and building mass transit to ease the paralyzing traffic, which happen to be most businessmen's biggest complaints. **********Thailand also has a new Finance Minister, Virabongsa Ramangura, who when appointed Monday was in Vientiane, Laos, finishing a contract to advise the Laotian Government. In the face of rising oil prices, he said, he would concentrate on more austerity in Government spending and perhaps, finally, a tax overhaul. A nonpartisan technocrat and economic adviser to former Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda, Mr. Ramangura said he was known as an ''austerity economist.'' **********Almost more important, Mr. Virabongsa is regarded as a far less stubborn and difficult man than his flamboyant predecessor, Pramual Sabhavasu, a party regular in Chart Thai, the leading party in the ruling coalition. Mr. Pramual was named to a deputy prime minister's post. Mr. Pramual, known for his toughness, said he had not been told in advance of the change, and he left the ministry in tears. A lot of bankers were happy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/busin.main_headline: I.B.M. Said to Aid Project On Computers and Writing
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/busin.print_headline: I.B.M. Said to Aid Project On Computers and Writing
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/busin.body_text: **********The International Business Machines Corporation is reported to be a major supporter of the Go Corporation, a new company in Foster City, Calif, that is working on a portable computer that recognizes handwriting. **********According to the trade journal PC Week, I.B.M. is one of Go's primary financial backers and is providing the company with technology. In addition, the publication said, I.B.M. will act as a reseller of the Go machine to corporate accounts. **********Carol Broadbent, a spokeswoman for Go, said the company would not comment on speculation or rumors. An endorsement from I.B.M., however, would significantly increase the chances that Go's technology will become the standard for computers that use a pen or stylus as their main input rather than a keyboard. **********Data entered into a computer using either a pen or stylus would be redisplayed as computer-generated characters and could then be stored as text or serve as commands to operate the computer. Such systems would make it easier for first-time users to operate computers. **********Competition Mounting **********The Go machine, for which no release date has been set, already faces heavy competition from much larger companies. Canon Electronics and the Sony Corporation have recently introduced portable computers for the Japanese market that recognize handwritten Japanese characters. **********Last September, the Grid Systems Corporation, a unit of the Tandy Corporation, introduced the Gridpad, a 4.5-pound portable computer that can read printed handwriting and is compatible with the MS-DOS software operating system used in I.B.M. and compatible personal computers. The Gridpad sells for $2,370, plus $425 for a memory card. **********Go's computer is said to be more sophisticated than these machines, and Go executives have hinted that it will not use MS-DOS, which was developed for disk-based computers, but will use its own system and solid-state memory. A new software company, Slate, founded by Dan Bricklin, the creator of Visicalc, is believed to be developing application programs specifically for the Go computer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/30/world.main_headline: Japan Promises Grants and Food, But Lack of Arms Aid Nettles U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/30/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Japan Promises Grants and Food, But Lack of Arms Aid Nettles U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/30/world.body_text: **********Japan unveiled a long-awaited program on Wednesday night to help finance the international effort against Iraq, but the package drew unusual criticism from American officials for the absence of direct tangible aid to the military buildup in the Persian Gulf. **********The package includes an unspecified amount of loans and grants to Egypt, Turkey and Jordan, the dispatching of 100 medical specialists to the region, and a pledge to supply refrigeration equipment, water and other goods to help soldiers cope with the desert heat. **********Officials said the aid program might ultimately amount to billions of dollars, but that any estimate would be vague because Tokyo plans long negotiations on the terms of loans and grants and the specific projects to be financed. **********The Finance Ministry said last week that Japan would provide financial aid to countries hit hard by a loss in revenue because of the gulf crisis. But this week it stipulated that such help would be granted only in coordination with other countries and the International Monetary Fund, which is already pressing Egypt to adopt difficult austerity measures. **********These requirements would almost certainly delay the aid and limit the amount of money available, offering little immediate relief to countries that are short of cash because of the cutoff in Middle Eastern oil or the loss of remittances from nationals working in oilfields there. **********Tokyo also pledged Wednesday night to transport food, water and medical supplies to the gulf on Japanese civilian aircraft and ships, and to pay for military equipment to be flown there on planes and ships chartered from other nations. **********Today, Japanese officials said the cost of chartering ships and planes and shipping medical and other supplies to the Middle East would be about $1 billion. **********Constitution Bans Force **********Despite public pressure from Washington to do more than simply underwrite the military efforts undertaken by others, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said it would violate Japan's Constitution for the country to transport any military personnel or equipment to a region of potential combat. **********''There are things we can do and cannot do,'' the Prime Minister said, adding that the package ''represents the maximum extent we can go.'' **********Japan's Constitution, written by the United States after World War II, renounces ''the threat or use of force as a means of settling international disputes.'' It has long been cited by Tokyo as a barrier to action, even in using military aircraft to aid earthquake victims in Armenia in 1988. **********Mr. Kaifu, who looked grim and fatigued at his news conference Wednesday night, seemed to be more concerned with Japanese opposition to his package as too radical than with American concerns that it is too modest. He appealed to the Japanese to abandon their aloof approach to world political crises. **********''If Japan's response is delayed and the world gets the impression that Japan does nothing for peace in the region, when its own important national interest is at stake, Japan's future will be lost,'' the Prime Minister declared. **********There was no official comment from the United States immediately after Mr. Kaifu announced the package. But American officials made it clear earlier in the day that they were ''very unhappy,'' as one put it, with the omission of an indirect or direct Japanese military role. **********''If you look at the situation in the Middle East, we judge it to be basically a military situation,'' said an American official, his voice edged with sarcasm. ''There's a limited number of Girl Scout cookies that can be used there.'' **********In another unusual move, the United States Ambassador, Michael H. Armacost, told Japanese editorial writers on Tuesday evening that Americans were feeling ''impatience, bewilderment and exasperation'' with Japan's delays in announcing its plans in the gulf, a spokesman for the American Embassy said. **********He said Mr. Armacost expressed concern that Japanese assistance would be ''so circumscribed as to hinder its operational usefulness and thus its political value.'' The Ambassador has made it clear that he does not agree that the Constitution prevents further action. **********U.S. Wants Minesweepers **********Among the steps urged by Mr. Armacost and other officials is the use of Japanese minesweepers to patrol waters in the gulf. They also have asked that Japanese ships normally used for transporting automobiles to the United States be commandeered to send tanks and other equipment to the Middle East. **********Aides to Mr. Armacost, who only last week were praising Japan for its swift expression of support in the days after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, had a different tone on Wednesday, saying that Tokyo's inaction would stir resentment in Congress that Japan is not putting itself at risk like other nations. **********Some also warned that Japan's response might set back Tokyo's quest for a seat on the United Nations Security Council. **********Taizo Watanabe, a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, said he could not say whether the aid to Turkey, Egypt and Jordan would be ''in the millions or billions'' of dollars. He said the assistance would likely be in the form of low-cost loans or grants for projects to be identified later. **********Project loans, however, are not what the countries of the Middle East need right now, many experts say. These countries are suffering rather from a loss of cash flow amounting to billions of dollars. Mr. Watanabe said it was his understanding that Japan would not be meeting the Middle Eastern country's ''cash needs.'' **********Officials and experts said there were several reasons for Japan's failure to come forward with a bolder package. Among them is the Japanese people's reluctance to violate the spirit or letter of a Constitution that has taken on an almost sanctified status. **********Some Japanese officials are said to fear that a greater military role for Japan would alarm Asian neighbors that remain wary about the country's intentions 45 years after the end of World War II. Others say that the Japanese oppose giving more authority to the military, whom they blame for the disaster of World War II. **********The Foreign Ministry and Mr. Kaifu himself have been described by officials in the last few weeks as the most eager for Japan to step up its role in the Middle East crisis. But wider measures were opposed by other ministries and by political rivals of Mr. Kaifu, who do not like to see him succeed or improve his image. **********Mr. Watanabe said on Wednesday night that as a practical matter, Japan would be prevented from transporting combat-related personnel or equipment on commercial aircraft because the employees of shipping and aircraft companies have made it clear they would refuse to carry such cargo into a war zone. **********Japan Air Lines is said to be worried about several of its employees being held hostage by Iraq.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/world.main_headline: A Curtain Falls on Bob Hope's Show
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/world.print_headline: STANDOFF IN THE GULF; A Curtain Falls on Bob Hope's Show
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/world.body_text: **********The Pentagon announced today that it was restricting news coverage of, of all things, the Bob Hope Christmas shows for American troops here. And Bob Hope seemed perplexed. **********"Did I ever say keep the press away? I live for the press." the 87-year-old comedian said at a Christmas Day news conference. "That's not my idea, believe me." **********The first of Mr. Hope's six or seven troop shows was staged on Christmas Eve for about 7,000 soldiers at a site near a military installation in Saudi Arabia. Under military rules for reporters here, the location of American installations cannot be given. **********In a statement released by Pentagon spokesmen in Riyadh, the Defense Department said it had "restricted media coverage of Bob Hope's visit for two reasons." **********"The first reason is security," it said. "And secondly, it is felt that media coverage of his shows and visits, however well intentioned, have a very great likelihood of being exploited by the Iraqis for propaganda purposes." Filmed for Television **********Representatives of news organizations here said they thought the rule went far beyond previous restrictions. **********Even as news organizations were being barred from coverage of the shows, the shows were being filmed for use on an NBC television special scheduled for broadcast on Jan. 12. **********"Suddenly Bob Hope's humor is classified?" asked Laurence Jolidon, a reporter for USA Today who represents print news organizations here in negotiations with the Pentagon over access to events. "Something has gotten a little bit out of whack here. If it's O.K. to show on television next month, it should be O.K. to publish tomorrow." **********Since American troops were sent here after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Pentagon has barred reporters from observing non-Islamic religious services attended by American troops. **********The Defense Department has said it fears the Iraqi Government would use the news reports to further its argument that Islamic holy places are being defiled by non-Muslim soldiers here. 'They've Got a Problem' **********Such strict reporting rules had not been extended to other nonmilitary events. The comedian Steve Martin visited Saudi Arabia this year to meet with troops and although he did not stage a formal show a few reporters were allowed to attend some of his encounters with soldiers. **********At his news conference here today, Mr. Hope, who has been appearing at Christmas shows for American troops overseas since 1941, said he was surprised to learn that news organizations, including the military newspaper Stars & Stripes, were being banned from the shows here. **********But he insisted that he understood the Pentagon's restrictions, which he said were intended to avoid offending Muslim religious leaders in Saudi Arabia. **********"They've got a problem," he said. "Because the King is running the place, they have their religion and their beliefs and you have to kind of abide by it. If it was in vaudeville, I don't think I could." **********Saudi censors routinely bar displays of female flesh as well as any reporting, commentary and humor critical of the Saudi Government or Saudi customs. Some Jokes Are Removed **********As a result, Mr. Hope said he had been forced to censor his material heavily in consultation with the Pentagon and to remove a number of jokes, including those that deal with "the clothing the women wear around here." **********"You have to be very careful," he said. "We were briefed on that, you know. I don't mean once. We were briefed on that about three times. I can understand their concern over here because they have another religion." **********Mr. Hope said that a more serious restriction was that on performances by women -- Saudi women must be veiled in public -- and that as a result he was forced to leave a number of women out of the show in Saudi Arabia, including the performers Ann Jillian, Marie Osmond and the Pointer Sisters. **********"When I got to the plane, they said, 'There will be no girls,' " he said. "It's a religious thing." An Exception Is Made **********The exception, he said, was his wife, Dolores, who was allowed to appear Christmas Eve to sing "White Christmas" to the troops. "They let Dolores in, which is damn nice," Mr. Hope said. **********The other women in the show will rejoin the troupe this week in Bahrain, which places far fewer restrictions on entertainment. **********Mr. Hope and his troupe will be performing for American troops now serving on Navy ships anchored in Bahrain. **********Mr. Hope said today that he made a European tour in May and vowed that it would be his last overseas tour. "I said this definitely is my final trip, this is my final tour," he said. **********"But then up popped madman," he said, referring to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. "I finally said, We have to go again." He added: "The feeling of the entire country is the same. This is our blood and guts over here and this is the day of all days, Christmas."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/04/busin.body_text: **********In a significant trade victory for the White House, an international trade panel has determined that Thailand's ban on imported cigarettes is illegal, although it upheld a ban on advertising, United States trade officials said today. **********The United States and Thailand have tentatively agreed to talk in two weeks about opening the Thai market to foreign cigarettes, the trade officials said. The Office of the United States Trade Representative has been campaigning for years to have Asian markets opened to American cigarettes, and barriers in Thailand are the latest to be broken after those of South Korea, Taiwan and Japan. **********The push to enter the Asian markets has caused concern among health advocates who fear that many people who do not smoke now may begin when American cigarettes backed by strong marketing tactics are available. The ban on advertising was seen as a victory in part for their side. **********Full Council to Vote **********The panel that made the ruling was set up by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, to resolve disputes. Its report is to be put to a vote by the full GATT Council on Nov. 7 and is expected to be ratified. **********While the report said Thailand must open its borders to foreign cigarettes, it also took the unusual step of raising the issue of health in saying that Thailand's ban on cigarette advertising was appropriate. **********In pressing these trade questions, the Bush Administration has raised a hornet's nest of criticism because it pits two of the nation's missions against one another. While the Secretary of Health and Human Services and the Surgeon General have spoken angrily about ''selling death'' at home, department officials say they have been asked to be quiet about whether the United States should be selling the same products abroad. **********Surgeon General Is Quiet **********''For me to talk about it would be almost disrespectful of my party,'' said Surgeon General Antonia Novello in a news conference last week. **********The trade representative's office, for its part, said there were health issues involved, but as long as cigarettes were legal both in the United States and in Thailand, American cigarettes should not be kept out of Thailand. **********Timothy O'Leary, a spokesman for the trade office, said: ''The evidence is overwhelming that tobacco products are harmful. Countries have a sovereign right to protect the health of their citizens against it. But what the Government of Thailand has done is create a monopoly under which they alone sell cigarettes. It is simply discriminatory.'' **********'Best We Could Hope For' **********Public health advocates said the decision, made in Geneva on Sept. 21 and kept confidential, ''is the best we could hope for,'' said John L. Bloom, manager of international issues at the Advocacy Institute, a nonprofit health advocacy group in Washington. **********Dr. Greg N. Connolly, director of the office on smoking and health in the Massachusetts Department of Public Health, said he thought the agreement was a victory for Thailand in some ways. **********The United States had sought not only to open the country, but to knock down taxes and tariffs on imported cigarettes that are on the books in Thailand but unused. The GATT panel said the taxes and tariffs were appropriate as long as they were comparable to taxes on other, similar domestic goods. **********Reasoning for Ban **********In addition, while the American Government has succeeded in other countries in getting American ads permitted, the GATT panel in this case said that since cigarettes were hazardous, Thailand was justified in trying to control their use so long as those attempts cover both national and foreign products. **********''All the tools of advertising and marketing needed to enter the market have been denied,'' Dr. Connolly said. ''Just raising the issue the way they have has also created in Thailand a smoking and health movement years before its time.'' **********The United States Cigarette Export Association estimates that the Thai market, once open, could produce $150 million in sales for United States companies. Bootlegged American cigarettes already have a share of the Thai market estimated to be 5 percent. **********The trade representative's office is now considering what retaliatory action will be taken against Thailand if that market does not open soon. **********Retaliatory Tariff **********A first measure may come even before Thailand has a chance to negotiate the issue. The trade office on Oct. 15 may publish a list of Thai products against which the Government will levy a retaliatory tariff of up to 100 percent if needed. The publication of a list of potential targets of retaliation is considered extremely serious by the Thais, because companies using or selling those products may elect to stop using them from uncertainty about their future price and supply. **********Among the exports likely to be on the list are jewelry, canned tuna, tobacco, coffee, rubber, sugar, canned pineapple and baby corn, which account for $350 million to $500 million a year in trade. **********Mr. O'Leary at the trade office said no decision had been made on whether to publish the list. **********In addition to the Government's complaint before GATT, cigarette manufacturers have asked the trade representative to take action to force the Thai Government to allow advertising and wide distribution of their cigarettes. A spokesman for the trade office said it had made no decision yet on whether to try to force Thailand, separate from the GATT action, to end its ban on cigarette ads. The United States can retaliate separately on those issues. **********Canada's Beer Barrier **********GENEVA, Oct. 3 (Reuters) - The United States complained in world trade talks today that Canada was discriminating against beer imports from America, despite a two-and-a-half-year-old ruling to end unfair marketing practices. **********The deputy United States trade representative, Rufus Yerxa, told a panel for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that Canadian provincial marketing boards used discriminatory listing practices and restrictions on points of sale and marked up the prices of imported beer above reasonable estimates of distribution costs. **********Canadian Ambassador John Weekes said a petition submitted by a United States brewery contained many errors of fact, and he denied that provincial listing practices discriminated against imported beers. **********He said Canada had asked the United States for details of their specific concerns but that Washington had not replied.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/14/world.main_headline: Tunisian Leader Begins Visit to Washington
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/14/world.print_headline: Tunisian Leader Begins Visit to Washington
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/14/world.body_text: **********The President of Tunisia will begin a three-day visit to Washington on Monday with two pivotal issues on his agenda: the immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel, and the Western outcry about Iraq's manufacture and deployment of long-range missiles, chemical weapons and other advanced military technology. **********In an interview before his departure, the President, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, said that Arab nations were not opposed to the settlement of Soviet Jews in Israel but that they strongly opposed their resettlement in the West Bank, the Gaza Strip and Jerusalem. **********Mr. Ben Ali, whose country is a firm Western ally with close ties to France and the United States, said he would also try to explain to President Bush on Tuesday, when the two men are to meet, that Iraq's pursuit of modern weapons technology was a legitimate defensive policy. **********Most Arab countries have rallied behind Iraq in the face of severe attacks on its new arms policy by Western news agencies, Western governments and Israel. The League of Arab Nations announced on Thursday that it would hold a summit meeting on May 28 in Baghdad to discuss the Soviet Jews and the Iraqi arms purchases. **********The Tunisian leader said the issue of Jewish immigration had become the most urgent concern of the Arab nations. In the last year, several thousand Soviet Jews have resettled in Israel each month, and although very few are moving to the Arab lands, a good number are settling in East Jerusalem, the main cause of concern for the Arabs. **********''We are aware, of course, that any resolution cannot be found in placing obstacles or dams to block immigration,'' Mr. Ben Ali said. ''What we are asking for is that those Jews emigrating to Israel do not settle in the occupied territories of the West Bank and Gaza, where Palestinians live.'' **********On the issue of Iraqi arms, Mr. Ben Ali said: ''All Iraq is saying is that it will defend itself only if attacked. What's wrong with that? Arab countries that realize scientific and technological progress must not automatically be viewed as a threat to Israel. In fact, many of them see themselves as potential victims of Israeli attacks.'' **********Mr. Ben Ali, 53 years old, an electronics engineer, took power in Tunisia in November 1987 after a panel of doctors declared that the former President, Habib Bourgiba, then 84, was senile and unable to govern. Mr. Ben Ali was Prime Minister at the time. He was elected President for a five-year term in April 1989. **********He spent much of his professional career in military intelligence and counterespionage.
