https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/24/world.main_headline: Election Means Little in Contra Camp
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/24/world.print_headline: Election Means Little in Contra Camp
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/24/world.body_text: **********While this country prepares for elections, rebels in the steamy forests here are getting ready for war. **********''The day we turn over our weapons, they'll put us in handcuffs,'' said Zorro, a 20-year-old rebel who said he had been battling the ruling Sandinista Government for seven years. ''Our fight goes on.'' **********The rebels, known as contras, said they were convinced that President Daniel Ortega Saavedra would lose the election on Sunday to Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's coalition but that he would refuse to surrender power. **********''We're sons of God and so are the Sandinistas, but while they have the Communist poison in them, we can't have confidence in them,'' said Zorro. **********Stronghold in Jungle **********He and other contras interviewed in this area, a longtime rebel stronghold in the jungle-crowned mountains above Jinotega, vowed to continue their decade-old war until the leftist Sandinistas are driven from power, democracy is established and ''repression ended.'' **********''We'll fight until there's a legitimate government and full human rights,'' said Centella, the commander of the 176 rebels of the Third Company of the Pedro Joaquin Gonzalez Battalion. ''We're sure, almost positive, that if Violeta wins, the Sandinistas won't give up power.'' **********The 800-strong battalion, like others in Nicaragua's sparsely populated northern tier, has spent the last six months infiltrating from Honduran base camps and building up its civilian support network along the country's volcanic spine. **********In the process, the contras, who started as a proxy unit for the United States in its efforts to overthrow the Sandinista Government, seem on the verge of becoming a self-sustaining guerrilla army. Bit by bit, the rebels are beginning to live off the land and off their support among anti-Government peasants. Paradoxically, that is largely a result of the cutoff of United States military aid two years ago. **********Survival Could Be Fatal Flaw **********The rebels' survival could become a fatal flaw in the Central American peace negotiations. Although the region's five Presidents agreed at a series of summit meetings to disband the rebel army in return for presidential elections here, they never consulted the contras. The rebels, who view themselves as freedom fighters and the guarantors of Nicaraguan democracy, have refused to abide by the accords and lay down their arms. **********''I won't abandon the fight until I see the end - a democratic Nicaragua,'' Fernando, calling himself a seven-year veteran of the war, said during an interview on Thursday. **********The contras' cause, in the view of many outsiders, has rarely appeared so futile. For years the rebels relied almost entirely on their Honduran bases for sanctuary and on Washington for money and military supplies. But those twin pillars could crumble at any moment under the regional peace accords. **********The rebels acknowledge a lack of a large-scale network for obtaining arms, ammunition and other military supplies, and they refer to their guns as ''presents from Papa Bush.'' **********Morale Extremely High **********But an overnight visit with 90 rebels near La Reforma, a hilltop hamlet 100 miles north of the capital, found morale extremely high. The contras were healthy, well fed and well equipped, even though they carried only light weapons like AK-47 automatic assault rifles. **********Many of the rebels were wearing boots captured from the Sandinistas. Byron, a 20-year-old squad commander, said the battalion had seized more ammunition in the last six months than it had used. He said it had recovered 200 AK-47 assault rifles, 20 RPG-7 light rockets and 30 machine guns. **********The insurgents clearly have the support of much of the local population, most of whom made it clear they plan to vote for the opposition coalition, known as UNO. A small boy ran up to one patrol resting near a farmhouse to warn it that a Sandinista detachment was approaching. The rebels discovered it was a false alarm. **********The intelligence system, while less than foolproof, remains highly effective, providing detailed information on Sandinista troop movements. The Nicaraguan Army, several civilians said, rarely enters the area with fewer than 100 soldiers and almost never without setting off the contras' silent alarm system. **********Handouts From Civilians **********Although a group of rebels was caught in an ambush during dinner last month, the rebels were quickly informed this morning when a Sandinista company moved into the hills. The contras were cautious, but seemed confident even when separated from the army by as little as two miles. **********Several contras said they had not left Nicaragua in more than a year. They added that they had no money left and that they survived entirely on handouts from civilian supporters in their zone. **********The peasants often shared what little they had. One family welcomed them with a heaping bowl of steaming beans, a four-inch stack of tortillas and pots of sweetened coffee. **********''The population wants our presence,'' Zorro said. ''If we're not here, they know that Daniel Ortega and his friends are going to mess with the people.'' **********While many civilians were clearly committed to the rebels, the contras also received support because they for the moment had the might. When the army passes through, one civilian noted, it also is given food. ''We're in a war zone,'' said one farmer. ''Here, bullets rule.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/04/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Ties for Israel and Bulgaria
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/04/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Ties for Israel and Bulgaria
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/04/world.body_text: **********Israel and Bulgaria restored diplomatic relations today after a 23-year break and signed an agreement that covers air transportation, telecommunications, tourism, agriculture, mutual protection of investments and dealings between banks. Bulgaria and other Eastern bloc countries broke relations with Israel after the 1967 war. With the changes that have swept Eastern Europe, only Moscow has not restored diplomatic ties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/13/busin.body_text: **********Ames Department Stores Inc. today reported a second-quarter loss of $152.5 million, but store officials said the loss before nonrecurring charges was significantly smaller than expected. **********The discount store chain, which filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code in April, lost $11.1 million in 1989's second quarter. **********Ames said the latest loss reflected $73.1 million in nonrecurring charges, including adjustment in amounts of accounts payable in the bankruptcy claims filing process, a reserve for inventory markdowns and a writedown of certain management information systems installed as part of the Zayre store consolidation. **********''The $79.4 million loss before nonrecurring charges was significantly less than we had anticipated because of better-than-expected summer clearance sales,'' said Stephen L. Pistner, Ames's chief executive. **********Ames reported sales for the quarter of $563.3 million, a 54 percent decline from last year's adjusted total. The 1989 adjusted sales, excluding sales from 221 stores closed in this year's second quarter, totaled $1.22 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/03/busin.body_text: **********The United States and the European Community renewed pressure today on Japan to import more foreign goods. **********Japan has achieved ''impressive results'' in cutting restrictions on imports of wine, alcohol and passenger cars but has kept protection against other merchandise too high, the European Community delegate, Roger Abbot, told a council meeting of the 96-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The United States delegate, Rufus Yerxa, said Japanese regulation of trade is still a problem. He said despite some progress, ''much remains to be done'' in Tokyo's efforts to lift obstacles to farm imports. **********Friction between Japan and its two largest trading partners has eased since Tokyo began liberalizing its policy in the mid-1980's. The GATT council chairman, Rubens Ricupero of Brazil, summing up a two-day review of Japan's trade policy by GATT delegates, said members welcomed positive trends in Japan's trade policies but still harbored concerns. The Japanese Ambassador, Minoru Endo, said his country has taken ''giant steps'' to lower trade barriers. Criticism of Tokyo often seems ''to stem from an outdated perception about us,'' Mr. Endo told a session of GATT's council.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/busin.main_headline: Gerber Products Fills Two Corporate Posts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Gerber Products Fills Two Corporate Posts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/busin.body_text: **********The Gerber Products Company named a new vice chairman and executive vice president yesterday as it completed management changes that began in January when its chairman and chief executive left the company. **********Robert L. Johnston, 59 years old, a 36-year employee of Gerber, moved from the presidency of the Gerber Products division and the post of corporate executive vice president to become vice chairman, a position that has been vacant. **********The company named James T. Smith, 43, to succeed Mr. Johnston. Mr. Smith joins Gerber from the Procter & Gamble Company, where he has most recently been general manager in Germany for health and beauty aids. The changes are effective Jan. 1. **********Mr. Smith's move to Gerber puts him in the No. 2 spot at the baby food and children's products company based in Fremont, Mich. Mr. Johnston said the company's chairman, president and chief executive, Alfred A. Piergallini, 44, had been looking for someone to succeed him in the event of unforeseen circumstances. **********Mr. Johnston said that he had been named to the vice chairman post, a position that he noted was not normally on the company's organizational charts, to make way for Mr. Smith. Mr. Johnston said that as vice chairman he would be doing special assignments. **********Mr. Piergallini was chief operating officer of the company in January when David W. Johnson, president, chairman and chief executive, left to take the top posts at the Campbell Soup Company. **********Mr. Piergallini had been at the company for only nine months when he was named to the top posts at Gerber. He was senior vice president of the Carnation Company when he was hired by Gerber.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/15/busin.main_headline: Times Co. Magazines Introducing an Option
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/15/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA; Times Co. Magazines Introducing an Option
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/15/busin.body_text: **********The Magazine Group of The New York Times Company is introducing an option for advertisers to make tailor-made ad purchases in the various publications of its women's magazine division. **********The Hearst Corporation and Time Warner Inc. have similar plans for their magazine groups, and Murdoch Magazines announced Tuesday that it had started a group advertising sales program that offers cash rebates for some advertisers based on the number of pages and titles used. **********The Times's plan, called Action Plus, offers an opportunity for advertisers to customize ad placements in Family Circle, McCall's, Child or Decorating Remodeling in combination with any single-topic publications that come out at various times of the year. The plan will provide the type of discounts normally available only when advertisers buy space in an entire group of magazines and will also allow for joint marketing partnerships and group promotions. **********Advertisers will be able to choose which magazine or combination of magazines they want to appear in, rather than buy into every magazine in the group. The Times Company's Magazine Group said it would also offer joint programs in its sports and leisure division. **********"We will be creating a whole new generation of marketing partnerships and efficiencies in advertising buys," said Charles H. Townsend, president and chief operating officer of Family Circle.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/world.main_headline: Nicaraguans Plan To Unlock U.S. Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/world.print_headline: Nicaraguans Plan To Unlock U.S. Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/world.body_text: **********A team of economic advisers to the Nicaraguan President-elect, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, is to arrive here on Monday seeking at least $550 million in aid from the United States and international lending institutions to revive a war-shattered economy. **********Jose Antonio Alvarado, a Nicaraguan-born investment banker from Miami who is serving on Mrs. Chamorro's delegation, said in a telephone interview that she would seek $500 million in loans and grants over 18 months to create jobs, reinvigorate Nicaraguan agriculture and develop the country's industrial base. **********The four-member delegation will also seek $50 million or more for a special government fund to encourage small business. **********Mr. Alvarado said his group's itinerary included meetings with the International Monetary Fund, the Inter-American Development Bank and the World Bank. Describing the Nicaraguan request as ''very modest,'' he emphasized the importance of an economic revival to ''the consolidation of a democratic government.'' **********''We, the United States and the international banking institutions have to move forward as a team,'' he said. **********Persuading the Policy Makers **********The most important mission of the Nicaraguan delegation will be to describe the incoming government's needs to a group of officials from the State, Treasury and Commerce Departments and other United States agencies. The interagency panel is headed by Bernard W. Aronson, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs. **********''We are prepared to give significant economic aid to Nicaragua,'' Mr. Aronson said. ''Mrs. Chamorro says her two priorities are economic recovery and national reconciliation, and we want to support her on both as effectively and generously as we can.'' **********Mr. Aronson said it was too early to specify how much aid the United States would be willing to give the new Nicaraguan leaders, who are to take office on April 25. **********His group met for the first time on Thursday. A participant who asked not to be identified said the panel had not readied a plan beyond agreeing that the American trade embargo against Nicaragua should be lifted. **********''There was nobody at the table who gave a serious analysis of specifics on the economy,'' the official said. ''People first have to look at how we can undo what we have done.'' **********Washington's Budget Limits **********Several experts are concerned that Washington will not be able to meet all of Nicaragua's needs. The United States already faces commitments to aid Panama and several countries in Eastern Europe at a time of large American budget deficits. **********''For 10 years we had money for the contras and every single effort to destroy Nicaragua, but now there is no money left to rebuild it,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, the chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee that deals with foreign aid. **********Several members of Congress and of the Bush Administration ''talk of helping Nicaragua, but I have the checkbook here and it is already overdrawn,'' he said in an interview. **********A senior official at an international lending institution, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said: ''Nicaragua needs large bridge loans, but there will be delays. Bankers and investors will say, 'Before I invest, I want to see how these new guys work out.' '' **********Legacy of War and Disasters **********The new government headed by Mrs. Chamorro will face a difficult challenge. As the President-elect seeks the smoothest possible transition from Sandinista rule, particularly the handing over of control by the security forces, she will also be dealing with the legacy of civil war, natural disasters, the United States trade embargo and poor economic management. **********Inflation in Nicaragua was 1,700 percent last year. Unemployment stands at 25 percent, and an estimated 45 percent of Nicaraguans are underemployed. The Government in Managua is effectively bankrupt, and many in the private business sector and the skilled labor force have fled the country. **********As April approaches, Nicaraguan farmers need immediate financing to buy seeds and fertilizer. **********Commercial bankers and aid specialists at the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank say they cannot lend money to Nicaragua as long as it remains in arrears on its $8 billion foreign debt. Additional loans are unlikely to be granted, they say, unless the United States persuades Japan and Western European Governments to join in providing $500 million in interim loans to bolster Managua's foreign exchange reserves. **********Washington must also allow American shipping companies to return to Nicaraguan ports to pick up coffee, cotton and sugar, something they have not done since President Ronald Reagan imposed the trade embargo in 1985.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/busin.body_text: **********Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday that it would spend $540 million over the next five years to build drug laboratories and plants near the company headquarters in Indianapolis. **********Lilly, which has said that its earnings will grow 22 percent this year from $939.5 million in 1989, expects to add 500 employees at the new site in the first phase and 500 more by the end of the 1990's. It currently has 3,000 employees in Indianapolis. **********The pharmaceutical company said the expansion, which will eventually cost $1 billion, will include $120 million for a new biotechnology laboratory, $145 million in other projects to be completed by 1994, and $90 million in site improvements and utilities. **********The technology center will also house Lilly's previously announced $150 million synthetic human insulin plant and a $35 million administration building already under construction. **********Analysts said Lilly's plans reflected the relative strength in the pharmaceutical industry at a time of weakening in the overall economy. ''Lilly's products are not sensitive to economic downturns; they are not discretionary spending for consumers,'' said Robert H. Uhl at Salomon Brothers. Ronald Nordmann at Paine Webber Securities said other large pharmaceutical companies like Merck & Company and the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company had also made significant investments in biotechnology. **********Eli Lilly's shares fell 37.5 cents yesterday, to $72.625, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Jefferson Smurfit In Recycling Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/busin.body_text: **********The Jefferson Smurfit Group P.L.C. agreed to buy a Southern California newsprint recycling mill from the Giant Group Ltd. for $95 million plus $25 million later if Jefferson Smurfit decides to expand the mill within several years. The mill, the Golden State Newsprint Company in Pomona, Calif., also operates 10 recycling centers. **********Jefferson Smurfit, an Irish paper packaging and printing company, said the acquisition fitted its strategy of building its newsprint business. The Giant Group acquired the mill last year from Media General Inc. after failing to gain control of the communications company. In a deal to liquidate its 10 percent stake, Giant agreed to sell its shares back to Media General for $44 million in cash and the paper mill. Giant's shares rose $1.125 each today, to $19.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/busin.main_headline: Economic Memo;   Quiet Moves at Bank Talks: A Reshaping of East Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/busin.print_headline: Economic Memo;   Quiet Moves at Bank Talks: A Reshaping of East Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/busin.body_text: **********The Middle East crisis dominated the speeches and news conferences at the annual meeting this week of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. But away from the newsmakers, in hotel rooms outfitted with conference tables, Eastern Europe's emerging free market economies were quietly being shaped. **********The Eastern Europeans themselves might still be arguing about the pace of transition from central planning to free markets. But for the I.M.F. and the World Bank, the issue is settled: It should be done quickly, with the promise of loans as pressure to speed up the process. **********''If someone comes to us and says, 'We want to do it gradually,' we go a long way to talk them out of a gradual approach,'' said Eugenio F. Lari, the World Bank's European chief. **********Last fall, when Eastern Europe threw off Communism en masse, he wasn't so sure of himself. ''We had a fleeting temptation to sit back and see how the transition worked, and then make loans,'' he said. ''But that would have made us irrelevant.'' **********The Poles and the Hungarians have been big borrowers this year, although the Hungarians have had misgivings about the quick-transition strategy. Their worry was that unemployment, say, would become unbearably high if all price ceilings were removed overnight or state companies were sold too rapidly. But the Hungarians are coming around, Mr. Lari said. ''As of the moment, none of our members are talking gradualism.'' **********Czechoslovakia, a new World Bank-I.M.F. member, is the next most likely big borrower, and Mr. Lari, greeting visitors in shirt-sleeves and suspenders, got into loan talk with Vaclav Klaus, the Czechoslovak Finance Minister, like him an enthusiast of go-fast transition. **********World Bank loans are particularly important for the transition process because they finance projects that help make free markets work: importing machinery, for example, for newly private factories, or financing unemployment insurance. **********The I.M.F. has a different sort of leverage: more than $1 billion in loans outstanding in Eastern Europe to provide badly needed hard currency to pay foreign debts and bills. **********Rival Soviet Delegations **********For the Soviet Union, the issue also was transition economics. The Gorbachev Government, up for I.M.F.-World Bank membership, sent five officials - and found themselves upstaged by a rival Soviet delegation. **********The Gorbachev people presented themselves as quiet agnostics on the transition issue, since the Soviet Parliament has not yet decided whether the transition should be a slow process, as Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov advocates, or a speedy one, in accord with the ''500 Day Plan'' of Stanislav S. Shatalin. The 12 unofficial delegates came to sell the Shatalin plan. **********George Soros, a Wall Street financier, paid the air fares and hotel expenses of the Shatalin group. And the delegates - six helped to write the 600-page plan - had sessions with anyone whose good opinion of the Shatalin ideas might carry weight with the Soviet Parliament. **********The roster included prominent American economists and Congressmen, European central bank chieftains and corporate executives. An Izvestia reporter traveled with the members of the team and sent back dispatches on their salesmanship. **********''We seek understanding, and if there is understanding, there will be support,'' said Grigory Yavlinsky, the 37-year-old Deputy Prime Minister of the Russian Republic, a leader of the group. English translations of the 600-page plan were also passed out. **********Mr. Yavlinsky's English was weak, and when he got stuck during an interview, Mr. Soros pitched in with the Shatalin plan's virtues and intricacies. Mr. Soros grew up in Hungary, made a fortune on Wall Street in the 1980's and now supports foundations he established in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union to promote rapid transition to free markets. **********Rising Cost of Loans **********With considerable fanfare, I.M.F. officials promised more loans to help offset the cost of higher oil prices. But not much was said about their rising cost for the borrower - usually a poor underdeveloped nation. **********The I.M.F. has roughly $10 billion outstanding in short-term credits carrying an interest rate of 9.7 percent a year. The average floating rate in recent years has been 7.5 percent. **********The problem is, the I.M.F. is essentially a glorified credit union, and too many of its borrowers today are behind on repayment. What the institution has traditionally done is raise the money it lends at, say, 7.5 percent by borrowing, largely from member nations, at 6.5 percent, and pocketing the percentage point difference to cover administrative expenses. **********Now, however, nine borrowing nations are $4 billion in arrears on repayment, depriving the I.M.F. of interest income to cover costs. The temporary solution has been to increase the interest rate spread, partly at the borrower's expense -just when interest rates around the world are rising anyway. **********Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F.'s managing director, suggested this week that the major lenders - the United States, West Germany, Japan and other industrial nations - provide special subsidies for third world borrowers, or some other relief. **********''There was not a lot of sympathy for his suggestions among the major nations,'' said Ernesto Hernandez-Cata, an I.M.F. senior adviser.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/15/world.body_text: **********The outbreak of large-scale fighting between rival Lebanese Christian factions 12 weeks ago has prompted major new migrations of refugees, both out of the country and inside it. **********A report issued by the Chamber of Commerce and Industry at the beginning of this month said 100,000 Lebanese, primarily Christians, have left the country since the latest fighting began. Two hundred thousand other Christians sought refuge in safer areas in Lebanon, according to security officials. **********As many as 800,000 Lebanese have left the country since the civil war began on April 13, 1975. This is nearly one-fourth of the entire population. **********The Mediterranean island of Cyprus, 150 miles away, has become a halfway house for Lebanese emigrants who have despaired of their country's ever becoming peaceful again. They flock to foreign consulates there to obtain entry visas. Lebanon's national carrier, Middle East Airlines, has three flights a week to Larnaca, and they are booked solid for many weeks ahead. **********''Cyprus is our Ellis Island,'' said Malik Abu Jedid, a 29-year-old bank clerk who said he applied for a visa to Canada to join an older brother. #80,000 Live in France Four countries are most favored for well-off Lebanese emigrants: France, the United States, Canada and Australia. Nearly 80,000 now reside in France, two-thirds of whom are in Paris, according to statistics. **********About 100 Lebanese apply daily for visas at the United States and Canadian consulates in the Cypriot capital, Nicosia. Canada is reported to process 600 a month, but only 10 percent of applicants succeed in getting visitor or immigration visas to the United States. **********Hundreds apply each month for visas at the Australian Embassy in Damascus, the Syrian capital. **********Many have joined relatives in South America, mainly in Brazil and Venezuela, while others have gone to African countries such as Liberia, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Zaire and South Africa, according to officials. **********Thousands, desperate to get out, tried to pass themselves off as political refugees in Scandinavian countries, especially Sweden. But the Stockholm Government shut the door last month, and sent back 150 Lebanese who it said had arrived on counterfeit visas. **********Many of these Lebanese tried to enter Sweden via Poland. Polish visas were easy to come by, until late last month when the Polish Embassy in West Beirut sent most of its staff home after an attempt to kill one of them. A clandestine group said it had carried out the attack to protest a Polish pledge of help to Soviet Jews emigrating to Israel. **********Apartment Destroyed by Shells **********''We have nothing left to keep us here,'' said Mrs. Edmund Jabbour, the mother of two girls and a boy between 5 and 12. She and her husband, owner of a men's boutique, were packing to leave for Houston after receiving a United States immigration visa. Mrs. Jabbour said their apartment in Christian East Beirut was smashed by artillery shells in February. Her husband's shop received a direct hit during the artillery exchanges last fall between the Lebanese and Syrian armies. **********The fighting between Christians pits supporters of Gen. Michel Aoun, the leader of the Lebanese Army, against the Lebanese Forces militia, led by Samir Geagea. General Aoun opposes the Government of President Elias Hrawi, whom he accuses of giving in to the Muslims and accepting the Syrian military presence in Lebanon, and Mr. Geagea supports the Government. **********Khalil Mansour, a 32-year-old engineer, said he was taking his wife and two sons, 7 and 9, to Australia. ''At least there, I can be sure they will go to school,'' he said. **********Schools and universities have been closed in the Christian enclave for nearly a year now. **********No Water or Electricity **********Harig Keomedjian, a jeweler of Armenian extraction, said: ''We want to have normal life. Where I am going at least we will have water and electricity.'' He is immigrating to Montreal. **********Since the fighting began, Beirut and most areas in Lebanon have been without power or water supply. Power cables and water mains have been destroyed by artillery shells. **********Since no restrictions are imposed on money leaving the country, capital flight has been as big as the human exodus, contributing to the economic recession Lebanon has been suffering because of continuing violence. **********The Government draft budget for this year shows a 65 percent deficit. **********According to Abdel Chakour al-Shaalan, who heads the Middle East section at the International Monetary Fund, Lebanese holdings in banks abroad total nearly $20 billion. **********Emigration has been part of Lebanese life for 130 years. Government statistics show that as many as 13 million people of Lebanese origin now live in 25 countries, including 2 million in the United States and 5 million in Brazil.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Apple Computer's Price Cuts Ended
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.body_text: **********Apple Computer Inc.'s chairman, John Sculley, said price cuts intended to help the company increase its market share of lower-priced products were mostly over. In expectation of the recent introduction by the Microsoft Corporation of its Windows 3.0 software, Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., cut prices in February for its Macintosh SE by 17 percent and its laser-printer by 14 percent. **********Despite the cuts, Apple has protected its profit margins by cost controls, Mr. Scully said. A change in the company's sales mix is also protecting profits. Sales are shifting from the Apple II series, which carries small gross margins, to Macintosh products with higher gross margins.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/world.body_text: **********The head of the United Nations Childrens Fund accused the world's richer countries of '' aid fatigue'' today as he appealed for more help for the victims of two of Africa's longest running and bloodiest civil wars-- the decade-old conflicts in Sudan and Mozambique. **********This warning that Africa's repeated calls for help are starting to strain donors generosity came from UNICEF Executive Director, James P. Grant, as he asked them for $ 31 million in medical and rehabilitation supplies for Sudan this year and another $ 11 million for Mozambique. **********His request is part of a wider appeal for $235 million worth of emergency relief, the amount that the United Nations believes the two countries will need to stave off famine and epidemic disease this year. Mr Grant said 4.5 million civilians remain at risk in Sudan, the vast majority of them women and children. In Mozambique, he said, 1.5 million people have been displaced by the civil war, most of them women and children, including an estimated 448,000 orphaned or abandoned children. **********The launching of UNICEF's latest appeal for help coincided with the release of new United Nations figures showing that western aid pledges to Africa are running behind what many countries are expected to need this year to avert catastrophy. **********The Food and Agriculture Organization in Rome estimated recently that pledges of food aid to sub-Saharan Africa are about 1.2 million tons short of the 8.6 million tons of imported food the region will need this year. **********Mr. Grant said the response to the $135 million aid program launched in April for Mozambique had been thin. Meanwhile, he said, the need for aid has increased since April as a pullback by the Renamo guerrillas gave relief agencies access to another 700,000 sick and hungry people. **********The Rome-based World Food Program, which coordinates deliveries, reported recently that it had received pledges for only 29 percent of the 229,000 tons of emergency food relief needed this year in Mozambique. **********Mr. Grant said that two thirds of the food required to feed people in the war-torn southern half of the Sudan is ready for shipping, but that the Government in Khartoum is blocking some deliveries. **********The Government tried to cut off all supplies last winter in an effort to starve the rebvels into surrendering, he said, but is now permitting some airlifts to southern cities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/busin.main_headline: Japan in Pact On Mexican Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/busin.print_headline: Japan in Pact On Mexican Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/busin.body_text: **********Mexico's state-run oil monopoly has signed an agreement to supply Japan with $4 billion worth of petroleum in the next five years, officials said. **********Petroleos Mexicanos, known as Pemex, signed the agreement on Sunday in Tokyo with a consortium of 19 Japanese petroleum companies, a statement from Pemex said. **********The Japanese assured **********Pemex that Japan would buy 150,000 barrels of Mexican petroleum a day for the next five years, the statement said. **********A 10-year agreement regulating Mexican oil sales to Japan expired in December. **********The new five-year compact represents a cutback of 30,000 barrels a day in Japan's purchase of Mexican crude. **********In 1989, Japan was Mexico's third-largest buyer of crude oil, consuming 14 percent of Mexico's total sales. Mexico supplies 5 percent of Japan's oil demand, Pemex said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/26/busin.body_text: **********The Norfolk Southern Corporation said today that its second-quarter earnings fell 10.2 percent from a year earlier, when the company had a one-time $13.6 million gain. **********The transportation company said it earned $155.9 million, or 95 cents a share, down from $173.7 million, or 99 cents a share, in the 1989 quarter. **********Second-quarter revenue totaled $1.18 billion, up less than 1 percent from $1.17 billion in 1989. **********The drop in earnings was attributed in part to the $13.6 million after-tax gain that inflated Norfolk Southern's 1989 second-quarter earnings. The gain came from the sale of a portion of Norfolk Southern's trailer-train holdings. **********The company also said some of its divisions reported drops in revenue or increases in expenses, but it gave no other reasons for the income decline. A company spokesman said Norfolk Southern's earnings had been affected by fuel costs and other factors. **********Norfolk Southern's shares were unchanged today, at $44.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
