https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/12/world.main_headline: The Jerusalem Post's Owners Pledge an Independent Policy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/12/world.print_headline: The Jerusalem Post's Owners Pledge an Independent Policy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/12/world.body_text: **********The owners of The Jerusalem Post have pledged to respect the newspaper's editorial independence, but 30 senior journalists who resigned over the issue rejected an offer to return to work. **********''These promises are worthless,'' Menachem Shalev, a spokesman for the journalists, said today, adding that they were going ahead with efforts to set up an alternative English-language newspaper upholding The Post's liberal tradition. **********The Post, critical of Israel's treatment of Palestinians in the occupied territories, has been in turmoil since its editor, Erwin Frenkel, resigned Dec. 26 saying that Hollinger, a Canadian newspaper chain that bought the paper last year, had infringed on his editorial freedom. Hollinger, headed by Conrad Black, owns 204 newspapers, including the Daily Telegraph in Britain. **********Publisher's Ouster Sought **********Thirty journalists, including most senior editors, resigned last week, demanding that Hollinger remove its publisher, Yehuda Levy, a reserve colonel, who was appointed to manage the newspaper. **********Mr. Levy barred an editorial criticizing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir from The Post's international edition in November and applied for membership of the Israeli editors' committee saying he would be involved in editorial affairs. **********On Thursday, the paper published the contents of a letter from Mr. Levy pledging not to interfere in editorial affairs, a pledge the remaining staff accepted by a large majority. **********''The dispute is at an end,'' said Greer Fay Cashman, a member of the editorial staff committee. ''It is not as much as we would have liked to get but it is far better than we had hoped,'' she said. **********''We want to find a way for those who left to come back with their honor intact,'' she said. **********Greer Fay Cashman is one of several left-of-center journalists who stayed on, vowing to fight for editorial freedom from within. She acknowledged that Mr. Levy's pledge was not legally binding.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   20,000 in Bucharest Demand Release of Student
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   20,000 in Bucharest Demand Release of Student
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/world.body_text: **********More than 20,000 people gathered outside government buildings in Bucharest today in the biggest opposition protest since the December uprising that ousted Nicolae Ceausescu, the Communist dictator. **********Students addressing the crowd in Victory Square demanded the release of a jailed student leader, Marian Munteanu, and called on the Government of the National Salvation Front to observe fundamental human rights. **********''Human rights in Romania should be on the same level as the civilized world,'' said Mihai Gheorghiu, vice president of Bucharest University's Student League. **********Marchers carried pictures of Mr. Munteanu and banners proclaiming the innocence of other students arrested after violence last month. **********Students had been joined by thousands of middle-aged people and couples with children in an hourlong march through the capital. Hundreds of onlookers lining the route cheered and waved flowers. **********Appeals for Nonviolence **********Soldiers stood shoulder-to-shoulder around government buildings, but marchers heeded student appeals for a peaceful demonstration. There were no reports of violence and the rally dispersed peacefully after three hours. **********''I don't know what the Government's reaction will be, but they must take account of our protest and the wishes of thousands of people,'' Mr. Gheorghiu said after his speech. **********Protesters at the rally shouted: ''Judge the miners! The miners should be brought to court!'' and carried banners reading: ''Blood for Students. Thanks for the Miners.'' President Ion Iliescu thanked coal miners after they took control in areas of Bucharest last month to crush anti-Government protests, saying they had helped thwart a fascist coup. #6 Killed in Miners' Assault The miners attacked people in the streets with iron bars and pickaxes and ransacked opposition party offices. Six people died in three days of violence. **********Mr. Iliescu summoned the miners after students and other opponents had occupied University Square for seven weeks, protesting what they charged was continuing Communist influence in the government. **********An engineer, Mihai Murarescu, said he was disappointed that Prime Minister Petre Roman had only sent his Cabinet secretary to receive a petition calling for the release of students. **********A group of protesters delivered the same petition to the Justice Ministry. **********''All students are united behind Munteanu's case,'' Mr. Murarescu said at the end of the rally. ''We have proof of Munteanu's innocence.'' **********Students have accused the Government of holding Mr. Munteanu as a political prisoner and said his arrest was an abuse of human rights. **********Mr. Munteanu, leader of Bucharest University Students' League, was badly injured in the violence in June and is being held in a hospital at the Jilava Jail, near Bucharest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/20/busin.main_headline: New President At VW in U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/20/busin.print_headline: New President At VW in U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/20/busin.body_text: **********Volkswagen A.G., the German auto maker, today named William J. Young president and chief executive of Volkswagen of America Inc. **********Mr. Young, who is 47 years old, currently oversees the sale of Volkswagen cars in the United States as a vice president at Volkswagen of America's headquarters in Troy, Mich. He will continue to manage sales operations in the United States after he assumes the top job at Volkswagen of America in the first quarter of 1991, according to the company. Volkswagen's Audi of America subsidiary will also report to Mr. Young. **********Volkswagen used to produce vehicles for sale in the United States at a factory in Westmoreland, Pa. But slumping sales caused its share of the United States market to fall from a peak of 5.6 percent in 1969 to 1.2 percent through October 1990, and the company closed the factory in 1988. The cars it sells in the United States now are imported from Germany and Brazil. **********Mr. Young replaces Hans- Jorg Hungerland, 49, who will return to Germany to join a newly created board of management. Mr. Hungerland, who assumed the top job at Volkswagen of America in March 1989, will be responsible for Volkswagen and Audi sales worldwide.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/20/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates have peaked and should start falling this spring, a group of private economists predicted today. **********Members of the Shadow Open Market Committee said they believed a variety of consumer and business loans would decline in coming months, reflecting a sluggish economy and declining inflationary pressures. **********The economists forecast that banks' prime lending rate, the benchmark for many business and consumer loans, should drop from 10 percent to 9 1/2 percent or perhaps as low as 9 percent by summer. **********Fixed-rate mortgages, which are about 10.25 percent, will fall to 9.8 percent by midyear and remain below 10 percent for the rest of 1990, the outlook predicted. **********Jerry Jordan, a senior economist at First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles, who compiled the group's forecast, said that weakness in the economy would encourage the Federal Reserve to loosen its grip on credit in coming months. **********The panel forecast that the Federal funds rate, an indication of the Fed's intentions about interest rates, would dip from 8.25 percent down to 7.5 percent by midyear. **********The shadow committee meets twice a year to assess actions of the Federal Reserve whose chief policy-setting body, the Federal Open Market Committee, will meet next week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/busin.main_headline: New Interactive TV Threatens the Bliss Of Couch Potatoes
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/busin.print_headline: New Interactive TV Threatens the Bliss Of Couch Potatoes
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/busin.body_text: **********New television services that capitalize on computer technology are beginning to allow viewers to become more involved in what they watch, either by controlling what is seen on the screen or by becoming armchair participants in game shows or sporting events. **********In Montreal and in Springfield, Mass., some viewers of an experimental cable television service have been able to select from among several camera angles when watching a football game or a concert. **********In Sacramento, Calif., about 150 households are testing a system that allows viewers to play along with quiz shows like ''Jeopardy'' or ''Wheel of Fortune'' using small computer terminals. When it is fully operational, viewers will compete for prizes against other viewers, with scores tallied at the end of the show and compared, although not on the air. **********One California company already has a system in use in about 400 bars in which customers compete for prizes by predicting, as one example, what plays the quarterback will call in a televised football game. Under an agreement with National Football League Properties announced recently, the system is expected to be in homes nationwide by next year. Another company is developing a program in which a vote by viewers would determine the outcome of a mystery show. **********All this is known as interactive television, and it can transform viewing from a passive experience into one in which people are actively involved. **********''You've just created a whole additional dimension to television,'' said Thomas S. Rogers, president of NBC Cable and head of business development for the network. **********But many skeptics think such television programming will not catch on. Some argue that the typical ''couch potato'' does not want to interact with a television. **********''Most of the time, what the individual wants to do is sit back and relax,'' said Russell Neuman, who studies audience response to new video technologies at the Media Lab of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. **********The new services are being developed and tested in various cities by a handful of small companies. But major television companies and advertisers are closely watching the developments. **********One company, Interactive Network Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., has attracted financial backing from NBC; United Artists Entertainment; A. C. Nielsen; Ameritech, the Bell System company serving the Midwest, and Le Groupe Videotron, a large Canadian cable television company. **********The technology of another company, New York-based ACTV Inc., is being evaluated for its advertising potential by McCann-Erickson, the advertising agency, with financing provided by General Motors, Coca-Cola and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. **********The skeptics have history on their side. Two-way television, as it was once called, was tried in the early 1980's, most notably in the Qube cable television systems in Columbus, Ohio, and other cities, owned by Warner Amex Cable, a joint venture of Warner Communications Inc. and the American Express Company. By touching buttons on a keypad, viewers could play along with game shows, order merchandise and answer polls, although the poll results were considered unscientific. **********But Qube failed because its programming was judged not compelling and its prices were considered too high. Today, some executives and analysts think the new systems have a better chance of succeeding for a number of reasons. **********For one, Qube used expensive technology in which viewers' choices were sent back to the studio through the two-way cable that distributed the programs to homes. The new services use more inexpensive telephone lines to relay signals from the home back to the studio, either through a modem that conveys computer data or by having the viewer push the buttons of a Touch-Tone phone. A computerized device in the home that receives instructions from the studio can also respond to viewers' choices without having to send signals back to the studio. **********Moreover, years of exposure to video games and computers mean that consumers now are ''more acclimated to interactivity,'' said Michael Mascioni of Alexander & Associates, a consulting firm in New York. **********The Simple Approach **********So far, the only interactivity that appears to be developing into a successful business is the simplest approach, requiring no special equipment in homes. That involves allowing viewers to order merchandise on shopping networks by calling an ''800'' telephone number or to respond to questions on television by calling a ''900'' number, for which the caller is charged from 50 cents to $3. **********ABC's ''Monday Night Football,'' for instance, allowed viewers to select plays. MTV, the music video network, has used the 900 numbers for numerous contests. **********Another form of interactivity allows viewers to request programs. One such is the Video Jukebox Network, which is now offered on cable or low-power local television stations in 94 locations reaching seven million households. Viewers can call a 900 number, for a charge of $2 to $3, and request that a particular music video be shown. Everyone watching the channel sees the video. **********Andrew H. Orgel, the president of Miami-based Video Jukebox Network Inc, said the ability of the program to attract callers, even in cities with MTV, shows that ''individuals will pay to control their televisions, even if services are available free.'' **********The Real Promise **********But the real promise of interactivity, some people in the industry say, is the ability to provide services that would allow users to interact with a program, rather than just choose a particular program. **********ACTV has a system now being sold to cable television customers in Montreal and recently tested in Springfield, Mass., that allows viewers to pick among four video channels showing different views of the same event. **********In watching a sports event, for instance, viewers can choose their own camera angle. A program about the rock star Peter Gabriel allows viewers to focus on a particular musician. Viewers watching an exercise program can select the exercises tailored for their age group or a particular part of the body. **********The drawback of ACTV is that it requires four channels to transmit, and many cable television systems do not have the channels to spare. **********Controlling the Outcome **********Even more sophisticated systems would let viewers control the outcome of a drama. Laser Arts Interactive, a Los Angeles company, is developing a program called ''Sherlock Phones'' in which viewers, registering their choices by phone, would by consensus determine which course the detective should follow. The program would progress by showing the film clip that matched the audience's preference. **********Some experts think letting viewers choose the outcome of programs would rob shows of their emotional impact. ''It flies in the face of at least 2,000 years of dramatic experience,'' said Robert Kubey, assistant professor of communication at Rutgers University. **********Several other companies have developed systems that allow viewers to play along with professional sports events or quiz shows. **********A system in bars in which viewers can guess what plays the quarterback will call next is sold by NTN Communications Inc., Carlsbad, Calif. Customers' responses are entered through computer terminals around the bar that communicate with a central scoreboard, which displays each individual's score and communicates by telephone to a central computer to determine national winners. **********NTN as well as Interactive Network and Interactive Systems of Beaverton, Ore., are developing similar systems for the home. Last Tuesday, NTN, Interactive Network and National Football League Properties Inc. announced an agreement to make NTN's ''QB1'' game available to home TV viewers. The system will cost $400 to $500 for the control unit, with a subscription fee of about $15 a month. It is expected to be available in Northern California this year and across the country next year. **********Big League Baseball **********Interactive Network has signed an agreement with Major League Baseball allowing it to show a regularly scheduled game and permit home viewers to compete for prizes by predicting what each batter will do. **********Radio signals broadcast with the games control operation of a home terminal, which keeps track of the user's score. After the game, viewers wanting to compete for prizes would transmit the results from their terminal over a telephone line to a central computer, which would compare the results. **********Interactive Network is testing its service in Sacramento and hopes to begin commercial service in a few California cities this fall. **********But some experts say consumers might not be willing to pay the $400 that Interactive Network is planning to charge for its terminal, plus the monthly subscription fee of $15 or so. **********Mattel's Failed Product **********Mattel Inc. has tried selling a terminal developed by Interactive Systems that allowed viewers to play along with ''Wheel of Fortune.'' About 200,000 terminals were sold at a price of about $70 before the product was discontinued, said Jack Galmiche, president of Interactive Systems. He said his company was now developing a terminal that would be used with many programs, not just one, and that he hoped to rent it to consumers for a few dollars a month. **********Gary Arlen, editor of Interactivity Report, a newsletter in Bethesda, Md., said the fact that each competing company had its own technology that required a separate terminal was another barrier to success of these services. **********Still another important factor will be how well such services can attract and serve advertising. The potential is there to allow viewers watching a commercial to press a button on their terminals to get more information on a product or have a discount coupon printed out instantaneously, giving advertisers valuable knowledge about who wants their products. **********''What we're looking for,'' said Martin Nisenholtz, president of the Interactive Marketing Group, a division of Ogilvy & Mather, ''is some measure of increased efficiency, some sense that the advertiser is buying a more targeted audience than if he just blasted his message out there.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/30/busin.main_headline: Patents;   Protecting Spacecraft From Debris in Orbit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/30/busin.print_headline: Patents;   Protecting Spacecraft From Debris in Orbit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/30/busin.body_text: **********Engineers at the General Research Corporation, a scientific consulting firm in Vienna, Va., obtained a patent this week for what amounts to a garbage collector in space. Its purpose: to protect spacecraft from collisions with orbiting debris. **********''As we increase the use of space, we also increase the amount of debris we place in orbit,'' said Cyrus L. Butner, one of the inventors. Small particles pose the greatest threat because of their large numbers. The speed of such particles can reach 10 miles a second, so even dust-sized particles can cause significant damage. **********The new device is a cone filled with either plastic fibers or streaming droplets of water, which absorb debris much like a sponge. The advantage over traditional space shields, Mr. Butner said, is that the collision of particles against the spacecraft's surface does not propel new debris into motion that can cause damage of its own. **********Mr. Butner said the collector could be deployed in many ways. A large number of small units could be patched together on the surface of the space station, replacing ordinary shielding. Large units could also be stationed around the spacecraft or sent in advance of the craft as orbital ''street sweepers.'' **********The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has financed some research on the technology, but the project has been stalled by budget uncertainties concerning the space station. **********Mr. Butner and Charles Gartrell received patent 4,936,528.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/11/busin.main_headline: New York City Chooses Firms for Bond Offering
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/11/busin.print_headline: New York City Chooses Firms for Bond Offering
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/11/busin.body_text: **********Ending a fierce competition on Wall Street, New York City has named the five securities firms that will serve as senior managers for its general-obligation bond offerings over the next two years. **********City officials said on Friday that Bear, Stearns & Company, the First Boston Corporation, Goldman, Sachs & Company, Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. had been chosen from among 53 companies that had sought to manage the offerings. **********As senior managers, the five firms will earn most of underwriting fees generated from an estimated $6 billion in general obligation bonds that are expected to be issued by the city over the next two years. **********In the course of the selection process, Mayor David N. Dinkins and Elizabeth Holtzman, the city's Comptroller, told the contestants that a firm's business connections with South Africa would be an important consideration. **********In a joint news release, Mr. Dinkins and Ms. Holtzman also said efforts by firms to promote equal employment opportunities would be taken into account as well. **********Based on the list of senior managers, however, it appears that economic considerations carried more weight with city officials in the decision-making process than worries about social responsibility. **********The five firms selected all have various ties with South Africa. But they also have the ability to underwrite and distribute the city's securities at far lower interest rates than smaller firms with no ties to South Africa could be expected to deliver. **********''Having a policy that is socially responsible has to be balanced off with the administration's responsibility to be fiscally prudent,'' said a senior city official, who asked not to be identified. **********''At current rate levels, one basis point on $100 million is worth about $90,000 in present value terms,'' he said. (A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.) ''When you consider the magnitude of our program and what those savings mean, you are talking about tens of millions of dollars,'' he said. ''We have to go out and find the best people to sell our bonds. We have a fiscal responsibility to do that.'' **********In their news release, the Mayor and the Comptroller said the city reserved the right to replace any of the senior managers selected if they ''fail to demonstrate progress'' in curbing ties to South Africa or in promoting equal opportunity employment. **********The Mayor and Ms. Holtzman also announced that Grigsby, Branford & Powell, a minority-owned securities firm, and the Artemis Capital Group, a firm owned by women were named as co-senior managers for a new equipment financing program. It is the first time that a minority-owned firm or one owned by women has been named senior managing underwriter on a city debt offering. **********The names of the co-managers for the City's general obligation bond issues will be announced this week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/busin.main_headline: Japanese Give in Grudgingly On a New Way of Shopping
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/busin.print_headline: Japanese Give in Grudgingly On a New Way of Shopping
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/busin.body_text: **********A few months ago the Summit supermarket and department store in Nakano, a quiet neighborhood on the west side of Tokyo, posted notices that it would stay open an hour later every evening, until 7 o'clock. **********Within hours, the store was mobbed by owners of small shops, who carried protest signs and shouted accusations that Summit was being deceitful. The crowd kept up its protest until the store's management came out to negotiate. **********"They acted without talking to us," said Michihisa Ando, who owns a small camera store a few blocks away. "That is why we got so mad." **********Throughout Japan, battles over hours, floor space and other matters are beginning. They involve large stores, maverick mid-size stores like Summit and the traditional family-owned businesses that have long dominated retailing in Japan. The instigator of this turmoil is the United States. **********Washington has long complained of Japanese barriers to trade, and after years of resistance, Japan agreed earlier this year to drastically weaken the power of small shopowners to keep bigger competitors out. That has radically improved the economics of opening large stores here.  Outcome is Unclear **********But it is not clear whether large stores, once they open, will sell many more imported goods than small shops, or whether they will help drive down the cost of consumer goods, thereby increasing consumption, the premises that underlay America's demands for change. For one thing, with a few exceptions like Toys "R" Us and Tower Records, the big retailers now rushing into previously off-limits neighborhoods are largely owned by Japanese, not Americans. **********The agreement to foster competition was a important concession Japan made after Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and President Bush, in talks in Palm Springs, Calif., last spring, broke the deadlock in trade negotiations between the countries. **********The countries held negotiations with the unwieldy name of the Structural Impediments Initiative, signifying that the Governments were trying to resolve underlying conflicts in how the national cultures and economies work. In the talks, Japan agreed, among other things, to toughen its antitrust enforcement and loosen the relationships among Japanese companies that exclude outside suppliers. The United States vowed to cut its budget deficit, increase savings, and improve education in hopes of making its economy more competitive. **********Without question Japan's antiquated and inefficient retailing system, in which wholesalers sometimes send a truck to deliver five boxes of detergent and the abacus still reigns supreme, is an area in which one can starkly see the results of America's endless trade talks with Japan. **********Already, there are groundbreakings all over the country for shopping malls and large stores. **********"I think we are beginning to prevail," a Japanese partner of Toys "R" Us said the other day, after a meeting in the Tokyo suburb of Chiba, where plans for a giant toy store were described to a sullen but largely uncomplaining group of local merchants. "I think they are coming to see the big stores as inevitable, maybe even beneficial in some neighborhoods." **********Beneficial is not how Ryusuke Shinoyama, who heads the association of shopowners in Nakano, would describe the changes. "It is certain that the number of large-scale retailers will be increased," Mr. Shinoyama said at a gathering of shopowners at a sushi shop in their neighborhood. "But it is also certain that Japanese local society will be destroyed. You already see it happening." **********With the supermarket and the smaller shops all staying open until 7 P.M. an uneasy truce now prevails in Nakano, whose business district, like those of most Tokyo neighborhoods, is centered on the Japan Railways station. Most shopowners are older people who rebuilt the neighborhood after it was flattened by American bombs near the end of World War II. They sweep the streets in front of their stores, and greet weary returning workers with cries of "okaeri nasai," roughly "welcome home." **********And most of them play by Japanese retailing's unwritten rules: no big sales promotions that lead to price wars, no negative advertising, and limited introductions of products, which might disrupt the "orderliness" of neighborhood markets. **********Then came Summit Stores Inc., a mid-size supermarket chain. It is owned by the Sumitomo Corporation, a subsidiary of the huge corporate group that includes the Sumitomo Bank and manufacturing companies. **********"We knew right away that it would be big trouble, and there was opposition immediately," said Mr. Ando, who has already seen much of his camera business drawn away by big stores in Shinjuku, a giant Tokyo shopping center a few stops away on the train. **********The shopkeepers took advantage of the law that American negotiators finally succeeded in modifying earlier this year: the Large-Scale Retail Store Law, which requires neighborhood approval for any store larger than 600 square yards. The 1.3 million owners of small stores form the bedrock of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and they feared little retribution, until American complaints gave Government bureaucrats and large department stores the excuse they were waiting for. **********Though Japan's complex distribution system is often blamed for the inefficiencies of the retail market here, and the resulting high prices, manufacturers themselves play a significant role. The high prices Japanese pay at home in effect subsidize the competitive prices Japanese manufacturers offer elsewhere. **********Japanese consumers rarely complain about the prices they pay for Japanese-made goods. But they vote with their travel budgets. Many Japanese return from vacations and business trips with Japanese-made goods that they bought for perhaps a third less overseas. **********Summit wanted to open in Nakano in 1981 or 1982, but the negotiations dragged on until 1987. To reach agreement, the company offered numerous concessions. It reduced its floor space. It agreed to close 48 days a year, rather than its original plan of 29. It agreed to shut each night at 6 P.M. **********"Still, the influence was greater than we thought," said Mr. Shinoyama, the head of the Nakano shopowners' group. Within three years of Summit's opening, seven or eight nearby stores, most selling meat and vegetables, closed or rented their locations to other retailers, he added.  The American Goals **********Still, what remains unclear is whether all this change is achieving the goal the United States had in mind: lower prices, increased consumption and a narrowed trade gap. **********Masafumi Jimbo, the manager of the Summit store, said he had made space available for imported products, like Levi's jeans. "We have definitely been told that we are to promote the sales of imports," he added, as his assistants entered stock data on a computer network. That, in turn, may force the local shopkeepers to stock imported goods as well. **********The pressure to allow in imports has been so strong that efforts to slow stores like Toys "R" Us are faltering. The toy chain has announced plans to open more than 100 stores in Japan, starting with four next year. Its partner is perhaps the most successful retailer in Japan, the licensee for McDonald's restaurants, which owns prime retail sites and holds a major stake in Toys "R" Us Japan. **********For a while, after owners of toy stores in Nigata Prefecture, an important farming belt, mounted repeated protests, it looked as though the toy chain faced years of negotiation. But Toys "R" Us is learning how to play the game Japanese style. It is putting most of its big stores in largely undeveloped neighborhoods, near highways and inside shopping malls -- away from local shops. It is holding community meetings to explain its plans. And it has learned how to apply political pressure. **********The Japanese, ever attuned to symbolic messages, saw the future when the wife of Japan's trade minister returned from a visit to Washington not long ago laden with gifts -- all bought in a shopping spree at a Toys "R" Us store.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Forum on Mideast Crisis Proposed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/world.body_text: **********Based on the so-called Helsinki process that helped ease East-West tensions over the last 15 years, Spain and Italy proposed today that a broad new organization be created to address security and development problems throughout the Mediterranean and the Middle East. **********The initiative, which also has the backing of France and Portugal, was originally born of growing concern that economic problems and population pressures in North Africa would continue to stimulate large-scale emigration to the countries of southern Europe. **********''But the gulf crisis has reminded us how, despite the end of the East-West confrontation, the North-South issue remains fundamental if we are to build a new international order,'' Italy's Foreign Minister, Gianni de Michelis, said. **********Underlining the model for their new organization, the plan was unveiled at a meeting in Palma de Mallorca, organized by the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. That conference gave birth to the 1975 Helsinki accords committing signatories to respect human rights and promote democracy. **********Recalling 'Spirit of Helsinki' **********''We must apply the spirit of Helsinki to the Mediterranean and the Middle East,'' Spain's Foreign Minister, Francisco Fernandez-Ordonez, told the meeting today. ''Events in the gulf have shown in a dramatic way the lack of a system for preventing and discussing crises in the area.'' **********So far, preparations for a Conference on Security and Cooperation in the Mediterranean have involved Spain, Italy, Portugal and France in Europe and Morocco, Tunisia, Algeria, Libya and Mauritania in North Africa. But the plan is that it eventually embrace other nations in Europe and the Middle East as well as the United States and the Soviet Union. **********Mr. De Michelis said that both Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization would be invited to take part. Recognizing the possibility of an Israeli boycott, he noted that the Helsinki process operated well despite the absence of one country, Albania. **********Spanish officials have said the purpose of the conference is not to resolve specific disputes in the region, but rather to establish a broad code of conduct covering a variety of problems, from the inviolability of borders and democracy to immigration and economic development.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/09/world.main_headline: Hussein's Summit Message: Gulf Crisis Is an Arab Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/09/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Hussein's Summit Message: Gulf Crisis Is an Arab Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/09/world.body_text: **********Instead, he demanded that the Persian Gulf crisis be settled along lines he put forward on Aug. 12. **********In essence, that proposal would have allowed Iraq to retain Kuwait and its oil fields while the crisis was left to the Arab nations to resolve, and it would also have tied the withdrawal of Iraqi troop from Kuwait to Israel's withdrawal from occupied Arab lands. **********''Both of you will not be able to produce the right answer to an Arab issue,'' Mr. Hussein said. **********But the message appeared to have been crafted as much with the intention of goading Mr. Gorbachev into rejecting the American hope for a still tougher Soviet stand against Iraq. **********The 53-year-old Mr. Hussein, whose Government signed a friendship treaty with the Kremlin in the 1970's and whose army fights mainly with Soviet weapons, said the Helsinki meeting would demonstrate to the world whether Moscow was finished as a superpower, or was prepared now to make a show of strength and stop playing second fiddle to the United States. **********Raising Doubts About Moscow **********''He who represents the Soviet Union should remember that doubts about the place of the Soviet Union as a superpower have gotten into the mind of every politician in the world for some time now, especially as the U.S. began to assume to be the sole power in the world and when it became arrogant with no one in sight to show it a more balanced course.'' **********Mr. Hussein added, ''Those concerned should choose this crucial time, through this decisive issue, to restore to the Soviet Union its role by adopting a stand that is in harmony with justice and fairness.'' He defined this as meaning that Moscow should break with the United States and other Western powers, and with the United Nations Security Council, in their demands for an immediate and unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. **********As for President Bush, Mr. Hussein, who has previously called Mr. Bush ''a liar'' and compared him to Hitler, adopted a somewhat softer line and said that the American leader should abandon his effort to force Iraq from Kuwait for the sake of his own prestige and that of the United States. **********While offering no hint that he was prepared to bow before the pressures mounting against him, Mr. Hussein acknowledged in the message that the outcome of the Helsinki meeting could be portentous - for Iraq and the world. The close attention that Baghdad is giving the summit meeting was underscored by the newscast precceding Mr. Hussein's message, which included interviews with Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait. Several of the soldiers denounced the idea of Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev joining to impose a settlement in the gulf crisis. **********After opening the message with the standard Muslim greeting to the two leaders, ''peace be upon you,'' Mr. Hussein said that they were ''in a position to decide whatever relates to the future of good or evil for humanity.'' **********He also spoke of the responsibility of Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev ''to save our region the evil of war, and the ensuing evils,'' and appealed to God to infuse ''the light of faith into your hard hearts so that they will see the paths of righteousness.'' **********In this, and in many other passages of the message, the Iraqi leader presented himself as a faithful believer and, in his confrontation with the West, as the champion of the world's Muslims. The posture contrasts with Baghdad's harsh suppression of Muslim leaders earlier during Mr. Hussein's 12-year tenure as the ruler of Iraq. **********The message also included hints of the shrewd, mocking figure who rose from a motorcycle-borne gunman in the streets of Baghdad to become one of the most powerful and feared leaders in the modern Arab history. **********At one point, he referred to Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev as ''masters of the White House and the Kremlin,'' a blunt, even crude break with normal diplomatic usage for communications between heads of state. **********'Backward and Corrupt Rulers' **********The message also spoke of ''the backward and corrupt rulers'' of oil-producing Kuwait and accused them of having ''conspired'' against Iraq, apparently by refusing economic and territorial demands from Baghdad in the period before the invasion. **********But as much as anything, the message appeared to be a fresh effort by Mr. Hussein to foment trouble for the majority of Arab leaders who have aligned themselves with the United States and other nations in condemning Iraq. Again, he accused the United States of defiling Muslim holy places in Saudi Arabia by sending troops. **********He spoke of those who would ''try to trespass in God's house and in the prophet Mohammed's tomb,'' declaring, ''Whatever cover those trespassers may come under, whatever their justifications are, God will not forgive them.'' **********Before the message was broadcast, Baghdad television announced a new decree by Mr. Hussein intended to increase Iraq's food production in the face of the United Nations economic sanctions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/19/world.main_headline: Moscow a Year Later: Rutted Streets and Despair
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/19/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Moscow a Year Later: Rutted Streets and Despair
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/19/world.body_text: **********A few impressions of Moscow after an absence of a year: **********The rutted streets and cluttered courtyards of the city center speak of a marked deterioration in the economy, in just a year. Russian friends speak of empty shelves in the stores, which seem about as empty as they were a year ago, and say the reason for this is that nobody sees much point in working hard anymore. **********And there is a sense of despair about the process of change that was not evident a year ago. **********Echoing several other intellectuals, a friend who works on the staff of the Central Committee of the Communist Party said President Mikhail S. Gorbachev waited too long to try to push through serious economic changes. Now it may be too late. New Executive Powers Diplomats and Russians agree that the Communist Party, whose Central Committee voted last week to give up its constitutional guarantee of the leading role prescribed for it by every Soviet political leader since Lenin, had long ago lost the authority or the ability to put the country's affairs in order. **********It will not collapse suddenly like the Communist parties of East Germany and Czechoslovakia, they say, not in Russia at least, but the parties of the ethnic Muslim republics along the country's southern border are beginning to collapse in a way that looks, from a distance, remarkably like the way the ones in Eastern Europe fell apart. **********''Perestroika,'' which has brought a new openness and freedom of debate, seems to have gone seriously wrong as a policy of pulling the country out of economic decline, and Mr. Gorbachev told the elected legislature this week that it was in a critical stage. **********Now, too late, some believe, he is asking for sweeping new executive powers. The legislature, several deputies say, talks and talks, just as freely and openly as the House of Commons or the United States Senate does, but unlike them it gets little done. The country needs a strong executive, Mr. Gorbachev told them, because an elected president ought to replace the Communist Party Politburo, which in a democracy should not have such executive powers anyway. **********Not Yet a Democracy **********''A rule-of-law state has no room for dictatorship by any class, and even less so for the power of a management bureaucracy,'' said the party's draft platform that the Central Committee approved last week. But it only recognized a state of affairs that already exists. The party is no longer ''the'' party. **********But neither is the Soviet Union, yet, a democracy. ''We don't have a tradition of democracy in this country,'' said the writer Anatoly N. Rybakov, one of the earliest beneficiaries of Mr. Gorbachev's policy of glasnost. ''People don't understand that in a democracy, you can lose elections, and when you lose, you have to submit to the rule of the majority until your turn comes again.'' **********Mr. Gorbachev has not yet proceeded to serious economic revision. The legislature is still debating whether and how to introduce private property. **********But the only kind of private enterprise ordinary people can see around them, they do not like much: private farmers charging 15 rubles a kilogram for hothouse tomatoes, and mafia-like joint-venture businessmen who rent Zil limousines and dine in private restaurants that accept Western currency only, imitating the mores and privileges of the now discredited party elite. **********''People in Russia are used to having nothing,'' said Anatoly S. Pankov, a journalist from Siberia. A Central Committee official said, ''The ideal of social justice here is that everybody should have nothing not that entrepreneurs should prosper and spread the wealth.'' **********Mood of Gloom and Anxiety **********The party's draft platform puts it this way: ''We have approached a point when the previous system of economic management and government is not operating to a considerable extent, while new mechanisms have not yet started to work at full capacity.'' **********In plain Russian, to many people, that means that Mr. Gorbachev has wrecked the old system, with its assurances of social and economic stability at the price of intellectual freedom, and given them a half-baked new one that does not work but leaves them free to take to the streets to protest. **********And so the mood among the ordinary people in Moscow, unlike the mood in Prague or even East Berlin these days, is not one of eager anticipation of new freedoms but one of gloom and anxiety. **********''I hear a million people could be on the streets on Feb. 25,'' a Communist functionary said of a rumored demonstration, though that seemed like just one more rumor. But it seemed credible because several hundred thousand people did take to the streets on Feb. 4, as the Central Committee was gathering for its session, to tell their leaders that they were not happy with the way things were going. **********Concessions on Arms Control **********Small wonder, with all of that going on, that Mr. Gorbachev is making concession after concession in arms control, and even seeming to agree to the idea of German unification in a country that still remembers, painfully, the 20 million dead it suffered at the hands of the Nazis in World War II. **********''He has to find some way to sell that to the people at home that doesn't make it sound like a capitulation,'' a Western diplomat said. A Russian journalist friend thought that would be difficult. ''A lot of people think he's wrecked our internal stability, now he's taking away our external security belt,'' he said. ''And maybe they'll decide pretty soon that they don't want him anymore.'' **********Perhaps. The only thing that is certain in Moscow these days is that everything is uncertain. **********2,000 NATIONALISTS PROTEST **********MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (AP) - About 2,000 Russian nationalists staged a rally today to complain about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms, the warming of relations with the United States and the growing nationalism in non-Russian republics. **********The protesters gathered in deep snow near the Soviet television's 1,600-foot-tall transmission tower also heard speakers accuse Mr. Gorbachev of being power-hungry and plunging the Soviet Union into poverty and misery. **********The harshest attack on Mr. Gorbachev came from Boris Unko of the United Front of Workers of Russia, a group fighting Gorbachev's market-oriented economic reforms and unhappy about the nationalism in non-Russian republics. **********Among the evils wrought by Mr. Gorbachev's reforms, Mr. Unko said, were rock music, ''modernism and pornography,'' ''insults'' to heroes of the Bolshevik Revolution and World War II and others ''who built socialist society.'' He said Mr. Gorbachev had sold out to the elite and forgotten about the working class. **********He said Mr. Gorbachev is trying to become a dictator, adding that the Soviet leader should have known his reforms would bring more harm than good. **********Mr. Unko said: ''Any grandmother could have predicted the consequences of such a course. But you keep different company, the elite, property-holders. You make friends with President-murderer Bush, also a fighter for democracy who spilled blood in much-suffering Panama.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/10/world.main_headline: 5 Countries to Meet on Reviving Cambodia Peace Talks, Paris Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/10/world.print_headline: 5 Countries to Meet on Reviving Cambodia Peace Talks, Paris Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/10/world.body_text: **********Amid new concern over stepped-up attacks by Khmer Rouge guerrillas, the United States, the Soviet Union, China, France and Britain are to meet here on Monday to discuss ways of reviving stalled peace efforts on Cambodia. **********Announcing the meeting today, a French Government spokesman said the five Governments would give special attention to an Australian plan to put Cambodia under a temporary United Nations administration pending free elections. **********Diplomats said the meeting was proposed by Washington and immediately endorsed by Moscow. As permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, the five powers have special responsibilities for international peace and security under the United Nations Charter. **********''There has been a lot of talk of an enhanced role for the U.N. in Cambodia,'' a United States official said. ''The situation on the ground makes it more urgent. The United States has been trying to get the diplomatic track going again for some time.'' **********Talks and a Surge in Fighting **********A monthlong 19-nation peace conference on Cambodia ended in failure here in August amid sharp differences between the Vietnamese-backed Government of Prime Minister Hun Sen, which controls Phnom Penh, and three loosely allied rebel groups, including the Khmer Rouge. **********At the time, officials said they did not expect new peace talks until after the warring factions had tested their strength anew during the current six-month dry season and, in particular, in the wake of the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops last September. **********But diplomats said peace efforts are now being renewed in response to a surge of fighting and assertions of major victories by the Khmer Rouge, which brought terror to Cambodia during the rule of Pol Pot from 1975 to late 1978. More than a million Cambodians died under the Khmer Rouge rule. **********In recent days, the Khmer Rouge radio has asserted that its rebels launched a major attack on Battambang, Cambodia's second largest city, and grenade attacks on Phnom Penh. Reports from Cambodia confirmed an increase in rebel activities, but said the Khmer Rouge assertions were exaggerated. **********China Favors Sihanouk Plan **********A senior Australian official, Michael Costello, reportedly met Prime Minister Hun Sen over the weekend to explain his Government's peace plan. He then flew to Bangkok for talks with Chinese, Indonesian and Vietnamese officials. Mr. Costello is expected to arrive in Paris on Thursday. **********The Australian plan, modeled after a similar formula that enabled Namibia to hold free elections and end its occupation by South Africa last year, has been welcomed by the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union. **********But China, which supports the Khmer Rouge, has said it favors a plan put forward by the former Cambodian ruler, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, involving formation of a four-party coalition government comprising the three rebel groups and the Hun Sen regime to rule until free elections are held.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/busin.main_headline: Prominent Speculator Is Indicted in Japanese Stock Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/busin.print_headline: Prominent Speculator Is Indicted in Japanese Stock Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/busin.body_text: **********Prosecutors today indicted one of Japan's best-known and most politically influential stock speculators, Matsuhiro Kotani, today on charges that he manipulated a stock. But the prosecutors left many disappointed when they indicated that the inquiry was now likely to end. **********Mr. Kotani, who is 53 years old and is reported to have ties with more than a dozen top Japanese politicians, and a partner earned millions of dollars by manipulating the shares of the Fujita Tourist Enterprises Company earlier this year, the Government said. **********The shares of Fujita Tourist, a leading operator of hotels and restaurants, rose from 3,300 yen, or about $22, a share on April 2 to a peak of 5,200 yen, or about $35, a share on April 24 because of heavy buying done secretly. **********Political Implications **********The case is being watched closely for its political implications and as a sign of how sincere Japanese authorities are in their professed aim of clamping down on stock market fraud. Perceptions have long existed that the Tokyo stock market favors powerful companies and politicians, with individual investors paying for the abuses. **********Mr. Kotani and another speculator, Shuichi Yamamoto, the former head of a construction company, were reported to have sold about six million shares at the peak of the purported scheme, and used the profits to repay a personal debt to the Kokusai Kogyo Company, an aerial surveying and property company that Mr. Kotani had taken over in a hostile raid several years ago. **********Mr. Kotani and Mr. Yamamoto were arrested last month, and many questions have arisen as to whether the Government would indict them and then investigate what news reports had said were their connections to the ruling Liberal Democratic Party. Two months ago, four former senior executives of Kokusai Kogyo were arrested on charges that they had used inside information during Mr. Kotani's hostile takeover to reap about $10 million in illicit profits. **********Aides' Roles Detailed **********Newspaper reports then carried detailed accounts of how aides to several leading politicans, including former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, profited during the Kokusai Kogyo takeover with Mr. Kotani's help. No charges have been filed against any politicians or aides. **********Television reports said then that the Government had evidence implicating six other individuals in the scheme, including one at the Daiwa Securities Company and another at the Tobishima Lease Corporation. **********Another recent case added to this view. Reports circulated last month that a dozen or more Japanese securities companies had been caught unfairly compensating some of their large corporate customers for market losses. **********According to leaks in the Japanese press, tax authorities had uncovered bogus securities transactions used to repay the customers for more than $100 million in losses in recent years, largely from the stock market crash in October 1987. **********Reports Are Denied **********Two of the firms implicated, Daiwa Securities and the Yamaichi Securities Company, initially denied the reports. Yamaichi later agreed to pay a penalty of 3.2 billion yen, or about $21.5 million, and the brokerage reiterated that it had not intentionally covered customer losses. **********In addition, a leading bank, the Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, admitted that it had arranged along with Yamaichi to compensate some customers for stock-trading losses, an illegal practice. **********The reports added to long-held suspicions that Japanese brokerages routinely guaranteed their big institutional customers a minimum return on stock trades - something not available to individual investors. **********The brokers were reported to have sold securities to the big customers at below-market prices, and then repurchased them later at much higher prices. Such riskless stock deals are also illegal in the United States and have brought prison sentences to some of those caught up in the American insider trading scandal, including Ivan F. Boesky, the former Wall Street arbitrager. **********A number of securities industry officials were struck by the fact that the case was uncovered by the tax authorities, not the Finance Ministry's securities bureau, which has the primary responsibility for policing the markets. **********Tighter Trading Laws **********Japan tightened its insider trading laws just a year ago, but it has made only one other arrest for such illegal trading or stock manipulation. **********The Recruit scandal, which burst into the headlines early last year and brought down a prime minister, involved a wealthy entrepreneur who passed out unlisted shares in a real estate company he controlled just before it went public.
