The bank, which attracted about a third of its shareholder funds from 41 religious organizations and another third from institutions like the American Express Company and J. P. Morgan & Company, promised to concentrate on lending to small businesses in low- and moderate-income neighborhoods of New York City. **********From an office on Livingston Street, Brooklyn, the bank will also offer consumer services, with federally insured deposits at market interest rates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/23/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; National Advertisers Elect New Officers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/23/busin.body_text: **********Philip Guarascio was elected chairman of the Association of National Advertisers yesterday at the group's annual meeting in Naples, Fla. **********Mr. Guarascio, who will head the 29-member board of national marketing and advertising executives, is executive director of corporate advertising and marketing at the General Motors Corporation. **********L. Ross Love, vice president of advertising for the Procter & Gamble Company, was elected vice chairman. Elected directors were: Richard Costello of General Electric; Charles B. Fruit, Anheuser-Busch; John L. Moorhead, Pepsi-Cola; John O'C. Nugent, Unilever U.S.A., and Janet L. Soderstrom, Visa USA. **********Mr. Guarascio, who was vice chairman of the organziation last year, is a specialist in automobile marketing. He begain his career as an assistant media buyer at Benton & Bowles in 1964, where he eventually became senior vice president and director of media management. He is best known for G.M.'s corporate image campaigns and is also responsible for aggressively pushing G.M. into integrated marketing. **********"I think that my main objective as chairman is the brilliant execution of an already-strong and substantial plan," Mr. Guarascio said in a telephone interview yesterday. "We want to make sure our membership-retention and programs are more successful and that we bring the A.N.A.'s voice further up the line to more senior levels of management."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/17/busin.main_headline: Georgia Pacific Seeks New Nekoosa Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Georgia Pacific Seeks New Nekoosa Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/17/busin.body_text: **********The Georgia Pacific Corporation, which is engaged in a battle to win control of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, said yesterday that it had begun to solicit proxies to remove Great Northern's board at a special shareholders meeting. **********Georgia Pacific, the giant paper producer based in Atlanta, also said that it was seeking to strike down a Great Northern shareholder rights plan that includes a provision intended to make a hostile takeover prohibitively expensive. The special shareholder meeting is scheduled for March 2 in Portland, Me. **********Georgia Pacific indicated it had no recourse but the proxy fight because the rival paper producer had rejected its $3.8 billion tender offer. ''Despite our repeated statements that all aspects of our offer, including price, are negotiable, the board has refused to meet with us,'' said T. Marshall Hahn Jr., Georgia Pacific's chairman and chief executive. **********Within the last two weeks, more than 75 percent of Great Northern's shares have been tendered, Georgia Pacific said. ''We believe that shareholders have sent a strong message that they want the board to support the offer,'' Mr. Hahn said. **********Meanwhile, Great Northern maintained yesterday that the $63-a-share all-cash offer was inadequate and that the combination of the two paper concerns would violate antitrust laws. Last month, the Federal Trade Commission indicated a merger of the two companies would not violate antitrust laws. **********Stephen M. Hill, a spokesman for Great Northern, said that the company was mailing its own proxy material to shareholders in an effort to maintain its board. **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Great Northern's stock was up $2.25, closing at $58.50. Georgia Pacific's stock was up $1.375, closing at $48.75. **********Sherman Chao, an analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc., said that it appeared increasingly likely that Georgia Pacific would prevail in its effort to acquire Great Northern, which is based in Norwalk, Conn. **********''Barring any unusual events right now in the courts it appears that Georgia Pacific has got the deal, in that 75 percent of the shares have been tendered,'' Mr. Chao said. ''And 75 percent is also a threshold needed to remove Great Northern's board.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/world.body_text: **********The Attorney General of Mexico said today that his Government would continue cooperative narcotics-control efforts with the United States, despite tensions caused by the capture of a Mexican doctor brought to the United States to face charges of aiding in the killing of an American drug agent in 1985. **********The Mexican Attorney General, Enrique Alvarez del Castillo, told reporters after an hourlong meeting with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh of the United States, ''The difficulties we face with the United States should not interfere with the very broad relationship which is in the interest of both nations.'' **********Mr. Alvarez del Castillo's remarks appeared considerably more conciliatory than his recent comments, in which he has at times threatened to curtail drug-enforcement operations with the United States because of the abduction of the Mexican suspect, Humberto Alvarez Machain. **********After the meeting, a senior United States law-enforcement official said that Mr. Thornburgh told the Mexican officials that an internal Justice Department investigation had determined that the plan to capture Dr. Alvarez was initiated by high-ranking Mexican police officers who earlier this year met in Los Angeles with Drug Enforcement Administration officials, who consented to the proposal. **********Bush's 'No. 1 Priority' **********The official declined to discuss whether the drug agency played any subsequent role in the abduction, and said it remained unclear whether the Mexican police officials acted with approval of their superiors. **********Mr. Thornburgh said after the meeting that Federal prosecutors were likely to provide additional details about the capture of Dr. Alvarez at a court hearing in Los Angeles scheduled for later this month. **********Earlier today, Mr. Thornburgh said he met with President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle Friday to discuss the strained relations with Mexico. The Attorney General said Mr. Bush insisted that his ''No. 1 priority'' was prosecuting the people responsible for the 1985 torture and killing of Enrique Camarena Salazar, the Drug Enforcement Administration agent. **********Mr. Thornburgh's comments seem to signal that the Administration is determined to pursue the prosecution of Dr. Alvarez over the objections of the Mexican Government. **********Strains on U.S.-Mexico Ties **********''I believe we are both very satisfied at the high level of cooperation that has existed between the United States and Mexico,'' Mr. Thornburgh said after the session today. ''We are committed to continuing that high level of cooperation, with the inevitable problems that come up in a cooperative venture.'' **********The Alvarez case has cast a pall over efforts to improve cooperation between the United States and Mexico in the fight against drug trafficking. **********The arrest of Dr. Alvarez has caused an uproar in Mexico. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari expressed his ''strong displeasure'' over the incident in a meeting in Mexico last month with Mr. Quayle. **********And Mexican officials have bitterly denounced the incident as a violation of Mexico's national sovereignty after reports published in both countries suggested that Dr. Alvarez was abducted by bounty hunters operating with the knowledge of the Drug Enforcement Administration. **********Mr. Alvarez del Castillo and other Mexican officials have demanded a detailed explanation of the circumstances surrounding the capture of Dr. Alvarez, who was taken from Guadalajara to El Paso, where he was arrested on April 3 by agents from the drug agency. The Alvarez case has also prompted Mexico to ask the United States for new ground rules restricting the activities of American drug agents in Mexico.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/16/busin.main_headline: Joint Venture for Memory Chips Officially Declared Dead
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/16/busin.print_headline: Joint Venture for Memory Chips Officially Declared Dead
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/16/busin.body_text: **********U.S. Memories, a ground-breaking attempt by American computer companies to cooperate in producing memory chips, was officially declared dead today by its organizers. **********Some electronics industry executives said the bad experience in trying to organize the joint venture might discourage others from trying to form similar ventures as a way of making American industry more competitive. **********''The inability to achieve consensus does not augur well for similar efforts in the United States,'' said Wilfred Corrigan, the chairman of U.S. Memories and also the chief executive of the LSI Logic Corporation, a Silicon Valley semiconductor company. **********But executives of computer companies that did not join say the failure of U.S. Memories was related to particular problems with market conditions and its business plan, and did not mean other kinds of ventures should be ruled out. **********Mr. Corrigan spoke at a news conference here about the decision to dissolve U.S. Memories because not enough computer companies were willing to invest in the venture. **********The failure of U.S. Memories, which was intended to reduce the reliance of American computer companies on Japanese chip suppliers, is likely to undermine moves in Washington to provide Government assistance in areas like high-definition television. Opponents of such efforts are likely to ask why the Government should help the industry when it appears unwilling to help itself. **********''I think the Hill is going to be very disappointed,'' said Richard Iverson, president of the American Electronics Association, referring to Congress. **********In an emotional speech here, Sanford L. Kane, the president of U.S. Memories, criticized the computer industry for shortsightedness and a lack of cooperation. **********''What happened today does not bode well for an industry that has made a decision that is a tactical one rather than a strategic one,'' he said. **********''We're kind of like an all-star sports team. The industry has a lot of superstars who are spectacular in their own way but don't know how to work together.'' **********The Japanese have teamwork, he said. ''As a result, they keep winning while we get knocked off one by one until it's too late to mount a counter-attack.'' **********Mr. Kane said it was evident that the venture would fail at a meeting on Wednesday in Dallas attended by the seven initial members as well as by four computer companies still thinking of joining - the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Compaq Computer Corporation, the NCR Corporation and Tandem Computers Inc. **********At that meeting Mr. Kane made a last-ditch effort to salvage U.S. Memories, presenting a plan that would require $350 million instead of the $500 million initially envisioned. **********Mr. Kane also said he was willing to start with only $150 million from the companies, with the rest to be raised on Wall Street. e But when the prospective contributions from each company were put on the board, it was clear that an adequate commitment would not be forthcoming even to meet the vastly reduced target, Mr. Kane said. He said he was disappointed by the small commitment the Hewlett-Packard Company, one of the original seven investors, was willing to make. ''The other six members maintain their commitments,'' he said. **********The other six members were the International Business Machines Corporation, the Digital Equipment Corporation, Advanced Micro Devices Inc, the Intel Corporation, the National Semiconductor Corporation and LSI Logic. **********Some computer industry executives have indicated over the last few months that ideological opposition to the idea of joint ventures was not behind the decision of companies like Apple Computer Inc. and Sun Microsystems Inc. to shun U.S. Memories. **********Rather, many computer companies have thought that such a venture is not needed. A few months ago there was a shortage of memory chips, but now there is a surplus. **********In addition there was widespread skepticism over the business plan for U.S. Memories, which was revised.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/busin.body_text: **********Sun Microsystems Inc., helped by strong sales of its low-priced computer work stations, reported sharply improved results for its fourth quarter and 1990 fiscal year. **********For the quarter ended June 30, Sun had net income of $49.1 million, or 51 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $20.3 million last year. Revenues jumped 62 percent, to $700.1 million, from $431.2 million. **********Sun, which was founded in 1982 and became one of the fastest growing companies in history, suffered its first loss ever in last year's fourth quarter. It suffered from a difficult transition to new products, component shortages and a breakdown of its internal data-processing operations that prevented it from keeping track of orders and production. But the Mountain View, Calif., company is now generally considered to have recovered, largely because of a hot-selling line of computers based on its Sparc microprocessor. **********Sun's stock slipped 50 cents today, to $29.75. It was the most-active issue in over-the-counter trading with more than 2.4 million shares traded.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/25/busin.body_text: **********With the deadline for Donald J. Trump to make a payment on a ''junk bond'' issue at midnight tomorrow, a group of banks is preparing a $20 million bridge loan as it presses to win final approval for a larger loan package to rescue the developer, bankers involved in the talks said yesterday. **********They also said the terms on the larger loan would include stringent restrictions on Mr. Trump's personal and business finances. **********As of yesterday evening, one foreign bank continued to oppose the package, bankers said. Another raised new objections to the plan over the weekend, they said. **********Missed Payments **********On June 15, Mr. Trump failed to make a $43 million payment on the bonds that were issued to build his Trump's Castle casino in Atlantic City, and a $30 million payment on a loan from the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. The larger loan package would provide Mr. Trump $65 million to make his payment to bondholders and would defer interest and principal payments on about $850 million in other bank loans for as long as five years. **********Before the 30-day bridge loan can be made, an agreement on the $65 million loan must be obtained from all banks that own chunks of nearly $2 billion in loans to the developer. The short-term credit is needed because the paperwork for the $65 million package cannot be completed by the deadline. **********The bridge loan, which would be supplemented by cash and bonds provided by the developer, would be replaced once documentation on the broader loan package is made final. **********The collateral on the $20 million bridge loan would be an array of Mr. Trump's personal property, including his interest in the Trump Tower retail complex and another New York condominium building, Trump Parc, as well as residential condominiums he owns in both, his private airplane and some stores in Trump Plaza. **********Among the restrictions the banks have outlined in the loan agreement is that Mr. Trump's monthly charitable contributions not exceed $100,000, and that his personal and household expenses not exceed $450,000 a month for the rest of the year, $375,000 a month in 1991 and $300,000 a month in 1992. **********In addition, the loan package requires Mr. Trump to adhere to a clear business plan with month-by-month cash flow projections and item-by-item disbursements. It also stipulates that a chief financial officer and a system of accounting controls be put in place in the Trump Organization by Sept. 30. The developer must also replace the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen with the firm of Kenneth Leventhal & Company. **********Also under the terms, the operating income of several of Mr. Trump's assets, including the Plaza Hotel, the Trump Shuttle airline, Trump Tower and a 76-acre inactive railyard that Mr. Trump owns on the West Side of Manhattan, would not be given to the Trump Organization but would provide payments for the loans attached to them. **********People involved in the talks said two large obstacles remained between Mr. Trump and the bankers. The first is Dresdner Bank A.G., a German bank that holds a $15 million share of a $75 million loan that the Chase Manhattan Bank made against the Trump Tower. Dresdner is the last holdout in that loan syndicate, in which there are also three Japanese banks, and although bankers from Chase and representatives of the Trump Organization had tried to win over the German bank on Saturday, it still refuses to approve the loan package, those involved said. **********These bankers said the big New York banks, particularly Chase, would put a great deal of pressure on Dresdner today to go along with the new loan package. Dresdner's top officers are being pulled into the negotiations. **********''They are bringing in the heavy artillery of senior management at this point,'' one banker said. ''It has gotten to the level of chairman, vice chairman and president of these banks.'' **********French Bank Balks **********A second problem emerged over the weekend when Societe Generale, a large French bank, began reneging on its decision to approve the package. Societe Generale, a member of the bank syndicate that has a $200 million loan to Mr. Trump on the Manhattan railyard, is balking at the deal because it does not want Mr. Trump to defer principal and interest payments on the loan. **********Representatives of all the major New York banks involved in the talks have said those banks will not purchase the loans of smaller banks, or buy them out of the deal, as the Dresdner Bank is said to want, and would allow Mr. Trump to default tomorrow on the bonds if approval is not received from all members of the various loan syndicates. **********Reluctance by Foreign Lenders **********Over the last two weeks, several foreign banks involved in loan syndicates led by Mr. Trump's biggest lenders - Citibank, Bankers Trust, Chase Manhattan Bank, and Manufacturers Hanover - were said to have balked at the new deal and later given their approval. **********Several Japanese banks in the Chase syndicates have tentatively agreed to the terms of the loan package and are expected to get final approval from their Tokyo offices this morning, bankers said. **********If Mr. Trump does not make the $43 million payment to Trump's Castle bondholders by midnight tomorrow, he will have defaulted on the bonds. As a consequence, he would probably lose control of that casino, one of three he owns in Atlantic City. Such a default could also lead to defaults on some of the developer's other loan agreements. His casino licenses could be in jeopardy and the developer might be forced to seek bankruptcy protection. **********Trump Sells Dutch Shipyard **********AMSTERDAM, June 24 (Reuters) - Donald J. Trump has sold the Dutch shipyard that was building his $210 million yacht only two months after he bought it. ''Trump sold the yard last week,'' said Andries Bosma, financial controller for the shipbuilder Amels Holland B.V., said Saturday. ''I know who to and for how much, but I cannot reveal the details.'' Earlier this month, as his financial troubles in the United States mounted, Mr. Trump ordered work on the new yacht to stop.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/24/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA; New Magazine Is Announced
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/24/busin.body_text: **********The Association of National Advertisers plans to begin publishing a new trade magazine, The Advertiser, in the spring. The new publication, which will begin as a quarterly, was announced yesterday at the organization's annual meeting in Naples, Fla. **********"This is not to be a magazine about advertising but a magazine for advertisers," said DeWitt F. Helm Jr., president of the association. "It will reflect the day-to-day need for hard- edged, practical information," he said. The Advertiser will accept advertising. **********Last May, the American Assocation of Advertising Agencies began Agency, a quarterly journal sent to its members.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/world.main_headline: After the Summit;   In Europe, Few Are Cheering But Satisfaction Is General
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/world.print_headline: After the Summit;   In Europe, Few Are Cheering But Satisfaction Is General
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/world.body_text: **********Political leaders and commentators in Western Europe said today that they were generally satisfied with the Soviet-American summit conference, but there was little outright cheering and even some harrumphing that the results were for the most part predictable. **********Several editorial writers also cautioned that despite his triumphant journey across the United States, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev still had to deal with considerable economic problems and political uncertainty when he returned to the Soviet Union. **********Some said that Mr. Gorbachev had been bolstered by his conversations with President Bush, but a more prevalent view was that he remained a man in trouble. A conservative Italian newspaper, Il Tempo, compared him to Richard M. Nixon, who attended a summit meeting in Moscow 16 years ago just before he was brought down by the Watergate scandals. **********''He is going home with the feeling of having earned more time,'' the newspaper said. ''Nixon, hounded by Watergate, had only a few more months. How many will Gorbachev have?'' **********'Only a Stage' **********Possibly because today was a national holiday in many European countries, official reaction to the summit talks was slender. Furthermore, press commentaries suggested there was a budding sense that a gathering of this sort, while still closely watched in Europe and reported in detail, had lost some luster and no longer meant as much as it did when the dominance of the United States and the Soviet Union was unassailable. **********''It marks a stage, but only a stage, in a drama which now has many actors,'' The Financial Times said in an editorial. **********The most clearly favorable comments came from the two Germanys, whose leaders repeated assertions made on Sunday that the Bush-Gorbachev summit conference had improved conditions for the unification of their countries despite continued Soviet misgivings about a united Germany's joining NATO. **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said the meeting showed that reunification ''can be solved in a timely fashion,'' including the delicate issue of German membership in the Atlantic alliance. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, in a separate statement, called the Washington talks ''a great success'' that showed that American-Soviet relations had taken ''a qualitative leap upward.'' **********Two Germanys Heartened **********For his part, Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere of East Germany declared that agreements reached on economic cooperation and on nuclear and chemical disarmament meant that the superpowers had begun to define security in ways that went beyond military terms. **********Essentially, the Germans focused on the aspects of the summit conference that pleased them, and they were particularly heartened by expressions of support for the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe as a strong forum for East-West cooperation. The conference is a 35-nation group that deals with military security, economic cooperation and human rights, and West German leaders view it as providing a broad European framework for future relations. **********In Britain, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told the BBC World Service on Sunday night that she was still a ''great fan'' of Mr. Gorbachev, who, she said, had looked at old-style Communism and ''had the courage and vision to say it is not working.'' **********But Mrs. Thatcher, who is to meet with the Soviet leader in Moscow this week, was uncompromising in insisting again that a united Germany must be a full member of NATO. Britain, she made clear, would not accept any proposal to have Germany join the alliance's political structure but remain outside its military framework. **********'The Seed of Compromise' **********There were no public pronouncements on the summit talks from the leaders of France and Italy, and in both countries press reaction tended to be favorable but restrained. **********Corriere della Sera, one of Italy's most respected newspapers, said the superpowers had ''sown the seed of compromise'' in creating a new European order. ''The American President has recognized the legitimacy of Soviet security requirements, and ruled out that a triumphant West would expel the Soviet Union from the executive suite of European destiny,'' the paper said. ''The Soviet President has promised to not put a stick in the wheel of German unification, and above all has confirmed the stabilizing effect of the United States military presence in the Old Continent.'' **********But in Paris, Le Monde chided Mr. Bush for making ''serious concessions, in part in disarmament negotiations but even more concerning little Lithuania.'' This was apparently a reference to the President's surprise decision to sign a trade agreement with Mr. Gorbachev even though the Soviet Union continues its economic embargo against the Baltic republic, which declared independence in March.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/23/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   The Big Selloff In O-T-C Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/23/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   The Big Selloff In O-T-C Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/23/busin.body_text: **********THE 400-point decline in the Dow Jones industrial average since mid-July has captured headlines, but the real carnage is taking place in the over-the-counter market. Investors describe the activity of recent weeks as the worst since the October 1987 crash. **********''It's a liquidity crisis that has led to a bloodbath,'' said Harvey P. Eisen, president of Sun America Asset Management, a New York investment firm. **********Unlike the crash in 1987, when the over-the-counter market was virtually paralyzed for several weeks after the Oct. 19 plunge, this decline has been relentless for several weeks. ''In 1987, it was over in a day,'' said Alan Radlo, portfolio manager of the $622 million Fidelity OTC Fund. ''This is going on and on and on. It's brutal.'' **********Yesterday, the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks fell 4.84 points, to 374.84. That is the lowest level for the Nasdaq index since Dec. 15, 1988. Tuesday's activity was even worse. The index lost 8.91 points, or 2.3 percent, to close at 379.68. And 554 of the more than 5,000 Nasdaq stocks hit new 52-week lows, more than any one-day session since Oct. 28, 1987. Also on Tuesday, over-the-counter trading volume jumped to 166.4 million, up from 115.5 million on Monday. It was still relatively heavy yesterday, at 146.1 million shares. **********Since July 16, when the Dow peaked at 2,999.75, the Nasdaq index is down 20.2 percent, the Dow is down 14.7 percent and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is down 14.2 percent. And for the year, the Nasdaq index is down 16.5 percent, compared with a 5.5 percent decline in the Dow. The decline in the Value Line index, with more than 3,000 stocks, is even greater, down 19 percent. ''There is a panic mentality when you talk to people,'' said Richard A. Freeman, senior vice president of Shearson Asset Management, who invests $165 million in over-the-counter stocks for three mutual funds. ''It's close to a capitulation.'' **********As often happens in nervous selloffs, the stocks of many of the market's best-performing companies have been hit the hardest. Portfolio managers at mutual funds who are jittery about the crisis in the Middle East and the fear of a recession are desperately trying to raise cash because they worry that their shareholders will start redeeming their shares. As a result, these fund managers are selling stocks of the largest, most liquid companies that had run up the most earlier in the year. **********Stocks of companies like Intel, Nike and Lin Broadcasting have dropped quite sharply as worrried investors continue to sell. The stock of Nike, for example, has dropped from $91.875 in mid-July to $62. Yesterday, it fell $5.375. Intel has dropped to $32.125 from $52 over the period; yesterday it slipped 12.5 cents. And Lin Broadcasting to $54.125 from $74; yesterday it lost $2.875. **********Investors complain that this recent market decline has been aggravated by poor trading volume. ''When you have less liquidity in a market, moves are much more violent,'' Mr. Freeman said. **********Wall Street dealers may be trading large blocks of the well-known companies like Nike and Intel, but when investors want to buy or sell shares of smaller companies, like Duty Free and Fifth Third Bank, they will often trade only 500 or 1,000 shares at a time. ''The liquidity factor has become nonexistent,'' said Mr. Radlo of Fidelity. In the October 1987 selloff, sellers complained that many dealers in the over-the-counter market did not pick up telephones. ''They're answering the phones this time, but are they making markets?'' Mr. Radlo said. He said Fidelity was beginning to use a trading system that bypasses over-the-counter brokers and buys and sells directly with other institutional investors. ''It's getting very frustrating trying to do business,'' he added. **********Indeed, since 1987 many dealers in listed securities and over-the-counter stocks have pulled back from making markets. Because they are unwilling to risk their capital in turbulent markets, prices of all securities have become more volatile. ''The business of making markets and providing liquidity is not very profitable for broker dealers,'' said Laszlo Birinyi, founder of Birinyi Associates, a New York securities research firm. **********For their part, dealers say such complaints are common in market declines. And they argue that it is unrealistic to expect them to stand up during turbulent periods. The over-the-counter market is now dominated by institutional investors, they say, and portfolio managers at mutual funds and bank trust departments often act in unison, trying to sell the same stock at the same time without the balancing force of individual investors. **********''They're all getting the same news on the same machine at the same time,'' said Myron J. Schuster, managing director and head of institutional trading at Ernst & Company, a New York broker. ''How can you have liquidity?'' Tuesday's selloff in the over-the-counter market was one of the worst since mid-July, traders said, and no one is willing to predict when it might end. ''We're still in the midst of it,'' Mr. Schuster said. As a result of the bargains created by the selling, some portfolio managers, including Mr. Radlo at Fidelity, have been cautiously buying stocks like the State Street Bank and Trust Company and Nike, but they are not spending all of their cash. ''Why should I fight the tape?'' he said. ''You can't get out of the way of this.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Is It a Film? Is It an Ad? Harder to Tell
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Is It a Film? Is It an Ad? Harder to Tell
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/busin.body_text: **********WHEN Pauline Kael, the film critic for The New Yorker, entitled the first collection of her criticism ''I Lost It at the Movies,'' the ''it'' presumably was a whimsical reference to her innocence and insularity. **********Another film critic, Mark Crispin Miller, worries now that the movies themselves are losing it. In an essay that will be included in the forthcoming book ''Seeing Through Movies,'' Mr. Miller argues forcefully that American cinema has been corrupted by the goals and methods of advertising. **********Mr. Miller, known for his explorations of American television for The New Republic and other publications, looks at contemporary films and everywhere sees product placements, happy endings and anti-realism that are drawn from and promote the same disposable culture extolled by advertising. **********''Conceived and sold as 'product,' just like the many products that it sells, the movie passes right through you, leaving nothing in you but a vague, angry craving for another one,'' writes Mr. Miller, a 40-year-old associate professor at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. **********A shorter version of the essay, entitled ''Hollywood: The Ad,'' will be published as the cover article in the April issue of The Atlantic magazine. The book, which was edited by Mr. Miller, is scheduled to be published in June by Pantheon. **********Using as a reference point the idiosyncratic visions of the films of the 1970's, Mr. Miller attempts to show that the change in Hollywood has been dramatic and recent. Older films like ''The Godfather II'' or ''Chinatown'' had themes that however dark were informed by realistic relationships between people and their society. But today's films, typified by ''Top Gun'' and ''Ferris Bueller's Day Off,'' are uplifting versions of an impossible America where opposites always attract, good guys always win, and the environment is filled with fantastic action, cathartic violence, brilliant colors and a limited handful of brand names. **********To a large extent, Mr. Miller contends, the sole purpose of this ''deliberately anti-realistic'' cinematic construction is to market products whose manufacturers pay to feature them in films. As such, new movies are little different from commercials, for their purpose ''is to enhance the product by meticulously placing it within the sort of idealized display that occurs nowhere in real life.'' **********In an interview, Mr. Miller affirmed his belief that the change in American cinema dates to the acquisition of the big studios by global marketing conglomerates. ''Cinema,'' he said, ''is no longer supervised by businessmen who have a powerful affection for and knowledge of the craft of making movies. The crisis relates to excessive control by forces that are anti-esthetic and are interested only in an immediate hit.'' **********Evidence certainly exists to indicate that a blatant marketing imperative is driving much current American movie-making. Advertising Age recently reported, for example, that the Walt Disney Company's Buena Vista Pictures unit sent large consumer-products companies letters soliciting product placements for a new movie entitled ''Mr. Destiny.'' For $20,000, the companies could have a product seen in the film; for $40,000 an actor would mention the product, and for $60,000 an actor would actually use it. **********Worse than product placements, Mr. Miller said, was the twisting and turning of all current movies to conclude on happy notes. He pointed out that at least three of the five nominees for best picture this year -''Glory,'' ''Born on the Fourth of July'' and ''Field of Dreams'' - include climactic moments of what he called ''gratuitous applause,'' aimed at dissipating any lingering bittersweetness. **********''I worry about a country whose citizens can't tolerate the slightest bit of darkness,'' Mr. Miller said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/07/busin.main_headline: Discount Warehouses Get A New Best Seller: Books
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/07/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Discount Warehouses Get A New Best Seller: Books
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/07/busin.body_text: **********Beside rows of deck chairs and fluorescent shorts, the books are piled on metal skids in a warehouse big enough to be an aircraft hangar. Shoppers browse through the selection, which includes best sellers, cookbooks and coffee-table books. Occasionally, they drop one into their cavernous shopping carts, along with asparagus, kitchen paper and M&M's. **********Scribner's Fifth Avenue it is not. But books are being sold. ''I never read the books, but they are such a good deal that I buy them,'' said Dennis O'Connell, a businessman. **********In his cart, next to some rubber piping, he has Dennis Clifford's ''Plan Your Estate,'' priced at $10.99, against a list price of $17.95, and Judith Ferguson's ''The Step by Step Cookbook,'' costing $12.49, compared with a list price of $39.95. **********Such bargains are drawing a growing number of people to membership-only discount warehouses, including this Price Club in Nesconset. There are now more than 280 such warehouses in the United States, more than four times the number there were five years ago. And with their explosive expansion, the warehouses are selling more and more books - to the point where, on selected titles, they may now sell as many or more as the big Waldenbooks and B. Dalton book chains. **********Analysts say the warehouses - led by Price, and including Sam's, Costco and Pace - now sell at least $350 million in books a year. That is much less than the approximately $2.4 billion sold by the two big chains, but it has grown sharply in recent years and is concentrated on a relatively small number of titles. **********As a result, publishing analysts believe the American book market is changing again. Dominated during the 1980's by the rapid growth of the chains and their challenge to traditional book stores, it is now characterized by the chains' attempts to adjust to new competition, in which the warehouses are prominent and surviving independent stores stronger. **********Referring to the warehouses, Bruce Harris, director of trade publishing for Random House, said, ''They are getting to the point where, on a few selected titles, they are able to clear quantities in a league with the chain buyers.'' **********Tom Hayworth, vice president of Advance Marketing Services, a San Diego-based wholesaler specializing in selling books to the warehouses, estimated that annual warehouse book sales had grown ''at least tenfold in the last five years.'' **********''It is mind-boggling the volume of books you can move in one of these places,'' he said. **********Typically, the warehouses are vast expanses exceeding 100,000 square feet, selling everything from pretzels to books. **********By operating on a no-frills, high-volume, low-inventory basis, they are able to offer something close to the 50 percent discount generally given to wholesalers by book publishers. **********With a range of 150 to 250 books, they do not yet stock sufficient titles or exist in enough locations to pose a direct threat to the chains, analysts say. They also have membership requirements, although these are loose enough to allow Price Club alone to have more than 5.6 million members, most of whom pay a $25 annual fee. **********Moreover, many customers appear to be impulse buyers who would not otherwise purchase books. Publishers are pleased because they believe the warehouses are adding to the overall book market, which continues to grow steadily, rather than taking customers from other stores. **********Pressure on the Chains **********Still, by slashing prices on books by authors like Robert Ludlum and Danielle Steel far below the discounts offered by chains, the warehouses are challenging B. Dalton and Waldenbooks in their core best-seller business and prodding them to adopt a wider range of titles. **********For example, Price Club sells Mr. Ludlum's latest best seller, ''The Bourne Ultimatum'' at $12.29, a 44 percent discount from Random House's list price of $21.95. Philip Roth's ''Deception,'' published by Simon & Schuster, is discounted 42 percent, to $10.99, and Rosamunde Pilcher's ''September,'' published by St. Martin's Press, is 42 percent cheaper, at $13.29. **********In general, discounts on books sold at stores owned by B. Dalton and Waldenbooks vary from 15 percent to 35 percent. For example, Ms. Pilcher's book is being sold for $17.42 at Waldenbooks and $19.50 at B. Dalton. At Barnes & Noble, which is owned by B. Dalton, the price is $16.07. Independent bookstores generally sell at the full list price. **********''Warehouses like Price are pummeling the best sellers and taking some of our sales,'' said Harry Hoffman, chief executive of Waldenbooks. ''So we are having to take a wider range of books. **********'Best Seller Sales Are Flat' **********''Our sales growth now is primarily in our backlist,'' he said, ''where sales in the first four months of 1990 were 25 percent above the same period of 1989. Best seller sales are flat.'' **********Gary Del Vecchio, president of B. Dalton's Doubleday Book Stores, also said increased sales of backlist books were compensating for falling sales of big-name authors. B. Dalton has begun its first campaign to promote little-known or first-time authors. **********Publishers are increasingly aware of the potential of the warehouses to sell large quantities of books. Both Little, Brown & Company and Random House said Price Club was among their top 10 clients. For Mr. Ludlum's latest book, more than 150,000 copies have already been sold through various warehouses, or about 20 percent of total sales up to now, publishers said. **********Price, with total sales of all merchandise exceeding $5 billion at its 47 North American warehouses, is the largest of the warehouse groups. It is followed by Sam's, with more than 125 smaller warehouses; Costco, with about 60, and Pace, with about 40. **********Sharp Growth in Sales **********Typically, publishers sell large quantities of selected books to Advance Marketing, which distributes them to Price Club and other warehouses. The company now provides books to more than 280 warehouse clubs, compared with just 63 in 1985. Its sales have risen to $155 million last year from $24 million in 1985. **********Although many books sold in warehouses are by big-name authors, there are other titles as well. ''We search our backlist for things that might appeal to the warehouses,'' said Mr. Harris of Random House. **********Robert E. Price, president of Price Club, said his company bought many of its books from Advance Marketing, but some were bought directly from the publishers. **********Mr. Price declined to detail book sales, but said they had risen in line with the company's overall performance. Price's revenues have grown sharply in recent years, from $1.8 billion in 1985 to $5.03 billion last year. **********''The chains are our competitors,'' he said. ''Everybody out there is.'' **********But for Jill Keller, a gym teacher shopping at Price Club, there is no competition. ''This is cheaper than the chains, and this where I buy my books'' she said. And she tossed ''The Official Baseball Card Price Guide'' into her cart, alongside giant packs of Minute Maid and bagels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/07/world.main_headline: Mandela Hardens Line on White Rights
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/07/world.print_headline: Mandela Hardens Line on White Rights
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/07/world.body_text: **********Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress leader, told supporters today that he would urge President F. W. de Klerk to abandon his insistence on guarantees for South Africa's white minority before the Government and the congress next held talks on the nation's future. **********''At a time when we want to move away from all forms of racialism, we do not want discussions which have started so well to be determined by any solution which is based on race,'' Mr. Mandela said. ''And I'm going to ask de Klerk that he must not bring this issue to any conference between the A.N.C. and the Government.'' **********Mr. Mandela addressed a crowd of nearly 40,000 African National Congress supporters at a soccer stadium. The rally was held to report on the talks that the congress held with the Government for three days last week. **********The two sides announced on Friday that they had made considerable progress toward overcoming obstacles to broader negotiations on a new constitution that would give blacks a political voice. **********Communist in Delegation **********Other members of the congress's negotiating team - including Joe Slovo, General Secretary of the South African Communist Party, and Alfred Nzo, General Secretary of the A.N.C. - appeared at the rally with Mr. Mandela. They seemed eager to send a message that the success of the talks last week did not mean that the congress had compromised its principles. **********It was unclear whether Mr. Mandela was announcing new conditions for the African National Congress's participation in talks with the Government or was merely trying to reassure supporters that the organization had not retreated on its longstanding demand for a one person, one vote system, which would introduce rule by the black majority in South Africa. **********But his comments today seemed the toughest that Mr. Mandela has made in public on the Government's concern for protection of the white minority since his release from prison three months ago. **********Talks Could Be Undermined **********If Mr. Mandela presses his objection to minority guarantees, as he promised today, it could affect the resumption of the talks. The Government's willingness to negotiate is predicated on a belief that guarantees must be built into any new constitution to insure that whites, about 5 million in a population estimated at 37 million, will not be dominated by blacks. Mr. de Klerk promised this in asking whites to support his vision of evolutionary change. **********Mr. Mandela said he would meet with President de Klerk before the next round of talks. ''And one of the things I am going to urge upon him is to abandon the concept of group rights - minority rights - without any reservation,'' he said. **********''The fact that Mr. de Klerk is determined to bring this concept to the negotiating table means that white South Africa does not yet trust us,'' Mr. Mandela said. The African National Congress has contended that there will be sufficient guarantees for individuals in a unitary, democratic and nonracial South Africa. **********Botha Unhappy, Too **********Mr. de Klerk encountered criticism from another direction in a report that former President P. W. Botha refused to renew his membership in the National Party, to which he belonged for more than 50 years, because of the direction it has taken under Mr. de Klerk. **********The Afrikaans-language newspaper Rapport today said Mr. Botha objected not just to the President's policies but to the inclusion of Mr. Slovo, who has been living in Zambia, in the African National Congress's delegation last week. **********President Botha quit as party leader two weeks after suffering a stroke in January 1989. But he hung on as President, despite pressure on him to retire, until he was forced out last August by his own Cabinet. **********The former President, who was bitter about his ouster, met recently with Ferdi Hartzenberg, deputy leader of the opposition Conservative Party. But Mr. Botha was thought unlikely to join the right-wing Conservatives or to form his own National Party faction.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   G.M. Chairman Gets 'No' Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/busin.body_text: **********The California Public Employees Retirement System, a large holder of the stock of the General Motors Corporation, said today that it had voted against the re-election of the departing G.M. chairman, Roger B. Smith, to the board. **********Dale Hanson, chief executive of the system, said in an interview, ''We think it's awkward to have a new C.E.O. coming in and having your predecessor sitting on the board.'' **********As of Monday, the California retirement fund held 4.7 million shares of common stock, 1.8 million series E and 824,000 series H, Mr. Hanson said. G.M. has about 782 million shares outstanding, which includes 602 million common shares. **********G.M. has nominated 20 people for election or re-election at the annual meeting on Friday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/04/busin.body_text: **********Lion Nathan Ltd. of New Zealand said today that it had settled all but the final financing details of its joint venture purchase of Bond Brewing Ltd. The acquisition would make Lion the largest beverage company in Australia and New Zealand. **********It said it had taken over management of the breweries from Bond Brewing after completing all conditions to set up its joint venture with Bell Resources. **********''We are fully confident that the final formalities will be completed within a week,'' Lion's chief executive, Douglas Myers, said. **********The breweries were sold to Bell for about $1.5 billion by the Bond Corporation to reduce its large debts. **********Lion negotiated with Bell to set up a joint venture to run Bond Breweries by agreeing to pay up to $290 million, which would largely be used to repay bondholders in Bond Brewing. **********Most analysts have praised the deal for Lion, saying it has greatly increased Lion's size at a cheap price. The Bond breweries have been losing market share but are still estimated to have 37 percent of the Australian market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/27/world.main_headline: U.S. to Press U.N. Chief on Human Rights in Cuba
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/27/world.print_headline: U.S. to Press U.N. Chief on Human Rights in Cuba
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/27/world.body_text: **********In an effort to keep the international spotlight on Cuba's rights record, the Bush Administration is heading for a clash with the United Nations Secretary General and the Cuban Government when the Human Rights Commission starts its annual meeting in Geneva on Monday, American diplomats and United Nations officials say. **********The United States is pressing the Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, to submit a written report to the 43-nation commission on his talks with Cuban officials over the last year about suspected human rights violations by the Castro Government. **********These include reports that Cubans who gave evidence to an investigating team sent to Havana by the commission in 1988 were subsequently arrested and mistreated. The team's report said some of its witnesses were punished afterward, and American officials say repraisals have continued. **********Vice President Dan Quayle personally requested such a report when he met the Secretary General here on Dec. 11. American officials say the Secretary General told the Vice President then that he would issue a report if any member nation asked for it. The United States followed up Mr. Quayle's request with a letter asking for a report. **********On Wednesday, however, the Secretary General wrote back to the United States representative, Thomas R. Pickering, saying he would submit a report on Cuba's human rights record only if the Human Rights Commission formally instructed him to do so at its coming session. **********U.S. Cites 1989 Resolution **********The Bush Administration takes the view that the Secretary General is already empowered to make the report under an ambiguously worded resolution approved at last year's meeting. **********This asked him to discuss with the Cuban authorities the commission's 1988 investigation into Cuba's human rights record, including assertions that witnesses were intimidated. It then says, ''These contacts and their results will be taken up by the Secretary General in an appropriate manner.'' American officials argue that a report to the Human Rights Commission constitutes ''an appropriate manner'' of following up on the contacts if requested by a member nation. **********The Secretary General has already been asked to report to this year's commission meeting on human rights violations in China, using information ''provided by the Government of China and by other reliable sources.'' **********Such a report on Cuba, diplomats say, would enable the Bush Administration to focus the commission's attention on the human rights situation there in a way that may otherwise be difficult to do. Cuba is not formally on this year's commission agenda, although members may raise charges of rights abuses in any part of the world. **********With Cuba a commission member and the third world in a majority, Western diplomats believe the United States has little hope of pushing through a new resolution next week asking the Secretary General for an immediate report. **********State Department officials this week expressed surprise and irritation with the Secretary General's letter, saying it represents a change in position and goes back on the assurances given Mr. Quayle. **********Effort on Central America **********While United Nations officials say last year's resolution does not specifically require the Secretary General to make a report, American diplomats say they are convinced that Mr. Perez de Cuellar is holding back mainly because he thinks that writing such a report would be perceived as an anti-Cuban, pro-American gesture, which might impair his peacemaking efforts in Central America. **********These are at a delicate stage, with the Secretary General trying to draw the United States, the Soviet Union and Cuba more deeply into the quest for a regional settlement as the three outside powers most directly concerned with the area. **********The United Nations is also deploying a peacekeeping force in Central America to monitor compliance with the peace plan the five nations of the region have accepted in principle but are having trouble carrying out.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/world.body_text: **********Responding to the concerns of his Western backers, Prince Norodom Sihanouk distanced himself further from the Communist Khmer Rouge today, signing a communique with Hun Sen, the Prime Minister of Cambodia, that the Khmer Rouge refused to support. **********Speaking alongside his non-Communist ally, Son Sann, Prince Sihanouk said the two men and their followers would abide by the terms of the communique, even though their allies, the Khmer Rouge, would not do so. **********The statement calls for the establishment of a Supreme National Council by the end of July to embody Cambodian sovereignty until new elections can be held and a new government formed. **********The communique says the council will be made up of equal numbers of representatives from the two rival governments, as Mr. Hun Sen wishes - not of equal numbers from the four Cambodian factions, as the Khmer Rouge demands. **********'Voluntary Self-Restraint' **********The communique also calls for ''voluntary self-restraint on the use of force'' - diplomatic language for a cease-fire that cannot be enforced -beginning on the first day that the Supreme National Council meets. **********But Prince Sihanouk admitted at a news conference tonight that no cease-fire or lasting peace in Cambodia could be reached until the Khmer Rouge agreed to take part. **********He also said the Supreme National Council would not truly be representative of Cambodian sovereignty until the Khmer Rouge took part. **********''There will be no Khmer Rouge -they do not want to participate in the Supreme National Council at all,'' the Prince said. ''But in my opinion, the Supreme National Council will really be a symbol of sovereignty only on the day the Khmer Rouge join as full members. In order to have peace in Cambodia, we need to make peace with the Khmer Rouge. We must persuade the Khmer Rouge to join us inside the Supreme Council.'' **********Pressure Off Western Nations **********But if the Prince and Mr. Son Sann do what they have now promised to do -form a Supreme National Council with Mr. Hun Sen even without the participation of the Khmer Rouge - it will enable the United Nations this fall to give Cambodia's seat there to the council, thereby further legitimizing Mr. Hun Sen and isolating the Khmer Rouge. **********It would also take some of the pressure off the Bush Administration and other Western governments that have been increasingly criticized for indirectly supporting the Khmer Rouge by their support for the Prince and Mr. Son Sann. **********Cambodia's seat is currently held by the Sihanouk coalition, which includes the Khmer Rouge, who were driven out of power when the Vietnamese invaded Cambodia in 1978. Under the Khmer Rouge, more than a million Cambodians were killed or died of starvation and disease during a brutal campaign of restructuring. **********But as the Prince implied tonight, such an pact is likely to do little to end the war in Cambodia, the brunt of which is carried by the Khmer Rouge, and may intensify the fighting. **********If they are cut out of any settlement, they will have little incentive to stop fighting, and Asian and European diplomats make clear that no country will agree to put international peacekeeping troops into Cambodia as long as the Khmer Rouge have not agreed in principle, at least, to lay down their arms. **********Talks Turn Sour **********Japanese officials started the two days of talks confidently, working from a draft text that the Thai Defense Minister, Gen. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, had gotten all four factions to sign. **********Japanese officials spoke of the meeting as a first venture into regional peacemaking since the end of World War II, and as a diplomatic exercise more commensurate with Japan's standing as a world economic power. **********But what was envisaged as two days of negotiation between Mr. Hun Sen and Prince Sihanouk as the two leaders of rival sides quickly turned sour. The Khmer Rouge, scheduled to attend as part of the Prince's delegation, boycotted the first meeting on Monday, which adjourned after 25 minutes. **********The bipartite negotiations never resumed. Although General Chavalit and Japanese officials shuttled among the factions, they spent most of their time in conversation with the Khmer Rouge and the Sihanouk side. Officials with Mr. Hun Sen said there was little for them to do but wait. **********Japanese 'Very Annoyed' **********A joint Hun Sen-Sihanouk news conference turned into separate ones, and then it was announced that Mr. Hun Sen would not speak this evening after all. Throughout, Japanese officials tried to keep smiles on their faces, although one official said the Japanese were ''very annoyed'' with the Cambodians, the Khmer Rouge in particular. **********In the end, what Prince Sihanouk and Mr. Hun Sen signed tonight was a communique little different from the one that the four factions initialed last month. **********But the real importance of the meeting here is likely to be the growing isolation of the Khmer Rouge within a diplomatic process that is accelerating, and that is treating Mr. Hun Sen with much more respect than before.
