https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/02/busin.body_text: **********This year's steep drop in prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange may have saved the world's largest company, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, from being broken up. **********For three years, debate has raged within the Japanese Government over proposals to split Nippon into local and long-distance companies, thus splintering the largest and one of the most lucrative near-monopolies in Japan. **********But when the deadline for decision came on Friday, the Government agreed to delay any breakup for at least five years. Many experts here think that the decision effectively means that Nippon and its unions have prevailed, and the move may be derailed forever. **********Like the divestment of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in the United States through the mid-1980's, the Nippon breakup was seen as a way to create competition in one of the world's most intricate and heavily used telephone networks. **********Saved by a Price Plunge **********But in the end, Government officials say, Nippon was saved not by arguments over the wisdom of a split but by the political atmosphere created by the remarkable plunge of its share prices. The free fall began a year and a half ago in the midst of the stock-and-influence peddling scandal centering on the Recruit Company. Even after the scandal faded, the stock continued to fall. **********''We have avoided the worst case, the nightmare,'' a senior official of Nippon said on Friday, after the Government made its announcement. **********For Japanese investors, Nippon is the ultimate blue-chip stock, and from the time the company was offered to the public in 1986, affluent Japanese scrambled to get a share or two. That was all most people could afford. The offering price was 1,197,000 yen, or about $7,575 a share at current exchange rates. **********At one point in 1987, the share price soared to 3,180,000 yen - more than $20,000 a share. To many Japanese, it seemed like the company, capitalized at a higher value than any other in the world, could only go up. The telecommunications business was booming, and the land that Nippon owns for its local telephone offices is undervalued on the company's balance sheets by billions of dollars. **********But Nippon was quickly enmeshed in the Recruit scandal, and its stock fell after its chairman, Hisashi Shinto, was arrested. He is on trial now. More recently, the decline has been accelerated by a Government report advocating that the company's domestic long-distance service be spun off into a separate company. Nippon stock has plummeted to little more than $7,000 a share, well below the initial offering price. **********Perhaps the most anxious shareholder is the Japanese Ministry of Finance. The Government owns 66.8 percent of the company. Last year, as the price fell, it had to postpone a public offering of additional shares that was expected to relieve Japan's budget deficit and pay for a range of programs. In recent days, Ministry of Finance officials made no secret of their growing displeasure. **********At the same time, Haruo Yamaguchi, the chief executive of Nippon, stepped up his campaign to convince Government officials, journalists, shareholders and the company's workers that a breakup would be disastrous. **********''It would be a very negative thing,'' Mr. Yamaguchi said two weeks ago during a lunch with a small group of foreign correspondents. ''We would have to raise our rates, and the network itself would suffer, much like in the United States.'' **********Three Telephone Networks **********A breakup would have left Japan with three telephone networks. Already, international telephone service is handled by another former government monopoly, KDD, which has watched its business dwindle as low-cost competitiors have begun to win an unexpectedly large number of customers. **********Under the breakup plan, Nippon would have been left with only local calling. Since it has been heavily subsidizing local service with its long-distance revenues, local rates would surely have risen. **********The other camp in the bitter Government dispute was the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, which had strongly advocated a breakup. It said local-calling service could have turned profitable if the company became more efficient. **********But the Ministry of Finance argued that the company's stock might not recover for years, and in the end it won the support of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Airlines Announce Plan to Cooperate
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/busin.body_text: **********USAir and Air France announced a joint marketing program for coordination of schedules, marketing and joint facilities. As part of the deal, each carrier will be able to buy blocks of seats from the other for resale on designated trans-Atlantic flights. The agreement, which was in the form of a letter of intent, is the first of its kind between Air France and a leading United States carrier. **********The airlines plan to explore joint advertising and sales promotions, code sharing, cargo development, automation improvements and shared use of Air France's terminal at Charles de Gaulle Airport when USAir begins Philadelphia-to-Paris service next year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/23/world.main_headline: Channel Tunnel City Worries About Job Loss
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/23/world.print_headline: Channel Tunnel City Worries About Job Loss
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/23/world.body_text: **********Sheila Simpson can distinctly remember the last time Folkestone was in such a state of turmoil. **********"I lived here through the Second World War, and we were blitzed from across the Channel," she said. "We were shelled nightly. But even that was nothing compared to what has happened here in the last few years." **********Mrs. Simpson, Mayor of this sprawling 580-year-old city on the southeast coast of England, was referring to the effect that construction work on the underwater tunnel that links Britain and France has had here since the workbegan more than three years ago. **********And though the construction will eventually end, Mrs. Simpson said, the impact on Folkestone's economy will linger for decades and may very likely be negative. "We will be in trouble in three years' time if we don't get our act together," she said. **********The town's economy, she said, is buoyed by the tourist trade generated by the ferry service that now operates between Folkestone and Boulogne, France. Thousands of Britains use the ferry for day trips to the Continent, she said, often just to take advantage of the tax-free spirits and cigarettes that can be bought on board and in France. Butcompletion of the tunnel, along with the removal of economic boundaries in the European Community in 1992, will essentially render the port and the ferry service obsolete, she said. **********And though hundreds of thousands of tourists and businessmen are expected to use the tunnel after it opens in June 1993, few will ever set foot in Folkestone, Mrs. Simpson said. **********The reason is that the tunnel entrance and exit, the 345-acre Folkestone Channel Tunnel Terminal, is west and north of Folkestone's business district. While people using the ferry now have to pass through the business district to get to the harbor, those usingthe tunnel will bypass the town center. **********"I think Folkestone will lose out," said Ron Barnett, manager of the London-Paris Hotel near the harbor. "The tunnel comes straight out onto the motorway, and people coming out of the tunnel are already going to be on their way out of Folkestone." **********Nevertheless, some business officials said, Folkestone has profited from the tunnel construction. **********"Two and a half years ago we had 30 empty stores on High Street," said Victor H. Seymour, vice president of the Folkestone Chamber of Commerce. "Now there are none." **********A survey commissioned by the Kent County Council, the governing body of the county in which Folkestone is situated, showed that tunnel construction had created almost 6,500 jobs in the area as of January 1990.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/world.main_headline: Kremlin Softens Its Threat to Armenia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/world.print_headline: Kremlin Softens Its Threat to Armenia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Government has agreed not to send troops into the republic of Armenia to disarm militant groups that have refused to surrender their weapons, the newly elected nationalist President of the republic said today. **********The agreement, reached after talks in Moscow between the Armenian President, Levan Ter-Petrosyan, and Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov of the Soviet Union, removes a potential flashpoint in the Caucasus region, where political violence has often erupted in recent years. **********At a news conference, Mr. Ter-Petrosyan said Moscow had extended the deadline of a presidential decree ordering the surrender of illegal arms, and had given sole responsiblity for their collection to the local authorities. ''We have an agreement that we will be able to carry out the decree freely without intervention from outside,'' he said. **********In a decree issued July 25, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev set today as the deadline for armed groups to hand over their weapons, or else face their forcible seizure by Soviet troops. The measure was directed at politically sensitive regions, principally Armenia, where open warfare has broken out between rival gangs using weapons stolen from police and army depots. #1,600 Weapons Turned In The Soviet Ministry of Internal Affairs reported today that across the country, a total of 1,600 weapons had been handed in since the decree was issued, and that more were still coming in. On Wednesday, the Minister of Internal Affairs, Vadim V. Bakatin, appealed to Mr. Gorbachev to extend the deadline indefinitely, citing a new, ''responsible'' approach on the part of the newly installed authorities in Armenia. **********Disarming criminal gangs and militant groups will be a difficult and delicate task for the republic's police forces, a spokesman for a leading Armenian nationalist group said today. But Amburtsum Galtsyan of the Karabakh Committee added: ''The most important thing is that people support us. If Gorbachev sent in troops, there would have been a violent reaction.'' **********The agreement between Mr. Ter-Petrosyan and Mr. Ryzhkov signals a new stage in Moscow's willingness to relinquish control to new political forces emerging at the republic level. It also softens the impact of the presidential decree, which with its threat of intervention by federal troops, had been viewed in some republics as a challenge to local sovereignty. The Armenian Parliament voted to suspend the decree. **********A turning point in the crisis in Armenia was the election last week of Mr. Ter-Petrosyan, a leader of the nationalist movement, a linguistic scholar and a former political prisoner who spent the first six months of last year in jail under investigation for his political activities. Mr. Ter-Petrosyan, who is 45 years old, was arrested during Mr. Gorbahcev's visit to Armenia after the December 1988 earthquake. **********Phone Call From Gorbachev **********Two days ago, Mr. Gorbachev, who is on vacation in the Crimea, called Mr. Ter-Petrosyan to congratulate him on his election. **********Mr. Ter-Petrosyan also said he was ready to establish better relations with Azerbaijan, the republic that borders Armenia and with which it has been fighting over control of the mountainous territory of Nagorno-Karabakh. **********The first order of business for the new government is to restore stability to a republic that has been badly shaken by lawlessness, he said. **********In recent weeks, the Armenian capital, Yerevan, has been depicted by the Soviet press as a gunfighters' corral, where shootouts are almost an evening sport.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/07/busin.body_text: **********Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that its profit in the fourth quarter of last year grew by nearly 8 percent and by more than 18 percent for the year. **********Fourth-quarter earnings for the company - whose businesses include not only soft drinks but also snack foods like Doritos tortilla chips and restaurants like Pizza Hut - rose to $202.1 million, or 76 cents a share, from $187.7 million, or 72 cents a share, in the corresponding period of the previous year. **********The company's sales in the quarter rose by 18.9 percent, to $4.78 billion from $4.02 billion. **********Charges Affect Earnings **********Pepsico, based in Purchase, N.Y., said its quarterly earnings were lowered by $13.2 million because of special charges taken to cover reorganization expenses. **********The charges stemmed from a decentralization of the operations of its growing international soft-drink business and the Taco Bell restaurant chain. **********For the international expenses, the company charged $12.3 million against earnings, before taxes, to acquire more offices and additional staff for its overseas unit, creating six regional offices instead of a centralized center near Pepsico's headquarters. For the decentralization effort at Taco Bell, the company charged $5.5 million against pretax earnings to cover the expenses of adding office space and arranging relocations. The charges totaled $17.8 million, or $13.2 million after taxes. **********Pepsico's annual results also included reorganization charges, plus a special gain. **********For the year, the company's earnings grew by 18.2 percent, to $901.4 million, or $3.40 a share, from $762.2 million, or $2.90 a share. Its sales increased by 21.6 percent, to $15.24 billion from $12.53 billion. $8 Million Special Charge The company's 1989 profit includes an $8 million special charge against pretax earnings to cover reorganizing the domestic operations of its Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation unit. The subsidiary has been hurt by saturation in the fast-food market and by a growing consumer preference for grilled chicken, which it does not offer. **********Adding the Pepsico international and Taco Bell charges to the Kentucky Fried Chicken charge largely offset a $32.5 million credit from keeping a Japanese bottler previously set for sale. The final result for the year is a $1.8 million after-tax credit, or one cent a share. **********The soft-drink business, Pepsico's largest unit at about 38 percent of 1989 annual revenue, continued to show substantial gains. Its earnings for the year rose 49 percent, to $690.1 million, and sales rose nearly 25 percent, to $5.78 billion. **********Restaurants, the company's second-largest business, reported a yearly earnings growth of 20 percent, to $421.2 million, and sales increases of nearly 20 percent, to $5.25 billion. Pizza Hut Inc. posted a strong gain of 36 percent, to $208.6 million, and Taco Bell, 38 percent, to $112.6 million, but profits at Kentucky Fried Chicken declined by 14 percent, to $100 million, including the $5.5 million reorganization charge, from $116.5 million in 1988. **********Frito-Lay Inc., the company's snack-food business, reported a 1989 profit gain of nearly 14 percent, to $820.9 million, and a sales increase of more than 9 percent, to $4.22 billion. **********In trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, Pepsico's stock rose $1 a share, to $59.375.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/26/busin.main_headline: Business Scene;   Retailing Trouble Is Fundamental
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/26/busin.print_headline: Business Scene;   Retailing Trouble Is Fundamental
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/26/busin.body_text: **********AS everyone knows, retailers are in trouble. **********Bankruptcies have put Bloomingdale's, Saks **********Fifth Avenue and other big-name department stores on the auction block. And in a weak economy, consumers are being extra careful about spending. But once the bankruptcies are history and the economy is robust again, America's retailers will still be in trouble. The problem is that the public is rattling around in too many stores - with too much shopping space. **********This space glut is widely acknowledged among retailers. Ira Silver, chief economist of J. C. Penney Company, holds a typical view. ''To be successful in this situation, you have to be a really good merchant,'' he said. ''But if everyone somehow got to be a really good merchant, there would still be a shakeout because we are a nation with too much store space for the number of buyers.'' **********That is hard on retailers, but a bonanza for consumers in two respects. With so much space in which to offer all sorts of merchandise, the price discounting that became widespread last year, particularly in clothing, is likely to continue. Secondly, to make themselves immune to the oversupply of store space, some big retailers are trying to be more sensitive to the needs of shoppers. **********Thus, Penney found itself selling general merchandise - refrigerators, auto parts, consumer electronics, gardening equipment, clothing - in big shopping malls that in the 1980's developed an overabundance of this type of store. ''We switched to high-quality apparel, a market segment that was not over-stored in our shopping centers,'' Mr. Silver said. **********Similarly, Nordstrom Inc., the big West Coast clothing store chain that is expanding in the East, has drawn customers by smothering them with smiling sales people. ''You have to focus on something, and our focus is customer service,'' said John Goesling, Nordstrom's chief financial officer. **********But the overcapacity produces plenty of stress. There are constant store closings and job losses, mostly among smaller operations. ''It does terrible things to people's careers,'' said Alice McCord of the National Retail Merchants Association. **********Even retail workers who keep their jobs feel the strain. Nordstrom, for instance, has been accused by the State of Washington of systematically failing to pay sales people for some work. The company is said to have required employees to work some hours without punching in their time cards. Mr. Goesling did not comment on the charges. But he says that Nordstrom ''expects a lot from our people and is not a place for everyone to work.'' **********If overcapacity is disruptive, measuring the extent of it is complicated. Commerce Department data indicate that retail sales space has been increasing at a faster rate than sales revenue and that space in the nation's shopping malls - the main area of expansion - has grown by 20 percent since 1986. But shopper traffic through the malls has risen by less than 10 percent, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers. **********The glut is, however, uneven. The Sun Belt states are very over-stored, while those around the Great Lakes have escaped the problem. What is more, store construction rises in tandem with housing construction rather than higher sales revenue, according to George Christie, chief economist at the F. W. Dodge Division of McGraw-Hill, which compiles construction data. If people buy more, that simply allows nearby retailers to make greater use of existing space. **********Mr. Christie says that from 1970 until 1985, retail floor space grew invariably by 200 million square feet for every one million new single-family houses. And then in 1985, store construction jumped to 250 million square feet for every million new houses and stayed at this ratio through last year, although construction has slowed in recent months. ''We might get back to a normal ratio this year or next,'' Mr. Christie said. **********Why the overbuilding? Two factors were cash-rich pension funds seeking profitable investments and savings and loan associations no longer required to lend only for housing. They decided that shopping malls would pay off, and many of the bigger ones have. But the thousands of ''strip centers'' of half-a-dozen small stores are suffering from high turnover and vacancy rates. **********The overbuilding coincided with other trends that reduced the supply of shoppers. The baby boomers do not shop as much as they did when they were mostly under 30. Working women are not big shoppers either. And many families buy from catalogues rather than stores. **********Clearly, this is a hard period for retailers, and it seems likely to last until floor space gets back into line with demand - perhaps by 1993, Mr. Christie said. Retailers, in effect, are now paying the price for the exuberant building boom of the 1980's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/30/world.main_headline: As Mandela Stumps for Sanctions, South Africa Debates Them
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/30/world.print_headline: As Mandela Stumps for Sanctions, South Africa Debates Them
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/30/world.body_text: **********Nelson Mandela's plea for Western countries to maintain economic sanctions against South Africa has galvanized the debate over their effectiveness in hastening the end of apartheid. **********It is increasingly apparent that the cumulative damage of sanctions will be difficult for a post-apartheid government to correct. But many whites here say that sanctions have outlived their intended purpose - to shock the Government into change - and that their economic impact has been overrated. **********Many South African blacks, on the other hand, value such measures as symbols of international support for their struggle, though the sanctions hurt their incomes more than those of their white employers. **********Frederik van Zyl Slabbert, a liberal white who quit Parliament to promote more direct dialogue between whites and blacks, described the debate on sanctions as ''a quagmire of confusion, half-truths, platitudes, provocation and deception.'' **********''It is also riddled with laudable intentions frustrated by reality,'' said Mr. Slabbert, speaking last week in Port Elizabeth. He added that the argument would endure, ''if only because of its ability to generate more heat than light.'' **********Opponents Are Derided **********Some blacks who question the efficacy of sanctions, like the Zulu leader, Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, have been vilified as collaborators. **********''It is automatically assumed,'' Ismail Lagardien wrote in The Sowetan, the largest black newspaper, ''that if someone is opposed to economic sanctions against South Africa, this person is in favor of apartheid, white domination and capitalism. On the other hand, the person who supports the call for sanctions is seen as sound of mind and character, and most definitely part of the liberation struggle.'' **********The white minority Government fueled the argument by initially dismissing the effect of sanctions, even while it enacted a law declaring it a crime to publicly advocate the curbs. **********''They would not make it illegal if it didn't hurt,'' said Max Sisulu, chief economist for the African National Congress. **********More recently, officials have conceded that sanctions restricted growth and limited access to foreign loans. Because of sanctions, Finance Minister Barend du Plessis said, ''we lost a few yards in the 100-meter race.'' **********Shrinking of Economy **********A study released in May by the Investor Responsibility Research Center in Washington said sanctions had cost South Africa between $15 billion and $27 billion. It estimated that the bation's economy is 20 percent to 35 percent smaller today than it would have been without restrictions on investment capital and the need to produce costly substitutions of imports. But the study also found South Africa much less vulnerable to sanctions than it was 10 or 20 years ago. **********South Africa's acquired ability to live with sanctions has become conspicuous in its foreign trade, which accounts for at least 55 percent of the gross domestic product. The latest trade figures suggest that South Africa will run a surplus of $2 billion this year. Moreover, the nation has found other markets and investors to replace those lost from the United States. **********The Trade and Industry Minister, Kent Durr, reported in Parliament last week that foreign companies planned to invest billions of dollars in South Africa in the next six months, with nearly $1.7 billion going into the country's automobile industry. Mr. Durr did not say where the money would come from, but West Germany and Japan have filled the vacuum left by departing auto makers from the United States. **********In a meeting with foreign journalists in February, Chris Stals, the governor of the South African Reserve Bank, observed that economic sanctions fell into three categories - trade boycotts, disinvestment and the withdrawal of loans. Only the last had been devastating, Mr. Stals said. **********After foreign banks called in loans in 1985, $12 billion flowed out of the country. But some Western economists attributed this not to sanctions but to a loss of investor confidence created by unrest in the black townships, Flow of Rands Prevented ''Since 1985, we've had to run the economy on a cash basis,'' Mr. du Plessis told foreign journalists. ''It's the equivalent of a household trying to raise its standard of living without access to a banking facility.'' **********But when Western companies stopped doing business in South Africa, Mr. Stals said no factories were closed and little money was lost because the South African rand was kept inside the country, with only the right to use it bought and sold abroad as the so-called ''financial rand.'' **********''In terms of the balance of payments, disinvestment had little effect,'' he said. **********Mr. Stals noted that some South African corporations profited from disinvestment by buying foreign subsidiaries at low prices. ''It led to a bigger concentration of economic power into the hands of the few conglomerates,'' he said. **********Where disinvestment has hurt is in disrupting access to new technology and investment from former parent companies. **********'Hurts Apartheid More' **********Some proponents of sanctions now concede that the besieged economy's inability to create any new jobs has left more blacks unemployed, but say the price must be paid. **********''Yes, we recognize that sanctions hurt the blacks, but it hurts apartheid more,'' Max Sisulu said. **********A survey of 1,400 blacks released by the Chamber of Mines a year ago found that 82 percent opposed sanctions. **********Sanctions remain significant in bolstering the morale of those who confront apartheid daily, but they also figure in the domestic political maneuvering that is preceding the negotations proposed by President F. W. de Klerk on the country's future. By influencing the schedule for the lifting of sanctions, the African National Congress has a weapon to wield against the Government and black rivals like Chief Buthelezi. **********Mr. Mandela, the African National Congress leader whose world tour has been aimed in part at preserving sanctions, has said removing them too soon could make the Government complacent about the gradual pace of change. **********Effect on the Future **********But in his recent visit to Western Europe, Mr. de Klerk spread a message that sanctions were unnecessary since he was busy dismantling apartheid. He and his supporters contend that repealing the curbs would give him tangible evidence to prove to nervous whites that dismantling apartheid can benefit them, too. **********Whatever the future of sanctions, their stunting of economic opportunity and employment seems bound to plague a post-apartheid South Africa. **********''The whole idea of sanctions was to signal to South Africans the displeasure of the U.S. Congress over political events in this country,'' said Prof. Carl F. Noffke, director of the Institute of American Studies at Rand Afrikaans University. ''But you can't continue with that signal unless you want to destroy a country.'' **********Mr. Mandela has proposed large-scale foreign investment to rebuild the economy, once apartheid is ended. But Mr. Stals said investment funds withdrawn by banks from South Africa would probably end up in Eastern Europe. **********Mr. Slabbert, speaking in Port Elizabeth last week, said: ''The most dangerous illusion created by the sanctions debate is that when de Klerk and Mandela agree to end the call for sanctions, untold millions of investment capital will pour into South Africa. Nothing of the sort will happen.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/24/busin.main_headline: SAVINGS FAILURES EXPECTED TO SOAR, THE TREASURY SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/24/busin.print_headline: SAVINGS FAILURES EXPECTED TO SOAR, THE TREASURY SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/24/busin.body_text: **********The Administration told Congress today that more than 1,000 savings and loan associations - 40 percent of the industry - might eventually have to be seized by the Government, twice the number it had initially projected. **********Blaming rising interest rates and sizable areas of weakness in the nation's real estate markets, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told the Senate Banking Committee that based on the new projection the $73 billion that Congress appropriated for the bailout last year would have to be raised at least to $89 billion, and perhaps to as high as $130 billion. **********''It is now clear that the amounts projected and authorized will fall short of what is required,'' Mr. Brady said. **********A Shift in Position **********Mr. Brady's testimony represented an extraordinary admission by the Administration, which for more than a year has insisted that there was no compelling reason to change its estimates of the cost of the biggest financial debacle in the nation's history, even though private analysts were warning that the Treasury's original numbers were woefully inadequate. **********''Reality has arrived and we should be thankful for it,'' said Bert Ely, a financial consultant based in Alexandria, Va. ''The Treasury has put realistic numbers on the table.'' **********But the figures Mr. Brady gave today represent only a portion of the overall cost of the cleanup. They do not include the cost of the deals struck in 1988 for the sale of more than 200 institutions before the bailout law was passed. And, citing the same economic factors, a top regulator admitted today that those costs are also rising. [Page D20.]  The new estimates also do not include the huge amounts of interest the taxpayers will have to pay to finance the bailout. **********When those are added in, the total cost of the bailout to the taxpayer and the industry could easily exceed $250 billion over the next 10 years, and approach $500 billion over 30 years. Last month, the General Accounting Office said the cost of the bailout including interest would range from $325 billion to $500 billion. **********Mr. Brady said his agency did not include the interest costs because such costs are not included in accounting for Government programs. ''It would be like saying that the $30 billion Kennedy space program actually cost $92 billion,'' he said. **********Today's estimates were arrived at differently from the $61 billion that Administration officials estimated on Tuesday would be added to next fiscal year's budget deficit because of the bailout. **********Getting the Bad News Out **********Some experts were surprised that the Treasury was willing to paint such a grim picture. ''I think the word must have come down that Brady get the bad news out once and for all and not run the risk that as 1992 approaches they have to change their numbers again,'' said one industry expert who asked not to be identified. **********The clear message from Mr. Brady and the Administration was that Congress would need to appropriate large sums of additional money to guarantee that insured depositors not lose any money. Mr. Brady said he would support either an open-ended appropriation or a set figure, whichever the Congress wanted. But he warned that since the cost of the bailout is a moving target, a specific figure might prove to be inadequate and Congress might find it would have to take up the issue again. **********The savings and loan industry ran into deep troubles in the mid-1980's as the result of slack regulation at the Federal and state levels and highly speculative investments in real estate by savings and loan entrepreneurs whose lending practices bordered on the fraudulent. **********The debacle created billions of dollars of losses for depositors. The Government, which is obligated to cover losses on insured deposits, is now making good on those guarantees. Mr. Brady stressed today that management and stockholders were not being bailed out but that depositors were being rescued. **********Bailout Officials Attend **********Mr. Brady testified as chairman of the Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created last year to oversee the bailout. He appeared with the four other board members: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman; Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and two members from the private sector, Robert C. Larson, a real estate specialist, and Philip C. Jackson, a former Federal Reserve official. **********The new estimates also come at a time of delicate budget negotiations between the White House and Congress. The Administration has said that the soaring cost of the bailout has been a driving force behind its desire to get a budget agreement. **********Mr. Brady said the biggest contributors to the rise in costs have been higher interest rates and the weak real estate markets. Both factors are sending more savings units into insolvency and making it harder to find buyers for either their assets or their branch offices. **********''Thrifts are just not as attractive a franchise relative to banks as they once were,'' Mr. Brady said. **********Accounting for the Deficit **********One issue that Mr. Brady and others will have to solve is how, on a budgetary basis, the Government should treat the high costs of the cleanup, as well as the large volumes of interim financing, often referred to as working capital, the trust corporation needs. The issue is what portion of the costs to count as part of the Federal deficit. **********Mr. Brady said he would support keeping the working capital off budget, and thus not counted in the deficit, since it is used to pay off depositors after an institution is seized. Once the Government liquidates the assets of an institution, often in a later fiscal period, it recovers large amounts of the money that it borrowed to pay the depositors. Such transactions produce swings that tend to skew the budget picture. **********Mr. Brady did say that the Government should count as part of the deficit any payments to depositors that are not ultimately covered by the sale of assets. But he said he would leave to the budget negotiators the issue of whether the bailout costs should be used in calculating whether the deficit is meeting the budget targets of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law. **********The latest numbers are likely to confuse the public, since industry experts, academics, regulators, members of Congress and the General Accounting Office have issued sharply varying projections. **********Projections by Category **********The projections have basically fallen into three categories. **********One measures the problem in terms of what it would cost today to cover the losses of depositors' money, ''As if you could write a check and solve the entire problem right now,'' a senior Treasury official said. **********Last year, the Treasury said that $50 billion would be enough for the Resolution Trust Corporation to handle failures between August 1989 and August 1992, and another $23 billion would cover failures after that. It has now expanded that estimate so that in the most optimistic case the cost would be $89 billion, and in the worst case, if real estate prices continue to be depressed, it would cost $130 billion. **********Other projections, including those of the Office of Management and Budget, have calculated how much the bailout would cost, including interest on borrowings over the next 10 and 30 years. Last year, the 10-year cost was put at $159 billion, while the 30-year cost was estimated to be more than $250 billion. **********But Mr. Greenspan said today that the numbers projected by the Treasury implied even higher overall costs than the $320 billion to $500 billion in the G.A.O.'s most recent projections. **********Perhaps the most graphic illustration of the huge upward adjustment by the Treasury was its projection that in the worst case as many as 1,037 savings and loan institutions with $530 billion in assets might have to be seized before the Resolution Trust Corporation completes its work in August 1996. **********But Mr. Greenspan did not seem overly concerned about the higher figures. He said he did not expect that the extra borrowing implied by the higher cost estimates would have much of an effect on credit markets. **********''In and of itself, it should not affect interest rates,'' he said. **********Survivors and Casualties **********A new calculation by the Office of Thrift Supervision divides the savings industry into four categories of comparative health. **********One group covers 1,267 well-capitalized and profitable institutions, with assets of $399 billion. A second group comprises 621 institutions, with $327 billion in assets, that are expected to meet the new capital requirements. Few if any of these are expected to fail. **********A third group comprises 315 savings associations, with assets of $152 billion that are troubled by poor earnings and low capital levels. The fourth group covers 299 institutions, with $193 billion in assets, and they are expected to fail. **********In the worse-case projection, all the institutions in the last two groups would fail.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Morgan Stanley & Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 50 investment banking jobs, or 6 percent of the 800-member division. It is expected that this round of cuts will be followed by investment banking layoffs at other Wall Street firms. **********Similar layoffs have taken place at Paine Webber Inc. and Shearson Lehman. But Morgan Stanley's are significant because of the firm's reputation. It is considered a corporate finance powerhouse and its investment bankers are generally viewed as the elite of Wall Street and were instrumental in arranging some of the biggest deals of the 1980's. **********Investment banking is considered one of the most prestigious and profitable lines of business on Wall Street, and while the securities industry has been swept by layoffs in other areas, this is the first time a brokerage firm of Morgan Stanley's caliber has cut investment bankers.  'No Clear Precedent' **********A spokesman for Morgan Stanley said the cuts would come from all four investment banking areas: corporate finance, mergers and acquisitions, capital markets and real estate. He said those being let go range from junior analysts to "quite senior people," although the spokesman declined to indentify the employees involved. **********"These layoffs are a reflection of the firm's feelings about the business outlook in the intermediate-term future," said the spokesman, who spoke on the condition he would not be identified. He added that there was "no clear precedent" for the layoffs and that "nothing quite like this has happened before." **********The layoffs come at a time when Morgan's overall earnings have been holding up. But its investment banking revenues have fallen steadily throughout the year. For instance, in the second quarter, investment banking fees dropped by 30 percent from the period a year earlier, and were down 8 percent in the third quarter from the 1989 quarter. **********"The true earnings of the firm have held up relatively well this year," the spokesman said. "But you've certainly seen the statistics on merger activity so far this year, and the outlook for that is uncertain at best."'   'Not Surprising' **********Michael Goldstein, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said the layoffs reflected "the basically weak business environment." **********"This is not suprising," he added. "I've been expecting the entire Street's investment banking capacity to contract because investment banking revenues have been at their lowest level since 1984 and a lot of jobs were added since then." **********But investment banking, which generally involves raising capital for American companies and arranging financing for mergers and buyouts, has been hard hit by the economic downturn as well as the stagnation of the "junk bond" market. American corporations are not raising money to expand and the number of mergers and buyouts has fallen sharply since their heyday in the 1980's. **********The Morgan spokesman said the layoffs would have no effect on fourth-quarter earnings and that no charge would be taken. By the end of the year, he said, he expected that the investment banking department would number about 750, and he added that no further investment banking layoffs were planned.  Expansion Abroad **********The firm has about 7,100 employees, up from 6,600 at the beginning of the year. But the expansion has taken place in Morgan Stanley offices overseas, primarily in London, Tokyo and Hong Kong, and not in New York. **********Morgan is not planning any major structural changes as a result of the layoffs, but the spokesman said the firm would merge its capital markets, debt and equity operations. **********Since the 1987 market crash, employment in the securities business has fallen by 50,000, to 210,000. But most of the cutbacks have resulted from the collapse of several firms, most notably E. F. Hutton & Company and Drexel Burnham Lambert. **********At the same time, profits in the industry have been battered. The double-digit profits of the early 1980's have shrunk to an average of 4 percent since 1987, according to the Securities Industry Association. Pretax return on equity, which averaged 50 percent in the 1980's, has fallen to an average of 7 percent since the market crash, the association reports.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/04/busin.main_headline: All About/Exercise Machines; The Fitness Boom Ends Up at Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/04/busin.print_headline: All About/Exercise Machines; The Fitness Boom Ends Up at Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/04/busin.body_text: **********THE Marines still do their pull-ups.Heavyweights jump rope.  But these days more and more ordinary Americans are trying to get in shape with elaborate and expensive home exercise equipment. Last year, they spent $1.73 billion, triple what they spent in 1980. **********Exercise machines are the latest in the fitness boom, suitable for an aging, family-minded generation. **********Richard Miller, owner of Cutler Owens, the Gym Source, says his New York store began as a full-line sporting goods retailer that catered to runners and tennis players in the 1970's. He started selling exercise equipment in 1981 and gradually eliminated everything else, concentrating on higher-end products.  "I figured the ultimate would be in the home," he said. "People were in the health clubs, they got married and had kids, and they are staying at home." **********In National Sporting Goods Association consumer surveys, retail sales of home fitness equipment grew 22 percent in 1988 and 19 percent in 1989. The equipment accounts for about 15 percent of sporting goods sales, more than any other category except hunting. The products range from a bottom-of-the-line exercise bicycle, for less than $100, to computerized treadmills for more than $3,000. **********Some in the industry wonder if the growth can continue. How many people will keep sweating in the privacy of their homes? they ask. And if more machines end up in closets, will fewer new ones be sold? A Fickle Business **********Matching Trends Is a Key to Success **********Exercise equipment fads can be fleeting. Rowing machines were the rage several years ago; now, sales are slow. Treadmills and stair machines are popular, but for how long? Several companies are bringing out weight machines, for those less interested in endurance than in strength. **********Manufacturers have learned that buyers can be quick to rebel when they don't get results, said Wayne Sales, merchandise manager for sporting goods at K Mart. In the mid-1980's, he said, sales stagnated. "We saw a lot of equipment that was gimmicky." Since then, he added, "There has been a resurgence of basic, fundamental equipment." **********Pamela Miller, fitness editor at Sportstyle, a trade magazine, says consumers who are fickle about equipment usually retain their dedication to good health. When they become discouraged with one machine, they try another, she said. But others in the industry fear that the boom will end as buyers consign their machines to the closet. **********Manufacturers always stand ready to provide new products. Those companies that keep up with the trends lead the industry. Most are privately held, keeping even their sales figures to themselves. But Sportstyle reports that Diversified Products of Opelika, Ala., was the industry leader last year with sales of $220 million, up 22 percent. Weslo Inc., of Logan, Utah, and its sister company, Proform Fitness Products Inc., are growing even faster, with a 94 percent gain, to $204 million, last year. **********These companies prosper by offering a range of products at all prices.  They rely heavily on giant retail chains like Sears, Roebuck & Company and the K Mart Corporation, which account for an increasing share of industry sales. After the leaders, about three dozen smaller companies tend to be more specialized. **********The largest of the more specialized companies is Nordic Track, of Chaska, Minn., a unit of the publicly held CML Group Inc. Its machines mimic the action of cross-country skiing, allowing skiers to train without snow and lame runners to pile up their mileage without torturing their knees. Nordic has relied exclusively on mail order, but it is about to open its first retail outlet, in Washington. Nordic's revenues have risen from $14 million in 1986, when CML took over, to $85 million for the fiscal year that ended in July. **********Not every exercise equipment company can keep up with the industry's pace. Last year, Escalade Inc., of Evansville, Ind., a maker of recreational products and office equipment, acquired 55 percent of Marcy Fitness Products, a financially troubled manufacturer of weight benches and related goods. John Wilson, secretary-treasurer of Escalade, explained that Marcy had tried to expand too quickly and failed to control expenses. Although the takeover kept Marcy in business, the company's sales failed to pick up, and the financial drain has left the parent concern in the red. Threats to Sales **********Flimsy Equipment, Bored Customers **********For many home athletes, buying fancy machines is much less taxing than using them. Do most buyers keep on rowing, running, skiing or lifting long enough to generate more sales? "That is the proverbial question," said Bill Smith, vice president of marketing for Diversified Products. "Interest does tend to wane." But in a survey, he found that equipment use was surprisingly high, with more than half of all buyers remaining consistent users of the products. **********Nordic Track attempted to telephone 1,209 buyers who had owned its machines for five years. Of the 207 reached, 69 percent said they were still using the equipment, averaging three and a half workouts a week of 25 minutes each. **********Some say that boredom and flimsy low-priced machines threaten the industry's success. Steve Onder, general manager of the Sports Training Institute in Manhattan, a personal training and physical therapy center, said the most popular, lower-priced equipment "doesn't support a long-term training program." A cheap treadmill does not have a motor capable of turning the belt fast enough for jogging, he said. **********Sebastian Di Casoli, director of marketing services for the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association, says some buyers give up when they find the machines cannot exercise for them. "A lot of people do it to relieve guilty feelings about their weight," he said. "It does get boring and many machines end up in the closet." **********Some makers have found innovative ways of fending off boredom. The Precor 9.4sp treadmill, list price $4,500, can be set for 48 exercise programs in miles, 48 in kilometers, or programs of the owner's choosing. The Walking Center in Beverly Hills, Calif., has another way to make its dozen treadmills -- priced at $2,500 to $3,000, or $95 a month to use them in the showroom -- more inviting. Each is hooked up to a television with an earphone. The Outlook **********A Recession Might Even Help Sales **********Makers of exercise equipment insist that their sales will remain firm even as the nation's economy sags. In troubled times, consumers usually back away from major purchases. But exercise equipment is so new that few long-term records exist. "Leisure-time goods do fairly well in a recession, but exercise equipment might be different," Mr. Di Casoli said. "There is no data. On top of that, the items that are growing are the more expensive ones like treadmills and stair machines." **********Gary Stevenson, a founder and the chief operating officer of Weslo, says workout machine sales will increase as many families find they offer an economical way to sweat out a recession. "People will drop vacations," he said. "They will also tend to stop paying for health clubs, weight-loss centers. There is early evidence they will buy equipment for the home." **********Even the Middle East crisis may help, some say. As John Walsh, the exercise equipment buyer for Sears, said, "Usually when times get tough, people will stay at home and more equipment will be sold. We saw this in the gasoline crises of the 1970's." **********Fitness industry executives say they also have demographics on their side. As the population ages, the demand for equipment can only increase, they say. Industry statistics show that 35- to 65-year-olds are the biggest buyers. They are usually secure in their occupation, have more money than the elderly or young, and are more resistant to a recession. **********For all their marketing and innovations, many makers of fitness equipment say their best sales device might be the mirror. As Phyllis Nwransky, public relations manager at the Weider Health and Fitness Corporation, put it, "If we don't do something, we get fat and lazy and we look funny." A MUSCULAR MANUFACTURER **********FOR some entrepreneurs, helping others build muscles seemed like a good way to build wealth. Weslo Inc., one of the fastest-growing manufacturers of exercise equipment, entered the business to balance seasonal sales of wood stoves. **********In 1977, Scott Watterson and Gary Stevenson, students at Utah State University, after two years as Mormon missionaries in the Far East, began importing kitchenware and marble products to pay for their educations. Two years later, they added a third partner, Blaine Hancey Jr., to jump on a trend. In the midst of an energy crisis, their company bought the rights to Fire King wood stoves and developed a network of retailers, mostly in the West. **********Then the partners looked for something to sell in the spring and summer. They settled on trampolines. That business brought them to sporting goods trade shows. There, Mr. Stevenson says, "We recognized that Americans were looking for a way to stay well." **********They began importing simple exercise cycles and then started making treadmills in Logan, Utah, where the company is based. They expanded to a full line of equipment, including elaborate home gyms. Weslo makes 70 to 80 percent of its products in Logan and the rest in Taiwan now. **********Weslo bought the rights to the Proform name in 1987, after Nike, the sneaker maker, abandoned exercise equipment. Weslo itself was bought in 1988 by the the Weider Health and Fitness Corporation, a maker of weights and food supplements and publisher of several fitness magazines. The company was founded by Joe Weider, a bodybuilder who helped train Arnold Schwarzenegger. **********Mr. Stevenson and Mr. Watterson, still in charge, continue to demonstrate agility as well as strength. Weslo has cultivated the big department stores so well that earlier this year, it was cited by Sears, Roebuck merchandise buyers for products that made outstanding contributions to the stores' sales. **********And Weslo is always updating its equipment. Its treadmills now offer computerized monitors for pulse, calorie consumption and equivalent distance. "You need something motivational," Mr. Stevenson said. " Feedback makes the task less mundane."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/10/busin.body_text: **********Entertainment Weekly, the magazine begun in February by the Time Inc. Magazine Company, has purchased the name and subscription list of 7 Days, which ceased publication on April 16. **********The 7 Days list has more than 20,000 names of affluent New Yorkers. The weekly magazine, started two years ago, focused on the New York arts and entertainment scene. It was closed by its publisher, Leonard Stern, after reportedly losing about $5 million a year. **********The sale price was not disclosed. Michael J. Klingensmith, the publisher of Entertainment Weekly, said the sale involved ''cash and a not insignificant liability,'' a reference to unfulfilled subscriptions. Subscribers will be offered issues of Entertainment Weekly for the remaining portion of their 7 Days subscriptions. **********''We will hold on to the name, but I can't tell you today what we will do with it other than to say there is a possibility in the back of our minds of supplementing the national Entertainment Weekly with metro inserts,'' Mr. Klingensmith said. **********These inserts would appear in big cities and vary from one market to another, he said. They would feature information about local clubs and maybe even movie times and include local advertising. **********''Acquiring the name preserves a number of options for us,'' Mr. Klingensmith said. ''It also preserves the option of not having other people have the name.'' **********Entertainment Weekly has a national circulation of 600,000, with less than 50,000 in the New York area. **********Soon after Entertainment Weekly made its debut in February, readers and advertisers complained that the magazine was difficult to read. Mr. Klingensmith said that a number of changes in graphics were under way, including use of bolder type and the reorganization of some pages.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/28/busin.main_headline: Your Money;   New Software Offers Advice
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/28/busin.print_headline: Your Money;   New Software Offers Advice
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/28/busin.body_text: **********Three new software packages offer great help in personal finance. Hyatt Legal Services' Home Lawyer and WillMaker 4.0 can help with legal matters, while Make Your Paycheck Last helps people keep their spending within their income. **********All three programs are inexpensive, as software goes, easy to use and will speed up tasks that would take much more time using books, pencils, paper and calculators. But users of the legal programs should be ever mindful of what programmers call GIGO, for garbage in, garbage out. When in doubt about a point of law, it is best to consult a lawyer, not to take a stab at it and produce a legal-sounding document that could lead to trouble. **********WillMaker 4.0 for I.B.M. and compatible personal computers is available from retailers or directly from Nolo of Berkeley, Calif., (1-800-992-6656, or 1-800-445-6656 in California) for $55.95, which is 20 percent off the list price of $69.95. The Macintosh version will be out in August. **********To write a will, the user answers a series of questions on the computer screen, consulting the thorough reference manual that comes with the program if necessary. When the interview is finished, the program prints out a will. It can produce wills for either single or married people that are valid in all states except Louisiana. Among the features of WillMaker 4.0 are the abilities to make up to 28 specific bequests, set up trusts for minor beneficiaries in accord with the Uniform Transfers to Minors Act and transfer data to a word-processing file for custom formatting and printing. **********Hyatt Legal Services Home Lawyer, which lists at $99 and is widely available for $69, is based on the master documents of Hyatt Legal Services, the nation's largest general-practice law firm. It was produced by Overdrive Systems Inc. of Cleveland, a legal software company, and is marketed by MECA Ventures Inc., which sells Andrew Tobias's Managing Your Money and Taxcut. The original version of Home Lawyer was introduced in the spring in Egghead Discount Software stores, and an upgrade was released this month to many software stores. **********Home Lawyer also relies on an on-screen interview to put together and print out a variety of legal documents: wills (although with fewer specific bequests than WillMaker and a less detailed interview), various powers of attorney, revocation of power of attorney, residential lease, promissory note, bill of sale for motor vehicle, general bill of sale, employment agreement, independent contractor agreement and special letters for offer of employment, demand of money owed, bad check notice, defective product complaint and request for credit report. **********Three primary reasons for wills are to appoint an executor, to name guardians for minor children and to make specific bequests that would not be covered under a state's intestacy laws - for example, a book or painting that has sentimental value, money or jewelry to someone who would otherwise receive nothing or a bequest to a religious institution or charity. Each program will enable users to do these things, and in a test of each it was possible to load the program into the computer and produce a will in less than an hour. **********Each program advises people whose estates exceed $600,000 to go to a lawyer for estate planning, because estate taxes can be whittled down by using gifts and trusts. People whose personal situations are complex - say a partner in a business or someone who has been divorced and has children by the previous marriage - are also likely to need expert advice. **********Even those who find the will portion of Home Lawyer inadequate may find the program pays for itself by producing letters or documents in a minute or two. **********Steven Potash, president of Overdrive Systems, said, ''Our purpose is to save people a lot of time and expense.'' Certain areas were deliberately avoided, he said, ''because we would not be doing the client a service.'' **********Make Your Paycheck Last is available in some software stores or directly from Harsand Press (1-800-451-0643) for $19.95 for disk only or $24.95 for disk and the book of the same name by Harold Moe. **********Mr. Moe, an airline pilot, despaired of the complicated advice he got from lawyers, accountants and bankers on how to get out of debt. So, he and his wife, Sandy, sat down at the kitchen table and figured out how to set goals for what they wanted and how to give financial priority to achieving those goals, while forgoing the less-important things. They succeeded, and he wrote a book of common-sense financial advice. **********In conjunction with Disk-Count Software Inc. of St. Paul, they have produced a companion program that is extremely easy to use for keeping track of personal finances.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/08/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;   Venezuela Improving Oil Quality
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/08/busin.body_text: **********Stacks of pipes near well-drilling rigs here point to a transformation in oil production in Venezuela, the nation with the largest proven oil reserves in the Americas. **********By drilling to new depths below the table-flat plains of eastern Venezuela, oil workers are starting to tap a sea of highly prized low-sulfur light and medium crude oil. **********''This is the largest oilfield discovery in Venezuela in the last 25 years, another Prudhoe Bay,'' said Norbert G. Sporn, a spokesman for Petroleos de Venezuela, the state oil company. **********From the neutral vantage point of a London office, Kim Fuad, an editor for the Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, described the fields here as ''a tremendous windfall for Venezuela.'' **********Up to 15 Billion Barrels **********''These finds are very big - 10 to 15 billion barrels,'' said Mr. Fuad, a Venezuela expert. ''That's more than half of United States proven reserves.'' **********Indirectly, the fields also represent a boon for the United States, which receives two-thirds of Venezuela's oil exports. United States oil production has been dropping in recent years, and during the 1990's imports are expected to increase by about 50 percent from their current level of 8.5 million barrels a day. **********With the threat of war enveloping the Middle East, Government officials here have started touting Venezuela - four days by oil tanker from the United States - as a ''friendly, safe source.'' **********''Here in the region, we potentially have the oil to meet any crisis,'' Carlos Andres Perez, the nation's President, said in an interview in Caracas recently. ''The United States can trust, always depend on, Venezuela as a safe supplier.'' **********Working Around the Clock **********To meet the expected increased demand, geologists and laborers are working around the clock on a crash program to increase production in 15 months to 500,000 barrels a day, from 300,000 barrels today. **********During the next 10 years, the production program is expected to change the mix of oil drilled in Venezuela, the Western Hemisphere's largest oil exporter. **********Venezuela has historically produced low-value high-sulfur heavy crude from the nation's western region. Today, about 70 percent of Venezuela's oil comes from this region, largely from around Lake Maracaibo. **********But with new discoveries around here, 70 percent of Venezuela's proven reserves are now in the east, with light and medium crude oil predominating. **********''The future of Venezuela's oil industry is going to be in the east,'' Mr. Sporn predicted, surveying a landscape where oil rigs broke a baking-hot monotony of cattle ranches and cornfields. **********An Important Difference **********By 1995, Venezuela's production is expected to be evenly split between heavy crude and the higher-value light and medium crude oils. For a country that last year relied on oil exports for 76 percent of its income, the difference is important: in recent months, higher-quality oil has sold for as much as $8 a barrel more than lower-quality oil. **********A quirk of history is helping the Venezuelans to put the fields into production quickly. Thanks to a legacy of 70 years of oil production here, oil pipelines and tank farms are already in place. **********The old wells started to run dry in the late 1960's, leading to two decades of economic stagnation in this state, Monagas, and in the neighboring state of Anzoategui. But in the late 1980's, new technology allowed the Venezuelan companies operating here, Lagaven and Corpoven, to pierce the old well threshold of 5,000 feet and to reach depths of 20,000 feet. **********High-resolution seismic surveys, aerogravimetric surveys, steam injection and three-dimensional computer models were among the new technologies that allowed Venezuelans to map out new, deeper fields here in the late 1980's. **********Although deep drilling is more expensive, the payoff has been greater. On the average, the deep wells here produce 7,000 barrels a day. By contrast, the average well in Venezuela produces 120 barrels a day. **********Today, the main obstacle to rapidly increasing production is a worldwide shortage of drilling rigs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   On Patrol in the Desert, Marines Fight Boredom
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   On Patrol in the Desert, Marines Fight Boredom
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/world.body_text: **********The water, produced from a desalting plant, has a strong chlorine aftertaste. It is like drinking from a warm swimming pool. #17 Days in the Desert The marines of Bravo Company, part of the Third Light Armored Infantry Battalion from the huge Marine base at Twenty Nine Palms, Calif., have been living like this for 17 days. **********Equipped with night vision scopes and diesel-powered vehicles, they have become the new nomads of the desert, confronting some of the toughest conditions faced by the United States military in Saudi Arabia. Under Pentagon rules, their location cannot be disclosed. **********Their mission is to provide early warning of an Iraqi attack and to delay an Iraqi advance so that heavier Marine units behind them can muster a defense and prepare a counterattack. **********The vehicles are too lightly armored to withstand a blast from a tank or from the air, and would depend primarily on their speed to survive. The vehicles are equipped with 25-millimeter guns, and some have TOW anti-tank missiles. **********Fighting Boredom **********Under a glowing full moon, some commanders talk about their plans to keep up morale and fight boredom through constant exercises, including some at night. **********''We keep moving and training,'' said Lieut. Charles Protzmann, who is from Rhode Island. ''That is what keeps marines sharp. **********''The worst thing to have is any kind of boredom,'' he said. ''We try to keep them as busy as possible.'' **********But some marines say they are having a hard time adjusting. **********''There are a couple of guys who are really stressed,'' said Lance Cpl. Michael McCarthy, a 23-year-old gunner from Salt Lake City. **********Finding the Way Home **********''They get up in the morning and say, 'God, I wonder what they are going to do with me today.' Which direction are we going to go? Who are they going to put down inside for a trip to somewhere 30 miles from here and then pop him up and say, 'You got to get us back'? The vehicles that get lost get chewed out,'' he added, pointing to the flat terrain. **********The low roar of the engines and the squawk of the radios punctures the still desert night. In the last several weeks, the temperature has started to drop, and the marines, who faced the scorching heat by day, cover themselves when they sleep against the evening chill. **********The marines say that the light armored vehicles are holding up pretty well. But the marines say that they do not yet have some needed spare parts for the vehicles, and some in Bravo Company complained about the maps. **********Some said that the scale of the maps they carry is inadequate, adding that more finely detailed maps have been ordered but have yet to arrive. **********Back at a maintenace facility in a rear area, the marines are handing out supplies, like razors and shaving cream. Marines there also can get three free sodas a day, two free envelopes a day, five sheets of paper a day, and five cotton swabs. **********But Corporal McCarthy said his seven-man vehicle crew was sharing two razors and a bar of soap. **********''That's the difference between the rear area and the forward area,'' shrugged one battalion officer. **********For entertainment, one marine is reading a book on Arab-Israeli relations. **********A Letter From Home **********One reported pastime is catching snakes and scorpions, while another is to put two large desert beetles on a piece of food and watch them fight. Others live for the mail.  Sgt. Joe Cook, 23, said that he was worried about a young recruit in his crew. **********''He has only been in the Corps seven months and is homesick, and his girlfriend has not written him yet,'' Sergeant Cook said. **********''You can't keep a relationship like that going too well over here. She does not know when she'll see him again or what it means for him to be overseas. He'll be looking for that letter when the mail comes in tonight and if he does not find it, it'll be tough.'' **********Sgt. Kevin Bates, a 29-year-old native of Utah, married with an 18-month-old daughter, got his mail tonight. **********He stood watch from 2:30 to 4 this morning on top of the C Square, the company's command and control vehicle full of radio equipment, which some have nicknamed the Goat Herder. **********Reading his letters by the red glow of a Marine flashlight, designed so that the beams do not carry very far, Sergeant Bates opened a letter from his mother, postmarked Aug. 28. **********''Take good care of yourself and wear your gas mask,'' she writes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/busin.main_headline: Managing; Emulating the Best of the Best
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/busin.print_headline: Managing; Emulating the Best of the Best
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/busin.body_text: **********When the GTE Corporation wants to know whether it is doing a good job delivering telephone service, it compares itself to local Bell companies or to overseas telephone companies. When it wants to see if its telephone equipment matches the highest quality standards, it compares its methods and products against Sweden's L. M. Erickson and other highly regarded competitors. **********But a couple years ago, when it realized that its billing system was confusing customers, it went to the American Express Company, one of the country's most experienced billers, for guidance. By going outside its own industry, GTE wound up with a billing system so much better than the industry standard that several competitors have paid GTE to help them replicate it. **********"We may be doing as well as, or even better than, our competitors in various services, but that doesn't mean we can't create an even larger 'positive' gap between us and them," said D. Otis Wolkins, GTE's vice president of quality services and marketing administration. **********Benchmarking -- the formal name for identifying and emulating the companies that are best at a given activity -- has come a long way since the 1970's, when the term first started making the corporate rounds. **********Back then, benchmarking was confined mostly to manufacturing companies like the Ford Motor Company or the Xerox Corporation, both of which reclaimed market share by dissecting competitors' cars and copiers and applying what they learned to their own. **********BY the mid-80's, companies had realized that they could use benchmarking techniques and principles to model their customer service, accounting and other nonmanufacturing departments after the competitors who do it best. When data about the internal workings of competitors' operations proved difficult to get, consultants could generally be counted on to provide suitably disguised descriptions of best industry practices. **********Benchmarking has moved into Phase 3 now, in which companies are looking beyond their own industries. Executives -- particularly those in charge of quality -- are scouring trade magazines, calling consultants and professional associations for recommendations, browsing through electronic data bases, all in hopes of ferreting out    the    expert practitioner in any given function. **********"Our clients no longer ask, 'Who is the best in the industry' at doing something," said Michael E. Hora, vice president of A.T. Kearney Inc., a Chicago consulting firm. "Now they ask, 'Who is the best in the world?' " **********Companies that have gone outside their industry to pick up tips often can document terrific savings. A couple of years ago, Motorola Inc.'s finance department began applying electronic data-transfer and other techniques it picked up from the First National Bank of Chicago's check clearing operations to its own operations for closing its books each month. Result: It took Motorola 8,000 fewer person-hours to audit the 1989 books than it did to audit those of 1986, despite a sales increase of more than 50 percent. **********"Because we weren't dealing with a competitor, the information flow was free and easy," said William B. Smith Jr., vice president and senior quality assurance manager of Motorola's communications sector. **********INDEED, executives bent on benchmarking report that, as long as there are no proprietary secrets involved, companies are quite proud to show off their systems. **********L. L. Bean Inc., the catalog distribution company, has played host to myriad companies looking for tips on how to spruce up their distribution or warehousing operations. And when Bean decided it wanted to benchmark its succession planning and management development systems against companies with good human resources reputations, it visited Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, International Business Machines and Disney. A team of Bean managers recently returned from London, where they studied Marks & Spencer's inventory management systems. **********"We're happy to share our information on distribution, and we've found that companies are happy to share information on the areas they're best at," said Austin H. Farrar, Bean's vice president of human resources. **********The information flows particularly freely when companies benchmark against their own customers. When American Express wanted to learn about self-directed work teams, it went to the General Electric Company. It sought guidance from Motorola on training. "They're customers of ours and we're customers of theirs, and that makes it easier to exchange information," said James M. Li, chief quality and credit officer for American Express travel-related services.  THEN THERE'S SELF-CONTEMPLATION **********Before a company can compare itself to anyone else, it must take a long, hard look at its own operations. The Xerox Corporation has discovered that such self-scrutiny can be valuable in itself. **********One Xerox operation wanted to make its physical facilities more attractive to customers. Before looking at other companies' showrooms and reception areas, the benchmarking team checked out their own. **********To the team's horror, they discovered a junked car in the parking lot -- a car that had probably been giving a look of seediness to the place for some time. "No one had ever noticed it, because no one had ever really bothered to look," said John E. Kelsch, Xerox's director of quality. **********Another Xerox operation realized that its state-of-the-art computer system for processing customers' orders was hidden away in the back office. "They reorganized their office and put their computers where they could be spotted," Mr. Kelsch said. "They say customers seem very impressed."
