https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/11/busin.body_text: **********Time Warner Inc., the media, entertainment and publishing giant, is preparing to start a chain of some 100 entertainment stores in regional shopping centers on the order of the successful Disney Stores, retail and financial executives in New York said yesterday. **********Like the 50 Disney Stores, which sell merchandise using the famous Disney cartoon characters, the Time Warner stores are expected to sell toys, clothes, pictures and similar goods aimed at children with Bugs Bunny and other characters from the company's Looney Tunes cartoons. **********Retail sources said that Peter Starrett, who has been the president of the Lamston Plymouth stores owned by the Tribeca Company, New York, had been selected by Time Warner to head the new entertainment chain. **********Comment on the project could not be obtained from Time Warner's offices in Burbank, Calif. But an executive close to the project said, ''Time Warner isn't quite ready to announce it but plans to make a publicity splash sometime soon.'' **********Mr. Starrett is a former president of Children's Place, a juvenile-wear chain that was sold to Federated Department Stores and later divested by it. He is expected to report directly to the heads of Time Warner's movie production companies, Robert Daily and Terry Semple. He could not be reached for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   For Americans, a Dash Across Desert
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   For Americans, a Dash Across Desert
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/world.body_text: **********Frank J. Jiral, a Texas oil man, and five other Americans piled into two cars at 4 A.M. Wednesday and headed south out of Baghdad across the scorching desert, bound for the Iraqi-Jordanian border. **********''The airport was closed, and we didn't know when it would be open, so we decided to take a drive,'' Mr. Jiral said in a powerful understatement as he downed a frosty can of beer in a high-rise hotel here this afternoon. **********Mr. Jiral, who represents a Houston oilfield construction company, spent most of today on the telephone trying to arrange for transportation from the Jordanian border to here for a colleague in Iraq. He was unaware that with American troops landing in Saudi Arabia, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq was taking steps to prevent most other foreigners from leaving the country. **********With the air-conditioning turned up high and the color television flickering, Mr. Jiral said he had hardly noticed the 120-degree temperature in the deserts. **********''When you're from Texas,'' he said with a soft drawl, ''you don't notice a little heat.'' **********Hitching the Last 200 Miles **********Nearly running out of fuel a few miles short of the only gasoline station on the more than 600-mile-long ribbon of desolate highway, abandoning one of the cars because of blown-out tires and finally having to hitch a ride for the last 200 miles or so had been nothing much either, he said. **********The tall, graying Texan, who has worked in construction and oil field projects abroad for 25 years, said he never strongly considered himself in serious danger. **********But among the handful of Americans who made the dash across the desert on Wednesday, Mr. Jiral was the exception. United States officials estimate that 500 Americans have been stranded in Iraq, and 3,000 more in the tiny Persian Gulf state of Kuwait since last week, when the Iraqi Army invaded and took over Kuwait Precisely how many Americans made it out of Iraq is not clear. **********With telephone and telex lines cut since the invasion, increased signs of war preparations in Baghdad and shortwave radio news reports bringing updates of efforts by world powers to isolate President Hussein, ''it became clear that time was running out, that the window was closing,'' said John Norman, a banking consultant from Raleigh, N.C. He arrived here late Wednesday night, shortly after Mr. Jiral and his friends. **********Threat of Hostage-Taking **********''The concept of the potentiality of being a hostage was certainly there,'' said Pat Schenning of Alexandria, Va., another consultant who had been working with Mr. Norman to modernize Iraq's banking system. **********Mr. Schenning said he and three other banking consultants had planned to wait until Friday to see if the airport reopened, then make a run for it. **********The Americans and other foreigners had been grouped in several hotels according to nationality. At first some were told not to leave the hotels. But most were able to walk the streets as they liked. They say they were treated cordially, never threatened, never wanting for comfortable lodgings and food. Many relaxed in the hotel pools. **********But the group of consultants moved up their plans when they heard that American troops were on the way. **********Briefing From U.S. Diplomat **********Mr. Jiral listened to the senior American diplomat in Baghdad, Joseph Wilson, the charge d'affaires, as he told a group of Americans Tuesday night that Washington advised that they evacuate. But Mr. Jiral added that he could not say whether the borders were open and could not help with transportation. **********Mr. Wilson had been briefing the Americans daily, Mr. Jiral said, keeping them up to date on discussions with the Iraqi Government on how and when they might depart. Now, Mr. Jiral understood, the diplomat was saying he could offer no way out. **********''I gave it my best shot,'' Mr. Jiral and some other Americans quoted Mr. Wilson as saying in the briefing Tuesday night. **********That was it for Mr. Jiral. ''I said right then, I'm leaving tomorrow,'' the Texan said. **********Mr. Jiral and the other businessmen were traveling on visas that provided for automatic departure permission under normal times, and immigration officers at the border simply stamped their passports and waved them through. But Mr. Jiral said holders of resident visas were required to get specific permission to leave Iraq. **********No New Exit Visas **********No one was issuing exit visas this week in Iraq, and Mr. Jiral said many acquaintances were unwilling to take the long trip across the border only to be turned back. Others with visas like Mr. Jiral's, he said, decided that driving to the border was too risky. **********Frank Zurawel, a soft-drink machinery technician from Dix Hills, L.I., who was in Iraq repairing a broken 7-Up machine, said that at one point he was told by Government officials that he could not leave Baghdad because ''I wouldn't be able to get past the checkpoints.'' **********He finally threw in with Mr.Jiral, and they came across no checkpoints until they reached the border. **********''As a gentleman said to me, you cover as many bases as you can, and after that you tense your stomach and get on with it,'' Mr. Norman said. ''That's basicaly the conclusion we reached. We had to do something now.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/12/busin.main_headline: Businessland Planning To Reduce Its Staff
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/12/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Businessland Planning To Reduce Its Staff
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/12/busin.body_text: **********Businessland Inc., a leading computer retailer, said today that it would lay off from 5 percent to 7 percent of its worldwide work force of 3,900. **********The company said the reduction would result in a one-time charge of $1 million to $2 million. **********Businessland said the employee cuts were a result of economies of scale realized through two recent acquisitions and efficiencies achieved through a multimillion-dollar investment in internal computers to automate its operations. **********The company said it expects the cuts to result in savings of more than $12 million a year. **********Businessland shares closed today at $7.125, down 62.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********''The moves we are making are in keeping with the realities of the market and the long-term strategic priorities of Businessland,'' said David A. Norman, the company's chairman, president and chief executive. ''They will not impact the level and quality of technical support and service.'' **********Despite the general slowdown in personal computer sales, Mr. Norman said, Businessland's sales growth remains strong with estimated revenues in excess of $370 million in the quarter ended Dec. 31. That compared with $301 million in the period a year earlier. He said that operating margins continue to be under pressure but that the company was profitable before extraordinary expenses or write-offs resulting from the restructuring. Businessland will report second-quarter results on Jan. 24. **********Shortly after Businessland lost the franchise for the Compaq Computer Corporation last April, Mr. Norman predicted that the company would more than make up for those lost revenues in becoming the sole distributor of the new work station from Next Inc. Today he said this had not been the case. **********''The loss of Compaq had a greater impact on our revenues and margins than we expected,'' Mr. Norman said. Because of delays in shipping the final version of the Next operating system software, ''there was no way Next could make up the large revenue loss that Businessland experienced,'' he said. While he declined to specify how many Next machines Businessland had sold, he said that it sold a number ''in the hundreds'' in the last quarter and that he expects it to pick up in 1990.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve Board said today that it had approved limited securities underwriting and dealing by three foreign banking companies that operate subsidiaries in the United States. **********The three are the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, the Royal Bank of Canada and Barclays P.L.C. of London. **********A spokesman for the Fed said the banks would be subject to the same conditions imposed on a small number of large United States banks that received regulatory approval to expand into the securities business last year. **********The central bank said approval had been given to Canadian Imperial and Royal Bank to underwrite and deal in debt and equity securities and to Barclays to underwrite and deal in debt securities through subsidiaries. **********But it said the banks could not proceed until the Fed reviewed structural safeguards intended to protect the safety and soundness of the banks. **********A few United States banks were granted similar powers last January, but the Fed also delayed the start of their activities to review the adequacy of their safeguards. **********In a separate announcement, the Fed said it had approved the First Union Corporation's application to engage in the private placement of all types of securities through a subsidiary, First Union Securities Inc. **********Private placement of securities does not come under the legal definition of underwriting and dealing in securities, which is restricted for banks under the Glass-Steagall Act.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/world.print_headline: IRAQ SEEKS PEACE WITH IRAN, TURNING BACK SPOILS OF WAR IN MOVE TO END ITS ISOLATION;   Teheran is Pleased
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/world.body_text: **********Iraq took a dramatic step today to counter its growing international isolation over the invasion of Kuwait, offering to meet almost all of Iran's conditions for settling key issues persisting from their eight-year war. **********President Saddam Hussein's apparent decision to give up his longstanding goals against Iran seemed intended to free military units deployed along the Iranian border for use if a conflict develops with forces in Saudi Arabia. **********The decision may also reflect a calculated hope by Baghdad that Iran, in return for the concessions, might help Iraq evade international economic sanctions. **********A Hint of Approval **********Iran immediately implied that it would be amenable to Iraq's offer of peace, saying that it would be reviewed ''with optimism.'' **********But Iran, which initially condemned the invasion of Kuwait and later expressed concern at the decision of the United States and other Western powers to send troops to the region, has not indicated whether it will help Iraq in its economic plight. **********The initiative by the Iraqi President, made in a letter to President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran, represented one of the most significant moves since Washington's decision to throw its full weight behind an effort to protect Saudi Arabia and to compel Iraq to pull out of Kuwait. **********'Fishing in Muddy Waters' **********The Iraqi leader's letter held out a possibility of a ''new life in which cooperation prevails under the shadow of Islamic principles and that each of us respects the rights of the other and keeps away those fishing in muddy waters on our shores.'' **********It came as the two sides were nearing the 10th anniversary of the outbreak of the war, on Sept. 19, when Iraq invaded Iran, which was then holding American hostages and was in the throes of the Islamic revolution that toppled the Shah in 1979. **********Ostensibly, Iraq invaded because of a dispute over Shatt al Arab, the strategic border waterway at the head of the Persian Gulf used by both countries. **********President Hussein is bound to be faced by questions from his military about why Baghdad waged such a high-cost war with Iran, only to offer to return to the pre-war borders with Iran, something that Mr. Hussein had repeatedly said he would never accept. **********There are estimates that more than a million people died in the war, in which a cease-fire was declared in 1988, with heavy casualties, air and missile attacks, human-wave assaults by Iran and the use of poison gas by Iraq. Millions of people were wounded or driven from their homes. **********Iranian officials said secret and direct talks were held between the two nations over the last few weeks. **********They added that they viewed the Iraqi concessions as a direct result of the economic and military pressures on Baghdad after the invasion of Kuwait, including trade sanctions decreed by the United Nations Security Council, naval interdictions by American and other warships and a buildup of an multi-national force in Saudi Arabia. **********The Iraqi leader's conciliatory gesture to Teheran was announced over Iraqi radio and television. It promised the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from about 700 square miles of Iranian territory. It also called for the exchange of nearly 100,000 prisoners of war and an equal division of the Shatt al Arab estuary. **********Iraq Canceled Waterway Pact **********When the war broke out in 1980, Mr. Hussein canceled a 1975 agreement between the two countries to divide the waterway, which is Iraq's only outlet to the Persian Gulf. **********Since then, Iraq had insisted that it would ''never'' allow Iran sovereignty over any part of the waterway. Iraq also insisted that it would not allow an exchange of prisoners nor pull back from Iranian territory until Iran had conceded this point. **********The Iraqi leader said today that his troops would begin to withdraw from Iran on Friday and might start releasing prisoners of war even before reciprocal action by Iran. **********Iranian officials said the first high-level contact between the two countries started in April with a letter from President Hussein to President Rafsanjani. It was followed by several unannounced meetings and one public meeting between foreign ministers in Geneva in July. **********Shortly after that, Iran and Iraq cooperated in pressing other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise oil prices, just before the invasion of Kuwait. **********These events seemed to confirm suggestions by many Persian Gulf experts that the two countries have many common interests in areas like oil policy and opposition to the United States military presence in the gulf area. **********It was not clear whether Iran would be willing to take the kind of actions that could alleviate the growing international pressure on Iraq. Given the long border between Iran and Iraq, the worldwide embargo against Iraq could be thwarted if Teheran allowed its territory to become a transit route for Iraqi imports. **********The announcement by Iraq underlined Baghdad's eagerness to ease the pressure on its frontier with Iran so it could concentrate strength in response to the military buildup in Saudi Arabia. **********In announcing his offer today, President Hussein noted the Islamic heritage of both nations, even though his secular Baathist Government has harshly repressed the Islamic fundamentalist movement, Al Dawa al-Islamiya, which was allied with Iran, and executed scores of the movement's leaders. **********'Dear Brother' **********In his letter to President Rafsanjani, the Iraqi leader referred to the Iranian as ''Dear Brother.'' The letter said, in part: ''Everything has become clear and everthing you wanted and concentrated upon has been realized.'' **********The tone was a sharp change in Baghdad's attitude toward the Iranian Government. Over the last decade, the Iraqi press and broadcasting have repeatedly described the Iranian leaders, including Mr. Rafsanjani, as ''princes of darkness,'' ''Persian inferiors'' and ''imposters.'' **********In his message, President Hussein said he was looking forward to a peace treaty between the countries ''from an honorable position toward a new life in which cooperation prevails under the shadow of Islamic principles.'' **********In a move related to the gulf crisis, foreign embassies in Kuwait were ordered today to move to Baghdad. All Kuwaitis who served in the diplomatic service and their families have been taken to Baghdad and jailed. **********Many of the newest refugees from Kuwait in Saudi Arabia say the situation in Kuwait is deteriorating and that food is scarce. Nine Britons who arrived in Bahrain last night said that shooting was heard every night as Kuwaitis continued to wage hit-and-run raids on Iraqi positions. **********One of Syria's three vice presidents was reported today to be on his way to Teheran for consultations with the Iranian leadership. Syria, long a rival of Iraq, will probably try to persuade Teheran not to ease its pressure on Iraq. **********In the Iranian capital, Morteza Sarmadi, spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, seemed pleased with the Iraqi offer to settle all remaining disputes, stressing that it represented significant concessions to Iran. **********Iran Hails Iraqi Offer **********TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 15 (Reuters) - Iran hailed Iraq's acceptance of its terms for peace as the biggest victory since the 1979 Islamic revolution. **********It predicted a new era of ''lasting and just peace'' with Iraq after President Hussein announced that he was ready to accept a 1975 border treaty that he had renounced in 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/busin.main_headline: Earthly Risks of Business in Space
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/busin.print_headline: Earthly Risks of Business in Space
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/busin.body_text: **********When the founders of Space Services Inc. built a rocket and named it the Conestoga, they had in mind an image of dogged determination in the face of daunting risk. They never intended their pioneering enterprise to be facing that risk in the financial desert just short of the next watering hole. **********But after spending 10 years and some $19 million seeking a profitable niche launching small satellites high into space for government and commercial customers, Space Services does seem to be swooping very low, or, indeed, about to crash. **********The story of the company's dramatic attempts to survive contain a number of important lessons for commercializing and exploring space in the decades to come. **********Space Services' major corporate investor has abandoned the venture. Its main individual investor has exhausted his resources. The company has almost no tangible assets, and its 26 employees have all been furloughed. New investors are needed, and quickly, but the search for them is not going well. **********Ironically, the company's crisis comes at the very moment when a strong market for launching small satellites is beginning to emerge. Analysts say a billion-dollar business has finally begun to coalesce and small satellites are, or will soon be, providing key data in a variety of fields - like television, cellular-phone communication, scientific research and to navigation for ships, planes or even trucks and taxis. **********The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Air Force both have competitions under way to purchase launching services from commercial enterprises for satellites weighing less than half a ton. And analysts say the market for small satellite launchings by private companies is about to blossom. **********For Space Services, the new business is arriving in the nick of abort-launch time, if not too late. Space Services recently delivered NASA nearly 500 pounds of documents detailing its bid to provide between 7 and 10 launchings on the Conestoga rocket, starting in 1992. This contract will be worth perhaps $100 million to the winning company. But on Friday, Space Services was unable to meet a contract deadline for the Air Force. **********Some of the Space Services employees are still coming to work, though without pay, to prepare a bid for yet another NASA contract. **********''It is day to day, hour to hour,'' said Donald K. (Deke) Slayton, the somewhat grizzled former astronaut who runs Space Services, from its modest headquarters suite on the outskirts of Houston. **********Before the 1980's, NASA handled all American satellite launchings, with rockets built for it by outside contractors. The satellite's owner, whether it was the Pentagon or a commercial concern, would pay NASA for the launching service. **********But the space agency gradually relinquished that role; private launching companies became even more important after the Space Shuttle Challenger exploded in 1986. **********There have been nine successful launchings handled by private American companies under license, and a total of 35 scheduled, including one by Space Services and several by Orbital Sciences, its main competitor in small-rocket launchings. **********The lion's share of the private launchings are handled by three makers of large rockets for heavy satellites: the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the General Dynamics Corporation and the Martin Marietta Corporation. But it was the tiny, unknown Space Services that established a number of crucial precedents for the industry. **********In 1982, Space Services became the first company to launch a satellite spending nothing but private funds; the payload was a test dummy, but it went into orbit. In 1985, Space Services was the first company to obtain a United States Government license to provide commercial launch services. In 1989, it was the first to conduct a licensed launch under contract, with two scientific payloads on suborbital flights. **********''Unfortunately, there is a saying in the venture-capital industry that pioneers end up with arrows in their backs,'' said David O. Wicks Jr., a Houston investor who is not involved in the company but specializes in the space industry. **********Ten years ago a handful of investors, led by a soft-spoken real estate developer named David Hanna, bet that a small enterprise could find a place in carrying small satellites into space. Mr. Hanna and his associates put a modest fortune, now totaling $12 million, into a company they called Space Services Inc. Mr. Hanna, the biggest investor, is chairman. Outer space was a new frontier, he believed, but big business and big government would only succeed in messing things up there. **********The Federal government appeared to endorse Mr. Hanna's philosophy, setting forth policies supporting it - like the decision, made after the Challenger explosion, that no more commercial satellites would be launched from NASA's shuttles. Nonetheless, business was slow to develop. **********Then the company got a new infusion of cash from Development Ventures Inc. of Houston. Since 1986, DVI has invested about $7 million, and it now owns 7 percent of the shares outright and owns warrants for another 75 percent, giving it effective control of the company. **********But Space Services never made a profit, and DVI has decided against any further investment. **********''We just reached the limits of how much we could invest in this kind of company,'' said Dan Bulla of Houston Industries. ''We still think there is a market there. We sincerely hope they can make it.'' **********Executives of Space Services are bitter about DVI's decision. They compare the venture capital group to a gambler who plays a slot machine only to leave the casino while the wheels are spill spinning. **********Space Services, they point out, spent about $1 million preparing its bid for the NASA contract that is now about to be awarded - a project that is expected to be worth perhaps 100 times that million in revenues to the winner. It will be impossible for Space Services to win that contract unless it can prove itself financially sound, which means finding a new investor. But that search is not easy. ''The typical venture capitalists are looking at their own formula,'' said Mr. Slayton. ''They are looking for fast paybacks and high multiples. And so far, there is nothing in space showing them that. Everything in space requires patient money.'' **********A Commerce Department study of five other companies seeking to become established in commercial space ventures found that all have faced the same financial obstacle - finding a strategic investor with enough money and patience - with varying degrees of success. **********The investment limits of venture capitalists are usually modest compared with the immense capital needs that typify the aerospace industry, the study found. They ''like to see the opportunity in a business plan to make five times their investment in three to five years,'' the study concluded. ''These are severe challenges for space-related projects.'' **********Both Mr. Hanna and Mr. Slayton, who has not invested in the company, say they want a new investor to buy out DVI's share in the company, but they have been unable to determine from DVI how much it would ask. **********There have been hard times before. The company's first attempted launching, in 1981, was a total failure. Mr. Slayton, who at the time was still working at NASA, says it was ''strictly a hobby shop type of thing.'' Their big mistake was using liquid fuel instead of more reliable solid rocket fuel. ''They blew the damn thing up,'' Mr. Slayton said. **********Undaunted, the company hired Mr. Slayton when he retired from NASA to try a second launch. Built from off-the-shelf parts supplied by Morton Thiokol and other aerospace companies, the first Conestoga rocket was launched successfully in 1982 from Matagorda Island in the Gulf of Mexico. **********The company had proved several things. It could raise enough private money to pay for a launch. It could manage a team of subcontractors. It could, eventually, obtain needed government approval - no minor accomplishment. **********The company did have its struggles with the Federal bureaucracy, but the difficulties eventually accomplished something else very important. **********According to people in the Government and the aerospace industry, Space Services demonstrated that the cumbersome process of getting approvals for launchings was standing in the way of an entire industry's development. As a result, the Government has now set up a much simpler licensing process at the new space office of the Department of Transportation. **********What Space Services had not yet demonstrated was that anybody wanted its services. There were fitful efforts to win contracts for launching earth-sensing satellites, navigation and so forth. There was one esoteric agreement in which the company would shoot cremated remains into orbit for funeral homes. **********Finally, last year, the company won a substantial, if modest commercial contract for a university consortium. Scientists successfully conducted more than 140 brief experiments in the weightlessness of the brief gravity-free flight. The contract was completed ahead of schedule within budget for a fixed price. **********A second launch for the consortium, operated by the University of Alabama, failed, however, when a gyroscope malfunctioned in flight. The payload was ejected in flight and parachuted safely back to earth. Space Services relaunched that payload successfully in May and plans to conduct a fourth launch. **********More than 30 other companies, universities or other institutions have now entered the field. Each has its technical strengths and weaknesses, and each must operate within its own peculiar financial straits. Whether they succeed remains a question. **********But if they do, it will be Space Services that blazed their trail, as surely as the wagon trains left wheel ruts for others to follow a century and a half ago. **********THE SMALL-SATELLITE MARKET **********Electronics companies find that more and more power can be put into small 1,000-pound satellites. As a result, 36 corporations, universities and other organizations are now working on small-satellite projects. **********Peter J. Armitage, a vice president of Space Services, says a market of between 30 and 60 orbital launches exists for small payloads over the next five years, and as many as 100 suborbital launches per year. **********Richard Scott, Washington representative of Motorola, said: ''You add all those up and you wind up with $1 billion of business that was not here a year ago.'' Motorola plans to shoot up a constellation of 77 satellites for worldwide cellular telephone communications by the mid-90's. **********Among the competitors is the Orbital Sciences Corporation. It has demonstrated a winged missile, called Pegasus, which is carried under the belly of an airplane before blasting off into orbit. **********Another competitor is the American Rocket Company. It suffered a disastrous accident on its first attempt to launch a hybrid rocket that combined both liquid and solid fuels, but the company is still in the field. Others are the LTV Aerospace Corporation, which plans to modify its Scout rocket by adding boosters derived from the European Ariane program, and the Lockheed Corporation, which may convert the Poseidon submarine-launched ballistic missiles as they are retired by the Navy under an arms control treaty.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene;   Unusual View On Interest Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene;   Unusual View On Interest Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.body_text: **********THE good news, say Robert J. Barro of Harvard University and Xavier Sala i Martin of Yale University, is that high interest rates are not bad for the economy. The even better news, say the two economists, is that the size of the Federal deficit doesn't matter. **********Two surprising conclusions. According to conventional wisdom, high rates limit growth, slow investment, put a brake on economic activity and can lead to a recession. Today's high rates have already led to protests by home builders, who have seen sales fall, and to rumors of a rift between the Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve over interest-rate policy. **********The conventional wisdom also says that when the Federal Government borrows to finance the deficit or bail out savings and loan institutions, it competes for scarce capital in the domestic markets and drives rates up. **********But if Professors Barro and Sala i Martin are right, the conventional wisdom is wrong. **********Professors Barro and Sala i Martin have constructed an ingenious model that uses economic and financial data from the 10 major industrialized countries going back as far as 1952. The model simulates the effect of business activity on interest rates, adjusted for inflation, through a series of elaborate equations. The two economists constructed a world index of interest rates for the 10 countries they studied. With their model, they say they can forecast future real interest rates, which are defined as nominal rates less inflation. **********The first conclusion from their continuing research, presented as a working paper, is that ''high real rates of interest reflect increased rather than diminished business opportunities,'' Professor Barro said. The conventional wisdom is that high rates slow business activity by making it more expensive to invest. **********Their second finding is that American rates are strongly influenced by business conditions in the other countries surveyed and not just by domestic factors like the savings rate and Government borrowing. Interest rates in the United States seem especially sensitive to what is going on in the world's stock markets. **********As the two scholars see things, the chain of logic runs as follows: good business conditions lead to higher stock market prices as investors looking for profit opportunities eagerly bid up stocks. And those higher prices suck in money from the rest of the economy. Interest rates go up as the demand for funds increases. **********And the process goes on beyond national borders. Opportunities in one country influence rates in the next. ''Rising stock markets abroad mean rising interest rates in the United States,'' Professor Barro said. ''We were quite excited when we found this out.'' The two economists forecast an average interest rate of 5.5 percent, adjusted for inflation, in most of the industrialized world this year, falling to 4.7 percent by mid-decade as growth slows. **********While Professors Barro and Sala i Martin generally see rising rates as a vigorous competition for investment funds and thus a sign of health, they concede that at some point high interest rates can choke off investment and lead to a recession. But that happens, Professor Barro said, ''when interest rates go up as a result of tight monetary policy.'' During the 1982 recession, for example, rates climbed ''because the Fed kept money tight.'' **********The two professors put little faith in low interest rates as a spur to growth. They say this should be clear from looking at recent events. In the 1970's, interest rates were very low because they were reflective of sluggish economic activity, a low stock market and little investment opportunity, they say. When rates picked up, later in the decade, it was because business activity also picked up. **********What these findings mean for policy makers is that it would be a mistake to conclude that rising rates are bad for growth. **********''Today's average real interest rate for the 10 countries we studied is the highest we have seen since the 1920's,'' Professor Barro said. But these high rates have been accompanied by a ''significant rise in investment in the 10 countries we studied, to levels not seen since the late 1960's. That's very bullish for growth.'' **********The model has been criticized because it is still only a preliminary effort and because it ''overstates how much economists really know about what moves interest rates,'' said Robert E. Lucas Jr., a professor of economics at the University of Chicago. ''Everyone knows that sometimes the stock and bond markets move in the same direction and that there appears to be a link,'' he said. ''But sometimes they don't.'' Professor Barro concedes that his efforts are still preliminary, but contends that the model has advanced economists' understanding of what moves rates. ''I'm going out on a limb, but I think we have found predictors of future rates,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/24/busin.main_headline: Profits Fall at Salomon And at Morgan Stanley
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/24/busin.print_headline: EARNINGS; Profits Fall at Salomon And at Morgan Stanley
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/24/busin.body_text: **********Third-quarter earnings fell at Salomon Inc. and at the Morgan Stanley Group. The earnings at Salomon were aided by strong results from its oil trading operations, but its net was hurt by a one-time charge. At Morgan Stanley, a volatile trading environment helped offset a decline in investment banking and underwriting activity. **********Alex. Brown Inc., the holding company for the Baltimore brokerage firm Alex. Brown & Sons Inc., reported a loss for the quarter, in part because of losses on securities in its inventory, including a $2 million loss on shares in a company that it had underwritten. **********In more detail, the company reports follow. Salomon Inc. **********Salomon Inc. reported a 55.4 percent drop in net earnings, to $79 million, or 55 cents a share, compared with $177 million, or $1.28 a share, a year earlier. Revenues fell 1.9 percent, to $2.57 billion from $2.62 billion. **********This year's net includes a one-time pretax charge of $200 million for a restructuring of the company's Philipp Brothers commodities unit. Excluding this charge, Salomon earnings would have risen to $201 million, or $1.62 a share. **********Salomon's earnings were aided by what the company termed an "exceptional" third-quarter performance in its oil trading and refining business. Pretax earnings in this division were $369 million, up from $56 million in the 1989 third quarter. **********"Their oil business was operating on all eight cylinders," said Dean Eberling, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers. "What was most important for them was the volatility of the oil markets and the rapid rise in oil prices, especially in August." **********During this period, oil prices rose to a high of $40 a barrel, before falling to the current level of $28 a barrel. As a result of the sharp decline in oil prices over the last several days, analysts anticipate that the fourth-quarter earnings from this activity will not equal the strong third-quarter showing. **********Earnings in the company's securities segment, hurt by a fall-off in investment banking revenues and by reduced securities trading, were lower than they were in either the 1989 third quarter or the first two quarters of 1990. Pretax earnings from securities operations were $56 million, down from $231 million in the 1989 third quarter, $218 million in the 1990 first quarter and $211 million in the 1990 second quarter.  Morgan Stanley **********Market volatility -- this time in securities trading -- helped offset a slowdown in merchant banking and securities underwriting at Morgan Stanley. The company reported a 28.9 percent slide in net income, to $71.9 million, or $1.82 a share, from $101.1 million, or $2.54 a share, in the third quarter of 1989. Revenues rose 1 percent, to $588 million from $582.4 million. **********The company reported increased trading revenues, to $245 million, from $188 million in the 1989 third quarter. High volatility in the bond, equity and foreign currency markets enabled the firm the make trading profits. **********"Their trading results were quite impressive, especially in fixed income and non-U.S.-dollar securities," said James Hanbury, an analyst with Wertheim Schroder & Company. "But they've been affected by a slowdown in merchant banking and investment banking activities, and their trading business was good enough to offset some of that, but not all of it." **********Investment banking revenues slipped to $176 million, from $192 million for the 1989 third quarter. **********"Morgan Stanley's performance in the third quarter reflects an absence of merchant banking investment revenues as well as a decline in investment banking activity," the company said in a prepared statement. "Revenues from global sales and trading of fixed income products were significantly higher, while our financial results also benefited from strong performances in foreign exchange, commodities and equity trading." Alex. Brown **********Alex. Brown reported a loss of $3.1 million in the third quarter, in contrast to earnings of $6.3 million, or 38 cents a share, in the 1989 third quarter. Revenues fell 27.1 percent, to $58 million from $79.6 million. **********Donald B. Hebb Jr., the firm's president, said there had been a slowdown in the pace of the securities business because of "concerns about war in the Middle East and a recession at home." **********The firm was particularly hurt by several losses in securities held in inventory. Among these was a $2 million loss from its holding of shares in In-Store Advertising Inc., a company that Alex. Brown & Sons had previously underwritten. The firm specializes in initial public offerings for smaller companies -- a market segment that has been particularly hurt by the recent drop in share prices.
