Burger King Executive Is Named Del Taco Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/02/busin.print_headline:
Business People;

Burger King Executive Is Named Del Taco Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/02/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Kevin K. Moriarty, who started in the restaurant business at Moriarty's Cafe, his family's restaurant in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, has been named president and chief executive of Del Taco Inc., a Mexican fast-food chain based in Costa Mesa, Calif. **********Kevin K. Moriarty, who started in the restaurant business at Moriarty's Cafe, his family's restaurant in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, has been named president and chief executive of Del Taco Inc., a Mexican fast-food chain based in Costa Mesa, Calif. **********Mr. Moriarty, 42, spent 16 years as a manager and executive with Burger King. He now joins a Southern California-based company that is the nation's second-largest Mexican food chain behind Taco Bell. Del Taco operates 339 Del Taco and Naugles restaurants in Arizona, California, Illinois, Missouri, Nevada and Utah. Three-fourths of them are company owned. **********The privately held company, with annual sales of more than $200 million, was formed in 1988 by the merger of Del Taco and Naugles, another chain that was previously owned by Collins Foods International. In January, Del Taco Inc. was bought by an investor group that included the company's management and the G.E. Capital Corporation. The company said it was profitable. Mr. Moriarty replaces Wayne W. Armstrong, who resigned to ''pursue other interests'' less than seven months after leading the buyout, the company said. **********''We expect to have a lot of fun and challenge No. 1,'' Mr. Moriarty said yesterday, his first day on the job. ''The Mexican segment is very exciting, and it's still growing.'' **********Mr. Moriarty was 18 when he went to work at Moriarty's Cafe. Years later, Mr. Moriarty took a job as a Burger King restaurant manager to learn the fast-food business. **********He wound up staying on, rising to the position of vice president for the Chicago region, then executive vice president and general manager of two divisions of Burger King USA. **********Mr. Moriarty has a two-year business and marketing degree from Suffolk Community College in Selden, L.I. He flies single-engine planes and hopes to start giving more time to boating and fishing as hobbies. **********He and his wife, Pat, and two sons, Brian and Sean, will move from Chicago to Orange County, Calif.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/busin.main_headline: Wall Street;   The Camden Zero-Coupon Quandary
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/busin.print_headline: Wall Street;   The Camden Zero-Coupon Quandary
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/busin.body_text: **********Underwriters and lawyers agree that the Camden County Municipal Utility Authority bond issue now being marketed to investors across the country is one of the most unusual refinancing deals the tax-exempt market has seen in years. **********But they agree on little else about the New Jersey county's offering, which is being sold at a time when the interest-rate climate has made refinancing issues of any sort relatively rare . Is the Camden issue, as its defenders say, an ingenious innovation that can help hard-pressed communities ease their debt-service costs? Or is it, as some critics charge, a deal that creeps so close to the edge of Federal tax rules that it will bring a backlash of new regulations from Washington? **********The legal debate comes down to this: How much interest income is the Camden authority permitted to earn on the revenues that it will free up as a result of having refinanced its pre-existing debt? **********Just as homeowners may take advantage of lower interest rates to refinance their mortgages and cut their monthly payments, the authority is trying to reduce its debt service costs by selling $115.8 million in new bonds, called the 1990A Series, and setting the money aside to pay debt service on older, more expensive bonds sold in 1987. (In addition, it has raised $121.7 million in 1990B Series bonds to replace some short-term notes, a straightforward transaction of little interest to bond lawyers.) There is no dispute over how much interest the authority can earn on the money it is setting aside to service its earlier debt. Washington has stringent rules to prevent municipalities from reaping arbitrage profits by raising money at low tax-exempt rates and investing it at higher rates. Under these anti-arbitrage rules, an agency that sells 7 percent municipal bonds today cannot earn more than 7 percent interest on those escrowed funds. Doing otherwise could endanger the bonds' tax-exempt status. **********But in the Camden issue, designed by investment bankers at Butcher & Singer in Philadelphia and First Fidelity Bank in Newark the authority has sold zero-coupon bonds that require no debt service at all until 1998. (Zero-coupon bonds pay no annual interest, but are sold at prices substantially below their face value, so that the investor profits from the difference between the purchase price and the final maturity value.) As required, the authority will invest the 1990A Series proceeds in an escrow account - let's call it Account A - with a yield matching that on the newly sold bonds. It will use that fund to pay the debt service on the old 1987 bonds for the next seven years. **********But - and this is the ''but'' that worries some lawyers - the authority also plans to deposit all the general sewer-system revenues it otherwise would have spent to pay debt service on the 1987 bonds into a new investment fund - call it Account B. And the money in Account B is invested at a yield higher than that on the 1990A bonds. **********Come 1997, the first date on which the old 1987 bonds can be redeemed, the authority has the option of using Account B to pay off those bonds or to build part of its still-incomplete sewer system. Is the arrangement a good one? George Tuttle, the First Fidelity investment banker who worked with Butcher & Singer on the deal, defends it as ''an efficient structure that saves the authority $9 million. The way you handle the tax issues is to make sure you have the highest quality legal advice, and that's what we did.'' **********But the normally polite bond counsel community, the lawyers who review municipal bonds to insure that they qualify as tax-exempt investments, is deeply divided on the question. ''We have put in enough controls to satisfy us and, I think, to satisfy others,'' said Matthew Lewin, a partner at Chapman & Cutler, in Chicago, which has reviewed and approved the Camden structure. ''But, yes, there are a significant number who would not share our opinion.'' **********Underwriters at a few large Wall Street firms report privately that their own bond lawyers have doubts about the approach, , which Mr. Lewin attributed to their unfamiliarity with the specifics of the deal. **********The complex refinancing approach and the exclusive reliance on zero-coupon bonds make the Camden issue ''the kind of deal that investment bankers will put into their files for future reference,'' said Kurt van Kuller, a managing director of Lebenthal & Company in New York. But his own impressions? ''Well, frankly,'' he said, ''it seems very squirrely to me.'' **********In his view, the authority's Account B bears a strong resemblance to invested sinking funds, a once-popular bond financing technique that fell into disuse when the Federal rules against excess arbitrage were strengthened in 1978. **********''The lawyer says that this does not have the 'excess arbitrage' features of invested sinking funds,'' said Mr. van Kuller. ''But if I were a large institutional investor, I'd have a legal staff on retainer working with me to check into these issues. . . . and that's expensive.'' **********But the real cost of this financial innovation goes far beyond legal fees, warned Sam Katz, the co-chief executive at Public Financial Management in Philadelphia, a large public finance advisory firm. ''We're entering a period when the Congress and the Internal Revenue Service seem inclined to correct some of the public finance problems caused by their past overzealousness,'' Mr. Katz said. ''When people push the envelope to the very limit, it portrays our industry as one that is unprepared to live within the rules.'' And that, he said, ultimately could saddle all public borrowers with new rules that would make it more cumbersome and expensive for everyone to finance essential public projects. **********Despite these worries, the Camden deal has come to market at a time when zero-coupon bonds are both extremely scarce and increasingly popular among people planning for retirement, say, or college tuition bills. **********But Mr. van Kuller said he would not be surprised if, given the questions surrounding the structure, the price on the bonds dropped a bit to produce a higher yield for buyers. ''The market doesn't always solve these problems,'' he said. ''But it always adjusts to them.'' **********DESPITE CORPORATE PROGRESS, A STOCK STILL SLEEPS **********The stock market, jittery about the ''junk bond'' market and all the companies that borrow there, paid little attention last week when the Kroger Company announced that it had ended 1989 with less debt and lower interest rates. Kroger's stock closed the week up just a few cents, at $13.50. **********At that price, the stock looks like a bargain to some analysts. Charles E. Cerankosky of Prescott Ball & Turben in Cleveland notes that the company's improved financial prospects are already reflected in the prices of its junk bonds. ''Obviously the bond market sees an excellent investment here,'' he said. **********Edward Comeau, a food industry analyst at Oppenheimer & Company, said the stock's problem is probably rooted in the market's current intolerance for debt. Given that mood, and tighter food industry margins this year, he is not recommending the shares right now. But, he said, patient investors could find that the shares have ''good upside potential.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/03/world.main_headline: The Iraqi Invasion;   INVADING IRAQIS SEIZE KUWAIT AND ITS OIL; U.S. CONDEMNS ATTACK, URGES UNITED ACTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/03/world.print_headline: The Iraqi Invasion;   INVADING IRAQIS SEIZE KUWAIT AND ITS OIL; U.S. CONDEMNS ATTACK, URGES UNITED ACTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/03/world.body_text: **********Iraqi troops stormed into the desert sheikdom of Kuwait today, seizing control of its capital city and its rich oilfields, driving its ruler into exile, plunging the strategic Persian Gulf region into crisis and sending tremors of anxiety around the world. **********President Bush condemned the invasion as ''naked aggression'' and sought to enlist world leaders in collective action against Iraq. **********Faced with a dire threat from the truculent Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, to a region containing much of the world's oil reserves and with world financial markets in turmoil, Mr. Bush banned nearly all imports from Iraq and froze the nation's assets in the United States. At a news conference in Woody Creek, Colo., the President and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain raised the possibility of economic or even military action by the United Nations. **********Iraq Suspends Payments **********In response, Iraq, which had been accusing Kuwait for weeks of stealing its oil and violating production limits set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, suspended debt payments to the United States. Western experts asserted that Iraq had been motivated by a financial squeeze that only more oil dollars could ease and by ambitions for regional dominance. **********Although oil prices rose sharply today, analysts noted that world inventories are unusually high, and they saw no immediate threat to supplies. **********Witnesses in Kuwait said that hundreds of people were killed or wounded today as Iraqi ground forces, led by columns of tanks, surged into the desert emirate at the head of the gulf. Other troops came by air. **********For Mr. Bush, the invasion posed manifold problems: the difficulty of direct military action despite the huge commitment of money and resources to the gulf in recent years; fear of another surge in oil prices, which could hurt economic growth and rekindle inflation; the potential disruption of the fragile budget negotiations between the White House and the Congress, in which a gasoline tax has been considered, and possible damage to the Republican Party in elections this fall. **********Reuters reported that the Kuwaiti forces continued to resist tonight in at least one area of the capital, at the main military barracks. Earlier reports spoke of explosions and gunfire echoing around the steel-and-glass skyscrapers of the city center in fierce fighting at dawn. But the Iraqi Army, the most powerful in the Arab world, vastly outnumbered the Kuwaiti forces, and 12 hours after the invasion began the Iraqis were reported in control of the airport, central bank and all key government buildings. **********The State Department reported that Iraqi troops had taken six American oilfield workers into custody near the Kuwait-Iraq border. Officials said their whereabouts were unknown. **********The President said he could not confirm that Americans had been seized, but that if it were true, ''it would affect me in a very dramatic way because I view as a fundamental responsibility of my Presidency protecting American citizens.'' **********Mr. Bush said this morning that American military intervention was not under active consideration, but Lieut. Gen. Howard Graves of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, traveling in Mongolia with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, said the United States was considering ''political, military or economic moves'' against Iraq. And after flying west to meet Mrs. Thatcher and deliver a speech at the Aspen Institute, the President said, ''We're not ruling any options in but we're not ruling any options out.'' **********Warships Head Toward Gulf **********An American naval task force, headed by the carrier Independence with 60 fighters and bombers, sailed from the Indian Ocean toward the mouth of the Persian Gulf in a show of strength. The Kuwaiti Ambassador in Washington, a close relative of the Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who is now in Saudi Arabia, pleaded for immediate American military intervention. **********At the United Nations, the Security Council issued a unanimous call for an Iraqi withdrawal despite Iraqi assertions, brushed aside by virtually all nations, that Baghdad had been asked to send troops into Kuwait by rebel elements there and that Iraqi forces would be withdrawn from Kuwait within a few weeks. **********Mrs. Thatcher called Mr. Hussein's behavior ''intolerable'' and said that ''a collective and effective will of the nations belonging to the U.N.'' was needed. **********United States and British officials referred to Chapter 7 of the United Nations Charter, which permits the Security Council to use economic sanctions or military action against any nation that threatens the peace. **********Such action was always difficult to take during the cold war because it was very rare to find all five permanent members of the Security Council in agreement on any major dispute. **********Soviet Shipments Suspended **********But the Soviet Union, a principal arms supplier to Iraq, immediately suspended its military shipments to that country, and the United States and the Soviet Union planned a joint statement on Friday after Mr. Baker arrives in Moscow. He hurriedly changed his travel plans after receiving news of the invasion. **********Still there seemed to be little practical action that anyone could take in the days immediately ahead to reverse the Iraqi conquest. If Baghdad absorbs Kuwait or sets up a compliant government there, the oil reserves under Iraqi control will be doubled to about 195 billion barrels, making it second only to Saudi Arabia, which has 255 billion barrels. **********The invasion appeared to have the potential to shift not only the economic but also the military and political balance in the region. **********Moving swiftly today to endorse the President's actions against Iraq, the House voted 416 to 0 to impose trade sanctions and to cut off Export-Import Bank credits. **********The Senate unanimously approved a resolution calling for multilateral actions ''involving air, sea and land forces'' under the United Nations charter to restore international peace and security to the region. **********Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, called Mr. Hussein ''the Hitler of the Middle East'' and criticized Mr. Bush for not having moved earlier to forestall an invasion. Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, an influential member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, complained that there had been ''a kind of inertia'' to American policy toward Iraq in recent weeks. **********Fears Over Saudi Arabia **********Several lawmakers suggested that Mr. Hussein might now be emboldened to move into neighboring Saudi Arabia. Senator David Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, who was briefed by the Central Intelligence Agency this morning, noted that the primary Saudi oilfields are only 250 miles from Kuwait, with no terrain ''that would impede a rapid movement of forces'' by Iraq. **********''We have to understand that our national interests are very much at stake,'' Mr. Boren said. ''I think it would be wrong to underestimate the ultimate aims of Saddam Hussein. He really hopes in the long run to put Iraq on a par with the kind of power he sees the Western powers as having.'' **********Judith Kipper, a Middle East specialist at the Brookings Institution, described the conflict in Kuwait as ''a war of resources.'' **********''This is the first post-cold-war crisis in the economically dependent world,'' she said. ''With the end of the East-West game, small countries can act with impunity to rearrange the neighborhood. Iraq is a superpower in its own area, but they need cash to service their debt and rebuild their oil industry. He gets cash from oil; oil prices are going up. Plus, they have historic claims to Kuwait, which Saddam Hussein has chosen to act upon.'' **********Gary Sick, a Middle East expert in the Ford, Carter and Reagan administrations who now teaches at Columbia University, said that condemnations by nations around the world would have ''no effect at all.'' **********''Saddam Hussein obviously expected that when he did it,'' Mr. Sick said. ''He can't be surprised by the reaction, and he obviously discounted that in advance. Some tangible steps will have to be taken if in fact Saddam Hussein is to be persuaded that this didn't work out to his benefit.'' **********Washington Is Galvanized **********The news of the invasion galvanized Washington on Wednesday night and this morning. **********Mr. Bush was told of the invasion at 9 P.M. on Wednesday in the residential quarters of the White House, officials said, and was awakened from time to time during the night for briefings by his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft. He signed his orders on Iraqi assets and trade at 5 A.M., they said. **********At 8 this morning, the President met at length with his senior advisers, including the chairman of the Joint Chiefs, Gen. Colin L. Powell. **********Michael J. Boskin, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser, said that if oil prices rose 25 percent, and he seemed to consider this plausible, it would have ''some deleterious effect on our economy.'' **********Such a rise in prices would slow growth slightly, he said, but not enough to produce a recession. Growth, though meager, is still running at slightly more than 1 percent. **********Later the Department of Energy said the turmoil in the Middle East posed ''no immediate threat'' to American supplies of petroleum products. It estimated that in January to May of this year, Iraq supplied 8 percent of United States oil imports, about 3.6 percent of total United States demand. For Kuwait, the department said, the comparable figures were much smaller -just over 1 percent and less than one-half of 1 percent. **********The Energy Secretary, James D. Watkins, said that crude oil stocks in the United States stood at near-record levels and that world inventories were also unusually high at the moment. This country's Strategic Petroleum Reserve, a statement by the department said, could offset the amount of oil the United States has been importing from both Iraq and Kuwait - about 730,000 barrels a day - for more than 800 days. **********Crude Oil Prices Rise **********Still, crude oil prices shot up to more than $23 a barrel, and some economists said that gasoline prices would rise by at least a nickel a gallon within a week. **********Recalling the Arab oil embargo of the 1970's that forced millions of Americans to wait in long lines, analysts noted that the United States is more dependent on Middle East oil now than it was then. The American Petroleum Institute, which represents United States oil companies, spoke recently of a ''potentially ominous'' trend that has brought oil imports to nearly half of total American consumption. **********Mediation Efforts Collapse **********Arab mediation efforts to head off the crisis broke down Wednesday with the collapse of talks between Iran and Kuwait in the Saudi Arabian port of Jidda on the Red Sea. Mr. Bush said tonight, after talking by phone with a number of Arab leaders, that he was hopeful of a new regional initiative, but there were no reports of concrete plans to bring the two sides together. **********Only a few hours after the collapse of the talks, Iraqi armor, led by more than 350 main battle tanks, began racing across the 80-odd miles of desert that separate Kuwait City, a modern enclave on the gulf, from the frontier. It took the Iraqi forces, using weapons supplied largely by the Soviet Union, France and China, little time to overwhelm the Kuwaiti defenders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/07/busin.main_headline: A Craze May Outsprint Its Creator
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/07/busin.print_headline: A Craze May Outsprint Its Creator
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/07/busin.body_text: **********Rollerblade Inc., a tiny company based near Minneapolis that brought out a roller skate with a single row of wheels, has spawned a sport called blading that in the last three years has become something of a national craze. **********But holding onto the industry lead may be more difficult than pioneering the in-line roller skate, illustrating the hazards of developing a product that is so easy to copy. **********Rollerblade, which introduced the first in-line skate in 1980, has an estimated 66 percent of a market that is expected to top $50 million this year - almost as big as the conventional roller skate business. But growing competition and Rollerblade's recent inability to supply a surge in demand may undermine its lead. Since 1986, eight companies have come out with in-line skates, including established roller- and ice-skate makers like Roller Derby, Bauer and Riedell. **********Although they generally cost twice as much as conventional roller skates, in-line skates - which range in price from $79 for regular models to $399 for a racing skate - are popular because they are faster than conventional models and provide skaters with a better aerobic workout, requiring the use of more muscles. And they are also more difficult to master. **********Rollerblade gave competitors an opening into the market early this year, when it kept some store owners waiting as long as several months for shipments because it was unable to fill demand. ''Six months ago, the competition did not exist, and the name Rollerblade was like magic,'' said Lee Cole, owner of Skates on Haight, a San Francisco-based retailer of skating equipment. ''But not anymore.'' **********John Sundet, Rollerblade's president, says the company has remedied the problem and is now only four weeks behind in deliveries. It has installed a new computer system to help track inventories and has added a third shift, doubling its work force to 140 people at its assembly plant in Eden Prairie, Minn., a Minneapolis suburb where it also has its headquarters. The plant now operates around the clock, producing 3,000 to 4,000 skates a day. **********Mr. Sundet estimates that Rollerblade can sell 400,000 pairs of skates by the end of the year, up from 140,000 last year. Since it is privately held, Rollerblade does not release sales figures. But Randy Geise of Geise Design Associates, a marketing research firm in Minneapolis, estimates that its sales were about $15 million last year and expects them to reach about $35 million this year. **********The company was founded in 1980 by Scott Olson, a 20-year-old hockey player with the Winnipeg Jets' farm teams in the Midwest. He envisioned a roller skate with the action of an ice skate that hockey players and skiers could use to train off-season. He found an 18th-century design for a model that he planned to re-create with modern materials. **********Left to Languish **********But after he discovered a similar in-line skate already on the market, he bought the patent from the manufacturer, the Chicago Roller Skate Company, which had let the product languish. He and his brother Brennan perfected the design, using a plastic-molded ski-type boot atop a blade of polyurethane wheels. In 1980, they started selling the skates door-to-door to sporting goods stores, and to athletes and Scott's teammates. **********Sales were just a trickle. ''We went knocking on doors, and people were laughing in our faces,'' said Brennan, who is now 27 years old and the director of research and development at Rollerblade. **********Short on money, Mr. Olson was forced to sell 94 percent of the company in 1984 for an undisclosed price to Robert Naegele Jr., a Minneapolis advertising entrepreneur who owns a billboard company. **********A Power Struggle **********Mr. Olson resigned as president in December 1985 in what he characterizes as a power struggle with his new boss. ''Bob Naegele came in originally to help fund the company, and then he took control of it,'' said Mr. Olson, 31, who has since introduced a competing skate called Switchit that accommodates either wheels or an ice-skating blade. **********After the president brought in by Mr. Naegele resigned in 1987, Mr. Sundet, chief financial officer of the company since 1986, became president. A former director of finance at the Tonka Corporation, he set out to broaden the company's reach. **********''Our main buyers were hockey players, who were 95 percent male and between 18 and 25 years old,'' he said. ''We changed to the mainstream and targeted 18- to 35-year-old males and females. That is when our sales improved.'' **********But as sales picked up in 1987 so did the competition. First Team Sports Inc., also in Minneapolis, started manufacturing its Ultra-wheels brand skates in April 1986, bringing out the first line for children. The patent expired in 1985. **********Much Competition **********David Soderquist, president of First Team Sports and a former sales representative for Rollerblade, said he expects to sell 225,000 pairs of skates this year. **********The Roller Derby Skate Corporation in Litchfield, Ill., a manufacturer of standard roller skates since 1936, produces a skate that appeals to skaters who are accustomed to the toe-stopper design of conventional roller skates. Most in-line skates have a rubber stopper on the heel. **********The ice skate manufacturer Bauer, a subsidiary of Canstar Sports U.S.A., entered the market this year with a skate, which has a boot of leather rather than plastic. **********On the defensive, Rollerblade has taken legal action against several competitors. It sued First Team Sports and its two founders, both former Rollerblade employees, for misappropriating trade secrets and copying the company's sales promotions. First Team paid Rollerblade $10,000 in an out-of-court settlement. **********Rollerblade has also sued Bauer and Mr. Olson's Innovative Sport Systems Inc. for using brand names that resemble its own. **********Celebrity Promotions **********The competitive battle is also heating up outside the courtroom, with a rush by companies to sign up celebrity promoters. First Team Sports recently signed Wayne Gretzky, the Los Angeles Kings hockey star, and his wife, Janet Jones Gretzky, to a four-year contract to promote its skate. **********And competitors are moving into new retail markets like discount chains and department stores. Rollerblade recently expanded into Macy's and Nordstrom. **********All manufacturers are also trying to develop a skate that is lighter, safer and more comfortable. **********''We have been pioneers and continue to maintan an edge,'' Mr. Sundet said. ''You only get one shot at pioneering a new sport, and that's exciting.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/busin.main_headline: Patents;   Getting the Smoke Out Of a Building on Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/busin.print_headline: Patents;   Getting the Smoke Out Of a Building on Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/busin.body_text: **********A retired engineer who supervised much of the design and construction of San Francisco's subway system during the 1970's has drawn on that experience to invent an emergency ventilation system to remove smoke from burning buildings. **********The system, invented by Wilmot McCutchen of Orinda, Calif., works like a giant vacuum cleaner. It consists of two huge fans on the roof, at the mouth of ventilation shafts that reach down through the building. The shafts, separate from the normal heating and air-conditioning ducts, have vents that open on every floor if a fire is nearby. **********The fans draw air out of the area on fire and out of the building. The process is made easier, the inventor said, because the fan creates a partial vacuum around the burning area, which in turn pulls in fresh air from other parts of the building and creates a breeze that flows up the shaft. **********Mr. McCutchen obtained patent 4,944,216.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Simmons to Fight Lockheed Rule
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/busin.body_text: **********The Texas financier Harold C. Simmons, already waging a proxy fight for control of the board of the Lockheed Corporation, said he would also seek to eliminate the anti-takeover plan of the Calabasas, Calif., military contractor. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Simmons said he would solicit proxies to remove the plan. **********The Lockheed plan effectively prevents Mr. Simmons from buying more than 20 percent of the company's shares because, if he did, Lockheed's other shareholders would be allowed to purchase additional stock from the company at half price. This would increase the number of shares outstanding and effectively reduce the value and influence of his stake. Mr. Simmons now controls 18.94 percent of Lockheed's 63.3 million shares. A spokesman for Lockheed had no comment on the filing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/02/world.body_text: **********Maoist guerrillas shot to death the deputy mayors of two Andean villages who were members of the Democratic Front, the opposition coalition of presidential candidate Mario Vargas Llosa, the police said. The Shining Path rebels left notes on both bodies that said: ''This is how the new starvers of the people die,'' the police said. They said a group of 15 guerrillas entered the town of San Juan de Iscos, 140 miles east of Lima, before dawn Wednesday, dragged the Deputy Mayor from his home and shot him in the town square. The same guerrillas killed the Deputy Mayor of Ahuac, 130 miles east of Lima, on Monday night, the police said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/busin.main_headline: CAMPEAU'S STORES MEET THE DEADLINE TO PAY SUPPLIERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/busin.print_headline: CAMPEAU'S STORES MEET THE DEADLINE TO PAY SUPPLIERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/busin.body_text: **********The American retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation, which include some of the nation's most famous department stores, said yesterday that they had met a deadline for paying suppliers for December merchandise. **********The onerous debts of Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores, which own Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus, Jordan Marsh and six other chains, have raised the specter of bankruptcy. Had the Campeau divisions missed the payments, their remaining suppliers would have cut off shipments and could have forced the companies to file for bankruptcy protection. **********Cash From Holiday Sales **********The decision to pay the bills with cash raised during the recent holiday season followed an apparent change of heart by some of Campeau's largest banks and creditors. They had previously opposed such payments, saying they would prefer that Campeau preserve its cash, file for bankruptcy and begin a reorganization of the company. **********But yesterday some creditors said they had decided the suppliers should be paid because the department stores, which are the collateral for the banks' loans, need merchandise if they are to remain valuable assets. **********''The key is restoring stability to the situation, so that the trade is confident enough to continue shipping merchandise,'' said an executive at one of the banks that hold Campeau's debt. He said the creditors wanted customers to ''go back to thinking about the merchandise rather than reading the business news.'' **********Sought an Extension **********Earlier this week, Campeau executives had asked suppliers for an extension on the $100 million in payments due yesterday. While it was not clear how all the suppliers had responded, a number of them said publicly that they had rejected the request. **********Executives at some large fashion houses said they were pleasantly surprised when Campeau notified them that they would be paid. But some said they were convinced the stores would still file for bankruptcy protection in the next several days. [Page D8.]  The day's developments revived the hopes of some participants in the negotiations between Campeau and its banks that the company might be able to struggle through without resorting to a bankruptcy court. **********As a practical matter all the parties to the recent discussions have been preparing for a bankruptcy filing at any moment. **********People involved in determining the company's fate said Campeau had arranged for a $300 million line of credit with Chemical Bank that would be used if the company entered bankruptcy. That money could be used to pay the most pressing bills, enabling the company to keep operating. **********Arranging such a commitment is often one of a company's final steps before entering bankruptcy. **********Campeau faces another deadline on Monday, when Allied and Federated must assure a syndicate of American and Japanese banks led by Citibank that they are solvent. If they do not, the loans could be declared in default, which would force Campeau to file for bankruptcy protection. **********A banker at one member of the Citibank syndicate said the banks had been urging Campeau to announce a plan describing how it would deal with its crushing debt load of more than $7 billion. **********Campeau incurred those obligations to buy Federated, for $6.6 billion in 1988, and Allied, for which it paid $3.6 billion in 1986. Federated alone is facing interest payments of more than $100 million by February, and it has acknowledged that it is likely to face cash shortages in the next two weeks. **********Facing the Monday deadline, Campeau's directors met yesterday for a third straight day in Toronto, where the company has its headquarters. No details of the talks were disclosed, and another meeting was scheduled for today. **********''It remains a very fluid situation,'' said a lawyer who is being kept apprised of the Toronto meeting. ''What everyone is waiting for is a sign of who is taking charge of the situation. The lenders, in particular, want a sense that someone is home.'' **********Struggle on the Board **********The three largest shareholders of Campeau, all of which have seats on the company's 12-man board, are the company's founder and chairman, Robert Campeau; the National Bank of Canada, which last week received 29 percent of the company's stock after Mr. Campeau defaulted on a loan, and the three Reichmann brothers, whose family controls one of the world's largest real estate empires, Olympia & York Development Ltd. **********No clear signal has been given to the company's creditors, employees, customers or Wall Street about which group, if any, is dominating the board's deliberations. But it is widely perceived that Mr. Campeau is no longer in control. **********Late in the afternoon Campeau said its chief financial officer, Russell S. Davis, had resigned. **********Mr. Davis, 54 years old, had been Mr. Campeau's financial adviser since the acquisition of Federated in the spring of 1988. He had been at Federated since 1984 and is highly regarded in the retailing industry. **********The company gave no details about why he had left and Mr. Davis was said not to be in his office. Campeau immediately named Chance Bahadur, an executive of the Marriott Corporation, as executive vice president and chief financial officer. **********News From Headquarters **********The news that payments were being made to suppliers came from the Cincinnati headquarters of Federated and Allied. Those two Campeau divisions also own Burdines and Maas/Jordan Marsh in Florida; The Bon Marche in Seattle; Rich's/Goldsmith's in Atlanta; Lazarus in Cincinnati, and Stern's in New Jersey. **********Callers to the Cincinnati headquarters heard a tape recording that said, ''The company's only comment is that it is processing checks in the normal course of business.'' **********Some suppliers are paid by the electronic transfer of money to their bank accounts from the retailer's banks. Others are paid by checks. **********Many suppliers expressed nervousness that they might not receive their checks before a bankruptcy filing or that the checks would not clear before such a time. If the checks did not clear, suppliers' payments could be delayed until bankruptcy proceedings were under way. **********Should the stores file for bankruptcy protection, they would remain open. But what merchandise they would have available in coming weeks would depend on what arrangements they could make with suppliers. **********Special Financing **********The $300 million line of credit from Chemical Bank is known as a debtor-in-possession financing. It is a critical element of any Chapter 11 proceeding and is a relatively low-risk loan for the lender. **********The loan would be backed by assets of the company; if those fail to cover a default, the lender would have a priority in a bankruptcy proceeding. **********The statute protecting a lender of such financing is intended to encourage credit to assure the short-term viability of the company in bankruptcy. But it has also proved to be highly lucrative to lenders, and Chemical has become a leader in making such loans. **********Typically, the lender charges a special fee that is negotiable on top of ordinary interest and the bank's expenses. In addition, such lenders also get a commitment fee for any amount of the credit line that goes unused.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/12/world.main_headline: Mandela Is Reported Ailing And Is Hospitalized in Kenya
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/12/world.print_headline: Mandela Is Reported Ailing And Is Hospitalized in Kenya
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/12/world.body_text: **********Nelson Mandela, reportedly suffering from pneumonia, arrived in Nairobi today and was said to have been admitted to a hospital. **********The anti-apartheid leader was diagnosed as having a slight case of pneumonia and was flown from Ethiopia for treatment, according to The Star newspaper of Johannesburg. The 71-year-old Mandela was attending the Organization of African Unity's summit in Addis Ababa. **********A hospital official and a diplomat said Mr. Mandela was admitted to Nairobi Hospital within hours of his arrival. **********Mr. Mandela looked ill upon arriving in Kenya accompanied by his wife, Winnie. He walked slowly down the stairs to the runway. **********After greeting President Daniel arap Moi and his Cabinet and waving to a small crowd of airport workers and security officials, Mr. Mandela and Mr. Moi climbed into the President's limousine and were driven away. Winnie Mandela left in a separate vehicle.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/world.main_headline: East Germany's New Ideal: Prosperity Above All
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   East Germany's New Ideal: Prosperity Above All
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/world.body_text: **********This Saxon village is trim and prosperous enough to be in West Germany, yet its people cannot be sure that it will be allowed to survive. **********Around Ermlitz and a handful of nearby villages are the Auen, the characteristic landscapes of woods and meadows celebrated for their bucolic beauty and German lore. **********But beneath them are large deposits of lignite, East Germany's main source of energy. Under the Communist Government that was overthrown last autumn, Ermlitz and its neighbors were condemned to be bulldozed, adding to the open-face strip mines that mar the countryside that long ago was Aue, too. **********Environment Not an Issue **********Still, with the country's first free parliamentary elections only six days off, the ecological life or death of the villages is not an issue. To the disappointment of environmentalists, the people of this area, like those throughout this country of 16 million, seem transfixed by one issue: How soon can they become as prosperous as West Germany? **********''Our system of values has totally collapsed,'' said Andreas Rattunde, an elementary school teacher in the nearby town of Schkeuditz, one of a handful of local members of the new Green Party, whose chief concern is the environment. **********This region, dominated by the cities of Leipzig and Halle, is widely regarded as East Germany's environmental disaster area and one of the worst such areas of the entire Continent. Yet the Green Party and the Green League, another environmental grouping, have failed to find a following that would make their views count in the voting. **********In the Halle area lie the large chemical concerns of Leuna and Buna, each employing 20,000 to 30,000 workers. They and smaller enterprises have filled the air, soil and water of the region with so many toxic substances that medical statisticians have calculated the life expectancy of this densely populated region at five years less than the national average of 73. **********The Rev. Eduard Kindler, pastor of the medieval evangelical cathedral in Merseburg, quoted Ulrich Klose, a leader of the West German Social Democrats, as saying during an election speech in that stately town that by West German law the entire region would have to be evacuated as unlivable. **********Reminders of the Hazards **********Mr. Kindler said the exaggeration was only slight. But he agreed with most people interviewed during two days in this area that environmental concerns were not a major election issue. He said his parishioners were aware of the hazards by the prevalence of chronic irritations of the respiratory system and mucous membrane, as well as skin eruptions, and of pale children with runny noses. **********Parts of Merseburg, as well as other towns and villages, are permanently covered by a white chemical dust, and a sour smell fills people's nostrils. **********Public awareness has been heightened recently because the fall of the Government of Erich Honecker has removed the taboo that had forbidden any public discussion of the ecological blight and its effects on health. Virtually all of the two dozen or so parties and movements that are presenting candidates in Sunday's voting are paying at least lip service to the environment. **********But no ordinary voter addressed at random volunteered a belief that environmental problems were an issue. **********Mr. Kindler said it was not only the overwhelming weight of what he called ''the German question'' - the wish for speedy reunification - that made the environmentalists' campaign so ineffective. **********Fear That Jobs Will Vanish **********''The people are in a deep dilemma,'' he said. ''They know that Leuna and Buna are obsolete compared to West Germany's chemical industry. This region is terribly afraid that for economic reasons alone 50,000 jobs here are endangered. They don't like to think about the ecological problems that could also mean that their factories will be closed. **********''They are putting it out of mind like smokers do. They also know what cigarettes do to them, but push that knowledge aside.'' **********Mayor Gerhard Godicke of Ermlitz said the people here are simply thinking of how soon they, too, can drive about in West German cars instead of tiny vehicles of local production. Such material desires have pushed their worry about the survival of their villages temporarily out of mind. **********But Mr. Godicke is proud that he organized a successful citizens' environmental campaign. He took quick advantage of the political upheaval to organize, with the help of churchmen and ecologists, a protest march in January, unusual in this conservative region of compliant cattle, pig and sheep farmers joined in a state cooperative. Even older residents could not recall any such unofficial demonstration ever occurring here. **********As every village church bell pealed, many for the first time in decades because worshippers had years ago bowed to Communist pressure, about 1,200 people marched through the Auen to the mine headquarters at Rassnitz to confront its directors with their demands. **********A harassed manager said he had no authority to decide, but Mr. Godicke said shortly thereafter that informal word had reached him from district authorities that the villages would be removed from the lignite industry's jurisdiction. But they don't have it in writing. **********Mr. Godicke and five other mayors took their courage in their hands -''We would have never done this before,'' he said - and wrote a letter of protest to Prime Minster Hans Modrow, demanding official action to save the Auen. Proudly, the mayor showed phrases in which years of frustration under a dictatorial Government exploded into words of un-German assertiveness toward the highest authority. **********''We citizens are bitter and angry over these measures, which are contrary to sensible ecology, and the senseless destruction, delaying tactics, silence, ignorance and arrogance of the relevant enterprises and state organs,'' the mayors wrote. They have not received a reply. **********But Mr. Rattunde, the Green representative, was skeptical. ''If somebody offers them enough Deutschemarks, they'll sell the Auen,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/20/world.main_headline: U.S. Officials Say Outcome Promises to Benefit NATO
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/20/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   U.S. Officials Say Outcome Promises to Benefit NATO
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/20/world.body_text: **********The Bush Administration today hailed the election in East Germany as a victory ''for all who support democratic values'' and some officials said it would increase the chances that a unified Germany would remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. **********Officially, the Administration was circumspect in its analysis of how the victory by conservative East Germans backed by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany would affect efforts to unify the two Germanys. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said only that the election was evidence that the unification process is ''inexorable.'' **********But other Administration officials said privately that the election results promised to play into NATO's hands. **********One official said the unification process would be ''much more orderly and predictable in the sense that you don't have two governments on either side of the inter-German border with very different agendas.'' **********Kohl's Hand Strengthened **********''It obviously enhances Kohl's ability to control the process,'' the official said; Mr. Kohl actively supported the East German Alliance for Germany, which was led by the Christian Democrats. **********''He doesn't have complete control but their version of unification is very similar to his,'' an official said. That vision, this official and others said, includes the continued membership of a unified Germany in the NATO military alliance. **********Another official said it was too early to draw many firm conclusions about the election results. ''They now have to form a government and there were some points of differences among the three main groups in the alliance on how unification should be accomplished,'' the official said. **********He and other United States officials were careful not to say that they were seeking to slow down unification. But they said they thought the election results would quash any sentiment that unification should occur in a matter of weeks, instead of months. **********Unification 'Without Chaos' **********''What we've been seeing in the last couple of weeks, which is reinforced in the elections, is a desire not to slow down unification necessarily but to make sure that it is done deliberately, without chaos and without being hasty about it,'' an official said. **********''Apparently the talk in Bonn is that it probably could not be accomplished before the end of the year and perhaps not even in the first months of next year,'' he said. ''The East German alliance are probably pretty much on the same wavelength as Bonn.'' **********At his daily news briefing, Mr. Fitzwater said: ''This is a victory not only for the people of the German Democratic Republic, but for all Germans and all who support democratic values. We join them and the people of Federal Republic in celebrating this historic occasion.'' **********Asked whether the United States sees any remaining obstacles to unifying the two Germanys, Mr. Fitzwater replied: ''There are obstacles in the sense of issues to be resolved and problems to be dealt with. But it does appear that the march toward reunification is inexorable.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/busin.main_headline: Two Views On Whittle's TV Reports
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;   Two Views On Whittle's TV Reports
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/busin.body_text: **********A PLAN by Whittle Communications to put advertiser-supported television programming into doctors' waiting rooms is meeting with widespread interest from advertising agencies. But television executives are questioning the analysis used by the Tennessee company to support its claim that the programming will reach consumers whom network television does not attract. **********Whittle said two weeks ago that it was developing an hourlong television news program aimed primarily at young mothers. The program would play continuously on a combination large-screen television and videodisk player to be installed in 20,000 physicians' waiting rooms. The program, called Special Reports Television, will change 24 times a year. Whittle says the program will reach 44 million people. **********Advertisers are being offered $5.5 million packages that will combine two 30-second commercials an hour on all 24 shows with a page of advertising in Whittle's three quarterly Special Reports magazines for doctors' offices. **********Whittle argues that its target audience - women between 25 and 54 years old, particularly those in their late 20's and early 30's with children - is barely touched by network television. The company says that the people who watch the most television account for 51 percent of all prime-time viewing but are not a desirable market for most consumer-products companies. Citing data from the Simmons Market Research Bureau, Whittle says that 63 percent of this group are unemployed and 52 percent have household incomes under $20,000. **********Whittle says 46 percent of the 38 million women with children in the United States are among the most infrequent television viewers. The waiting rooms of pediatricians, obstetrician-gynecologists and family practitioners, the company says, are the places to reach them. **********Marketing executives, having heard that argument before from Whittle, have spent $80 million on advertising during the first two years of the company's Special Reports magazines. **********Some advertising executives had been critical of Whittle's projections and research for the magazines, and some advised their clients to reduce their ad expenditures in them. But many of these executives say they have been impressed by the rigor of the research the company has used to support Special Reports Television. **********Calling Special Reports Television ''extremely creative,'' John J. Sisk, Jr., the director of network negotiations at J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., said it could turn out to be ''a form of television that can reach potential customers no one else can reach.'' **********Nevertheless, questions have arisen about Whittle's new project. **********The company is basing the marketing of its waiting-room network on what is known in television as a quintile analysis, in which a large market is divided into five groups, from the heaviest to the lightest viewers. Whittle says the networks draw primarily from the heaviest, but least desirable viewers, in quintiles one and two, instead of what it calls the more attractive, light viewers in quintiles four and five. **********But television executives say the fifth quintile is of little interest to marketers. Robert Niles, vice president of research at NBC, characterized that quintile as largely ''a downscale audience'' made up of ''second-shift workers, blue-collar and older people who go to bed early.'' **********Others question the lengths to which Whittle takes its quintile analysis. Willard Hadlock, the head of media services at the Leo Burnett advertising agency, said: ''Quintiles four and five are not necessarily the lightest viewers. In some cases, they're the heaviest viewers. When they're home with a baby, they watch a lot of TV.'' **********Furthermore, both network and agency executives say that network schedules can be tailored to reach the light viewers, and they question whether even pregnant women or young mothers go to their physicians often enough to give the advertising punch. **********''Effective advertising is a combination of reach and frequency,'' said David F. Poltrack, senior vice president of research at CBS. ''With Whittle's program, you don't get frequency. I don't know too many people who go to the doctor's more than once every two weeks.'' **********Mr. Poltrack compared Special Reports Television to airline advertising, which also reaches a selective, affluent audience, but too infrequently to represent a threat to network television. **********Mr. Sisk of J. Walter Thompson, nevertheless, called Whittle's television project ''another form of chipping away at the networks.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/21/world.main_headline: Aquino Defends Effort To Save Quake Victims
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/21/world.print_headline: Aquino Defends Effort To Save Quake Victims
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/21/world.body_text: **********President Corazon C. Aquino defended her Government today against criticism that it has been slow and ineffective in aiding victims of an earthquake that killed nearly 700 people. **********''Let us not blame others,'' she said in a nationally televised address, her first since the quake on Monday. ''What we need to do now is help each other.'' **********Five days after the earthquake, measuring 7.7 on the Richter scale, officials said reports of damage and deaths were still trickling in from remote areas. By latest counts, 674 people were killed and more than 2,600 injured. **********Mrs. Aquino ordered several aides to take over relief operations, apparently bypassing the disaster-coordinating agency led by Defense Secretary Fidel V. Ramos. **********The President, who is grappling with a Communist insurgency, rebellious military officers and popular discontent, has come under criticism for a Government rescue effort described by many as inadequate. **********A United States Marine OV-1 observation plane taking part in rescue operations crashed today near Baguio, killing one of the two crew members.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/02/world.main_headline: Summit in Washington;   Wide Differences Over Germany Are Still Said to Divide the Superpowers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/02/world.print_headline: Summit in Washington;   Wide Differences Over Germany Are Still Said to Divide the Superpowers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/02/world.body_text: **********Despite some vague remarks on Thursday from both President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev about narrowing their differences on Germany, American and Soviet officials said today that the gaps between them on this critical issue still appeared to be wide. **********Indeed, Mr. Gorbachev used a meeting today with Congressional leaders at the Soviet Embassy to complain about the Administration's ''rather rigid position'' that ''a united Germany belong to NATO.'' **********Mr. Bush telephoned the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, first thing today to assure him that he did not diverge from his position that a unified Germany must remain a member of the NATO alliance. **********The discussion that took place on Thursday afternoon between the two Presidents on the German question appears to have been a combination of diplomacy and public posturing. On the diplomatic side, an Administration official said, the two men laid out their longstanding positions on the German question, with a new nuance here or there, but no surprises. **********Insistence on NATO Role **********That American position in short, the official said, is that Germany is going to be united, it is going to be in NATO, and the United States stands ready to make that fact as politically, economically and militarily acceptable to Moscow as possible. **********Mr. Gorbachev countered with what one American official described as ''an extremely peculiar'' performance on Germany. In an ''animated, confident and thrusting'' speaking style, the official said, Mr. Gorbachev gave ''an extraordinarily vague presentation - it was elaborate, convuluted and imprecise.'' **********Through the haze, officials said, he made clear that the Soviet people simply could not accept the idea that their enemy of World War II - a united Germany - and their enemy of the cold war - NATO - should now be joined in one alliance. Germany should be in both alliances, he said, which should eventually give way to some new pan-European security framework. **********At the close, however, Mr. Gorbachev asked aloud whether it ''shouldn't be the German people who decide whether or not they are in NATO.'' Mr. Bush, confident that the German people want to remain in the alliance, tried to press the Soviet leader on how they might establish this point, but he could not pin him down, officials said. **********Gorbachev Seemed Upbeat **********Public relations came into play when Mr. Gorbachev left the White House saying ''something emerged'' in their discussions on Germany, and appearing generally quite upbeat. He also said Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, would be holding ''in depth'' talks to work on details, giving rise to speculation that a breakthrough on Germany was imminent. **********Mr. Gorbachev's upbeat approach seemed consistent with Soviet efforts to avoid being depicted as the ''spoiler'' standing in the way of a smooth, speedy German unification and to emphasize that Moscow is the one spinning out new ideas for an idyllic Europe free of all military alliances. **********Mr. Bush, apparently not wanting to contradict Mr. Gorbachev at the very outset of the summit talks and intrigued by the Soviet leader's closing remark on letting the Germans decide, said he too was ''encouraged'' by their discussion. **********Nothing Fundamentally New **********As the day wore on, though, Administration officials, speaking not for attribution, began letting it be known that Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze were not planning any more talks on the German question and that nothing fundamentally new had really come up in the Bush-Gorbachev talks on this issue. **********Today, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, tried to get the two Presidents down from the tree they had climbed together by saying: ''I think the confusion just arose over the interpretation of what the word 'new' means, if you can believe that. We had some new - meaning different, is the way I would describe it - different formulations of our positions, but nothing was agreed to.'' **********Many Administration officials say they believe that if there is going to be any real movement by the Soviets on the German question, it might be foreshadowed in the private meetings between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev at Camp David on Saturday. But more likely, officials say, is that Mr. Gorbachev will not make any new move on Germany - an explosive domestic political issue for him - until after the Communist Party congress in early July. **********On Repackaging NATO **********President Bush's position, as laid out on Thursday, is that to make a unified Germany in NATO palatable to the Soviets, the United States, West Germany and the NATO allies have agreed to package it in this way: *********** After German unification, no NATO troops will be extended to the territory of what is now East Germany, so there will be no increased threat to Soviet forces. *********** The 300,000 to 400,000 Soviet troops now in East Germany will be able to remain there for a transitional period of a few years. *********** The West German Government will pay the estimated $180 million cost of maintaining the Soviet troops in East Germany for the transition period, and will also pay for the construction of new housing for them back in the Soviet Union. *********** NATO will begin revamping its force structure - downgrading readiness of certain units, scaling back its military training programs, developing multi-national fighting units, scraping plans to modernize its short-range nuclear missiles - to respond to the diminished threat from the East and to make NATO less threatening to Moscow. *********** As soon as the Soviets agree to conclude the current conventional forces treaty now being negotiated in Vienna - the treaty would sharply reduce Soviet and American troops, armor and artillery forces in Europe - the Germans, in conjunction with NATO, will be prepared to begin immediately discussing limitations on the size of a united Germany's armed forces. *********** The United States has offered to begin looking for ways to institutionalize the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to transform it into some sort of ''club'' that every nation in Europe could belong to, an official said. The Conference could be given a permanent secretariat, hold more frequent meetings and be given responsibilities for everything from crisis management to election monitoring. With the Soviet-led Warsaw pact disintegrating and NATO remaining intact, the idea is to use the Conference as a framework that could give the Soviets a sense of both belonging to and playing a leading role in a pan-European organization - but one that would be a compliment to NATO, not a substitute.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/busin.main_headline: Court Clears Sale Of Amdura Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Court Clears Sale Of Amdura Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/busin.body_text: **********The Amdura Corporation said the United States District Court had approved the sale of the assets of the company's Coast-to-Coast Stores subsidiary to the Servistar Corporation. Amdura said it expects the sale to close within 35 days. **********Under the deal, the company will operate as a cooperative owned by current Coast-to-Coast store owners. All employees of the hardware chain will be retained, and its headquarters will remain in Denver. Amdura and Coast-to-Coast filed for protection under Chapter 11 of United States Bankruptcy Code on April 2. Servistar is a hardware cooperative based in Butler, Pa.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/busin.main_headline: The Media Business;   Fox Reaches Accord To Broaden Its Cable
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/busin.print_headline: The Media Business;   Fox Reaches Accord To Broaden Its Cable
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/busin.body_text: **********The agreement is significant because ''it is the first time that cable systems are serving as network affiliates, Bob Thomson, a spokesman for Tele-Communications, said. **********The Fox network, a unit of the News Corporation Ltd., now reaches 91 percent of the country. The agreement would initially give it exposure to an additional 1 percent. Preston Padden, a senior vice president at Fox, said the company was hopeful that comparable agreements with other cable operators would provide exposure to an additional 4 percent of the country. **********While the agreement offers Fox the opportunity to reach more viewers, it provides Tele-Communications the chance to sell a wider variety of programming to potential customers. **********The economics of the pending agreement were still being ironed out yesterday. But Fox will either sell local advertising itself in each market or receive six cents per subscriber from Tele-Communications for the first 500,000 subscribers and five cents for each additonal subscriber thereafter. **********Advertising Sales Office **********Mr. Padden said that in areas where Fox could establish an advertising sales office reaching a sufficiently large number of subscribers, it would be reasonable to set up a sales office. Otherwise, it was likely Fox would not get involved in sales itself. **********About 40 percent of the cable households that now receive Fox view it on UHF stations, which are generally at the upper end of the dial. But under the agreement, Tele-Communications will now move the Fox affiliates it already carries to the lower end of the dial. Mr. Padden explained that the move was beneficial because research had shown that viewers searching for programming to watch would more often watch those stations between channels 2 and 13. **********By agreeing to carry the Fox network on channels 2 to 13, which are generally VHF channels, Tele-Communications is also taking a stand against CBS on the cable re-regulation bill. CBS supported an amendment in the House bill that prohibits cable operators from putting anything but local broadcast stations and C-Span on the lowest tier of channels. That is the tier that the Government can regulate. **********By agreeing to move the Fox affiliates onto the lowest tier, Tele-Communications is challenging CBS and the notion that the Government can control what is on the lowest tier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/07/world.main_headline: Hundreds Rally in Mongolia As Their Leader Tours China
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/07/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   Hundreds Rally in Mongolia As Their Leader Tours China
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/07/world.body_text: **********About 1,000 Mongolians demonstrated today in support of pro-democracy protesters staging a sit-in in the capital, and hunger strikers in other parts of the country fasted through an eighth day. **********In China, the Mongolian President, Punsalmaagiyn Ochirbat, continued his visit and headed to Inner Mongolia, a region where three million ethnic Mongolians live under Chinese rule. **********As Mr. Ochirbat met Chinese leaders, Ulan Bator's official news agencies described the situation at home as ''chaos'' caused by illegal demonstrations, strikes and hunger strikes against the Communist authorities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/24/busin.body_text: **********Citing eroding construction-related markets, the Manville Corporation today reported second-quarter earnings of $52.6 million, or 41 cents a share, down 24 percent from $69.4 million, or 55 cents a share, a year earlier. **********Sales were $561.1 million in the quarter, down slighlty from the $564.6 million reported a year earlier. **********For the first six months of 1990, the company reported net income of $77.5 million, or 58 cents a share, down 25 percent from $103.8 million, or 80 cents a share, in 1989. Sales were up slightly over the first six months of last year, at $1.08 billion, compared with $1.07 billion during the period last year. **********''Our second-quarter results reflect a mixture of forces driving our company,'' said Tom Stephens, chairman, chief executive and president of the Denver-based building products company. **********''Construction-related markets continued to erode slowly, and while demand for our coated paperboard products was strong, packaging sales were down,'' he said. **********''In Brazil, our domestic markets continue to be negatively affected by the country's new economic program, but our exports from Brazil remain on target,'' Mr. Stephens said. ''We remain confident about Manville's long-term prospects in Brazil and continue to strengthen our position in worldwide paper markets.'' **********Mr. Stephens said the competitive pressures in all of the company's product lines were expected to intensify during the second half of 1990. **********Manville, which employs more than 18,000 worldwide, filed for Chapter 11 reorganization in 1982 as it faced billions of dollars' worth of lawsuits stemming from asbestos-related operations. The company emerged from Chapter 11 protection in 1988 with a plan to repay creditors and people claiming personal injury or property damage from asbestos.

**********Unsecured creditors of Charles H. Keating Jr.'s bankrupt American Continental Corporation reached an agreement with the Government last week that will settle claims against the company's former subsidiary, the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. **********The Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency that was created to manage the savings and loan bailout and which now controls Lincoln, agreed to pay holders of the subordinated debentures $21 million. **********This represents only partial payment for the $250 million in the company's outstanding ''junk bonds'' that are now essentialy worthless. The unsecured creditors' primary case is not against the Government, but against Mr. Keating, members of his family and other former officials of the company. **********They have been accused of conducting a policy of persuading thousands of retirees and other small depositors to withdraw their insured funds from Lincoln and invest them in high-risk American Continental junk bonds, while telling them that their funds were still insured.

The size of the issue was increased from a planned $250 million. **********Underwriters said the notes, which are due on Aug. 1, 1997, have a 9 1/4 percent coupon and are priced at 99.885, to yield 9.272 percent, or about 98 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/31/busin.main_headline: Borden Appointment Seen As Prelude to Job as Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/31/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Borden Appointment Seen As Prelude to Job as Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/31/busin.body_text: **********Borden Inc. yesterday named Anthony S. D'Amato as president and chief operating officer, making him the likely next leader of the $7.6 billion company. **********Mr. D'Amato, 59, is expected to succeed R. J. Ventres, 65, chairman and chief executive, when he retires. Mr. Ventres was named chief executive in November 1986 and chairman in February 1987. He is scheduled to retire in November 1991 as chief executive and February 1992 as chairman. **********The post of president has been vacant. ''Mr. D'Amato's promotion is an important step in preparation for an orderly succession,'' Mr. Ventres said. The pattern at Borden has been to promote the president to the chief executive post, a spokesman said. **********The two men have known each other for 30 years at Borden and Mr. Ventres has a high regard for Mr. D'Amato,, who was selected over three other candidates. ''He can hit the ground running faster than anybody else I know,'' Mr. Ventres said. **********Others in the running for the president's post were Jon G. Hettinger, 48, who runs the grocery unit; George J. Waydo, 46, snacks and international, and Richard W. Fowlkes, 55, dairy. **********In a recent report on Borden, Prudential-Bache analysts picked Mr. D'Amato as winner of ''the coveted Elsie stakes,'' pointing out that Mr. D'amato, Mr. Ventres and the retired chairman, Eugene Sullivan, all came out of Borden's chemical side. Mr. D'Amato, however, pointed out yesterday that his background was not in commodity chemicals but in plastics and wallcoverings, businesses closer to the consumer. **********Mr. D'Amato, the company said, played a key role in developing Borden's packaging film business and in building up its wall-covering operation, which is now the world's largest. **********Joseph M. Saggese, 58, will succeed Mr. D'Amato as president of the packaging and industrial products group. Mr. Saggese was also named a member of the office of the chairman, where he joins Mr. Ventres, Mr. D'Amato and the heads of the dairy, grocery and snacks businesses. Mr. D'Amato holds a degree in chemical engineering from the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/21/busin.main_headline: Dow Up 1.74 Points on Sluggish Volume
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/21/busin.print_headline: Dow Up 1.74 Points on Sluggish Volume
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/21/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices ended the day with a thin gain, after rising in early trading and then quickly falling. Volume continued to be sluggish. **********By closing time, the Dow Jones industrial average stood at 2,895.30, up 1.74 points. Volume rose slightly, to 137.42 million shares, from 134.9 million the day before, with 777 issues down and 668 ahead. **********The big drag on the stock and bond market appeared to be yesterday's survey of economic conditions around the country as reported in the so-called beige book from the nation's 12 Federal Reserve banks. **********''The tone of district reports,'' said the Federal Reserve's summary of the findings, ''suggests continued slow growth in the economy with little change in the underlying inflation rate.'' **********Sung Won Sohn, chief economist of the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said, ''What they're saying is that economic conditions are weakening and the beige book is confirming that. The upshot is that economic weakness is accumulating and inflation is becoming less of a concern.'' **********Gains among the 30 industrial blue chips were relatively minor. Alcoa - up 1, to 66 - was the only stock in the group to gain as much as a point. Alcoa officials said they knew of no reason to account for the rise. **********Upjohn, the pharmaceutical company and long a rumored takeover target, rose 2 1/8, to 42 1/8, in heavy trading. Schering-Plough, another often-rumored takeover candidate, rose 1, to 46, also in heavy trading. **********Haven in Drug Stocks **********Schering's chairman, Robert P. Luciano, told analysts that the company expected earnings this year to rise at least 18 percent. But drug stocks are a traditional haven during uncertain times and volume in drug stocks yesterday was particularly strong. **********Abbott Labs rose 1, to 40, with more than one million shares traded after Mimi Cutler Willard, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton, recommended the stock. Bausch & Lomb rose 1, to 65 3/4. Warner Lambert rose 1 5/8, to 63. Johnson & Johnson gained 7/8, to 64 5/8. **********Nike, which makes athletic shoes, rose 2 5/8, to 77 5/8, in heavy trading after Heidi Steinberg, who follows the stock at Salomon Brothers, recommended it on price weakness and because she expected strong profits this year. **********On the Amex, Binks Manufacturing rose 2 1/4, to 42, on news of a takeover bid. Kelso Management, which owns 7.7 percent, said an unidentified Chicago company had offered much more than the $45 earlier bid by the Illinois Tool Works.
