https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/19/busin.main_headline: Dow Falls 18.07 in Heavy Program Selling
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/19/busin.print_headline: Dow Falls 18.07 in Heavy Program Selling
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/19/busin.body_text: **********Investors turned cautious yesterday amid heavy program selling, depressing stock prices for the first time in more than a week and leaving the Dow 3,000 level as a barrier still to be crossed. **********By the end of the day the Dow Jones industrial average stood at 2,981.68, down 18.07 points. **********The bellwether Dow average has, in fact, pierced the barrier several times since it first broke through last Friday but it has never been able to hold above that level until the close of a trading day, and, the record does not really count until it does. **********Trading volume slumped a bit, to 168.8 million shares, from 176.8 million the day before. Stocks that fell outnumbered those that gained by 1,030 to 483. 60 Stocks at New Lows Sixty stocks set new lows, including Polaroid, the instant-photo camera company. After reporting a 23 percent drop in profits, it slid 3 1/4 to close at 36 in heavy trading; during the day it reached a new low of 35 1/4. **********''Three thousand is giving people pause,'' said Ronald J. Hill, investment strategist at Brown Brothers Harriman. ''It's just a psychological constraint. We're going into territory we've never been before, and that makes people pause and think if stocks are expensive at these levels.'' **********David B. Bostian, chief economist for Jesup, Josephthal & Company, said, ''You've had three attempts'' to reach 3,000 ''and they failed.'' **********Referring to statements before the Senate Banking Committee yesterday by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Fed, he added, ''And there was nothing in Greenspan's testimony that the market could read into the lowering of interest rates,'' a move that would send the market up again. **********Mr. Bostian said that ''the euphoria'' over the easing of interest rates last Friday ''is now over'' and ''there's no immediate prospect of a further reduction.'' **********Moreover, he argued, investors might soon begin to focus on the budget talks in Washington, with their ''risk of tax increases'' and the posssibility that if Congress and the Administration are unable to negotiate an agreement, automatic spending cuts would be imposed by law. **********Transportation Issues Tumble **********Along with the decline in the Dow industrials, the Dow transportation stocks tumbled 16.06, to 1,171.53. UAL rose 1/2, to 162 1/2, after its nonunion workers joined in a union effort to buy the air carrier, but AMR, parent of American Airlines, fell 2 7/8, to 61 5/8, after reporting lower second-quarter profits. Delta Air Lines fell 2 3/8, to 73, after Paul P. Karos, airline analyst at the First Boston Corporation, cut his earnings estimates for Delta and AMR. Conrail fell 1 3/8, to 49 5/8, after reporting lower profits. **********Among the industrials, United Technologies, which fell 1 1/2, to 60 1/2, was the only Dow blue chip to sink as much as a point. A.T.&T. rose 1/8, to 37 1/8; Coca-Cola rose 1/8, to 47 3/8; Philip Morris fell 3/8, to 50 1/8, and I.B.M. fell 7/8, to 119 7/8, all in heavy trading. **********United Telecommunications, the phone company, which fell 8 3/4 Tuesday after reporting a 55 percent drop in profits, topped the New York Stock Exchange active list for the second day, falling another 2 1/4, to 27 1/4, with 10.03 million shares changing hands. **********MCI, the long-distance company, which fell 1 5/8 Tuesday, fell another 1 7/8, to 36 1/2, on nearly 13 million shares, making it the most heavily traded stock in yesterday's over-the-counter trading. **********Century Telephone rose 1 1/4, to 32 1/4, in a weak telephone group. Bell Atlantic fell 1, to 45 3/8; Nynex fell 1 1/8, to 78 1/8, and Rochester Telephone fell 1 3/8, to 32 5/8. **********Drug stocks also weakened. Warner Lambert fell 1 7/8, to 67 1/4, and American Home Products fell 2 1/8, to 52 1/4, despite higher profits. Lilly fell 3 7/8, to 85, after a New York woman charged in a suit that its drug Prozac made her try to kill herself. But Pfizer rose 2, to 71 1/4, and Upjohn rose 2 3/8, to 43 7/8, a new high, after favorable earnings reports. **********Birinyi Associates said heavy program trading - largely selling -clipped nearly 19 points off the Dow. The S.&P. 500 index fell 3.30, to 364.22; the Nasdaq composite index fell 3.66, to 460.82, and the Amex market-value index fell 2.33, to 362.06.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/27/busin.snippet: LEAD: A 190-unit condominium called Pondside, under construction in Greenburgh, N.Y., is the first project to be built under a novel zoning ordinance adopted three years ago by this Westchester town to promote affordable housing.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/27/busin.main_headline:
Lower-Cost Housing;

Zoning Limits Size of Westchester Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/27/busin.print_headline:
Lower-Cost Housing;

Zoning Limits Size of Westchester Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/27/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: A 190-unit condominium called Pondside, under construction in Greenburgh, N.Y., is the first project to be built under a novel zoning ordinance adopted three years ago by this Westchester town to promote affordable housing. **********A 190-unit condominium called Pondside, under construction in Greenburgh, N.Y., is the first project to be built under a novel zoning ordinance adopted three years ago by this Westchester town to promote affordable housing. **********Prices at the development range up to $339,000 for a three-bedroom town house, but they start at $138,500 for a 622-square-foot, one-bedroom apartment. **********The developer, the Ginsburg Development Corporation of Hawthorne, N.Y., is offering 57 smaller, less costly units along with larger apartments and town houses to comply with the town's ordinance that at least 30 percent of the units meet size restrictions and other guidelines intended to keep their cost down. The ordinance affects property in the town's unincorporated areas that have multifamily zoning, a category that permits up to 10 units to the acre. **********Several communities in Westchester give developers higher densities in return for lower-cost units, but Greenburgh decided to take the different approach. **********''People are very concerned about traffic,'' said Edith Silberstein, the town's Commissioner of Planning, ''and neither did we want another level of government that would impose price constraints.'' **********Most new construction has been priced in the $300,000 to $500,000 range, town officials said. Now about 350 lower-cost units in addition to those at Pondside are expected to be built within three years. **********To qualify for affordable status, one-bedroom units cannot exceed 650 square feet, and two-bedroom units are limited to 750 square feet. These units can have only one bathroom. **********At Pondside, which is offering a mix of two- and three-bedroom town houses and apartments, the small-size units will be available in two four-story elevator buildings, each of which will have 48 apartments. **********The first apartment building, which will be ready for occupancy in November, offers 29 one-bedroom units ranging from 622 square feet to 650 square feet, with prices ranging from $138,500 up to $160,500. Prices for other apartments start at $162,000 for a 750-square-foot, one-bedroom unit and rise to $213,500 for a 1,092-square-foot, two-bedroom apartment. Ground-floor apartments all have private patios, a few units on upper floors have terraces, and many apartments have bay windows. **********The small one-bedroom units are being offered first to people who live or work in Greenburgh. Seven of the 12 purchasers who have bought apartments since pre-construction sales began in October have elected to buy the smaller units. **********The second building will offer 28 of the smaller apartments, but sales on those have not yet started. **********Prices for the town houses start at $249,500 for a two-bedroom, 1,956-square-foot unit, and the highest-priced unit, at $339,000, offers 2,758 square feet and a one-car garage. **********The 17.5-acre property, which is on Stadium Road and Route 100A near White Plains, could have been developed as an apartment-house complex. **********But adjoining single-family neighborhoods made the mix of town houses and apartments more appropriate, said Martin Ginsburg, who is developing the project with his brother Samuel. **********''We felt there is a need for both types of units, and our development concept was a self-contained, parklike community where people who want the convenience of an elevator building can also have amenities, and where people who prefer town house living can have it within walking distance of shopping and transportation,'' he said. **********The slope of the site gives town houses three living levels. Kitchens and living rooms, which lead out to rear decks, are on the street level; bedrooms are on the second floor, and walkout basements lead to private rear patios. Twelve of the 24 town houses in the first section have been sold since sales began in October. Models will open in June, and occupancy will start late in July. **********Two man-made ponds, each about half an acre, are centrally placed so that 40 percent of the units will have water views. The landscaping will have a Japanese theme, and also more formal areas to complement the Georgian-style architecture of the town houses and the apartment buildings. Do H. Chung & Partners of Stamford is the architect, and David Ferris Miller of Croton-on-Hudson is the landscape architect. **********Residences will be sold under a condominium form of ownership. But the 13.8 acres of common area, which includes a clubhouse, two tennis courts, an outdoor swimming pool and a half-mile jogging trail, will be owned and managed by a homeowners' association. **********The association will buy the property from the developers for $500,000, payable over 30 years at 10 percent interest. Monthly loan payments of $4,387.86 will be apportioned among the condominium owners, adding an average of $23 to monthly expenditures that with taxes included will range from $384 for a one-bedroom apartment to $585 for a three-bedroom town house.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/02/busin.body_text: **********The Acura NSX sports car that will be roaring down American roads later in August has swooping lines, a heart-stopping 168-mile-an-hour top speed and a long list of other characteristics that the Honda Motor Company says a competitive ''super car'' should have. **********Still, at $60,000 for two seats, the car will appeal to only a few thousand buyers. But beyond the exotic looks and near race-car performance, the NSX represents a clear technical leap forward that could mean stronger sales for all Honda luxury cars. **********''The true significance of this car is the way it enhances Acura's high-performance image,'' said Christopher Cedergren of J. D. Power & Associates, an automotive-marketing consulting firm in Westlake Village, Calif. ''With the NSX, you can have a sexy, exotic performance car with the maintenance cost of a Honda Accord.'' **********The NSX, shown to reporters at a race track here this week, also symbolizes the Japanese auto industry's determination to place challengers into every marketing niche of the industry, no matter how small. **********In building the NSX, Honda extensively redesigned outside body parts and inside components to reduce size and weight. It also refined the engine technology to coax enormous power from six cylinders. **********The resulting car, due in American showrooms in two weeks, makes Honda the first Japanese auto maker to offer a vehicle that matches the lightning-fast performance characteristics of the super cars from Ferrari, Lamborghini and Porsche that cost $100,000 and more. **********Honda engineers say innovations introduced in the NSX will appear in other new models destined for the American market, starting with two new Acura sports luxury models that are to be introduced within nine months. **********To show off the NSX's handling and performance characteristics, Honda executives have been inviting automotive journalists and reviewers to race tracks around the country, including the Portland International Raceway, for test drives. Porsche and Ferrari models were provided for comparison. **********Extremely Glowing Reviews **********Suprisingly, the NSX's gears and clutch feel the same as those in regular Hondas. But the power and sound of the engine seem awesome to one accustomed to conventional cars. Just a few seconds after pressing the accelerator, the driver can see the speedometer closing on 110 miles an hour. Despite the high speed, there is little sense of danger or urgency, even in fairly sharp curves. **********NSX stands for ''new sports car experimental,'' as it was called internally while it was under development. The car has already been trumpeted on the covers of most car magazines and has received extremely glowing reviews, even by the standards of the sometimes boosterish automotive press. **********One important development in the car was the use of aluminum for NSX's body, rather than steel or plastic. Aluminum is 40 percent lighter than steel but also five or six times more expensive and very difficult to bend and weld because it tears easily. Honda engineers said that what they learned about special welding equipment, dies and aluminum alloys could result in more aluminum parts on future cars, especially if energy prices increase and fuel efficiency standards get stricter, requiring lighter-weight vehicles. **********Multivalve Technology **********The NSX's engine is placed in the middle of the car behind the two-seat passenger compartment, which is unusual but not new. The engine derives much of its uncanny power from the four valves on each of the six cylinders, rather than the more common two. The additional valves allow more air in and out of the combustion chambers where the fuel ignites, resulting in more power. **********This multivalve technology, found on most Japanese-made cars, normally requires a small sacrifice in power when the engine is operating at low speeds or starting to move from a standing stop. **********To overcome that effect, Honda developed special electromechanical valve controls that enable the NSX to accelerate from 0 to 60 miles an hour in less than six seconds, a rare feat. The Nissan Infiniti Q45 luxury sedan is the only other car available in the United States to offer similar technology. **********Relentless efforts to cut the size of components to make them fit in the compact NSX left a comparatively large amount of elbow and leg room for driver and passenger and good visibility in all directions - features not found in similar cars. **********Honda's Sales Goal **********If the three new Acura models are as successful as the current two, they will probably vault Honda well past the Chrysler Corporation as the nation's third-best selling car company, after the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company. **********''If this puts us ahead of Chrysler, then it does,'' said Thomas Elliott, executive vice president of Honda's American sales organization. ''Frankly, our goal is to sell a million cars a year'' within the next five years. **********Currently, Honda and Acura sell about 840,000 cars a year; the auto maker was selling 552,000 cars in 1985, before the Acura was introduced. Meanwhile, Chrysler, which once sold about a million cars a year, has seen its sales slide to a level just slightly higher than Honda's. **********By itself, the NSX will have only a marginal effect on the American car market. Honda hopes to sell 3,000, just a drop in the sea of 14 million to 15 million vehicles of all kinds sold annually. **********So far this year, Japanese car brands have captured a 28.4 percent share of the American market, up from 24.3 percent a year earlier. **********Psychological Effect **********But the greatest effect of Honda's new sports car could be psychological. Honda is hoping that attention to the NSX will spill over Acura's entirely redesigned Legend sedan, scheduled to make its debut this fall, as well as a second new Acura sedan, equipped with a five-cylinder engine, that will be smaller than the Legend but larger than the sporty Integra compact. **********The expanded array of Acura vehicles is primarily aimed at customers of sporty European luxury cars like some Mercedes-Benz and BMW models, at current Honda owners and at owners of Toyota's Lexus and Nissan's Infiniti brands. **********Honda, whose racing engines have dominated the Formula One car racing circuit for several years, began developing the Acura NSX five years ago. The concept meshed with the auto maker's overall American marketing strategy, which was to create a separate line of sports luxury vehicles in 1986. In its first year, Acura sold 52,869 cars; last year that number had grown to 142,061, surpassing BMW, Mercedes-Benz and Volvo.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Norton Resisting Acquisition Offers

Advisers to Norton, which is resisting a takeover bid of $75 a share, or $1.64 billion, from BTR P.L.C., a British conglomerate, said the company was still holding talks with third parties interested in taking minority positions. **********A Federal district judge, meanwhile, appointed a monitor to attend Norton's annual meeting on Thursday, when three seats on the board will be contested. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/busin.main_headline: Profits Off at Shell and B. P.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/busin.print_headline: Profits Off at Shell and B. P.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/10/busin.body_text: **********The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today that its profit fell 44.3 percent in the second quarter and the British Petroleum Company reported a drop of 88.9 percent. **********Each cited weaker crude oil prices in the period that ended more than a month ago, before prices surged in reaction to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Royal Dutch/Shell said its results also reflected lower margins in its chemical division and the weakness of the dollar. **********Royal Dutch/Shell, which is based in the Hague, the Netherlands, and in London, said its net income for the three months ended June 30 fell to $:563 million, or $940 million, from $:1.01 billion a year earlier. Revenue rose 3.7 percent, to $:16.7 billion, or $27.9 billion, from $:16.1 billion a year earlier. **********The London-based B.P., which owns the Standard Oil Company, based in Cleveland, said its second-quarter net income fell to $:53 million, or $92 million, from $:477 million a year earlier. Its revenue fell 1.1. percent, to $:7.26 billion, or $12.2 billion, from $:7.34 billion a year earlier. **********The results for both companies are not directly comparable with those for American companies, since they use an accounting method that values inventories at their acquisition costs rather than at current costs. American companies generally use a method that values inventories at current value.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Michaels Stores Buyout Bid Ends
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/busin.body_text: **********The leveraged buyout of Michaels Stores Inc., an Irving, Tex., retail chain, by MSI Holdings has ended because of financing problems related to the weakening ''junk bond'' market, the company said. Michaels Stores said it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $3 million to $5 million to cover expenses. **********MSI Holdings Inc. was formed last year by Grauer & Wheat Inc., a private investment firm, and Arcadia Partners, an affiliate of the Robert M. Bass Group, to take the company private. The buyout was challenged by several shareholders in a class-action suit. Michaels fell 87.5 cents a share today, to $4.375, on the American Stock Exchange, where its 16.7 percent decline was the second-largest of the day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.main_headline: Arabs to Assail Israel on Soviet Jews
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.print_headline: Arabs to Assail Israel on Soviet Jews
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.body_text: **********Arab nations are planning a major diplomatic campaign to warn the world that the expected arrival of hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews in Israel over the next few years threatens to increase tension in the Middle East and reduce the chances of peace. **********The campaign, which may culminate in an appeal to the United Nations Security Council, seeks in particular to put international pressure on Israel not to allow the new Soviet immigrants to settle in the occupied territories, which Arab countries now regard as the occupied state of Palestine. **********In Tunis last Monday, Arab League foreign ministers decided to send a delegation to Washington this month to express their concerns directly to President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. **********The delegation, made up of the foreign ministers of Algeria, Syria, Iraq, Jordan and Saudi Arabia, will also visit Moscow and Dublin for talks. The Irish Government holds the rotating presidency of the European Community. **********Appeal to Security Council **********During those meetings, the Arab foreign ministers are to argue that increased Jewish immigration to Israel is likely to raise tensions, particularly if it swells the Israeli settlements in the occupied territories and encourages their annexation, Clovis Maksoud, the Arab League representative at the United Nations, said. **********The delegation is to also seek support for a possible appeal to the Security Council, asserting that a new influx of Soviet Jews could pose a threat to international peace and security. **********''This is an option we have and which we are considering,'' Ambassador Maksoud said in an interview. ''Our intention is to warn the world community that increased Soviet emigration to Israel will create an explosive situation and heighten tension in the occupied areas.'' **********Mr. Maksoud argued that most Soviet Jews will go to Israel only because they cannot get into the United States under a quota recently imposed by Washington. ''Why should Soviet Jews be forced to go to Israel against their preference while Palestinian refugees are denied the right to return to their homeland?'' he said. **********The Israeli Government has given conflicting signals about whether it intends to settle new Soviet immigrants in the occupied territories. **********On Jan. 30, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said the Government would not encourage them to live there, and Israeli officials assert that less than 1 percent of the new arrivals have chosen to do so. **********But only two weeks earlier, the Prime Minister stirred up a political storm by calling for a ''big'' Israel to accommodate ''a big immigration,'' remarks that many took as a call for annexation of the occupied territories.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/busin.main_headline: Chrysler Halts Plans To Make a Mini-Jeep
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Chrysler Halts Plans To Make a Mini-Jeep
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/busin.body_text: **********Amid a worsening economic climate and pressure on automotive producers worldwide, the Chrysler Corporation scrubbed plans today to produce a mini-Jeep for lack of a joint-venture partner. **********Chrysler had initially estimated that the entire project would cost $500 million. **********The No. 3 United States auto maker had first planned to build the vehicle -- code-named JJ for junior Jeep -- as a 50-50 venture with Renault, the French auto maker. But Renault backed out in June, saying the alliance "wasn't feasible." **********Chrysler tried to replace Renault with Fiat, the Italian auto maker, but talks leading toward a broad cooperative agreement, including joint production of a small Jeep, fell through earlier this month. **********Although the JJ was not envisioned as an important volume seller or money maker for Chrysler on the scale of its mini-van or Jeep Cherokee, the cancellation shows how auto makers' capital resources have been strained by soft sales worldwide. **********For Chrysler, the disappointment is another in a series that began when the company's performance turned downward in 1989. **********A prepared statement said that "while attractive as a joint venture, the JJ project as a stand-alone program required too great a commitment of resources that are needed for higher-priority product programs." **********For Chrysler's approximately 1,500 Jeep-Eagle dealers, the cancellation may be a bitter pill since they have been begging Chrysler for new Jeep models to make up for the weakness of the Eagle brand. **********Chrysler said it intended to maintain a "dominant position" in the market for larger sport utility vehicles and was "studying several alternatives to enhance the value of the Jeep franchise." **********Ray Scofield, sales manager of Buerge Jeep-Eagle in Los Angeles, suggested the best thing Chrysler could do would be to bring out the planned luxury Jeep model, code-named ZJ, as soon as possable. **********Chrysler's stock was unchanged today at $11.25 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/31/busin.body_text: **********Amid fear that war could break out in the Persian Gulf, about 600 foreign workers have resigned from Saudi Aramco, and many more are expected to leave, a Saudi executive of the company said today. **********But production by the giant state-owned oil company has not been affected, he said. The executive, who asked not to be named, said he believed the number of resignations ''may double or triple in the next three months, mainly because people will take time to find other jobs and sell their assets.'' **********Those who have resigned include 40 Americans. Many of the 12,000 foreigners working for Saudi Aramco sent their families home in the early days of the gulf crisis, company executives said. **********Among those planning to leave are 250 employees on loan from Exxon, Texaco, Chevron and Mobil. The American companies are affiliated with Saudi Aramco, which became wholly owned by the Saudi Government in 1988. **********The official said the company was trying to keep the employees by offering each $3,000 a month bonus,, free airline tickets and insurance benefits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Catalyst Selling Energy Unit Stake
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/17/busin.body_text: **********The Catalyst Energy Corporation, a privately owned power producer, hired Lehman Brothers to seek a buyer for its 83.5 percent stake in the United Thermal Corporation, a producer and distributor of steam and heat. Catalyst was taken private in a 1988 leveraged buyout led by Thomas B. Pickens 3d, the youngest son of T. Boone Pickens. **********The planned sale, disclosed yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, is expected to help the company raise some of the cash it owes the Bronfman family of Toronto for financing the 1988 buyout. United Thermal has only about 14.4 million shares outstanding, and the stock, which trades infrequently over-the-counter, was last traded at $1.75.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/05/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet Aide Rejects Notion That Military Opposes Gorbachev
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/05/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet Aide Rejects Notion That Military Opposes Gorbachev
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/05/world.body_text: **********A top aide to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev denied today that the Soviet leader faced a challenge from the military, but the aide condemned ''ultrarightists,'' who he said were working to destroy reform. **********The aide, Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, a member of the Communist Party Politburo, also said at a news conference that Moscow would be ready for talks with Lithuania if the Baltic republic's leaders froze their independence declaration. **********''We have no facts to suggest that the army is working in any way at all against perestroika or against the processes that are under way in our society,'' Mr. Yakovlev said. **********Denies Reports in West **********He added that Western reports in the last two days suggesting that elements in the military staged a show of force in February to press Mr. Gorbachev into policy changes had ''no basis.'' **********''There were no army movements, and no demands made on Gorbachev or on the Government,'' he said. **********But he said an anti-Gorbachev outburst by some marchers during Red Square demonstrations on May Day was organized by extreme hard-liners who wanted a return to ''slavelike obedience and subjugation of the people.'' **********Mr. Yakovlev confirmed that Mr. Gorbachev and other leaders left the Red Square reviewing stand because of the conduct of some marchers. **********''Yes, the leadership left the tribune and left it for political reasons, being very strongly in disagreement with the ultraright conservative positions being expressed by people who had come onto the square,'' he said. ''Of course, we should not overestimate the significance of such excesses. But we should not underestimate them or pretend not to notice.'' **********A Question of Pace **********The protest marchers in the May Day parade carried banners and shouted slogans suggesting that most believed that the pace of reforms was too slow. **********But Mr. Yakovlev, who was on the reviewing stand, asserted that slogans carried by marchers ''witness uncontestably that they came from ultraconservative forces and movements, from those who were more suited by the situation of arbitrariness, lawlessness and slavelike obedience'' of the past. **********''It is understandable that those forces are unhappy with perestroika,'' he said. ''They cannot hide their hatred for the democratic process, and are ready, judging by their slogans, for any form of violence.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/23/busin.body_text: **********The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that it was working with Soviet officials and economists to develop futures and options markets for the ruble. **********''As the Soviets dismantle their past economic system of rigid controls and move toward a market driven economy, it is imperative that their monetary unit become an accepted world currency,'' said Leo Melamed, executive committee chairman of the Merc, where trading of foreign currency futures had its inception in 1972. **********Mr. Melamed, considered a pioneer in currency futures, said he expected the exchange to begin trading in the ruble late in 1991. **********''The big question is how fast the Russians move to convertibility,'' he said. ''It hinges on that.'' **********Western economists say the ruble cannot become truly convertible to other currencies until the Soviet Union establishes a market pricing system for all its goods and allows free cross-border trade. **********They also say it is not possible to have a convertible currency in a controlled market. **********Also, the currency does not circulate outside the Soviet Union. Over the years, Soviet businesses wanting to trade with Western companies have had to trade rubles with the Soviet Government for Western currencies. While the situation has loosened somewhat in recent years, the rate of exchange is still set by Soviet officials.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/busin.main_headline: World Markets;   Will Tokyo's Slide Snowball?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/busin.print_headline: World Markets;   Will Tokyo's Slide Snowball?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/busin.body_text: **********It is becoming a regular reflex to check the Nikkei 225 - Tokyo's closely watched stock index - early in the evening in New York. Since the beginning of the year, it has been plunging with regularity and has helped bring down many other major markets. **********It seems fairly certain that if the declines continue in Tokyo they will continue elsewhere. But what is still open to debate is whether this Tokyo slide will be just a sharp correction or will snowball into a crash. **********One way to examine the question is to look at the bond market, whose sudden drop in Tokyo helped touch off the equity slump. Slumping bond markets elsewhere, including in Britain and France, are also contributing to the January chill in the markets. **********This is the third time since 1985 that a global bond market slump has been set off by a sudden and sharp jump in Japanese interest rates. **********The first time was in the fall of 1985, after the United States and its economic allies decided in the Plaza accord to force down the exchange value of the dollar, which was at record highs. In about four weeks, from mid-October to mid-November, interest rates on three-month yen deposits in Europe went from 6.5 percent to 8.12 percent while the yield on the 10-year Japanese Government bond, on a semi-annual compound basis, zipped up from 5.8 percent to 7.15 percent. **********The move to tighten by the Bank of Japan came when the dollar, after dropping initially after the Plaza accord was announced, began to rise against the yen. But in about a month, with the yen again gaining on the dollar, interest rates had fallen and the bond market reversed. And there was no significant decline in the stock market. **********The next jump in rates was, yes indeed, the one that preceded the October 1987 crash on Wall Street. It started in August, when the Bank of Japan was worried about inflation. Looking back, Nicholas Sargen, director of bond market research at Salomon Brothers, said there was no measurable sign of inflation in the price indexes. The Bank of Japan, however, focused on the rise in Japanese land prices and the ''speculative bubble in equities,'' in Mr. Sargen's words. Interest rates went from 3.94 percent to 4.95 percent on three-month yen deposits in Europe and from 4.44 percent to 7.16 percent on the 10-year Government bond from the end of August to Oct. 16. By the end of November, rates had fallen back to about where they had been, after the Bank of Japan eased up following the crash. **********The third rate jump began in the middle of last month with three-month yen deposits at 6.5 percent and the 10-year bond at 5.37 percent. By Friday, three-month deposits had risen to 7 percent while the 10-year bond was at 6.4 percent. There have been stronger signs of inflation now than in 1987, although it may be subsiding a bit. Mr. Sargen again believes that the Bank of Japan has based its tightening move on rising land prices and the high stock prices in Tokyo. The bank's aim, he said, is to curb ''future inflation.'' In addition, the central bank is worried about the very weak yen, which was the problem in 1985. **********The unknown is how long it will take for this rate increase to unwind and how much damage will be done to stocks in the interim. **********Mr. Sargen said that the big difference between this episode and the one in 1987 is that there is not - at least now - international disagreement over policy, as there was among the United States, Japan and West Germany in the year of the crash. **********Still, Mr. Sargen said it could be April or later before the Bank of Japan sees enough reassuring numbers on inflation to cause it to let interest rates come down some. And the weak yen could even prompt another ratcheting up in interest rates. **********This means the pressure on the stock market could last much longer and the cumulative impact - both in Tokyo and abroad - could be significant. **********The Nikkei is now at 36,836.54, having posted a rise Friday for the first time in five trading days. While the Nikkei 225 is down 5.3 percent for the year, Friday's level still implies that investors expect the interest rate jump to unwind quickly, limiting damage to the stock market. But if interest rates remain at this level for some time, the risk is that the Nikkei could fall much more.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/22/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;   The Bundesbank's Partial Success
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/22/busin.body_text: **********With its aggressive strategy to strengthen the mark, the Bundesbank of West Germany has shown again why it is considered the most skilled of the West's central banks and a primary player in the economic future of Europe. But not everything has gone according to plan. **********The mark now stands at its highest level against the dollar in almost two years, thanks to the Bundesbank's interest rate increases all last year, capped by a 1 percent rise in October, and the central bank's surprising dollar-selling two weeks ago, an action that helped send the dollar down by more than four pfennigs. On Friday, the dollar fell to 1.7105 marks, from 1.7150 marks the previous day. **********But the Bundesbank has failed so far in its central goal: strengthening the mark against other major European currencies. Even the Italian lira, which was devalued earlier this month, was down by less than 1 percent against the mark last week, and the French franc has appreciated. **********And the central bank's unexpected intervention the first week of the year may have backfired somewhat by being more disruptive than anticipated, analysts say. **********Keeping the Pressure **********Bundesbank officials have made it clear that they intend to keep the pressure on West Germany's European trading partners to devalue their currencies or to slow their economic growth by raising interest rates to maintain parity with the mark. Either move would help the West Germans shrink their record trade surplus with Europe. **********The Bundesbank could also still move to raise interest rates another notch if it concluded that this would be useful in a parallel effort to curb the wage increases that will come out of the crucial labor negotiations with metal workers next month. **********For the dollar, this strategy means even more downward pressure will be coming, against the mark and other European currencies. This could add to inflation in the United States, as imports become more expensive. And if the stronger mark, along with the promise of the economic opening of Eastern Europe, continues to divert foreign capital from the United States to West Germany and Europe, interest rates here could rise. **********'Uncooperative Policy' **********Some of the analysts contend the Bundesbank is being self-centered, refusing to account for the effect of its policy on the dollar, the United States, Japan and other economies, the European Monetary System or the goal of a single market in Europe. **********''From an international point of view, it is a very uncooperative policy,'' said David Morrison, the chief international economist at Goldman,Sachs & Company in London. ''The Bundesbank decided to do what they wanted to, and the rest could lump it.'' **********But other analysts are less worried. They contend that for now, the strategy is helping the United States, whose Treasury has favored a weaker dollar to help lower the American trade deficit by making imports more expensive and exports more competitive. Norbert Walter, the senior economist at Deutsche Bank A.G. in Frankfurt, said, ''I haven't seen much complaint about the Bundesbank moves.'' **********The Bundesbank strategy is no secret. The central bank's president, Karl Otto Pohl, and members of the Bundesbank board have said they want the mark to be stronger. **********Opening of Borders **********In this effort they have been helped by the opening of Eastern Europe, which has lured investment to West Germany and helped strengthen the currency. The Bundesbank also took advantage of the lowering of interest rates in the United States and the resulting downward pressure on the dollar. **********One reason for a stronger mark is the desire of West Germany to make its exports more expensive and thus reduce the trade surplus with its European trading partners. The surplus is growing annually and adding to global trade tensions. **********A second reason is the Bundesbank's anti-inflation fight. A stronger mark, in this case against the dollar, makes many of the countries' imports, which are priced in dollars, less expensive. **********And another reason is the critical labor talks ahead between industry and the 3.5 million metal workers represented by IG Metall. A new increase in interest rates would give a signal to industry that a generous contract will be more difficult to offset with profits because the economy will not be growing as fast. **********Realigning the System **********The Bundesbank contends that the best way to achieve its strategy is through realigning the European Monetary System, which could be forced by a strengthening mark. Such an adjustment would devalue the other currencies in the system, including the French franc. **********But the Bundesbank has been frustrated in this goal because its trading partners, especially France, and members of the West German Government do not want a realignment. The French Government has been willing to push up interest rates along with the West Germans, keeping the franc in line with the mark and slowing the French economy to maintain its anti-inflation policy. **********The West German Government does not like the idea of a realignment now because it could slow the movement toward monetary union and the fixed exchange rates that are possible after the economic unification of Europe begins in late 1992. **********''A realignment of the E.M.S. is not on the agenda because the major players do not want it,'' Mr. Pohl acknowledged recently. **********Higher Interest Rates **********The next best alternative is to maintain pressure by raising interest rates and keeping the mark strong. When countries like France then follow by raising their rates, their economies will be slowed. With slower growth, the West German surplus could be curbed because fewer exports will be bought abroad. **********The startling selling of dollars on Jan. 4 was also an effort to keep the mark strong by heading off the rapid appreciation of the dollar on Jan. 2 and 3 and by dampening the idea that the dollar would stage a January rally like it did in 1989. The dollar had risen to 1.7350 marks on Jan. 4, from 1.6910 marks at the end of last year. **********The intervention came as the dollar was around 1.73 marks, well within the range of 1.70 marks to 1.90 marks believed to be set by the Group of Seven, which includes the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada. This intervention is what made the move to push the dollar lower so surprising and raised questions about whether the Group of Seven was setting a new lower range for the dollar. **********More Effect on Market **********John Lipsky, the director of international bond research at Salomon Brothers Inc. in London, said the Bundesbank probably was trying to make sure the market did not think it was acquiescing in a higher dollar, and therefore, a weaker mark. **********He said the bank's selling had much more effect on the market than intended because it coincided with large orders to sell dollars, which led to frenzied selling that pushed down the dollar to 1.6785 marks in late trading in New York on Jan 4, from 1.7224 marks on Jan. 3. **********The sharp fall caused confusion in the market and more volatility than the Bundesbank would have wanted. **********''When the Bundesbank intervened, people felt that it made sense,'' said one official who understands the bank's strategy. ''But you never know the reaction of the market. And, maybe if the Bundesbank had known how the market would react, the position might have been different.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/busin.main_headline: G.M. to Begin Production Of a Battery-Powered Car
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/busin.print_headline: G.M. to Begin Production Of a Battery-Powered Car
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/busin.body_text: **********Responding to concerns about poor air quality, the General Motors Corporation announced today that it would proceed with commercial production of a battery-powered electric car for personal use. **********Despite the announcement, the project seemed to remain somewhat speculative. G.M. acknowledged that a number of technical, regulatory and market uncertainties had not been cleared up. Indeed, G.M. cited competitive reasons for declining to answer the most critical questions about when or where it would begin production of the car and what technology would be used. **********G.M. had displayed a battery-powered car called the Impact in January and said it would decide on the commercial feasibility of the vehicle within a few months. The Impact would be the basis for the car that G.M. said it would produce. **********Timely Announcement **********The announcement that the company planned to begin production was made by Roger B. Smith, the chairman of G.M., at the National Press Club in Washington. The announcement came less than a week before Earth Day and at a time when Congress is considering broad clean-air legislation that could force auto makers to put new pollution controls on their vehicles. **********A spokesman said later that the company had not established a definite date and place for the start of production. **********Mr. Smith said G.M.'s goal was to be ''the first automobile company since the early days of the auto industry to mass-produce an electric car'' that is safe, performs well and that consumers find appealing. **********''What that means is that the Impact is suitable for most urban drivers' daily activities,'' he added. **********G.M. has said the car will accelerate from standstill to 60 miles an hour in eight seconds and run for 125 miles before its battery needs recharging. The Big Three and some foreign auto makers have also been testing battery-powered vans. **********Support for Zero Emissions **********Mr. Smith said that public and governmental reaction to the Impact has been positive since G.M. began displaying a prototype at auto shows in Los Angeles, Chicago and Geneva. ''People are concerned about the range of the car, but they're also very much impressed by the fact that Impact produces zero emissions,'' he said. **********In the late 1970's, at the height of the energy crisis, G.M. said it would be building 100,000 battery-powered cars a year by 1984, a plan that was abandoned for lack of interest by the public, a company spokesman said. **********Mr. Smith said the technology had improved, ''so it's possible to do this with a fresh design.'' **********G.M. is seeking changes in Federal regulations to make production of the car more feasible, Mr. Smith said. Although he was not specific, he said that current safety standards were meant for the size and weight of internal combustion cars. **********G.M. will also lobby the Government for electric cars to be counted in the calculation of corporate average fuel economy, he said. **********The Battery Problem **********But the biggest question is about the vehicle's power source, its battery. Scientists who worked on the Impact prototype noted that it used conventional lead-acid batteries, which emit relatively little power and must be replaced each year at considerable expense. **********Noting that the battery ''is such an essential piece of the final picture,'' Mr. Smith said developing one for commercial production might require ''a broad-based development effort, one that involves not only the entire domestic auto industry and the Government, but the electric utility industry as well.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/18/world.main_headline: India Hopes Its Red Cross Can Unload Ship
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/18/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   India Hopes Its Red Cross Can Unload Ship
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/18/world.body_text: **********As an Indian ship loaded with food headed across the Arabian Sea toward the Persian Gulf, Prime Minister V. P. Singh said today that he hoped a delegation from the Indian Red Cross aboard the ship would be allowed to supervise unloading of the food for Indians in Iraq or Kuwait. **********The ship, which left the port of Cochin on Sunday, is expected to arrive at a port in Kuwait or Iraq in about six days. The Prime Minister said he hoped the Red Cross delegation would meet the United Nations definition of an international aid organization for purposes of unloading. **********The ship is regarded here as a test case under a United Nations Security Council decision allowing humanitarian aid to enter Iraq if the aid is unloaded under the supervision of an international organization. **********The 9,745 tons of food aboard the Indian ship, the Vishwa Siddhi, is intended primarily for Indian citizens stranded in Iraq and Kuwait.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/22/busin.body_text: **********The rating of debt securities issued by the News Corporation Ltd. has been lowered, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday. The rating change affects about $1.7 billion (United States) in securities issued by the Australian media company controlled by Rupert Murdoch. **********Moody's said its action stemmed from a weakening in the media and entertainment businesses in general. **********The rating agency said News Corporation's aggressive expansion in the late 1980's, financed by borrowed money, was based on ready access to worldwide financial markets and the ability to quickly sell media assets when their market values were rising. Moody's said that because these conditions had changed, the company's financial flexibility had been hampered and its protections for debt holders had become strained. **********Moody's said it expected that declining operating margins in the media and entertainment industries would put pressure on the company's earnings over the intermediate term. **********The rating of the company's senior debt was lowered to B-1, from Ba-2, and that of the subordinated debt to B-3, from Ba- 3.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/15/busin.body_text: **********Prices of long-term Treasury securities tumbled yesterday, while the shorter maturities held firm. **********Dealers said prices of the longer issues were eroded by the Middle East crisis, the rising price of oil and its potential impact on inflation, the bane of the fixed-income market. **********One result was that the yield on the Treasury's benchmark long bonds again surged higher than 9 percent, a level considered by many economists in and out of Government as hobbling an already weak economy. But dealers also noted that rising Treasury yields were helping make the Government's debt issues competitive with Japanese and West German bonds. **********Yield Rises to 9.01 Percent **********Late in the session, the long bonds were being offered at 97 8/32, down 19/32 on the day. This caused the yield to climb to 9.01 percent, from 8.94 percent the day before and 8.90 percent a week ago. **********The economic statistics released by the Government were in line with market expectations and was thus largely ignored by traders. **********''There wasn't much retail business or trading for that matter,'' said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Inc. ''Traders and speculators who were long the market in expectation that this was the Friday when the Fed would start easing credit were again disappointed and spent much of the afternoon hedging their positions with short selling.'' **********As for the August Producer Price Index and other economic data, Mr. Ricchiuto said that ''the numbers offered no surprises and only served to confirm what the Street knew, that the economy continues to soften.'' **********But the economic data did serve to shore up the shorter Treasury debt issues. If the weakening economy does indeed prompt the Fed to ease credit, prices of bills and short-term notes would be the most immediately and beneficially affected by any decline in interest rates. **********The 90-day bills were unchanged at 7.36 percent, as were the six-month bills at 7.27 percent, while investors seeking to lock in longer rates caused the one-year bills to rise by two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, at 7.21 percent. **********Also closely watched are the Treasury's long notes, the 8.75's of August 2000, because their yields are compared with those on Japanese and German issues of similar maturities. The long notes fell 12/32, to 99 8/32, for a yield of 8.86 percent, compared with 8.78 percent a week ago. **********By comparison, the yield on the Japanese 10-year bonds, their longest maturity, climbed to 8.42 percent from 8.25 percent a week ago, while that on the German 10-year long bonds rose to 9.02 percent from 8.99 percent. **********But the shorter Treasury notes held relatively firm. The 8 1/8's of 1992 dipped 1/32, to 100 6/32, to yield 8.01 percent, while the 8 1/2's of 1995 fell by 5/32, to 100 1/32, for a yield of 8.48 percent. **********William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds and a credit market specialist, said that although the key Federal funds rate showed an easing to 7.75 percent from 7 15/16 percent, it did not reflect any change in Fed policy. Rather, the drop in the rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans was probably caused by an excessive infusion of reserves by the Fed on Thursday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/26/world.body_text: **********It was a typical day's Babel of self-determination in the Soviet Union. **********The Moldavian Republic was distracted from its own anti-Moscow separatist plans to face the determined rebellion of one of its parts, the Gagauz minority, who were beginning ad hoc independence elections. **********The rarely noticed Chuvash Autonomous Republic was claiming sovereignty over its own natural resources within the Russian Republic. Members of Russia's insurgent Parliament, themselves so frustrated by the centrifugal disarray of life, were musing on the question of outright secession. **********The even less noticed Mari Autonomous Republic was following up its own proud declaration of sovereignty, demanding control over its rivers and mines and announcing three official languages: Lowland Mari, Highland Mari and Russian.  Stop Signs in Byelorussia **********The Byelorussian Republic was using its highway policemen as internal customs guards, stopping motorists from Lithuania and other neighboring republics used to shopping in local stores for food and other basic needs. **********The Tyumen Oblast, a large oil region in the Russian Republic, hurriedly appointed a study commission to deal with its own fractious components: the Yamal-Nenets district, which has suddenly dubbed itself a full republic, and the Khanty-Mansi district, which is seriously thinking about it. **********Even the greatly revived Russian Orthodox Church, opening an assembly of its hierarchy, had high on its debating list the Ukrainian Orthodox Church's insistence on self-government. **********The nation's daily agenda of group and subgroup rebellion is so crowded lately that it is hard to get a contumacious word in edgewise, according to the private complaint of one official of the Lithuanian Republic, which has been kept waiting since March for the denouement of its dramatic declaration of independence. **********"We must not panic," President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was shown declaring tonight on television, speaking of the general situation in the nation as he tried to rally the demoralized trade union leadership, the Communist tentacle no longer trusted by ordinary workers, who are planning tougher unions.  The Army Looks Back **********The Soviet Army, attending to that earlier rebellion, announced that it was going ahead with the Nov. 7 parades celebrating the Bolshevik Revolution even though insurgent city governments are opposed and students are threatening sit-ins. "I can not understand the desire of certain people to forget their past," complained Lieut. Gen. Anatoly Golovnev. **********He was swimming against a tide of popular indifference and resentment, which might have eased some tonight with the Government's announcement that a big soccer playoff game would be inaugurated Nov. 7. **********In Kiev, the leaders of Rukh, the Ukrainian nationalist movement, opened a meeting to decide whether these anarchic times finally require naked endorsement of the ultimate goal, the Ukraine's full departure from the Soviet Union. **********Things were routinely tense in the ethnic enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh, where the one new twist was that police investigators looking into the endless Armenian-Azerbaijani fighting were kidnapped. **********Hopeful new commercial bankers in Russia who had just gone through the registration paperwork with the Soviet Union Government received notice from the central Russian Republic bank that this was all invalid and they should re-register with the rival Russian bank to be safe.  Moldavians on the Move **********Fresh formulations of despair were being fashioned by those politicians not already out of the country on the many new junkets to Western research institutes, where distant experts try to stay insightful about chaos. It is unclear whether these now frequent seminar absences of so many talkative politicians is encouraging in affording time for them to actually go off and think of something new, or discouraging in suggesting that those who pay closest attention feel the itch to travel. **********The current state of the union has become "inadmissable for a civilized society," according to the latest agenda preamble adopted by the politicians of the Russian Republic Parliament. A "government of national trust" can save this place, the politicians contended in the day's typical ream of warnings and hopes. **********As the Gagauz minority offered the Moldavian Government a taste of its own feistiness and reached for self-determination, vigilante busloads of Moldavian patriots were reported on the road toward the Gagauz polls in southern Moldavia. They acted under a new Moldavian law to "stabilize the socio-politico atmosphere" with citizen volunteers, some of whom were shouting, "Moldavians to arms!" **********The tension was a distraction from Moldavia's corollary problem with the newly declared Trans-Dniesterian Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic, another swatch of the vast Soviet Union with long simmering grievances about identity and prerogatives. **********By the end of this long but typical day of variations on the theme of self-determination, the Kazakhstan Parliament, not being left behind, joined other republics in declaring its sovereignty as taking precedence over all others, from the airspace above to the flora and fauna below.

The Executive Life;
When Politics and Profits Just Don't Mix
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/04/busin.print_headline:
The Executive Life;
When Politics and Profits Just Don't Mix
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/04/busin.body_text: **********TIANANMEN Square. The mere mention of Beijing's biggest public plaza brings back horrific memories of the bloody student uprising that was staged there last year and then quashed by the Chinese Government. Relations between the United States and China have since chilled considerably, and Congress has sought to show its disapproval of the Communist Government's violent crackdown through various diplomatic sanctions. **********But American executives have not seemed as inclined to back off from China. I.B.M., Exxon and Mobil Oil are just three of the big American corporations with operations in China, and there are scores of trading companies that do business there. **********"Obviously, we don't do business with a country if the United States has imposed a ban on trade, as with North Vietnam or Cuba," explained Arno Schallamach, senior vice president of the Commodities Trading International Corporation, an import-export company in Greenwich, Conn. "But beyond that, the reality of the world of business is that the issue of politics never enters into discussions." **********So it was that on a recent stormy evening on Manhattan's West Side, dozens of American business men and women happily sipped cocktails and munched snacks in the lobby of the Chinese Consulate. They had gathered for a contract-signing ceremony marking the Chinese Government's recent $24 million purchase of fertilizer from Commodities Trading -- one of several functions that China is quietly holding in the coming weeks for its American partners as it completes a trade mission here for some $300 million worth of United States products. **********"This is a way to get around the U.S. Government's policy of no high-level contact with China," noted Kathryn Wei, a Chinese-born American who is the chief executive of the Falcon Shipping Group, a shipping company in New York. "This is a business reception; we don't want politics here." **********To many executives, a country's human rights record or political persuasion is virtually irrelevant in deciding whether to strike a deal. "Businessmen are apolitical," said another partygoer, E. S. Finley, chief executive of the International Commodities Export Corporation of Purchase, N.Y. "A businessman cannot tell the world how to act and so will discount any personal attitude he has. Of course, there is a limit. When a situation becomes so outrageous, as with Iraq, even a trading company would shy away from it even without an embargo." **********Of course, industrial companies run a greater risk of having their products boycotted when consumers disagree with their business practices and may act to stave off opposition even before it surfaces. Coca-Cola, for instance, was one of the early American enterprises to pull out of South Africa because of apartheid, leaving in 1986 before consumer activism peaked. "The decision was a statement of our opposition to apartheid and of our support for the economic future of blacks," said a spokesman. **********At the Chinese Consulate, an enormous embroidered mural of the Chinese Temple of Heaven is the only noteworthy adornment in an otherwise drab setting. Located in a neighborhood known for its cheap, open-air parking lots, the building, at 12th Avenue and 42d Street, was formerly a Howard Johnson Motor Lodge. With linoleum floors, fluorescent lighting and mint-green walls, its reception area seems more fitting for a big-city bus station than a foreign legation. **********"This building was bought in the 1970's, when President Nixon was friendly with the Chinese Government," Ms. Wei said. "Now, the Chinese Government isn't allowed to buy any buildings in the U.S.; so they can't move to a nicer place." **********The style of entertainment at the consulate is similarly unimpressive, particularly compared with the distinguished affairs held for executives in the lavishly decorated European embassies across town. In keeping with the spartan atmosphere, cocktails were served in disposable cups at the reception. Hors d'oeuvres were eschewed in favor of an enormous buffet of Chinese dishes, all served on paper plates with plastic forks. **********But a utilitarian entertaining style belies the spending might of these Chinese hosts. "The Chinese have been customers of ours for years," said Sameer Zahr, chief executive of Commodities Trading International. "They are a great, great trading partner." Mr. Zahr, who had just signed the $24 million fertilizer contract with the Chinese, was sweating under the lights of the roving television cameras focused on him. Chinese cable television had sent a film crew to record the great event for later broadcast. **********As far as Mr. Zahr is concerned, Tiananmen Square was a non-event. "We have never had any problems with the Chinese," he said firmly. "They are extremely efficient and honorable. At the time of the student uprising, I had $10 million in exports yet to be shipped to the Chinese." Despite the disruption of the government, he said, China honored the entire order. **********Robert Lavinia, president of Phibro Refining Inc., an oil refining company, agreed. "I've actually played basketball with some other people in Tiananmen Square since the trouble there," he said. **********A bigger problem for many of them is language. Although younger Chinese are increasingly fluent in English, the more senior, older executives and officials are not, so the simplest discussion can turn into a protracted interchange. Witness one American executive bidding goodbye to his Chinese partner.  "Let's by all means stay in touch," said the American jovially. At his partner's uncomprehending look, he repeated loudly, "In touch. You know," he said even more loudly, "IN TOUCH!"

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/busin.body_text: **********Merck & Company and Medi-Cal, the California Medicaid program, said yesterday that they had agreed on Merck's offer to supply prescription drugs at discount prices. **********Under the Merck program, which breaks with the pharmaceutical industry policy of refusing discounts in the $3.5 billion Federal-state Medicaid drug program for the poor, Medi-Cal will lift current restrictions against four Merck products. **********Merck will pay Medi-Cal about $2.8 million in quarterly rebates in the first year to reduce the price of all Merck products, matching its lowest discounts, to Federal military and veterans hospitals. Merck's Federal discounts are 7 to 13 percent, depending on the product. **********John L. Zabriskie, president of Merck Sharp & Dohme, the Rahway, N.J., company's American drug manufacturing unit, said Merck had also signed discount agreements with Medicaid programs in South Carolina and Utah. He said ''agreements in principle'' had been made with 10 other Medicaid programs in Arkansas, Connecticut, Delaware, the District of Columbia, Florida, Georgia, Maryland, North Carolina, Oregon and Texas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/world.main_headline: U.S. Views Threat by Iraq As Strategy to Split Critics
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   U.S. Views Threat by Iraq As Strategy to Split Critics
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/world.body_text: **********Bush Administration officials said today that Saddam Hussein's threat Sunday to attack Israel and Saudi Arabian oilfields if trade sanctions ''strangled'' Iraq's economy appears to be part of Baghdad's continuing political strategy to split the international coalition opposing Iraq. **********But they said that discounting the tone of comments as merely threatening bravado would be a repetition of a mistake the Administration made in July, before Iraq invaded Kuwait, when it underestimated the Iraqi President's willingness to take military action. **********''It's a deliberate step in his plan to keep what he's got and drive our coalition apart,'' said one Pentagon official. ''At the same time, we're not sloughing this off. He has the capability to do these things.'' **********By invoking fears of an attack on Israel and projecting images of oilfields burning out of control to send oil prices soaring and plunging Western economies deeply into recession, the Iraqi leader was trying to make the costs of war sound so horrific as to discourage any attack against Baghdad, officials explained. **********'A Daily Diatribe' **********While the officials acknowledged the statements marked an escalation in Mr. Hussein's bellicose oratory, they took pains to note that the threats were conveyed within an established context of intimidating public displays and comments emanating from Baghdad. ''We get a daily diatribe from Saddam, and this is another one of them,'' said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater. **********Iraq announced Sunday that Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz was canceling a visit to New York to attend the United Nations General Assembly because the United States would not permit his Iraqi airliner to land. **********State Department officials said the Mr. Aziz could take a commercial flight to New York, but that no Iraqi government plane would be allowed to land while Baghdad held hostage the 1,000 Americans remaining in Iraq and occupied Kuwait. **********President Bush today reiterated the Administration's position against any negotiations with Baghdad until Iraq abided by the United Nations sanctions, and withdrew its forces from Kuwait. **********In doing so, Mr. Bush noted the lack of success that Arab leaders, including Jordan's King Hussein, have had in brokering a settlement. **********''Whoever else has stepped up to the plate, they have struck out because of this man's insistence on remaining in Kuwait,'' Mr. Bush told a group of leaders from the Arab-American community at the White House. **********Pressures on Jordan **********Earlier in the day, Mr. Fitzwater's comments about King Hussein were even more pointed. When asked about the king's call for the removal of American troops from Saudi Arabia, Mr. Fitzwater said that the Jordanian monarch ''has some difficult pressures on him, but nevertheless, we are disappointed in the conduct of that country at this point.'' **********When pressed by the Arab-American group to explain the objective of American involvement in the Gulf, President Bush said it was to thwart hostile aggression: ''Iraq is no model of democracy, nor was Kuwait. That isn't the question here. The question is international law and respect for one's neighbor.'' **********For Government officials and Middle East scholars who have been trying to weigh Mr. Hussein's real intentions, his increasingly threatening comments in recent days recalled the days just before the invasion of Kuwait, when the Iraqi leader's ominous rhetoric was discounted in Washington as well as European and Arab capitals. **********Although Iraqi forces are currently arrayed in a defensive posture along the Saudi border, military experts said an Iraqi rocket attack against Israel or Saudi oilfields would not require extensive preparation. **********Administration officials said they were discouraged that Mr. Hussein has so far shown no sign of seeking a way out of the crisis. If anything, they said, his dismemberment of Kuwait, including a decision enacted today to replace the Kuwaiti currency with the Iraqi dinar, suggested a commitment to remain as an occupying power. **********Today brought no change in the tone or substance of Mr. Hussein's warnings. **********''Kuwait is Iraqi and we won't give it up even if we fight over it for a thousand years,'' Baghdad radio quoted Mr. Hussein as saying today. **********Israeli Reaction **********JERUSALEM, Sept. 24 (Special to The New York Times) - Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir warned today that Israel stood ready to ''repay'' any attack by Iraq. **********Responding to the most bellicose statement yet from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Israeli officials sought to keep the low profile requested by the United States. But all used almost the same words, saying they took the threat seriously. **********''We of course, are taking his threats seriously and preparing for them,'' Mr. Shamir told Israel radio this evening, ''to anticipate, prevent and, God forbid, if he'll really attack, to repay him.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/world.main_headline: Lebanon Faction Claims Attack on Israeli Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/world.print_headline: Lebanon Faction Claims Attack on Israeli Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/world.body_text: **********An Islamic fundamentalist movement based in Lebanon took responsibility today for the assault on a tour bus carrying Israelis in Egypt, the worst terrorist attack here in years. The group, part of the coalition of extremist factions known as Islamic Holy War, said the killings on Sunday were meant to show opposition to Mideast peace efforts and to the tide of Soviet Jews entering Israel. **********The claim of responsibility was the second one in the attack. Just after the killings, a man saying he represented a previously unheard-of Egyptian group phoned an international news agency to take responsibility for the raid. The claim from the group, the Organization for the Defense of the Oppressed of Egypt's Prisons, met with skepticism. **********The assault sent tremors of rage and bewilderment across Egypt today, and raised questions about the country's ability to broker peace, to attract the tourism that brings in vital hard currency and to counter attacks on Israelis on the bus route to Cairo. **********Getaway Car Is Traced **********The state-owned Middle East News Agency quoted the Egyptian police today as saying a Palestinian believed to be one of the attackers was arrested. The agency said the suspect arrived in Egypt two weeks ago with other members of the attack squad, but it did not elaborate. **********An Interior Ministry spokesman who discussed the investigation said he was unable to confirm reports that the driver of the getaway car, said to be a Palestinian living in Egypt, had been arrested. **********The Egyptian police said today that they had traced the killers' getaway car to a rental company and had rounded up what an Interior Ministry spokesman said was hundreds of people for questioning. **********The faction of Islamic Holy War broadcast its claim over a Syrian radio station used by an organization that Western specialists have associated with some of the worst terrorist attacks of recent years, including the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988. **********Tonight, the radio station, used by Ahmed Jabril's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command, broadcast a message said to have been recorded by one of the gunmen. It said: ''I say to the Zionists, Kill one of us and we will kill 1,000. We will follow you to the moon. You will not escape even if you go to the moon.'' **********Roadblocks and Searches **********The speaker, who was not identifed by name, spoke Arabic with a Palestinian accent. It was not clear when the recording was made. **********The Egyptian authorities ordered roadblocks and car searches in several parts of the country, and briefly detained three men carrying Saudi passports on suspicion of involvement in the raid. The men were freed after six hours of interrogation, the police said. **********By the account of Egyptian and Israeli officials, two masked gunmen driving a white car swerved in front of a bus carrying 31 Israeli tourists, many of them academics with their families, as it headed to Cairo from Rafa, on Egypt's border with the occupied Gaza Strip. The attackers told two Egyptians, a tour guide and the driver, to get off, then opened fire with automatic rifles and grenades, Israeli officials said, quoting accounts by survivors. **********Worried about the impact of the attack on diplomacy, Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid of Egypt called the killing ''an attempt to place obstacles before the peace process, which is proceeding with relative success.'' **********Many Israeli Tourists **********''Egypt is determined to pursue the path of peace because this is the only one that can lead to stability in the region,'' he said, echoing sentiments by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. **********Egypt is the only Arab country at peace with Israel and has been a venue for Israeli tourists since the Camp David peace treaty was signed in 1979. More than 100,000 Israelis visited Egypt last year, Israeli officials said, and israelis had come to regard Egypt as a safe destination despite the lack of security along bus routes. **********Tour operators in Egypt said today that they had not detected a panicky exodus by Israelis visiting Egypt or major cancellations of projected tours. But the attack left some Israelis feeling nervous and uneasy. ''We would all like to leave,'' an Israeli diplomat said. **********The police were reported to have mounted extra security in Maadi, the southern suburb where many Israeli and American diplomats live. **********Early today, the police said they had found the abandoned car used by the assailants in a village in the Nile Delta 12 miles north of Cairo. The car was traced to a rental company here whose personnel told police investigators that they rented it nine days ago to a man carrying a Jordanian passport, company officials said. **********Careful Planning Seen **********The officials, who declined to be identified, said the man who rented the car paid cash for a 10-day rental. They would not give his name. **********Western diplomats said the attack seemed marked by the kind of careful planning that has not been associated with Egyptian extremists since a group called Egypt's Revolution was broken up after attacks on Israeli and American officials in the mid-1980's. **********In Damascus, a radio station used by pro-Syrian Palestinian movements said the attack was ''a reply to the steps of capitulation being prepared.'' **********The radio station was apparently referring to the newest American effort to bring together the Foreign Ministers of Egypt and Israel for talks that would lead to Palestinian-Israeli negotiations on the the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, where a Palestinian uprising has been under way for more than two years. **********'Countries of Death' **********The broadcast identified the assailants as the Al-Suri Martyr Unit, from what was called the Martyrdom Lovers' Battalion, associated with Islamic Jihad. The communique warned Soviet Jews planning to emigrate to Israel, ''The Islamic Jihad is waiting for you.'' The Jews were heading ''not for lands of milk and honey'' but for ''countries of death for invaders,'' the broadcast said. **********The Palestine Liberation Organization formally distanced itself from the assault. Sayed Kamal, the P.L.O. representative here, said the organization remained committed to a 1985 declaration forswearing guerrilla actions outside Israel and the occupied territories. **********''As a matter of principle and strategy, the P.L.O. is opposed to any infringement of Egypt's security and sovereignty,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/09/busin.main_headline: New York Times Company Reports 4th-Quarter Loss
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/09/busin.print_headline: New York Times Company Reports 4th-Quarter Loss
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/09/busin.body_text: **********The New York Times Company yesterday reported a loss of $19 million in the fourth quarter, compared with net income of $50.4 million, or 64 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988. **********Revenues in the quarter rose 4.5 percent, to $470.2 million, from $450 million a year earlier. **********For all of 1989, net income rose 29.2 percent, to a record $266.6 million, or $3.39 a share, compared with $167.7 million, or $2.08 a share, in 1988.
