The earnings included an after-tax gain of $193.3 million, or $2.46 a share, from the sale of the company's cable television system in August. **********Revenues rose 4.1 percent, to $1.77 billion from $1.7 billion. **********The company's continuing operations, which include newspapers, magazines, broadcasting and information services and forest products, produced a loss of $19 million in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a profit of $48.5 million a year earlier. For the year, income from these operations declined 57.6 percent, to $68.2 million, or 87 cents a share, from $161 million, or $2 a share, in 1988. **********In Line With Expectations **********That was in line with estimates by the company and industry analysts. Times stock closed yesterday at $24.375, unchanged, in trading on the American Stock Exchange. **********The company said the decline in its operations for the quarter and the year was primarily attributable to the weakness of the New York region's economy, which affected advertising linage at The New York Times. **********The company said income from continuing operations was also reduced by three factors: *********** A charge of 57 cents a share in the fourth quarter that reflected the reduced value of the company's investment in the Forest Products Group, as well as for some costs associated with voluntary staff reductions at The New York Times. *********** A reduction of 11 cents a share in the fourth quarter and 18 cents a share for the year resulting from organizatonal changes after the acquisitions of McCall's, Golf World (U.S.) and Sailing World magazines. *********** A charge of 3 cents a share in the fourth quarter resulting from a settlement of litigation involving home delivery dealers. **********Were it not for those factors, the company said, earnings from continuing operations would have been 47 cents a share in the fourth quarter and $1.65 a share for 1989. **********John Reidy, a media analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said: ''The earnings were in line with expectations. They promised us some write-offs in December. Like other papers in the Northeast, retail advertising remains in a slump, and now the help-wanted area of the classified part of the business is in trouble.'' **********Chairman's Outlook **********Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the chairman and chief executive, said earnings from continuing operations in 1990 were expected to exceed the 87 cents a share reported for 1989. **********At the newspaper group, which includes The New York Times, 35 smaller newspapers and a one-third interest in The International Herald Tribune, operating profit in the fourth quarter fell 63 percent, to $25.1 million, from $68.5 million in the fourth quarter of 1988. Revenues rose 2.2 percent, to $375.2 million, from $367.3 million. **********For the year, operating profit for the newspaper group fell 21 percent, to $182.9 million, from $231.5 million in 1988, as revenues rose 1.4 percent, to $1.4 billion, from $1.38 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Espionage;   Cold-War Riddle: A Most Unusual Spy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Espionage;   Cold-War Riddle: A Most Unusual Spy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/world.body_text: **********From the day in 1961 that he first met F.B.I. agents in Manhattan, Donald F. seemed a most unusual spy. **********He knew secrets of the Soviet Union's military intelligence network and its nuclear arsenal that could be found nowhere else. He tipped the Americans and the British to Soviet agents who might otherwise have never been detected. In a job where longevity is rare, he was a grand old man, juggling two careers - globetrotting Soviet diplomat, American agent - for at least two decades. **********When Pravda, the Soviet Communist daily, reported last week that Donald F., ''one of the most important'' spies of recent years, had been captured and sentenced to death, an American official privately called it a major loss. **********Code Name Top Hat **********The official may be right. Although Pravda did not identify Donald F., a review of Soviet diplomatic records shows that he is a senior Soviet Army officer, Lieut. Gen. Dmitri Fedorovich Polyakov. That conclusion is confirmed by former American intelligence officials. **********General Polyakov, who served in the military from the 1950's to the 1980's, was known to the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency by the code name Top Hat, the former officials said. **********According to Pentagon records, General Polyakov last served as a lieutenant general in the Soviet Army Air Defense Command. That is a top post in the force, charged with defending the Soviet Union against nuclear attack. **********Mystery and Suspicion **********But beyond agreeing that General Polyakov held what Pravda called ''a very important position,'' the report of the spy's downfall remains shrouded in a half-light of mystery and suspicion. Despite his decades of ostensibly faithful service to the Western cause, some American experts have never been satisfied that General Polyakov was not at heart an agent of deception for the Soviet Union. **********The Pravda account provides new grist for the debate. While much of the newspaper's report accurately tracks General Polyakov's diplomatic career, experts say, the article veers from the truth at enough points to leave analysts puzzled and skeptical. **********For example, the Dmitri F. Polyakov known to American officials was not recently captured and sentenced to death, but has been dead for several years. Experts who believe in General Polyakov's genuineness say he was apparently swept up and executed in a wave of arrests of American agents in the mid-1980's, shortly after a series of security lapses rocked the C.I.A.'s Moscow station. **********''A couple of years ago, for reasons that aren't clear to us, the Russians got a bunch of our guys and killed them,'' said a former official. ''The consensus of the community is that he was one of them.'' That conclusion was later confirmed by Government experts. **********Perhaps a Double Agent **********Others say General Polyakov has retired from espionage and could not have been caught in the act of sending messages to the C.I.A., as the Pravda account reported. **********Equally mysterious is why Pravda would admit that an American agent duped the K.G.B. at all. Some say it seeks to bolster the sagging career of a K.G.B. colonel, Aleksandr Dukhanin, who Pravda says captured General Polyakov. Colonel Dukhanin has been accused of bungling a corruption inquiry involving a Politburo member, Yegor K. Ligachev, who is a conservative critic of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********Others say the aim is to burnish the image of the K.G.B. at a time when other Communist secret police agencies, from Rumania's Securitate to East Germany's Stasi, are being disbanded. The article on Donald F., which also praises the K.G.B.'s attacks on internal corruption, is one of many recent reports that cast the agency in a favorable light. **********Still others contend that he was not an American spy at all, but a Soviet ''dangle'' whose 20-year mission was to spread false information and foul the trails left by other Soviet agents in the C.I.A. and F.B.I. In that view, General Polyakov either died peacefully or has retired with honors, and the Pravda report is but a final twist intended to convince the United States of his loyalty. **********Among those holding that view are Peter Wright, the former assistant director of British intelligence and author of the book ''Spycatcher,'' and Edward Jay Epstein, an American writer on intelligence issues, along with a legion of former C.I.A. officials who analyzed Top Hat and other Soviet ''moles'' of the 1960's. **********''I never believed he was genuine,'' said one of the former C.I.A. officials. The official, like others interviewed, declined to be identified. The former official said he reviewed Top Hat's credentials in the mid-1970's as part of an analysis of Soviet informers ordered by William E. Colby, the Director of Central Intelligence at the time. **********'The Guy Was Legit' **********General Polyakov's defenders are equally adamant. ''The guy was legit, absolutely,'' said an F.B.I. expert on the Soviet Union from the 1960's. ''There was never any controversy about it.'' **********Although Mr. Wright and others say the F.B.I. and C.I.A. decided in 1978 that Top Hat was a Soviet double agent, Government officials insist that he was genuine and that ''there has never been a legitimate debate'' about his loyalties. **********Legitimate or not, the debate has been never ending. The C.I.A.'s legendary spymaster of the 1960's, James Jesus Angleton, concluded early on that Top Hat and a second Soviet agent recruited at the United Nations, Fedora, were fakes. Their mission, he believed, was to discredit evidence provided by a Soviet defector, Anatoli Golitsin, that a Soviet spy had penetrated the C.I.A.'s highest levels. **********Mr. Angleton never found the spy, and the turmoil that his search caused led to his dismissal from the C.I.A. But the debate over Top Hat and Fedora did not end. His successors conducted a review that appeared to clear Top Hat, but concluded that Fedora was in fact a double agent for the K.G.B. **********Casey Reopens Debate **********In the early 1980's, President Reagan's Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, reopened the debate. His own inquiry, mounted by a team of former agency officials, concluded somewhat weakly that ''the charge of being a plant could not be substantiated,'' a former C.I.A. official said. **********The public record, pieced together from books and the Pravda account, settles nothing. **********Diplomatic records show that General Polyakov served in the Soviet Mission to the United Nations in New York in 1956 and again from 1959 to 1962, when he was promoted to the rank of colonel. After a stint in Moscow, he was posted in 1966 at the Soviet Embassy in Burma, where he was the military attache. **********In the early 1970's, he moved to the Soviet Embassy in New Delhi and returned for a second tour in 1980, with the rank of major general, before returning again to Moscow. **********Classified Conversations **********The diplomatic cover masked at least two other secret lives. John Barron, an author and intelligence expert, wrote in 1974 that General Polyakov was a Soviet spy while at the United Nations. Former American officials say he was an agent for the military intelligence agency, G.R.U. **********Pravda reported that he first approached the F.B.I. in November 1961 and later met American agents several times at the ''Kamerun Hotel,'' apparently a reference to the old Cameron Hotel on West 86th Street. Pravda said the C.I.A., which assumed control of him in Burma, later communicated through personal ads in the classified advertising section of The New York Times, all addressed to ''MOODY-Donald F.'' Such an ad appeared in The Times for 10 consecutive days in May 1964. **********American officials of that era said General Polyakov seemed invaluable, providing names of Soviet spies, details of G.R.U. operations and political information on the Government in Moscow. **********''Back in those days, there weren't too many defectors, and he was the best the bureau had,'' an official said. ''It was pretty big stuff.'' Who Misled Whom? **********Mr. Wright said Top Hat provided the F.B.I. with copies of stolen British defense documents, leading to the arrest of a major Soviet spy, Frank Bossard, by the British secret service. **********But Mr. Wright dismissed the tip as a Soviet attempt to generate rifts in the British-American alliance, since the documents in question contained top United States defense secrets. **********Other authors, including Mr. Epstein, say Top Hat and Fedora gave the F.B.I and C.I.A. data suggesting that Soviet nuclear missiles were far less accurate than they actually were. The misleading data, fed to the United States through the 1970's, misled the Nixon and Carter Administrations into making seriously flawed agreements with Moscow on limiting nuclear weapons, those writers contend. **********But another C.I.A. official said that Mr. Casey's review of the evidence refuted those charges, and that ''the record was pretty good as far as the analysis and conclusions'' about Soviet nuclear abilities were concerned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/world.body_text: **********The bridge across the Narva River, guarded by medieval fortresses built by Estonia on this bank and by the czars on the other, links this industrial town to its twin of Ivangorod and marks the border between Estonia and Russia. **********It is the bond also between this town of shortages and high prices and its far poorer Russian neighbor, where store shelves are virtually bare. **********A 37-year-old metalworker, his fur cap pulled deep over his face against a freezing rain outside, turned from the counter of Ivangorod's biggest food store with nothing but a chunk of margarine and a bag of colored candy in his shopping basket. He prepared to continue his quest for food wherever he could find it. **********"I do the shopping, because when my wife does it she gets too upset and nervous," he said. **********He said he had obtained his meager purchases on his November ration coupons, which the saleswoman had clipped off his card after much discussion. "Because in November there wasn't even this to be had," the man said, nodding toward his nearly empty basket.Old people are even worse off, he said, because their pensions make them dependent on what they can buy at the low-priced state stores in the Russian federation without recourse to the better-supplied Estonian stores. **********The man said he would be happy to live in Estonia, where he works, if that republic achieves its goal of independence. "But maybe Russia will get independence, too," he added. "Maybe it will even have a revolution." **********Pointing again at his basket, he said, "I don't know how Gorbachev lives, but I know our Communists here don't live like this." **********The manager at the store's single checkout counter, asked whether she would take time to talk about the troubles of her work, replied: "What problem? We have so many." **********Shoppers go back and forth across the bridge, she said, although Estonia in October proclaimed an "economic frontier" around its territory to prevent a drain on its resources. **********Much more is available on the Estonian side, but prices here have tripled since October. This has caused residents from here to shop for food in Ivangorod to save a ruble or two. **********This morning what they found in the Russian town were dusty jars of pickles, tiny brown-flecked apples, small turnips and black radishes that went soft waiting for customers, as well as small, fresh herrings. Maybe bigger fish have stopped swimming in the Gulf of Finland and the Baltic Sea afew miles away, the manager said. **********Of course she would like to live in Estonia if it regains its independence, the woman said, "but the Estonians don't like us Russians." However accurate this generalization may be in the rest of Estonia, it applies fully in this northeastern region, where Russians have almost completely supplanted the original population. **********In this grievously polluted region -- where large deposits of oil shale are mined and burned to supply electricity or are converted into fertilizer, solvents and other chemicals -- masses of Russian workers were settled after World War II, when Moscow re-established its 1940 annexation of Estonia. **********This was done for exclusively demographic reasons, to Russify a strategic region, said Prof. Endel Lipmaa, a nuclear physicist and chemist, who is alsoMinister in the non-Communist government that is negotiating with Moscow to achieve Estonia's independence. He said the chemical industry was not only severely polluting but also uneconomic, costing more than it produces. **********In the republic as a whole, Estonians outnumber Russians by about 60 to 40 percent of the population of 1.6 million, but this area is more than 90 percent Russian. **********As a result of this imbalance, the Russian-controlled Narva municipal administration is ignoring the "economic frontier" and does not interfere with cross-border traffic. **********"Of course they come over here to shop," said a Russian saleswoman in Narva's biggest food store. "What does it matter if prices are higher? At least here you can buy something."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/busin.snippet: LEAD: AN urban landscape of freeways, palm trees and jumbled communities, Los Angeles confounds many because it lacks geographical focus.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: AN urban landscape of freeways, palm trees and jumbled communities, Los Angeles confounds many because it lacks geographical focus. **********AN urban landscape of freeways, palm trees and jumbled communities, Los Angeles confounds many because it lacks geographical focus. **********Some people might even say there is no such city as Los Angeles, only adjacent towns like Santa Monica and Beverly Hills. **********But there is a magazine called Los Angeles. **********The publication is recognized as one of the most profitable monthlies devoted to a particular city. That success is noteworthy because it comes at a time when some regional publications are having financial trouble and many - Los Angeles magazine among them - are facing new competition. **********''A good indication of the strength of Los Angeles magazine is the fact that there have been a number of start-ups recently in the general magazine field, and Los Angeles has been able to hold its circulation during the start-up phase, when the most money is spent to promote a new title,'' said Jim Kuhn, the president of Metrocorp, the Philadelphia-based company that publishes Boston, Philadelphia and Manhattan,inc. magazines. **********Los Angeles magazine competes with several regional publications, including California magazine and two that recently started up - Angeles, which is a spinoff of California, and L.A. Style, which is owned by the American Express Company. **********Geoff Miller, a founder of Los Angeles who will become its publisher on Jan. 16, remembers why Los Angeles magazine was created 30 years ago. He also remembers that it was not easy. **********''It was such a hard city to figure out, even when you're living here,'' he said. ''We thought it needed a monthly magazine to help.'' **********Some readers took to the magazine immediately. But it took the advertising community, Mr. Miller said, at least a half-dozen years to warm up to the idea. He said Los Angeles was the first of the modern city magazines to publish, beating New York magazine, which is a weekly, and others by several years. **********Today, Los Angeles, which is owned by Capital Cities/ABC Inc., has a circulation of 172,000 and it ranks among the top city and regional publications by advertising linage, with 1,840 pages in 1989. **********About 40 percent of its advertising comes from coveted national advertisers, Mr. Miller said, about twice the amount found in some other city magazines. **********Mr. Miller said Los Angeles magazine fared well partly because it followed the interests of its well-heeled readers. **********In a city where Hollywood and aerobics dominate conversation, and politics and government corruption do not, Los Angeles magazine follows the trends. **********''People here are more interested in developing their own life styles than in fitting into an existing social structure, so we try to bend the magzine that way to help them get the most out of their lives,'' Mr. Miller said. **********One recent issue advised readers where to find the best personal fitness trainer and the best hand car wash for pampered cars. Other articles explore parts of the city like Koreatown and trendy Melrose Avenue. **********To attract impulse buyers, who see the magazine in supermarkets, nearly every issue features a glamorous celebrity on the cover. **********Paul Benjou, executive director of Gaynor/Group One Communications Inc., a media management firm based in New York, said he expected Los Angeles magazine to fortify its strong position in the next decade. **********''Even national publications are turning to local markets because that's where opportunities exist,'' he said. '' 'Micromarketing' is a buzzword cropping up that means taking the focus away from the national level and addressing the local level, where the action is. The fact is that local publications address local issues and events more definitively than do the nationals. That gives them an edge at least into the 90's.'' **********One danger of local magazine publishing, Mr. Kuhn said, is that success is dependent in part on the strength of the local economy. This year, he said, Metrocorp's Philadelphia and Boston magazines have suffered partly because economic growth in the two cities is stifled. **********The same malaise could strike Los Angeles, though Mr. Miller said his magazine had avoided bad years by broadening its focus. **********''We had a thriving real estate section through the first real estate boom in the 1970's,'' he said. ''When that dropped almost overnight by at least half, we had other areas to turn to like travel. At other times, we had department store advertising. We have always had fallback areas so we have been able to avoid a tremendous down year.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.main_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Poland;   Warsaw Cabinet Asked To Move Up Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Poland;   Warsaw Cabinet Asked To Move Up Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.body_text: **********Although Poland is the first East European nation since the early postwar years to install a government not dominated by Communists, many Poles are pressing the Solidarity-led Government to hasten political change. **********With Poles convinced that Czechoslovakia has leapfrogged ahead of them in the movement toward democracy, pressures have grown to advance the date of local elections so that municipal governments no longer remain undemocratic fiefs controlled by Communist officials. **********''The people are very impatient,'' said Grazyna Staniszewska, a member of Parliament from the Solidarity union federation. ''People are worried that although there have been changes in Parliament and in the national leadership, there have not been enough changes where people have most day-to-day contact - that is, towns and villages.'' **********Responding to this pressure, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki said in a major address on Thursday that local elections should be scheduled for late in April. Government officials had previously talked of holding the elections in June or early in the autumn. **********'Authentic Local Government' **********''The most urgent of all jobs right now is to create an authentic local government system,'' said the Prime Minister, whose Cabinet took office in September, ending four decades of unchallenged Communist rule. ''Until authentic local government has been installed, we will not be able to defeat the resistance that we are encountering in trying to put our reforms into practice.'' **********Mr. Mazowiecki expressed the concerns of many advocates of change that the Communist apparatus, the nomenklatura, remains an obstacle at the national and local levels to carrying out the Government's program. **********In an essay this week in the newspaper Rzeczpospolita, Bronislaw Geremek, leader of Solidarity's delegation in Parliament, wrote, ''Local elections may become a powerful weapon in breaking up the nomenklatura at all levels of power and in shaking up local cliques.'' **********Many Solidarity officials also believe that local elections will create a surge in grass-roots political activity, which they say can promote improvement in areas like housing and the environment. **********Timetable for Voting **********Mr. Geremek wrote, ''The moment has come when we need to accelerate change, to again speed up the course of history.'' He called for holding local elections in the first half of 1990 and for preparing a new constitution this year, rather than next year, as has been planned. **********Some members of the Communist Party see blatant politics behind Solidarity's call for local elections this spring. **********They say the Government wants to give voters an exhilarating dose of local democracy to take their minds off the pain caused by Poland's crash economic program. The program, which went into effect on Jan. 1, is aimed at fighting inflation and changing Poland into a market economy. Since its start, most price controls have been removed, subsidies to consumers and industry slashed, and income lost by the majority of Poles. **********Slawomir Wiatr, a Communist legislator, said, ''There is an old saying from Rome: 'If you don't have bread, you organize circuses.' This is not the last of the festivities we'll see to exploit people's emotions.'' **********Both Groups Apprehensive **********Communists concede that their party will do poorly in local voting. At a congress scheduled for next weekend, the Communists are expected to dissolve their party and reconstitute themselves into one or more social democratic parties. **********And Solidarity officials admit that that holding local elections in April could also be risky for their group because of the painful price increases and layoffs that have resulting from the Government's economic program. **********The Government got good news late Friday night when striking miners at the Niwka Modrzejow coal mine in Sosnowiec agreed to end a four-day walkout for higher pay. Four other Silesian mines had agreed earlier in the day to end their walkouts.These strikes, prompted by wage controls, were the worst labor unrest since Mr. Mazowiecki took office. **********Solidarity and Communist members of Parliament are convinced that, barring unforeseen obstacles, local balloting will in fact be held late in April or early in May. **********Future of Jaruzelski **********More quietly, there is talk about moving up the date for the next presidential election, which is scheduled for six years from now. ''It's not discussed out loud, but you can tell the feeling is growing,'' said Mr. Staniszewska of Solidarity. **********Such a move could be seen as an affront to President Wojciech Jarulzelski, the Communist general who acceded to the political changes that led to last year's Parliament elections and the Solidarity-led Cabinet. **********Many politicians say, however, that if General Jarulzelski is convinced that Poland is in a stable, healthy state, he would decide not to run rather than risk a political campaign.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/07/busin.main_headline: For Airlines, a Heated Push Into the Pacific Rim
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/07/busin.print_headline: For Airlines, a Heated Push Into the Pacific Rim
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/07/busin.body_text: **********A few years ago, Jerry Connelly, a fashion executive in New York who flies regularly to the Far East, booked his flights to cities like Hong Kong a just few days ahead of time. But no more. ''Now you need at least a week or two's notice,'' he said. ''Sometimes I can't even get a seat then.'' **********Mr. Connelly's frustration is a sign of the airline industry's Asian bonanza. Spurred by the blossoming economies and relaxed travel policies in countries like Japan, Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore, air travel to and from Asia is booming and airlines are clamoring to grab a chunk of the fastest-growing market in the world. ''United States carriers are gaga about the Asian market,'' said John Ash, managing director of Global Aviation, a consulting firm in Washington. ''Everybody wants a piece of it.'' But it won't come easily. Certain Asian countries like Japan do not have open-sky policies and therefore prohibit carriers from flying into their airports at will. And airports are already congested, especially in travel-crazed Japan. While new long-range jets could help alleviate overcrowding by bypassing current stopovers, production of these planes has been hamstrung by labor strikes. What is more, Asian airlines, with their lower labor costs and reputation for attentive service, are proving to be tough competitors. **********And rivalries in the Far East among American carriers are also expected to heat up. Until recently, Asia was the domain of two United States lines: Northwest Airlines and United Air Lines. But others, like American, Delta and Continental, have gained a toehold in the region in recent years. Northwest now commands only 42 percent, and United 29 percent, of the travel in the Pacific handled by American carriers. **********The newcomers, dividing the remaining 29 percent of that travel, are primed to expand. ''The American carriers are chafing at the bit, wishing they could fly from, say, Chicago to Tokyo,'' said Mary Hunt, editor of Business Traveler International. **********New Routes Ahead **********An agreement signed in November by the United States and Japan could enable more of them to establish routes into Tokyo, the gateway to the Pacific rim. **********Last Thursday, Washington formally opened bidding for six routes provided for under the accord, which could increase air service between the two nations by 30 percent. Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner called the pact ''the most dramatic expansion of air services to Japan since the original bilateral agreement was signed in 1952.'' **********But Northwest and United are the least likely of the American carriers to win rights to the new routes. To stimulate competition, the Transportation Department said it is more inclined to award those routes to carriers that currently have less of a Pacific presence. **********The two carriers still rely heavily on that traffic. Pacific flights now account for more than half of Northwest's revenues, and for 30 percent of United's. While United's domestic traffic has dropped slightly, its Pacific traffic soared nearly 24 percent over the last year. **********United made its big push into the Pacific in 1985 with its $750 million purchase of Pan American World Airways's extensive Pacific routes - one of the largest acquisitions of such a network in the industry and, in retrospect, one of the shrewdest. ''At least initially, there will be enough room for everybody,'' said Raymond Neidl, an analyst with Dillon, Reed. ''But the competition will begin to erode their market share.'' **********The Pacific routes are rich with business travelers and, until recently, relatively competition-free. In general, long flights are more profitable for airlines than short hops, since they do not require as many employees on the ground. And in the Pacific, airlines need not discount as many seats as they do on European flights. **********Indeed, keeping planes filled is hardly a problem. Traffic between North America and Asia is expected to grow at about 10 percent annually for at least the next decade, about twice as fast as the rate within the United States. And cargo traffic there is also on the rise. ''It's the growth market for the 1990's,'' said Kevin Murphy, an analyst with Morgan Stanley. **********The Japanese, riding a strong yen, are leading the boom. In 1986, 5.5 million Japanese traveled abroad. In 1989, it was 10 million. **********The Koreans and Taiwanese are also traveling more. Last year Korea relaxed age restrictions on travel for its citizens, who previously had to be 50 years or older to travel freely. The threshold age was lowered to 30 in 1987 and the restriction was lifted altogether last year. As a result, the number of Koreans traveling abroad is expected to double this year. Likewise, the number of Taiwanese travelers is expected to double to four million people by the decade's end. ''Suddenly there's a new lode of people who can afford air travel,'' said Michael Hewitt, secretary general of the Orient Airlines Association in Manila. **********The one Asian country where the airlines are not deploying more airplanes is mainland China. Since the Tiananmen Square uprising in May, Northwest has cut its flights from Osaka to Shanghai to one a week, from two. **********But the surge in travel has clogged the Pacific airways and even caused shortages of hotel rooms in certain cities like Bangkok. Load factors, or the percentage of seats filled, on Pacific routes now average 70 percent or better, compared with 64 percent in the United States. And Asia, as an archipelago, has no land-transportation alternatives linking its countries to offer relief. **********Clogged Airports **********The International Air Transport Association has flagged airports in Hong Kong, Tokyo, Bombay and Sydney as the region's most congested. ''The capacity of airports is being stretched to the limits,'' said Ken Chamberlain, executive vice president of the Pacific Asia Travel Association. ''Travel is an increasingly difficult experience.'' **********''Flights for the last year were chock-a-block,'' said Richard Chao, owner of Taiwan Travel, a travel agency in Taipei. ''The public isn't happy with the airline situation here. There isn't much flexibility.'' **********To relieve congestion, Hong Kong is building a new $5 billion airport to replace Kai Tak International, which, with its single runway surrounded by mountains, is dreaded by pilots and passengers. Meanwhile, Japan is building a new airport near Osaka on a man-made island - well clear of communities that have insisted on an 8:30 P.M. curfew at the current airport. **********But the biggest bottleneck in Asia is Tokyo's Narita Airport. With only one runway, it is already operating 40 percent over its capacity of 13 million passengers a year. An attempt to build more runways has run headlong into fierce opposition from local farmers and other landowners. **********Alternative Gateways **********Given this congestion, airlines are looking for alternatives gateways to the Pacific. Both United and Northwest, for instance, are developing Seoul as a ''mini hub'' for the region. **********And many carriers have placed orders for a new, extra-long-range jumbo jet, the Boeing 747-400, that could enable them to fly nonstop from the United States to Seoul or Bangkok with a full passenger load. United, for one, has 15 747-400's on order, all of which will be deployed on the Pacific routes. **********The trouble is, a backlog of orders and an eight-week strike at Boeing has stalled delivery of the jets to many airlines and forced them to delay their expansion plans. Japan Airlines has delayed its expansion until 1991 as it awaits delivery of 15 Boeing jumbo jets, a company spokesman said. **********Unlike the American and European air-travel markets, where battles are fought with super-saver fares and bonus mileage, the contest for the Pacific market is being waged with fine china and after-dinner drinks. Asian carriers like Singapore Airlines and Cathay Pacific have a reputation for pampering their passengers to extremes unheard of in the United States. ''There's no way a Western carrier can compete with an Asian one on service,'' said Mr. Starkman, the analyst. **********But American carriers are trying. At a cost of $45 million, United is revamping the business-class sections on its 747's and DC-10's, adding wider seats and more flight attendants. On occasion, it also dispatches an employee to fly on a rival's flight to report on the quality of service. ''These are among the best airlines in the world'' said William C. Speicher, senior vice president of Pacific marketing for United. ''Its tough competition. There's no doubt about it.'' **********Northwest, under its new owner, hotelier Alfred Checchi, is attempting to shift its image as a discount airline. It recently began an advertising campaign in America that reminds potential passengers that telephones are pink in Hong Kong and that one shouldn't slurp noodles in Taiwan. And the airline, which has been flying the Pacific routes for 42 years, now offers such ammenities as concierge service at the airport and in-flight ice cream sundaes. ''We could never do something like this between Minneapolis and Chicago,'' said Robert Gibbons, a company spokesman. ''When you have passengers for 8 to 14 hours, you can pamper them.'' **********The airlines are emphasizing service on their Asian flights because of the high percentage of business travelers, who generally pay more for their tickets and are most likely to bring repeat business. **********For instance, the 747's that Japan Air Line flies between New York and Tokyo are outfitted with 196 first-class and business-class seats and only 60 coach. Pacific flights are popular with business executives in part because some employers prohibit business-class travel across the Atlantic but permit it for the longer transPacific flights. **********In assimilating to Asian culture, American airlines have made some blunders. When United began its concierge service in Tokyo, it identified its employees by having them wear white carnations. In Japan, the color symbolizes death and mourning. United switched to red. **********And American carriers may not have bargained for such tough competition. Asian carriers bring more than their sparkling service. They bring impressive bankrolls. Japan Airlines, which was privatized in 1987, is investing $6.1 billion in new planes, maintenance facilities and computer reservation equipment. All Nippon Airlines, Japan's largest domestic airline, has begun to fly to Los Angeles and Washington, and is gearing up for a major expansion into the United States. **********To compete for American passengers looking to fly to the Far East, Asian carriers are also beginning to match the Americans' most potent marketing tool - frequent-flier programs. For instance, passengers on Philippine airlines can earn a free trip after racking up 30,000 miles - only three round trips to the United States. American carriers require more than double that travel for a free trip. **********To woo travel agents, the Asians pay a handsome 26 percent commission on flights to and from the Far East - a move that United and Northwest have followed. Travel agents earn about 10 percent on American business. **********Of course, American airlines still have one critical advantage with consumers: their strong domestic feeder systems. Foreign airlines are prohibitted from flying between two American cities. **********The coming battle for the Asian and American carriers is for control of the computer reservation systems being developed in the Far East. About two-thirds of the airline tickets sold for transPacific flights are purchased in Asia. But fewer travel agencies use computer reservations systems there than in the United States. The airlines that succeed in linking up with the new systems will go a long way toward determining the long-term survivors. ''The computer systems are up for grabs,'' Mr. Speicher said. ''There aren't real strong alliances in one camp or another.'' **********For now, thought, attention is focused on the new flights between Tokyo and America, which are scheduled to begin in October. The six new routes could mean 125 more flights a week. Virtually every major American carrier has applied for the right to fly one of the routes. Officials in cities like Houston, Denver, Phoenix and Miami have also aggressively lobbied Washington for airline service from their communities to Asia. **********Regardless of who wins the new routes, however, one thing is unlikely to change. In terms of air travel, the United States will continue to have a trade surplus with Japan. ''This is a wonderful aberration in the U.S. and Japan trade picture,'' said Jeffrey Shane the Transportation Department official who was the architect of the recent agreement with Japan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/30/busin.main_headline: Dollar Rises Against Yen And Mark
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/30/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS; Dollar Rises Against Yen And Mark
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/30/busin.body_text: **********The dollar surged yesterday, jumping more than 2 percent against the Japanese yen and more than 1 percent against the German mark. **********The rally, which pushed the dollar over the 1.50 level against the mark and 133 against the yen, is the first significant break upward for the dollar in months. It comes after a long decline that has pushed it to repeated lows against the mark and the Swiss franc. **********Much of the jump yesterday, traders said, was a response to the tensions in the Middle East, which were fueled by rumors of shooting, later denied, and to reports that troops had been put on special alert status in preparation for a possible Iraqi strike. Late in the day, the United Nations Security Council, in a 12-to-2 vote, authorized the use of force against Iraq.   Big Drop for Yen **********The yen, which fell the most, is also hurt from concern about the Japanese economy and from the fear of a string of business failures after the Kyowa Company announced its bankruptcy filing this week. The yen has also fallen sharply against European currencies, including the mark, reflecting a negative feeling about the currency that is temporarily overshadowing the bearish sentiment for the dollar. A prediction of an earthquake in Tokyo this weekend also unsettled the yen. **********But some traders said they saw the start of a little rally for the dollar that could be supported by gulf tensions and the ususal dollar buying at the end of the year that comes with the closing of corporate books. They contended that the market had tried, but failed recently, to push the dollar even lower, and so was now considering the potential for an upward move. **********"I thought the move was going to take place over a two-or-three-week period," said Robert A. White, a vice president at First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles. "But it all happened in one day." **********He said the sharp jump reflected the thinness of the market; also, many people, still betting on a decline in the dollar, were caught short and had to scramble to buy to protect themselves from large losses. **********Many investors and traders use stop-loss orders to avoid or limit their losses, and the American currency moved through several of these levels. **********"Traders here are reacting less to negative news," added Andrew Smith, the executive vice chairman of London & Bishopsgate International Inc. in New York. "The market was looking for reasons to take the dollar up." He thinks many traders are misreading the signs pointing to a lower dollar. **********Victor M. Polce, a vice president at Algemene Bank Nederland in New York, argued against yesterday's jump in the dollar being the sign of a new rally. "The fundamentals still point to the dollar going down," he said, adding that the bank advised its clients not to buy dollars in this atmosphere, despite the dollar's rise. **********The United States economy is in decline, Mr. Polce said, and interest rates here are still expected to decline, while they are expected to stay level or rise abroad, making the dollar a less attractive investment. **********In late trading, the dollar was at 133.20 yen, up from 130.10 on Wednesday and up from 127.15 the day before Thanksgiving. Against the mark, the American currency was at 1.5043, up from 1.4863 on Wednesday and from 1.4760 last Wednesday. **********The pound, which closed at $1.9430, down from $1.9685, also dropped sharply against the dollar yesterday, partly because of comments from the new British Prime Minister, John Major, who said he opposed the imposition of a single currency for Europe. **********The comment could be interpreted to mean that Mr. Major would not be as willing as thought to ease away from the adamant opposition of the former Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, to such a move.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/03/busin.main_headline: Unit of Bond Group Moves Against Parent
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/03/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Unit of Bond Group Moves Against Parent
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/03/busin.body_text: **********One of the companies controlled by Alan Bond, the prominent Australian businessman, turned against its parent today, filing court papers that seek to liquidate four Bond group units, including Alan Bond's privately owned Dallhold Investments. **********The action by Bell Resources came as a surprise. **********Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. is already fighting off creditors in several other court actions as it struggles with debts of more than $4.5 billion. Its failure would be Australia's largest. **********The focus so far has been on Bond's Australian brewery units. Bond also owes United States creditors about $30.6 million related to its takeover two years ago of the G. Heileman Brewing Company of La Crosse, Wis. **********Bell Resources, which Bond took over in 1987, went to the Western Australian Supreme Court to take action against Dallhold, the Bond Corporation, a Dallhold subsidiary and Bond Media, which owns an Australian television network. **********Bell Resources was cash rich when the Australian entrepreneur Robert Holmes a Court sold out in 1987, but it is now owed about $975 million by the Bond Corporation. **********Bell's petitions involve debts totaling $22 million, a very small part of Bond's debt. **********Bond said it would fight the petition by Bell Resources because it believed Bell had already agreed to defer the payment date. **********Bond lost control of the Bell Resources' board in December when a 19.9 percent shareholder began a petition in court to wind up Bell's operations. That action was dropped after Bond agreed to the appointment of an independent chairman and two directors representing the shareholder. **********But it was only the first in a mounting series of legal actions involving the Bond group. **********In the longest action, the Bond Corporation is awaiting a decision on its application to overturn the appointment of receivers for its Australian breweries. **********Creditors owed $920 million are demanding their money immediately, and another group owed $530 million has also threatened action unless the receivers are ousted by Monday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/23/busin.main_headline: Wall Street; The Dow and a Decade of Discount Rate Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/23/busin.print_headline: Wall Street; The Dow and a Decade of Discount Rate Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/23/busin.body_text: **********The conventional wisdom is that the Federal Reserve Board delivered a giant Christmas gift to Wall Street last week by cutting the discount rate a half-point, from 7 percent to 6.5 percent. And figures collected by the archivists at Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in New York, show how such assumptions arose. **********Not counting this recent action, the Fed has cut the discount rate by a half-point or more on 25 occasions during the past decade. The Birinyi folks checked to see where the Dow Jones industrial average stood three months after a major discount rate cut. And, in 18 of the 25 cases, the Dow was higher. Pretty reassuring, huh? **********But before you uncork the champagne, look carefully at the record during the brief economic downturn in the first half of 1980 and the much deeper recession that began in July 1981 and continued through November 1982. Despite a lot of pushing and shoving from the Fed, the market didn't start to rebound until the recession was nearly over. Aspirin, anyone?

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/27/busin.main_headline: G.E. Agrees to Pay $16.1 Million Fine For Pentagon Fraud
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/27/busin.print_headline: G.E. Agrees to Pay $16.1 Million Fine For Pentagon Fraud
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/27/busin.body_text: **********The General Electric Company, which was convicted in a jury trial in February of overcharging the Army for a battlefield computer system, agreed yesterday to pay one of the largest fines ever assessed for defrauding the Defense Department. **********G.E. will pay $16.1 million in criminal and civil penalties related to overcharges by the Management and Technical Services Company, a subsidiary of its aerospace group, based in King of Prussia, Pa. The penalties are the cornerstone of a $30 million sentencing agreement with the Justice Department, which also covered a number of disputes that have not led to criminal or civil charges. **********The three-year inquiry on the battlefield computer case, conducted by the Pentagon and the United States Attorney in Philadelphia, was one of many investigations of military contractors begun in the 1980's as the nation's weapons spending increased sharply. **********In February, the Northrop Corporation agreed to pay $17 million for falsifying test data on components of the Cruise missile and the Harrier jet. The largest military fraud settlement was reached in 1988, when the Sundstrand Corporation paid $115 million for overbilling the Government for military hardware. Sundstrand's billings included the cost of numerous executive perquisites, including country club dues and salaries for servants. **********Michael J. Rotko, the Acting United States Attorney in charge of the case, said the conviction and the sentence ''should send an important message to defense contractors that the United States will use all the weapons in its arsenal to protect the integrity of the defense procurement process.'' **********In an unusual feature, the G.E. agreement includes $11.7 million to settle several other Government complaints, which had not resulted in lawsuits. In those disputes, the Government argued that the company had padded 400 bids that affected 200 contracts it received and had engaged in other unlawful activities on a number of military and space-related contracts. **********''G.E. and the Government viewed this case as an opportunity to close the books on a number of other matters,'' said Catherine Votaw, an assistant United States attorney in Philadelphia. **********The battlefield computer case involved products that the company began producing for use in Army vehicles in 1983 under a $254 million contract. After a 14-week criminal trial, the company in February was convicted of defrauding the Government by not reporting a savings of $8 million it realized when subcontractors supplied components at prices that were lower than had been expected. The company faced a maximum fine of $71.9 million. **********Statement by the Judge **********The settlement included a promise by G.E. not to appeal its conviction or the sentence. In handing down the sentence as recommended by the Government in the settlement, United States District Judge Lowell Reed Jr. described it as ''fair, adequate, and in the best interest of the public.'' **********G.E. and the Government said in a joint statement that the sentencing agreement reflected the company's recent record of ''significant efforts'' to guarantee compliance with Government procurement laws and regulations. They told Judge Reed that his acceptance of the agreement would encourage other contractors to strengthen compliance programs. **********About 400 employees are now charged with overseeing compliance in the company's aerospace group, which is responsible for most of its military contracts, according to George Jamison, a company spokesman. The company has also adopted new disciplinary codes, stepped up outside auditing and expanded its training. Some 12,500 employees attended training programs in the last two years, Mr. Jamison said. **********Two Managers Convicted **********Two managers of the subsidiary, Gerald A. Leo and James Badolato, were convicted along with the company in the February trial. Mr. Rotko, the prosecutor, said that there had been evidence at the trial that the superiors of the two employees had ''looked the other way while fraud was committed.'' But no other G.E. employees were charged. **********Mr. Leo, a former purchasing manager who is 52 years old, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Reed to 10 months in prison and fined $15,000 for four counts of mail fraud and one count of trying to deceive Federal investigators. He plans to appeal, according to Seymour Toll, his attorney. **********Mr. Badolato, a former subcontracts manager who is 43, was convicted of misleading auditors and submitting false documents. He was sentenced to five months in prison and fined $10,000. Gregory Miller, his attorney, said Mr. Badolato also intends to appeal. **********Both men were suspended by G.E. in 1983 when the dispute began. **********''There are huge disputes about the facts in this case,'' Mr. Toll said yesterday. The G.E. statement yesterday said that the company believed the men were not guilty, although the jury found otherwise, and that the company had not yet decided whether to continue to pay for their defense. **********No Statement by Chairman **********Last night, spokesmen in the company's headquarters in Fairfield, Conn., were unable to identify the executives who had been the immediate superiors of either of the defendants when the fraud occurred. There was no statement from John F. Welch Jr., the company's chairman, when the settlement was announced and he could not be reached last night. **********The agreement was reported on the evening news broadcast on NBC, a network owned by G.E. **********The other disputes settled yesterday mainly involved longstanding bidding practices that the company voluntarily disclosed to the Government. In one of them, known as gross rate protection, the company padded its projected labor costs by sums equivalent to the cost of administrative expenses and other activities that it expected the Government would not be willing to pay for in a proposed contract. The settlement included triple compensation for the cost of such padding. **********The total $11.7 million compensation on the matters unrelated to the battlefield computer represented an adjustment of 1 percent in the value of the contracts involved, Mr. Jamison said. **********Ms. Votaw said that only one dispute remains between her office and the company - a disagreement over whether the company included illegal contingencies and reserves in a number of big contracts signed between 1982 and 1985. The two sides are continuing to discuss the matter. **********In addition to $10 million in criminal penalties and $6.1 million in civil fines, the portion of the settlement related to the battlefield computer included $2.2 million that the company agreed to pay as restitution for the overcharges. The company said that it had already paid $3.7 million in 1985 in a previous restitution agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/24/world.main_headline: Last Planned Refugee Flight From Iraq Arrives in the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/24/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Last Planned Refugee Flight From Iraq Arrives in the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/24/world.body_text: **********A jet carrying 112 people from Iraqi-occupied Kuwait arrived in the United States today after a flight from Baghdad via London. **********The DC-10 landed at Raleigh-Durham airport. No further American-chartered evacuation flights are scheduled, officials said. **********''This is the last we've been told to prepare for,'' said Joe Myers, director of the North Carolina Emergency Management Division. **********The plane left London with 55 American citizens, 2 Canadians and 55 evacuees of other nationalities, United States Embassy officials said. **********The Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, has allowed some women and children to leave, but has kept foreign men behind at strategic sites.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/busin.body_text: **********Washington will place Taiwan on a list of unfair trading partners next week, leading to possible United States trade sanctions against the export-driven nation, Taiwan newspapers reported this week. **********Quoting ''high trade officials,'' The United Daily News and China Times reported that Taipei officials had been told that Taiwan would be placed on the list of unfair trading partners next week. **********In Washington, the Office of the United States Trade Representative, which compiles the list of unfair traders, would not confirm that Taiwan was on the list. Officials in Taipei called the reports rumors. **********In talks last month, the United States and Taiwan failed to reach a compromise on Washington's demands for protection of intellectual property rights, equal treatment for American banks and wider market access for United States insurance companies on the island.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/world.main_headline: Ukraine Introduces a Form of Currency
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/world.print_headline: Ukraine Introduces a Form of Currency
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/world.body_text: **********The Ukraine today became the first Soviet republic to introduce its own crude currency, official coupons that come in every resident's pay envelope and must be used with Soviet rubles to purchase most consumer goods. **********The measure was described by officials in the second-largest Soviet republic as a remedy for inflation and empty shelves, and a step toward replacing the ruble with new Ukrainian money. **********Grocery and department stores in the republic were reported suddenly full of scarce food, clothing and appliances, apparently brought out of warehouses to win public support for the coupons. **********But residents said the new system generated considerable confusion and sporadic protests as it was introduced in shops across the republic.  Fear of Panic Buying **********In this day of economic separatism, the program is the most far-reaching experiment yet to protect one republic's stores from being stripped by panic buying, black-market speculators and visitors from other republics. **********Other republics and cities have increasingly sought to impose stability in their markets with various forms of protectionism. Rationing coupons for essential goods are common in much of the country. Many cities, including Moscow, have sharply restricted shopping by consumers who cannot prove that they are local residents. **********Estonia, a Baltic republic, has established customs posts on its borders to prevent outsiders from leaving with trunkloads of consumer items. **********The Ukraine's system, sprung on the public with little advance notice by the republic's government, works this way: On payday, every worker gets his usual salary in rubles, plus coupons showing a face value equivalent to 70 percent of his pay.  What Coupons Buy **********For most purchases of industrial goods, food and gasoline, a shopper must pay the price in rubles along with an equivalent amount in coupons. **********Rubles can be used without coupons for rent, bus fare, most services, medicine and basic food items that have not yet fallen into short supply in the Ukraine, including bread, milk and baby food. The policy also provides an elaborate procedure for consumers who want to use savings for major purchases like cars. **********The measure was drafted in secrecy and disclosed only a few days ago to prevent a buying panic. The Parliament of the republic declined to block the plan on Wednesday. **********Vitold P. Fokin, acting Prime Minister of the Ukraine, told Soviet television that the coupons would help balance supply and demand and bring order to the marketplace. **********"For the last two or three years, in all republics, we've had all kinds of rationing coupons, identification badges and passport rules," he said. "Until now, the Ukraine has refrained from introducing such extreme and unpopular measures and has tried to cope with a mass exodus of goods from the republic by increasing its production. But we became convinced that this was not effective."  Playing to Ukrainian Sentiment **********Ukrainian officials argued that since only Ukrainians will have the coupons, the system will prevent the flow of scarce products to other republics. This also plays to the growing sense of Ukrainian patriotism that has fueled a nationalist political opposition. **********Critics said the system would aggravate political and commercial relations with neighboring republics and would probably not work. **********Oleg S. Bai, an aide to the Ukrainian Parliament, said the new coupons -- which he described as "shadow money" -- would themselves quickly become a black-market item. **********"They are already selling coupons in the pedestrian underpasses," he said. **********Confusion prevailed in many stores, as clerks and shoppers tried to figure out the system. Many customers did not realize that the coupons must be used together with rubles.  No Change Given **********Quarrels broke out because the coupons come only in denominations of a ruble or more. **********"If you buy sausage or cheese for 2.28 rubles, nobody knows what to do," said Marina Taran, a reporter for Kiev radio. "My daughter says her girlfriend tried, and the shop tried to take three coupons. It's very complicated."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/04/busin.body_text: **********COMPANIES **********A New, More Subdued, Mood at Shearson Lehman **********An era of daring and deal-making at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. undoubtedly ended Tuesday night with the resignation of Peter A. Cohen as chairman and chief executive. His replacement, Howard L. Clark Jr., has been chief financial officer at the American Express Company, Shearson's corporate parent. Though Mr. Clark was once an investment banker himself, he is likely to have Shearson adopt the conservative ways of American Express, where traveler's check receipts are invested in safe, short-term municipal securities. Riskier activies - merchant banking, real estate and bridge loans - might be trimmed. Analysts say Shearson will gradually devote more effort to retail brokerage. American Express, after all, is a consumer company. **********The Exchange After Phelan **********Now comes the New York Stock Exchange's chance to see how well it can get along without John J. Phelan Jr. He announced Friday that he would retire as exchange chairman by the end of the year. Mr. Phelan has won credit for turning an exchange that was becoming anachronistic and conflict-ridden in the 1970's into one capable of trading hundreds of millions of shares a day with no strain. Balancing the rival interests of floor traders and investment houses, he convinced the exchange to invest hundreds of millions on computer technlogy. And after the 1987 crash, he gave investors reassurance and calm. A former floor trader himself, he began at the exchange as a runner. **********Whipping Up the Product Mix **********The Philip Morris Companies sold more food than tobacco for the first time in 1989. But even after buying Kraft and its food brands - Jell-O, Cheez Whiz - in December 1988, the company still finds that tobacco accounts for about 65 percent of annual earnings. Philip Morris reported last week that fourth-quarter profits more than doubled to $863 million. *********** **********Coca-Cola profited from leaving the movie business. A $509 million gain from selling its interest in Columbia Pictures more than tripled fourth-quarter earnings, to $757 million. *********** **********The nation's largest steel company had a fourth quarter that appeared to repay its diversification into oil. Higher energy prices helped USX increase earnings 54 percent to $244 million. *********** **********Caesars World, it seems, got slaughtered at the baccarat tables. The company predicted sharply lower earnings for the quarter ending Jan. 31, and blamed bad luck in the casinos. As Henry Gluck, the company's chief executive, said, ''The laws of probability work in strange ways.'' *********** **********At Boeing, a 48-day strike cut fourth-quarter earnings 56 percent to $77 million. **********One of Europe's largest drug companies said Friday it plans to buy a majority stake in Genentech Inc., the pioneering American biotechnology company. Roche Holding Ltd. of Switzerland is to invest $2.1 million for a 60 percent share of the company, with an option to buy the rest. As part of the agreement, Robert A. Swanson, Genentech's chief executive, would become chairman and G. Kirk Raab, president, would replace him. **********An Optical Computer? **********It looks like the runner-up in a high school science fair. But the first optical computer, displayed last week, already has the ability to perform some operations as quickly as huge supercomputers. Researchers at A.T.&T.'s Bell Labs who developed the device hope that in several years optical computers will far surpass conventional machines. Instead of electric currents and silicon chips, the new computer uses laser beams, mirrors and lenses. Some scientists scoff at its commercial potential, while others foresee an optical computer on the market in a decade. **********Executives on the Move **********A five-year, $10 million package convinced Allen I. Questrom to become chief executive of Allied Stores and Federated Department Stores on Friday. Questrom had initially turned down the job in favor of remaining chief executive of Neiman Marcus. *********** **********The Campeau Corporation might not sell Bloomingdale's after all. Federated Stores Inc., the company's American subsidiary, plans to spend the next month or two deciding whether to accept one of several bids. Meanwhile, Robert Campeau himself might be joining his stores in insolvency. Available records indicate that his $500 million fortune has shrunk with the plunge in Campeau stock, and he is in default on two major bank loans. *********** **********Thomas S. Murphy, who built Capital Cities/ABC Inc. from a bankrupt UHF television station in Albany into a $5 billion media empire, said Thursday that he will step down as chief executive May 31. Daniel B. Burke, the company president, is to succeed him. **********S.&L.'s - It's Not Over Yet **********Savings and loan news: Federal regulators seized Centrust Bank, Florida's largest savings and loan, on Friday. They said that management had wasted assets on yachts, art and oriental rugs. The regulators also announced on Friday the sale of Bright Banc Savings Association, one of Texas's largest S.&L.'s, to the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio. On the brighter side, American Savings Bank, of California, sold to the Robert M. Bass Group more than a year ago, reported a $214.2 million profit for 1989. **********THE ECONOMY **********Greenspan on Recession **********Don't count on the Federal Reserve Board to lower interest rates soon. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, told Congress last Tuesday that, based on the Government's index of leading economic indicators, his staff sees only a 20 percent chance of a recession in the next six months. The economic index, released Wednesday, rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in December, the largest gain since April, even after accounting for the end of the Boeing strike in late November. But another figure last week pointed to continuing weakness. New home sales fell 9.6 percent in December and 3.8 percent for all of 1989, making it the slowest year since 1984. **********Job Data, the Good and the Bad **********Unemployment edged down one-tenth of a point to 5.2 percent in January. But Friday's unemployment report may not be as healthy as it seems. Manufacturing jobs fell for the 10th straight month, with the auto industry hit hardest. And Richard B. Freeeman, for one, a Harvard economist, argued that stagnant real wages are a more accurate guide to the economy than low, stable unemployment. ''If we hold the same unemployment rate for the next 20 years and do not have any real wage growth, that would be a disaster,'' he said. Recent wage improvements have only matched inflation, he added. *********** **********Renewed aircraft business after the Boeing strike contributed to a 1.9 percent rise in factory orders for December. But excluding transportation, orders rose just two-tenths of 1 percent. **********The Bush Budget **********President Bush gave Congress a budget last week that would restrain military spending, lower capital gains taxes, expand some domestic programs while cutting others and sharply reduce the budget deficit. Democrats dismissed it as an impossible, impractical relic of the Reagan years. They reacted more warmly Wednesday night when the President, in his first State of the Union message, proposed sharp new reductions in Soviet and United States troops in Europe. Behind the budget battles this year will lie a fight over economics. The Bush Administration assumes a healthy 2.6 percent economic growth rate; the Congressional Budget Office, 1.8 percent. If the President is right, the deficit will meet his target of $63 billion; if Congress is right, the deficit will be $100 billion. The consensus of private economists is on the side of Congress. But the Administration was more optimistic than Congress and the economists last year - and the Administration turned out to be right. **********INTERNATIONAL **********ast and East, Head to Head **********The opening of Eastern Europe and the availability of its low-wage labor force could hobble some Asian economies. Asia may be able to produce textiles and shoes more cheaply, but Eastern Europe offers better-educated workers to handle technology and electronics. As Ed Hewett, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, put it, that Asia's ''four tigers'' - South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong -have less to fear than their poorer neighbors around the Pacific. With Eastern European workers available for capitalism, he said, ''It's almost as if you suddenly created a Philippines in the middle of Europe.'' But Eastern Europe's situation is ''like the Philippines in other ways,'' Mr. Hewett cautioned. ''Troubled.'' **********McDonald's in Moscow **********The workings of digestible materialism culminated Wednesday in the opening of the Soviet Union's first McDonald's. The chain's largest restaurant, smack on Moscow's Pushkin Square, was mobbed with customers eager for ''Beeg Meks.'' For McDonald's, the toughest task was drilling Soviet farmers and counter help in the ways of standardized production and relentless good cheer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/29/world.main_headline: Constituent Lobby Calls For Yeltsin's Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/29/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   Constituent Lobby Calls For Yeltsin's Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/29/world.body_text: **********Members of the Russian Parliament returned today to the task of choosing a president of the republic, and reported that they were being inundated by telegrams and phone calls from angry, impatient voters urging them to stop stalling and elect Boris N. Yeltsin, a rival of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********''We all feel the hot breath of the voters,'' said Dmitri Volkogonov, a military historian and Yeltsin supporter who declined to become a compromise candidate as the election process went into its fourth day. **********Three candidates, including Mr. Yeltsin, are competing in another round of voting scheduled for Tuesday. **********In a runoff election Saturday, Mr. Yeltsin, an increasingly formidable critic and rival to Mr. Gorbachev, fell 28 votes short of the required 531 votes, a majority of the 1,060 members of the Russian Parliament. **********Yeltsin Bid to Conservatives **********Today, Mr. Yeltsin, who has the backing of the liberal Democratic Russia coalition, tried to break the deadlock by offering to form a coalition government with his conservative opponents. **********In the first two rounds of voting last week, Mr. Yeltsin was opposed by a solid bloc of deputies loyal to the Commmunist Party apparatus. Their choice in the first rounds of balloting was Ivan K. Polozkov, a hard-liner. **********Today, Mr. Polozkov withdrew his nomination as the party swung its support behind Aleksandr V. Vlasov, the Prime Minister of the republic, whose career has been closely linked to that of Mr. Gorbachev. **********Mr. Vlasov took himself out of the running last week after he was sharply criticized for a tepid performance in defense of government policies. Rejoining the race, he confirmed that he had dropped out because he chose not ''to oppose a candidate backed by the party Central Committee.'' **********Yeltsin Too Radical for Some **********The party's switch in tactics would offer moderate Communists a more acceptable option to Mr. Yeltsin, who is seen by many as too radical and headstrong. But by hastily dropping one candidate for another, the party has also reminded deputies - and their electors - that old-style subservience is still expected of members of the Communist Party apparatus. **********But several deputies, speaking from the lectern today, indicated that the wishes of the Communist Party were no longer relevant. A delegate from Mr. Polozkov's Krasnodar district, said the reports from back home were clear. ''The people are ready only for Yeltsin,'' he said. **********A delegate from the textile city of Ivanovo reported the results of one informal poll that showed 3,700 respondents out of total of 3,716 as backing Mr. Yeltsin. A deputy from the Far East said 90 percent of telegrams from Vladivostok were in support of Mr. Yeltsin. **********''The train of national consensus is already on its way,'' said a collective farm chairman. ''And I am referring not just to the people who go to meetings, but to the average people.'' **********Mr. Yeltsin already has strong support from the liberal strongholds in Moscow and Leningrad and from industrial regions in the Urals, where he served as a party leader before coming to Moscow in 1986. **********His popularity dates back to his conflict with Mr. Gorbachev and hard-liners in the Politburo in 1987 - which led to his resignation as head of the Moscow Communist Party organization. He is now hugely popular, and is widely seen as a credible alternative to Mr. Gorbachev - a leader who has captured the faith of an otherwise deeply skeptical population. **********Debate an Embarrassment **********Several deputies proposed various coalition combinations for the Russian Republic as a way of closing the long election debate, which has been televised nationally in full and at times has become a political embarrassment in advance of Mr. Gorbachev's departure for Canada and the United States. **********Deputies report that when they go home, voters tell them they should be ashamed of wasting time bickering over procedures. **********Today, another stormy protest broke out when the presiding officer proposed that both Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Polozkov, as losers in the runoff election Saturday, should be barred from running again. **********Angry Yeltsin supporters stormed the podium, interrupting debate for 15 minutes, until the chairman reversed himself, ruling that the two men could be candidates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/busin.body_text: **********Lawrence K. Fish, who last week became chairman of the Bank of New England Corporation, said today that he plans to reduce the troubled holding company's work force, continue selling assets and possibly sell subsidiaries. **********Mr. Fish offered few specifics of his plan, except to say that the bank, now valued at $25 billion, would ultimately be significantly smaller. ''In time, I hope we'll be thought of by how good we are, not how big we are,'' he said. **********On Friday, the former Bank of Boston executive was named chairman and chief executive of the company and its Boston-based subsidiary. Mr. Fish replaces Walter J. Connolly Jr., who was ousted this year after the bank suffered huge losses, mostly in real estate lending. **********Mr. Fish said his top priority was to complete the planned sale of $6 billion in assets. He said the bank was selling its home-equity lines for more than $1 billion and would also sell its lease assets and other commercial lending assets. **********The sale of the bank's affiliates in Maine and Rhode Island is being considered, said Mr. Fish, who planned to meet this week with executives at the Old Colony subsidiary, in Providence, R.I. and the Maine National Bank, in Portland, Me. **********He declined to identify the prospective buyers. **********There are no plans to sell the **********Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/31/busin.main_headline: U.S. Easing On Exports Of Computers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/31/busin.print_headline: U.S. Easing On Exports Of Computers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/31/busin.body_text: **********The Pentagon said today that it would no longer block sales of the least powerful American-made mainframe computers to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, leaving control of such exports to the Commerce Department. **********A Defense Department spokesman called the move ''a streamlining process,'' adding that the Pentagon already approves many computer exports to Eastern Europe. **********Other Administration officials said the announcement was a concession to the Commerce Department in the long-running battle between the two agencies over whether advanced American technology should be sold to the Soviet Union. **********European Competitors Cited **********The Commerce Department and some American manufacturers have advocated lowering export barriers on some technologies, arguing that European competitors already sell similar products to the East with little or no government review. **********The Defense Department's announcement today covers what it called low-end mainframes like the International Business Machines Company's 3031, 4331 and 4341. The Pentagon also decided to end its veto power over exports to the same nations of sophisticated medical equipment, including CAT scanners, magnetic resonance imagers and cancer-treatment equipment. **********Also, the Pentagon will no longer exercise its right to block the exhibition of certain high-technology products at trade shows in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. **********Today's action was welcomed by computer makers, but its significance appears to be more political than commercial or strategic. Although they are called mainframes, the machines at issue are generally less powerful than many desktop models, like the widely used I.B.M. PC-AT, computer experts said. The United States has already agreed to a proposal that would end all export controls on such desktops among the 17 nations in the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, or Cocom. If adopted, the proposal would end all government reviews of such sales to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. **********The low-end mainframes involved in today's decision are not covered by Cocom export regulations, but remain subject to export reviews by individual Cocom members. **********The United States reviews and has often rejected proposals by American companies to export the mainframes, especially to the Soviets.
