But European governments have taken a more relaxed attitude, and many models similar to American mainframes have already been sold in the Eastern bloc, Administration officials said. **********Because the Pentagon has most often vetoed export proposals, today's decision means that more United States-manufactured mainframes will be sold abroad, primarily to the Soviets. But the Soviets have little hard currency to spare for such purchases, and not much more of the industrial and commercial infrastructure in which they would be most useful. **********Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said in a written statement today that the Pentagon decision ''reflects the Administration's understanding of changing circumstances in East-West relations.'' **********Some computer industry experts suggested that the Pentagon was bowing to Congress, which is in the midst of revising Federal export laws and could rescind much of the Defense Department's existing authority to block exports.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/09/busin.main_headline: Top Operating Post Is Filled By Kemper
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Top Operating Post Is Filled By Kemper
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/09/busin.body_text: **********Continuing a corporate reorganization that has paid off in the stock market, the Kemper Corporation yesterday named David B. Mathis president and chief operating officer among several other executive changes. **********Last year Kemper, based in Long Grove, Ill., announced plans to divide its Kemper Group into two units to improve performance. The Kemper Corporation's chief executive, Joseph E. Luecke, explained that the publicly held corporation - with operations in financial services, life insurance and reinsurance - would operate separately from the Kemper National Insurance Companies. **********Mr. Mathis said yesterday that investors liked the reorganization plan, with the Kemper Corporation's stock moving as high as $51 from $24 last year. The stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $38.625, down 25 cents. Part of the transaction got the Kemper Corporation out of the national property and casualty insurance business. **********A series of other management changes were announced yesterday, giving the two Kemper companies separate maangement teams and separate boards, effective in May. **********Mr. Luecke, 63 years old, will continue as chairman and chief executive of the Kemper Corporation and as chairman of the Kemper National Insurance Companies. He relinquished the positions of president and chief operating officer at the Kemper Corporation to Mr. Mathis, who is 51. At Kemper National Insurance, Gerald L. Maatman, 59, president, was also named chief executive. **********Mr. Luecke is scheduled to retire in 1992, and yesterday's moves put Mr. Mathis in line to succeed him, although Mr. Mathis declined to discuss succession yesterday. ''Right now I want to do a good job as president,'' he said in a telephone interview. **********The Kemper Corporation's financial services include several regional brokerage firms and management of about $60 billion in investments. **********Mr. Mathis graduated from Lake Forest College on a Kemper scholarship and has been with the company ever since. He first worked in San Francisco and moved to Europe to start up Kemper's international operations, returning to the United States in 1972. He headed reinsurance operations and most recently has been executive vice president in charge of insurance operations for the Kemper Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/busin.main_headline: Texas Realty Executive Appointed by Bramalea
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Texas Realty Executive Appointed by Bramalea
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/busin.body_text: **********Marvin G. Marshall, a Texas real estate executive, has been named president and chief executive of Bramalea Ltd., a Toronto-based developer that has nearly $5 billion in assets. **********Mr. Marshall, 52, will replace the current president and chief executive, Benjamin Swirsky, 48, who is relinquishing his day-to-day activities at Bramalea and taking the post of vice chairman. **********Bramalea is 69 percent owned by the Trizec Corporation of Calgary, Alberta, which says it is the largest publicly owned real estate company in North America. Olympia & York owns 36 percent of Trizec's shares and the Edper Group, controlled by Peter F. and Edward M. Bronfman, owns 40 percent. **********Bramalea has developed or managed 40 million square feet of property. The company is also active in home building in Toronto and Southern California. Nearly half of its portfolio, which includes retail, office, hotel and industrial properties, is in the United States. **********Mr. Marshall came from Houston, were he was president and chief executive of Cullen Center Inc., a 4.8-million-square-foot project in that city's downtown. Real estate executives said Mr. Marshall's experience in the troubled Houston market would be valuable at Bramalea, which after years of growth is facing a severe downturn in the Toronto residential market. **********In an interview last week, Mr. Marshall said Bramalea was well positioned to weather the downturn in the overbuilt real estate markets in the United States. He added that the company would closely analyze individual markets in search of opportunities, and cited a few bright spots in commercial real estate in the United States. **********''We have been pleasantly surprised by the strength of the office market in Oakland'' and suburban San Francisco, he said. He added that there were some opportunities in Dallas, Houston and Atlanta, but said that ''I can't think of any area in the Northeast that would be particularly attractive to us.'' **********After high school, Mr. Marshall went straight into the business world. ''I went through sort of a nontraditional approach to education,'' he said. Mr. Marshall has taken real estate classes at the University of Missouri, in Kansas City, and at Southern Methodist University in Dallas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/20/busin.main_headline: Talking Business with Robert A. Stanger;   Real Estate Woe For Syndicators
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/20/busin.print_headline: Talking Business with Robert A. Stanger;   Real Estate Woe For Syndicators
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/20/busin.body_text: **********Last week's announcement that VMS Realty Partners, one of the nation's largest sellers of real estate partnerships, was suspending nonessential payments to outsiders provided further evidence of serious problems in the real estate syndication business. **********Robert A. Stanger, the president of Robert A. Stanger & Company and a leading consultant in the real estate securities business, discussed the problems of the syndication business. **********Q. What precisely is the cause of VMS's problems? **********A. Although I have not talked to the company, my best sense is that VMS's problems do not relate to the syndication process itself but rather to VMS's activity as a developer. Either with its own funds or with bank loans or with someone else's money, VMS has done what developers normally do: It has acquired land and built on it, and some of its projects just have not worked out. Either buildings didn't lease up or they didn't get the rents they had expected. **********There is also a problem of size here. If you buy one property in a down market, you might get lucky and pick one that will do well. But if you are like VMS and are buying $1 billion in property and you are broadly based, you will do as well as real estate in general in the last few years - not very well. **********Q. How likely are VMS's individual lenders to get their money back? **********A. To answer that, I would need to know the stage of development of the properties that are securing VMS loans. I would need to know how long it will be before VMS's buildings begin servicing their debt and renegotiated debt. And even if I had all the information about VMS's properties, I would still be giving you only a seat-of-the-pants response. The reason is that part of the answer is imponderable because it is anybody's guess as to what will happen to realty markets. **********Q. Should we conclude from VMS's experience that other syndicators are in deep financial trouble? **********A. No. The basic reason is that there is not a lot of construction lending in syndication. There used to be back in 1981, when there were tax advantages associated with the construction phase of lending, but that is no longer the case. Most syndication today involves either ownership of buildings or lending against completed, occupied structures. **********Q. Is tighter regulation of syndicators needed? **********A. Have you ever heard of the Securities and Exchange Commission? Have you ever heard of the North American Securities Administrators Association? Both of them already regulate syndication. The problem is that no regulation in the world can prevent a bad investment. When problems arise in partnerships it is typically from the investment rather than the money-raising process. Saying we need more regulation of syndicators is like saying that we should tighten regulation of mutual funds that do not perform well. What's at fault is not legislatable or regulatable: investment judgment. **********Q. How have syndicators performed relative to other money managers? **********A. Nineteen percent of all mutual funds have lost money in the last three years on a total return basis. Our estimate is that real estate syndicators turned in about the same performance. **********Q. What is the outlook for real estate partnerships? **********A. The outlook is grim, and it will depend on the real estate cycle itself. We have been in a significant bear market for real estate over the last three to five years. When rents start to go up and building values rise, people will perceive a change in the investment environment for real estate and will be interested again in partnerships. Until that happens, they won't be interested. **********Q. Even though the near-term outlook is grim, might this be precisely the time to buy into real estate parnterships? **********A. Rather than reading all the negative headlines and being scared, I'd say that reading those headlines is a condition to finding a bottom of the real estate market. If the headline says, ''Don't touch it with a 10-foot pole,'' the contrarian says, ''Buy it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/busin.main_headline:
Condominiums in Connecticut;
With Sales Strong, a Greenwich Builder Raises Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/busin.print_headline:
Condominiums in Connecticut;
With Sales Strong, a Greenwich Builder Raises Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/busin.body_text: **********At a time when many builders in the New York metropolitan area are cutting prices to attract buyers, a Greenwich, Conn., developer, Glenville Associates-Hawthorne, has been raising prices because its sales have been so strong. **********The price increases at the 80-unit Hawthorne condominium have averaged less than 10 percent since sales began in March. Still, the increases indicate that there is still a strong market for housing that gives purchasers the features they want. The project, a mix of town houses and apartments, is being built on a six-acre site in Glenville, a section of Greenwich. **********Of the 18 units in the first phase, which was ready for occupancy in May, 17 are sold. Occupancy of the 16 units in the second phase began this week. Eight of those, including all four of the three-bedroom town houses, are sold. And of the 29 units in the project's third phase, on which construction has just begun, eight are under contract. A fourth phase will be built later. **********The condos range from one-bedroom apartments to two-bedroom duplexes. The eight purchasers in the final phase had only floor plans to go by, and cannot move in until June. **********"There is always a demand for housing, even in a lousy market," said Steven J. Schacter, who is developing the project as a joint venture with Tony Schneider of Philadelphia and Seymour Schwartz and his son, Eric, of Greenwich. "We bought our land in 1979," Mr. Schachter said, "so we are able to sell at better prices and in a better location than people who bought in the 1980's and paid through the nose for inferior sites." **********Prices range from $149,900 for a 650-square-foot, one-bedroom unit in an elevator building to $354,900 for a three-bedroom, 1,500-square-foot town house. Bett McCarthy, executive vice president of the Greenwich Board of Realtors, said such prices were reasonable for new construction in Greenwich. In that affluent community, unlike many other areas, prices have remained relatively stable even as the number of sales has fallen, she said. **********The median selling price of condominiums, which include new and resale units, listed by the Greenwich Multiple Listing Service dropped from $320,000 in October 1989 to $300,000 in October 1990. But the median selling price for houses, $675,000, was the same in October as a year earlier, she said. The number of sales, however, has fallen since 1987. In the first 10 months of this year, there were 519 sales, compared with 581 in the comparable period last year and 706 in 1987. **********Part of the attraction of Hawthorne is its setting. Glenville's shops and restaurants are within walking distance, and the houses are being built high on a hill overlooking the Byram River. They also overlook a historic restoration of a cotton mill. **********Glenville grew up around the mill, which was established in the late 1700's. The original mill buildings were destroyed, but several built in the late 19th century have been restored and turned into offices and shops by a partnership of Mr. Schachter's uncle, Ralph Schachter, and Seymour Schwartz. They purchased the mill property in 1979. **********The six-acre Hawthorne tract, at Pemberwick and Glenville Roads, was taken over by Glenville Associates in 1989 for development as a separate entity, but it is also the final phase of development for the whole 30-acre mill complex. **********The first stage of development was completed five years ago. That phase, called the Mill, includes the office and retail compound as well as two residential condominiums with a total of 58 units. Of the total of 30 acres, about half, including woods adjoining the Hawthorne tract, has been set aside as permanent open space. **********A 120-year-old railroad station has been converted into small shops. Another 65,000 square feet of mostly new construction, designed to blend with the mill buildings, contains offices, shops and 12 residential rental units. **********A 100-year-old Victorian house on the mill property was also restored and converted to offices. The architect of the Mill, Robert Schwartz of Greenwich, is also the architect of Hawthorne. **********Of the 80 units, 19 will have one bedroom, 43 will have two bedrooms and 18, three. All but 10 have garages.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/busin.body_text: **********Kuwait's oil minister was quoted today as saying that OPEC's oil output quotas should be scrapped as soon as possible. **********''From a practical standpoint they are already irrelevant, so all that is needed is a recognition of that fact,'' the official, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, told the Middle East Economic Survey in an interview. **********The 13-nation Organization of **********Petroleum Exporting Countries last November set an output ceiling of 22.1 million barrels daily. But oil industry sources estimate that total January output was at least one million barrels a day above that level as some members, including Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, have exceeded their limits. **********The sheik told the newsletter that Kuwait was producing crude above its OPEC quota of 1.5 million barrels but declined to give a figure. A recent survey put output at 1.9 million barrels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/world.main_headline: U.S. TO BACK FUND TO PROTECT OZONE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/world.print_headline: U.S. TO BACK FUND TO PROTECT OZONE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/world.body_text: **********Reversing a policy decision, the White House said today that it would support a new international fund to help poorer countries phase out chemicals that are destroying the earth's ozone layer. **********The new policy removes the last big hurdle to an international agreement for a ban on the chemicals, including chlorofluorocarbons. The accord is expected at a meeting in London next week. **********Bush Administration officials said the United States expected to contribute $20 million to $25 million to the fund, which would total $150 million to $250 million. Today's announcement did not change the expected amount of the American contribution. **********Scientific Findings **********Although the amount of money involved is relatively small, White House officials led by the chief of staff, John H. Sununu, originally opposed setting up a new fund rather than providing the same amount of aid through existing institutions like the World Bank. The White House feared that a new fund would set a precedent for expensive new foreign aid programs on the environment. **********Chlorofluorocarbons and certain other chlorine-containing chemicals produced by industry have been found by scientists to be severely depleting ozone molecules in the upper atmosphere. That ozone shields the earth's surface from excessive ultraviolet radiation from the sun, which can cause skin cancer and cataracts and suppress the immune system in humans; the radiation also damages crops and wildlife. **********The White House has been under heavy domestic and international pressure to reverse its decision. Many other countries have warned that the American opposition to a fund to help the poorer countries could undermine the effort to bar future production of chlorofluorocarbons. **********Thatcher Writes Bush **********Last week, for example, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain wrote to President Bush urging him to reconsider, Administration officials say. On Tuesday, Mustafa K. Tolba, executive director of the United Nations Environmental Program, called on the United States to provide help to the developing countries. Environmental organizations and even the industries that make and use chlorofluorocarbons, called the original White House decision a mistake and asked for its reversal. **********The House of Representatives has already authorized $30 million to help the developing countries protect the ozone layer. A similar proposal has been introduced in the Senate. Members of Congress from both parties have written to the President urging him to change policy. **********Stephen Hart, a White House spokesman, said today that the change came as result of ''internal Administration discussions.'' Mr. Sununu issued a statement today saying that at the London meeting the United States would propose a new fund, operated and administered by the World Bank, to help the poorer countries phase out chlorofluorocarbon production. **********A U.S. Condition **********But Mr. Sununu's statement said the United States would support the fund only if it was not considered a precedent for dealing with other international aid programs. Mr. Hart said the White House intended to have such a caveat written into any agreement. **********The United States proposal would also build in strict controls to assure that the financial aid is used for its intended purposes. **********A treaty signed in Montreal in 1987 under the auspices of the United Nations Environment Program requires a 50 percent reduction in the production and use of chlorofluorocarbons by the year 2000. But subsequent scientific data on the seriousness of the problem have shown that such a reduction would not be adequate. The United States and most other countries now support a total phaseout by 2000 and sharp reductions in other ozone-depleting chemicals, including methyl chloroform. **********Many developing countries have insisted that they would not be able to phase in substitutes without additional assistance. India and China, two countries with development plans that call for substantially expanded use of the chemicals, have said they will not join a treaty to eliminate the use of the chemicals without substantial new economic and technical help. **********Praise for White House Change **********The change of White House policy was praised today by members of Congress, environmentalists and industry representatives. **********''Hurray for the President,'' said Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, one of those who wrote to Mr. Bush urging him to reconsider. ''This is a very wise political decision but more than that it is a very wise decision for the future of the world.'' **********David D. Doniger, a lawyer and expert on chlorofluorocarbons for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a national environmental group, said of the White House decision: ''They have closed the hole in ozone policy that they opened themselves.'' **********But Mr. Doniger also complained that the American plan for phasing out chlorofluorocarbons by 2000 was too slow and that members of the European Community had been urging a faster schedule to reflect the gravity of the threat to the ozone layer. **********Kevin J. Fay, executive director of the Alliance for Responsible CFC Policy, an association of companies that make and use the chemicals, said, ''Hopefully, with this measure, government, industry and environmental community can move forward with a solution for solving this global problem.'' **********On a separate issue involving the global atmosphere, the West German Cabinet on Wednesday decided to reduce that country's carbon dioxide emissions by 25 percent by 2005. West Germany thus is the first major nation to formally adopt a target and timetable for reducing industrial emissions that, many scientists believe, will lead to a warming of the earth.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/26/busin.main_headline: I.C.H. to Make Offer For First Executive
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/26/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   I.C.H. to Make Offer For First Executive
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/26/busin.body_text: **********The I.C.H. Corporation said today that it would form a group to make an offer for the First Executive Corporation, the insurance company stung last week by a huge write-off in its ''junk bond'' portfolio. **********I.C.H., an insurance holding company that owns 20 percent of First Executive, announced its intentions after First Executive agreed to waive provisions of an earlier ''standstill'' agreement between the companies that prohibited an acquisition offer. **********I.C.H., which is based in Louisville, Ky., said any offer would be in cash and would be for all common shares of First Executive. Under the terms of its agreement with First Executive, I.C.H. would have to make its offer by July 1. **********I.C.H. said it would approach other large shareholders of First Executive, which include Rosewood Financial Inc., a Texas partnership controlled by Caroline Rose Hunt, and the Airlie Group L.P., an investment group that includes the Bass family of Texas, to participate in the offer. **********I.C.H. is already struggling with large debts, and analysts expressed some skepticism about its ability to raise financing for any offer. **********Investors reacted cautiously today. First Executive's shares rose 12.5 cents, to $3.625, in over-the-counter trading. I.C.H. fell 25 cents, to $3.75, on the American Stock Exchange. **********First Executive stunned Wall Street late last Friday with the news that it would take charges of up to $515 million in the fourth quarter because of problems with its junk bond portfolio, which is suffering from defaults by issuers and the sharp drop in market prices. The company said the charges would result in a substantial loss for 1989. **********The news sent the Los Angeles-based company's stock price down sharply, from $7 at the end of last week to as low as $3 this week. The stock had traded above $10 last year. **********I.C.H. did not indicate how much it might be willing to pay. Analysts say it is difficult to put a value on First Executive because of the uncertainties about the future performance of the junk bond portfolio, which currently has a market value of $1.4 billion less than its $14 billion book value. **********As First Executive's largest shareholder, I.C.H. was hit hardest by the plunge in the company's shares. John A. Franco, I.C.H.'s chief executive, said I.C.H. will have to take a write-down in the value of its investment in First Executive, causing a loss for the fourth quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/14/busin.main_headline: GTE Picks President For Its New Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/14/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   GTE Picks President For Its New Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/14/busin.body_text: **********The GTE Corporation has named Terry S. Parker president of its new Telecommunications Products and Services Group. **********Mr. Parker, who is 45 years old, had been president of GTE's mobile communications division in Houston since 1988. Mr. Parker joined GTE in 1969 working at the General Telephone Company of Indiana. **********His appointment is considered an indication of the importance of cellular phones within the telephone industry, Tony Hamilton, a company spokesman said. The new group combines GTE's lightly regulated divisions: government systems, information services, mobile communications and spacenet units. **********The creation of the new group will give Charles R. Lee, GTE's president and chief operating officer, more time to complete GTE's merger with the Contel Corporation, a leading local telephone and cellular service corporation. **********The merger, which is expected to be completed by 1991, will make GTE, based in Stamford, Conn., the second-largest cellular company in the United States. **********Several of Contel's business units may fall under the direction of Mr. Parker, whose responsibilities will include coordinating projects among the four divisions. **********''What makes this job attractive to me is that we have the opportunity now to pool the resources of these divisions,'' Mr. Parker said. ''This is really a marriage of technological capabilities.'' **********Mr. Parker has also been named to the company's policy committee and will continue to run the mobile communications division until the merger with Contel is complete. **********Paul G. Kozlowski, the president and chief executive officer of Contel cellular will replace Mr. Parker as president of the mobile communications division after the merger, a GTE spokesman said. **********GTE's cellular customers increased to 382,000 last year from 202,000 in 1988. **********GTE subsidiaries operate in 46 states and 41 countries, with combined revenues and sales of $17.4 billion. Net income last year was $1.4 billion. **********Mr. Parker has been vice president of marketing for GTE's Midwestern telephone operations and vice president for regulatory affairs from 1982 to 1985. He had been vice president and controller for General Telephone Company of Michigan from 1980 to 1982. **********Mr. Parker has a degree in accounting from Ball State University and a master's degree in business from Indiana University. He lives in Houston with his wife, Kimberly, and their two children. He plans to travel frequently between Stamford, Conn., Houston and GTE's divisions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/25/busin.main_headline: Net Plunges At Two Big Brokerages
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/25/busin.print_headline: Net Plunges At Two Big Brokerages
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/25/busin.body_text: **********Reflecting the slump on Wall Street, two of the largest investment houses, the Morgan Stanley Group and Salomon Inc., reported quarterly earnings yesterday that were down sharply from the comparable period last year. **********For the quarter ending June 30, Morgan Stanley posted an earnings decline of 48.2 percent, to $58 million, or $1.44 a share, compared with $112.1 million, or $2.83 a share, in the 1989 quarter. Salomon posted a drop of 52 percent, at $120 million, or 89 cents a share, from $253 million, or $1.89 a share, in the 1989 quarter. **********Analysts called the results at both firms respectable, considering the general decline in the industry. **********''Both Morgan Stanley and Salomon showed very decent earnings given the operating environment.'' said Perrin Long, an analyst at Lipper Analytical. **********In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday Morgan Stanley's shares dropped $6, to $66.50, and Salomon's shares were unchanged at $24.50. **********Morgan Stanley **********For Morgan Stanley, which until yesterday's announcement appeared to have weathered the bad news that has struck at most other firms, the lower profits reflected substantially reduced merchant banking and investment banking businesses compared with a strong quarter in those areas last year. **********Investment banking revenue fell 26.5 percent, to $166 million, in the quarter from $226 million a year earlier. The firm's trading profits dropped to $61.8 million from $65.1 million, while investment revenue plummeted to $516,000 from $51.5 million. **********For the quarter, the firm reported revenues of $1.45 billion, compared with $1.52 billion for the second quarter of last year. The figures put the firm's earnings for the first six months at $140.2 million, or $3.51 a share, compared with $193.3 million, or $4.86 a share, for the first six months of 1989. **********Salomon **********At Salomon, executives emphasized that for the first six months, the firm was doing better than for the similar period in 1989. **********For the first six months, the firm posted income of $239 million on revenues of $4.45 billion, compared with earnings of $225 million and revenues of $3.87 billion for the first six months of last year. **********In the latest quarter, the firm suffered a loss of $62 million in its commodities unit, compared with a $3 million loss for the second quarter of 1989. The loss brings the commodities unit losses to $83 million for the first six months of the year, prompting an executive at the firm to note that the continuing losses in the unit would probably lead to a shake-up soon. **********The firm's brokerage unit made $211 million before taxes, down from $364 million in the 1989 quarter. **********Salomon's Phibro Energy oil unit reported pretax earnings of $49 million, down from $92 million in the similar period last year, but up substantially from $4 million in earnings for the first quarter. **********Salomon reported quarterly revenues of $2.09 billion, compared with $2.33 billion for the second quarter last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   Dow Back Above 200-Day Average
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   Dow Back Above 200-Day Average
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/busin.body_text: **********THE stock market yesterday faced a substantial technical test, one that it seems to have passed. **********The test came as the Dow Jones industrial average tried to bounce back after falling below its 200-day moving average, a level that is followed by many technical analysts and that has proved to be an important point throughout the bull market that began in 1982. **********Repeatedly during the decade, market retreats were halted as soon as the Dow fell to its 200-day moving average - that is, to the average of closing levels of the index for each of the last 200 trading days, about 10 1/2 months. Prices then rebounded to higher levels in most cases, as the halt of declines at the moving average figure was taken as a sign that the bull market was intact. **********In the two cases where the market did not show immediate strength after falling below the 200-day moving average, it was time to sell stocks and do so quickly. Those cases came in January 1984, early in the only prolonged slide since 1982, and in October 1987, providing just enough warning for a very nimble investor to get out before the crash. **********Because of the market's habit of bouncing back, there were some who were ready to buy when trading opened yesterday, hoping that a bounce would result. In addition, there was encouragement from Japan, whose market weakness earlier in January had fed on and intensified the slide in American stock prices. The Tokyo stock market managed to shrug off Monday's 77.45-point fall in the Dow and rally. **********But the Dow's rally proved to be a short-lived one, vanishing before the morning was out and yielding to a 12-point deficit. The Dow regained strength in the afternoon, however, and closed up 14.87 points, to 2,615.32. That was 8.36 points, or 32-hundredths of 1 percent, above its 200-day moving average of 2,606.96. **********On Monday, the plunge had left the average 4.94 points, or 19-hundredths of 1 percent, below the 200-day moving average, which was then 2,605.39. **********The history in the bull market that began in 1982 shows that in December 1984 and August and November 1988 the Dow fell to just below its 200-day moving average, then rallied almost immediately. On other occasions in 1984 and 1985, it rallied after falling to just above the 200-day figure. **********But twice that level failed to provide support, and any time the market slipped more than 1.3 percent below the average it was time to get out. **********The most dramatic incident came in October 1987, when the Dow slipped below its moving average on Oct. 15 for the first time since 1984. Instead of bouncing back, it plunged 108 points the next day, Friday, Oct. 16, leaving it 5 percent below its 200-day average. The following Monday, Oct. 19, saw the index fall a record 508 points. The 1984 case was less dramatic, but getting out as the indicator dropped to 2 percent below the moving average would have saved an investor from a further 10 percent decline. **********No technical indicator is infallible, but the sheer fact that some speculators follow one can give it some impact, at least on a short-term basis. Yesterday's buying was concentrated in blue-chip stocks, with some buying by index-arbitrage program traders. Among the 30 stocks in the Dow, 16 were up, 11 down and 3 unchanged. For the Big Board as a whole, however, more stocks declined than rose. **********New worries arose after a late blip up in interest rates following a disappointing auction of 40-year bonds by the Resolution Funding Corporation. ''That's another hurdle,'' said Robert Farrell, the chief market analyst for Merrill Lynch, who thinks that highly bearish stock market sentiment will lead to a temporary rally within a month or two, but fears the decline will then resume. **********Another technician who saw the bounce back from the 200-day average as only a temporary positive was Stan Weinstein, the editor of the Professional Tape Reader newsletter of Hollywood, Fla. ''Longer term, this market is sick and is going to disintegrate,'' he said, citing the fact that few stocks rallied with the Dow as the year began. ''I don't think a rally could do much more than 2,700, and then the next decline will break the 200-day average.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/10/world.main_headline: Gorbachev Signs Treaty in Bonn And Is Hailed for His Unity Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/10/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE; Gorbachev Signs Treaty in Bonn And Is Hailed for His Unity Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/10/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was hailed in Germany today on the anniversary of the breach of the Berlin wall for helping make German unity possible. But the Soviet leader's reduced status was underscored when he appealed to the Germans to be tolerant of the Soviet troops still stationed on their soil. **********At a news conference, Mr. Gorbachev also gave a strong reaffirmation of solidarity with the West against Iraq. "The joint action in the United Nations Security Council condemned the aggressor," he said. "We have taken decisive measures, and all efforts to shake this unity are doomed." **********The principal reason for Mr. Gorbachev's visit was to sign a treaty of "good-neighborliness, partnership and cooperation" with Germany that he and Chancellor Helmut Kohl had agreed to as part of the broad package that cleared the way for Moscow's endorsement of German unity. Bush Visit Later in Month **********Mr. Gorbachev became the first foreign leader to make a state visit to the reunited Germany, and the treaty was the first to be signed since reunification on Oct. 3. President Bush is expected to make a brief visit shortly before the Paris summit meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe this month. **********Mr. Gorbachev's visit was marked by demonstrations of official friendship and cooperation. For Mr. Kohl, who is campaigning for the all-German elections scheduled for Dec. 3, it also provided a well-timed chance to bask in the continued popularity of the Soviet leader, who despite his troubles at home is still held in high esteem by Germans as the man they perceive as having made possible the reunification of their nation. **********"We Germans in particular acknowledge with deep gratitude your personal contribution to the propitious turning point in our history," Mr. Kohl told Mr. Gorbachev at a state banquet this evening. **********"A year ago today the Berlin wall collapsed," Mr. Kohl said. "A few weeks ago our divided nation recovered its unity in freedom and in harmony with all its neighbors and partners. The fact that you are the first foreign head of state to visit our united country augments our esteem." **********But it was also clear that Mr. Gorbachev was not the same leader who had drawn chants of "Gorby! Gorby!" when he first visited Bonn in June 1989. Then he was still undisputed master of the Soviet Union, and still held levers over the Germans. **********This time, his shaky standing at home was evidenced by the fact that Mr. Gorbachev had delayed his visit by several days because of unspecified Soviet problems. His weakened standing was further underscored by his appeal to the Germans to treat the Soviet soldiers remaining in their land "as a test of the ability to build relations among people truly on the basis of humanity and friendship." **********The Germans agreed last summer to let the Soviets phase their military withdrawal from the former East Germany over four years. But the pullout has been marred by numerous defections and by outbursts of hostility from Germans. **********"The euphoria of breaking with everything that was connected with the G.D.R. regime, especially in recent years, has given painful tones, even an anti-Soviet element, to the attitudes of a certain portion of Germans toward the Soviet Union," Mr. Gorbachev said. "But I am convinced that this is only a temporary development." No New Aid Pledges **********German officials indicated that Mr. Gorbachev received no new pledges of financial aid on this trip. Germany has already pledged a hefty package, including 3 billion marks, or $2 billion, in interest-free loans and 12 billion marks, or $8 billion, in assistance for the Soviet troop withdrawal, and Bonn is facing heavy expenditures in eastern Germany. **********But the Germans did agree to increase their purchases of oil and gas from the Soviet Union, and to send a team of experts to advise Moscow on economic reforms. **********The treaty that served as the centerpiece of the visit basically defined far-reaching cooperation in economic, scientific, cultural and political spheres between Germany and the Soviet Union. Unlike similar treaties signed with other European countries, however, it also included a nonaggression clause that called on both sides to "never and under no circumstances be the first to employ armed forces against one another or against third states." **********France, for example, signed a similar treaty with Moscow on Oct. 29, but rejected a nonaggression clause. **********In his comments, Mr. Gorbachev seemed to take pains to preclude any impression that the treaty created a special relationship between Germany and the Soviet Union, perhaps mindful that some Europeans might hear echoes of the infamous Soviet-Nazi pact that preceded World War II. Treaty 'Not Unique' **********"The Soviet-German Treaty is not aimed against anyone," Mr. Gorbachev said. He declared that the improved relations with Germany were due in large part to the improvement in Soviet-Amercan relations, as well as in Moscow's ties to France and Britain. He insisted, too, that "our treaty is not unique," that a similar pact had been signed with France and that another might soon be reached with Britain. **********Mr. Gorbachev said he and Mr. Kohl spent considerable time discussing the Persian Gulf crisis, but he gave few details. **********At the news conference, he spoke of the cooperation achieved at the United Nations as a "great victory." **********"Maybe this seems strange to you," he said, "but this is the first time since the war, maybe in all history, that we have acted in the spirit of unity in so critical a situation in the context of the United Nations." **********On the question of further measures, however, Mr. Gorbachev said, "We do not need to discuss any plans for any operations here."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/15/busin.body_text: **********Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report fell in the week ended yesterday. **********Analysts at Donoghue's said the markets continued to react to weak economic news and the anticipation of an easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve. Oil prices are stable and inflationary numbers have been reasonable, they said. **********"But the Federal Reserve still has to take that first bite, and most likely there will be some disappointment as expectations of how much always outruns the actual amount," said Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist. **********Given the current rate of return on Treasury securities and bank certificates of deposit, yields offered by money market funds are still competitive, but the crossover point is drawing near, when investors who monitor the differences in yields will commit themselves. "That's when you'll see the cash flow into the funds dwindle," Mr. Frank said.  Tax-Exempt Yield **********Managers of tax-exempt money market funds lowered the average number of days that securities are held in portfolios by a day, to 55 days. **********Assets fell by $94 million, to $83.7 billion, as the average seven-day tax-exempt compounded yield dropped by 11 basis points, to 5.19 percent, and the 30-day compounded average yield fell 9 basis points, to 5.36 percent. **********For investors in a 28 percent tax bracket, the equivalent taxable seven-day yield is 7.20 percent, and for investors in a 33 percent bracket, the rate is 7.74 percent. **********Among tax-exempt funds with assets of better than $100 million that are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund produced the best return for the week. The fund is managed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc., Milwaukee.  Taxable Fund Assets **********Assets of taxable funds increased by $500 million, to $410.1 billion. Institutional funds rose by $500 million, to $89.4 billion, while consumer assets with no new cash inflow displayed a lot of switching within the category. Donoghue's said consumers shifted about $800 million from non-Treasury funds to Treasuries. **********The average maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios remained unchanged at 45 days. **********Donoghue's said the seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market fund fell 5 basis points, to 7.61 percent, while the 30-day average yield, slipped 2 basis points, to 7.68 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/05/busin.body_text: **********Japan announced Friday that it was resuming a development loan program for China that has been frozen since the brutal suppression of pro-democracy protests in Beijing last year. **********Japan will make available up to $283 million to China for seven projects "to contribute to economic stability and to promote the economic modernization efforts of the country," the Foreign Ministry said. **********It said in a statement that Japan's Ambassador to China, Hiroshi Hashimoto, and Qi Huaiyuan, a Chinese Foreign Ministry official, had exchanged a memorandum of understanding on the plan. **********The money is part of a five-year package of development loans to China totaling $6.28 billion. **********In July, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu promised to resume the loans gradually. Other industrialized democracies have also been gradually easing sanctions on China in recent months. **********The terms of the loans to China include an annual interest rate of 2.5 percent and a 30-year repayment period. Japan will not require that Japanese companies be involved in the programs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/18/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Philip Morris Unit In German Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/18/busin.body_text: **********Philip Morris G.m.b.H., the West German subsidiary of the Philip Morris Companies, has agreed to acquire the East German cigarette manufacturer VEB Kombinat Tabak. Terms were not disclosed. **********George Knox, a Philip Morris spokesman, said the companies had signed a letter to merge and the deal was expected to close this month. Philip Morris sells about six billion cigarettes in Eastern Europe a year, Mr. Knox said. VEB, based in Dresden, produces about 10 billion cigarettes annually.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/30/world.main_headline: Premier of Trinidad Offers to Quit if Rebels End Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/30/world.print_headline: Premier of Trinidad Offers to Quit if Rebels End Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/30/world.body_text: **********Trinidad and Tobago's security chief said today there was scant hope of an early breakthrough in negotiations for the release of Prime Minister Arthur N .R. Robinson, who was taken hostage on Friday in a coup attempt by Muslim rebels and reportedly wired to explosives. **********Gunfire and widespread looting continued for the third day, turning the capital's downtown streets into a virtual combat zone. A curfew was extended throughout this two-island Caribbean nation in an effort to restore order. **********A senior official at Port of Spain's main hospital said that at least 300 people had been wounded since the group of Muslim militants began its attempt to topple the Government on Friday. The leader of the group, Abu Bakr, said his aim was to end Government corruption. **********Appearing on national television, Security Minister Herbert Atwell described the negotiations with the group holding Mr. Robinson and key members of his Cabinet at the Parliament building as a ''touch-and-go situation.'' **********Exploring 'Reasonable Options' **********''We are going to exhaust all reasonable options for a peaceful solution,'' he said, adding ''I am in no position to give any hope'' for an early solution. Asked how long he believed the standoff would last, he replied: ''If I could answer that, I could win the lottery. I can give no indication.'' **********It was the Government's first statement on its negotiations with members of the radical Jamaat al- Muslimeen group, and it flatly contradicted rebel statements that Mr. Robinson had agreed to resign and that an accord was near. **********Flying with President Bush from Kennebunkport, Me., to Washington, the United States national security adviser, Brent Scrowcroft, also denied a report today of a deal involving the 63-year-old Prime Minister's resignation. **********Mr. Robinson, who was wounded in the leg when the rebels stormed the Parliament, has served as Prime Minister since 1986. Elections are not due until the end of 1991. **********Curfew Extended **********Announcing tougher security measures in Trinidad and Tobago, which has a population of 1.3 million, Mr. Atwell said that a national curfew was being extended from 12 to 18 hours a day and that military and police units had begun joint patrols. **********Mr. Atwell, who was not in the Parliament when the rebels burst in firing AK-47 assault rifles, said the Government had decided to impose a 24-hour curfew around the Parliament and the television station where the rebels are holed up. **********In storming the Parliament building and seizing control of a state-run television station on Friday, the Muslim rebels said they had toppled the elected Government. **********The army and the police have remained loyal to the Government and surrounded the buildings held by the rebels. A tense standoff resulted. **********Despite the capture of Mr. Robinson and other officials, ''the Government is functioning and is taking every step to restore security,'' Mr. Atwell said. **********Accord Had Been Predicted **********The extremists led by Abu Bakr are known as the Jamaat al-Muslimeen. About 250 of the group's members are believed to be involved in the coup attempt. **********The rebels said late Saturday that they were close to an agreement that provided for Mr. Robinson's resignation, new elections within 90 days and an amnesty for the coup plotters. **********But almost 24 hours after that statement was issued by a rebel spokesman, the state radio station quoted a rebel leader as saying that the negotiations were taking longer than expected. **********As gunfire continued to crackle today in Port of Spain, a senior official at the capital's main hospital said that about 300 people had been wounded, most of them by gunfire, since violence flared Friday. **********Stewart Smith, assistant administrator of the city's state-run General Hospital, said about 200 of those people were still being treated. The Caribbean News Agency reported over the weekend that 22 people had been killed. **********Measures Against Looters **********Announcing the deployment of police and military patrols, the Acting Police Superintendent, Leonard Taylor, said late today, ''There has been serious looting and we are going to take stronger measures to prevent it.'' **********The radio said that the police were under orders to shoot looters, who have rampaged through the center of the capital and left practically every shop empty. **********The rebels denied reports that they had demanded a plane to fly Abu Bakr and his followers to Libya, a country that the rebel leader has visited several times. **********The Government radio said that negotiations for an end to the hostage crisis were continuing, with a senior Anglican cleric, Knolly Clarke, acting as a mediator. Ignoring the Signs?  A senior police official said today that the Government had ignored police warnings that the Muslim group was planning violent operations with the backing of Libya. **********The official, who declined to be named, said that the police raided one of the group's communes earlier this year and discovered a cache of weapons. Last December, he said, three Libyans visited Trinidad to train Muslim militants. **********Although detailed information on these activities was relayed to the Government, no action was taken, he said. **********Trinidad and Tobago, a multiracial, oil-producing republic off the Venezuelan coast, has been hit hard by a fall in oil prices. Unemployment has jumped to 20 percent. **********Foreigners Seek to Leave **********Commercial flights to Port of Spain were suspended again today. **********At the Hilton Hotel, dozens of foreigners, including a number of Americans and Europeans on vacation, crowded into the lobby seeking information on when they could leave. **********The capital's residents were advised to stay off the streets. **********The Bishop of Trinidad and Tobago, Clive Abdulah, appealed today for an end to the looting. ''Those who have set up a whole convoy of vehicles to take away large iterms such as refrigerators, TV's and video recorders should stop,'' he said in a radio broadcast. **********Residents of the capital said that the coup attempt was precipitated by a police raid last month on swampland reclaimed and developed by the Muslim group on the outskirts of the capital over the past decade. **********The group had built schools, a mosque and other buildings on the land, which the Government says the group does not own and is seeking to have them vacate. **********Rebels Trained in Libya **********WASHINGTON, July 29 (Special to The New York Times) - The leaders of the Muslim group holding the Prime Minister of Trinidad and other hostages received training in Libya last fall, State Department officials said today, but it is unclear whether the militants acted alone or had foreign backing for their coup attempt. **********''These people definitely have a Libyan connection,'' said a department official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Among those who were trained in Libya were the group's leader, Abu Bakr, and two aides, the official said. **********Mr. Abu Bakr was described by a State Department official as a ''do-gooder'' who has tried to cultivate a following among the country's poor. **********An official of the Trinidad Defense Ministry, interviewed by telephone today, described the group as ''radical'' and ''fanatical,'' but said that it had not been actively involved in politics. **********In an interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation monitored today in Barbados, Mr. Abu Bakr said he had visited Libya several times. **********''I am a personal friend of Colonel Qaddafi,'' he said. ''I am a Muslim and they are Muslims. I have also had help from other Muslim countries, such as Saudi Arabia.'' **********State Department officials expressed disbelief that the group had any ties to Saudi Arabia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   BAGHDAD WARNS DIPLOMATS AGAINST 'ACT OF AGGRESSION'; HUSSEIN SHOWS OFF HOSTAGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   BAGHDAD WARNS DIPLOMATS AGAINST 'ACT OF AGGRESSION'; HUSSEIN SHOWS OFF HOSTAGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/world.body_text: **********Iraq warned the United States and more than two dozen other nations Thursday that if they challenged a deadline today and tried to keep their embassies in Iraq-occupied Kuwait open, as they have vowed to do, Baghdad would take it as an ''act of aggression.'' **********Ambassador W. Nathaniel Howell 3d and fewer than a dozen aides remained in the American Embassy early today. Indications here Thursday night were that any Iraqi effort to shut down the United States Embassy or those of other nations would not trigger an immediate response by the American military, as long as no attempt was made to harm or kill the American citizens who remain inside. **********The Bush Administration appears to have concluded that the Iraqis are preparing to cut off water, power and telephone lines to the embassies. But the Iraqis are seen as unlikely to take any other overt military action to invade the buildings, which are considered sovereign territory of the nations involved. **********Uncertainty on Deadline **********American officials said they were uncertain about the exact deadline imposed by the Iraqis for closing embassies in Kuwait. Some accounts gave it as noon today (5 A.M. Eastern standard time), while others gave it as 8 P.M. today, or 1 P.M. EST. **********But the impression here Thursday night was that the United States and other countries believed that diplomats in Kuwait could only hold out for a matter of days under such circumstances. **********The ''red lines'' set by the Bush Administration as intolerable Iraqi action that could prompt a military response were more extreme: the killing of American citizens, an Iraqi military attack on Saudi Arabia or its oilfields, or an attack by Iraqi forces on Israel - a possibility that may be the one most feared by Mr. Bush, according to indications here Thursday night. **********There were also indications that the Administration was moving toward a decision in the next day or two to start boarding or disabling Iraqi oil tankers. **********Soviet Influence **********The Administration is said to have been delaying such action primarily at the urging of the Soviet Union, which is concerned about the fate of 5,000 to 8,000 of its citizens living in Iraq. Moscow also is said to have argued that there is a glimmer of hope that Iraq might back down in the face of international sanctions, basing that contention on a visit to the Soviet Union this week by the Deputy Prime Minister of Iraq, Sadun Hammadi. **********While the Administration has not addressed the issue of how Mr. Bush intends to weigh the lives of American hostages against the potential need for military action, the impression here is that Mr. Bush would use force if he believes it is unavoidable - even if that might endanger the lives of Americans and other foreigners. **********Mr. Bush has almost said as much himself, declaring that while American lives are important to him, the United Nations sanctions imposed against Iraq after the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 must be enforced. **********''I think any decision maker in the United States or in any of these countries is concerned about the lives of innocent civilians, innocent people,'' Mr. Bush said Wednesday at a news conference here. ''And so, you weigh that very thoroughly against your actions. Having said that, international law in this case, the Chapter 7 sanctions, must be enforced.'' **********A convoy carrying more than 100 people from the United States Embassy - diplomats, dependents and the entire Marine guard detachment -crossed from Kuwait into Iraq on Thursday, leaving behind Ambassador Howell and fewer than a dozen aides. A senior White House official said, ''A few Marine guards aren't going to fight off the entire Iraqi Army.'' **********The diplomats who stayed behind risked being taken hostage, for Baghdad has said that envoys who remain in Kuwait after the deadline will lose diplomatic status. **********Only India and Lebanon, among major nations, acceded to Iraqi orders to close their embassies. There were unofficial reports that the Philippines would also do so. But like the United States, most countries evacuated most of their staffs; Britain left only four diplomats in place, including Ambassador Michael Weston. **********Suggesting that a showdown could be near, European officials said they had been told that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq would surround the embassies with troops. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney warned that this would be a mistake. A Belgian official said all of the European Community ambassadors might assemble in one place ''to make their expulsion as dramatic as possible.'' **********The Pentagon said Thursday that as many as 49,703 servicemen and women could be involved in the first two rounds of a limited reserve callup, 10,000 more than officials had said on Wednesday. Britain announced the dispatch of a second 12-plane squadron of Tornado attack aircraft, American minesweepers were dispatched to join the Persian Gulf flotilla and a United States military unit, the 7th Medical Command, was sent from Germany to Saudi Arabia. No Breakthrough at U.N.  In another military development, officials said that American sailors had already boarded about a half-dozen merchant ships suspected of violating the United Nations embargo on Iraqi commerce. **********Washington's effort to win explicit United Nations support for the naval blockade it has been leading yielded some progress as representatives of the five permanent members of the Security Council - the United States, France, Britain, China and the Soviet Union - sent a draft resolution to their Governments for review. Diplomats said France and Britain had accepted the wording of the proposal, but that Soviet objections had not yet been resolved. **********Mr. Bush said in the news conference on Wednesday that he was willing to wait only a little longer for United Nations action before ordering American ships to use force to halt vessels that violate the sanctions. **********As the Middle East crisis entered its fourth week, Iraq continued to move foreigners from Kuwait to Baghdad and its environs. Poles returning home reported that about three dozen Americans were taken last Friday to the Chemadex chemical plant at Al Qaim in western Iraq, where the Eastern Europeans had been working. American experts said the plant produces phosphorus fertilizers, not chemical weapons. **********Outrage at Iraqi Broadcast **********American officials, reportedly including Mr. Bush, were outraged by an Iraqi television broadcast on Thursday in which an avuncular President Hussein met with a number of hostages, playfully ruffling a small boy's hair. Most of the captives seemed to be British. **********The broadcast seemed to be an attempt by Mr. Hussein, who has been denounced in the West as a bully, to demonstrate his benevolence toward individuals while signaling that an American attack on Iraq would inevitably cost the lives of Western women and children. **********Richard A. Boucher, a State Department spokesman, denounced the broadcast as ''shameful theatrics.'' The British Foreign Office assailed it as a ''repulsive charade.'' **********Baghdad radio reported Thursday night that the Iraqi leader had authorized the release of a 15-year-old British youth who was separated from his family during the crisis. The broadcast gave his name as Alex Cameron Farni, but The Associated Press said that officials at the British Foreign Office in London later identified him as Alex Barnett. A spokesman for British Airways quoted by the news agency said the boy was traveling to the Gulf region from London without his family when his plane was stranded in Kuwait. **********Elite Iraqi Troop Movements **********The State Department said it had counted 56 Americans who were in the hands of the Iraqis - 41 seized in Iraq and 15 in Kuwait. Mr. Bush declared earlier this week that the 2,500 non-official Americans in Kuwait and the 530 in Iraq must now be considered hostages. **********In Tokyo, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said that 178 Japanese had been flown in three groups to Baghdad from the Japanese Embassy in Kuwait, where they had taken refuge. Another group of 62 was reportedly following. Shortly before the movements, Japan announced its intention to help reimburse countries that supported United Nations sanctions against Iraq at considerable cost to their own domestic economies. **********Two Under Secretaries of the United Nations met on Thursday with nine hostages at an undisclosed location about an hour's drive from Baghdad, a spokesman for the organization said. **********The nationalities of the nine captives, men between the ages of 17 and 63, were not given. The United Nations Under Secretaries, Virenda Dayal and Kofi Annan, arrived in Iraq on Tuesday to seek the release of some of the thousands of foreigners, including 21,000 Westerners estimated to be trapped by the conflict. **********A Pentagon official said Thursday night that there were signs that Iraq was pulling back elements of the elite Presidential Guard, the vanguard of the force that invaded Kuwait, from the Saudi border and replacing them with ''second stringers.'' **********Concern Over Soviet Advisers **********The official said it was unclear why the guard units were pulling back. He suggested that Mr. Hussein may not want to entrench his elite fighters along the front lines, or that the Iraqi President fears coup attempts from within his ranks and needs the guard's help. **********Jordan, which announced on Wednesday that it was closing its border with Iraq to all refugees, left it open for another day Thursday. At least 30,000 more refugees poured through the Ruweishid border crossing as King Hussein of Jordan embarked on another peace-seeking mission to Arab capitals, starting with a trip to the Sudan. **********Although Mr. Bush praised Soviet cooperation in American efforts as ''superb'' on Wednesday, United States officials said they were troubled by the presence of almost 200 Soviet military advisers in Iraq. Mr. Boucher said the Administration strongly believed ''that it is inappropriate to provide any form of military assistance to Iraq.'' **********The Soviet Union's reluctance to have the United Nations promptly endorse a blockade also irritated policy makers here. **********'Mounting Toward a Peak' **********Still, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, Yuri Gremitskykh, pleased Washington with his comment Thursday that ''Iraq should change drastically the policy which it is pursuing now.'' He added, ''Baghdad has lost much, politically and morally, in the eyes of world public opinion by its illegal and inhumane actions against citizens of third countries.'' **********In Israel, which is separated from Iraq by an increasingly shaky Jordan, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir warned that the crisis was ''mounting toward a peak,'' and a civil-defense official urged citizens to stock up on food, tape their windows shut and mix a homemade antidote in anticipation of Iraqi use of poison gas. **********But in Washington, military officers said the Bush Administration had canceled an earlier alert issued to two United States-based Ranger battalions, in the belief that their involvement would feed speculation about a commando-type thrust by American forces into Iraq or Kuwait. **********Representative Dante B. Fascell, the Florida Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs Committee, called on the President to tell Congress in a joint session when lawmakers return in two weeks exactly what his intentions are in the Persian Gulf. Among other things, he said he wanted to know how the enormous military undertaking would be financed and whether other countries were ready to pay a share of costs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/busin.main_headline: A Company Gives Up on New York
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/busin.print_headline: FORUM; A Company Gives Up on New York
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/busin.body_text: **********THE budget agreement that is now working its way toward enactment is a good one. It will not achieve all that is claimed for it, but it will make substantial cuts in the deficit that are real. The tax increases and some of the entitlement cuts will be locked into substantive law, and, barring a shooting war in the Persian Gulf, future defense spending is likely to be less than what the budget agreement promises. **********We Americans are finally facing up, if only partially, to correcting a decade of public and private profligacy, during which the country borrowed massively at home and abroad to finance a consumption boom. As a nation we now save and invest only 3 percent of our national income. Our economic future depends on raising national saving, mainly through getting rid of the Federal budget deficit and ultimately turning it into a surplus. The budget agreement is a major step in that direction. **********The magnitude of the sacrifices the American people have now been asked to make is actually quite small. The sum of all the tax increases, about which such a titanic struggle has been waged, will amount to something like seven-tenths of 1 percent of national income. Yet listening to months of rhetoric about "fairness" -- on the part of the Democrats -- and "the need to preserve incentives," on the part of the Republicans, made it seem that the country was engaged in some massive economic restructuring, a perestroika of our own. **********The progressivity of the latest tax agreement makes it better than the original proposal. And establishing the principle that progressive income taxes are not off-limits when taxes have to be raised is worthwhile. **********But most of the political fights that erupted were not worth bringing the whole agreement to the brink of defeat. Reducing the gasoline tax increase from 12 cents to 5 cents a gallon, for example, will mean a savings of only about $1.40 a week for the average family. Inequality in the United States has indeed increased over the past 15 years, but the tax code was not the principal culprit. **********The Republican position in the recent squabble was particularly silly. Does anyone really believe that American productivity and efficiency will be seriously affected by whether upper-income executives and Silicon Valley entrepreneurs pay a top-bracket rate of 28, 31 or 33 percent? Do our German and Japanese competitors appear to be severely handicapped by the fact that one has a top income tax rate of 53 percent and the other of 50 percent? Only in the heat of an ideological passion, could grown people make so much of so little. **********The payoff from reducing the budget deficit will not be immediate. It will not rescue us from the recession we are apparently entering. Rather, it will come from larger national savings and investment, whose benefits in the form of higher economic growth will show up only gradually. **********It is terribly hard to muster political support to do painful things for such subtle and distant goals. And for eight years the country has had two popular Presidents who have not only failed to use their office to mobilize public opinion toward that goal, but have actively blocked the modest tax increases that were obviously necessary to reach it. **********Small wonder that the Congressional troops concentrated on bickering about how the costs were to be divided. The bully pulpit had never been used to educate the troops' constituents on what the benefits would be. **********In the end what is truly remarkable is the fact that the system ended up doing the responsible thing. President Bush deserves credit for reversing his stand on taxes. But the real heroes are the Congressional leadership. Ultimately, even the troops in the trenches look as if they will respond with an act of political courage. The majority will vote for a tax increase two weeks before an election. It is not such a bad system after all.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.main_headline: In Beijing, Wishful Whispers That Li Will Fall
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.print_headline: In Beijing, Wishful Whispers That Li Will Fall
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.body_text: **********The whispers among Chinese officials these days are all about power struggles or major reshuffles in the leadership. **********Many of the whispers concern a possible demotion for Prime Minister Li Peng. The problem with assessing the rumors is that Mr. Li appears to be one of the most disliked people in China these days, many Chinese and foreign diplomats say. Thus it is difficult to tell whether the rumors are based on fact or on wishful thinking. **********Whether or not Mr. Li falls, other senior leaders are widely expected to be replaced during the National People's Congress in March and April. Most accounts are that there will be one or two new deputy prime ministers, and perhaps a new vice president. **********Those mentioned for the posts tend to favor economic liberalization, and if they are promoted, as is rumored, it would be a sign that perhaps China is returning to the path of economic restructuring that it pursued for a decade before the violent crackdown in June. **********The rumors about Mr. Li are mostly traded among middle-level and senior officials. Even if they are not true, they could impair his effectiveness. **********One official said he and other policy advisers were now unenthusiastic about providing information and recommendations for the Prime Minister because they believe that he might not be around much longer. **********So far, no one says he has seen a document spelling out Mr. Li's resignation, and there is no clear evidence that he is in difficulty. Indeed, there is some evidence to the contrary. A friend of Mr. Li, Zou Jiahua, was named to the pivotal position of head of the State Planning Commission last month. **********But some Chinese officials say Mr. Li was highly embarrassed at the fifth plenum of the Communist Party Central Committee, in November. They say he made a detailed proposal to the Central Committee, calling for rewriting the formula for how much money the provinces pass on to the central Government. The proposal would have called for higher contributions from the provinces; the Central Committee, which includes many provincial leaders, rejected it. **********Those who believe that Mr. Li will lose his job note that China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, hinted at that on May 31 in a speech that has still not been officially released. ''We should change the group of leaders,'' Mr. Deng said in the speech. ''The new group of leaders should be a brand new one that conveys a new image to the people.'' **********Mentioned most often by Chinese officials to replace Mr. Li is Li Ruihuan, a 66-year-old former construction worker who is one of six members of the Politburo's standing committee. He is more popular than most top officials, and he is regarded as a centrist. **********A senior Chinese cited an incident in support of the theory that a power struggle was under way. The official said the Prime Minister's office telephoned the national television headquarters to complain that the news clip of Li Ruihuan meeting with a foreign dignitary lasted longer than the one of Li Peng meeting with the dignitary. **********Aside from Li Ruihuan, the most widely mentioned candidates for promotion are Zhu Rongji, the ruler of Shanghai, and Ye Xuanping, the Governor of Guangdong Province. Mr. Zhu and Mr. Ye, who are believed to be under consideration for deputy prime ministers, are regarded as among the strongest advocates of economic restructuring left in the leadership.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/03/busin.main_headline: All About/Platinum;   A Thriving Market Guaranteed By Both Vanity and Pollution
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/03/busin.print_headline: All About/Platinum;   A Thriving Market Guaranteed By Both Vanity and Pollution
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/03/busin.body_text: **********When the Ford Motor Company announced in December 1988 that it had developed a catalytic converter that would not require platinum, the metal's price plunged. Platinum producers feared that demand would evaporate. But Ford's new converter is still in testing, and platinum demand is near an all-time high. **********Platinum prices have been sustained at about $500 an ounce this year by environmentally conscious governments in the United States and Europe, and by status-conscious Japanese. The metal's leading uses are in jewelry and catalytic converters. **********Jewelry accounted for 38 percent of the 3.4 million ounces sold outside Communist (or formerly Communist) nations in 1989. A record 1.15 million ounces of platinum went for jewelry in Japan, almost 20 times the amount used by American jewelers. **********Another 37 percent of the non-Communist world's demand came from producers of catalytic converters. Slightly more than half of this amount went into converters in the United States, the first country whose air pollution standards made the devices necessary. Tougher American pollution laws will require a new generation of converters that will use even more platinum. **********The likelihood of tighter environmental standards is making the converters more common in Europe as well, especially in West Germany, where stricter anti-pollution regulations are already in place. **********Platinum is also an important chemical catalyst, used in making many products worth far less per ounce than the pure metal: gasoline, fiberglass, optical glass, certain types of rubber, some electrical equipment, even plastic seat covers and nylon carpeting. But the metal's chemical use has diminished as manufacturers seek ways of doing without this costly ingredient. **********Investors, too, are becoming less likely to buy platinum as they become disenchanted with the financial returns. **********And the music industry's platinum records? They are usually made of nickel, with shiny foil or paint, and not a single gram of platinum. **********Of Metal and Politics **********South Africa, Soviets Are Main Suppliers **********For all the economic sanctions the United States has invoked against South African apartheid, trade in platinum continues undisturbed. The non-Communist world depended on South Africa last year for 77 percent of its platinum, and the United States was no exception, buying in about the same proportion. **********The only other major source, the Soviet Union, produced about 16 percent of international supplies - up from about 10 percent in previous years, as the Soviet Union tried to earn more Western currencies. **********The worldwide stock of platinum is close to meeting demand, but turmoil in either country could disrupt shipments. **********Some analysts suggest that political reforms in the Soviet Union and South Africa could bring new militancy among mine workers looking for improved conditions. News of unrest in either country regularly sends platinum prices climbing; calm sends them back down. While jewelry makers could easily turn to gold and silver, automobile makers cannot. **********Jeremy S. Croombes, an analyst at Johnson, Matthey P.L.C., the London-based corporation that is the world's largest trader in the metal, said he is especially worried about unrest among black miners in South Africa. **********''The black population might want to sit back and let various leaders negotiate on their behalf,'' Mr. Croombs said. ''Or they may want to make their voices heard through strikes and industrial disruption.'' **********Investment Ups and Downs **********Once-Healthy Market Collapsed Last Year **********For a while, platinum appeared likely to join silver and gold as a mainstay in any precious-metal portfolio. Investment demand, virtually nil until the early 1980's, grew to 155,000 ounces in 1983, 490,000 ounces in 1985 and 630,000 in 1988. A range of bars and coins was proliferating. **********But last year, as gold and silver prices stagnated, investors decided they needed only 160,000 more ounces of platinum. The Japanese, the world's most active platinum investors, turned away abruptly, cutting their demand from 415,000 ounces in 1988 to 65,000 in 1989. **********''The demand for platinum as an investment tool has been dragged down by gold and silver prices, which have performed more poorly than platinum,'' said Bruce Kaplan, a precious metals consultant in Los Angeles. Last year, platinum prices fell from about $560 an ounce to about $500. Investors are less interested in using platinum as a hedge against inflation, Mr. Kaplan said. **********Higher demand from jewelry and industry sources has kept platinum prices relatively stable this year - which might be making the metal less attractive to investors. **********Common wisdom in the platinum business is that the metal seems brighter when its price is moving, no matter which way.
