The Japanese are said to buy when the price is falling, while Europeans and Americans jump in on the way up. **********New Technology **********It Isn't Likely To Curb Demand **********For a while, it seemed that Michigan had more to say about platinum prices than producers or investors. In December 1988, Ford announced ambitious tests of a catalytic converter made without platinum. About 40,000 Cougars and Thunderbirds in California were to be equipped with the new devices. On the day of Ford's announcement, platinum prices plunged $71 per ounce. Ask the company how things are going with its platinum-free converters now, and the response is a copy of the 1988 press release. **********Platinum assists in converting nitrogen oxide pollutants in automobile exhaust into carbon dioxide and water. Few still believe that pollution control equipment can dispense with platinum entirely. **********Ford says that even if converters without platinum are practical now, tighter emissions standards might require platinum to be reintroduced. **********Ford contends that its new converters will at least enable the company, and the nation, to lessen its reliance on South Africa and the Soviet Union. **********Some auto makers are increasing their use of rhodium, another precious metal that is often found in platinum ores. ''Rhodium will undoubtedly be an essential component of auto catalysts used in Europe,'' Mr. Croombs said. Its use in catalytic converters increased 16 percent worldwide in 1989. At $1,600 an ounce, rhodium is far more costly and rare than platinum, but also more efficient for use in converters. **********But even as some turn to other metals, the demand for platinum in converters increased 9 percent in 1989 and is likely to grow more quickly this year. The growth is likely to be greatest in Western Europe, where only three of every 10 cars already have the converters. **********WHEN PRICE IS NO OBJECT **********Where price is no object, platinum fuel cells are fine. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has used the exotic batteries to power its space shuttles. **********Now the developers of these cells need to make the giant leap back to earth and find less expensive, everyday applications. **********The cells, which look somewhat like stacks of car batteries, use platinum to catalyze a chemical combination of hydrogen and oxygen, generating electricity. Lee Marino, a spokesman for Johnson Matthey P.L.C., said that the fuel cells waste 10 percent less of their power than do standard utility engines. **********Major corporations are eager to pursue this new technology. International Fuel Cells, a division of the United Technologies Corporation, is already selling platinum fuel-cell generators that can heat and provide emergency power for small apartment buildings. **********A Japanese joint venture between International Fuel Cells and the Toshiba Corporation developed the cells for the space shuttle. **********In the longer range, scientists say that the power cells can propel buses and delivery trucks. ''There are a variety of potential applications for the future that we're only beginning to explore,'' Mr. Morino said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/25/busin.body_text: **********E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company today reported a 2.6 percent drop in its third-quarter earnings, with increases in its petroleum operations offset by slower growth in the company's chemicals businesses. **********The company reported net income of $533 million in the quarter, down from $547 million a year earlier. Earnings per share were flat at 79 cents and reflected the lower number of shares this year because of a stock-buyback program. **********Revenues for the quarter were up 15.6 percent, at $9.93 billion, compared with $8.59 billion in 1989. **********"Third-quarter results reflect strong performance from our petroleum operations," Du Pont's chairman, Edgar S. Woolard Jr., said. "At the same time, earnings in several of our chemical businesses continued to be adversely affected by the slowdown in the U.S. economy." **********Du Pont said the improvement in petroleum earnings was partly a result of higher oil prices, which soared after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The company said 70 percent of the overall improvement was a result of operations overseas, where there was a strong demand for petroleum products and greater efficiency at the company's refineries. **********Du Pont also said its quarterly results included gains of 8 cents a share from the sale of an interest in a North Sea oil property and an instrument systems business. **********The company's shares were unchanged today at $34.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/12/busin.body_text: **********Here in the root and stalk of tobacco country, everyone knows that marketing something that carries a health warning from the Surgeon General is bound to provoke an argument. Mix in race and you really have a shouting match. Just ask the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company. **********Last month, in a first for a cigarette maker, Reynolds said it would test-market a cigarette that it expects will appeal ''most strongly'' to blacks. The proposed brand name is Uptown, a menthol cigarette. The multimillion-dollar test market, scheduled to begin Feb. 5, is in Philadelphia, which has a large black population. **********If successful, the campaign for Uptown cigarettes - with their narrowly focused market, packaging and menthol taste - is sure to prompt Reynolds's rivals to try similar explicit marketing campaigns to blacks and perhaps other minorities. **********Marketing cigarettes to minorities is not new; saying so is. Billboards, newspaper advertisements and promotional circulars have featured black and Hispanic models for years. **********But critics, like the American Cancer Society, see the Uptown campaign as an alarming escalation in cigarette marketing. They believe the campaign exploits blacks, especially the ghetto poor. [In Philadelphia, representatives of 30 black and Hispanic religious and community organizations agreed Thursday to organize a protest of Uptown's sale. [''We want to halt it before Feb. 5,'' said Patti LePera, vice president-marketing and communications for the Philadelphia branch of the American Cancer Society. ''We want R. J. Reynolds to know we don't want it here.'']  Mary L. Clarke, the president of the Charlotte-Mecklenburg, N.C., branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said: ''With the poor health among black folks today, we do not need anything else to cause even more health problems. R. J. Reynolds's targeting of blacks is unethical.'' **********Black publications find themselves in the middle. The Philadelphia Tribune, a 105-year-old newspaper with a circulation of 108,000, plans to carry Uptown advertisements next month. ''We don't have the right to make a choice for our readers,'' said the newspaper's president, Robert W. Bogle. ''What we're doing is not illegal or immoral.'' **********Black magazines are also caught in the crossfire. They often depend on cigarette revenue to a greater extent than black newspapers. **********''R. J. Reynolds has been an advertiser for a long time,'' said Jeff Burns, vice president of Johnson Publishing, parent of Ebony and Jet magazines, which are scheduled to carry Uptown advertisements. ''This is just another product.'' Publishers Information Bureau estimates that for the first 11 months of 1989 Ebony received about 7 percent of its $35 million in revenue from cigarette advertising and Jet about 10 percent of its $16.4 million. **********'Tough Business Decision' **********Taking such advertising is ''a tough business decision,'' said Barbara A. Britton, national advertising director for Essence magazine. ''But it's advertising that is treated like any other advertising.'' The Publishers Information Bureau estimates that Essence received about 9 percent of its $18 million in ad revenue from cigarettes for the first 11 months of 1989, but Ms. Britton said the estimate was ''slightly overstated.'' **********''It's unfair to single out minority publications on this issue,'' she added. ''Given the health issue in America, this is a question that should be posed to the white media as well.'' Indeed, most newspapers and magazines accept cigarette advertising. **********Because of the health issue, cigarette makers are hobbled in selling to blacks, said Jerome D. Williams, an assistant professor of marketing at Pennsylvania State University who studies ethnic marketing. ''The irony is that if R. J. Reynolds made shoes or shirts and specifically marketed to blacks, they would probably be regarded as progressive and socially positive,'' said Mr. Williams, who is black. **********A Shrinking Industry **********For its part, Reynolds says it is only following the Darwinian dictates of the cigarette market. With the industry shrinking a further 6 percent last year, the business has long been a struggle of clawing customers away from competitors rather than wooing new smokers. The result is a vast proliferation of cigarette brands aimed at narrower and narrower market segments: There are more than 350 brands and styles (low-tar, filter, box, menthol, 100-millimeter versions and so forth) of cigarettes. Lorillard, for example, is test-marketing Harley-Davidson cigarettes, named after the motorcycle, for men aged 21 to 35. **********Reynolds, the unit that must provide much-needed cash flow for debt-laden RJR Nabisco, had a 1989 market share of 28.6 percent, said John C. Maxwell Jr., a tobacco analyst with Wheat First Securities in Richmond. The company lost 3.2 share points last year, partly because it discontinued ''trade loading,'' which is the shipment of more units than distributors can sell, thus inflating sales. But it also lost share because of competition, mainly from Philip Morris, the market leader with a 41.9 percent share. **********Nearly 44 percent of black adults smoke, compared with 37 percent of whites, according to the Simmons Market Research Bureau. Although blacks make up only 13 percent of the 58 million adults who smoke, or about 7.4 million, many cigarette marketers believe blacks are fiercely brand loyal and thus make ideal cigarette customers. **********Stakes Are High **********''Everything we do is going to be assaulted and picked at by the anti-smokers,'' said David Iauco, senior vice president-marketing for R. J. Reynolds, who was not surprised by the controversy. ''But taking away business from our competitors is the only thing that Uptown is about.'' **********The marketing stakes are high for a cigarette maker. While Reynolds will not disclose marketing costs for Uptown, it estimates that a typical test market costs $2 million to $10 million. Such expensive testing is necessary since a nationwide cigarette introduction can cost $100 million to $150 million. **********In a business where market shares are measured in tiny slivers, a single market share point is worth $358 million. The industry is immensely profitable because cigarette manufacture has become so efficient. For example, the huge Reynolds factory near Winston-Salem can produce more than 475 million cigarettes a day. **********It is difficult for manufacturers to determine how to appeal to smokers. They are not quite certain, for example, what women prefer. Marketers know only that women like long, thin cigarettes. Philip Morris's Virginia Slims, the dominant women's brand, was introduced in the late 1960's; no other women's brand -including those that smell sweet, taste lemony or are ultra-long and thin - has been as successful. **********Expensive Failures **********Hispanic smokers, who make up 15 percent of the market, show no special preference, buying such mainstream brands as Philip Morris's Marlboros and Reynolds's Winston. **********Asians, like Hispanic consumers, are diverse in ethnicity and nationality. making marketing programs difficult. **********Marketing campaigns for blacks are easier because of their preference for menthol, which has never been explained. According to Reynolds, 69 percent of black smokers prefer menthol, compared with 27 percent for smokers over all. **********There are three major menthol brands: Salem, Kool and Newport. Mr. Maxwell, the tobacco analyst, said only the Newport brand, made by Lorillard, a unit of the Loews Corporation, is prospering. Reynolds's Salem is losing substantial market share, with 6.2 percent in 1989, down from 7.3 percent in 1988. Brown & Williamson's Kool is flat at 6 percent. **********Newport Gains Market Share **********Only Newport saw its market share grow: to 4.8 percent from 4.4 percent. Newport's unit sales grew as well, to 25 million in 1989 from 24.8 million a year earlier. That is not much, but both its rivals experienced declines in cigarette sales. **********Those three brands constitute 53 percent of the market for black smokers, but flip-flopped in ranking, with Newport on top at 22 percent, Kool at 16 percent and Salem at 15 percent, according to R. J. Reynolds. **********Newport's secret may be the menthol recipe. The cigarette has the least menthol of the three brands; Salem has the most. To appeal to blacks in the ages of 21 to 34, the company planned a cigarette with less menthol flavoring, 19 milligrams of ''tar'' and 1.3 milligrams of nicotine - not a low-tar brand, but not especially strong either. **********'A Classy Sounding Name' **********Development of the new cigarette began in late 1988, when Salem was clearly losing ground among blacks. Trone Advertising, a Greensboro, N. C., agency, developed a list of about 20 names, later narrowed to 5, for the new cigarette. **********The name Uptown scored the highest in consumer surveys, Reynolds said. Uptown was not selected because it suggests the Harlem section of New York City. None of the other four names had any ethnic character to them either, the company said. **********''Uptown was meant to be a classy sounding name, that is all,'' said Timothy C. Harris, director of special markets. **********To appeal to blacks seeking a less pronounced menthol taste, Reynolds decided against using green, the traditional color to signal menthol, on the packaging. Instead, it used black and gold, the colors of luxury European cigarettes. The typeface, Onyx, was chosen for its ''classic, stylish look,'' Mr. Harris said. **********In the narrowest bit of marketing toward blacks, Uptown cigarettes are packed with the filters facing down, the reverse of the usual arrangement. Market research indicated blacks opened cigarette packs from the bottom, possibly to avoid crushing the filters. **********Six-Month Test **********To test the cigarette, Reynolds picked Philadelphia, which has about a 40 percent black population. The test will last at least six months. Much of the company's marketing funds will go to advertising, which will be carried in black newspapers, The Phildelphia New Observer and The Tribune, as well as such national black magazines as Ebony and Jet. It will also be used for billboards, posters inside buses, and point-of-purchase displays where cigarettes are sold The ads represent typical cigarette marketing, with beautiful models enjoying urban nightlife and smoking cigarettes. The slogan is ''Uptown. The Place. The Taste.'' Despite the heavy marketing to blacks, Reynolds does not say that Uptown is a cigarette designed for blacks. Rather, the company says, it is a cigarette for the entire market but which is likely to attract a disproportionate number of black smokers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/busin.body_text: **********The Quaker State Corporation is offering a free warranty on engine parts of new cars lubricated by its oil for 10 years or 250,000 miles. Car owners must meet strict rules, including having an oil and filter change every four months or 4,000 miles using Quaker State oil. The warranty does not cover claims already covered by auto manufacturers' warranties, but it will pay for deductibles not covered by the auto makers' extended service contracts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/busin.main_headline: The Executive Computer;   With Sound, Graphics - It's Multimedia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/busin.print_headline: The Executive Computer;   With Sound, Graphics - It's Multimedia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/busin.body_text: **********The Audio Visual Connection from the International Business Machines Corporation allows companies to create computer presentations that include text, sound, voice, graphics and video images - and at relatively low cost. **********Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh, a graphics-based computer that set the standards for ease of use, already has a head start in this field, which goes by the nebulous term multimedia. The Commodore Amiga, from Commodore Business Machines Inc., is also well suited to multimedia production. But I.B.M. PC's and compatible models have never been known for good sound or graphics. Until now. **********Multimedia is a buzzword these days, although the concept is hardly new. Television, for example, is a multimedia device. Some analysts have suggested that computers and television are destined to merge, resulting in ''smart TV's'' or ''video computers.'' Although the integration of full-motion video on a computer screen is still some time off, products like the Audio Visual Connection represent an initial step in that direction. **********The concept is simple: a computer-based sales presentation or training program that includes photographs, video, animated diagrams, a musical soundtrack, a spoken narration, text and data drawn from the user's data base, all put together with sophisticated techniques borrowed from professional audio-visual productions. Its designers believe it will hold a viewer's attention much better than the ''slide shows'' that are common on computers today. **********But multimedia is not yet simple or inexpensive, and those it must be to catch on in corporate offices. **********I.B.M.'s Audio Video Connection is a $3,310 combination of software and two plug-in boards that is designed to work on high-end PS/2 computers. One board captures and processes audio signals, the other video. The boards fit into Micro Channel expansion slots, a type of slot used by I.B.M. and a few other personal computer makers. **********One application that uses Audio Video is an interactive guide to the city of Austin, Tex., where I.B.M. developed the plug-in boards. The system mixes color photographic and still-frame video images of Austin with a soundtrack, and links it to a data base containing text, sound and images. Using a mouse, the user can select topics of interest - parks, for example, or high-technology companies - and a slick presentation begins. **********Such presentations, without the computer involvement, are nothing new. Cities, companies and government agencies routinely make promotional videotapes. **********But computer multimedia has advantages. While television or video tape is passive, computer multimedia can be interactive. The viewer can control the order of the presentation through keyboard or mouse commands (or by touching the screen in some cases), exploring the material randomly instead of linearly, as with a video tape. Laser video disks are also interactive, but they are more difficult to produce. **********Computer multimedia applications are, in general, less expensive to make than video productions, once the start-up equipment and training costs are absorbed. ''In short time, I was able to put together a five-and-a-half-minute presentation that would have cost the client $5,000 to $10,000 if it had been produced on video,'' said Mark C. Sherman, president of Audio Visual Computer Applications Inc. of Austin. ''Using A.V.C., it was $1,500,'' he said, referring to the Audio Video Connection. Professional audio-visual productions often cost more than $1,000 a minute, because they are extremely labor intensive, he said. **********But the relatively low cost of Audio Video may be misleading, Mr. Sherman cautioned. To produce his results, which compare favorably with those of a professional audio-visual studio, Mr. Sherman uses a powerful computer with high-resolution graphics and a special monitor, a digital video camera, audio and video cassette decks, a slide digitizer, a studio video monitor and other equipment. That means he is taking advantage of Audio Video using hardware that cost more than $30,000. It might be a hard sell to persuade corporate audio-visual departments to make that kind of investment. **********Another potential hurdle is that Audio Video appears to be complex, restricting its usefulness to companies where at least some employees have a good understanding of both audio-visual production and computers. As a result, the Audio Video Connection may find its greatest use among audio-visual professionals and companies that develop multimedia applications. **********One such company is Creative Services Inc., of McLean, Va., which uses Audio Video to produce multimedia applications for clients including Disney World and the Pentagon. The company also has ''a contract with Caterpillar to develop manufacturing training applications,'' said Judith A. Mezzullo, vice president of marketing, who said she expects training to be the most significant application for Audio Video in the next decade. ''Data can be changed rapidly and modifications to manufacturing equipment can be updated quickly,'' she said. ''With a video disk, you have to create a new disk and have it manufactured, mailed out and installed.'' Audio Video can be updated on a computer network, she said, adding, ''Where data is changing and you need the most current data, this is better than video disks.'' **********Creative Services is also developing a multimedia network version of the multiple listing service used by realtors. Such a system would enable clients to sit at a computer with a local real estate agent, fill out a profile of their housing requirements (four bedrooms, four baths, fireplace, trees and so on) and finances (in the $200,000 range, with $50,000 down and study their choices in other cities. Within minutes, the system would show them exterior, interior and neighborhood views of perhaps a dozen houses that come closest to meeting their descriptions. The program could also check local mortgage and tax rates and show the clients graphically what it would cost, including closing costs and monthly payments, to move into each house. **********Such an application would require far more data capacity than is available on most computer networks today. But long-distance carriers and regional telephone companies are planning to install fiber-optic digital phone networks in the mid-1990's that have far larger capacity and may be able to handle such applications. **********Another important advantage of multimedia is that because the information in the presentation was created by and drawn from a computer, it can be changed or updated in less time, and at less expense, than with video, which would have to be refilmed, edited, manufactured and mailed. **********Neither I.B.M.'s Model 70, with its limited expansion slots, nor the Model 80, with its relatively slow microprocessor, is an ideal Audio Visual Connection machine. Until I.B.M. comes up with a better computer, the best machine to run the Audio Visual Connection would seem to be a bigger, faster Micro Channel machine, like the Advanced Logic Research Microflex 3300, which is powered by a 33-megahertz Intel 80386 processor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/13/world.body_text: **********The last-minute failure of the Israeli Labor Party to form a new government has again focused attention on the role of a charismatic Brooklyn rabbi who asserts an unusual amount of influence in Israel. **********The 88-year-old rabbi, Menachem Mendel Schneerson, the Grand Rabbi of Lubavitch, has never been to Israel, although his picture hangs in many Israeli homes and offices and stares down at traffic from billboards in Jerusalem and Safad, Israel's historic center of mysticism. **********The rabbi's aides in Brooklyn and in Israel insist he is not politically involved. But two of his followers thwarted Labor's chance to form a government on Wednesday when they bolted from supporting the party, citing a religious ruling of Rabbi Schneerson, known affectionately by his followers as the Lubavitcher Rebbe. **********The rabbi has ruled that it is against Jewish law, known as halacha, to give up Israeli territory, even in exchange for peace. To support his position, he reasons from a legal conclusion in a 16th-century code known as the Shulchan Aruch, written in Safad, in Galilee, by Joseph Caro, a rabbinical scholar. **********A Labor Platform **********He differs with several other rabbis, who argue from similar souces that peace is a greater principle than land. But Rabbi Schneerson's influence is greater. **********The notion of land for peace is a cornerstone of the platform of Labor and distinguishes it most starkly from its rival, the Likud party, which has insisted it will not cede land. **********Labor, led by Shimon Peres, was given the first chance to try to form a new parliamentary majority after Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Government fell in a vote of no confidence three weeks ago. After the defections on Wednesday, Mr. Peres was given another two weeks to try to put together another majority. **********The two defectors were Avraham Verdiger and Eliahu Mizrahi, both of the Orthodox Agudat Israel Party, a party that had committed its support to help Labor form a government. **********In Brooklyn yesterday, the chief spokesman and personal aide to Rabbi Schneerson confirmed that Mr. Verdiger had called the office before Wednesday's session and asked if the grand rabbi's position had changed. Mr. Verdiger was told that there was no change and that, in fact, Rabbi Schneerson, in a recent Sabbath address, had restated his position. **********''When Verdiger heard this, he deduced, on his own, that he was in the wrong place; hence the defection,'' said the spokesman, Rabbi Yehudah Krinsky. At no time was he told how to vote, the rabbi said. ''We are not political,'' he said. **********But when asked whether Rabbi Schneerson supported either of the leading parties, Rabbi Krinsky said, ''I would say clearly that the Rebbe would be opposed to any government that would have on its agenda the return or compromise of any territories.'' **********He insisted that that was a religious judgment rather than a political one. And he said no pressure would be brought to bear on other religious party members who were planning to support Labor. **********Organized in 18th Century **********Rabbi Schneerson is the seventh leader in a Hasidic dynasty that dates to late 18th-century Russia. The Hasidic movement was founded earlier in the century as a reaction to the Enlightenment, and stressed piety, song, dance and mysticism. **********By most accounts, Lubavitch is the largest of the Hasidic groups to survive the killing of six million European Jews. Rabbi Krinksy said there were 25,000 followers in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn alone, where Rabbi Schneerson lives, and more than one million worldwide. **********While others said that the worldwide number was grossly exaggerated, they tended to agree with Rabbi Krinsky that the organization is enormously influential. It has 1,000 centers in the world, and just in this week of Passover has held seders, or festival meals, at its centers in Nepal, Hong Kong, Honolulu, Rome, Budapest and Moscow. **********Rabbi Irving Greenberg, an Orthodox rabbi who has been a critic of Luvavitch, said the organization has been underestimated. **********''It is more than a sweet little rabbi who brings you matzoh on Passover,'' he said referring to Lubavitch's outreach work in sharing Jewish symbols. **********Called Most Powerful **********''Lubavitch is the single most powerful movement in the Jewish world,'' said Rabbi Greenberg, who is the director of the Center for Learning and Leadership, an interbranch Jewish organization based in Manhattan. **********While Rabbi Krinsky refused to make public the annual budget of Lubavitch, Rabbi Greenberg estimated that it was at least $100 million since the cost of running each individual center was at a minimum, $100,000 a year. **********Much of the Lubavitch money is raised from nonobservant Jews who want to support what they see as an authentic Jewish tradition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/20/world.body_text: **********President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua has expressed concern to Salvadoran and United States officials that shipments of arms continue to pass through her country to the guerrillas in El Salvador, a senior State Department official said. **********Mrs. Chamorro brought up the arms shipments in a conversation with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in Antigua, Guatemala, on Monday at the end of a three-day meeting of Central American Presidents dominated by economic issues. **********A senior State Department official who attended the meeting said Mrs. Chamorro indicated that small arms were still being sent to the rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front rebels, presumably by Sandinistas, even though the Sandinistas no longer control the Government. **********''Mrs. Chamorro also discussed the matter with President Cristiani,'' the official said, referring to Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador. The official, who asked not to be identified, also said that radio messages were still being transmitted from Nicaragua to the Salvadoran guerrillas. **********'It's Very Troublesome' **********''She promised to get back to President Cristiani and look for ways to put an end to this,'' a second Administration official said. ''One thing she has to do is better identify who is responsible.'' He added that ''it's very troublesome'' that Soviet-manufactured AK-47 assault rifles and ammunition continue to pass through Nicaragua into El Salvador. **********United States officials hoped that after Mrs. Chamorro defeated President Daniel Ortega Saavedra in elections in February and took office almost two months ago, she could halt shipments of arms and other supplies from Nicaragua to El Salvador. Those shipments, believed by United States officials to originate in Cuba, have sporadically fueled the Salvadoran revolution since 1980. **********Mrs. Chamorro and senior members of her Government, who were in a Cabinet meeting most of the day, were not available for comment. **********A spokesman for the Sandinista party, Dionesio Marenco, said of the reported arms shipments: ''It seems very strange. That couldn't happen.'' **********While Mrs. Chamorro has made headway in exerting her authority and cutting the size of the Sandinista army, the Nicaraguan officer corps is still dominated by members of the Sandinista party, which has long expressed support for the Salvadoran guerrillas challenging the Government of President Cristiani. #2 Shipments Reported Seized Since April there have been two seizures of arms in Honduras that four Hondurans arrested during the confiscations said were en route to El Salvador from Nicaragua, Honduran and United States officials said. **********Such reports are hardening the position of senior Salvadoran officers as negotiations between the Cristiani Government and the guerrillas with United Nations mediation appear to be picking up momentum. ''Many officers wonder why we should negotiate when the guerrillas continue to be so aggressive,'' one said. **********Shipments of arms through Nicaragua to El Salvador were particularly heavy preceding a January 1981 guerrilla offensive. For the next eight years, shipments came irregularly and most analysts agree that they were not major in size. **********Shipments of rifles and explosives picked up in the second half of last year in anticipation of the guerrilla offensive in November. **********On Nov. 25, as the offensive was winding down, an unmarked plane carrying 24 SA-7 surface-to-air missiles crashed in eastern El Salvador. The plane had flight plans aboard that indicated it had taken off from a Nicaraguan airstrip, leading San Salvador to suspend relations with Managua.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/20/busin.body_text: **********The Unisys Corporation reported today that its second-quarter profit fell sharply, blaming weak domestic sales in part for the results. **********Unisys said it earned $11.8 million, down from $53.6 million in the second quarter of 1989. The nation's third-largest computer company said revenue totaled $2.47 billion, down from $2.57 billion for the second quarter of 1989. That quarter benefited significantly from the initial volume shipment of the company's new 2200 Series mainframe computers, the company said. **********After allowing for the mandatory preferred dividends, the company had no per-share earnings on its common stock in the recent quarter, compared with 17 cents in the quarter a year earlier. **********Unisys's share price was up 12.5 cents, to $12.75, in New York Stock Exchange trading. **********Unisys said its worldwide orders posted a slight gain in the quarter as orders for military systems rebounded from depressed levels a year earlier. Gains in international commercial computer orders were offset by continued weakness in United States orders. **********The quarterly comparison was hurt by last year's strong 2200 Series sales, particularly abroad, Unisys said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/07/busin.main_headline: New Estimate on Savings Bailout Says Cost Could Be $500 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/07/busin.print_headline: New Estimate on Savings Bailout Says Cost Could Be $500 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/07/busin.body_text: **********The cost of the Government's savings and loan bailout could grow to as much as $500 billion, roughly twice as high as previous official estimates, the head of the General Accounting Office said today. **********In testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, the agency's chief, Charles A. Bowsher, said the cost of the bailout could range from $325 billion to $500 billion over three decades, depending on the outlook for the economy and the trend of real estate values. Many of the troubled savings institutions invested heavily in real estate developments. **********The estimates by Mr. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, were far higher than the previous official estimates. Last July, the Administration's Office of Management and Budget put the cost at $257 billion. **********The rescue, Mr. Bowsher said, will be ''bigger than all the bailouts of New York City, Chrysler, and Lockheed put together.'' **********The Taxpayers Will Pay **********Most of the costs will be paid by the taxpayers. The Administration has estimated that more than $100 billion can be obtained from selling off assets from the hundreds of failed institutions the Government has seized in recent months and from other sources, like the Federal insurance premiums paid by the savings industry. But the rest of the bill must be paid by the Treasury, though the payment could be spread over as much as 33 years. **********The rising cost of the bailout will add to the Federal Government's chronic budget deficit, which makes the United States dependent on foreign capital and slows economic growth. **********''It looks as if we have spent the peace dividend,'' said Senator Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota. He referred to the savings in military spending that many legislators expect as the United States and the Soviet Union agree to cuts in armaments. **********Mr. Bowsher said that in the period since Congress authorized the bailout last year the cost estimate had increased because the number of troubled institutions had risen, the interest rates on bonds to finance the bailout had gone up and real estate values had fallen. Declining real estate prices in many parts of the country not only add to the problems of the savings industry, but also decrease the amount of money the Government takes in when it sells the real estate assets of seized institutions, he said. **********The $325 billion estimate, Mr. Bowsher said, assumes a fairly strong economy and modest interest costs. If interest rates rise, the cost could easily reach $400 billion, he added. An economic recession, he said, could mean that ''a cost of a half a trillion dollars is possible, unfortunately.'' **********He warned that new legislation would be needed because the money authorized by Congress last year will not be enough. **********Still, analysts said the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created last year to handle the bailout, apparently does not face any immediate cash shortage. It has $18.8 billion and the authority to issue $20 billion in bonds, so there should be no need for legislation to provide additional money until the middle of 1991, one Congressional analyst said. **********Although the cost of the rescue is spread over more than 30 years, the heaviest burden on the Treasury comes in the early years when money is needed to close institutions and pay depositors. **********Another Estimate Is Expected **********L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, told Congress last month that his staff was preparing new estimates on the bailout's cost. Experts within the agency, who asked not to be identified, said the expectation was that the figure would be far higher than the $325 billion minimum estimated by Mr. Bowsher. **********Stephen Katsanos, a spokesman for the agency, said trends within the savings industry indicate that more than 600 institutions will ultimately have to be bailed out. Mr. Bowsher's office, which is an investigative arm of Congress, assumed in its most optimistic estimate that 560 savings and loans would be involved. At present, 351 institutions are controlled by the Government. **********Private experts have been even more pessimistic. Bert Ely, a consultant based in Alexandria, Va., estimates that the final tally of institutions needing help will be 700 to 900. **********The bailout comes after the collapse of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which guaranteed deposits and had accumulated losses of $87 billion when it was closed last year and was replaced by the Savings Association Insurance Fund. The Resolution Trust Corporation handles the actual bailout operation, selling off the assets of insolvent institutions to recover as much money as possible. **********Speculative Investments **********The savings industry crisis began after the regulation of savings and loans was eased in the mid-1980's. Many institutions strayed far from their traditional business of collecting consumer deposits and making home mortgage loans. The most aggressive institutions put millions of dollars into speculative investments ranging from real estate developments to ''junk bonds.'' When these markets dropped, the institutions became insolvent. **********Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn and a member of the House Banking Committee, warned that the growing cost of the bailout promised more trouble for the Federal budget. ''An increasing part of the rescue funds will come from the Government's general revenues, because the other sources have already been used up,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/world.main_headline: Deng Reappears to Cast Vote in Beijing
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/world.print_headline: Deng Reappears to Cast Vote in Beijing
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/world.body_text: **********Wobbly but beaming, China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, appeared on television tonight for the first time in five months, casting a vote in local elections conducted throughout the city. **********More than five million people were expected to go to the polls today in Beijing to elect representatives to local councils, the only Government institution elected directly by the Chinese people. **********At some polling stations, there was great fanfare, with firecrackers and streamers, but for the most part, many citizens privately expressed their indifference to the process. **********"I'm sure there will be a lot of abstention votes this time," said a worker who helped organize voters in her district. "We are given so little information on the candidates. The people never meet them and so it's nearly impossible to tell them apart. None of them share my views, so I'm just going to abstain."  Complaints on Information **********Indeed, many voters complained privately about the lack of information on the candidates and about their doubts that the candidates would ever voice the real views of the people. Still, the Government was promoting today's elections, which occur once every three years, as an example of China's political openness and democratic process. **********The 86-year-old Mr. Deng was shown on television filling out his ballot and, escorted by his daughter, walking carefully over to the red ballot box. He gingerly stuffed his ballot into the box. **********"That's all, right?" Mr. Deng appeared to say, and then he walked away from the box. Mr. Deng was last seen on a publicity trip to the Asian Games village, where Beijing staged a mini-Olympics in the fall. **********His television appearance at the polls today indicates that Chinese leaders want to stress the importance of the elections -- and perhaps rebut rumors that Mr. Deng is on his deathbed. **********National television also showed the Communist Party General Secretary, Jiang Zemin, Prime Minister Li Peng and President Yang Shangkun casting their votes at the polls. **********"The system of the People's Congress is the fundamental system of China," the official New China News Agency said in a paraphrase of comments by Prime Minister Li. "While continuing its economic reform, China will also carry out political reform." **********Voters today elect representatives to the local People's Congress, which then elects deputies to a higher level people's congress. The congresses convene annually as a rubber stamp for the Government's legislation. **********More than 90 percent of eligible voters were expected to turn out at the polls, but many people say they are going to the polls because it is their duty, and they do not want any repercussions from their work units, which keep a roster of the voters.  Biographies Are Posted **********There are competing candidates in the election, normally four candidates for three positions, or three candidates for two positions. But all the candidates are officially approved, and often there is little difference among them. **********At Beijing University, where brief biographies of the candidates were posted, many students still said they knew nothing about the candidates. The candidates apparently were carefully screened, and the popular former president of the university, Ding Shisun, withdrew his nomination, students at the university said. Mr. Ding was dismissed by the Government after the 1989 army crackdown on the democracy movement. **********Some students scanned the biographies just before they entered the polling halls. **********"I have no idea who these candidates are," a second-year student said. "It doesn't mean much anyway. Elections here are not like in America." **********Candidates rarely appear at the polling stations. Most citizens vote through their work units, which distribute materials about the candidates. **********At Fengsheng election district in west Beijing, the three candidates had videos of themselves distributed throughout the local work units, poll organizers said.  But more than a dozen people approached at the poll today said they had not heard about a video. **********At Jianguomen election district in east Beijing, poll organizers tried their best to portray the great respect that voters had for the election process. **********But several voters said they selected candidates at random. One woman exclaimed to her friend that she did not know any of the candidates. **********"Just put a mark next to any of the names," the friend said, as the woman began drawing a circle next to two of the names. The friend added, "It's all the same anyway."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/world.main_headline: Top 5 in U.N. Council Near Accord Over Claims Against Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/world.print_headline: Top 5 in U.N. Council Near Accord Over Claims Against Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/world.body_text: **********The five permanent Security Council members are close to agreement on a plan inviting governments to prepare lists of financial claims against Iraq arising out of its occupation of Kuwait as well as lists of human rights violations by Iraqi forces there. **********The proposed resolution also calls on the Iraqi Government to allow the remaining foreign embassies in occupied Kuwait to be resupplied with food, water and other necessities. It also urges the United Nations Secretary General to continue his efforts to find a diplomatic solution to the gulf crisis within the framework of the Council's existing resolutions that demand Iraq's unconditional withdrawal. **********The United Nations representatives from Britain, France, the United States, the Soviet Union and China -the five permanent Council members with a veto on decisions - tentatively agreed on the resolution on Wednesday night, diplomats said today. **********But they reported that Washington had still not accepted the text, although the four other permanent members are ready to vote for it. Administration officials in Washington said Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d had not had time to review the draft resolution. **********Represents a Compromise **********The emerging new resolution represents a compromise between differing British and American views of what the Security Council should do next to increase the pressure on Baghdad to withdraw and refocus attention on the gulf crisis after last week's Council vote condemning Israel for the violence in Jerusalem. **********Last month, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain called for the Security Council to approve a new resolution that would compensate victims of Iraq's invasion for financial losses they have suffered out of frozen overseas Iraqi assets. She also said President Saddam Hussein and other Iraqi leaders should be tried for war crimes by a Nuremburg-style commission. **********But the United States asked Britain to tone down these demands. It expressed fears that any new punitive Security Council action against Iraq so soon after last Friday's vote condemning Israel might encourage Arab and other third world countries to press for the Council to take similar mesures against Israel as well. **********Instead Mr. Baker proposed that the Security Council pressure Baghdad to allow embassies still holding out in Kuwait to be resupplied with food and water. **********Diplomats say the new resolution represents a compromise between these two view points. For the first time, it establishes the principal that Iraq will be held responsible for the financial consequences of its invasion by saying governments should compile lists of their citizens claims. **********It also establishes that Iraq will be held accountable for human rights violations by its forces, and notably of the Fourth Geneva Protocol of 1947 governing the treatment of civilians in war zones. Again governments will be invited to prepare evidence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/27/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Kaiser Aluminum In Public Offering

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/12/busin.main_headline: UAL Offers Employees 20% Stake in the Airline
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/12/busin.print_headline: UAL Offers Employees 20% Stake in the Airline
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/12/busin.body_text: **********Two days after its board rejected the latest union buyout offer, the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, said yesterday that it planned to beef up its employee stock purchase program to let employees buy up to 20 percent of the airline. **********The unions reacted coolly to the offer but did not reject it outright. Employees now own less than 1 percent of the company's shares. Their rejected proposal called for 100 percent ownership. **********V. Diane Robertson, F.C. Dubinsky and John F. Peterpaul, the heads of United's three principal unions, said in a prepared statement, ''While the unions representing the flight attendants, pilots, machinists and other employees of United agree that United employees should own UAL stock, management's proposal for limited stock ownership raises numerous issues which must be addressed in negotiations.'' **********Prepared to Meet **********The union chiefs said they were prepared to meet with United management to discuss issues raised by the proposal. **********Under the UAL proposal, employees could buy UAL stock at a 15 percent discount from the market price and at reduced brokerage fees. The plan would also allow employees to buy non-discounted stock in other investment plans, such as 401(k) programs. **********UAL would buy the stock on the open market, rather than issue it from its own store of shares. **********Lawrence M. Nagin, UAL's senior vice president and general counsel, called the plan ''an attractive investment opportunity'' for employees but declined to characterize the unions' reaction. **********'Dear Fellow Employee' **********The plan was made known yesterday in the ninth paragraph of a ''Dear Fellow Employee'' letter, dated Wednesday, from UAL's chairman, Stephen M. Wolf. **********Mr. Wolf said in the letter, ''The fact is that neither the good faith of those seeking the buyout nor the inherent value of United can be faulted.'' **********He said the poor economy, the Persian Gulf crisis and investor aversion to highly leveraged airlines ''simply prevented the transaction from being completed.'' **********On Tuesday, UAL's board of directors rejected the unions' bid to buy United Airlines, the unions' fifth attempt. The move was widely thought to end three years of struggle over United's ownership and to strengthen the position of Mr. Wolf, whom the unions have sought to replace. **********The three principal UAL unions -representing the machinists, pilots and the flight attendants - are working under expired contracts and have suggested they will mount an attempt to oust directors. **********The board rejected the unions' latest offer of $3.38 billion because the unions had been unable to get sufficient financing. The bid was valued far lower than a $4.38 billion bid in April. **********UAL's share price rose $3 yesterday, to $92, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/world.main_headline: ISRAEL'S JETS RAID SHIITES IN LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/world.print_headline: ISRAEL'S JETS RAID SHIITES IN LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/world.body_text: **********For the second day in succession, Israeli fighter-bombers pounded bases belonging to the pro-Iranian Party of God in southern Lebanon today. **********Two gunmen of the Shiite Muslim faction were killed and four others wounded when the jets rocketed the strongholds in the area of Ain Buswar in the district of Iqlim al-Toffah, 25 miles southeast of Beirut. Two other Party of God members were known to have died and seven were wounded in an attack by the Israeli Air Force Sunday on the same area. **********The Israeli attacks raised fears that reported plans for the release of a Western hostage held here could be delayed. The Party of God is widely thought to hold six Americans and 10 other Westerners captive. **********The raids came as the Party of God had been building up its forces in Iqlim al-Toffah, an important district east of the port city of Sidon, for a major battle against rival Shiite militiamen, members of the mainstream Amal movement. **********Rumors of a Hostage Release **********The Israeli assaults also coincided with reported preparations for freeing at least one hostage. Rumors abound in West Beirut, the Muslim sector of the capital, that the release of a European hostage is imminent. Shiites close to the Party of God said today that the Syrian military command in the city has been told by the kidnappers to make the necessary preparations to receive the captive, whose identity remains unknown. **********The Iranian press agency initiated the speculation with a report from Beirut on Saturday that a Western captive, probably a European, would be freed soon. **********Syria, which has 40,000 troops in Lebanon, in the past has acted as go-between in the release of the captives. **********News reports here said the hostage to be released is Brian Keenan, who holds dual Irish and British nationality. Keenan, an English teacher at the American University of Beirut, disappeared in West Beirut four years ago. No group has taken responsibility for his abduction. **********In response to the Israeli raids, the Party of God has bombarded the Christian town of Jezzin 12 miles east of Ain Buswar, with artillery. Damage was reported, but no casualties. Jezzin is under the control of the Israeli-sponsored and predominantly Christian militia known as the South Lebanon Army.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/01/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Northrop Sale Of Properties
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/01/busin.body_text: **********The Northrop Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell two office buildings, one of which houses its corporate headquarters, and another 53-acre site. The price of the sales is more than $250 million. **********''The proceeds from these sales will be applied to the company's debt as part of our overall policy to sell assets not related to or no longer needed for our operations,'' said Kent Kresa, Northrop's president and chief executive. **********The two buildings, situated in the Century City district of Los Angeles, will be sold to the California State Teachers' Retirement System. One building is 15 stories tall, the other is 19 stories, and they contain about 540,000 square feet of space. **********Northrop's corporate staff will continue to occupy the 131,000 square feet it now uses in one of the buildings, under a separate lease agreement. **********The second property, 53 acres in Anaheim, Calif., an Orange County suburb, will be sold to Taiyo Development U.S.A., the American subsidiary of a Japanese real estate company. **********Northrop said that the sale of the Century City property is expected to close in February and that the Anaheim sale is expected to close in 1991.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/18/busin.main_headline: Wall Street;   The Mystery of the Rising Stock
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/18/busin.print_headline: Wall Street;   The Mystery of the Rising Stock
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/18/busin.body_text: **********The shares of Southland Communications Inc., a small paging company based in Santa Ana, Calif., jumped 43 percent in over-the-counter trading last Wednesday. With refreshing candor, the company's executives put out a statement that day saying they knew of no reason for the rise in the share price. **********A review of Southland's financial records doesn't suggest any explanation either. Indeed, the company's finances have become so frail that some Wall Street bears have been betting heavily that Southland will not sustain its recent rally. And that, in Wall Street's perverse way, may help explain last week's price jump. **********According to Southland's most recent public filings, for the fiscal year that ended Oct. 31, 1989, the company is nearly out of cash and running out of credit, both from its bankers and its paging-equipment suppliers. **********And while the company's reported revenues in 1989 climbed substantially over those in 1988, so did its costs, including the amount of interest it paid on money it borrowed to meet its cash needs. In fact, Southland's auditors, in their review of the company's annual results, cautioned that chronic losses and a lack of working capital ''raise substantial doubt about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern.'' **********Moreover, a supposedly beneficial purchase of another small paging operation, which company officials have been promising for more than 18 months, has hit some new and potentially time-consuming regulatory snags, according to the company's public filings. Pacific Bell has asked the California Public Utilities Commission to block Southland's acquisition of the A-plus Beepers Company. A spokesman for Bell said his company is claiming that A-plus's customers actually belong to Pacific Bell, because A-plus had been acting as its Bell's agent when it signed up the customers. The P.U.C. has scheduled a hearing on the case for April 3, the spokesman said. Southland said it will review its plans if the P.U.C. blocks the deal. In short, Southland is facing a host of problems. But Ahmad N. Bayaa, Southland's chairman and leading shareholder, said he believes the company's troubles are largely behind it. In this business, he said, ''there is a lot of investment up front and the rewards come later.'' **********Of course, the ''beeper'' business itself has become increasingly competitive. In this regard, Southland's corporate structure would seem to give it something of an edge. It transferred its Federal and state P.U.C. licenses to a separate corporation, owned by Mr. Bayaa's brother, Ziad, and rents its airtime back at bargain rates. **********But even so, the company's paging business has never been able to make ends meet. And the arrangement has stripped Southland of one of the most valuable assets of any paging company, its transmission license. **********Of course, investors can be durable optimists at times, seeing silk purses where only sow's ears are visible to others. That may explain Southland's stock-price history. The shares, which were trading at $3.63 last May, had moved up to $13.50 by early September. **********That rally cooled a bit by Christmas, but prices hovered around $9 through the end of January. After the company filed its fiscal 1989 results on Jan. 29, the stock even began a modest rally and spent February in the neighborhood of $9.50 a share, before sliding back to $8.75 in early March. **********On March 6, Southland announced somewhat vaguely that it ''intended to raise up to $5 million'' by privately selling an undisclosed number of shares to ''a select group of foreign investors'' whom it did not identify. The market ignored the news, and Southland's shares continued to be quoted at $8.75 through last Tuesday. **********Then, between Wednesday morning and Thursday afternoon, the stock soared to $12.75 on uncharacteristically heavy volume. **********The move got the O.T.C. market's attention - especially among bearish short-sellers, who had borrowed Southland shares and sold them at those earlier single-digit prices, expecting to profit by later replacing the borrowed stock with even cheaper shares. **********Some of these bears were complaining bitterly last week that they were the victims of a ''short squeeze.'' In this classic Wall Street maneuver, bullish investors demand the physical return of their own shares, which their brokers may have loaned out to the ''shorts.'' The move forces the short-sellers to become purchasers of the stock - unwilling ones, since they must buy shares in the marketplace to replace the ones they have borrowed from brokers and sold. **********Several market-makers, who did not want to be quoted by name, attributed last week's climb to just such a squeeze. Such strategies are easier to execute, they pointed out, if a stock is illiquid and not widely held. And Southland's latest reports show that it has just 77 shareholders, fewer than the 300 required for listed companies on the National Association of Securities Dealers automated market, where Southland trades. The company explains that many of these investors ''were believed to be nominees for the actual beneficial owners.'' **********In any case, the bears on Wall Street aren't the only ones who were selling Southland shares as the price was climbing. The Bayaa brothers, the company's top executives, have been selling some of their original holdings as well, according to S.E.C. records. Since the stock began to rally last spring, the two men have reported sales of more than 82,000 shares. **********Ahmad Bayaa explained: ''We all have our own personal needs . . . I needed to take care of some personal matters, but we believe very strongly in the company and we're in it for the long term, for sure.'' **********Assuming that these shares fetched $9 each, the prevailing market price when they were sold, the executives made about $738,000 on the transactions - an amount that almost equals the entire book value of the company itself. **********UTILITY INDEX: A CRYSTAL BALL FOR INTEREST RATES? **********Interest rate forecasters often seek clues to the future in the behavior of dividend-paying utility stocks, considered to be the Big Board equivalents of long-term Treasury bonds. **********But the trick these days is to detect when utility-stock traders are being prescient, and when they're simply being practical. **********The 15 stocks in the Dow Jones utility index certainly have been running out of steam, falling 8 percent since mid-December. But is the index just reacting sensibly to the 10 percent decline in the price of 30-year Treasury bonds in the same period? Or giving a Delphic warning of even higher rates ahead? **********''We really don't know,'' concedes Mickey Levy, chief economist at First Fidelity Bank in Newark. ''I would say it is because interest rates have already risen more than people expected, while economic fundamentals remain weak.'' **********If the index is simply mirroring the rise in the long bonds, as Mr. Levy suspects, ''then it isn't necessarily indicating that rates will go higher,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/24/world.main_headline: Le Pen, Isolated in France, Opposes Gulf Involvement
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/24/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Le Pen, Isolated in France, Opposes Gulf Involvement
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/24/world.body_text: **********The flags of France and its regions flapped noisily and the music was rousing as the far-right leader, Jean-Marie Le Pen, boomed out his nationalistic message today to about 15,000 supporters from atop a blue pyramid-turned-podium. **********Not for the first time, Mr. Le Pen has chosen to stand alone among French politicians, arguing that it is his patriotic duty to oppose France's military involvement in the Persian Gulf crisis because the country has nothing to gain and everything to lose. **********''We have no vital interests at stake,'' the former paratrooper said. ''We are not an ally of the country that was attacked. In fact, most of our interests are linked to the country that attacked. Do we want our soldiers dying for billionaire emirs and advocates of Islamic fundamentalism?'' **********Mr. Le Pen's position, first announced just days after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, has drawn fierce criticism from across the political spectrum here. Today he seemed anxious to explain it in detail so that at least his followers could understand his logic. **********Appeals to Iraq **********He also used the occasion to appeal to the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, to release the 300 or so French hostages still being held in Iraq and Kuwait. Mr. Le Pen urged Mr. Hussein to remember that France armed Iraq for 20 years, and that even now ''there is one big party'' in France that has not criticized his regime. **********But Mr. Le Pen's main strategy appears to be domestic, gambling on the possibility that if fighting breaks out, public opinion here will rapidly turn against French participation in the multinational force blockading Iraq -and his National Front will profit. **********Until now, Mr. Le Pen's following has largely been built on his vocal opposition to the growing presence of Arabs and other immigrants here. National polls indicate that he has the support of about 15 percent of French voters, a figure that rises to 30 percent in towns and neighborhoods with large immigrant populations. **********While insisting that the National Front is not ''xenophobic or racist,'' he once again blasted the Socialist Government of President Francois Mitterrand for failing to control immigration, warning that ''one million immigrants are entering this country every three or four years.'' About 5 million foreigners, 70 percent of them Arabs, live in France, which has a population of roughly 55 million. **********Says He Is a Target **********Asserting that he is singled out for attack by the Government and press twice each year, Mr. Le Pen noted that many blamed his National Front for the desecration of Jewish graves in May at a cemetery in Carpentras in southern France. Nearly ''five months later, where's the evidence?'' he asked. **********He said the latest campaign against the National Front involved distorting his position on the gulf crisis by suggesting he had sought to justify Iraq's seizure of foreign hostages. ''Our main worry is the security of French citizens, either the soldiers caught in this detestable maneuver or our hostages,'' he said. **********He blamed the Mitterrand Government for the detention of French nationals, claiming that most had been sent to Iraq by Government-owned companies involved in arming Iraq. **********''When the Government decided to break a 20-year alliance with Iraq, why didn't it get them out first?'' he asked. ''Even the French Ambassador was not there.'' **********'6,000 Kilometers Away' **********''Others say that if we don't go to war with Iraq, it will invade Israel,'' he went on. ''But Israel says it is not involved in the conflict. So if Israel, which is in the region, is not involved, why should France, which is 6,000 kilometers away, become involved?'' **********France, the United States and other major Western powers have tried to avoid involving Israel in their standoff with Iraq, preferring to seek broad support from Arab countries. **********With the crowd strangely silent as he spoke, Mr. Le Pen described the fate that he said awaited France if war broke out. ''Inflation, recession, a huge trade deficit, massive unemployment and immigration from third world countries ruined by the crisis will follow,'' he said. **********At the climax of his hourlong speech, he pledged that the National Front would fill ''the deficit of truth'' in France, and he led the crowd in singing the Marseillaise, the national anthem.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/28/world.main_headline: Manila Seizes Ex-Defense Chief, Citing Tie to Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/28/world.print_headline: Manila Seizes Ex-Defense Chief, Citing Tie to Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/28/world.body_text: **********Senator Juan Ponce Enrile, the former Defense Minister who helped install President Corazon C. Aquino in the 1986 election and revolt that toppled the Marcos dictatorship, was arrested today in connection with a coup attempt that nearly overthrew the Aquino Government in early December. **********Agents of the National Bureau of Investigation arrested Mr. Enrile at the Philippine Senate building in a recess this afternoon. Mr. Enrile, 66 years old, had appeared before a packed gallery just minutes earlier to denounce the charges as ''the product of invention and fabrication.'' **********Mr. Enrile went quietly with the arresting officers. The judge in the case, Jaime Salazar, said the senator would be held without bail. Mr. Enrile is charged with rebellion, murder and attempted murder, and could face life in prison if convicted. **********Six others have been charged in connection with the rebellion, which lasted from Dec. 1 to Dec. 9 and left 113 dead and more than 600 wounded. One of those charged is Gregorio B. Honasan, the cashiered lieutenant colonel suspected of helping organize the revolt. Mr. Honasan has been in hiding since escaping from prison in 1988. The charges against Mr. Enrile stem from statements by witnesses who asserted that they saw Mr. Honasan and about 100 other mutinous soldiers at Senator Enrile's house on the first day of the coup. Mr. Enrile says he has not seen Mr. Honasan since 1987. **********Mr. Enrile accused the Government of trying to silence him. As the secretary general of the Nationalist Party, he is one of the most forceful opponents of the Aquino Government. **********He said today the Government might even try to kill him. ''In that case they would be doing me a favor,'' he said. ''I will have a place in history.'' **********Mr. Enrile's lawyer, Rene Cayetano, said he would appeal to the Supreme Court to question the legality of the senator's arrest. ''This really shows the Government is out to politically harass Enrile,'' he said. **********Mrs. Aquino said she was happy that charges had been filed against the senator, her spokesman said. She has reportedly told the armed forces to be prepared for any unrest that may result from Mr. Enrile's arrest, a reference to a possible military uprising. The army's loyalty to Mrs. Aquino remains a matter of debate, and Mr. Enrile, who was Defense Minister for 17 years under the deposed dictator, Ferdinand E. Marcos, still has many soldiers on his side. **********Charged along with Mr. Enrile and Mr. Honasan are Gov. Rodolfo Aguinaldo of Cagayan Province; two retired military officers, Brig. Gen. Felix Brawner and Lieut. Col. Billy Bibit, and a businessman and his wife. **********Mr. Enrile was also charged separately with harboring criminals as a result of the reported meeting with Mr. Honasan. Mr Honasan was once the senator's aide and chief security officer. Mr. Honasan, who has been charged with leading an earlier attempt to topple Mrs. Aquino in 1987. **********In a big rally on Sunday marking the fourth anniversary of the uprising that brought her to power, Mrs. Aquino strongly criticized Mr. Enrile for plotting against her Government and for claiming sole credit for installing her in the presidency. **********In a speech aimed at the senator, she said: ''Be a man. Or better yet, be a woman.'' She also told a cheering crowd, ''Without you, Enrile could have harmed me and I would not be President now. You did not abandon me.'' **********As Defense Minister to Mr. Marcos, who died in exile in Hawaii in September, Mr. Enrile was much feared as the chief administrator of martial law. But in February 1986, after Mr. Marcos sought to invalidate the election that independent observers said was won by Mrs. Aquino, Mr. Enrile led a military mutiny that combined with a popular uprising to unseat Mr. Marcos. **********After that, Mr. Enrile served as Mrs. Aquino's Defense Minister for nine months. He resigned in November 1986 after he was implicated in a plot to topple the her new Government. No charges were filed against him then. **********Mr. Enrile was elected senator in 1987. He is believed to be one of the richest men in the Philippines. His companies flourished in the recovery accompanying Mrs. Aquino's rise.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Air France Speeds Cost-Cutting Pace
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/21/busin.body_text: **********Air France said it would intensify a cost-cutting program in response to a loss estimated at $32 million in the first half of 1990 and worries about fuel price increases in the second half. The state-owned company said its directors had decided to delay until 1991 all non-aircraft investments planned for the rest of this year. Nonessential work on buildings or information systems will also be deferred. **********Air France has also adopted a hiring freeze, with the exception of navigation personnel. A program of chartering planes from other companies will be phased out. The measures follow the announcement by the company's chairman, Bernard Attali, in June that Air France was cutting back flights on certain routes because of sluggish traffic growth.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East;   Honecker, in Disgrace and in Poor Health, Is Arrested as He Leaves a Berlin Hospital
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East;   Honecker, in Disgrace and in Poor Health, Is Arrested as He Leaves a Berlin Hospital
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.body_text: **********East Germany's relentless pursuit of its former hard-line leaders finally reached Erich Honecker today. The ousted Communist Party chief was released from the hospital and immediately arrested. **********The 77-year-old Mr. Honecker, who resigned on Oct. 19 under the pressure of public opposition, has been under treatment for cancer. **********The state prosecutor general, Hans-Jurgen Joseph, said Mr. Honecker would be tried for high treason in mid-March along with Erich Mielke, the 82-year-old former Minister of State Security; Gunter Mittag, the former Party Secretary for Economic Affairs, and Joachim Herrmann, the former secretary for propaganda. **********Mr. Joseph said Mr. Honecker was to remain under medical supervision. The official press agency said the former leader's doctors considered him unfit for arrest. A similar argument was made by Wolfgang Vogel, the lawyer celebrated for arranging several spy trades, who is defending Mr. Honecker. **********Surgery in August **********Mr. Honecker fell ill in June and underwent surgery in August. The press agency quoted a doctor as saying that the former leader's gall bladder and part of his colon were removed. He was operated on again on Jan. 10 for a tumor on his right kidney. **********The East German television said Mr. Honecker was visited by his wife, Margot, a former Education Minister, and his daughter and granddaughter before leaving the hospital through the main entrance. He was taken to the Rummelsburg jail by plainclothes policemen. Mr. Honecker was shown on the television walking forward unassisted, his expression stern. **********The press agency quoted a urologist, Dr. Peter Althaus, as saying that Mr. Honecker was dejected on parting with his family. ''He finds it difficult to understand the events taking place,'' Dr. Althaus was quoted as saying. **********Warning Against Revenge **********In an interview with a West German paper, Express, Prime Minister Hans Modrow warned against simple feelings of revenge and said he would support pardoning Mr. Honecker or waiving his prison term. Mr. Modrow was the Dresden party chief when Mr. Honecker was in power, and fell afoul of the leadership for his reformist views. **********Mr. Honecker was the 14th member of his old Politburo to be arrested in a continuing investigation into the repressive rule that fell last October under the pressure of growing public agitation. Besides Mr. Mielke, Mr. Mittag and Mr. Herrmann, the others include these officials: **********Hermann Axen, formerly charged with international relations; Hans-Joachim Bohme, former First Secretary of the party organization in Halle; Heinz Kessler, former Minister of Defense; Gunter Kleiber, former Deputy Prime Minister; Werner Krolikowski, former party secretary; Horst Sindermann, former President of the Parliament; Willi Stoph, former head of the trade unions; Gerhard Muller, former First Secretary of Erfurt, and Gerhard Schurer, former chairman of the State Planning Commission.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/30/world.main_headline: U.S. and Asian Allies Deadlock Over Boat People
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/30/world.print_headline: U.S. and Asian Allies Deadlock Over Boat People
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/30/world.body_text: **********Three days of talks between the United States and its Southeast Asian allies have failed to break a deadlock on how to treat thousands of Vietnamese refugees who continue to arrive on foreign shores every year. **********The impasse over whether nations have the right to forcibly repatriate selected refugees back to Vietnam threatens to tear apart international agreements under which Hong Kong and nations like Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand and the Philippines admit Vietnamese who flee their country, despite risk of becoming victims to pirates or stormy seas. **********The Southeast Asian nations want to begin to clear out the 125,000 Vietnamese who inhabit squalid camps in their countries, and prevent more people from leaving Vietnam. But the United States, which finances much of the refugee relief and grants a large number of Vietnamese permanent refuge, has opposed involuntary return of refugees, even among those classified as economic migrants. **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d presented the six foreign ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, what was described as a modified American position on Vietnamese ''boat people'' under which refugees would be encouraged though not required to return to their homeland. **********Counseling Is Suggested **********Mr. Baker suggested that while the United States could not support involuntary repatriation, it would not oppose returning ''those who do not object'' after screening and counseling. He also said the United States was committed to resettling or returning all asylum-seekers by late 1992. **********But today, at the close of the Asean meeting, officials who say their countries have the sovereign right to accept or not accept refugees sternly dismissed Mr. Baker's position as a thinly veiled restatement of the old American position against forced repatriation. **********In private meetings, the Asian foreign ministers told Mr. Baker that if Washington did not move closer to their position, they might eventually be forced to scrap the Comprehensive Plan of Action on Indo-Chinese refugees, under which several Asian countries and Hong Kong offer Vietnamese asylum with the financial support of Western industrialized nations. The agreement, they say, guarantees resettlement for poltiical refugees, not economic migrants. **********''The gap between Asean and the United States remains quite big,'' said Datuk A. Kamil Jaafar, Secretary General of the Malaysian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. ''The Baker position does not represent a movement forward.'' **********Baker Plan Called Unworkable **********Helen Barber, the acting director of the Southeast Asia Bureau of the Philippine Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said the Baker position ''is not workable,'' because it does not distinguish between political refugees and migrants who leave Vietnam to escape poverty. **********Mrs. Barber added that the Comprehensive Plan of Action ''is in danger; it can fall apart if there is no movement by the United States.'' **********The principle of first asylum has suffered a severe setback over the last 15 months as Malaysia pushed off an estimated 8,700 boat people trying to land on its shores.
