Scores of those refugees have been robbed, raped or killed by pirates after they were refused entrance. **********The discord between the United States and the Asian nations was highlighted three weeks ago when a 28-nation conference on boat people in Geneva was postponed because participants saw no hope for bridging the gap on forced repatriation. **********Such discord prompted Thorvald Stoltenberg, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, to shuttle around Europe, Asia and the United States to try to come up with a compromise arrangement before the Asean meeting to save the principle of first asylum. **********The outlines of Mr. Stoltenberg's proposal were endorsed by Mr. Baker before the Asean meeting. **********Southeast Asian diplomats said they find the Stoltenberg proposal vague, and they indicated that they hoped the United States would further modify its position on the refugees. **********Accept Refugees, U.S. Urged **********Raul Manglapus, the Philippines Foreign Minister, said the United States should simply accept all the Vietnamese refugees. **********''The United States,'' he said, ''has all the land in the world to absorb them.'' **********Other Asian diplomats privately expressed hope that the United States would improve relations with Vietnam. An end to the economic embargo of Hanoi, they suggested, would improve the Vietnamese economy and dampen the desire of many to leave. **********Mr. Baker's attendance at the Asean meeting was very much a mission to soothe tensions on the refugee issue and explain recent shifts in Cambodian policy. He privately told the foreign ministers that the Administration was in part obliged to respond to Congressional pressures when it dropped diplomatic support for the Cambodian guerrilla coalition, but that President Bush continued to share their desire to limit Vietnamese power in the region. **********The foreign ministers told Mr. Baker that they would like him to consult with them more on Indochina policy in the future, but they resisted expressing harsh public criticism of American policy on Cambodia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/25/busin.main_headline: A New Geography For the Coal Industry
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/25/busin.print_headline: A New Geography For the Coal Industry
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/25/busin.body_text: **********THE rumble of change is being heard in the coal fields of America. **********Utilities are exploring the costs and availability of lower-sulfur coal. Miners in central Appalachia and the western United States are contemplating big gains in production. Railroads expect a surge in shipments. And the high-sulfur mines of the Midwest and northern and southern Appalachia are looking at leaner times. **********Under the new Clean Air Act approved by Congress last month, restrictions on sulfur dioxide emissions, which contribute heavily to acid rain, will take effect in 1995 and tighten in 2000, with each round requiring more coal-burning utilities to find lower-sulfur fuel or to install scrubbers or other cleanup technology. **********These restriction have not previously been applied to old plants. By some estimates, one-eighth of the coal-burning plants in the United States will have to shift to different suppliers, sometimes more than 1,000 miles away. Supply relationships that have existed for decades will be disrupted. **********"This is going to be the biggest change in the use of coal at utilities in the past 50 years," said Scott B. Sitzer, an economist at the Department of Energy. **********Among producers, Ashland Coal will see compound annual earnings growth of 20 percent through 1995 because of increased demand for central Appalachian low-sulfur coal, said Rafael A. Villagran, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers. Another Appalachian producer, Westmoreland Coal, and a company in the Powder River Basin of northeast Wyoming, Nerco Inc., will also benefit, he said. **********The losers will probably be "mom-and-pop" mining companies that lack the resources to buy low-sulfur reserves or build the mines to produce them. Bigger companies may already have such reserves or be able to acquire them. The largest company, Peabody Holdings, a subsidiary of Hansen P.L.C., has big low-sulfur reserves in Montana, but offering that coal to its customers may mean a cut in profits. Because of daunting transportation costs, Western supplies, even with their attractive low sulfur levels, sell for less at the mine than do Peabody's extensive coal holdings in the East. **********Consolidation Coal, a subsidiary of Du Pont, is the second-largest American coal producer, and does not have extensive low-sulfur reserves, but it is regarded as highly efficient and, as one expert said, will "be the last guys to go." **********Among railroads, CSX and Norfolk Southern would benefit because they would haul more coal from central Appalachia, said Sandor J. Toth, senior analyst at the Fieldston Company, of Washington, a coal transportation publishing and consulting firm. In the West, Burlington Northern Union Pacific and Southern Pacific would haul more coal, he said. **********Eastern Enterprises, which owns the Midland Enterprises barge company, would also benefit, said Mr. Villagran of Shearson. Its barges ply a variety of inland waterways, including the Ohio and Mississippi rivers. **********AS for consumers, higher transportation charges and the cost of scrubbers will almost certainly push up electric rates sharply in places -- primarily in the Middle West -- now using high-sulfur coal. Coal accounted for 32.3 percent of the energy produced in the nation last year, and represents the vast majority of American fossil-fuel reserves. The United States has more than one-third of the world's coal reserves. **********When the Clean Air Act was first passed, in 1970, it meant big changes for new generating stations, but older coal-using plants were exempt. **********This time, all the older plants are affected, and some experts say that so many utilities will rush for new supplies at once that they will bid up the price of rail freight. The market for coal at the mine is also likely to change, with the now-modest price spread between low- and high-sulfur coals likely to widen. Similar price changes occurred in the oil market back when regulators set limits on sulfur dioxide emissions from oil-burning plants. **********C oal does not now operate in a national market. For one thing, the product varies sharply from deposit to deposit in energy content per pound and other factors, and most boilers can handle only a small range of coals. For another, proximity has historically been the most important determinant, with relatively little coal shipped over long distances. **********Currently, the difference in price between low-sulfur and high is small. In Eastern Kentucky, where high- and low-sulfur coals are available, the premium for low-sulfur is usually about 25 cents per million British thermal units, said A. Denny Ellerman, a vice president of Charles River Associates, a consulting firm. (A million B.T.U.'s is an amount of heat sufficient to make about 100 kilowatt-hours of electricity. That is a little less than the typical American household uses in a week.) But the premium exists only for the lowest-sulfur coals; intermediate grades actually sell for about the same as high-sulfur fuel. **********THE reason is that under the current regulations, a generating station is either in compliance or it is not; being most of the way there is of no help. The new act, however, allows averaging of the emissions of plants owned by the same utility. **********According to Department of Energy figures, coal-fired plants comprise 300 gigawatts of electrical capacity, or 44 percent of the total generating capacity. The balance includes plants fired by natural gas and oil, nuclear reactors and hydroelectric stations. The coal plants work more of the year, however, producing about 56 percent of the electricity. **********Of the total capacity of 300 gigawatts, 70 gigawatts are already treated with scrubbers, according to the Department of Energy. Additional plants with a total of 42 gigawatts of capacity will probably switch to lower-sulfur coal, and plants with 92 gigawatts of capacity will install scrubbers, said C. Hoff Stauffer Jr., a vice president of Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc. **********Shearson's estimate runs a little lower: plants with 40 gigawatts will switch fuels and plants with 55 to 60 gigawatts will add scrubbers. **********A few plants will try other solutions, like building new boilers that produce less pollution, or burning coal with natural gas to cut emissions. But under a system of emissions-trading approved by Congress, not every plant will have to change. A utility that adds a scrubber to its biggest, dirtiest plant would save so much sulfur dioxide that it could apply its "overcompliance" to smaller units that it did not clean up. **********Even with the wide expectation of large-scale coal switching, the low-sulfur coal producers are not rushing into new investments, however. At ARCO Coal, in Denver, which owns the Black Thunder mine, the biggest in the country, Curtis E. Burton, a spokesman, said the first step was to see which strategy the electric companies favor to comply with the new rules -- low-sulfur coal or scrubbers. "Every utility has to sit down and do some serious calculation, what makes sense for them to meet the new standards," Mr. Burton said. **********The Black Thunder mine, in the Powder River Basin in northeast Wyoming, produces nearly 30 million tons of coal a year, or about 3 percent of the United States' total. It is very low-sulfur coal, suitable for blending with high-sulfur coal to produce a mix that still burns with emissions below the Federal limit. **********AN ANALYSIS performed for the Environmental Protection Agency by ICF Resources Inc. in July predicted that a bill like the one that eventually passed Congress would cut coal production by up to 97 million tons from the high-sulfur areas of the Middle West and northern Appalachia by the year 2005, compared with what production would have been without a new law. The replacement coal would come mostly from central Appalachia, with some from the West. The Western coal is extremely low sulfur, below 0.7 percent; central Appalachian coal is between 0.7 and 2 percent. **********Companies in both the Appalachians and the Powder River Basin have ample capacity to produce low-sulfur coal and can expand capacity quickly, so big low-sulfur price changes are unlikely. Mr. Burton said his company foresaw "very small increases" in prices. Even with a higher demand for Powder River Basin coal, he said, competition would still be strong among producers of that type. "We're going to have to go out and hustle for every new piece of business," he said. **********A bigger barrier for Western coal is the cost of transportation. Delivery to power plants in the Middle West or Southeast can run as high as $25 a ton. Coal from the region generally sells for $5 to $7 a ton, so transportation can account for four-fifths of the delivered cost for the coal, although this is an extreme case; rail charges are usually closer to half the cost. **********But the effect of the Clean Air Act on the price of rail transport is hard to predict because costs are expected to rise sharply with volume, Mr. Toth said. If many utilities switch quickly to Western coal and begin hauling their fuel 1,500 miles instead of 200 miles, "you're talking about a lot of new cars, and a lot of new locomotives," he explained, adding, "Unless the railroads do some upgrading, we think there will be some problems." **********At the moment, Mr. Toth noted, "You can get rail rates from the Powder River Basin of a penny a pound a mile." And "Some utilities are going to make their investment decisions based on that number." That could turn out to be a big mistake. If railroad costs rise, he said, a trip that formerly cost $12 a ton could jump to $14. **********In any event, the railroads are reluctant to take major steps, he said, until it becomes clearer precisely what steps and what combinations of strategies the utilities are going to pursue, just how much low-sulfur coal will be shipped and how many new scrubbers will be installed instead. **********TRADING IN THE RIGHT TO POLLUTE **********THE new Clean Air Act will let coal-burning utilities produce, buy and sell something besides electricity: the right to pollute. **********In a system that has some economists cheering and utility regulators scratching their heads, the law will allow utilities to overcomply -- by reducing sulfur dioxide emissions below the legal limit -- and then "sell" the extra to another company. **********Suppose two companies each have to remove 1,000 tons of sulfur dioxide a year; one can do the job for $400 a ton, the other has to spend $600. The first can remove 2,000 tons and sell the extra reduction of 1,000 tons to the second company. If the price is more than $400, the first company makes a profit; if less than $600, the second company saves money. **********Scrubbers are, in fact, most cost-effective on big plants, especially the nation's 107 "big dirties," as they are known. A scrubber on a big dirty might cut sulfur-dioxide emission by 99 percent -- from 5 pounds per million British thermal units, say, to 0.05 pounds. Since the standard, when fully phased in, is 1.2 pounds, a plant that installed a scrubber would have 1.15 pounds to sell or to store against problems that might come up in the future. **********Estimates vary on the worth of this pollution commodity, but Paul R. Portney of Resources for the Future, in Washington, puts the figure at about $2.5 billion. **********"There is a shared savings," said Ashley C. Brown of the Ohio Public Utilities Commission, adding that savings can reduce rates. **********But it is not clear who should benefit, shareholder or consumer. Normally, electric customers pay for all construction through their electric bills, and get the benefit in available electricity. They could be asked to pay for extra anti-pollution equipment, and, indeed, get the benefit in reduced rates if the pollution trade works. **********But there will be some risk, both in trading in the volatile energy market and in using machinery that can quickly become obsolete. If the trade goes bad -- if the utility, say, finds itself having spent more to create a pollution credit than it can sell the credit for -- then the investment might be judged imprudent by state regulators. In that case, shareholders might have to eat the loss in the form of reduced dividends. **********Should the shareholder be asked to assume that level of risk without the possibility of gain?

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/30/busin.body_text: **********Czechoslovakia expects to join the International Monetary Fund and World Bank by the time the groups hold their annual meeting in September, the Czech Finance Minister, Vaclav Klaus, said last week. He said no decision had been made on what borrowing Czechoslovakia would need as it moves to reform its economy. Mr. Klaus said the country was moving ahead on privatization that would turn most of the country's state-owned enterprises over to its citizens.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/busin.main_headline: The Media Business: Advertising - Addenda;   DDB Needham Buys Baker Advertising
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/busin.print_headline: The Media Business: Advertising - Addenda;   DDB Needham Buys Baker Advertising
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/busin.body_text: **********DDB Needham has acquired Baker Advertising, an agency based in Troy, Mich. DDB Needham did not disclose terms of the deal but said it would merge Baker with DDB Needham Detroit. **********Until now, DDB Needham's Detroit outpost has worked only for Audi and Volkswagen, which bill about $140 million. **********Baker brings to the merger $18 million in billings for clients including several divisions of the Stanley Works and the Detroit Tigers baseball team. **********Ernest W. Baker, who founded Baker Advertising in 1964, will become chairman and chief executive of the merged agency. Bob Freeman, who had been president of the office, will take another assignment, the agency said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.main_headline: U.S. Issues Off in Foreign Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;   U.S. Issues Off in Foreign Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities dipped and interest rates rose slightly in thin trading overseas yesterday, as market participants in the United States took Columbus Day off. **********Analysts said the small drop in prices, which amounted to as much as 3/8 point for some securities, was somewhat surprising, because the dollar was battered on foreign currency markets. **********At the close of trading in Europe, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 99 11/32, down 9/32, to yield 8.81 percent, up from 8.78 percent late Friday. **********On the Chicago Board of Trade, which was open for business yesterday, the near Treasury bond futures contract closed at a price of 90 15/32, down 15/32. **********Although the House of Representatives approved a vaguely worded budget agreement late Sunday night, and the Senate appeared likely to do the same, it remained uncertain late yesterday whether President Bush would go along with the plan. **********The House also approved an increase in the Federal debt ceiling, to $3.19 trillion. The increase would be enough to carry the Government through Oct. 20. The Senate, which was deliberating over the budget last night, was also expected to approve the increase in the debt ceiling. **********Should Mr. Bush decide to veto the new budget, the debt ceiling would not be raised and today's auctions of three-month and six-month Treasury bills would be delayed, analysts said. **********Despite the budget proposal's vague terms and promises, economists said they did not anticipate an adverse reaction in the credit markets to the plan when traders return in force today. **********''I don't think the market will be tremendously put off by it,'' said Susan M. Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers. ''People may be a bit more disturbed by the fact that the accord is a bit flimsier than its predecessor. But you can't cast stones right now because you don't know what is in the package.'' **********Under the terms of the budget agreement reached by the House, specific spending cuts and tax increases are to be agreed to by various Congressional committees over the next two weeks. **********Activity in other debt markets was limited because of the holiday. **********Prices of investment-grade and high-yield ''junk bonds'' were unchanged in extremely sparse trading. **********And participants in the tax-exempt municipal bond market said prices of New York City bonds, which were marked down by as much as 2 points on Friday, were basically unchanged yesterday. As on Friday, few city bonds actually changed hands yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;   Interest Rates Up at Citicorp
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates rose sharply at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday, reflecting the rise in short-term rates in the last few weeks. **********The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.296 percent, up from 8.1805 percent last week. It is now at its highest level since the Dec. 19, 1989, auction, when the rate was 8.33 percent. Citicorp said it also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 8.26 percent, up from 8.12 percent, and the highest since the Oct. 3, 1989, auction, when the rate was 8.536 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/24/busin.body_text: **********THE ECONOMY **********Profiting From the Bailout **********How to profit from the savings and loan bailout: First, default on a real estate project. Then, go back into business under a new name. Finally, turn around and buy the property from the Government at a fraction of its initial cost. Such are the shenanigans already afflicting Federal sales of property seized from failed savings and loans. There's more: consultants and former savings executives drawing six-figure payments to manage failed institutions; country-club expenses billed to the Government; a deposit on the sale of one building made with a suitcase of cash. Should the Government screen buyers, managers and brokers to make sure none were involved in the savings and loan collapse? Do that in Texas, some say, and almost nobody would be left to broker or buy. But with a single state accounting for more than half the 35,908 properties (book value $14.9 billion) up for sale, the bailout is likely to result in a flood of funds from the rest of the nation into Texas. **********Pointing Fingers in Washington **********It was tough enough for Democrats and Republicans to observe a tacit nonaggression pact when the savings and loan bailout amounted to some piddling tens of billions. But now that it is a certified, half-trillion-dollar disaster, politicians from the President on down are hunting for someone - someone else - to blame. Democrats accuse the Administration of causing a second savings and loan crisis by bungling the bailout that Congress approved last year. ''The minute the bill was signed, there was an abdication of responsibility,'' Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, said at a recent hearing. Marlin Fitzwater, speaking for the President, responded sharply last week. He cited the roles several Democratic senators and House members played in the mess, and said, ''There are a lot of battles that can be fought on this turf, and we're ready.'' **********Accusations Against Neil Bush **********Mr. Fitzwater's attack on the Democrats took place the same day it was revealed that Federal regulators had considered banning the President's son, Neil, from the banking business. A draft document released by the House Banking Committee said Mr. Bush had violated rules on conflicts of interest three times as a director of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. For lack of evidence, the Office of Thrift Supervision has instead has sought only to prohibit Mr. Bush from violating the rules again. Mr. Bush has said he did nothing wrong. **********Bargains, but for Whom? **********Last week brought a sobering example of the losses the Government can expect for real estate taken from failed savings institutions. The Gibraltar Savings Association invested $330 milion in the Stonebridge Ranch, a dazzling spread of golf courses, man-made ponds and million-dollar homes north of Dallas. Richard C. Strauss, son of the former Democratic Party chairman, Robert S. Strauss, was the project's manager. The Government agreed on Thursday to sell it for $61 million to Yukio Kitano, a Japanese industrialist. **********Credit Crunch Is Relative **********Alan Greenspan isn't keeping Fed-guessers guessing. On Thursday, the Federal Reserve Board chairman said on Capitol Hill that the economy will keep chugging along without risk of recession. And, implicitly, without easier money from the Fed. And what about those complaints of a credit crunch? Credit seems tight only when compared with the lax standards that bankers and regulators have allowed, he said. **********No Free Ride for LTV **********The Supreme Court ruled last week that the Government can limit its Aid to Corporations with Dependent Pensioners. Only the truly needy companies will qualify, not those in search of a handout. In the case at issue, the LTV Corporation filed for bankruptcy four years ago and turned its responsibilities over to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, which paid reduced benefits. Then LTV agreed in talks with the United Steelworkers of America to make up much of the difference between the Federal payouts and its former pension plan. The agency saw that its safety net was becoming more of a trampoline. It ordered LTV to resume paying for its pension plan without Government support, and the case went to court. The ruling will keep corporations from dumping more of their pension costs on the agency, which is already in financial trouble **********Economy Winds Down **********The latest gross national product economy is gasping but growing. A 1.9 percent annual growth rate for the first quarter, after a 1.1 percent rise in the fourth quarter last year, continued the weakest pace of expansion since 1986. The first-quarter number was revised last week from an earlier estimate of 1.3 percent, but economists paid more attention to a lowered figure for consumption. ''It points to slower growth ahead,'' said Joseph Carson, senior economist at Chemical Bank. **********Stocks Stumble **********The Dow Jones industrial average fell 78.71 points last week to 2,857.18. Traders blamed familiar culprits: computerized trading programs, a weakening bond market and fears of lower corporate profits. **********COMPANIES **********The Patent Wars **********Between Japan and America, the patent battles can be as punishing as the trade wars. A Federal District Court judge banned Motorola Inc. and Hitachi Ltd. from selling some chips last week; a higher court soon issued a stay. Analysts say Motorola faces the greater threat. The patent squabble pits Motorola's popular 68030 chip, used in Apple Macintosh and Sun Microsystems computers, against a Hitachi chip not yet sold in this country. ''If both chips had to stop shipping, Motorola would be hurt more,'' said John M. Geraghty, an analyst at First Boston. He added that Motorola is accused of far fewer patent violations than Hitachi. The broader issue might be the balance of power in patents, he said, with Japanese companies finding it much easier to enforce patent rights in the United States than American companies do in Japan. Hitachi led all companies in American patents last year, with 1,053. **********Ben's Advice for Mr. Trump **********Donald J. Trump went to the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, where he presumably studied the art of leverage. He might have done better to study the teachings of the university's father, Benjamin Franklin. ''He who goes a-borrowing goes a-sorrowing,'' Franklin said. If Mr. Trump can claim that his methods rescued Central Park's Wollman Rink, Franklin even made the colonial postal system profitable. Mr. Trump has insisted he is no gambler: ''I've never gambled in my life. To me, a gambler is someone who plays slot machines. I prefer to own slot machines.'' But Franklin would have kept him from exaggerating his casinos' expected performance. ''Ah, think what you do when you run in debt; you give to another power over your liberty,'' Franklin said. ''The second vice is lying, the first is running in debt. 'Tis hard for an empty bag to stand upright.'' Even outside of work, Mr. Trump has failed to follow some of Franklin's best-known advice: ''In all your amours, you should prefer old women to young ones.'' **********In Brief **********E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company plans to build four plants to produce refrigerants that, unlike chlorofluorocarbons, would not deplete the atmosphere's ozone layer. *********** **********The House Judiciary Committee voted last week to repeal most of the insurance industry's exemptions from antitrust law, the first time such a measure has gone so far. It is still more likely to become a ''cash cow'' - provoking insurance companies to raise their campaign contributions - than a law. **********INTERNATIONAL **********Bustin' the Charts **********Rapper turned recording mogul? M. C. Hammer said last week that he was starting his own label, Bustin' Records. Mr. Hammer's first venture in the industry came three years ago, when he was an assistant to Charles Finley, owner of the Oakland Athletics baseball team. He borrowed enough from a couple players to press his own record, then sold thousands from his basement and the back of his car. A contract with Capital Records followed. Now Mr. Hammer's second album, ''Please Hammer Don't Hurt 'Em,'' has the top spot on Billboard's chart, and his own label has plans to release albums by 10 new groups. **********'Junk' Casualty **********The Coniston Partners will be among Wall Street's most feared corporate raiders no more. They plan to return the proceeds from their main, $700 million investment fund to backers. With the stock market high and the ''junk bond'' market low, Coniston has all but run out of financing and promising deals. The firm was founded on the familiar 1980's premise that forcing companies to cough up huge payoffs for noisy, impatient investors would somehow improve corporate performance. That notion at least did wonders for Coniston's performance, with 40 percent annual returns common until the firm lagged the stock market last year. The partners plan to keep their stakes in TW Services Inc. and the UAL Corporation, which after repeated raids and restructuring has gone from being the nation's largest airline to No. 2. **********An Even Bigger Philip Morris **********The Philip Morris Companies agreed on Friday to buy most of the operations of Jacobs Suchard A.G., the Swiss coffee and chocolate company, for $3.8 billion. The deal will vastly expand Philip Morris's presence in Europe, where its Kraft General Foods subsidiary already has revenues of more than $3 billion. Suchard's products include the familiar triangular Toblerone chocolate bars. Suchard will further Philip Morris's diversification away from tobacco. **********A First Bout of Unemployment **********East German unemployment is already surging. The official rate rose from 100,000 to 130,000 in the first two weeks of June. East German leaders have said they expect at least 20 percent of their nation's businesses to shut down after the two German economies become one on July 2. Economists say that more than 2 million of East Germany's 9 million workers will lose their jobs over the next year. Under its Communist rulers, the country had no unemployment - but plenty of inefficient factories spewing out second-rate goods. **********The Real Taj **********The ''Trumped-up Taj,'' one Indian newspaper called it. Indian publications just can't see how a wealthy American could transform a classic Mogul memorial into a mish-mash of onion domes, minarets and zillion-watt neon signs. ''It demonstrates that Hollywood does not have a monopoly on bad taste,'' said The Saturday Statesman. The original Taj was built in the 17th century by Shah Jehan as a tomb for his beloved consort, Mumtaz Mahal. Unlike Donald J. Trump, The Sunday Observer said, Shah Jehan needed no bank loans. Mr. Trump, meanwhile, continued negotiating with his bankers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/31/busin.main_headline: Milken's Lawyers File Brief, Making Final Arguments
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/31/busin.print_headline: Milken's Lawyers File Brief, Making Final Arguments
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/31/busin.body_text: **********Lawyers for Michael R. Milken filed a brief yesterday with their final arguments in the former financier's pre-sentencing hearing, contending that the evidence had disproved the "Government's portrayal of him as a 'master criminal.' " **********Government prosecutors had been scheduled to file their arguments as well with Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood but were unable to meet the deadline after the court ordered that certain references be deleted. The Government's memorandum is expected to be filed today. **********The defense brief, signed by Arthur L. Liman, Mr. Milken's lead attorney, contains no surprises. Rather, it is a step-by-step summary of Mr. Milken's arguments that he was not involved in any illegal activity in three other transactions that were the focus of the hearing.  The Government's Case **********Mr. Milken, the former head of the high-yield "junk bond" division of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., pleaded guilty to six felonies in April. Judge Wood ordered the hearing to determine whether Mr. Milken's crimes were part of a broader criminal conspiracy, as the Government says, or were individual instances of going too far to help a client, as the defense contends. **********The Government chose three transactions to demonstrate that Mr. Milken committed more crimes than those he admitted. The first involved a 1986 manipulation of shares of the Wickes Companies Inc., in what the Government contends was an effort by Mr. Milken to push the stock price up to allow Wickes to redeem an exepensive preferred security. **********While agreeing a manipulation took place, the defense argued in its brief that the Government had no consistent evidence that Mr. Milken was part of it. Witnesses contradicted one another about their roles in the manipulation, a fact that the defense used to challenge the credibility of the evidence. A Conspicuous Absence >HE> **********The defense also argued that the Government's failure to call Ivan F. Boesky, the former arbitrager and a key witness in the Government's investigation of Mr. Milken, "looms especially large." **********The defense brief also contended that the Government failed to prove its case in the second transaction. That involved the 1985 buyout of Storer Communications Inc., in which prosecutors contended that Mr. Milken misappropriated an equity stake from the deal and bribed money managers with it. **********Mr. Milken's lawyers said employee partnerships, which included Mr. Milken, received a large portion of the equity after committing to purchase $154 million worth of a risky preferred security. Such an investment in a Drexel deal was not unusual, given the relationship between Mr. Milken and the company, the document said. In 1985, Mr. Milken and his brother, Lowell, lent $27 million to the company, it said.   Caesar's World Bonds **********Giving money managers of high-yield bond funds the opportunity to invest in a partnership that held the Storer equity was not a bribe to get their institutional funds to invest in the deal, the defense document contended. All the money managers called by the Government testified that they received the offer to invest in the partnership after the funds had already purchased their securities. **********In the last transaction, in which the Government contends Mr. Milken engaged in insider trading in the bonds of Caesars World Inc., the defense argued that Mr. Milken had no inside information at the time he made trades in the bonds. In addition, the document says a trade that was the focus of testimony at the hearing took place days after Mr. Milken left the country for a vacation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/15/busin.main_headline: Fast Food and Bookstores Top List for Openings in '80's
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/15/busin.print_headline: Fast Food and Bookstores Top List for Openings in '80's
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/15/busin.body_text: **********In the last decade, Americans' love for fast food, reading, home electronics and sporting goods helped to cause a boom in specialty stores. But other changes in shopping habits and the population mix have led to only a slight overall gain in the number of retail establishments around the country, according to a new study. **********From 1980 to 1990, fast-food restaurants, bookstores, consumer electronics stores, apparel stores and sporting goods outlets led the list of new stores. The largest declines were in automotive stores, gasoline service stations and general merchandise stores. The information was compiled by Audits and Surveys Inc., one of the country's largest marketing research companies. **********The total number of stores rose only 6 percent, to 1,845,340, in the 1980's. That compares with a population gain of 11 percent and a 43 percent increase in total retail sales, the company said. 'Less Demand for Stores' **********"This means that there is now only 1 retail outlet per every 134 people against a ratio of 1 to 129 persons in 1980," said Solomon Dutka, chief executive officer of Audits and Surveys. **********"The World War II baby boomers are getting older and their numbers are not being replaced by new births because Americans are having fewer children per household. And there are more single-person households and later marriages. All this, despite a still growing population, means that in many cities there is less demand for stores." **********The data are compiled in the New York-based company's annual census of retail distribution, which is based on a nationwide sample of more than 40,000 retail and service stores. The survey was conducted in May and June and each store was visited by an interviewer from Audits and Surveys. The sample has a margin of error of 5 percent. **********The number of fast-food stores rose 78 percent in the 10-year period, to 119,880 from 67,290. It was the largest increase of all types of stores, said Audits and Surveys, followed by a 76 percent jump in the number of bookstores, to 17,620 from 10,020. **********Other big gainers were consumer electronics stores, up 54 percent, to 30,600 from 19,900, and chain drugstores, up 36 percent, to 18,230 from 13,400. The biggest losers were variety stores, down 38 percent, to 10,720, from 17,400, and gasoline service stations, down 32 percent, to 107,500 from 158,540.  Aging Population **********Several important factors influenced store openings and closings, Mr. Dutka said. He mentioned the aging population, the increase in the number of working women, large increases in the population of blacks and Hispanic people, and more double-income families. **********With more women working outside the home, the trend of couples and families eating out is growing, as is the popularity of one-stop shopping locations, he said. "The double-income household also is creating a larger market for more expensive merchandise and also provides opportunities for people to spend more money for their leisure-time activities," Mr. Dutka said. **********Americans are living longer and leading more active lives, Mr. Dutka said. "This is why the sporting goods are growing so much," he said. **********Some kinds of local and neighborhood stores are increasing, in great part because the two fastest-growing population groups are those of Hispanic background and blacks, who prefer to shop locally, he said. "While overall U.S. population grew 11 percent in the decade, the number of Hispanics in the country rose 32 percent and blacks by 15 percent," Mr. Dutka said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/25/busin.body_text: **********The board of the troubled Financial News Network and Infotechnology Inc., which owns 47 percent of FNN, announced a new management team for the companies yesterday in the face of severe cash-flow difficulties. **********The companies appointed Alan J. Hirschfield, and Allan R. Tessler as interim co-chief executives, replacing Earl W. Brian, who had been chief executive of both companies. Mr. Brian will continue as non-executive chairman and director of both companies. **********Mr. Hirschfield and Mr. Tessler will be responsible for restructuring Infotechnology and exploring options that could mean the sale of some or all of its businesses. Among its holdings, the company owns 97 percent of United Press International.   Insufficient Cash Flow **********Infotechnology also said its cash flow was insufficient to cover its operating expenses, to cover maturing bank loan obligations of $49.5 million at FNN and $20.7 million at Infotechnology, or to cover FNN's $88 million in obligations relating to its sale and leaseback programs of equipment. **********The company said it would require waivers or adjustments regarding certain defaults on the outstanding bank loans. **********Yesterday, Infotechnology's stock fell $1.06 1/4, to $3.06 1/4 a share, in over-the-counter trading. **********Lorraine Maxfield, an analyst at the Paulson Investment Company, said the cash shortages were a real surprise. **********Referring to a dispute between the company and its former auditors, Deloitte & Touche, over whether a $28 million capital expenditure should be taken against quarterly earnings or written off over a period of years, she said: "The last we knew, the big problem of the $28 million was a non-cash charge. Now the entire finances are looking more and more questionable, as if the whole thing were falling apart."   Financial Expertise **********FNN has already dismissed its auditors and its chief financial officer, C. Steven Bolen, asserting that his compensation was not authorized. **********In replacing Dr. Brian, Infotechnology turned to men with financial expertise, as well as management experience. **********Mr. Hirschfield is a former chief executive of the 20th Century Fox Corporation and of Columbia Pictures and is currently a managing director at Wertheim Schroder & Company. **********Mr. Tessler, a member of the Infotechnology board, is chairman of the International Financial Group, Ameriscribe Inc. and the International Controls Corporation. **********The first priorities of the new team will be to work with the banks and the companies that have leased equipment like data receivers, seeking waivers or adjustments on payment schedules. **********Earlier this month, Infotechnology said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was under Government investigation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/05/busin.main_headline: Hill, Holliday Is Poised For Success in New York
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/05/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Hill, Holliday Is Poised For Success in New York
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/05/busin.body_text: **********ONE of the hardest things for an agency outside New York is to establish a successful office on Madison Avenue. **********Many agencies have tried and most have failed, but the New York branch of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos (the firm is based in Boston) finally appears poised to become one of the rare success stories. **********Opened in 1985 with just one account, the $2 million Irish Tourist Board business, Hill, Holliday/New York recently won the $30 million account for Upjohn's Motrin IB analgesic. Now, the agency has billings of about $60 million and a roster of clients including Rolling Rock and Labatt's beers, E. J. Brach's candy and Sportschannel. **********The agency has established itself as an important player in the New York advertising scene and is competing in the creative reviews for two big accounts -- MCI Communications, at $50 million, and Nikon, at $15 million -- against some big names like Ammirati & Puris, TBWA Advertising and BBDO. **********Yet becoming established in New York has not been easy for Hill, Holliday. For the first few years it was plagued by the same problem that most outside agencies face when they move to Madison Avenue, some analysts said. In order to succeed, the New York branch must establish an identity separate from its well-known parent. Otherwise, clients can see no reason for choosing the offspring. **********"We had to differentiate ourselves from the main office because clients aren't interested in just a smaller version of Hill, Holliday," said Susan Smith, the managing director of the New York office. **********The agency had been having trouble doing that because management in New York had changed frequently and top executives from the Boston headquarters were too involved in running the office. **********But during the last year there have been several significant management changes. Hill, Holliday transferred Ms. Smith from Boston to run the New York office. Several other top people from Boston were also sent to New York. But the most important addition was John Ferrell, a former top creative executive at Young & Rubicam, who joined Hill, Holliday at the beginning of the year as it chief creative officer. **********With Mr. Ferrell on board, executives at the main office have given the New York office far more autonomy, Ms. Smith said. "They wouldn't second-guess his work," she added. **********What Mr. Ferrell has done in New York is establish the office as a specialist in packaged-goods, hiring experts in creating that kind of advertising. "Boston is a master at creating advertising for services like John Hancock insurance and hard goods like Wang computers," Mr. Ferrell said. "Clients who want the Hill Holliday touch for packaged goods can come to New York." **********Hill, Holliday, which has total billings of about $400 million, has made its reputation creating unconventional, often emotional, advertising like the lifelike mini-dramas for John Hancock insurance and the Zen-like ads to introduce Nissan's Infiniti that featured rocks and trees but no cars. **********The first big campaign created by Mr. Ferrell has a similar unexpected approach. Unlike most ads for pain killers, the Motrin commercials do not focus on someone who is suffering. The ads do not show the product or anyone getting relief. **********Instead, the commercials zero in on a person trying to help. One spot features a woman telling her husband, "I can't let you sit there and complain about your arthritis pain." The camera, which focuses solely on the woman talking about how she is going to help, bobs and weaves, cutting the woman partly out of the scene at times. It creates the effect of someone woozy with pain stumbling around a room. **********By creating a voyeuristic feeling and simulating how pain influences behavior, the agency is trying to create ads that hold the interest of consumers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/19/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Arnell/Bickford Plans To Open on West Coast
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/19/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Arnell/Bickford Plans To Open on West Coast
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/19/busin.body_text: **********Peter Arnell, the co-founder of Arnell/Bickford Associates, said his New York agency would open a West Coast office in Santa Monica, Calif., in April. Mr. Arnell said the decision to expand came after its client Donna Karan, the fashion designer, gave Arnell/Bickford a $2.5 million assignment for the design and advertising of 11 new boutiques in Japan. **********Mr. Arnell said that his partner, Ted Bickford, would split his time between New York and California.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/25/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Communists Take Lead In Mongolian Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/25/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Communists Take Lead In Mongolian Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/25/world.body_text: **********Mongolians apparently have handed their Communist rulers a comfortable victory in the vast Central Asian nation's first free elections, according to results from first-round voting announced today. **********Prime Minister Sharavyn Gunjaadorj told journalists that the number of opposition candidates contesting the main election had been whittled down to less than 20 percent of the total after Sunday's preliminary round. **********The Communists have ruled Mongolia, an arid land the size of Western Europe but with a population of only 2 million, for 69 years. **********Foreigners invited to observe the polling said it was marked by confusion but basically fair. About 92 percent of eligible voters cast ballots. **********Mongolians here spoke with delight of their first taste of democracy. **********''It was a wonderful feeling to be able to vote against the Communist Party for the first time,'' said one young man. ''It was like swearing at them.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/24/world.main_headline: Diplomacy Wins as 2 Koreas Compete at Soccer in Seoul
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/24/world.print_headline: Diplomacy Wins as 2 Koreas Compete at Soccer in Seoul
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/24/world.body_text: **********The two Koreas clashed on the soccer field today in a game dedicated to friendship, watched by the largest crowd to see a South Korean sports event since the 1988 Olympics. **********South Korea won 1-0, but the score was insignificant beside the diplomatic coup in having two enemy nations share a playing field for only the second time since World War II. The first time was two weeks ago in North Korea, when the northern team beat the South 2-1. **********About 5,000 plainclothes police officers were deployed inside and outside Olympic Stadium. The more tan 80,000 spectators were searched twice and passed through metal detectors to reach their seats. **********At the end of the game, spectators rose for a standing ovation as the athletes jogged around the stadium holding hands and waving. The teams exchanged shirts and waved them in the air as loudpeakers blared a song with the refrain, "Our wish is unification." **********"This is not purely a sports festival," said Kim Yu Sun, chairman of North Korea's Sports Guidance Committee, before the match began. "It should lead to a unification festival." **********Thousands roared in approval. **********"I hope this soccer match will be a springboard for national unification," the South Korean Sports Minister, Chung Dong Sung, said. **********The game, called North-South Unification Soccer, is the high point of a five-day visit by a 78-member North Korean sports delegation. The group is the first sports delegation from the Communist North to visit South Korea since the division of the peninsula in 1945. **********The visit is in return for a five-day trip to the North by South Korean soccer players earlier this month. That visit was only the second civilian exchange between the two countries in more than four decades. **********The Prime Ministers of both Koreas met for the second time last week in Pyongyang, where they agreed in principle to form a joint team for the 1992 Olympic Games and other international sports events.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/16/busin.body_text: **********An engineer presented a plan for developing new software to the vice president of his high-technology company. With his team, the engineer waited expectantly, hoping for praise and encouragement; the plan was the result of months of work. **********But the reaction from the vice president was harsh. ''These specifications are ridiculous,'' he said. ''They haven't a chance of getting past my desk.'' Then, his voice thick with sarcasm, he added, ''How long have you been out of graduate school?'' **********''The engineer was crushed,'' said Dr. Hendrie Weisinger, a psychologist at the School of Management at the University of California at Los Angeles, who tells the story. ''For two weeks, he could think only about his humiliation in front of his team. He hated the vice president and worried over his future. He thought of leaving the company.'' **********Dr. Weisinger - whose book ''The Critical Edge: How to Criticize Up and Down Your Organization and Make It Pay Off'' was published earlier this year by Harper & Row - offers the tale as an example of the most common errors managers make in giving criticism. ''The worst way to criticize is with a blanket statement, like, 'You're really screwing up,' without offering the person some way to do things better,'' said Dr. Weisinger. ''It leaves the other person feeling helpless and angry.'' **********Dr. Weisinger is one of several psychologists studying the fine art of criticism, which, they say, is typically approached with far too little finesse, if it is practiced at all. Yet failing to let people know when they are faltering is, of course, a recipe for disaster. **********An artful critique can be one of the most helpful messages a manager can send. ''It's how the manager delivers a criticism that determines whether its effects will be productive or disastrous,'' said Robert Baron, a professor of psychology and management at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y. The hallmarks of artful criticism include being specific, making no threats, placing no personal blame - and being timely. The key, said Dr. Baron, is that the person receiving the criticism feel that he or she is ''being helped to do better.'' **********''Giving criticism is one of the most important jobs a manager has,'' Dr. Weisinger said. ''But it's also one of the most unpleasant tasks managers face, and one of the most often put off.'' **********That delay can be costly. A supervisor's failure to give an employee timely criticism led to a $250,000 claim for wrongful termination, said Laurie Dutcher, director of human resources at the Capital Area Community Health Plan, in Latham, N.Y. **********''She was fired because of a terrible absentee record, but she didn't feel her performance was lacking in any way,'' Ms. Dutcher said. ''For years, her supervisor had put off telling her that she was remiss. We find that story often, with a manager being too uncomfortable giving criticism to let employees know when they are failing.'' **********Also, when managers let their dissatisfactions build up without saying anything at all, she said, the result is likely to be an outburst. ''Too often, a manager just blows up,'' said Dr. Baron. He encourages managers to ''give negative feedback as needed, regularly, and in small chunks, with suggestions for how to do the job better.'' a If a manager realizes he or she has offered crticism that is destructive, Dr. Baron urges an apology. ''You've damaged the relationship, and you have to get in there and repair things,'' he said. But many managers do not recognize their criticism as destructive. Dr. Weisinger said that the engineer, still feeling bitter, approached his boss two weeks later, and asked: ''What were you trying to accomplish?'' The vice president was astonished, said Dr. Weisinger. ''He simply hadn't realized how he was coming off.'' If criticism is being delivered ineffectively, Dr. Baron has found, the person receiving it simply makes excuses but does not change, is defensive and may simply avoid the critic. **********''The sign your criticism is skilful,'' he said, ''is that the person changes as you desired.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/busin.main_headline: Treasury Prices Fall in Light Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;   Treasury Prices Fall in Light Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities dipped and interest rates rose slightly in fairly light trading yesterday, as dealers positioned themselves for the release this morning of June employment data. **********The traders pushed prices lower early in the session in reaction to a report in The Wall Street Journal that the Bush Administration was considering whether to impose a sales tax on a wide range of securities, including stocks and bonds. Administration officials said yesterday that the odds were against such a tax. **********Adding to the decline was news that automobile sales for the last 10 days of June were far stronger than expected. **********Eight Million Cars Sold **********Automobile makers sold eight million cars at a seasonally adjusted annual rate during the period, the highest level since the middle of January. **********''The numbers were much stronger than anticipated, and were the first sign of consumer strength in some time, but I would be cautious in assuming this means that consumer spending is about to rise,'' said Michael J. Moran, the chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc. **********He noted that the domestic manufacturers, especially Honda of America Inc., which sold more cars than the Chrysler Corporation during the late-June sales period, often put on big incentives at the end of each month to spur sales. **********''You would need to see additional healthy numbers before concluding that people are spending again,'' Mr. Moran said. **********While talk of a securities tax and the auto sales numbers influenced trading to some degree, the dealers said the developments paled in significance next to the job data. **********''Potentially, the employment figures are very important for all financial markets, '' a government bond trader said. ''If the bond market sees a good set of numbers, short rates are likely to fall even more, which in all likelihood will have an impact on the stock market and on the dollar.'' **********Predictions on Data **********The traders and financial economists have said an increase in nonfarm payroll employment of less than 100,000 would have a salutary effect on interest rates. Conversely, if the employment number rises by 200,000 or more, market interest rates would almost certainly rise, they said. **********Excluding census workers, many of whom were dismissed last month, most analysts estimate that non-farm payroll employment rose by about 160,000. **********Some of the dealers said they sold securities yesterday to defend against the chance that the employment report might be stronger than anticipated. **********By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 103 26/32, down by 6/32, to yield 8.39 percent, up from 8.38 percent late on Tuesday. **********Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 103 5/32, down by 3/32, to yield 8.39 percent. And the 8 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 9/ 32, down by 3/32, to yield 8.21 percent. 30-Year Bonds Down to 8.79% Before the coming auctions, the 30-year bonds to be sold on Tuesday for the Resolution Funding Corporation were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 8.79 percent, down slightly from 8.81 percent on Tuesday. The agency was created to finance the bailout of the savings and loan industry. **********And the seven-year Treasury notes to be auctioned on Wednesday were offered in late when-issued trading at a price to yield 8.41 percent, up slightly from 8.39 percent. **********While the yields on bonds and notes rose slightly, short-term rates on Treasury bills moved in the other direction. The traders said optimism that the job data might prompt the Federal Reserve to ease credit conditions, coupled with a drop in stock prices, generated demand for bills yesterday. **********By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.65 percent, down by 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by a basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.56 percent. And one-year bill rates were unchanged, at an offered rate of 7.44 percent. **********Moody's Upgrades County **********In other developments, Moody's Investors Service Inc., which along with other primary ratings agencies has been busily downgrading the creditworthiness of various state and local governments this year, said yesterday that one of the country's critical problem areas in the 1980's had been returned to investment-grade status. **********The agency said it had lifted its ratings on Wayne County, Mich., which includes Detroit. **********Moody's lifted its ratings on more than $265.9 million worth of Wayne County's outstanding general obligation bonds to Baa, from Ba-1. The county had been rated at less than investment grade since October 1979. **********The agency said in a news release that Wayne County was upgraded because it had carried out a state-authorized fiscal stabilization plan. **********Activity in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds was light yesterday, the dealers said. The prices of most actively quoted issues were unchanged to up by an eighth of a point. **********Meanwhile, the traders of investment-grade corporate bonds said the prices of most issues dipped by about an eighth of a point, largely in sympathy with the decline in Treasury prices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/08/world.print_headline: THE IRAQI INVASION;   EUROPE AND JAPAN SUPPORT EMBARGO
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/08/world.body_text: **********As if anxious to dispel memories of their past support for the Baghdad Government, Western Europe and Japan have moved quickly to carry out European Community and United Nations resolutions ordering trade and arms embargoes against Iraq. **********But in throwing their weight behind the international campaign to isolate Iraq, Western Europe and Japan are also expecting to pay a stiff price for policies that in recent years have contributed enormously to strengthening President Saddam Hussein's position in the Middle East. **********France, Italy, West Germany and Spain have sold weapons to Iraq; France and Japan have given generous credits to Baghdad, and Britain is among numerous industrialized countries to have encouraged their private companies to do business with Iraq. **********The immediate impact of the crisis in these countries seems likely to be higher domestic oil prices, which could in turn slow economic growth. But Iraq also has huge outstanding debts to Japan and some European countries on which payments will now be indefinitely suspended. **********West Could Face Own Weapons **********If the current trade embargo leads to a naval blockade of Iraq, Western nations may find themselves confronting sophisticated weapons, including supersonic aircraft and missiles, that they themselves have supplied. **********In the hours and days that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week, Western Europe and Japan have nonetheless closed ranks with the United States, ordering freezes of Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets, banning oil imports from the two countries and forbidding exports to Iraq. **********One of the earliest signs of Western Europe's new determination to confront President Hussein has been its willingness to discuss the crisis at the headquarters of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Brussels. In the past, France in particular has insisted that NATO has no authority to act in the Middle East. **********''Usually in these cases you have the United States calling for action and the rest talking about diplomatic solutions,'' one NATO official said. ''Not this time. Everyone, including France, believes something should be done. And everyone, including France, agrees this is an issue of direct interest to NATO.'' **********France's position is specially complicated because it has long been Europe's main supplier of both armaments and credits to Iraq. For example, during Iraq's war with Iran between 1980 and 1988, France provided some $17 billion of armaments to Baghdad, including Mirage fighters and Exocet missiles. **********Iraq Owes France Billions **********Since the war ended, French construction and electronics companies have also signed important contracts with Iraq. Today, Iraq owes France around $4.5 billion, including $2.5 billion for weapons. Arms sales to Iraq were suspended in May only because Baghdad fell behind on its debt payments. **********When the crisis erupted last Thursday, however, France apparently decided it could not be seen wavering. It quickly froze Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets and took the initiative of proposing that the 12-nation European Community boycott Iraqi oil and cut off arms sales to the country. **********Some domestic critics have charged that the Government shares responsibility for Iraq's aggression. A cartoon in Le Monde today showed Western hostages being led away by a tank marked, ''Made in France.'' But this has only prompted the Government to take a firmer stance, including dispatching a frigate to join two warships already in the Gulf area. **********Britain, in contrast, is not believed to have supplied weapons to Iraq, but British companies have also been vying for lucrative contracts in Iraq. And in recent months, opposition politicians in London have accused Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of overlooking assorted abuses of Iraqi power in the name of protecting British business interests. **********Just this year, Iraq ignored British protests and hanged a London-based Iranian-born journalist on spying charges. Iraq was also accused of trying to smuggle American-made nuclear triggers through Heathrow Airport in London and of acquiring parts in Britain and elsewhere in Europe for a gigantic gun. Baghdad denied both charges. **********But after the invasion of Kuwait, a former British protectorate with an estimated $28 billion worth of assets in Britain, Mrs. Thatcher immediately ordered a freeze of Kuwaiti holdings and, during a quick visit to the United States, showed herself anxious to coordinate the Western response with President Bush. **********No Japanese Peacekeepers **********Japan's stake in the crisis can be measured by the fact that it has not only been the main provider of foreign aid to Iraq, is a major exporter to Iraq and is owed some $4.7 billion by the Baghdad Government, but has also received about 12 percent of its oil during the first six months of this year from Iraq and Kuwait. **********But despite some domestic claims that Tokyo hesitated in responding to the Kuwaiti invasion, waiting until Sunday to announce a full embargo of trade and aid, the Government has insisted that it moved quickly on sanctions, despite the considerable commercial losses involved. **********Japan is nonetheless bracing for criticism for not offering to involve its armed forces. ''Our Constitution prohibits our military contribution, even to peacekeeping forces,'' Taizo Watanabe, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said. ''We have made it clear we will do what we can in a non-military way. But we don't know what kind of a contribution we can make.'' **********In Western Europe, apart from Britain and France, no other country has so far indicated willingness to participate in a naval blockade of Iraq, while Greece has announced that United States bases in Crete could not be used as a springboard for military action in the Middle East. **********In Bonn, a spokesman said the question of West German involvement in a maritime blockade ''has not yet been raised'' and refused to comment further. The magazine Der Spiegel claimed this week that West German firms had helped Iraq develop ''military nuclear technology, construction of rockets and production of poison gases.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/busin.main_headline: Even as Profits Fall, Home Builder Plans to Gain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/busin.print_headline: Even as Profits Fall, Home Builder Plans to Gain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/busin.body_text: **********The Ryland Group, the nation's second-largest home builder, took analysts by surprise earlier this summer when it said it would earn less in the second quarter than it had expected. **********''Some people couldn't believe that what was happening to everybody else was happening to Ryland,'' said Melissa Cook, a New York-based analyst for Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. **********The Columbia, Md., builder of moderately priced houses has indeed started to smart from the real estate downturn that is already consolidating its rivals. With housing starts at their lowest level since the early 1980's, Ryland's net earnings declined 46 percent in the second quarter, to $5.7 million, from the corresponding period last year. **********Low-Risk, Conservative Strategy **********But Ryland is showing the same resilience in the low point of this cycle as it has shown in previous slumps. Its success arises from a low-risk, conservative approach that limits the 23-year-old company's profits in boom times, but cushions it from losses during the downturns. **********''They have a tremendous record of long-term performance and will come out ahead,'' said Kenneth Campbell of Audit Investments, a money management company in Montvale, N.J. ''You cannot kick them in the teeth now simply because they aren't going to perform this year.'' **********While hundreds of home builders have gone bankrupt since early 1989, Ryland, one of the few that are publicly traded, earned $170 million on revenues of $1.4 billion last year. Today, it is one of the least leveraged companies in the business, allowing it to borrow and expand at a time when competitors are retrenching. **********Aiming to Gain Market Share **********In fact, Charles E. (Ted) Peck, Ryland's chairman and chief executive, said the company aims to double shareholders' equity in each of the next five years - just as it has in every year for the last 17. It hopes to pick up market share as rivals weaken, luring home buyers with financing plans that few in the industry can afford to offer. **********At the heart of its strategy is the fact that Ryland, unlike many home builders, rarely ties up its money in raw land. It buys finished lots already equipped with roads, sewage, water and utility systems. This method enables the company to get its money out of properties more quickly and reduces its borrowing costs and the risks of having an inventory of undeveloped lots when demand for new houses is slack, as it is today. **********In the rare instance when it buys raw land - as it does in California because developed lots are scarce -Ryland minimizes its risk by buying the properties in joint ventures with financial institutions. **********Debt-to-Equity Ratio: 0.5 to 1 **********''By using financial partners, they get only half the profits, but they can keep capital in lines they prefer,'' said Barbara K. Allen, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company. As a result, Ryland's debt-to-equity ratio is only 0.5 to 1, Ms. Allen said. By contrast, the top 100 builders had an average ratio of 8.4 to 1 last year, according to Builder magazine. **********''Ryland may have missed out in some markets, but they are not suffering the catastrophic losses from borrowing that other builders are,'' Ms. Cook said. In fact, at a time when bank regulators are tightening commercial lending standards and developers of all stripes are finding it difficult to obtain financing, Ryland recently managed to complete a three-year revolving credit agreement with about a dozen banks for $265 million. **********''I think our conservative practices offer them some reassurance,'' Mr. Peck said. **********Cautious Top Executives **********Ryland's conservative approach is in keeping with the backgrounds of its top executives, analysts say. While most home builders are headed by risk-taking entrepreneurs, Mr. Peck, who is 64 years old, worked for the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation for 32 years before joining Ryland in 1981, where he considered himself ''an organizational man.'' He was most recently an executive vice president and director of Owens-Corning. **********Before becoming president of Ryland in May, Roger W. Schipke, who is 53, was a senior vice president of the General Electric Company's $5.6 billion-a-year appliance division. **********Mr. Schipke is scheduled to become chief executive in January and may become chairman later next year when Mr. Peck retires, analysts say. He is expected to carry on in the company's cautious tradition. **********''He seems very much like Mr. Peck and takes a very analytical, well-thought-out approach to strategy,'' Ms. Allen said. ''Mr. Schipke is expected to continue the positive leadership left under Mr. Peck.'' **********Orders Down 21% in First Half **********Yet, Ryland recently started to skid. The company booked 4,207 orders for homes (their average sale price last year was $116,000) during the first six months of this year, a 21 percent decline from the corresponding period in 1989. **********And times are getting tougher. Housing starts have slipped to their lowest level since the recession of nearly a decade ago. Based on July's figures, new houses and apartments are being built at a seasonably adjusted annual rate of 1.15 million, the lowest level since September 1982. **********And with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait earlier this month have come renewed fears of inflation and the prospect of higher interest rates, which would further hurt housing sales. **********More Bankruptcies Expected **********Analysts expect bankrupcties among home builders this year to top those in 1989, when 1,840 builders of single-family homes went under, according to statistics compiled by Dun & Bradstreet. That figure is scarcely 1 percent of the approximately 200,000 home builders nationwide, most of which build fewer than 10 houses a year. **********Indeed, Ryland's stock has been trading at its lowest level in two years. Trading as high as $25.50 a share in 1989, it closed yesterday at $11.50 on the New York Stock Exchange, down 25 cents. **********Yet Ryland says it is less vulnerable to the vagaries of regional economies than many of its rivals, most of which operate locally, because it builds houses in 17 states. **********Shift of Regional Profits **********While most builders began feeling the slowdown in demand in 1987, Ryland thrived until about a year ago because of its business in Washington, D.C., and California, where real estate values continued to increase until recently. Ryland is now likely to pin its hopes on regions experiencing slight rebounds like Phoenix, Houston and Denver. **********Ryland says its ability to provide financing also gives it an edge. It is one of only about two dozen home builders to provide financing to its buyers. Ryland's mortgage unit has accounted for about 17 percent of the company's earnings for the last five years. **********''The mortgage company is not a big-income item, but it definitely gives them an edge in times when credit is tight,'' said Michael Mead, vice president of research at Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc. in Baltimore.
