https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/27/world.main_headline: Oyama Journal;   One Plum After Another; Still the People Leave
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/27/world.print_headline: Oyama Journal;   One Plum After Another; Still the People Leave
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/27/world.body_text: **********Three decades ago, when the enemy in much of rural Japan was poverty combined with brutal working conditions, this riverside farming town became a symbol of self-improvement by encouraging the local farmers to break their dependence on rice and experiment with cash crops, principally plums and chestnuts. **********So successful was the project that today Oyama boasts that 600 of its 4,500 residents have been to Hawaii for vacations, a badge of affluence here. The town has its own television production station, and there is a computerized fan system to prevent frost damage to the bushy, well-kept rows of plum trees in the neighboring hills. **********One Big Problem **********It would have been yet another tale of the success of Japanese planning were it not for a deeply troubling piece of news to the local residents: despite Oyama's rising affluence, its population is shrinking, a dagger in the heart of its future. **********The population of the town, which spreads out from the crystal clear, gravelly Oyama River into the nearby wooded hills, fell from 6,500 in 1950 to 4,700 in 1975. That is when its plum- and chestnut-induced prosperity seemed to take hold, and the population leveled off. But the problem returned in 1986, as the population began to decline again, to about 4,500 now. And it is still falling. **********The most disconcerting aspect of this drop is that it has been concentrated among Oyama's youth. From 1955 to 1985, the number of people under 20 years old was halved to 1,300, while the number of people over 60 doubled, to slightly more than 1,000. **********''We just don't have the variety of things to do for young people here,'' Hideo Ogata, head of planning for the town government, said at the local farm cooperative recently on the last day of the plum harvest. **********As he observed plastic crates of the hard green plums, which are usually preserved in salt as a condiment, piling up on the loading dock, their sweet plummy scent filling the humid air, Mr. Ogata added, ''We've improved things a lot, but this is not a city.'' **********Now, Wealth Is the Enemy **********The enemy today, here in the center of Kyushu, the volcanic southern island, is not poverty but, in a sense, wealth. Freed from the need to scratch out a living in the countryside, many of Oyama's young people are fleeing for the more comfortable attractions of urban life. **********Reflecting this shift, Japan's cities are booming. The Tokyo metropolitan region's population has shot up from 21 million in 1965 to 24 million in 1970 and 31 million today, roughly a fourth of the nation's people. To Japan's leaders this is a source of concern that the cities have become much too big. **********It is a problem that goes to the heart of Japan's professed agrarian self-image and the realities of modern, industrialized Japan. The Government has regularly insisted when defending Japan's ban on imported rice that the farmers and their ancient traditions must be protected because they are the soul of the nation. **********But the young people of Oyama and other areas who prefer factory or white-collar jobs are making it clear that those symbols cannot compete with urban pleasures in a television age. **********''My generation was the U-turn generation,'' said Masakatsu Kurokawa, a 33-year-old hoisting his crates of plums onto a conveyer belt to be graded and then weighed. ''We left, and then came back when we saw how much people were making with the other crops. But you look at the young people here today: they're more individualistic and they say they need more variety. This place can't keep them.'' **********The Young Move Away **********Toyohiro Kawazu, who is 26, said he left for a while and worked in a supermarket in a nearby city, then returned to be with his family. ''I never thought of living away forever,'' he said, ''but a lot of my friends will.'' **********Mr. Ogata said: ''Before 1985, rarely did we have a problem with farmers getting one of their sons to take over the farms. Now it is common.'' **********It is a little to hard now to imagine the grinding poverty that older residents say existed here previously, when this was one of the poorest villages in one of the poorest prefectures in Japan. **********Harumi Yahata, the Mayor in the 1960's who began the self-improvement campaign, said many of the town's women had come down with a painful ailment because of their heavy work and poor diet. Children frequently suffered from malnutrition, he added. **********He told of the problems while sitting on the leather sofa of his comfortably air-conditioned home, surrounded by a large color television, a fax machine and, just outside the glass sliding doors leading to his backyard, an electric lawn mower. **********'We Need Something New' **********Mr. Yahata was emphatic in declaring that the town could overcome the problems once again, although many of the farmers at the cooperative did not agree. He acknowledged that it would be a constant battle, that Oyama could never expect the natural course of events to sustain it into the future. In effect, he was conceding that village life in a country that likes to think of itself as one big village was on a sort of life-support system: if it was stopped, the village would fail. **********''There are many things we could do,'' Mr. Yahata said. ''We have to shorten the work hours for the farmers, and we have to constantly find new products that require less work and have a higher value. We cannot stop, though. We need something new all the time, or Oyama will not survive. It will be a museum.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/busin.main_headline: B.P. to Auction Dutch Gas Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   B.P. to Auction Dutch Gas Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/busin.body_text: **********British Petroleum P.L.C. said it would auction off its gas exploration and production holding company in the Netherlands. **********B.P. refused to disclose the estimated value of BP Exploration B.V., a wholly owned subsidiary of British Petroleum Netherlands. **********The unit holds stakes in 23 offshore fields and two on shore. Analysts said the unit would fetch between $60 million and $70 million. **********The fields produce 14 million standard cubic feet of natural gas each day, said a British Petroleum spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. **********The yield is 1.2 percent of **********British Petroleum's world production and 2.1 percent of the company's European production, the spokesman said. **********The company added that the fields include two areas being developed that could add an additional three million standard cubic feet to the unit's daily production. **********Bids have been invited from a small number of companies, which B.P. declined to identify.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/20/world.main_headline: Managua Journal;   The Vice President's Shut Out but Won't Shut Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/20/world.print_headline: Managua Journal;   The Vice President's Shut Out but Won't Shut Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/20/world.body_text: **********As this country's second-highest elected official, Vice President Virgilio Godoy Reyes gets his share of fame, ceremonial appearances and portraits in his formal sash. What he doesn't get is a secretary, or a phone - or a desk, for that matter. **********More than six months after President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro defeated Sandinista leaders in national elections, she has made clear her determination to seek reconciliation with her former Sandinista opponents. But she has found no such truce with her Vice President. **********From the day after his inauguration, when he arrived at the presidential office building to find that he was not allowed past the front desk, Mr. Godoy has learned that his prickly conservative world view does not fit within the new President's vision of Nicaragua's political future. **********A political party boss and former Sandinista Labor Minister, Mr. Godoy was initially opposed by business people and the American Embassy here as too liberal to serve as Mrs. Chamorro's running mate. **********But as Mrs. Chamorro has moved to find common ground with Sandinista leaders, her Vice President's unyielding criticism of the former Government has made him the most visible spokesman for conservative Nicaraguans. **********All Official Doors Shut **********''With Godoy, people know what they're getting,'' a European diplomat said. ''If they are disappointed with the Government and angry with the Sandinistas, they turn to him as a man who will stick to the program. He says what they want to hear.'' The combative Vice President has lost few opportunities to express his disagreement with the way the new Government is handling its democratic mandate. Mrs. Chamorro has responded by shutting every official door Mr. Godoy might care to enter, whether to Cabinet meetings, political negotiating sessions, regional diplomatic talks or his own office. **********Mr. Godoy has no government budget, no government vehicle, no government aides, no government bodyguard - and, most poignantly of all, no government audience. **********''I go to each of the ministries to find out what is going on and to tell them what I think,'' Mr. Godoy said matter of factly. ''Otherwise no one would be talking to me at all.'' **********The political feud between the President and Vice President, who remain cordial, even friendly, in public, reflects the diversity of the political coalition that brought Mrs. Chamorro to power, and the marriage of convenience that gave Mr. Godoy the second spot on the ballot after he lost his battle with Mrs. Chamorro for the presidential nomination last fall. **********The conflict is an extension of campaign trail tensions that brought the chief advisers for both politicians to physical blows on a public stage at the height of the election process last January. It has since been played out in the National Assembly, where Mr. Godoy holds sway over at least a dozen and as many as two dozen seats in Mrs. Chamorro's 51-seat majority. **********A Target of the Sandinistas **********But relations have also been aggravated by the sharp tongue and independence of the Vice President himself, an experienced lawyer and former university professor. **********The political implications of the Vice President's maverick image have not been lost on the Sandinista leadership, which Mr. Godoy challenged on his own in national elections in 1984, winning 10 percent of the vote, even after formally withdrawing his name in the final moments of the campaign. **********Sandinista news organizations have generally avoided direct criticism of Mrs. Chamorro, who is a figure of broad national sympathy. Instead, they have focused blistering attacks on Mr. Godoy, who is portrayed as a dangerous, erratic reactionary. **********Such ostracism from the country's two major political forces pushed the Vice President into growing isolation soon after Inauguration Day last April. But it has brought him back into the limelight as tensions over Sandinista strikes and protests - and the Government's reaction to them -have grown. **********As Mrs. Chamorro negotiated to bring an end to violent Sandinista strikes in July, Mr. Godoy became an instant hero to armed pro-Government Nicaraguans, who took to the streets to tear down Sandinista barricades. **********The Voice Is Silenced **********Mrs. Chamorro brushed off Mr. Godoy's incendiary recommendation that she call her supporters into the streets to oppose the strike. **********But the Vice President's followers staked out their turf, anyway, taking over the politically turbulent neighborhood of Ciudad Jardin, where Mr. Godoy maintains the ramshackle offices of his political party. And with the Government stations off the air, the conservative Radio Corporation, from the same neighborhood, kept up a drumbeat of reports, interviewing Mr. Godoy about the situation and reporting on the spreading skirmishes outside its studios. **********That, it seems, was enough for Mrs. Chamorro and the Sandinistas alike. In the only such police action she has taken, Mrs. Chamorro ordered her riot squads to forcibly disarm the citizens of Ciudad Jardin. **********At the same time, a squad of four demolition experts, widely presumed to be from the Sandinista-controlled army, blew up Radio Corporation's transmitting tower, silencing Nicaragua's Vice President so that his Government could finish talking.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/02/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Chiat/Day Lays Off 30 In New York
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/02/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Chiat/Day Lays Off 30 In New York
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/02/busin.body_text: **********CHIAT/DAY/MOJO, the Venice, Calif., agency that seemed to have the golden touch in the last decade, announced yesterday that it had laid off 30 employees in its 150-person New York office, which has lost three major accounts this year. **********Chiat/Day employees, aware of the financial pressures on the agency, which built its reputation on its Nike and Apple Computer ads, said that the number of layoffs could go as high as 50 this month. **********Jane Newman, the president of the New York office, said the layoffs were necessary because one of the office's biggest clients, Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines, had decided to put its $35 million account into review. ''We aren't sure that we are going to re-pitch the account,'' she said. ''This is the prudent thing to do.'' **********If, as expected, the agency loses the Royal Caribbean account, it will be the fourth big loss this year for the New York office. It lost the $7 million Sara Lee bakery account; the $5 million to $10 million Bissel account and the $30 million Reebok account. American Express and the New York Life Insurance Company have also cut back substantially on their advertising spending with the Chiat/Day New York office, which currently has billings of about $130 million. **********The loss of the Royal Caribbean account would mean billings at the New York office would fall below the critical $100 million mark. It is generally believed in the industry that agencies with billings of less than $100 million would not be considered by national clients for their large accounts. **********The recent problems at the New York office have sparked rumors that there will be a management shake-up there, with several of the office's top executives leaving, including at least one senior creative executive. **********''We are very concerned about what is happening in New York, and we plan to fix it,'' said Bob Wolf, the chairman and chief executive of Chiat/Day's North American operations. But he would not comment on what, if any, changes would be made in light of the loss of accounts. **********Mr. Wolf said that the agency had no plans to cut back further in the New York office or to close it. ''We are still very committed to it,'' he said. ''New York is an important part of our future.'' **********Some advertising executives said a primary reason for the problems at the New York office was the frequent absences of Jay Chiat, the agency's founder, who moved his office to Manhattan when the New York branch was opened in 1981. He recently has been spending increasing amounts of time at the agency's other offices in the United States and abroad. **********Recently, Chiat/Day/Mojo, which has total billings of about $1 billion, has sold several of its smaller businesses. Last week, the agency announced it had reached an agreement to sell its public relations subsidiary, Jessica Dee Communications, for an undisclosed amount to the firm's management. In June, Chiat/Day sold most of its San Francisco operation to that agency's management. **********The agency's plans to establish itself as a big international advertising power seem to have stalled. Last year, Chiat/Day acquired Mojo MDA, an Australian agency, for about $68 million. The acquisition gave Chiat/ Day a valuable foothold in the Pacific Rim and also an office in London, which it could use as a jumping-off point to begin an assault on Europe. **********But its Australian operations have faltered lately. The agency is suffering primarily because of Australia's depressed economy. One of the agency's primary clients is the Australian tourism account, which has cut spending drastically. In addition, one of the agency's biggest clients, the Bond Corporation Holdings' brewing interests in Australia, filed for bankruptcy protection. **********The one bright spot, Mr. Wolf said, is the agency's flagship office in California. In the last 12 months, he said, that office has won about $30 million in new accounts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/world.main_headline: Italy Feeling It Doesn't Get Any Respect
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/world.print_headline: Italy Feeling It Doesn't Get Any Respect
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/world.body_text: **********The unkindest cut, the one that really sliced deep here, was a wisecrack about how the Italians were behaving like Marxists. In this case, Marx meant Groucho, Harpo and Chico. **********The observation came in a recent issue of The Economist. In an acerbic article that made Italian officials wince, the respected British weekly gave a firm thumbs down to the rotating presidency of the European Community that Italy has held since July and will yield soon after a gathering of Western European leaders here this weekend. **********The Italian presidency, the magazine said, quoting an unidentified diplomat, "is proving like a bus trip with the Marx Brothers in the driver's seat." **********That stung.   Detecting an Ethnic Slur **********Even Italians inclined to think the worst of their Government detected a vague ethnic slur, reflecting a perceived tendency among some Britons and others to treat Italy as a joke with good food, a place defined mainly by its temperamental phones and mails and not also by its humming economy. By many indicators, Italians are quick to point out, their economy is larger than Britain's. **********But beyond arguments over whether specific anti-Italian criticisms are fair -- and the feeling here is that they are not -- the sensitivity to such attacks underlines more fundamental concerns about where Italy fits in Europe's new order. **********Its economy is ample and its energetic Foreign Minister, Gianni De Michelis, seems to have no shortage of ideas for altering European structures. But in politics and diplomacy, Italy still falls short of the heavyweight division. Now, some commentators fret that the long shadow cast by the newly unified Germany may make the perennial Italian yearning for international respect harder to satisfy than ever. **********Along that line, Italy attached great importance to its opportunity to guide the European Community over the last half year, even if the job is a mechanical function, with each of the community's 12 members taking its turn.  Behaving for the Duration **********Indeed, many Italian officials and political analysts are convinced that the 17-month-old coalition of Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti would have fallen apart, like its 48 postwar predecessors, had it not been for a tacit agreement by politicians to behave themselves while the nation held the spotlight. Now that the center of the European Community universe is about to shift to Luxembourg, political experts say the Andreotti Government may be doomed. **********Still, it has been an important six months with Italy at the helm. **********Germany completed its reunification, the Soviet Union stumbled closer to collapse, the community took a big step toward creating a single currency and the cold war came to an official end with new agreements signed in Paris last month. **********And the Persian Gulf crisis erupted. Led by Mr. De Michelis, the Italians steered the community along a hard line on the anti-Iraq embargo and the release of the hostages in Baghdad's hands. "Europe held the line, and we must credit the Italian presidency for that," a European diplomat said. Number of Meetings Draws Scorn **********Nevertheless, others have heaped anonymous scorn on Rome, especially at community headquarters in Brussels. Much of the criticism amounts to a diplomatic version of inside baseball: sniffing about how the Italians called too many meetings with too little substance and preparation. **********Yes, a senior official here agreed, some of the criticism may be correct. But the image of an Italian bus careering wildly down the road with Harpo beeping his horn is not only an insult but, he said, is also wrong. Other Italians say their critics could do worse than to think more creatively about diplomacy instead of dwelling endlessly on organizational rituals. **********On that score, Mr. De Michelis has come to symbolize Italy's situation. **********Foreign publications rarely write about him without prominent references to his imperial girth, his long, unkempt hair and his passion for disco dancing. The 50-year-old Mr. De Michelis tends also to be voluble and quick to offer opinions on almost any subject. All this is presented by detractors as evidence that he and his country are not to be taken seriously. **********But Mr. De Michelis has also been accused of thoughtfulness, and some of his early ideas on expanding cooperation among Adriatic and Mediterranean states and on giving the European Community a greater military role are fast becoming conventional wisdom. Dangerous to Underestimate **********It sometimes seems easy to ignore Italy, but political experts warn that it is always dangerous to underestimate this country's talents for diplomacy and for seizing the political moment. **********Former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher learned that lesson after another summit meeting held here in October, when 11 of the 12 nations, led by the Italians, decided to move toward creating a central European bank by 1994 despite her objections. **********The others were living in "cloud cuckoo land," Mrs. Thatcher railed. But the domestic fallout from her intransigence set in motion her ouster in late November. **********Publicly, of course, Italian officials insist that they did not seek her downfall. But privately, and with satisfied smiles, they chide Mrs. Thatcher for having overlooked a few basic Marxist principles, especially Groucho's maxim about not belonging to a club that would have someone like him as a member.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/22/world.main_headline: Gorbachev Critics Step Up Their Attacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/22/world.print_headline: Gorbachev Critics Step Up Their Attacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/22/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's critics stepped up their complaints about his domestic performance today as he returned home from another summit meeting abroad. **********His chief rival and insurgent critic, Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian republic, suggested the possibility of a referendum to let the voters decide how powerful Mr. Gorbachev's authority should be. **********"Russia has a law on referendums, and we can hold one," Mr. Yeltsin said of the republic, the nation's largest and most economically powerful. **********Speaking to reporters, he re-emphasized his insistence on recognition of true sovereignty for Russia and other separatist republics and acknowledgment of the republics' control over their resources as a condition for realigning power in the Soviet Union.  Gorbachev Record Criticized **********At the same time, one of Mr. Gorbachev's most vociferous critics, Col. Viktor Alksnis, said he and fellow members of the national Congress's hard-line Soyuz caucus would propose the Soviet leader's resignation if he cannot do more to restore national order and defend the central Government's "command system" of power in the next month. **********"What have the last five years given us?" Colonel Alksnis asked, criticizing Mr. Gorbachev's record in an interview in the newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya. **********"You cannot blame everything on the 'command system,' " he was quoted as saying. "Whatever its obvious minuses, it enabled us to restore our ruined national economy in the five years after World War II."  Pressures Greeting Leader **********The rival critiques summarized the range of pressure awaiting the Soviet leader as he returned home to a Kremlin scrambling to avoid economic disaster and to patch together fresh emergency powers with the nation's republics. **********Last weekend, the national Parliament, after criticizing Mr. Gorbachev's failure to reverse the nation's political and economic crisis, gave initial approval to his emergency plan for extending greater responsibility to the republics for national government decisions, while also assuming more powers himself. This plan, which proposes limited power sharing through a Federation Council of republic representatives designed to seek consensus with the Kremlin, will be subject to further legislative debate. **********None of this boiling controversy was featured on tonight's main television news program, "Vremya," which carried an interview with a confident-sounding Mr. Gorbachev in Paris after the summit meeting. Unlike Western news reports, the Government-controlled program made no mention of the fact that Soviet officials in Paris were quietly lining up offers of emergency food supplies from Western nations.  Further Challenges Intended **********Among the other developments since his departure for the summit meeting is the decision by Azerbaijan to join other republics refusing to honor the central Government's order that prices on such luxury goods as jewelry and whisky should be decontrolled and float with demand. Officials of the Russian republic, the leader of this resistance, say is an economically pointless infringement on their sovereignty. **********Mr. Yeltsin has served notice almost daily that Russia considers the struggle over power-sharing as hardly settled and that he intends to challenge Mr. Gorbachev to yield further and explicitly recognize the statements by the nation's republis that they want more self-rule. **********Asked in the Paris interview about this confrontation, Mr. Gorbachev responded calmly that responsible people should be able to work together. **********"There is Boris Yeltsin, Valentin Petrov, Ivan Sidorov, Gorbachev and so forth," he said quietly, bracketing himself and his chief rival around two mundane, John Smith-like Soviet names, as if everyone's powers are equal in the current crisis. "We are all bound by responsibility for the country's fate." **********Mr. Yeltsin's point, in contrast, was that Mr. Gorbachev was seeking to keep far too much power while only talking of a revised Soviet Union in which he promises to decentralize more authority into the republics.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/19/world.main_headline: Behind U.S. Reversal: Gains by the Khmer Rouge
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/19/world.print_headline: Behind U.S. Reversal: Gains by the Khmer Rouge
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/19/world.body_text: **********Defense and intelligence officials say they are increasingly concerned that the Communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas are winning their war to oust the Vietnamese-backed Cambodian Government. The Bush Administration's announcement today that it is withdrawing recognition of the Cambodian rebel coalition and opening talks with Vietnam underlines that concern. **********State Department, Defense Department and Congressional analysts said that despite recent Khmer Rouge advances they do not believe the Cambodian Government will fall this year. **********They said that two non-Communist guerrilla groups loosely allied with the Khmer Rouge had failed to make similar advances. The two groups receive more than $15 million in yearly overt and covert American assistance. **********''A primary concern of our policy is to keep the Khmer Rouge from taking power,'' said a senior State Department official. ''Khmer Rouge military advances have caused concern.'' **********A Rainy Season Offensive **********''We want to do everything we can to prevent a return of the Khmer Rouge to power,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told reporters in Paris. **********Human-rights monitors have documented that more than a million Cambodians were killed under Khmer Rouge rule in the 1970's during a radical restructuring of society that included the forced mass migration of urban people into the countryside. **********Administration officials said that the Khmer Rouge rebels are following rural-based strategy similar to the one used in encircling Phnom Penh in 1975, when the Khmer Rouge came to power. **********American officials said that in their current rainy-season offensive, the rebels are taking advantage of the Government's decreased mobility. The rebels are spreading their forces across the countryside - from northwestern Siem Reap province and Bantheay Meanchey province to southern Kampot province - while they cut off major highways and communications lines to choke the cities. **********In the face of this offensive on northern, southern and central villages within 40 miles of the Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh, Government forces are retreating and in some cases dropping their weapons, the officials said. **********A Defense Department official said the Khmer Rouge strategy was directed at ''undermining the people's confidence in the Government and the Government's confidence in itself.'' The official continued: ''The Government forces are hard pressed and extended in contending with the Khmer Rouge offensive. Morale problems and corruption are clearly evident.'' **********The Vietnamese-backed Government of Prime Minister Hun Sen is struggling to manage a series of problems. The Government cannot pay all of its civil servants and soldiers, a situation made all the more severe by rising inflation and a decline in Vietnamese and Soviet economic aid. **********Regular Vietnamese Army forces, which once numbered up to 200,000, left the country last year. American officials report that a few thousand Vietnamese military advisers have returned to help beat back the offensive. **********Support for Khmer Rouge **********In briefings to other Government officials earlier this week, Central Intelligence Agency analysts estimated that the Khmer Rouge faction consists of 30,000 to 40,000 fighters, slightly larger than the size of the two non-Communist rebel groups combined. **********They fight a Government army of from 60,000 to 100,000 men. The C.I.A. estimated that the value of Chinese assistance to the Khmer Rouge approaches $100 million a year, while the non-Communist groups receive much less from several countries, including Singapore, which sends them $10 million a year in military hardware and other supplies. **********The C.I.A. estimates that the Khmer Rouge is backed in one form or another by 30 percent of the population, with larger proportions of support in areas they control, where they can exercise intimidation. **********C.I.A. analysts also said the non-Communist groups and Khmer Rouge share supply lines, raising questions of how the Bush Administration can continue to supply the non-Communists without inadvertently helping the Khmer Rouge. The deeper the American-supported groups operate inside Cambodia, the more dependent they are on the Khmer Rouge.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/07/busin.main_headline: The Hidden Pep in America's Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/07/busin.print_headline: The Hidden Pep in America's Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/07/busin.body_text: **********In their determination to sharply cut the budget deficit during the next five years, Congressional leaders and the President may be ignoring or overlooking important strengths in the American economy that over the long term could lessen the need for such drastic medicine. **********These strengths show up with surprising regularity in reviews of how businesses actually conduct their operations. **********Even so, business leaders and economists generally endorse the budget proposal now before Congress, at least in its initial stage, though many believe it may drive the nation toward recession. They do so if only to demonstrate that Government spending can be controlled. **********''Even someone as much in favor of deficit reduction as I am must agree that this package is initially contractionary,'' said Benjamin Friedman of Harvard University. **********But locking the nation into repeated cuts - taking $500 billion from the budget between now and 1995, as the President and Congressional leaders are proposing - could sap the country's productive strength and cut off potential for growth, making matters worse. **********Risking the hardship requires great faith in two interlocking economic theories that are widely espoused by economists but have not been fully tested since World War II, and they are often challenged by American corporations in daily practice. One theory is that during periods of economic difficulty the United States loses the capacity for robust economic growth; the other is that a budget deficit limits national growth. **********''The whole exercise in cutting the budget deficit and endangering the economy is based on the perception that the long expansion in the 1980's has pushed the economy close to its capacity to expand efficiently,'' said Robert M. Solow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a Nobel laureate in economics. ''If that is not true, then we are forcing ourselves into a hardship that might not be necessary.'' **********The theories go something like this: Just as a grocer who takes in $10,000 in sales but pays $5,000 in store rent has little left over to invest in a second store, so Americans, after loaning billions of dollars to the Government to pay all its bills, lack enough cash to invest in new sources of wealth. Neither the high rent nor the Government's outlays for weaponry, food stamps and many other programs are considered particularly wealth-producing. **********Lay the Blame on Spending **********In the news media, these theories show up in various forms. One is the criticism that Americans don't save enough, so there aren't enough funds available in the private sector to invest in new machinery and other wealth-producing devices - without help from the Japanese and the Europeans, who have become big American investors in the last decade. Sometimes consumers are blamed for the savings shortage; they're dismissed as profligate spenders. But mostly the Government is accused of dipping too heartily into the national savings pool for what amounts to wasteful consumption. Or borrowing too much from the Japanese and the Europeans, who in the future will drain billions of dollars in interest payments from the country. (In fact, Government debt held by foreigners ranged between 15 and 18 percent of the total in the 80's and is now 16.5 percent.) Another outcry is that the low civilian unemployment rate, 5.3 percent until recently and now only 5.7, is evidence that the nation lacks enough skilled workers to expand production and generate great new wealth. There simply aren't enough skilled people to open a new factory or expand an existing one without luring workers away from another operation, which then has to shut down. ''I don't know whether full employment is 5.1 percent or 5.5 percent, but compared with the early 80's, when it reached 9 percent, we are at full employment now,'' Mr. Friedman said. **********No economist doubts that the United States economy, or any economy, for that matter, has a growth ceiling. Many hold that the American ceiling today is roughly 6 percent a year, before adjustment for inflation. In other words, the United States can only add $300 billion in 1990 to a gross national product that generated $5.2 trillion last year in new manufactured goods and in payments for the numerous services that Americans performed. The $300 billion, in theory, is the nation's maximum growth capacity. **********The upshot is that the deficit - $149 billion in 1989 and more than $250 billion in 1990 - is growing at 67 percent, eating up potential investment funds in an economy that today is expanding not at its 6 percent maximum, but at only 4 percent. If allowed to grow unchecked, such deficits will choke off economic growth altogether. That's the theory, but ask business executives about these deadly growth ceilings and a much more amorphous picture emerges, one suggesting that deficit reduction might be an oversold solution and the deficits themselves an exaggerated danger. **********Even with very little Government belt-tightening, the economy might be made to grow faster than the deficit, the businessmen seem to suggest. Or as Richard Ayers, chairman and chief executive of the Stanley Works, the tool manufacturer, put it: ''If people ask me, 'Is Stanley operating at full capacity,' I say to them, 'that is a crazy question.' I don't know what full capacity means.'' **********Dynamics of Growth **********Four corporate experiences help to illustrate the dynamics of economic growth: *********** The Stanley Works, whose network of factories includes a Dallas operation that manufactures sockets and wrenches, found that bottlenecks had developed last year in heat-treating and plating, two of the 20 or so steps that go into making these tools. A relatively small investment in new equipment for these steps increased overall production capacity by more than 20 percent, Mr. Ayers said. **********Theoretically, high interest rates - corporations often pay 9 percent or more to borrow for investment - should have discouraged Stanley from making the investment. The high rates reflect the shrunken savings pool in the private sector, and they do discourage many companies already deeply in debt. But in thousands of investment decisions, they aren't an obstacle. In Stanley's case, ''given the big increase in output, the cost of the capital was a minor factor,'' Mr. Ayers said. A limited supply of labor is also often a minor factor. Stanley makes steel tape rules in Norwalk, Conn., its headquarters, and in Besancon, France; the former for the American market and the latter for Europe. But when demand surges in the United States then, rather than increase the work force in Connecticut and perhaps bid up wages in a tight labor market, Stanley imports extra tapes from Besancon. And the line vanishes between America's labor supply and the world's. **********''One virtue of capitalism is that it is very adaptable,'' said Richard Freeman, a labor economist at Harvard. ''A tight labor market leads to all sorts of inventive solutions.'' *********** Gillette, operating a factory in South Boston that makes razors and blades, has found that applicants for the 2,000 factory floor jobs are, increasingly, immigrants whose English is weak. Many know enough English to hire on as packers, at more than $8 an hour, but not enough to move up to machine operators, said Timothy Horan, director of human resources for Gillette's manufacturing group. So the company is beginning to offer courses in English, in effect upgrading each immigrant worker's productivity. **********The machine operators are also drawn from impoverished South Boston neighborhoods, and many are school dropouts. To do their jobs, Gillette requires that they carry out various math calculations to monitor the efficiency of their machinery. Many can't do the math, so the company runs math courses. Gillette still scours the Boston area for skilled machinery repair people, who can earn $14 an hour, but here too standards are changing. **********''Our engineers might be asked to find ways to simplify repair work, or we might soon set up a training classification,'' Mr. Horan said, challenging the economic thesis that Gillette has hit its labor-supply ceiling. As Rudolph G. Penner, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, explains the theory, ''The more you press, the more the cost in training people or in paying higher wages to get trained people.'' As labor costs rise, so does the national inflation rate, diluting the value of the new production. That's how ceilings work. **********Mr. Horan doesn't quite agree. ''The training classification would be costly,'' he said, ''but in the end you might get good value because you wouldn't pay these people as much as a skilled mechanic. In the end, it wouldn't be inflationary because you get a payoff.'' *********** The National Mutual Life Insurance Company, faced with growing competition for life insurance sales, invested $1 million in new computer equipment and software to automate many tasks. In addition, work was reorganized. Service departments, for example, that might once have responded to any customer's telephoned request, no matter how time-consuming, were given guidelines that required them to ''ration'' their replies, said Frederic H. Bertrand, chairman and chief executive. **********As a result, without any loss in revenue, employment at National's Montpelier, Vt., headquarters has fallen to 1,009 today from 1,450 in 1987, and two of the five management layers have been eliminated. ''Computerization gets data faster to decision makers,'' Mr. Bertrand said. **********Why wasn't National so productivity-minded five years ago? Competition was less. Fluctuating interest rates gave the numerous life insurance companies offering policies the opportunity to compete on the yields their policies earned for their customers. ''People shop for life insurance as if it were certificates of deposit,'' Mr. Bertrand said. Such shopping has shrunk profit margins at National and other companies, prompting much effort and outlay for productivity. **********National did not borrow the money for its recent investment. It simply drew on retained earnings. Such corporate income, held at the bank, is part of the nation's savings pool. National in effect financed its investment in labor productivity, increasing the capacity of its work force, by ''borrowing'' from this pool. But the investment wasn't made because the savings existed. Investment does not automatically and instantaneously equal savings, as economic theory often suggests. The driving force in National's case was competition and lower profit margins. The money might also have been distributed as dividends and spent on consumption. **********''Capacity is a nebulous notion,'' said Edward F. Denison, a senior fellow and a specialist in productivity at the Brookings Institution. ''Until you test the system, you don't know what the capacity is. When a company has to do something to survive, to compete, it thinks of ways to get what it needs.'' *********** Penney's, faced with weak department store sales as the economy has grown sluggish over the past year, has invested in a computerized cash register system for its network of stores. Its main feature is a simplified way to ring up a sale, whether the purchaser pays cash or offers a credit card, buys one shirt, or an assortment of shirts and ties. **********''There isn't the necessity of a separate credit-card imprint; you just sign the receipt,'' said Ira Silver, Penney's chief economist. ''The machines cut the cashier process from two or three minutes to 30 seconds, and we keep better sales records.'' **********Increased Productivity **********The equipment takes time to install, but as it goes in, Penney's work force shrinks and becomes more productive. The sluggish economy, even a recession, prompts some companies to make their workers more productive - in effect, to expand the capacity of the American labor force. **********''When an economy goes through a shock, a boom or a recession, many opportunities are created for a business to reorganize in a different way,'' said Albert Wojnilower, a senior economist at the First Boston Corporation.'' **********Many factors, then, dictate how quickly and by how much the American economy will grow. Recession plays a role. So does competition. And government policy, including cuts in the budget deficit. As Mr. Solow of M.I.T. notes, the $35 billion or so in first-year budget cuts under the five-year package now before Congress, shifted to the private sector, would add substantially to the nation's array of plants and equipment, if the money were fully invested. **********Such a sum could add 7 percent to the $510 billion in gross investment in plants and equipment that is expected this year. The proportion climbs to 17 percent, if the $35 billion is compared with the $200 billion in new investment only, leaving aside replacements of plants and equipment. **********The problem is that the investments might not be made; the banks might have the money, and interest rates might fall to lure borrowers, but with national demand way off, many companies will shy away from new investment. Why should the Stanley Works invest in heat treating and plating equipment to remove a potential bottleneck in the production of wrenches and sockets at its Dallas plant, when demand for these tools might be insufficient and production at the factory moves along too slowly for bottlenecks to occur. **********Many economists recognize the irony of cutting the budget deficit in the midst of a weak economy. ''If I were God, I would not have picked this moment to cut the budget deficit,'' Mr. Solow said. ''If I were George Bush, who is not God, I would have tried to pick a couple of years ago, when the economy was stronger. But it is better to cut the budget now than not at all.'' **********The Uses of Spending **********But in the years to come it is also conceivable that increased Government spending and involvement in the economy could be helpful, not harmful. Subsidizing corporate research, for example, might help Gillette develop automated razor-making machinery that can be repaired in some simple fashion. Incentives, perhaps tax breaks or trade rules, might convince Stanley to invest in enough new equipment in Norwalk to increase tape rule production there when demand in the American market surges. The new capacity, replacing imports from Stanley's French plant, in effect increases the rate at which the economy can grow. **********The main engine for economic growth, then, seems to be the steady demand that comes when both consumers and the Government are in a mood to spend. And objections to Government spending, even deficit spending, subside when the economy manages to grow at a faster pace than either the deficit or the total national debt. **********That was the case in the late 80's, when the deficit fell to 3 percent of the gross national product from 6 percent in 1983, and it was also the case in the 50's and 60's. Robust economic growth made the nation's debt a minor concern, although in the 50's and 60's, the debt was 45 percent or more of the gross national product Today it is 44.5 percent. Budget deficits, of course, surge during recessions. Tax revenues fall as income declines, but Government outlays remain strong. The deficit rose beyond the $200-billion-a-year level after the 1981-82 recession, and the cry went up for reform. Now as the economy weakens again and the annual deficit moves toward $300 billion, deficit cutting once more becomes an American obsession. **********The nation was similarly driven to seek a balanced budget in 1932. As the Depression began to unfold, the budget went from surplus into deficit. **********The switch came just before the Presidential nominating conventions, alarming both Democrats and Republicans. With Franklin Delano Roosevelt in agreement, the Hoover Administration and Congress, in a display of bipartisan accord, doubled income tax rates and cut spending sharply - all in the name of fiscal integrity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/busin.main_headline: Careers;   Personnel Executives On the Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/busin.print_headline: Careers;   Personnel Executives On the Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/busin.body_text: **********THE job of vice president or top manager in charge of human resources, or personnel departments, has become much more important in the last few years. Two recent surveys by leading management recruiters confirm the trend. **********Last week Carl W. Menk, chairman of Canny Bowen Inc., said in an interview: ''The vast majority of executives we surveyed expect the human resource function to increase in importance over the next three to five years. No one expects it to decrease.'' **********The survey, titled ''Effectiveness of the Human Resources Function,'' is based on responses from 82 chief executives and 84 human resources executives, mostly at Fortune 500 companies. **********A Heidrick & Struggles Inc. survey called ''Chief Human Resources Executive,'' which was based on 260 responses from the specialists, carries Mr. Menk's argument a step further. **********Emanuel N. Monogenis, a partner in the firm, said in an interview: ''The most important issue American companies will deal with during the next decade is not foreign competition nor mergers, but building and keeping a qualified work force.'' That means close attention to both recruitment, training and management development, he said. **********''Skills training at all levels has become much more important,'' Mr. Menk noted. **********Mr. Monogenis said there must also be emphasis on top managers learning how to handle an increasingly diverse work force, including women, blacks, Hispanic people and others, especially in the lower and middle managerial ranks. ''A happy byproduct will be more social tolerance and emphasis on ability,'' he said. **********Reasons for the changing role of human resources executives appear to be allied to business trends, both management recruiters agreed. **********For example, the rash of mergers and corporation cutbacks has made life more complex for human resources managers. They must help select persons to be discharged or retired; they must decide amounts of dismissal pay; they must assist departments to reorganize so that fewer people can handle the same amount or more work. **********At hundreds of companies, widespread dismissals with severance pay, early retirements and ''golden parachutes'' have been expensive, focusing more attention on the short-term bottom-line results The Heidrick & Struggles survey found that the cost to a company of dismissing an employee averaged $18,000. On average, the total turnover rate from all resignations and dismissals is an alarming 17.4 percent a year. **********Mr. Monogenis called this ''a huge indirect cost not presented glaringly enough to managements.'' Certainly it is not well known to stockholders, the real owners of companies. **********The Heidrick & Struggles survey also found that 40.8 percent of the respondents believe that employee stock ownership plans can help deter takeovers. So far, employees own almost 14 percent of the shares of the responding companies. **********Mr. Menk argues that more and more human resources directors will be line officers. By line officers he means those ''who have profit and loss responsibility,'' not just those who function as staff professionals. **********The Canny Bowen study found that only about 17 percent of companies responding so far have placed line officers as head of the human resources - officers whose orientation is to the bottom line. The study cited Citibank as one example of a company that has done so, along with CBS and Colgate-Palmolive. **********Mr. Menk said, ''Functions that most directly impact growth and profitability are given high priority, and they reflect the new role of human resource executives as part of top management.'' They have been clamoring to reach that level for years, he said, suggesting that ''chief executive officers should consider involving them in strategic planning and acquisitions.'' **********''Management succession and controlling benefits costs require more of a line mentality,'' Mr. Monogenis said. For example, controlling employee benefit program costs like health and pensions has ''become a critical issue.'' **********The Heidrick & Struggles study profiled the typical top human resources executive as a 48-year-old white Protestant male, married to his first wife. In most cases (54 percent), he has an advanced degree beyond the bachelor's level, probably a master of business administration. In his career, he has worked for three companies. **********For his efforts, he receives an average $189,000 yearly in salary and bonuses, a 35 percent increase above salary averages reported by Heidrick & Struggles in a similar 1984 survey. **********Approaching compensation from a different angle, Mr. Menk's survey found that the median compensation of top human resources directors amounted to about 30 percent of the pay received by the chief executive. **********Mr. Monogenis stressed that there is, and perhaps always will be, a shortage of what he called excellent human resources directors. ''There are many good ones, but not many outstanding ones,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/04/world.body_text: **********President Fidel Castro has opened his country up to the foreign press this week for a glimpse at what Cuban officials describe as a nascent war of the airwaves. **********By the busloads, reporters are shown the Government's array of 160-foot antennae, small microwave dishes and even the MI-17 helicopters equipped with portable transmitters used to jam the signal of the United States-financed TV Marti, which is described here as hostile to Cuba and illegal. **********In interviews, Cuban technicians and military officers who operate the equipment all convey the officially correct note of indignation at the United States for what they universally describe as a violation of their country's sovereignty. **********''No other country receives foreign transmissions without first giving their permission,'' said one technician, Jose Luis Fialo, from his hilltop outpost in Lawton District. ''This is not normal.'' **********A War 'Has Already Begun' **********Stationed at a tall antenna in the hillside neighborhood, where pleasant villas complete with small, neat yards and wrought-iron fences overlook the sprawling capital, Mr. Fialo said he had volunteered for the honor of halting the American intrusion. **********At a military base on the city's outskirts, Lieut. Col. Tais Martinez, an air force officer in charge of Cuba's anti-TV Marti helicopter deployment grew animated when asked why it was necessary to block the foreign broadcast. **********''This is a war that has already begun,'' he said. ''When it ends depends upon the Americans. Only when we are left tranquil in our lives and activities can we stop these measures.'' **********Carlos Presno, another television technician in charge of jamming equipment in the crusty Vedado neighborhood, where people peered from ornately-sculpted balconies into the narrow streets below, declared the airwave war all but won. **********Scant Attention to Politics **********''The power of the U.S. broadcasts does not matter,'' he said. ''It is only a question of action and reaction. If they increase their signal, we have the means to neutralize it.'' **********To many Cubans, however, the official fervor against the broadcasts seems like much ado about nothing. **********Since the broadcasts began last week, each day's late-night programming has been followed within minutes by Cuban jamming, which American officials say has all but completely blocked TV Marti in the Havana area. **********One man said that while he had listened occasionally to music and news on Radio Marti, he thought its sister television station, with its situation comedies and soap operas drawn from Spanish-language networks in the United States, was better suited for a Miami audience. **********''I don't think people here are interested,'' he said. **********Others simply said they had not seen the program and could not provide any judgment. **********Asked what they thought of TV Marti, two 18-year-old university students in the crowd looked puzzled, consulted each other and answered, ''Who cares?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/world.body_text: **********China today announced the replacement of the entire leadership of the People's Armed Police, the 600,000-member national security force that is supposed to be the principal mechanism for maintaining order. **********The police were generally regarded as virtually useless against student protesters last year - which is why army troops were used in the crackdown - and the new appointments may be an attempt to toughen the force and assure strong security. **********In addition, a Western diplomat suggested that the Chinese leadership had reflected on the split in Romania between the Securitate police force and the army, and wanted to insure that the People's Armed Police could be trusted absolutely. **********People's Daily, which reported the change in a short article on the front page, did not give any reason for the shuffle. The article did not indicate if the former police leaders were given new responsibilities. **********Jockeying for Power Seen **********A Chinese official with access to top-level information said the shuffle was related to jockeying for power at the highest levels of the Chinese leadership. The official said China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, had ordered the shuffle to insure the police force's loyalty to him instead of to its past patron, Peng Zhen, the former security chief. **********The assertion could not be confirmed, but the official's credibility was bolstered because he said last month that a shuffle was under way. **********This official and others said the police leaders had been loyal to Mr. Peng, who is 88 years old and retired but retains considerable influence over security matters. While he is a longtime friend of Mr. Deng, Mr. Peng supports the harder line and more orthodox policies advocated by Mr. Deng's primary rival, Chen Yun, China's 84-year-old apostle of central planning. **********But a Western diplomat suggested that the principal reason for the change was that the police had been unprofessional and unreliable. **********The new police commander is Zhou Yushu, who until now has served as head of the 24th Army in the Beijing Military Region. The 24th Army was given a major role in the June crackdown, including responsibility for the university district, and it was generally regarded as having performed well, the diplomat said. The 24th Army was far less violent than other units, yet controlled the area it was assigned. **********It may be significant that Mr. Zhou is from the Beijing Military Region because the area was run for many years by Qin Jiwei, the Defense Minister and a protege of Mr. Deng. Thus Mr. Zhou may be loyal to Mr. Deng's faction. **********The new political commissar is Xu Shouzeng, but nothing is known of his background. The two new deputy commanders are Wang Wenli, until now the police chief of staff, and Lu Shouyan, the political commissar at a military hospital in Shanghai. **********A diplomat noted that there has been a general effort to strengthen the armed police recently, so the force can maintain order without calling upon army assistance. **********Chinese with connections in the military say that since the lifting of martial law in the capital last month, one of every three military regiments still in the capital has been turned into a police regiment. Soldiers in the other regiments nominally remain in the army but have been given police uniforms to wear when they go in public.
