https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/26/busin.main_headline: Brady Expects Some New Limits To Be Put on Deposit Insurance
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/26/busin.print_headline: Brady Expects Some New Limits To Be Put on Deposit Insurance
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/26/busin.body_text: **********Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the Bush Administration was leaning in the direction of limiting individuals and businesses to a maximum of $100,000 in deposit insurance, whether in one or several accounts. **********He said, however, that the Government was not likely to reduce the current $100,000 level of insurance that is in place for deposits at Federally insured banks, savings and loan associations and credit unions. **********His testimony before the Senate Banking Committee was the clearest signal yet about where the Bush Administration is heading on changes in the nation's bank deposit insurance system. Many experts see such changes, which would be subject to approval by Congress, as crucial to avoiding further debacles like the savings and loan crisis. The bailout of that industry over the next 30 years is likely to cost taxpayers upward of $500 billion. **********Present Coverage Is Wide **********Currently depositors are insured for $100,000 in deposits in each institution where they have accounts, as well as for money in joint accounts up to $100,000, creating almost unlimited coverage. **********When asked whether insurance should be restricted to only one account, Mr. Brady said, ''If you are going to start any place, that would be a place to start.'' **********But he stressed that he did not believe the $100,000 level should be reduced. **********''I can't see at this particular point in time a rush to lower that amount of insurance at a time that we have a question of confidence not only in our banks, but in our thrifts,'' Mr. Brady said. **********He added that the Administration would not make a formal recommendation until later this year when it finishes a study of the deposit insurance system, mandated by the savings and loan bailout bill of 1989. **********Mr. Brady's comments were significant in light of recent speculation in the banking industry that the Government might try to reduce the $100,000 insurance limit to as low as $50,000. **********Changes are being considered in the deposit insurance system in an effort to both restrict the financial exposure of the Government and impose discipline from the market place on bankers who otherwise have few incentives to pursue prudent lending practices. For the nation's weaker institutions, many of which have invested in risky assets, any changes would be expected to add to the pressure on them to either seek a merger partner or focus on more secure investments. **********One probable outcome of limiting deposit insurance, either through the dollar amount or the number of accounts, would be that some depositors would shift some money to Treasury securities and other safe investments. Depositors are also likely to move money from weaker institutions to stronger ones that have less chance of failure. **********Although any changes could cause uncertainty in the short run, experts strongly agree that, done properly, they will strengthen the nation's financial system. **********A primary concern of the Bush Administration, which has been stung by the fact that it is presiding over the nation's costliest financial crisis, is that regulatory precedent has now effectively extended the Government's blanket guarantee to all deposits at the nation's 13,000 banks, 2,500 savings and loan associations and 15,000 credit unions. **********Regulators acknowledge that under current practice all deposits, whether under the $100,000 limit or above, are effectively backed by the Government, and they are casting about for ways to lower that exposure. **********A Limited Effect Expected **********Experts said today that a plan like the one Mr. Brady described to limit the number of insured accounts would have a modest effect on the amount of money insured. Of the $4 trillion in total deposits at insured institutions, about $3 trillion was explicity insured as of the end of last year. Analysts say that limiting the number of accounts could reduce the Government's obligations to between $2 trillion and $2.4 trillion. **********But before such a plan could be effective, the Government would have to eliminate what has effectively become blanket insurance coverage for depositors. **********That practice evolved from the Government's rescue of Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company in 1984. Fearful that allowing depositor losses at the failing Continental would create a crisis of confidence and a run on other shaky institutions, Federal banking regulators effectively extended blanket insurance coverage to all the bank's deposits, promising to take whatever actions necessary to insure that depositors would not lose money. **********Out of a sense of fairness, the regulators later exended that policy to smaller institutions. And that practice has been further entrenched by the nervousness surrounding the savings and loan crisis, which Mr. Brady alluded to today. **********Government officials acknowledge that such a policy represents a radical departure from the original intent of deposit insurance - to provide a Federal safety net for the savings of the unsophisticated depositor. **********Computer technology has also played a role in changing the nature of deposit insurance. Under the current system, financial institutions other than banks, like brokerage firms, are able to offer wealthy investors essentially 100 percent protection for millions of dollars by creating accounts for up to $100,000 at scores of banks. **********This practice helped stimulate explosive growth among savings and loan associations in the mid-1980's, permitting high-risk operators to attract billions of dollars in so-called hot money from money brokers and to make lavish loans to real estate speculators and other investors. **********Regulators now say that if deposit insurance had been limited in the mid-1980's to $100,000 per individual, or, as some recommend, per Social Security account, the savings industry would never have experienced that kind of growth. **********How a system would be structured to limit deposit insurance to $100,000 per individual is still unclear. **********Various Arrangements **********The issues will revolve around whether the $100,000 is limited to one account at one bank or whether an individual could specify several accounts totaling $100,000. It is also unclear whether future insurance coverage would be denied to an individual who has already received an insurance payout on a $100,000 deposit at a failed institution. **********Experts say, however, that any of these arrangements could be easily circumvented, at least to some extent. A husband, for example, could put money in accounts in his wife's or children's names. **********The Treasury will also have to address the issue of how to handle depositors at giant banks if such an institution should fail. A proposal from the American Bankers Association calls for the Government to stipulate in advance that any depositor at a giant bank can be expected to take a limited loss - of about 12 percent - on uninsured deposits. Treasury officials have said they are looking at ways to encourage the banking industry to offer private insurance for banks. **********Members of Congress at the hearing today also raised concerns about how banks would go about offering accounts that did not carry deposit insurance. Some said banks might have to pay higher interest rates on these accounts than on Government-backed savings. **********Just a Starting Point **********The ideas discussed today by Mr. Brady are probably only a starting point for the Administration in its overhaul of deposit insurance. But they also represent an approach that is gaining in popularity among members of Congress since it would primarily be aimed at reducing benefits to the very wealthy and would not represent a radical shift in the insurance system at a time when confidence is fragile. **********Many members of Congress have said that they would not support a plan to lower insurance levels to $50,000, for fear of constituent backlash. **********But the proposal to limit insurance to one $100,000 account per individual also has its drawbacks. It would affect two voting groups the lawmakers do not like to cross - retirees and small businesses. These two types of depositors often have multiple accounts to protect either a life's savings or accumulated cash and they might find themselves suddenly more exposed to loss under a new system.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/05/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing;   As Publishing Turmoil Rises, Business Expertise Is Sought
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/05/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing;   As Publishing Turmoil Rises, Business Expertise Is Sought
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/05/busin.body_text: **********The American publishing industry is in turmoil. Some leading publishers have been forced out; employees have been laid off, and companies are feeling more pressure to focus on profits. **********So a question is increasingly being asked: do the people who run publishing houses have sufficient expertise in business, as well as books, to manage companies that deal with ever-larger sums of money? **********Simply posing the question creates discomfort. Some people in publishing see the question as an insidious attack by accountants on the diversity of America's literary culture. Others argue that it heralds a salutary, if tough, adjustment for a profession that for too long has muddled through without coming to terms with computers, marketing and balance sheets. **********But there is agreement on why people in publishing are now under tough scrutiny: too much money has been lost on too many books. The fierce competition for the books of leading authors and celebrities has swollen advances to a point where, often, they are not recouped. This trend, coupled with the spread of book chains, has led to bigger printings, bigger returns of unsold books and big losses. **********At the same time, the media giants that have bought publishing houses ''are simply more demanding,'' said Leonard Riggio, president of B. Dalton Bookseller. **********These simmering tensions boiled to the surface last week when Andre Schiffrin, the managing director of the Pantheon Books division of Random House, was forced out, apparently because he refused to cut his annual book list despite heavy losses. **********Although many people in the industry said the forced resignation was reasonable, five senior editors at Pantheon, an imprint that has resisted the commercial for the iconoclastic, resigned in sympathy. They called Mr. Schiffrin's departure a symbol of ''a world in which books belong to accountants.'' **********Pantheon, with annual sales of less than $20 million, represents no more than about 3 percent of Random House's sales. But rightly or wrongly, it has become the flash point of a broader debate over whether publishers must think more about making money and be better trained to do so. **********Many believe that debate has been building since Robert L. Bernstein, long the president of Random House, was forced out five months ago by S. I. Newhouse Jr., the chairman of Advance Publications, which owns the publishing house. **********Mr. Bernstein stood for a long-successful, but also gentlemanly and culturally committed, style of publishing. His departure was widely interpreted as a signal that publishing management had to get tougher. **********Bookish and Businesslike **********Publishing executives with solid backgrounds in business as well as books are suddenly in demand to counterbalance what Arlynn Greenbaum, marketing director of Little, Brown & Company, called ''the widespread seat-of-the-pants approach to publishing.'' **********Such bookish yet businesslike executives seem in short supply. Publishing executives said the West German media conglomerate Bertelsmann A.G. had found few suitable candidates for the vacant chief executive position at its Bantam Doubleday Dell group, while Simon & Schuster has also left a top position unoccupied for several months. **********''There is a dearth of people with a feel for books and a solid financial sense,'' said William Shinker, publisher of the trade division of Harper & Row Inc. ''People used to feel publishing was about a kind of mysterious alchemy, and we'd like to move away from that.'' **********A leading literary agent, Morton Janklow, said low salaries were responsible for much of the industry's lack of talent at both the top and middle levels of management. ''For too long, the typical person who went into publishing had been to a good university, done an arts major, could not write and did not want to teach,'' he said. ''Publishing is a badly managed cottage industry that now needs more Harvard M.B.A.'s.'' **********Harold Hoffman, president and chief executive of Waldenbooks, the largest American book chain, contends that many publishers are business dinosaurs. ''Have publishers found out what Americans want to read?'' he asked. ''Several executives have no idea what is happening at the commercial end'' in the $6 billion retail book business, he said. **********Multimillion-dollar book purchases - like those of ''My Turn,'' Nancy Reagan's memoirs, published by Random House, and James Clavell's ''Whirlwind,'' published by William Morrow & Company - have reinforced the sense that publishers are spending freely on books unlikely to earn back the money paid for them. **********One sign of the industry's lack of business sophistication, many say, is that that most publishing houses are not fully computerized. Some executives suggested that computerization could cut perhaps as much as 30 percent from manufacturing costs. ''What other word-oriented industry is not fully computerized at this point?'' asked Marcy Posner, a former associate publisher at Pantheon. **********Parker Ladd, a director at the Association of American Publishers, also asserts that much could be done to sell more books profitably. Last year, he said, his association, Waldenbooks, the B. Dalton chain and two other partners put up $125,000 to study an advertising campaign to get more Americans to read books. Just 13 percent of Americans buy general-interest books in stores, according to the association. **********''But when it came to putting up the $14 million for a full year's advertising,'' Mr. Ladd said, ''everybody just faded and the project folded.'' **********A research project that tries to bring more rigor into publishing is about to be started at Little, Brown, which is owned by Time Warner Inc. Groups of fiction readers will gather next month to discuss why they buy books by some leading fiction authors like Danielle Steele rather than by selected Little, Brown authors. **********But many are skeptical - or alarmed - by such ideas. They believe publishing is essentially about the unpredictable. **********''Product management in publishing is very iffy,'' said Jonathan Galassi, editor in chief at Farrar, Straus & Giroux, ''You can't eliminate the gamble and be a good publisher.'' **********Some people in the industry contend that big corporations like Bertelsmann and Advance Publications are putting unreasonable pressures on publishers to produce profits because they have overpaid for recent acquisitions or, in the case of Time Warner, face large debts. The result of this process, they say, will be the progressive commercialization of American publishing and a narrowing of the country's culture. **********Prime Interest Is Profit **********Moreover, they say, the conglomerates fail to appreciate that publishers slowly build up worth by accumulating back lists of fine books and cannot be fast-moving cash cows. **********''Because the prime interest of these conglomerates is profit, institutions like Pantheon and things like first novels are more and more marginal,'' argued Noam Chomsky, the author. And, Mr. Bernstein said, ''the history of publishing shows that those interested in books do it better than those interested in money.'' **********But Kelso Sutton, president of the Time Inc. Book Company, said his company was fully aware that ''you can't research your way to good creative solutions.'' **********A widespread hope is that a compromise can be reached under which good literature will be published, creativity thrive and publishing houses become more profitable. **********''The corporation has a responsibility to allow editors to publish good literature,'' said Phyllis Grann, the president of Putnam. ''In return, editors must impose more fiscal responsibility on themselves.'' Paramount Communicationsd (Simon & Schuster) News Corporationd (Harper & Row) BDBd (B. Dalton) K Martd (Waldenbooks) Hearstd (William Morrow)

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/15/world.main_headline: Uncovering of Spies Jolts East Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/15/world.print_headline: Uncovering of Spies Jolts East Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/15/world.body_text: **********New charges and countercharges about East German officials' links with the former secret police have jolted East Germany's Government and caused deep turmoil in advance of German reunification. **********The debate over the former spying agency, known as the Stasi, reached a high point today when Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere announced that he was stripping Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel of the job of dismantling the organization. **********The move, announced by a Government spokeswoman in East Berlin, came after a tumultuous week in which Mr. Diestel, a 38-year-old lawyer, was forced to admit that a senior aide in the dismantling process was a Stasi agent. **********Mr. de Maiziere also said that 3 government ministers and 68 deputies in the first democratically elected East German Parliament were former agents. Although he did not say who made the accusations, a parliamentary committee is investigating links to the Stasi and most similar assertions have come from its members. **********A Legislator Resigns **********Wolfgang Thierse, chairman of the East German Social Democrats, said one legislator, a Social Democrat, had already resigned his seat in the face of accusations and that others were being investigated. **********On Thursday, after hours of bitter debate, Parliament voted down a measure to drive Mr. Diestel from office. The vote was 184 to 107, with 18 absentions. But today Mr. de Maiziere, whose Government will dissolve after the two Germanys reunify next month, said that he was appointing Eberhard Stief, until now Mr. Diestel's deputy in the Stasi dismantling, to oversee the process. **********The search for agents has become a permanent headache for Mr. de Maiziere. For if a kind of benign tolerance for former Communists prevails in much of East Germany, anger is sharply focused at former members of the Stasi, the security machine that compiled extensive files on more than five million East Germans, about a third of the population. At its height, the Stasi is believed to have employed 85,500 people, with more than half a million paid informers. **********Mr. Diestel is generally praised for his efforts to root out Stasi agents. But he has also come under intense pressure from left and right, and there are regular calls for his resignation. **********Dismantler Was Also a Spy **********On Tuesday, Mr. Diestel, who took office in April, was forced to admit that the man he had appointed to oversee the dissolution of the Stasi, Dieter Stein, and 12 other senior ministry officials turned out to be secret Stasi agents. All were dismissed. **********Mr. de Maiziere said he had ordered investigations into possible former Stasi links of three of his government ministers, including Environment Minister Karl-Hermann Steinberg. **********Mr. Steinberg has denied working for the Stasi, though he admits that, like many East Germans, he was forced to prepare reports for the security agency about people he met on trips abroad. The names of the other ministers suspected of Stasi links have not been made public. **********This week, education officials in West Berlin disclosed that last January, under the Government of the last Communist Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, as many as 1,000 to 1,500 former Stasi agents were given jobs as schoolteachers in the East Berlin school system. They said the goal was evidently not to infiltrate classrooms, but simply to find jobs for some of the tens of thousands of agents who were dismissed as part of the Stasi dismantling.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/23/busin.body_text: **********Reebok International Ltd., blaming sluggish sales of its footwear in the United States, reported a 17.8 percent drop in third-quarter earnings today. Reebok said earnings totaled $41 million, or 36 cents a share, for the quarter that ended on Sept. 30. That compared with earnings of $49.8 million, or 44 cents a share, for the comparable period last year. Its sales increased 12.2 percent, to $588.8 million from $524.5 million. The company said its sales for the Reebok brand outside the United States more than doubled, exceeding $360 million, during the first three quarters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/04/busin.main_headline: How One Man's Ego Wrecked a Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/04/busin.print_headline: How One Man's Ego Wrecked a Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/04/busin.body_text: **********It was the Christmas season and the Bank of New England was having a party. Gathered at the swank Meridien Hotel here, bank executives cheerily greeted prominent business people as they dined on hors d'oeuvres and kept their glasses filled. To the casual observer, it was a scene of glad tidings and seasonal bonhomie. **********Back at headquarters, however, there was no cheer. Federal regulators had just combed through the books and, shocked by the widespread bad loans they had found, ''read the riot act,'' according to one insider. After four years of solid earnings, the bank was in a crisis. Top management's days were numbered and anxious directors, lawyers and investment bankers met around the clock. As they did, the bank's condition only worsened. The bad loans ''came in waves,'' said one insider. First, they were in the millions, then the billions. The fate of the bank hung by a thread. And it still does.  ''What happened to Bank of New England is even worse than Texas,'' said Masaru Kakutani, an analyst with Moody's Investors Service Inc. ''There's a strong probability of their requiring Federal assistance.'' James Hanbury, an analyst with Wertheim Schroder & Company, added, ''The survival odds are 50-50. The company's got a sliver of capital and lots of bad loans.'' **********Indeed, a Texas-style financial disaster has come to New England and the wreckage is stunning. Thousands of Bank of New England employees are being let go. The bank's bond and stockholders have seen their investments dwindle to virtually nothing. And regional businesses complain they are being strangled by a credit crunch, brought on, in part, they say, by the chilling effect this episode has had on all lending in their area. **********Ambition and Carelessness **********The fall, so far and so fast, of such a pillar of the New England banking community is the tale of the overreaching drive, sloppy management and hubris of one man - Walter J. Connolly Jr., the bank's recently ousted chairman. A marketing whiz, Mr. Connolly came to Boston with the notion of creating the biggest and boldest bank in the region, and built the second largest, through costly acquisitions and aggressive real estate lending. Unfortunately, he did it at the expense of the basics of banking. As long as the so-called Massachusetts miracle heated the region, the bank's imprudent lending went unnoticed. But when the ''miracle'' ended, the Bank of New England tumbled like a house of cards. **********Now, the survivors are left to sort through the rubble. Last week, the bank said it would name a new chairman to replace H. Ridgely Bullock, a board member who is serving in that post temporarily. The naming of Lawrence K. Fish, former president of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association in Beverly Hills, Calif., was openly discussed by bank insiders, but never announced. On Friday, the bank said an announcement is due ''shortly.'' Whether it is Mr. Bullock, Mr. Fish or another, the task ahead is daunting. **********The bank, which announced that its losses for 1989 will reach $1.1 billion, agreed last Thursday to Federal cease-and-desist orders giving regulators broad oversight powers. Some $3 billion in deposits is expected to flow out in the coming months, the bank estimates, and it is frantically selling assets to raise cash and meet Federal capital rules. So far, some $3.7 billion in assets have been sold and nearly $4 billion more are on the block. The bank has also borrowed heavily from the Boston Federal Reserve Bank - some $1.6 billion last week alone. Nonperforming loans are now estimated at $2.3 billion.  Such deep problems have the tightknit Boston banking community concerned. Federal regulators, wary of troubled real estate loans, have visited other area banks, most notably the Bank of Boston and the Shawmut National Bank Corporation. Regardless of the findings, bankers say, the Bank of New England debacle has tarred them all. It has already depressed their own shares, making it more difficult for them to raise capital and leaving them more vulnerable to takeovers. **********''We're all in the same boat,'' said William M. Crozier Jr., president of BayBanks Inc. ''And they're rocking the boat. It would be better for the rest of us in the boat if they could just sit down.'' **********Mr. Connolly shook the boat from the start. The Connecticut banker came to Boston in 1985 and in four short years turned the sleepy $7 billion bank into a $31 billion giant poised to overtake the venerable Bank of Boston as the biggest. Boston, which traces its banking lineage to the Revolutionary War, never saw anything like it. ''There were all dry eyes when Connolly left town,'' said one leading Boston banker, who declined to be named. **********Mr. Connolly, 61, has retreated to Cape Cod where, in a telephone interview last week, he blamed problems on the ''dramatic'' real estate downturn and ''more aggressive'' regulators. Speaking in halting phrases, he sounded almost apologetic: ''This was something nobody expected and I certainly regret. There are a lot of reasons why things have come to the point they have. A lot of us would have done things differently. Most troubling for me personally is the disruption and dislocations to so many people's lives.'' **********Such sensitivity was never Mr. Connolly's hallmark; in fact, words generally offered to describe him were ''arrogant'' and ''aggressive.'' **********Insatiable Appetite **********On the way up, Mr. Connolly displayed an insatiable appetite for small banks and gobbled them at a pace - and price - that stunned bankers here. His drive even took him to the Supreme Court, which approved the 1985 merger of the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, the Hartford-based bank he headed, and the Bank of New England. **********This decision affirmed the constitutionality of regional interstate banking and set Mr. Connolly on a spree in which he snapped up 20 other banks, including the Worcester, Mass.-based Conifer Group at a record three-and-a-half times earnings, or $656 million. When the dust settled, his colossus ranked 18th in the nation. **********Having spent so much, Mr. Connolly then embarked on a lending binge, particularly in the overheated real estate market, to get the high returns and big fees such loans provided. **********''Walter Connolly had grandiose plans to grow the bank like crazy,'' said Mr. Hanbury of Wertheim Schroder. ''His acquisitions were too expensive, and that forced him to grow loans rapidly. The easiest was real estate, since developers borrow as long as banks lend.'' Nearly 38 percent of the bank's $25 billion portfolio was in real estate, more than any major New England lender. **********Loan concentration wasn't the only problem; so was loan quality. Intense competition - from savings banks that had gone public, from savings and loans and from the region's other banks - pushed Mr. Connolly into increasingly marginal loans. Making matters worse, after assembling his empire, Mr. Connolly had little talent for managing it. Scant attention was paid to implementing controls over the disbursement of so much money. **********''The quality of their loans was very poor,'' said H. Rodgin Cohen, a banking lawyer at Sullivan & Cromwell, in New York. ''They made loans other people turned down and there was pressure from on high to do so.'' **********Out of Their Depth **********The bank was a model of decentralization - and, often, confusion. Mr. Connolly left decisions to local officers and small-town bankers were making big-city deals. ''Many officers knew how to make loans for banks much smaller,'' said one bank insider. ''They didn't always rise to the occasion.'' Said one lawyer close to the bank: ''They were throwing money out the window in an overheated market. It was without limits, appraisals or review. These were sloppy loans by not-astute bankers.'' **********Even Mr. Connolly now admits controls were lacking: ''Looking back, procedures could have been tighter.'' **********''Walter Connolly could run a $9 billion company,'' said James E. Moynihan, a senior vice president at Advest Inc., a Boston-based research firm. ''But he did not have the depth to run a $30 billion company. When you have a $30 billion bank with 17,000 employees, you can no longer run it on the buddy system.'' **********Behind this, however, was Mr. Connolly's ego; his desire to be the leader of a generation of New England bankers who occupied the top spots at rival banks. This group included Joel Alvord at Shawmut, who lived near Mr. Connolly in Hartford and played golf and tennis at the same clubs, and J. Terrence Murray, at Fleet/Norstar, who bid against Mr. Connolly for banks. And there was Ira Stepanian at the Bank of Boston, the pinnacle of the Brahmin establishment that stood as an ever-present challenge. **********''The trouble began when Walter's ego got in the way and overwhelmed his business sense,'' said Thomas Finneran, chairman of the banking committee of the Massachusetts State Legislature. ''He didn't want to lose Conifer to Terry Murray, who was also bidding on it. So he paid too much. And he wanted in the worst way to pass the Bank of Boston. He was just a tough guy to cross, and he had a reputation of wiping out people who stood in his way. Ruthless was one word I heard more about him than about any other person I know. Utterly ruthless.'' **********Mr. Connolly's empire began to unravel last November when Federal examiners, concerned about the bank's exposure to a deteriorating real estate market, descended. Clearly, the bank was caught unawares. Just that September, it sold $200 million in bonds through Morgan Stanley & Company, offering a rosy picture to the Securities and Exchange Commission. (Today, those bonds are trading at 25 cents on the dollar.) In October, at least eight insiders, including the chief financial officer, bought bank shares by the thousands. Local Federal Reserve officials say they had warned the bank about declining real estate but, said one, ''the bank didn't believe us.'' **********On Nov. 27, in a Boston meeting with regulators, the bank agreed to set aside a $400 million reserve for bad loans. The first hint of trouble came the next day in a carefully worded news release saying a ''substantial'' reserve was set up. **********A week later, a new group of Texas-hardened examiners, who had worked on the Mcorp banking collapse, arrived and a tougher tone sounded. Mr. Connolly and other executives were called to a meeting with regulators in Boston on Dec. 7 and told that the situation was out of control, that the regulators had never seen such terrible loans and that the survival of the bank was in question. **********''To say everyone was surprised would be a masterpiece of understatement,'' said DeRoy C. Thomas, a board member and president of the ITT Corporation. Added Edward D. Herlihy, a lawyer at the New York-based firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, which represents the board: ''Between Nov. 22 and three weeks later, the whole world changed for Connolly and the bank because some guys from Texas came up and said Boston was another Houston.'' **********There was grumbling that regulators came down hard. But, in Washington, Dean S. Marriott, a senior deputy comptroller at the Comptroller of the Currency, bristles at such talk: ''The charge floating around New England is about our tougher standards. But we haven't changed. We have, however, brought more expertise from Texas to bear on Bank of New England and other banks.'' **********All-Night Sessions **********Mr. Thomas took over running the bank from a stunned Mr. Connolly, who was shunted aside. Mr. Thomas set up board committees - to sell assets, find a new chairman and calm depositors. Investment bankers from Lazard Freres and Goldman Sachs began all-night sessions to learn the complexities of a big troubled bank and how to save it. **********Merger discussions with Fleet/Norstar were held but halted by regulators who feared a healthy Fleet would be infected. Day-and-night talks were held with Citicorp to buy the credit-card division and the bank's Connecticut subsidiary. The City of Boston and other big depositors threatened to pull funds, and did. Equity capital sunk to a dangerously low 1 percent of assets. **********And the bank had no money to cover some $180 million in commercial paper obligations coming due - which, if not paid, would cause bankruptcy. That was staved off by an 11th-hour tax refund rushed from the Internal Revenue Service. Insiders feared the bank might collapse, causing a run on all New England banks. **********Meanwhile, the regulators kept finding more bad loans and by Dec. 21 laid down the law: Mr. Connolly, said to be in an ''absolute state of shock,'' would have to go. On Friday before Christmas, Mr. Connolly resigned. **********Well-known bankers were approached, but declined the job. They included Richard Ravitch, who rescued the Bowery Savings Bank in New York; William J. McDonough, former vice chairman of the First Chicago Corporation, and John Terell, former president of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. (Mr. Bullock was named interim chairman on Jan. 26.) **********'Here's the Keys' **********By mid-January, weary bank representatives, worn down by the regulators, met again with Mr. Marriott, of the comptroller's office. To test whether the regulators wanted to take over the bank or let it work out its problems, Mr. Thomas issued a challenge. ''Here's the keys,'' he said. ''You take the bank.'' When Mr. Marriott demurred, the group got the sign they wanted. **********Today, the bank is paddling fast. It has a string of asset sales under its belt, is luring depositors with mouth-watering interest rates and is waging an advertising campaign to win investor confidence. **********As for Mr. Connolly, he said he's ''got a lot of thinking to do.'' He may only get two weeks' pay as severance from his employment contract, which had two years to go. Had the bank been sold during his final weeks, he would have gotten a $7 million golden parachute. As it is, however, he's left with little: Most of his net worth is in Bank of New England stock. **********BILLIONS ON THE BLOCK **********There's a great sale going on. It's of the Bank of New England. **********Goldman, Sachs & Company and Lazard Freres & Company are aggressively peddling some $4 billion in bank assets. But some analysts and bank insiders worry that such massive sales will leave the bank with few income-generating assets for the future. **********Right now, the bank is just trying to survive the next few months and bring its assets down to around $20 billion. This is so it will not be forced to borrow to meet reserve requirements backing its deposit obligations. **********''Asset sales buy them time and get them to tomorrow,'' said Charles Peabody, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company. ''The question is once the sales are done, where the bank stands as an operating entity and what will be left to generate operating income. But they have no choice.'' **********The bank sold its credit-card business to Citicorp for $828 million, a figure analysts say is top dollar. But it did not fare as well selling its BancNew England Leasing Group to the Bank of Tokyo. The Japanese had agreed to pay a $110 million premium for the group. But once the troubles arose, that came down to $92.5 million, of which $30 million is a note - not much-needed cash. **********The bank is about to announce the sale of $1.3 billion in home equity loans; it has just agreed to sell $900 million in highly leveraged loans and is marketing residential mortgages, commercial loans and auto loans. It also sold $1.4 billion in municipal bonds and $450 million in leasing assets. **********The trickiest sales may be of the subsidiary banks, especially Connecticut Bank and Trust, where Walter J. Connolly Jr., the bank's recently ousted chairman, got his start. So many good assets have been stripped from C.B.T. that potential buyers fear getting stuck with the bad. They worry also about C.B.T.'s real estate portfolio. In addition, Bank of New England debtholders must approve any C.B.T. sale and may well demand compensation to offset the loss of a subsidiary whose revenues stood behind their debt. These problems are so daunting that early suitors - Citicorp and Fleet/Norstar were among them - appear to have lost interest. **********HECTIC DAYS AT NEW ENGLAND **********It was pretty hectic at the Bank of New England last week. The bank almost got a new chairman, and it signed detailed agreements with Federal regulators setting a tight timetable to recover its financial health. **********Word from well-placed sources at the bank began to leak out at midweek that Lawrence K. Fish, 45, would be named chairman. But by week's end, nothing was forthcoming from the bank. **********If he is named, it would be something of a homecoming. Two years ago, Mr. Fish left the Bank of Boston, where he had worked for 16 years, to become president of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association in Beverly Hills, Calif. **********His task was to reorganize the savings institution - which is plagued by massive losses in high-risk, high-yield ''junk bonds'' - along traditional banking lines. He left 17 months later, with both Columbia and Mr. Fish saying that his plan had eliminated his job and that his leaving was voluntary and not related to the institution's problems. **********Analysts have described Mr. Fish as an aggressive and hard-working decision maker. At the Bank of Boston, he held a variety of overseas posts before becoming head of New England retail operations. **********The agreement with Federal regulators includes such unusual provisions as allowing the regulators to review every bank officer at the level of senior vice president and above. It also sets out practices, already part of the regulatory review process, for proper lending procedures and real estate appraisals. And it bars the bank from paying dividends without Federal approval. **********AT A GLANCE: Bank of New England **********All dollar amounts in thousands, except per share data           Three months ended       Dec. 31   1989   1988        Net Income   ($1,113,300)   $281,700        Earnings per share   --   $4.06                Year ended        Return on Equity    (68.08%)    18.56%        Return on Assets    (3.48%)   0.94%                          Total assets, Dec. 31, 1989   $29,773,000        Stock Holders Equity   458,000        Net interest revenue   980,919        Noninterest revenue    307,904                   Book value per share,        Dec. 31, 1989   $6.17          Stock price, March 2, 1990        N.Y.S.E. consolidated close   4 1/2        Stock price, 52-week range   2 1/2-24 1/2        Employees,march 2, 1990   17,500        Headquarters   Boston        (Loss)

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/09/busin.body_text: **********An informal search is under way to find a successor to Marvin S. Traub, longtime chairman of Bloomingdale's, sometime before 1993, officials of the department store chain and its corporate parent said yesterday. **********They said the process was not a formal search but a long-term effort by Federated Stores Inc., owner of the 15-store chain, and Mr. Traub himself. Allen I. Questrom, chairman and chief executive of Federated, and James M. Zimmerman, president and chief operating officer, were said to be personally involved in the process. **********Mr. Traub, who is generally considered one of the most innovative merchants in American retailing, turned 65 years old in April. But he is not being forced to retire because Federated has no policy of mandatory retirement for its division heads. **********Carol Sanger, vice president for public relations at Federated, said Mr. Traub's employment contract, which was to expire earlier this year, had been extended. Although she would not specify the length of the new contract, retail industry executives said it was for three years. **********Asked why Federated was seeking a successor so soon, Ms. Sanger replied: "It would not be prudent to do otherwise. We recognized that we would eventually have to deal with that issue, so that it is logical to begin the process well ahead of time."  A 'Preliminary' Effort **********In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Traub demonstrated some reticence about the effort to find his successor. "It's all at a very preliminary stage, and I cannot comment further other than there's certainly no immediate urgency," he said. **********But he added, "I'll certainly be around for a while, and there are many exciting things going on, and will go on, at Bloomingdale's, and I will want to see them through." **********Several weeks ago, when Mr. Questrom was asked how long Mr. Traub would be running Bloomingdale's, he said, "As long as he wants to, because we think he is a great merchant." **********The retail industry seems to agree. In January, the National Retail Federation plans to award Mr. Traub its annual gold medal for distinguished retailing, which is considered the highest recognition American retailers give to their peers. **********Mr. Traub has been grappling with problems at Bloomingdale's: sales have been soft for more than a year and the company has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since the beginning of 1990. Bloomingdale's and eight other store chains owned by Federated fell under the court proceedings when Federated and the Allied Stores Corporation, the two American retailing entities of the troubled Campeau Corporation of Toronto, filed for bankruptcy protection in January. Improving Business **********Business at Bloomingdale's, however, has been improving, Mr. Traub said. "October was better than September, which was better than August," he said. **********Names that have been mentioned as possible successors to Mr. Traub include Marshall Hilsberg, chairman and chief executive of Lord & Taylor, the fashion chain owned by Federated's rival, the May Department Stores Company; Michael Gould, the chairman of the Giorgio cosmetics company in California and the former chairman of the J. W. Robinson department stores in Los Angeles, and Millard S. Drexler, president of The Gap Inc., Bruno, Calif., and the former president of the Ann Taylor stores. **********But a senior executive at Bloomingdale's observed: "Any name you hear today in speculation will probably be wrong by the time any decision is made." **********While Mr. Traub was reluctant to sound as though he was stepping down, he admitted to one project that suggests an eventual retirement: He plans to write his autobiography. **********He said he had selected Random House as the publisher and was negotiating terms. "It's several years down the road," he said, adding that the book would be a combination of an autobiography and a set of memoirs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/24/busin.body_text: **********Eurotunnel, the British-French company, today raised its estimate again for the cost of completing the channel tunnel and predicted that the rail line linking France and England would cost as much as $:7.5 billion, or about $12.27 billion. **********At a news conference, Eurotunnel executives said half of the 93 miles of tunneling in the three-tunnel project had been completed. Noting the progress, the executives said they were still confident that the tunnelers would meet beneath the English Channel at the end of November and that the tunnel service would go into operation in June 1993. **********The new cost projection is $:300 million ($490.8 million) higher than Eurotunnel predicted in January and about $:500 million ($818 million) more than in the fall. The original estimate in 1987 was $:4.87 billion. **********Graham Corbett, Eurotunnel's managing director of finance and administration, said the main reasons that the projection was higher than the one made last fall were an expected $818 million in additional tunneling costs and $286.3 million for raising additional money. He said the costs would have been even higher without the $327.2 million in anticipated savings from previously announced changes in the tunnel. **********To pay the higher bill, Eurotunnel hopes to persuade its syndicate of more than 200 banks to agree to lend it an additional $2.62 billion to $3.27 billion and to raise an additional $654.4 million to $818 million from a stock offering. **********Alastair Morton, Eurotunnel's deputy chairman and chief executive, said negotiations with the company's lead banks had been largely completed. Eurotunnel hopes to gain the bank syndicate's approval by the end of the summer and to complete the stock sale by the end of the year. **********Mr. Morton said Eurotunnel and Transmanche-Link, the consortium of 10 British and French construction companies that are building the tunnel, have yet to resolve their disagreement over who should bear the projected higher cost of the terminals and outfitting the tunnels. While Mr. Morton said independent studies made him confident that Eurotunnel would win, he predicted that the disagreement would go to arbitration and might end up in litigation. **********Eurotunnel previously raised $:1 billion in equity and obtained $:5 billion in promised bank loans. The additional financing would provide Eurotunnel with a total of $:8 billion to $:8.5 billion ($13.09 billion to $13.91 billion), which ''far exceeds our forecast of the project's cost,'' Mr. Corbett said. But Eurotunnel wants to make sure it has a cushion, he said. **********Mr. Morton added, ''We do not intend to go through this process again.'' **********In trading on the London Stock Exchange today, Eurotunnel's shares closed at $:5.78, or $9.456, up 5 pence, or 8.2 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/25/busin.body_text: **********The Exxon Corporation said today that its net income in the third quarter was unchanged from the period a year ago. Higher oil prices depressed profits in refining, marketing and chemical operations and increased profits in worldwide crude production. **********The Unocal Corporation said earnings in the quarter increased by 53.2 percent, with its production unit benefiting from higher oil prices and its refining, marketing and chemical operations recording modest declines. **********Oil prices averaging $4.60 more a barrel, at $20.22, than in the period last year raised profits in the production unit. The downturn in refining and marketing operations, as well as in chemicals, was less severe than reported by many oil companies in the period. **********One reason is that Unocal produces nearly as much crude oil as its refineries require. **********Following are details of the companies' results:   Exxon **********The world's largest oil company, based in Dallas, said it earned $1.08 billion, or 85 cents a share, the same as in the third quarter a year ago. Revenues rose 22.7 percent, to $29.02 billion from $23.66 billion. **********Profits in the quarter were aided by a onetime gain of $98 million from sales of foreign assets, compared with a onetime gain of $15 million from similar sales a year earlier. There were no write-offs or special charges taken in the latest quarter. **********The oil-and-gas production unit earned $930 million, compared with $667 million a year earlier, benefiting from worldwide crude prices that on average were $6.30 a barrel higher than in the quarter a year earlier. **********Profits in refining and marketing fell to $246 million, from $347 million a year ago, with $70 million of the decline coming in the United States. Chemical profits fell to $65 million from $250 million a year earlier. **********Petroleum and chemical refineries, which rely on crude as an important raw material, were unable to recover higher crude costs because competition prevented Exxon from raising prices of gasoline and other products at the same pace as crude oil, said Lawrence G. Rawl, chairman and chief executive. **********He said the refining and marketing unit, which produces and sells gasoline, operated at a loss in the United States during the two months after the Middle East crisis began. **********Earnings at Exxon's refining unit typically are depressed in times of rising crude prices because Exxon must buy large amounts of crude to supply its worldwide refineries. The refineries require 3.4 million barrels a day in the third quarter; the global exploration unit produced 1.7 million barrels a day. **********Exxon's shares were unchanged, at $48.50, on the New York Stock Exchange today.  Unocal **********The nation's 13th-largest oil company, based in Los Angeles, earned $121 million, or 52 cents a share, compared with $79 million, or 34 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue increased 9.3 percent, to $3.07 billion from $2.81 billion. **********Unocal's exploration and production unit earned $153 million, compared with $104 million a year earlier. Its refining and marketing unit earned $34 million, down from $39 million a year earlier. Profits in chemical operations fell slightly, to $8 million from $10 million. **********Unocal produced a daily average of 242,700 barrels of crude in the quarter, or 90 percent of the 270,300 barrels of average daily crude supplies needed by its refineries. **********The comparison with the quarter a year earlier was aided because the 1989 profit for refining and marketing was reduced by losses in a refinery operated in Beaumont, Tex. That refinery was later closed. Also, Unocal derived earnings in the 1990 quarter from a venture in refining with the Venezuelan Government. The venture was formed earlier this year. **********Unocal's shares gained 25 cents today, to $28.875, on the Big Board.
