https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation announced a final agreement to manufacture its mini-vans in Austria. The deal, which had been expected, creates a new joint venture company in which Chrysler and the Austrian manufacturer Steyr-Daimler-Puch Fahrzeugtecknik G.m.b.H. will each own 50 percent. **********The venture, called Eurostar, will produce the mini-vans at a new plant in Graz, Austria, beginning in the spring of 1991. Initial production is set at 25,000 vehicles a year, with long-term output expected to reach 125,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/world.main_headline: Romania Frees Student Held in 53-Day Protest
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   Romania Frees Student Held in 53-Day Protest
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/world.body_text: **********A student who led a 53-day anti-Government rally has been freed after six weeks' detention, and he denied charges today that he incited protesters to violence. **********The student, Marian Munteanu, whose beating and detention drew domestic and international protest, was released on Thursday night. In an interview in his apartment today, he called his time in jail ''a nightmare'' and pledged to continue working with the student movement. **********''These six weeks of detention have aged me many years,'' he said. **********Mr. Munteanu, the 28-year-old president of the Bucharest student union, was a leader of an anti-Government rally that the police violently dispersed on June 13 after 53 days. **********The authorities' decision to use force against the peaceful protesters led to riots. More violence broke out when miners loyal to President Ion Iliescu came to the capital to help quell the demonstrations. Six people were killed and scores injured in three days of unrest in the capital. **********Mr. Munteanu was hospitalized after being badly beaten by miners and then arrested days later. His release came shortly after the prosecutor general issued a statement saying the circumstances that led to Mr. Munteanu's ''preventive detention'' had changed and his release would no longer represent a threat to public order.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/world.main_headline: Convoy Heads to Baghdad With Powdered Milk, but No Exemptions
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Convoy Heads to Baghdad With Powdered Milk, but No Exemptions
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/world.body_text: **********A convoy of more than 40 tractor-trailers loaded with food set out from this capital at dusk today on a 570-mile journey across a desert road to Baghdad. **********The convoy's sponsors were a group of Palestinian volunteer agencies based in Jordan, and their action in dispatching the food supplies was an opening shot in what is likely to be a protracted battle. At issue are the United Nations economic sanctions against Iraq, and how much food, and under what arrangements, will be permitted to pass through the blockade that the United Nations Security Council has imposed on Baghdad. **********The organizers of the convoy said they had not sought exemption from the Security Council's sanctions committee for the convoy, as required under the terms of the sanctions, because their undertaking was a humanitarian one. The organizers said the cartons of powdered milk, sugar, rice, pasta and vegetables were to be unloaded sometime Tuesday evening and turned over to the Iraqi Labor Ministry in Baghdad. They said the food was intended for Iraqi children. **********Children Chant Slogans **********Hundreds of children who gathered to see the tractor-trailers depart chanted slogans in support of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. ''With our souls and blood,'' the children shouted, ''we sacrifice ourselves to you, Saddam.'' **********On Sunday, apparently prompted by tightening food shortages, Mr. Hussein issued a warning to the United States and other nations with military forces deployed against Iraq that Baghdad would not allow its 16 million people to be ''strangled'' by the United Nations embargo. Mr. Hussein implied that Iraq might mount pre-emptive strikes against Israel and against oilfields in Saudi Arabia and other Arab states arrayed against Iraq. **********Mr. Hussein's statement set the stage for what diplomats here and in Baghdad said today is likely to be a new, and, for the United States and its allies, increasingly awkward phase of the confrontation with Iraq. **********Mr. Hussein has already indicated that he intends to use the specter of food shortages in Iraq to weaken and perhaps break the common front among nations that have condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The diplomats predicted that Baghdad would increasingly publicize scenes of Iraqi women and children, in particular, suffering from food shortages. **********An official representing a United Nations relief agency in Amman put it bluntly. ''How long will the Americans be able to hold to the embargo when the television news begins to show shots of hungry children?'' he said. **********The situation poses a dilemma for Jordan, which is caught between strong support for Iraq among its 3.5 million people and a desire not to alienate Western nations that are its main sources of aid. Senior officials on the Government's Higher Committee for Relief, set up to handle refugees from the invasion arriving in Jordan, said tonight that they had no knowledge of the food convoy heading for Iraq. **********A senior Foreign Ministry official said that the Government had not approved the convoy. ''I didn't have any idea about this,'' he said. **********Shipments Subject to Approval **********When it voted 10 days ago to approve shipments of food through the embargo ''to relieve human suffering,'' the Security Council authorized its sanctions committee to review specific cases and approve shipments. The Council ruled that food should be provided ''through the United Nations in cooperation with the International Committee of the Red Cross or other appropriate humanitarian agencies and distributed by them or under their supervision in order to insure that they reach the intended beneficiaries.'' **********Officials of the United Nations committee in New York say that only one exemption has been granted - to India, the nation that pressed the issue hardest. The committee gave permission for an Indian ship, the Vishwa Siddhi, to carry 10,000 tons of food for Indian and other Asian residents of Kuwait. **********Indian diplomats in Baghdad said today that their Ambassador, Kamal Bakhshi, was in Umm Qasr, a port in southern Iraq, awaiting the ship's arrival, which United Nations officials said is expected on Tuesday. **********Jordan has said that it will abide by the United Nations sanctions. But the Palestinian convoy that left Amman today appeared not to meet the conditions set by the sanctions committee. Abu Mohammed, a spokesman for the General Union of Voluntary Societies, the Palestinian organization that chartered the tractor-trailers, said that distribution of the food would be left to the Iraqi authorities. **********United Nations officials said that at least 60,000 Asians are in transit camps around Baghdad, and that conditions there may be worse than anything evacuees encountered when they began pouring into camps in the Jordanian desert last month. **********Diplomats who have visited the Baghdad camps said that they are closely guarded by heavily armed Iraqi security forces, that food is extremely scarce, and that there are no organized sanitary arrangements. **********United Nations officials here said that information about Asians in the Baghdad camps and about food shortages in Kuwait was extremely sketchy because nearly all United Nations staff members who are not Iraqis or Kuwaitis were evacuated shortly after the Iraqi invasion. But the officials said that Asians who arrived in Jordan over the weekend were markedly weaker than those who arrived only a week ago, and that their accounts of their stays in the Baghdad camps were grim. **********''What we are seeing is just the tip of the iceberg,'' a United Nations official said. ''I'm afraid that if we don't get more supplies into Iraq, we may end up with some of these people dying before they even get here.'' **********Iran Says It Seized Food **********CAIRO, Sept. 24 (Special to The New York Times) - The Iranian authorities said today they had seized 29 people accused of trying to smuggle food across a remote border region into Iraq, the first suggestion that Teheran is enforcing the international embargo imposed after Baghdad's invasion of Kuwait. **********The Iranian press agency said two bands of smugglers trying to cross the frontier had been arrested with contraband food including rice, vegetable oil and sugar and had been handed over to a revolutionary court in the northwestern Kurdish-speaking city of Sanandaj. It gave no other details. Iran officially supports the international sanctions imposed on Iraq. But there have been suggestions, despite Iranian denials, that Teheran has agreed with Baghdad to provide food in exchange for oil. **********The announcement coincides with a visit to Iran by the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad, his first since the Islamic revolution of 1979. Syria is considered Iraq's archrival in Arab politics.  The Syrian leader is said by diplomats to be pressing Iran for a tough stance against Baghdad, Teheran's foe in the eight-year gulf war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene;   War Is No Way To Start a Career
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene;   War Is No Way To Start a Career
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/busin.body_text: **********WAR, as everyone knows, is not good for children and other living things. What is more debatable, however, is war's long-term effect on adults who make it back to civilian life. **********Studies after World War II showed that soldiers had served themselves by serving Uncle Sam: on average, male veterans have outearned non-veterans by 10 to 20 percent. But soldiers of the Vietnam years have earned 10 to 20 percent less in the civilian job market. **********One often-cited explanation for the contrast is job discrimination. Employers, goes the argument, want nothing to do with those who were exposed to the demoralizing effects of drugs and defeat. Others think the difference in veterans' work experience says more about recruitment than about life in the military. World War II veterans, they argue, were the best and the brightest; in Vietnam the Army was forced to draw disproportionately from the poor and untrained. **********Now, two economists, Joshua Angrist of Harvard and Alan Krueger of Princeton, have hit upon an ingenious way to untangle the puzzle. In both wars, they discovered, draft procedures created an arbitrary link between birth dates and the probability of serving in the armed forces. And in both, men with no distinguishing characteristic other than being born on the wrong date earned substantially less in civilian life than men who lucked out. **********The Angrist-Krueger analysis of World War II veterans, published as a working paper by the National Bureau of Economic Research, makes use of the fact that draft boards drew on the pool of men in simple chronological order of their birth. Roughly 75 percent of the men born in the first six months of 1926 ended up in the military. Thereafter, the probability declined quarter by quarter: Just 22 percent of those born near the end of 1928 ever served. **********It seems unlikely that youth alone was, in itself, a key to success in the postwar labor market. But strikingly, younger workers earned more, strongly suggesting that military service was a handicap. The authors calculate that adjusted for other factors, World War II veterans have earned about 5 percent less over the decades. **********Mr. Angrist's study of Vietnam experience, to be published in June in the American Economic Review, exploits an even sharper statistical distinction. During the Vietnam War, birth-date lotteries were used to set draft priorities within each group coming of draft age. In 1971, for example, 20-year-olds born on the first 125 dates chosen like the numbers in Lotto were eligible; the rest were exempt. **********Most draft-eligibles never served. Still, draft status made a big difference: Two eligibles in seven ended up in uniform, compared with just one exempt in seven. By matching birth dates with earnings data, Mr. Angrist figures that military service during Vietnam reduced average earnings for white males by about 15 percent. The earnings of non-whites did not seem to be affected. **********The enduring psychological damage from combat may play a role for the relatively small percentage of veterans who were ever under fire. But Mr. Angrist's interpretation of the earnings deficit is more straightforward: Skills acquired in the military do not make up for the lost years of civilian experience. Nor, apparently, does that modest privilege of veteran status, G.I. Bill education subsidies. **********The trade-off is closer for non-whites, Mr. Angrist speculates, because they entered the Army with fewer skills and left fewer opportunities behind. **********The numbers offer a new perspective on an old issue. Americans have long rationalized tight limits on assistance to war veterans on the ground that the time spent in uniform was an advantage in later life. In fact, it appears to be quite costly, at least for men who were not already victims of poverty or discrimination. **********The results might also lead to second thoughts about the use of national service as a means of giving the underclass a second chance to gain the discipline needed to succeed in a middle-class world. **********Mr. Angrist's numbers suggest no net benefits for recruits who met the Army's minimum standards. Nor does a recently published analysis of the post-military earnings of low-aptitude recruits, admitted to the Army under a special dispensation during the 1960's and 1970's. Indeed, according to the Human Resources Research Organization in Alexandria, Va., veterans of ''Project 100,000'' did less well in the civilian job market than comparably skilled non-veterans. **********War may make men out of boys. It does not seem to make them better breadwinners.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/28/busin.body_text: **********Propelled by rebates, sales of vehicles made in the United States rose by 12.6 percent in mid-November, compared with sluggish demand in the period last year. **********Several analysts said they were at a loss to explain why vehicle sales continued at a fairly steady pace despite a weakening economy. **********Hefty rebates, averaging $1,400 to $1,500 on many domestic models, "help explain some of the increase in sales over last year," said David Healy, an analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. in New York. Nevertheless, he said, "It's as if car buyers are oblivious to the fact that we're in a recession."   The Fleet Factor **********Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst with Dean Witter Securities Inc. in San Francisco, said he was "flabbergasted" by the figures. **********"Fleets have largely finished taking deliveries of 1991 models, so they are not much of a factor" in the latest results, he said. **********But other analysts said fleets were the primary factor in the latest sales gains posted by the Big Three. **********"Fleets are still a huge part of the equation," said Joseph S. Phillippi of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in New York. **********Joel Pitcoff, a market analyst for the Ford Motor Company, said, "This is a time of the year when fleet sales represent a higher proportion of overall sales." **********The 10 auto makers that manufacture in the United States sold 291,287 vehicles, compared with 255,492 a year ago. **********Car sales surged by 16.7 percent, to 182,749. Seasonally adjusted, cars sold at an annual rate of 7.1 million, compared with an annual rate of 6.1 million in the period last year. So far this year, cars have sold at an annual rate of 7 million. **********Sales of domestic light trucks rose by 9.8 percent, to 108,538, reversing several weeks of sales declines that auto makers and dealers had attributed to the lower fuel economy of pickup trucks and mini-vans compared with many car models. **********The Japanese auto makers with plants in the United States increased light-vehicle sales by 27.5 percent in mid-November, while those of the Big Three increased by 13.4 percent. Japanese "transplants" held 10.6 percent of the American market in the middle of the month, up from 9.5 percent in last year's period.   G.M.'s Rise Nearly 17% **********General Motors sold 77,538 cars in mid-November, up by 16.9 percent from last year. G.M. reported improving sales of several of its small cars, including the Geo Metro and Storm, Chevrolet Cavalier and Pontiac Sunbird. **********Some larger models also sold well, like Oldsmobile's Cutlass Supreme and Buick's intermediate Regal, and the full-size Park Avenue. G.M.'s light-truck sales rose by 10.6 percent, to 44,180 units, mainly from increased sales of the company's plastic-body APV vans. **********Ford's car sales rose 17.6 percent during the period, to 49,364 cars, led by the subcompact Escort. Strong sales gains were also posted by the full-size Crown Victoria and intermediate Taurus sedans -- two models popular with fleets. Ford sold 37,648 light trucks, a gain of 14.6 percent, with sales gains posted by its Explorer four-wheel-drive vehicle and Aerostar van. **********The Chrysler Corporation's sales of pickups, Jeeps and mini-vans were flat, however, and the company continued to lose market share in that critical segment. Chrysler sold 22,865 light trucks, a gain of less than 1 percent. Chrysler's car sales increased 10.8 percent, to 22,362 cars.   'Transplants' Fare Well **********The Honda Motor Company posted a gain of 5.2 percent in sales of cars made at its plant in Marysville, Ohio. The Toyota Motor Corporation, which confirmed plans today to expand its plant in Georgetown, Ky., reported sales of 9,025 cars in mid-November, an increase of 53.4 percent. The Nissan Motor Company sold 3,399 Sentra cars, up by 45.9 percent, and 2,709 compact pickup trucks, a decline of 18.6 percent. The vehicles are made at Nissan's plant in Smyrna, Tenn. **********Among the remaining transplant manufacturers, the Mazda Motor Corporation sold 1,541 cars, an increase of 57.6 percent, and the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation sold 1,383 automobiles, a rise of 39.7 percent. **********Subaru of America, which began selling domestically produced cars in the American market last summer, sold 431 autos in mid-November, and Isuzu Motors Ltd., Subaru's partner in a plant in Lafayette, Ind., sold 1,136 light trucks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/busin.body_text: **********Nycor Inc., a company controlled by the family that also controls the Fedders Corporation, said today that it had acquired an 8.2 percent stake in the Zenith Electronics Corporation and that it might seek control of the Glenview, Ill., consumer electronics concern. **********In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Nycor said it had become Zenith's largest shareholder. The Peapack, N.J., company said it might also make a direct capital investment in Zenith, buy more Zenith stock or seek representation on the company's board. **********A spokesman for Zenith said the company had no comment on Nycor's filing. **********Earlier this month, Zenith reported a third-quarter loss of $11.6 million on sales of $342.3 million. The company makes picture tubes for television manufacturers and video recorders. **********Nycor is controlled by Salvatore Giordano and members of his family. The company formerly manufactured rotary compressors for air-conditioners and automotive components, but it sold those operations in the last two years and is now "principally engaged in a search for businesses to acquire." **********The Giordano family also controls Fedders, the air-conditioning maker that is also based in Peapack. **********Nycor purchased 2.2 million Zenith shares for $10.8 million, or an average purchase price of $4.94 a share. Zenith has 26.7 million shares outstanding. The company's stock closed down 50 cents today, at $5.625, giving the company a market value of $150 million. Nycor stock was unchanged at $2.875 in over-the-counter trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/11/busin.body_text: **********The Boone Company, an investment company owned by the United States takeover specialist T. Boone Pickens, asked Japan's Fair Trade Commission today to investigate possible violations of antimonopoly laws by Japanese auto makers and parts suppliers. A commission official, Yoshiro Sekine, said the panel would study Boone's contentions. **********Mr. Pickens has been seeking greater participation in the management of the Koito Manufacturing Company, an auto parts maker. He became Koito's largest shareholder in March 1989. **********Mr. Sekine said Boone had contended that Japan's 11 auto makers put unfair pressure on parts suppliers to lower the prices of their products. He said Boone also contended that the auto makers' close relations with parts makers limited free competition among the parts suppliers and hindered entry by outside companies, especially foreign makers, into the Japanese market. **********Koito's second-largest shareholder is the Toyota Motor Corporation, Koito's largest customer. **********Mr. Pickens's purchase of the Koito shares has stirred speculation that he is trying to force the company to buy them back at a premium price, a practice known as greenmail. **********Mr. Pickens has denied that that is his intention.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/busin.main_headline: President Is Promoted To Top Post at MMR
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   President Is Promoted To Top Post at MMR
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/busin.body_text: **********The MMR Holding Corporation, the nation's third-largest mechanical and electrical contracting company, yesterday named Robert G. Bening chief executive. He will succeed James B. Rutland, who is appealing his conviction last year for bid-rigging. **********Mr. Rutland and Samuel Weems, the company's chief financial officer, have resigned, the company said. Mr. Bening, 56, who has been president and chief operating officer since joining the company in September, was given a board seat as well as the chief executive's post. **********Mr. Rutland will serve as a consultant for six months, the company said. MMR Holding, based in Baton Rouge, La., provides construction and engineering service to industrial, commercial and government clients. **********Mr. Rutland was convicted by a jury in Federal court in July, sentenced to six months in jail, 400 hours of community service and fined $103,000. The company's MMR Corporation unit was fined $1 million for its role in the case. **********The conviction stemmed from an investigation in 1981 in connection with a federally financed sewage plant in Georgia. **********In a news release announcing Mr. Bening's appointment, MMR said that in light of continuing restrictions on the corporation's cash flow, the board had directed Mr. Bening to undertake a review of the corporation and explore all its options. Mr. Bening said he could not comment on whether the restrictions on cash flow referred to the fine the company might have to pay or whether the business might be put up for sale. **********The company was taken private in a leveraged buyout in 1983 and taken public again in 1987. Its shares are traded over the counter. **********Mr. Bening joined MMR Holding from Metcalf & Eddy, a Boston engineering company and a unit of Air and Water Technologies. **********He had spent two years at Metcalf & Eddy and the previous 25 in the Army Corps of Engineers, retiring as a colonel. Mr. Bening holds a degree in civil engineering from the Missouri School of Mines, now the University of Missouri at Rolla. He also holds a master of engineering degree from the University of Illinois.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/20/busin.main_headline: Mutual Funds;   Bracing for Tougher Times
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/20/busin.print_headline: Mutual Funds;   Bracing for Tougher Times
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/20/busin.body_text: **********Once upon a time - more than 120 years ago - a small East Texas river town called Jefferson was thriving as steamships carried cotton and timber down the Red River to the Mississippi and thence to New Orleans. Then one day, the railroad magnate Jay Gould (no relation to this writer) came to Jefferson. He wanted to bring his railroad through town, but local leaders scoffed and Jay Gould took his railroad plans somewhere else. Not long afterward, the Red River around Jefferson became unnavigable and the once-booming town boomed no more. **********Historians say this is not just a tall tale, although they can't confirm all the details. But when Thomas R. Powers, chairman of the Investment Company Institute's board of governors, told it at the industry's recent convention, it left an uneasy stillness in a room crowded with hundreds of fund executives. One man who has attended seven of these annual gatherings said he had never heard a speech that left the audience so quiet. **********Mr. Powers clearly wasn't the only one who saw this as an apocryphal tale about the industry's struggle to keep up with changing times. Such sobering fare is not the usual stuff of the industry's conventions. Sure, there was some of the back-slapping and self-congratulation so prevalent in earlier years. Yet for an industry that just broke the $1 trillion mark, the tone was oddly subdued. ''I'm not hearing a lot of 'atta-boys' this year,'' one executive said. **********For some, the pessimism was subsumed in anger. ''The industry had better sit up and start paying attention,'' said Palomba Weingarten, chairman of the Los Angeles-based Pilgrim Group, who believes that most executives underestimate the competitive impact of banks, especially foreign ones. **********There were plenty of other reasons for pinched faces. There has been a clear shift away from the easy money of the 1980's. The industry's explosive growth during the past decade cannot be sustained and its increasingly important role in financial markets makes it fair game for competitors and regulators alike. Funds will be forced to struggle just to keep the money they already manage. Clearly, boom times are over. **********''Today's friendly competition will probably turn ugly,'' said Heidi S. Fiske, a New York City consultant on financial services and marketing, who was commissioned by the institute to look at industry conditions in the coming decade. A preview of her report, scheduled for release to institute members this summer, shows what's behind the industry's pessimism. **********She forecasts industry growth as ''healthy but probably slower,'' with yearly growth in assets of about 12 percent, almost two-thirds less than the annual rate recorded during the 80's. There are two reasons for the slowdown: Funds will have to compete against each other, and they will begin to lose market share to banks and other outside competitors. The investment pie is expected to reach $3 trillion by the end of the decade, said Alfred P. Johnson, a mutual fund consultant based in McLean, Va. ''Demand will be there, but supply will be there in spades,'' he said. **********As a result, fund executives will probably start viewing each other with a more jaundiced eye. At conventions in the past, they could afford to be generous, to swap stories and try to come up with new schemes to split an ever-expanding pool of investors' money. **********But price wars are pushing down revenues. For example, two industry giants - Fidelity Investments and the Dreyfus Corporation - are in a battle for investor money, subsidizing expenses to raise yields but shaving profit margins. At the same time, fund expenses - for labor, technology and marketing - are rising. The industry's average expense ratio - funds' expenses as a percentage of average assets - has been up steadily since 1985, said Morningstar Inc., a Chicago mutual fund research firm. **********And expenses are likely to rise even faster this decade. The market is saturated with new types of funds, and now fund groups are trying to grab market share with better service. But that will require large capital investments in computers and telecommunications. ''It's a tough act, and expensive, but there's a need for funds to differentiate themselves with service,'' said Brian S. Mattes, a spokesman for the Vanguard Group, a fund company based in Valley Forge, Pa. **********The resulting margin squeeze is expected to shrink some fund group's profits badly by mid-decade. One likely consequence is industry consolidation. Smaller groups unable to compete on price or carve out a niche may fail. It is already more economical to buy existing funds than create new ones. There were 15 mergers last year and six so far this year, and in coming years, merging funds ''will be the thing to do,'' said Wayne S. Huff, a research associate with Charles E. Simon & Company, a Washington research firm. **********The industry is clearly at a crossroads and the memory of Jefferson is fresh in the minds of fund executives. But one beneficiary of all the turmoil may be you: According to Mr. Johnson, investors are likely to reap the rewards of lower fees and charges as competition accelerates. **********THE TOO-HIGH RETURNS **********Traditionally, stock market investments return about 10 percent and bonds return about 7 percent. But the raging bull market of the 1980's knocked that standard out of kilter, and only recently have bonds moved back to their traditional levels. **********Stocks have not followed suit. The accompanying chart shows just far stocks have to fall to return to levels that market analysts consider normal. **********Right now, the return on stock funds is about 30 percent higher than the historic norm. Although bond fund returns were clearly higher than usual for the five-year period, they dropped to a more traditional level in the last year. **********Market experts say investors who were spoiled by the fat gains in the stock market during the 1980's will have to adjust their expectations of gains in coming years. Indeed, they should expect returns to go back to the norm - that is, for the market to drop 30 percent. But nobody is willing to say when that could happen.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/21/world.main_headline: Peru Drug Fund Used in War, Aide Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/21/world.print_headline: Peru Drug Fund Used in War, Aide Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/21/world.body_text: **********The State Department's chief narcotics specialist acknowledged to Congress today that millions of dollars in American drug-control aid to Peru would be used in part to fight leftist guerrilla groups that are said to protect coca growers and traffickers. **********''I want to be very frank in saying that where the insurgency and the drug traffickers are inextricably bound together, we have to deal with them together,'' said the official, Melvyn Levitsky, Assistant Secretary of State for international narcotics matters. ''We have an interest in helping them fight that insurgency.'' **********Mr. Levitsky's comments in testimony before a House Foreign Affaars subcommittee drew a sharp, skeptical response from the panel's acting chairman, Representative Peter H. Kostmayer, who questioned whether the United States, which has already assigned military trainers to Peru, was being drawn into a counterinsurgency war that ''we cannot win.'' **********Wary of Guerrilla Wars **********''I continue to have grave doubts about the militarization of the Andean anti-narcotics effort,'' said Mr. Kostmayer, a Pennsylvania Democrat. ''Are we getting the United States involved through the back door in fighting guerrilla wars?'' **********The Bush Administration has committed $35 million in military aid to Peru in what American officials acknowledge privately, but rarely confirm publicly, is an effort to assist the Peruvian Government in its decade-old struggle with the Shining Path, a brutal guerrilla group that controls large parts of the country and seeks to impose a worker-peasant state. **********The newly elected President of Peru, Alberto Fujimori, has not yet said whether he will accept the American aid package. **********U.S. Officials Optimistic **********State Department officials who spoke on condition that they not be identified said the Administration was optimistic that Mr. Fujimori would eventually be persuaded to accept United States military aid, including assistance from additional American military trainers, in combating the Shining Path, or Sendero Luminoso. **********''The Sendero Luminoso is a major part of the drug picture,'' Mr. Levitsky said at today's hearing of the House panel, the Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Western Hemisphere affairs. ''They protect the drug traffickers. They negotiate between the growers and the traffickers and increasingly they are engaged in drug trafficking themselves.'' **********Mr. Levitsky insisted that American military involvement in Peru would be limited, and that American military trainers would not join in combat operations against drug traffickers. **********Today's debate in the House subcommittee came after a newly released private study, sponsored in part by the State Department, that predicts a military coup in Peru and identifies a growing threat from the Shining Path. **********The report, which was prepared by the Rand Corporation, a California-based research organization that often serves as a Government consultant, found that because of political and economic turmoil in Peru, ''the real question is not whether there will be a coup but when.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/busin.main_headline: C.D. and Bank Fund Yields Are Mostly Down for Week
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/busin.print_headline: C.D. and Bank Fund Yields Are Mostly Down for Week
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/busin.body_text: **********Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were mostly down for the week ended yesterday. **********Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor, a publication that tracks bank deposit rates, continue to see further erosion in C.D. yields. Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, notes that the longer bank rates remain nearly flat, the slower their movement up or down when rates do change. ''This is the longest consecutive period without interest rates making a significant adjustment in the seven and a half years of banking deregulation,'' Mr. Heady said. **********At the Treasury's regular weekly bill auction held Monday, interest rates declined moderately. The auction results are widely recognized as having an influence over what many banks may eventually pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposit. **********The average discount rate for the new three-month bill declined 11 basis points, to 7.69 percent, while the six-month bill dropped 12 basis points, to 7.62 percent. **********In the weekly survey of New York area banks and savings institutions, yields offered on money market accounts were unchanged to down. And the declines were only slight. **********Analysts noted that commercial banks continue to move faster in lowering their yields than the savings and loan institutions. Commercial banks dropped yields by 2 basis points on their money market accounts, to 6.35 percent; three-month certificates to 7.93 percent, and six-month certificates to 8.04 percent. **********At the savings institutions the yield on a money market account declined, but rose by a basis point, to 8.15 percent, for a three-month C.D. and by the same amount on a six-month C.D., to 8.26 percent. **********Among 20 large banks nationwide, average yields dropped a basis point, to 6.47 percent, on money market accounts and by 2 basis points, to 7.80 percent, on six-month certificates. **********The outlook this week at some of the large credit unions in the country is similar. Money market accounts are down an average 2 basis points, to 6.68 percent, and a six-month certificate is off by a basis point, to 8.07 percent. **********The longer maturities on the average are unchanged. A one-year is 8.25 percent, a two-and-a-half-year is 8.31 percent and the five-year maturities are at 8.35 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/02/busin.body_text: **********Purchasers in the biggest savings and loan bailout of 1988 are enjoying millions of dollars of risk-free profits and regulators should renegotiate the deal, Senator Howard Metzenbaum said today. **********The Ohio Democrat said a Federal Home Loan Bank of Dallas memorandum obtained by his Senate Judiciary antitrust subcommittee showed that taxpayers likely would have been better off if regulators liquidated the First Gibraltar Bank of Houston rather than bailing it out in December 1988. **********Instead of liquidating, the regulators pledged $5 billion in future aid and $1.2 billion in tax benefits to Ronald O. Perelman, the New York financier, and other investors, who put up $315 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/01/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation today reported a 47 percent decline in second-quarter profits, reflecting lower vehicle shipments and the increased cost of offering bigger incentives to car and truck buyers. **********The same two factors also depressed the quarterly earnings reported last week by the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation. **********Chrysler's results were generally in line with analysts' forecasts, and Chrysler shares closed unchanged at $15.125 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Chrysler officials told analysts today at a meeting in New York that a third-quarter loss, which had been expected because of a halt in mini-van production while plants are retooled for new models, would be greater than many on Wall Street had predicted. $222 Million Loss Estimated David Healy, an analyst with Barclays deZoete Wedd, said Chrysler would lose approximately $222 million, or about $1 a share, in the third quarter. Other analysts' estimates ranged from 80 cents to $1 a share. Prior to the meeting analysts had anticipated a loss of about 65 cents a share. **********The earnings report came as Chrysler was in a third week of negotiations with the United Auto Workers union on a new contract. **********At the meeting with analysts, Chrysler had some other surprises as well. It said it had taken a quarterly charge against earnings of approximately $22 million to partly cover the cost of ending a joint venture with Renault, the French car company. The company also told analysts that its second-quarter pension costs were $22 million higher than than those in the first quarter for some hourly and salaried workers who retired early. **********Analysts Disappointed **********Chrysler said its financial services subsidiary contributed $85 million or 47 percent of the company's net income in the second quarter. But Jack V. Kirnan, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York, and other analysts said they were disappointed that the company did not earn more from its automotive operations. **********''I find it quite disturbing that Chrysler's operating profit was not higher, given the fact that the company cut $250 million from its costs during the quarter,'' Mr. Kirnan said. ''It goes to show how badly Chrysler could use overseas operations, which it doesn't have.'' **********Chrysler's factory sales of cars and trucks fell 15.8 percent in the second quarter, to 585,615 vehicles. Auto makers record revenues and earn profits when they ship cars from factories to dealers. **********Chrysler reported a second-quarter profit of $180 million, or 81 cents a share, down 47 percent from $341 million, or $1.46 a share in the same period last year. Revenue was $8.8 billion, down 10.1 percent from $9.8 billion in the comparable period last year. **********All three domestic auto makers have responded to growing competition in the North American market by discounting their cars and trucks through cash rebates and cut-rate financing offered to customers. **********Higher incentive costs were partly responsible for the drop in G.M.'s quarterly profit, which fell 38 percent to $900 million, and for the decline in Ford's profit, down 45 percent to $770.7 million. **********Chrysler's incentives were the highest of the Big Three, averaging $1,250 for each car and truck sold in the second quarter, and totaling $780 million over the three months ended in June. **********Chrysler said it spent $780 million on incentives in the second quarter, $180 million more than it spent in the comparable period a year earlier, or about $500 more for each vehicle sold. **********''If not for the huge year-to-year increase in per-unit incentive costs, we would have made more money this quarter than we did in the second quarter of 1989,'' said Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman. **********No Profit on Gulfstream Sale **********Although Chysler was able to sell its Gulfstream Aerospace subsidiary in March for $825 million, the company said its pretax gain of $40 million from the sale was entirely offset by an equal amount of income tax on the transaction. As a result, ''on an after-tax basis, we made no money on sale of Gulfstream,'' said Jerome B. York, executive vice president, finance at Chrysler. **********Chrysler executives acknowledged that it had become harder to find investors willing to buy the short-term debt securities issued by Chrysler's financial subsidiary since the company's debt was downgraded by credit agencies in late June. The debt securities, or commercial paper, are used by Chrysler to finance auto loans to dealers and retail customers. **********In the last month, Chrysler has been forced to repay holders of its commercial paper whose investment policies preclude them from holding debt securities rated at Chrysler's current BBB- rating, the lowest investment-grade rating. **********Chrysler's financial subsidiary has borrowed $3.5 billion through credit lines it has established with banks to pay off holders of its commercial paper, said John T. Tierney, chairman of Chrysler Finance. **********The cost to Chrysler will be approximately $25 million over 12 months, Mr. Tierney said, partly reflecting the higher interest rates Chrysler must pay on its bank borrowings since its debt was downgraded. **********The action ''will reduce gross profit for Chrysler's Financial subsidiary,'' said Joseph Phillippi, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York. **********Mr. Phillippi said the action by Chrysler did not threaten the survival or viability of the financial subsidiary, ''but this makes it more expensive for them to operate.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/01/world.main_headline: Iraqi Envoy Calls Bush's Bid For Talks 'Important Step'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/01/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; Iraqi Envoy Calls Bush's Bid For Talks 'Important Step'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/01/world.body_text: **********Iraqi officials reacted with surprise and enthusiasm tonight to President Bush's offer to hold direct talks with Iraq in an effort to avoid war over Kuwait. **********Although there was no immediate response from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Baghdad's Ambassador to France said, "This is a very important step and we hope it is going to achieve what we are all striving for: negotiations instead of beating the drums of war." **********The Ambassador, Abdul Razak al-Hashimi, was speaking on a British Broadcasting Corporation radio program monitored in Amman. **********Another Iraqi official, reached by phone in Baghdad, said President Bush's offer to meet with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq and to dispatch Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to the Iraqi capital was "the first good news from Washington in months." **********The Iraqi official, who spoke on the condition that he not be named, said he was optimistic that President Hussein would welcome the opportunity to meet with American officials to reach a peaceful settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis. "This is what we have been saying for some time now, that we want talks," he said. **********Because of the eight-hour time difference between the Iraqi capital and Washington, word of President Bush's announcement did not reach Baghdad until early evening, leaving little time to prepare an official response today, the Iraqis said. **********In recent days, President Hussein has called on the Bush Administration to open talks over Kuwait's future, although the Iraqi leader has yet to say that his forces would eventually be willing to withdraw from Kuwait. **********Until his announcement today, President Bush had insisted that he would refuse to negotiate with Iraq until after Iraqi forces had withdrawn from Kuwait unconditionally. **********Mr. Bush's offer to hold direct talks with Iraq came a day after the United Nations Security Council authorized the use of force against Iraq if Iraqi forces do not leave Kuwait by Jan. 15. Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, setting off a crisis that has threatened to escalate into war. U.N. Resolution Denounced **********Earlier in the day, before President Bush's announcement, the Iraqi Government said in a defiant statement read on Baghdad radio that the United Nations resolution was "illegal and invalid." The statement said the resolution was "an American document from start to finish" and accused the Bush Administration of bribing other nations for their votes. **********"Money was paid to a number of governments of Security Council members and immense pressure was put on them from the President of the United States and his Secretary of State," the statement said. The resolution, it added, "is disgraceful and tarnishes with shame the nations which helped issue it." **********Similar criticism of the resolution was offered today by senior officials in the Jordanian Government and within the Palestine Liberation Organization.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/02/busin.main_headline: The Failure of Traditional Law Schools
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/02/busin.print_headline: FORUM;   The Failure of Traditional Law Schools
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/02/busin.body_text: **********The popular assumptions that legal education transfers specialized information about the practice of law and teaches law students how to do legal work are misconceived. Likewise, the imagined stereotype of the masterful law professor transferring nuggets of wisdom through an intellectually rigorous Socratic dialogue is largely a product of fiction. **********The law student does, of course, learn some hard doctrinal law - torts, contracts and so forth. It is inevitable and unavoidable. But the essential doctrinal rules are readily compressed into a six-week bar review course after law school. It is from these courses that many law students ultimately learn the rules necessary to obtain professional certification. What then does the law school do? **********First, law schools baptize students in the traditional approach modeled on the study of law-as-a-science. This approach, developed in 1870 by Christopher Langdell, a Harvard Law School dean, takes place within the ''laboratory'' of the casebook study of appellate cases. Appellate decisions are based on a re-examination of law; they accept the facts of the case as fixed at trial. **********Unfortunately, after graduation most lawyers practice in the factually indeterminate world of the trial attorney, rather than in the legally indeterminate world of the appellate attorney. **********Second, the appellate cases studied exclusively in the traditional law school curriculum come at the end of the litigation process. Law schools thus implicitly present litigation as the norm and the focus of professional practice. This presumption that litigation is the proper and exclusive mechanism for legal dispute resolution is wrong. Litigation is a poor mechanism for resolving most legal disputes; it is expensive, time-consuming and often harrowing. **********Some law schools have significantly modified the traditional curriculum. In the Lawyering Program at New York University Law School, first-year law students learn to cope with the problems of clients who have not yet entered the litigious universe depicted in the appellate cases. Using role-playing, videotaped clinical simulations and factually complex problems set in the time-frame that occurs prior to trial, the N.Y.U. curriculum emphasizes negotiation, interpersonal relationships and non-litigatory mechanisms for dispute resolution. **********These students are acculturated into the practicing attorney's complex world in which the legal rules may be merely a shell of straightforward propositions and the primary difficulties may be rooted in conflicting relationships. They learn to marshal facts into coherent stories that fit into readily identifiable legal categories. **********Unfortunately, only a few law schools are implementing such programs, even though there is a growing realization among lawyers and scholars of the law that current institutional pedagogy is woefully misshapen for the purpose of training competent attorneys. **********It is all of us who pay the price for perpetuating today's law school curriculum. But even more important, law students are not trained to engage in the creative open-ended thought processes and cooperative non-adversarial thinking often required to resolve legal problems effectively.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/30/world.main_headline: Toward the Summit: Reporter's Notebook;   The Gorbachev Show Must Go On
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/30/world.print_headline: Toward the Summit: Reporter's Notebook;   The Gorbachev Show Must Go On
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/30/world.body_text: **********Despite all the down-to-the-second planning of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's supposedly spontaneous walkabout today, the Soviet President briefly confounded the plans of security guards and well-wishers alike. He was 20 minutes late, didn't stop in the designated spot, and then just stayed and stayed. **********As more than a thousand people waited behind steel barricades, Mr. Gorbachev's limousine slowed down at the secure area where his trademark visit with the people was to start and then suddenly speeded up. The crowds thought at first that he had been taken aback by the handful of Lithuanian and Estonian flags waved by a few demonstrators mingled in the waiting crowds. **********But Mr. Gorbachev did stop after all. He got out of his car 15 yards down the street, then waded into an excited mob, smiling, calm and fully confident. **********He leaned across a parked car, placed his hands on the hood and said, ''I see you're all in a good mood.'' **********With Raisa Gorbachev at his side, he then fielded questions from an excited group, also managing to autograph books and shake hands. **********One young man from Lithuania asked him about the situation in that Baltic republic, which has declared independence from Moscow. Mr. Gorbachev said: ''We feel we could be in a very difficult situation. Let's sit down and do it in a constitutional fashion.'' **********Another man, Thomas Kovacs, 22 years old, shouted out, ''I'm Hungarian! Thank you for liberating my country!'' **********Mr. Gorbachev paused a beat and said, ''Thank you.'' **********Most of the questions were softballs, and even the hard questions were asked in soft voices. Mr. Gorbachev's answers, too, were intended to please the crowd ''You should know that your country is a neighbor and that we have many things in common,'' he told his admiring listeners, many of them applauding. He shook hands all around. **********Mr. Gorbachev permitted himself one joke. He told a crowd of Canadians: ''I made an important proposal to the Governor General. Anyone who lives and breathes the clean air here should be tax free.'' The crowd laughed. He said, ''You have too many taxes, I presume.'' **********Surprise! Surprise! **********For weary officials in Ottawa, Mr. Gorbachev's surprise meeting with ordinary citizens was about as spontaneous as the sun rising in the east. **********The Soviet advance team that traveled to Ottawa two weeks ago to prepare Mr. Gorbachev's visit made it gloomily clear from the start: Our Man Always Does This. **********The rest was planning. Canadian security forces took a dim view of the Soviet advance team's first choice, a noisy, crowded and colorful open-air vegetable market in the heart of Ottawa. The Russians, Canadian officials say, were crestfallen at the word nyet. **********They rallied when the Canadians suggested a more practical alternative, Sparks Street, a pedestrian lane of shops and cafes in a more easily protected section of downtown Ottawa. **********Timing was always an issue. The Russians preferred late afternoon, but late afternoon in downtown Ottawa, after government employees race home to their suburbs in droves, might as well be midnight for crowd value. **********Could we announce the spontaneous stop ahead of time, say, in the morning? asked the Canadians, wanting to insure enthusiastic crowds. **********''Absolutely not,'' a Canadian official quoted the Russians as saying. ''This is supposed to be spontaneous.'' They split the difference by agreeing to inform local radio stations at 4 P.M. **********Boris N. Yeltsin, Mr. Gorbachev's political rival, tried to expose this trick in his autobiography ''Against the Grain,'' explaining how the signature Gorbachev meet-the-people stops were so meticulously planned that in some Soviet provinces local dissidents were arrested in advance. **********Soviet citizens may have wearied of the trick, but Westerners love the gimmickry. ''We've been flooded with calls, people asking, where will he stop, where can we see him,'' a Canadian official said. **********And He Said 'Hi,' Too **********Mr. Gorbachev gave another version of a spontaneous stop after his arrival ceremony at the Uplands International Airport outside Ottawa. After reviewing the guards, signing the guest book, and greeting his Canadian hosts, Mr. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, walked over to a pen where some 1,000 waving and giggling Canadian elementary schoolchildren waited expectantly. Mr. Gorbachev surveyed the sea of Day-Glo pink beanies and lime-yellow T-shirts and bravely waded in. **********He smiled and shook hands, then smiled and shook more hands. ''I talked to him,'' one fifth grader, Lisa Dutil, said authoritatively. ''I said 'hi,' and then I said 'yo,' and then I said 'peace.' He said 'hi' back.'' **********Vishal Vasdey, who is 10 years old, felt he could speak for his entire school. ''We all think he's a nice guy,'' he said of Mr. Gorbachev, ''He let people vote, and he let McDonald's go to the Soviet Union.'' **********Rachel Duern, a sixth grader, didn't actually speak to the Soviet President because she was too intent on getting his autograph. She succeeded. His scrawled signature, she said, would go into a place of honor in her autograoh book, right after ''Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck, other people, and my family.'' **********The Guest That Wasn't **********James Wormington Jr., whose house faces the main road from the airport, decided to try to tempt Mr. Gorbachev to come to him. He strung a huge handwritten sign above his porch that said, in Russian: ''Greetings, Mr. Gorbachev. Come in for a beer,'' hung out the Canadian flag, set a table with an ice-cold beer and two glassses, sat down and waited for the motorcade to pass. **********Mr. Wormington, a high school math teacher, thought it just might work. ''He always makes impromptu stops, so I figured this might be one of them. If he can stop in New York City, he can certainly stop off here.'' **********Mr. Wormington swore he saw the Soviet limousines slow down as they passed. ''I think Shevardnadze gave me the thumbs-up sign,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   LITHUANIANS HALT SOVIET SHIPMENTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   LITHUANIANS HALT SOVIET SHIPMENTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/world.body_text: **********Lithuania announced today that it had cut off meat and milk exports to Soviet customers in retaliation for a Kremlin economic embargo, and offered to barter farm products directly with Soviet cities now controlled by political insurgents. **********The Lithuanian Prime Minister, Kazimiera Prunskiene, who heads a new ''anti-blockade'' commission, said the breakaway republic had proposed independent trade relations with the cities of Moscow, Leningrad and Lvov, where political upstarts wrested control from the Communist Party in recent local elections. **********The tactic seemed unlikely to bring relief from the Kremlin's seven-day oil and natural gas embargo, which has already caused industry to lay off thousands of workers and generated a flourishing black market in gasoline. **********An Effect on Soviet Union **********''This is science fiction,'' one Lithuanian member of Parliament scoffed privately after listening to the Government's latest plan. **********But the move may help mobilize political support for the renegade republic in Soviet cities where newly elected insurgent majorities backed Lithuanian independence. **********Already there are signs that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's blockade is pinching neighboring regions of the Soviet Union, which depend heavily on gasoline and oil from the Mazeikiai refinery in Lithuania. Mazeikiai, now choked to a standstill by the oil cutoff, also supplies oil to parts of Latvia, Estonia and the Kaliningrad and Pskov regions of the Russian republic. **********Jobs in Jeopardy **********A member of the Leningrad City Council, Aleksandr Seryakov, said today that the jobs of 18,000 garment workers were in danger because they depend on fabrics from Lithuania,and other factories that use components from Lithuania are now slowing down. **********Mr. Seryakov, who visited Lithuania last week, said that the Leningrad Council was interested in direct barter of their industrial products and metals for Lithuanian food, but that it was ''unrealistic'' to think this could be organized quickly. **********Moscow repeated today that it would not begin negotiations with the Lithuanians until they had repealed or suspended their declaration of independence, made March 11, and accepted the Soviet Constitution's pre-eminence. **********A Soviet Procedure **********Yevgeny M. Primakov, a member of Mr. Gorbachev's cabinet, told the Soviet press agency Tass, ''talks between Moscow and Vilnius on Lithuania's secession can begin only if Lithuania withdraws to the March 10 line, that is, the day before Lithuania proclaimed independence.'' **********Moscow insists Lithuania can have its independence, but only by following a secession law enacted in April, which calls for approval by referendum, a transition of up to five years in which the republic must satisfy all financial and territorial claims, and final approval by the Soviet Congress of Peoples Deputies. **********Lithuania has offered to amend laws passed since March 11 and to consider some kind of freeze on the putting of independence into effect as part of a negotiated settlement, but it refuses to revert to Soviet sovereignty. The Lithuanians say they need not follow Soviet laws because the republic's forced annexation by Stalin in 1940 was illegal. **********A delegation sent to Moscow by Vilnius has had no official contact except for a phone call from Mr. Primakov advising them to go home until they are willing to play by Soviet rules. **********Extensive Hoarding **********Reports from Lithuania today described extensive hoarding of food staples and black-market gasoline brought from neighboring Soviet Byelorussia selling for up to 20 times the official price in some cities. **********Assertions by Lithuanian officials that the oil and gas embargo had expanded to a total economic blockade were denied by Moscow officials, and appeared to be exaggerated. **********The chief railroad dispatcher in Vilnius, Kestutis Juras, said in a telephone interview tonight that cargo handlers in Vilnius who normally unload 1,200 incoming boxcars a day were now handling about 600. Oil products, steel and citrus fruits were the main cargoes that had stopped arriving, he said. **********The Lithuanian Parliament today adopted a package of emergency measures, including the cutoff of meat and milk exports not only to central Soviet distribution centers but to military installations in Lithuanian areas. **********Officials said the republic exported 8,000 tons of meat a month to Moscow and 4,000 tons to Leningrad, plus dairy products, enough to be felt in cities where consumers already complain of empty shelves. **********Since the embargo began officials from Leningrad, Lvov in the western Ukraine, and the Moldavian capital of Kishinev have been among those traveling to Vilnius to explore direct economic ties. **********Prime Minister Prunskiene said oilworkers in the Siberian petroleum region of Tyumen had also expressed interest in trading oil and gas for scarce food supplies, although how it would be carried out through Moscow-controlled pipelines was hard to imagine. **********Mrs. Prunskiene has had no success with appeals to Western countries for help during the embargo. She said that with Lithuania's foreign-currency accounts frozen by Moscow, the republic would have to rely on donations, barter or credit if it finds foreign suppliers. **********Lithuanian officials said that 7,500 people were unemployed in the republic of 3.7 million because of shutdowns forced by the energy embargo, and that the number was expected to hit 35,000 by early May.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/17/world.main_headline: EARLIER HARM SEEN IN GLOBAL WARMING
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/17/world.print_headline: EARLIER HARM SEEN IN GLOBAL WARMING
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/17/world.body_text: **********After two years of study, an international group of scientists working under United Nations auspices has found that global warming could cause serious environmental damage starting in the early years of the next century, long before the maximum temperature levels predicted by many scientists are reached. **********And for the first time, they recommended establishing limits beyond which the average global temperature and sea level should not be permitted to rise, lest the world be subjected to serious and ever-increasing risks. **********These limits are well below the levels that another international scientific panel said last June will ultimately result if heat-trapping gases, mainly carbon dioxide, continue to pour into the atmosphere at the present rate. **********A report issued yesterday also includes a detailed analysis of measures that might bring the expected warming under control and concludes that if the measures are aggressively pursued, the limits can be achieved. **********Steps Toward Formal Treaty **********The conclusions, recommendations and supporting analyses will furnish grist for the Second World Climate Conference starting in Geneva on Oct. 29, a gathering sponsored by the United Nations at which governments from around the world expect to take the first steps toward what they hope will be a formal treaty aimed at controlling global warming. **********Two international groups of scientists have been studying the problem, both with United Nations sponsorship. One, operating as part of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, was formed in late 1988 to advise the governments attending the World Climate Conference. The other, which was formed in 1986 and was the progenitor of the intergovernmental panel, has no government affiliation but rather is an association of independent scientists called the Advisory Group on Greenhouse Gases. **********The independent group's report, issued yesterday in London, Stockholm and New York, goes beyond the scientific assessment of the intergovernmental panel, made public last June, in attempting to set targets for the control of global warming. **********Among the practical measures that the scientists said might be taken to limit the warming were improved energy efficiency, greater reliance on natural gas, reforestation and the adoption of alternative energy sources that are both technologically and economically feasible. The sources include solar, wind, geothermal and biomass technologies. ''Limiting emissions so we can stay below the minimums should be attainable,'' said Michael Oppenheimer, senior scientist for the Environmental Defense Fund, who was the chairman of the working group on control measures. **********Rate of Increase Forecast **********In June, the scientists advising the intergovernmental group predicted that under what it called the ''business as usual'' scenario, the average global temperature would rise by nearly two degrees Fahrenheit by the year 2025 and by more than five degrees by the end of the next century. The rate of increase, which scientists say is as important as the absolute increase because of the difficulty of adjusting to rapid climatic change, was predicted at about half a degree per decade. **********In the report issued yesterday, the independent scientists said that to minimize the risk of environmental damage, the rate of increase should be held below one-fifth of a degree per decade. **********An absolute increase beyond 1990 of more than about two degrees above pre-industrial levels, it said, ''may elicit rapid, unpredictable and non-linear responses that could lead to extensive ecosystem damage.'' Non-linear responses refer, for example, to sudden jumps in global temperature rather than even, gradual increases. **********The report last June of the intergovernmental scientific panel said that the world has already warmed by about half a degree to one degree since the industrial age began, but scientists do not know whether this rise was caused by greenhouse gases emitted as a result of human activity or whether it is attributable to natural climatic variability and therefore, possibly, is temporary. **********'Severe Impacts' Without Action **********The report said that the atmosphere may already contain enough heat-trapping gases to push the global temperature above the two-degree target. ''This means that unless we take very prompt and significant actions to reduce greenhouse emissions, we're very likely to experience severe impacts,'' said Peter Gleick, a co-chairman of the working group dealing with targets. He directs the global environmental programs of the Pacific Institute in Berkeley, Calif., a non-profit research institute. **********The report established an ''upper limit'' of about 3.5 degrees in temperature increase since the start of the industrial age ''beyond which the risks of grave damage to ecosystems, and of non-linear responses, are expected to increase rapidly.'' **********While the voluminous study was reviewed in detail by other scientists before it was issued, not all authorities were initially prepared to give it unqualified endorsement. **********''It sounds as if they've taken the worst-case scenarios and tried to make the case for a maximum effort,'' said William D. Nordhaus, a Yale University economist who cautioned that he had not yet had a chance to read the report. He has been the chairman or co-chairman of a number of National Academy of Sciences panels looking into global warming.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/09/busin.main_headline: Your Money;   Burden of Loads On Mutual Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/09/busin.print_headline: Your Money;   Burden of Loads On Mutual Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Loads, as mutual fund fees are known, are aptly named. They can certainly weigh down a fund's return to shareholders. **********This is not to say investors should buy only no-load funds. Some funds' superior performance can more than offset their loads. The Fidelity Magellan Fund under the legendary Peter Lynch is the outstanding example of the past decade. The fund, which has a 3 percent load, posted a total return averaging 23.9 percent a year for the decade, well ahead of a 14.8 percent average annual return by the issues in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index. **********But the majority of equity funds underperform the index, just as a majority of bond funds underperform bond indexes in total return. One reason is the funds' management expenses, as well as the loads that some charge and the 12b-1 fees - annual assessments for selling and advertising costs, named for the section of the securities law that authorizes them - that some funds charge. Rating services generally base total return numbers on capital appreciation and dividend after expenses but before loads. **********''Any investor should be the educated consumer,'' said Joel S. Isaacson, the partner who is in charge of personal financial planning for Weber Lipshie & Company, certified public accountants, in New York. ''Both blatant costs and hidden costs'' like an annual 12b-1 fee or a load on reinvested dividends ''can be a major differential in what a fund yields,'' he said. **********Like many financial advisers who recommend but do not sell products, he often recommends the Vanguard family of funds in Valley Forge, Pa., as the low-cost producer. Its bond fund expenses are around a third of a percentage point, and Mr. Isaacson noted that for a bond fund particularly, keeping expenses 60 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, lower than many competitors can make a big difference in return. **********Tim Kochis, national director of executive financial counseling for Deloitte & Touche in San Francisco, said he often recommended stock-index mutual funds to clients because of ''relatively low cost, automatic diversification and automatic record keeping with reinvested capital gains and dividends.'' **********He contends that it is unrealistic for most investors to think they can beat the market over the long term. The way to keep up is to buy into a fund that mirrors the S.&P. index. Its management fees will be low because a computer essentially replaces a portfolio manager and research staff. ''You maximize profits by keeping costs as low as posible,'' Mr. Kochis said. This is appropriate for long-term needs like I.R.A., Keogh or other retirement plans, but it is not a universal recommendation, he added. For some people with high levels of discretionary income, it can be appropriate to put some money into higher-risk funds with the potential for higher reward. Then the impact of any loads and 12b-1 fees must be considered, given the investment's projected duration. **********T. Rowe Price, the Baltimore-based manager of no-load funds, released a study this week showing the impact of loads and 12b-1 fees over 25 years, assuming a 10 percent annual return. If $10,000 was put into a no-load fund, it would grow to $108,347. In a fund with an 8.5 percent load, the maximum permitted by law, it would grow to $99,138. In a no-load fund with a 1 percent annual 12b-1 fee, it would reach $86,231. **********''A 12b-1 can be insidious over time,'' said Steven E. Norwitz, vice president of Price, ''and our studies show most people hold funds 10 years or more.'' **********The totals accumulated for 25 years for $2,000 invested annually are $216,364 for a no-load, $197,973 for an 8.5 percent load, and $184,648 for a no-load with a 1 percent 12b-1 fee. Generally, no-load funds are marketed directly by management companies, as are some low-load funds. Load funds are sold by brokers who spend time with the client. The load is a sales commission; it is not related to the portfolio manager's skill. **********There may be front-end loads, which reduce the amount of money going to work for an investor from the start, or back-end loads, sometimes referred to as redemption or exit fees. There may also be deferred sales charges, a type of back-end load that may be 5 percent or 6 percent if shares are redeemed after a short holding period, but decreases over time. And there may be 12b-1 fees. All funds also have management expenses. **********All fees and expenses must be shown in a standard table in the first few pages of a fund's prospectus under S.E.C. regulations, so an investor would be well advised to study the prospectus.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/26/busin.main_headline: Ad About Pantheon Leads to Quarrel Between Publishers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/26/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Ad About Pantheon Leads to Quarrel Between Publishers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/26/busin.body_text: **********A provocative advertisement in The New York Review of Books has strained relations between two of America's leading publishers, Random House Inc. and Farrar, Straus & Giroux. **********The full-page advertisement, which appealed for new authors to come to Hill & Wang, an imprint of Farrar, Straus, denounced "the sorry destruction of Pantheon Books," an imprint of Random House. It was signed by Arthur J. Rosenthal, the former head of the Harvard University Press and now the publisher of Hill & Wang. **********Mr. Rosenthal was clearly referring to the dismissal earlier this year of Andre Schiffrin, who headed Pantheon for 28 years before being replaced in March by Fred Jordan. For Mr. Schiffrin and the eight Pantheon editors who quit in sympathy with him, his dismissal was a case of the corprate bulldozer blocking an important channel for contrary voices. 38 Books on the Spring List **********Random House, however, has said the departure of Mr. Schiffrin was the consequence of Pantheon's losses and emphasized its commitment to maintaining the imprint. Pantheon has just published a spring list, with 38 books on it. "There has been no sellout," Erroll McDonald, Pantheon's executive editor, has said. **********Reacting to the Hill & Wang statement, Alberto Vitale, the chief executive of Random House, said: "The advertisement is in terribly bad taste. I am shocked that a man of the stature of Arthur Rosenthal would do something like that." **********Mr. Jordan of Pantheon added: "It's not the sort of thing I'd do. I'm surprised. The fact is that we are very much alive." **********Roger Straus, the chairman of Farrar, Straus, reiterated the advertisement's message, saying that he thought Pantheon had been effectively dismembered and that "the firing of Mr. Schiffrin was not the most marvelously diplomatic thing I've ever seen." **********He said Pantheon's current list was largely an attempt to deal with the public relations problems that stemmed from the departure of Mr. Schiffrin. **********Mr. Rosenthal declined to comment on the advertisement, which sought to differentiate Hill & Wang from imprints like Pantheon that are part of large corporations. Hill & Wang, the ad said, would represent "freshness of spirit, freedom from corporate constraints or a computer model making the publishing decisions." **********Sara Bershtel, a former Pantheon editor, has come to Hill & Wang as executive editor, bringing several Pantheon authors with her. **********Both Random House and Farrar, Straus are privately held companies that do not disclose their sales or profits. But Random House is a far bigger enterprise and part of S. I. Newhouse Jr.'s media empire, Advance Publications Inc. **********The Pantheon dispute that the advertisement revives has never entirely died down. It has been fanned by a prominent article in an August issue of Publishers Weekly criticizing Mr. Schiffrin, and by a continuing debate over whether big corporations are quashing variety in publishing.
