Stilgenbauer, vice president and chief financial officer of its Brooks Drug Inc. subsidiary, to president of its Superx Drugs division. Mr. Stilgenbauer replaces Gary Hendren, who is on special assignment for the parent company's chief executive. *********** Lorillard Inc., New York, a tobacco company that is a subsidiary of Loews Corp., promoted Katie Augustyn and Victor Lindley, senior brand managers, to group brand directors. *********** Nynex Corp., New York, the telecommunications company, appointed Graham Darley managing director of its Asian/Pacific operations. *********** Sterling Drug Inc., New York, a unit of Eastman Kodak Co., named Charles M. Mayr assistant director of external communications. *********** U S West Inc., Englewood, Colo., the holding company for communications subsidiaries, appointed Alain Treille vice president of international operations for its marketing resources group.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/busin.body_text: **********SLOW and steady may win some races, but not the ones where the Safety-Kleen Corporation has been involved. **********Safety-Kleen made its mark by moving rapidly to build the only nationwide network for reclaiming waste solvents and other fluids from auto body shops, dry cleaners and other small businesses, then steadily signing up clients to the point that it now makes more than 15,000 pickups daily from about 250,000 customers. **********The payoff: Safety-Kleen racked up earnings gains of more than 20 percent for 18 straight years from 1970 through 1988. No company has ever reported such strong earnings growth over such a long period. **********But Safety-Kleen stumbled last year, if earnings growth of 8.6 percent -- to $46 million on revenues of $478.1 million -- can be called stumbling. **********Since then, Donald W. Brinckman, Safety-Kleen's chief executive throughout the marathon of success, has been anxious to prove that Safety-Kleen can pick up where it left off. The company is pouring money into plants and collection systems for recycling used oil and a wider variety of chemicals, anticipating that quick expansion of capacity will bring a return to growth rates of 20 percent during the environmentally conscious 1990's. This year, the earnings growth rate is expected to top 15 percent. **********Investors seem to be betting that Mr. Brinckman can pull it off. Safety-Kleen shares have a price-to-earnings ratio about double the market average, among the highest in the popular waste-handling segment. Last week, Safety-Kleen completed a public offering of three million new shares of its common stock at $33.50 per share. This will allow the company to retire enough debt to cut pre-tax interest expenses by $8 million next year, according to Robert Willm-schen, the company's vice president of finance. **********"Money managers love this company and won't listen to analysts who say that it has become overvalued compared to others in the environmental group," said Vishnu Swarup, who follows environmental stocks for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. **********Safety-Kleen fell on its version of hard times when its older businesses could not grow fast enough to support its heavy capital investment in new businesses. And some of the new ventures, particularly oil recycling, have developed more slowly than the company hoped. **********"We could see the break coming, but there was still some disappointment," said Mr. Brinckman, a 59-year-old executive who combines a taste for strategy with the drive and imposing bulk of a linebacker. **********Mr. Brinckman hopes the company will return to its old growth rate in 1991, when a $55 million refinery the company is building in East Chicago for processing used oil into lube oil and fuel comes on line. **********The rapid rise in oil prices brought on by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait will undoubtedly help, but Safety-Kleen is stifling the natural urge to raise at a comparable clip the price of reclaimed oil from its existing refinery in Breslau, Ontario. **********"We are not attempting to optimize our earnings based on the oil price rise," said Joseph F. Knott, the company's president and chief operating officer. "We are not in this for the short term." **********One reason for moving slowly on pricing is that Safety-Kleen needs to persuade big oil companies to buy its re-refined oil and sell it under their own names. Safety-Kleen, which is based in this industrial city 35 miles west of Chicago, has neither the marketing expertise nor the name recognition among lube oil buyers to easily unload all the oil it hopes to reclaim. **********THE company already collects 80 million gallons of used motor oil and industrial lubricants annually from 65,000 customers, but that represents a small fraction of the total supply, which analysts estimated to be 2 billion gallons annually. The Environmental Protection Agency estimates that 800 million gallons annually are recycled by numerous small companies, some for re-refining and some for blending into fuel oil. **********"Our biggest challenge in this business will be to get the big oil companies to realize that it's in their interest for used oil to be handled in an environmentally sound way and to get them into the circle," said Joseph Chaloub, the Safety-Kleen vice president who manages the oil recovery business from Breslau. **********Safety-Kleen also needs to close the gap between the 17 cents a gallon it costs to collect used oil and the 12 cents it is currently able to charge businesses for picking it up. The company expects the E.P.A. eventually to issue regulations classifying waste oil as a hazardous waste and creating penalties for improper disposal. Then Safety-Kleen figures there would be fewer disposal options, giving it the leverage to raise pickup prices to between 20 and 25 cents a gallon. **********But the E.P.A. has been reluctant to regulate waste oil, in part because much of the oil thrown out is disposed of by individual car owners who would be outside the reach of any regulations it is authorized to adopt. The agency fears that such regulations could backfire -- if service stations charged car owners more for oil changes to cover rising disposal costs, more people might dispose of the oil in the nearest drain. **********Safety-Kleen owes its name to a device for cleaning auto parts invented in Milwaukee in the early 1950's. It was little more than a sink mounted over a barrel filled with solvent and equipped with a pump to shoot the solvent into the sink. A filter below the sink trapped most waste, allowing the solvent to be used many times. **********After first trying to sell the devices, Safety-Kleen's initial owners decided to lease them and charge users for servicing. Several hundred units had been placed in auto shops when Mr. Brinckman, then an executive for Chicago Rawhide Inc., came calling in 1968, looking for companies to acquire that fit in with Rawhide's plans to sell its seals and other parts to the auto parts replacement market. **********MR. BRINCKMAN persuaded Rawhide to buy Safety-Kleen, for $25,000 in cash and $120,000 in assumed debt, describing it as "a Geiger counter for finding people who would buy auto replacement parts." He quickly divided the country into seven regions with 130 service routes and sent teams out on a marketing blitz to sign up customers. The company also instituted a system that allowed route managers to become branch managers and raise their income by adding sales and service representatives. **********Rawhide spun off Safety-Kleen to its shareholders in 1974 and the company went public five years later. Since then, tightening environmental laws have repeatedly increased the value of the company's recycling services, gradually shifting investor perceptions of Safety-Kleen -- and the company's self-image -- from that of a business selling convenience to auto mechanics to that of a leader in the battle to control pollution. **********The most obvious change came in 1984 when Safety-Kleen pounced on the opportunity created by E.P.A. regulations that brought small businesses like dry cleaners under its supervision. Within two years, the company was making monthly pickups of used cleaning fluids and solvents at more than half of the nation's 25,000 dry cleaners. **********The company expanded again by acquiring chemical reclamation businesses, including the McKesson Corporation's Envirosystems subsidiary in 1987. Today, after investing millions of dollars to upgrade McKesson facilities, the company's Fluid Recovery Service can handle nearly 300 different chemicals. The growth of this unit, which became profitable last year on revenues of $22 million, is also giving the company a foot in the door at industrial sites that can use its traditional parts cleaners. **********AS it grows, Safety-Kleen is also seeking more business from bigger waste generators, an effort that has led it to develop a separate sales staff for national accounts. **********"It requires a change of style for us to work on deals that can take two or three years to complete and to talk to coat-and-tie guys," said Mr. Knott, who ran Chemical Waste Management, the nation's leading handler of hazardous waste from large-scale producers, before joining Safety-Kleen in 1987. **********Nevertheless, the company's bedrock customers are likely to remain the dry cleaners, auto body shops and other mom-and-pop generators of waste products. The logistics and accounting involved in managing so many small customers may be daunting for Safety-Kleen, but it also discourages would-be competitors. **********"Nothing we do is easy," said Mr. Brinckman, happily.   LITTLE ROOM FOR RIVALS **********LIFE is rough for the small privately owned independent operators who are the Safety-Kleen Corporation's only competition in its original business of supplying parts-cleaning equipment to garage owners. **********Independents say Safety-Kleen is careful to avoid price cuts that might be called predatory underpricing but quick to match prices of smaller rivals that are gaining market share. **********"Safety-Kleen is pretty ruthless when it comes to competition," said Joseph W. Janecky, whose company, Resolve Industries of Denver, makes parts-cleaning equipment that the independents sell or lease to auto shops. Mr. Janecky once harbored dreams of becoming a strong No. 2 to Safety-Kleen in the equipment-rental and solvent-recycling segment of the business, but ran into financial disagreements with investors that led him to sell his routes in 1988. Not surprisingly, the highest bidder was Safety-Kleen. **********"It takes so much capital," said Mr. Janecky. "And now it takes a ton of lawyers as well to deal with all the regulations." Recently, he hosted a meeting that led 11 of the independents to set up a trade association that will share expertise on dealing with regulations as well as marketing ideas. In all, Mr. Janecky estimated, there are fewer than 25 independents, which together have about 5 percent of the market. **********The independents often offer lower prices than Safety-Kleen and some may be willing to supply a garage owner with customized equipment. Washington Chemical Inc. of Spokane has managed to overtake Safety-Kleen in that eastern Washington city because its local recycling facility allows it to offer a more complete range of services. **********However, the independents' main attraction these days is often simply that they are not Safety-Kleen. "Safety-Kleen has a pretty hard sell when it comes to ancillary products like wheel sealers and hand cleaners," said Mr. Janecky, who said that he admires the company and is a shareholder. "They pester some customers so much they get irritated. And customers want a choice."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/world.main_headline: Mongolia Communists Offer To Resign From Government
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/world.print_headline: Mongolia Communists Offer To Resign From Government
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/world.body_text: **********Mongolia's Communist leaders offered to resign today in the face of protests by thousands of people calling for multiparty democracy, Eastern European press agencies reported from the Mongolian capital, Ulan Bator. **********The East German press agency A.D.N. and the Soviet press agency Tass said a national referendum would be organized to give the people an opportunity to say whether they had confidence in the Mongolian Parliament. **********A.D.N. said the Mongolian Communist Party Politburo had ''given in'' to demands for resignation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/23/world.main_headline: In Polish Race, No Parties Need Apply
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/23/world.print_headline: In Polish Race, No Parties Need Apply
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/23/world.body_text: **********Poland's presidential election campaign, now entering its final stage, has embraced most of the external trappings of democracy, from bumper stickers to posters to opinion polls and last-minute mudslinging. **********But as Poles prepare to vote Sunday in their first free presidential election in 68 years, there is one obviously missing element: national political parties. **********When the Communist Party lost much of its monolithic power more than a year ago, there was a general expectation that it would be replaced by political groups representing the varied and often contradictory interests of such constituencies as farmers, industrial workers and the rising enterpreneurial class. **********Instead, this fall's presidential campaign has been characterized by the politics of personality and a pervasive distrust of organized parties.  An Unexpected Challenger **********This trend is being disclosed by the remarkable showing of Stanislaw Tyminski, an emigre businessman from Canada and Peru, who has come from nowhere in three weeks to mount a serious challenge in public opinion polls. **********Mr. Tyminski was virtually unknown when he announced his candidacy. Moreover, unlike his more established rivals -- Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki -- he played no role in the struggle to overturn Communist rule. **********"In the absence of parties, we have something like the Greens in West Germany or like Proposition 13 in California," said Andrzej Wroblewski, the editor of the Polish financial weekly Gazeta Bankowa. "People here are angry at anyone who could be seen as an authority." **********The latest public opinion poll shows that Mr. Walesa leads with 28 percent of the vote, with Mr. Tyminski at 21 percent and Mr. Mazowiecki at 17 percent. Under the election rules, a second round will be held Dec. 9 if no candidate wins a majority on Nov. 25. Emulating Solidarity **********For the last month, the six candidates in the race have done their best to try to emulate the Solidarity movement, which at the start of the decade was able to attract 10 million members with a program of anti-Communism designed to appeal to all Poles, regardless of their trade, profession, social group or geographic region. **********In interviews, Mr. Walesa always portrays himself as being above or apart from any political parties. **********Mr. Mazowiecki, the candidate with the greatest appeal to the most educated voters, has for his part sought to reach out to rural dwellers by promising telephones in every village within two years and stressing a platform promise that "Polish farmers should have no fears for the future." **********That optimism stands in sharp contrast to the statements of Ryszard Bujak, one of Mr. Mazowiecki's leading supporters, who repeatedly says Poland's economic restructuring requires the bankruptcy of millions of small, inefficient farmers. **********In both the local elections earlier this year and the presidential race, politicians in Poland quickly concluded that declaring themselves members of a "party" inevitably invoked memories of "the party." **********"We think of ourselves as a party that has not yet consolidated," said Stanislaw Rojek, the secretary of the Center Alliance, a group that someday hopes to play a role similar to the Western Europe's Christian Democratic parties. No More Big Parties **********"There is a considerable dislike of people for political parties as such because of the Communist past," Mr. Rojek said. "But this is something that is slowly changing. Still there won't be anymore big parties in Poland. Their time is over." **********The Center Alliance, which has 60,000 to 70,000 members among Poland's 27 million voters, has been the most vocal force behind the candidacy of Mr. Walesa. Broadly speaking, its supporters come from the center-right of the political spectrum. Its main opponent, the Civic Movement for Democratic Action, has been organizing on behalf of Mr. Mazowiecki. **********A third major grouping, bidding to become the political voice of the 30 percent of the Polish population living in rural areas, is the Peasants' Party. Its presidential candidate, Roman Bartoszcze, has hovered between 5 and 10 percent in the opinion polls. **********Mr. Wroblewski said the lack of established political structures in Poland -- coupled with an intense longing for simple solutions to complicated problems -- explains the sudden emergence of Mr. Tyminski. **********"What party structure means is not only an electoral machine to win elections," Mr. Wroblewski said. "It's a certain system of gradual filtration of programs, of people. When you're in a political party, you have some place where you can turn to the person next to you and ask: 'Does this comply with the philosophy of our party?' That hardly exists here. The very idea was completely compromised by the Communist system." 'A Pole Can Do It' **********Supporters of Mr. Tyminski said in interviews that they saw him as a fresh face. They were attracted to his success in Western business, and, in the words of Mr. Wroblewski, "he says to people, 'A Pole can do it.' " **********After weeks of ignoring Mr. Tyminski, the Polish press reported today that he had been refused entry into the military in the 1960's because of mental illness. Another report said he had often traveled to Poland before the fall of Communism, despite his statements to the contrary. The report noted that he obtained visas several times from the Polish Consulate in Tripoli, Libya. **********Polish television and newspapers also criticized Mr. Tyminski for falsely charging that the Prime Minister planned to sell state enterprises for too low a price. The documents cited by Mr. Tyminski as proof of this charge actually refer to the company's annual sales, not the offering price. **********But it was unclear whether the attacks on Mr. Tyminski by established press organizations would not be counterproductive, since for many years Poles say they have learned not to trust what they read in the newspapers or see on television.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/18/busin.main_headline: Accounts Seized in Inquiry On Colombian Drug Profits
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/18/busin.print_headline: Accounts Seized in Inquiry On Colombian Drug Profits
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/18/busin.body_text: **********The Justice Department announced today that based on a review of bank records seized in Panama after the American invasion, as well as in other foreign countries, it had obtained a court order freezing hundreds of bank accounts in the United States suspected of having been used to hide nearly $400 million in Colombian drug profits. **********Federal investigators said that while relatively little money remained in the accounts, a review of the bank records would offer the Government its best opportunity to date to determine how the Medellin drug cartel had conducted its day-to-day business in the United States. **********More than half of the 173 banks involved are in New York and Florida, where many of the nation's largest drug-trafficking organizations are based. **********The banks, which include Chase Manhattan, Chemical and the Bank of America, have not been accused of any wrongdoing. Justice Department investigators said that the banks appeared to be largely unaware that the accounts were being used to launder drug proceeds. **********Attorney General Dick Thornburgh hailed today's move, saying in a statement that ''our ability to examine these bank records may well be the key to unlocking the totality of the secret financial arrangements of the Medellin cartel in the United States.'' **********The other nations in which bank records were obtained were: Colombia, Uruguay, Luxembourg, Switzerland, Britain, Canada and Austria. **********The move to freeze the bank accounts is the most recent effort in Operation Polar Cap, an investigation by the Justice and Treasury Departments to determine how Colombian drug dealers secretly transfer the proceeds of drug sales through American banks. These transfers are known as money laundering. The Justice Department has estimated that more than $1 billion in drug profits was taken out of the United States from 1987 to 1989. **********''We've had no idea how they go about their day-to-day business,'' said Peter G. Djinis, a trial lawyer at the Justice Department. But he said in an interview that with this week's action, ''now we're going to find out where the money is going and about the frequency of these disbursements.'' Money Flowed Back to U.S. Investigators said that the examination of foreign bank records showed that of the $1 billion in drug profits moved out of the United States, nearly $350 million was eventually transferred back to American banks. Some $50 million in drug money apparently never left American accounts, they said. **********''The cartel needs these secret U.S. accounts in order to run their illegal business here,'' Mr. Thornburgh said. ''The massive scope of the cocaine trade in the U.S. requires large amounts of capital for the operation of the cartel's daily activities, as well as to maintain the company's payroll.'' **********Under the court order, signed Monday by Federal District Judge William C. O'Kelley in Atlanta, banks in 22 states and the District of Columbia must turn over records on 754 bank accounts. Of those accounts, 684 were also frozen under the court order, pending a move by Federal prosecutors to seize any remaining drug money. **********Federal investigators said that the frozen accounts were linked to Eduardo Martinez Romero, the reputed financial leader of the Medillin cartel. Mr. Martinez, who was extradicted to the United States from Colombia last year, is now awaiting trial on money-laundering charges. **********Few Funds Expected **********Mr. Djinis, the Justice Department lawyer, said that because Mr. Martinez is in custody and the money-laundering operation had been largely shut down, prosecutors expected to find relatively little money in the accounts. ''We're looking for information instead,'' he said. **********Several of the largest banks involved in the investigation insisted that they had no knowledge that the accounts may have been used to launder the proceeds of drug sales. They said today that they would cooperate with the Justice Department. **********Peter Magnani, a spokesman for the Bank of America in San Francisco, said, ''We don't knowingly aid in the commission of a crime - of course we will cooperate fully.'' **********Kenneth B. Herz, a spokesman for Chemical Bank in New York, said, ''We received the order this morning, and we are in the process of checking'' the account records requested by the Justice Department.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/busin.main_headline: Talking Deals;   Music Producer Faces Big Choice
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/busin.print_headline: Talking Deals;   Music Producer Faces Big Choice
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/busin.body_text: **********A BATTLE over the David Geffen Company is being waged. **********But when the dust settles, longtime associates of Mr. Geffen are betting that the deal he signs may well be a renewal of his distribution agreement with Time Warner Inc. instead of a sale to Thorn EMI, the British company that has been in talks to buy Geffen, the largest independent record company. **********The prediction is based, in part, on Mr. Geffen's successful longtime relationship with Time Warner's chairman, Steven J. Ross. **********People close to the Thorn EMI negotiations, however, have said that Mr. Geffen is near a deal to sell his company to the hardware and music company for $700 million, but no official announcement has been made. **********The Geffen company's existing contract with Warner is ending at a time when Geffen, a major producer of rock music, is doing particularly well and the outlook for the industry is bullish. **********Because Geffen currently distributes through Warner Records, its sales and profits are not reported separately. But Geffen has been immensely successful in recent years with performers like Cher and the rock groups Guns and Roses, Aerosmith and White Snake. **********The 47-year-old Mr. Geffen has also invested, together with Warner, in a number of Broadway shows, including ''Cats,'' ''Little Shop of Horrors'' and ''Dream Girls.'' His company has also produced a handful of films, including ''Risky Business'' and ''Little Shop of Horrors.'' **********People in the industry believe that Geffen's record operations alone had sales of about $225 million in 1989, with operating profits estimated to be $40 million to $50 million. Those figures do not include profits from Broadway shows or film releases. And the Geffen company has no debt. **********Time Warner and Geffen have a deal in which Warner Records distributes Geffen's records and the two share the profits. Beyond that, however, Warner gets a distribution fee and makes profits from manufacturing cassettes. All in all, Time Warner may have taken in $30 million to $50 million last year from its deal with Geffen. **********The relationship with Geffen is crucial to Mr. Ross's global strategy. American rock music continues to gain market share in many markets abroad, and the Geffen history of discovering hit groups is unusually strong. **********This is a particularly healthy time for the record business because sales of compact disks are gaining at the expense of albums and cassettes, and the disks provide a higher profit margin. Also, a wider variety of music is now popular, from jazz to rap. The record business also remains one in which capital investment is still relatively low compared with the potential return from a hit. **********Thorn EMI has reportedly offered Mr. Geffen $700 million for his business, half in stock and half in cash, a figure so high that it caught the music industry by surprise. That price would be about three times sales. Harold Vogel, a media analyst at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, said such a multiple was at the very high end of recent transactions. For example, Polygram paid 2.1 times 1988 sales when it bought A&M Records for $219 million. **********A deal with Thorn EMI would include giving Mr. Geffen one of the top two positions in that company's music group, people close to the talks said. **********Some analysts say his help is needed by EMI, the music arm of Thorn EMI. Robert Collins, an analyst at Kleinwort, Benson Securities in London, said EMI ''does not have a reputation for the highest management in the music business.'' Mr. Geffen has declined to comment on any agreement.  The half-cash, half-stock offer that Thorn EMI has reportedly made would be costly for it. Even if, as Mr. Collins explained it, the company avoids a heavy dilution of its per-share earnings by using a convertible preferred stock, ''it would still dilute earnings for a year or more.'' **********Using stock as well as cash could, however, serve as an incentive to Mr. Geffen to play a strong role in the company. **********Mr. Geffen is already immensely wealthy. Not only does he own all his company, but he also has extensive real estate holdings in Beverly Hills and an important art collection. **********Analysts said Thorn EMI had offered such a high price because it was weak in American rock. In the end, the business still comes down to picking hits, and Mr. Geffen's team of men and women who line up performers is considered among the best in the industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/23/world.main_headline: East Germans Agree to Unification Date
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/23/world.print_headline: East Germans Agree to Unification Date
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/23/world.body_text: **********The East German Parliament ended weeks of bitter dispute early this morning by agreeing to Oct. 3 as the date for formal unification with West Germany. **********The selection of a date was entirely at the discretion of East Germany. It does not need to be ratified by the West German Government. Article 23 of West Germany's Constitution allows former German states to join the Federal Republic upon their accession. **********The vote was 294 to 62. The approval of two-thirds of the 400 legislators in Parliament was needed for passage. **********''This is a truly historical event,'' said Sabine Bergmann-Pohl, the Parliament's president. There was thunderous applause. **********The proposal was an eleventh-hour compromise put forward jointly by the governing Christian Democratic Union, the Social Democratic Party, the German Social Union and the Free Democratic Party. **********Looking Toward Completed Talks **********The four parties said the selection of Oct. 3 was based on the assumption that the ''two-plus-four talks'' between the two Germanys and the four World War II allies - Britain, France, the United States and the Soviet Union -on the issues of German sovereignty will have been completed. **********The date is also one day after the conclusion of a meeting of foreign minsters of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe on Oct. 2, which is expected to settle the final external questions related to unification. **********The parties involved also assume that negotiations and the parliamentary processes tied to the second state treaty covering political and legal aspects of unification will have reached a conclusion. That treaty is currently being negotiated by the East and West German Governments. **********Before approving the motion for unity on Oct. 3, Parliament voted down a proposal by the German Social Union for immediate accession and a proposal by the Social Democratic Party for formal merger on Sept. 15. **********This morning's move means that East Germany will pass into history four days shy of the 41st anniversary of its founding on Oct. 7, 1949. **********''Parliament has decided no more and no less than the demise of East Germany on October 3,'' said Gregor Gysi, leader of the Party of Democratic Socialism, the remnant of the Communist Party that ruled East Germany with an iron hand for four decades. **********A Talk With Kohl **********Parliament had been called into session by Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere in an attempt to force a decision on the unity date. It came after a telephone conversation with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany Wednesday morning in which Bonn's leader reportedly expressed his growing impatience with the controversy and said he was willing to accept a date earlier than Oct. 14. **********The final setting of a date for formal unification ended an episode in which the Christian Democrats and Social Democrats in both Germanys sank into a partisan welter of proposals and counterproposals on dates for unity and all-German elections as the fabric of East German society continued to unravel. **********''It is time that we end this tortuous discussion over the date of accession to the Federal Republic of Germany and find a common solution,'' Mr. de Maiziere told Parliament as the late-night session began. **********The issue has become a matter of amusement here. Hans-Joachim Friedrichs, West Germany's most respected television newscaster, opened his broadcast Tuesday night by running down the confusing events of the day, then looking into the camera and asking his viewers, ''Are you still there?'' **********The first all-German elections since 1933 are scheduled for Dec. 2, after unification. On Wednesday, the East German Parliament approved an election law that had failed to get the needed two-thirds approval in a vote two weeks ago. **********On the election law, Parliament voted 295 to 74 to adopt the West German method of requiring a political party to get at least 5 percent of the total vote in order to be represented in the legislature.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/busin.main_headline: Ford Loses Patent Suit On Wipers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/busin.print_headline: Ford Loses Patent Suit On Wipers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/busin.body_text: **********A former engineering professor who says he invented the intermittent windshield wiper now used by most major car and truck manufacturers has won a bellwether patent-infringement case against the Ford Motor Company. **********A jury in Detroit ruled that Robert W. Kearns, who has waged a lonely 12-year legal battle against the automobile industry, was entitled to seek royalties on Ford's sales of the device, which allows a driver to adjust the intervals at which the wiper sweeps the windshield. **********In the Ford case, Mr. Kearns is seeking $50 for every vehicle to which his patent would apply. **********Possibly $1 Billion **********On Feb. 26, the same jury will weigh arguments on just how much money Ford should pay Mr. Kearns. If the inventor gets everything he wants, the case could cost the entire automobile industry hundreds of millions of dollars, and possibly more than $1 billion. **********But Mr. Kearns must overcome many obstacles: the judge could set aside the jury verdict, or Ford would almost certainly appeal. **********Mr. Kearns has suits pending against most of the world's other major car makers, from General Motors to BMW to Porsche, and the outcome of those cases will likely be heavily influenced by the result of the suit against Ford because many of the same principles apply in each case and the same Federal District Court is overseeing them. **********The essence of Ford's defense, which the jury rejected, was that Mr. Kearns's patents involved nothing new and were therefore invalid. The company cited earlier patents that it argued anticipated Mr. Kearns's claims. **********But the jury sided almost entirely with the 62-year-old inventor, who installed a set of his wipers on a 1962 Ford and took it to the auto maker. Mr. Kearns argued that because Ford engineers frequently asked him to discuss the design, he thought the company would buy the system. But it never did. **********In answering a long list of questions posed by Judge Avern Cohn, the jury decided that none of the earlier inventions cited by Ford had made Mr. Kearns's invention obvious and therefore unworthy of a patent. **********Important Victory **********Neither side would comment on the decision, citing a strict gag order from Judge Cohn. But the verdict clearly marks an important victory in what had for a long time seemed like a quixotic exercise. **********Mr. Kearns says he invented his device in the early 1960's. Until that time, intermittent windshield wipers were generally powered by vacuum pumps. Mr. Kearns designed an electronic device that was more practical and convenient, and obtained a series of related patents from 1967 to 1974. **********Mr. Kearns argued that he showed the device, mounted on a Ford Galaxy, to Ford officials in 1963. He also tried to commercialize the invention through a company called the Tann Corporation, but again was unsuccessful. Meanwhile, American car makers began introducing devices similar to his invention around 1969. **********The suit against Ford was filed in 1978, and those against other manufacturers have mostly come since then. **********Interest of Patent Lawyers **********The inventor has drawn the interest of top patent lawyers. In recent years, he has been represented on a contingency basis by Arnold White & Durkee, one of the most respected patent firms in the country. **********Some patent lawyers who have followed the case said they were not surprised by Mr. Kearns's victory. Experts said Ford had at one point tried to reach a settlement with Mr. Kearns but was not successful. **********''Ford is paying the price for the extremely arrogant anti-patent attitude of a generation ago,'' said Harold Wegner, a Washington patent lawyer. **********Outsider to the Car Industry **********Mr. Kearns, an outsider to the car industry all his life, taught engineering at Wayne State University in the 1960's and then went on to become commissioner of buildings and safety engineering for the city of Detroit. In 1971 he joined the Federal Bureau of National Standards. He retired in 1976 and later moved to Gaithersburg, Md. **********Judge Cohn ruled earlier that Mr. Kearns had failed to prove he could make and market the system on his own and therefore was not entitled to the ''lost profits'' that a manufacturer could claim - a sum greater than the royalties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/06/busin.main_headline: Chairman Is Named For Emery Worldwide
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/06/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Chairman Is Named For Emery Worldwide
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/06/busin.body_text: **********Long a leader in the trucking industry, Consolidated fell into a financial crisis after the April 1989 acquisition of Emery Air Freight for $478 million. Unable to reverse Emery's losses, which were running at $1 million a week at the time of the acquisition, Consolidated reported its first loss since 1961 and suspended its common stock dividend for the first time in 19 years. **********In July, Lary R. Scott, 54, Consolidated's president and chief executive officer and the architect of the Emery deal, resigned under pressure and was replaced by the former chief executive of Consolidated, Raymond O'Brien, who is 68. J. Frank Leach, 69, who had been on Consolidated's board since 1975, but was not an employee, joined as president and chief operating officer. **********Mr. Bass, who is credited with returning Coopervision to operating profitability, believes he can do the same for Emery. It is ''a company with 42 years of infrastructure and a franchise,'' he said. ''We have the ability to leverage that franchise and exploit niches underexplored by other players,'' he said, but added that he was not yet sure how to do so. ''Literally, I've got a lot of homework to do,'' he said. **********Before joining Cooper in March 1989, Mr. Bass was vice chairman and president of Federal Express. He is also a former chairman and chief executive officer of Midway Airlines. He received his B.A. in English from Middlebury College in Vermont. He and his wife, Paula, have three children.

Hofman, the managing director of G.M. Hungary, said recruitment of 850 workers for the $200 million project will begin in December. G.M. said the plant will make 1.6-liter engines. The company expects to have 60 to 70 Hungarian dealers by 1993.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/27/busin.main_headline: The Media Business;   For Authors, the Key Words Are in the Book Contracts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/27/busin.print_headline: The Media Business;   For Authors, the Key Words Are in the Book Contracts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/27/busin.body_text: **********Publishing used to be about trust. But today, the old relationships between authors and publishers have given way to growing differences over the contracts that define the business ties between them. **********''What has changed is the trust -it's gone,'' said Joni Evans, the publisher of Random House. ''There has been paranoia on both sides. The money is high, the risks are high and the old relationships between authors, editors and publishers have been disrupted.'' **********This ''paranoia'' inevitably centers on contracts. They were once the formal statements of much deeper understandings. Now, they have become more contentious as writers and editors have grown far more fickle in their attachment to particular publishers, the money involved has spiraled and the genial publishing houses of the past have been transformed into mere units of huge media corporations. **********''Contracts have grown more and more complex and difficult as they have gotten bigger,'' said Charles E. Hayward, the president of Simon & Schuster's trade book division. ''We are having to formalize what might previously have been an understanding on both sides.'' **********Of course, most book contracts still work smoothly. But many also go wrong, leading to book cancellations, bruised feelings and even lawsuits. **********This year, there was the unprecedented case of McGraw-Hill's suit against the estate of the author James Baldwin to recover a six-figure advance paid to him before his death in 1987. The company later dropped the suit. **********And there is the case of the author Roger Kahn, who wrote the best-selling ''The Boys of Summer'' and has been embroiled in a bitter dispute with Laurence J. Kirschbaum, the president of Warner Books. **********In July 1987, Mr. Kahn's 22-year-old-son committed suicide. The author was then in the midst of writing a $750,000 book for Warner about the baseball star Pete Rose. He and Mr. Rose had already received $225,000 of the advance, split evenly between them. But after his son's death, Mr. Kahn said, he felt unable to write. **********At the time of the suicide, the book, which had been due in April, was already late. Two weeks after the suicide, Mr. Kahn said, Mr. Kirschbaum told him, ''We need the book.'' **********When it was not completed by December, Warner canceled the contract and later sued to recover the $225,000 advance. **********''Warner's behavior was unbelievable,'' Mr. Kahn said. ''To sue a writer after a death in the family just shows no sense of civil behavior. Do publishers often treat writers in this way?'' **********Mr. Kirschbaum disputed Mr. Kahn's account of what happened. He said he felt devastated when he learned of the suicide and told Mr. Kahn to take a couple of months off. But when Warner still had no more than 20 percent of the manuscript five months after the suicide, it felt compelled to cancel the book, he said. **********''We spent hundreds of hours on this very expensive book, and Mr. Kahn was just not fair about it from day one,'' Mr. Kirschbaum said. **********In the end, the suit was settled. Mr. Kahn and Mr. Rose, whose book was ultimately published by Macmillan Inc., agreed to pay Warner $150,000 of the advance in several stages. **********Questions About Boilerplate **********As such conflicts have become more frequent, writers are questioning the standard, so-called boilerplate contracts of publishing houses. They are particularly concerned because last-minute cancellations of books have become more common. At Bantam Doubleday Dell this year, ''Dangerous Thoughts'' by Yuri Orlov; ''Constructive Thinking: The Intelligence That Counts'' by Seymour Epstein, and Luciano Benetton's life story have all been canceled after the manuscripts were completed. **********In this light, authors want to know why, as boilerplate contracts state, they should have to return money advanced to them if publishers deem a manuscript unsatisfactory. **********Typically, boilerplate contracts state that if a text is not satisfactory ''in the publisher's judgment,'' then the author ''agrees to repay forthwith all amounts which may have been advanced hereunder.'' **********''This is one of the most troubling clauses,'' said J. Anthony Lukas, the Pulitzer Prize-winning writer. ''You can spend several years on a book, and then be told it's not being published and we don't have to tell you why. And you have to pay back the advance.'' **********Basis for Negotiation **********Publishers say they cannot guarantee money to authors when they may find themselves with an unpublishable manuscript. Moreover, they argue that their boilerplates are merely a basis for negotiation with authors and their agents. Indeed, the contracts are routinely changed. **********But agents are increasingly wary. Some say they try to get a better description of what a satisfactory manuscript is. **********''In this new climate, we've all become increasingly careful about watching manuscript delivery dates,'' said Kathy Robbins, an agent. **********''When author-editor relationships were more stable, no one worried if a manuscript was a few months late,'' she added. ''But now, editors and publishers come and go. So if an editor tells me it's all right to be late, I make sure I get that in writing.'' **********Amanda Urban, another agent, said she found that increasingly an agent's role was ''to serve a book down the line'' to iron out any difficulties that might arise. And she said she had always been able to resolve conflicts amicably. **********But Ms. Urban added that she recently had a client who brought in his own lawyer, and the lawyer commented on a boilerplate publishing contract: ''Nobody in his right mind would sign a document like that. The publisher has all the advantages.'' **********'Rolling Thunder of Audits' **********Many authors are also contesting payments of royalties and the increasingly large reserves on royalties that publishers retain as a safeguard against unsold books coming back from stores. **********Robert K. Massie, the president of the Authors Guild, said he would like to see ''a rolling thunder of audits'' to make sure payments are being properly made. Moreover, authors want to know why they should accept a so-called ''option clause,'' which commits them to offering their next book to the same publisher. **********''It is no longer an even playing field,'' Mr. Lukas said. ''On the one side, you have a group of individual contractors, the authors, and on the other, multinational corporations. There is a pretense that this is an even bargaining situation. But thousands of authors do not even have agents. We would like to even out the playing field a little by negotiating, house by house, a minimum acceptable contract.'' **********Contract Discussions **********Mr. Massie disclosed that over the last two years writers and publishers held an unprecedented series of discussions about contracts. But in the view of the authors, the talks failed. **********The meetings were attended by publishers including Ms. Evans of Random House and Mr. Hayward of Simon & Schuster, lawyers from several publishing houses and writers. **********''The idea was to reach a consensus on how to publish books,'' Mr. Massie said. **********But Ms. Evans said the only point of the talks was to get to know each side's concerns. She added that the meetings had been useful and that Random House was reviewing a possible new boilerplate contract. **********Mr. Hayward called the meetings ''rather frustrating.'' **********''There were a lot of good intentions,'' he said, ''but the objectives were not laid out.'' **********For Mr. Massie, however, the aim is clear: ''We wanted to get a standard basic contract. But it was a two-year process that went nowhere.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/14/world.main_headline: Mandela Says South Africa Persecuted His Wife
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/14/world.print_headline: Mandela Says South Africa Persecuted His Wife
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/14/world.body_text: **********Nelson Mandela, the South African black nationalist leader, today defended his wife, Winnie, saying she had been the victim of the ''most scandalous persecution'' by the Government. **********It was Mr. Mandela's first comment on criticisms of Mrs. Mandela, one of whose former bodyguards is on trial in connection with the kidnapping and killing of a black teen-ager. **********Three men have testified that they were abducted in December 1988 along with the teen-ager and taken to Mrs. Mandela's house in Soweto. They testified that she beat them with a whip and with her fists and permitted her bodyguards to assault them. **********The boy, James (Stompie) Mokhetsi Seipei, was later found dead in a field. **********Ostracized for a Time **********Mrs. Mandela has said she was not present during the beatings. She was ostracized for a time by some anti-apartheid leaders over the activities of her bodyguards and questions over her own involvement. **********But a few months later, she resumed making appearances with other anti-apartheid leaders, and has been publicly at the side of her husband since his release from prison in February. **********Mrs. Mandela has not been charged in the case, and both the prosecution and defense have said they will not call her to testify. **********Mr. Mandela, who is traveling in Africa, made no specific reference to the allegations. But he told a crowd of 30,000 cheering Nigerians, ''Even now as I am talking to you she is still being persecuted in South Africa.'' **********He said Winnie Mandela was ''the victim of the most scandalous persecution by the Government and its agencies.'' Despite Government restrictions on her activities during his 27 years in prison, she ''fought back against all forms of injustice,'' Mr. Mandela said. **********He thanked the Nigerian Government and people for support during his time in prison. **********Earlier, in the Angolan capital, Luanda, Mr. Mandela urged the West not to end sanctions against South Africa. **********De Klerk on European Tour **********''Our policy is very clear,'' he said. ''We have called on the international community to isolate South Africa and that is still our position.'' **********President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa is on a European tour, during which he has been touting progress made in ending apartheid and arguing that it is time to end the diplomatic and economic isolation of South Africa. **********The South African Government outlawed the African National Congress in 1960, and the organization began a guerrilla campaign the following year to overthrow white minority rule and end the system of racial segregation. **********Mr. de Klerk legalized the A.N.C. in February and met with Mr. Mandela last month. Delegations from the Government and the A.N.C. reached a broad agreement to work for an end to political violence and to prepare the way for black entry into government. **********Pressing Demand for Suffrage **********Mr. Mandela indicated that the congress was prepared to compromise with Mr. de Klerk on several points, but said demands for full voting rights were not negotiable. **********''The demand of one person one vote is one on which it is inconceivable to expect us to compromise,'' he said. ''What would this fight have been all about, if we are not going to press that demand exactly as it is?'' **********He promised that the A.N.C. would work to address white fears about black suffrage. **********''We mean to remove any concerns . . . because it is absolutely necessary for the future of South Africa to retain white expertise and skill,'' he said. **********Asked whether he intended to run for president in any future democratic elections in South Africa, Mr. Mandela, who is 71 years old, said he had ''no such ambition.'' **********But, he said, ''I will do what the A.N.C. and the South African people require me to do.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/29/busin.main_headline: U.S. Is Changing Its Tune On Liberalization of Trade
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/29/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT; U.S. Is Changing Its Tune On Liberalization of Trade
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/29/busin.body_text: **********After years of pushing for an end to nations' restrictions on financial, engineering, communications and other services, Washington is losing some of its enthusiasm for liberalization. **********The reason is practical politics -- some United States industries are unhappy about giving up protection and could well have the lobbying muscle to block Congressional approval of any agreement that might emerge from the 105-nation trade talks currently under way in Geneva. **********"We've moved from rhetoric to the real thing," said Calman J. Cohen, vice president for the Emergency Committee for American Trade, a group of 64 American multinational companies that generally support liberalization. "It's an example of having to take the middle ground the closer we get to the final days." **********In recent days, the Bush Administration has signaled that it wants to exclude four sectors -- shipping, civil aviation, telecommunications and banking -- from the clear, open, nonrestrictive rules being written in Geneva. **********The banking, telecommunications and airline industries had originally supported the push for liberalization, hoping their competitive skills would enable them to penetrate foreign markets. The shipping industry has never had much enthusiasm for ending its protectionism. **********Bush Administration officials deny that they are retreating from their initial goals of broad-scale liberalization. "We are not backing down, but assessing the situation and determining what the best negotiating stance is," said a senior aide to the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills. Exceptions for the four sectors have occasioned some dismay among the negotiating partners. **********The shift by the United States is causing some alarm within the European Community generally. **********"We're very concerned," a senior Danish official said. "This is the sort of thing that can multiply and lead to unraveling." **********France is now seeking an exception for so-called cultural industries, which means that films and television programs from the United States might face new quotas and restrictions.   Shipping Industry Blamed **********Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, blames the maritime industry, which won an exclusion from the Canadian-American free-trade agreement of 1989 and seems to be achieving the same thing in the current talks, known as the Uruguay Round. **********"We will be avalanched with quotas and restrictions, all of which would be perfectly legitimate if the U.S. maritime industry succeeds in bending the United States trade representative to its will," Mr. Valenti said. **********Shipping has a long history of protection, going back to the Jones Act of 1920, which reserves all inland waterway and coastal traffic for American ships and crews. The United States shipping industry has been outspoken in its opposition to liberalization. **********In the negotiations on the Canadian agreement, the maritime industry showed its strength by getting more than half the members of the Senate and House to sign resolutions declaring the Jones Act out of bounds in any trade negotiations. **********In the final run there may not be much argument at the trade talks about exempting shipping, since nearly all countries have similar laws requiring ports to be serviced by their own carriers.   Position of Regulators **********The situations of the other three sectors share one element -- regulation by agencies reluctant to give up a regulatory grip in the interests of freer trade. **********Aviation routes are negotiated by the State and Transportation Departments subject to a network of bilateral arrangements under the 1944 Chicago Convention. **********The route negotiations are governed by strict and narrow reciprocity. What a country gets in terms of access to a new market it has to be willing to cede in access to its own market. In aviation, there is no equivalent market access for all countries, which is one of the guiding principles of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the multinational forum that is sponsoring the Urguay Round of talks. **********To provide unconditional open skies, one of the goals of the Geneva talks, would bring chaos, aviation regulators insist, a view widely shared by airline executives.  Treasury and Fed Concerns **********Banking is regulated chiefly by the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve Board, with the principal goal of maintaining the safety and soundness of depository institutions. **********The regulators -- including treasurers and finance ministers of most other countries -- are generally not keen about having banking on the trade agenda. **********In Washington, territorial strains also figure. Treasury officials say that if there is to be any further opening of banking services in the interests of freer trade, they should handle the negotiations, not Mrs. Hills's office. **********Telecommunications is governed by the Federal Communications Commission, whose chairman, Alfred C. Sikes, warned Mrs. Hills in a letter in August that coverage of basic voice telephone service in the trade talks could "significantly impair" the regulatory framework of the Communications Act of 1934. Her response has been to seek exemptions in line with his request, which was made at the behest of the top United States long-distance companies. **********Basic service in most countries is provided by state monopolies, and some American officials fear that an agreement in telecommunications might lead to a one-sided commitment by the United States to keep its market open without any additional access to foreign markets with solidly entrenched state monopolies.  Benefits in Narrower Accord **********While it would seem that credible liberalization must include all service industries without exception, a narrower accord could still be beneficial, many experts maintain. **********Even if banking is removed from the financial-services category, a number of other areas could be opened up -- for example, insurance, credit cards, commodities bartering, electronic fund transfers, securities underwriting and traveler's checks. **********"The goal hasn't changed," said Margaret S. Wigglesworth, executive director of the Coalition of Service Industries, representing the service sector, which generates two-thirds of the United States gross national product. "What we've discovered in all this is that some areas of services do not lend themselves to immediate liberalization."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/world.main_headline: South Africa's New Era;   Exiled South African Communist Says Situation Is Now More Volatile
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/world.print_headline: South Africa's New Era;   Exiled South African Communist Says Situation Is Now More Volatile
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/world.body_text: **********The general secretary of the South African Communist Party said today that the changes announced by President F. W. de Klerk had made the political climate in that country more volatile and that the situation could worsen if the Government did not go further in meeting its opponents' demands. **********Joe Slovo, who is also a senior official of the African National Congress, said in an interview that Mr. de Klerk, who last week announced, among other measures, the legalization of the Congress and the Communist Party, had ''willy-nilly triggered off a new situation'' and had shown ''a degree of freshness and courage.'' **********But Mr. Slovo cautioned against euphoria over what he called partial measures, saying that Mr. de Klerk would have to take steps to ''normalize political life'' in the country by lifting state-of-emergency regulations and releasing all political prisoners, among other measures, before he and other political opponents could return from exile. **********''He's raised expectations both outside and inside the country,'' Mr. Slovo said of Mr. de Klerk, adding that it would have been ''utter suicide'' for the President to have done nothing. ''If he doesn't go further, I think he will be in a worse situation than he was before the announcement. If he doesn't, he will not emerge from the crisis.'' **********Mr. Slovo is meeting here with other senior officials of the Congress, the leading group fighting white domination in South Africa, to exchange ideas about how to respond to Mr. de Klerk's decision to lift the bans on political opponents, release the jailed African National Congress Leader, Nelson Mandela, soon, and suspend executions, all of which were important demands of the Congress. **********Political Prisoners to Be Freed **********The President said also that he would free those political prisoners not sentenced for such offenses as murder or terrorism and end emergency press censorship. But he did not repeal South Africa's three-year-old state of emergency regulations, saying that there was still too much political unrest, and did not announce an end to the system of legislated racial segregation known as apartheid. **********The gathering in Stockholm, which includes Walter Sisulu and other veteran Congress leaders who were released from jail last year, is to be followed soon by a meeting of the group's national executive committee. **********The officials had arranged to visit Stockholm to meet with the organization's president, Oliver Tambo, who is in a clinic here recovering from a stroke, before Mr. de Klerk made the announcement in a speech at the opening of Parliament. **********Asked to describe the current political situation in South Africa, Mr. Slovo said: ''In a word, volatile; from every side, from our side and from the Government's side. From de Klerk's side, he's got major divisions within his constituency and already the right wing is making threatening noises. From our side, of course, the volatility consists of the new space which de Klerk has been forced to provide, increased organization and political activity.'' **********The African National Congress had been banned for 30 years and the South African Communist Party for 40. Mr. Slovo, a former head of the Congress's military wing, whose wife, Ruth First, was killed in 1982 by a letter bomb he believes was sent by South African agents, has not been in South Africa since 1963. He said that exiled members of the African National Congress and Communist Party were studying how and when to return home. But he said that Mr. de Klerk's proposals, which did not include amnesty for political opponents in exile, had left many ''ambiguities'' and ''an uncertain situation.'' **********'Armed Activity Played a Role' **********''We have been engaged in a political struggle,'' said Mr. Slovo, a soft-spoken, stocky, gray-haired white South African who has long been the South African Communist Party's most prominent member, ''in which armed activity played a role. We can't look at our membership and leadership as consisting of two segments, those who commited political offenses and those who committed so-called terrorist offenses. If de Klerk is serious about preparing the ground for dialogue, he must address this question.'' **********Mr. Slovo said that the main participants at any negotiations over the future of South Africa would be the Government and the Congress, which would represent opponents of apartheid. He said a basic stumbling block in any negotiations would be if the Government, which is seeking to protect the rights of the white minority in any refashioned political landscape, ''is not prepared to sit down seriously to discuss the process of moving to majority rule, to democracy in South Africa.'' **********After apartheid is abolished, Mr. Slovo said, ''affirmative action'' will be needed to help the poor, who constitute 80 percent of the population. He said it would be inconceivable for the private sector or foreign capital to have no role in a post-apartheid South Africa, but said the main question was whether ''the whole direction is determined by the private sector or a force that acts in the long-term interests of the majority.'' **********''De Klerk said the surge toward freedom in Eastern Europe proved to be an unstoppable tide,'' Mr. Slovo said, referring to the President's speech. ''I think he should realize that this is going to happen in South Africa unless he goes much further. It's going to be an unstoppable tide. The only question is how that tide moves. He should think about that a little more carefully.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/busin.main_headline: Seamen's Bank Seized; Chase Buys Its Deposits
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/busin.print_headline: Seamen's Bank Seized; Chase Buys Its Deposits
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/busin.body_text: **********The Seamen's Bank for Savings, which was formed in 1839 to encourage thrift among seamen, was put under the control of Federal regulators at the close of business yesterday. All of its deposits were bought by the Chase Manhattan Bank, which will begin operating Seamen's 13 branches today. **********The Seamen's Bank fell on hard times in the early 1980's when sharply higher interest rates paid on deposits caused losses at many savings banks. The losses from high interest rates were compounded in 1987 and 1988 when Seamen's invested heavily in new kinds of mortgage-backed securities. The securities failed to protect the company from fluctuating interest rates and, instead, resulted in large losses. In the first nine months of 1989, Seamen's lost $166.8 million. **********The Federal takeover of Seamen's is expected to cost the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation $350 million to $400 million, according to Alan Whitney, a spokesman for the F.D.I.C. The Government insurance fund, with assets of about $14 billion, will sell Seamen's assets, including loans and securities, and use the proceeds to repay creditors other than depositors. The F.D.I.C insurance fund is separate from the reorganized insurance fund created by Congress last year to rescue the savings and loan industry. $5 Million Price Chase, which will rename the branches, plans to combine Seamen's $2.1 billion of deposits and 13 branches with the $13.7 billion of consumer deposits and 185 Chase branches in New York City, Long Island and Westchester County. For the right to buy the deposits, Chase paid $5 million, beating the price offered by another, unidentified bidder. Chase said it planned to honor the interest rates on all Seamen's deposits until they mature. **********Chase has set up a phone line at 800-862-4273 for customers with questions about their deposits. Seamen's customers with questions about loans from the bank may call the F.D.I.C. in New York City at 212-428-4560. **********''Chase is getting a pretty good franchise,'' said Henry S. Peltz, an analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a securities firm. Like other savings banks in the New York market, Seamen's branches operated with much higher levels of deposits than normal at commercial banks. **********Besides the benefits of a larger deposit base, Chase expects to benefit by offering Seamen's customers various other services like credit cards and personal loans. **********The collapse of Seamen's comes at a time when a consolidation of savings banks in New York is moving ahead on several fronts. **********Mr. Peltz said that even strong savings banks would consider partners because they ''recognize that size and economies of scale are critical to profitability and meeting capital guidelines.'' **********Among financially strong savings banks, the Manhattan Savings Bank agreed in recent months to be acquired by the Republic New York Corporation, which will merge it with the Williamsburgh Savings Bank. Apple Savings Bank has rejected a $38-a-share bid from Stanley Stahl, a New York developer, for stock he does not already own. **********Home Savings Bank, Brooklyn, is discussing a merger with the Bowery Savings Bank, a unit of H. F. Ahmanson & Company. And Crossland Savings of Brooklyn, the largest savings bank on the East Coast, is working on plans to raise new capital after the breakdown of negotiations to obtain a $150 million capital injection from the Coast-to-Coast Financial Corporation of Chicago.
