https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/28/world.main_headline: DEMOCRATS PRESS BUSH TO PUT OFF MILITARY ACTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/28/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; DEMOCRATS PRESS BUSH TO PUT OFF MILITARY ACTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/28/world.body_text: **********With the United Nations Security Council due to approve a resolution later this week authorizing the use of military force against Iraq any time after Jan. 15, Senate Democrats urged the Bush Administration today to delay taking military action and give economic sanctions more time to work. **********As the Senate Armed Services Committee opened hearings on the Persian Gulf crisis, Senator Sam Nunn, the chairman of the panel, once again questioned the need for rushing into combat with Iraq. Senator Nunn's caution was generally echoed by the nine other Democrats at the hearing. **********Some conservative Republicans expressed concern that the hearing was playing into the hands of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq by suggesting that the United States lacked the will to use military force and disclosing that there were divisions in the United States.  'Lighting Our Own Fuse' **********"Time is working on our side," Senator Nunn said, suggesting that economic sanctions would be effective in prompting President Hussein to withdraw Iraqi troops from Kuwait. **********"We are lighting our own fuse," the Georgia Democrat complained to reporters after the hearing, saying that the Administration had limited its options by building up a large military force in the gulf and shelving plans for troop rotations. **********In Baghdad today, Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz expressed defiance in the face of efforts to make Baghdad's forces pull out of Kuwait. Mr. Aziz dismissed the importance of the proposed United Nations resolution that would authorize the use of force to oust Iraq from Kuwait, saying that his country would "never succumb to pressure."  [ Page A14. ] A List of Questions **********The Congressional hearings, which grew out of concern that President Bush would go to war without consulting Congress, represent an effort by Mr. Nunn and his Senate colleagues to influence American policy even as the Bush Administration continues to threaten Iraq with a winter war unless Iraqi forces leave Kuwait. **********Senator Nunn, whose views on military issues carry great weight in the Senate, began the hearing by reading a list of questions that he said should guide the national debate over possible offensive action against Iraq. **********"The question is not whether military action is justified; it is," Mr. Nunn said. "The question is whether military action is wise at this time and in our own national interest." **********"Is it in our vital interest to liberate Kuwait through military action by a largely American military force?" he asked. "Will economic sanctions force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait?" **********"How long can we sustain over 400,000 American troops in Saudi Arabia," Mr. Nunn continued. **********"Should our military objectives extend beyond the restoration of Kuwaiti sovereignty to the elimination of key aspects of Iraq's offensive military capability, particularly their ongoing nuclear efforts?" **********"How durable is the multinational coalition?" he also asked. **********Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, the second-ranking Democrat on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said separately that President Bush, through an envoy, should initiate talks with President Hussein. **********The talks, he said at a breakfast meeting with reporters, should not be for negotiations but rather to explain United States intentions in the Middle East, which Mr. Hamilton said might not be clear to the Iraqi President.  Schlesinger Testifies **********The first witness today, James R. Schlesinger, Defense Secretary in the Ford and Nixon Administrations, told the Committee that economic sanctions would be successful in forcing Iraqi troops to leave Kuwait if only the Administration would give them time to work. **********Mr. Schlesinger, who also served as Director of Central Intelligence, said that an early "official estimate," which he suggested committee members would hear more about in a closed-door intelligence briefing later in the day, held that it would take a year for the sanctions to take effect. "It now appears to be working more rapidly than anticipated," Mr. Schlesinger said. **********"In three months time, civilian production in Iraq is estimated to have declined by some 40 percent," he said. "Oil exports are essentially nil and export earning have dropped correspondingly. The hoard of hard currency, necessary to sustain smuggling, is dwindling away. The economic pressure can only grow worse." **********But Mr. Schlesinger asserted that the effectiveness of economic sanctions would be diminished if President Hussein believed that the underlying American goal was not just to liberate Kuwait but also to eliminate Iraq's military ability or remove Mr. Hussein from power. 'Sound Advice,' Nunn Says **********He also asserted that an American military victory over Iraq "may result in an enmity directed at the United States for an extended period, not only by Iraq and its present supporters, but ultimately among the publics of some of the nations now allied to us." **********Senator Nunn said in an interview later that Mr. Schlesinger had provided "sound advice" that paralleled his own counsel to the Administration. **********"The real cost is lives," said Senator Richard C. Shelby, an Alabama Democrat, indicating agreement with the thrust of Mr. Schlesinger's presentation. **********Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, said of economic sanctions in a statement, "Instead of eliminating troop rotations and adding huge numbers of American forces, the President should be displaying American staying power for the long haul."  Glenn Expresses Concern **********Senator John Glenn, the Ohio Democrat, also expressed concern that President Bush would order an attack "before the embargo has had time to really bite and to be effective." **********Senator Nunn said he agreed with the Administration's decision to seek a United Nations resolution authorizing force to build pressure on Iraq.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY EARNINGS;   Boise Cascade Net Down 57%
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/busin.body_text: **********Weak demand for paper products coupled with higher prices for logs and wood chips sent the Boise Cascade Corporation's first-quarter net income plunging by 57 percent, the company said today. **********The wood-products company said its profit totaled $33.6 million, or 79 cents a share, down from $78.3 million, or $1.74, in the quarter a year ago. **********Sales were off by 3 percent, to $1.07 billion from $1.1 billion. **********Operating income from the company's paper segment, which has accounted for up to two-thirds of Boise Cascade's income, dropped to less than $51 million in the first quarter from nearly $127 million a year earlier. **********Operating income from the building products segment slumped to $19.1 million, from $22.1 million the previous year, as log prices were up and lumber prices down. **********The company said its office products segment reported record sales and operating income in the first quarter. Sales jumped 12 percent and income was up 16 percent on what the company said was seasonally robust demand combined with an increased corporate emphasis on operating efficiency.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/busin.main_headline: Dole Foods President Goes to Leading Rival
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Dole Foods President Goes to Leading Rival
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/busin.body_text: **********In a major food industry shuffle, Robert W. Fisher, president of Castle & Cooke Inc.'s Dole Food Company, is leaving to join a rival, the PPI Del Monte Tropical Fruit Company. **********Mr. Fisher, 52 years old, who has been with Dole 25 years and has been president since 1986, had been preparing the company for a spinoff from Castle & Cooke into a publicly held company. In May, however, Castle & Cooke delayed the deal, citing tax and financing problems. **********Mr. Fisher declined interviews yesterday, and it could not be determined whether his decision to leave was linked to the proposed spinoff and its problems. A spokeswoman, Carol Klein, declined comment. The company, which has David H. Murdock, the financier, as its chairman and chief executive, has a reputation among Wall Street analysts for being uncommunicative. **********Dole is a worldwide producer of fresh fruit and vegetables, as is PPI Del Monte, which is based in Coral Gables, Fla. Polly Peck International, a London-based food company, bought the Del Monte fresh foods business last fall from RJR Nabisco Inc. The Del Monte canned and processed food units were sold separately. **********Polly Peck, led by Asil Nadir, an international business executive, is now No. 3 in produce behind Castle & Cooke and the United Brands Company. **********Mr. Nadir announced yesterday that Brian Haycox, head of PPI Del Monte, had been named chief executive of the food division of Polly Peck and beginning Sept. 1 would be in charge of the company's North and South American food activities. **********Mr. Fisher will become chief operating officer of PPI Del Monte and will report to Mr. Haycox. In a statment, Mr. Haycox called Mr. Fisher one of the most prominent executives in the produce industry and said his hiring would give PPI Del Monte management depth ''at a time when we are planning major expansions of our operations.'' **********PPI Del Monte says it is the third-largest distributor of bananas, which make up 75 percent of its sales, and the largest pineapple distributor. The company employs 12,000 people worldwide. **********Mr. Nadir, a British citizen, originally came from the Turkish part of Cyprus, where he began marketing fruit from Turkey and Cyprus. He holds a 25 percent interest in Polly Peck, which is in leisure operations, manufacturing and the sale of electronic products, as well as food.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Delta Withdraws Moscow Proposal
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/busin.body_text: **********Delta Air Lines asked to withdraw its proposal for a nonstop flight from Atlanta to Moscow and filed instead for a route with one stop in Germany. The Atlanta-based airline had previously asked the Department of Transportation for permission to operate three weekly nonstop flights between Atlanta and Moscow-Leningrad in 1991. **********Delta cited increased fuel costs and economic conditions in the United States and the Soviet Union as reasons for the decision not to pursue nonstop service.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East;   Havel Plan for Summit Site
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East;   Havel Plan for Summit Site
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.body_text: **********President Vaclav Havel today offered Prague instead of Washington as the site of the next summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********Mr. Havel told the Czechoslovak legislature that he would make the proposal personally when he saw Mr. Gorbachev in Moscow early next month and when he makes a state visit to the United States soon afterward. President Gorbachev and President Bush last met in Malta at the beginning of December, and Mr. Bush invited Mr. Gorbachev to the United States for their next meeting. **********Mr. Havel said he was trying to use his office to strengthen the prestige of Czechoslovakia in the world. His first official visit was a one-day trip to East and West Germany. In the next few days, he said, he would go to Poland, Hungary, and Rumania. **********Czechoslovakia began negotiations with the Soviet Union Jan. 15 on a withdrawal of the 70,000 to 75,000 Soviet troops that have been stationed here since the Warsaw Pact invasion of the country in 1968. Mr. Havel is expected to press the country's demand that half of them Gorbachev in Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/world.main_headline: Iran Sees Time Nearing For New Ties to Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/world.print_headline: Iran Sees Time Nearing For New Ties to Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/world.body_text: **********Reacting to recent comments by Britain's Foreign Minister about Islam and Salman Rushdie's novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' an Iranian ayatollah said today that Britain had ''almost met'' Iran's conditions for restoring diplomatic relations. **********In a letter to a member of the British Parliament that was made public on Wednesday, the Foreign Minister, Douglas Hurd, called Islam ''one of the world's great religions,'' adding, ''we have the greatest respect for it and its values.'' **********''The British Government had nothing to do with the publishing of 'The Satanic Verses,' '' he said. ''Nor has it encouraged its publication in other countries. There is no question of the British Government or people wishing to insult Islam.'' **********Mr. Rushdie has been in hiding since February 1989, when Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini attacked his novel as blasphemous and ordered Muslims to kill the novelist, who is a British citizen. A month later, Iran severed diplomatic relations with London, saying Britain supported Mr. Rushdie and did not show respect for Islam. **********Called 'Relatively Encouraging' **********The Iranian press agency today quoted Ayatollah Mohammad Emami Kashani as saying, ''By condemning Salman Rushdie and respecting beliefs of the Muslims, Britain has almost met the conditions set by Parliament.'' **********Ayatollah Kashani is a member of the Guardian Council, which oversees the Iranian Parliament. **********A spokesman for Britain's Foreign Office called the comment ''relatively encouraging'' but noted that no similar response had been conveyed through official channels. **********Asked whether it was possible that Iran was more eager to improve relations with Britain following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the spokesman said: ''It's rather difficult to say. We don't see any immediate linkage.'' **********Several Issues Involved **********The Foreign Office spokesman pointed out that the death sentence against Mr. Rushdie was still blocking the resumption of normal relations as were two other issues. **********One issue is the Britons believed held hostage in Lebanon by groups loyal to Iran: Terry Waite, Jackie Mann and John McCarthy. A fourth hostage, Brian Keenan, is from Northern Ireland, but his family has asked him to be classified as Irish in the hope that that might increase his chances of being released. **********Britain is also upset over Iran's imprisonment of Roger Cooper, a British businessman, since December 1985. No formal charges have been brought against him, although Iranian news organizations labeled him a spy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/14/busin.body_text: **********The United States and the Soviet Union have tentatively agreed to hold trade talks in Paris from April 24 to 26, a United States Embassy spokeswoman said today. The meeting will be the fourth in a series aimed at gaining most-favored-nation trade status for Moscow, allowing its exports to enter the United States with lower duties. Most nations in the world already enjoy the lower tariffs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/03/world.body_text: **********An agreement last week between Japanese and North Korean leaders to open discussions on establishing diplomatic relations has stirred unusual confusion and criticism in Japan, embarrassing the Government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. **********Even as Mr. Kaifu was traveling from New York to the Middle East to cement his standing as a world statesman, critics at home were calling attention to what they said was an unusual disarray in his Government, raising questions about how much he is in control of his team. **********The criticism comes on top of widespread negative comments about the time it is taking Mr. Kaifu to assemble an aid package for the international efforts against Iraq. The polls show that Mr. Kaifu remains popular, but politicians say the criticism could undercut his ability to govern effectively. **********The latest problem for Mr. Kaifu occurred after the visit to Pyongyang last week of Shin Kanemaru, a former Deputy Prime Minister who is widely known as the most influential power broker in the governing Liberal Democratic Party. **********Tokyo Assails Communique **********On Friday, Mr. Kanemaru's delegation signed a statement with North Korean leaders calling for an early dialogue to establish diplomatic relations. They also promised an unspecified amount of money to compensate North Korea for Japan's past colonization of the Korean peninsula. **********Mr. Kanemaru's delegation of politicians was unofficial, representing the Liberal Democratic Party and the Japan Socialist Party. But the widespread perception in Japan and Korea was that it had Mr. Kaifu's blessings and spoke for his Government. **********With his close associate, former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, who resigned last year, Mr. Kanemaru is seen as the principal political patron whose support keeps Mr. Kaifu in office, mainly because of the vast amount of patronage and financial resources Mr. Kanemaru controls. **********But this week it was disclosed that the Foreign Ministry, which will be in charge of carrying out the negotiations with Pyongyang, was incensed at being shut out of Mr. Kanemaru's discussions last week. Indeed, Foreign Ministry officials said the Pyongyang communique had no official standing. **********Breach of Protocol **********The communique raised eyebrows in Tokyo and in South Korea, because it seemed to adopt some of North Korea's longstanding positions, using language like ''Korea is one,'' a longtime code phrase by Pyongyang for its position that Seoul is an illegitimate usurper and pawn of Washington. **********The communique also promised that Japan would compensate Korea for injustices in the years after 1945, which diplomats said was confusing to them because Japan has had no dealings with Pyongyang since World War II. **********In Seoul, President Roh Tae Woo said he wanted clarifications, asserting that South Korea had never been compensated for the postwar years. But Foreign Ministry officials said they could not clarify the communique because their officials were excluded from key meetings in Pyongyang. **********Mr. Kanemaru said this week that if the criticism became too strong, he would resign from politics -a statement that was not taken seriously in the party, considering his power base. **********Prime Minister Kaifu, speaking in New York, said his Government would embark on talks with North Korea but raised doubts about whether Japan would compensate Korea for the post-1945 period. **********It was the second time in the last few weeks that Mr. Kaifu had been undercut by one of the people seen as his patrons. On a visit to China last month, Mr. Takeshita talked to reporters at length about the prospects of a Cabinet shuffling and the chances of Mr. Kaifu's visiting China in the future. Newspaper reports in Japan said he sounded like an incumbent Prime Minister, showing that he seemed to be more in control than Mr. Kaifu. **********The Koreas and the U.N. **********UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 2 (Special to The New York Times) - The North Korean Government has said in a letter to the President of the Security Council that it is willing to discuss ''various solutions'' to its previous demand that North and South Korea be represented by a single delegate at the United Nations. **********The South Koreans, who established diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union on Sunday in a move that appeared to pave the way for their admission to the United Nations, insist on separate seats for the two Koreas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/17/busin.main_headline: Your Money;   Advice for Elderly On Health Policies
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/17/busin.print_headline: Your Money;   Advice for Elderly On Health Policies
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/17/busin.body_text: **********Older taxpayers may be taken aback when they start to fill out their 1989 income tax forms. Many thought they had won a major victory in December when Congress repealed the surtax for catastrophic medical care that could have run as high as $800 per person or $1,600 per couple. But there it is on the forms, line 54 of the Form 1040 and line 23 of the 1040A. **********''Ignore it,'' said Hal M. Cohen of Deloitte & Touche. ''Don't use it. The forms had already been printed when the surtax was repealed.'' Those who included that liability when making estimated tax payments last year ''will get it back as a refund,'' he added. **********Mr. Cohen, who is based in Morristown, N.J., is a member of the accounting firm's executive financial planning group. So he has a suggestion for how to use the funds that would have paid the surtax: buy supplemental medical insurance. **********''The emotional and financial expenses of a long-term illness can deplete the assets and income of two generations,'' he said, if a family must pay for the uninsured portion of doctor and hospital bills or for custodial or nursing-home care not covered under Medicare that can cost $20,000 a year or more. **********Consequently, Mr. Cohen is advising all his older clients, as well as those who may be responsible for elderly parents, to be sure they have adequate health-care insurance ''in order to avoid financial disaster or substandard medical care.'' **********Once a person reaches age 65, he or she is eligible for Medicare. It becomes the primary carrier for those who are retired, and supplemental ''medigap'' insurance is available through private carriers. Medicare pays 80 percent of allowable charges, but medical costs often exceed Medicare's allowable limits. **********Medicare and the medigap policies will pay for nursing-home stays in approved facilities with medical staffs after hospitalization. Unlike Medicaid, which is the medical-welfare program for the indigent, Medicare will not pay for long-term custodial care for people who have not been hospitalized, like those suffering from Alzheimer's disease. So middle-class people are likely to need private insurance for this. **********''Shop around,'' Mr. Cohen said. ''There can be tremendous differences among policies,'' both in terms of the cost and of the coverage provided. He suggested starting with the American Association of Retired Persons, which markets a Prudential medigap plan, or by consulting an independent insurance agent. **********Insurance is regulated by state insurance commissions, so what is available in one state may not be available in another. **********Tamara G. Telesko, vice president of Chase U.S. Private Banking, part of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said that with the frequent need for custodial care among the elderly, more people are becoming aware of the need for private insurance to supplement Medicare. However, she cautioned, this is a relatively new product, and actuarial data are still being developed. With rising health-care costs, premiums may rise. **********Deloitte & Touche has advised its clients to look for policies that provide a waiver of premium in the event of disability, a maximum benefit period for one nursing-home stay of at least four years and a daily nursing-home benefit of about $80, with inflation protection written into the policy. Inflation protection can increase the premium cost by as much as one-third. **********It is also important to make sure that the company issuing the policy is financially sound. One way to do this is to check the rating issued by A.M. Best & Company. Ratings range from A+ (superior) to C (poor). **********Among the features Deloitte & Touche recommends in considering policies are these: *********** Guaranteed Renewability. The policy should be guaranteed renewable for life, except for nonpayment of premium, so that the insurer cannot cancel the policy when the individual is making use of its coverage. *********** Deductible Period. This is the period, generally 21 to 365 days, that must pass before the insurer begins to pay benefits. Although the shorter period is preferable, the longer period may reduce the premium. *********** Grace Period. This is the time, generally seven to 31 days, after the premium due date, before which the insurer may cancel the policy. It gives the policyholder some protection, should he or she forget to pay the premium on time. *********** Care Coverage. The policy should say clearly whether it covers skilled, intermediate and custodial care without a pre-hospitalization requirement. Also, some policies provide long-term home care only as a rider for an extra charge. **********Alzheimer's disease is generally described in policy language as ''organically based mental conditions,'' and if such coverage is not specifically mentioned, Alzheimer's is probably not included. **********In deciding on coverage, people need to do a cash-flow analysis to help determine how long they are able and willing to pay for their own medical costs before they would need insurance. And they need to determine whether they have any retiree health-care benefits. **********Two groups are more likely than most to have these benefits, Mr. Cohen said - executives whose compensation package included them and union members.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/23/busin.body_text: **********An employee of a subsidiary of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. settled charges today that he had traded on insider information before Grand Met announced that it was buying the Pillsbury Company in 1988. **********Stuart A. Godfrey, a resident of Larchmont, N.Y., settled the civil charges, filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission in Federal court in Manhattan, without admitting or denying the allegations. Mr. Godfrey is the manager of corporate accounting at the Inter-Continental Hotels Corporation, a subsidiary of Grand Met. **********Mr. Godfrey was permanently enjoined from further violations of Federal civil anti-fraud statutes and agreed to repay $16,215 in profits and interest and pay a fine of $14,221. **********According to the complaint, Mr. Godfrey purchased call option contracts on Pillsbury stock on Sept. 16, 1988, giving him the right to buy stock at a fixed price until November. After Grand Met's announcement in October of its merger agreement, Pillsbury stock climbed to $57.50 a share, from $39.125. The S.E.C. said Mr. Godfrey then sold the call options for $14,221 in illegal profits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/12/busin.body_text: **********The Hoechst Celanese Corporation said on Thursday that its earnings fell 33.8 percent in the first quarter because of weakness in several markets for its chemical and textile products. **********Net earnings fell to $43 million on sales of $1.3 billion, compared with earnings of $65 million on sales of $1.4 billion in the first three months of 1989. **********''We've experienced a very slow start this year, mainly due to the impact of cold-weather problems at the beginning, some softening of selling prices in commodity chemicals, and a major downturn in the domestic auto-production industry,'' said Ernest H. Drew, president and chief operating officer. **********''We still remain optimistic that we'll see an improvement starting in the second quarter and gaining strength throughout the second half of the year.'' **********The company is a subsidiary of the West German chemical company Hoechst A.G. **********Sales in the life-sciences group were up 7 percent over 1989 because of the strong performances of home health-care products, herbicides and a cattle-growth substance, the company said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.body_text: **********President Bush's choice as the next chief regulator of the nation's savings and loan industry today faced a highly skeptical Senate Banking Committee, whose members voiced deep worry that his lack of experience in the financial industry did not qualify him for the job. **********Coming at a time of crisis in the savings industry, and in the Government's huge effort to bail it out, the tenor of the confirmation hearings for the nominee, T. Timothy Ryan Jr., a former Labor Department lawyer in the Reagan Administration, cast doubt on his chances. **********With the bailout process essentially at a standstill because of court battles on the constitutionality of recent regulatory actions, and Government officials acknowledging that it will remain that way until a Senate-confirmed regulator is in place, the Administration had hoped that Mr. Ryan would be approved by the end of next week, before a scheduled April 11 hearing in the case. **********The hearing also provided a moment of drama in an unscheduled appearance by Charles H. Keating Jr., the Phoenix developer whose failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association has come to symbolize to many the ills of the industry. **********Troubled by Statements **********Members of the committee were particularly troubled by statements by Mr. Ryan, nominated as the next director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, that he did not ''have an opinion'' on whether there should be a savings and loan industry in the future. He also said that deregulatory measures passed by Congress in 1982 had contributed to the crisis. **********What Bush Administration officials knew would be a tough hearing became worse than expected, with senators and Banking Committee staff members saying they had never before seen such skepticism expressed at a nomination hearing. **********''I am not prejudging the outcome of this confirmation process, but some members have already expressed to me serious reservations about your nomination,'' Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the committee, told Mr. Ryan. **********''I am one of those troubled members,'' said Senator Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, who said he was alarmed that Mr. Ryan had ''virtually no exposure in no way, shape, or form in the financial industry.'' Connie Mack, a Florida Republican, added, ''You don't have the background or scope of knowledge to understand what is taking place in the trenches.'' **********The White House is under intense pressure to come up with a permanent appointee as director of the savings office. **********The bailout legislation of last summer called for M. Danny Wall, then chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, to be appointed automatically as head of the newly created office. A recent suit by a Chicago savings association seeking to avert a Government takeover case challenged the constitutionality of that appointment, on the ground that Mr. Wall had not been confirmed in his new post. **********Though an appeals court granted a stay of a lower court's ruling that the appointment was unconstitutional, several other lawsuits have been filed, contending that all regulatory and enforcement actions by the agency are invalid. **********Experience Cited **********Given the urgency, the Ryan nomination surprised many. At the hearing today, Mr. Ryan acknowledged that he lacked expertise in the financial sector, but contended that his experience as a manager of a Government bureaucracy, a reputation as a tough enforcer and almost a decade as a lawyer in a Washington law firm were sufficient qualifications for the job. **********''I have experience in managing people and a proven track record in enforcement,'' the 44-year-old Mr. Ryan told the committee. ''Quite frankly, gentlemen, I make things happen. I get things done.'' **********But that did not seem to be enough for a number of members of the committee, who repeatedly wondered why at such a time the Administration did not choose someone with extensive expertise in the savings industry. **********Senator Alan Cranston, the California Democrat, asked Mr. Ryan whether deregulation had contributed to the crisis. **********Citing the Garn-St Germain Act of 1982, Mr. Ryan said, ''It appears that the results have not been positive.'' **********Mr. Ryan was quickly taken to task by Senator Jack Garn, Republican of Utah, who said that the legislation bearing his name provided only modest deregulation for the industry, and that it was excessive deregulation at the state level that was to blame. **********Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, who sat in on the session, also questioned whether Mr. Ryan had acted improperly in his dealings with the teamsters' union's Central States pension fund. Mr. Ryan, then at the Labor Department, had supported former Attorney General William Saxbe as independent special counsel for the pension fund; Mr. Saxbe later became associated with Mr. Ryan's law firm, bringing the firm business. Mr. Ryan denied any impropriety in that arrangement. **********Mr. Keating, after requesting the opportunity to appear before the committee to object to the Ryan nomination and being turned down, appeared in the hearing room today. He passed out a statement that objected to the Ryan nomination and held a small news conference, complaining about the lack of qualified regulators in the industry and blaming them for the industry's woes. **********Awkward Setting **********It provided an awkward setting, particularly for Mr. Riegle and Mr. Cranston. They and three other Senators are under investigaion by the Senate Ethics Committee for intervening on behalf of Mr. Keating with regulators after receiving large campaign contributions from him. **********Today, neither Mr. Riegle nor Mr. Cranston acknowledged Mr. Keating's presence in the room. **********Though some senators called for a vote today to send the Ryan nomination back to the White House, the earliest the panel can vote will be on Tuesday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/busin.body_text: *********** Bank of Montreal said it had com-pleted the estimated $23 million (Canadian), or $19.8 million (United States), sale of its 20 percent stake in Banque Transatlantique, a French bank, to the bank's largest shareholder, Credit Industriel et Commercial de Paris. *********** Compagnie Generale d'Electricite, Paris, the French telecommunications and engineering concern, said it would place between $150 million and $200 million of its shares with private investors in the United States by mid-July. *********** Metric Realty, Foster City, Calif., a real estate and investment company, said it had become a wholly owned subsidiary of Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., after Met Life, which already owned 50 percent of Metric, exercised an option to buy the remaining interest in the company. *********** Midlantic National Bank, a subsidiary of Midlantic Corp., Edison, N.J., said it had bought the corporate trust business of National Westminster Bank NJ, a subsidiary of National Westminster Bank P.L.C., London. Terms were not disclosed. *********** Nova Corp. of Alberta, Calgary, a petrochemicals and energy company, has completed the sale of its valve manufacturing unit, Grove Italia S.p.A., for $114 million (Canadian), or $98.1 million (United States) to an investment group headed by Sanpaolo Finance S.p.A., a subsidiary of Instituto Bancario San Paolo di Torino, an Italian bank. *********** Pfizer Inc., New York, a pharmaceuticals, health products and chemicals company, said it would sell its citric acid business to Archer-Daniels-Midland Co., Decatur, Ill., an agricultural products and chemicals company. Terms were not disclosed. *********** SmithKline Biologicals S.A., the Belgian unit of SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., has received a 243.7 million franc, or $7.2 million, grant from the Belgian Government for research and development of vaccines. *********** Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, Paris, the state-controlled oil company, and the Amoco Corp., Chicago, signed an agreement for Elf to buy Amoco's gasoline refining and retailing business in Britain, Terms were not disclosed. *********** Tiffany & Co., New York, said it would acquire most of the assets of the McTeigue division of Krementz & Co., Newark, a jewelry manufacturer. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/25/world.main_headline: Amid Crisis, West Meets Mideast in Saudi Arabia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/25/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Amid Crisis, West Meets Mideast in Saudi Arabia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/25/world.body_text: **********The arrival of American and foreign troops in Saudi Arabia and the flood of Kuwaiti refugees here are helping to pry open Saudi society, which has been hermetically sealed. **********This deeply conservative Muslim country of about 16 million people is being exposed to the glare of international news reporting, and Saudis are being drawn into a social enterprise that is radically different from their retiring ways and conspicuous traditions. **********So far, the Saudi Government has done its best to insulate its people from the effect of this crisis, keeping foreign troops well out of sight in all civilian regions - several hundred miles from this port city and from the inland capital of Riyadh - and maintaining a business-as-usual facade in its news reports and daily economic activities. **********Saudi newspapers and television news talk of the ''Islamic, Arab and other multinational forces,'' arriving here to stand up to Iraq - practically ignoring that the bulk of these troops are American soldiers that include women, Christians and Jews, in a country that is almost 100 percent Muslim. **********In Dhahran, Al Khobar and Dammam, the heart of the Saudi oil industry and its vital pipelines, pumping stations and oilfields, barely 200 miles from where Iraq's missiles and troops are stationed, shops are open late into the night, hotels are full of guests, and military vehicles are only rarely seen. The American troops are out of sight, 15 to 20 miles away in the desert. **********Oil has made the Saudis one of the world's most prosperous nations, with an economic growth rate of 5 percent and virtually no unemployment. In Jidda, where the Saudi Government has been for the summer, the pulse of life is untouched. Cars linger over the long seaside corniche, and Egyptian soap-operas fill television programming. **********On the nightly news Saudi soldiers are paraded and senior Saudi officials review troops endlessly and listen to patriotic poems. But there is little discussion of the huge American buildup under way and virtually no mention of Iraqi troop movements close to the Saudi borders. **********''We don't feel a thing,'' said a senior oil executive in Dhahran as he drove his car up and down the main avenues of the oil town that is the headquarters of the Aramco oil company. ''If it weren't for foreign radio stations you would not suspect we are on the verge of war.'' **********A Xenophobic Grip **********Yet, a deep and fundamental debate has started in Saudi circles about the impact of this crisis on the future of the country. **********Saudi intellectuals and liberals are thrilled by the notion that the presence of American troops, and the immense good will the world is showing Saudi Arabia, will loosen the hold of the fundamentalist Muslim religious leaders, who have opposed every step of modernization in this country, from the education of girls to the introduction of television. **********But the purpose of the foreign presence does not escape Saudi officials. They are concluding that this country can absorb a first strike by Iraq, but fervently hoping that the United States would hit first, with a devastating attack on Iraqi forces. **********''We think that there is a 3 percent chance of missiles getting through to our vital oil facilities,'' said one Saudi official, who expressed confidence that the combined American-Saudi airpower can handle any such atack with a ''knockout'' blow to Iraq's air force and missile launchers. **********Saudi intelligence officials estimate that Iraq's rate of production of land-to-land missiles is two per day, and a Saudi defense offical said it is believed that Iraq has not perfected the technique of mounting chemical warheads on its missiles. **********''The greatest probability is that they have to deliver chemical payloads by airplanes or artillery, which gives them a limited range of operation,'' said the defense official, who like many Saudis and foreigners interviewed here about the current crisis, asked for anonymity. **********In the streets of this desert country, the burning topic of conversation is the threat of war, and foreigners fret over whether they should stay or leave, while Saudis are content to bask in the notion that with American troops here and the whole world standing against Iraq, there is little doubt that President Saddam Hussein's days are numbered. **********''He is finished,'' said Khalid Ali Alturki, a successful businessman who lives in Al Khobar, speaking of President Hussein. ''The only question is how much it will cost - not whether it will happen. I think Kuwait will pay a heavy price, but no matter how much it costs, it is worth it to have back the country and rid us of Saddam.'' **********Saudi officials and senior members of the ruling Kuwaiti al-Sabah family who live here in the summer capital of Taif, said that Kuwait is indeed putting its formidable economic muscle behind the military effort against Iraq. **********It is understood from these officials that Kuwait, which holds foreign assets estimated at over $100 billion under the control of its Government-in-exile in Taif, is increasingly footing a growing part of the enormous costs of the deployment here of the American, Egyptian and other forces, which is running at some $25 million a day. **********''We are willing to sacrifice everything,'' said the Kuwaiti Crown Prince, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, in a meeting with the foreign press on Thrusday in Taif. **********Kuwaitis Underwriting **********Kuwait and Saudi Arabia are also believed to have advanced financial aid to Egypt to compensate for the rising costs of moving back tens of thousands of Egyptians fleeing Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait from Jordan. **********And, Saudi Arabia has been carrying the cost of housing, feeding and giving refuge to some 100,000 Kuwaitis who are refugees here. **********But Saudis in decision-making positions are rethinking the country's financial aid to the Palestine Liberation Organization. They make it clear that they will no longer deal with the current leadership of the P.L.O. and that they expect Yasir Arafat to be replaced as its chairman if the organization expects to resume normal ties and continue to receive financial aid. **********In Saudi Arabia, hardly a single Saudi misses the opportunity to vilify Mr. Arafat, who is seen as having betrayed this country and other gulf Emirates by siding with Iraq in the conflict. **********''From now on, we will support causes not people,'' said one well-placed Saudi in an extensive interview today. ''We are making the point that Yasir Arafat is finished here but that other Palestinian leaders who appreciate all the financial help we have extended to the Palestinian movement over the years and who have not turned against us will be welcome.'' **********Officially, the Saudi Government denies that there has been any break with the P.L.O. Saudi officials said that a request by Mr. Arafat to come here a few days ago was politely turned down, but on Thursday King Fahd received Hani al-Hassan, a senior P.L.O. leader who is widely seen as sympathetic to the gulf monarchies within the Palestinian movement. **********In conversations with many Saudis, including ordinary citizens, there appears to be a firm conviction that Iraq, the P.L.O., Yemen and Jordan have conspired to subdue the gulf emirates and Saudi Arabia in the hope of each getting rewards out of what is described as an obvious plot. **********''When Saddam attacked Kuwait, he really calculated that we will back down,'' said a Cabinet minister. ''Eventually they thought the P.L.O. would dominate Kuwait using the 400,000 Palestinians living there to govern and that Yemen would get a territorial adjustment in the South taking some land from us there. Jordan and Iraq would reap substantial financial aid from a subdued Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.'' **********The talk of the future in this region now envisages a whole different scenario. ''This is the beginning of what I think is going to be a rollback of the excessive influence of the Saudi religious establishment,'' a liberal Saudi official said. **********Faced with the immense good will the world has shown Saudi Arabia, the most conservative religious leaders, led by Sheik al-Baaz, the most senior religious figure in the kingdom, conceded in television interviews over the past few days that even though those who came here to ''defend Islam'' include ''atheists and Christians,'' not to mention women, they will be ''rewarded by God for their good deed,'' thus putting the seals of approval on the American presence here. **********American Habits **********Even though they deny it, American troops here are believed to have access to alcoholic drinks, including beer, and as their numbers rise to an anticipated 200,000, their influence is bound to be felt more strongly. **********Already in the Eastern province of Saudi Arabia, where the bulk of Kuwaiti refugees and American troops are, Kuwaiti women and American women soldiers have been seen driving their cars and jeeps in a country where women are strictly forbidden from driving. **********There is a story that has circulated widely in Saudi Arabia over the past few days: that an American woman soldier in uniform drove her car into Al Khobar to shop. Her behavior was viewed as nothing less than scandalous in a society where women virtually never appear alone in public. **********The soldier was approached by a Mutawaa, one of the Islamic fundamentalists who enforce laws of proper behavior. The Mutawaa raised his cane warning the soldier to get back into her car and go away. Whereupon, the story goes, the American pulled her gun and pointed it at his face sending him scrambling for cover. **********''It does not matter that the story is true or not,'' said a Cabinet minister who was among 14 people recounting it over a lunch recently. ''What matters is that everyone wants to believe that it is true,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/20/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWSB.P. to Reduce Staff by 1,150
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWSB.P. to Reduce Staff by 1,150
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/20/busin.body_text: **********The British Petroleum Company said today that it was cutting 1,150 jobs, or nearly half the staff, at its London headquarters in a reorganization intended to lower costs and make the oil giant more flexible. **********About 900 people will be laid off and the rest will be transferred, said a spokesman, who was not identified in accordance with British practice. **********The cuts, mainly affecting workers in administrative, computing and information services, would reduce by 46 percent the 2,500-member staff currently employed at the company's headquarters. B.P. has 118,000 employees worldwide. **********The cuts are part of B.P.'s **********''Project 1990'' to reduce the company's complexity and reduce expenses. **********B.P. said it was simplifying management by removing layers of managers, replacing departments with flexible teams and reducing the number of boards and committees. **********The announcement follows a reduction of 1,700 jobs, or 17 percent, in B.P.'s exploration and production activities last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/15/world.main_headline: U.S. Seeks to Deny Furnaces to Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/15/world.print_headline: U.S. Seeks to Deny Furnaces to Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/15/world.body_text: **********Concerned about the growing sophistication of Iraq's military, the Pentagon is leading a last-minute effort to prevent Baghdad from importing industrial furnaces that some experts say could be used to make components for missiles and atomic weapons. **********In a letter sent this week, Paul D. Wolfowitz, the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, urged the State Department to prohibit the Consarc Corporation of Rancocas, N.J., from shipping the furnaces, in which titanium and other exotic metals can be melted and cast, to a Government installation near the Iraqi capital. **********Mr. Wolfowitz's action comes days before a temporary Government ban on the export of the furnaces is set to expire. The sale had Commerce Department approval, but the Customs Service ordered Consarc last month to delay the shipment for 20 days while officials studied the furnaces's capabilities more closely. That prohibition expires on Tuesday. **********List of Prohibited Exports **********The Pentagon effort underscores a growing worry of United States officials that a recent easing of controls on high-technology exports, primarily aimed at Eastern European nations, will make it easier for some third-world dictatorships to acquire advanced military components. **********Some officials believe that the sale to Iraq could easily have been barred had a category of industrial furnaces similar to the Consarc equipment, once on a list of prohibited exports, not been removed in an agreement with European allies in early June. **********Iraq contends that the furnaces will be used primarily to process titanium, a strong, lightweight metal, for use in artificial arms and legs. But United States officials said this week that a review of the furnaces's specifications indicated that they were far more technologically sophisticated than such a purpose would require. **********In particular, they said, one device, called an induction skull melting furnace, has state-of-the-art technology found almost nowhere else in the United States or Europe. **********''The primary concern is that they can make parts for missiles,'' said an official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ''In tandem, these furnaces give the Iraqis a capacity for a production line much greater than they need for medical prosthetics.'' **********In an interview on Friday, the president of Consarc, Raymond J. Roberts, said that he was ''somewhat mystified'' by the controversy and that two similar furnaces in the United States and West Germany did not have military uses. **********Seeking Advanced Equipment **********Iraq's military is making an extensive effort to purchase advanced-technology equipment abroad for its missile and conventional and nuclear weapons programs. The American and British authorities said in April that they had foiled an Iraqi attempt April to use a front company in Britain to buy triggers for nuclear devices. **********Mr. Roberts said Consarc had won Commerce Department approval a year ago to sell Iraq three furnaces, including the skull melting furnace, so named because it has a crucible inside it shaped like a skull. Two other furnaces bound for Iraq are now in Britain. **********Officials said export applications listed the buyer of the furnaces as the Iraqi Ministry of Industry and Minerals, a nonexistent agency. They said the actual destination was a military research complex in the Karbala region of Iraq, just south of Baghdad, which is managed by the Ministry of Industry and Military Industrialization. **********Last month, as the three furnaces were being prepared for shipment near Philadelphia, the Customs Service became concerned that the skull melting furnace had restricted military applications and ordered the shipment held for inspection. **********The Commerce Department, which originally approved the export application, declined to comment on the matter on Friday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/09/busin.body_text: **********''Golden West is one of the best financial firms in the country, period,'' said Peter Treadway, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. **********There has not been much good news from the savings and loan industry for the past five years. Hundreds of institutions have collapsed and hundreds more are in danger of failure, victims of regional economic downturns, poor management and outright fraud. The cost to taxpayers will reach into the hundreds of billions of dollars. Industry executives are widely viewed as incompetent or criminal, and all too often the stereotype is true. **********But a significant portion of the industry has always remained profitable and honest. The Sandlers, for example, are conservative, methodical, penny-pinching and risk-averse in the extreme - and they have spent nearly three decades shaping Golden West, now the nation's sixth-largest savings and loan, in their image. The antithesis of the high-rollers attracted to the industry by deregulation, they remain downright boring - and proudly so. **********An Appetite for Calm **********''Perhaps we can best characterize Golden West's attitude toward lending by simply saying that your management likes to sleep undisturbed by worries and nightmares,'' the Sandlers wrote in a letter to shareholders in their most recent annual report. **********The Sandlers use all the techniques of modern financial management, paying especially close attention to cost control. But the core of their business is decidedly - some might say refreshingly - old-fashioned: The company lends out Federally insured deposits almost exclusively in the form of home mortgage loans, forgoing potentially more lucrative but far riskier loans and direct investments in shopping centers, office buildings and other commercial real estate. Of the 27,436 loans it made last year, 93 percent went to single-family homes and virtually all of the rest to multi-unit residential housing. **********It does this through a network that seems almost anachronistic in this age of one-stop financial shopping. It has 205 branches in California and five other states and operates 65 loan offices in 16 states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. **********For the most part, the branches accept only savings deposits, eschewing the business of offering checking and other ''transaction'' accounts that might attract more customers but are far more expensive to maintain. To keep costs low, the company does not even have automated teller machines, almost certainly making it the largest financial institution in the nation not to offer that service. Most of its customers are old-fashioned savers, who patiently deposit their funds in return for competitive interest rates. ''They've identified their customer and the services the customer wants, and they don't provide anything else,'' Mr. Treadway said. ''They have tremendous control of expenses.'' As archaic as the strategy might seem, it has worked. Golden West's earnings have been consistently strong at a time when the industry as a whole has been running up huge losses. The company's shares are worth 10 times what they were at the beginning of the 1980's. It has almost no bad loans. **********Even as most other institutions scramble to raise more capital to meet the Government's tougher new standards for financial strength, Golden West is in the enviable position of having far more capital than regulations require. Unlike most savings and loans, Golden West has also been able to raise new capital in the financial markets in recent months, completing two subordinated debt offerings totaling $215 million. **********As a result, it is one of the few institutions with the capability of expanding, either by acquisition or internal growth. In May, for example, the company acquired from the Government the $725 million in deposits held by a failed savings institution in Colorado, already its second-largest market after California. And just last week, the company completed the acquisition of Community Federal Savings and Loan in Ramsey, N.J. Community Federal, with six branches and assets of $460 million, gives Golden West its first deposit-taking offices in the Northeast. **********The Partnership **********The Sandlers have been running Golden West together since acquiring it for $4.1 million in 1963, when it had $34 million in assets. They took it public in 1968, and today, assets have grown to $20 billion. **********Mr. Sandler, 58 years old, is a former New York lawyer who serves as chairman and co-chief executive and, in his three-piece suit, looks very much the old-fashioned banker. Mrs. Sandler, 59, learned about the industry as a securities analyst on Wall Street. She holds the titles of co-chief executive and president. The two finish each others' sentences, prompt each other to tell favorite stories and appear to have long since worked out whatever problems might have cropped up in the marriage of their personal and business lives. **********''You know that old saying about it being lonely at the top?'' asked Mr. Sandler. ''Well, it's not here.'' **********Moreover, they are clearly enjoying the vindication of their cautious approach after having been roundly criticized by Wall Street for not being aggressive enough and disparaged by competitors for running something of a dinosaur. ''Over 20 years, running the institution in our fashion, through all the turmoil that's taken place, our compound annual rate of growth and earnings is 20 percent,'' said Mr. Sandler, ticking off the kind of statistic that has turned Golden West into a current favorite among stock analysts. ''To my knowledge, no bank or thrift has done that.'' **********Yet the Sandlers still face questions about whether their approach can continue to work in an age of full-service banking. Most of Golden West's major competitors - including its two biggest rivals, H. F. Ahmanson & Company of Los Angeles and the Great Western Financial Company of Beverly Hills - are positioning themselves to compete directly with commercial banks. **********Believing that the distinctions between banks and savings and loans will continue to disappear in coming years, both Ahmanson and Great Western are pushing to get more transaction accounts from customers. Great Western offers consumer loans and other services that were once the exclusive province of banks. **********''Golden West is very strong for what it attempts to do, but that's not the only route to success as the banking and thrift worlds come together,'' said Bert Ely, an industry consultant in Alexandria, Va. ''The thing I worry about is that while their strategy certainly works today, it may not work five years from now.'' **********Looking at Change **********The Sandlers say they have nothing against change. After Congress and the state legislatures deregulated the industry during the early 1980's, ''We researched discount brokerage,'' said Mr. Sandler. ''We just couldn't figure out how to make money in it. Everyone else got into it, and a few years later they were all getting out.'' **********Now, Mr. Sandler said, the company is studying the possibility of offering traditional checking and other transaction accounts. ''We're going to analyze it, and if there's a role for it, we'll go ahead with it,'' he said. **********Still, the Sandlers freely admit that they see no advantage to plunging into new businesses just to be trendy or to match the competition. **********Golden West's most clearly visible advantage is its low operating costs. The company's general and administrative expenses last year - the cost of running the company - were $181.8 million, or 0.97 percent of total assets, down from 1.14 percent the year before. That compares to 1.57 percent of assets on average last year for the 10 other largest savings and loan companies in California. **********If the company's expense ratio had been the same as that of its competitors, its earnings last year would have been $86.5 million, or $1.37 a share, instead of its actual profits of $157.9 million, or $2.51 a share. In this year's second quarter, Golden West earned $49 million, or 78 cents a share, a 22 percent increase over the same period in 1989. **********The greater profit margin gives the company more flexibility in deciding how many new loans to make - and therefore it may say no to riskier loans that other institutions might consider as they try to generate higher earnings. **********''Because we're such a profitable company, we can operate well with a lower volume,'' Mrs. Sandler said. ''We don't have a high-fixed-overhead loan machine that we have to feed continually.'' **********The company's cost advantage comes from many things, large and small. It does not have the expense of installing and maintaining automated teller machines nor the costs involved in traditional checking accounts, which require expensive check-processing equipment, data bases and manpower. Cost-consciousness is so ingrained that branch managers charge executives visiting from headquarters for the phone calls they make from the branch. **********The company also studies the work load in its branches and has an hour-by-hour and day-by-day model for each staffing requirement. Of the 1,050 employees who work in its branches, more than 500 are on permanent part-time status, keeping payroll costs low. The company has something of a reputation for stinginess and has never invested much in the appearance of its branches. **********A Modest Look **********''Their branches are - I wouldn't call them low rent, because that would be unfair,'' said Eric I. Hemel, an analyst at the First Boston Corporation. ''They're streamlined. They're smaller and more Spartan. They're a visual metaphor for the entire company.'' Just as important to Golden West's success as cost-cutting is the high quality of its loan portfolio, a result, to some extent, of its almost total concentration on home mortgage lending. Borrowers, after all, are less likely to default on their mortgages than on any other type of loan. **********And even within the field of mortgage lending, Golden West stands out. Last year, an impressive 93 percent of its residential loans were made with downpayments of 20 percent or more, considerably higher than the industry average. The result has been to keep the number of bad loans to a minuscule five-tenths of 1 percent of total loans last year. **********Just Say No **********How do they do this? The Sandlers point to a deeply ingrained corporate culture, which holds that there is no shame for a loan officer to say no. Indeed, when in two periods in the last decade economic conditions or intense competition suggested that they would have to lower credit standards to attract borrowers, they instead virtually swore off making new loans, even at the cost of not growing for a year or two. **********''We were damned by Wall Street,'' Mrs. Sandler said. ''When you have zero loan growth for two years, you really feel the heat.'' **********But by retaining earnings at a time when it was not growing in asset size, Golden West improved its underlying financial strength. **********The strategy paid off when Congress, in legislation passed last year to bail out and reform the industry, substantially increased capital requirements. **********Today, as one of the few institutions whose capital levels greatly exceed all three of the Government's new minimum tests for financial strength, Golden West has options closed to most institutions. Chief among them is the ability to grow. **********Many analysts think the company's next big move will be in Florida, where it holds an option to acquire Beach Federal Savings, a failed institution in Boynton Beach owned by the Government. **********But whatever Golden West does - and however it chooses to adapt to growing competition from banks and to the always changing regulatory climate - as long as the Sandlers stay in charge, it is certain to remain conservative, even dull. ''We have a jewel of a company,'' Mrs. Sandler said, ''and we're not about to do anything to jeopardize it.'' **********THE SANDLERS, SIDE BY SIDE **********OAKLAND, Calif. **********It is not always easy for Herb and Marion Sandler to be husband and wife as well as co-chief executives. They will occasionally be at a dinner party or business gathering when the men and women drift into separate groups. ''The wives gather here and the gentlemen gather there, and I want to be over there where Herb is talking about business,'' Mrs. Sandler said. ''It can be a little awkward.'' **********But aside from that type of situation, the Sandlers say they have almost no problems working alongside each other. ''If we came at things differently all the time, it would be impossible, but that's true for any executives working closely together, not just husbands and wives,'' Mrs. Sandler said. After graduating from City College of New York and Columbia University Law School, Mr. Sandler became a lawyer and represented a number of savings institutions. Mrs. Sandler, after graduating from Harvard and New York University's business school, worked as a securities analyst, following the stocks of savings and loan companies. After their marriage, in 1961, they talked constantly about how they were unimpressed by the quality of the management running most savings institutions. Finally, deciding to see if they could do better, they moved to the West Coast from New York to scout small savings institutions that might be takeover candidates. In 1963, they made a deal for Golden West. **********Today, they work in adjacent offices and are in and out of meetings together all day. And although it's clear that they run the company, they stress repeatedly how much they rely on the two other members of their office of the chairman - James T. Judd, 51 years old, and Russell W. Kettell, 46, both senior executive vice presidents. ''This isn't the Herb and Marion show,'' Mr. Sandler said. Although they are not planning on retiring any time soon, the Sandlers have a succession plan in place, in case of the unexpected. Mr. Judd and Mr. Kettell are at the top of the list. ''We call it the Mack Truck question,'' Mr. Sandler said. ''We all have backups ready to go in case something happens. The idea of somebody being indispensable is anathema to corporate governance.'' **********THE SEATTLE STAR **********When listing the nation's best-managed savings institutions, analysts usually mention a handful of other large California-based companies in addition to Golden West, including the Great Western Financial Corporation of Beverly Hills and H. F. Ahmanson & Company of Los Angeles. **********But there are also small, little-known institutions like the Washington Federal Savings and Loan Association of Seattle - ''arguably the stellar performer - pound for pound, inch for inch - of the nation's savings institution industry,'' according to Eric I. Hemel, an analyst at the First Boston Corporation. **********Washington Federal has $2.6 billion in assets and 65 branches in Washington, Oregon and Idaho. It is perhaps the strongest company in the industry as measured by its capital reserves. **********Unlike most other institutions, Washington Federal continues to make mostly fixed-rate instead of adjustable-rate mortgages. Fixed-rate mortgages can be riskier than adjustables for savings institutions because they become less profitable if interest rates rise. **********Elliot Knutson, Washington Federal's chairman, said he has never been worried. ''We've been profitable every month for 30 years,'' he said. ''If you keep your costs low enough and your people are good enough and your capitalization is strong enough, you can keep the risks low.''
