https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/17/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   How Much Should Companies Tell?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/17/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   How Much Should Companies Tell?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/17/busin.body_text: **********A bitter and intensifying quarrel between Caterpillar Inc. and Wall Street analysts over the company's delayed disclosure of information that proved damaging to its stock price raises several important questions for companies and investors alike: **********Should a company alert analysts if it knows they are disseminating inaccurate information? Should multinational companies like Caterpillar be required to disclose their profits from individual countries if one or more of them is contributing disproportionately to the profits? Do Wall Street analysts - supposed to be the eyes and ears of investors - often make naive assumptions about a company's operations? **********These questions arose from a briefing for analysts on June 25 that was called by Caterpillar, the world's largest maker of earth-moving equipment. When the company announced before the session that its Brazilian operations had sunk into a deep slump because of economic changes in that country, the company's stock dropped only slightly. **********Stock Plunges **********But later that day, Caterpillar informed analysts in a telephone conference call just how important its Brazil operations are - they provided 20 percent of 1989 profits. In large part because of the circumstances in Brazil, Caterpillar told analysts that earnings in its second quarter, ended June 30, would be ''less than half'' the $99 million it earned in the first quarter and that profits for the year would be ''substantially lower'' than 1989 results. **********Caterpillar's stock, which trades on the New York Stock Exchange, went into an immediate free fall, dropping to $52 over two days, from $63, or by more than $1 billion. Analysts, after all, had assumed in their earnings estimates that the Brazil operations were relatively unimportant, since they had generated only 5 percent of Caterpillar's 1989 revenues. **********Some experts in financial analysis say the assumptions demonstrate how naive the investment community can be. But analysts accuse the company of failing to disclose on a timely basis the critical importance of Brazil. They say that Caterpillar had allowed them to disseminate optimistic earnings estimates even though its executives knew the estimates were based on a false assumption. **********The analysts contend that some investors would not have suffered such losses had Caterpillar been forthcoming earlier. Between March 16, when the Brazilian economic package was announced, and June 25, when the company disclosed the importance of Brazil to its overall profit picture, Caterpillar's market value rose by roughly $700 million. **********''The whole concept of what Cat has been earning and the quality of those earnings has been brought into question by the disclosure about Brazil,'' said Alex Blanton, an analyst who follows the company at Merrill Lynch. **********Tobias Levkovich of Smith Barney said: ''People are angry because they lost a lot of money on the stock. . But there is clearly now a credibility problem at Cat.'' **********Caterpillar executives say they were merely following company policy of not disclosing profits from individual countries for competitive reasons. They say Caterpillar never comments on the accuracy of analysts' reports, no matter how far off the mark. They say they decided to abandon those rules only when it became clear that Brazil's economic package would have a major effect, well beyond what the company itself had anticipated. ''As soon as we saw it was going to have a profound impact, we went to the marketplace with it,'' said Len A. Kuchan, head of investor relations at Caterpillar. **********In fact, a number of companies, including Citicorp, Sears, Roebuck and Parker Hannifin, the heavy machinery company, do not comment on analysts' forecasts as a matter of policy. These companies prefer to release information at formal analysts' meetings or in connection with earnings announcements. **********Under accounting rules, companies must break out the assets or revenues from operations in a particular country only if they exceed 10 percent of total revenues or assets. Companies are not required under securities laws to help analysts or to correct misinformation being circulated by investment professionals. **********''A company is free to adopt a policy of not comenting on any analyst report,'' said Richard Phillips, a Washington lawyer who is an authority on disclosure. **********But what companies clearly may not do is create misimpressions. Experts said an argument might be made that in disclosing only sales but not profits or losses about its Brazilian operations Caterpillar had set the stage for analysts to err. **********''The importance of Brazil to earnings should have been highlighted in the company's annual report, or Cat should have issued a special news release,'' said Edward D. Hurlihy, a securities law expert at the New York law firm of Wachtel, Lipton, Rosen & Katz. ''There is a real question in my mind as to whether they were derelict in their disclosure.'' **********Some investor-relations professionals suggest that Caterpillar should have disclosed the information earlier in the game anyway. ''If you want analysts to be comfortable with your company, you will keep them informed,'' said Lou Thompson, president of the National Investor Relations Institute, a Washington trade group. **********Caterpillar's June 25 announcement, no doubt, took analysts by surprise. Many of them rushed to cut their earnings estimates. Merrill Lynch, which had forecast that the company would earn $5.25 a share this year, has lowered the projection to $2.50. The First Boston Corporation had predicted that Caterpillar would earn $4.50 a share; now it sees $2.25. Oppenheimer & Company cut its earnings estimate to $2 from $4, and Morgan Stanley, to $2.50 from $4.25. **********A good part of the reductions in these estimates could be attributed to Caterpillar's Brazilian troubles. But the company is also hurting from the strength of the dollar against the yen, which has enabled a major competitor, Komatsu of Japan, to hold down price increases because it bills customers in dollars. Caterpillar is also feeling the effects of the slowdown in construction spending. **********As a result, some people think analysts' estimates on Caterpillar's earnings should have been closer to reality than they were. **********''People stopped listening,'' said Eli S. Lustgarten, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. who placed a ''hold'' recommendation on Caterpillar shares several months ago. ''They were afraid of missing a big run-up in the stock.'' **********Some analysts say this is not the first time the company has permitted them to stray far from the mark only to be told the true situation at the last minute. In the fall of 1988, for instance, analysts circulated reports saying that Caterpillar would enjoy double-digit increases in earnings per share in 1989. The company said nothing to dispute those reports. In the following January, Caterpillar said it expected earnings to be flat. **********''It kicked the stock from $66 to $60 before you could blink an eye,'' said Karen A. Ubelhart, the Caterpillar analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ''That's why you can get blown away by Cat - because they don't give you much help.'' **********Having taken a fall, is Caterpillar's stock, which rose $1, to $53.375, on the New York Stock Exchange today, now a good buy? **********Mr. Lustgarten of Paine Webber said that over the next few quarters, cash invested in Caterpillar is ''dead money.'' He worries that the company could give more details of its trouble at a meeting with analysts later this month, sending the stock lower. In the past, he noted, Caterpillar stock has typically bottomed out at the company's book value per share - the excess of assets over liabilities. Recently, that has been $45. **********''Given that declines in volume are just now being announced, it is too early to buy the stock,'' Mr. Lustgarten said. **********But a number of other analysts say that Caterpillar is a good bet for long-term investors. At McDonald & Company, a Cleveland-based securities firm, Patrick E. Sheridan said that Caterpillar had nearly a 50 percent share of the construction equipment market and was an acknowledged leader in quality. He predicts that the company's stock will climb to $70 in the next few years. **********''A friend of mine, a New York analyst, says this company is going to win and that it's just a question of when,'' Mr. Sheridan said. ''I couldn't have said it better.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/busin.main_headline: After the Run of Rich Deals, Risk in Arbitrage is Back
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/busin.print_headline: After the Run of Rich Deals, Risk in Arbitrage is Back
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/busin.body_text: **********At a time when a shaky ''junk bond'' market and a paucity of takeover deals have sent many Wall Street arbitragers to the sidelines, a few stalwarts are still hanging in. In fact, they contend that the current bloodbath in takeover stocks should not be cause for concern. Rather, they say, it should be seen as just another business opportunity. **********''A lot of people are nervous and think the world is coming to an end,'' said one veteran arbitrager, who declined to be named. ''But right now, the business is terrific for a firm that is well positioned and really does its homework. It will make money.'' **********To be sure, that's a decidedly contrarian viewpoint among Wall Street's arbitragers, a secretive, tightknit band of investors who buy stocks in takeover deals. Wall Street at large has the jitters, but arbitragers have been stung in particular by the failure last October of the proposed buyout of the UAL Corporation. This has left some with multimillion-dollar losses and even more with a fear of dipping into the market too aggressively. **********In the last few months, many arbitragers have been ''cleaned out of the marketplace,'' said Guy Wyser-Pratte, head of arbitrage at Prudential-Bache Securities. Other traditional players, like Salomon Brothers; Smith Barney; Prescott, Ball & Turben, and even Mr. Wyser-Pratte, have scaled back considerably. **********Still, some arbitragers, largely independent operators, say there is money to be made where others fear to tread. They say that spreads between takeover bids and the underlying shares are the widest in years. The key is to pick the right deals from the few around and to have enough nerve to stay the course. **********''People have gotten beat up and discouraged and tired,'' said Richard Nye of Baker, Nye, a private New York investment firm. To Mr. Nye, this represents a ''moment of great opportunity.'' Even though Mr. Nye said that his firm has scaled back, he insists that, ''on a selective basis, there are some very attractive opportunities.'' **********Arbitragers make money by betting on the outcome of takeovers, restructurings, leveraged buyouts and bankruptcies. They buy massive amounts of stock in hopes of cashing in when the deal is consummated. The returns can be enormous; but the losses can be equally staggering if the deal collapses. **********Arbitrage is generally portrayed as high-risk, but veterans say they are really quite conservative at heart - their investments are based on intense research and a keen eye for potential losses. In fact, today's environment, veteran arbitragers say, is what highlights the risk in risk arbitrage, something, they say, that many new entrants into the business lost sight of in the heady days of takeovers and buyouts in the late 1980's. **********That point was brutally driven home by the fiasco at UAL, the parent of United Airlines. **********In that deal, a $300-a-share bid by the pilots' union and top management triggered a high-wire drama that ended when lenders balked at providing funds for the highly leveraged transaction. The company's unions are putting together another buyout proposal, but no formal bid has been made and none is imminently expected. **********Several big investors have been left with huge potential losses. Coniston Partners, for example, which bought 11.8 percent of the company for an average disclosed price of $161 a share, is facing paper losses of more than $60 million. Last Friday, UAL stock closed at $136.50 a share. **********If that didn't scare many away - or wipe them out - the takeover news since then has only continued to be bad. The virtual collapse of the market for high-risk, high-yield junk bonds - the primary source of financing for speculative takeovers and buyouts - as well as a sharp contraction in takeover lending by commercial banks have pretty much brought activity to a halt. **********And the failure of such celebrated takeovers as the acquisition of the Federated and Allied retail store groups by Canadian investor Robert Campeau and the sour publicity surrounding megadeals like the RJR Nabisco buyout have only increased the concern over such deals - and decreased their numbers. **********Even some of the few deals around - ones that would be considered small potatoes in days gone by - have met with sad demises. A proposed $367 million, $30-a-share takeover of the Birmingham Steel Corporation by the Harbert Corporation was halted last month when financing could not be arranged. The stock closed last Friday at $16.875. **********And a $24-a-share, $672 million acquisition of Philips Industries, a manufacturer based in Dayton, Ohio, has been halted because of financing problems. When the deal was first announced last September, Philips was to be acquired by a unit of Merrill Lynch & Company at $25.50 a share. But that buyout price was cut in November before the deal was halted last month. Last Friday, Philips closed at $15. **********''You are entering situations and they are just not panning out the way they would have a year ago,'' said Michael Greenberg, a senior vice president at Prescott, Ball. ''So that's why it's tough being an arb. You put money on the line in these transactions and they are not going through. You are not getting rewarded. The market is lousy.'' **********In such a market, the contrarians say, the task is to do enough research to know when to buy and whether to hold or sell. The current roster of takeover stocks has seen its shares drop considerably in value in the last few weeks. This has created nervousness and paper losses, but it could also produce tremendous gains for the gutsy arbitrager who has a cool head and bets right. **********''When you see panic and uncertainty, you will see spreads, and in a time of panic, these do not reflect reality,'' said Mr. Wyser-Pratte. Added one arbitrager who is currently buying takeover stocks: ''One of the reasons that takeover stocks are going down is because others are too frightened to buy them. This is what makes it a terrific business now.'' **********Arbitragers still in the market are looking at a handful of deals: *********** Following a hostile $58-a-share bid from the Georgia-Pacific Corporation last October, the stock of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation shot up about $20 a share, amid talk that the final price would be between $65 and $70 a share. Last week, Georgia-Pacific, which now is bidding $63 a share, won a major court victory that could end the long takeover fight. Great Northern's stock closed at $61.375 on Friday. *********** Last Thursday, management at Sea Containers Ltd. proposed a second $70-a-share recapitalization plan. The new plan was viewed as less attractive in some respects than the original, which was proposed last October in the face of a hostile bid. Sea Containers stock fell $3.75 on Thursday and Friday, closing the week at $62.875. *********** The shares of the Lin Broadcasting Corporation, which had traded as high as $130, closed Friday at $113.375. It appears that a planned sale of a majority stake to the McCaw Cellular Communications Corporation might have financing trouble. *********** And then there is the Hilton Hotels Corporation, which put itself up for sale last August and saw its stock rise to $115.50 a share. But no buyer has emerged. Hilton stock closed Friday at $61.75. **********With numbers like these, it is not surprising that so many traditional players have cut back their arbitrage activities to a shoestring operation - contrarians notwithstanding. Some firms, like the Blackstone Group, which had raised some $175 million for arbitrage, have even decided to leave the business. **********''It will be a good business to be in at some future period; the question is when,'' said Stephen Schwarzman, a Blackstone partner. **********Said Lewis L. Glucksman, vice chairman at Smith Barney: ''The smart money is waiting on the sidelines. We've got almost no exposure at this time. There have been so many busted deals all over the place that the smart money is waiting until deals don't bust so fast.'' **********The wait may be lengthy, given that concerns about a possible economic slowdown have not only dampened takeover activity even further but have also caused the stock market in general to be sluggish. **********''It's like a huge trend right now,'' said Mr. Greenberg at Prescott, Ball. ''The collapse of the junk-bond market is a repudiation of everything that happened in the last five years. The way it feels in your gut is like no deal can get done. And as each one of the deals out there doesn't get done, it makes arbs in the other deals more nervous.'' Despite this, still others feel arbitrage is not dead. ''A lot of these deals will work,'' one arbitrager said. ''The real business of arbitrage will go on forever. There will be good times and bad times. But there will always be situations, and the people who say that arbitrage is dead are ridiculous.'' **********FROM OBSCURITY TO EXCESS **********Until the 1980's, arbitrage was an arcane activity performed by a handful of firms, primarily L. F. Rothschild, Goldman Sachs, Salomon Brothers and Bear, Stearns. The business consisted of these firms cautiously investing their capital in announced takeover deals. **********As buyouts, takeovers and the bull market took hold in the mid-1980's, a band of individual arbitragers appeared on the scene. Perhaps the best known was Ivan Boesky, who was later brought down for insider trading. **********These new investors transformed the business by amassing large pools of money through limited partnerships that they formed with outside investors. What was once a money-making activity for Wall Street partners now was available to institutional investors and wealthy individuals. **********This new era also saw the risk of the business increase. Big bettors, like Mr. Boesky, would stun the arbitrage community by putting all their chips on one deal - forsaking the golden rule of diversification. Moreover, the investment pools frequently purchased stocks on margin. **********But a rising tide of takeover deals kept the business growing and the risk at bay. Money chased deals and there were plenty of deals to chase. The growth of the ''junk bond'' market over the same time fueled a speculative takeover and buyout boom that provided endless opportunity for arbitragers. Not surprisingly, more people set themselves up as arbitragers, and more money poured into the business. **********But as the 1990's begin, Mr. Boesky, who ultimately went to prison for his illegal activities, is a shameful symbol of Wall Street's excesses and the junk-bond market is in shambles. **********The collapse of the UAL deal and the problems at the Campeau Corporation may well bring arbitrage back to its conservative roots.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/11/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Concurrent Computer Appoints Top Officers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/11/busin.body_text: **********Mr. Brown said the company's substantial losses in recent quarters mask its strengths. ''A lot of the red ink you're seeing is related to the merger two years ago and restructuring within the company to adjust to lower-than-anticipated revenues,'' he said in a telephone interview. ''They do have strong cash flow,'' which he said was as important to a heavily leveraged company as positive earnings. **********''I look forward to the challenges which Concurrent faces in the computer industry,'' Mr. Brown said. ''With the company's large installed base and strong product development programs, we will continue to be a leading supplier of real-time solutions to the commercial, technical and government markets both here and abroad.'' **********Mr. Brown comes to Concurrent from the Penn Central Corporation, where since 1985 he has been president and chief executive officer of Penn Central Industries Group Inc., a $1 billion subsidiary. Previous to his employment at Penn Central, he served for 15 years at the ITT Corporation, where he was a corporate vice president and group executive for the Defense Space Group. **********A former naval officer, Mr. Brown received his B.A. degree from the University of California at Berkeley, and he has a B.S. degree in electrical engineering from the Naval Post Graduate School in Monterey, Calif. He and his wife, Margaret, have four children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   Witches Come Home to Roost
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   Witches Come Home to Roost
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/busin.body_text: **********THE witches were out on Friday, and now the questions are starting. **********The sudden fall in the Dow Jones industrial average in the final hour on Friday, as July futures and options contracts on the Major Market Index expired, renewed all the questions about volatility brought on by contract expirations. **********What is bringing on the questions is not the amount of the fall - more than 35 Dow points in the final hour of trading - but the fact it happened at all. Changes, imposed by the exchanges, that were supposed to minimize the volatility of the expiration may instead have intensified it. **********The principal change was the disclosure of order imbalances brought on by ''market on close'' orders, which are to be executed at the closing price and are the province of index arbitrage traders. The idea was that seeing those imbalances, and realizing that they were likely to move stock prices, other investors could put in offsetting orders. That would provide the other investors with better prices than they might have gotten otherwise and help to control volatility in the period that became known as the ''triple witching hour,'' because of the expiration of stock options, stock index options and stock index futures. **********The policy changes were supposed to take advantage of the nature of index arbitrage. When futures contracts are trading for less than their fair value, as can happen, traders can buy the contract and, more or less simultaneously, sell the underlying stocks. That strategy is easy with the Major Market Index, which is based on only 20 stocks. When the contracts expire, they are sure to be worth exactly the same as the underlying index, and traders simply buy back the stocks at the close of trading. In doing so, they get the prices that determine the value of the expiring contracts. **********Late last week, the rumor was that there would be heavy buying as a result of the Major Market Index expiration. Sure enough, the announced imbalances showed big buy orders. But even as they were being reported, prices started to fall. Anyone who put in sell orders to offset the imbalances wound up getting prices far lower than expected. **********What happened? One rumor is that there were games being played, and that some ''buy on close'' orders were suddenly withdrawn. It is legal to withdraw an order, unless it is for the purpose of market manipulation, and the New York Stock Exchange says it is studying the trading. **********Another explanation says that the buy imbalances, while large, were simply not so big as many had expected. When traders saw that development, they expected prices to fall and began to sell stock index futures and options based on other contracts, notably the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures, which did not expire this month. As the selling grew in Chicago, waves of index arbitrage selling hit the New York market, which was ill prepared for it. **********An aggravating factor may have been the fact that all this action was happening late on a summer Friday afternoon, after many money managers and traders had packed up and left for the weekend. The last hour on Friday is one of the lowest for liquidity. **********The Big Board has tried to solve that problem by having index option and futures expirations based on opening rather than closing prices. The argument is that with more traders at their desks, and with more time to sort out imbalances, volatility can be restrained much more effectively. **********But while officials in charge of the S.&P. 500 futures contract, which is traded on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, have gone along, the Major Market Index contract continues to expire at the close. The Chicago Board of Trade, where the futures contracts are traded, and the American Stock Exchange, which handles the options, have contended there is no evidence that a change is needed. Friday's experience may renew the pressure for such a change. **********If preliminary inquiries, already under way, come up with suspicious trading practices that warrant full-scale investigations, it will be interesting to see how they proceed. Any such investigation would look at futures trading, which is regulated by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, as well as stock and option trading, which are under the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********At the moment, suspicions between the securities and futures industries are as high as they have ever been, as the S.E.C. and the Bush Administration are pushing Congress to transfer the stock-index futures authority to the S.E.C. **********After the Oct. 13, 1989, fall of 190 points in the Dow, an S.E.C. report was much more critical of futures traders than was a study by the futures commission. In both industries, there is a belief that those reports showed that the other industry's regulator was prejudiced about futures trading. For them to cooperate now will not be easy, but it may be necessary.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/07/world.main_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: East Germany;   Berlin Communist Urges Troop Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/07/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: East Germany;   Berlin Communist Urges Troop Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/07/world.body_text: **********The head of East Germany's Communist Party proposed today that all NATO and Warsaw Pact forces quit both Germanys within a decade, adding spice to an already bitter political struggle shaping in East Germany. **********The proposal by Gregor Gysi, the new party chief, was not likely to become Government policy or be accepted by NATO or the Warsaw Pact any time soon. But as a political ploy it played directly into a conflict between the Communists and the opposition that has soured East Germany's euphoric march toward democracy. **********According to A.D.N., the East German press agency, Mr. Gysi proposed at a party meeting that all allied troops leave by 1999 and that both Germanys cut their armies in half within a year. **********''Without an end to military rivalry between the two German states, any talk of the unity of the nation is not credible,'' Mr. Gysi said in introducing a program he dubbed ''Security 2000.'' **********Aggressive New Campaign **********Mr. Gysi is not in the Government, and the Communists may lose control of the Government when free elections are held May 6. But diplomats saw the proposal as an effort to position the Communists as champions of disarmament and national unity as part of an aggressive new campaign by the party to revive its fallen fortunes. **********According to a recent public-opinion poll conducted by sociologists from the East German Academy for Social Sciences, support for the Communists has grown to 34 percent, far more than that of any opposition party. The accuracy of the poll could not be checked, but the newly active Communists have alarmed both the opposition and the West German Government. **********Over the past week, East German opposition groups have accused the Communists of manipulating their control of the Government and the press to gain unfair advantage, and of trying to reconstruct the security apparatus, using purported neo-fascist incidents to justify doing so. **********The incidents, including anti-Soviet slogans painted on Soviet war memorials, were given extensive publicity in the East German press, and the Communists held a mass anti-fascist protest on Wednesday. But many in the opposition charged that the government had deliberately sensationalized the incidents to foment fear in the population and strengthen the Communists' hand. **********Fears of New Security Forces **********At the Wednesday session of ''round table'' talks between the Communists and eight opposition groups, the opposition angrily contended that the Government had begun to construct a new security agency in place of the despised State Security apparatus and demanded a full report by Monday. **********Bonn has joined the opposition in accusing the Communists of denying the fledgling political parties equal access to important offices and the press. A West German Government spokesman, Norbert Schafer, said Friday that all parties had to be able to compete in the May elections on equal terms. ''According to our observations, this does not exist at the moment,'' he said. **********Mr. Gysi rejected the criticism in an interview with West German television, and the East Berlin Government said it would supply the opposition with cars, office space, paper and printing, and access to radio and newspapers. **********The East German Communists, for their part, have accused the opposition parties of miring the discussions in procedural disputes. At the stormy session of the ''round table'' talks last week, the head of the caretaker government, Prime Minister Hans Modrow, threatened to cancel the elections unless the opposition quit its bickering. **********Failure by the Opposition **********According to diplomats and experts in Bonn, the state of affairs in East Berlin reflects in part a failure by the East German opposition to assert leadership over the popular movement that drove out the Communist old guard and compelled the party to grant extraordinary concessions. **********Unlike the opposition in Czechoslovakia, which rallied behind the dissident playwright Vaclav Havel and the Civic Forum to secure a majority voice in the caretaker government, the opposition in East Germany has remained fragmented and without a nationally recognized leadership. **********New Forum, the coalition of dissidents and intellectuals that gained considerable exposure abroad in the first weeks of the East German revolution, has failed to evolve into a political force. This weekend, leaders of New Forum are finally meeting to decide whether to become a political party. In the meantime, the East German poll week found that support for the movement had slipped to 5.8 percent, from 9 percent. **********The only non-Communist party to make sizable gains was the East German Christian Democratic Union, which saw its support rise to to 7.9 percent. from 1.7 percent, probably because it shares a name and has the support of the party of the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl. **********Rallying the Communist Forces **********At the same time, the Communist Party appears to have rallied its forces. The press agency A.D.N. today reported that the party still had 1.4 million members, down from 2.3 million when it was master of the country but far more than any opposition group. Of the largest, New Forum has claimed about 200,000 supporters and the East German Christian Democrats about 140,000 members. **********The opposition's accusations seemed to sour the mood that had prevailed through the end of 1989, when West German and foreign leaders flocked to meet with the new East German leaders and the opening of the Brandenburg Gate seemed to symbolize a reunion that was leading toward at least a confederation. **********Some politicians in Bonn and East Berlin now assert that Mr. Kohl and the other leaders who visited East Germany only encouraged the East German Communists. **********Konrad Weiss, a member of Democracy Now, the East German opposition group, wrote in an open letter to Mr. Kohl that ''you have clearly favored the Communists and their representatives while neglecting opposition groups.'' **********'Democratic Fig Leaf' **********Annemarie Renger, a deputy speaker of the West German Parliament from the Social Democratic Party, charged that the ''round table'' talks were becoming ''a democratic fig leaf for the Communist Party.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/busin.body_text: **********Government prosecutors argued in a memorandum released yesterday that the pre-sentencing hearing of Michael R. Milken established that the former financier had "committed serious crimes" in addition to those he has admitted. **********The memorandum said the evidence showed that Mr. Milken, who pleaded guilty to six felonies in April, engaged in repeated criminal activity as part of the way he did business. **********"The hearing revealed that Milken committed crimes as part of a pattern of deceptive and unlawful practices undertaken by him and others at his direction for the purpose of consolidating market power and obtaining financial gain," the document said.  Follows Defense Memorandum **********The document was released one day after a memorandum filed by lawyers for Mr. Milken, which contended that the evidence had disproved the "Government's portrayal of him as a 'master criminal.' " **********The release of the Government document, which was filed on Tuesday, was delayed a day by Federal District Judge Kimba M. Wood, who ordered that certain references to crimes involving other individuals be deleted. **********Judge Wood ordered the hearing to determine whether the crimes of Mr. Milken, the former head of the high-yield "junk bond" division of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., were part of a broader criminal conspiracy, as the Government says, or were individual instances of going too far to help a client, as the defense contends. **********The Government chose three transactions to demonstrate that Mr. Milken committed more crimes than those he admitted. The first involved a 1986 manipulation of shares of the Wickes Companies, in what the Government contends was an effort by Mr. Milken to push the stock price up to allow Wickes to redeem an expensive preferred security. **********In their memorandum, the prosecutors noted the testimony of Peter Gardiner, a former Drexel employee, who said Mr. Milken had ordered him to manipulate the stock of Wickes when the former financier pointed to a machine that listed stock prices and said "Peter. Wickes. Six and an eighth."  Boesky Ties Cited **********The Government says the manipulation, which was done through the trading firm of Ivan F. Boesky, the fallen arbitrager, could only have been done by Mr. Milken. At that time, "Milken, alone in the high-yield department, had the authority to use the Boesky organization for illegal purposes." **********In the second transaction, the 1985 buyout of Storer Communications Inc. by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, prosecutors contended in their memorandum that they had proved that Mr. Milken misappropriated an equity stake from the deal and had improperly given money managers an interest in it. **********"Milken himself deliberately deceived K.K.R. concerning the allocation of the equity," the Government document says. **********The document also says thatproviding money managers an interest in MacPherson Partners, a partnership that held the Storer equity, "violated numerous Federal criminal provisions."  Caesars World Bonds **********In the last transaction, the Government contended Mr. Milken engaged in insider trading in the bonds of Caesars World Inc. The Government document restated the argument that Mr. Milken learned in June 1983 that the company planned to swap debt for equity. **********Perhaps the most damaging information came regarding a phone call Mr. Milken had with Prescott Crocker, an institutional investor who sold Caesars World bonds and accused the firm of insider trading. Mr. Crocker testified that Mr. Milken offered to engage in illegal trading to make up the losses and told him that he knew nothing of the debt exchange, a contention the Government says is a lie. **********"Milken's conversations with Crocker are powerful evidence of his guilt," the memorandum says.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/25/busin.main_headline: Business and the Law;   Bankruptcy Work Is Getting Respect
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/25/busin.print_headline: Business and the Law;   Bankruptcy Work Is Getting Respect
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/25/busin.body_text: **********FOR decades, the largest and most established law firms in the nation avoided bankruptcy work because it was disdained by highbrow partners as lower than divorce and criminal law and too distasteful for their practices. That attitude has changed. **********The bankruptcy specialty has replaced mergers and acquisitions as the hot area of the law in the 1990's. **********When big firms had clients who needed advice on bankruptcy law, the matter was usually referred to boutique outfits with bankruptcy specialists. These smaller firms posed no threat of stealing the client because as specialists they were limited to the arcane provisions of the Bankruptcy Code. **********The firm nationally regarded as the top bankruptcy boutique has been Manhattan-based Levin & Weintraub, Crames & Edelman. Its 14 lawyers, led by Michael J. Crames, have been beneficiaries of the referral system. They have found themselves in pivotal roles in many high-profile bankruptcies, including those of Texaco, Revco and Eastern Airlines. **********And one large firm that had continually refused to expand its own bankruptcy practice was Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, even though many of the New York firm's largest clients were banks and other financial institutions. **********Now, Levin & Weintraub and Kaye, Scholer have decided to merge. The two firms announced Friday that they will become one on July 1. **********The merger reflects the growing pressure on large firms to establish bankruptcy specialties, as well as the recognition by boutiques that they can no longer survive without the resources of large firms. **********For Levin & Weintraub, which had coveted its independence and had spurned other offers over the years, the move came after significant defections by lawyers who were lured to larger practices last year. Myron Trepper, one of Levin & Weintraub's partners, left with two other valued lawyers to bolster the bankruptcy practice of another large firm, Willkie, Farr & Gallagher. Integrated Resources was among the clients the partners took with them. **********Mr. Crames, whose bread and butter had been referrals from the large firms, began to see that many of those firms had decided to keep bankruptcy cases for themselves. **********Davis, Polk & Wardwell, for instance, which had shared its LTV and Manville clients with Mr. Crames when it came to Chapter 11 filings, recently decided that it would be better off keeping future bankruptcy business for itself. **********''Times had changed,'' Mr. Crames said in an interview on Friday. ''As Jimmy Durante used to say, everyone wants to get into the act.'' **********For its part, Kaye, Scholer decided it was time to shed its attitude of bankruptcy as a stained collar practice. While it had two partners and six associates working in the area, the view of the 375-lawyer firm toward bankruptcy had never been strong. **********''Kaye, Scholer never had a major bankruptcy practice because it was frowned upon as being second-rate, like ambulance chasing,'' said a partner at the firm who asked that he not be identified. ''This merger is a clear recognition that while bankruptcy was once viewed as unbecoming, money talks. We need these people.'' **********Nonetheless, partners at the firm said there had been a vocal minority at Kaye, Scholer who objected to the acquisition, arguing that it could create conflicts of interest and might not be worth the potential extra expense. **********Lawyers from the two firms are in the midst of conducting a check to see whether any of their clients are in conflict with one another. **********In the meantime, other bankruptcy lawyers see the new combination as a strong symbol of the changing times and predict that the new entity will be formidable. **********''The age of boutiques, for all practical purposes, is over,'' said Harvey R. Miller, Mr. Crames's adversary in scores of big and little proceedings over many years. Mr. Miller, the partner at Weil, Gotshal & Manges who heads the nation's largest bankruptcy practice, said the move would probably lead to even fewer referrals to Mr. Crames by other firms in direct competition with Kaye, Scholer. **********But that probably will not hurt Mr. Crames's practice, said Joel B. Zweibel, a bankruptcy specialist who once worked at Kaye, Scholer and who recently joined O'Melveny & Myers. **********''He has an excellent name and a significant share of the market,'' Mr. Zweibel said. ''I have no doubts that he will continue to have a substantial practice. It's a good match for him and a good catch for the firm.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/24/busin.main_headline: Boeing and McDonnell Joining Concorde Study
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/24/busin.print_headline: Boeing and McDonnell Joining Concorde Study
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/24/busin.body_text: **********The nation's two major commercial aircraft manufacturers, the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, said today that they would join with the major European plane makers to study the feasibility of developing a new generation of supersonic airliners. **********Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, which have researched supersonic planes on their own for decades, said they would participate in a ''study group'' formed by British Aerospace P.L.C. and Societe Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale of France. **********The British and French companies, which manufactured the supersonic airliner Concorde, announced plans earlier this month for a faster, more fuel-efficient ''Son of Concorde'' that could travel greater distances - Europe to Japan, for example - and invited participation by other nations. The study group will also include Deutsche Airbus, West Germany's leading builder of airliners and a subsidiary of Daimler-Benz. $10 Billion to Develop the Plane British Aerospace and Aerospatiale have estimated that it could cost $10 billion to develop the plane. The willingness of the major European and American commercial aircraft manufacturers to participate in the study underscores the high risks involved with assuming such huge costs. **********''Any program would be of a significant size, certainly beyond our means to go it alone,'' said Donald Graf, who heads McDonnell Douglas's research into supersonic aircraft. **********The group said in a statement that it would look into a variety of issues over the next year, ''including global environmental concerns and expected high program investment and risk levels.'' **********The group said it would examine the probable level of demand for a new supersonic plane from airlines and would assess the compatability of its members in working together. **********Environmental Concerns **********McDonnell Douglas and Boeing have long expressed interest in building a supersonic airliner. Boeing even started building a prototype during the late 1960's, but abandoned it, largely because of concern about the noise it would make on takeoff and the sonic boom that would reverberate to earth when the plane passed overhead at speeds greater than the speed of sound, roughly 750 miles an hour. **********Analysts say it remains unclear whether any supersonic airliner can be commercially viable. The Concorde cost $2 billion to develop and required heavy subsidies from the British and French governments. The manufacturers hoped to sell hundreds of the plane, but ended up selling only 14, seven to British Airways and seven to Air France. **********Commercial supersonic flight has always been hampered by a variety of environmental and economic concerns. Because of the sonic boom, the Concorde's routes have been largely limited to those that take it primarily over the Atlantic Ocean. Environmentalists say the release of combustion gases from supersonic engines can harm the ozone layer. The current Concorde cannot carry enough fuel to fly from Europe or North America to the Far East, one of the most rapidly expanding airline markets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/28/world.main_headline: Human Rights Group Accuses Zaire of Abuse
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/28/world.print_headline: Human Rights Group Accuses Zaire of Abuse
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/28/world.body_text: **********A report released by the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights asserts that the Government of Zaire has engaged in a ''systematic pattern of abuses'' that includes arbitrary arrests and beatings, banishment of political opponents and severe restrictions on freedoms of speech and the press. **********The report, ''Zaire: Repression as Policy,'' comes at a time when President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire has stated his intention to liberalize his country's political system and move toward free elections. In April Mr. Mobutu announced an end to his one-party state and the sanctioning of three opposition parties. But the report asserts that only a month later Zairean security forces attacked students at the University of Lubumbashi, killing at least 12 students, in response to a series of protests. **********''Despite almost annual pronouncements of reforms since 1978,'' the human rights group said, ''the judiciary has not prevented or punished arbitrary arrest and detention by security forces.'' It also asserted that Government agencies assigned to the protection of individual liberties lack ''the credibility, authority and political will to redress human rights abuses.'' **********The Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, based in New York, is an independent watchdog group that reports on human rights around the world. Its chairman is Marvin E. Frankel, a former United States Federal judge. **********Administration Criticized **********The group's report also criticized the Bush Administration for continuing to press Congress to approve $56 million in economic and military aid for Zaire for the fiscal year 1991. **********''Future bilateral U.S. aid,'' the report said, ''should be conditioned directly and explicitly on demonstrable progress, by the Government of Zaire, in assuring the basic rights of its citizens.'' **********A State Department official responded: ''We're not making any comments on the report but in general we think we are doing things to promote human rights in Zaire. We do things privately and we do things publicly.'' **********The Zairean ambassador to Washington, Tatanene Manata, said he also would not comment on the report. But he added: ''We have made a lot of progress since 1986 in human rights. You can go to Kinshasa and read the newspaper and see we have freedom of expression and freedom of trade unions and freedom of association.'' **********A copy of the report may be obtained for $12 from the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10001.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/25/world.body_text: **********The Chinese Communist Party Central Committee is expected to meet for six days beginning Tuesday to approve the nation's next five-year economic plan, which takes effect in January. **********The long-awaited meeting of the Central Committee will also approve a broader 10-year program that will include a call for greater priority on seeking reunification with Taiwan, said a Chinese official with access to top-level documents. **********The dates of the meeting have not yet been announced, and in the past, the leadership has generally disclosed information on the meetings only after they are concluded. This meeting was originally expected to convene by the fall, but was apparently pushed back because of differences of opinion about economic policy and other matters.  Discord With Beijing **********Throughout the fall, there were stormy disagreements between the central authorities and province governors over the degree of autonomy the localities would enjoy during the five-year plan, and about the level of taxes paid by the provinces to the national Government in Beijing. The Chinese official said the local authorities had generally gained the upper hand in the arguments and would retain considerable autonomy. **********The five-year plan will continue to pay tribute to the decade-long open-door policy, but it will reportedly be short of specific calls for substantially greater restructuring. In an effort to maintain political as well as economic stability, growth rates will be held to 5 to 6 percent, the official said. This is significantly lower than the average growth rates of the last decade. **********The bulk of the five-year plan spells out targets for economic production in areas like agriculture, natural resources, energy and light industry, and export and import industries. **********China has significantly improved its trade position, achieving a surplus of $6.2 billion in the first 10 months of this year, and its foreign exchange reserves have increased to about $26 billion. But the domestic economy is still suffering from a slowdown, and many Chinese officials do not expect a full recovery next year. China's three-year economic austerity program, which was begun in the fall of 1988, had been expected to end by next December. Now it is not clear whether the austerity measures will be extended.  Localities Tend to Prevail **********For the most part, the provinces will be able to retain 80 percent of the foreign exchange they earn from exports and turn over 20 percent to Beijing. In return, the state will halt subsidies for exports beginning in January, according to a State Council document now being circulated among officials. **********While no sweeping changes in the leadership are expected during the meeting, it is not clear whether the party will expand the Politburo, the highest policy-making body. The Politburo now has 14 members, with three positions left vacant since 1989. **********During the spring and summer of that year, Hu Yaobang died, and two other members, Zhao Ziyang and Hu Qili, were dismissed from the policy-making body in connection with the military crackdown in June 1989.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/04/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Children's-TV Bill Troubles White House
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/04/busin.body_text: **********The White House raised constitutional objections today to legislation that would restrict commercials on children's television programming, but officials left open the possibility that President Bush might allow the measure to stand in light of its overwhelming support in Congress. **********Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said no decision had yet been made on the bill, which is under review by the Justice Department. But other officials suggested that Mr. Bush could simply allow it to become law without his signature, while keeping up his public opposition to it. **********Congress has not yet overturned a veto by Mr. Bush, but this measure apparently has enough support in both houses to do so and the White House might not want to make this measure a test of Mr. Bush's unblemished veto history. **********No Regulations Now **********The measure, which was approved by the House on Monday on a voice vote without dissent and by the Senate last week, would restrict commercials on children's programming to 10 minutes an hour on weekends and 12 minutes on weekdays. **********There are now no regulations on the amount of commercial time allowed on television. Industry studies have found that some stations show as much as 11 to 12 minutes of commercials an hour during children's broadcasts on weekends and 14 minutes on weekdays. **********The new bill would also compel broadcasters to offer educational programming for children or risk losing their broadcast licenses. It would require the Federal Communications Commission to examine the length of cartoon shows based on characters, like the Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles, that are also popular toys. **********''We do believe there is a need to improve the quality of children's television,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. But he added: ''Conditioning broadcasting renewals on program content is constitutionally suspect. Similarly, imposing rigid quantitative limits on advertising during children's programming is also questionable constitutionally and could have adverse consequences for children's programming.'' **********Cut in Programming Feared **********Administration officials said the White House was concerned that limiting commercial time would lead to reductions in the amount of children's programming by making it less lucrative. **********Peggy Charren, president of Action for Children's Television, a lobbying group for improved programming, said the bill conformed to the Communications Act of 1934, which says that broadcasters must serve the public in return for their licenses. **********Until the Reagan Administration deregulated television in 1984, the 1934 measure was used to require stations to broadcast specific amounts of educational programming. ''All this bill does is make children part of that public interest obligation,'' Ms. Charren said. **********''It's inconceivable for it to be legal to require broadcasters to serve adults and illegal to require them to serve children,'' she said. ''It doesn't say I or anyone else has to like the stuff you put on your nonfiction show. It says you have to have some education, but it doesn't say you have to do it any particular way or that you even have to do it right. It is the least restrictive way you can tell broadcasters to take care of kids, too.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/world.main_headline: Parallel Seen in Mandela Release And Shifts to Black Rule in Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/world.print_headline: Parallel Seen in Mandela Release And Shifts to Black Rule in Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/world.body_text: **********Black African leaders have greeted the release of Nelson Mandela with caution, emphasizing that it is only a beginning. But they nevertheless see a parallel between the emerging situation in South Africa and the move from white colonial rule to black majority rule in several black African countries, particularly Kenya. **********Like Mr. Mandela, Kenya's first President at independence, Jomo Kenyatta, had been put in jail by the ruling whites. And as with Mr. Mandela, a group of more mainstream whites began to talk to Mr. Kenyatta while he was still locked up. **********''I took the view, unlike most of the settlers, that 10 percent of the population could not lead in perpetuity without the backing of the British Government and the rest of the population,'' said Peter Marrian, one of the three prominent white politicians who visited Mr. Kenyatta in jail and saw him as the future leader. **********Mr. Kenyatta was convicted in 1952 by a colonial court on charges of managing the Mau Mau rebellion against the settlers. He remained in detention for 10 years, the last several in a Government house. ''There was no doubt his trial was not fair,'' said Mr. Marrian, now a stockbroker in Nairobi and an officer of the colonial-era Muthaiga Club. ''I met several people afterwards, including top Kenyan policemen, who said he should not have been convicted.'' **********'He Was Just Like Mandela' **********The year before Mr. Kenyatta's release, Mr. Marrian, known among African politicians as the white who had dared to run on the platform that the ''sanctity of the white highlands is bunk,'' was invited by one of them to visit Mr. Kenyatta. **********''I spent three hours with him alone,'' Mr. Marrian said. ''Everything he told me came to pass. He said to me, 'People say Kenyatta wants to push the Europeans into the sea.' He made it clear that if they stayed and accepted the fact of an African government, then they were welcome to stay.'' **********On the day of Mr. Kenyatta's release, Petal Allen, the daughter of another mainstream white politician, recalls the African coming to her father's house for an interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation. **********''He was just like Mandela, so magnaminous,'' said Mrs. Allen, a well-known liberal member of the white community here. ''He said, 'We don't want the whites to be frightened.' '' **********Social Pariah Among Whites **********A little later, Mr. Kenyatta addressed a meeting of the farmer's union, the bastion of white landowners, whom Mr. Marrian said had all sworn they would leave Kenya the day Mr. Kenyatta came out of jail. ''Two things happened after he spoke,'' Mr. Marrian said. ''He got a standing ovation and the second was, they said, 'The day he dies, we leave Kenya.' '' **********Mr. Marrian, who became a minister in Mr. Kenyatta's Government, said his pre-independence advocacy for Mr. Kenyatta and that of his two colleagues, Sir Derek Erskine and Bruce McKenzie, made them pariahs among whites. ''I could empty the bar at Muthaiga by walking into it,'' he said. **********After independence in 1963, white landowners were compensated by the British Government in British pounds for their land. ''There was vast transfer of land from white ownership to black with very little trouble,'' Mr. Marrian said. **********While the talks with Mr. Kenyatta in jail bear some resemblance to the dialogue that went on with Mr. Mandela, and both black leaders carried messages of conciliation to the whites on their release, the similarities probably stop there, Mr. Marrian said. ''All told, there were about 70,000 whites at the time in Kenya. In South Africa, you have four million. It's a different ball game.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/19/busin.main_headline: Next Inc. Returns to Center Stage
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/19/busin.print_headline: Next Inc. Returns to Center Stage
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/19/busin.body_text: **********Steven P. Jobs returned to the stage at this city's symphony hall today, hoping to rekindle the sense of anticipation his computer company, Next Inc., had when it introduced its first product in the same place two years ago. **********The announcement of four new computers did not have quite the sizzle of the previous introduction, which was the Silicon Valley equivalent of opening night at the opera. But there is general agreement that there was more steak this time, and that the new machines will do better than the original one, a hulking black cube that was criticized as slow and overpriced and that had only lackluster sales. **********Orders Already Taken **********Indeed, Mr. Jobs, the evangelical boy wonder of the personal computer industry who is only slightly more subdued at 35 years old, announced that Next has already received orders for 15,000 of the new machines. That is thought to be at least 50 percent higher than the number of machines sold by the company so far. **********The new machines remedy many of the shortcomings of the first model. They are faster, because all of them use the latest Motorola 68040 microprocessor and because the innovative but slow optical disk has been replaced by a more conventional but speedier hard magnetic disk. They are cheaper, with the least expensive model selling for $5,000, half the price of the old machine. **********Two of the new models can display color images, whereas the first machine could display only black and white. And there are several more of what Mr. Jobs called ''best of breed'' software packages available for the machine from leading vendors, including the Lotus Development Corporation, Ashton-Tate Corporation and the Wordperfect Corporation. **********Analysts and industry executives say Next now has a good shot at becoming successful and profitable. Executives of Next, based in Redwood City, Calif., hope the company will become profitable by early next year. **********However, it might be too late for Mr. Jobs to realize his ambition of duplicating the success he had as the founder of Apple Computer Inc., of producing a computer that becomes a class unto itself, fundamentally changing the industry as did the personal computers from Apple and International Business Machines and the work stations from Sun Microsystems Inc. **********''I just don't believe that coming in late with these new products he has the opportunity to become the next PC for everybody,'' said Tim Bajarin, an analyst with Creative Strategies Research International, a market research firm. **********A Surge of Competitors **********In the two years it has taken Next to iron out bugs, competitors including Sun, Apple, I.B.M. and the Compaq Computer Corporation have filled millions of desks that might once have welcomed a Next machine. And while Next has eliminated many of the obvious shortcomings of its first computer, it is still unclear whether the machine offers enough unique features to draw buyers to it. **********Competitors can also leapfrog Next in the coming year. In addition, the favorable reviews the products received today could fade upon closer analysis, as happened two years ago. Indeed, it is often said in the computer business that Mr. Jobs generates a ''reality distortion field'' that makes people see things his way, at least while they are in his presence. **********Another company with Next's record might have been out of business by now. But Next officials say they have enough cash on hand to exist for at least another year even without another sale. That is because the company received a $100 million investment from Canon, the Japanese office equipment and camera manufacturer, and tens of millions of dollars from I.B.M., which promises eventually to offer Next's basic software as an option for its computer work stations. **********Still, this is widely viewed as the last chance for Next, which was founded in 1985, when Mr. Jobs left Apple after losing a power struggle with Apple's chief executive, John Sculley. **********Mr. Jobs now concedes that the company has not fared as well as he had hoped, something he long declined to admit. ''Introducing a new platform is like pushing a boulder uphill,'' he said Monday night at a dinner for customers. But he quickly predicted the boulder was now finally ready to roll downhill. **********In a separate interview he said, ''I think our main challenge will be convincing people we're a viable competitor.'' He added: ''We're cautiously optimistic. We don't want to get carried away.'' **********This is quite humble talk for Mr. Jobs, who was once widely known for lambasting competitors as ''brain damaged.'' But Mr. Jobs has had to swallow a lot of pride in the last two years. In designing the new machines, he has caved in to pressure and given up on some unusual features of his first machine that some found odd but that Mr. Jobs had insisted users would want. **********''It looks like he wants to be successful more than he wants to be right,'' said Seymour Merrin, a consultant in Palo Alto, Calif. **********Next's New Look **********Gone, at least in two models, is the black cube, replaced by a much more svelte unit the size of pizza box upon which the monitor can rest. The optical disk drive is relegated to an option, and most of the machines will no longer contain the complete works of Shakespeare on disk. The new machines also contain floppy disk drives, so that software companies can finally distribute software on floppy disks. **********The new machines start with the Nextstation, a machine with a list price of $5,000 that includes a black and white screen and a 105-megabyte hard-disk drive and 8 megabytes of internal memory. A color version of the Nextstation will sell for $8,000. These machines have the new pizza-box shape. **********The Nextcube, which retains the original cube shape, will start at $8,000. It is meant for those who need more storage; it can be expanded to hold up to 2.8 billion characters of memory on hard disks. **********The upper end of the line is the Nextdimension, a color machine that will sell for $14,000. It will allow displays of images of near-photographic quality and will allow television pictures to be played in a window on the computer screen. **********The black-and-white machines will be available in November and the color ones in the first quarter of next year, the company said. **********To bolster its chances of winning corporate accounts, Next is beginning to sell directly to companies and is adding distributors that specialize in selling computers to particular industries. In the past, corporations could buy Next computers only through Businessland Inc., the retailer. **********What will make people buy Next machines? Next is relying on a new spreadsheet program called Improv written by Lotus for the company's machine. Improv allows users instantly to rearrange the presentation of their data in a way not possible with other spreadsheets. **********The company also hopes to win sales to companies that need to write their own programs, because the Next computers come with tools that help automate programming.
